title: Seattle: Houseboats Move Upscale
description: NOT long ago, politicians could get an easy headline by railing against the ''damp dens'' of radicals and scofflaws living on Lake Union. But high moorage fees and protective city legislation have now driven out all but a handful of the colorful Bohemian types who contributed to the singular reputation of this city's houseboat community, one of the largest in the country.

title: POP: MICHELE BAUTIER
description: THE New Jersey-based pop-jazz singer Michele Bautier was virtually unknown in New York until she won a talent contest at Freddy's Supper Club (308 East 49th Street) last July. Since then, she has earned almost unanimous critical acclaim and become a regular performer at the club. Following two successful engagements there earlier this year singing a mixed bag of standards by Duke Ellington and Harold Arlen, Miss Bautier has put together an entirely new program that features a number of contemporary pop-rock songs, in addition to standards.

title: JAZZ: THE LEADERS IN A DEBUT
description: THE LEADERS, an all-star jazz group, have their first engagement at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, through Sunday.

title: HARD LOOKS FOR ISRAEL'S CHIEF OF SECURITY
description: THE struggle between Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Attorney General Yitzhak Zamir over whether the police should investigate the head of Israel's domestic intelligence service touches some of this country's deepest ethical dilemmas: Can military and security officials, in the heat of a terrorist attack on civilians, be realistically expected to deal with terrorists as armed, mortal enemies until a capture, then suddenly choke off emotion and treat them calmly, according them the rights the law implies? Can any society expect its officials to make such swift transitions and distinctions? But without insisting upon such distinctions, what kind of society would Israel be?

title: ELEGANCE IN A HOTEL SETTING
description: DINERS who associate chain hotels and motels with pedestrian dining may have to rethink their views. A new trend is gathering force in Connecticut: an effort to create an upscale image in many new hotel dining rooms.

title: FREDERICK WISEMAN TAKES HIS CAMERA TO THE RACES
description: Hard to believe, perhaps, but it was 20 years ago this spring that an elfin figure was racing around the corridors of the Bridgewater, (Mass.) State Prison for the Criminally Insane, gathering footage for a film that was to prove such a milestone that even today people pause and grow pensive at its name. Frederick Wiseman was 36 at the time, and his ''Titicut Follies'' emerged as a classic cinema verite documentary, establishing him as a leading film maker in part because he was able to reveal not only immense brutality at the institution but also rare moments of humanity.

title: AT ITS BEST, IT WAS A SEASON THAT ILLUMINATED OUR WORLD
description: As ritual has it, the 1985-86 New York theater season is officially over tonight, when the Broadway establishment hands out its Tony Awards on television. If the Tony winners and losers seem beside the point, it's not completely Broadway's fault. The world became a stage in the season's waning weeks, with a gruesome vengeance that might upstage any play. One could well feel silly and irrelevant going about one's business attending the theater while the front pages screamed of terrorism, of nuclear disaster, or the willful forgetting of the past by the man who would be president of the country where Hitler was born. In such a civilization - or absence of same - does one stay home to watch the late-breaking news and brood, or go off to see the most profusely nominated Tony contender, ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood''?

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Gemstone Cornucopia At Factory Outlet Embraceables - established in the county four years ago and based in North White Plains as a costume-jewelry factory for the last two years -is having a two-day inventory clearance at wholesale prices or below Saturday from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. and next Sunday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Checks can be accepted with two identifications but not credit cards.

title:
SIGN-OFF;
A Look Back at Wall Street
description: AS my colleagues, past and present, are only too fond of reminding me, I left Wall Street about 1,000 points ago on the Dow. Back then, in the late 1970's, Wall Street and the financial community in general were just beginning the revolution that has created the investment supermarkets that are out there ''capturing'' all our assets. And the salesmen of Wall Street were just beginning to accumulate impressive titles on their business cards.

title: ROBERT TRENT JONES CREATES GOLF COURSES THAT SURVIVE
description: THE solitude was disturbed only by the familiar click-clack of cleated shoes on pavement and clinking of silverware in the clubhouse restaurant, sounds indigenous to a golf course and compatible with the buzzing and chirping that nature does on the fairways. Among the games that people play, golf is more like shooting the rapids or mountain climbing than hitting a baseball or making a basket, for it focuses on overcoming a number of hazards, natural and manmade.

title: AN ISOLATED SOVIET PIANIST PLAYS CHOPIN'S PRELUDES
description: In 1979 the Soviet pianist Vladimir Feltsman and his wife applied for emigration visas to Israel. Since then he has been virtually silenced as far as the public is concerned. He is able to practice in his one-room apartment in Moscow. He is occasionally assigned to appearances in remote Soviet towns, where the pianos are usually in poor condition and the audiences not very knowledgeable. Requests from the West to Soviet officials for engagements are ignored or given a negative response.

title: COOKING
description: The spring publishing season has yielded an eclectic crop of cookbooks. Absent for the most part are those extravagant and glossy picture books that tell you how to organize a country picnic around provisions that look like the degustation menu at Lutece. Is the market finally saturated with $40 life style food books? I doubt it. Just wait until the fall gift-giving season. The selection of new titles described below reflects a continued interest in regional foods, both domestic and foreign, as well as an ever-greater concern for health and fitness. Both are especially welcome as we head into the hot months.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Development Troubles Atlantic Beach
description: FOR more than a decade, residents of the Village of Atlantic Beach and its neighboring enclaves, Atlantic Beach Estates and East Atlantic Beach, have fretted over development of a 17-acre oceanfront parcel.

title: Land of the Rising Yen Beckons
description: THE Tokyo stock market is beckoning to American investors who want to venture beyond their own backyards and take advantage of the worldwide bull market. Lower prices, disinflation and a tendency among Japanese manufacturers to hold back on capital investment while the rising yen is setting records have made corporations and individuals flush with new cash for investment. As bond yields in Japan continue to fall in tandem with discount rate cuts, the cash is flowing into equities.

title: BLACKS ON CAMPUS
description: Although highly qualified black faculty members are frequently lured to top-rated institutions by lucrative offers and incentives, there are many who experience isolation and alienation in the academic environment, where their numbers are minuscule.

title: BEACH BLANKET BOOK BAG
description: THE CHARACTER FACTORY Baden-Powell and the Origins of the Boy Scout Movement. By Michael Rosenthal. Illustrated. 335 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.

title: PLUMBING A COMPANY'S BIOGRAPHY
description: EVERY year companies spend thousands of dollars to turn out glossy annual reports filled with color pictures and rosy pronouncements intended to present their businesses in the best light. Tucked in between all the hype, however, are kernels of information that can give the savvy investor an accurate assessment of a company's financial health and prospects. But what to look for and how to interpret it? Four experts discuss their formulas for sizing up companies from their annual reports and offer investors clues on what to watch for when reading the reports. Look at the Footnotes

title: Marcia D. Jacobs Becomes a Bride
description: Marcia Davoren Jacobs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jacobs 3d of Old Saybrook, Conn., was married yesterday to James Edward Hooper 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hooper 2d of Owings Mills, Md., and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. John Wing performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Nantucket.

title:
A COMPETITIVE LIABILITY;
RIDDING WALL STREET OF A SHORT-TERM BIAS
description: AMERICA'S growing problems with international competition are too often blamed on the usual suspects: high labor costs, unfair trade practices and the overvalued dollar. The role of our financial system is overlooked. It shouldn't be. By favoring short-term, high-return deals at the expense of riskier, long-term investments, the capital markets discourage investment in the companies and technologies that we need to compete in world markets.

title: RISING RENTS SQUEEZE SUBURBAN 'MOM-AND-POP' STORES
description: ALTHOUGH the lease on their art gallery in Hoboken, N.J., does not come up for another year and a half, Edward and Diane Greene can already see the handwriting on the wall.

title: Cynthia H. Bird Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Hewitt Bird, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Waddell Bird of Nashville, Tenn., and Bay Head, N.J., was married yesterday to William Bernard Grogan Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Grogan of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. W. Wesley Konrad performed the ceremony at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Bay Head.

title: Keeping A Cool Head With Futures
description: THE futures and options markets often seem to be a place where a sort of financial alchemy overtakes the normal laws of physics. You can pay a Volkswagen-sized downpayment, but drive away with a Ferrari, and yet, if you turn your head, even for a moment, the Ferrari may turn into a heap of scrap metal.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: PHILADELPHIA ART SHOW - Philadelphia asserts that its traditional annual spring art show in Rittenhouse Square is the oldest outdoor art exhibit in the country. The show will mark its 55th year when nearly 2,000 works by some 120 professional artists go on display Wednesday through Sunday.

title: TWO PIANISTS SHINE IN THE MOZART CONCERTOS
description: Over the past 10 years or so, two distinctly different pianists have worked steadily at recording all the Mozart piano concertos. Alfred Brendel's project for Philips records is shared with Neville Marriner conducting the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields. Murray Perahia's recordings, made in collaboration with the English Chamber Orchestra, are for CBS Masterworks.

title: FILMING OF UPDIKE BOOK DIVIDES A SEASIDE TOWN
description: The white steeple of a 202-year-old church rises above the town green in this seaside community, a picturesque scene, though hardly one of a kind in New England.

title: 'OLD WORLD VALUES' STILL ALIVE IN WORK ON ELLIS ISLAND
description: PART of Joseph Del Guidice's legacy from his grandparents was a sense of ''doing a job to the best of your ability and being proud of what you had done.''

title: Margaret J. McFarland Becomes Bride
description: Margaret Jean McFarland, the daughter of Mrs. J. Malcolm McFarland of Cranbury, N.J., and the late Mr. McFarland, was married yesterday to Dr. John Sante Symington, a son of Stuart Symington Jr., and Dr. Janey Symington of St. Louis. The Rev. Laurence D. Fish, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in Hightstown, N.J., at the Ayer Memorial Chapel at the Peddie School, of which the bride is an alumna.

title: Dominicans Vote For Happy Days
description: For many voters in the Dominican Republic, the former President, Joaquin Balaguer, is a reminder of happier days when the country's sugar exports brought good prices and a bit of prosperity. Last week, Mr. Balaguer, now 78 years old and unable to read because of failing eyesight, was acclaimed as President for the fifth time in a career that goes back 54 years.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: To Have and Have Not, Starring Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall, Walter Brennan; directed by Howard Hawks, 1944. M-G-M Home Video, 101 minutes.

title: A NEW ENGLAND UTOPIA
description: THE LAND WAS UNLIKE ANYTHING IRA Howard Levy had found before: 60 acres adjoining a nature preserve in southern New England with rolling hills, mountain views and a rare collection of conifer trees that had been maturing on the property for more than 40 years. The only flaw in this otherwise utopian setting was the main house - a rather ugly 1950's structure. ''We literally tried to give it away,'' recalls Levy, senior vice president of corporate marketing design for Estee Lauder. ''But nobody wanted it. Much to the outrage of the community, we tore the house down.'' Not a surprising decision, given Levy's penchant for building new homes. Over the last 10 years, he has overseen the completion of three sleek International Style houses on Long Island. ''After the overload of aggressive Hamptons' architecture, it was time for change,'' he says.

title: BRONX GIRL TRADES HUBBUB FOR CALM WITH FRESH AIR FAMILY
description: FOR two weeks last summer, Yasmary Gonzalez woke to the sounds of chirping birds instead of police sirens. She ran around a goldfish-filled pond in her host family's backyard instead of across traffic-filled streets. And when she fell from the jungle gym there was cool grass underfoot instead of the hot asphalt outside her Bronx apartment.

title: WHEN THE MIDDLE CLASS SNAPS
description: THE PROFESSOR AND THE PROSTITUTE And Other True Tales of Murder and Madness. By Linda Wolfe. Illustrated. 228 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95. IN a rather curious, autobiographical introduction to the nine true stories in ''The Professor and the Prostitute,'' Linda Wolfe informs the reader that she is a ''psychological'' writer whose interest is in ''people who inhabit the middle class . . . people I, and many others like me, might know, entertain, work beside.'' She had hoped to become a novelist, but, concluding that her imagination was ''impoverished,'' decided to ''try using fictional techniques to fuel nonfiction'' -as she seems to see it, to go slumming with style.

title: Miami Rallies to Win
description: Mike Fiore doubled home the winning run in a ninth inning rally today that powered Miami to a 6-2 victory over Oklahoma State in the college baseball World Series.

title: NEW ISSUES FROM EUROPE PROVIDE A BOOST FOR CONSERVATION AND NATURE
description: Collectors who seek a topic of manageable proportions may find one in the Europa issues. The annual series dates back to 1956, when the six members of the European Coal and Steel Community issued stamps to symbolize their cooperation. By 1973, over 20 nations were issuing stamps, most in the common design chosen by the Congress of European Posts and Telecommunications (C.E.P.T.).

title: Marxism And History
description: James M. Markham's article ''Who Owns the Past?'' (April 27), on East Germany's use of German history and conservative historical figures such as Luther and Bismarck in its quest for popular acceptance, mirrors events in almost all Leninist Communist states.

title: NEW REACTOR WOULD USE SUSTAINED ATOMIC FUSION
description: A preliminary design has been completed for a nuclear reactor that scientists hope will be the first to create a fusion reaction that will achieve ignition, thus sustaining itself at temperatures of hundreds of millions of degrees.

title: Haitian Court Convicts Duvalier Aide of Murder
description: A top military aide of former President Jean-Claude Duvalier was convicted today of murder and sentenced to 15 years in prison.

title: RADIATION IN SOVIET VEAL REPORTED
description: A cut of veal purchased at a Moscow food market and analyzed in France had radiation 6 to 10 times the level considered safe by the European Community, a diplomat said today.

title: THE TAXATION PITFALLS OF HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A HOMEOWNER'S reluctance to improve his property because of the anticipation of additional property taxes is understandable and justified.

title: BEACH BLANKET BOOK BAG
description: THE FUNERAL MAKERS By Cathie Pelletier. 247 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $16.95.

title: Palermo
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''What's Doing in Palermo'' (Travel, April 13): A few years ago we were pleased to spend a week at the Hotel La Torre in Mondello, just outside Palermo. The article says that the hotel is ''in the heat of the summer a very pleasant place to stay'' We were there in late November (we left Palermo on Thanksgiving Day) and at that time the weather was still delightful.

title: HACKENSACK AIDE, UNDER FIRE, RETIRES
description: THE City Manager here, Joseph J. Squillace, who retired yesterday, can receive $185,000 with his final paycheck on Friday if the City Council declines to suspend the payment.

title: KEAN TAKES HIS MESSAGE OF 'INCLUSION' ON THE ROAD
description: GOVERNOR KEAN carried his message of inclusion to New York Republicans last week as some prominent Democrats back home were winding up their campaigns for nomination in Tuesday's primary elections.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHITMAN AND THE GHOSTS OF THE OLD HOUSE
description: The 167th anniversary of the birth of Walt Whitman is being observed today in Huntington by the Walt Whitman Birthplace Association, which annually publishes The West Hills Review, a literary journal. The 1986 Review includes ''The Old House'' by Eunice Conger Halls, a poet who teaches at the State University of New York at Farmingdale. Excerpts from ''The Old House'' follow.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the publisher of ''Around the Day in Eighty Worlds'' by Julio Cortazar was listed incorrectly in ''Noted With Pleasure'' May 11. The publisher is North Point Press.

title: TOWN SPLIT ON WHETHER ENROLLMENT IS UP OR DOWN
description: A TOWN facing the prospect of closing one of its schools because of declining enrollment is hardly a new phenomenon around Connecticut.

title: MUSIC: KENN HICKS, TENOR
description: THE tenor Kenn Hicks chose an unusually diverse program for his Thursday evening concert at Alice Tully Hall: a motet by Vivaldi; arias from Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' and Meyerbeer's ''L'Africaine;'' songs by Schubert, Sibelius and the American composers Charles Ives, Ned Rorem, and John Work; three spirituals, and some Neapolitan songs.

title: Carter Jones, Student, Bride of Bruce Meyer
description: Carter Jones, the daughter of Meade Barner Jones of Paoli, Pa., and the late L. Davis Jones, was married yesterday to Bruce Robison Meyer, a son of Mary-Louise Shadman Meyer of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Norman Meyer. The Rev. Berna Derby, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother in Paoli.

title: Retirement: Plan Ahead For Income
description: AS people prepare to retire, they usually cover the basics. They learn about their pension, their Social Security benefits, their coverage under a company health plan and the role of Medicare. But there is much more that individuals should consider in planning for retirement, the experts say.

title: OKAMOTO HAS LEAD ON CLOSING BIRDIES
description: Ayako Okamoto moved a step closer to winning the 32d Ladies Professional Golf Association championship today when she birdied four of the last five holes, including the last three, and retained her three-shot lead after three rounds.

title: Midlife Switch
description: AT the age of 38, Douglas Kreeger was a merchant without a store. In March 1984, he had sold Kreeger & Sons, the camping and backpacking chain with the distinctive logotype showing a man with a child in a backpack.

title: TALES OUT OF SCHOOL
description: EDUCATIONAL MYTHS I HAVE KNOWN AND LOVED By Baird W. Whitlock. 115 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $12.95. LABELED A to Z, the 26 brief essays in Baird W. Whitlock's book purport to demolish 26 educational ''myths.'' What are some of these myths? One is that faculty members in the Northeast are ''more liberal than faculties in the rest of the country.'' Mr. Whitlock's argument: schools and colleges in the Northeast are actually conservative in their unwillingness to experiment with new programs. Another myth is that artists are ''more sensitive'' than the rest of us. Mr. Whitlock's argument: some of the artists with whom he has served on faculties were actually very insensitive to their colleagues or students.

title: BEACH BLANKET BOOK BAG
description: ENTER TALKING By Joan Rivers with Richard Meryman. Illustrated. 398 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $17.95. ENTER talking? In this era of the hype, Joan Rivers's title wins hands down as the year's greatest understatement. She does not merely talk, she takes aim, begins to fire and rakes her audience - 373 pages plus index, acknowledgements, and last but far from least, a heartfelt dedication ''To Edgar [ her husband ] who made this book happen, and to Johnny Carson, who made it all happen.''

title: Store Clerk Is Shot to Death In Argument Over a Receipt
description: A Brooklyn grocery store clerk was killed and the proprietor wounded yesterday afternoon when a man fired at least six shots after what police said was an argument over a receipt.

title: SEARCHING - STILL - FOR A WEATHERVANE COMPOSER
description: Those of us who grew up believing in the concept of the artist as weathervane find it increasingly difficult nowadays to deal with a musical culture in which the wind seems to be blowing in every direction at once. Deny it or not, we find ourselves anxiously peering around corners in hopes of locating the next great prophet, the next avant-garde spearhead. I found myself mulling over this propensity recently when the New York Philharmonic presented an entire evening of Gyorgy Ligeti's theater music to open its ''Horizons '86'' series.

title: LAWMAKERS PUSH TO RESOLVE L.I. ISSUES
description: THERE are two sure signs that summer and the close of the legislative session are near: The roses are blooming on the Capitol lawn, and lawmakers are hastening to pass unresolved bills before leaving for election-year campaigns.

title: POLICE OFFICERS MEET THE PRESS -- AND GARNER MIXED REVIEWS
description: IT was County Police Sgt. Anthony Cequeria's turn to face the press. He had been told that the body of a public official had just been found and that this appeared to be a suicide. A note had been left at the scene, it was said, that implicated other politicians and some police officers in what might be a major corruption scandal.

title: Two States Are Pulled Over
description: For the first time since the Federal speed limit became 55 miles an hour more than a decade ago, drivers in two states have been found honoring it more in the breach than not. So the Department of Transportation announced last week that it would, as the law requires, withhold Federal highway funds from Arizona, which could lose as much as $5.1 million this year, and Vermont, which could lose $1.9 million.

title: THE PELTON TRIAL LEAVES MOST QUESTIONS UNANSWERED
description: ONE of the most dramatic moments in a murder trial occurs when the prosecution shows pictures of the bloodied victim. The sobering tableau - the dead body, the family quietly sobbing in the courtroom - gives the jurors something to ponder as they weigh the evidence in the case.

title: TAKING THE BEST SELLERS SERIOUSLY: WHERE SEX MEETS SELF-IMPROVEMENT
description: I HAVE spent the last month or so taking the best seller as seriously as it takes itself. Books are commodities bought and sold on the free market, and money is the only available index of their value. Some of the books I have been reading must be very valuable indeed. Their authors and publishers and agents are enriched by them and are driven to a unitary view of value.

title: PRESS WELCOMES COOPERATION PLEA
description: Many journalists welcomed Thursday's call by Government officials for ''cooperation'' regarding disclosure of sensitive information by news organizations, which the journalists said was a softening of recent threats to prosecute news organizations under espionage law.

title: Classical Music
description: This is one of those periods in the year when New York's customarily frantic musical activity subsides a bit and the choices confronting inveterate concertgoers fall off sharply. Nevertheless, instances of unhackneyed programming are still to be found, and two examples are promised for this week.

title: BEACH BLANKET BOOK BAG
description: THE PATIENT HAS THE FLOOR By Alistair Cooke. 204 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: ADJUSTING TO LOW INFLATION
description: INVESTORS are changing how they put their money to work, embracing financial assets - stocks, bonds and mutual funds - and abandoning gold, metals, oil and other hard assets favored in the high-inflation era of the late 1970's.

title: A HEALTHY WAY TO EXTEND FOOD LIFE
description: WHEN Prometheus robbed the gods of fire and gave it to man, he did so in an era of limited government regulation. Were he to attempt the same feat today, he would no doubt be frustrated by an array of demands to justify his gift scientifically and to allay the health and safety concerns of the government and the public.

title: Dale Westerlund Is Wed
description: Dale Sue Westerlund, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Westerlund of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Moultonboro, N.H., was married yesterday to Joseph S. Kolanko, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Kolanko of Rossford, Ohio. The Rev. Edd Payne, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Charles Kavanagh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Chappaqua. The bride is an assistant account executive at Walter Kaye Associates, Manhattan insurance brokers, and her husband is an officer at Chemical Bank.

title: Wendy L. Gould Wed To Steven A. Shenfeld
description: Wendy L. Gould, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fredric Gould of Old Brookville, L.I., and Vail, Colo., and Steven A. Shenfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Shenfeld of Hewlett, L.I., were married last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York by Rabbi Abner Bergman.

title: Half Right and All Wrong on SALT
description: President Reagan is half right to call the SALT II arms treaty ''fatally flawed.'' It is flawed; it restrains some weapons without really curbing nuclear technology. He is also half right to adhere to the treaty without asking Congress to ratify. Though the Russians would benefit more if both sides break out of the limits, those limits generally favor the United States.

title: ROBOTICS SOCIETY ORGANIZES TO SWAP THE NEW TECHNOLOGY
description: ''BONG BONG,'' began the keynote speaker at the meeting of the newly formed Connecticut Robotics Society. ''Hello, everybody. I am very clever, but this is not unusual, because all robots are very clever.''

title: Austrian Killed In Crash
description: Jo Gartner of Austria was killed early today in The 24 Hours of LeMans when his Porsche crashed and burst into flames.

title: STATUE OF LIBERTY CENTENNIAL EVENTS
description: Following are some events connected with the centennial (for general information about Liberty Weekend events, or time and place of American Wind Symphony concerts, call (800) 345-LADY).

title: Insurance Yields Get Competitive
description: WHEN Rosalie Resnick, a New York securities trader, had some money to invest last year, she chose a $100,000 variable life insurance policy.

title: CORRUPTION INQUIRY IS AT A NEW STAGE
description: New York City's municipal corruption scandal has reached an important crossroads, in the view of politicians, prosecutors and government officals.

title: Mixed-Use Condo
description: At first a parochial elementary school, later considered as the site for a disco, the burned-out building stood vacant at the corner of East 30th Street and Third Avenue for more than a decade. The site lies between the Murray Hill and Gramercy Park areas.

title: THE CARPACCIO RENAISSANCE
description: WHEN ITALY'S FAMED CIPRIANI FAMILY blessed New York with its new restaurant - aptly named Harry Cipriani - in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel last November, I was flooded with memories of Venice. For all the aimless debutantes and Armani-clad stockbrokers crowding the waiting area, the place nevertheless reeks of the original Harry's Bar, just a few steps from the San Marco water-taxi stop.

title: WHERE THE ELEGANT MEETS THE ORDINARY
description: In London's fashionable Chelsea, a row of two-story flats, small shops, an occasional restaurant, a shoe-repair store and a bakery all line a narrow two-way street that is secluded from the traffic and noise of Brompton Road and other busy streets that surround it. It's a pretty street, one that at first glance seems not unlike dozens of others in London. Walton Street is special, though; like few others in the city, this short street, a little more than a quarter of a mile long, reflects a broad spectrum of London life. Moreover, it is a street in transition, where fashionable shops are taking up residence beside the long-established hardware store and dry cleaner.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Supreme Court has given the Federal Environmental Protection Agency clearance to clean up the Lone Pine Landfill in Marlboro Township, but the decision left open the possibility that the agency will not be able to collect all of the cost ($17 million) from the companies whose chemicals were dumped illegally at Lone Pine, one of New Jersey's most serious Superfund sites.

title: LOUDSPEAKERS FOR THE GREAT OUTDOORS
description: At the onset of summer, music - along with just about everything else -moves outdoors. Listeners lucky enough to have a bit of acreage around the house, or maybe just a backyard big enough to keep neighbors out of earshot, are busily rigging the grounds for stereo alfresco. After all, music under the open sky has long been one of the delectable aspects of summer festivals, and with a suitable pair of outdoor speakers, it can be can be domesticated for home consumption.

title: 'FRESH AIR' FAMILIES AWAIT CITY CHILDREN
description: EVERY year, Sid Sussman watches the children get off the bus from New York City.

title: INLAND WETLANDS DISCUSSED
description: YEAR after year, legislation intended to protect New Jersey's dwindling inland wetlands has, to quote Russell Cookingham, director of the state's Division of Fish and Wildlife, ''fallen by the wayside for one reason or another.''

title: Archbishop Lifts Ban On a Pregnant Student
description: A Roman Catholic archbishop has set aside church policies and ordered high school officials to allow a pregnant senior to graduate with her class.

title: CAN'T ANYBODY HERE WRITE THESE GAMES? THE TROUBLE WITH SPORTS FICTION
description: WHY are there so few great sports novels? In America, as in my native England, we are tirelessly fascinated by sports and ever absorbed by the feats of athletes. We suffer from no lack of original and powerful writers. So why, when we set down a list of the great novels about sports, does it seem so short?

title: SRI LANKA TRAIN BLAST KILLS 12
description: Twelve people were killed and 40 were wounded today by a bomb that exploded in a passenger train in a Colombo suburb, a military spokesman said.

title: Cynthia B. Goldstein Wed To Peter J. Cirlin on L.I.
description: Cynthia B. Goldstein and Peter J. Cirlin were married yesterday at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., by Rabbi Steven Folberg. Parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Terry Goldstein of Kings Point and East Hampton, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Cirlin of Beechurst, Queens.

title: TAYLOR DOUTHIT
description: Taylor Douthit, whose glove is in the Baseball Hall of Fame for a record he set 58 years ago, died May 28 after a short illness.

title: VILLAGE AT ODDS WITH POLICE
description: THE South Shore village of Woodsburgh battled the Nassau County Police Department in the courts for eight years for the right to establish its own police force.

title: Laura Joseph a Bride
description: Laura Adele Joseph, a writer and public-relations executive in New York, and Robert Andrew Mogil, an insurance account executive in New York, were married last night at the Oakwood Club in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. Rabbi Daniel Jeremy Silver and Cantor Sarah Sager officiated. The bride, a magna cum laude graduate of Duke University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Joseph Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Mr. Mogil, a cum laude graduate of Duke, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Mogil of Hewlett Neck, L.I.

title: 'MISTAKE' DEFEATS GUIDRY
description: Ron Guidry sat quietly at his locker this afternoon and lamented the poor luck and untimely pitching that had led to a 4-3 Yankee loss to the Oakland A's. He made few mistakes, he concluded, but they all were decisive.

title: Martha McNally, James Kerney 2d Exchange Vows
description: Martha McNally, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McNally of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James Kerney 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Kerney of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Pittsford, Vt. The Rev. Robert T. Kennedy performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title:
SUMMER READING;
TRAVEL
description: IN the introduction to his ''Tales of Travel'' in 1923, Lord Curzon wrote: ''Travel is still the science of the unexpected and the unknown. The joys of travel . . . lie in a good many things: in the observation of new people and scenes, in the making of discoveries, in the zest of sport or adventure, in the pleasures of companionship. . . . One can make friends with places as well as people; and an hour's, even a minute's experience in one spot may be more precious than a sojourn of months in another. These are the intimacies that survive, and constitute a perpetual endowment.''

title: MEXICO'S BAD IMAGE IN THE U.S., AND VICE VERSA
description: IT may be a historical footnote for Americans, but Mexicans will never forget that their country was defeated by the United States in the Mexican-American War of 1848 and forced to cede half its territory. They also remember the conspicuous interference of the United States at several points during their revolution beginning in 1910, including the landing of American marines. So relations between the United States and Mexico are marked by the latter's belief that its powerful neighbor to the north is always ready to intervene in its affairs.

title: HOMETOWN BOYS MAKE GOOD...
description: Ritterize (RIT'ter-ize) An attempt to rescue a brokerage house from scandal or other unseemly plight by sending in what appears to be a hard-hitting, competitive, straight shooter -often named Rittereiser - to take command.

title: SUMMER OFFERS A SPECTRUM OF SHOWS, FROM MOTOWN MUSIC TO BROADWAY FARE
description: For television, at least, summer is not the hottest of seasons, as the networks stock their schedules with reruns and gear up for the fall showcase. For cable, though, the seasonal lull represents a welcome opportunity to capture more viewers - and it will try to light a few fires on its own with premieres that range from concert specials to World Cup action and from documentaries to Broadway plays.

title: SHIITE-PALESTINIAN FIGHT RAGES IN BEIRUT
description: Heavy fighting involving artillery, tanks and rocket-propelled grenades resumed today between Shiite Moslem militiamen and Palestinians around three refugee districts on the southern outskirts of Beirut, and many casualties were reported by both sides.

title: ASTROS BEAT EXPOS ON DAVIS'S HOMER
description: Glenn Davis hit a home run that broke an eighth-inning tie tonight and lifted the Houston Astros over the Montreal Expos, 4-3.

title: HUMAN-ORGAN TRANSPLANTS GAIN WITH NEW STATE LAWS
description: When Mary Jane O'Neill walked into her office at New York City's Eye Bank for Sight Restoration Tuesday, she hoped that perhaps one dying person in that city had donated an eye for transplanting over the long holiday weekend. Ten people had. ''It's incredible,'' said Mrs. O'Neill, the eye bank's executive director. ''The number of donors is growing all the time now.''

title:
ART;
OUT OF THE '60's, A MEETING OF HISTORY AND ESTHETICS
description: VIEWED with the hindsight of two decades, the emergence in the 1960's of Pop Art, Minimalism and Color Field abstraction appears as a logical, almost inevitable reaction against Abstract Expressionism, the dominant movement in American art since the late 1940's.

title: Thomas C. Lynch Dies at 83; Ex-Attorney General on Coast
description: Thomas Connor Lynch, a former California Attorney General who was the only Democrat to win statewide office in Ronald Reagan's 1966 gubernatorial sweep, died of cancer Thursday. He was 83 years old.

title: Simpson Has Edge
description: Terry Simpson, who is considered the favorite among the three candidates deemed likely to succeed Al Arbour as coach of the Islanders, said yesterday from his home in Saskatchewan that Bill Torrey, the Islander general manager, had telephoned him following Arbour's resignation to apprise him of the coaching vacancies, and that they planned to hold further discussions this week. Simpson is the only one to have met with Torrey in the last month and the only one approached by him about the vacant coaching job since Arbour's announcement last week.

title: Suzanne O'Neill Marries
description: Suzanne Honora O'Neill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis O'Neill of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Cooperstown, N.Y., was married yesterday to Timothy Edward Lees, a son of Mrs. Therese K. Lees of Upper Saddle River and William R. Lees of Morristown, N.J. Msgr. Thaddeus Wojciehowski performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Church in Trenton. The bride is a special assistant to Governor Kean of New Jersey and her husband is a money broker in New York.

title: BASEBALL ON THEIR MINDS -- THE LURE OF THE DIAMOND, THE PLACE OF THE PLOT
description: ''DURING those years when most men of promise achieve an adult education, if only in the school of war,'' wrote F. Scott Fitzgerald upon Ring Lardner's death, in lamenting what he saw as Lardner's vast, unfulfilled potential, ''Ring moved in the company of a few dozen illiterates playing a boy's game. A boy's game with no more possibilities than a boy could master, a game bounded by walls which kept out danger, change or adventure.''

title: DANCE: LAUGHING STONE
description: MYTH-making seems to be a growing interest among younger modern-dance choreographers at work today in New York. With her great gift for condensation and vibrant, theatrical abstraction, Sin Cha Hong would seem to be an ideal mythologizer. There has been a suggestion of mysterious storytelling in many of the dances by this Korean-born choreographer, as well as a sense of some primal community, often among women, and of a metaphoric journey through life.

title: Fairfield Rentals Surprisingly Negotiable
description: LONG considered one of the more difficult places in the New York metropolitan region to find rental housing of any kind and at any price, Fairfield County has lately been flooded with apartments and condominums for rent.

title: Warehousing
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Pains
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CONSTRUCTION, THE 1636 WAY, AT THE OLD STATE HOUSE
description: PASSERS-BY at the Old State House in Hartford have been stopping to stare at an unusual work crew laboring on the east lawn of the historic building.

title: THE WEST BANK OF THE HUDSON PERPARES FOR LIBERTY CELEBRATION
description: WHILE New York City prepares to herald the centennial of the Statue of Liberty, plans also are being made on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River, which will offer an assortment of vantage points for watching the main events.

title: No Headline
description: Robert Allen's comments May 11 [ ''Community Colleges Comment on 'Quality Control' '' ] are a real disservice to the students and faculty of Nassau Community College. His observations are a response to a critical essay on community college education by William Powers of Suffolk County Community College [ Opinion Page, April 27 ] .

title: New Products Sweeping The Markets
description: AN array of new investment products has swept the financial markets in recent years, often leaving investors baffled as to which products, if any, are best suited to their needs. While many of today's so-called new investment vehicles are repackaged variations of the long-familiar stock and bond mutual funds, some are indeed unique, reflecting both the recent changes in the financial markets and the needs of investors.

title: KEENE WORKING ON A HIGH NOTE
description: ''WE HAVE no history, no tradition, not even a central concert hall to call our home,'' Christopher Keene, the music director of the Long Island Philharmonic, said the other day. ''But our audiences began to come very quickly, because it was clear that this was an orchestra better than any Long Island had ever known.'' This is an exciting time for the Long Island Philharmonic. While the orchestra already serves an annual audience of more than 100,000 people and offers master classes, open rehearsals and preconcert lectures, its activities are expanding. Recordings are planned, and today the orchestra begins a series of regular radio concerts over WQXR.

title: SPACE ODYSSEYS, ODDITIES AND OPPORTUNITIES
description: AT THE moment, America's space program does not seem poised for a new golden age.

title: Robert Flock Marries Laureen Burke on L.I.
description: Laureen Anne Burke, a daughter of Elizabeth Anne Burke of Garden City, L.I., and Robert Joseph Burke of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Benjamin Flock, a son of Joan Flock of Garden City and the late Charles Flock. Msgr. Emil A. Wcela and the Rev. Luke Travers performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Joseph's Church in Garden City.

title: CLEANUP IS REVIVING ISTANBUL'S GOLDEN HORN
description: Now and again lately, porpoises have been sighted in the Golden Horn, and if they are netted quickly and rushed back into the Bosporus, they may survive their incautious incursion into the fabled inlet's polluted waters.

title: JAZZ: JAKI BYARD, PIANIST
description: JAKI BYARD, one of a fading breed of jazz pianists whose experience and curiosity is so wide-ranging that he can fit into almost any situation, played solo piano through last night at the Burgundy Cafe/Gallery.

title: AT PELTON'S ESPIONAGE TRIAL, EVEN THE EVIDENCE IS SECRET
description: Even before Ronald W. Pelton told the Federal Bureau of Investigation about selling intelligence secrets to the Soviet Union, a bureau agent testified today, he was in so much trouble that his interrogators feared he would be arrested by another agency before he could confess.

title: Carey Churchill Is Wed To Clifford Steven Cort
description: Carey Cunningham Churchill and Clifford Steven Cort were married yesterday at the Union League Club. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman officiated. The bride, the marketing manager for the Tucker Anthony Management Corporation in Boston, is the daughter of John P. Churchill of Califon, N.J., and Mary Carey Churchill of New York, director of corporate affairs for Grey Advertising.

title: LOVE OF BLOOMS
description: FLOWERS AND FRUIT By Colette. Edited by Robert Phelps. Translated by Matthew Ward. 163 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95. NO one has written better about gardens than Colette. Her mother, Sido, gardened passionately above and below their house at Saint-Sauveur-en-Puisaye. Colette, her youngest child, was left to moon and dawdle around the plants as much as she liked. Plants were her earliest and most faithful companions; she looked into them as deep and hard as only a child can, and she never forgot what she learned. Of each she remembered the mode and the imprint, as well as the way it behaved in garden society. The gardens she liked least were the ones she herself had to make from scratch; she entered fully into the atmosphere of gardens already existing, complete with their animals and insects. Each crumbling wall, with its rampant stragglers and tangled blooms attended by ragged butterflies, worked its way into her memory.

title: MUSIC IN PUERTO RICO, HIKING IN JAPAN
description: IN SAN JUAN, 30TH SEASON FOR CASALS FESTIVAL -With visiting maestros, visiting soloists and a visiting orchestra, the Casals Festival in Puerto Rico - a musical event founded by the cellist Pablo Casals - will celebrate its 30th anniversary this year.

title: Running With The Bulls On Wall St.
description: PREDICTING the stock market in coming months comes down to figuring out whether the declining oil prices and interest rates that have sent stock prices to record heights will prevail, the experts say.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO OFFSET WATER DEFICIENCY
description: NOW that summer is fast approaching, a few random observations about the 1986 spring season are in order.

title: TEEN-AGE PITCHER STRIKES OUT ANGER
description: IN a sense, the pitcher's mound has become the main vehicle in Buffy Spezzano's pursuit of life.

title: Ciro Toscano, Engineer, Wed to Siobhan Fergus
description: Siobhan Fergus, a sales consultant for the New York Health and Racquet Club, and Ciro Toscano, an electrical engineer at the Sperry Corporation in Great Neck, L.I., were married yesterday at the Church of Saint Thomas More in Manhattan by the Rev. Thomas Joyce, a Roman Catholic priest.

title:
DINING OUT;
STOREFRONT DINING IN MAPLEWOOD
description: THANK goodness for restaurant owners who write to reviewers, asking that they come to their restaurants. Without them, many charming places might never be discovered by any but local diners.

title: REWARD OFFERED IN ATTACK ON TRAINMAN
description: NJ TRANSIT and the union representing its trainmen have offfered a joint $10,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of the four men said to be responsible for throwing a 20-year-old trainman off a speeding train here last month.

title: Dr. John Sconzo Wed To Catherine H. White
description: Catherine Hall White, a nurse, and Dr. John Michael Sconzo, who received a medical degree last month, were married yesterday at the Community Church in Glen Rock, N.J., by the Rev. Vernon Dethmers, a minister of the Reformed Church.

title: In First Place, Astros Live In Luxury and Anonymity
description: THE Mets have a heftier lead, but the Houston Astros have spent more time leading the National League West than the Mets have leading the National League East. The Astros have been in first place alone for 40 of the season's 55 days, the Mets 39 days. No one has matched the Astros' style of lofty living, but no one has lived so luxuriously in such anonymity. The Astros truly are baseball's best-kept secret.

title: OVERCOMING FIRST-ROUND BLUES
description: In unpopularity among the players, the first round of a tournament ranks second only to the final round.

title: DIVULGE AND EQUALIZE WINNERS IN SMITH HANDICAP
description: Divulge and Equalize scored similarly styled victories an hour apart in the divided Red Smith Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday, but raced over drastically different surfaces. Divulge just missed a course record while smoking along through the sunshine on a rock-hard inner turf course, then Equalize raced through the rain after a downpour had turned the footing slow and soggy.

title: Sunday Observer; Flying With a Heavy Heart
description: ECONOMISTS SAY airline deregulation is the best thing to happen to customers since the invention of the electric salami slicer, and they have figures to prove it.

title: LIFE IS WHAT INTERRUPTS FISHING TRIPS
description: MISADVENTURES OF A FLY FISHERMAN My Life With and Without Papa. By Jack Hemingway. Illustrated. 326 pp. Dallas: Taylor Publishing Company. $17.95.

title: Graduation Incentive
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC IN PROGRAM OF NEW WORKS
description: THE New York Philharmonic's Friday night concert at Avery Fisher Hall had several rewards, but none more heartening for this listener than the sight of a large auditorium nearly filled with people listening to the music of their time. And listening intently - spontaneously cheering (and occasionally booing) at the end of each work.

title: GLOUCESTER MARKS 300th YEAR
description: SEVEN weeks of events marking the tercentenary of Gloucester County will reach a high point here next Sunday with the dedication of a granite monument honoring both the founders and residents.

title: What's On Top? Add-On Condos Called Lollipops
description: LOLLIPOP condominiums are coming to town and the New York State Attorney General's office is not giving them a warm reception. ''It's the new disease in the industry,'' said Mary Sabatini DiStephan, section chief in the Real Estate Financing Bureau, which reviews plans for condominiums and cooperatives.

title: Fowler a Candidate
description: Among the five candidates for the job of head basketball coach at Appalachian State in Boone, N.C., is Ned Fowler, who resigned from Tulane last year in the wake of that school's point-shaving scandal. Kevin Cantwell vacated the Appalachian State job to become Bobby Cremins's assistant at Georgia Tech, and the other four candidates for the job are: Gerry Vaillancourt, Cantwell's assistant; Joe Williams, former Florida State coach; Ball State coach, Al Brown and former Colorado coach, Tom Apke.

title: BUS LINES GETTING AID
description: PRIVATE bus companies providing service in eight New Jersey counties will be receiving refurbished rolling stock, courtesy of NJ Transit.

title: 3 COMMUNITIES JOIN SANCTUARY DRIVE
description: THE alien-sanctuary movement, begun in Arizona in 1982, has spread to Connecticut. An increasing number of churches are openly supporting creation of havens in the state for Central American refugees.

title: OFFICIALS SAY TERRORIST GROUP HAD ITS ROOTS IN EFFORT TO IMPROVE PRISON LIFE
description: A nine-year pattern of bombings, murder and bank robberies, charged to eight people in a Federal indictment here this week, had its origins in a movement to seek better conditions for prison inmates, according to Federal law-enforcement officials.

title: Miss Evans Wed To R. W. Bodner
description: Elizabeth Hendrik Evans, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Evans of Cohasset, Mass., was married yesterday to Randall Wayne Bodner, a son of Elsie M. Bodner of Danville, Ky., and Jack K. Bodner of Corning, N.Y. The Rev. John J. Keohane performed the ceremony at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Cohasset.

title: MARKETING TO SNEEZERS AND SNIFFLERS
description: IN 1984, the last full year in which Benadryl was sold by prescription, the antihistamine brought the Warner-Lambert Company $20 million in revenues. Then, in mid-1985, the company got permission from the Food and Drug Administration to sell Benadryl over the counter. The result: Sales rocketed to $32 million in the last six months of 1985 alone. ''When you have the aura of a high-tech prescription drug being opened up to the people, it's a strong selling point,'' said David K. Crossen, a drug analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.

title: Mr. Outside Tackles the Taxis
description: The easy part of becoming chairman of New York's Taxi and Limousine Commission is improving on your predecessor. The hard part is bringing good management and policy to an agency and industry overwhelmed by incompetence and corruption. Gorman Gilbert, Mayor Koch's choice to succeed Jay Turoff, has his work cut out.

title: EXPLORING LITTLE-KNOWN PARKS
description: Because of cheaper gasoline and qualms about traveling to Europe, America's best-known national and state parks are expecting a deluge of visitors this summer. At Yosemite National Park, for example, where campsites and hotel rooms are always scarce during the summer, even parking spaces will be rationed this year.

title: A New Allegation Of Insider Trading
description: The Government's crackdown on insider trading continued last week with the indictment of four young Wall Street professionals - a lawyer, a stockbroker and two financial analysts - and a client of the stockbroker's. They were accused of trading in stocks and options on the basis of closely held information stolen from the files of a New York law firm that represents many large corporations.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Deficit Looms Larger - Back in February, the Office of Management and Budget estimated the 1986 deficit at roughly $202 billion. The Congressional Budget Office put the figure at $208 billion. But Gert Von Der Linde, economist for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, says it will be higher. Current patterns of revenue-gathering and spending, he says, suggest a deficit of $222.6 billion for fiscal 1986, which ends on Oct. 1.

title: Bond Executive And Ann Derrey Exchange Vows
description: Ann Stewart Derrey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fairbairn Derrey of Westfield, N.J., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., and Douglass Andrew Bermingham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eldridge Langstaff Bermingham of South Londonderry, Vt., were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield. The Rev. Beatrice Blair performed the ceremony.

title: 8-FOOT TOOTH FINDS A HOME
description: A NEW HAVEN dentist got rid of his biggest toothache last week. Although it required the use of a tow truck, he said the extraction was well worth the trouble.

title:
BRIEFING;
Kemp Counts His Fans
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York was considerably bouyed the other day when a letter arrived from New Hampshire, signed by 34 Republican members of the State Legislature, urging him to run for President.

title: IN COLOMBIA VOLCANO STIRS MORE TROUBLE
description: Isolated white and pink crosses, each marked with the fateful date of Nov. 13, 1985, now stand in silent protest against the fury of nature on the vast and desolate mudbank where about 22,000 people lie buried.

title: ARE EAST AND WEST EDGING CLOSER, OR JUST EDGY?
description: THE gamut of strains, dangers and opportunities in Soviet-American relations was unusually evident last week. There was substantial activity on both sides - on the Middle East, arms control and human rights. But with prospects in doubt for a second summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, diplomats and analysts were hard pressed to find a consistent pattern.

title: Patricia M. Beilman and David Poor Are Married
description: Patricia Marie Beilman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lewis Beilman of Madison, Wis., and David Brownlow Poor, a son of Mrs. Daniel Sidney Poor of Ridgewood, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mr. Poor, were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Kenneth B. Swanson officiated.

title: 'AIN'T MISBEHAVIN'' IS STILL ENDEARING
description: THE American Theater Wing's 40th annual Tony Awards, which will be telecast live from New York City's Minskoff Theater tonight at 9 P.M. on the CBS network, reflect the scarcity of musicals to sing and dance about. One longs, wistfully, for a season of more melodic substance and sustenance.

title: ANXIOUS FAMILIES AWAIT IDENTITIES OF FATAL BUS CRASH VICTIMS
description: Struggling to maintain their composure, scores of anxious friends and family members waited today in a retirement home for the identities of 18 people who were killed and 22 who were injured when a tour bus plunged into a central California river Friday morning.

title: And Now It's Down to Three
description: The news was gladly received east of the Mississippi: The Reagan Administration had selected three potential sites for a nuclear waste dump - in Nevada, Washington and Texas - and suspended plans for a second repository.

title: Kim Ann Fararo Wed To Bennett W. Brooks
description: Kim Ann Fararo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sal Fararo of Dumont, N.J., was married yesterday to Bennett William Brooks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Brooks of New York. The Rev. Thomas O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Albert Sturmer performed the ceremony at the Seven Hills Country Inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: THE PERSIAN GULF REDISCOVERS BELT-TIGHTENING
description: A DECADE has passed since soaring oil prices transformed the Persian Gulf kingdoms, with their sun-baked mud towns and dusty camel tracks, into an Arabian Nights fairyland of air-conditioned palaces, marble shopping malls and six-lane highways trimmed with purple mimosa.

title: Leverage, a 2-Edged Sword
description: THE magic of using leverage - the employing of borrowed funds to make an investment - has nowhere been more apparent than in real estate.

title: Switching Loyalty Called an Error
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 90 Days for 8 Seconds
description: The conviction and 90-day jail term of James Eliason, who rode his motorized dirt bike on a public road for eight seconds, was upheld this week in State Superior Court. A three-judge panel ruled that he was properly convicted of driving an unregistered motor vehicle and driving with a suspended license for a one-block, eight-second excursion on a residential street in Bethlehem Township. In his appeal, Mr. Eliason argued that his offense was so minor it did not warrant the stigma of a criminal conviction.

title: Great Books, Misread: Fear of Orwell
description: The pitfalls of cultural detente are sadly apparent in the decision to let the Soviet Union censor an international drama festival in Baltimore. The president of the sponsoring institute, Wole Soyinka, a Nigerian playwright, bowed to Soviet boycott threats and barred a British dramatization of Orwell's ''Animal Farm.'' Mr. Soyinka's defenders say he was bound by this language in the institute's charter: ''The organization shall be guided by the principle of mutual respect of the national traditions of each country.''

title: ARMENIAN CHURCH BEING BUILT AT SHORE
description: WHEN Kevork Hovnanian arrived in the United States from Iraq 27 years ago, he made a quiet promise to build a church some day in honor of the one family member who had not accompanied him: his mother, Yester, who had died some years earlier.

title: HYPNOTIST WITH EYE ON STOCKS
description: ''I MAKE 90 percent of my income as an entertainer,'' said Ken Weber of Great Neck. ''I spend 90 percent of my time on the newsletter.''

title: FINDING CLUES IN A SLIGHT HITCH
description: Some bridge hands end with one player suffering from shock. He is disappointed to find that a ''sure'' trump trick has disappeared thanks to the efforts of a shrewd opponent. This happened to the West player on the diagramed deal played at the Mill Basin Club in Brooklyn, but he had to take some of the responsibility: He hesitated slightly in the middle of the play for no good reason and gave the declarer a valuable clue.

title: Katherine Ann Kalin Plans To Wed William Medlock
description: An October wedding is planned by Katherine Ann Kalin and William Nicholson Medlock, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Richard Kalin of Madison, Conn., have announced. Mr. Medlock is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Medlock of Port Washington, L.I.

title: WHEN WEAPONS DON'T LIVE UP TO THE SPECS
description: TO Representative Sam Stratton, a Democrat from upstate New York, the recent dispute over tests of an Army vehicle known as the Bradley revealed ''a system that's flying blind.''

title: THE SWISS STOP KEEPING SECRETS
description: LAST March 25, Pedro Yap, a member of the Philippine Commission on Good Government, was en route to Bern to talk with the Swiss Government about repatriating the estimated hundreds of millions of dollars that Ferdinand Marcos had on deposit in Swiss banks. While traveling, he learned that Switzerland, unasked, had frozen Mr. Marcos's assets. That meant the Philippine Government could not touch them - but neither could Mr Marcos.

title: Miss McCoy Wed To J. A. McCarthy
description: Sarah Beeckman McCoy, a microbiologist at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., and James Albert McCarthy, an associate in the government relations department of the Hershey Foods Corporation in Washington, were married yesterday at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington. The Rev. Joseph Michini officiated.

title: COPING WITH A HOMESICK CAMPER
description: I USED to wake up every morning at 6 A.M. and watch the sun rise,'' said Lori Musinger, 18 years old, recalling her first summer at sleep-away camp as a homesick 8-year-old. ''At instructional swim, I'd sit in the water and cry.''

title: EDWARD I. MAHER
description: Edward I. Maher, former vice president in charge of public relations for the National Association of Manufacturers, died Thursday at his home in Port Washington, L.I., after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Focus: Dallas; The Glut at The Top of The Market
description: DESPITE worrisome slumps in the oil industry and commercial real estate, the Dallas economy remains strong and is continuing to add jobs. But although the city apparently will again finish the year among the top five in new-home sales, that is of little comfort to dozens of speculative builders of luxury homes.

title: U.A.W. TO ADDRESS UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: When the delegates gather Sunday for the triennial convention of the United Automobile Workers in Anaheim, Calif., they will be without their Canadian branch for the first time in 50 years and facing fundamental questions about the union's future in a rapidly changing industry.

title: Boat Safety Law Toughening
description: National Safe Boating Week, which begins today, reflects an attempt by Federal officials to draw attention to safety in a sport that involves as many as 68 million Americans. But their precautions go further than that.

title: Opie Beats Gengler In 'Softball' Squash
description: Lisa Opie of England, the second-ranked women's squash racquets player in the world, easily defeated Nancy Gengler of New York City yesterday at the $50,000 Swan Laser Die U.S. Pro Softball Squash Championships.

title: SOVIET SAYS REAGAN ENDANGERS 2 KEY ARMS PACTS
description: The Soviet Union said today that President Reagan's decision to go beyond negotiated limits in nuclear arms was an ''exceptionally dangerous measure,'' and it warned that if he went ahead, Moscow would no longer consider itself bound by the treaties on strategic weapons.

title: KINDERGARTEN TRIAL BY FIRE
description: KINDERGARTEN registration: I made a big deal about it, and that was a mistake. By the time the big day arrived, Aaron, my 4-year-old, balked. ''I don't wanna go!''

title:
BRIEFING;
A Cosmos Club Speech
description: On the advice of counsel, Assistant Secretary of Defense James H. Webb Jr. has decided to go ahead with an address to the male-only Cosmos Club in Washington on Monday. He made his decision despite a complaint lodged by the Americans for Democratic Action that speaking at the Cosmos Club would violate Federal regulations barring discrimination on the basis of sex.

title: Recent Sales
description: BRANCHBURG $207,900 10 Winding Willow Way *2*4 bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; beamed *2*ceiling, patio, deck; taxes $2,503. EAST ORANGE $57,900 15 Stockton Place *2*6-bedroom, 2-bath, older colonial; enclosed *2*porch, basement, rec room, taxes $2,018. MAPLEWOOD $163,000 30 Lancaster Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; basement *2*workshop and darkroom, den, enclosed porch; taxes $3,427. PARAMUS $575,000 174 Alpine Drive *2*4-beddroom, 3 1/2-bath, 25-year-old contemporary; *2*pool, tennis court, 1.25 acres; taxes $6,911. SECAUCUS $207,000 112 Hamon Cove Tower *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old high-rise condominium; *2*foyer, balcony $430 monthly maintenance; taxes $3,260. SHORT HILLS $640,000 205 Highland Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 3-bath, 34-year-old expanded ranch; *2*pool, breakfast nook, 1 acre; taxes $10,152. OTHER AREAS MASSAPEQUA, L.I. $225,000 22 Lake Shore Boulevard *2*3-bedroom, 3-bath, 30-year-old split-level; sunken living-room, *2*slate patio, lakefront; taxes, $4,000. NORWALK, CONN. $305,000 1 Pine Hill Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 130-year-old restored Victorian, *2*wine cellar, back staircase, 1.1 acres; taxes $5,556. CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. $167,000 11 Pine Hill Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 23-year-old contemporary; eat-in kitchen, *2*deck off dining area, 2-car garage, 0.57 acre; taxes $2,712.

title: SURPRISES LODGED IN SENATE TAX PLAN
description: Tax lawyers, accountants and individuals may find a few surprises in the completed version of the Senate Finance Committee's tax revision plan, including the extension of tax shelter restrictions to many people who put money into small businesses.

title: PARENTS DIVORCE AND THE CHILDREN SUFFER
description: ''IT was awful, so awful!'' Josiah sobbed. The rest of my first-grade class had gone to music so Josiah and I were alone in the corner by the fish tank. He climbed into my lap.

title: Adjusting to Holden Caulfield
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPER MILL PLAYHOUSE OFFERS A SCINTILLATING HIT IN 'CANDIDE'
description: WITH its delicious ''Candide,'' the Paper Mill Playhouse, which specializes in shows of mass appeal, mostly musicals, reaches the rare level of artistic excellence. What is more, it has come up with the state's best show of the season, musical or not.

title: Michigan State Fire Fells 12
description: A fire broke out early today on the top floor of a six-story dormitory at Michigan State University, injuring 12 students and forcing residents from the building, but the blaze was quickly put out by firefighters, the authorities said. The fire at East Holmes Hall was reported at 5:27 A.M.

title: BEDFORD WEIGHS 15-MILE GREENBELT PLAN
description: TOWN officials in Bedford are proposing a conservation plan that would create a greenbelt system linking the various open spaces throughout the town.

title: KRISTIANSEN IS FIRST IN MINI MARATHON
description: The L'eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park yesterday shaped up as a race among several top runners, but from the early stages to the finish it turned out to be a race between Ingrid Kristiansen and eight motor vehicles.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: WE'D be pretty miserable if we never got any, but then again, getting them can also be a problem. If we say, ''Yes,'' we may regret it; if we say, ''No,'' we may regret it. What to do? How to know?

title: METS' KNIGHT HAS A WHIRLWIND WEEK
description: ''It was a very eventful week,'' Ray Knight conceded. ''You know, as far as having a baby one day and getting into a fight the next day, I don't do either very often.''

title: Episcopalians Reject Woman as Bishop
description: Clergy and lay delegates representing 27,000 members of the capital's Episocopal diocese, today chose the Rev. Ronald Haines as an assistant bishop, rejecting another priest who would have been the first woman elevated to the church hierarchy since its founding.

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. MUST AID BRITAIN ON EXTRADITIONS
description: President Reagan, seeking to prod the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to act on a new extradition treaty with Britain, warned today against allowing ''terrorists'' a ''safe haven'' in the United States.

title: Belinda T. Buck Married in Jersey
description: Belinda Therese Buck was married yesterday to Morten Henrik Kielland at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J., by the Rev. Alfred M. Niese. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Austin Buck of Bernardsville.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SODA POPPERY The History of Soft Drinks in America. By Stephen N. Tchudi. Illustrated. 148 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $13.95. (Ages 10 to 14) I AM, I confess, my dentist's dream patient, when I can afford to see him or pay his bills. I consume 64 ounces of a particular soft drink a day, which adds up to 23,360 ounces every year or 700,800 ounces over the span of my adult life to date.

title: CABARET: HELEN SCHNEIDER
description: WHEN Helen Schneider was singing at Trude Heller's, Tramps and the Bottom Line 9 or 10 years ago, she was already well grounded in blues, rock, jazz and pop singing. There was critical acclaim for her vocal and emotional range and her ability to develop fresh approaches to familiar material. But there were also objections that she stayed too close to cabaret convention and that ''a long-winded, rambling monologue about herself'' almost brought her act ''to a leaden halt.''

title: 'THANKS, TEACHER' GOES A LONG WAY IN A TOUGH JOB
description: A RECENT news article pointed out that a significant number of schoolteachers are leaving the profession. This is unfortunate.

title: Lisa A. Doyle Has Wedding In Bay State
description: Lisa Ann Doyle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Doyle Jr. of Salem, Mass., was married yesterday to Peter Eaton Gardiner, a son of Janet E. Glover of Hanover, N.H., and Robert M. Gardiner of Far Hills, N.J., and Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. John McCormack performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Salem.

title: PARIS
description: Spring came late in Paris, what with the coldest, rainiest April in decades, and that meant a certain postponement in the annual transformation of the city from indoor to outdoor spectacle. But the sun has reappeared; shoulders have relaxed; the mornings are once again punctuated by a cacophony, the rattling of wood on pavement as black-vested waiters put the chairs and tables of sidewalk cafes into place.

title: Linkage in the East Village
description: For most of New York's history, the eastern bulge of Manhattan, tucked below Union Square and above the Manhattan Bridge, was known as the Lower East Side.

title: Cable TV
description: Variety marks a group of film entries that will be shown for the first time on cable this week. Joe Dante's ''Gremlins'' (1984) is a funny but frightening fantasy about a group of small furry creatures who take over a small town. It's showing on Sunday at 9 A.M. and 9 P.M. on HBO and at 8 P.M. on WHT; Tuesday at 1 P.M. and 8 P.M. on Cinemax; Thursday at 10 A.M. and 7 P.M. on HBO; Saturday at 10 A.M. and 10 P.M. on Cinemax, at noon and at 8 P.M. on Showtime. Chevy Chase heads a sporting cast in ''Fletch'' (1985), a breezy, lightweight comic mystery set in Los Angeles - Sunday on Showtime at 10 A.M. and 8 P.M. and at noon and 8 P.M. on Cinemax; Wednesday on Cinemax at 10:30 A.M., 8 P.M. and 4:40 A.M., also at 8 P.M. on WHT; Friday at 12:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. on Showtime and on Cinemax at 4:30 P.M. and 11:30 P.M.

title: FRESH AIR FUND BRIGHTENS WEEKEND FOR GIRLS
description: Mirabel Guzman stared at her compass and asked, ''How does this thing know which way north, west or south is?'' Other girls were pitching their tents, while two more called out from the nearby woods, where they were hunched over deer tracks.

title: DISTINCTLY AMERICAN SOPRANO
description: Beverly Sills had an unfortunate recording career. Her great fame dates from the 1966 New York City Opera production of Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' - suddenly, hitherto dormant critics, record executives and opera lovers in general woke up to the fact that there was a fine, distinctly American soprano in our midst, with a voice that was sweet, healthy and adaptable, and a temperament suited to both coloratura fripperies and dramatic roles of breadth and power. Unfortunately, like most overnight successes, Miss Sills had been hard at work for quite some time, as diva-in-residence at the City Opera since 1955. But, during these years when her voice was at its freshest, she was offered the opportunity to make only one major album - a complete recording of Douglas Moore's ''Ballad of Baby Doe'' for M-G-M in 1959 (most recently available on Deutsche Grammophon).

title: Soviet Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: AQUINO IS WORKING ON SOME LAWS TO RULE BY
description: AT their first informal meetings last week, members of the Philippines' new constitutional commission spent hours arguing over whether to arrange their offices alphabetically, what to wear at the opening ceremony tomorrow and whether to address one another formally.

title: LITTLE LEAGUE LAGGING
description: IN the clubhouse of the Westbury Amateur Baseball Association, the oldtimers talk about the glory days. Two decades after a group of 14- and 15-year-olds won the Senior Minor Little League World Championship, the league's patriarchs point to the yellowed team pictures on the wall and still get excited.

title: Chernobyl's Toll Continues to Rise
description: Not so many years ago, the Kremlin scorned rock music and the rest of bourgeois art imported from the decadent West as a waste of time enjoyed by hippies, hooligans, parasites and ''nekulturniye'' - uncultured citizens.

title: SOME DAYS IN JUNE WITH THE YANKEES' QUIET HERO
description: FOR Lou Gehrig, the ill-fated Iron Horse of baseball, June was always a watershed month.

title: MEXICO WAS ONLY WINNER
description: MEXICO literally rose from the rubble yesterday to present a stirring opening of the World Cup of soccer, the most popular sporting event in the world. From the destruction and terror of a massive earthquake last Sept. 19, this endangered but resilient nation today became the first nation to ever hold the World Cup twice.

title: SUFFOLK VOTES SHOREHAM SUIT, CHARGING DECEPTION BY LILCO
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has voted to file a Federal lawsuit charging that for 15 years the Long Island Lighting Company lied about escalating costs for the Shoreham nuclear power plant and that it concealed design and construction defects.

title: Carillon for Kennedy Library
description: A veterans' group has presented a carillon to the John F. Kennedy Library here. The carillon, dedicated Thursday on what would have been Kennedy's 69th birthday, is a gift from the American Veterans of World War II, Korea and Vietnam.

title: Roundtable: Experts Name Their Investment Choices
description: Amid one of the strongest bull markets of the postwar period, three leading Wall Street figures were asked to assess the outlook for the next six months to a year and discuss investment strategies appropriate for individuals. They are: Elaine M. Garzarelli, director of sector analysis and executive vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.; A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services Inc., and James S. Martin, executive vice president of the College Retirement Equities Fund. They were interviewed by Jan M. Rosen and Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times staff.

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
OLD BRIDGE
description: AT the crossroads of New Jersey, where north gently rolls into south, sits Old Bridge, a sprawling 42-square-mile township where pastoral surroundings serve as counterpoint to its rapid growth, including the $500 million Metro Park South mixed-use project now under construction.

title: A Little Giant To Battle I.B.M. In Mainframes
description: The Burroughs Corporation succeeded last week in taking over the Sperry Corporation, but its main target was I.B.M. The merger will create the nation's second-largest computer company, one that the Burroughs chairman, W. Michael Blumenthal, said would have the ''critical mass'' necessary to give the International Business Machines Corporation genuine competition.

title: Barbara Delaney And Neil Roman Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Delaney Sr. of Louisville, Ky., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Jean Delaney to Neil Kenneth Roman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Roman Jr. of New York. A Sept. 13 wedding is planned.

title: SECTIONS OF STATEMENT BY MOSCOW ON ARMS
description: Following are excerpts from a Soviet Government statement today on arms control and the 1979 strategic arms treaty, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: SPY DAMAGE HELD GRAVE BUT BRIEF
description: Intelligence experts say grave damage occurred when the Soviet Union learned details of the National Security Agency's methods of intercepting military communications, but they believe the agency is now well on its way to recovering its lost abilities.

title: Student Is Wed To Sally Rogers
description: Sally A. Rogers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence B. Rogers Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James Mitchell 3d, the son of Senior Master Sgt. Mitchell Jr., U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Mitchell of Buckingham, Pa. The Rev. Richard H. Stearns performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich.

title: BUSINESS OF MOVING EXECUTIVES EXPANDS
description: DURING their 22 years of marriage, Kate and Larry Lipchiz, both 40 years old, have moved 14 times. But it was their most recent move, from Seneca, S.C., to a rented house in Stamford, Conn., that Kate Lipchiz said was the easiest.

title: IN HIS FATHER'S FOOTSTEPS
description: IT WAS A SUMMER NIGHT ON LONG ISLAND IN 1964, AND Dr. William Cahan was taking his two sons for an after-dinner ice cream, their weekend ritual. Traffic was backed up on the way to the Carvel stand, and Dr. Cahan pulled onto the shoulder to get a look. Up ahead he saw the dazed onlookers, the two smashed cars and the man lying face down in a pool of blood.

title: POLAND ARRESTS FUGITIVE LEADER FROM SOLIDARITY
description: The most sought-after fugitive leader of the Solidarity underground, Zbigniew Bujak, has been captured, the Polish Interior Ministry announced today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Briefing column on the Washington Talk page Saturday incorrectly reported the date of the Celebrity Invitational Dog Show to benefit the Capital Children's Museum. The date is June 8.

title: Amy Vorenberg Planning to Wed Paul A. Maggiotto
description: James Vorenberg, dean of the Harvard Law School, and Mrs. Vorenberg of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mr. Vorenberg's daughter Amy Vorenberg to Paul Anthony Maggiotto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Joseph Maggiotto of Buffalo. A Sept. 13 wedding is planned.

title: LATEST FAILURE CRIPPLES WEST'S SATELLITE ABILITY
description: Officials suspended European space launchings today after an Ariane rocket was destroyed in midair Friday night, throwing the West's launching capability into disarray.

title: About Men; The Alpine Fraternity
description: I STARTED ROCK CLIMBING AT 17, ON THE sandstone cliffs near my home in Boulder, Colo. It was the perfect adolescent kick, more challenging than glue-sniffing, every bit as scary as getting Dad's station wagon up to 100 miles an hour out on Marshall Road. Soon, climbing became more than mere thrill: fleeing the bourgeois tyranny of high school and family, my partners and I could enact a secret utopia of rope and piton. By my sophomore year in college, mountaineering was the most important thing in life. So it would remain for more than a decade.

title: Labor Pains
description: To the Editor:

title: One Prosecutor Is Appointed. . .
description: Michael K. Deaver got last week something that he says he wants -the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate allegations that he turned knowledge and access acquired in public service too quickly to the benefit of private clients, violating a variety of Federal conflict-of-interest statutes.
