title: More Help for The Homeless?
description: One of the most troubling aspects of New York City's barracks-style shelters for the homeless has been the warehousing together of old and young; of the healthy or relatively healthy with alcoholics, drug users and the mentally ill. Last week the Koch administration proposed an $82 million plan to provide separate housing for people with different needs.

title: BEHIND THE MASS CITIZENSHIP CEREMONY
description: MANY OF the immigrants who will become citizens at Ellis Island on July 3 could be doing so because of the initiative of five New Jersey members of Congress.

title: What Tax Proposals Mean
description: AFTER months of uncertainty, a clearer picture of the direction of tax policy is coming into focus on Capitol Hill, providing investors with a better insight into the potential dangers and opportunities of everything from tax shelters to bank accounts.

title:
CHOICES FOR EVERY PORTFOLIO;
A Golden Era For Mutual Funds
description: MUTUAL funds took 56 years to accumulate their first $100 billion in assets. But in the five years since 1980, investors have added an additional $400 billion to funds, putting them over the half-trillion dollar mark. ''If investors could keep this up, the funds would own everything,'' marvels Jon Fossel, marketing director for the Alliance Capital Management Corporation in Manhattan, which manages a group of mutual funds.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 1, 1986
description: Fiction

title: CHESNOKOV ROUTS WILANDER IN PARIS
description: Andrei Chesnokov, ranked first in the Soviet Union but only 81st in the world, was at the top of his game today as he routed Mats Wilander of Sweden, the defending champion, in straight sets at the French Open.

title: HOLIDAY SECURITY IS TIGHT
description: WITH millions of people expected at special events on both sides of the Hudson River over the July 4 weekend, law-enforcement officials will have more on their hands than traffic and crowd control.

title: Updating the Zoning in Murray Hill
description: IN New York, zoning revision never ends. It is an ongoing process of adaptation. But the nature of the revisions does change, and the most recent proposals from the Manhattan office of the Department of City Planning, though not of broad geographic impact, demonstrate how the 1980's contrast with the 1970's from the standpoint of land-use planning in largely developed locations.

title: COMPUTERS CAN KEEP PLANT RECORDS
description: ''March 30. Purple hyacinth begins to bloom.'' So wrote 22-year-old Thomas Jefferson on a spring day in Virginia in 1766, starting the lifetime garden notebooks he would keep even during his presidency. Would Jefferson, always receptive to new ideas, have welcomed a computer to marshal all that data?

title: BACKYARD CULTURE
description: LONG after the students in Barbara Fechter's sixth-grade class have forgotten what Scout troop they once joined, or what Little League team won or lost, they will remember the Backyard Civilization they built in the woods behind their Westorchard School in Chappaqua.

title: Solid Market In New York
description: NEW YORK'S residential real estate market continues to register strong growth, Manhattan brokers and consultants say. But they warn of a flood of luxury condominiums already choking the investment market. About 15,000 condominium units - one result of hastened building schedules because of the recent expiration of a tax program - are expected to come onto the market in the next two years.

title: The Political Lineup for 1986 and Beyond
description: For both parties last week, the politics of 1988 seemed as prominent as the elections of 1986. The first steps in Michigan's selection of convention delegates sent a signal that the religious right is emerging as a new force in the Republican party. And the decision by a tenth state, Maryland, to join the growing regional primary movement gave the generally conservative South new strength in the Democratic Presidential nominating process.

title: WHERE HAVE ALL THE PEOPLE GONE?
description: SOMETIMES, when I go out the door and down the driveway to the mailbox, I half expect to see tumbleweed rolling down the middle of the street. My neighborhood, at high noon on a weekday, resembles a ghost town.

title: Contra Moderates Are Dealt a Stronger Hand
description: Peace seems to have broken out between rival factions of the contras, the guerrillas opposing the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua. After months of bickering and weeks of bargaining, an accord was reached in Miami last week that seems to strengthen the role of Arturo Cruz and Alfonso Robelo - who are willing to consider a negotiated settlement with the Sandinistas - and weakens that of Adolfo Calero - an ideological conservative whose allies believe the Managua regime must be overthrown militarily.

title: RETROSPECTIVE OF DIEGO RIVERA WORK CELEBRATES THE ARTIST'S CENTENNIAL
description: Famous all over the world as a leading Communist artist, he was not only expelled from the Mexican Communist Party, but his petitions for readmission were rejected for the next quarter of a century as well.

title: BOND MARKET OPTIMISM
description: The proposed tax revision bill could provide a big lift for bonds, some experts contend.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NOT SO FAST SONGOLOLO Written and illustrated by Niki Daly. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry/Atheneum. $11.95. (Ages 5 to 8) THE names in ''Not So Fast Songololo'' should be read aloud or sung.

title: DANCE: TWO 'DON QUIXOTE' CASTS
description: TWO different casts of ''Don Quixote'' gave interestingly different accounts of the ballet in performances by the American Ballet Theater on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mikhail Baryshnikov has chosen to tell his story in mostly lighthearted, stage-filling swirls of color and bustle. Kitri is a tempestuous charmer and Basil her eager, teasing lover. There is never any doubt that the two will find a way to marry. And Don Quixote's dreaming breaks into really dark madness only once, introducing a dream ballet that is one of the happiest conceits of the production, conceived and directed by Mr. Baryshnikov with choreography inspired by Marius Petipa and Alexander Gorsky.

title: The Shantytown at Yale Was Also Higher Education
description: To the Editor:

title: A President Needs Discreet Science Advisers
description: To the Editor:

title: FRESH-AIR CHILD ONE OF FAMILY
description: Sitting in the living room of their spacious Garden City home, Charles and Kathleen Krieg recalled recently how James Smith, now 14, seemed a little nervous when he first came to stay with them four summers ago as part of The Fresh Air Fund's Friendly Towns program.

title: Adm. Yost Takes Command Of Coast Guard at Ceremony
description: With the 295-foot Coast Guard tall ship Eagle looming behind him in the Washington Navy Yard, Adm.

title: A PORTRAIT OF TEDDY ROOSEVELT, OUR FIRST MEDIA PRESIDENT
description: ''The Indomitable Teddy Roosevelt'' is a curiosity: a documentary mixed in, but not insensibly so, with docudrama, and called, in the press release, a ''historical drama.'' In fact, it is a drama, even though it is not fiction, and even though it has no one other than the 26th President of the United States worth paying attention to in its two hours. It is a curiosity for another reason, too. How often does a network - in this case ABC - present a documentary about great figures from our past? Moreover, ABC is offering this documentary at 7 o'clock tonight, a respectable hour for viewing. This critic does not have the slightest idea how programming like this came to pass - perhaps it is an impulse by Capital Cities, ABC's new management - but whatever the reason it is entirely refreshing. It is nice to see a program about American history; it is a bonus when it turns out to be well done.

title: THE WIRETAPPING LAW NEEDS SOME RENOVATION
description: LAWS, like technology, can grow obsolete. That is particularly true of laws that deal with technology. It is only 18 years since Congress passed the statute that prohibits tapping a telephone without a search warrant. But that law protects an ever-shrinking portion of a communications universe that has grown to include electronic mail, cellular telephones and other devices unknown to its drafters in 1968.

title: Hillary Mandel Becomes a Bride
description: Hillary Mandel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Mandel of New York and White Lake, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Gilbert Greenstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Greenstein of Jericho, L.I., and Raleigh, N.C. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in New York.

title: Margaret Carroll Wed To Stowe H. Tattersall
description: Margaret Duffus Carroll, an estate and trust administrator at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, and Stowe Holding Tattersall, an assistant vice president in the private clients group of Bankers Trust Company in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Edward Johnston officiated at the Episcopal ceremony in Christ's Church in Rye, N.Y.

title: RAHAL TAKES INDY 500 IN CLOSEST THREE-CAR FINISH
description: The Indianapolis 500 came down to a three-man, five-mile sprint today. With two laps to go on the two-and-a-half-mile track, Bobby Rahal made one lightning move and won the 70th, fastest and richest running of America's premier auto race.

title: PALERMO
description: To the Editor: Not mentioned in ''What's Doing in Palermo'' was a religious site (and sight) that, while not for the faint at heart, is fascinating. In the lower level of the Capuchin monastery, nearly 2,000 bodies, embalmed and preserved in oils and chemicals over the centuries, repose above ground in various stages of decay, fully dressed, down to shoes and hats.

title: Off-the-Books Income
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFUSING QUESTIONS ON THE BALLOT
description: TO EASE a growing real-estate tax burden on New Jersey's elderly homeowners, the Legislature provided for $50 supplemental homestead rebates to aged and disabled homeowners, in addition to regular rebates mailed annually to the state's real-property owners.

title: Pop Music
description: The last of this season's ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series at the 92d Street Y this weekend will hold to this season's theme of Broadway musicals of the 1940's but with a personal twist.

title: Partnerships Cut Back on Tax Breaks
description: BUFFETED by change in recent years, partnerships have shifted toward income-oriented programs that carry limited tax breaks, and away from projects in which the major attraction was the huge tax write-offs that they provided.

title: U.N. DEBATES THE WORDING OF AFRICA AID PLAN
description: Delegates from major industrialized countries and African nations debated in a closed basement conference room here today over the contents of a key document that will come out of the special session on the African continent's economic situation.

title: BACK TO THE REAL MEMORIAL DAY
description: I never fought in a war. Although I did serve in the post-Korea pre-Vietnam peacetime Army, the only battlefields I saw were as a tourist. I never had a relative or a friend killed, or even wounded, in a war. My knowledge of war, like that of most Americans, came from newspapers, photos and the movies.

title: The Scandal May No Longer Be Merely Municipal
description: A key defendant in the growing New York City municipal scandal was accused last week of having paid bribes in return for a lucrative state contract. The State Commission of Investigation said it had found evidence suggesting that a real estate company in which Michael J. Lazar was a partner had paid $47,000 in bribes to lease a Queens building for state offices. The lease was worth $33 million over 10 years.

title: Artists and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlene Louise MacDonald Becomes Bride of Thomas Francis Curry on L.I.
description: Charlene Louise MacDonald, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. MacDonald of Huntington, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Francis Curry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ora J. Curry of Laurel Hollow, L.I. The Rev. John J. Fitzgerald officiated at St. Patrick Roman Catholic Church in Huntington.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Phoebe, Don't Frown Some artists suffer their art and others revel in it. Raphael Soyer is a reveler. He tells us how it feels in ''Artists Observed'' (Abrams), with photographs by Harvey Stein and an introductory essay by Elaine A. King.

title: WHEN DEFEAT IS JUST AN ACCENT MARK AWAY
description: The night before the big day, all the little Spanish spellers were nervous.

title: Mormon Assets
description: To the Editor:

title: Wind Foils Statue Placement
description: Wind gusts thwarted efforts today by a Texas Army National Guard helicopter crew to lower the state's new ''Goddess of Liberty'' statue onto the Capitol dome. The helicopter made eight attempts to lower the 3,000-pound statue onto a 15-foot metal rod atop the dome, but gave up because of wind gusts. ''When the time is right, we'll do it,'' said Gov. Mark White, who, along with hundreds of others, gathered around the Capitol to view the event.

title: A PURPLE-HEART MUSEUM IS PLANNED
description: ORGANIZERS in Derby say they have begun to take steps to make the town the site of the nation's first museum honoring recipients of the Purple Heart. They hope the museum's opening will coincide with the National Convention of the Order of the Purple Heart in Hartford next year.

title: LOCAL MORATORIUMS: NOT THE ONLY ANSWER
description: In response to ''Keep Local Destinies in Local Hands,'' by Orville H. Schell [ May 18 ] :

title: ISRAEL DENIES RUNNING A SPYING OPERATION IN U.S.
description: The Israeli Government today strongly denied reports of a widespread and well-financed Israeli intelligence operation that gathered classified material in the United States.

title: N.Y. BOY CHEERS FRESH AIR FAMILY
description: KEN and Diane Arifian of Brookfield Center say they believe in the simple things in life. They own and have restored a 200-year-old colonial home, and think that children, no matter where they live, should be given the same opportunities as everyone else.

title: FIRST SUBWAY RIDE TO THE BELMONT
description: WHEN the conductor George Seuffert strikes up the band to play ''The Sidewalks of New York'' for next Saturday's 118th running of the Belmont Stakes, it will only be the 22d consecutive running for me.

title: ALLENTOWN POLICEMEN AWARDED $400,000 FOR DEMOTION
description: City officials here are trying to figure out who will pay $400,000 in damages awarded to two police officers who were demoted after opposing the successful mayoral campaign of Joseph S. Daddona in 1981. Last week a Federal district judge ordered Mayor Daddona to pay each of the officers $100,000 in punitive damages. Carson Gable, a former Police Chief, was also ordered to pay the men $40,000 each in punitive damages. Mr. Daddona, Mr. Gable and the city itself will also be required to pay compensatory damages totaling more than $120,000 that were awarded by the jury.

title: A PRINCELY SCHLOSS IN BAVARIA
description: Civilization, recent experiences to the contrary, is often catching; and when, in the 17th century, German princes heard about Versailles, they promptly realized that here was a good example to follow, especially since country castles were a great rarity in their own country. The devastations and dangers of the Thirty Years' War had made it safer to remain behind fortifications and good stout walls, but by the 1690's, its ravages were beginning to fade and the time had clearly come to enjoy life again.

title: ALBANY DEBATING WAYS TO COMBAT CORRUPTION
description: Any anticorruption legislation introduced in the State Senate this session is expected to focus on city, rather than state, government.

title: THE DESIGNATED DIFFERENCE
description: STEVE LYONS, the Red Sox center fielder, was on second base with one out. But on a fly ball to left field, he unwisely tagged up and was thrown out at third. In the dugout, John McNamara, the Red Sox manager, shook his head. Lyons was tossed his glove by a teammate and trotted to center field. When the inning ended, McNamara took him into the dugout tunnel to explain the facts of baseball life.

title: Physician, Prove Thyself
description: Although doctors may not have tenure, obtaining a license to practice medicine has traditionally guaranteed a lifetime of work. But under a rule proposed last week by Governor Cuomo, physicians in New York State would be required for the first time to pass competency reviews before their licenses are renewed.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Eric Clapton Live in Concert, MusicVideo, 60 minutes. $29.95. The guitarist-singer Eric Clapton comes across at his best in this straightforward concert video.

title: MUSICIANS HELP FIGHT HUNGER
description: MUSICIANS and singers in the state have joined forces to help feed the hungry in New Jersey with their own version of a Live Aid-''We Are the World'' fund-raising campaign.

title: Israel Rabbis Criticized
description: Leading Reform Jews from North America on a visit here say they have found that the Israeli religious establishment is coming down harder on non-Orthodox branches of Judaism. Spokesmen for the group of 35 from Reform synagogues in the United States and Canada said Thursday that they were losing patience and pledged a more diligent campaign in Israel and at home against ''increasing efforts by a rigid and suffocating Orthodox rabbinate to impose its views on the people of Israel and Jews everywhere.''

title: BOGGS 5 FOR 5 AS RED SOX WIN
description: Wade Boggs's 5-for-5 game tonight raised his major league-leading average to .402 as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Minnesota Twins, 7-2.

title: Constance Lohse Wed To Robert Brewer Jr.
description: Constance Butler Lohse, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Webb Lohse of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert G. Brewer Jr., the son of Doris V. Fichtner of Rockville, Md., and Dr. Brewer of Virginia Beach, Va. The Rev. Douglas G. Tompkins, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Short Hills Club.

title: NOW, REPORTS ARE AS EASY AS 1-2-3
description: A WHOLE industry of add-ons and supplemental software has grown up around Lotus 1-2-3. Now Lotus itself seems to have taken notice of this burgeoning market spawned by a never-ending demand for additional capabilities and greater finesse in dealing with its spreadsheet. The company has a series of companion software packages in the works.

title: Cooking The Light Fantastic
description: I was pleased to see Marian Burros's article ''Cooking the Light Fantastic'' (Food, April 27). It reminds us of what can be done to produce food with a flavor/calorie quotient that is within acceptable limits.

title: THE LIBERAL SHIPWRECK
description: THE OUTSIDE STORY How Democrats and Republicans Re-elected Reagan. By Richard Brookhiser. 298 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95. EVER since Theodore H. White wrote ''The

title:
IS FOOD IRRADIATION SAFE?;
THE F.D.A.'S GAME OF 'GENETIC ROULETTE'
description: ONE would think, after the accidents at Chernobyl and Three Mile Island, that the Government would have developed a healthy skepticism about nuclear technologies. Apparently, it has not.

title: R. N. Gilbert Wed To Miss Dempsey
description: Elizabeth Ruth Dempsey, the daughter of Adele Dempsey of Rowayton, Conn., and Raymond J. Dempsey of New York, was married yesterday to Roger Neil Gilbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gilbert of Reading, England. The Rev. Robert Walker officiated at the ceremony at the United Methodist Church of Darien, Conn.

title: Anthony Carroll Weds Mary Cullen, an Editor
description: Mary A. Cullen, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert W. Cullen of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Anthony J. Carroll, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Carroll of Old Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Henry Boyle performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: METS' STREAK IS ENDED
description: It's not exactly man bites dog. But the San Francisco Giants scored four runs in the first inning and went on to beat the Mets, 7-3, last night before a sellout crowd of 50,498 at Shea Stadium, ending the Mets' winning streak at six games and the Giants' losing streak at four.

title: GENRES THAT GROW IN THE SPRING
description: For some years now, as a city gardener, I have tended a literary garden on my terrace, designed not only for the eye and ear of the present, but for the foreseeable future as well.

title: Alexandra Evon Fox Wed
description: Alexandra Evon Fox, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Fox of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert C. Mucci, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Mucci of Rochelle Park, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Taylor at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bedford Village, N.Y. The bride's father is a manager of aviation for the Mobil Oil Corporation in Stamford, Conn. The bridegroom's father is an executive vice president of the Title USA Insurance Corporation in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Soviet Suspensions
description: A pair of Soviet ice skating judges have been suspended for three years and one year for awarding biased scores. Natalya Danilenko got the three-year ban from The International Skating Union, which ruled that during the World Figure Skating Championships in Geneva last March, Danilenko had awarded a 5.9 score to fellow Soviet, Aleksandr Fadeev, although he fell twice during free skating and once touched the ice with his hand to steady himself.

title: THE TAX BILL STIRS WALL STREET'S JUICES
description: THE possibility that capital gains and dividends will soon be taxed at the same rate has many on Wall Street uneasy. They argue that such a system - a prime facet of the tax revision bill now wending its way through the Senate - will discourage capital formation. But at the same time, the experts say the stock market may be strong, fueled by higher reported corporate earnings and more-generous dividend payouts.

title: RIGHTISTS DEFIANT AT PRETORIA RALLY
description: Under the shadow of their principal shrine, at least 8,000 Afrikaners gathered today to celebrate their past and hear calls for a future based on total racial separation.

title: REGIONAL PLANNING NEEDED ON 'DESTINY'
description: Orville H. Schell's passionate defense of local land-use regulation and of the moratorium as a useful tool [ ''To Keep Local Destinies in Local Hands,'' May 18 ] seems to me to belabor the obvious while avoiding the larger issues.

title: MIZE LEADS KEMPER OPEN
description: Larry Mize shot a 2-under-par 70 today to take the lead in the third round of the $500,000 Kemper Open being played at Congressional Country Club for the last time.

title: CHAMBER AND JAZZ CONCERTS SCHEDULED
description: THE county's big three summer festivals - Lyndhurst, Summerfare and Caramoor - won't be under way for several weeks or more, which is why the interim cycle of chamber-music concerts at Sarah Lawrence College and the Westchester Conservatory's yearly June Jazz series are especially welcome.

title: CLASSIC FARE WITH MODERN FLAIR
description: SOUTHAMPTON'S colonial Post House has a menu as new as today. Stylish food created with contemporary flair is combined with several enduring classics, all of which whet the appetite. More inspiration in the actual cooking and this would be an unqualified winner; as it is, the results are an uneven blend of delights and disappointments.

title: NEW ROCHELLE RECALLS LANDMARK BIAS RULING
description: SOME of New Rochelle's leading figures will gather today at a downtown park, once the site of an elementary school, to commemorate an event of 25 years ago that originally brought unwelcome attention to the city.

title: COMMUNITY COLLEGES: ADDITIONAL VIEWS
description: Words can hardly describe my feelings. After reading the article '' 'Quality Control' at Community Colleges,'' on April 27, I can honestly say that a false picture of my school has been painted and the artist who painted it is not truly an artist.

title: JOHNSON OUTRUNS LEWIS
description: The Olympic champion Carl Lewis, saying he is still the world's fastest human, lost to Ben Johnson of Canada in the fastest 100 meters this year but came back to capture the 200 today in the Bruce Jenner Classic.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Any rejection of this treaty would be an affront to British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, one European leader who at great political risk stood shoulder-to-shoulder with us during our operations against Qaddafi's terrorism.'' - President Reagan, supporting a revised extradition treaty with Britain. [ 1:4. ]

title: Cynthia Jacobsen Is Wed To J. Richard Leaman 3d
description: Cynthia Scott Jacobsen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Valdemar F. Jacobsen of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Sea Island, Ga., was married yesterday to J. Richard Leaman 3d of Media, Pa. The Rev. William Rogers performed the ceremony at the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I believe there was a hearing on the proposed settlement of the suit affecting passengers who flew to Britain or back from 1982 to 1984. Can you give us an update on where this refund plan stands? -R. J. H., Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. Answer:A spokesman for the Settlement Administrator in New York said settlement of the class-action suit against Pan American World Airways, British Airways and Trans World Airlines that stemmed from the demise of Laker Airways was approved in Federal District Court in Washington in March. The office, the spokesman said, was now reviewing all the claims and hoped to complete the task by the end of this year.

title: STUDENT TESTING COMES UNDER FIRE
description: WITH individual scores on this year's High School Proficiency Test due back at the state's school districts on June 10 and 20 - and 42,000 students expected to have failed one or more of the three sections - interest in testing is expected to pick up just as standardized testing enters a new stage of conflict.

title: Erica Broman Is Bride
description: Erica A. Broman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Broman of Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday to C. David Vickowski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Vickowski of Wilbraham, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Clarke Schaff at the First Congregational Church in Longmeadow. The bride is executive producer and host of ''Insight Out,'' a program on WTXX, a television station in Waterbury, Conn. Mr. Vickowski is an associate with Computerland in Northampton, Mass.

title: THE LITIGATOR: DAVID BOIES, THE WALL STREET LAWYER EVERYONE WANTS
description: IT IS EARLY SATURDAY AFTERNOON, BUT AT THE LOWER Manhattan headquarters of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, it could just as well be Monday. Attorneys scurry purposefully through the corridors, clutching their yellow pads. The only sign that this not a normal workday is the lawyers' garb: a melange of open-necked sport shirts and denims. This, coupled with the fact that most of the attorneys are under 40, makes the place seem less like the headquarters of a major Wall Street law firm than a law school library the week before final exams.

title: Miss Beh Is Wed To T. D. Werblin
description: Patricia Elizabeth Beh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth F. Beh of Plandome, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas David Werblin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Werblin of Rumson, N.J., at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior in New York.

title: MONITORS YIELD THE SHARPEST IMAGES
description: In video, at least, things have been getting better. But while some improvements are accorded much promotional fuss and fanfare, others - though often equally important -draw hardly any attention at all.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This anti-trade bill isn't protectionism - it's destructionism.''

title: DANCE: THREE WORKS BY BALANCHINE
description: BY presenting George Balanchine's ''Donizetti Variations,'' ''Firebird'' and ''Slaughter on Tenth Avenue'' on Thursday night at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet offered light entertainment. Yet historically minded dance fans could find the program worth pondering, for each work called attention to something from ballet's past.

title: IMMIGRANTS SHARE THE PAST WITH PEOPLE
description: ADAM GUIDA, an eighth grader at the Isaac E. Young Junior High School in New Rochelle, wore his light blue ''Ocean Pacific'' T-shirt the day he interviewed 81-year-old Henry Strassburg.

title: Julie Rogers Is Married
description: Julie Babineau Rogers, a stockbroker for Rose & Company in Boston, and Lyman Greenleaf Bullard Jr., an associate in the Boston law firm of Choate, Hall & Stewart, were married yesterday at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Conn. Msgr. Francis X. McGuire officiated, assisted by the Rev. J. Edson Pike, an Episcopal priest. Mrs. Bullard, a graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Courtenay Rogers of New Canaan. Mr. Bullard, a graduate of Harvard College and Boston College Law School, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bullard of Andover, Mass.

title: A Lengthening List of Charges
description: Many of the charges were not new, but they had not previously been put together in a single indictment. In understated legal language, they described nine years of mayhem -bombings, bank robberies, attempted murder and murder - allegedly committed by two related radical groups seeking to overthrow the Government.

title: PETEY AMONG THE CORNHEADS
description: SOMETIMES I LIVE IN THE COUNTRY By Frederick Busch. 218 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $15.95. WHEN first seen, Petey, the 13-year-old protagonist of Frederick Busch's vivid, moving novel, is playing Russian roulette. Having stuffed the cold barrel of his father's handgun into his mouth, he is about to pull the trigger when he remembers to open his eyes. ''He didn't want to miss anything.'' This is suicide-as-sideshow, and Petey is a true American adolescent - entertained by his own despair.

title: INSIDE 'COBRA' MAY DWELL A PUSSYCAT
description: In that its plot is incoherent and its politics less easily analyzed than those of a bald eagle, ''Cobra,'' Sylvester Stallone's new hit, is a terrible movie, but let's not be beastly to it. Let's not become unglued. Let's follow the lead of Dr. Joyce Brothers, who, on the day after the movie opened, rushed into print to explain the extraordinary popularity of the ''Rocky'' and ''Rambo'' films, and now of ''Cobra.'' In the genteel prose of her syndicated column, Dr. Brothers wrote:

title: FRENCH ROLE UNDER NAZIS IN WAR IS REVIVED IN NEW DISPUTE
description: A rightist legislator this month revived the disputed issue of French attitudes during World War II when he appeared to accuse the left of having collaborated with the puppet Vichy regime set up after the German invasion.

title: COUNTY WORKERS RESIST JOINING INDIAN POINT DRILL
description: DESPITE heightened public awareness following the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl last April, county and Federal officials say the full-scale Indian Point emergency drill on Wednesday, the fourth regularly scheduled one since the exercises began in 1982, will be ''business as usual'' with no new procedures added as a result of the Soviet incident.

title: DEATH AND DESTRUCTION IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: SINCE its formation in 1975, the sprawling squatters' camp known as Crossroads has been a symbol of defiance. In the last two weeks, it has also been the scene of some of the worst of the violence that has convulsed South Africa for nearly two years.

title: POLITICAL DRAMA WITH ECHOES FROM THE STEINWAY
description: A Steinway grand sits center stage. Its keyboard faces the audience, and shortly into the first act one of the play's principals is commanded to play.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LITERARY SALUTE While not necessarily a milestone, the 167th anniversary of Walt Whitman's birth is important enough for the Walt Whitman Birthplace Association to have booked ''A Salute to American Letters'' for today, and to bring in some big literary names to mark the occasion. There will be two programs, ''Celebrating the Art of Prose'' and ''Celebrating the Art of Poetry,'' with readings and conversation by the Whitman biographer Justin Kaplan, the novelist Anne Bernays and the poet Galway Kinnell. The festivities, complete with formal party with refreshments and the awarding of the association's $250 MacLachlin Poetry Prize, start at 1:30 P.M. at Sweet Hollow Hall on Gwynne Road in Huntington Station. Everything is free.

title: Susan E. Banker Weds Frank E. A. Ostrander
description: Susan Eileen Banker, a daughter of Mary E. Banker and the late Richard H. Banker of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Frank Eugene Alexander Ostrander, a son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Taylor Ostrander of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. David Wayne performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Episcopal Church in Croton-on-Hudson.

title: A TRAVELER CONFRONTS HIS VULNERABILITY
description: When the ancient jeep stopped tumbling and dumped me on the cracked pavement on a Himalayan foothill in Nepal, an adventure began that was unlike any other I'd had in more than a year of roaming hidden corners of Asia. Without risk there is no adventure, but not until I was hurt did I learn how great the risks of injury are in a remote place.

title: Why Mr. Reagan Blundered on SALT
description: The President's announcement last Tuesday that we will no longer be bound by the second strategic arms limitation treaty -and would violate one of its central provisions later this year if the Soviet Union does not make ''radical changes'' in its behavior - may be judged by history as his most serious mistake. Both in its substance and in the manner in which it was made, this decision illustrates the Reagan Administration's ambivalence about arms control and its deep confusion about our nation's strategic goals.

title: ART
description: Disconcerting as it may be to publishers who knock themselves out to produce color plates that are ever larger, more shiny and more numerous, it is a fact of life that some of the best books ever written about art have had no illustrations at all. Diderot, Baudelaire, the Goncourt brothers - not to mention their predecessors in Italy, Germany and England - had no illustrations to work with. Their own energies sufficed. Nor has their strain died out. It is also a fact of life that despite all the efforts of the trade publishers, some of the best reading on the subject of the fine arts today is to be found in learned periodicals, where the general reader rarely seeks it out. It would be hard, for instance, to find writing about art more eloquent than Rainer Maria Rilke's ''Letters on Cezanne'' or a combination of scholarship and detection that could compare with Yvonne Hackenbroch's ''Reinhold Vasters, Goldsmith.'' But the Rilke is all text and no pictures, and the Hackenbroch comes in Volume 19/20 of the ''Metropolitan Museum Journal,'' just published. In both cases the current mold of art book publishing is broken, to our advantage.

title: NBC PHONE REPORT CRITICIZED
description: The Government's top telephone official said Thursday that NBC News was ''out of the ballpark'' on a report that local rate increases are forcing many elderly Americans to give up their telephones.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CLARINETIST IN NEWARK The clarinetist Richard Stoltzman, who in March became the first wind player to win the Avery Fisher Prize, will appear with the Cathedral Symphony Orchestra in Newark today as the ensemble ends its season at the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart.

title: DYSON ANNOUNCES BID FOR U.S. SENATE
description: John S. Dyson, the former chairman of the State Power Authority, announced his candidacy yesterday for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, denouncing the incumbent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, as a captive of special interests.

title: JOYS OF SUMMER: OUTDOOR CONCERTS AND MUCH MORE
description: WHILE the summer of '86 may go down in Long Island history books as the year of the U.S. Open, there will be more activity on the Island than golf.

title: The Protection Game
description: ''Protection'' is the word in Washington these days, but it takes a little time to sort out who is protecting whom from what. You have to take the issues one at a time.

title: U.S.F.L. TRYOUTS STIR DREAMS
description: The long-distance award went to Steve Fibranz, a professed linebacker from Anchorage, Alaska, whose excuse was ''nervousness.'' The optimist award went to a 43-year-oldstock broker from Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., Rod Patten, who played only intramural football at Penn State. The persistence award went to Ed Washington, a defensive end from Houston who cannot recite all the similar tryout camps he has attended. And the I'm-my-own-man citation went to Darryl Perry, the smaller brother of William (The Refrigerator) Perry of the Chicago Bears.

title: CAN WE STILL TRUST RANGER RICK?
description: PLAYING GOD IN YELLOWSTONE The Destruction of America's First National Park. By Alston Chase. 446 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $24.95.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: HERE COME THE BABIES -- CAN THE COWS BE FAR BEHIND?
description: AFTER an interruption of almost 15 years, milk is beginning to flow back into my life. At the moment it is little more than a trickle but with pretentions of becoming a stream. Perhaps in time, it will resemble the great torrent of my youth, that ceaseless flood of calcium and vitamin D that washed before it three meals daily and half-a-dozen snacks.

title: MOSCOW PROPOSES REDUCTION IN ARMS BUT GIVES WARNING
description: The Soviet Union, in private talks, has offered a new negotiating approach to reducing strategic nuclear forces. But in a statement issued today, it warned that it would increase its forces if the United States exceeded the limits set in previously negotiated treaties.

title: Kristen F. Yonker Wed
description: Kristen Frances Yonker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Yonker of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Barry C. Twomey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neil F. Twomey of Wyckoff, N.J. The Rev. Ralph Wagner officiated at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J. The bride, a graduate of the University of Vermont with a master's degree in nutrition from Boston University, is a dietitian. Mr. Twomey, a magna cum laude, Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Connecticut College with an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago, is an assistant vice president at Laidlaw Adams & Peck.

title: WHERE TO PITCH A TENT
description: CALIFORNIA McArthur-Burney Falls Memorial State Park Information: 916-335-2777.

title: STEVE REICH, A FORMER YOUNG TURK, APPROACHES 50
description: The world premiere of Steve Reich's ''Music for 18 Musicians'' in 1976 was heralded by stark white posters, decorated with a few measures of music, plastered on the grimy walls of SoHo. There were no advance news stories, no radio appearances, and little of the fraternal support aficionados traditionally lend to new music events. Yet Town Hall was almost full, with an audience seemingly made up of students, artists and musicians, and the 55-minute work - a succession of shimmering, ethereal aural colors propelled by a steady pulse - was followed by a stomping, cheering ovation. Tonal, repetitive, insistently rhythmic - Mr. Reich's work seemed to many a new musical idiom, unmistakably of its time, but far removed from the snarls and tangles of much 20th-century music.

title: J.R. Toobin Weds Amy B. McIntosh
description: The wedding of Amy B. McIntosh and Jeffrey Ross Toobin, graduates of Harvard University, where the bride also received an M.B.A. degree and the bridegroom expects to receive a law degree next week, took place yesterday at the Georgian Suite in New York. Justice Sybil Hart Kooper of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, officiated.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Sperry gave in to Burroughs's advances. It agreed to be acquired for $76.50 a share, or $4.8 billion, creating the second-largest computer company after I.B.M. The price is well below the $80 a share Sperry was hoping to command and not much above Burroughs's previous offer of $75. Burroughs had started the bidding at $70 a share early in May, coupling it with a tender offer that angered Sperry into threatening a self-tender. But Sperry apparently was unable to find a more generous partner, and thus was forced to reward the persistence of W. Michael Blumenthal, the former Treasury Secretary and Burroughs's chairman.

title: 4-DAY SERIES AT APOLLO THEATER CELEBRATES BLACK ARTISTS AND FILM MAKERS
description: CAB CALLOWAY, Lena Horne and the Nicholas Brothers are coming to Harlem's Apollo Theater - not to its stage, which has seen so many great black performers over the years, but to its screen. They and many other black stars are part of ''From Harlem to Hollywood,'' a four-day film series beginning Thursday that will benefit the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame and the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.

title: THE DANCE: CHRISTMAS IN MAY
description: IT'S Christmas. No, neither the weather nor our calendars have been deceiving us. In the real world, a warm May has just turned into June. But in the ballet world it's Christmas, for on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, American Ballet Theater revived Mikhail Baryshnikov's version of ''The Nutcracker,'' that ever-popular fantasy about a little girl's Christmas dream.

title: A TOUGH IMMIGRATION POLICY AGAINST UNDESIRABLE VIRUSES
description: TWO small farms near Belle Glade, Fla., became the scene of unusual activity last week in the Federal Government's effort to combat exotic livestock diseases. The threat was African swine fever. Federal inspectors built holding pens and drew blood samples from 150 pigs in response to a report that the herds might be infected with the world's most serious swine disease.

title: Baltimore Papers Make Some News
description: It was, naturally enough, the lead story in The Sun of Baltimore on Thursday. But the sale of that newspaper, its sister publication, The Evening Sun, two television stations and some small magazines also was big news across the country.

title: Insiders' Trading: Tips For the Savvy
description: IN late 1984, five top executives of the Dataram Corporation began buying the company's stock in the open market.

title: Melissa Feldman Marries Marc Karetsky, a Broker
description: Melissa Jill Feldman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Feldman of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Marc J. Karetsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred J. Karetsky of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. and Cantor Joseph Boardman performed the ceremony at the Fenway Country Club in Scarsdale.

title: STAGE: CLEBERT FORD AND ABBEY LINCOLN IN 'STORIES'
description: THE people and their stories are familiar - an old man and woman left behind in a devastated Detroit ghetto abandoned by upward-bound youths who might not have been able to get out of it at all in the good old days. Many of the lines, even the jokes, in ''Stories About the Old Days'' we have heard before. But, in the production at the Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center, Abbey Lincoln and Clebert Ford endow these people with extraordinary emotional power. And Bill Harris has given his story some mythic overtones: There is no self-pity in the characters, nor do they blame others for the suffering they slowly acknowledge to one another; the man is angrily defying God and the woman is trying to overcome a grief she can admit is there only by tricking the man into forcing her to tell him about it. They nudge open the door ever so slightly into a place where the unspeakable is whispered.

title: A U.S. PRESENCE AT LeMANS
description: The postponement of the Indy 500 because of rain last Sunday and Monday meant that the two biggest auto races in the world fell this year on the same weekend. The 24 Hours of LeMans started yesterday, just three hours before the green flag fell at Indy.

title: ORDINARY SPLENDORS
description: THE WOMAN WHO ESCAPED FROM SHAME By Toby Olson. 324 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95. THREE sailors discharged and on the loose in San Diego. Not for me a promising beginning; I await the false heartiness of self-conscious vernacular, the blurry, beery onslaught of the so-called Real. We find ourselves hooked by it again, these days. I think: but Toby Olson is a poet, and a good one - what is he doing in these conventional alleyways?

title: A TEXAS TRIAL: TALE OF DEATH AND TORTURE
description: Every day the crowds come early, mostly retirees, students and farm and ranch couples who mingle outside the second-floor courtroom with the genial ease of country people gathering before Sunday church services.

title: ECHOES OF EMPIRE IN SINGAPORE
description: The Germans didn't have much of a Pacific empire:

title: OUTSIDERS SPUR REBIRTH OF BALTIMORE
description: In the years when this city was little more than a decaying traffic stop between New York and Washington, the waiting room at the Mount Royal train station was equipped with rows of hard wooden rockers.

title:
BRIEFING;
Kirk Prepares a Response
description: In an unusual move, the Democratic national chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., is scheduled to deliver the Democratic response next Saturday to President Reagan's weekly radio address.

title: A PARENT'S PERSPECTIVE ON DESEGREGATION
description: WHEN the court decision on Lincoln School was handed down in 1961, I was a schoolchild myself in an urban area far away from New Rochelle. My hometown had itself some years before dealt with the painful and wrenching issue of integration just as New Rochelle was then doing, and from a black teen-ager's vantage point it looked to me to be the burning issue of our times.

title:
BRIEFING;
A Domenici Collision
description: Being chairman of the Senate Budget Committee is stressful enough, but Senator Pete V. Domenici was also involved in an automobile accident not long ago.

title: BASIC ENTRIES IN THE GARDENER'S HANDBOOK
description: Those who are learning to use their trowels and hoes often need a helping hand. Experienced gardeners may use strange words that leave a novice wondering. Or helpers at garden centers and nurseries suggest deeds that mystify the uninitiated. Although some terminology may seem obvious, there are fine points worth mentioning. Hence a glossary to provide some help. ANNUAL -

title: Harriet Rogers Is Wed To Thomas J. Linskey
description: Harriet Lovell Rogers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Rogers of Darien and Stonington, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Joseph Linskey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Linskey of Los Angeles. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in Stonington.

title: MEANWHILE, BACK AT THE STATE PARK...
description: JERSEY CITY

title: 40 AFFORDABLES FOR NEWARK'S CENTRAL WARD
description: TWO decades ago, Newark's Central Ward was devastated by racial riots that started the city on a long, steep decline. The crowded streets - lined with the oldest and most deteriorated housing in Newark - were left with fire-blackened storefronts and boarded up windows. Eventually, the old frame houses were razed one by one until entire blocks lay vacant.

title: DIVESTMENT BILL SIGNED BY CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo signed a bill today that could prompt the sale of up to $740 million in stock that the state pension fund owns in 12 American companies that do business in Northern Ireland.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 3:05 P.M. Ron Darling, still undefeated and making his 10th start of the season, goes after his seventh victory, against Mike Krukow, who outpitched Dwight Gooden in San Francisco 10 days ago. (Television - Channel 9, 3 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 3 P.M.) Yankees vs. A's, at Oakland, Calif. (Television -Channel 11, 4:05 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 4 P.M.) Astros vs. Montreal Expos, at Houston (Television -Channel 7, 3 P.M.) N.C.A.A. Division I College World Series, at Omaha (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M. and 8 P.M.) Basketball Rockets vs. Boston Celtics, at Houston. The Rockets, down by 2-0, are hoping that the change in site will bring a change in outcome. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) Soccer Spain vs. Brazil, World Cup game, at Guadalajara, Mexico. In international play, Brazil has a 4-1-2 edge over Spain. (Television - Channel 4, 1:55 P.M. Channel 41, 10:30 P.M., tape delay). France vs. Canada, at Leon. The two countries have never met in international play. (Television - Channel 41, 5:45 P.M., live) Tennis French Open Championships, at Roland Garros Stadium, Paris (Television - Channel 4, noon.) Eastern Masters Men's 35 and over Grand Prix Tournament, at Jericho-Westbury Indoor Tennis, off Exit 40 of the Long Island Expressway at Jericho Turnpike, 2 P.M., opening round. Butch Seewagen is the defending champion. Other Events AUTO RACING: 24 Hours at LeMans, conclusion of endurance race. GOLF: Kemper Open, at Bethesda, Md., final round.

title: THE DANCE: 'EPISODES'
description: IN an unexpected bit of archeological research, the New York City Ballet has dug into its own past and resurrected the solo that George Balanchine choreographed for Paul Taylor in ''Episodes,'' his 1959 ballet to music by Anton Webern.

title: NEW YORK'S REPUBLICANS BANK ON THE SUBURBS
description: THE New York Republican ticket selected here last week was the most obvious manifestation to date of a dramatic shift.

title: REAGAN IS AS INTENT AS EVER ON MAKING OVER THE COURTS
description: MANY Democrats concede that a number of judges who took their places on the Federal bench during Ronald Reagan's first four years are perhaps too conservative, but by any measure are first-rate legal scholars. The roster of these well-regarded first-term nominees includes such judges as Robert H. Bork, recruited from the Yale Law School, and Richard A. Posner and Antonin Scalia, formerly of the University of Chicago faculty.

title: Topics; Great Books, Misread: Babbittry and Punditry
description: A mystery and a political lesson flare up out of the table that accompanied Time magazine's cover story last week on Governor Cuomo. The table compares him with other Democratic Presidential possibilities like Hart, Jackson, Bradley, Gephardt, Babbitt and Biden.

title: The Ming Tombs
description: To the Editor: I have not visited the Ming tombs, but I understand it is a place of quiet beauty and a popular place for picnics. Therefore, I shuddered when I learned (''China Tees Off in Style,'' Travel, March 30) that not only will the Peking Golf Club course ''traverse ground considered sacred for centuries,'' but also that plans are on the drawing board for an amusement park and an overhead train to bring foreign tourists there.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
VOLUNTEERS PAR EXCELLENCE
description: WHEN she was 14 years old, Cathy Burke volunteered at the Westchester Classic golf tournament. ''I was working on the leader board, the board that showed who was ahead,'' she recalled recently. ''In those days, scoring was done manually, not electronically. At one point, we needed to post the name of a player, but we couldn't find the sign. No one could find it. So we kids wrote out his name in mustard, and made a sign out of that.''

title: PLAYING HARDBALL WITH THE PRESS
description: GOOD-BYE TO THE LOW PROFILE The Art of Creative Confrontation. By Herb Schmertz with William Novak. 242 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95. HERB SCHMERTZ, Mobil Oil's vice president for public affairs, has written a lively and often humorous book telling businessmen how they should face - and face down - the press. As Mr. Schmertz revels in his many confrontations with the news media, he also slips in evidence to support the conclusion that he is a most ingenious and important corporate public relations man.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHEN the new auditorium at the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory officially becomes the Oliver and Lorraine Grace Auditorium tonight, the prominent scientists and dignitaries gathered at the dedication should be aware of just how much they have to thank the Graces for.

title: BOOK AGENT TELLS OF SIDE-DOOR ENTRY
description: ''I REMEMBER back to the time when not many choices other than being a secretary were open to women,'' said Mary Jane Ross, a literary agent who lives in Tenafly, as she discussed the ''beginnings of my career.''

title: CREAMY PORRIDGE FOR NORWEGIANS
description: The American skiers, thirsty after a long day's touring in the brilliant spring sunshine on the Rondane plateau in central Norway, started gulping down glasses of cool, syrupy red currant juice the moment they sat down at the dinner table, only to be reprimanded by their Norwegian-born guide. ''Don't drink it all now,'' he said, moving the glass pitchers out of reach. ''It is supposed to go with your rommegrot.''

title: AFGHANS' SECOND CITY IS NOW MOSTLY RUINS
description: Large areas of this city, once the second largest in Afghanistan, lie in ruins, and much of the surrounding countryside is devoid of normal life.

title: Comings and Goings
description: With the cancellation of next Saturday's World Boxing Association light-heavyweight fight - billed as the first title bout in the Bermuda Triangle - between the titleholder Marvin Johnson and Jean Marie Emebe, was put off because Johnson suffered a back injury, the promoters have substituted a 10-round heavyweight bout between James (Bonecrusher) Smith and Jesse Ferguson.

title: The Buoyant Bourses
description: Picking the winners in Western European stock markets was child's play last year for most investors, and especially so for Americans. The descent of the dollar magnified already substantial stock-price advances in European markets after converting the stronger local currencies into weaker dollars. In 1985, the run-ups in dollar terms topped 100 percent in such markets as West Germany, Austria and Italy.

title: POLAND GAINS ADMISSION TO THE INTERNATIONAL MONETARY FUND
description: The Polish Government, saddled with a $31 billion debt, was admitted to the International Monetary Fund on Thursday, and Warsaw has welcomed the development with low-key composure.

title: THE MEMORIES LIVE ON IN THE HOUSES WE LEAVE
description: WE WERE talking about being rooted in private homes, and a friend told me a story.

title: NEW YORK PORT CHANGES WITH SHIFTING ECONOMY
description: New York Harbor, which has been the core of the city's industrial might for more than a century, is steadily losing ground as the nation's pre-eminent seaport, according to economists and shipping company executives.

title: OUT-OF-TOWN BUILDERS BRING THEIR SHOWS TO NEW YORK
description: It is tempting to identify three unusual, medium-sized skyscrapers nearing completion in Manhattan not by their architects but by their developers. After all, the architects are familiar names - Edward Larrabee Barnes, Kevin Roche and the partnership of John Burgee and Philip Johnson. What is new to New York are the builders - Boston Properties and Gerald Hines Interests, both nationally known real-estate firms that are now making their first attempt to scale the Olympus of real-estate development, Manhattan.

title: NEW YORK LIBRARY SYSTEM OFFERS COMPUTER TIME
description: Jerome Levy sounded delighted as he explained how he had programmed his microcomputer to do something it had never done before - make a sound.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Medea, Starring Maria Callas, with Giuseppi Gentile, Laurent Terzieff, Massimo Girotti and Margareth Clementi; directed by Pier Paolo Pasolini, 1979. Video Arts International, 100 minutes.

title: Tuning Out
description: After two weeks of televised testimony against him, Chief Justice Joseph A. Bevilacqua of the Rhode Island Supreme Court had heard enough.

title: French Set Off Nuclear Blast In a Pacific Proving Ground
description: France has exploded another nuclear device at Mururoa Atoll in the South Pacific, the fourth this year, New Zealand scientists said today.

title: BLACKS ON CAMPUS
description: Brent Staples's article on declining black enrollment made many important points, but I must take issue with the manner in which Mr. Staples portrayed Columbia College. In his characterization of our conversation - ''she hits the prep schools and privates'' -he omitted a lengthy discussion we had about the measures Columbia has successfully undertaken to offset declining black enrollment.

title: Art
description: Andy Warhol is now so generally regarded as a department of the entertainment industry that it is good to be reminded of the time, 20 and more years ago, when he was a serious and challenging painter, and one whose early work often turns out to have worn very well.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Searching Coolers On Long Island - LONG Beach, L.I., does not allow alcohol on its beach. But the law, almost 20 years old, was never strictly enforced because Long Beach is just that, a very long beach, three miles of white sand.

title: Driver Dies in Rally Held in West Germany
description: The Grand Prix driver Marc Surer of Switzerland was seriously injured and his co-driver, Michel Wyder, was killed today when their Ford RS 200 lost control during a rally in West Germany, ran into a tree and burst into flames.

title: GROWTH PREDICTED
description: MARKED by steady growth rates in the last few decades, Gloucester County will continue the pace into its fourth century, county officials say, because of the availability of prime land for development and the geographical luck that puts it near Philadelphia, a few miles across the Delaware River.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Miss Joslin Weds Gerard Klingman
description: Elaine Penney Joslin, a daughter of Justice and Mrs. Norman Earl Joslin of Buffalo, was married yesterday to Gerard Albert Klingman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Joseph Klingman of Hauppauge, L.I. The Rev. Dr. Kurt A. Klingbeil performed the ceremony at the Kenmore (N.Y.) Baptist Church.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO OFFSET WATER DEFICIENCY
description: NOW that summer is fast approaching, a few random observations about the 1986 spring season are in order.

title: DANCE CONTEST IS AN L.I. FIRST
description: WHEN Peter Morrison began studying ballet seven years ago, the teen-ager from Stony Brook ''got a lot of teasing,'' he recalled. ''My friends used to kid me and I guess it bothered me at first.'' Not enough to make him stop dancing, however.

title: Verplank Wins
description: Oklahoma State's Scott Verplank shot a 1-over-par 73 today for a total of 282 to win the N.C.A.A. Division I men's golf championship.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: At a cocktail party in Connecticut, I found myself listening to a group of Europeans, mostly German, discussing a recently completed two-week tour of Mexico. ''Mexico is a fascinating country,'' a young German man was saying. ''The people are friendly, but they are so very poor. Also, I was particularly bothered by the way the American tourists contributed to the problem.

title: COONEY STOPS GREGG IN FIRST
description: After an 18-month absence from the ring, Gerry Cooney needed only 1 minute 26 seconds today to reestablish himself as a force in the heavyweight division.

title: Intruder Stabs Dancer In a Brooklyn Break-In
description: A dancer was assaulted in her Brooklyn apartment yesterday morning by a burglar who stabbed her three times in the chest, the police said.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 1, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. 2 6 (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 2 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 1 6 (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 3 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert 3 13 Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 4 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 5 28 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 5 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison 4 40 Keillor. (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 6 THE BOOK OF ABRAHAM, by Marek 15 3 Halter. (Holt, $19.95.) One hundred generations in the history of a Jewish family. 7 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. 7 3 (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion. 8 11 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. 6 11 (Putnam, $17.95.) Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 9 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, 8 18 by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in Afghanistan. 10 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. 14 14 Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the America of the future, men and women perform assigned services. 11* THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest 1 Hemingway. (Scribners, $18.95.) A writer and his wife have affairs with the same woman on their European honeymoon; Hemingway's last unpublished novel. * 12 NOBODY LIVES FOREVER, by John 1 Gardner. (Putnam, $12.95.) James Bond on the trail of the kidnapper of his devoted housekeeper. 13 HIGH HEARTS, by Rita 13 3 Mae Brown. (Bantam, $17.95.) The experiences of a Virginia belle who joins the Confederate cavalry. 14* THE SONGS OF DISTANT EARTH, by 12 3 Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) Two groups of colonists from Earth meet on a paradisiacal planet. 15 MAGIC KINGDOM FOR SALE: Sold! 2 by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $16.95.) The dilapidated kingdom of Landover proves more than Ben Holiday bargained for. Nonfiction 1 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. 1 4 (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. 2 12 (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme. 3 THE TRIUMPH OF POLITICS, by David 3 4 A. Stockman. (Harper & Row, $21.95.) Why President Reagan was unable to balance the budget. 4 ENTER TALKING, by Joan Rivers with 4 4 Richard Meryman. (Delacorte, $17.95.) The talk-show hostess' long professional climb. 5 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo 5 16 Buscaglia. (Slack/ Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 6 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, 6 7 by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95) A rabbi on ''the search for a life that matters.'' 7 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. 9 6 (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 8 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, 8 3 by James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 9 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS 10 9 WIFE FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) Strange neurological disabilities. 10 BESS W. TRUMAN, by Margaret Truman. 7 5 (Macmillan, $19.95.) Her daughter shows the former First Lady's private side. 11 ALL GOD'S CHILDREN NEED TRAVELING SHOES, 13 2 by Maya Angelou. (Random House, $15.95.) A memoir that carries the writer's story from her native Arkansas to her ancestral Ghana. 12 BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE, by Alec 11 10 Guinness. (Knopf, $17.95.) The autobiography of the distinguished English actor. 13 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee 12 83 Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 14 ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. 14 14 (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for 76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic. 15 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel 166 Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 16* THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. 15 13 (Crown, $18.95.) The life and loves of J. Paul Getty, who was the richest man in the world. Advice and Self-Help 1 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond 1 41 and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney 2 27 with Sallie Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises designed to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 3 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin 4 2 Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 4 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin 3 35 Norwood. (Tarcher/St. Martin's, $14.95.) Ways to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 5 THE BE (HAPPY) ATTITUDES, by Robert 5 30 Schuller. (Word, $12.95.)

title: VIRGINIA CITY MINES HISTORY
description: In spite of appearances Virginia City, the former capital of Montana Territory, is not really a ghost town. There are 150 full-time residents. But the handful of people in Virginia City today is a far cry from the glory days when some 35,000 people lived in and around the mountain town.

title: BITTEN BY THE FUN OF SHOWING OFF FIDO
description: EVERY year Connecticut is host to at least 15 all-breed dog shows, at which up to 2,500 dogs of some 130 breeds compete for awards. These festive affairs are sometimes visible to the casual weekend driver: dozens of yellow- and white-striped tents, high on a hill or down in a valley.

title: EUROPE KEEPS UP PRESSURE ON LIBYA
description: IN the seven weeks since American bombers struck at Tripoli and Benghazi, an ambiguous calm has settled over the debate about terrorism, which had badly roiled relations between the United States and its European allies. In this breathing space, President Reagan is getting something like the benefit of strategic doubt in such countries as Italy, Britain and France. Said a senior adviser to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who supported the attack on Libya: ''The initial European feeling that it was a bad thing to do what President Reagan did has diminished. There has been a realization that the Europeans also have responsibilities.''

title: G.M. Working On Hudson Plant
description: WORKERS cheered last June when Governor Cuomo announced some of the benefits that would allow the General Motors Corporation to keep its automobile-assembly plant open on the Hudson River in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: MUSICALS ENLIVEN OLD THEATER AGAIN
description: THE Garde Theater in New London, once a home to vaudeville acts, is vibrant again with music, backstage bustle and the excitement of live shows. Built in 1926 and in recent years open only sporadically as a movie house, it has been reclaimed just as have similar old, downtown theaters in other Connecticut cities.

title: A Noteworthy Collection
description: This list of paperbacks is a selection from the New & Noteworthy column since the December 1985 Christmas issue. LOVE MEDICINE, by Louise Erdrich. (Bantam, $6.95.) Seven characters tell their stories in this novel set on and around a North Dakota Indian reservation between 1934 and 1984. FINDING THE CENTER: Two Narratives, by V. S. Naipaul. (Vintage, $4.95.) An autobiographical reflection and a memoir of a trip to the Ivory Coast in 1982. MEN AND ANGELS, by Mary Gordon. (Ballantine, $4.50.) A novel about a young art historian and her fanatically religious mother's helper. HOOPLA, by Harry Stein. (St. Martin's, $7.95.) A part-fact, part-fiction re-creation of baseball's ''Black Sox'' scandal of 1919. THE WAR BETWEEN THE TATES, by Alison Lurie. (Avon, $3.95.) A novel of domestic strife and infidelity in a college town in the late 1960's. THE TRUE CONFESSIONS OF AN ALBINO TERRORIST, by Breyten Breytenbach. (McGraw-Hill, $5.95.) The South African poet's memoir of his trial and imprisonment on trumped-up charges of terrorism. HURRY HOME, by John Edgar Wideman. (Owl/Henry Holt, $6.95.) A novel of the black ghetto and a man who refuses to become part of the white world.

title: THE MEMOIRS OF A JAZZMAN
description: THIS YEAR, AS USUAL, NEW YORK'S JVC JAZZ FESTIVAL (June 20-29), formerly the Kool Jazz Festival, will represent all eras of jazz. Similarly, Clyde Bernhardt's career and his memoirs recall the world of jazz almost from its beginnings. His mother was a schoolteacher and his father a mine foreman in North Carolina. Clyde, born in 1905, was one of eight children, two of whom died in infancy. ''My memory goes back to the famous singers I knew or saw,'' he wrote in the introduction to his book: ''Ma Rainey, Bessie Smith, Ethel Waters, Princess White, Mamie Smith and a few the history books don't remember. I heard Bessie Smith, whose husband was a first cousin to the wife of my uncle, sing in North Carolina in 1918. I been in many orchestras - jazz, swing, dance and society bands.'' In the excerpts that follow, he tells, first, of his stint in 1931 with Joseph (King) Oliver (1885-1938), a trumpeter and bandleader who was one of the earliest New Orleans jazzmen and Louis Armstrong's mentor. In the second part, Bernhardt recounts his experiences in 1942 with Jay (Hootie) McShann (1909 - ) the Kansas City pianist whose swing band was home on and off to Charlie (Yardbird) Parker, the alto saxophonist who was to become one of the founders of be-bop and the avant-garde in jazz. Parker's first records were made with McShann's band.

title: Athletes Bypass N.C.A.A. Event
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's outdoor track and field championships will be held here Wednesday through Saturday, with an impressive collection of athletes. Perhaps more impressive is the list of athletes who decided not to be here because they wanted to control their destinies, mostly financial.

title: TINY DELAWARE'S CORPORATE CLOUT
description: EMERGENCY room physicians at a city hospital here recently concluded that a hemorrhaging patient had less than six hours to live unless he consented to surgery. But the 41-year-old man adamantly refused the operation, arguing that it was unnecessary.

title: SALES OF LAMP AID DISABLED
description: AN increase in the number of forest fires across the country last year has led to a demand for a product made at a Hartford work center for the handicapped.

title: A CONTINENT'S WEAKENING GRIP ON SURVIVAL
description: PARTLY because of widespread environmental destruction and uncontrolled population growth, Africans are growing less food per capita than they did 20 years ago. The decline has brought a heavy toll in malnutrition, illness and shortened lives.

title: Archibald Named
description: Nate Archibald has been named coach of the New Jersey Jammers of the United States Basketball League in place of Cazzie Russell, who left the team and is sought by several clubs in the Continental Basketball Association.

title: NEW BUFFALO RAPID-TRANSIT LINE IS IMPERILED
description: Buffalo's year-old rapid-transit line might be forced to shut down unless a new source of revenue is found to cover its operating deficits, a state study group reported this week.

title: SCHWANN GOES MONTHLY WITH CD'S
description: The publishers of the Schwann catalogue have apparently seen the handwriting on the wall on the future of compact disks and have decided to make their quarterly Compact Disk Catalogue into a monthly. At the same time, they have relegated the LP/cassette catalogue to less frequent publication - perhaps twice a year.

title: A NIGHT IN THE LIFE OF THE CAPITAL'S RUSSIANS
description: When Prince Alexis N. Obolensky tries to describe the variety of Russians who live in this city, he resorts to an old Russian saying:

title: Susan Alden Weds Denis Frelinghuysen
description: Susan Wolcott Alden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ellinwood Alden of Riverside, Conn., and Bear Island, Sunset, Me., was married yesterday to Denis de Viry Frelinghuysen, a son of Roselyne de Viry Frelinghuysen of Princeton, N.J., and Sarasota, Fla., and the late Thomas T. K. Frelinghuysen. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: A FAIRY TALE OF MERRY ENGLAND
description: Theater Three has made a welcomed annual practice of presenting the delightful comic operettas of Gilbert and Sullivan. To close their 1985-86 season, they have chosen ''Iolanthe,'' that clever fairy tale in which the entire British House of Lords gets involved with a lovely troupe of fairies.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: VOICES OF LATVIA The existence of Latvia, at least in its music, will be reaffirmed in the yearly spring concert by the New York Latvian Concert Choir 8 P.M. Friday at Elizabeth Seton College, at 1061 North Broadway in Yonkers. The 10-year-old, 100-voice choir will repeat the performance, embellished by the Bronx Arts Ensemble, at 2:30 P.M. Saturday in Alice Tully Hall at Lincoln Center.

title: Flash Floods Kill 8 In Pittsburgh Suburbs
description: Rescuers searching muddy riverbanks found four bodies today, bringing to eight the number killed in Pittsburgh's suburbs after thunderstorms brought flash floods and mud slides Friday.

title: BONDHOLDERS BETTING ON SAFE RETURNS
description: THE bond rally that began last fall shows no signs of slowing down, as investors bet that low inflation will continue to bring them steady and safe returns on their investments. They are putting money into a panoply of credit instruments, ranging from newly popular convertible bonds and Series EE savings bonds, to last year's hot-selling Ginnie Maes. And the uncertainty created by the pending tax revision proposals is presenting opportunities for municipal bond buyers through the end of the year.

title: CONVICTS, GLAD TO BE OUT, SPRUCE UP THE ROADSIDE
description: PRISON inmates have returned to public roads in Connecticut, but not in the chain gangs of old.

title: Headliners; Counterattack
description: It was almost possible to feel sorry for the bicycle-riding purse-snatcher who bore down upon 86-year-old Vera Tucker last week as she walked near her home in one of Manhattan's most expensive Upper East Side neighborhoods.

title: KATHERING BARRETT AND B.C. SWETT EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Katherine Leah Barrett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin G. Barrett of New York and Water Mill, L.I., was married yesterday to Benjamin Chanler Swett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven C. Swett of Purdys, N.Y. The Rev. Henry H. Sturtevant, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, L.I.

title: DATA BANK: June 1, 1986
How It Works
description: To the Editor:

title: Spies And Sports
description: As one who shares Mark Goodson's indifference to sports, I applaud his courage in emerging from that particular closet (''Lousy at Sports,'' About Men, May 11). In my case, this unmanly tendency came close to having serious, and possibly fatal, consequences.

title: BRITISH CUISINE: SUN SETS ON KIDNEY PIE AND CLOTTED CREAM
description: AS anyone who has recently been to Great Britain knows, British food has undergone a revolution. Young homegrown chefs, trained on the Continent or in the kitchens of top French chefs, have evolved a cuisine of their own, encompassing the best of British and French traditions.

title: A REPORT CARD FOR CUOMO'S FIRST TERM
description: IN announcing recently that he would seek re-election, Governor Cuomo cited increased support for education as one his first administration's major accomplishments. He noted a $1.95 billion annual increase in state aid to public schools since 1982 and called attention to an effort to establish new high schools for gifted students and the creation of advanced technology centers at several universities to help promote economic development.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
PSYCHOTHERAPY SPEAKERS
description: The county chapter of the Society of Clinical Social Work Psychotherapists now offers a speakers bureau to provide seminars or workshops on a variety of subjects during lunch breaks at schools or offices, or after work hours. The society also offers a telephone-referral service that can match the caller's needs with an appropriate clinician in the area.

title: FOR SOME BALL PARKS, ENTERTAINMENT, NOT TRADITION, IS TREND
description: THIS is baseball: a midsummer afternoon on the north side of Chicago, ivy crawling up the red brick walls of Wrigley Field, the stands teeming with boisterous youngsters. The Cubs are in the race, the game is tied and it's the seventh- inning stretch.

title: Douglas Scott Deal Is Wed To Susan Marjorie Blaxill
description: Susan Marjorie Blaxill, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Blaxill of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Douglas Scott Deal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Troy Maris Deal Jr. of Orlando, Fla. The Rev. John Crocker Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Princeton.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN REBELS SUDDENLY IN SPOTLIGHT
description: The phones have been constantly ringing in the cramped American headquarters of the African National Congress since South African raids against the rebel group's offices in three African nations earlier this month.

title: BARD COLLEGE PLANS THEATER FOR NEW FESTIVAL
description: Bard College has announced plans for the construction of a $5 million, 1,500-seat amphitheater on the campus to house a new Hudson Valley Summer Arts Festival of music, ballet and possibly opera.

title: ADDING YEARS TO THE LIFE OF A PRINT
description: IT takes imagination, the kind that might have captivated H. G. Wells, to stand over a tray of developer watching a print come up and wonder how people 100 years from now will feel about the picture. With today's quality printing paper and chemical technology, pictures can last that long and longer.

title: GARDENING
description: Gardening is by and large an intuitive, private matter between person and plant, a solitary recreation in which communion with kindred spirits is always welcome. This season's garden books are a broad mixture, as the seed catalogues might say, although few among them seem hardy enough to become perennials. The British unsurprisingly retain their lead as world champions of horticultural articulation, strewing clever, fresh advice and Latinate species names with the confidence they apply to tying in a clematis. Ah, tradition. FARTHER AFIELD: A Gardener's Excursions. By Allen Lacy. 286 pp. (Farrar, Straus, $17.95.) Allen Lacy, who gardens somewhere in suburban New Jersey, is right up there with Henry Mitchell of Washington and Eleanor Perenyi of Stonington, Conn., as America's answer to Christopher Lloyd, the proprietor of Great Dixter in Sussex, England, a writer who is read for his wit as well as his wisdom. ''Home Ground,'' Mr. Lacy's first published collection, placed him among that admirable elite who elevate the pleasant pastime of writing personally and with firm opinions about their private gardens into something that approaches literature. If Mr. should explain why. He has gone farther afield indeed, visiting professional growers, mail-order houses and vast estates in Costa Rica, Switzerland, Germany, the Netherlands, Majorca and elsewhere on assignments for assorted publications. Garden journalism is a curious hybrid. Mr. Lacy was more interesting and original when he stayed home and mused on the transience of his columbines.
