The productive half of ''Farther Afield'' has Mr. Lacy watching his quinces, lifting his lily tubers, considering his fritillaries, relenting on his soapworts (a close call) and succumbing to the hosta craze ''after a lifetime of indifference.''

title: Kyoto
description: To the Editor: I hope that Clyde Haberman's description of the procedure for applying to the Imperial Household Agency in Kyoto for permission to visit the Imperial Villas (Travel, April 27) will not discourage anyone from including the villas in trip plans.

title: A Promising Economic Landscape
description: ALTHOUGH inflation has usually been considered good for the stock market, disinflation has proven to be even better. That is the lesson of the past several years and the biggest reason that more records may well be set in coming months, according to many professionals.

title: CITY U. LAW GRADUATES TO TEST A SPECIAL CREDO
description: When the City University Law School at Queens College observes its first commencement Friday, among the 130 graduates will be a former saxophonist for a funk band and a former welder in a steel mill.

title: Tyrone B. Stephens Exchanges Vows With Hilary Anne Henderson on L.I.
description: Hilary Anne Henderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Alexander Henderson of New York and Nissequogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Tyrone Bert Stephens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Bert Stephens of Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Donald Webster performed the ceremony at the St. James (L.I.) Episcopal Church.

title: England
description: To the Editor: Mary-Lou Weisman's article entitled ''Finding a Real Home Away From Home'' (Travel, May 4) brings back our own memories of English hospitality coming with the room.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: YALE-HARVARD ROW ''It will be quite a race,'' said Tony Johnson, coach of the Yale University rowing team. The crew has been training at Gale's Ferry for the 121st Yale-Harvard Regatta at 5 P.M. Saturday on the Thames River in New London. Last year's loss was a big disappointment for Yale after breaking Harvard's 18-year winning streak in 1981 and starting its own four-year winning streak.

title: Teresa R. Morris, Student, Marries Robert J. Herman
description: Teresa Ruth Morris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Morris of Totowa, N.J., and Robert Jay Herman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Herman of Jamesburg, N.J., were married last night at the Forsgate Country Club in Jamesburg by Rabbi Alfred B. Landsberg.

title: Chips Without Bargaining
description: The White House has announced that the U.S. will break out of SALT II limits on strategic weapons later this year unless the Russians take drastic moves to improve compliance with existing treaties.

title: HE IS A CAMERA
description: THE LAST FILM OF EMILE VICO By Thomas Gavin. 403 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95. THIS complex, ambitious and sometimes surreal second novel by Thomas Gavin has as many layers as an onion - a description that also perfectly suits the brilliant auteur, Emile Vico, as he is perceived by the narrator, his cameraman, Griswold Farley. At first, the novel appears to be a murder mystery set in 1930's Hollywood, with an ambiance as authentic as a reel of Movietone News. But more is going on here than the disappearance of a famous author/director/star and the subsequent police investigation of Vico's beautiful, estranged second wife, Lisa, and Farley. Was it murder, suicide, or was the actor -as one old-timer suggests - simply eaten up by the camera? (''Want to find Vico? . . . Look in that last can of film.'') Is Farley himself the killer, or is it his elusive alter ego, the untrustworthy Spyhawk? Or is there some more serious hidden meaning here?

title: Talking Repairs; Borrowing Without Collateral
description: UNLIKE a cooperative corporation, which holds title to a property on behalf of its shareholders, a condominium association does not own property that can serve as collateral for a loan. This inhibits the ability of a condominium association to borrow for major repairs or capital improvements.

title: MISSIONARIES FOR DEMOCRACY: U.S. AID FOR GLOBAL PLURALISM
description: For several years after Soviet troops entered Afghanistan in 1979, a former editor and Information Minister in Kabul tried to get money to restore the village school system destroyed in rebel-held areas of his country.

title: Mets Are a Link To Past Glory
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: INCHING TOWARD CONTROLLING ASTHMA
description: DRUG companies are pumping many millions of dollars each year into finding a drug that can combat asthma without causing high blood pressure, irregular heart beat, osteoporosis or any of the other dangerous side effects that have been linked to existing asthma remedies. Now, finally, there is at least a glimmer of light at the tunnel's end.

title: British Character Is Defended
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ASTHMA AND ALLERGY MEDICINES
description: ADD the huge number of people with hay fever to those who break out in hives from certain foods to those gasping for air from an asthma attack. Opinion Research Corporation, in Princeton, N.J., did that in 1985, and came up with a staggering statistic: More than 58 million Americans suffer from allergies and asthma.

title: The New Guard
description: For two top military posts, President Reagan has chosen officers who have had different sorts of careers. Adm.

title:
ART;
IN STAMFORD SHOW, PAPER IS THE MEDIUM AND THE SUBJECT
description: ''NEW AMERICAN PAPERWORKS'' at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center through June 15, organized by the World Print Congress, has been touring museums and art centers around the globe since 1982. It consists of art in which paper is more than the medium - it is the subject. This particular show is a most handsome and diverse way to illustrate this concept.

title: Boston Cleaning Up Image of Cab Drivers
description: Come Sunday, shorts, T-shirts and sandals will be on the list of forbidden attire for Boston cab drivers.

title: Tamara Jacobs Is Wed to David Bernard Epstein
description: Tamara Eileen Louise Jacobs, president of her own public-relations concern in New York, and David Bernard Epstein, vice president of Citicorp Investment Bank in New York, were married last night at the Touro Synagogue in Newport, R.I. Lieut. Comdr. Arnold Resnicoff, a Navy chaplain, officiated.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO OFFSET WATER DEFICIENCY
description: NOW that summer is fast approaching, a few random observations about the 1986 spring season are in order.

title: WHEN SHINGLES BREAK, REPAIR IN HASTE OR REPENT AT LEISURE
description: CRACKS and small splits in wood or asbestos home shingles are not really a problem and seldom require further attention. But wide cracks and bad splits or broken-off sections that allow water to enter do need to be attended to, or further deterioration may result.

title: SCHOOL TEAMS FIGHT DRINKING AND DRUGS
description: AS he does every year, Larry Ciotti, coach of the varsity football team at Daniel Hand High School in Madison, was lecturing his players on drug and alcohol abuse in 1978, a few days before a preseason practice game against South Windsor High.

title: ARTISTS AND POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Is Wed To Miss Ambrose
description: Deborah Therese Ambrose, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis Ambrose of Pinehurst, N.C., formerly of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to David Joseph Wismer, a son of the late Rev. and Mrs. Eli Fry Wismer of Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. Frederick A. Koch performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Pinehurst.

title: Thai Aide Dismisses Accusations of Torture
description: In the first official response to accusations that Thai troops tortured Cambodian refugees in March, Prasong Soonsiri, the head of this country's National Security Council, said Friday that the charge may have been intended ''to defame Thailand.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEXICO ANNOUNCES ANOTHER SILVER LIBERTAD
description: The 1986 version of Mexico's Libertad, a one-ounce silver bullion coin, is scheduled for introduction tomorrow in the United States. This will be the fifth annual issue in the series which started with a coin dated 1982.

title:
GARDENING;
WAYS TO OFFSET WATER DEFICIENCY
description: NOW that summer is fast approaching, a few random observations about the 1986 spring season are in order.

title: DOCTORS IN ONTARIO STRIKE OVER FEE SYSTEM
description: ABOUT 75 percent of Ontario's 17,000 doctors went on strike for two days last week. It was the latest round in their fight to stop the provincial government from setting limits on physicians' fees.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
Wilmington, Del.: Visionary Plans For an Old Site
description: SEATTLE-STYLE space needles, history museums and yacht clubs with marinas were ideas that emerged from a national competition that sought multiuse redevelopment plans for the site of Sweden's first North American colony in 1638.

title: Salvaged Oil Barge Docks Safely on S.I.
description: A barge that was raised from Long Island Sound in a delicate salvage operation was docked safely at a commercial shipyard in Staten Island, a Coast Guard official said yesterday.

title: Blacks On Campus
description: In describing his own development as a black professional, Brent Staples notes that, even as a talented black youth, he would not have gone to college without appropriate encouragement and opportunity (''The Dwindling Black Presence on Campus,'' April 27). He then quotes ''experts'' who argue that the presence of blacks in college is diminishing because of a lack of talented students and faculty.

title: SOUP KITCHEN NEEDS A HAND
description: Twice a week, 60-year-old Johnny Johnson puts aside his pride and sits down to be served a hot, free meal at the Long Beach soup kitchen.

title: Refugees Said to Return To Uganda After Raids
description: More than 50,000 Ugandan refugees have fled recent armed attacks at their camps in the Sudan and are being returned to their homeland by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, officials of the agency said Friday.

title: DEALING IN THE AIRLINE 'GRAY' MARKET
description: LAST April, David P. McCall, a New York graphics designer, called travel agents to price tickets for a vacation in Kauai, one of the Hawaiian Islands. Discouraged by the fares quoted, he followed a friend's recommendation and contacted a broker who deals in so-called ''frequent flier'' credits. Three weeks later, Mr. McCall was on his way to Kauai first class for $749 round-trip - less than one-third of the airlines' asking price.

title: BLACKS ON CAMPUS
description: In the conclusion to his article, Brent Staples wonders ''who will supply providence [ to young inner-city blacks ] in the future.'' A possible solution may exist with those black alumni who matriculated in predominately white institutions as a result of the increased recruitment during the 1970's.

title: NURSING-HOME PETS A BOON TO RESIDENTS
description: ELDERLY people checking into nursing homes around the state are finding more than a clean bed, a friendly nurse and companionship. Dogs, cats, birds, fish and an occasional pig are also greeting them.

title: NEW MEASURE COULD BREAK IMPASSE ON RECYCLING
description: THE plastics industry, which more than any other fears mandatory recycling, may find the latest proposal - to be disclosed Thursday before the Senate Energy and Environment Committee -easier to live with.

title: Japanese Official, in Moscow, Reports Discord Over Islands
description: Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe of Japan said today that he had had ''heated discussions'' with officials in the Soviet Union about a group of Pacific islands claimed by both countries.

title: On Language; CLASS CLEAVAGE
description: STROH'S IS SPOKEN here.''

title: UNFINISHED PROJECTS: 'I'LL WRITE TOMORROW'
description: The Book Review asked the following authors what literary project has haunted them over the years - an idea for a book that's too compelling to let go, but that somehow hasn't been finished, or even started yet. GARRISON KEILLOR, Author of ''Lake Wobegon Days.'' One summer 20 years ago I knew an old lady who had no close relatives and who was afraid of dying alone and unnoticed in the city of St. Paul. She asked me to dinner and after dinner she asked me to write her obituary. I was a good writer, she said, so I'd be able to present her life in an honest, graceful way and also make it succinct for the newspapers. Of course I agreed to do it. She was the first person to consider my talents useful. So I took notes on her recollections of childhood, her career as a social worker, her religious conversion, and wrote it up and stashed it away and went back to college. She died in Oakland, Calif., about eight years later, I think, alone in a hospital. I hadn't been in touch with her for a long time. I looked at the obituary I'd written and was embarrassed by its extravagant antique style; I tried to rework it as fiction, with her as my mother; and finally I put it away where it sits waiting for me now, years later, on my conscience. I think about Katharine often, a sweet fat lady on a hot night in July, fanning herself and laying out her story for a young man writing on a legal pad.

title: TWO TOP SOUTH DAKOTA REPUBLICANS FACE OFF OVER SENATE NOMINATION
description: South Dakotans expected fireworks when Gov. William J. Janklow announced in February that he would challenge the re-election of his fellow Republican, Senator James Abdnor.

title: Great Neck Conversion
description: Since 1950, Great Neck Terrace, a 644-unit garden apartment complex in Great Neck, has been a haven of moderate-cost rental housing in a community better known for its million-dollar waterfront homes.

title: COOLING THE CELTICS IS GOAL OF ROCKETS
description: The way the Boston Celtics handled the Houston Rockets in the first two games of the National Basketball Association championship - easily, very easily, winning by an average margin of two touchdowns and a field goal - it would seem that something as simple as change of venue could not have much of an effect on the misfortunes of the losing team.

title: ABOUT CARS Cabriolet Fuels Jaguar Comeback
description: THE design is 11 years old now, but it shows no signs of age. Jaguar's XJ-S is as sleek and sexy as ever - but this year the company has updated the formula just a bit, resulting in a long-awaited breath of fresh air for Jag fans.

title:
ANTIQUES;
WICKER: ITS APPEAL IS TO MORE THAN JUST NOSTALGIA
description: THE RESURGENCE of interest in wicker isn't necessarily nostalgic, nor is it always based on attributes of function and comfort.

title: STATE PANEL URGES FREEZING M.T.A. FARES TILL 1990
description: A state panel recommended yesterday that transit and commuter fares, which have tripled in the last 10 years, be frozen until 1990 to maintain or increase ridership as part of a long-term plan to meet the financial needs of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: GETTING RELIEF WITHOUT FALLING ASLEEP
description: FOR years, antihistamine users had to take the good with the bad. The good was relief from itching, sniffling, and other allergy symptoms. But because antihistamines - compounds that combat histamines, the body-produced chemicals that are among the prime causes of allergy symptoms - pass from the blood to the brain, the bad part was inevitable drowsiness.

title: Rita McCloy Has Wedding
description: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Rita Anne McCloy and Mark Edward Stephanz. The Rev. Thomas Mulvanerty performed the ceremony.

title: WESTPORT GROUP NURTURES PLAYS
description: WHEN Keir Dullea and his wife, Susie Fuller, moved to Westport four years ago, Miss Fuller wanted to form a workshop for professional playwriting and performing. Her concept came out of her training as an actress and director in London, where she met and married Mr. Dullea 15 years ago.

title: Springfield, Mass., Seeks Source of Toxic Fumes
description: Health officials say they are stumped over the source of a chemical leak that forced thousands of people to flee the center of the city and hospitalized at least 60.

title: Striking Back at Nick-Pack
description: Nick-Pack has been caught and convicted of political mugging and it's about time. After four-plus years, a Federal court has ruled that the National Conservative Political Action Committee -NCPAC - impermissibly threw its money against Daniel Patrick Moynihan when he ran for re-election to the Senate from New York in 1982.

title: HALLOWED OBJECTS THAT HAVE COME THROUGH THE FIRES
description: There was every reason to suppose that ''Treasures of the Jewish Museum'' at the Jewish Museum in New York would be exactly what it is - as varied, and as touching, an anthology as we could hope to see. The objects are beautiful, almost without exception. But even when they are not beautiful they come freighted with feelings that go way beyond esthetics. They stand, in fact, for continuity, for survival, for beliefs and traditions that have passed through the fire many times over and come through intact. It is as if someone had dipped a long spoon into the stinking cauldron of recent history and come up with nothing that was not complete, and sane, and hallowed.

title: In Africa, the Deadly Tsetse War Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ VIRTUOSOS USHER IN A SECOND GOLDEN AGE OF THE CLARINET
description: The clarinet has been heard so rarely in jazz since the coming of modernism in the 1940's that it's easy to forget that it used to be one of the major jazz horns, like the trumpet or the various saxophones. In fact, younger jazz fans encountering the ''licorice stick'' today often ask, ''What kind of saxophone is that?''

title: PUNJAB LEADERS STILL SPLIT OVER APRIL TEMPLE RAID
description: A month after paramilitary policemen ousted 300 Sikh extremists from the Golden Temple at Amritsar, the mainstream Sikh leaders of Punjab remain angry and divided over the wisdom of the raid.

title: CROPS BECKON FOR 'PICK YOUR OWN'
description: FARMS across the North Shore will see the first of Long Island's strawberry bounty this week. South Shore strawberries are expected to be ready to pick about a week later.

title: U.S. Gives Italians Command Of Base on Island Near Libya
description: The United States Coast Guard communications station on the island of Lampedusa, which was the target of a Libyan missile attack in April, has been turned over to Italian command, the Defense Ministry reported today.

title: CHINESE PUPPETS WITH ANCIENT LINEAGE
description: Chinese puppets date back more than 2,000 years and are probably rooted in ancient religious rituals.

title: A COMMUNITY KEEPS UP THE TRADITION
description: Because of rising insurance costs, this Bergen County community will be the only one in the county to have a Liberty Weekend fireworks display.

title: THE OTHER SIDE OF AIRLINE DEREGULATION
description: ''WHEN we deregulated the airlines, we did not deregulate safety,'' Representative Norman Y. Mineta likes to remind officials of the Federal Aviation Administration, who have been called with growing frequency before his aviation subcommittee. But, the California Democrat invariably adds, the F.A.A.'s difficulties in coping with the profusion of carriers born of economic deregulation has brought ''de facto deregulation of air safety.''

title: Verbatim; A Raise for Congress
description: 'Members of Congress are the 535 members of the board of the largest corporation in the world.

title: MOFFETT, STILL IN CONTEST, WOOS THE UNCOMMITTED
description: AFTER weeks of public battles to line up state convention delegates, the contest for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination between Governor O'Neill and his challenger, Toby Moffett, shifted last week to behind-the-scenes persuasion.

title: PRINT DISPLAY AT NEUBERGER EXPLORES WOMEN AND DEATH
description: THE State University at Purchase sleeps, but only in the academic sense, for the Neuberger Museum remains open and has a lot to offer. The major exhibition is the fifth yearly ''Awards in the Visual Arts,'' already reviewed in this column by William Zimmer. Notable among the smaller displays, however, is one that, organized by a graduate art-history student, Annie Raulerson, examines the relationship between woman and death as it was variously perceived in Europe from the Middle Ages until the 19th century.

title: LAND THAT WON'T SOON LOSE ITS SCARS
description: FROM the air, what had once been a carpet of green stretching to the horizon was now a flat, blackened scar extending over thousands of acres in North Carolina. ''All the brush and trees and timber was either totally consumed by flame or just sucked up and blown away by the firestorm,'' said Bill Miller, a state forester who flew over the area in Pender County. ''It looks as level as the asphalt on a paved street.''

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: OWNERS of small businesses in the state will draft a report June 9 telling Governor Kean and the Legislature how government can help them meet their needs and concerns.

title: UNDER THE POLITICAL RUG -- POVERTY
description: IT HAS become unfashionable in political circles to discuss the needs of the poor. Conditioned by the current administrations in Washington and Trenton to believe that we ''deserve a [ tax ] break today,'' and encouraged to think of ourselves first, we have somehow lost our sense of community and our communal responsibility for the poor who live among us.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: MUSIC: SOUND WAVE
description: ''SOUND WAVE N.Y.C.,'' a three-night sampler of new-music performer-composers, opened Friday at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. It offered minimalism, a little electronics, and some music with words.

title: THOUGHTS ABOUT SECOND THOUGHTS ABOUT WINNING THE LOTTERY
description: THE TELEPHONE had just rung in the late afternoon of a typically very warm July day. I was about to step into the shower when I heard my wife call,''It's for you.''

title: PROSECUTORS EYE RHODE ISLAND JUDGE
description: The top Federal and state prosecutors in Rhode Island say they want to pursue the evidence that was collected but not presented publicly in the state's first impeachment proceeding.

title: Lisa Calicchio to Wed Donald Jackson on L.I.
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Calicchio of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Mara Calicchio, to Donald J. Jackson, a son of Helen Jackson of New York and the late Alfred George Jackson. A June 21 wedding is planned in Southampton.

title: BEIRUT SLIPS AT BIT FURTHER INTO CHAOS
description: A prominent Lebanese militia commander recently had his car seized by gunmen in West Beirut. When he protested, the gunmen told him: ''You are a militia leader; we are thieves. You have to do your job, and we have to do ours.''

title: VACATION IS JUST A STONE'S THROW AWAY
description: FLOWERS are blooming on the Champs-Elysees, cafe patrons are sipping Viennese coffee along the Ringstrasse, larks are soaring in the Cotswolds, and here I am in eastern Connecticut in the springtime. I should be feeling wistful about missing the seductions of the wider world, but I'm not. My corner of Connecticut has its real charms.

title: Labor Pains
description: To the Editor:

title: David and Lisa Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: STORYTELLING IN CLAY AND FABRIC
description: THE ART of telling stories through pictorial images is being revived by artists in almost every medium. The term ''narrative art'' is being applied to their work. Sometimes, such work incorporates human imagery, interpreted through a sensibility attuned to the psychological side of life.

title: Aiding the Aged
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE THE SENSES ARE FULFILLED JUST OUTSIDE THE WINDOW
description: IT is now all of 20 years since I became conscious of Connecticut. In New York, on a visit from England, I was roused early one morning in May and driven to lunch with Alexander Calder, the sculptor, and his wife, Louisa James Calder, in Roxbury. The Calders were everyone's favorite Americans, the spirits were high. It was really rather early, though, and quite possibly I dozed off. Waking, I found myself in wonderland.

title: STAGE: McGUIRE'S 'GOD'S BIRTHDAY'
description: BETWEEN indulging himself and indulging his audience, Michael McGuire can make almost impossible, and sometimes dangerous, demands on actors. In his new play, ''God's Birthday in the Year of Our Lord 1945,'' company members of the Theater in Action under the direction of Lev Shekhtman give such a perfectly disciplined performance that one would not be surprised to see them fall in for close-order drill at some point. They could outperform the Marine band.

title: SIZING UP SUPERPOWERS: 'OUT OF SYNC'
description: After devoting 40 years to the quest for a more rational relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union, a leading American Sovietologist says he believes the two nations are now ''out of sync'' with each other and unlikely to reach new arms-control accords for some time.

title: Nanci J. Silverman Is Wed To a Broadcast Executive
description: Nanci J. Silverman, a senior account executive at Young & Rubicam in New York, and Fred S. Slobodin, a vice president and director of broadcast production for Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline in New York, were married last night at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Dr. Charles Agin officiated.

title: Miss Muscara Is the Bride Of M.J. Cernichiari, Trader
description: Shirley-Anne Muscara, a television commercial producer for N. W. Ayer, and Miguel Jorge Cernichiari, a foreign-exchange trader for the Bank of Montreal in New York, were married yesterday at the Center for Inter-American Relations by Michael Grupp, a leader in the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Cultural.

title: REAL ESTATE, SELECTIVITY IS A MUST
description: IF the climate for real estate investment were gauged on a red-light, green-light system, the year's market conditions would register a bright yellow in the eyes of consultants and financial planners.

title: Susan C. Gilder, a Model, And Edward Hayes Wed
description: Susan Candace Gilder, the daughter of Mrs. Owen C. Moore of Stockton, Calif., and the late Capt. Jackson H. Gilder, U.S.A., was married yesterday to Edward Walter Hayes, a son of Edward J. Hayes of Sag Harbor, L.I., and Jean Hayes of Bohemia, L.I. The Rev. Bernard J. Ryan performed the ceremony at the Mary Immaculate Roman Catholic Church in Bellport, L.I.

title: DEAN WEBER WED TO LYNNE BLEICH
description: Lynne D. Bleich, the daughter of L. Dorothy Bleich of Oakland, N.J., and the late Theodore L. Bleich, was married yesterday to Dean Alan Weber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Weber of Tenafly, N.J. The Revs. Carol Anderson and John P. Croneberger, Episcopal priests, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Atonement in Tenafly, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Bruce K. Waltke, a Presbyterian minister who is the bride's uncle.

title: FROM SMITH'S TAVERN TO I.B.M.: NORTH CASTLE CELEBRATES 250 YEARS
description: IN 1736, a group of farmers got together and decided to form a town on the land that had been sold to them by the Siwanoy Indians 70 years earlier.

title: INFANT CHIC: THE ALLURE OF BABY BONNETS
description: A BABY in a bonnet is one of life's truly irresistible sights. Of course the babies don't know that, although they may wonder why more passers-by than usual are stopping to smile at them as they are trundled or carried through the streets of New York.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE signs of summer are everywhere.

title: Carol L. Montgomery Becomes a Bride
description: Carol Lynne Montgomery, a daughter of Harold Butler Montgomery of Ambler, Pa., and the late Elizabeth Hannan Montgomery, was married yesterday to Joseph Francis O'Rourke, the son of Elizabeth M. O'Rourke of Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. David Toolan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: BIRD WATCHERS AID STATE ATLAS PROGRAM
description: WALKING through the Pachaug State Forest in Voluntown, Robert Dewire heard a pine warbler somewhere in the nearby evergreens. Quickly, he played the song of the pine warbler on the small tape player he had brought along, and just as quickly, the real pine warbler flew out of the trees, chirping vigorously.

title:
MUSIC;
YOUTH ORCHESTRA SETS FINALE
description: ''FASTER than a speeding bullet,'' the conductor Eugene Minor exhorted the student musicians. Then, some moments later, he told them:

title: CRIME
description: One of the most unusual thrillers that will come your way this year is THE HOUND OF HEAVEN by Glover Wright (Arbor House, $15.95). It is hard to describe: part adventure story, part religious study, part allegory, part tale of the supernatural. Whatever it is, it catches the reader from the beginning, and the tension never lets up.

title: OWNERS OF COTTAGES VOW TO IGNORE BROOKHAVEN ON EVICTIONS
description: OWNERS of 101 cottages on West Meadow Beach in Stony Brook say they will ignore eviction orders from the Town of Brookhaven in the latest chapter of a long dispute over their rights to the cottages.

title:
DINING OUT;
DEPENDABILITY IN BANKSVILLE
description: THE standard most difficult for a restaurant to maintain is consistency. At most places, accomplishments rise and fall like the Dow. No sooner are we served an Olympian feast than we hear that the star chef has moved elsewhere, leaving the kitchen in unsure hands. But such extremes might be past history for La Cremaillere, for in the last several years Waldy Malouf has wielded the wooden spoon in that kitchen with a skill diners might begin to depend upon.

title: BOOTLEGGERS, KNEEWALKERS AND ACROBATIC DOLLS
description: DRIVING THE BODY BACK By Mary Swander. 81 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95. SOURCE By Fred Chappell. 57 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $6.95. SWAN'S ISLAND By Elizabeth Spires. 56 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. Paper, $8.95.MARY SWANDER'S ''Driving the Body

title: PROSECUTION DETAILS SPY SUSPECT'S SPENDING
description: Jerry A. Whitworth, on trial here on charges of espionage and tax fraud, lived extravagantly and spent thousands of dollars on gold coins, works of art, jewelry, lingerie and other items, according to records of banks and merchants introduced as evidence here.

title: GRANT TO ENLARGE CHILD-ABUSE EFFORT
description: HOPING to address what District Attorney Carl A. Vergari called the ''shocking and growing problem of child sexual abuse,'' the county will increase its Domestic Violence Prosecution Unit to prosecute all cases of child abuse.

title: Q AND A
description: Real-Estate Courses - Question: I am contemplating a career change and I am interested in real estate, particularly the appraisal area. Are there any accredited training programs offered by universities or professional associations in New York area? . . ., R. B. Manhattan Answer: You have more than one option in your search for real estate courses. The broadest array of courses is offered by New York University's Real Estate Institute. The institute, which is part of the School of Continuing Eduation, offers courses ranging from appraisal to real estate brokering and development.

title: How We May Negotiate The Japanese Maze
description: To the Editor:

title: Katherine Greenberg Weds Fellow Lawyer
description: Katherine Anne Greenberg and Edmond Gabbay, who both graduated last year from the Fordham Law School, were married yesterday at the deSeversky Conference Center in Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi David Benedict officiated.

title: HANNA SCHYGULLA TRIES LIFE'S LIGHT SIDE
description: What an unlikely mix.

title: RECYCLING: REGIONAL BENEFIT ON WASTE DISPOSAL
description: THE management of solid waste is one of the most difficult environmental and health problems society has had to solve. Everyone wants their garbage picked up, but no one wants it to put down.

title: TRACK TITLE TO BROOKLYN TECH
description: Brooklyn Tech successfully defended its team title yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League boys outdoor track and field championships with a winning total of 149 points at St. John's University. John F. Kennedy of the Bronx was second at 89 points and Tottenville of Staten Island third at 86.

title: REVENGE IN ST. PETERSBURG
description: A TASTE OF LIBERTY (Poor Avrosimov). By Bulat Okudzhava. Translated by Leo Gruliow. 223 pp. Ann Arbor, Mich.: Ardis. Cloth, $29.50. Paper, $9.95. I MET Bulat Okudzhava, the author of ''A Taste of Liberty,'' in January 1960 on my first visit to Leningrad. A group of poets from Moscow invited me one evening to the Oktyabr Hotel, where they were to read their new poems. Mr. Okudzhava is both a writer and a singer. To a simple guitar accompaniment, he performed the ballads that were to make him famous when he began singing them in public. We were all spellbound. Mr. Okudzhava was slender, elegant, dark-eyed. Though his performance was low-key, his ballads were full of lyric power. There was a slightly conspiratorial intensity to that evening; the poets present were all young, and their hopes for a freer, more humane Soviet Union were running high. They were not unlike the characters in ''A Taste of Liberty'' - the Decembrists, the young army officers who dreamed of a bright future for Russia in the 1820's, only to be banished or executed when their rebellion was crushed.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
VOLUNTEERS IN PARKS
description: ''The volunteers get a nice course in natural history and learn about the history of the property also,'' Alison Beall, curator of the Marshlands Conservancy in Rye, said, discussing the Volunteers in Parks training program that will be held there this month.

title: Afro-American Music
description: To the Editor:

title: REDISCOVERING THE GRANDEUR OF THE TETONS
description: Wyoming is a state of great plains divided by mountain ranges with stirring names:

title: A SELECTIVE GUIDE TO 50 NEW CLASSICAL CD RELEASES
description: With compact disks established in the marketplace and proliferating on record-store shelves, the time has long passed when one listener could hope to hear all the halfway promising disks and make a comprehensive selection of the best of them.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Ideas & Trends May 18 incorrectly described an attempt to deny tenure to Dr. Les Kurtz, a sociology professor at the University of Texas. The students who led the unsuccessful campaign against Dr. Kurtz were not affiliated with Accuracy in Academia.

title: BOOKS FOR VACATION READING
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1985. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography & Biography

title: Reused Lofts
description: Although many are no longer needed by the manufacturers and warehousemen for whom they were built, the city's many loft buildings still are much in demand.

title: MINING CHINATOWN'S 'MOUNTAIN OF GOLD'
description: IN 1949, when young Joseph Chu got his first glimpse of Chinatown's crooked streets, his impulse was to turn and leave. Fewer than 10,000 people, most of them down at the heels, lived in the area, making do in some of the city's most dilapidated housing. What future, what fortune could possibly lie there?

title: Adjusting to Holden Caulfield
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOREHAM DISPUTE CLAIMS CARNEY AS LATEST POLITICAL CASUALTY
description: THE growing political casualty list from the Shoreham nuclear plant issue is making the plant one of the most potent issues to affect Long Island politics in many years, Republican and Democratic politicians agreed last week.

title: '1 TO 1' TUTORING AIDS NEWARK PUPILS
description: CRETIA CLARK, a 12-year-old sixth-grader at the McKinley School here, and Marge Cully of Hazlet, a New Jersey Bell employee, were part of an unlikely group of picnickers in the Newark Museum's sunny garden recently.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a computer entry error, the hard-cover fiction best-seller list published on May 25 reversed the ranking of two books. ''I'll Take Manhattan,'' by Judith Krantz (Crown), should have been No. 1. ''A Perfect Spy,'' by John le Carre (Knopf), should have been No. 2.

title: EUROPE SEEKS TO ATTRACT THE WARY AMERICAN
description: With high season at hand, many in the trans-Atlantic and European travel business are seeking ways to salvage whatever American patronage they can from the ruins of what they had once expected to be a profitable year. An assortment of high-pressure marketing campaigns - some representing real bargains but others more in the nature of gimmicks - have been initiated in recent weeks. Indications are that as the season progresses and airlines are faced with empty seats and hotels with empty rooms, bargains may abound for those who wait to make reservations or even show up in Europe without them.

title: Americans Finding Buys Overseas
description: DR. MARVYN D. COHEN decided last year to try something new with some of the $200,000 he had saved for retirement. After hearing a lecture given by an investment specialist at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., the pediatrician from Columbus, Ga., decided to put a portion of his money into a mutual fund specializing in foreign investments.

title: PANHANDLE WORRIED ABOUT WASTE PLAN
description: The milo is going in now, the wheat is heading for an early harvest, the corn's up and so are the sugar beets. Tempers are up too in the Panhandle of Texas since Wednesday when the Reagan Administration said that the salt bed deep under the rich clay soil of Deaf Smith County was one of three sites under final consideration to dispose of the nation's growing pile of high-level nuclear waste.

title: THEATRICAL LIFE FAR FROM BROADWAY
description: In my mail slot at the Mark Taper Forum this morning there are six plays. Two are about what happened to the ''Big Chill'' generation after it went sour; one concerns a married woman who finds bliss in a lesbian relationship (the second such drama this week), and two are abstract theater events, one about Jack the Ripper, one about Faust. The first is inspired by a strong feminist ethic, the second, perhaps, by the dangers of nuclear power, but it is hard to tell. There is also a play from a Beverly Hills dentist, who informs me, by way of introduction, that in the 60's he wrote a book called ''Teeth, Teeth, Teeth,'' which Rolling Stone called ''the book of the decade.'' His play, he assures me, is not an adaptation of ''Teeth, Teeth, Teeth,'' but something completely new. It is called ''Nothing but the Tooth.'' Are there any buyers for these goods?

title: A BIRTHDAY FOR BOND STREET
description: Cheating only a little bit, Bond Street is celebrating its tercentenary this week. London's reigning champion in the world heavyweight shopping division will be en fete to mark three centuries of devotion to the anciens and nouveaux riches, starting around the corner today with a service at St. George's Church to square its collective conscience with the Almighty, and proceeding from there to an outdoor costume pageant on Tuesday, a carnival ball on Thursday and children's gala street party on Saturday.

title: LIFE AFTER: 'WE HAVE DECIDED TO ELIMINATE YOUR POSITION'
description: ''UNFORTUNATELY, we have decided to eliminate your position.'' Those were the words that I heard last Nov. 12. I couldn't believe it, and yet it was true. My director called and asked, in a friendly voice, how I was and if I could come down to his office for a minute. A minute. That's all it took. Twenty-six years of hard work and dedication were wiped out, effective Jan. 31.I was being discarded like an unwanted card in a poker game. Although not verbalized, I was being told that I was no longer of value.

title: GUIDES
description: Ralph Waldo Emerson thought the difference between landscapes is small ''but there is a great difference between beholders.'' A casual browse through the travel guide section of any bookstore shows that publishers agree at least with his second point. Never has there been such a range of choices for travelers.

title: A VIRTUOSO REFLECTS UPON ASPECTS OF HIS ART
description: The violinist is that peculiarly human phenomenon distilled to a rare potency -half tiger, half poet. The violinist is an incarnation of a very specific animal agility in the service of a singularly human transfiguration. It is up to the violinist to speak of human memory, feeling or thought: the violinist makes such intangibles palpable by expressing them in sound and in rhythm. It seems to me that the violinist must possess the poet's gift of piercing the protective hide which grows on propagandists, stockbrokers and slave traders, to penetrate the deeper truth which lies within.

title: DR. ROGER BIRON
description: Dr. Roger Biron, medical administrator and president of the medical staff at the Manhattan Psychiatric Center on Wards Island, died Tuesday night at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 43 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 3 Investors, 3 Successful Game Plans
description: For anyone who has a few million dollars or more it is relatively easy to find investment advisers. Banks, securities firms and professional advisers are eager to lock into such business and earn handsome fees for giving advice. Getting professional investment help is far more difficult, however, for most people, who do not have millions to invest. As a result, many middle-income people are left to their own devices. And some, by developing clear strategies, have done quite well. 'BEING PATIENT PAID OFF' JAMES A. HANDAL, a savvy 34-year-old investor of modest wealth, earns between $40,000 and $50,000 a year. Mr. Handal manages a special branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank at 75th Street and Lexington Avenue, where customers - with incomes ranging from $35,000 to $250,000 - bank by appointment. While catering to Chase's customers, Mr. Handal also closely monitors his own investments, which climbed in value by about 40 percent over the last year.

title: RIGHTS ABUSES SAID TO RISE SHARPLY IN SOUTH KOREA
description: Human-rights abuses in South Korea have sharply risen since Secretary of State George P. Shultz visited Seoul three weeks ago and praised President Chun Doo Hwan, two human-rights organizations said last week.

title: Beaufort, S.C.: The Rise of the Low Country
description: MOST of the South Carolina coast between Charleston and Savannah, Ga., is a long, low landscape of saw grass, blackwater lagoons and live oak trees draped with Spanish moss. Even now, for most visitors, it is just something to pass through on their way to the booming oceanfront resort communities on Hilton Head, Seabrook and Kiawah Islands.

title: Eliot Ammidon, Teacher, Is Engaged To Philip Morgan Jacobs, Accountant
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt Ammidon Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Eliot Hamilton Ammidon to Philip Morgan Jacobs, the son of Kareen M. Jacobs and the late Jay Winfield Jacobs of Greenwich, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title: WHEN NOVELTY IS NOT ENOUGH
description: The idea that both dancers and audiences require new works in every season dies hard. In fact, the idea has not died at all. Witness the five premieres American Ballet Theater has already presented in a season that has not even reached the halfway mark at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: CITY IS ASSAILED ON DECISION TO USE FLUSHING AIRPORT AS AUTO POUND
description: Flushing Airport in Queens, which closed in 1984, will be used as a temporary pound for towed automobiles as the first step of a city plan to expand its storage areas for seized cars.

title: Lane Miller Has Wedding
description: Lane Miller, a daughter of Patricia H. McNitt of Annapolis, Md., and William M. Miller of New York and Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to John P. Bohach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bohach of Minneapolis. The Rev. Dr. Howard Nutting, a Congregationalist minister, officiated at the ceremony at the home of the bride's father in Weston.

title: HORSE RACING: 'HIDDEN GIANT' OF THE ISLAND'S ECONOMY
description: AS THE shadows lengthen over the Belmont Park grandstand late next Saturday afternoon, a handful of 3-year-old colts will explode out of the starting gate in front of 40,000 to 50,000 screaming fans and race hell-bent to win the 118th Belmont Stakes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JUNE 1, 1986
description: International Moscow offered to begin reductions of strategic nuclear forces if the United States and the Soviet Union both pledge not to withdraw from the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty for an extended period and take steps to strengthen the treaty, Reagan Administration officials said. The Soviet proposal was made at a session of the Geneva arms talks on Thursday, two days after the Administration announced that the United States would no longer be bound by the limits of the 1979 strategic arms treaty, officials said. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Senate action on an extradition treaty with Britain is being sought by President Reagan, who warned against allowing ''terrorists'' a ''safe haven'' in the United States. In his weekly radio speech, Mr. Reagan linked the treaty to larger efforts at combating international terrorism. The revised 1972 treaty, which was signed last June by the United States and Britain, includes new provisions that end exemption from extradition for crimes that have been justified as politically motivated. [ 1:4. ] The capture of a Solidarity fugitive was announced by Poland. The Interior Ministry said Zbigniew Bujak, the most sought-after fugitive leader of the Solidarity underground, had been arrested. Mr. Bujak, a 31-year-old electrician, went into hiding when martial law was declared on Dec. 13, 1981. [ 1:5. ] Europe halted space launchings after an Ariane rocket was destroyed in midflight Friday night, throwing the West's launching capability into disarray. An independent panel is to investigate the fourth failure of an Ariane in 18 launchings.

title: Social Events; Partying for a Cause
description: JEWISH MUSEUM GALA -June 2 - A 6 P.M. reception and viewing of the current exhibitions at the Jewish Museum on Fifth Avenue at 92d Street will open the museum's annual black-tie spring gala. Following the reception, buses will transport guests to the Waldorf-Astoria for dining and dancing. Tickets, $300 to $2,500, which includes a visit with the artist George Segal in his studio and the choice of one of his screen prints, from 212-860-1885. Helping Big Brothers June 3 - There will be cocktails and hors d'oeuvres on the upstairs deck at 7 P.M., filet mignon and chilled lobster on the lower barge at 8:30 and dancing and entertainment inside the Water Club on the East River at 30th Street starting at 9:30 P.M. The party benefits Big Brothers of New York, which matches boys and girls from troubled homes with trustworthy adults who seek to provide guidance and friendship. Tickets, $150, from Mrs. Stone at 212-6862042. Seaport Party June 3 - Mothers for More Halfway Houses was founded in 1984 to provide care for young adults who are released from mental institutions, often without any follow-up rehabilitation. A major goal of the group is to establish a model treatment and research house in Manhattan, all of which prompts a black-tie benefit at the Pier 17 Pavilion at the South Street Seaport starting with cocktails at 7:30 P.M., followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment. Tickets, $110 or $200 per couple; for dancing only at 9:30, $40, or $45 at the door, from 212-580-4836.

title: Slayings At Grocery
description: THE DISPUTE in the small Brooklyn grocery store last June started over paying for a can of soda and ended with three teen-agers dead, a fourth wounded and the proprietor sought for homicide.

title: MUSIC: GREEK CHORALE
description: THE Metropolitan Greek Chorale, whose spring concert took place yesterday afternoon in Merkin Concert Hall, makes its impact through fervor and generosity of tone. Bruckner's ''Ecce Sacerdos'' sounded through these 38 voices with severe majesty and power, while Brahms's ''Da unten im Tale'' was cushioned with enough vocal plush to remind one afresh how lovely a song it is.

title: ERRORS COSTLY AS METS LOSE
description: You can't blame it all on Mike Krukow, even though he outpitched Dwight Gooden 10 days ago in San Francisco and outpitched Ron Darling yesterday before 49,041 persons in Shea Stadium.

title: The National Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Wind Storm in Karachi Slums Kills 11 and Injures Over 200
description: A swirling dust storm knocked down flimsy wood and bamboo shanties in Karachi's slums, killing at least 11 people and injuring hundreds, the authorities said today.

title: ACCORD ELUDES LAWYERS IN JOHNSON ESTATE CASE
description: A tentative out-of-court settlement in the legal battle over the estate of the late J. Seward Johnson appeared to have fallen apart yesterday.

title: Accident Kills Sky Diver
description: Merlene Jones Carnes, an experienced sky diver, pulled the wrong cord on her parachute pack Friday, then apparently became confused and never pulled the emergency ripcord as she plunged 4,000 feet to her death, officials said. Mrs. Carnes, 36 years old, of Rockwall, was killed after she and two other sky divers jumped near the Aero Country Municipal Airport, about 50 miles north of Dallas.

title: Businessland Ends Talks
description: Businessland Inc., a nationwide retail computer chain based in San Jose, Calif., has ended its negotiations to acquire MBI Business Centers Inc., a chain of 34 computer stores mainly in the East.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE CAMBRIDGE APOSTLES: A History of Cambridge University's Elite Intellectual Secret Society. By Richard Deacon. 214 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

title: 8 New Mutual Funds Set by Money Manager
description: In the bull market of the 1960's, Fred Alger gained Wall Street attention as a go-go mutual fund manager who climbed to the top of the performance derby. It is bull market time again, and Mr. Alger is reappearing in the mutual fund business.

title: 'SPEARFIELD'S DAUGHTER,' A MINI-SERIES
description: IN the opening scene of ''Spearfield's Daughter,'' a three-part mini-series beginning tonight at 8 o'clock on WNYW/Channel 5, a woman watches two bodies being removed from the street ouside her luxury Manhattan apartment. She was meant to be one of the victims. The rest of the story, the ''concept,'' has been distilled in a press release: ''She reflects over the events which have brought her to the pinnacle of success in the explosive world of international journalism, yet has kept her personal life in a state of emotional disarray.''

title: Rumania Separates U.N. Aide From His Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Defeated by Pornography
description: Does pornography cause sex crimes? In 1970 a commission chosen by President Johnson couldn't find a connection and it recommended repeal of obscenity laws that keep adults from viewing and reading what they like. Now commissioners chosen by Attorney General Edwin Meese say they have found there is a causal link and urge stepped-up Federal and state prosecution of pornography. Who's right? Most people have long since chosen sides. Likewise the Meese commission, which was loaded with members predisposed to crack down on pornography. It ended up appealing more to sensibility than evidence. Its 11 members could not even agree on a definition of pornography. They have left the controversy where they found it, in a mess.

title: MET OPERA ENDS LAST NATIONAL TOUR
description: Fondness and regret blended in Northrop Auditorum here Saturday at the final performance in the Metropolitan Opera's century-old tradition of touring the country.

title: Washington Watch; Evaluating Tokyo Summit
description: TWO Washington consultants have organized what is shaping up as one of the most ambitious private events on the world economic agenda this year. On the weekend of June 28 they will bring together in Zurich 100 or so central bankers, finance ministers, private economists, financiers and major industrialists.

title: THE DUCK CLUB: ANTI-COMMUNISM AND INVESTMENT ADVICE FOR MILLIONAIRES
description: Every Saturday afternoon, in the backyard of his home, Robert White fires off about 500 rounds from his .22-caliber pistol at a target 25 feet away. He rarely misses.

title: Technologies Goes to Ogilvy
description: Back in February, the United Technologies Corporation decided to consolidate its advertising from a dozen agencies into one. On Friday, Ogilvy & Mather was the one named to handle the entire corporate and product budget of some $18 million to $22 million a year.

title: Easy as 1, 2, 3
description: When Jane Preyer, the women's tennis coach at Duke, was weighing athletic scholarships for next fall, she had trouble ranking her prospects. The O'Reilly girl from New Jersey seemed pretty strong, but so did the O'Reilly girl from New Jersey, and so, for that matter, did the O'Reilly girl from New Jersey.

title: WATSON 'READY TO WIN'
description: BACK when Tom Watson was the PGA Tour's leading money winner for four consecutive years from 1977 through 1980, he once stood on a practice green watching Jack Nicklaus miss more 4-foot putts than he made.

title: COLD SHOULDER FOR EX-MEMBERS ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: It is quite ordinary for former members of Congress to return to Capitol Hill to use their emeritus status to lobby present members. Dozens do it.

title: Robert Longman Wed To Judith Greenebaum
description: Judith Greenebaum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Greenebaum of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Stratford, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Longman, a son of Donald Longman of Los Altos Hills, Calif., and the late Charlotte Longman. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the Chappaqua, N.Y., home of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Klein, the bride's brother-in-law and sister.

title: CITY SLICKERS AT RANCH SALE: BUYING TEXAS MYTH BY THE ACRE
description: The rocky Texas Hill Country is green from the spring rains, and the endless ranches dotted with scrub oak, mesquite and cactus look so prosperous that it is hard to believe they are in such trouble.

title: FERNANDEZ, 14, SCORES UPSET IN TENNIS
description: Mary Joe Fernandez of the United States, who turns 15 on Aug. 19, became the second youngest woman ever to reach the quarterfinals of the French Open when she defeated fourth-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany today, 7-6, 7-5.

title: CUOMO CHOICES EXPECTED TO WIN PARTY'S BACKING
description: With Governor Cuomo firmly in control, the New York State Democratic Committee is expected Monday and Tuesday to designate a state ticket headed by the Governor and virtually selected by him.

title: HOPES FOR LOWER RATES FADE
description: Signs of a sluggish economy have kept alive hopes of renewed interest rate declines, but those hopes have faded in the last several weeks as credit market participants worry that the Federal Reserve is not so willing to push for lower interest rates as in the last two years.

title: Japan-Soviet Talks Planned
description: Soviet and Japanese officials are to meet in Tokyo next year in an effort to improve relations, according to a communique issued today and published by the official press agency Tass. The communique described talks here between Soviet leaders and the Japanese Foreign Minister, Shintaro Abe, as ''businesslike and vigorous.'' Mr. Abe said Saturday, before leaving Moscow, that he had had heated exchanges with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, on a territorial dispute over four formerly Japanese islands north of Japan that the Soviet Union occupied at the end of World War II.

title:
BRIEFING;
Urgent Plea for Hawkins
description: Arecent fund-raising letter sent to 30,000 Republican contributors in Florida says that Senator Paula Hawkins's re-election campaign is in serious jeopardy.

title: PROVIDING A RESPITE FOR ALZHEIMER FAMILIES
description: It was 9:29 on a morning that had brought torrents of rain to the streets of Manhattan, but Betty Gursky and her husband, Samuel, were punctual as always. Two other faithful regulars, Sol Hirsch and his wife, Henrietta, arrived at almost the same time. Soon, others in the group began to assemble: Frank, who was all smiles; Hannah, whose face never lost its serenity, and Helen, whose expressive eyes seemed to find interest in every feature of the room.

title: Market Place; Newspaper Issues Favored
description: FAVORABLE operating conditions and proposed tax changes - along with recent sales of several prominent properties for record sums - have sent newspaper stocks racing ahead. Despite this surge in equity prices, Wall Street analysts said Friday that they still recommended selected purchases within the group.

title: Bid by Economist
description: The Economist Newspaper Ltd., publisher of the Economist Magazine, said yesterday that it offered $115 a share, or about $5.4 million, to acquire the Business International Corporation, a New York-based publishing, research and consulting concern that is privately held.

title: Nelson Honored
description: Byron Nelson is being honored tomorrow night on the 50th anniversary of his victory in the 1936 Metropolitan Golf Association Open championship at Quaker Ridge Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. Back in those days, Nelson said, the Met Open was a nationally important tournament and ''it was the first big one I won.''

title: A.T.&T. IS STRUCK, BUT CALLS GO ON
description: About 155,000 members of the Communications Workers of America began a strike against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today, but the company said that telephone service throughout the country remained mostly unimpaired.

title: CLOTHES PROVOKE BATTLES
description: THE father sorted through the size 12 pants rack in the boys' department and held up a pair of gray dungarees. ''Look,'' he said to his 11-year-old son, ''aren't these nice?''

title: FATALITY MARS LE MANS
description: Derek Bell of Britain, Hans Stuck of West Germany and Al Holbert of the United States drove a Porsche to victory at the 54th Le Mans 24-hour endurance race today, but the triumph was marred by the death of Jo Gartner of Austria.

title: Advertising; Ted Bates Is Dropped By Colgate
description: AS the advertising community expected, Colgate-Palmolive on Friday announced that it was removing its advertising assignments from Ted Bates Worldwide. Speculation on the budget has put it in the $80 million neighborhood.

title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS
description: Often an event captures headlines, then fades from view with important questions unanswered - questions that defy news reporting, at least for a while. This column periodically reviews the status of such questions.

title: ROCK: JACKSON BROWNE AT RADIO CITY
description: WHEN Jackson Browne released his first album in 1972, he immediately established himself as an appealingly authentic spokesman of Southern California mysticism during the twilight of the hippie era. Mr. Browne's songs espoused a genteel hippie populism animated by a ''psychedelic'' vision of the relationship between humanity and the rest of the environment. But many of his songs also carried a current of foreboding. Mr. Browne envisioned American society, distracted by material pursuits, already turning away from Utopian spiritual and social ideals of the counterculture - ideals he continues to cherish.

title: PACE PICKS UP FOR INDY VICTOR
description: Now that Bobby Rahal has won the Indianapolis 500, he knows life will be different.

title: ROCKETS WIN BY 106-104
description: The Houston Rockets were reeling, staring directly into a deficit from which no team in professional basketball's 39-year playoff history has ever recovered. But just when it looked as if their unexpected rise to postseason prominence was over, the Rockets rallied today for an exciting 106-104 victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: Section of J Line Reopens
description: A section of the J line in Brooklyn that was closed Thursday after a broken water main caused elevated tracks to sink was returned to service yesterday, a Transit Authority spokesman said. The line resumed operating in both directions at 11:40 A.M. The water main break occurred at the corner of Quincy Street and Broadway near the Gates Avenue station in the Bushwick section, halting subway service between Eastern Parkway and Myrtle Avenue.

title: 15,000 Alcoa Workers Strike
description: About 15,000 aluminum workers went on strike early today against the Aluminum Company of America and picketed Alcoa plants in eight states after negotiators failed to reach agreement on a new contract.

title: HEBREW UNION: SOUTH AFRICAN WARNS CLASS ON DIVESTING
description: A member of the South African Parliament and a longtime opponent of apartheid, Helen Suzman, warned the graduating class of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion yesterday that the enthusiasm among some Americans for sanctions and divestment in South Africa was misplaced.

title: THE RISE AND FALL OF SPENDTHRIFT FARM
description: 1937; Spendthrift Farm founded by Leslie Combs 2d.

title: JAZZ: DICK WELLSTOOD, PIANIST
description: LAST August the pianist Dick Wellstood, a full-time musician for 39 years, gave up music to join a law firm, making his first use of a law degree he received in 1958. Last week, Mr. Wellstood returned to the piano and Hanratty's, Second Avenue near 92nd Street, having learned that a life in music may have its frustrations but things can be worse in the real world.

title: BRADLEY IS FIRST TO GET GRAND SLAM
description: Pat Bradley continued to make golf history today as she sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the tournament's final hole to win the 32d annual L.P.G.A. Championship by a shot over Patty Sheehan. Miss Bradley become the first player to win the four major tournaments that make up the grand slam of women's golf.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., Cleveland, an iron ore, timber and lake shipping concern, elected M. Thomas Moore president, succeeding Edwin B. Johnson, who is retiring; William R. Calfee was named executive vice president and chief operating officer, effective July 1.

title: Why the U.N. Is Worth Saving
description: It is interesting and sad that the United Nations, which we helped found 40 years ago, is enduring a financial crisis that threatens to shut it down, and nobody seems much to care. Indeed, the fact that the General Assembly had to be called back into special session rated only the briefest mention in New York and Washington, and nothing at all most everywhere else.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1986
description: The Economy

title:
BRIEFING;
Washington Woos a Party
description: The city of Washington will be touting itself today when its officials meet with members of the Democratic Party's site selection committee, a much-wooed group that is reviewing possible locations for the party's 1988 convention.

title: DISSIDENT POLES RALLY FOR CAPTIVE LEADER
description: Polish dissidents in several cities rallied today in defense of Zbigniew Bujak, the fugitive leader of the Solidarity underground whose capture was announced here Saturday.

title: Gene Leone Is Dead at 88; A Restaurateur in Manhattan
description: Gene Leone, the former owner and operator of Mamma Leone's restaurant, which was founded by his mother in New York City's theater district, has died after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Backing Seen For S.B.A.
description: For the second year in a row the Reagan Administration has shelved plans to abolish the Small Business Administration, according to some members of Congress.

title: Khan Advances To Squash Final
description: Top-seeded Jahangir Khan of Pakistan defeated Gawain Briars of England, 9-3, 9-1, 9-1, yesterday to move into the finals of the $50,000 Swan Laser Die United States Pro Softball Squash Championships.

title: Camcorder, CD Sales May Double in 1986
description: This year's sales of stereo televisions, video camcorders and compact disk players will double last year's levels, the Electronic Industries Association forecast today as it opened its Summer Consumer Electronics Show here.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:35 P.M. Radio -WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M) Yankees vs.

title: THE OPERA: 'WERTHER'
description: AN afternoon thunderstorm had partly cooled the city, but the news hadn't yet reached the fifth floor loft in the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West 73d Street, where the Riverside Opera Ensemble presented Jules Massenet's ''Werther'' on Saturday night. A single fan whirled, makeup dripped, players and audience sweltered, and Werther, once again, killed himself for the love of Charlotte.

title: USE OF DISCLOSURES
description: The Reagan Administration has been following a pattern of disclosing highly classified information to support its foreign policies, even though a number of Administration officials say these disclosures have endangered intelligence sources and methods. This fits the well-established practice of its predecessors, with two important variations: In the memory of a number of past and present officials, the Reagan team does it more often. And this Administration has been more aggressive in threatening the news media with prosecution for conveying similar intelligence information to the American people.

title: OUTDOORS: PREPARATIONS FOR ADVANCED MOUNTAINEERS
description: ALMOST inevitably, those who take to the woods - whether on day hikes or extended backpacking trips - will be tugged toward the hills and the mountains. And as their fitness and skills improve, they will attempt more challenging ascents.

title: WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY: JIHAN SADAT ADVOCATES LIFETIME LEARNING
description: Jihan Sadat, the widow of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, urged graduates of Wesleyan University today to pursue learning throughout their lives.

title: Activist for Homeless Begins Hunger Strike
description: An advocate for the homeless, Mitch Snyder, began a hunger strike today aimed at getting the Reagan Administration to provide the $5 million he said it had promised for repairing a crumbling shelter in the shadow of the Capitol.

title: MOSLEM OBSERVANCES ALTER THE PACE AT U.N.
description: It forced President Abdou Diouf of Senegal to beg out of the Sport Aid run last Monday. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar served grape juice at dinner because of it. The cafeteria extended its hours. And the chief French delegate abandoned protocol and merged an intimate sitdown dinner and a late-afternoon cocktail party into one enormous buffet.

title: Bartender Seeking Reduced Sentence
description: A former Pittsburgh bartender who pleaded guilty to selling cocaine to major league baseball players is seeking a reduction in his four-year prison sentence.

title: Japan Jobless At a Record
description: Japan's jobless rate rose to 2.9 percent in April, matching the highest level since record-keeping began in January 1953, the Government reported Friday.

title: RELIGIOUS RIGHT CHALLENGING G.O.P.
description: The sudden emergence of the Rev. Pat Robertson and the religious right in Presidential politics means Republicans must reassess their strategies for 1988, their advisers and political experts say.

title: Rescue Judges From the Bosses
description: It's hard to be an independent judge and still run for re-election. Unlike Federal judges, tenured for life, state judges must occasionally weigh the temptation of straying from strict law to please the electorate. Nonetheless, most states insist that they periodically submit to the voters. New York clings to that notion of popular government with a peculiar, undemocratic wrinkle: Its political bosses choose first-time candidates for most courts and also those running for re-election. That mocks the very idea of election.

title: CORNELL UNIVERSITY: 5,000 GET DEGREES AT A TRADITIONAL CEREMONY
description: In ceremonies that attracted 25,000 people, Cornell University today awarded degrees to 5,000 students, including 3,400 undergraduates.

title: Pets and Hot Weather
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubt on Product Liability Law
description: For all the thunder over the issue, Congress is unlikely to enact a product liability law this year, Senator John C. Danforth told a meeting of business executives in St. Louis last week. But Mr. Danforth, a Missouri Republican who is the chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee and the author of a product liability bill, will keep pressing the matter next year.

title: PIANO: RICHARD NANES
description: RICHARD NANES, a New Jersey businessman who also plays the piano and composes, presented himself and his music at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine Saturday night.

title: Investigation Continues In California Bus Plunge
description: Experts continued an investigation today at the site along a twisting, scenic highway through the Sierra Nevada where 18 people died in a bus plunge Friday. The police said they were still trying to determine whether speeding caused the accident.

title: Once in a Lifetime
description: Last Wednesday was the anniversary of a landmark date in track and field: May 28, 1955, when a young Hungarian soldier named Laszlo Tabori clocked 3 minutes 59 seconds, beating Chris Chataway and Brian Hewson of Britain by eight-tenths of a second in a one-mile race at White City Stadium in London. That distant day, barely a year after Roger Bannister first broke the four-minute barrier, marked the first time that as many as three milers had duplicated Bannister's feat in the same race, as well as the first time that anybody had done it other than Bannister and his archrival, John Landy. The New York Times called it ''one of the most magnificent mile races in history.''

title: A HIGH SCHOOL LOOKS HARD AT VALUES
description: When the police arrived at a recent teen-age drinking party here, many startled youths abandoned their beer cans and fled into nearby woods, hurrying away in the hope they had outraced trouble. They had not. Judged guilty of violating the code of behavior at Weston High School, about 70 students who attended the party were suspended for 10 days from all extracurricular activities.

title: CASH VS. CACHET AT NEW YORKER
description: Last September, anyone watching ''Cagney and Lacey,'' the hit television series, saw commercials touting The New Yorker. It was the first time the prestigious magazine had resorted to network TV to sell itself, and the pitch may even have reached the proverbial little old lady in Dubuque.

title: CHALLENGE TO RODINO CLOSELY WATCHED
description: The most closely watched of the Congressional primary elections tomorrow in New Jersey will be the bid of Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. for a 20th term, against Newark Councilman Donald M. Payne, whose campaign has tapped a long-deferred desire of blacks in the district to elect the state's first black Congressman.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BEHIND THE LIONS Bryant Park, between 42d and 40th Streets behind the New York Public Library, was for three years, from 1822 to 1825, potter's field. After its later incarnation as the Crystal Palace it became, in 1871, Reservoir Park. In 1884 it was renamed for the poet William Cullen Bryant and in 1933 it took on the appearance it has today.

title: WESLEYAN VOTES A DIVESMENT PLAN
description: Wesleyan University's board of trustees has voted to sell the university's stock in one company with operations in South Africa and adopted a ''no purchase'' list of companies with unsatisfactory records in opposing apartheid in South Africa.

title: EXPERTS GLOOMY ON MEXICO
description: Mexico's struggling economy is steadily deteriorating in the face of continuing high inflation and Government deficits. With little hope that the price of crude oil will soon return to the levels of last year, bankers and economists here are increasingly pessimistic about the country's prospects for working itself out of its economic troubles.

title: MURRAY'S QUIET, INNER DRIVE
description: WHEN the Baltimore Orioles come to town Friday for a three-game series against the Yankees, they will include in their familiar cast of characters their first team captain in the club's history. Not surprisingly, he is Eddie Murray, the 10-year veteran first baseman and the team's unofficial leader.

title: MANY AT NEW YORK TELEPHONE REFUSE TO CROSS PICKET LINES
description: Thousands of communications workers struck the American Telephone & Telegraph Company in New York State as part of the nationwide walkout yesterday, and hundreds of New York Telephone Company workers honored their picket lines, according to union and company spokesmen.

title: CLEMENS ACHIEVES 9-0 MARK
description: Unbeaten Roger Clemens, with the support of home runs by Don Baylor and Dwight Evans, recorded his ninth consecutive victory today as the Boston Red Sox beat the Minnesota Twins, 6-3.

title: U.N. IN AGREEMENT ON STEPS TO BRING AFRICAN RECOVERY
description: The General Assembly unanimously agreed tonight to commit itself to a ''spirit of genuine and equal partnership'' to revive Africa's devastated economies.

title: DANCE: SCOTTISH BALLET'S 'SYLPHIDE'
description: The Scottish Ballet secured a firm place in the hearts of Charleston audiences by the end of its American debut performance on Friday at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., if cheers, whistles and exuberant applause are any guide. The response was not surprising. Judging by this program, the Scottish Ballet - created in 1969 when Peter Darrell, its director, moved the Bristol-based Western Theater Ballet to Glasgow and changed its name - does not seem to be about bravura technical effects or showcasing the newest in ballet. But it is a company with good solid technical skills, a gift for creating atmosphere and telling stories, and, most of all, a look of commitment and endearing straightforwardness.

title: FEMINISM LURES YOUNG ALLIES
description: Many of the women who heard Betty Friedan speak last week at Marymount Manhattan College had not yet been to kindergarten when the landmark book that inspired the modern women's movement, ''The Feminine Mystique,'' was published more than 20 years ago. Some had not even been born.

title: LOST SCHOONER AND CREW ARE HONORED IN BALTIMORE
description: As the Navy band played taps this morning, about 1,400 people gathered on the grassy ramparts of old Fort McHenry to memorialize the Pride of Baltimore, its captain and three crewmen, who died when the schooner sank in a freakish squall north of Puerto Rico on May 14.

title: Quake Near San Francisco
description: An earthquake centered about 90 miles south of San Francisco rattled windows and cupboards early Saturday but caused no injuries or serious damage, the authorities said today.

title: A Different Viewpoint On Agency Conflicts
description: While conflicts were causing problems in New York, in Chicago a second enlightened comment on the subject was made by a major advertiser speaking at the International Advertising Association as it ended its weeklong meeting Friday at the downtown Hyatt Regency Hotel.

title: Israel Stonewalls
description: When does a democracy's need for security begin to undermine its principles?

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: How many golfers have scored holes-in-one at the United States Open?

title: Board to Test Promotion Plan For Pupils Up to Third Grade
description: The Board of Education has agreed to test a proposal by the United Federation of Teachers that would allow elementary school students to progress from first through third grades at their own pace.

title: Balloons and Painted Faces At a Children's Festival
description: Little girls sporting pigtails formed a wave of lime-green and lemon-yellow tutus, working their way across the amphitheater yesterday at the Brooklyn Children's Museum.

title: Officials in Sri Lanka Blame Loose Security in Bombings
description: Sri Lankan troops were on alert today after officials blamed lax security by both the public and security forces for two bomb blasts that killed 22 people and wounded 100 in Colombo.

title: How to Put Technology to Work Collecting New York City's Tolls
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer to Give $1 Million Back
description: The state will recover more than $1 million from a former Old Court Savings and Loan executive, the second official of the defunct thrift unit to plead guilty to stealing money from it, prosecutors said.

title: SPENDTHRIFT, ONCE THE PRIDE OF KENTUCKY, IS HUMBLED
description: SPENDTHRIFT FARM and the Combs family that founded it have been towering symbols of the blue-chip American thoroughbred breeding industry for nearly 50 years. The Lexington, Ky., farm, a birthplace of numerous champions and home of prize stallions, and the Combses, self-styled as silver-tongued horse traders who enjoyed talking a good game as much as playing one, seemed to epitomize the affluence and success surrounding the very top of a lucrative market.

title: In Austria, the Past Is Far From Forgotten
description: To the Editor:

title: POPE SAID TO STILL WANT EASTERN TIES
description: Vatican officials said today that Pope John Paul's sharp attack on Marxism in his latest encyclical did not preclude new diplomatic openings to Eastern Europe or exchanges with individual Marxists.

title: Agencies Shut 3 Institutions
description: A commercial bank in Oklahoma and another in Montana failed last week and were taken over by other financial institutions, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said. Separately, Federal regulators also closed a California thrift institution.

title: BACK HOME, SENATOR GETS SUPPORT FOR TAX BILL
description: For more than an hour, Senator David Pryor fielded questions and comments about the Senate Finance Committee's tax revision bill from a standing-room-only crowd at Palmere's Restaurant in Arkadelphia, a town of about 10,000 people an hour's drive south of here.

title: Young Friend of Elderly To Get President's Award
description: When he was 14 years old, Louis Leeder of Flatbush was so upset by the suffering of the poor that he took all the savings from his allowance and, with his parents, formed an antipoverty organization.

title: Owner of a Nude Statue Lending It to City Again
description: ''Lovers' Bench,'' whose three bronze nude occupants attracted a lot of attention in Dante Park opposite Lincoln Center, has taken up temporary residence in the Hamptons at the family home of its owner, the real-estate developer Abe Hirschfeld.

title: 'AMAZING STORIES' TRIES NEW TACTICS
description: The first season of ''Amazing Stories'' was amazing in ways that no one expected.

title: BUDGET PANEL ASSERTS BAD MANAGEMENT LED TO CALL TO RAISE TAXES
