description: The Citizens Budget Commission said yesterday that poor planning by the Koch administration, rather than cuts in Federal aid, had produced a ''bad city budget'' that would raise taxes by $160 million and do little to improve city services.

title: Teen-Ager Is Stabbed; Racial Motive Is Seen
description: A Brooklyn youth was stabbed in what appeared to be a racially motivated assault, the police said yesterday.

title: CONTROVERSIAL GOAL WINS FOR BRAZIL, 1-0
description: Brazil, one of the favorites in the World Cup, overcame a distinctly conservative game plan by Spain today and rode Socrates's controversial second-half goal to a 1-0 victory.

title: Precisionist Wins
description: Precisionist, the odds-on favorite, held off the fast-closing Super Diamond, a 16-to-1 shot, by a half-length today to win the $323,400 Californian at Hollywood Park.

title: DOUBTS ABOUT AMERICA
description: Of all countries Britain has been the warmest toward Americans - the most admiring of our strengths, the most indulgent of our faults. So it is a shock to come here and find America an object of sharp doubts, even of antagonism.

title: FIVE TONYS ARE WON BY 'DROOD'
description: ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' the loose adaptation of the unfinished Dickens novel, and ''I'm Not Rappaport,'' Herb Gardner's play about two New York octogenarians, walked away with major honors at the 40th annual Tony Awards ceremony last night at the Minskoff Theater.

title: New Cap for Near-District Skyline
description: District of Columbia zoning laws in effect since the early 1900's strictly limit the height of buildings in the capital, guaranteeing that the Washington Monument's 555 feet, 5 inches dominate the city's skyline.

title: Transit Union Ends Pennsylvania Strike
description: Union members overwhelmingly ratified a three-year contract today to end a suburban transit strike that has inconvenienced 30,000 commuters for two months.

title: Treasury Computerizing Debt
description: The days - nearly 200 years of them - when frugal Americans could buy and stash away the Treasury's handsomely engraved bills, notes and bonds are over as of July. Not only that, sending investors a Treasury check in the mail for the interest on such securities will be over then, too.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JUNE 2, 1986
description: International

title: Katherine Horn Marries Richard Peter Steinberg
description: Katherine Mary Horn and Richard Peter Steinberg were married yesterday at the New Castle, N.Y., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Steve Horn.

title:
BRIEFING;
They Did It With Chalk
description: This summer marks the 50th anniversary of the Federal air traffic control system, and five of its pioneers will be in Washington today to be honored by the Federal Aviation Administrator, Donald D. Engen.

title: Ecuadorean Opposition Takes Early Vote Lead
description: Early returns indicated that Ecuadoreans were voting against a Government-sponsored proposal in a plebiscite in national elections today, with the results seen as a sharp setback to President Leon Febres Cordero's conservative economic policies.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Never underestimate the insignificant.'' - Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, head of the special Democratic group on television in the Senate. [ A14:4. ]

title: BANKERS WARY ON GARN BILL
description: Several of the nation's largest money center banks are considering backing away from support of comprehensive banking legislation being drafted by Senator Jake Garn, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.

title:
BRIEFING;
Uncle Les Wants You!
description: The invitation to a June 23 fund-raising event for Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, announces: ''Aspin's Army of the Potomac Begins Its Eighth Campaign - Re-enlist.'' Mr. Aspin is, in fact, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, but is currently in the midst of his ninth Congressional campaign. His press secretary deftly explained, ''When he first ran, he probably didn't have an army on the Potomac.'' The cost of re-enlistment is $50 a person.

title: KNEPPER OF ASTROS POSTS NINTH VICTORY
description: Bob Knepper became the National League's first nine-game winner this season, and Glenn Davis hit a homer and drove in four runs today in leading the Houston Astros to an 8-4 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: THIRD STRAIGHT DAY OF 90-DEGREE HEAT IN CITY
description: The calendar said June, but the sidewalks said August yesterday when the third consecutive day of 90-degree heat left city-bound New Yorkers breathless and surly.

title: Catching Up
description: * Katrina Adams, the young tennis player who leaped from the weed-infested courts of Chicago's inner city to the role of No. 1 in singles on the women's team at Northwestern (''A 17-Year-Old Has the Power Needed to Reach the Top,'' The New York Times, April 13), has now completed her freshman year with a 22-5 record in dual matches, 7-3 in tournaments and a No. 6 national collegiate ranking. Miss Adams teamed with Diane Donnelly to advance all the way to the doubles semifinals in the recent N.C.A.A. championship but was upset in the opening round of singles. ''I need to become tougher mentally,'' she says, ''and to be more aggressive on the court.''

title: THE STAGE: GUNTER GRASS'S 'FLOOD'
description: IN selecting for its debut production Gunter Grass's play ''Flood,'' the new Project III Ensemble Theater has taken on a considerable challenge and, it is gratifying to report, has acquitted itself admirably. This parable of a house threatened by destruction, which Mr. Grass wrote three decades ago, when his native Germany was still recovering from the destruction of World War II, bears the marks more of a speculative than of a dramatic bent. ''Flood'' is no exemplar of a well-made play; the action is sporadic, the characterization rudimentary. The accomplishment of Charles Otte, who directed and also did the effective lighting, is to give dramatic form to the distinguished writer's dark reflections on human responses to catastrophe. The result can be seen at the Ensemble Theater.

title: New Battles Erupt In Beirut Suburbs
description: Gun battles went on unabated today in Beirut's southern suburbs between Palestinians in three districts and militiamen of the Shiite Moslem movement Amal, who surround the areas.

title: Maine Eliminated In College Series
description: Jeff Yurtin batted in five runs, one with a home run, to help Louisiana State eliminate Maine from the College World Series today with an 8-4 victory.

title: GOODEN SHOWING THE WAY TO A RELATIVE NEWCOMER
description: The name of their game was ''Strikeout.'' This was long before that name became the professional trademark of Gary Sheffield's uncle, before Dwight Gooden earned his doctorate in baseball, before he entered Hillsborough High School, and before the letter K hung in bunches from the upper deck at Shea Stadium, 9 and 10 and 15 and 16 at a time.

title: TAFFETA, LACE AND BITTERNESS
description: SWATHED in acres of taffeta and miles of lace, New York's bridal industry is heading into the June wedding season with bitterness in its heart.

title: BELMONT FIELD LACKS TOP 2
description: For the second time in two years, the Belmont Stakes has failed to attract the most glamorous 3-year-old in the country. Snow Chief, like Spend a Buck last year, went for and won the rich Garden State Stakes and is now passing the final leg of the Triple Crown because his handlers fear the mile-and-a-half distance would overtax the colt. This Belmont, which will be run Saturday, will also lack Ogygian, the other hot 3-year-old around, who instead will run in the shorter Colin Stakes on the Belmont Day card.

title: National Steel Gets A Japanese Leader
description: The National Steel Corporation, in a management shakeup, is getting a top Japanese steel executive as its new president and chief operating officer.

title: The U.N. Today: June 2, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 3 P.M.

title: MUSIC: JANE SIBERRY, SINGER
description: THE Canadian art-rock singer and composer Jane Siberry is one of pop's more fascinating eccentrics. As a songwriter, Miss Siberry strays way over the boundaries of conventional pop form to create enigmatic, free-form set pieces that have the feel and changeability of Impressionistic tone poems.

title: The State Strikes Back
description: In a strange city, far away from everyday reality, a momentous battle is being fought over the Star Wars missile defense system. Can Paul Nitze, the Obi-Wan Kenobi of the State Department, save the U.S. Treasury from disappearing into a black hole of endless spending on unworkable defenses? Or will Lieut. Gen. James Abrahamson, former manager of NASA's fiscally disastrous space shuttle, launch Star Wars prematurely with similarly catastrophic results?

title: Philip Wiest Is Married To Jeannine Khoutieff
description: Jeannine Marie Khoutieff, the daughter of Rita Khoutieff and Boris William Khoutieff, both of New York, was married yesterday to Philip Wiest, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Wiest of New York. Justice Richard Wallach of New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony aboard Mariner 3, a yacht, in New York Harbor.

title: Kenneth S. Cook Wed To Cynthia Lee Rosen
description: Cynthia Lee Rosen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Rosen of New York, Boca Raton, Fla., and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Seth Cook, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Cook of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel.

title: CITY BALLET: 'SCOTCH SYMPHONY'
description: IN ''Scotch Symphony,'' which the New York City Ballet presented Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, George Balanchine evoked both Highland folk dances and such a 19th-century ballet as ''La Sylphide,'' which was set in Scotland.

title: FRANCE WARNS U.S. ON TRADE CLASH
description: France has warned the Reagan Administration that its demand for immediate compensation for the loss of $600 million worth of American grain sales to Spain could delay new international trade-freeing talks planned for next September, officials have disclosed.

title: Miss Mann Wed To Gary Horlick
description: Kathryn L. Mann, a lawyer for the Treasury Department, and Gary N. Horlick, a partner in the Washington law firm of O'Melveny & Myers, were married yesterday.

title: Soviet Army Completes Tunnel at Chernobyl
description: A Soviet Army team has blasted a tunnel through to the Chernobyl nuclear plant's No. 4 reactor, carefully setting explosive charges so as not to shake the ruined block and working quickly to avoid long exposure to radiation, a newspaper reported today.

title: Miss Lindenauer Weds P.A. Weinberg
description: Deborah Beth Lindenauer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S. Martin Lindenauer of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Peter Amory Weinberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Weinberg Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. Rabbi Sherwin Wine and the Rev. Alanson Houghton, an Episcopal priest who is the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Michigan League in Ann Arbor.

title: COLLEGES USE HONORARY DEGREES TO RAISE ISSUES RATHER THAN ENDOWMENTS
description: Honorary degrees, traditionally bestowed by American colleges and universities during commencement season as a way to note academic or civic accomplishments, are increasingly being used to take positions on political, social and moral issues.

title: Lost Opportunities
description: Regardless of which 3-year-old captures the Belmont Stakes Saturday, for the eighth straight year there will be no Triple Crown winner. Deservedly so, for no horse in that period has really been good enough to join the 11 that have worn the Crown, with one exception: Spectacular Bid, who finished third in the 1979 Belmont to horses he would thrash for the rest of his career.

title: ROLM SET TO ENTER NEW NICHE
description: The Rolm Corporation, a manufacturer of office telephone systems, plans to introduce a system for small and medium-size businesses on Monday, entering a new and highly competitive portion of the market.

title: Judy Sund Weds Edward S. Gilbert
description: Judy Ellen Sund, an assistant professor of art history at Duke University, and Edward Scott Gilbert, an associate of the New York law firm of Schulte Roth & Zabel, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. Vincent L. Broderick, a Federal judge for the Southern District of New York, officiated.

title: Ryan Has Elbow Injury
description: The Houston Astros are believed ready to put Nolan Ryan on the 21-day disabled list following an elbow injury he suffered Saturday night.

title: ISRAELI CABINET REPLACES AIDE SEEKING INQUIRY
description: The Israeli Cabinet today replaced the Attorney General who went against its wishes in ordering a criminal investigation of the head of Shin Beth, the internal security organization.

title: SPAIN'S CHIEF ENTERS POLITICAL BULLRING
description: The sun had just passed high noon and sweat was beginning to show on the brows of the more than 10,000 people when Felipe Gonzalez walked into the bullring here.

title: Switch Is Completed To 'Bull's-Eye' Token
description: The New York City public-transit system completed the switch from all-brass to ''bull's-eye'' tokens last night when 2,600 turnstiles in its stations were programmed to reject the old and yield only to the new.

title: OF RED TIES, CHEESE, THE SENATE AND LIVE TV
description: For a month now, the Senate has been practicing quietly, and intramurally, with its new television venture.

title: JOHN (3-0) PITCHES WELL
description: Even now, after he has pitched six times in a Yankee uniform at the advanced baseball age of 43, Tommy John still seems like a pitching marvel. The sinkerball still drops surely, the batters still hit grounders, the games remain impressive.

title: Possible Mate Takes Handicap
description: Possible Mate carried top weight of 123 pounds to a three-quarter length victory over Lucky Touch, who carried just 110 pounds, in the $86,250 New York Handicap for older fillies yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: IMMIGRANTS AND INDUSTRY: OLD FORMULA REVIVING A MILL TOWN
description: In a city that knows all the woes of urban America, the morning-after has arrived.

title: DRUG PRODUCTION IN U.S. IS REPORTED AT RECORD LEVELS
description: While the United States castigates Mexico for failing to control narcotics trafficking, production of marijuana and cocaine in this country are at record levels, according to Federal estimates.

title: Colleges Propose A Ban on Boosters
description: The College Football Association proposed today that all ''boosters'' be banned from the recruiting process and also instituted a study to determine the feasibility of a post-season playoff.

title: No Vacancy for Children
description: If you're a landlord with scarce apartments to rent, you'd rather rent to adults without children; they make less noise and cause less damage. If you're an elderly tenant looking for peace and quiet, you might prefer neighbors without children; they don't stop the elevators or park tricycles in your path.

title: ORTHODOX JEWS PROTEST VISITING ISRAELI MAYOR
description: More than 6,000 Orthodox Jews, protesting what they called the unfair policies of Mayor Teddy Kollek of Jerusalem, rallied yesterday evening outside the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where Mr. Kollek addressed a fund-raising dinner.

title: Man, 76, Is a Suicide; His Wife Is Near Death
description: An elderly Park Avenue man was found dead and his wife near death yesterday afternoon in what the police said was an apparent suicide pact.

title: YOUNG, EAGER AND INDICTED
description: They were young Wall Street professionals, the kind who consider networking serious business. They sported degrees from fine schools, among them Stanford and Wharton. They got together, worked out and talked at the Vertical Club, an East Side health club patronized, in good part, by the financial set.

title: DREXEL OVERHAULING SECURITY PRACTICES
description: Having been stung for a third time in less than a month when one of its analysts was indicted last week on insider trading charges, Drexel Burnham Lambert is responding with an overhaul of its security procedures by outside experts, according to a memo circulated at the firm Friday by its chief executive, Frederick H. Joseph.

title: Woman's Body Found After Texas Flooding
description: Park workers found a woman's body beneath a bridge today a day after she was washed away by floodwaters as storms dumped up to 5 inches of rain on south and central Texas.

title: Binghams Sell A TV Station
description: The Bingham family, continuing to divest itself of its communications holdings, has sold Louisville's top-rated television station to the Providence Journal Company for $85.7 million, it was announced Friday.

title: Treasury Focus on Short-Term Bills
description: Treasury financing this week is confined to the short-term bill market, with no note auctions expected until the middle of the month.

title: ST. JOHN'S: SCHOOL CHIEF MAKES A PLEA FOR HONESTY
description: The president of St. John's University told the graduating students of the law and graduate schools yesterday that honesty and integrity were the most important tools to take with them into the world.

title: GLENN D. KITTLER
description: Glenn D. Kittler, who wrote more than 35 books and was a contributing editor to Guideposts magazine for three decades, died of a heart attack Saturday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bridge: Sixth-Seeded Team Wins Reisinger Knockout Title
description: Six days of play in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship ended Saturday, with the title going to the group that was originally seeded sixth.

title: TAX AMENDMENT HOPES DIM
description: Senators and lobbyists seeking changes in the Senate Finance Committee's tax revision plan are growing increasingly skeptical that they will be able to muster enough support on the Senate floor to push through major amendments.

title: Nancy Ann Herfort Weds C.I. Clarvit in Westchester
description: The wedding of Nancy Ann Herfort, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Herfort of White Plains, to Charles Ira Clarvit, a son of William Clarvit of Amityville, L.I., and the late Selma Clarvit, took place yesterday at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: Robyn Klinger Wed To Jeffrey M. Winik
description: Robyn B. Klinger, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Klinger of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Jeffrey M. Winik, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Winik of Valley Stream, L.I. were married yesterday at Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream by Rabbi Harold Saperstein.

title: Oxford First Deal
description: The Oxford First Corporation, a financial services company, said it had agreed to be acquired by the Banc One Corporation of Ohio in an exchange of stock valued at about $77 million.

title: A 'ROKET' LAUNCHING
description: ON this, the 150th anniversary of the Republic of Texas, there are a lot of facts being disseminated here. One of them, boasted a clerk in a gift shop, is that there are more cows in Texas than people.

title: JOHN JAY COLLEGE: F.B.I. CHIEF LAUDS GRADUATES
description: Six hundred graduates of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, the majority of them working law-enforcement professionals, were labeled ''survivors'' yesterday by William H. Webster, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: A LOOK AT ORGAN TRANSPLANTS ON 13
description: ''TRANSPLANTING HOPE'' is not a program for the squeamish. It takes the viewer into a California hospital during a kidney transplant operation. We watch the actual organ being handled outside the body and then inserted by the surgeon.

title: BALLET: TWO NEW CASTS IN 'NUTCRACKER' AT MET
description: THE front curtain by Boris Aronson for Mikhail Baryshnikov's version of ''The Nutcracker'' has a Surrealistic tone. Like Mr. Baryshnikov's production, Mr. Aronson's decor reveals a point of view. How well the leading performers fit into the framework depends upon their understanding of their roles.

title: NORMAN WINS KEMPER OPEN ON 6TH PLAYOFF HOLE
description: Greg Norman parred the sixth playoff hole today to win the Kemper Open after Larry Mize put his approach shot into the water and dropped his next shot into another water hazard on the other side of the green.

title: Profit Drives Australia's Kangaroo Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM U.N. AFRICA PROGRAM
description: Following are excerpts from the special General Assembly session's document on the economic crisis in Africa:

title: Brenda Hochberg Becomes a Bride
description: Brenda Hochberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Hochberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Dalgarno, the son of Audrey Dalgarno of Aberdeen, Scotland, and the late Robert Dalgarno. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: Scoffing at Wall Street Poll
description: Wall Street executives, masters of the art of financial speculation, seem to be markedly less astute in speculating about Presidential appointments. Take the matter of a successor to Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, should the President decline to reappoint him to a new term in 1987 or should Mr. Volcker decline to accept.

title: FOR A TV 'MINISERIES,' CAMERAS ROLL AT AUSCHWITZ
description: Once again the train steamed past the gate at Birkenau to the ramp where the SS men and inmate trusties pulled people from boxcars. The German shepherds strained at their leashes and barked, showing their teeth.

title: LAROUCHE FOLLOWERS IN NEW JERSEY OFFER A SLATE FOR PRIMARY
description: Inspired by the success of followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. in the Illinois Democratic primary elections in March, the New Jersey branch of the LaRouche organization has fielded candidates for Congress in 13 of the state's 14 Congressional districts in the primary elections on tomorrow.

title: It's Like Inviting Pinochet to July 4
description: The Chilean ship Esmeralda is one of the world's most beautiful sailing vessels, a four-masted barkentine 353 feet long. She has been invited to participate, in New York Harbor on July 4, in the largest gathering of tall ships in history, and at first glance would seem a natural choice for this honor. It was, however, a terrible - though perhaps unwitting - mistake to invite the Esmeralda to a celebration of liberty and democracy.

title: Fateful Omissions
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. DISMISSES SOVIET'S WARNING AGAINST SCRAPPING ARMS ACCORD
description: The Reagan Administration today dismissed the Soviet Union's warning that it would not remain bound to the limits set in the 1979 strategic arms treaty if the United States went ahead with announced plans to scrap the accord by the end of the year.

title: ANDERSON PLANS AFFECT 4 CLAYTON DAUGHTERS
description: Whichever way the tussle for control of Anderson, Clayton & Company works out, it seems certain that the four elderly daughters of the company's founder, the late William L. Clayton, will profit handsomely.

title: Dora Russell, Social Activist And Wife of the Philosopher
description: Dora Russell, a social activist and the second of the philosopher Bertrand Russell's four wives, died of a stroke at her clifftop home in this Cornwall village. She was 92 years old.

title: A.T.&T. OPERATORS-FOR-A-DAY TRY TO LEARN ON THE JOB
description: Years ago, before divestiture and breakups and long-distance carrier selection ballots, there was a strike at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's headquarters in Omaha, and Sharon Lippett did a day's duty as a directory assistance operator.

title: China Studies Stock Markets
description: China may set up stock exchanges in major cities such as Canton, Shanghai, Tianjin and Wuhan in the course of developing its capital markets, the official China Daily said today. It said well-run companies are now allowed to issue shares to raise capital, and such issues have gone well.

title: No Big Hit
description: Indictments of the aluminum bat (Scouting, May 14) continue to be handed up by collegiate coaches and officials, and at a pace that has now grown dizzying. The only thing happening faster in college baseball is the rate of runs scored, which, the critics say, is exactly the point.

title: UNDER FIRE, WOMAN QUITS AS PORTLAND POLICE CHIEF
description: Penny E. Harrington, the only woman serving as the Police Chief in a major American city, resigned today, a few hours before the release of an investigative report that characterized her administration as a failure. She was in office 17 months. A special investigating commission, headed by Sidney I. Lezak, a former United States Attorney, said Chief Harrington had shown ''defects of leadership'' that ''cost her the confidence'' of her command.

title: PRIMO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Why Apartheid's End Is I.B.M.'s Business
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMON CRIB TOYS CALLED DANGEROUS
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission today moved to recall 1.6 million crib toys sold by Johnson & Johnson and said the toys are a strangulation hazard.

title: MOON'S CREATION NOW ATTRIBUTED TO GIANT CRASH
description: ASTRONOMERS studying one of the most ancient mysteries of science, the origin of the moon, are embracing a theory that just a few years ago seemed fantastic: that the moon was born in a catastrophic collision between the earth and another planet the size of Mars.

title: Chinese Credit Cards
description: The Bank of China has begun issuing cards that will be honored at the Diaoyutai state guesthouse and 35 other businesses, state-run television news said. The brief report said the Long March cards, to be used to represent foreign exchange certificates, had been issued by the Peking branch of the bank. The cards apparently will not be available to most Chinese since they do not have access to the certificates, which are China's convertible currency.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED IN CRIME SPREE
description: A Bronx teen-ager was arrested and charged last night with raping and sodomizing a woman and was accused of committing a string of robberies over the last two months in which he laid in wait for his victims on a footpath beneath the George Washington Bridge, the police said.

title: WARNER AND HBO DEAL SEEN
description: In an attempt to maintain its competitive edge against Showtime, Home Box Office, the nation's largest pay television service, is set to sign a $600 million, five-year contract with Warner Brothers for the rights to about 125 Warner Brothers films, according to sources familiar with the negotiations.

title: TROUBLE IN YELLOWSTONE
description: SEVERAL years ago, Alston Chase, a philosophy professor and amateur biologist, did some sleuthing, came up with insights as to why Yellowstone National Park had so few bears and wrote an article.

title: A Counsel Moves On
description: Richard A. Hauser, deputy counsel to the President since 1981, is resigning June 13 to practice law in Washington.

title: ADMINISTRATION IS DIVIDED ON FUTURE OF ABM TREATY
description: The Reagan Administration, which has said it will no longer be bound by the 1979 strategic arms treaty, is divided over how long the United States should be strictly bound by the 1972 antiballistic missile treaty, Administration officials said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MIDDAY MIRTH ''Laugh-at-Lunch'' - a 50-minute-hour designed for the lunch-break crowd, and part of the American Place Theater's American Humorists Series - will today feature the author Roy Blount Jr. A former editor at Sports Illustrated magazine and a frequent talk-show guest, Mr. Blount has written several best-selling books including ''I'm Just a Bug on the Windshield of Life'' and ''One Fell Soup.'' He will speak on a variety of subjects in the theater's Subplot Cafe today and Thursday at 1 P.M. and tomorrow at noon. The theater is at 111 West 46th Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue; information 247-0393.

title: 3 Million at Canada Fair
description: The attendance at the World's Fair here topped three million in May, the opening month. Organizers say they now hope for 20 million visitors before the fair closes in October, instead of the 13 million originally estimated.

title: Pigs, AIDS and Belle Glade
description: A double medical mystery, involving two deadly diseases, has briefly enveloped the small Florida town of Belle Glade. A poor community of sugar cane farmers on the south shore of Lake Okeechobee, it has 49 recorded cases of AIDS out of a population of 15,000, a stunning per capita figure. And for a few days last week there were fears that for the first time in America, African swine fever had also been found there.

title: CANADA SETS TARIFF RETALIATION
description: Canada today retaliated against a United States tariff on cedar shingles with a barrage of tariffs on American goods, contributing to mounting trade tensions between the world's two biggest trading partners.

title: NU HORIZONS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Oil, Petroleum Products Are Lowest in a Month
description: Crude oil and petroleum product futures slid to their lowest levels in a month on the world oil market yesterday, as attention focused more closely on the full meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries set for late this month.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have not the slightest desire to return. I think anyone in a sound mental state would not want to return from freedom to prison.

title: The Invisible Shadow
description: In an otherwise unexceptionable restaurant, a salad plate was composed entirely of canned vegetables. A day or so earlier, a tourist could not help noticing the absence of dairy herds from the beautiful hillside pastures of the Black Forest near Triberg.

title: No Contract Talks Scheduled As Strike Continues at Alcoa
description: The strike against the Aluminium Company of America continued in nine states today with no talks scheduled.

title: West Coast Banker Retires
description: James B. Wiesler, vice chairman and head of Bank of America's retail operations, will take early retirement, the bank said today.

title: V BAND SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
For a U.S. Treaty To Help Britain
description: The United States Senate is soon to face a crucial decision on legislation making possible the extradition of individuals wanted in Britain for terrorist crimes. Should opponents of the legislation prevail, we will have rebuffed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Government. They, alone among our allies, supported our decision to strike terrorist centers in Libya six weeks ago.

title: A FEW DAYS IN MOSCOW
description: Yelena G. Bonner, on her arrival here, said she planned to spend two or three days in Moscow before returning to Gorky.

title: Nakasone Calls Elections For Parliament July 6
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, ignoring opposition objections, dissolved the House of Representatives today, paving the way for elections in both houses of Parliament on July 6.

title: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Year to March 29
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $429,000. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $257,000.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Continental Equities Corp. of America, the broker-dealer unit of Continental Corp., announced that Peter J. Cross had joined the unit as a senior vice president.

title: AQUINO ASKS PANEL TO 'BE QUICK' IN PREPARING AN NEW CONSTITUTION
description: A 48-member commission gathered today to begin drafting a new Philippine constitution. President Corazon C. Aquino urged it to act quickly to restore a democratic basis to the nation's Government.

title: Computers By Tandon
description: The Tandon Corporation, a maker of computer disk drives that reported a $135 million loss last year, said it would seek a way out of its difficulties by selling its own brand of personal computers in the United States before the year is out. The company already makes computers for sale by other companies.

title: UTAH MEDICAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to April 30
Digital to Acquire Unit From Trilogy
description: Trilogy Ltd. said it had agreed to sell the operations and interconnect and packaging technology rights of its Technology Group to the Digital Equipment Corporation for $10 million in cash and the assumption of certain assets and related obligations. The Systems group accounts for 85 of Trilogy's 315 employees and will remain based at the company's Cupertino, Calif., headquarters.

title: MEXICO DRUG PROFITS FLOWING TO U.S.
description: Mexican drug traffickers have deposited billions of dollars in United States banks and other financial institutions in recent years, a significant part of their illicit profits, according to public documents and American law enforcement officials.

title: POLICE TO REQUIRE DRUG TESTS IN ORGANIZED-CRIME BUREAU
description: The New York City Police Department will begin mandatory drug testing of all members of its organized-crime control bureau, the unit that includes the narcotics division, under an order that took effect yesterday.

title: Carew, at Home, Calls Himself Out
description: Rod Carew was dressed as a businessman, wearing a black jacket and tie and sitting behind a table that held at least a dozen microphones. But it was not a business decision he made today when he officially announced his retirement from baseball.

title: GROMYKO SEES A U.S. 'BLUNDER' ON ARMS PACT
description: President Andrei A. Gromyko told a group of visiting British lawmakers today that President Reagan's plan to break out of the 1979 treaty on strategic arms limitation was a ''major blunder'' that could wreck the accord.

title: Thompson Seeks Trade
description: Unhappy with his limited playing time, Jason Thompson has asked Montreal to trade him. The first baseman, who earns $1 million a year, was acquired by the Expos from the Pirates at the end of spring training.

title: Merrill Buyback
description: The board of Merrill Lynch & Company approved a stock buyback plan under which the securities company would buy up to five million of its own shares, or 4.7 percent of those outstanding, over the next several years on the open market.

title: King Hussein in France
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Paris today for talks expected to center on his efforts to rally feuding Arab nations for a summit meeting to discuss Middle East peace and the Iran-Iraq war. The King is scheduled to leave Wednesday for Washington, where he will meet with President Reagan next Monday.

title: If a Company Tests for Drugs
description: Drug testing in the workplace has a proved effect of reducing drug use by employees. But is drug testing performed accurately, fairly and with a proper respect for the rights of individuals?

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief report on May 21 about daylight time around the world misstated the practice in Israel. That country, like many others, moves its clocks ahead one hour. The practice began this year on May 17, approved by Parliament over opposition from some Orthodox religious groups.

title: Factory Orders Rise 0.1%
description: Orders to United States factories for manufactured goods rose one-tenth of 1 percent in April and demand for items related to consumer spending went up significantly, the Government and private analysts said today.

title: SIGMA SOFTWARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. CITES COOPERATION BY ISRAEL
description: A White House spokesman today evaded questions about whether the United States was satisfied with the Israeli Government's cooperation in the investigation of a former Navy employee accused of spying for Israel.

title: The U.N. Today; June 3, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: NEW CENTURY PRODUCTIONS LTD reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $631,000, or 5 cents a share. c-Net loss.

title: COURT BACKS F.T.C. ON DENTIST RULING
description: The Supreme Court, reiterating that professional groups enjoy no special privilege to restrain competition, today ruled unanimously that a group of Indiana dentists had acted illegally in boycotting an insurance cost-containment program.

title: Feeding the Hungry Is a Federal-Size Job
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL INFORMATION NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NOTES ON FASHION
description: NORMA KAMALI's OMO label stands for ''On My Own,'' and that's how the designer likes to be. Originally, her new designer collection was to be manufactured by the Jones Apparel Group, which also makes her sportswear. Now she's decided to produce it herself.

title: IRAQ: ON THE ROAD AGAIN
description: The new concrete guardhouse outside the Castel Plaza las Fuentes motel was not built for the benefit of visitors with business at the Carta Blanca brewery or the Nissan factory.

title: Johnson on 15-Day List
description: Howard Johnson of the Mets has a hairline fracture of his right forearm and was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday. That, plus the fact Darryl Strawberry has a bruised left thumb and may miss another week, has made Manager Dave Johnson angry with himself and the 24-man roster setup.

title: SOVIET UNION, ARGENTINA WIN OPENERS
description: The Soviet Union and Argentina stepped up the pace of the World Cup today by dominating their opening matches.

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 19
description: b-Includes a gain from sale of Handyman unit of $2,700,000. The company's year-ago figures have been restated as a result of the adoption of Financial Accounting Standards Number 87 in the fourth quarter of 1985.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 17
CHIRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a charge of $250,000 representing a reserve for aging accounts receivable. c-After a credit of $333,000 representing a one-time favorable adjustment to inventory.

title: BANKS WOOING THE CONSUMER
description: Bankers all across America are rolling out the red carpet for the consumer.

title: BABY SURVIVES 17-FLOOR FALL FROM APARTMENT IN QUEENS
description: An 11-month-old boy crawled out a window and fell 17 floors from his family's apartment in Queens yesterday but survived, although badly injured, when a tree broke his fall.

title: ROCKETS INSPIRED BY WIGGINS
description: The ball, rebound, basket and game were right there for Ralph Sampson to take. Just a flick of his hand and the Houston Rockets would be well on their way toward a victory of great proportions.

title: AMERICAN CABLESYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $232,000 on the sale of assets. c-Includes gains on the sale of assets of $31,953,000 for the latest 9 months and $1,837,000 for the year- ago period. d-Net loss.

title: THEATER: FOUR ONE-ACTS AT ENSEMBLE STUDIO
description: THE four one-acts in Series C of the Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon '86 include one nifty little comedy; a warm and wise play about a black family; a failed melodrama, and a romantic comedy with funny lines and situations that wobbles on a very weak premise.

title: MIAMI CATCHER'S COMEBACK
description: Chris Magno sat back on his bed, his uniform still on from practice, his baseball suntan complete near the end of his senior season, his University of Miami team still unbeaten in the College World Series.

title: ONWARD AND UPWARD AT 65 WORDS A MINUTE
description: ''Ladies! Where are the freshmen?'' shouted the school vice president, looking frazzled. A graduation march can turn into chaos if the administration does not take a firm hand. ''Ladies, I've put you in a straight line,'' the vice president warned. ''Do not come out of a straight line, ladies.''

title: Education Venture By Apple, 2 Others
description: Apple Computer Inc. said that it had entered into a technical collaboration with the National Geographic Society and Lucasfilm Ltd. to explore the use of optical technologies such as videodisks and compact disks in education. Apple said the effort would explore ways to use the immense storage capabilities of optical media to bring together text, film, video, audio and software to provide teachers with new ways to deliver information.

title: Rahal Honored
description: Bobby Rahal, who took the lead from Kevin Cogan with a sudden burst of speed two laps from the finish and then won the Indianapolis 500 with the fastest final lap in the race's history, was honored yesterday at the Tavern on the Green where he officially announced he would drive in the Chase Grand Prix at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J., June 27-29. Rahal was asked how he was able to get the crucial jump on Cogan when, after four laps under a cautionary yellow flag, the field went to a green flag that permitted passing.

title: MUSIC: 'HORIZONS 86' OFFERS BERIO PROGRAM
description: THE New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons '86'' series devoted an entire program last night to works of Luciano Berio, the most talented of the experimental composers who broke onto the European scene after World War II. The concert contained only about 40 minutes of music, but at least half of that time could be considered well spent, which is far above the average for such contemporary events. Mr. Berio's scores, with their references to poetry and philosophy, almost invariably engage the listener's mind as well as his ears. Furthermore, there is often a strong vein of Commedia dell'arte running through his works, a vein he mines with the skill of a trained vaudevillian.

title: A 6.5 % Stake In Orion Pictures
description: Metromedia Inc. and John W. Kluge, its chairman, said that they held 6.5 percent of the Orion Pictures Corporation. Mr. Kluge, who is on the board of Orion, said in his filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the purchase was for investment purposes only. A source familiar with the transaction said the stock had been acquired in two privately negotiated transactions from two venture funds that originally were part of a group organized by Warburg Pincus & Company, an investment concern, in 1982 when Orion Pictures was taken over by Arthur Krim and his associates.

title: Lawyer Nominated For Top I.R.S. Post
description: Lawrence B. Gibbs, a Dallas lawyer who worked at the Internal Revenue Service in the 1970's, was nominated yesterday by President Reagan to head the agency.

title: 2 ARMS PACTS IN SPOTLIGHT
description: The ABM Treaty One of two treaties negotiated in an initial series of strategic arms limitation talks, known as SALT I. The ABM Treaty, covering antiballistic missiles, and the second treaty, which was an interim agreement limiting offensive arms, were signed by Leonid I. Brezhnev and President Nixon in Moscow in May 1972 after four years of negotiations.

title: 2 Issues Offered By Mesa, Ariz.
description: Mesa, Ariz., yesterday began offering a total of about $108 million of general obligation and utility system revenue refunding bonds in two issues through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: WILLIAM DAMSBY
description: William Damsby, who combined vivid acting with a dark, versatile voice to become a leading baritone with the New York City Opera, died of pneumonia Sunday at his home in New York. He was 44 years old.

title: Farm Trade Dispute
description: Officials from the United States and the European Community today resumed attempts to settle a conflict over American farm exports, trade sources said.

title: Reagan Fills Treasury Job
description: President Reagan said yesterday that he would nominate Michael R. Darby, an economics professor at the University of California at Los Angeles, to be Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Policy. If confirmed by the Senate, Dr. Darby, 40 years old, would succeed Manuel H. Johnson Jr., whom the President appointed to the Federal Reserve Board. Dr. Darby, who earned a

title: YANKEES BEATEN IN NINTH
description: The Yankees mixed an evening of horrendous defense with an electrifying comeback tonight. In the end, they were left with an 8-7 loss to the California Angels when Brian Downing lined a single just inside the third-base line off Dave Righetti, scoring Doug DeCinces with the deciding run.

title: PELTON TELLS SPY JURY HE ADMITTED HE MIGHT HAVE JEOPARDIZED LIVES
description: Ronald W. Pelton took the stand at his espionage trial today and acknowledged telling the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he may have jeopardized lives when he compromised a project to eavesdrop on the Soviet Union.

title: Dr. Mary Bryan, Nutritionist And Ex-Columbia Professor
description: Dr. Mary De Garmo Bryan, a home economist and professor emeritus at Columbia University, died May 12 at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. She was 94 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TECTONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $224,000. Corrected from Saturday, May 31, editions.

title: QUARTZ ENGINEERING & MATERIALS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. CONCERNS URGE END TO APARTHEID
description: More than 80 member companies of the American Chamber of Commerce in South Africa placed full-page newspaper advertisements around the country today to call for sweeping changes in apartheid and the legalization of outlawed political organizations.

title: 1,000 Sikhs Arrested In Punjab in 2 Days
description: Nearly 1,000 Sikh militants have been arrested in the Punjab in two days of largely peaceful protests marking the second anniversary of an army raid on the Golden Temple, the Sikhs' holiest shrine, the authorities reported today.

title: RED SOX WIN, 3-1; 5TH IN ROW FOR BOYD
description: The reliever Steve Crawford rescued Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd from a seventh inning jam and Jim Rice drove in two runs tonight, helping the Boston Red Sox to a 3-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD A CHALLENGE IN CABLE TV FRANCHISE SUIT
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that cable television operators enjoy some First Amendment protection, and deferred a final decision on whether a city may limit access to all or part of its territory to a single cable company.

title: WHITING PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SALE OF PEUGEOT STAKE
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would sell its 12.5 percent stake in the French auto maker Peugeot and use the estimated $275 million gain to improve its American plants.

title: City Issues a Warning On Measles Outbreak
description: New York City is facing its first significant outbreak of measles since 1980, and children should be immunized at the age of 12 months instead of the usual 15 months, the city's Health Department said yesterday.

title: ORANGE JULIUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $817,000, primarily on the sale of part of the company's music, games and tobacco vending operations. c-Net income and includes a gain of $92,000 on the sale of property and equipment.

title: RUMANIA TO LET 1,000 EMIGRATE, STATE DEPT. SAYS
description: Rumania has told the United States in recent weeks that it will allow more than 1,000 people to emigrate, the State Department said today.

title: S.E.C.'s Area Chief Resigning
description: Ira Lee Sorkin, the bushy-browed, highly regarded and scrappy New Yorker who has directed the Securities Exchange Commission's New York office for the last two years, has told the commission that he will resign effective Sept. 30 to return to private law practice.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE RULES EX-LECTURER AT YALE HID HIS TIES TO NAZIS
description: A Federal judge in Connecticut ruled yesterday that a former Yale University lecturer should be stripped of his United States citizenship for having concealed his background as a wartime Nazi propagandist who called for the extermination of the Jews.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING UP A SLIGHT 0.8% UP APRIL
description: Construction spending rose a lackluster eight-tenths of 1 percent in April as a surge in new housing activity was tempered by a decline in commercial building as a result of a glut in office space, the Government said today.

title: Taxi 'Dispatcher' Scam Shames New York
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. HALVES PROPOSED CUT IN RESEARCH FUNDS
description: Saying it wants to compromise with universities, the Reagan Administration has halved its proposed cut in reimbursements for the administrative costs of federally financed research.

title: Ciba-Geigy Layoffs
description: The Ciba-Geigy Corporation announced today it would lay off about 575 workers over the next several years as it phases out the synthesis of industrial chemicals and builds a $90 million pharmaceutical production facility at its plant here. A company spokesman, Thomas Chizmadia, said the plant's approximately 950 workers were informed of the plans today. By the time the pharmaceutical plant is operating, Ciba-Geigy will employ only about 325 people in Toms River.

title: Clemente Jr. Retires
description: Citing financial difficulties associated with playing minor league baseball, Roberto Clemente Jr. has announced his retirement from the Charleston Rainbows, the San Diego Padres' Class A farm team in the South Atlantic League. The 20-year-old Clemente, the son of Hall of Famer and the former Pittsburgh Pirates' star, played two years in the Philadelphia Phillies' organization before he was released last year.

title: NEW YORK MEDICAL COLLEGE: 196 NEW DOCTORS ARE TOLD OF PROBLEMS AWAITING SOLUTIONS
description: A leading medical educator warned graduates of the New York Medical College today that they faced a turbulent professional world with ''more problems than solutions.''

title: Harold Hillenbrand, 79, Dies; A World Figure in Dentistry
description: Dr. Harold Hillenbrand, executive director emeritus of the American Dental Association and an international leader in dental education and administration, died here Saturday of heart failure. He was 79 years old.

title: Rostenkowski Admits Drunken Driving Charge
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was arrested early Sunday on drunken driving charges after attending his 40-year high school reunion in Wisconsin, the authorities said today.

title: Allied-Lyons Sues on Walker
description: Allied-Lyons P.L.C. sued Toronto's Reichmann family and its interests today for $5 billion (Canadian) in the latest escalation of the battle for the liquor operations of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd.

title: BELTRAN CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. Beltran is operating under Chapter 11 of the U.S. bankruptcy court.

title: WILTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $71,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $151,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss and includes tax credits of $68,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $141,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: 'HOLY WAR, HOLY TERROR' ON 13 LOOKS AT SHIITES
description: ISLAMIC fundamentalism has become an international problem, and Iran is its source. ''Frontline'' examines the phenomenon in ''Holy War, Holy Terror'' on WNET/Channel 13 at 10 tonight. It is an intelligent, and frightening, program.

title: CURBS ON SECRETS PLANNED BY AIDES
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials agreed today on a need to increase internal curbs to control the unauthorized disclosure of classified materials, but disagreed on what form such restrictions should take, Administration sources said today.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Christy Marshall has joined the Bloom Agency as senior vice president, director of corporate communications.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN OPPOSITION SPLITS OVER DIVESTMENT
description: When they meet students on the campuses of American universities, white opposition figures here say, they encounter a debate that offers no easy agreement and, more often, a mutual bewilderment.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AGAINST ALL HOPE. By Armando Valladares. Translated by Andrew Hurley. 381 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: POLYTECHNIC U.: CLASS IS TOLD THAT FAMILY IS IMPORTANT
description: Ending 10 years as chairman of the Polytechnic Corporation, Dr. Joseph J. Jacobs urged 700 graduating students at Polytechnic University yesterday to ''strive for excellence and remember your roots.''

title: BROADWAY'S '40TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS' ON CBS
description: WITH Alexander H. Cohen once again serving as executive producer, Sunday night's ''40th Annual Tony Awards'' special on CBS began with a parade of stars. It is a favorite Cohen device for television, used in everything from his ''Night of 100 Stars'' to, more recently, ''NBC's 60th Anniversary.'' The gimmick is hokey but, with Broadway in artistic and financial doldrums, it served the purpose of bringing a semblance of glitter to ceremonies that are, after all, a national advertisement for ticket sales.

title: TWIN IMAGE OF QUASAR QUESTIONED
description: DOUBTS have arisen regarding a report published four weeks ago on what appeared to be twin images of a single quasar, split by the gravitational effects of intervening material. The images are so widely separated that, if they are of a single quasar, no ordinary source of gravity could account for the phenomenon.

title: CUOMO ATTAINS PARTY'S BACKING BY ACCLAMATION
description: Governor Cuomo was endorsed by acclamation today for a second term by the Democratic State Committee.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Corp., Chicago, said it would sell its 16 percent stake in Analog Devices Inc. of Norwood, Mass.

title: PANEL OF EXPERTS SEES TREND TOWARD 'SMARTER' TEXTBOOKS
description: THE ''dumbing down'' of textbooks - a phrase coined by former Secretary of Education Terrel H. Bell - may at last have bottomed out, and a ''smartening up'' trend may be on its way.

title: Magazine Ads Decline
description: April was a poor month for the magazine business. The Publishers Information Bureau reported yesterday that its member magazines -which are most of the major ones -were down 6.1 percent in ad pages, to 13,541, compared with April 1985, while ad revenues dipped 4 percent, to $453.4 million.

title: Talking Business with N'Diaye of Development Bank; Aiding African Economies
description: Babacar N'Diaye became president of the African Development Bank a year ago with a goal of coordinating the 22-year-old institution's lending policies more closely with the development plans of the African nations in which it was making loans. The bank and the related African Development Fund, which are based in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, have financed development projects in agricultural, transportation, power and communication investments in more than 40 countries while maintaining a double-A rating from Moody's Investors Service.

title: IMPROVING, NOT ABANDONING, THE OLD
description: Nine months have passed without the introduction of a new type of personal computer, a remarkable hiatus in an industry that used to add new models and killed old ones more frequently than the Yankees change managers.

title: Shopwell to Act on A.&P. Bid
description: Shopwell Inc., the Bronx-based supermarket chain, is expected to accept an offer from the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company for close to $31 a share, or about $630 million, industry sources said yesterday.

title: ECUADOREAN, U.S. ALLY, IN VOTE SETBACK
description: One of Washington's strongest allies in Latin America, President Leon Febres Cordero of Ecuador, suffered a major political defeat in a referendum here Sunday, according to voting results announced today.

title: EUROPE WILL BUY NORWEGIAN GAS, CUTTING RELIANCE ON SOVIET SUPPLY
description: Several major Western European gas companies today announced a multibillion-dollar agreement to bring natural gas from Norway's North Sea fields.

title: IN JAPAN, GRATITUDE TO OTHERS IS STRESSED IN PSYCHOTHERAPY
description: THE patient feels withdrawn and aimless, living on the margins of life, and he is in torment. In despair he turns to a therapist who, in an intensive one-week assault on the psyche, tries to sweep away the pain and help him feel that life matters.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $130,000 for the quarter and $240,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: Salvadorans Try to Talk Again
description: President Duarte's call for new talks to end El Salvador's civil war is surely welcome. Representatives of the guerrilla coalition have shown some interest.

title: HEAD INJURIES IN MURDERERS
description: A STUDY of 13 men and 2 women convicted of murder and awaiting execution in American prisons has shown that all had experienced severe head injuries earlier in life and 12 displayed neurological problems of varying severity.

title: Way Cleared for Union To Absorb Hormel Local
description: A Federal district judge today cleared the way for the United Food and Commercial Workers Union to take over its dissident meatpackers' local in Austin, Minn., and negotiate an end to the nine-and-a-half-month strike against Geo. A. Hormel & Company. The judge, Edward Devitt, granted a preliminary injunction ordering Local P-9 to surrender its assets and affairs to a trustee appointed by the parent union.

title: Market Place; Analysts Like Bell Regionals
description: THE seven regional Bell companies have quietly and consistently outperformed the stock market since the start of 1984 - the date of their official divestiture by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. And several telecommunications analysts said yesterday that they continued to regard these stocks as attractive.

title: School Suspends Coach
description: Tommie Smith, banished from the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico City for giving the black power salute on the awards stand, following his victory in the 200-meter run, has been barred from coaching the Santa Monica (Calif.) College track team for one year for allowing an ineligible player to compete.

title: GLYNN ROBERT DONAHO
description: Vice Adm. Glynn Robert Donaho, who received the second highest military decoration for valor four times in World War II, died Wednesday.

title: Official at Shuttle Contractor Resigns
description: An official of the company that manufactures the space shuttle's solid-fuel booster rockets said today that he would retire June 30 because of controversy over his role in the decision to launch the shuttle Challenger Jan. 28.

title: EUROPEANS VOICE STRONG CRITICISM OF U.S. ARMS MOVES
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to abandon its adherence to the second strategic arms limitation treaty is drawing increasingly sharp criticism in Western Europe.

title: Books, in Bits and Pieces
description: In 1980, while he was in the Library of Congress examining four volumes published by William Caxton, England's first printer, Paul Needham made an important discovery: most of a fifth Caxton item, which had been sewn inside one of the other volumes.

title: ISRAELIS SEEM SPLIT ON INQUIRY INTO COVER-UP
description: Major differences appear to be developing between Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir over how to deal with the growing scandal in Israel's domestic intelligence service, Government sources said today.

title: New Structure For Maytag
description: The Maytag Company, a maker of home appliances based in Newton, Iowa, announced a new organizational structure yesterday resulting from its recent $740 million merger with Magic Chef Inc. of Cleveland, Tenn.

title: Purolator Courier To Lois Pitts
description: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/GGK has become the agency for Purolator Courier of Basking Ridge, N.J., which could spend $12 million on advertising in the next 12 months.

title: NUMERICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FOSTER HITS 2 IN ROMP
description: Thanks primarily to Dwight Gooden and George Foster, those Mets followers who feared an imminent collapse following two weekend losses to San Francisco can stop holding their collective breath and uncross their fingers.

title: Accounts
description: * Antigua-Barbuda Department of Tourism returns to Tromson Monroe Advertising and Public Relations for advertising, sales promotion and public relations.

title: WON NOBEL FOR ATOM STUDY
description: Dr. James Rainwater, a professor emeritus of physics at Columbia University who shared the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1975 for his work in analyzing the structure of atomic nuclei, died Saturday at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. He was 68 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Fall
description: Prices for Government securities continued their slide yesterday, with interest rates higher on both long- and short-term Treasury issues.

title: BALLET: THE KIROV DANCES IN TRENTON
description: The Kirov Ballet from Leningrad has not performed in New York and the rest of North America since 1964, which is time enough to build up a legend.

title: BLAZING SUPERNOVA LIGHTS ITS GALAXY'S SHROUD OF DUST
description: A BLAZING new supernova, an exploding star, has given astronomers in the southern hemisphere a rare opportunity to analyze the enigmatic dust clouds that shroud a relatively nearby galaxy.

title: THE SOFTWARE WRITER AS ARTIST
description: WHEN I was first starting out as a writer of short stories, a form of fiction of which I am still very fond, my favorite ancillary reading was the Paris Review interview series ''Writers at Work.'' Although I am not much of a believer in - actually, I rebel against - C. P. Snow's ''two cultures,'' the thought of someone publishing a similar volume recounting the work habits, ideals and thoughts of programmers never entered my mind. I wish it had.

title: BRAIN SURGERY TECHNIQUE MAKES A COMEBACK
description: Like an ever tightening noose, Parkinson's disease slowly took over Meyer's life, turning it into a kind of torture and leaving him a prisoner.

title: Bad Bargain for Chemical Weapons
description: Unilateral disarmament is not usually a policy President Reagan favors, but he has chosen just such a course on chemical weapons. Apparently he has privately agreed to withdraw America's chemical weapons from West Germany by 1992, an astonishingly inopportune decision that seems to undercut recently promising negotiations with the Soviet Union to ban these dreadful weapons altogether.

title: Reds Field A Home Team
description: When Chris Welsh, recently called up from the minors, took the mound Sunday as Cincinnati's pitcher, he gave the Reds a fifth hometown product in their starting lineup. Pete Rose, Ron Oester, Buddy Bell and Dave Parker all grew up and attended high school in Cincinnati, as did Welsh.

title: Arrest in Brooklyn Stabbing
description: A 19-year-old Hispanic youth was charged last night in what the police have called the racially motivated stabbing of an Oriental teen-ager in Coney Island Saturday night, the police said. The suspect, Raymond Cruz, who lives in Brooklyn's Fort Greene section, was charged with assault, aggravated harassment, possesion of a dangerous weapon and violating Federal civil rights statutes after he surrendered last night. The victim, Gary Moy, 17, of Starrett City, was in stable condition at Coney Island Hospital.

title: Miss Bonner Meets I. B. Singer
description: Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, had always expressed a desire to meet Isaac Bashevis Singer. She had read, with difficulty, several of his books in English and several short stories that had been translated in the Soviet Union in samizdat, the secret journals passed from hand to hand.

title: Zellerbach Unit
description: The James River Corporation and the Crown Zellerbach Corporation said they planned to sell the Zellerbach Distribution Group, which includes the Zellerbach Paper Company, the Virginia Paper Company and the Southern Paper Company.

title: RELIGION LACK IN TEXTS CITED
description: In one history textbook Joan of Arc is discussed without any mention of God or of her becoming a saint. In another, the Pilgrims' first Thanksgiving Day is described without any reference to their thanking God for their survival in the new land.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Don't Let Chernobyl Cripple U.S. Nuclear Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Mayor Koch's Tax Plan Penalizes Co-op Owners
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LOWER EAST SIDE'S NEW ARTISTS
description: In the early 1980's, Meyer Vaisman and Peter Nagy were young artists in Manhattan, both in their early 20's and both recently graduated from art school. And both, when unable to find an existing commercial gallery in New York to show their work, took an increasingly common step for young artists in Manhattan: they started their own galleries.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
T.V.A. PACT WITH A-PLANT CHIEF CALLED IMPROPER
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority's $710,000 employment contract with the manager of its crippled nuclear power program is ''without authority of law,'' Government auditors said today.

title: Kennedy Faults Arms Move
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said in the first televised session of the Senate today that President Reagan's decision to stop observing the limits of the 1979 arms treaty was the worst mistake of his presidency. For the United States to repudiate the treaty now will hurt it more than the Soviet Union, Senator Kennedy said, because the Russians would have had to dismantle 600 additional missile launchers and five additional submarines under the treaty.

title: CUOMO, SPEECH WRITER, WATCHES EVERY WORD
description: The Rev. J. Newman once roused his high school students, Mario M. Cuomo among them, with an unusual weekly composition assignment.

title: Bronx Science Reunion: '75% Doctors,' '25% Bums'
description: Greying, balding and bespectacled, most of the men milling around the Bistro in the Novotel Hotel barely resembled the photographs of their teen-age selves pinned to their lapels. Again and again, stolen glances at nametags became delighted gleams of recognition, as aging alumni of the Bronx High School of Science identified former classmates.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a $6.5 million loss from the writedown of the company's oil and gas properties. c-Net income. Whittaker said it adopted the new accounting rules for pension costs in the latest second quarter, decreasing losses by $800,000 for that period, and $1.5 million for the latest 6 months.

title: Group Buying Unit of Revlon
description: The Revlon Group Inc., shedding the last Revlon Inc. business designated for divestiture, agreed yesterday to sell its Technicon Corporation to an investor group led by the Cooper Development Company for $250 million in cash and $50 million in preferred stock.

title: IN HARD TIMES, GARMENT UNION PLACES HOPES ON NEW LEADERSHIP
description: When leaders of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union select a new president this week, they will be looking for someone to stem the decline of the once prominent union from two decades of decline.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,657,000 and a provision for disposal of discontinued operations of $9,300,000.

title: Metropolitan Antoni Is Dead; Headed Leningrad Orthodox
description: Metropolitan Antoni of Leningrad and Novgorod, one of the five senior bishops of the Russian Orthodox Church, died Thursday in the Soviet Union, Keston College reported today.

title: TV: GOOD DEBUT, BUT WHAT'S IT MEAN?
description: The Senate looks better on television than does the House; it is warmer and better lighted. What this will mean, however, is still an unresolved matter.

title: TAX-BILL CHANGES EXPECTED
description: Senator Bob Packwood today cautioned supporters of the Senate Finance Committee's tax-revision bill that many changes would be made in the measure when it went to conference with the House of Representatives.

title: FUNDS SET IN BID FOR ANDERSON
description: An investment group headed by Bear, Stearns & Company said yesterday that it had received commitments for the financing it needed to complete a proposed $655 million acquisition of Anderson, Clayton & Company.

title: Careers; 'Survivors' Syndrome' In Layoffs
description: WHEN the Occidental Petroleum Corporation recently announced the dismissal of 2,000 employees, the move was the latest in a series of cutbacks by many companies that have resulted in a lot of unemployed middle managers.

title: TRANS LEASING INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WHALE RESEARCHERS FIND FRONTIER IN L.I.'S BACKYARD
description: Sam Sadove and Colleen Coogan clung to the rigging atop Finback II, scanning the white-capped seas for ''footprints,'' birds dancing and ''puffs of smoke.''

title: Curtis W. Davis, 57, A Television Executive
description: Curtis W. Davis, a television producer who won three Emmy awards for cultural programming and was a vice president of programming for the Arts and Entertainment Network, died Saturday of cancer at New York Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Phone Bonds Yield 9.45%
description: The General Telephone Company of Michigan, a subsidiary of the GTE Corporation, is offering $80 million of 9 3/8 percent first mortgage bonds due 2016 at a price of 99.25, to yield 9.45 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: State Department; Till Reassignment Do Us Part?
description: Like many professional couples, Jane A. Coon and her husband, Carleton S. Coon, have to balance the demands of their careers against the needs of their marriage. But their task became unusually difficult in 1981 when Mrs. Coon was appointed Ambassador to Bangladesh and her husband became Ambassador to Nepal.

title: Rival Moslem Militias Battling in Beirut
description: Shiite and Sunni militias fought street battles today in what the police called a spillover from the war for control of the Palestinian neighborhoods.

title: ADVANCED GENETIC SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a gain of $209,000 from the sale of closed store leases. c-Net loss.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $272,000 for the quarter and $545,000 for the 6 months. c-After net from discontinued operations of $475,000 for the quarter and $706,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago results were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: SHULTZ DENOUNCES APARTHEID, SAYING: 'IT MUST GO SOON'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that ''Western interests - moral, strategic, economic and political - will suffer'' if apartheid in South Africa is not soon ended peacefully.

title: F.A.A. CITES PAN AM OVER MAINTENANCE
description: A special inspection found Pan Am World Airways to be violating a number of aircraft maintenance regulations, according to officials at the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
COSMOPOLITAN CARE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY: SPACE CENTER TO BE NAMED AFTER CHALLENGER ASTRONAUT
description: The president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology told graduates at commencement exercises today that the institute's Center for Space Research would be named for Ronald E. McNair, one of the seven astronauts killed Jan. 28 in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Long-Lost Symbols Recovered and Displayed
description: As far as the Equitable Life Assurance Society knew, they were lost. There was no trace of the two marble-and-bronze busts that had become the reassuring symbols on Equitable stationery and insurance forms.

title: 10 South Koreans Jailed For Sit-In at U.S. Center
description: Ten students were sentenced to jail terms of one year to three years today for occupying the United States Cultural Center in Kwangju in December, court officials said.

title: Offer for Kinney
description: Kinney System Inc., one of New York's leading parking lot operators, said that it had agreed to be acquired by the Cromwell Group Inc., a closely held concern that manages industrial companies.

title: Peoples Makes New Bid for Zale
description: Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Toronto said that it had made a third offer to buy the Zale Corporation. Under the increased terms, shareholders would receive $42 cash and $4 worth of newly issued preferred Zale stock for each common share, for a total price of $502 million.

title: CALIFORNIA A KEY AS 9 STATES VOTE
description: In a primary election with national implications, California Republicans will decide Tuesday who will challenge Senator Alan Cranston when he seeks a fourth term in November.

title: 'DIVORCE IS CHANGING AMERICA' ON NBC
description: NO question about it: Divorce is a nuisance, a pain and a plague. You didn't know that already? ''Divorce is Changing America'' gathers up the most recent statistics, although it's so wide-eyed in presenting them that it appears to think it has discovered something new. The NBC News ''White Paper'' will be seen on Channel 4 at 10 tonight.

title: Sumitomo, FMC in Deal
description: The FMC Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell a 49 percent interest in its domestic construction equipment business to Sumitomo Heavy Industries as part of a joint venture with the Japanese company. Although FMC declined to disclose the value of the deal, analysts speculated that Sumitomo - a leading producer of ships and machinery - would pay between $50 million and $75 million for its interest in the FMC operation.

title: ALEXANDER KUTIN
description: Alexander Emelianoff Kutin, the founder and conductor of the Balalaika Symphonic Orchestra of New York, died Saturday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan after a short illness. Mr. Kutin, a resident of Greenwich Village since World War II, was 87 years old.

title: Who Loves Japan?
description: Look for more ''Japan bashing'' this week from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Its East Asia subcommittee under Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, will hold a hearing Thursday on what American officials say is the refusal by Japan to allow American companies to bid on a $6 billion project to rebuild the Osaka airport.

title: TIME FLEW AS FAST AS THE CARS
description: Waking last Saturday with the knowledge that much of the day must be spent watching the Indianapolis 500 made for a rocky start. Two things seemed certain: First, the sun would shine all day in New York. Second, we shut-ins would be captives to 4 1/2 hours of speeding blurs going ''Mmmmmmmmm--zoom,'' followed by 30 minutes of hero worship for the winner.

title: Some Federal Jobs Go Begging
description: In this year of the budget-balancing initiative, Government agencies are looking for ways to trim back. Staff and programs are being pared away.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JUNE 3, 1986
description: International

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Utility's Offering Totals $120 Million
description: The New England Power Company is offering $120 million of general and refunding bonds in two parts through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: 'SWAGGER' IS THE WORD AS FUR SHOWS OPEN
description: Everthing is overscale, Bill Blass said, the length, the collars, the sweep, and if women are looking for a new fur coat, they should concentrate on the big ones.

title: Advertising; Procter Drops Y.&R.
description: EVER since Procter & Gamble acquired Richardson-Vick last year the advertising community has been waiting for the mighty Cincinnati soaper to dump Young & Rubicam, the rare agency that fled the P.& G. fold. Yesterday it happened. The New York-based agency has lost billings estimated at $45 million by Leading National Advertisers, an independent media measuring service.

title: BORMAN TO LEAVE EASTERN
description: Frank Borman, who led Eastern Air Lines through 16 of its most tumultuous years, said yesterday that he would resign as chairman and chief executive officer on June 30 and move to New Mexico, where he will help operate his son's car dealership.

title: MESTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Off Everyone's Reading List
description: The Senate has issued a 1,489-page text of the tax revision bill approved by the Senate Finance Committee and a 1,124-page committee analysis of the legislation. Rounding out the trilogy is a 452-page book that is intended to go unread.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
REDLAKE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Reintroduction of Wolves
description: The wolf, which roamed this sprawling park until being driven out in the 1920's, may return if the National Park Service can overcome opposition. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service's regional office in Denver is reviewing a park service proposal to reintroduce 30 breeding pairs of timber wolves to the nation's oldest national park. Although some support for the proposal has emerged in Congress, the Wyoming Congressional delegation opposes it, as does the Idaho Cattleman's Association.

title: A Change for Legume
description: When it came to the Legume account, Smith/Greenland's gain was DFS-Dorland Worldwide's loss. The Montvale, N.J., company makes frozen, low-calorie, no-cholestorol Italian, Mexican and Japanese dishes. The budget is a high-calorie $1 million.

title: Nader Critical of Insurers
description: Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, and the National Insurance Consumer Organization charged yesterday that property and casualty insurance companies dramatically increased their first-quarter profits, while ''gouging'' the public with increased premiums.

title: Who Are These Guys?
description: One day in 1971, Harry Walker, manager of the Houston Astros, summoned from the bullpen an untested rookie right-hander named Larry Yount, older brother of Robin Yount. While warming up on the mound for his debut, however, Yount pulled an arm muscle, marking the end of his major league career, in which he never threw an official pitch.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Comings and Goings
