description: The Philadelphia Flyers signed Chico Resch, the N.H.L.'s oldest player, to a one-year contract. The goaltender, who will turn 38 on July 10, was acquired by the Flyers March 11 from the Devils in exchange for a third-round pick in this year's entry draft. Resch also played for the Islanders. . . . The Detroit Red Wings have released the right wing Danny Gare, their team captain the last four seasons, and the goalie Ed Mio, obtained from the Rangers in 1983. . . . Robert Pratt, who played 13 games in the National Football League with the Baltimore Colts and from 1982 with the Seattle Seahawks, has retired. . . . The Detroit Pistons star Isiah Thomas underwent the second of two operations on his left thumb yesterday, and the procedure was declared a success. . . . Del Harris, former coach of the Houston Rockets, has been hired by the Milwaukee Bucks as an assistant coach.

title: Chinese Praise For Television
description: Television advertising got a testimonial the other day from a rather unexpected quarter -China.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JUNE 3, 1986
description: International

title: Don't Let Chernobyl Cripple U.S. Nuclear Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawmakers Fault Expulsion Of a Journalist by Indonesia
description: Six Democrats and the ranking Republican on a subcommittee of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives have written a letter to President Suharto of Indonesia to protest the expulsion in April of a New York Times correspondent, Barbara Crossette.

title: Stouffer Foods Official Is Appointed President
description: The Stouffer Foods Corporation, the nation's leading producer of frozen prepared foods, said yesterday that David H. Jennings, vice president of sales, had been named president.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A map in Metropolitan Report yesterday with an article about economic improvements in Paterson, N.J., positioned the center of the city incorrectly. It is north of Route 80 on the right bank of the Passaic River.

title: U.S. Seen Joining Suit
description: The Justice Department is expected to join on Tuesday a lawsuit filed against TRW Inc., the military contractor, by three former employees who accuse it of receiving millions of dollars in overcharges on military contracts, participants in the case said today.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Net income

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AGREES TO MEET WALDHEIM'S LAWYERS
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had agreed to meet with lawyers for Kurt Waldheim as the department considers whether to bar Mr. Waldheim from entering the United States because of what he did while serving in the German Army in World War II.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS MENTALLY ILL ON BENEFIT SUITS
description: The Supreme Court, rejecting a Justice Department appeal, ruled unanimously today that thousands of mentally ill New Yorkers had a right to sue the Government for illegally using a ''clandestine'' policy to deny them disability benefits.

title: HESITANT BONNER IS BACK IN SOVIET
description: Yelena G. Bonner flew reluctantly back to the Soviet Union today, declaring that she was returning only because she wanted to be with her husband, the physicist Andrei D. Sakharov.

title: ALABAMA VOTING ON WALLACE SUCCESSOR TODAY
description: Alabama voters will help launch a new era in the state's political history Tuesday, when they choose candidates to succeed retiring Gov. George Corley Wallace.

title: CHAMPS-ELYSEES VISTA: FAST FOOD, FADED ELEGANCE
description: It is midnight on the Champs-Elysees and the famed avenue has assumed a kind of motorcycle-gang look.

title: TAX BILL'S KEY NUMBERS MAN
description: A sign on the door to David H. Brockway's office in the House of Representatives' Longworth Building proclaims him ''Chief Tax Drone.'' Behind his back, he is sometimes called Senator Brockway Both titles reflect the critical behind-the-scenes role played by Mr. Brockway, who as staff chief of Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation is intimately involved in the architecture of nearly every tax plan that surfaces in Congress. That includes both the Packwood plan now before the Senate and the House bill.

title: Senior Golf Starts Today
description: The United States Senior Golf Association, whose purpose is to ''conserve and promote the best interests and the traditional spirit'' of golf, will conduct its 82d annual championship today and Wednesday in Westchester County and lower Connecticut.

title: Don't Let Chernobyl Cripple U.S. Nuclear Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: ALTERNATIVE HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Trump Fire Under the Wollman Ice
description: Can Donald Trump deliver a rebuilt Wollman Memorial Skating Rink faster than City Hall can do the job? It's hard to imagine anyone taking longer than City Hall. New Yorkers have been denied use of the Central Park rink for six years while city planners and contractors fumbled the job. Mr. Trump deserves praise for forcing the question of the city's efficiency. Ideally, when they meet with him today, city officials will find a way to take advantage of his resources and motivation without sacrificing any public interest.

title: Northern Trust Loses Primary Dealer Status
description: The Northern Trust Company, the third-largest bank in Illinois, said yesterday that it had been dropped from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's list of primary dealers because its customer-trading volume in government securities no longer met the Fed's minimum guideline.

title: POLYMERIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MEADOWLAKE IS WINNER
description: Meadowlake, who dazzled Midwesterners as a 2-year-old but spent the winter sidelined with foot problems, made a triumphant return to the races yesterday with an impressive 3 3/4-length victory at Belmont Park.

title: GRAF, AT MATCH POINT, LOSES
description: Steffi Graf, the fastest-rising star in pro tennis, suffered a sudden loss of momentum today when she was beaten by Hana Mandlikova in the quarterfinals of the French Open.

title: NEWMARK & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1986.

title: Bridge: A Former World Champion Aids a New Cable TV Show
description: The first attempt to present bridge on cable television to New York viewers begins tonight and is to be presented weekly from 6 to 7 P.M.

title: USHER TESTIFIES ON ABC TALKS
description: Harry Usher, the commissioner of the United States Football League, testified in Federal District Court yesterday that pressure from the National Football League adversely affected his ability to negotiate contracts for the U.S.F.L. with ABC Sports.

title: DEAVER'S LOBBYING FOR PUERTO RICO BROUGHT REPRIMAND FROM SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in January, questioned the ''appropriateness'' of an investment proposal backed by Michael K. Deaver, involving Japan and Puerto Rico.

title: Question From Metroliner: Can You Hear Me Calling?
description: The last refuge from telephone addicts crumbled yesterday, as Amtrak inaugurated its first Railfones, on the Metroliner between New York and Washington.

title: SOME LAUGHS, SOME QUALMS AS SENATORS TAKE TO THE AIR
description: Today, for the first time, the Senate broadcast its floor debate on television to the general public, and lawmakers hailed it as a landmark step that could alter the character of Congress and the political world.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Chess: The Calcutta International Is Won by Georgi Agzamov
description: The Calcutta International Tournament, the strongest ever held in India, the birthplace of chess, was won by the 31-year-old Russian grandmaster Georgi Agzamov, who scored 10-3 in the round-robin competition.

title: Why Apartheid's End Is I.B.M.'s Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Squash Title to Khan
description: Jahangir Khan of Pakistan, the world champion, defeated Ross Norman of New Zealand, 9-5, 9-4, 9-6, last night to capture the $50,000 Swan Laser Die United States Pro Softball Squash Championships.

title: Cadbury Will Buy RJR Nabisco Units
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said yesterday that it would buy the Canada Dry and Sunkist soft-drink operations from RJR Nabisco Inc. for $230 million and that it would then sell Canada Dry's Canadian bottling plants to the Coca-Cola Company for $90 million.

title: U.S. AND DEFENSE AGREE TO MOVE CORRUPTION TRIAL OUTSIDE THE CITY
description: The prosecutor and defense lawyers in the Federal case involving corruption in the city's Parking Violations Bureau agreed in principle yesterday to move the trial outside New York City.

title: Calm at Mount St. Helens
description: All is calm again in the rumbling, buckling heart of Mount St. Helens after an eruption that has added more than 60 feet to the height of the volcano's dome.

title: Congress; Democrats Press the 'Safety' Issue
description: Representative William R. Carney announced recently that he would not run for re-election, and in explaining his decision the Long Island Republican acknowledged that his main political problem was the new Shoreham nuclear power plant in his district. He wants the plant to open, but many of his constituents do not, and the whole issue has clouded his chances for another term.

title: MASSBANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Massbank, which went public May 28, did not report per share figures.

title: TELECONCEPTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
UP A TREE ON MADISON AVE.
description: Call her Rhoda. But call her. According to her foster father, she's the lonely child of a bitter divorce and she's looking for a new home. And it better be a big home. Rhoda is 14 feet tall and 11 feet wide.

title: Stocks Continue Down; Dow Falls 14.76 Points
description: Stock prices declined for the second consecutive session as Wall Street, after ignoring weakness in the bond markets of late, decided once again to move in tandem with the credit markets.

title: No Talks in Second Day Of Phone Workers Strike
description: Talks between the communication workers union and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company remained in recess yesterday, the second day of a nationwide strike.

title: Old Pact to Run Rink Hinges on Trump Deal
description: City Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said yesterday that the city had signed a nonbinding agreement three years ago with a London-based company to operate the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink and the adjacent restaurant when the rink's reconstruction was completed.

title: MCLEAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Q&A
description: Q.

title: FOTOMAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
15 YEARS LATER, BINGHAM DENIES GIVING GUN TO GEORGE JACKSON
description: Stephen M. Bingham testified today at his trial on murder charges stemming from a prison uprising that he never gave a gun or ammunition to George Jackson while Mr. Jackson was in prison, or saw Mr. Jackson with a gun.

title: SALVADORAN REBEL SAYS GUERRILLAS ACCEPT DUARTE PROPOSAL ON TALKS
description: The Salvadoran leftist guerrilla front will accept a Government offer to reopen peace talks this summer, a leading rebel political official said today.

title: Scientific Illiteracy
description: To what extent do Americans understand the basic scientific words and ideas that recur in many current public debates? Not to a great extent, according to a 1985 survey of science literacy among 2,000 adults, conducted by Jon D. Miller of Northern Illinois University. Only one-third of the respondents, for example, said they had a clear understanding of what a molecule is, and only 16 percent said they clearly understood what DNA is. Moreover, in similar studies, only half of those who claimed such knowledge were able to define the terms properly when tested.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Koch Rebuffs Report Criticizing '87 Budget
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that the Citizens Budget Commission had hurt the city's fight against proposed reductions in Federal aid by saying ''poor planning,'' not the cuts, were responsible for Mayor Koch's austere 1987 budget proposal.

title: Donahue Charges Dropped
description: A man involved in a fistfight with the television talk-show host Phil Donahue at La Guardia Airport last Month agreed yesterday in Queens Criminal Court to drop assault and harassment charges against Mr. Donahue. Attorneys for the man, William Ferguson of Ridgefield Park, N.J., said he was considering filing a civil suit. The dismissal hinged on Mr. Donahue's promise not to file counter-charges.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ACCORD REACHED ON JOHNSON WILL
description: The four-month court battle over the will of the late J. Seward Johnson ended yesterday in an out-of-court settlement that will require his widow to pay out $160 million of the $500 million estate.

title: PROGRAMMING & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
Armco-U.S. Steel Pact
description: Armco Inc. and the United States Steel Corporation said today that they had signed a letter of intent to create a joint venture involving their oilfield supply and service divisions. A spokesman for Armco said there would probably be some job cuts but would not say how many. Armco's oilfield unit employs 2,400 people nationwide; U.S. Steel's division employs 1,200.

title: South Korean Leader Meets With an Opponent
description: President Chun Doo Hwan met with the head of South Korea's main opposition party today, but they failed to achieve any breakthrough on the central political issue here, a continuing debate over constitutional revision.

title: TUROFF IS LINKED TO ISSUING MORE FREE TAXI MEDALLIONS
description: New York City's former taxi chief, Jay L. Turoff, who is already under investigation on irregularities in the awarding of 123 free taxi medallions, also secretly issued two free medallions to a major fleet cab company, according to city records.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The headline supplied by editors yesterday on a Washington dispatch about Secretary of State George P. Shultz's reaction to Tokyo lobbying by Michael K. Deaver in behalf of Puerto Rico misstated a key point of the dispatch. Mr. Shultz questioned the ''appropriateness'' of an investment proposal backed by Mr. Deaver involving Japan and Puerto Rico; he did not reprimand or rebuke Mr. Deaver.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Margaret M. Coudriet has been named senior vice president of DFS Dorland/Direct.

title: Bronx Man Is Arrested In Slaying of 4 in April
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with shooting to death four men in a city housing project on April 30 in what the police say may have been a drug-related reprisal.

title: Humor but No Mirth
description: The Supreme Court is not noted for its levity, but Justice Harry A. Blackmun ventured into humor yesterday - judiciously, of course - while announcing the Court's opinion in a case involving the tax treatment of accrued jackpots in casino slot machines.

title: IRIS ADAMS LIBRESCO
description: Iris Adams Libresco, a lawyer and vice president of a Westport, Conn., management consulting business, died May 22 at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. She was 59 years old and lived in Westport.

title: BINGHAM SAYS FEAR CAUSED '71 FLIGHT
description: Stephen M. Bingham ended a second day under cross-examination at his murder and conspiracy trial today, repeatedly insisting that he became a fugitive for 13 years out of fear, not guilt.

title: Tax Reform: On Camera, in Camera
description: The Senate leadership's strategy for the tax reform debate that starts today is all talk and no action - and for once, that's absolutely the right approach. Let the senators make imposing speeches to their brand-new television audience about the Finance Committee's bill. But let them understand that the Senate floor is no place to try fine-tuning so intricate a construction. The place to get the hard work done is not in front of the cameras but in camera, before a focused conference committee of the House and Senate.

title: PUBLIC IMPACT, PERSONAL TOLL: ANOTHER SIDE OF CITY SCANDAL
description: On the eve of his indictment in March in New York City's corruption scandal, E. Martin Solomon, a 48-year-old vice president of Citisource Inc., called his elderly father in Florida to soften the impending shock.

title: No Explosives Found, Sikhs' Lawyer Asserts
description: The police found no explosives in the homes or workplaces of the five Sikhs arrested in Montreal on Friday, Robert Beaudet, their lawyer, said. The five were arraigned on charges of conspiring to possess explosives with intent to injure.

title: 7 OF 10 IN SURVEY SAY THEY'RE FANS
description: Americans by wide margins consider themselves sports fans (71 percent), participate in sports or fitness activities (73 percent), and favor mandatory drug testing of professional athletes (73 percent).

title: REAGAN EXTENDS LOW TARIFF ON IMPORTS FROM RUMANIA
description: President Reagan today approved another yearlong extension of trade benefits to Rumania, but said he did so ''with difficulty'' because of its poor record on human rights. In a statement, the President said: ''I am disppointed by the very limited response of the Rumanian Government to numerous expressions of strong U.S. public, Congressional and Administration concern about its performance in areas of human rights and religious issues.''

title: Laws That Only an Incumbent Could Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Lead Seniors' at 71
description: Ed Tutwiler of Indianapolis and Dale Morey of High Point, N.C., who have played in many Walker Cup matches, tied today for the lead in the first round of the 82d annual championship of the United States Seniors' Golf Association.

title: Economic Scene; MILITARY COSTS AN ISRAELI ISSUE
description: PRIME MINISTER SHIMON PERES, in the midst of controversies here over the purported misconduct of Israel's intelligence services at home and abroad, stressed in an interview the most positive of his administration's accomplishments: the sharp drop in Israeli inflation.

title: U.S. PRIVATE GROUP SEEKING $500,000 TO MONITOR A-TESTS
description: A private group that signed an agreement with the Soviet Academy of Sciences last week to set up on-site monitoring of nuclear underground tests began a campaign today to raise $500,000 to pay for the first year of the program.

title: WIDE DRUG USE FOUND IN PEOPLE HELD IN CRIMES
description: More than half of the men and women arrested in New York City and Washington, D.C., for serious crimes were found to be using one or more illegal drugs, a rate much higher than previously believed, according to a Justice Department study released today.

title: REAGAN IS PRESSED TO BACK TAX RISE
description: The chairman of the Republican-controlled Senate Budget Committee today told President Reagan that unless he agreed to a revenue increase, not even the Senate's 1987 military budget level would be approved.

title: Triple Play
description: When the national collegiate outdoor track and field championships begin today at Indianapolis, Wendy Brown will be taking dead aim at history, hoping to become the first athlete - male or female - to score in the high jump, the long jump and the triple jump in the same N.C.A.A. meet.

title: SUTTON'S 298th TOPS UNSETTLED YANKEES
description: The evening began with changes. It ended with another Yankee defeat, this one coming when 41-year-old Don Sutton pitched superbly for his 298th victory and 38-year-old Bob Boone hit a three-run homer to lift the California Angels to a 4-2 triumph.

title: Enjoying Youth Longer
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM REVIVES 'PLAIN OF PRAYER'
description: BY offering Martha Graham's ''Plain of Prayer'' on Sunday afternoon at the City Center Theater, the Martha Graham Dance Company has revived an enigma.

title: The Convention City Sweepstakes
description: City officials here treated some important Democrats to a free lunch this week.

title: BARRY'S JEWELERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
A BACHELOR PARTY FOR LEE HEE KYO
description: Lee Hee Kyo, the groom-to-be, did not seem to be fully enjoying his bachelor party. He is departing for Korea to be married, and there are all of those last-minute wedding details to worry about - such as ''to whom?''

title: LEAD FOUND IN WATER AT WORLD TRADE CENTER
description: Drinking water was shut off last night on 16 floors of state offices high in one of the twin towers of the World Trade Center after unacceptable levels of lead were found in samples.

title: INQUIRY BY CITY INTO BABY'S FALL FROM 17TH FLOOR
description: Health Department officials began an investigation yesterday into why a window guard had not been installed in the Queens apartment from which an 11-month-old boy fell 17 floors to the ground Monday. The infant, whose fall was broken by the leaves and limbs of a mulberry tree, suffered multiple injuries.

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $448,681, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,882,116, or 53 cents a share, for the 9 months. The 9 months results also included a gain from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle of $780,093, or 14 cents a share. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $436,419, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,286,007, or 44 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: South African Workers Plan Strike on June 16
description: South Africa's largest labor federation said today that it would back a one-day strike on June 16 to mark the 10th anniversary of the 1976 Soweto uprising.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: Citicorp Rates Up at Auction
description: At its weekly auction of commercial paper, Citicorp sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.837 percent, an increase from the 6.664 percent average rate at last week's auction.

title: MANUFACTURER OF SHUTTLE ROCKETS ANNOUNCES SHIFTS IN MANAGEMENT
description: Morton Thiokol Inc., the manufacturer of the booster rockets identified as the cause of the space shuttle Challenger disaster, announced major management changes in its space division yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, an obituary yesterday of a leading baritone with the New York City Opera misspelled his name. He was William Dansby, not Damsby.

title: CELTICS DOWN ROCKETS FOR 3-1 LEAD
description: This was why Bill Walton came to the Boston Celtics, why he left the sun and surf of Southern California to play for a team on the other, colder coast. It was to become a critical member of a team that could win a world title.

title: Loews's CBS Stake
description: The Loews Corporation has increased its stake in CBS Inc. from 16.7 percent, to 17.7 percent.

title: GIFTS OF SEASON AND SONG
description: 1. Italian Silver Spoon - If you are looking for an elegant wedding gift, in this season of weddings, Buccellati's pierced, wide-mouthed vegetable spoon is a fine choice.

title: FORMER NASA HEAD IS CHOICE OF REAGAN FOR SCIENCE ADVISOR
description: Dr. William R. Graham, who became acting administer of the space agency just before the shuttle Challenger disaster in January, was named by President Reagan today as his chief science adviser.

title: PANEL WILL URGE WIDE NASA REVIEW OF SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The Presidential commission on the space shuttle disaster will urge the space agency to review many critical components in the shuttle besides the faulty rocket joint that caused the disaster.

title: FRANCE CHECKING WALDHEIM REPORT
description: The Government is investigating charges that French officials knew as early as 1979 that Kurt Waldheim had given a false account of his World War II service with the German Army, a spokesman for Prime Minister Jacques Chirac said today.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Give TV Its Day
description: Television in the Senate of the United States is supposed to be a temporary experiment, but you can be sure it's here to stay. For most senators will give up almost any other addiction except the tube.

title: WHO'S NOT RAPPAPORT?
description: It's not ''Dallas,'' it's Houston; and it's not ''I'm Not Rappaport,'' it's the National Basketball Association Finals. But it's the stuff of theater, and prime-time soap opera.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $2,464,000 from the disposal of the company's semiconductor equipment operations. c-Net loss and includes an $18 million writeoff related to the company's semiconductor equipment operations.

title: RED SOX CAPTURE 4TH IN ROW
description: Rich Gedman sparked a two-run third inning with a run-scoring double, and Don Baylor hit a two-run homer in the seventh tonight, leading the Boston Red Sox to a 5-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Another Round In Hockey Battle
description: In a luncheon talk during the Stanley Cup finals last month, John Ziegler described the season's rise in the incidence of player fisticuffs as ''alarming and disturbing.'' Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League, went on to say that one ''disproportionate'' set of statistics - that 2 percent of all players were accounting for 20 percent of major penalties assessed for fighting - would have to be addressed ''in some way.'' In just which way wasn't made clear.

title: U.S. Reportedly Knew Of Poland's Plans in '81
description: A Polish official notified the United States in advance of the 1981 crackdown on the Solidarity union, according to a published report.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $28,900,000 for the quarter and $50,400,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago results include earnings from the Consumer and Industrial Products Group which was sold in September 1985. As a result of its restructuring, Gulf & Western has modified its corporate name to Gulf & Western Inc., effective immediately.

title: Bridge: Commercial League Offers Games for Business People
description: For many players who do a day's work in Manhattan and live in the suburbs the Metropolitan Commercial League offers a pleasant way of enjoying bridge in a convenient time frame. Once or twice a month they can play a head-to-head match that typically starts at 6 P.M. and is likely to end soon after 9 P.M.

title: OREO, AT 75, WORLD'S FAVORITE COOKIE
description: John Bagli loves his work. The week goes by too quickly for him. ''Every time I turn around, it's Friday,'' he says.

title: MBI BUSINESS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Fannie Mae Planning 2 Separate Financings
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday announced two separate financings, one to raise new cash through the sale of $1.3 billion of debentures priced at par, and the other to sell $500 million of 9 percent mortgage-backed securities .

title: COURT VOIDS NEW YORK LIQUOR LAW
description: The Supreme Court struck down a New York State law today that had the effect of restricting discounting by liquor producers in other states.

title: G.& W. NET DROPS 15% IN QUARTER
description: Gulf and Western Inc., the diversifed publishing and information resources company, reported yesterday that earnings in its second fiscal quarter of 1986 dropped 15 percent although revenues edged up 3.2 percent.

title: Italy Plans New Lira
description: Italy's Government approved a draft law today calling for a new lira worth 1,000 present lire. The change, intended to help spur the economy, could begin early next year if Parliament acts promptly, Treasury Minister Giovanni Goria said. Calculations would be transformed in Italy, where a cup of coffee now costs 600 lire and a small car costs 10 million lire.

title: 18,000 CHERNOBYL EVACUEES GIVEN CHECKUPS AT HOSPITALS
description: About 18,000 people suffered from headaches, coughing, respiratory trouble and some spat blood after the Chernobyl nuclear disaster, and the death toll now stands at 25, Soviet doctors said today.

title: A MURDOCH AIDE ACCUSES PRINTERS AFTER FIRE AT LONDON WAREHOUSE
description: A huge fire destroyed a giant warehouse belonging to the publisher Rupert Murdoch early today. The company and some dismissed print workers traded accusations over who set the blaze.

title: REAGAN ASKS VOTE FOR SAUDI MISSILES
description: President Reagan told Republican Congressional leaders today that a Senate vote later this week on the sale of missiles to Saudi Arabia would ''have a profound effect'' on United States relations with Arab states.

title: Persico Trial Goes to Jury
description: A jury deliberated for its first full day yesterday in the seven-month-old trial of Carmine Persico and eight other men charged with operating a Mafia family as a racketeering enterprise. The jury, which is sequestered, began its deliberations Monday evening after receiving final instructions from Judge John F. Keenan in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Mr. Persico is charged with being the boss of the Colombo crime family.

title: PHILLIES' STREAK ENDED BY DODGERS
description: Greg Brock hit two homers and doubled to drive in four runs tonight, and Fernando Valenzuela overcame a shaky start to help Los Angeles break the Phillies' seven-game winning streak with an 11-4 rout.

title: ANDERSON VOTE BEGINS
description: Executives of Anderson, Clayton & Company declined to predict victory today as shareholders began voting on a company-supported, $451 million recapitalization plan. The company said on Monday that it would continue to vote through 5 P.M., Eastern standard time, on Thursday.

title: PADRES EDGE METS ON MARTINEZ HOMER
description: The ball that Kevin McReynolds hit took a sharp right turn at the last second and Mookie Wilson missed it. The ball that Carmelo Martinez hit minutes later took no detours and did not miss the left-field stands.

title: 'Big Deal' to Close Sunday
description: ''Big Deal,'' the musical based on the Italian film ''Big Deal on Madonna Street,'' will close after the evening performance on Sunday at the Broadway Theater. The play, directed and choreographed by Bob Fosse, will have run for seven previews and 70 regular performances.

title: STAGE: SPOLETO'S CIRCUS
description: This city was one of the earliest and most important centers for theater in the United States, with the first ballet in America produced here in 1735. So it seemed appropriate that the Spoleto Festival looked to the past in two of last weekend's chief events - a circus and a ballet from the 19th century. The Scottish Ballet was on hand with its production of August Bournonville's ''Sylphide,'' said to be one of the most authentic versions of the 19th-century ballet. And just across the street the Circus Flora set up its tent in Marion Square - a re-creation of the first circus to perform in Charleston, in 1810.

title: TECH DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company went public in April.

title: Working Profile: Representative John D. Dingell; How a Huntsman Stalks His Legislative Prey
description: John D. Dingell's passion is hunting. He says he likes the solitude of the deep woods, the kinship of fellow hunters and matching his wits with those of a wild animal.

title: A New York City Kind of Cottage Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Camcorder Campaign Is Sony's Biggest Ever
description: Sony's new multimillion-dollar ''Moving Snapshots'' campaign for a line of 8-millimeter video products will be the largest single-product campaign in the company's history.

title: NBC's Nightly News Leads Network Ratings
description: NBC's Nightly News with Tom Brokaw led the weekly evening news ratings for the week ending May 30. It was the first time since Sept. 28, 1981, that the NBC program outscored The CBS Evening News with Dan Rather.

title: CML GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
MUSIC: WEILL'S 'LOST IN THE STARS' AT 92D STREET Y
description: THIS season the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Y has been exploring ''Broadway Songs of the 40's.'' For the final program, the subject is Kurt Weill, and for the first time in its 16-year history, the series has enlisted an instrumental ensemble and chorus for the presentation of a complete work.

title: MEDICAL SHOPPING CENTER
description: NOTHING is more crucial to the success of a shopping center than the creation of a tenant mix whose diversity will draw shoppers and minimize competition among retailers.

title: Advertising; 'Register' Book As Ad Medium
description: There is a preoccupation among creators of advertising media about reaching the swells, the upscale, the affluent, the possessors of moneybags.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC AT A LANDMARK Despite the building and rebuilding that has occurred in the city over the last 200 years, the Abigail Adams Smith Museum has miraculously eluded the wrecker's ball, the builder's eye and the developer's plan. This landmark house, at 421 East 61st Street, began its existence in 1799, ignobly, as the stable on the East River estate of Col. William Stephens Smith and Abigail Adams Smith, the daughter of the second President, John Adams. It has been a residence several times, a country inn and, since 1939, a museum with an 18th-century, country-style garden.

title: America Sells Out
description: It is an immense clearance sale.

title: LIBERTY WEEKEND TRANSIT LINKS SET
description: A special system of July 4 weekend shuttle buses and discount-fare trains has been created in New Jersey to funnel up to 150,000 people into Liberty State Park - a broad waterfront expanse here with commanding views of New York Harbor.

title: MAYOR SAYS BOTNICK WAS NOT MISLEADING ON LACK OF DEGREE
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that Victor E. Botnick, a top mayoral aide and chairman of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, never graduated from college, and had never misled anyone about it.

title: LONG LAYOFF COULD IMPERIL RAMPAGE'S CHANCES
description: ''You'll win the Belmont,'' Pat Day said to Rampage's owners a minute after riding the colt to a fourth-place finish in the Kentucky Derby on May 3, and horseplayers everywhere were thinking the same thing.

title: THE BALANCED SLATE OF THE DEMOCRATS CONTRASTS WITH G.O.P. DOWNSTATE TILT
description: As state Democrats completed their nominating session here today, the sharp contrasts that will be presented to the voters in November were already evident, even before the formal campaigning begins.

title: MUSICIANS TAKING CITY CABARET LAW TO COURT
description: In the jazz capital of the world, there is dissonance.

title: HOUSE APPROVES MEASURE TO MAKE COMPUTER FRAUD A FEDERAL CRIME
description: Heeding warnings that computer crime ''will be the crime wave of the next decade,'' the House of Representatives today passed a bill making the use of computers for some cases of fraud or theft a Federal felony.

title: ODETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary net loss of $301,000 resulted from issuance and distribution expenses incurred in the company's exchange offer during fiscal year 1985.

title: GREAT DAY FOR MEXICO
description: After a 16-year wait, soccer-crazy Mexico saw its dreams come true today: Mexico's team played in the World Cup on Mexican soil and battled its way to victory in the team's opening game before some 110,000 screaming fans.

title: After 6 Years, Deaf Juror Takes Her Place
description: Mary Beth Miller tried to suppress a smile as she made her way to the jury box in a robbery trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan last week. She did not want the judge to think that she was not serious about her civic responsibilities.

title: COMPUTERLAND SALE IS SET BY FOUNDER
description: William H. Millard is planning to sell Computerland, the world's largest computer retailer.

title: RENAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $72,000 for the quarter and $198,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: The Artful Roger
description: Roger Clemens of the Red Sox is scheduled to pitch Friday night at Milwaukee, where victory would raise his record to 10-0. If the last two-thirds of the season is anywhere near as kind as the first third has been, Clemens will join some very exclusive company. Only these nine pitchers in the last 50 years have won 20 games more than they've lost in a single major league season: Carl Hubbell, 1936 Giants...26-6; Hal Newhouser, 1945 Tigers...29-9; Robin Roberts, 1952 Phillies...28-7;Don Newcombe, 1956 Dodgers...27-7; Whitey Ford, 1961 Yankees...25-4; Sandy Koufax, 1963 Dodgers...25-5; Denny McLain, 1968 Tigers...31-6; Ron Guidry, 1978 Yankees...25-3; Dwight Gooden, 1985 Mets...24-4.

title: TEMPLETON FOREIGN FUND reports earnings for As of May 31
HOLTZMAN URGES LIMITS ON TERM OF COUNTY CHIEF
description: Brooklyn District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman called yesterday for sharp new restrictions on the activities of county political leaders, including limiting the time a county leader could hold that post.

title: AN OLD SCHOOL AND NEW HOPE IN BROOKLYN
description: For Angel Orensanz, a sculptor, one glance at the dilapidated red schoolhouse on Kosciusko Street in Brooklyn turned into a lonely crusade to save it from destruction.

title: Defense Ends in Seattle Trial
description: The defense attorney for a defendant accused of killing a prominent lawyer, his wife and their two young sons rested his case late today and closing arguments were scheduled for Wednesday. The defendant, David L. Rice, 27 years old, saw the two adult victims, Charles and Annie Goldmark, as targets in his war against Communists, according to defense testimony. Mr. Rice has pleaded innocent by reason of insanity.

title: DANCE: 1,500 CHILDREN IN 'CHINA DIG'
description: JACQUES D'AMBOISE certainly does know how to put on a show. Questions might be raised about some elements in the program Mr. d'Amboise and his National Dance Institute presented on Monday night at the Felt Forum to celebrate the institute's 10th anniversary. But there was an undeniable exuberance, color and ingenuity to ''China Dig,'' the homespun mega-spectacle that was the program's main event, as 1,500 American schoolchildren, 56 Chinese public-school students from Peking and 12 men and women from the New York City Police Department danced, sang and clowned their way through a trip to the center of the earth and out the other side.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Included equity earnings of $2,216,646 for the latest quarter and $2,544,399 for the year-ago period. The latest quarter's equity earnings included $189,238 of Paul Harris Stores Inc. The 1986 results include operations of the Miller-Wohl Company and Winkelman Stores Inc. for a 14-week period as compared to a 13-week period in the prior year as a result of the company's change in fiscal 1987 to a 52-53 week fiscal year ending the Saturday closest to Jan. 31. The share earnings and shares outstanding figures were retroactively adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock distribution effective Feb. 3, 1986.

title: MANHATTAN LOT SOARS IN VALUE
description: In the last decade, New York real estate has ridden the most spectacular bull market in memory. The new towers on Madison Avenue and the expensive condominiums uptown have disgorged buckets of gold for real estate developers.

title: A ZIONIST LEADER IN THE U.S.
description: Rudolf Goldschmid Sonneborn, a New York industrialist, a longtime leader of the American Zionist movement and one of the most prominent fund-raisers for the young state of Israel in the 1940's and 1950's, died Sunday at his estate in Danbury, Conn. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CITY OPTIMISTIC ON TRUMP OFFER
description: Koch administration officials emerged from a meeting with the developer Donald J. Trump yesterday saying they were optimistic that he would be able to proceed with his offer to rebuild the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink. However, the two sides continue to favor different strategies.

title: TEMPLETON GROWTH FUND LTD reports earnings for As of May 31
EAST EUROPE, VA.
description: From Foggy Bottom to Capitol Hill, a preachy chorus wearies the world with its patronizing call for ''democratic elections'' in other countries - especially in countries whose regimes do not please us. The virtue of American-style democratic elections, like the virtue of American weapons and military training, is translated into the summum bonum of American foreign policy.

title: MERRILL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE DELEGATES' CHOICES FOR DEMOCRATIC TICKET
description: Mario M. Cuomo - Elected Governor in 1982, narrowly defeating Mayor Koch in the Democratic primary and Lewis R. Lehrman, the Republican, in the general election . . . Began political career as Secretary of State under Gov. Hugh L. Carey in 1975 . . . Lost New York City mayoral race to Mayor Koch in 1977 . . . Elected Lieutenant Governor in 1978 . . . Author of two books: ''Forest Hills Diary: The Crisis of Low-Income Housing,'' and ''Diaries of Mario M. Cuomo: The Campaign for Governor,'' . . . An attorney . . . Born in South Jamaica, Queens, on June 15, 1932, son of Italian immigrants . . . Attended public and Roman Catholic parochial schools in Queens . . . Received undergraduate and law degrees from St. John's University . . . Briefly played minor league baseball in 1952 . . . Has five children: Margaret, 31, Andrew, 28, Maria, 24, Madeline, 21, and Christopher, 15 . . . Lives in Albany and in Holliswood, Queens, with wife, Matilda. Stan Lundine

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: LET'S say you are baby-sitting with 18-month-old Anthony who, while you are watching television, starts rummaging through your purse. You find him chewing on the last of the 10 aspirins you were carrying. What do you do?

title: LABOR BOARD REBUFFS A CHALLENGE TO U.A.W. ACCORD AT G.M. PLANT
description: The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation won a major challenge Monday to their agreement for union representation at G.M.'s $3.5 billion Saturn Corporation plant being built in Tennessee.

title: What Separates a Jeeves From a Butler
description: To the Editor:

title: New Du Pont Unit
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it was combining its $2 billion automotive materials business into a new unit that would concentrate on the production of materials for a largely plastic car. Edgar S. Woolard Jr., vice chairman of the chemical company based in Wilmington, Del., said that by placing most of its $2 billion-a-year automotive business in a single division, Du Pont was positioning itself to be a major supplier to General Motors, Ford and Chrysler in the auto industry's ''evolution toward a new type of car with Du Pont polymers as components.'' Mr. Woolard said he expected the switch from a high proportion of metals in cars to plastics by 1990.

title: SENATE EXTENDS LAW PROVIDING STUDENT LOANS
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly passed a bill extending programs that offer loans and grants to college students for five more years.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding results have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Jan. 16, 1986.

title: The U.N. Today: June 4, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL I FUND reports earnings for As of May 31
THE ART OF RED GROOMS EXPLORED ON CHANNEL 13
description: A half-hour essay on WNET/ Channel 13 at 8:30 this evening uses its title to ask the question ''Who Is Red Grooms?'' Unfortunately, the answer contrived for the occasion is never more than superficial. Produced by David Othmer on an obviously minuscule budget, the program is really little more than a sketchy summary of a widely praised Red Grooms retrospective as it was shown last summer at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia. Judith Stein, the curator, provides the narration, starting with the observation that the art of Grooms encompasses ''everything you can think of, and then its opposite.''

title: We Shouldn't Try to Buy Popularity at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAMANS FAIL A SCIENTIST
description: Augusto Ruschi, the naturalist whom shamans tried to cure of a liver disease he said came from touching poisonous toads, died today in a hospital, his nurse reported. He was 70 years old.

title: ARCHBISHOP OF NEWARK STEPS DOWN
description: Archbishop Peter L. Gerety resigned today as the spiritual leader of the 1.3 million Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of Newark.

title: MORE ON FATTY FISH
description: AN article in this column on May 14 recommended mackerel as a good source of omega-3 fatty acids, which help to lower cholesterol levels. But it caused confusion with the erroneous statement that ''Fatty fish should be eaten only once a month because of possible chemical contamination.''

title: Palmer's Decision
description: After being shut out of the United States Open for three years in a row, Arnold Palmer said he would not try to qualify again. ''This is the last time I'll try,'' he said.

title: Bid to Impeach Judge
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, introduced today a resolution calling for impeachment of imprisoned Federal District Judge Harry Claiborne of Nevada. Mr. Claiborne, chief judge of the Federal District Court in his state, was convicted in 1984 of two counts of tax evasion for failing to report $106,000 in law practice income on returns for 1978 and 1979.

title: VARITRONIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $293,000 for the quarter and $614,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: TIGHT G.O.P. CONTEST IN CALIFORNIA FOR CHANCE TO CHALLENGE CRANSTON
description: Two California Republicans from opposite sides of their party's political spectrum were in a tight battle tonight for the right to challenge Senator Alan Cranston this November.

title: Tennessee Suspends 2
description: The University of Tennessee's 15-week investigation of its athletic program turned up six possible National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations and led to the suspension of Carlos Reveiz, an all-Southeastern Conference kicker, and Kelly Ziegler, a linebacker, from the Volunteer football team, officials said. The university's interim report, copies of which have been shared with the S.E.C. and the N.C.A.A., also recommended a public reprimand for Coach Johnny Majors for not reporting at least two violations.

title: PACT ON EXTRADITION IS GAINING
description: A revised extradition treaty between the United States and Britain gained momentum today when the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee offered to amend it to meet objections that have kept it stalled in the committee since last fall.

title: PELTON DENIES STATEMENTS TO F.B.I. AS SPY CASE TESTIMONY CONCLUDES
description: Testimony in the espionage trial of Ronald W. Pelton concluded today with the defendant vigorously denying several of the most damaging statements attributed to him by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: On Rural America
description: Excerpts from a speech by Senator John Melcher, Democrat of Montana, before the Senate, June 2:

title: 3-Part Offering By FBC Mortgage
description: FBC Mortgage Securities Trust II is offering $500 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Bonner Is Off by Train To Gorky Banishment
description: Yelena G. Bonner boarded a train for Gorky today, saying that she was eager to get back to her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov. She said she expected to return here to pick up baggage that had been shipped separately from the United States.

title: WHO DONE IT? FOOD CAN THICKEN THE PLOT
description: WHEN the Judas Goats, a loose association of some 200 fans of Robert Parker's Spenser mysteries, held their annual get-together in Cambridge, Mass., last weekend, the fare came straight out of Mr. Parker's novels. Prepared and served at Tapas, a restaurant on Massachusetts Avenue near Porter Square, the oyster stew was from ''Promised Land'' (1976), the roast duck from ''Taming a Sea-Horse'' (1986) and the cherry cobbler from ''Ceremony'' (1982).

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Ethnic Pantry Relocates The Ethnic Pantry, a mail-order source for nuts, herbs, spices and exotic condiments, will move from Grayslake, Ill., to Jacksonville, Fla., this summer. Some of the inventory, however, is not being moved and is being offered through June 30 at substantial discounts. For example, imported Indian basmati rice, regularly $3.85 a pound, is $1.95; large Indonesian krupuk (shrimp chips) are reduced to $2.75 a pound from $5.45; dried fava beans, originally $4.95 a pound, are now $1.60; two ounces of dried ancho chilies are 85 cents, down from $1.70; slivered blanched almonds are $2.75 a pound, reduced from $7.95, and some of the Joyce Chen line of Chinese sauces are half price.

title: United Jersey Buys Jersey Banks
description: United Jersey Banks of Princeton, N.J. said it had reached an agreement to acquire Commercial Bancshares Inc., of Jersey City, N.J., for approximately $285 million.

title: 3 Ruled Liable in St. Joe Case
description: Federal District Judge Milton Pollack ruled yesterday that Giuseppe B. Tome, an Italian living in Switzerland, violated anti-fraud provisions of Federal securities law by trading in St. Joe Minerals stock five years ago on the basis of inside information.

title: AFTER A SIX-YEAR WAIT, A NEW FEELIES ALBUM
description: A JAPANESE television crew set up cameras and lights in Maxwell's, the Hoboken rock club, earlier this week. They had come to capture a performance by the Feelies, the frequently elusive band from Haledon, N.J., and although it was a week night, the group also drew a large and enthusiastic audience. After spending the better part of the last decade leading a hit-and-run existence - venturing forth periodically to perform in a New York or New Jersey club, then scurrying back to Haledon for the next several months or years - the Feelies are entering a more active phase.

title: ON EVE OF SENATE TAX DEBATE, JOCKEYING BEGINS
description: Senators from both parties jockeyed for position today as the Senate prepared to begin debate Wednesday on tax-revision legislation.

title: CONCERT: DRESHER AND REICH WORKS
description: THE old man was angry.

title: TREE TESTS MAY MAKE CITY GREEN
description: An amicable solution to a dispute between an arboretum and an adjacent high-speed toll road has led to an innovative new laboratory that could produce some lessons, and plants, for other cities.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
USHER PLACES BLAME ON N.F.L.
description: In his second day of testimony, Harry Usher, the commissioner of the United States Football League, said yesterday that a strategy presented to National Football League executives at a seminar in 1984, which included putting pressure on ABC not to give the U.S.F.L. a new television contract, was ''brilliant,'' that ''it has worked'' and that as a result, ''we are dying.''

title: AIDS TESTS PLANNED FOR PIGS
description: The Florida Health Department announced today that it would conduct additional tests on swine herds in Belle Glade, Fla., to determine whether the animals might have been infected with the virus believed to cause AIDS.

title: KRIEK GAINS PARIS SEMIFINALS
description: They literally laughed when hard-hitting Johan Kriek walked into the locker room at the start of the French Open.

title: Advertising; Pants Project
description: McCaffrey & Ratner is working on an interesting project for Cluett-Peabody: a new product in the trouser category.

title: Advertising; Blockbuster Spots Gain Popularity
description: IT appears that the television advertising ploy known as the blockbuster is gaining in popularity.

title: Red Wings Drop Park
description: After his National Hockey League team turned in a dismal record last season, including a club record of 57 defeats, Jimmy Devellano, the general manager of the Detroit Red Wings, has decided to bite the bullet. But it is the team's coach, Brad Park, who is feeling the pain.

title: MACHINE IMAGERY, HOMEY DECORATION
description: THE Oreo is the stuff of legend in part because of its taste and its texture - a pleasing juxtaposition of soft, sweet cream and hard, crisp chocolate -but also because of its appearance. It stands as the archetype of its kind, a reminder that cookies are designed as consciously as buildings, and sometimes better.

title: THURMOND CALLS FOR INQUIRY ON TEXTILE EXPERT'S ACTIVITIES
description: Senator Strom Thurmond asked the Justice Department today to investigate the activities of Walter C. Lenahan, a former Government official who helped draft Federal textile policy and then went to work advising Hong Kong on textile negotiations.

title: OF PIT BULLS, COLT MANIA AND UPSCALE PREGNANT
description: Young toughs here are measuring their bark by their dog's bite. Fighting with pit bulls, long a problem elsewhere, has come to Philadelphia.

title: Nicaragua Rebel Gets Asylum in Costa Rica
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, the former Nicaraguan rebel leader, was granted political asylum here today, 18 days after giving up his fight against the Sandinista Government.

title: AQUINO AT 100 DAYS: REVERED 'BECAUSE SHE IS US'
description: When Corazon C. Aquino, as a presidential candidate, first started talking about what she would accomplish in her first 100 days as President, one of her advisers recalls, ''talk was easy'' because she was not expected to take office.

title: After 125 Years, The Greys Admit a Girl
description: For 125 years, the Knickerbocker Greys were a tradition - for boys. Now that Alexandra Hallen, 9 years old, has spoken up, they will also be a tradition for girls.

title: Dade County
description: A $106.5 million issue of Dade County, Fla., public improvement refunding bonds was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Yields on the tax-exempt issue range from 4.75 percent for an issue due in 1987 to 6.30 percent in 1991, 7.60 percent in 1996, 8.10 percent in 2001 and 8.25 percent for issues due from 2005 through 2007. Because the bonds are insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company they are rated triple A by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Proceeds from the sale will be used to advance the refunding of outstanding public improvement bonds.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PCB's Released in Fire
description: A fire broke out in an electrical transformer at a city-operated junk yard at the Brooklyn Navy Yard early yesterday, spewing PCB's, a toxic chemical, into the air, authorities said. A spokesman for the City Environmental Protection Department, Bill Andrews, said the area was cordoned off until the extent of the danger could be analyzed. Chemists took samples to determine whether the PCB's, polychlorinated biphenyls, burned, giving off dioxins, another toxic substance.

title: LATE SURGE PUSHES DOW UP BY 8.48
description: Wall Street ended its two-day losing streak yesterday, encouraged by easing pressures on interest rates.

title: If Apartheid Is That Evil . . .
description: Secretary of State Shultz seems to understand that the hour is late for peaceful change in South Africa. For a year he has been denouncing apartheid as ''evil'' and ''repugnant.'' Now he adds a passionate warning that it imposes an intolerable ''moral, strategic, economic and political'' burden on Western interests.

title: NEWBERY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a writedown of $1.4 million of its oil and gas properties and pre- tax losses on investments of $2.1 million, both for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mel Stute, the trainer of Snow Chief, said the standout 3-year-old colt would run in the St. Paul Derby June 29 at Canterbury Downs in Shakopee, Minn., if nothing unexpected happens. Stute said, ''If he does well, he'll go on to the Haskell'' an invitation race at Monmouth Park, in New Jersey July 26. . . . Francis Peay will remain as interim head football coach at Northwestern through the 1986 season. Peay, former defensive coordinator for the Wildcats, was named interim coach in March after Dennis Green resigned.

title: LUGAR ASKS MORE FOR MANILA
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that the United States should show its support for the new Philippine Government by providing $100 million more in aid than the Reagan Administration has sought.

title: Runner, 24, Dies After Training
description: A medical examiner said today that Jeff Drenth, a 24-year-old distance runner, died from an irregular heart rhythm when he collapsed after a training run.

title: Ford Official Joins Chrysler Operation
description: Robert A. Lutz, who kept Ford's European operations profitable when the company's domestic sales plunged in the early 1980's, will take on that territory for Chrysler and Lee A. Iacocca, one of his former colleagues at Ford.

title: Market Place; MORE CAUTION FOR PORTFOLIOS
description: INVESTMENT strategists at two major brokerage firms - E. F. Hutton & Company and Paine Webber Inc. - have lowered their sights on near-term prospects for the stock market.

title: YORK COLLEGE: SUTTON URGES HELP FOR NEEDY
description: Percy E. Sutton, the former Borough President of Manhattan, told the members of York College's graduating class yesterday that they should return to their childhood neighborhoods and help those in need.

title: WEST GERMAN CHANCELLOR CREATES A CABINET POST FOR NUCLEAR SAFETY
description: Faced with rising opposition to West Germany's nuclear energy program, Chancellor Helmut Kohl today announced the creation of a new Cabinet post for nuclear safety.

title: Lippincott & Margulies Chooses New Chairman
description: Lippincott & Margulies, the New York consulting firm that has designed many a corporate logotype (Chrysler, Amtrak) and devised many a company name (Nynex, Hartmarx) announced yesterday that it had chosen Clive Chajet to be its chairman.

title: Olin Agrees to Settle Alabama DDT Case
description: More than 6,000 residents of northern Alabama affected by DDT that leaked from a plant of the Olin Corportion have agreed to accept damages from a $15 million fund of the company.

title: Hope for Yonkers Schools
description: After resisting for years, Yonkers, N.Y., may finally be close to accepting a reasonable court plan to desegregate its schools. If energetically pursued, it could be a model for desegregation without mandatory busing.

title: Dedeaux Out as Coach
description: Rod Dedeaux, who led Southern California to a record 11 national baseball championships in 45 years as head coach and helped develop more than 50 major leaguers, including Tom Seaver, Fred Lynn and Dave Kingman, made it official yesterday. He announced he was stepping down as coach but would take the post of director of baseball at U.S.C. The 71-year-old Dedeaux, whose retirement had been expected, said he planned to remain ''totally involved'' with U.S.C. baseball and hoped to help restore the program to its former glory.

title: U.S. MOVE ON CANADA DOUBTED
description: Reagan Administration trade officials said today that the United States, barring a domestic outcry, would probably not counter-retaliate against higher Canadian tariffs against a range of American products.

title: U.S. EXPECTS GUILTY PLEAS IN ISRAEL SPY CASE
description: A former Navy analyst and his wife are expected to plead guilty Wednesday to Federal charges in connection with an Israeli espionage operation that gathered classified material in the United States, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: IN INDIA'S HEAT, THE MANGO IS PERFECTION
description: It is the height of the hot season now in India, and everyone has a strategy to beat the heat: air-conditioners or a trip to the mountains if you are rich, or a ceiling fan or a cot placed under a tree if you are not. But ask Indians what provides the greatest relief and the reply will likely be the same - a mango.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for 13wks to April 19
SMALLER NEW YORK WINERIES, IN TROUBLE, PRESS FOR QUALITY
description: TEN years ago today, Hugh L. Carey, then the Governor of New York, signed into law the Farm Winery Act. The purpose of the law and later amendments was to encourage development of the state's premium-wine industry. Many wine makers say that the legislation is achieving its goal but that the state's wineries now face problems that lie outside its scope.

title: Masco to Buy Henredon
description: The Masco Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Henredon Furniture Industries, a leading maker of medium- to high-priced wood and upholstered furniture, for $298.7 million.

title: Dr. Louis F. Bishop, 85, Dies; Leader in Field of Cardiology
description: Dr. Louis F. Bishop, a clinical cardiologist, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: FIERY ACCEPTANCE BY CUOMO ENDS A SPIRITED CONVENTION
description: As hundreds of delegates chanted ''Mario! Mario! Mario!'' Governor Cuomo accepted the Democratic Party's nomination for a second term today and pledged to lead the state ''from recovery to a whole new era of progress.''

title: Peoples Would Sell Some Zale Assets
description: Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Toronto said if it gained control of the Zale Corporation, it would have the Dallas-based retail jewelry chain ''sell some or all of its assets other than its Zale Jewelers and Fine Jewelers Guild operations,'' to help finance the acquisition.

title: SKI LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
RODINO SCORES EASY VICTORY OVER COUNCILMAN IN PRIMARY
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the dean of the New Jersey Congressional delegation, easily won his party's nomination for a 20th term today, despite a strong effort by the Rev. Jesse Jackson to persuade voters to nominate a black candidate.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago first quarter results include $2.9 million in sales from the company's former Craft Showcase stores.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 4, 1986
description: International

title: DRESS BARN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: The share earnings results are adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split on May 3, 1985, and 5-for-2 stock split on May 2, 1986.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: I HAVE never understood the popularity of state lottery contests. On my way to the bus I pass long lines of people holding scraps of paper with strange sequences of numbers scrawled upon them and I'm baffled. I don't know how to play the lottery, and anyway I don't believe this is how you make a lot of money fast. You make a lot of money fast by writing a trashy novel, which is made into a television mini-series: that is, by dint of hard work.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: HILL & KNOWLTON TO BUY GRAY, THE LOBBYISTS
description: Gray & Company, one of the most influential lobbying firms in Washington, has agreed to be acquired for $21 million by Hill & Knowlton, the world's second-largest public relations company, the firms announced yesterday.

title: REAGAN TO VIEW SHOW FROM CARRIER
description: President Reagan will watch the fireworks on the evening of July 4 from aboard the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy, which will be anchored in New York Harbor southeast of Liberty Island, the White House said yesterday.

title: U.S. Assumes TRW Suit
description: The Justice Department said today that it had decided to take over a $1.2 billion price-fixing and antitrust lawsuit against TRW Inc. that accuses the military contractor of overcharging the Defense Department. The suit was filed by three former employees who were dismissed.

title: The Disabled 9, the Administration 0
description: For five years the Reagan Administration has waged cold-blooded war on handicapped Americans entitled to Federal disability aid. It has unlawfully cut benefits and then laid administrative snares for those who tried to win them back. This week, thanks in large measure to New York City's Corporation Counsel, F.A.O. Schwarz Jr., the handicapped gained a powerful ally: the Supreme Court.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. This is the finale of the home stand. The Mets next have a four-game series in Pittsburgh and return home on Monday to face Philadelphia. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. California Angels, at Anaheim, Calif. Final game of the road trip. The Yankees come home to face the Baltimore Orioles over the weekend. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 10:30 P.M.) College World Series, at Omaha, Neb. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M. live.) Boxing Jimmy Paul vs. Cubanito Perez, 15 rounds, for Paul's I.B.F. lightweight championship; Carlos Santos vs. Buster Drayton, 15 rounds, for the vacant I.B.F. junior middleweight championship; Gaby Canizales vs. Bernardo Pinango, 15 rounds, for Canizales's W.B.A. bantamweight championship. Byrne Meadowlands Arena, first preliminary 7:30 P.M. (Television - Showtime, 7:30 P.M.) Soccer World Cup: West Germany vs. Uruguay, at Queretaro (Television - Channel 41, 1:45 P.M. ESPN, 2 P.M. live). Scotland vs. Denmark, at Neza. (Television -Channel 41, 5:45 P.M.) Paraguay vs. Iraq, at Toluca. (Television - Channel 41, 11 P.M. tape.) Tennis French Open, at Paris.

title: COOPER LASERSONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a gain from product licensing of about $1 million. c-Net loss.

title: Other NASA Data Got To China Before '79
description: To the Editor:

title: 53 DIE IN FIERCE FIGHTING IN WEST BEIRUT
description: The fiercest fighting in a year engulfed West Beirut today as Shiite Moslem militiamen clashed in separate battles with Palestinians and a pro-Palestinian Sunni Moslem faction.

title: Argentine Admiral Accused Of Rights Abuses Dies at 61
description: Ruben Chamorro, a retired vice admiral who was accused of commanding a torture and execution center in the campaign against leftists in the 1970's, died of a heart attack Monday, military sources said. He was 61 years old.

title: GORBACHEV FAVORS ATOM SAFETY CODE
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev called on other nations today to join the Soviet Union in strengthening safeguards against nuclear disasters such as Chernobyl.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 22
Conference on Dance
description: ''Mirror, Mirror: Critics Look at Criticism,'' the annual conference of the Dance Critics Association, will take place Thursday through Sunday at Riverside Church, Claremont Avenue and 120th Street.

title: ENGLAND IS UPSET BY PORTUGAL, 1-0
description: Carlos Manuel, whose goal against West Germany in the qualifying round got Portugal into the World Cup, scored with 15 minutes remaining today, lifting his team to a 1-0 upset of England.

title: After 10 Years, Garden For Children Is Back
description: Long on sunshine and short on speeches, the dedication yesterday of the renewed children's garden at the New York Botanical Garden was, appropriately, devoted to children.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: DEATH VALLEY & THE AMARGOSA: A Land of Illusion. By Richard E. Lingenfelter. 664 pages. University of California Press. $39.95.

title: PRESIDENT URGES CONGRESS TO BACK HIS ARMS BUILDUP
description: President Reagan appealed to Congress today to continue to finance his space-based missile defense program and improvements in the nation's nuclear forces.

title: Bond and Note Prices Up a Bit
description: Bond and note prices edged upward yesterday in light trading as the credit markets staged a tentative comeback from the steep declines on Monday.

title: Governor's Passion
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: WINE TALK
description: What's in a name? That which we call a rose By any other name would smell as sweet. Shakespeare

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is quite obvious that there is a practical need to start, without delay, setting up an international regime for the safe development of nuclear energy.

title: YESHIVA UNIVERSITY: ISRAELI SEES CRUCIAL TIME FOR '86 CLASS
description: Benjamin Netanyahu, the chief Israeli delegate to the United Nations, called more than 1,500 graduates at Yeshiva University yesterday ''the keepers of the flame and the bearers of the torch,'' and urged them to help guarantee the survival of Israel.

title: WISEMAN EXAMINES RACETRACKS
description: ''RACETRACK,'' two hours, black and white, no narration, is Frederick Wiseman's vision of horse racing. Mr. Wiseman, perhaps our best-known documentary maker, has made a career of recording the American experience, filming subjects as diverse as the criminally insane and the customers at Nieman-Marcus. The results can be downright boring; they can also be enthralling. ''Racetrack,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, is one of Mr. Wiseman's better works.

title: ABC'S RIVALS CHALLENGE 'LIBERTY' EXCLUSIVITY
description: ''Liberty Weekend,'' the nation's official Independence Day celebration keyed to the unveiling of the Statue of Liberty, was largely conceived as a made-for-television event - and key portions of it were sold to ABC on an exclusive basis for $10 million.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE rush-hour B train was Brooklyn-bound with Carol Bloch and Leonore Gordon among the straphangers. The subway had just pulled into 34th Street. The doors slid open easily, except for the one near Miss Bloch and Miss Gordon, which struggled and shook but still stayed shut. The door was insistent, continuing to tremble and lurch, when suddenly its window fell onto the subway car floor.

title: Ex-Delaware Governor Making Presidential Bid
description: Former Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th announced the formation of a Presidential campaign committee.

title: Visiting Russian in U.S. Calls Jamming Counterproductive
description: Vladimir Posner, the Soviet commentator now touring the United States, said today that he regarded Soviet jamming of some Western radio broadcasts as ''counterproductive.''

title: The Peace of the Richards
description: ''T he War of the Richards'' was the description of one of the major power joustings during most of President Reagan's first term, featuring Richard R. Burt of the State Department versus Richard N. Perle of the Defense Department.

title: FLAW IN TITAN'S BOOSTERS IS IDENTIFIED
description: Investigators of the April explosion of a Titan rocket have identified a serious manufacturing and maintenance flaw that raises new concerns about the safety of the space shuttle, according to Federal officials who oversee the space program.

title: Public Funeral Service Held for 7th Astronaut
description: Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka of the Air Force was remembered as a humble hero as he was buried in a Buddhist ceremony Monday. It was the last public funeral service for the seven astronauts killed aboard the space shuttle Challenger.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SINCE my apprenticeship in a Paris restaurant, in my teens, I have been intrigued by the flavor and color of paprika - as intrigued as many home cooks today. Whenever I print a recipe that calls for paprika, the letters come in asking, for example, whether Hungarian paprika and sweet red American pepper are one and the same.

title: Libya Retains Fiat Holdings
description: Libya has refused to sell its substantial and profitable holdings of Fiat S.p.A. stock despite efforts by the company's leadership to buy back the shares, Giovanni Agnelli, president of the Fiat group, said today at a stockholders meeting.

title: A.& P. TO PAY $64 MILLION TO ACQUIRE SHOPWELL
description: Moving to strengthen its foothold in the New York City area, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said yesterday that it would acquire Shopwell Inc. for $31 a share in cash, or about $64 million.

title: Opera Ebony to Offer 'Madama Butterfly'
description: Opera Ebony, a nonprofit company devoted to creating performance opportunities for black opera singers, musicians, conductors and composers, will offer two performances of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly,'' tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 4, at Aaron Davis Hall of City College, 134th Street and Convent Avenue.

title: Tax Proposals Will Hurt Charities and Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVES BEGIN IN CONGRESS TO INSURE THAT U.S. OBSERVES ARMS TREATY
description: Amid sharp criticism of President Reagan's decision to abandon the 1979 strategic arms treaty, Democrats and Republicans began efforts today aimed at forcing the White House to continue to observe the terms of the pact.

title: Manhattan Dismissal
description: After winning only two of 28 games in his first season as basketball coach at Manhattan College, Tom Sullivan was dismissed from his duties when his one-year contract was not renewed.

title: Phone Company Hiring Temporary Operators
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is hiring thousands of temporary telephone operators to replace striking workers. Meanwhile, negotiators for the company and its largest employee union held what were described as largely unproductive bargaining sessions today.

title: Piano Recital by Kautsky
description: The pianist Catherine Kautsky will play works by Mozart, Schubert and George Crumb at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: DAME ANNA NEAGLE, ACTRESS IN BRITISH FILMS AND THEATER
description: Dame Anna Neagle, a British stage and screen actress whose career spanned more than half a century, died in a nursing home near London yesterday. She was 81 years old.

title: BLAIR ACCEPTS RELIANCE OFFER
description: John Blair & Company, seeking to thwart a hostile takeover by Macfadden Holdings Inc., agreed yesterday to be acquired by Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Capital Group for $27 a share in cash and a package of notes.

title: NUCLEAR WASTE ISN'T POLITICAL
description: When the Department of Energy selected three unlucky finalists in the competition for the nation's first high-level nuclear waste dump last week, the news was greeted with cheers from states no longer on the chopping block. It should more appropriately have been met with indignation, for it is proof that science has taken a back seat to politics.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 4, 1986
description: The Economy

title: TEMPLETON GLOBAL II FUND reports earnings for As of May 31
Peabody Coal Co. Pleads Guilty in Miner's Death
description: The Peabody Coal Company has pleaded guilty to felony charges of violating Federal mine safety regulations stemming from the death of a worker.

title: Swans but No Vodka
description: There was ample evidence of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's drive toward moderation at a black-tie reception at the Soviet Embassy the other night. There was no vodka.

title: TOTAL ASSETS PROTECTION INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $44,518. c-Net loss. Revenue represents contract revenue.

title: STAGE: 3 MODERN PLAYS ARE REVIVED IN LONDON
description: Tom Stoppard latently discovered the theatrical properties of love in ''The Real Thing'' and, three years later, he remains smitten. In Mr. Stoppard's latest endeavor, ''Dalliance'' - an adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's 1895 play ''Liebelei'' -the timeless passions of ''The Real Thing'' are set to the dying waltz strains of fin de siecle Vienna. Yet there's a fascinating inversion of point of view in the new work. If ''The Real Thing'' saw sexual dalliance from the perspective of the injured male ego, Schnitzler has forced Mr. Stoppard to cope with a victimized heroine - Christine, a prototypically Viennese ''sweet young girl'' who is casually seduced and abandoned by a narcissistic chocolate soldier.

title: S.E.C. Settles Puritan Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has reached a settlement with two former officers of the Puritan Fashions Corporation - Andrew Rosen, the chief executive, and Samuel Rubenstein, the chief financial officer.

title: Reagan on the Road Again
description: To the delight of Republican Party officials, President Reagan will be back on the road today campaigning and raising money for a Republican Senate candidate.

title: Garnish Adds Glamour
description: STUDENTS attending cooking demonstrations often ask me why their foods never look as stunning as those in food magazines and glossy cookbooks. One reason is probably the garnishes: foods prepared by master chefs have garnishes, beautiful ones at that, while foods prepared by home cooks often go without. Yet when a few simple techniques are mastered, it is possible to transform a plain-looking dish into something elegant.

title: ACCOMPLICES' CONFESSIONS RULED 'UNRELIABLE'
description: The Supreme Court held today that the out-of-court confession of a defendant's alleged accomplice is ''presumptively unreliable'' and may not be used against the defendant unless special circumstances suggest it can be trusted.

title: TEMPLETON WORLD FUND reports earnings for As of May 31
description: All assets figures represent net assets.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Terry Crowley Jr., shortstop, and assigned him to Bluefield of Appalachian League.

title: U.S. Criticizes Papandreou For Statement on Terrorism
description: The State Department characterized as ''baseless and unhelpful'' today recent statements by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece that criticized American policy on combating international terrorism.

title: U.S. MAY SELL OFF URANIUM PLANTS
description: The Administration is considering selling the plants that process uranium for the nation's nuclear power utilities, according to officials.

title: WE SHOULDN'T TRY TO BUY POPULARITY AT THE U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: VIETNAMESE RESTAURANTS: ROOM TO GROW
