description: WHEN I first tasted Vietnamese cooking in Paris nearly 20 years ago, I realized it was a cuisine to be reckoned with. When I visited Saigon several years later, I was convinced of this.

title: A STAR RUNNER SETS FAST PACE IN MOTHERHOOD
description: SOMETIME this weekend, Mary Decker Slaney will lace up her Nikes, tiptoe past the nursery in her Eugene, Ore., home and run her first workout since becoming a mother last Friday morning. She is not expecting to approach the pace she ran last August, when she set the women's world record for the mile (4 minutes 16.71 seconds). After nine months of pregnancy and nine hours of hard labor, Mrs. Slaney has but one goal in mind: a fast comeback.

title: SALVADOR REBELS NAME 4 LEADERS TO HOLD TALKS WITH GOVERNMENT
description: The Salvadoran leftist guerrilla movement formally accepted an offer today to reopen peace talks with the Government and said its most senior commanders would attend the meeting.

title: THE FRUIT IS PLENTIFUL IN FLORIDA
description: Come summer and south Floridians start giving away mangoes to their neighbors the way home gardeners up north give away zucchini. Backyard trees produce boxes of the fruit in a rush between now and September, with many trees producing a harvest within a period of a few weeks.

title: DEAVER'S BERLIN VISIT REFLECTS TIES TO GOVERNMENT
description: Richard R. Burt, the United States Ambassador to West Germany, said today that he and his wife invited Michael K. Deaver to Berlin last February to seek a contract to publicize next year's 750th anniversary of the founding of Berlin.

title: Aquino Government Pleased With Its U.S. Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: City Unwittingly Sold Jewelry of Fake Gold
description: The New York City Police Department, auctioning off confiscated merchandise, has unwittingly been selling fake gold jewelry, the department and the Better Business Bureau said yesterday.

title: ISRAELI IN CASE: FEW FACTS KNOWN
description: Little is known in the United States about the four Israeli officials named today as unindicted co-conspirators in an espionage operation in which a American has pleaded guilty.

title: ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and includes a special tax charge of $55,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary tax benefit of $265,000, or 11 cents a share, for the year.

title: Peso Tumbles In Free Market
description: The value of the peso plunged again today, tumbling to record lows approaching 600 pesos to the dollar on the free market.

title: JUDGE BACKS DISCIPLINE AT INSTITUTE FOR AUTISTIC
description: In a sharply worded ruling, a judge today ordered a Massachusetts state agency not to bar a school for autistic children from using a program of physical punishments as treatment.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The quarter to April 30 and 12 months to April 30 represent 3 months ended April 30 and 12 months ended April 30, respectively. The results have been restated.

title: Advertising; Presenting Of Effie Awards
description: THE Pizza Hut advertising by Chiat/Day of Los Angeles and New York won the Grand Effie award presented last night by the New York Chapter of the American Marketing Association. Earlier the agency was shocked to learn without warning that it had lost the business of Nike Inc., for which it had done award-winning advertising.

title: G.O.P. VICTOR VOWS TOUGH FIGHT AGAINST CRANSTON
description: Representative Ed Zschau, winner of a 13-way race for the Republican Senate nomination Tuesday, said today that he expected to raise as much as $12 million in an effort to unseat Senator Alan Cranston in November.

title: INTERNATIONAL ROBOMATION- INTELLIGENCE reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Pornography Charged In Rock-Album Poster
description: Five people, including the lead singer of the Dead Kennedys rock band, have been charged with pornography for including a sexually explicit poster with the album ''Frankenchrist.''

title: DARKER SIDE OF U.S.-ISRAELI TIES REVEALED
description: Relations between United States and Israeli intelligence agencies are normally marked by intimate cooperation. But the guilty plea today by Jonathan Jay Pollard, combined with the naming of four Israeli officials as co-conspirators who were not indicted, underlines another facet of the relationship: When the interests of the two nations diverge, they spy on each other.

title: KOCH PANEL OPPOSES COMMERCIAL RENT CONTROL
description: A mayoral panel has submitted its recommendations on commercial rents to Mayor Koch, with the majority coming out against imposing rent controls, but with a small minority sharply disagreeing and favoring new, strong regulations to limit rent increases.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SEE SOVIET ARMS OFFER AIDING 'STAR WARS'
description: Some knowledgeable United States officials say they see an important opportunity in the Soviet offer to begin reductions in strategic nuclear weapons if the United States pledges to observe the antiballistic missile treaty of 1972 for 15 to 20 more years.

title: PROTESTERS IN HAITI DEMAND OUSTER OF SEVERAL IN REGIME
description: A new wave of anti-Government protests broke out here today with demonstrators calling for the removal of one of the three members of the governing military-civilian council and several Cabinet officials.

title: MUSIC: 'LE TAMBOURIN,' BY RANDS
description: THE final concert in the New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons '86'' series, despite that promising title, offered no clearer a view of music's future than those that went before it. There was, however, the New York premiere of Suites Nos. l and 2 of Bernard Rands's ''Tambourin,'' which represented the recent past most honorably and, for the most part, most pleasantly. Actually, the 28-minute piece, each of whose six movements is based in some way on a Van Gogh painting or drawing, went back much of the time in its harmonic idiom and general outlook to post-Debussy Impressionism, to the point of suggesting an engulfed cathedral in the last episode, ''The Church at Arles.''

title: 3 New Clients For Emmerling
description: John Emmerling Inc., which happens to have the same name as its chairman, who does not use the Inc., is announcing three new clients.

title: SWITCHCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The figures reflect the acquisition in February of Spectrum Communications and Electronics Corporation, accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Split on Using Tax Bill Funds
description: Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, and Pete V. Domenici, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, today split on how to use any windfall revenues that would be generated in the 1987 fiscal year by the tax-overhaul bill.

title: Ex-Racer Pleads Guilty
description: The former race car driver John Paul Sr. pleaded guilty yesterday in St. Augustine, Fla., to a state charge of attempted first-degree murder in the wounding of a Federal drug witness. After rejecting a plea-bargaining agreement offered just two weeks ago, Paul, 47 years old, changed his mind five days before his scheduled trial date.

title: BAD PHONE ON JET, BAD SCARE ON GROUND
description: Perhaps it was the pitch of the caller's voice. Perhaps it was the static. But something made the friend on the ground think that Flight 740 had a bomb on board.

title: NUMEREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Bridge: Rare Partnership Sequence From Cavendish Club Pairs
description: A partnership sequence that uses every inch of space is not uncommon: one club-one diamond-one heart-one spade-one no-trump, for example. But for the same thing to happen around the table is very rare.

title: CAIRO'S BARE CUPBOARD: RAMADAN UNSWEETENED
description: The sun dropped like a brilliant orange ball in the evening sky as the three soldiers waited on the parapets of the citadel built by Saladin in the 12th century.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $469,000 for the quarter and $1,902,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $334,000 for the quarter and $909,000 for the year and a gain of $785,000 on insurance recovery for the quarter and the year. The share earnings figures are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in February 1986.

title: Before Liftoff, Warnings of Ice
description: Ninety minutes before the space shuttle Challenger was destroyed Jan. 28, rocket engineers likened the scene at the launching pad to ''Dr. Zhivago,'' according to a network news broadcast tonight.

title: Enserch Partners Cuts Gas Sales
description: Enserch Exploration Partners Ltd. said that it would reduce its natural gas sales on the spot market by 100 million cubic feet a day, or 30 percent, awaiting higher prices. The announcement comes after similar moves by the Pennzoil Company, which reduced sales by 225 million cubic feet a day, or 50 percent, and the Coastal Corporation, which curtailed its south Texas production by 53 percent.

title: MARCUS SCHLOSS OFFICER INITIATED INSIDER INQUIRY
description: The purported insider-trading ring for which five young Wall Street professionals were indicted last week came to light in March, when Arthur Ainsberg, the compliance officer at Marcus Schloss & Company, told Federal authorities that Andrew Solomon, an arbitrage analyst at the firm, was using inside information.

title: Creating a New Breed of Bounty Hunters
description: To the Editor:

title: Henson at the Pole
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI AIDE LACKS WALDHEIM PROOF
description: The Israeli Justice Minister said today that the Government had been unable to turn up any firm evidence that Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General, personally took part in atrocities while he was an officer in the German Army in World War II.

title: The U.N. Today; June 5, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: AQUINO CHALLENGES NATION
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that the theme of her presidency had been freedom, and she challenged her countrymen, saying, ''What are you going to do for your country in the second 100 days?''

title: BROWNING'S 1-HITTER TOPS CUBS FOR REDS
description: Tom Browning pitched a one-hitter - a second-inning single by Jody Davis -and struck out a career-high nine tonight in leading the Cincinnati Reds past the Chicago Cubs, 2-0.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 11
Shahrastani Takes Derby
description: Shahrastani held off Dancing Brave, the 2-1 favorite, by a head in a late sprint today to win the $511,000 Epsom Derby. Shahrastani, owned by the

title: VALEDICTORIANS GATHER AND THE MIND BOGGLES For Him, It's Cap Weather At the Convention Center
description: Vartan Gregorian was a high school valedictorian. Isaac Asimov was not.

title: School Lesson About Steroids
description: Adolescence being a time of quick growth, it's hardly surprising when a teen-age boy sprouts up a couple of inches within a few months and begins to develop the heft and the manly physique to go along with his new height. But when a 5-foot-9-inch high school student goes from 135 pounds to 185 from the start of the fall semester to the middle of the spring without adding an inch in height, there are suspicions that his normal development might be getting a little help -specifically, given the times, from anabolic steroids.

title: BIFLYX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of stock of $36,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $61,000 for the quarter and $72,000 for the 9 months. The 9 months net loss also includes a gain on the sale of stock of $100,000.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bruce Sutter of the Atlanta Braves, who was placed on the 21-day disabled list last Sunday because of tendinitis in his right shoulder, said he feared that he might not be able to pitch again until the second half of the season. . . . In balloting that ended Monday, four new members were elected to the National Track and Field Hall of Fame: Bob Seagren, the 1968 Olympic pole vault champion; Barney Ewell, a 1948 Olympic gold medalist in the 400-meter relay; Ron Laird, who scored 65 career race-walk victories over three decades, and Andy Bakjian, an official who died last February. The four will be inducted in ceremonies Dec. 6 at The Athletics Congress convention in Tampa, Fla. . . . Hubie Brooks and Jeff Reardon of the Montreal Expos were named the National League's player and pitcher of the month for May.

title: A CELEBRATION AT THE JOHNSON ESTATE
description: A beaming Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the long court battle over her husband's will behind her, held a small victory celebration today at Jasna Polana, her 140-acre Princeton estate, and gave a handful of visitors a glimpse of life among the rich - the very, very rich.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
BECKER BOWS TO PERNFORS AT FRENCH OPEN
description: With a couple of creative definitions, the United States today could claim two of the four male semifinalists at the French Open, which no American man has won since 1955.

title: Nicklaus Jr. Gains In British Golf
description: Jack Nicklaus Jr. advanced in his quest for the only major golfing title to elude his father when he survived the opening day of match play at the British Amateur today.

title: Something New Out of Africa
description: Unanimous resolutions of the United Nations are usually meaningless. An exception is the landmark document on Africa's economic calamities just approved by the General Assembly. It forsakes jargon about New International Orders and neocolonialism to address, in practical terms, the need for self-help, price incentives, reforestation and monetary reforms. It speaks positively even of ''the private sector.'' It's an approach that Americans can applaud, and nourish.

title: Bank Agency Resignation
description: Donald I. Hovde, a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said yesterday that he would leave his position on Aug. 31, after three years at the bank board. He is the second member of the the three-member board to announce plans to leave.

title: 'Beatlemania' Ordered To Pay $10 Million
description: Superior Court Judge Paul Breckenridge today ordered producers of the ''Beatlemania'' stage show and film to pay Apple Corps Ltd. $10 million.

title: MITCHELL'S HIT IN 8TH TURNS BACK PADRES
description: The Mets have not kept it a secret, but apparently no one has told the San Diego Padres that Dave Johnson disdains the sacrifice bunt.

title: Baby Is Reconsidered For Heart Transplant
description: A hospital is reconsidering its refusal to list the infant son of unwed parents as a heart transplant candidate, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Senate TV and Jobs
description: The introduction of television coverage in the Senate is not being greeted with unanimous approval.

title: DANCE: 'EL PENITENTE,' BY GRAHAM
description: ''EL PENITENTE'' is a bold, stark little trio whose departure point is the Penitentes of the Southwest and the public rites of purification through penance practiced by the sect. First performed in 1940, ''El Penitente'' seems to be one of Martha Graham's simplest dances, an almost bustling sequence of 10 brief scenes of piety and play, as they might have been enacted by traveling players of other times. But a performance of the trio by the Martha Graham Dance Company on Tuesday at City Center, when it re-entered the repertory after a nine-year absence in a revival dedicated to the Arizona State University Centennial, suggested that that simplicity is somewhat deceptive.

title: On Snowmobiles
description: The President's Commission on Americans Outdoors is just finishing a nationwide examination of outdoor recreation - what's good, what's bad, what's safe or unsafe, what should be promoted - and its chapter on snowmobiling should contain some unexpectedly exciting reading.

title: LOFT FOR VINTAGE FURNITURE
description: STANLEY COREN, right, has expanded his store, the Beige Gallery, at 119 Greenwich Avenue, to include a loft, one block away, in which he displays his collections of furniture from the 1940's, 50's and 60's.

title: POP: RALPH CARTER, SINGER
description: RALPH CARTER, the 24-year-old actor and singer who achieved national attention on the television series ''Good Times,'' is a pop-soul balladeer whose stylistic polish exceeds his limited vocal resources. Mr. Carter, who is appearing at Sweetwater's (170 Amsterdam Avenue, at 67th Street) through June 7, has a light baritone that can be agreeable when his voice is relaxed enough not to sound pinched and artificially manufactured.

title: PHILIPPINE MILITARY CHIEF ASSERTS THE REBELS HAVE RESUMED FIGHT
description: The chief of the Philippines armed forces said today that Communist rebels had taken advantage of the ''liberal atmosphere'' of the new Government of President Corazon C. Aquino to resume their armed activities and extend their local influence.

title: Libya Rules Elaborated
description: American businesses still operating in Libya are being told by the United States Government that they may continue negotiating the sale of their assets after the June 30 deadline for ceasing all operations there.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $312,000 for the quarter and $5,659,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income and includes a tax benefit of $384,000 for the quarter.

title: PRODUCTS TO HELP THE OLD AND ABLE
description: Fears of falling in the shower and the frustration of hunting for light switches in the dark need not number among the worries for octogenarians living on their own.

title: SHEETS AND A SPLASH OF COLOR CAN BRING THE SUMMER INDOORS
description: AS the days grow sultry, even with air-conditioning, rooms that looked warm and cozy in winter can seem oppressive. Thick rugs, dark colors and plush upholstery feel hot and stuffy. Summer sleight of hand is needed to transform a winter room into one that is casual, bright and airy.

title: Alf Gundersen Is Dead at 87; Developed Prostate Surgery
description: Alf Gundersen, former president of the Gundersen Clinic and the developer of a prostate treatment, died Sunday at his home here. He was 87 years old.

title: STRIVING BUT STILL LAGGING: PUERTO RICANS WONDER WHY
description: A series of studies released in the last year showing that Puerto Ricans lag behind other Hispanic groups in virtually every major index of economic and social progress has provoked a heated debate in New York's Puerto Rican community, the largest in the United States, over why they have failed to make economic strides.

title: TEXT OF THE GOVERNMENT'S SUMMARY OF ITS ESPIONAGE CASE AGAINST POLLARD
description: Following is the text of a statement, entitled a Factual Proffer, presented by the Federal Government in Federal District Court here today summarizing the facts it was prepared to prove against Jonathan Jay Pollard on a charge of conspiracy to commit espionage:

title: Advertising; People
description: * Marion Flores has been elected an executive vice president of the Bloom Companies, and Hal Goluboff and James V. Clarke have been named senior vice president-associate creative directors of the Bloom Agency, New York.

title: CONCERT: GRAND PIANO AND HIGH WIRE
description: PHILIPPE PETIT had danced around the spires of Notre Dame Cathedral, walked between the twin towers of the World Trade Center and tiptoed across the Passaic River. And last night, Mr. Petit helped the Cathedral of St. John the Divine celebrate its 100th birthday by stepping, climbing, prancing and somersaulting high above an audience of nearly 1000 spectators, to musical accompaniment by Paul Winter and Evelyne Crochet.

title: THE G.O.P. GOES BACK TO NATURE
description: Because it was vigorously opposed by the White House, legislation to control acid rain appeared all but dead for the duration of the Reagan Administration. Recently, however, an acid rain bill has risen like a phoenix in the House of Representatives and is starting to move through the legislative process.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Woman, 87, Murdered In West 57th St. Home
description: An 87-year-old woman was found stabbed to death last night in her apartment on West 57th Street where she lived alone, the police reported.

title: For Him, It's Cap Weather At the Convention Center
description: Thomas F. Galvin gave a situation report yesterday on the air-conditioning at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Medication Plays a Real Role in Psychotherapy
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: SETA KARAKASHIAN
description: BECAUSE few pianists ever range significantly beyond the conventional repertory in search of recital material, Seta Karakashian deserves credit for having devised a program of works by Carlos Seixas, Arthur Farwell, Charles Alkan and Tchaikovsky for her appearance at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night.

title: Victory Markets Turns Down Offer
description: Victory Markets Inc., a New York State supermarket chain, rejected an offer of $30 a share, or about $54 million, from LNC Industries Proprietary Ltd.

title: Water Tests in State Offices Find Permissible Lead Levels
description: Partial results of new tests of drinking water in state offices in four buildings at the World Trade Center have found no unacceptable traces of lead, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: BETWIXT AND BETWEEN A TABBY AND A TIGER
description: S. Bruce Smart Jr. is an unusual ''hit man.''

title: Allergy Kills Brown Student
description: Chili thickened with peanut butter caused a severe allergic reaction that killed an 18-year-old Brown University freshman in February, an autopsy completed Monday confirmed.

title: Ali Must Defend
description: Now, nobody is saying that Muhammad Ali looks anything like a kiwi bird, not even in profile on the cover of Muhammad Ali's Champion Brand shoe polish. But the way the folks at the Kiwi shoe polish company see it, even allowing for certain differences between the picture of the flightless New Zealand bird on their cans and the picture of the former heavyweight champion of the world on his cans, Ali's round shoe polish cans bear a remarkable resemblance to Kiwi's round shoe polish cans.

title: PLANNING THE TASKS OF JUNE
description: WHILE the early bulbs and flowering shrubs have finished blooming, the extended daylight hours make this a good month for ongoing terrace and backyard gardening tasks.

title: Medication Plays a Real Role in Psychotherapy
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Baseball
description: The 5-foot-11-inch, 145-pound Will, responding favorably to Steinbrenner's interest: ''My aim in life is to be known as Stretch.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Control Data Corp., Minneapolis, a computer systems and peripheral products concern, appointed John K. Buckner executive vice president and chief financial officer, replacing Marvin Rogers in the latter post.

title: WHERE SEARS HAS STUMBLED
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, has pushed hard in recent years to persuade its huge customer base to use its new brokerage and real estate businesses. But in seeking to diversify beyond shirts, stoves and stereos, many analysts say, Sears has paid too little attention to its roots and left the retailing foundation of its empire vulnerable.

title: Restorers of Gracie Mansion Earn No Preferential Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORT PREDICTS DECLINE IN NEW U.S. HOUSEHOLDS
description: The Census Bureau has estimated that Americans will slow their rate of forming new households by the end of the century because the baby-boom generation is maturing and there are already fewer young people to set up homes of their own.

title: HBO and Warner Sign Film Deal
description: Time Inc.'s Home Box Office and Warner Brothers Inc., a division of Warner Communications Inc., have signed an agreement that would give Home Box Office, the nation's largest pay-television service, the rights to Warner Brothers' films for the next five years.

title: U.S. Sued Over Chemical In Decaffeinated Coffee
description: Two consumer groups filed suit today in Federal District Court in an effort force the Food and Drug Administration to begin procedures that would ban a possible cancer-causing chemical used in making decaffeinated coffee.

title: Louisiana Authority Sets Education Bonds
description: The Louisiana Public Facilities Authority is offering $100 million in higher education revenue assistance bonds due in 1996 and priced at par to yield 9.95 percent, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: RATES RISE SHARPLY ON BILLS, BONDS
description: Short-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday as comments by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, about potential problems on the inflation front injected new anxiety into an already battered credit market.

title: 9 7/8% Sonat Notes
description: Sonat Inc., a diversified energy company, yesterday began offering $200 million of 9 7/8 percent notes at a price of par, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.&P.

title: F.D.A. TO APPROVE INTERFERON FOR USE AGAINST RARE CANCER
description: The Federal Government will approve a type of interferon for commercial use against a rare form of cancer, the first time the genetically produced antiviral drug will be available by prescription, a drug company said today.

title: SAN ANTONIO FLOODED BY RECORD RAIN
description: A record-breaking deluge coming after almost a week of intermittent rain caused widespread flooding today and forced the evacuation of about 250 families people throughout this city and surrounding areas.

title: Advertising; Del Laboratories Adds TBWA to Its Roster
description: Del Laboratories of Farmingdale, L.I., which spends about $10 million a year on advertising, announced yesterday that it was adding TBWA Advertising to its agency roster.

title: NORTHWEST POWER SETTLEMENT SOUGHT
description: A settlement may be possible in efforts to resolve the tangled Federal litigation surrounding the Washington Public Power Supply System's $2.25 billion default in July 1983, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: LAWRENCE J. FRIEDMAN
description: Lawrence J. Friedman, former dean of the Los Angeles Psychoanalytic Institute and author of ''How Much Pleasure, How Much Pain?'' died at his home here May 28 of bone cancer.

title: U.S. Stance On the Dollar
description: The United States did not intervene to support the dollar for its own account in the foreign exchange markets during the three months ended April 30, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

title: SHULTZ ENDORSES AQUINO'S GOVERNMENT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz yesterday strongly endorsed President Corazon C. Aquino's Government in the Philippines and urged American businessmen and financial circles to support its ''comprehensive reforms.''

title: U.S. Shelter Funds Bring End to Hunger Strike
description: The White House issued a statement today saying that it would release emergency Federal funds to repair a shelter for the homeless, prompting an activist, Mitch Snyder, to end a four-day hunger strike.

title: SOUTHAMPTON GARDEN CONFERENCE 4:2.6>
description: Whether an experienced horticulturist or weekend weeder, a gardener can further the possibilities of his or her landscape with a visit to the Parrish Art Museum on 25 Jobs Lane, Southampton, L.I., the week of June 7-14 for a special presentation, ''Landscape Pleasures: Designers Collaborate with Nature.'' The museum's 1.6-acre arboretum will be the stage for landscape designers and the exhibition of a variety of flowering and woody plants. Along with the 250 trees and shrubs, several of which are the largest specimens on Long Island, that make up the formal gardens of the Parrish, there will be exhibits of unusual flowering plants and rare and slow-growing trees from local nurseries.

title: It's Happening in Monterrey
description: They take off their shirts in public and fry their white skin until it is the color of the red on the Union Jack. Some of them parade through the streets in shorts made of their national flag and some of them wear fetching chartreuse tights and little else.

title: STUARTS DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
MOSCOW SAYS U.S. DECISION DIMS CHANCES FOR MEETING
description: The Soviet Union said today that President Reagan's decision to go beyond negotiated limits in nuclear weapons undermined the entire arms-control process and diminished the chances for a summit meeting in 1986.

title: Option Plea Expected
description: The major options exchanges intend to ask the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve liberalized guidelines for selecting stocks on which options can be traded, industry sources said yesterday.

title: FINANCES ARE FOCUS OF SPY TRIAL
description: Prosecutors in the trial of Jerry A. Whitworth, a former Navy radioman accused of passing classified military data to a Soviet spy ring, today presented a summary of the defendant's financial dealings.

title: Minneapolis Candidate Freed of Twinkie Charge
description: Charges were dismissed today against a 71-year-old City Council candidate who had been accused of handing out $31 worth of Twinkies, Ho Ho's and coffee to elderly voters.

title: Dow Off 7.14; Volcker Remark Cited
description: Stock prices dropped moderately on Wall Street yesterday and trading volume remained weak as investors, worried about a statement on inflation made by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, decided that it was time to take profits.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes currency losses of $602,000 for the quarter and $1,879,000 for the 9 months and a provision of $14,189,000 for the quarter and 9 months for losses on the sale of European Trailer operations and discontinuance of rail service operations. The 9 months net loss also included an extraordinary charge of $480,000. c-Net income and includes currency gains of $135,000 for the quarter and $256,000 for the 9 months. The company said its latest third quarter results provide for estimated pre-tax income of $11 million and an after-tax loss of about $4 million from the anticipated sale of Gelco Tip Europe. The results also include a pre- tax charge of $11 million to establish a reserve for losses on the disposal of rail services equipment and for costs of closing the rail services operations. The resulting after-tax charge, including the effect of a reversal of $4.3 million investment tax credit, was $10.2 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JUNE 5, 1986
description: International

title: BOTNICK'S ROLE CALLED IMPROPER
description: An independent health-planning agency that serves New York City chose a new executive director last night amid charges that the choice was illegal and represented a move by the Koch administration to control the agency.

title: KEY NASA ROCKET OFFICIAL QUITS
description: The head of the Marshall Space Flight Center, which supervises rocket construction for the space agency, said yesterday that he was resigning to make room for a successor who will help redesign the American space program.

title: INTERCARE INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
CABARET: WARREN AEVON
description: OVER the last decade, the West Coast singer-songwriter Warren Zevon has carved a special niche for himself in rock as the thinking man's wastrel. Most of Mr. Zevon's best-known songs are subversive, darkly funny celebrations of the would-be soldier of fortune that exists in many of us.

title: Sikhs at Golden Temple Kill Guard and Wound 7
description: About 200 Sikh militants rampaged through the Golden Temple today after a ''Martyrs' Day'' rally, killing one volunteer guard with a sword and wounding seven. Authorities said 79 people were arrested for questioning.

title: Lax Pursuit of Reckless Bikers
description: The bicycle - compact, agile and non-polluting - ought to be a welcome addition to New York City's transit mix. But the proliferation of cycling commuters and messengers adds a lethal volatility to the urban scene.

title: INNOVATIVE INTERIOR DESIGNER
description: Michael Taylor, an influential American interior designer, died of spinal meningitis Tuesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 59 years old.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ISSUES AN ORDER BARRING SOWETO OBSERVANCES
description: The South African authorities today outlawed any commemorations from now until June 30 of the 1976 uprisings in Soweto, Johannesburg's sprawling black satellite city.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Portugal Has Problems, But So Does the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: 'STILL SEPARATE, STILL UNEQUAL' ON 13
description: TONIGHT at 8:30, in one of its most telling programs this season, ''Currents,'' the earnest weekly public television series on WNET/Channel 13 that often discovers worms in the metropolitan New York apple, looks at what has happened to the schools since the 1954 Supreme Court decision in Brown v. Board of Education. The landmark ruling held that separate but equal schools were inherently unequal and should be desegregated ''with all deliberate speed.''

title: End to Miller Trial Seen Near
description: Testimony in the retrial of Richard W. Miller, the first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to be charged with espionage will end this week and jurors will begin deliberating after hearing final arguments next week, according to Federal District Judge David Kenyon. Mr. Miller's first trial ended in a jury deadlock last November, and his retrial began in January. A former receptionist for a doctor who treated Svetlana Ogorodnikov, charged along with Mr. Miller, said there was no record of Mrs. Ogorodnikov having an abortion in 1984, as she had said.

title: Shultz's Chernobyl Lesson
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told a group of European visitors today that the Chernobyl disaster underscored the need for a reduction in nuclear warheads sought by the United States. He said he had been told that radioactive fallout from the power plant accident was equivalent to that caused by one warhead on a nuclear weapon such as the American MX or the Soviet SS-18.

title: U.S. ACCUSES POLAND
description: The Reagan Administration accused Poland today of making ''trumped-up charges'' that the United States had kept from Solidarity leaders secret information about the impending imposition by Polish authorities of martial law in December 1981.

title: CONCERT: TREBLE ENSEMBLE
description: THE New York Treble Singers, under direction of Virginia Davidson, is an ensemble of 12 women dedicated to exploring the repertory of music for treble voices. Although its Tuesday evening program at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Chapel seemed rather artificially compartmentalized - it was titled ''Love's Labels'' and divided into sections called ''Love of God,'' ''Women in Love,'' ''Love of Work,'' ''Gershwin Songs of Love,'' even ''Purcell in Love'' - there were enough musical rewards to keep one's attention.

title: Of 'Yackers' and 'Mooches'
description: The term ''grip-and-grin'' is but one of many coming out of Washington that could enrich a dictionary of modern English usage. The other day, for example, the American Association of Retired Persons warned its members against being victimized by ''yackers'' preying on ''mooches.''

title: MAYOR VETOES CHANGES IN LAW ON HOMOSEXUALS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday vetoed an amendment to the city's homosexual rights law that would have increased the number of dwellings exempt from the law.

title: NATIONAL HMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FIRE SWEEPS TERMINAL MARKET
description: Fire swept through a large portion of the Bronx Terminal Market yesterday evening, causing extensive damage and forcing the market to close today.

title: U.S. PREPARING DRUG DRIVE ALONG THE MEXICAN BORDER
description: Hundreds of Federal officers will be sent to the Mexican border to take part in a major new effort to combat what the Treasury Department is calling a ''crisis'' in drug and arms trafficking, illegal immigration and related criminal activity, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: HIGH RENT DISTRICT: ROOM WITH A JULY 4 VIEW
description: Alan McCord's seventh-floor loft on West Street has huge windows, access to the roof and a direct view of the Statue of Liberty. He has rented it out for July 4 for $25,000.

title: A Divided Society
description: Rich, poor, north, south, public, private: the contrasts are stark in Britain today. It is an extraordinarily divided society.

title: Jersey Scofflaw Drive Finds Mayor's Tickets
description: A drive to rid this community of parking ticket scofflaws has snared Mayor Paul Monacelli and his wife, Roseanne, who over the past 18 months had ignored 75 tickets they had accumulated with three different cars.

title:
WHERE THE SIX-DAY WAR HAS LEAD;
Paralyzing Hostility
description: The 19 years since Israel took possession of the West Bank and Gaza, during the Six-Day War, have brought to light a disturbing symmetry between Israelis and Palestinians. The similarity does not lie in the conditions under which each exists - one people has a state of its own, the other does not - but in their attitudes, in their perceptions of themselves and of each other. It is a symmetry that goes to the depths of their souls.

title: A Stubborn Swath On Brooklyn Bridge
description: Admirers of the Brooklyn Bridge were startled, and agitated, by the appearance over a month ago of broad swath of yellow paint splashed on the base of the granite Brooklyn tower.

title: ITT Rate Plan
description: The ITT Corporation said that its long-distance telephone subsidiary, U.S. Transmission Systems, will reduce its rates by up to 21 percent on July 1. ITT said rates for its Longer Distance service and Preferred Calling would be reduced by as much as 16 percent and rates for some of its SMART-WATS services would be cut by 21 percent.

title: STAR TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
3 STATES IN REGION SHOW JOB GROWTH
description: A new study of employment in the 1980's shows that although the West and South are still leading the rest of the nation in job gains, some older industrial states are moving far ahead of others in their regions.

title: O'NEILL AND CHINA, STRANGE INTERLUDE
description: Liu Haiping, a gentle, 42 year-old Chinese specialist on Eugene O'Neill, is still somewhat incredulous. Last month a Chinese provincial troupe put on a production of O'Neill's ''Desire Under the Elms'' in Shanghai.

title: AMERICAN AIRCRAFT reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Comparisons with the year-ago period were not meaningful because the company acquired its two operating subsidiaries in October 1985.

title: NIEKRO AND HOLLAND YIELD ONE HIT AS YANKS GET 18
description: Joe Niekro, the Yankees' 41-year-old pitcher, came within four outs tonight of his first no-hitter, but it was spoiled by Gary Pettis's two-out double in the eighth inning. Niekro then settled for a one-hit, 11-0 victory over the California Angels.

title: PRIMARIES POINT TO BATTLES FOR STATE CONTROL
description: The results of Tuesday's primary voting point toward pitched battles this fall in California, Alabama and South Dakota that figure heavily in party strategies in the fight for control of the Senate, political experts said today.

title: Good - and Better - in Queens
description: When Joseph Addabbo was first elected to Congress 25 years ago, his southeast Queens district held fewer than 400,000 people, mostly lower-middle-class whites. By the time of his death last April, he had risen to be chairman of the House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee and the district had been transformed in character. The population is now more than half a million; whites are about 35 percent. More than half are black, mostly homeowners like the whites they succeeded; the remainder are mainly Asians and Hispanics. The changes are manifest in the number of qualified candidates running in Tuesday's special election to fill Mr. Addabbo's seat until the regular election in November.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about Mexico's victory in World Cup soccer misidentified the group in which the team plays. It is in Group B, with Belgium, Iraq and Paraguay.

title: POWERTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
U.S. TRAVEL TO EUROPE IS REBOUNDING
description: Major international airlines and some domestic travel agents say they have seen a resurgence in bookings to Europe in the last several weeks, as travelers apparently overcome their fears of terrorism.

title: LTV Picks Unit's Chief For One of Its Top Posts
description: The LTV Corporation, an aerospace, steel and energy company, said yesterday that it had named Robert L. Kirk president and chief operating officer.

title: PLANNING THE TASKS OF JUNE
description: JUNE belongs to the roses. To keep rosebushes in tiptop shape all summer, don't delay use of a rose spray, every week to 10 days. It should contain an insecticide (for Japanese beetles) and a fungicide (for black spot). Since rosebushes are heavy feeders, give one last application of fertilizer - a scant handful per plant - to stimulate a good crop of flowers in September.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $16,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: PELTON JURY DELIBERATES FOR SIX HOURS
description: The jury in the espionage trial of Ronald W. Pelton deliberated for more than six hours tonight but retired without reaching a verdict.

title: MONTREAL HEARING HELD FOR 5 SIKHS
description: Five Sikhs charged with conspiring to possess explosives with intent to injure appeared today at an open hearing in provincial court here, and the presiding judge agreed to a defense request that no information about the proceedings be published or broadcast.

title: WALTON ENJOYS RARE FEELING
description: Even after his most fulfilling moment in the past nine long and painful seasons, Bill Walton said he still did not think he had been accepted as a full-fledged member of the Boston Celtics.

title: West Coast Bank Shift
description: The Bank of America, in a restructuring of its wholesale lending, investment banking and corporate payment services, today announced the addition of Richard T. Griffith and Jamie B. Stewart Jr. to the bank's world banking division.

title: No Peace for Afghans
description: Afghan resistance groups are working on a plan to call an assembly of all the forces opposing the Soviet-backed Kabul Government and to choose a leader, according to Prof. Sibgatullah Modjadeddi. He flew from Peshawar, Pakistan, to attend an international conference here on conditions of a political solution for his country. He said the effort should be completed before winter.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies of Metropolitan Report yesterday about District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman's testimony before the city-state Commission on Integrity in Government omitted a key paragraph and thus misstated the nature of legislation called for by Miss Holtzman and other prosecutors. The legislation would give them powers similar to their Federal counterparts in granting limited immunity for grand jury testimony, would broaden the legal definitions of bribery and influence peddling and would let them use the uncorroborated testimony of accomplices to crimes. Legislation to enact many of these changes was proposed by Governor Cuomo earlier this year but has been blocked in the Democratic-led Assembly.

title: BALLET: KIROV AT WOLFTRAP
description: Absence makes the heart grow fonder.

title: 60-Second Debate; Should the Government withhold funds from states that refuse to raise their minimum drinking age to 21 by Oct. 1?
description: NORMA PHILLIPS, National president of Mothers Against Drunk Driving.

title: Hanover Bank Officer Quits
description: Garry R. Southern, senior vice president in the merchant banking group of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, has resigned as a result of policy differences, the bank said yesterday.

title: Time and Science '86
description: Time Inc. is considering acquiring Science '86, a magazine published by the American Association for the Advancement of Science, according to sources familiar with the talks. No price was disclosed. Time already owns Discover, which (like most science magazines) has lost advertising.

title: Mets Change Training Site
description: The Mets, whose spring training base in St. Petersburg has been shared with St. Louis since the Mets' inception in 1962, announced formally today that they would shift their spring headquarters to Port Saint Lucie in 1988.

title: IF LENGTH WERE ALL, OR, WHY A 10 1/2-HOUR PLAY?
description: PLEASURE is pleasure and pain is pain, but sometimes pleasure passes through pain to a higher level of pleasure. Or so, at least, was my theory when I decided to subject myself to two 10 1/2-hour plays in French on consecutive days.

title: Report on Voting On Anderson Bid
description: A source close to the heirs of the Clayton family fortune said that all voting members of the family, which controls 55 percent of the common shares of Anderson, Clayton & Company, had voted in favor of a $451 million recapitalization plan favored by management.

title: STRONGER YEN SQUEEZES JAPAN
description: Here, where exporting has long been equated with survival, the strength of the yen has become a national obsession.

title: A CHILEAN EXILE RETURNS IN DISGUISE
description: Angered to find he was listed among 5,000 Chileans permanently exiled by the Pinochet Government, the film director Miguel Littin went home in disguise last year and spent six weeks making a lengthy documentary about contemporary Chile.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The stuccoed wall in our family room has been stained by smoke from an oil lamp and a coal stove. How can we remove the stains without smearing and if we can't, how should we prepare the surface for repainting? A. First use a vacuum to remove as much of soot and soil as you can, then wash the wall with a strong detergent, preferably one containing TSP (trisodium phosphate).

title: LAROUCHE SLATE IS BADLY BEATEN IN JERSEY RACES
description: Candidates allied with Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. and running under the slogan ''F.D.R. Democrats'' failed to capture any party nominations for Congress in primary elections Tuesday in New Jersey and ran far behind the Democratic Party regulars they challenged.

title: Technology; Electronic Imaging Gains
description: FOUR years ago, the Sony Corporation introduced an electronic still camera that enabled a photographer to take a picture, view it on a television screen at home and, if desired, make a print on the spot.

title: Talking Peace
description: George Steinbrenner, after the Yankees had been granted an extra amateur-draft pick - the political columnist George Will - in a gag arranged by Will's friend Peter Ueberroth: ''We'll offer him whatever it takes. On road trips, he and I and Billy Martin can talk about nonaggression pacts. Maybe he can explain all those things to Billy.''

title: JAZZ: BENNY CARTER QUINTET
description: ONE of the fascinations of hearing Benny Carter these days is that, after more than 50 years as a model of tone and phrasing on the alto saxophone, he cannot be taken for granted. At the Whippoorwill, a warm, attractive new jazz room downstairs from the restaurant Joanna, 18 East 18th Street, where he is leading a quintet through Sunday, Mr. Carter is not living in his past but is still building on it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 5, 1986
description: Markets

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh, 7:35 P.M. The Mets visit Three Rivers Stadium for a four-game weekend series. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Padres vs. Atlanta Braves, at San Diego. (Television - WTBS, 10:05 P.M.) College World Series, at Omaha. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Basketball Rockets vs. Boston Celtics, at Houston. Fifth game of N.B.A. Finals. The Celtics looking for their 16th championship took a 3-1 lead in the series Tuesday night. (Television - Channel 2, 9 P.M.) Boxing Michael (the Silk) Olajide, vs. Randy Smith, middleweights, 10 rounds at the Felt Forum. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M.) Golf Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, at the Westchester Country Club, Harrison, N.Y., opening round, 7:30 A.M. McDonald's Championships, at White Manor Country Club, Malvern, Pa. Opening round of L.P.G.A. event. British Masters, at Woburn, Scotland. Soccer World Cup. Italy vs. Argentina, at Puebla, 2 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 2 P.M. Channel 41, 1:45 P.M. live); Bulgaria vs. South Korea, at Mexico City, 6 P.M. (Television - Channel 41, 5:45 P.M. live); France vs. Soviet Union, 2 P.M. (Television - Channel 41, 11 P.M., tape.) Tennis French Open, at Paris, women's semifinals. Chris Evert Lloyd vs.

title: URUGRAY TIED, 1-1, BY WEST GERMANY
description: West Germany, which gave up an easy goal after only four minutes, drew even with six minutes remaining today to tie Uruguay, 1-1, in a battle between two former two-time World Cup winners.

title: ON LADIES' MILE, HOMESTEADERS AMID PAST GLORY >
description: THROUGH panoramic windows in their third-story living room, Jane and John Stubbs enjoy a view that stretches from 18th Street north along Broadway and from the present day back to the Gilded Age, into the heart of Ladies' Mile. Daytime visitors to Stubbs

title: A Meerkat Mistake
description: For its April issue, Smithsonian magazine had considered running a cover picture of 10 meerkats that, except for the fur on their bodies and the sand under their feet, looked something like a covey of commuters wondering where their Long Island Rail Road train was.

title: MAY 21-31 AUTO SALES DOWN 10.9%
description: Sales of domestically produced automobiles fell 10.9 percent in the May 21-31 period from the final 10 days of the month last year, the seven major manufacturers reported here today. Sales of light trucks in the period were stronger, however, up 7 percent from the comparable period last year, bringing total light-vehicle sales, including cars and light trucks, to 416,936, a decline of 6 percent from 1985.

title: BRANIFF INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income after a tax benefit of $700,000.

title: QUINONES SETS UP MINIMUMS FOR PERFORMANCE BY SCHOOLS
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones yesterday announced a set of minimum academic and attendance standards that he said all city schools must meet or face possible closing.

title: Fall Guys
description: How about those standings? The Cardinals, the Dodgers, the Blue Jays and the Royals will probably all escape the fate of the 1915 Philadelphia Athletics - the only team in modern major league history that plunged to a last-place finish after winning a league or division title the year before - but they remain candidates to join a select group. In terms of games won, these are the dozen worst one-season form reversals by clubs that failed to defend their crown:

title: President Adds Jobs At American Home
description: John R. Stafford, president of the American Home Products Corporation, was named yesterday to assume the additional titles of chairman and chief executive, effective Dec. 1.

title: KIN TOLD OF SHUTTLE FINDINGS
description: William P. Rogers, chairman of the Presidential commission investigating the space shuttle disaster, met at an undisclosed place here this morning with members of the families of the seven astronauts who died in the destruction of the Challenger.

title: Yields Are Mixed
description: Yields on certificates of deposit rose slightly, while bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds yields slipped in the week ended yesterday.

title: REAGAN TO STRESS SENATE CAMPAIGNS
description: President Reagan, campaigning today in a state critical to maintaining Republican control of the Senate, moved away from tying his support of Republican candidates to their backing of his Congressional agenda.

title: PUZO TO DO SCREENPLAY FOR 'GODFATHER, PART III'
description: Mario Puzo has signed a contract to write ''The Godfather, Part III'' for Paramount Pictures.

title: CITY, BOWING TO U.S. WILL PERMIT TANDEM TRUCKS ON CERTAIN ROADS
description: After a long fight with the Federal Government, New York City has agreed to a compromise that will allow tandem trucks on selected roadways at nonrush-hour times, city transportation officials said yesterday.

title: RED SOX WIN 5TH IN ROW, 6-4
description: Don Baylor, Bill Buckner and Rey Quinones hit home runs tonight, leading the Boston Red Sox to their fifth straight victory, a 6-4 decision over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Stop Bullying Mexico
description: For a few escapist days, Mexico can savor its first-round victory in the World Cup matches of which it is host. But the joy is lost on most in the United States, who ignore soccer almost as much as they do Mexico. Few neighbors are at once so close and distant, so tied by geography and divided by economics. Ignorance can explain - but not justify - the sour outbursts in Washington over Mexico's real and imagined misdeeds. Americans are making trouble with the wrong country over the wrong issues at the wrong time.

title: PROGRAM TO CURB FINANCIAL CRIME GAINS IN ALBANY
description: Key lawmakers announced agreement today on legislation to increase substantially the penalties for white-collar crimes.

title: CBS'S 'WEST 57TH FIGHTS TO SURVIVE
description: ''West 57th,'' the CBS News magazine show that has struggled for a year to find a permanent place on the network's prime-time schedule, has faltered badly in the ratings and will be given a final shot beginning next week in a new time period CBS feels is more favorable for the program.

title: Sun Co. Offers 9 3/8% Debentures
description: The Sun Company yesterday began offering $200 million of 9 3/8 percent sinking fund debentures due 2016 at a price of 97.80 to yield 9.60 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: A HANDEL CONCERT ON A&E NETWORK
description: ALTHOUGH he was born in Germany and spent much of his early career in Italy, George Frideric Handel has always been claimed by the British as their own. Indeed, he was Britain's semiofficial composer from the 1720's onward and, as such, naturally had a close association with Westminster Abbey. He wrote anthems for coronations and funerals there, conducted his music in the Abbey on many occasions and, with an audience of some 3,000 spectators, was buried there in 1759.

title: Boeing Order By Piedmont
description: Piedmont Airlines said yesterday that it had ordered 25 of a new type of Boeing 737 aircraft from the Boeing Company and had an option to buy 30 more. If the option is exercised, the order could be worth a total of $1.9 billion.

title: Quaker-Gaines
description: The Quaker Oats Company disclosed it had agreed to pay $7 million to the investment group that is seeking to acquire Anderson, Clayton & Company, if Quaker is allowed to acquire Anderson's Gaines pet food subsidiary before May 1987. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Quaker said that the investment group, which is made up of Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruss & Company, had agreed to pay Quaker $7 million if the group gains control of Anderson and Gaines is sold to a party other than Quaker. Quaker also told the S.E.C. that it had agreed to reimburse the investment group for up to $3 million in expenses.

title: Detroit's Rating Raised by S.&P.
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had upgraded Detroit's credit rating for unlimited general obligation bonds from double B to triple B, in recognition of ''a significant improvement'' in the city's financial condition.

title: Swiss Asylum Limited By Vote in Parliament
description: The upper house of the Swiss Parliament gave final approval today to a series of Government measures widely seen as aimed at restricting the number of refugees who can be granted asylum in Switzerland.

title: AMENDMENTS WAIT IN THE WINGS
description: Several major changes to the Senate Finance Committee's tax bill are expected to be proposed on the Senate floor. Senate Republican leaders are trying to keep the package intact, but a number of senators have said they would press these issues:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BLESSED ASSURANCE: At Home With the Bomb in Amarillo, Texas. By A. G. Mojtabai. 256 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $16.95.

title: CURTAIN UP FOR SENATE TAX DEBATE
description: With one senator after another calling it a historic occasion, the Senate began debate today on legislation that would overhaul the income tax system Congress has assembled piecemeal over decades.

title: FROM CHILDREN OF CHERNOBYL, STORIES OF FLIGHT AND OF FEARS
description: The last thing the children saw as buses took them from their homes in Pripyat was the fire-blackened side of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant and, as 12-year-old Olya Ryazanova said, ''a sort of mist, a misty cloud around it.''

title: POLE SAYS U.S. LEARNED OF PLANS FOR MARTIAL LAW
description: Senior American officials learned in advance from a defecting Polish colonel how and when the Polish authorities planned to impose martial law in 1981, the Polish Government's spokesman said today.

title: K Mart to Use Satellite Links
description: The K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest retailer, agreed to buy a $40 million telecommunications network to improve the efficiency of its marketing and credit-verification operations.

title: A CATHEDRAL CENTENNIAL WITH ART AND AERIALIST
description: The Very Rev. James Parks Morton likes to start his whirlwind tours of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, his cathedral, in the basement - the place that in many ways best expresses his vision of what the cathedral should be in the modern world.

title: HERS
description: ''ALWAYS make the bed before you go out in the kitchen to fix breakfast. (That way, if by some catastrophe you get nothing else done, at least you've done that.)'' ''Never plant nasturtiums in bright sunlight, I don't care what it says on the package.'' ''Artichokes taste best with cold milk.'' ''If you've been shopping in the afternoon, and he likes his dinner at 6, just set the table and put on a can of soup to get some smell going through the house. Then put him in a chair and give him a stiff drink. He won't know the difference.''

title: VOTE WINNER IN SECOND TRY: MAUREEN F. O'CONNOR
description: Maureen F. O'Connor, a former physical education teacher who suffered a bitter mayoral defeat at the hands of Roger Hedgecock in 1983, capped her once-precocious political career Tuesday night with an easy victory and will become the first woman to be Mayor of San Diego.

title: Merger to Create Top Canada Broker
description: Wood Gundy Inc. will merge with the Gordon Capital Corporation to create the largest securities company in Canada, the companies said yesterday in Toronto.

title: DESIGNERS' TIPS FOR THE WARMER MONTHS
description: DECOR changes for summer have traditionally been rooted as much in practicality as in esthetics. As early as the 16th century, bed linens or loose covers were thrown over velvet or brocaded upholstered furniture to protect them from fading under strong summer sunlight. Rugs were rolled up and stored to prevent moth damage, chandeliers were bagged in muslin to ward off dust, and gilt-framed mirrors were draped to prevent flyspecks.

title: COOPER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CALENDAR OF EVENTS: SHOW OF FURNITURE
description: Furniture '86, the Elements Gallery, 14 Liberty Way, between Lewis and Elm Streets, Greenwich, Conn., 203-661-0014.

title: EXXON STAFF CUT BY 15% UNDER VOLUNTARY PLAN
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that nearly 15 percent, or 6,200, of its employees in the United States had decided to leave the company under its voluntary separation program.

title: Drayton Wins Title
description: Buster Drayton won the vacated International Boxing Federation junior middleweight title by a majority decision in the headline bout of a championship tripleheader tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: New Charge On Robins
description: Government attorneys contend that the A.H. Robins Company improperly spent about $20 million after filing for voluntary bankruptcy - nearly triple the original estimate of $7 million.

title: FOR OGYGIAN, PLANS A AND B
description: The big draw for post positions at Belmont Park this morning will be the one for the 118th Belmont Stakes Saturday, but one of equal interest will be for the Colin Stakes on the same card.

title: Navy Competition
description: The Navy has found a second company to produce one of the service's most important antiaircraft missiles, a move that it hopes will save $550 million.

title: Gould Is Sued By Shareholders
description: Gould Inc., a computer products and military systems contractor, said that it had been named in a class action lawsuit filed in Federal District Court over a special charge of $130 million the company took for the first quarter of 1986.

title: NEW WAYS TO KEEP TIES NEAT
description: THERE are many different racks on the market to help keep ties organized. A sleek and modern new rack in chrome or chrome and brass is available at Baldwin Brass, 210 East 60th Street. It has a slim 20-inch bar with posts that measure 1 3/4 inches. Mounting hardware is included in the price of $63.50.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
Tutwiler Wins Seniors'
description: Ed Tutwiler won the 82d annual championship of the United States Seniors' Golf Association today, an event he also won in 1978. Tutwiler, a 1-handicap member of the Crooked Stick Country Club in Indianapolis, added a one-over-par 73 at the Apawamis Club to the par 71 he scored Tuesday at the Round Hill Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Tentative Pact In Atari Suit
description: A California Superior Court judge in Santa Clara County has tentatively approved the settlement of a class action suit brought by more than 500 former employees of Atari Inc., after they were laid off Feb. 22, 1983. The layoffs occurred when the Santa Clara-based company moved its computer and video game operations to Hong Kong and Taiwan.

title: OHRENSTEIN TO BLOCK BILL ON CITY HARBOR FESTIVAL
description: A key State Senator said today that he would hold up passage of legislation crucial to New York City's Fourth of July celebration until city officials came up with an improved plan to handle the millions of spectators expected to descend on lower Manhattan over the holiday weekend.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SUSPENDED ceilings, long familiar in offices and commercial establishments, are gaining acceptance in the home. Since over 90 percent of all those in the home are installed by nonprofessionals, manufacturers have put considerable effort into improving their aluminum grid systems so that the pieces snap together easily and the systems are simple to install.

title: BROADWAY BEATS SUMMER DOLDRUMS
description: Summer - for years Broadway's sluggish off season - will see a burst of activity this year in what some producers point to as a shift in the city's theatrical timetable.

title: Plan to Draw U.S. Retailers
description: Saying that the fear of terrorism is keeping American fashion buyers from Italy, a conglomerate of Italian businesses is expected to announce a plan today to attract retailers back to their country.

title: UNC Offerings
description: UNC Resources is selling $120 million of debt securities, equally divided between 10-year notes and 20-year convertible subordinated debentures, through the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. The 11 1/2 percent notes are offered at a price of 95.741 to yield 12.25 percent, while the issue of 7 1/2 percent debentures is offered at par. Each debenture is convertible into the company's common stock at $15.40 a share. The debentures and notes are rated B-3 by Moody's and B by S.&P.

title: TAX REFUNDS ARE WITHHELD FROM LOAN DEFAULTERS
description: The Government has recovered $135 million from loan defaulters so far this year through a pilot program that permits it to withhold tax refunds from those most delinquent in repaying debts, according to James C. Miller 3d, director of the Office of Management and Budget. Most of the defaulters are former college students.

title: Herbst Sets Mark in 10,000-Meters
description: Stephanie Herbst, a Wisconsin sophomore, won the women's 10,000-meter title in a record run tonight as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 65th annual outdoor track and field championships began.

title: REPORT EXAMINES HOSPITAL TRENDS
description: Nonprofit and investor-owned hospitals offer health care of similar quality, but the proprietary hospitals charge higher prices and provide less charity care, according to a major study issued today by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: EX-ABC EXECUTIVE TELLS OF TV PACTS
description: The relationship of ABC Sports and professional football came under intense scrutiny yesterday as opposing attorneys in the United States Football League's antitrust suit against the National Football League spent the 16th day of the trial questioning a former ABC Sports senior vice president.

title: AT THE ARMS TALKS, NO RIPPLES YET FROM REAGAN'S WORDS
description: Right on schedule - at precisely 11 A.M. - a convoy of six chauffered cars drove through the heavy sliding gates of the United States Mission in a hilly, wooded area here today and disgorged a team of 17 Soviet negotiators for a three-and-a-half-hour session with their American counterparts.

title: No Position to Judge
description: Ahmed Shata of Egypt is a shot-putter at Abilene Christian. Lars Sundin of Sweden is a discus thrower and shot-putter at Brigham Young.

title: TUNEUP FOR OPEN TO BEGIN
description: For the past few years, the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic has served as a solid warm-up for the United States Open, which has been held the following week. The deep and dense rough and fast greens at Westchester Country Club have been similar to what the United States Golf Association has laid out for the golfers in the Open.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aeronca Inc., Charlotte, N.C., said its board had determined that an unsolicited $5-a-share offer made by Fleet Aerospace Corp. on May 21 was inadequate and should be rejected.

title: HOME ELECTRONICS THAT DO IT ALL DEBUT IN CHICAGO
description: The line between electronic gadgets and useful devices for the home seemed somewhat blurred at the Summer Consumer Electronics Show here this week. Among the new products that bordered on the gimmicky were a voice-activiated Butler in a Box that will turn on lights, fans and television sets when its ''master'' orders it. Two of the most useful devices were remote-control units: one will silence a car alarm system from 50 feet away, and another will switch on house lights from a distance of 150 feet.

title: Advertising; Kellogg, Dairy Group In Joint Promotion
description: Among the more healthful commercial tie-ins with Miss Liberty's renovation will be a joint promotion by Kellogg and the American Dairy Association, which go together as naturally as ham and eggs.

title: CRACKING THE WHIP FOR FUN
description: A whip is a perfect prop for George Steinbrenner, who has been known to crack one now and then, not only on those occasions when he is hitching a ride in a sulky behind a pacer. The principal owner of the Yankees almost got into his car with a whip yesterday after taking several spins round the exercise oval at the Meadowlands racetrack. Remember, though, that the Yankees are due home today, following what some handicappers might call a rough trip on the West Coast, so perhaps Steinbrenner wasn't just being forgetful.

title:
WHERE THE SIX-DAY WAR HAS LED;
Time for Autonomy
description: On this 19th anniversary of the beginning of the Six-Day War, a war that resulted in Israel's control of the West Bank, there are no prospects for peace negotiations between Israel and a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. It is therefore crucial that Israel announce without delay that unless such talks begin by the end of 1986, it will singlehandedly implement an autonomy plan in parts of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: MOSLEMS BURY DEAD AND GET FOOD
description: Heavy fighting here eased today, allowing residents of the Moslem sector of the capital to emerge from shelters to bury the dead and buy food.

title: BIG MAGNET AND METAL TOOLS EQUAL NEW MEDICAL HAZARD
description: The powerful magnetism of a large, newly developed medical diagnostic scanner drew part of a fork lift into the device, seriously injuring a technician working inside, a medical journal reported today.

title: A HOME FOR RHODA
description: Rhoda, the rhododendron made homeless last month by a divorce, got a new home yesterday.

title: McEnroe to Return
description: John McEnroe, the third-ranked men's singles player in the world despite a self-imposed exile from tournament tennis that began in January, has agreed to compete in the Norstar Bank Hamlet Challenge Cup at The Hamlet East in Jericho, L.I., Aug. 19-24.

title: HIGH LEVELS OF DIOXIN FOUND AT NIAGARA FALLS
description: Heavy concentrations of dioxin have been found at a chemical plant site in Niagara Falls, N.Y., the Federal Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: READINGS AND WRITINGS The poet and writer Norman Rosten was named poet laureate of Brooklyn - a $1 a-year post - in 1979, primarily, he conceded at the time, because he lives there. He had written no poems on the borough, although one novel, ''Under the Boardwalk,'' was set in Coney Island. Some of his other books include, ''Love in All Its Disguises,'' ''Over and Out'' and his memoir, ''Marilyn: An Untold Story.'' Mr. Rosten's newest novel is ''Neighborhood Tales'' and he will read from it today at the Donnell Library Center (621-0642), 20 West 53d Street, at 6 P.M. Admission is free.

title: Market Place; Cray Soars; Doubts Rise
description: CRAY RESEARCH INC., the nation's leading manufacturer of supercomputers, has shown rapid growth over the last few years - and its stock has reflected this. Many investors, however, wonder how far the stock can go in an increasingly competitive environment.

title: FORMER NAVAL ANALYST AND WIFE PLEAD GUILTY TO SPYING FOR ISRAEL
description: A former United States Navy intelligence analyst pleaded guilty today to spying for Israel, and the Justice Department named four Israelis as unindicted conspirators in his espionage activities.

title: FOCUS OF INQUIRY IS ON ESPOSITO AND DEMOCRATS
description: The Federal authorities have begun a broad investigation of the Brooklyn Democratic organization and are examining relationships between Meade H. Esposito, the party's former county chairman, and reputed organized-crime figures, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Commons Clears Way For Channel Tunnel Bill
description: A project to link England and France by a tunnel under the English Channel cleared a major legislative hurdle in the House of Commons today.

title: Mayor Eastwood Ousts 'Unfriendly' Planners
description: Mayor Clint Eastwood, whose bitter feud with city planners led to his new political career, has struck back by ousting a majority of them.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,197,000 for the latest quarter and $323,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The moment has now arrived. We are on the tax bill, and it is the most radical tax bill the Congress has seen in half a century.''

title: CITY TO CHECK ROOFS FROM AIR
description: Building inspectors will fly over lower Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn and Staten Island in helicopters looking for evidence that commercial buildings are preparing to have July 4 rooftop parties without the proper permits, the Buildings Department said yesterday.

title: INSPECTIONS OF WALDHEIM FILES IN 1970'S REPORTED
description: Austrian, West German and French officials inspected the World War II military records of Kurt Waldheim in the 1970's, when he was in his first term as United Nations Secretary General, according to sources familiar with the documents.

title: Women's Mark In Jump Broken
description: Esmeralda Garcia, a Florida State senior from Brazil, and Terri Turner, a Texas senior, tonight made the two longest triple jumps ever by women.

title: Texas Air Stake
description: Spantax, Spain's charter airline, has agreed in principle to sell a stake, perhaps even a majority stake, to the Texas Air Corporation, a spokesman said.

title: Black Mississippian May Avoid a Runoff
description: A black candidate for the House nomination from the Second Congressional District may be able to avoid a runoff after officials rechecking ballots from Tuesday's primary added 243 votes to his unofficial tally.

title: Extradition Supplement Is More Than an Irish Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Shift by Kikkoman
description: In San Francisco, Kikkoman International, marketer of Japanese sauces and spices, has shifted its advertising account to DFS-Dorland from Grey Advertising in that city. The ad budget is more than $3 million.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''AS a private citizen, I was stunned. I was shocked. I felt terrible. I felt very sad, like everybody else did. I couldn't believe it had happened. I saw it over and over again on the screen, and each time I thought: 'It's not going to happen.' But it happened.''

title: Advertising; Xerox Winner Seen as Bates
description: For the Xerox Corporation the search for a new agency that began in late March is over at last. And the winner of the $40 million account is Ted Bates Advertising, New York, according to a reliable source.

title: Family Succession At Mutual of Omaha
description: Thomas J. Skutt was named yesterday to replace his father, the 84-year-old V. J. Skutt, as chairman of the Mutual of Omaha Companies, which the elder Mr. Skutt built into a major insurer.

title: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY: REAGAN FAULTED FOR DECISION TO IGNORE TREATY ON WEAPONS
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, denounced yesterday President Reagan's decision to cease to abide by the unratified 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty, calling it a prelude to ''an expensive and threatening new chapter in U.S.-Soviet relations.''

title: Drop in Money Funds
description: Assets of the nation's 360 money market mutual funds fell $815.7 million, to $224.59 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes an unusual charge of $21.4 million consisting primarily of costs associated with the company's restructuring plan announced last November. c-Net loss. d-Includes an extraordinary gain of $564,000, or 9 cents a share, from early retirement of debt.

title: GROWTH OF EMBRYO PROTEIN RAISES HOPE ON CANCER
description: Scientists have used techniques of genetic alteration to grow a rare protein of the human embryo that has shown promise as a drug against cancer.

title: METS ROUT PIRATES FOR STAND-INS, 7-0
description: Dawn Johnson was graduated from Lake Howell High School in Winter Park, Fla., tonight. And if her father was squirming in his seat in the auditorium, fretting about the team he left behind, he needn't have worried.

title: Charles F. Wennerstrum, 96; Served on Iowa's High Court
description: Charles Frederick Wennerstrum, a former Iowa Supreme Court Judge who presided over and sharply criticized some of the Nuremberg war crimes trials after World War II, died Sunday of a heart attack. He was 96 years old.

title: Who Says the World Has Aid Fatigue?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Louie Newton, 94, Dies; Led Southern Baptist Group
description: Dr. Louie D. Newton, a former president of the Southern Baptist Convention, the national organization that directs the country's largest Protestant denomination, died of pnuemonia Tuesday at Georgia Baptist Hospital in Atlanta. He was 94 years old and lived in Atlanta.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Computer Techniques Corp. has elected Edward D. Bright chairman; Oscar H. Schachter vice chairman and chief executive of its software division, and John F. Phillips president and chief executive of its Creative Socio-Medics Corp. subsidiary

title: PELTON CONVICTED OF SELLING SECRETS; U.S. AIDES SAY POLLARD IS GIVING JUSTICE DEPT. FURTHER INFORMATION
description: The former Navy analyst who admitted spying for Israel has begun providing the Justice Department with information about a number of Israeli espionage operations in the United States, senior Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: SCREEN: 'COSMIC EYE,' ANIMATION AND MUSIC
description: ''THE COSMIC EYE,'' Faith Hubley's first animated feature, is an unusually pretty film but, like its title, it's also a bit intimidating. Here is nothing less than an inventory of myths about mankind's origins, a review of the current state of the planet earth, plus some hope-filled speculations about the future. Will we survive? Mrs. Hubley thinks we will, though I'm not sure her film will convince the pessimists in the audience.

title: 2-YEAR-OLD DIES AFTER OPERATION IN DENTAL OFFICE
description: A 2-year-old Queens boy died yesterday afternoon hours after a routine dental operation went awry, the police said. Transportation of the child from the dentist's office to a hospital was apparently delayed by a dispute between the dentist and paramedics who were summoned by police officers, they added.

title: BOTNICK ADMITS LYING ABOUT COLLEGE DEGREES
description: Victor E. Botnick, a special adviser to Mayor Koch and chairman of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said yesterday that he had repeatedly made misleading statements about his credentials during his eight years in city government, and offered a public apology.

title: HARVARD UNIVERSITY: FOE OF SOUTH AFRICA WINS KEY POST ON BOARD
description: In a victory for dissident alumni, a graduate student who wants Harvard University to divest itself of its holdings in American companies doing business in South Africa has been elected to the school's board of overseers, it was announced today.

title: NEW THEATER REALM INSIDE A BRIDGE
description: THE Brooklyn Bridge has long inspired dreams and fantasies. But for sheer exotic color and ambition, few of those dreams could match ''The Memory Theater of Giulio Camillo,'' which opens tonight for 18 performances in the bridge's Brooklyn anchorage.

title: CORRECTION
