description: An article yesterday on Broadway's summer season misidentified the theater where ''Rags,'' a musical about immigrants at the turn of the century, is to open Aug. 7. It is the Mark Hellinger.

title: CABARET: DEBORAH DAVIS
description: AN unusual musical tug-of-war is happening on Tuesday evenings at Burgundy, the jazz cafe and art gallery on Amsterdam Avenue between 82d and 83d Streets, when Deborah Davis sings with Benny Green as her piano accompanist.

title: 79 Jews Leave Soviet in May
description: The Soviet Union allowed 79 Jews to emigrate in May, the agency helping them resettle said Thursday. The number of Jewish emigrants was 72 in April and 53 in March, according to the agency, the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration. Last year, 1,140 Soviet Jews were allowed to emigrate; in 1979, 51,330 Jews left the Soviet Union.

title: AN EX-LANDLORD IS AMONG 3 HELD
description: A 25-year-old woman who came to Manhattan from Texas last year and had begun a successful career as a fashion model was slashed in the face with a razor blade early yesterday.

title: Health Care for Performers
description: Max Weinberg, Bruce Springsteen's drummer, talked about his hands. The dancers Violette Verdi and Arthur Mitchell talked about their legs. Walter Charles, co-star of ''La Cage aux Folles,'' talked about his vocal cords.

title: British Health Partners Expand Into the U.S.
description: Michael J. Sinclair and Anthony H. Reeves, two Britons in the health-care business, have expanded into the United States.

title: Bicycles on Boardwalk Are Terror of Brighton
description: To the Editor:

title: CRIME PROGRAM HITS A MILESTONE IN ROBBERY CASE
description: Spurred by a tip from an anonymous caller, the police have arrested two men for the armed robbery of a Staten Island delicatessen, a case that had been at a standstill for months. The caller had seen a re-enactment of the crime on a television newscast.

title: RATES REGISTER SLIGHT DECLINE
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities, except for some 30-year bonds, fell slightly yesterday in response to statements by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that he was not advocating a tighter monetary policy.

title: Robins Cites Poor Advice
description: Poor communications between the A. H. Robins Company and its Chapter 11 bankruptcy lawyers led company officials to make debt payments without court approval, Robins's attorney, Dennis Drebsky, said today. Robins contended that the law firm that it hired to handle its case said some payments could be made on debts incurred before a bankruptcy filing without court clearance.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore, at Yankee Stadium, 7:35 P.M. First game of a brief three-game homestand. (Television -Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Mets at Pittsburgh, doubleheader, first game at 6:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 6 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050, 6 P.M.).

title: House to Begin Process To Impeach U.S. Judge
description: A House Judiciary subcommittee will begin impeachment proceeedings next week against Federal District Judge Harry Claiborne of Nevada, according to the panel's chairman.

title: Gulf States Bonds Get Lower Rating
description: The rating of the Gulf States Utilities Company's first mortgage bonds was reduced to speculative grade, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: MUSIC MOVES INTO THE OPEN AIR, FROM BOATS TO CITY STREETS
description: YOU can't blame music for feeling a little cooped up lately. Trapped in smoky clubs after dark, confined in stuffy concert halls, removed from such kindred sounds as birds's songs, human chatter, the rustle of leaves, traffic noise - all that could give an art form a bad case of cabin fever. This weekend, finally, music gets to step outside. It will be visiting the seashore, cruising the Hudson River, stepping out on the streets and echoing in city parks. And not a moment too soon.

title: REAGAN IS PRESSED ON ARMS PACT
description: Members of Congress from both parties applied new pressure on President Reagan today to persuade him to continue to adhere to the provisions of the unratified 1979 arms pact with the Soviet Union.

title: JUDGE REBUKED ON DOCKET SHIFTS
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that a Criminal Court judge who removed cases from his calendar because prosecutors were unprepared had abused his powers. The appeals court said the cases should be restored.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: SUBURB'S DISTRICT VYING WITH TOP PREP SCHOOLS
description: When the high school graduating class of 1999 enters kindergarten this fall, the cost of public education here will approach $7,000 a pupil.

title: INSIDER PLEADS GUILTY IN $12.6 MILLION STOCK CASE
description: Dennis B. Levine, a 33-year-old former Wall Street investment banker, yesterday settled Federal charges that he earned $12.6 million through illegal insider stock trading. He pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to four felony counts and agreed to cooperate in a continuing investigation of insider trading on Wall Street.

title: EX-OFFICER IS G.O.P. HOPE IN 5-WAY HOUSE CONTEST
description: Richard (Bo) Dietl is running for Congress with a .38-caliber handgun strapped to his left ankle, a vestige of his 15-year career in the New York City Police Department.

title: Villages' House Tour
description: A tour of old houses, including one built in 1663, will be held tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. in the villages of New Baltimore and Coxsackie, on the banks of the Hudson River in Greene County, sponsored by the county historical society.

title: Drug Epidemic of 80's Sweeps the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes equity in unremmitted earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. of $47,206,000, or 49 cents a share. c-Includes a negative amount of $11,461,000 because dividends received from Du Pont exceeded Seagram's equity in Du Pont earnings.

title: DRIFTER IS FOUND GUILTY OF KILLING A SEATTLE FAMILY
description: Rejecting an insanity plea, jurors found David Morse Rice guilty of aggravated murder today in the killing of Charles Goldmark and his family, a murder the prosecutors said was based on a generation-old political smear.

title: U.N. AGENCY SAYS THERE MAY BE 50,000 CASES OF AIDS IN AFRICA
description: At least 50,000 Africans may have contracted AIDS since 1980 and an estimated one million to two million people on the continent may be symptomless carriers of the virus that causes the disease, according to new estimates by the World Health Organization.

title: PATRICIA WHEEL
description: Patricia Wheel, a stage, film and television actress for more than 40 years, died June 3 in New York City after a long illness.

title: Specter's Stand
description: Commitments are often costly in politics, but rarely as costly as the stand taken last year by Senator Arlen Specter, a Pennsylva-nia Republican who is up for re-election this year. It stems from a 1985 debate over the MX missile, when White House officials told reporters that the President had only a limited amount of time to campaign for senators and that those who opposed the experimental weapon would not be at the top of his list. Mr. Specter, whose position on the forthcoming MX vote was unknown at the time, was mentioned by name. Mr. Specter subsequently voted for the MX, but said he wanted to avoid the appearance of a quid pro quo.

title: PAUL STEVENS
description: Paul Stevens, a stage and television actor for almost 40 years, died of pnuemonia Wednesday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 49ers Release Hicks
description: The veteran defensive back Dwight Hicks, a four-time Pro Bowl safety and member of the San Francisco 49ers' two Super Bowl teams, has been released after failing to agree on a new contract.

title: Beirut Battles Resume; Death Toll Exceeds 100
description: Heavy artillery and rocket fire engulfed Beirut's refugee districts today as Syrian-backed Shiite militiamen carried their offensive against Palestinians into a third week.

title: SCREEN: 'SPACECAMP,' AN UNSCHEDULED TRIP
description: ''SPACECAMP,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters, is about a group of teen-agers at a NASA summer camp for aspiring astronauts who take the ultimate unscheduled field trip without parental permission slips. They go to outer space.

title: ROCKETS ROLL AFTER SAMPSON IS EJECTED, TRAIL BY 3-2
description: After four hard-fought games, emotions spilled over and fists flew tonight. As a result, the Houston Rockets lost one of their most important players, Ralph Sampson, when he was ejected 2 minutes 20 seconds into the second period tonight against the Celtics.

title: TWO LEAD ON 65'S IN THE WESTCHESTER
description: Jay Haas, with five victories on the PGA Tour but none in the last three and a half years, and Tom Sieckmann, with no victories but a few triumphs in past years on the Asian tour, tied for the lead in the first round of the 20th annual Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic today.

title: ART: AFRICAN OBJECTS OF MONZINO COLLECTION
description: AFRICAN tribal art has never looked the same to the lay observer since the great exhibition of '' 'Primitivism' in 20th-Century Art'' that was organized by William Rubin, seconded by Kirk Varnedoe, at the Museum of Modern Art in 1984-85. It is, however, characteristic of the divide between specialists in African art and specialists in 20th-century art that neither the Modern Museum show nor the monumental two-volume catalogue that came with it is mentioned in the catalogue of ''African Aesthetics: the Carlo Monzino Collection,'' an exhibition of 100 superlative objects that can be seen through Sept. 7 at the Center for African Art, 54 East 68th Street.

title: Noonan Resigns
description: Peggy Noonan, considered one of the most talented of President Reagan's speechwriters, is leaving the White House. This week she submitted what may be the first resignation letter to a President signed with a small flurry of ''X's,'' a gesture of affection to the man known as the Great Communicator.

title: Henry Nash Smith Dies at 79; Berkeley Mark Twain Scholar
description: Henry Nash Smith, a professor of English and a Mark Twain scholar, died after an automobile accident May 30 near Elko, Nev. He was 79 years old and lived in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Indian Street Fair
description: The sights, sounds and aromas of India will fill the streets near the Fashion Institute of Technology, on 27th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, on Sunday. The street fair, sponsored by the school and other organizations, kicks off a major exhibition of Indian textiles at the school that will run through July 19. There will be storytelling, music, palm-reading and the re-creation of an Indian wedding, and a variety of Indian clothes, crafts and food will be on sale. Festival hours are 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Film About Kurosawa Opens 3-Part Series
description: ''A.K.,'' a documentary about the Japanese film director Akira Kurosawa, will open a three-part film series tonight at 7:30 at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street. The film is a profile of the director while he was working on the feature ''Ran.''

title: RUNNER QUITS RACE, LEAPS FROM BRIDGE
description: Kathy Ormsby of North Carolina State, who broke the collegiate record for the women's 10,000-meter run seven weeks ago, was hospitalized with a serious spinal injury today after she bolted from another 10,000-meter race Wednesday night and apparently attempted to commit suicide by jumping off a bridge.

title: ESPOSITO'S BUSINESS LINKS WITH UNION FIGURE STUDIED
description: Federal law-enforcement officials said yesterday that they were investigating business links between the former Democratic Party chairman in Brooklyn, Meade H. Esposito, and a convicted union leader, Nicholas Sands.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about New York's Puerto Rican community misidentified the victor in the 1985 Democratic primary election for Bronx Borough President. It was Stanley Simon, not Stanley M. Friedman.

title: GETTY PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes equity in loss of $34,000 of Slattery Group Inc. c-Includes equity in income of $260,000 of Slattery Group. The results were adjusted for the 4-for-3 stock split of March 1986 and the 5 percent stock dividend of September 1985.

title: THE ROLL-CALL IN THE SENATE
description: Following is the roll-call vote today by which the Senate sustained President Reagan's veto of a resolution that would have prohibited the sale of missiles to Saudi Arabia. The attempt to override the veto failed by one vote. A ''yes'' vote was to override the veto and oppose the sale; a ''no'' vote was to sustain the veto and support the sale. There were 66 votes in favor of overriding the veto and 34 against, but 67 votes - a two-thirds margin - were needed to override the veto.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE winds of change that propelled French restaurants toward sunny new climes in the 1970's passed right over La Caravelle without effect. This once-celebrated luxury liner remained anchored to its secure home port, convinced that the foolhardy adventurers would disappear over the horizon, never to be heard from again.

title: STAGE: 'MASTER CLASS'
description: WHAT Stalin did to nonconformist artists in the Soviet Union is no joke.

title: PELTON'S TRIAL: PROSECUTION AND CONVICTION WITHOUT DAMAGING DISCLOSURE
description: The conviction of Ronald W. Pelton, a former National Security Agency employee, was achieved without the Government's ever disclosing precisely what secrets he was accused of handing the Soviet Union.

title: BESIEGED BUILDER AMID THE RUINS
description: Two months ago Clem Haskins left his alma mater, Western Kentucky University, to start in on a lucrative five-year contract as coach of a program in tatters - Minnesota basketball. The Gophers finished ninth in the Big Ten this year after a season marred by rape charges against three of their starters, who face trial in Madison, Wis., next month and are no longer with the team; by a series of disciplinary suspensions that at one point left the squad with only five scholarship players, and by the midwinter resignation of Coach Jim Dutcher, who was later accused by the university of assisting an effort to raise legal fees for a player previously accused of rape.

title: F.C.C. Backs Sale of NBC
description: The General Electric Company's purchase of the National Broadcasting Company was approved today by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: SENATE WON'T CUT LIMITS ON INCOME
description: The Senate Thursday evening refused to reduce the amount of outside income Senators can earn.

title: JAZZ: ERNESTINE ANDERSON
description: THE veteran jazz singer Ernestine Anderson has never achieved the degree of recognition enjoyed by Sarah Vaughan or the late Dinah Washington, two singers that have left a strong mark on her style. But Miss Anderson, who combines sophisticated jazz phrasing with the rough energy of a blues shouter, possesses a musical intelligence comparable to theirs.

title: TIGHTER REVIEWS OF DOCTORS URGED
description: ''Nowhere near enough'' doctors are being disciplined by state medical boards, and organized medicine ''can no longer abide a brotherhood of silence'' on the incompetency of some physicians, Dr. Otis R. Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said yesterday.

title: Judge Rules for Trial In Child Molestation
description: A Superior Court judge has ruled that Raymond Buckey and his mother, Virginia, must stand trial on charges of molesting 14 children at the McMartin Preschool center in Manhattan Beach.

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes pre-tax charges of $1,241,000 from the sale of preferred stock and $752,000 on the sale of an airplane.

title: Report Doubts Need For Research Center
description: Serious questions are posed by the Reagan Administration's plan for a research center to help develop a space-based defense against missiles, a new report says.

title: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON PUBLIC HOUSING
description: Signaling a sharp break with the Federal housing policy of the last 50 years, the House of Representatives voted today to channel nearly all new funds for public housing into rehabilitation of existing units rather than new construction.

title: GIAMATTI LIKELY TO LEAD NATIONAL LEAGUE
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, the retiring president of Yale University who once said the only thing he ever wanted to be president of was the American League, has been designated as the next president of the National League, a league source said last night.

title: Staton at West End
description: The singer Dakota Staton will appear tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:15 A.M.; there will be no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $5 cover and a $5 minimum on Sunday.

title: Extending Lives, Both of Them
description: Sometime today, somewhere in the United States, somebody is going to get a new heart. Twenty people will get new kidneys; and sixty-five will get new eyes. Only a few decades ago organ transplants were the stuff of fiction; today they're a fact of many American lives.

title: City Ballet Gala
description: The theme was Russian. But other than one ballet choreographed by George Balanchine, a gala Wednesday night for the New York City Ballet was strictly a New York affair.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMS
description: SEMITES AND ANTI-SEMITES: An Inquiry Into Conflict and Prejudice. By Bernard Lewis. 283 pages. W. W. Norton. $18.95. STRICTLY speaking there are no such people as Semites, only people who speak one or another of the Semitic languages. The term, as Bernard Lewis explains in his powerful new study, is a classification devised by philologists in the 18th century, and though it has often been misappropriated by racial theorizers it has nothing to do with race in the anthropological sense.

title: THE LIFE AND MUSIC OF BILLIE HOLIDAY IN PLAY AND CONCERT
description: PROBABLY no voice in the history of jazz exerts a deeper fascination than the vulnerable, intimate slur of Billie Holiday, who died 27 years ago at the age of 44. With a vocal range of barely an octave and the timbre of a muted horn, Miss Holiday's singing was far from athletic, but it spanned the emotional range of the universe, communicating joy and pain with an immediacy that seemed at once artless and profoundly sophisticated.

title: Poland Is Not 'Normalized'
description: Last week, Poland was accepted into the International Monetary Fund. The Jaruzelski regime hopes thus to regain some of the respectability lost in the years of martial law and to qualify for badly needed Western credits and loans.

title: NAVY HOME PORT PLAN GAINS
description: The Navy's plan to build new home ports received a boost today when the Senate Armed Services Committee approved the release of funds for port construction at Staten Island and Everett, Wash., Congressional sources said today.

title: OF HISTORY AND POLITICS: BITTER FEMINIST DEBATE
description: More than a year ago, in the last of a series of landmark sex-bias cases brought by the Government against major corporations, a prominent women's historian appeared as an expert witness to defend Sears, Roebuck & Company from charges that it discriminated against women.

title: SCREEN: 'TEA IN HAREM,' STREET YOUTHS IN FRANCE
description: ''TEA IN THE HAREM'' is soft-core slice of life. It follows a couple of teen-agers, Madjid and Pat, whose pastimes include lifting wallets, stealing cars, pimping, copulating with lonely wives and making neighborhood nuisances of themselves. The movie, which opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Cinema, keeps insisting that they are charming, gallant, loyal to the point of sacrifice and generally superior to most of the adults around.

title: ISRAEL'S SPIES: WHO CONTROLS THEM?
description: The guilty plea entered Wednesday by a United States Navy analyst to charges of spying for Israel, coupled with the latest domestic intelligence scandal in Israel, has raised questions among Israeli officials and political specialists about who is in control of Israel's intelligence services.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: GALA FOR LA GUARDIA The Fiorello H. La Guardia High School for Music and the Arts marks its 50th anniversary this year, and to celebrate, a gala concert and art show will be held tonight at the Hunter College Concert Hall, on 69th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues. Since its inception in 1936 as the High School of Music and Art, the institution, which later merged with the School of Performing Arts, has been instrumental in preparing many of New York's talented youth for professional careers. Some illustrious names in show business - Liza Minnelli, Eartha Kitt, Ben Vereen and Susan Strasberg, to name a few - are among its 20,000 graduates. At tonight's concert, Eugene Fader will conduct the school's Senior Orchestra and Chorus in a program of Bach, Wagner, Tchaikovsky and Bizet. Joining them for a performance of ''I Got Rhythm'' is the jazz pianist Peter Nero, who is also an alumnus. The actress Helen Hayes will also present a tribute to the school. Original student artworks will be on view, both at Hunter College and at La Guardia High School, on Amsterdam Avenue at 65th Street. The concert begins at 7:30 P.M. and will be followed by a buffet supper at the high school. Another alumnus, Peter Yarrow of Peter, Paul and Mary, will entertain. Tickets are $10 for the art show and concert, and $15 for the buffet. Information: 546-1655.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $10,311,000 for the quarter and $13,678,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $14,025,000.

title: SENATE UPHOLDS ARMS FOR SAUDIS, BACKING REAGAN
description: President Reagan won a narrow victory in the Senate today as his supporters mustered enough votes to allow the sale of advanced missiles to Saudi Arabia. The margin was a single vote. Last month both houses of Congress approved a resolution blocking a stripped-down version of the arms package, and President Reagan vetoed that resolution. The vote today to override that veto was 66 to 34, but because a two-thirds vote is required, the President's opponents fell one vote short.

title: NEW FURS BY GALANOS: FROM SLINKY TO FULL
description: It's only his third fur collection, but James Galanos clearly understands the medium. Emphasizing luxury furs in opulent designs, he offers a wide choice of Russian lynx, sable, broadtail and chinchilla coats in the prevailing long, generous shapes of the new season. But that's not all. He shows plenty of straight hip-length jackets as well as boleros that blouse gently and curve into the waist. And superbly fitted coats are beautifully shaped to follow the lines of the bodice and burst into a full dramatic flare at the hemline.

title: SALE OF MGM UNITS IS SEEN
description: The Lorimar-Telepictures Corporation appears to have reached an agreement to buy the MGM Entertainment Company's film laboratory and real estate from Ted Turner for $190 million, a source familiar with the negotiations said late last night.

title: WHO CAN FIX THE WOLLMAN RINK FASTER? CITY AND TRUMP AGREE IT'S TRUMP
description: At this point in the long saga of the skating rink that no one could fix, city officials and the developer Donald J. Trump essentially agree on how to rebuild Central Park's Wollman Rink.

title: YANKS ARE READY FOR EASTERN RIVALS
description: As he leaned against an open doorway leading to the trainer's room, Joe Niekro seemed less impressed by his tantalizing bid to pitch a no-hitter than by the fact that the Yankees had given themselves fresh momentum.

title: ART: ANTON VAN DALEN'S PAINTINGS AND DRAWINGS
description: ANTON VAN DALEN has lived in the East Village since 1972. He knew it when its street life was violent enough to remind him of growing up in the Netherlands during World War II. He has also known the East Village since a number of drug-shooting galleries were closed, a greater number of art galleries were opened and entire sections of the neighborhood were confronted with gentrification. The handsome exhibition of paintings and drawings at the Edward Thorp Gallery, 103 Prince Street, through June 14, documents the artist's evolution during these restless years.

title: KOCH AIDE MAY GET STATE JOB
description: The Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, George Gross, is a leading candidate to become the new executive director of the state's Financial Control Board, according to officials of the Koch and Cuomo administrations.

title: New Judge Is Assigned For Presser's Trial
description: A new judge has been assigned to the racketeering and embezzlement trial of Jackie Presser, president of the teamsters' union, after defense attorneys argued that the first judge was biased.

title: Wheeling Closing
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation's Monessen plant will be permanently shut on Sept. 2 at a cost of about 600 jobs, the steelmaker said.

title: DANCE: 'TANGLED NIGHT,' A PREMIERE
description: ONE of Martha Graham's most successful recent works has been ''Acts of Light.'' This was the first time Miss Graham used the music by the Danish composer Carl Nielsen, and the work was commissioned in part in 1981 by Edward H. Michaelsen, a Danish-American business executive who is vice chairman of the Graham Dance Company's board.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Inkster Shoots 68 For 2-Shot Lead
description: Juli Inkster shot a four-under-par 68 today to take a two-shot lead over five other players after the first round of the $450,000 L.P.G.A. tournament at White Manor Country Club.

title: BEAR STEARNS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings results are not adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split which was declared yesterday. The results for the year ended April 30, 1986 include Bear Stearns & Company, the predecessor limited partnership, restated as if the business of the partnership had been conducted as a corporation for the 6 months ended Oct. 28, 1985. The results for the 3 and 12 months ended April 30, 1985 are similarly restated. Bear Stearns Companies succeeded to the business of Bear, Stearns & Company and became a publicly owned company on Oct. 29, 1985.

title: STILL-THRIVING TRADITIONAL INDIAN CRAFTS ON SHOW
description: In 1977, Ralph T. Coe first began to wonder if American Indians were still practicing such traditional crafts as weaving, basketry, pipe making and bead working.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bear, Stearns & Co., said its board of directors had declared a 3-for-2 split of its common stock payable July 15 to stockholders of record July 1 and approved an increase in the total number of authorized shares of cumulative convertible preferred and common stock to 210 million, from 110 million.

title: Bad Rights Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
ART: ROBERT THERRIEN IS SHOWING 28 WORKS
description: ROBERT THERRIEN is an artist who has something but what this is eludes precise definition. Born in Chicago, he has spent most of his 39 years in California, exhibiting in Los Angeles since 1975. His appearances in Manhattan, on the other hand, have been few and far between. The present show at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 420 West Broadway between Prince and Spring Streets, is only his second in eight years; he was included in last year's Whitney Biennial but - a distinction of a kind -was not among the multitude rounded up by the Museum of Modern Art for its international survey of 1984.

title: Advertising; People
description: * John Schneider has been named partner at Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago.

title: 4 PLEAD GUILTY IN INSIDER CASE
description: Four of the five young defendants charged in an insider-trading ring pleaded guilty yesterday - all except Michael N. David, the former lawyer at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison who is charged with stealing confidential information about upcoming takeovers.

title: Great Scott!
description: Amazing story of the week: Among the Houston Astros, whose pitchers have included Nolan Ryan, J. R. Richard and Don Wilson, who holds the club record for reaching 100 strikeouts on the earliest date in a season? Ryan? Richard? Wilson? No, no and no. It's Mike Scott, who got to the plateau on Wednesday night, eclipsing Richard's team mark, set in 1978, by five days.

title: SCREEN: 'CRIMEWAVE,' GANGSTER-FILM SPOOF
description: ''CRIMEWAVE,'' which opens a two-day run today at the Thalia, is a comedy made by and for movie buffs -people whose view of the world has been shaped almost exclusively by movies rather than first-hand experience.

title: Diner's Journal
description: UPPER Broadway in the Columbia University neighborhood abounds with little ethnic storefront restaurants catering to student tastes and budgets. One that is worth investigating even if your diploma is getting yellow around the edges is Au Grenier Cafe, a sunny walk-up French bistro-like place at Broadway near 111th Street, where lunch fare includes some tasty soups, salads and pates - and at bargain prices.

title: CONTRAS SET TO FREE 8 GERMANS
description: Nicaraguan rebels holding eight West German citizens say they are prepared to release the hostages, but only to what a rebel spokesman calls a ''responsible and neutral'' party.

title: Porn Again or Born Again on 42d Street?
description: At last, the visionary image of Manhattan's 42d Street can be discerned behind the sordid present. Once approved, the city-state redevelopment was immediately clouded by 27 direct legal challenges - and more recently by the unrelated indictment of one sponsor, Michael Lazar. But 26 of the cases have now been disposed of; Mr. Lazar has been removed; and it's now possible, with understanding on three fronts, to fill the void and fulfill the vision.

title: BALLET: 'THE NUTCRACKER'
description: CHOREOGRAPHICALLY, Mikhail Baryshnikov's stagings of ''The Nutcracker'' and ''Don Quixote'' may not be to everyone's taste. Yet, as American Ballet Theater demonstrated recently at the Metropolitan Opera House, the leading roles in these works can challenge dancers.

title: The U.N. Today: June 6, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Exxon to Transfer Pension Surplus
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it planned to withdraw more than $1 billion in surplus pension funds and use the money for general corporate purposes.

title: THE SCREEN: 'INVADERS FROM MARS'
description: YOUNG David Gardner and his father lie on the grass watching shooting stars in the night sky. David's mother comes out to gently usher the boy off to bed and his father walks with him, his arm around his son's shoulders. They go to a snug, wallpapered room where David is lovingly tucked in. It's an ideal view of family life.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: NEIGHBORS!'' Bill and Judith Moyers greeted Mary Tyler Moore and her husband, Dr. Robert Levine. Then the doctor and his wife said, ''Hello there, neighbors'' to Michael and Diandra Douglas. Then Peter Allen bounced in and gave neighborly handshakes to all of them. It was not your typical town get-together.

title: Playing Ball
description: In the international trade debate, it is one of the most common rallying cries: Give us a level playing field and Americans can compete.

title: SENATE PANEL HANDS REAGAN FIRST DEFEAT ON NOMINEE FOR JUDGESHIP
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today rejected the nomination of Jefferson B. Sessions 3d to be a Federal district judge in Alabama. It was the first time one of President Reagan's judicial nominees was rejected.

title: International Minerals
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, one of the world's largest fertilizer producers, said it expected to report a fourth-quarter net loss of $105 million to $150 million, largely because of current difficulties in its industrial and energy sectors. The company, based in Northbrook, Ill., said that it might sell all or part of its gas and oil operations and its industrial products segment.

title: KNEE-DEEP IN JUNE -- AND TIME FOR PICKING STRAWBERRIES RIPE ON THE VINE
description: It's strawberry-picking time again, and the berries are ripening in stages from south to north of Metropolitan New York.

title: Pitching for Jackson
description: Bo Jackson's representatives will meet today for a second time with John Schuerholz, the general manager of the Kansas City Royals, as the Tampa Bay Buccaneers await their turn at negotiating with the 1985 Heisman Trophy winner.

title: CANADIAN JUDGE WEIGHS BAIL FOR 5 SIKHS IN AIRLINER CASE
description: Final arguments were heard today in the bail hearing of five Sikhs accused of conspiring to possess explosives with intent to injure.

title: Dombrowski Dismissed
description: After eight years of adminsistrative work in the organization, Dave Dombrowski, vice president of baseball operation with the Chicago White Sox, was dismissed yesterday by General Manager Ken Harrelson. Harrelson said he dismissed Dombrowski because ''of differences in thinking and philosophy.''

title: Viacom Foresees Loss for Quarter
description: Viacom International, the diversified media company, said it would report a loss for the second quarter as a result of its previously announced repurchase of stock held by the New York investor Carl C. Icahn.

title: Where Are They Now?
description: An update on the status of the top 10 picks in the major leagues' amateur draft last June:

title: Of Special Interests, Then and Now
description: On April 16, 1790, the mustard manufacturers of Philadelphia sent a petition to Congress asking the lawmakers to impose ''an additional duty on imported mustard.'' That same spring, Congress was also asked to increase tariffs on foreign-made paint, cordage and cotton cloths.

title: THE CREATION OF A HIT PRODUCT
description: Combat, a roach killer developed by the American Cyanamid Company, is hailed today as a new-product success story, but success was scarcely immediate. Nor was it easy.

title: Chernobyl Death Toll Now Put at 26 by Soviet
description: A Soviet health official said today that 13 of the 19 people who received bone marrow transplants after getting massive doses of radiation in the Chernobyl disaster had died.

title: Business for Best Plays Increases After Tonys
description: As a result of winning the Tony Awards on June 1 for best play and best musical, box-office business increased dramatically for ''I'm Not Rappaport'' and ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' according to the producers's press representatives.

title: WNET BEGINS SERIES ABOUT THE TROJAN WAR
description: THE six-part series ''In Search of the Trojan War,'' which begins on WNET/Channel 13 at 8 tomorrow evening, could be subtitled ''Hiking With Mike and His Backpack.'' The host and the writer is Michael Wood, who seems to have decided that being scholarly might be fine but becoming a television personality is even better. The result is a startlingly odd clash between style and substance.

title: Print Import Curb Warning
description: The Reagan Administration warned today that Americans would lose jobs if Congress extended a 95-year-old law shielding the printing industry from imports by requiring that books by American authors be manufactured in the United States to receive copyright protection.

title: DRUG EPIDEMIC OF 80'S SWEEPS THE U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: One Strike Zone
description: Commissioner Peter Ueberroth has stepped into the controversy involving American League umpires and the crouching strike zone of the Rickey Henderson of the Yankees.

title: Italian Company Role In 'Star Wars' Sought
description: Italy has decided to open talks with the United States on the participation of Italian corporations in research into developing a space-based defense against missiles, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Albany Given Tax-Cut Plan
description: In the first step toward revising the state tax code, the Republican majority in the New York Senate has drafted a plan to lower state income tax rates if Congress overhauls the Federal tax system. Such action in Washington would make state taxpayers pay Albany more because the state income tax is calculated on the basis of figures on the Federal tax form.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AMERICAN architectural designs by Frank Lloyd Wright, Charles and Henry Greene and George Grant Elmslie are collected these days as seriously as is 18th-century furniture. Since 1982, when Christie's in New York began auctioning the early 20th-century furniture, stained-glass windows and accessories designed by these architects, the market for such material has blossomed and prices have steadily edged upward. This activity has attracted other rarities to auctions and made similar designs by craftsmen of the period, including Gustav Stickley and Harvey Ellis, far more desirable and expensive. As prices escalate, it seems, more designs, including some works never auctioned until now, are surfacing in much the same way as did the designs of Louis Comfort Tiffany when there was a boom in Art Nouveau works a decade ago.

title: Bush and Kemp in the Early Hall of Mirrors
description: At this early stage of jockeying, the contest for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination would be far less interesting if the realities matched appearances. Two cases in point are the unannounced campaigns of Vice President Bush and Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have always given Presidents the benefit of any doubts on vital foreign policy issues.'' - Senator J. James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, who switched his vote on the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia. [ A10:5. ]

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Helen Schneider, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005). Miss Schneider, whose last appearances in New York almost a decade ago were as a jazz and blues singer who was turning into a rock singer, has returned with half a dozen years as an actress added to her multifaceted singing. She's doing a monologue with pop songs of the 1920's, ''A Flapper Folly,'' that is a brilliant tour de force, presenting her as an actress as much as a singer and revealing unsuspected dramatic potential in songs that originally seemed merely happy or sappy. Tina Landau's crisp script and imaginative direction provide Miss Schneider with the basis for a cabaret triumph. Her last two performances are today and tomorrow at 9 P.M. There is a $15 music charge and a two-drink minimum.

title: Charmed Life
description: Mike Pagliarulo, the Yankees' gifted third baseman, abandoned superstition when he reached the majors in 1984. Or so he says. As an example, he recalls that Roy White, in reclaiming his job as a coach this spring, asked Pagliarulo if he would give up his uniform number, 6, which Pags had worn in his first two seasons with the team.

title: A SCOFFLAW DRIVE IN JERSEY GETS UNEXPECTED BENEFITS
description: The city that smoked out its mayor as one of its leading traffic-ticket scofflaws is finding that the publicity that prompted Mayor Paul Monacelli to pay up has brought additional benefits.

title: Dining Out Guide: Southern Cuisines
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. BON TEMPS ROULER, #59 Reade Street (513-1333) -

title: HITACHI LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The figures have been translated into United States currency at the rate of 170 yen equals U.S.$1.00, the approximate exchange rate prevailing on the Tokyo Foreign Exchange Market as of May 30, 1986. Share earnings represent American Depositary Share (ADS). Each ADS represents 10 shares of common stock. The net income per share, without ADS, totaled 30 cents for the latest year, compared with 42 cents for 1985.

title: Moody Quartet Plays
description: The saxophonist-flutist James Moody and his quartet will perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: SOVIET ARMS PACT BREACHES: CHARGES QUESTIONED
description: The Soviet Union has not breached key provisions of the 1979 arms pact, according to data cited by critics of President Reagan's announced policy of ending adherence to the treaty terms.

title: To Help Israel Improve Public Relations
description: The American Jewish Congress raised $200,000 at a dinner Wednesday night, to be used to teach public-relations skills to Israeli Government spokesmen.

title: DR. SHIRLEY LEON QUIMBY
description: Dr. Shirley Leon Quimby, a professor emeritus of physics at Columbia University whose research in solid-state physics led to the development of antimagnetic mine devices in World War II, died May 15 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old.

title: Advertising; HBM/Creamer in Talks With London Agency
description: HBM/Creamer, which is privately held and has seven United States offices and billings of about $400 million, said yesterday that it was having merger talks with the WCRS Group, a publicly held British communications company with about $200 million in billings.

title: Advertising; Prudential Drive for 4th of July
description: THE mighty Prudential, with Gibraltar as its symbol and $115 billion in assets, has never forgotten its more humble days before the turn of the century when it was the rare insurance company that would take a chance on selling life insurance to indigent immigrants.

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The company said latest results were adversely affected by costs associated with integrating the acquisition of Cilco Inc. and Richards Medical Co., purchased Feb. 28, 1986.

title: U.S. INCLUDES SYRIA IN CHEMICALS BAN
description: The United States announced today that it was banning the sale to Syria of eight chemicals that might be used to help Iran develop mustard gas and nerve gases for use in its war against Iraq.

title: Dodgers Drop Cedeno
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers have released the veteran outfielder Cesar Cedeno and recalled a pitcher, Carlos Diaz.

title: ITALY AND ARGENTINA PLAY TO A 1-1 TIE
description: Italy learned its lesson about giving up late goals last Saturday and was not about to commit the same grievous mistake today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 6, 1986
description: Markets

title: France Says Aide Saw Waldheim Records in '79
description: The Government said today that a junior French official in West Berlin inspected the World War II military records of Kurt Waldheim and three other former members of the German Army in 1979, while Mr. Waldheim was still United Nations Secretary General.

title: 8 SENATORS EXPLAIN WHY THEY SWITCHED VOTE
description: Eight Senators who switched their votes on the Saudi arms sale today cited as reasons the Reagan Administration's removal of Stinger portable missiles from the weapons package and the need to support the President on foreign policy.

title: He Can't Be Exonerated Of His Guilt
description: Hitler, Adolf Eichmann, Josef Mengele, Klaus Barbie - all were war criminals who, beyond any doubt, reasonable or otherwise, committed heinous crimes against humanity. Kurt Waldheim belongs in a different category altogether, and he may or may not in fact have been a war criminal. But that hardly exonerates him of guilt for his participation in the absolute evil of the Hitler era.

title: RENEWING A SECTION OF ALBANY
description: Seventy construction workers are swarming through blighted buildings on this city's Clinton Avenue these days, some tearing down pieces of the badly worn structures, others carefully reshaping elaborate cornices.

title: ABZUG RUNNING FOR CONGRESS FROM DISTRICT IN WESTCHESTER
description: Bella S. Abzug, the former three-term United States Representative from Manhattan, re-entered the political fray today in a new arena, the 20th Congressional District of Westchester County.

title: Davy P.R. Crockett
description: Political image-making has only recently been taken over by the professionals, but it has a long history on the American hustings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JUNE 6, 1986
description: International The President's backers mustered just enough votes in the Senate to allow the sale of advanced missiles to Saudi Arabia. The margin was a single vote. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Advertising; J.&J.'s Medipren Goes To Lowe Marschalk
description: Lowe Marschalk has been designated as agency for Johnson & Johnson's ibuprofen entry, Medipren, which it will be able to sell in September. Until then exclusive rights on marketing such products are held by Bristol-Myers, which has Nuprin, and American Home Products, whose product is Advil.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Business Week to Stone & Adler for direct response/broadcast advertising.

title: FORMER OFFICIAL FOUND GUILTY ON 4 OF COUNTS IN ESPIONAGE TRIAL
description: After deliberating for more than 12 hours, a Federal jury today found Ronald W. Pelton guilty of selling highly sensitive intelligence secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: REBELS TO DISCUSS TRUCE, AQUINO SAYS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she had received information that the leadership of the Communist rebels had named an envoy to discuss the possibility of a cease-fire.

title: MARYMOUNT MANHATTAN: VOLCKER SEES PERILOUS FUTURE
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, cautioned graduates of Marymount Manhattan College that while their skills are badly needed, they face many hurdles in their careers.

title: HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Market Place; Sheller-Globe's Secret Suitors
description: WHEN Sheller-Globe Corporation shareholders vote next week on a proposed buyout plan, they will be deciding whether to hand over each of their shares in the auto parts company for cash and notes estimated by Wall Street to be worth about $47.

title: BROADWAY
description: LAST fall, Marvin Hamlisch, the composer, said he would be in semi-shock if ''Smile,'' the new musical he was working on, didn't see the lights of Broadway. Well, everyone who cares about Mr. Hamlisch or his music can breathe a sigh of relief. ''Smile'' has, as they say, a date and a theater - Nov. 16 at the Lunt-Fontanne.

title: DAVID G. BAIRD
description: David G. Baird, a philanthropist and founder of Baird & Company, a New York stock brokerage now known as Baird, Patrick & Company, died Wednesday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 91 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: RICHARD WALKER FISKE
description: Richard Walker Fiske, marketing and special projects manager of the International Paper Company, died Wednesday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.

title: Union Pacific To Buy Katy
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had reinstated an agreement with Katy Industries under which it would acquire the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad for $110 millon. The railroad, known as the

title: Hearing Set on Tests Of Police for Drug Use
description: A state judge has scheduled a hearing for Thursday on a request for a temporary injunction to prohibit the New York City Police Department from testing members of its Organized Crime Control Bureau to see if they are using drugs.

title: END OF GIMBELS IS REPORTED NEAR
description: The owner of Gimbels, after six months of searching for a buyer who would continue to operate the two Manhattan outlets as department stores, has given up and will sell both properties to a real estate developer, according to parties close to the negotiations.

title: Policeman Set Afire in India
description: A crowd protesting a decision on what language will be taught in schools doused a policeman with gasoline and set him ablaze today in the city of Belgaum, the United News of India reported.

title: Rogues Rewarded
description: Rafi Eitan is a hero, almost a legend, in Israel. He was the agent who tracked Adolf Eichmann to his South American hideout, and led the team that seized the war criminal and brought him to Israel for trial. When American lawmen met a different Israeli official with the first name of Rafi and asked if he were Eitan, the man replied modestly, ''I should be so lucky.''

title: FERDINAND FAVORITE
description: Ten 3-year-olds, including four who were raised in the same pastures, were entered yesterday for the 118th Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park tomorrow.

title: ISRAELIS ACCUSED IN CASE
description: Rafael Eitan Rafael Eitan, a 58-year-old veteran of the shadowy world of Israel's secret services, is a former chief of operations of Mossad, Israel's equivalent of the Central Intelligence Agency. He also served as an adviser on terrorism to Prime Ministers Menachem Begin and Yitzhak Shamir.

title: Betty Carter to Perform
description: The singer Betty Carter and her trio will perform tonight at 7 P.M. at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse, 466 Grand Street at Henry Street (598-0400). Tickets are $6, $4 for students and over 65's.

title: THEATER: BILLIE HOLIDAY DEPICTED IN 'LADY DAY'
description: THE richest jazz singing in town just now is at the Vineyard Theater, in ''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar & Grill.'' But there is much more than singing and lovely jazz ensemble accompaniment. Lonette McKee's realization of Billie Holiday is a subtle, absorbing dramatic performance. Her gift for understatement, and her sense of humor, give her evocation of Holiday's life uplifting power.

title: FILM: SCHWARZENEGGER'S 'RAW DEAL'
description: IF he continues to make movies like ''Raw Deal,'' Arnold Schwarzenegger may well become the thinking kid's Sylvester Stallone. ''Raw Deal'' isn't exactly Oscar material. It does nothing for the cause of nonviolence. It will warm the hearts of gun lobbyists everywhere, and its final body count may be even higher than that in Mr. Stallone's ''Cobra.'' Yet ''Raw Deal'' somehow manages to be measurably less offensive. At times, it's almost funny - intentionally.

title: Anderson, Clayton
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company said shareholders had approved its plan to pay $37 a cash plus a new share valued at up to $10 in exchange for the company's 12.2 million shares outstanding.

title:
WHAT DID WALDHEIM DO IN THE WAR?;
Why the Critics Are Unfair
description: Among the many fond memories from my school years in America, there is an epitaph from Einstein that comes to mind when I grapple with the recent distortions regarding the record of my father, Kurt Waldheim: ''The right to search for the truth also implies a duty. Onemust not conceal any part of what one has found to be true.''

title: A Dark New Identity
description: President Reagan apparently doesn't care - but other Americans should - that his policies are causing much of the world to identify the United States, rather than the Soviet Union, as the primary obstacle to nuclear disarmament.

title: N.F.L. WINS EVIDENCE RULING
description: The National Football League yesterday gained what could be an important advantage in its defense against the United States Football League's antitrust suit.

title: Fulfilling a 'Dream'
description: In seven National Hockey League seasons with the Washington Capitals, Bengt Gustafsson, the left wing from Sweden, totaled 160 goals and 272 assists in 479 games - second in each category in the Capitals' history. Now he has turned down what he called ''a dream offer'' from Washington and will return to his native land to play next season with Bofors of the Swedish Second Division. Gustafsson, who is 28 years old, and David Poile, the general manager of the Capitals, left open the possibility that the player might return to Washington next season in time for the last part of the regular schedule and the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Wickes Companies, which emerged from bankruptcy in January 1985, is again turning to the ''junk bond'' market for the money it needs to finance unidentified acquisitions of other businesses.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Richard Lloyd, the Cucumbers and Persian Gulf at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place (477-3728). Richard Lloyd, the former guitarist for Television, now writes heartfelt, Dylan-flavored rock songs and laces them with extraordinary guitar work. He will top a bill with two of the area's best unsigned bands, Persian Gulf and the Cucumbers, in a benefit concert for Amnesty International. The Cucumbers and Persian Gulf share a taste for smart, stripped-down, unconventional yet highly danceable rock songs. The Cucumbers put a 1980's twist on ''girl group'' rock; over taut guitar lines and crisp syncopations worthy of early Talking Heads, Deena Shoshkes sings in a bright, innocent voice about love, betrayal and entropy, often harmonizing with the Cucumbers' other guitarist-songwriter, Jon Fried. Persian Gulf is gruffer and more disillusioned. Hal Shows's songs are as rawboned as the best Creedence Clearwater; they link personal frustration and political rage without wasting a word or a note. The Gyros open Saturday at 10 P.M., followed by Persian Gulf, the Cucumbers and Richard Lloyd. Tickets are $12.

title: 'WHITTINGHAM COUNTRY'
description: At dinner one night at a Los Angeles restaurant several years ago, Woody Stephens reached to pick up the tab, but Charlie Whittingham grabbed it.

title: SALVADORAN'S FUTILE BID TO BREAK FREE
description: In many ways he was like the thousands of other Salvadorans who have been caught between opposing forces in a civil war, a conflict they feel has gone on too long and fear is not close to ending.

title: FILM: GILBERT'S 'NOT QUITE PARADISE'
description: THE young volunteers at the kibbutz Kfar Ezra are a sturdy lot. Traveling from all over the world to experiment with communal living in Israel, they endure heat, dust, hard work and the rather remarkable bad humor of their Israeli hosts. The resident kibbutzniks play cute little jokes on the new arrivals, such as letting them think they are about to be bombed by Arabs. One of the nastiest of a decidedly inhospitable lot is Gila, played with a surly sneer by Joanna Pacula.

title: IT'S JUNE, AND FRAGRANCES WAFT ALL OVER TOWN
description: It isn't just the roses in bloom that are perfuming the air in New York this week. This is, by mayoral proclamation, Fragrance Week. Which explains those flower carts adding a touch of Paris to midtown streets, those floral wreaths on the lions guarding the 42d Street Public Library, and the even more aggressive than usual distribution of perfume samples in stores.

title: JOBS FOR SUMMER GO UNFILLED AS TEEN-AGERS SHUN LOW WAGES
description: As the summer job season approaches, many employers in cities and suburbs around the nation are encountering a conundrum: Despite statistics showing high unemployment among teen-agers, especially blacks, there are more openings than there are young applicants to fill them.

title: Key Rates
OPERETTA: VIENNESE COMPANY IN 'CZAREVITCH'
description: ''THE CZAREVITCH'' comes late in the canon of Franz Lehar's operettas and even later to this country. The Viennese Operetta Company of America, which staged the piece at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night, did so, indeed, with the claim that this 1927 work is new to the United States altogether, though recordings of it can be had.

title: SENATORS WON MANY EXCEPTIONS IN BILL TO AID SPECIFIC TAXPAYERS
description: The Senate Finance Committee's tax-revision bill, intended to create a more uniform tax system for businesses and individuals, contains dozens of special exceptions granted to individuals and corporations, ranging from Phillips Petroleum, Unocal and Walt Disney to a private estate that has been fighting the Internal Revenue Service in court for nine years.

title: Scott Sells Unit To Reynolds
description: The Scott Paper Company, a leading producer of toilet tissues and paper towels and napkins, said it had agreed to sell its Cut-Rite brand of wax paper to the Reynolds Metals Company. The company would not disclose the purchase price, but said that the gain from the sale would ''more than offset'' an $8 million one-time charge associated with an early retirement program put into effect by Scott during the second quarter.

title: More Delays on Banking Bill
description: The nine Democratic members of the House Rules Committee today unanimously voted to delay indefinitely any action on a hotly debated bill that would outlaw limited-service banks, Congressional sources said.

title: LLOYD, NAVRATILOVA SET FOR PARIS FINAL
description: There were dreams of a different women's final in the French Open this year. Young Steffi Graf was mentioned, as was the veteran Hana Mandlikova and the younger veteran Helena Sukova. Some whispered the names Gabriela Sabatini and Manuela Maleeva.

title: Baby Approved for a Heart
description: An infant with an underdeveloped heart will be considered for a heart transplant, hospital officials said today, reversing a decision to bar him because doctors had said his young, unwed parents could not afford adequate post-surgical care. The decision of the Loma Linda University Medical Center came after custody of the baby was transferred to his paternal grandparents. A hospital spokesman said a search for a donor heart had begun.

title: Rights Leaders Seized By Zimbabwean Police
description: Zimbabwean policemen today arrested the leaders of the country's top human rights group, the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace, a move that is expected to further strain relations between Zimbabwe and its Western aid donors, the United States and Britain.

title: MOTIVES ARE UNCLEAR IN MOVE TO EMBARRASS
description: Poland's assertion this week that the United States learned about plans to impose martial law in 1981, but withheld it from Solidarity is the latest Polish attempt to embarrass the Reagan Administration. There is agreement among diplomats and others that it is the most serious.

title: Estimate Board Shift Sought
description: A City Council committee unanimously passed a resolution yesterday calling on the State Legislature to strip the Board of Estimate of its budgetary powers. Such action would shift full powers over the budget to the Council, subject only to the Mayor's veto. After the 9-to-0 vote, Peter F. Vallone, the Council majority leader, predicted that the full Council would pass the resolution Wednesday.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After writedowns of $63.5 million on oil and gas properties and $7.75 million on drilling rigs and certain real estate in Dallas. c-Net income.

title: HAITI AT 'THE EDGE OF ANARCHY,' LEADER SAYS
description: Gen. Henri Namphy, the President of Haiti, said today that a wave of anti-Government protests this week had brought the country to ''the edge of anarchy.''

title: BRYAN (BITSY) GRANT
description: Bryan (Bitsy) Grant, who won more than 50 national amateur tennis tournaments during his career, died of cancer Thursday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A television review yesterday of ''Still Separate, Still Unequal,'' a segment of the WNET/Channel 13 series ''Currents'' that dealt with school integration, misidentified a high school in Englewood, N.J. It is Dwight Morrow High School.

title: Economic Scene; Israel's Search For Growth
description: THE halt of hyperinflation in Israel is the necessary but not sufficient condition for resumed economic growth.

title: Unlock the Dental Clinics in New York Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: S.I. BOROUGH CHIEF'S SON IS CLEARED IN ASSAULT
description: The 17-year-old son of Ralph J. Lamberti, the Staten Island Borough president, was cleared of assault charges by a grand jury yesterday in what the police had originally called a racially motivated attack on a black teen-ager.

title: VOLCKER DENIES FED POLICY SHIFT
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said today that he did not intend to signal a tighter monetary policy when, earlier this week, he pointed to the potential for revived inflation.

title: CLERICS VOW TO DEFY PRETORIA PROTEST BAN
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu urged the nation's churches today to defy a newly announced Government ban on commemorations of the 1976 Soweto uprising.

title: A Quest: $13,333 Left in Iran
description: When the Shah of Iran fell from power in January 1979, most Americans in that country who were not working in the United States Embassy quickly packed up their things and left.

title: ODETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $301,000 resulting from the issuance and distribution expenses incurred in the company's exchange offer during fiscal year 1985. Corrected from Wednesday, June 4, editions.

title: S.E.C. OFFERS REMEDIES FOR THE 'WITCHING HOUR'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed three ways to reduce the often-violent price swings in stocks on the four days a year when stock options, index options and futures on index options all expire, also called the ''triple witching hour.''

title: Bridge: A Young Manhattan Player Will Be Competing in Peking
description: When the Epson World Simultaneous Pairs is played June 14 under the auspices of the World Bridge Federation there will be some very young players and some players far from home.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Optioned Urbano Lugo, a relief pitcher, to Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League.

title: In a Hundred Centuries . . .
description: What is society to do with radioactive wastes that will remain dangerous for 10,000 years? Nuclear power plants were built on the premise that safe storage of their waste would be no problem. Thirty years later the Government is still groping for an acceptable site. Beating yet another retreat, the Department of Energy has now postponed its search for a permanent storage site in the Eastern United States.

title: RED SOX STOPPED BY BREWERS, 7-5
description: Dale Sveum, a Milwaukee rookie, hit a bases-loaded double in a four-run third inning, extending his hitting streak to 14 games, and Bill Wegman scattered six hits over seven and one-third innings tonight as the Brewers stopped a five-game winning streak by the Boston Red Sox with a 7-5 victory.

title: Late Program Buying Helps Dow Gain 16.15
description: A surge of buying by institutions in the last hour of trading yesterday changed a losing day on Wall Street into a winner, but volume remained in a slump as investors were still attempting to determine the Federal Reserve Board's feelings about interest rates.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 7, 1986
description: The Economy

title:
PATENTS;
A Device to Detect Counterfeit Currency
description: An improved apparatus, including a magnetic sensor, for detecting counterfeit currency has been invented for Brandt Inc. of Benselem, a Philadelphia suburb.

title: Metromedia Unit Sale Seen
description: Metromedia Inc., the communications concern that has been divesting itself of TV and radio stations and other properties, is considering the sale of its cellular radio and paging system, according to industry sources, who asked not to be named.

title: FOX PHOTO reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
RATES FALL SHARPLY ON JOB DATA
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday as weak employment data for May caused market participants to set aside the concerns that depressed trading activity and increased interest rates earlier in the week.

title: Reagan's TV Advice
description: As is his custom, President Reagan used some colorful language the other day when he gave senators advice on how to handle themselves when appearing on television on the floor of the Senate.

title: Aviation Official Resigns
description: Richard H. Jones, the second-highest official of the Federal Aviation Administration, plans to leave the agency July 15. Mr. Jones, a former Eastern Airlines pilot, was appointed Deputy Administrator of the F.A.A. in 1984 by President Reagan. He is was the first active airline pilot to work for the F.A.A. in a senior management position. His resignation was announced Wednesday.

title: Endorsement in Queens, Amended
description: We owe Richard Dietl an apology for underestimating his Republican-Conservative candidacy for Congress in Queens and, to add insult to injury, misspelling his name. His bid in Tuesday's special election, to fill the seat of the late Joseph Addabbo, merits serious consideration.

title: FIRMS ACT IN WAKE OF 2 SCANDALS
description: Stung by two major insider trading cases in the last month, Wall Street has responded with a spate of security procedure reviews and memorandums to employees emphasizing the need to keep inside information confidential and reminding them of the penalties for breaking the securities laws.

title: Big Board Directors Elect
description: The New York Stock Exchange's directors yesterday elected Richard R. Shinn executive vice chairman and Donald Stone vice chairman.

title: Eyes on Senator Heflin
description: When the hotly contested nomination of Jefferson B. Sessions 3d to a Federal judgeship in Alabama came up before the Senate Judiciary Committee this week, probably no vote was more closely watched than that of Senator Howell Heflin, a Democrat from, yes, Alabama.

title: ISRAELIS PUBLICLY SILENT ABOUT SPY'S GUILTY PLEA
description: Two days after an American caught spying for Israel pleaded guilty in Washington, officials here are withholding public comment on the case, apparently in the hope that the scandal will eventually blow over.

title: RECITAL: CATHERINE KAUTSKY
description: Catherine Kautsky is a pianist who can play Mozart and Schubert as though their sentiments and habits of musical speech coincided exactly with hers, and she did so most agreeably at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night. The works involved were Mozart's great Rondo in A minor and Schubert's Sonata in A (Op. Posth.)

title:
PATENTS;
Help for a Hangover
description: For the treatment of a hangover and high alcoholic content in the blood, a salt is recommended in a patent received this week by a French concern. The preparation is Betaine Citrate in an acceptable carrier. Philippe M. Guinot assigned patent No. 4,593,020 to a scientific council in Paris.

title: MARS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-Net income

title: Man Held in Sexual Assaults Is Charged in Brooklyn Killing
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man who is being held in connection with at least five sexual assaults in Brooklyn was charged yesterday with the murder of a Brooklyn teen-ager in February, the authorities said.

title: Credit Card War
description: Connecticut's credit card war heated up on Thursday as the Hartford-based Society for Savings announced a new interest rate of 10.9 percent.

title: 5 SIKHS ARE DENIED BAIL IN MONTREAL
description: Five Sikhs charged with possessing explosives with intent to injure were denied bail today.

title: Didn't Dot an i? You're Off the Ballot
description: In a perennial spring rite, New York State politicians seeking nomination in the September primaries have begun circulating petitions to gain a place on the ballot. The idea that a petition containing some minimum number of signatures be required of aspiring candidates is hardly objectionable. The problem is that in New York State the nitpicking legal requirements for valid signatures present insuperable obstacles to bona fide candidates who fail for one reason or other to dot their i's and cross their t's.

title: Boys High School Reunion
description: Frederick Pohl looked over the dust jacket of his new book, his 10th. It had just arrived from the printer.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT UP TO 7.2% IN MAY
description: The unemployment rate jumped two-tenths of a percentage point in May as the nation's economy generated only one new job for every two people who joined the labor force, the Government reported today.

title: NEW STAGE IN STRATFORD: THE SWAN
description: With the opening of its newest theater, the Swan, there is no century of English-speaking theater in which the Royal Shakespeare Company is not entrenched. Its five theaters -and its three profit-seeking productions being performed elsewhere -represent playwrights from the late 1500's to the present.

title: When La Guardia Said Parks Are for People
description: To the Editor:

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,773,000 for the quarter and year. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,137,000.

title: Article 517986 -- No Title
description: The Senate today approved a $3.9 billion supplemental appropriation bill for 1986 that includes anything from funds to keep the Commodity Credit Corporation operating to such election-year gems as a pilot project to speed blackbird migration.

title: Impala and KDI
description: The Impala Pacific Corporation has increased its stake in the KDI Corporation to 22.9 percent, from 20.9 percent.

title: D-Day Marked in Normandy
description: French, British, Canadian and United States officials went to Normandy today for ceremonies marking the 42d anniversary of D-day, when 156,000 Allied troops landed in France to start the final push against Nazi Germany.

title: JURORS DESCRIBE TURNING POINTS ON SPY VERDICT
description: The jury that convicted Ronald W. Pelton of espionage Thursday went to extraordinary lengths to decide that he had confessed voluntarily, according to three jurors.

title: On the Futility of Commissions on Pornography; Threat to the Family
description: To the Editor:

title: A Restaurant and Politics
description: In a transformation as much political as gastronomic, Vienna '79, a prominent, once highly rated Manhattan restaurant, has closed.

title: BITTERNESS GROWS AT A.T.&T. STRIKE
description: The head of the Communications Workers of America insisted today that he had ''the full support of every union in America'' and would increase pressure on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to settle its nationwide strike.

title: REAGAN PRESSES HARD FOR CONTRA AID
description: President Reagan today renewed his drive for $100 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, saying that the failure to finance their effort to overthrow the Sandinistas could mean a ''divided war-torn region with Nicaragua as a refuge for terrorism.''

title: CONSTANCE K. ENGLISH
description: Constance Kent English, a social activist in Rockland County, N.Y., for many years, died Thursday at her home in Pomona.

title: BRAWL MARS SPLIT BY METS
description: The Mets got into their second team brawl in 11 days tonight when they exchanged insults and punches with the Pittsburgh Pirates after accusing Rick Rhoden of cutting or otherwise doctoring the baseball.

title: Luciano Changes Mind
description: A former umpire changed his decision yesterday. Ron Luciano said in Endicott, N.Y., that he would not run for public office this year.

title: Florilegium Choir
description: The Florilegium Chamber Choir, under the direction of JoAnn Rice, will present the world premiere of Judith Lang Zaimont's ''Parable - A Tale of Abram and Isaac'' at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

title: Bridge; When a Defeat Is Inevitable, Despair May Be Best Course
description: Whether ''Nil desperandum,'' or ''Never despair,'' is a sound maxim for bridge players is open to doubt. There are times when a player should resign himself to defeat in order to limit the loss.

title: JUDGE SAYS ROBINS ACTS LOOK 'LIKE SUBTERFUGE'
description: A Federal judge said today that the A. H. Robins Company had acted suspiciously by having its subsidiaries make transactions that Robins itself was barred from making because of bankruptcy proceedings.

title: BRITISH PRINT UNIONS REJECT MURDOCK'S 'FINAL OFFER'
description: A $75 million ''final offer'' of compensation from the publisher Rupert Murdoch was decisively rejected by 5,500 former employes, whose unions have been picketing and demonstrating at his new plant for more than four months.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing International Race of Champions, at Detroit. Bobby Rahal, the Indianapolis 500 winner, leads the field of 12 of the world's top drivers in identically prepared IROC Z-28 Chevrolet Camaros. (Television - Channel 2, 5 P.M., tape.) Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 1:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 1:30 P.M.) Mets at Pittsburgh, 7:05 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7 P.M.) Dodgers vs. Houston Astros, at Los Angeles. (Television - Channel 4, 3:15 P.M.) Padres vs. Atlanta Braves, at San Diego. (Television - WTBS, 10 P.M.). Expos vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Montreal. (Radio - WCBS, 880; 7:20 P.M.) College World Series, at Omaha. (Television - ESPN, 5 and 8 P.M.) Boxing James (Bonecrusher) Smith vs. Jesse (Thunder) Ferguson, 10-round heavyweight bout at Hamilton, Bermuda. Smith, from Magnolia, N.C., is coming off an impressive victory over the former World Boxing Association champion Mike Weaver to improve his record to 16-5, with 13 knockouts. Ferguson, from Philadelphia, is 14-2, with 10 knockouts. (Television -Channel 9, 9 P.M.) Golf Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, at Harrison, N.Y., third round. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) L.P.G.A. McDonald's Championship, at Malvern, Pa., third round. (Television - USA, 3:30 P.M.) Soccer World Cup, at Mexico: Mexico vs. Paraguay, at Mexico City, 2 P.M. (Television - Channel 41, 1:45 P.M. live); Poland vs. Portugal at Monterrey, 6 P.M. (Television - Channel 41, 5:45 P.M. live); and Spain vs.

title: EXTRADITION TREATY FOR U.S. AND BRITAIN BACKED BY SENATORS
description: A new version of the disputed extradition treaty between the United States and Britain has won the support of a majority of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, committee sources said today.

title: ROBERT EDWARD LANG
description: Robert Edward Lang, the first director of Radio Free Europe and a former vice president of both CBS News and ABC News, died of cancer Tuesday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Punishing the Innocent Is Unjust Redress
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Canada Rift Widens
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was beginning an investigation that could lead to duties on Canadian softwood lumber imports, the latest in a series of trade disputes between the two nations.

title: DANCE: PREMIERE OF 'PICCOLO BALLETTO'
description: Jerome Robbins calls his newest ballet ''Piccolo Balletto,'' and a little ballet it is. It is a minor work without pretension, very well made. The Italian title is reflected in the ballet's commedia dell'arte spirit, which itself is underscored by Santo Loquasto's Harlequin and Columbine costumes.

title: SOVIET WAS REPORTEDLY TOLD ABOUT WALDHEIM
description: A former senior Yugoslav intelligence official said today that Soviet intelligence officers in Vienna were told ''in late 1947 or early 1948'' that Kurt Waldheim was sought by Yugoslavia for involvement in war crimes.

title: ALLIANCE TIRE & RUBBER CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it converted its results into dollars using the exchange rate of one new Israeli sheckel to 0.667 of a dollar.

title: Fauntroy's Numbers
description: Walter E. Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's nonvoting delegate in Congress, seldom misses a chance to make a pitch for upgraded status for Washington.

title: Civic Leaders Discuss Concerns for July 4th
description: A group of city, state and community leaders from lower Manhattan met yesterday to resolve concerns about safety, sanitation and access to the area during the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration on the Fourth of July weekend.

title: On the Futility of Commissions on Pornography
description: To the Editor:

title: Roof Rentals Are Taxable
description: Not that he wants to ''rain on the fireworks,'' as he put it. But the new City Finance Commissioner, Abraham Biderman, issued a ''friendly reminder'' to New Yorkers who plan to rent apartments with views for the Fourth of July weekend - the rental income is taxable.

title: RITE OF PROM SEASON: SPLURGES, BRUISED EGOS AND A SLEEPY VIGIL
description: Anyone who thinks that buying a corsage and renting some shoes and a tuxedo is all it takes to get ready for a prom probably also considers being asked for identification a compliment and classifies 18 as young.

title: Ex-Bank Aide in Guilty Plea
description: Wayne Liang, formerly a marketing director for Chinatown's failed Golden Pacific National Bank, has pleaded guilty in Federal court in Manhattan to conspiring to have the bank make and conceal an illegal campaign contribution to the ''Cranston for President Campaign'' in 1983.

title: NATIONAL HARDGOODS DISTRIBTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
WOUNDED MODEL RETAINS HER FAITH IN CAREER AND CITY
description: Her face raked with deep gashes, Marla Hanson said yesterday that the terrifying razor attack and wounds she suffered at the hands of thugs on a dark West Side street had not crushed her dreams of a modeling career or her faith in New York.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ILLEGAL GUNS SEIZED IN 2 RAIDS
description: Federal agents today seized 1,500 illegal machine guns, including some believed to have been bound for the Middle East and 12 ordered by Jean-Claude Duvalier before he was deposed as the President of Haiti, officials said.

title: WALDHEIM BOOK LACKS PASSAGE
description: In a key paragraph in the German-language edition of his memoir, ''In the Eye of the Storm,'' Kurt Waldheim writes that he returned to service in the German Army after recovering from a leg wound early in World War II and was in the area of Trieste when German troops capitulated in Italy.

title: A LEAN A.&P. FLEXES MUSCLES
description: James Wood, the chairman and chief executive at A.&P., recalls the time only a few years ago when his company was forced to buy other store chains to expand, because shopping-center developers would not accept stores with A.&P.'s own name: they did too poorly.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CALIFORNIA OIL SUIT IN LEGAL SETBACK
