description: In a setback for the state of California, a Federal district judge has ruled that the latest in a series of antitrust lawsuits charging eight oil companies with conspiracy and price-fixing must be decided in Federal court.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes losses from the initial operations of joint ventures of $669,000 for the quarter and $1,111,000 for the 6 months and charges from the excess of interest expense over investment income of 10 cents a share and 17 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Gains from the sale of securities were included of 6 cents a share for the quarter and 7 cents a share for the 6 months. c-Includes a gain from the sale of securities of 9 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months. Charges of 7 cents a share and 11 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, were included from the excess of interest expense over investment income.

title: PLANNING OFFICIAL RESIGNS AMID INVESTIGATIONS
description: Theodore E. Teah, who is under investigation by state and Federal authorities in connection with the city's corruption scandal, has resigned from the city's Planning Commission, the commission announced yesterday.

title: JUROR CONTENDS PEERS PRESSURED STUN-GUN VOTE
description: A juror in the case of two police officers convicted of torturing a prisoner with an electric stun gun said in an affidavit made public yesterday that she had agreed to the verdict because other jurors had made her ''fearful of being physically abused'' by them if she did not agree.

title: Hammering Canada's Shingles
description: President Reagan, who deplores protectionism, has now stirred up a good example of its destructiveness. Last month, at the urging of American shingle makers and a few senators, he slapped a 35 percent tariff on cedar shingles from Canada - a nice favor for a little industry. This week Canada slapped back, raising tariffs on American computer parts, Christmas trees, cider, tea bags and several other items. If those industries now lay off workers as Canadian sales slump, they'll know whom to blame. America's competitive tea bag producers will pay to protect uncompetitive shingle producers.

title: LONG ISLAND UNIVERSITY-BROOKLYN: CARE ABOUT SUFFERING, WEISEL TELLS GRADUATES
description: Elie Wiesel told the graduates of the Long Island University Brooklyn campus yesterday that unless they remained sensitive to suffering, their ''children will inherit the ruins of the world.''

title: MARVIN J. TAYLOR
description: Marvin J. Taylor, former associate director of the Association of Theological Schools in the United States and Canada, died of cancer May 29 at his home in Little Rock, Ark.

title: CITY JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 7.9%
description: New York City's unemployment rate edged downward to 7.9 percent in May, from 8.7 percent in April and 8.4 percent in May 1985, according to Federal labor statistics released yesterday.

title: 20th Bus Victim Is Listed
description: A woman whose body was presumably swept away after a tour bus slid into an icy river was identified Thursday as Meryle Martin.

title: This Whiskery Tedium
description: The Duke of Windsor shaved twice a day. This sad disclosure comes from the current Vanity Fair, which contains several hundred yards about how the Duke and Duchess soldiered bravely on in Paris exile with scarcely 20 servants in support.

title: ANITEC IMAGE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

PATENTS;
Reducing Pollutants From Furnaces
description: A method of reducing pollutant emission from certain furnaces in which coal or wood is burned was patented this week for the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Lifesaving Techniques Made More Cautious
description: The American Heart Association and American Red Cross today recommended improved lifesaving methods that, for the first time, list precautions for resuscitating victims who may have infectious diseases.

title: HEALTHPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush, Disclosing '85 Wealth, Puts Value of Gifts at $27,800
description: Vice President Bush received more than $27,800 in gifts last year, his financial disclosure form showed today.

title: GUNMEN KILL 3 AND INJURE 2 AT A BANK IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Two gunmen walked into a branch bank in this rural community today and without saying a word opened fire, killing three bank employees and critically wounding a bank manager and a customer, the police said.

title: Guggenheim's Attic
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Sets A Record At 1,885.90
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record level yesterday, as blue-chip issues outperformed other market segments in a session of mixed prices and light trading.

title: Address Books - or, the Game of the Name
description: My address book was a mess. Its spine was torn, its cover ragged; coffee and ink stained its pages. And it bulged with scraps of paper and business cards I'd carelessly thrown in the back. So I was delighted to receive a new address book for my birthday, a sleek red leather one that lay neat and flat on the corner of my desk.

title: CHIEF OF BELEAGUERED GARMENT UNION: JAY MAZUR
description: Jay Mazur took control of New York's largest union today, warning of bad times and promising something better.

title: Bowman to Remain
description: After intensive deliberations that lasted two months, the co-owners of the Buffalo Sabres have decided to retain Scotty Bowman as coach, general manager and director of hockey operations. Seymour H. Knox III, the chairman of the board, and his brother Northrup R. Knox, the president, announced that Bowman, the National Hockey League's leader in career coaching victories with 736, would come back even though the Sabres finished fifth and last in the Adams Division last season.

title: Ethiopian Official Quits, Vowing Not to Go Home
description: A leading Ethiopian relief official said today that he was quitting his post and would not return home.

title: Your Money; Collecting Liberty Coins
description: ASK Douglas Bowsky, customer service manager of the Sears, Roebuck & Company store in Brooklyn, about United States Liberty Coins and he responds with enthusiasm. ''The coins are doing very well,'' he said. ''The initial shipment came in and we had to go back and order.''

title: A Timely Tribute to Nathan Hale
description: The last few months have been difficult for the American intelligence community, what with battles over unauthorized disclosures to the press on one hand and confessions by intelligence officers of spying for foreign countries on the other.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AILEY DANCERS - The Alvin Ailey American Dance Center (997-1950) in Times Square is a 17-year-old school for dancers. The Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble is the school's student company. Some of the best students go on to the 28-year-old Alvin Ailey Dance Theater. Half of the theater troupe's dancers are graduates of the school. And a number of graduates and students, totaling 40 to 50 dancers in all, will dance together today at 8 P.M. Dance Theater members who are school alumni will perform works from the company's repertory. To Brazilian music the students will dance Walter Raines's ''Connotations'' and, with 17 dancers, ''Thresholds,'' by Penny Frank. Eight student dancers will perform in an excerpt from ''Dream Time,'' by Elisa Monte.

title: Second Lutheran Pastor Defrocked Over Protests
description: A second dissident Lutheran pastor has been defrocked for defying his superiors by staging protests for the unemployed aimed at many of Pittsburgh's major corporations.

title: FLOYD PENALIZES SELF, POSTS 67
description: Ray Floyd, one of the PGA Tour's most successful longtime campaigners, said, ''I've always felt that if you can lead your life on a standard set by the Rules of Golf, you're going to be a pretty straight individual.''

title: Teacher Pay-Raise Bill Passed in Connecticut
description: The Connecticut General Assembly approved last night a $92 million program to raise the pay of most of the state's 33,000 teachers and to revamp the way they are trained and licensed.

title: Filipino Reports Kidnapping
description: Three gunmen have kidnapped a French Roman Catholic missionary from Mindanao State University, a clergyman in Manila said today. The clergyman said the Rev. Michel Gigord, 46 years old, was abducted on Wednesday.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: The latest quarter and year figures include the results of Burris Industries and Rose Johnson Inc., which were acquired during the 1986 fiscal year.

title: 308 PRISONERS FREED IN NICARAGUA
description: The Government has freed 308 prisoners pardoned earlier in the week, including some who had been bodyguards for Anastasio Somoza Debayle, the former dictator.

title: On Baby Boomers
description: Excerpt from ''The Federal Budget and the Economy,'' an article by John H. Makin, director of fiscal policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute, which appeared in a recent issue of The AEI Economist:

title: SHARP INCREASE IS FOUND IN CATHOLICS WHO FAVOR WOMEN AS PRIESTS
description: A survey for the Catholic University of America has found a sharp increase in support among Roman Catholics in this country for the ordination of women as priests.

title: Radio Transmitters For Mountaineers
description: To the Editor:

title: SIKHS ARE DENIED BAIL IN MONTREAL
description: Five Sikhs charged with possessing explosives with intent to injure were denied bail today.

title: ORMSBY IS PERMANENTLY PARALYZED
description: Kathy Ormsby, the North Carolina State runner who bolted from a race and jumped off a bridge in an apparent suicide attempt Wednesday night, is paralyzed from just above the waist down, the physician in charge of her case said today.

title: PLAN FOR IRAQI-SYRIAN TALKS REPORTED
description: A high-ranking Iraqi official was quoted today as saying that his Government and Syria would soon hold talks, a step that could end two decades of antagonism.

title: CORRECTION
description: A theater review of ''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar & Grill'' in Weekend yesterday omitted the name of the director. He was Andre Ernotte.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JUNE 7, 1986
description: International

title: WEBSTER CLOTHES reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: The net income figures in both periods have been adjusted to reflect pro- forma tax provisions.

title: A Dartmouth Paper Settles Minister's Suit
description: A conservative student newspaper at Dartmouth College has settled a $3 million lawsuit filed by a former college chaplain who asserted that the paper had permanently damaged his reputation.

title: TV Offers Poor Role Models for Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAINEES CUT HAIR AND PRICE AT TOP SALONS
description: A haircut can cost $100 at the David Daines Hair Salon in Manhattan or it can cost nothing. Blond highlights at La Coupe can cost $150 or they can be free. There are similar bargains at other top hair emporiums such as Jean-Louis David, Bruno Le Salon, Vidal Sassoon, Pipino-Buccheri and Richard Stein Haircutting.

title: It Is Not Too Late to Save the Clinton Section
description: To the Editor:

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: At 'Ground Zero,' a Fear of the Fourth
description: ''To flee'' - that is Randi Sobel's plan for New York's historic, histrionic, hypertrophic Fourth of July celebration. She is not the only one with that in mind.

title: Truce in Southern Beirut Lasts Only Overnight
description: An uneasy truce took hold overnight at three Palestinian districts on the southern outskirts of Beirut, but it was broken today as Palestinian and Shiite Moslem fighters resumed clashes with rockets and machine guns.

title: OTHERS EXPECTED TO JOIN MERRILL IN RATE INCREASE
description: Discount brokers and analysts said yesterday that they expect most major brokers to emulate a move by Merrill Lynch & Company to raise its retail commission rates. Merrill Lynch announced that it would increase its rates by an average of 5 percent on stocks and stock options trades involving less than $10,000 starting June 20.

title: U.S. Retirement Plan Signed
description: President Reagan today signed into law legislation creating a three-tier plan to provide retirement benefits for all civilian Federal workers hired after Dec. 31, 1983. The law also covers members of Congress.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about guilty pleas in an insider-trading case incorrectly described the two offenses to which one defendant, Robert Salsbury, pleaded guilty. They were one count of endeavoring to obstruct justice and one count of conspiracy to commit mail fraud.

title: Botnick Punishment: Donation of 30 Days
description: Mayor Koch yesterday directed Victor E. Botnick, chairman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, to donate 30 days of community service working in a hospital as punishment for lying about his college background.

title: TURNER TO SELL MGM ASSETS
description: The Turner Broadcasting System said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a number of assets of the MGM Entertainment Company in two separate transactions. The sales will raise $490 million for Turner.

title: CLEMENS WINS, 3-0, FOR No. 10
description: Roger Clemens pitched a four-hitter for his 10th straight victory and Wade Boggs raised his average to .404 and drove in three runs tonight, giving the Boston Red Sox a 3-0 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Batus Selling Four Gimbels Stores
description: Batus Inc. said it had agreed to sell four Gimbels stores in suburban Pittsburgh to the May Department Stores Company. It also said it planned to close two other stores and sublease a seventh.

title: Consumer Borrowing Up Sharply
description: Americans increased their short-term installment debt at a 9.1 percent annual rate in April, up from a revised 6.8 percent rate in March but down from the 11.8 percent credit growth rate in the first quarter of 1986, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $15,000.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,854,000 for the quarter and $4,135,000 for the 6 months.

title: Smithsonian to Close Underground Garage
description: The Smithsonian Institution, after consulting with a private security company and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, will close an underground parking garage to the public Saturday as part of a larger effort to forestall terrorist acts in the capital.

title: 'PROUD PARENT' HUSSEIN ADDRESSES 45 GRADUATES
description: King Hussein of Jordan came here today to pay homage to a princess - his daughter, the volleyball captain.

title: U.S. URGES ISRAEL TO HELP IN INQUIRY ON ESPIONAGE CASE
description: The United States called on Israel today to provide ''full cooperation'' in the investigation of the evidence turned over by a former Navy analyst who has admitted spying for Israel.

title: STATE LEADS IN REPLACING U.S. ECONOMIC AID
description: New York has emerged in the forefront of states striving to restructure their own economies after undergoing drastic reductions in their manufacturing industries.

title: U.S. CUSTOMS IS ORDERED TO RELEASE MARCOS GOODS
description: A Federal District Court judge ordered the United States Customs Service today to release millions of dollars' worth of currency, jewelry and other valuables that Ferdinand E. Marcos brought into this country in February.

title: Boys Choir of Harlem
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem will present a benefit concert of pop, jazz, classics and spirituals at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

title: Turmoil in Cincinnati
description: Since Marge Schott bought controlling interest of the Cincinnati Reds a year-and-a-half ago, six top front office staffers have quit.

title: Inquiry Starts in Death Of a Boy After Surgery
description: The Queens District Attorney and the state agency that oversees dentists began a joint inquiry yesterday into the death of a 2-year-old Forest Hills boy on Thursday, six hours after a dental operation.

title: RECORD-KEEPING FOR PET OWNERS
description: In the category of ''what won't they think of next?'' comes the Pet Passport, the answer to pet lovers' prayers for a document containing important information on the care, feeding and identification of their animals.

title: 'MR. BELMONT' AND PEPPER
description: Below the red-and-white petunias in flower pots hanging outside Barn 3 at Belmont Park, a black Labrador retriever named Pepper was curled up, sleeping on the dirt.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. Six billion of these American icons are sold every year. What are they and why are they in the news? 2. The Israeli Cabinet replaced Yitzhak Zamir, the Attorney General, because he defied its wishes. What did Mr. Zamir do? 3. In what has become Manhattan's newest high-rent district, Alan McCord has leased his loft for one day for $25,000. Explain. 4. ''Today we catch up with the 20th century,'' Senator Bob Dole said as he and his colleagues embarked on a historic event. What happened? 5. Using new computer simulations, astronomers are embracing a theory about the origin of the Moon that just a few years ago seemed fantastic. What is it? 6. The bridal industry is heading into the June wedding season with bitterness, and the focus of this ill feeling is 1385 Broadway. Explain. 7. ''I think anyone in a sound mental state would not want to return from freedom to prison.'' Who made this comment and what were the circumstances? 8. In recent months, the number of human organ transplants has increased dramatically across the nation. What is the reason? 9. By winning the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship, Pat Bradley reached a milestone never before attained in women's golf. What did she accomplish? 10. Urban planners in Washington are concerned because a proposed skyscraper in suburban Maryland would exceed 555 feet, 5 inches in height.

title: MANAGER OUT AT THE PLATE
description: Steve Boros, the San Diego Padres manager, was ejected before tonight's game against the Atlanta Braves for bringing to the plate during the exchange of lineups a videotape of a controversial triple play.

title: 13 Beached Whales Fight For Life in Florida
description: Biologists were trying today to save 13 beached whales, aided by volunteers who were keeping the mammals' blow holes out of the water.

title: Rear-Seat Belts Planned by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would incorporate rear-seat lap-shoulder safety belts as standard equipment in selected 1987 models and in all of its cars by 1989.

title: TAKEOVER IS REJECTED BY CARVEL
description: The Carvel Corporation, whose empire of franchised ice cream stores is one of the nation's largest, said yesterday that it had rejected an offer to be acquired for $84.5 million by the Twistee Treat Corporation, a tiny Florida company with a chain of ice cream cone-shaped outlets.

title: NEIL FLANAGAN
description: Neil Flanagan, an actor and director who won an Obie award in 1967 for his starring role in Lanford Wilson's ''Madness of Lady Bright,'' died yesterday at his home in Los Angeles, where he had lived since 1977. Mr. Flanagan, who was 52 years old, had suffered from AIDS, according to his family.

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $415,000.

title: Tainted Blood Recipient Seeks $2.5 Million
description: A man who said he received a transfusion of blood tainted with the AIDS virus from a Milwaukee County medical center is seeking $2.5 million from the county, the man's lawyer said today.

title: Jetliner Reports Near Miss
description: An AirCal jetliner flying from Los Angeles to Portland came within 100 feet of a private plane Thursday before the jet's pilot banked to avoid a collision, according to the pilots' report to the Federal Aviation Administration. A spokesman for the agency in Seattle said the incident occurred as the AirCal jet, Flight 737, neared Portland.

title: PITCHER IS BALKING WITH A 20-2 RECORD
description: Mike Loynd was pitching in the game of his life last night. He stepped onto the mound for Florida State, the top-ranked baseball team in the nation, with the Seminoles one victory from a chance to play for the championship of the College World Series. A victory over Arizona would have been Loynd's 21st of the season, in the team's 71st game of the season, and would have tied the national collegiate record. Instead, he suffered only his second defeat of the season, losing a 5-0 lead before leaving with one out in the sixth inning of Arizona's 9-5 victory. It is possible Loynd will have one more chance at the record, but Florida State must stay alive in the double-elimination tournament and play for the championship Monday.

title: FINE IS CUT IN TEST OF GENE ALTERING
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today reduced the penalty against a California biotechnology concern that released a genetically altered chemical in the environment without authorization.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you ask young Americans about Vietnam, the reaction is the same: a lot of people don't want to talk about it.'' - Gerhardt Welley, leader of Youth for Waldheim. [ 2:5. ]

title: BONN OFFICIALS EXPECTED TO DELAY A CUT IN RATES
description: West German monetary authorities, whose fear of inflation has long made them loath to cut interest rates, are likely to stick to that position until key interest rates in other European countries are cut first, analysts say.

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $845,000 and a loss of $1,985,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $269,000 for the quarter and $659,000 for the 9 months.

title: Brazil Wins to Gain Round 2
description: Brazil, which is seeking to become the first nation to capture four World Cups, moved into the second round today with a 1-0 victory over Algeria.

title: CARRY-ON BAG LIMITS CONSIDERED
description: As more and more air travelers have sought to overcome slow baggage-handling by carrying their luggage aboard themselves, the airlines have been facing a mounting problem of where to stow it.

title: RHYTHM AND BLUES
description: SWEET SOUL MUSIC. Rhythm and Blues and the Southern Dream of Freedom.

title: POLICE TESTS ARE ASSAILED IN STATE STUDY
description: The design and grading of the New York City Police Department's entrance examination ''may not be consistent with minimum competence,'' according to a State Senate committee report released yesterday.

title: Hurdler Sets Mark
description: Danny Harris of Iowa State, a silver medalist in the 1984 Olympics, became a gold medalist for the third straight year tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's outdoor track and field championships.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10. 1. Oreo cookies are celebrating their 75th anniversary. 2. He ordered a criminal investigation of the head of Shin Beth, the internal security organization. 3. Mr. McCord's apartment and others in lower Manhattan that have direct views of the Statue of Liberty have brought high rental fees for the Fourth of July celebration in New York harbor. 4. The Senate began to broadcast its floor debate on television for the general public. The House began televising its proceedings in 1979. 5. That the Moon was born in a catastrophic collision between the Earth and another planet the size of Mars. 6. The building in the garment district is the headquarters for dozens of manufacturers of bridal dresses, and increasingly they are selling directly to customers instead of through retailers. 7. Yelena G. Bonner made the remark before flying back to the Soviet Union to be with her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident scientist. 8. The number of available organs has increased dramatically, a result of legislation enacted since January in 15 states requiring hospitals to solicit organ donations from families of dead or dying patients. 9. She became the first player to have won all four of the major tournaments making up the grand slam of women's golf. 10. The heights of buildings within the District are legally limited, so that the Washington Momument's 555 feet, 5 inches dominates the city's skyline. Opponents say the proposed building would diminish the monument's grandeur. 11.

title: Half a Response on Insurance
description: Finally, the Reagan Administration has responded to the hardships caused by the cost of liability insurance: it proposes a Federal law on product liability. Such a law may be needed, but this proposal falls far short of a meaningful response to the broader insurance crisis.

title: Why the Omissions on Medal of Liberty List
description: To the Editor:

title: No 'Star Wars' Crash Program, Please
description: The real issue in the debate over ''Star Wars'' is not whether we should conduct anti-ballistic missile research but rather the level of effort that is adequate. The Administration says a crash program for research is necessary. Certainly, research must continue, but such an accelerated effort would be a serious mistake.

title: Rain Could Cloud Belmont Outlook
description: The 118th Belmont Stakes, already an inscrutable race of limited significance, is likely to be further compromised by a muddy track today at Belmont Park.

title: MEDIATION EFFORT IN SOUTH AFRICA IS ENDED BY PANEL
description: A group of Commonwealth leaders has decided to give up its attempt at mediation between the South African Government and its main black nationalist opponents, a diplomat close to the group said here today.

title: Impressed at White House
description: A group of 97 eighth-graders and their teachers visiting the capital from the New York suburb of Ardsley, in Westchester County, got a V.I.P. tour of the White House the other day as the Secret Service attempted to make amends for having held the group up because of a minor traffic accident.

title:
PATENTS;
Protection for Flier In Emergency Ejection
description: As part of its design of a new cockpit for advanced-technology military aircraft, the Boeing Company proposes an ejection seat with attached parachute to enable a pilot to escape in an emergency.

title: Required Reading; On National Security
description: Excerpt from a speech by Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island, before the House of Representatives, June 4:

title: Times Square's Last Rites
description: Time is running out on Times Square the way the last seconds of a year tick down while a lighted ball high above descends every Dec. 31. But it is not to late to save Times Square.

title: TV: 'THE GREAT HEEP,' WITH C-3PO, ON ABC
description: ''If you saw the tragic state of my inner workings it would make your gyros crawl - I'm just a collection of old parts, hardly worth your trouble,'' protests the neurasthenic robot, C-3PO, as he faces mutilation at the hands of an apelike metal monster known as the Great Heep. One of the more endearing characters from George Lucas's ''Star Wars'' trilogy, C-3PO is the main protagonist of the one-hour animated adventure film, ''The Great Heep,'' directed by Clive A. Smith, that airs tonight at 8 o'clock on ABC.

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Irving Plaza Rock Club Closes for Lack of Rent
description: Irving Plaza, a rock club that was one of the city's major showcases for new bands, closed its doors yesterday.

title: Lieberman Makes Debut
description: Nancy Lieberman, the former United States Olympian, tonight became the first woman to play in a men's professional basketball league game. She scored 10 points, playing the entire second and fourth quarters, to help the Springfield Fame to a 135-115 victory over the Westchester Golden Apples in a United States Basketball League exhibition game.

title: Figure in Plot Gets 60-Year Prison Term
description: A man identified as the security chief for a white supremacist group known as the Order was sentenced today to 60 years in prison on Federal racketeering and conspiracy charges.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
EQUITEC FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Liberian Leader Pardons 34 Accused in Plot
description: Liberia's President, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, announced today that he had pardoned 34 people accused of conspiring to overthrow the Government.

title: AMID DISPUTES, SHUTTLE PANEL FINALLY FORGED AN AGREEMENT
description: The chairman of the President's commission on the space shuttle and the only Nobel laureate on the panel were at odds from the beginning. But now, after four months of investigating the Challenger disaster, the 13-member commission has reached a remarkable consensus, helped in part by the enormous, steadying influence of the first man to walk on the moon and by a two-star Air Force general.

title: NEW U.S. PRISON WILL BE ERECTED IN SOUTH JERSEY
description: For 18 months officials in this rural, economically stricken section of southern New Jersey have pressed hard to attract a new source of jobs - a Federal prison, of all things.

title: BARUCH: PIERCE SAYS OPPORTUNITIES STILL ABOUND
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Federal Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, urged the graduating class of the Bernard M. Baruch College yesterday to take full advantage of ''the greatest gift that America bestows,'' the gift of opportunity.

title: PATRICIA WHEEL
description: Patricia Wheel, a stage, film and television actress for more than 40 years, died June 3 in New York City after a long illness.

title: TRUMP TO REBUILD WOLLMAN RINK AT THE CITY'S EXPENSE BY DEC. 15
description: The developer Donald J. Trump will rebuild the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park at the city's expense under an agreement announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Charles F. Wennerstrum, 96; Served on Iowa's High Court
description: Charles Frederick Wennerstrum, a former Iowa Supreme Court judge who presided over and sharply criticized some of the Nuremberg war crimes trials after World War II, died Sunday of a heart attack. He was 96 years old.

title: PERNFORS STUNS LECONTE TO GAIN FINAL
description: One balloon fizzled at the French Open and another filled the stadium today as Johan Kriek lost and Mikael Pernfors won in the men's semifinals.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
BARRISTER INFORMATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding results give retroactive effect to a 3-for-2 stock split declared April 8, 1986.

title: INTERDYNE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: The company had negative sales after returns for the latest periods of $292,000 for the quarter and $276,000 for the 6 months, compared with sales of $143,000 for the year-ago quarter and $537,000 for the 6 months in 1985. Interdyne Co. said that sales for the quarter were impacted by returns of product under its previously announced recall program and the company also said that the problem for which the recall program was initiated has been corrected.

title: IN QUEST OF THE REAL TEX-MEX
description: By common agreement, the best Tex-Mex food in the United States is found in San Antonio. But where the line is drawn between Mexican food and Tex-Mex is beyond a Northerner's comprehension.

title: LABOR MOVEMENT: ERA OF HARD TIMES
description: Six thousand flight attendants strike Trans World Airlines. The strike is broken by hiring new workers, and 4,400 attendants lose their jobs with little complaint from other unionists.

title: THE MAYOR AND THE BOTNICK INCIDENT
description: From the beginning of the corruption scandal that has dominated his third term, Mayor Koch has made the same argument - that the wrongdoing is not ''systemic,'' that it is isolated and involves officials he did not appoint and in some cases did not even know.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and includes a gain of $185,000, or 6 cents a share, on the sale of real estate for the quarter and the 6 months.

title: PROSECUTOR ACCUSED ON HIS INQUIRY ON EDITOR
description: The prosecutor who brought about the resignation of a newspaper publisher by disclosing that he had fabricated a career as a combat pilot was accused by a grand jury Thursday of misusing his office to retaliate against the journalist for critical articles.

title: MASSACHUSETTS G.O.P. CANDIDATE FALSIFIED RECORD
description: A Republican candidate for Governor has admitted that he claimed falsely to have been a captain in the Special Forces in Vietnam, and politcal leaders say the incident was a furthur blow to an already weakened Republican Party here.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch yesterday from Cambridge, Mass., on commencement exercises at Harvard University, misidentified the recipient of an honorary doctorate of laws. He is Lewis Thomas, president emeritus of the Sloane-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: YANKEES FALL TO 3d PLACE
description: This was not what the Yankees had in mind for the start of their 27-game period of games against their division rivals. They lost to the Baltimore Orioles, 5-2, last night in a game that produced these results:

title: Citicorp Will Buy Shares of Quotron
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, said it plans to purchase tendered shares of Quotron Systems Inc., for which it has offered $19 each, or $680 million in cash, before the June 19 expiration of its tender offer.

title: Turks Convict 2 Libyans Of Bombing Attempt
description: Two Libyans were convicted today of possession of explosives in the attempted bombing of a United States officers' club, and a state security court sentenced them to five years in prison.

title: New Manhattan Coach
description: Bob DelleBovi, the assistant coach at Manhattan College, was named yesterday as head basketball coach. He replaces Tom Sullivan, who was dismissed earlier this week following a season in which the Jaspers were 2-26 over all and 1-13 in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference. It was Sullivan's first year as coach.

title: Northwestern Steel
description: An investment group that holds a 57.6 percent stake in the Northwestern Steel and Wire Company said it would cooperate to sell the Sterling, Ill., steel manufacturer.

title:
PATENTS;
Breath Test Can Keep Car at Curb
description: A BREATH tester called the Soberlizer, which prevents a car's ignition from starting if a driver has had too much to drink, was patented this week. Its manufacture is planned in the fall.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
PANEL LISTS 174 TAX-BILL EXCEPTIONS
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today released a list of 174 special exceptions contained in the tax-revision bill that benefit particular corporations or community projects.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Revenue represents contract revenue.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY McKINLEY
description: Thursday's evening of music by William Thomas McKinley at Merkin Concert Hall showed an openness to every conceivable style and at the same time a composer able to fix his signature to each. The New York New Music Ensemble, together with the Eroica Brass, were the players, and the program was both long and rich -with seven pieces ranging from one instrument to 14.

title: TWO MEN CONVICTED OF MURDERING OFFICER IN FUSILLADE IN 1981
description: Three trials and more than five years after a police officer died in his patrol car under a hail of gunfire on a Queens street, two former members of the Black Liberation Army were convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court of murdering the officer.

title: IN AUSTRIAN CAMPAIGN, EVEN BITTERNESS IS MUTED
description: ''Waldheim is a liar,'' read the first placard of the group of 16 young protesters today as they rounded Breinsbach Street and entered the packed Hauptplatz, where Kurt Waldheim had just begun to speak.

title: HAITIAN VOWS ELECTIONS BY END OF 1987
description: A high-ranking Haitian official, moving to defuse the country's latest political crisis, announced today that there would be presidential elections within 18 months.

title: Dr. Louie Newton, 94, Dies; Led Southern Baptist Group
description: Dr. Louie D. Newton, a former president of the Southern Baptist Convention, the national organization that directs the country's largest Protestant denomination, died of pnuemonia Tuesday at Georgia Baptist Hospital in Atlanta. He was 94 years old and lived in Atlanta.

title: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $925,000 for the quarter and $1,556,000 for the year.

title: GIMBELS AT 86th: A BORN LOSER
description: After Gimbel Brothers Inc. decided in 1968 to build a store on the upper edge of Manhattan's Upper East Side, officials of the company described the neighborhood as ''the richest suburb in the world.''

title: Gregory Smith Is Engaged To Margaret Eugenia Low
description: Prof. and Mrs. Francis E. Low of Belmont, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Eugenia Low to Gregory More Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Smith of Bethesda, Md. The wedding is to be June 28.

title: Juliana C. Reiss Becomes Bride Of Roger Smith
description: Juliana Cecelia Reiss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter G. Reiss of Westport, Conn., and Lake Placid, N.Y., was married yesterday to Roger Kingsley Smith, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard W. Smith of New Haven and Lake Placid. Msgr. John G. Nolan, national secretary general of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Assumption in Westport.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: CALL IT a conspiracy afoot -at least in summer books -to get readers up and walking, leisurely exploring and enjoying the open spaces.

title: COMING HOME TO A ROSEBUSH AND THE BILLS
description: On a sunny morning in Rome, lying sleepily in bed, I think about how pleasant it will be to sip hot coffee on the hotel rooftop . But, turning over on my lumpy pillow, I am also thinking about my life back home. How nice to have fresh orange juice once more, scrambled eggs and muffins. As I picture myself falling asleep to the sound of early crickets, I hear the increasing roar of Roman motor scooters and realize I am ready to go home.

title: WHERE ARE THE VOICES FOR THE ENVIRONMENT?
description: THE environmental consciousness that developed in the late 1960's and early 70's was in part a result of the work of ecologists like Rachel Carson, whose ''Silent Spring'' documented the devastating effects of chemical pesticides on wildlife.

title: CHILDREN OF POVERTY: CRISIS IN NEW YORK
description: IMAGINE THE MAYOR OF NEW YORK CALLING AN URGENT NEWS CONFERENCE to announce that the crisis of the city's poor children had reached such proportions that he was mobilizing the city's talents for a massive rescue effort not unlike the one that saved us from bankruptcy 10 years ago. I believe some such drastic action is warranted, even essential, because our city is threatened by the spreading blight of a poverty even crueler in some ways than that of the Great Depression half a century ago. Almost 40 percent of our children - 700,000 boys and girls - now live in families with incomes below the poverty line. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has estimated that half of the babies born in the city in 1980 can be expected to be on our welfare rolls before they reach the age of 18.

title: Karen Anne Wexler Wed In Amagansett Ceremony
description: Karen Anne Wexler, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Wexler of New York and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Douglas Scott Waite, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Waite of Hudson, Ohio. Town Justice Shepherd Frood performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents in Amagansett.

title: BILL SEEN AS A BOON TO DRUG CONCERNS
description: WHEN a bill allowing domestic pharmaceutical companies to sell drugs overseas, even though the Federal Food and Drug Administration had not yet deemed them safe and effective, passed the Senate recently, legislators, lobbyists and industry officials were talking more about jobs and trade than pharmaceuticals.

title: WRITERS IN UNIFORM
description: THE outbreak of the Spanish Civil War in July 1936, with the attempt by the group of Spanish generals led by Gen. Francisco Franco to make a pronunciamento overthrowing the Spanish Republic, resulted almost from the start in introducing onto Spanish soil two separate but coinciding wars. The first of these was purely Spanish, a continuation of the age-old struggle of the great Spanish landowners - aristocrats and leaders of the church hierarchy - with the peasants and (in later years) the industrial workers. There was also the further complication of the struggle of the Basques and Catalans for independence from the centralizers of Madrid.

title: FOUNDER OF CIRCLE LINE TOURS
description: Francis J. Barry, who founded the Circle Line boat tours around Manhattan and who played a leading role in the Port of New York for more than 40 years, died yesterday after a brief illness at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 79 years old and had residences in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: JOB AGENCY TAKES NO ONE UNDER 50
description: IF HE admitted his age, the job-seeker told Phyllis D. Worne, ''you may not help me, and then all I can look forward to is dying.''

title: Knicks Expect King Back
description: Scotty Stirling says Bernard King will be in the Knicks' training camp when it opens in October.

title: SUMMER'S FESTIVAL CONCERTS BEGIN
description: IF it is almost summer, then festival season is here: The South Shore Summer Series is already under way, with the Silvermine, Early Music and Music Mountain Festivals all opening within the week.

title: HAVE BALANCED TICKETS GONE THE WAY OF PRESSING THE FLESH?
description: QUICK! What's the religion of Stan Lundine, the upstate Congressman chosen by Governor Cuomo as his running mate? Do most voters know? Do they care?

title: HOROWITZ'S RETURN TO SOVIET A TRIUMPH FOR MUSIC AND MAN
description: I STILL have some special feelings about the recent Sunday morning when CBS televised the piano recital by Vladimir Horowitz that marked his triumphal return to Russia. About two hours before the program began, I took a walk over the road that borders a small nature conservancy near our home. Every stream was running clear and vigorously; some red-winged blackbirds in the marsh were whistling as if they could go on forever and just might; and the air had that wonderful early-spring warmth that brushes you on the shoulder blades and makes you glad to be alive. At the edge of a pond, the first turtle of another spring had found its log and clambered aboard - its tiny head and feet outstretched to catch the sunshine and the softly understated markings of its shell as lovely as anything else in the woods or sky.

title: EAST END DEBATING LIMITS ON MODERN ARCHITECTURE
description: EAST END officials, seeking to preserve the rural character of the region, are acting to try to limit the modern architectural designs employed in many new homes.

title: THE 50's: SWEET MUSIC, DIM MEMORIES
description: I WAS up on a ladder scraping the paint off my house when my wife told me that my brother was on the telephone.

title: AN AID IN BROWNOUTS: PORTABLE GENERATORS
description: The Long Island Lighting Company again threatens Long Island with brownouts [ ''Will There Be Brownouts This Summer?,'' May 4 ] . However, there is an existing unused power source available right now that many people including Lilco do not seem to be aware of.

title: REPUBLICAN DELEGATES CHOOSE CANDIDATES
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY Republicans gathered at the County Center in White Plains with placards, bunting and political-convention music last week to designate candidates for Congress and the state legislature and to hear from the leaders of the statewide Republican ticket.

title: Sutter Twins Separated
description: The Sutter twins, Rich and Don, who have played together for most of their hockey careers, have been separated as the result of a trade by the Philadelphia Flyers. Rich Sutter, a right wing who had 14 goals and 25 assists in 78 games with the Flyers last sesason, was traded to the Vancouver Canucks along with a defenseman, Dave Richter, and a draft pick in exchange for J. J. Daigneault and two draft choices.

title: Experiencing Apartheid
description: Sheila Rule's article was the most well-written, insightful and - yes - humorous article I've read in a long time. And, from a black reader, that says a lot! WILLIAM T. GREENE JR. Yorktown Heights, N.Y

title: A Secret Case And a Conviction
description: After receiving a rare look at the inner workings of the hypersecret National Security Agency, a Federal jury in Baltimore concluded last week that Ronald W. Pelton was guilty of selling to the K.G.B. details about America's ability to eavesdrop on Russian communications.

title: A MASTER OF CLOSE READING
description: SELECTED ESSAYS OF R. P. BLACKMUR Edited, and with an introduction, by Denis Donoghue. 372 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $17.50. THE critic R. P. Blackmur relished language and made close attention to its intricacies the hallmark of his intellectual life. What he wrote of Melville's achievement also says much about his own: ''Words, and their intimate arrangements . . . bring meaning to birth.''

title: Phillips to Work Out
description: Last Saturday, Andre Phillips won the 400-meter hurdles in San Jose, Calif., in 47.95 seconds, the fastest in the world this year.

title: Refinancing A Co-op
description: To the Editor:

title: Diplomatic Ties With the Vatican Violate the First Amendment; Name a Non-Catholic
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME ENCHANTED MEMENTOS OF THE HAMMERSTEINS
description: FOR most people, the name Hammerstein conjures Oscar Hammerstein 2d, the lyricist and librettist who collaborated with Richard Rodgers on the scores for ''Oklahoma!,'' ''Carousel,'' ''South Pacific,'' ''The King and I,'' and ''The Sound of Music,'' among other beloved Broadway shows. Few are aware, however, that ''Oscar Two,'' as he is referred to by the Hammerstein family, was only the most famous descendant of a colorful dynasty that helped to shape the New York theater and opera worlds for close to a century.

title: BUSH DISCLOSES SECRET ORDER CITING DRUGS AS SECURITY PERIL
description: Vice President Bush disclosed today that the Reagan Administration has issued a secret directive labelling drug smuggling a major security threat because it is intimately linked with terrorism.

title: CHALLENGER REPORT IS SAID TO OMIT SOME KEY SAFETY ISSUES FOR NASA
description: Even before it is formally placed in President Reagan's hands, the final report on the Challenger disaster is proving as notable for the criticisms it omits as for the conclusions it draws, according to members of the Presidential space shuttle commission and outside experts.

title: A BOOM IN TEXAS: GUARD DONKEYS
description: Most of the ranchers around here had themselves a pretty good laugh last summer when Perry Bushong forked over perfectly good money for 10 scruffy donkeys, taught them to make friends with his Rambouillet sheep and Angora goats and sent them out to work as the Hill Country's first guard donkeys.

title: Omaha Tries to Save Charm Of Its College World Series
description: EVERY day for more than a week, generations of families returned to Rosenblatt Stadium, a cozy ball park of concrete and wood not far from the Missouri River, for an occasion that has marked the beginning of more than three dozen Nebraska summers.

title: Vanessa M. Burnes Weds Patrick Daniel Bienvenue
description: Vanessa Maria Burnes, the daughter of Mrs. Weyman Mercer Smith of Stratford, Conn., and the late Thomas Burnes, was married yesterday to Patrick Daniel Bienvenue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Yuan Joseph Bienvenue of Toronto. The Rev. Charles Stubbs performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: MUSCOOT COW IS BUM STEER
description: Westchester County and its Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation are to be commended for the superb job they have done in re-creating Muscoot Farm in Somers [ ''Muscoot Farm in Somers Opens 2 New Additions,'' May 18 ] . It is a delight to see the surprise of down-county children when they visit Muscoot and see a storybook farm come to life - and view chickens laying eggs, cows giving milk, etc.

title: IT MAY BE THAT EXAGGERATION IS HERE TO STAY
description: Clifton Fadiman in a famous essay once lamented what he called the ''decline of attention,'' which he diagnosed as one of the leading social diseases of our time. Essayists, no doubt, were among the first to notice the dreaded ailment, but all writers and speakers, both public and private, recognize it and try to devise strategies to deal with it. And, since music is a form of public address, it is not surprising that musicians, too, become aware of this problem, which in the concert hall or opera house takes the form of program rustling, throat clearing or foot scraping. The ordinary performer's instinct when the audience's collective mind wanders is to panic and resort to exaggeration, to play louder and faster, for the same reason that the tourist raises his voice when his French is not understood by Parisian cab drivers.

title: FISHERMEN ANGRY ON LICENSING PLAN
description: Spring is the season for sports fishermen to cast their lines and their worries to the open seas. This year, however, the Reagan Administration wants to initiate a $10 fee for salt-water licenses, and fishermen are angry about it.

title: Tara Murphy Marries
description: Tara P. Murphy, a daughter of Ethel Power Murphy of Newtown, Conn., and Francis V. Murphy of Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to Justin K. Hixson, a son of Joseph R. Hixson of Boston and Betty Hixson of Bethel, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Kilbourne performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Woodbury, Conn. Mrs. Hixson, a graduate of the Boston Museum School and Tufts University, is an artist. Mr. Hixson, a graduate of the University of Connecticut who also received a J.D. degree from the Western New England College School of Law, is legislative director of the Student Association of the State University of New York at Albany.

title: BURMA'S SPLENDID ISOLATION
description: Burma has long subscribed to the dictum that good fences make good neighbors. By limiting contact with the outside world since 1962, Burma's xenophobic socialist-military government has largely insulated the country from its neighbors in Southeast Asia, and from the last half of the 20th century. Things eccentric and magnificent are captured in this isolation.

title: AVIATION CHIEF REJECTED AUDIT ON PAYROLL FRAUD
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration rejected findings by the Inspector General of the Transportation Department last year that there was payroll fraud in a regional office of the aviation agency, internal records show.

title: CELTICS LOOKING TO HOME-COURT EDGE
description: Larry Bird has tried to stir the masses for the Celtics' encounter with the newly energized Houston Rockets this afternoon at Boston Garden for what will no doubt be the most intensely combative contest of the series.

title: New Departure
description: For more than 30 years, the sprawling, two-story building was known as the East Side Airlines Terminal and it served thousands of travelers daily as the link between Manhattan and the two major airports in Queens.

title: THE COURT CUTS SOME RED TAPE IN ENTITLEMENTS
description: In upholding the right of thousands of mentally disabled people to sue for Social Security benefits, the Supreme Court last week implicitly rebuked the Reagan Administration for its handling of a major benefit program.

title: Ca Arrive
description: To the Editor: I was glad to hear that I was not the only one who suffered the inevitable Gallic shrug of shoulders, open-palm gesture and the act-of-God-phrase so typical of the French when something does not come off just right: ''Ca arrive.''

title: MUSIC: S.E.M. ENSEMBLE
description: THE venturesome free concert series at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris concluded its spring season Thursday night with a program by the S.E.M. Ensemble, under the direction of Petr Kotik.

title: Jody Conklin Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Earle Conklin of Fairfield, Conn., and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joanne Marie Conklin to Robert Howard Blake 3d, the son of Ethel Valentine Blake of New York and Mr. Blake Jr. of Westwood, N.J. The wedding is planned for Sept. 20. The future bride, who is known as Jody, is an art director with Brouillard Communications, a division of the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York.

title: TAKING ADOLESCENTS SERIOUSLY
description: LETTERS TO JUDY What Your Kids Wish They Could Tell You. By Judy Blume. 284 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95. JUDY BLUME is probably the most widely read author of novels for teen-agers, and the most widely criticized. She writes about things like menstruation and first sexual experience - issues that don't sit well with some adults. But these unmentionable topics are just the things that are on young people's minds.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ALEC GUINNESS AND GUY LOMBARDO
description: The Wind in the Willows: The Further Adventures of Toad. Narrated by Ian Carmichael; with voices by Michael Hordern, Richard Pearson, Peter Sallis and David Jason.

title: LATIN GROUP OFFERS NEW CENTRAL AMERICA TREATY
description: Latin American negotiators meeting here today unexpectedly offered a revised regional peace treaty to the Foreign Ministers of five Central American nations.

title: THAILAND AWAITS A CRUCIAL VOTE NEXT MONTH
description: Thailand is preparing for a national election next month, and if the campaign is already shaping up as one of the toughest in the country's short parliamentary history, politicians say, it is because this election will be the most important one Thailand has ever faced.

title: Tax Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER THE WAR WAS LOST
description: AN ARTIST OF THE FLOATING WORLD By Kazuo Ishiguro. 206 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95. IT is not unusual to find new novels by good writers, novels with precise wording, witty phrases, solid characterizations, scenes that engage. Good writers abound - good novelists are very rare. Kazuo Ishiguro is that rarity. His second novel, ''An Artist of the Floating World,'' is the kind that stretches the reader's awareness, teaching him to read more perceptively.

title: IT'S JUNE AND HERE COME THE BRIDES: MOTHER UNHEEDED, CEREMONY'S STILL FINE
description: ''WHY don't they ask for advice?'' I grumbled to my sister. ''Imagine trying to organize a wedding for 200 guests on their own! They don't have the experience. How can they take it in such a relaxed fashion?''

title: BUSINESS GRAPHICS FOR THE BEGINNER
description: A VERITABLE summer storm of graphics software is sweeping across my desk. Whether this represents, at long last, the boom that the computer industry has been forecasting for years or merely a self-fulfilling prophesy produced by the publishers is hard to determine. In all likelihood it is a bit of both.

title: How About Low-Cost Drugs for Addicts?
description: We are losing the war against drug addiction. Our strategy is wrong. I propose a different approach.

title: THE HOUSES WRIGHT BUILT
description: Every year, tens of thousands of visitors flock like faithful pilgrims to Oak Park, a town of 53,000 just west of the Chicago city line, to see its unequaled collection of 24 buildings designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. Eight more Wright buildings stand in the adjacent village of River Forest.

title: Trade Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: UNDER COMPARABLE WORTH, JOBS WON'T HAVE GENDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: ''THE PROBITY CHORUS'' by Richard Lemon. W. W. Norton & Company. 383 pages. $15.95.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: FREDDY AND THE PERILOUS ADVENTURE By Walter R. Brooks. Illustrated by Kurt Wiese. 245 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Paper, $3.95. (Ages 7 to 12) FREDDY the pig, the hero of Walter R. Brooks's series of books first published in the 1940's, can talk. Which isn't surprising, since he lives on the Beans' farm in upstate New York, where all the animals - from Mrs. Wiggins the cow, to Eek, Quik, Meenie and Cousin Augustus, the mice - speak acceptable, if sometimes addled, English.

title: TEAMMATE OF ORMSBY CITES PRESSURE ON ATHLETES TO EXCEL
description: Connie Jo Robinson was talking about Kathy Ormsby, her teammate on the North Carolina State women's track team.

title: USE OF THE DRUG 'CRACK' GROWING ON L.I.
description: IN A small, crowded room in Nassau County, a group of casually dressed men meet to discuss their plans for the evening. Most of them are unshaven, their hair unconventionally long.

title: Susan Oelerich Weds
description: Susan Mary Oelerich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Oelerich of Eufaula, Ala., was married yesterday to Rem V. Myers Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myers of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The bride's father is president and chief executive officer of the Manns Company, a manufacturer of fishing equipment in Eufaula. The bridegroom's father is a partner in the Huntington, L.I., law firm of Toaz, Buck, Myers, Bernst, Young, Cote & Lawrence.

title: 9 KILLED IN PUNJAB AS SIKH PROTEST ENDS
description: Gunmen suspected of being Sikh militants were reported today to have killed nine people. The attacks came at the end of a weeklong protest marking the second anniversary of the Indian Army assault on the Golden Temple, the Sikhs' holiest shrine.

title: Carol Ann Augenblick Weds Harold E. Rolfe
description: Carol Ann Augenblick, an associate with Davis Polk & Wardwell, and Harold Edward Rolfe, an associate with Cravath, Swaine & Moore, both New York law firms, were married yesterday at the Homestead Inn in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Richard H. Stearns, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: South Shore Is Winner In P.S.A.L. Girls' Track
description: Janu Williams led South Shore High School of Brooklyn to the team title yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League's girls' outdoor track and field championships at St. John's University in Queens.

title: YOUNG CONCERT ARTISTS - A MAGNET FOR TALENT
description: Not long ago, Daniel McKelway, a 21-year-old clarinetist from Boston, burst into the headquarters of Young Concert Artists, Inc., heading straight for the office of the director, Susan Wadsworth. ''Hey! Susan!'' he exclaimed. ''On Monday I got to play for Messaien. We did the 'Quartet for the End of Time' and he kept saying I wasn't blowing loud enough - well, I was blowing so hard it was unbelievable, but he kept saying 'Louder! Louder!' Anyway, he cleared up a lot of things for me and - by the way - the dynamics in the score are all wrong. He kept changing them. Imagine, Messaien! Greatest composer I've ever met.''

title: IT'S JUNE AND HERE COME THE BRIDES: WEDDING GOWN WALKS DOWN THE AISLE AGAIN
description: WE opened the box with anticipation and apprehension, she and I, carefully unfolding and lifting layers of tissue paper. At last the layers revealed the 25-year-old treasure. She lifted it from the box and smiled, holding the gown to her slim blue-jeaned figure. ''It's beautiful,'' she murmured.

title: Canine Waste
description: NEW YORK CITY dog owners were being fairly good about cleaning up after their pets back in June 1984.

title: Dance
description: A door will dance and make music in ''Dances for Men, Women and Moving Door,'' the collaboration with choreography by Douglas Dunn, decor by David Ireland and music by Alvin Lucier that Douglas Dunn and Dancers will offer Wednesday, Thursday and Saturday nights and next Sunday afternoon at Marymount Manhattan Theater. Sections of the evening-length piece pit men against men, women against women and both sexes against a door designed by Mr. Ireland, a San Francisco sculptor who in the past has made robes out of broomsticks. Mr. Lucier's score permits the door to tamper with sound as well as occupy space, for as the door moves it will interrupt sound waves emitted from loudspeakers.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CHICAGO;
Differing Views On State Center
description: A YEAR after its opening, the State of Illinois Center is still a center of controversy. Some find inspiration in Helmut Jahn's futuristic 16-story structure, like Gov. James Thompson, a Republican, who chose the design, approved $172 million in construction costs and took an office on the top floor.

title: A FOUNDER RESTORED TO HIS PEDESTAL
description: There is a tide in the affairs of mighty corporations, as of the men who run them, but never does it run so strongly as in an era of rampant takeovers. Witness the return of a 30-inch bronze bust of Charles Revson to a place of honor in the halls of Revlon.

title: The Fugitive
description: Recalling his days as a young lawyer drawn to radical causes, Stephen M. Bingham took the stand at his murder trial last week to tell his side of the story: He did not smuggle a gun into San Quentin Prison, he panicked upon learning that he was suspected of involvement in an inmate uprising and spent 13 years in hiding because, he said, he was ''perhaps not courageous enough to risk my life in prison.'' Mr. Bingham, now 44, is accused of giving a pistol to George Jackson, the black activist, on the day of the 1971 shootout. Six persons, including Mr. Jackson, were killed.

title: Antinoise Law
description: RESIDENTS of Larchmont, N.Y., who worked at home and cherished their peace and quiet faced a problem last June. As Glynne Woolfenden, a writer, put it, ''You'll be walking down the lovely tree-lined streets, and all of a sudden the leaf-blowing machines, those snarling monsters, shatter the serenity of the area.''

title: BANKAMERICA'S AUDACIOUS PURSUER
description: JOE PINOLA has gumption. Only a raw blend of gumption and audacity - even reined in by a banker's white shirt and pinstripes -could explain his bid to buy the BankAmerica Corporation, the second-biggest banking company in the country.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: NEW YORK JUDGE FACES DUAL CHALLENGE
description: New York City's Family Court system is the setting for some of the most bitter, passionate and painful contests in the judicial system - from cases of child custody to delinquency, abuse and divorce.

title: SHIPS AND DREAMS THAT PASS IN THE NIGHT
description: THE springtime sun causes some men to think of baseball and others to think of romance. But when the warm weather comes to Long Island, my thoughts are with the ships.

title: DUNHAM HAS BEEN A CONTROVERSIAL PIONEER
description: Katherine Dunham, dancer, choreographer, anthropologist, author and humanitarian, will receive the annual Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award this week when the festival opens its new season at Duke University in Durham, N.C., on Wednesday.

title: Poets at Risk?
description: To the Editor:

title: ALICE O'ROURKE AGAIN SETS ASIDE 'MORE NORMAL LIFE'
description: YES, conceded Alice T. O'Rourke, there are times she longs for a more normal life in which she could go window-shopping or for a stroll with her husband, have time to plant tomatoes or have dinner without telephone interruptions.

title: Under Comparable Worth, Jobs Won't Have Genders
description: To the Editor:

title: PARADE OF SCHOOLS
description: Mount Vernon's business district resounded with band music and marching feet last Monday afternoon, as 900 to 1,000 instrumentalists from the city's 12 elementary schools, middle school and high school staged their annual parade, a tradition that began in 1931. Each band marched to a different drummer, with selections ranging from ''The Marine Hymn'' and ''Anchors Aweigh,'' to ''Coral Rock,'' the choice of students at the Traphagen Elementary School, and ''Soul Rock'' and ''Rocko Latin'' by the Fulton Elementary School Band. One number, ''Tequila,'' was played in an original arrangement by a Mount Vernon high school student, Peter Rowley.

title: We Need a National 'Pain and Suffering' Cap
description: To the Editor:

title: BOB HOSKINS: TOUGH GUY, TENDER HEART
description: Bob Hoskins, who shared the Best Actor Award at Cannes this year for his performance as a small-time crook in Neil Jordan's romantic thriller ''Mona Lisa,'' which has its New York premiere Friday at Cinema 1, derides the idea that he is now a star. Sitting in the lounge of a smart London hotel and filling the air with broad Cockney vowels, he hoots with laughter at the notion of himself as a hot international property.

title: Progress Report For Mrs. Aquino
description: The unexpected presidency of Corazon C. Aquino marked its first 100 days last week. Mrs. Aquino gave an impassioned speech, and a staff report said she had fulfilled 10 of her pledges for the first three months, started on six others and had left one pending. She has re-established an independent Supreme Court, removed limits on the press, appointed a panel to write a new Constitution and, in spite of a stubborn if relatively small number of loyalists who continued sporadic protests last week, attempted to pull up by their roots remnants of the regime of her predecessor, Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: 'PAINTING CHURCHES' IS TRIBUTE TO HOWE
description: AS the curtain falls on Tina Howe's ''Painting Churches'' at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn., Fanny and Gardner Church, an elderly couple, begin a life-affirming waltz. At that transcendent moment, one is confident that ''Painting Churches'' will survive, because the playwright's lyric and literate words and genuine feeling have peered through a pedestrian production. This is a tribute to Miss Howe, but not to the Hartman.

title: Kate White, Editor, Weds Brad Holbrook, Newsman
description: Kate White, an executive editor of Mademoiselle magazine, and Brad Holbrook, a news anchorman for WPIX-TV, were married yesterday in the band shell of the Glens Falls (N.Y.) Park.

title: Courtney McLennan Wed
description: Courtney Noyes McLennan, a daughter of Mrs. Donald R. McLennan Jr. and the late Mr. McLennan of Ligonier, Pa., was married yesterday to Barnaby Myhrum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Myhrum of Peru, Vt. The Rev. Max E. Smith performed the ceremony at St. Michael's of the Valley Episcopal Church in Rector, Pa. Mrs. Myhrum's father was a vice president and director in the Pittsburgh office of Marsh & McLennan, the insurance brokerage concern, of which his grandfather, the late Donald Broderick McLennan of Lake Forest, Ill., was a founder in Chicago. Mr. Myhrum's father is a television director in New York.

title: Vietnam Refugees Rescued
description: A West German relief ship rescued 77 Vietnamese refugees, 28 of them children, from a small boat 210 miles southeast of the Vietnamese coast in the South China Sea today, the aid organization Cap Anamur said. The group said that the refugees were exhausted and hungry and had run out of water, and that about 30 ships on the Singapore-Hong Kong route had passed them without stopping.

title: Judy Truncer, Actress, Weds Thomas Watson
description: Judy Lynn Truncer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Truncer of Allentown, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas William Watson, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George W. Watson of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. J. Douglas Ousley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation in New York.

title: REAGAN TO ACCUSE SOVIET OF SENDING ARMS TO MANAGUA
description: White House officials said today that President Reagan, in a campaign to try to win Congressional approval of new aid for Nicaraguan rebels, would charge this week that the Soviet Union has resumed direct arms shipments to Managua.

title: Club in Rhode Island To Let Women Join
description: The University Club has voted to drop its 87-year-old custom of admitting only men, but Paul Greene, the club's president, said he did not expect a flood of women to apply.

title: SURVIVING CASTRO'S TORTURES
description: AGAINST ALL HOPE The Prison Memoirs of Armando Valladares. By Armando Valladares. Translated by Andrew Hurley. Illustrated. 381 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95. IN 1958, Jean-Paul Sartre helped rouse the conscience of France by writing an introduction to ''The Question'' by Henri Alleg, a small book that recounted the torture of a French opponent of the Algerian war in Algerian prisons. One had to decide, Sartre wrote, ''whether to be the torturer or the tortured.'' Alleg suffered the fate of all those tortured, Sartre wrote, and he showed ''the calm courage of the victim,'' as well as a modesty and lucidity ''which wake us and show us the truth.''

title: Miami Victorious
description: Kevin Ryan and Rick Raether combined for a five-hitter as defending champion Miami held off Arizona, 4-2, in the College World Series tonight.

title: 51 in Boston Don't Pass Test To Get High School Diploma
description: Fifty-one high school seniors who failed a required reading test will be denied diplomas and barred from graduation ceremonies, Superintendent of Schools Laval S. Wilson says.

title: Miss Mc Nulty Weds in Jersey
description: Kathryn Ann Mc Nulty, an assistant treasurer of the Chase Manhattan Bank in Boston, and Paul Carroll Nightingale, a lawyer with Goodwin, Procter & Hoar in Boston, were married yesterday at the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson, N.J. The Rev. William J. Kokoszka officiated, assisted by the Rev. Walter H. Taylor, an Episcopal priest.

title: A Quiet Hero Earned Respect
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MORE TUITION AID, MORE STRINGS, TOO
description: WHEN the television cameras were first turned on in the Senate chamber last week, the first issue on the floor was Federal grants and loans for higher education. Senators Robert T. Stafford, a Vermont Republican, and Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island - the leaders of the Subcommittee on Education, Arts and the Humanities of the Labor and Human Resources Committee - could not have been more pleased by the prime-time scheduling.

title: 2 STATES LOOKING AT USE OF WATER
description: Since colonial times in New England, the water supply has been regarded as both plentiful and unthreatened.

title: DISPUTE IN PENNSYLVANIA IS A CHOCOLATE MESS
description: The Hershey Chocolate Company says it is only thinking of the children. The competition is not so sure.

title: MONOLOGUES IN THREE TONES
description: SIN By Ai. 80 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $5.95. WILD GRATITUDE By Edward Hirsch. 78 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95. A SHORT HISTORY OF THE ISLAND OF BUTTERFLIES By Nicholas Christopher. 81 pp. New York: Viking. Cloth, $17.95. Penguin. Paper, $8.95. THE current popularity of the dramatic monologue among younger poets is due in part to the influence of Florence Anthony, who uses the pen name Ai. All her poems are monologues, and she has given the form a striking contemporaneity: imagine a Browning monologue rewritten in the terse manner of Sam Shepard and you have a good idea of what an Ai poem sounds like. Like Browning, she is almost perversely fascinated by the problems of evil. Whether they are the oppressors or the oppressed, her characters yearn for power above all else, and they know they must be corrupted to attain it. Her cast of personae is large, ranging from Latin American priests and farm women to John and Robert Kennedy, Joseph McCarthy and J. Robert Oppenheimer. Ai invariably captures her speakers in physical and psychological crisis, and she permits them neither eloquence nor redemption. Her characters offer a kind of stammering, desperate testimony, last-ditch efforts at self-justification before acknowledging their damnation. As the title of her new collection implies, Ai is ultimately a religious poet, but the deity she envisions is wrathful and she seems to identify with such a figure: these are poems in which violence and destruction become eerily voluptuous.

title: CANCELED JET APPARENTLY MET AIR FORCE NEEDS
description: Recent tests have shown that a new training jet that the military decided not to buy last year would meet the Air Force's needs for a modern trainer for fighter pilots, a Government agency reported.

title: Ma Bell Takes A Big Strike
description: Historically, telephone contracts have been pacesetters in labor negotiations. But the strike begun last week by 150,000 communications workers against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company quickly fell into a pattern familar in other industries.

title: A LaRouche Victory on Coast
description: A Democratic Party official's last-minute write-in campaign failed to stop a follower of the politicqal extremist Lyndon LaRouche from winning the Congressional nomination here.

title: YANKS LOSE AGAIN; METS LEAD BY 9
description: To Dave Johnson, there is no mystery about Dwight Gooden. He lost two games in a row last month, but tonight he won his third in a row when he pitched the Mets to a 6-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Lucy L. Klingenstein Becomes Bride Of Scott A. Butterworth in Rye, N.Y.
description: Lucy Lowe Klingenstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Klingenstein of Rye, N.Y., and Abaco, the Bahamas, was married in Rye yesterday to Scott Alan Butterworth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Butterworth of Cheshire, Conn. Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated at the ceremony in the garden of the bride's parents.

title: NUCLEAR WASTE PLAN ANGERS 2 WESTERN STATES
description: Asserting that politics, not science, is driving the search for the first permanent repository for radioactive waste, Washington State and Nevada are challenging the Department of Energy in Federal court.

title: NBC USES CABLE TO TEST THE PROGRAMMING WATERS
description: One would think that Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara would be looking forward to tomorrow night. After all, that's when a pilot for ''The Stiller and Meara Show,'' their situation comedy that was taped in April at the Ed Sullivan Theater in Manhattan, will be broadcast by NBC for millions of potential viewers to sample. But tomorrow's 8:30 P.M. telecast will have little meaning. The program's biggest test - which it failed - came 30 days ago, when NBC televised it on cable systems in four cities as part of an unpublicized and costly operation called ''Cable Previews.''

title: WHAT'S NEW IN FOOD PACKAGING
description: WITH the exception of the toothpaste pump and a few other eyebrow-raising packages to hit supermarket shelves over the last few years, innovations in consumer packaging have traditionally come from cosmetics companies. Long ago they recognized that unusually shaped mascara wands, see-through tubes for lipsticks, and other new packages can boost market share in the absence of a new product formula.

title: The Role of Profit In Health Care
description: As competition and commercialization increase in health care, hospitals tend more to business and less to charity, according to a major study released last week by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Brian Williams Weds Jane Stoddard, TV Producer
description: Jane Gillan Stoddard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hudson G. Stoddard of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Douglas Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon L. Williams of Middletown, N.J. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan.

title: PRIMITIVE VISIONS IN GROUP ART SHOW
description: The work of 30 contemporary American artists who have reached back to their cultural roots and to historical memories for inspiration is being shown here in a group exhibition entitled: ''Other Gods: Containers of Belief.''

title: REVERSE COMMUTES SPUR NEW BUS PLAN
description: THE county's Department of Transportation, responding to growth in the number of employees commuting from New York City to Westchester, has begun a marketing drive aimed at encouraging these reverse commuters to use the county's bus system.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL QUITS CIVIL RIGHTS POST TO LEAD A JEWISH GROUP
description: Morris B. Abram said yesterday that he had resigned as vice chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights to become chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations on July 1.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BARAWA: And the Ways Birds Fly in the Sky. By Michael Jackson. (Smithsonian Institution Press, $18.95.) The Smithsonian, which has published anthropological research and related literature since the 1940's, has added to its list a new genre, the ethnographic novel.

title: BOARD STUDIES STRIP SEARCH FOR STUDENTS
description: STUDENTS in Berlin may be required to undress and be searched for drugs, liquor or weapons under a policy proposed by a special committee of the school board there.

title: A STEP OUT OF THE TEX-MEX MOLD
description: FOR years, Mexican restaurants in Connecticut numbered less than a handful.

title: Sold: The Presidential Presence
description: How much is the Presidency worth? Why do you ask? It's not for sale. Of course it is. The White House and David Wolper, the producer, have sold it. The American Broadcasting Company has paid $10 million for certain exclusive rights to televise President Reagan during the celebrations on Liberty Weekend next month. That might come out to half a million a minute.

title: Susan McFarlan Becomes a Bride
description: Susan McFarlan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tracy W. McFarlan of Asheville, N.C., and James P. Rooney Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rooney of Cape May, N.J., and Naples, Fla., were married yesterday at Christ Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Michael Reynal And Miss Perry To Marry in '87
description: Mrs. R. Thompson Perry of Palm Beach, Fla., and John Holliday Perry Jr. of Palm Beach and Lee Stocking Island, the Bahamas, have announced the engagement of their daughter Christiana Putnam Perry to Michael Reynal, a son of Mrs. John Anthony Hayes of Palm Beach and Miguel Alfredo Reynal of Buenos Aires. A spring 1987 wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: WEE-HOURS TRENTON TOUR - Looking for something different?

title: POSTLIBERAL VISION
