description: DEMOCRACY AND CAPITALISM Property, Community, and the Contradictions of Modern Social Thought. By Samuel Bowles and Herbert Gintis. 244 pp. New York: Basic Books. $16.95. HOW does one reconcile liberty, socialism and democracy? With an optimism all the more remarkable for its buoyancy in current political tides, two radical economists, Samuel Bowles and Herbert Gintis, present a case for ''postliberal democracy.'' In such a society, the visions of Locke, Marx and the radical democrats would all at last be realized. The authors argue that any other social order is inherently contradictory, hence unstable. Indeed, much of the book explores the contradictions among the rights classical liberals defend against the unlawful intrusions of others, the Marxists' call for economic justice and the democrats' vision of participation as the means to autonomy and self-realization. Mr. Bowles and Mr. Gintis, both professors of economics at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, propose instead a ''visionary-historical conception'' of a world in which the claims of personal freedom, economic efficiency and popular sovereignty could all be simultaneously attained.

title: Madison Condos
description: Madison Avenue on the Upper East Side, which is known primarily for expensive shops and boutiques, has not seen much residential development in the last decade.

title: SEABROOK DELAY BRINGS NEW CHARGES
description: Operation of the Seabrook nuclear reactor has been delayed another five months at least, at an additional cost of $250 million to $300 million, according to its builders, who blame Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts for failing to approve emergency plans.

title: Kathryn Clark Is Wed
description: Kathryn Ruth Clark, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Clark of Marietta, Ga., and Douglas Warner Paige 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Paige of Bellport, L.I., were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Bellport by the Rev. John G. Coakley Jr. The bride, who was divorced, attended the University of Georgia and is a contracts technician with Thomas A. Green & Company, a New York reinsurance broker. Mr. Paige, a graduate of Lehigh University, is a systems manager with the New York Insurance Exchange.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: HOUSE:

title: NJ TRANSIT OFFERS BEACHGOING LURES
description: REDUCED fares and free beach passes are being dangled as incentives as NJ Transit seeks to attract summer riders to Shore resorts served by its trains and buses.

title: CAMPUS RECRUITING AND THE C.I.A.
description: KEVIN WARD was sitting in a snack bar at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies in Bologna, Italy, when he was approached by a stranger.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: SWEET COUNTRY, by Caroline Richards. (Fireside/ Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) This fictionalized treatment of the overthrow of Chile's President Salvador Allende in 1973 is a ''first-class political novel,'' Benjamin DeMott said here in 1979. Its principal achievement, he said, is ''the subtle interplay of political analysis and psychological self-scrutiny'' that appears in a diary kept by its heroine, a secretary to Allende's wife. THE OUTLAW YEARS: The History of the Land Pirates of the Natchez Trace, by Robert M. Coates. (University of Nebraska, $7.95.) In the early 19th century, the desperadoes who operated along the Natchez Trace - the overland route through Kentucky, Tennessee and Mississippi - aroused terror in the hearts of settlers and frontiersmen. This history chronicles the doings of such bandits as the psychopathic Samuel Mason, the dandified Joseph Hare and the dreaded Harpe brothers, of whom our reviewer, John Chamberlain, said in 1930, ''No Gilles de Rais could match them in refinements of cruelty, in diabolical, torturous death-dealing.'' He found the work ''enthralling'' and ''picturesque to the last detail.''

title: Staley Ann Cayce Is Married
description: Staley Ann Cayce and George Carter Sednaoui were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley. Mrs. Sednaoui, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. King Cayce of Houston and Delray Beach, Fla., attended the Chapin School and graduated from the Ethel Walker School and Vassar College. She is an assistant to the chairman of Plains Resources Inc. in New York, an oil and gas company with headquarters in Oklahoma City.

title: Italian President in Dublin
description: President Francesco Cossiga of Italy began a four-day state visit today, in which he is expected to urge Irish Government officials to strengthen economic ties between the two countries. Mr. Cossiga, who will be joined by Foreign Minister Giulio Andreotti on Sunday, is to meet with Ireland's Prime Minister, Garret FitzGerald. On Tuesday, Mr. Cossiga is to fly to Canada.

title: TRADING TALK
description: Wall Street traders work a short, fast day, and they talk the same way.

title: WHEN THE CASH REGISTER IS THE SCOREBOARD
description: COLLEGE athletics in the United States, spurred by large sums of money and influenced by groups outside the universities, has become a sophisticated, sprawling industry involving billions of dollars.

title: HAITI'S LEADER SETS DATE FOR PRESIDENTIAL VOTE
description: Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, Haiti's provisional President, declared tonight that presidential elections will be held here in 17 months.

title: Who Wants To Teach?
description: Nick Taylor lists the usual reasons why teaching is unattractive - poor salary, paperwork, etc. But there are other reasons, equally discouraging.

title: VICTORIANS AT THE HUDSON MUSEUM, UNCLE SAM IN RYE BROOK
description: THE Victorians are not the figures of fun they used to be, thanks to the ministrations of social historians and psychobiographers. Their art, too, has been rehabilitated - to an extent inconceivable even a decade ago.

title: SHE BLEW A KISS TO THE FIRING SQUAD
description: MATA HARI The True Story. By Russell Warren Howe. Illustrated. 292 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $17.95. MARGARETHA GEERTRUIDA MACLEOD (nee Zelle), alias Mata Hari, was a preposterous fraud: a dancer during the Belle Epoque and a spy in World War I whose contributions to both dance and espionage were of negligible importance. Her mysterious blend of sex and spying, combined with her death at the hands of a firing squad, have made her, nonetheless, a household name.

title: N. E. Eyle Wed To Miss Mitchell
description: Alexandra Elizabeth Mitchell, an associate editor of the Syracuse University Publications Office, and Nicolas Edward Eyle, a freelance corporate photographer, were married yesterday in the garden of the bridegroom's parent's home in Hamilton, N.Y. William Pearson Tolley, chancellor emeritus of Syracuse University and a Methodist minister, officiated.

title: THE BIGGEST NEWS
description: Excerpt from a Washington talk by the writer David McCollough that is included in ''Biography & Books,'' edited by John Y. Cole and newly published by the Library of Congress:

title: Susan I. Williams Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Isabel Williams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Williams of Atlanta, was married there yesterday to Denis Knowles Tinsley, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Tinsley of Dublin. The Rev. Harry Pritchett performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: Granada
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed Leslie Stainton's article ''The Granada of Federico Garcia Lorca'' (Travel, May 4). I share her admiration for this fascinating city, an inspiration for many poets, composers and novelists, and especially for Federico Garcia Lorca with whom Granada is so closely linked.

title: CONSUMER RATES

THEATER;
YOUNG PLAYWRIGHTS IN FESTIVAL
description: ''IT HAS to ring a bell inside me,'' Paul Sorvino told a visitor to his studio on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
QUICKSILVER NIGHTMARES
description: Roberta Allen, a visual artist whose work has been exhibited worldwide, accompanies her first collection of stories, THE TRAVELING WOMAN (Vehicle Editions, 238 Mott Street, New York, N.Y. 10012, Paper, $12), with her drawings in a handsome little book of her own design. Think of these 54 fiercely compressed stories as quicksilver dreams in which a single word or gesture is the exact metaphor for the separation between a man and a woman. Think of these stories as koans, or comments on the human condition to which the only response can be a deeper recognition of isolation. In ''Bottled,'' a woman comes upon a snake as she walks along the beach. ''A cobra here? We are not in a wild place.'' The man she is with traps the snake in a bottle, brings it to their hotel room, lies back to watch it. ''Bottled, alive, the snake slithers; writhing up and down and around its transparent cage. I was wrong, she thinks. This is a wild place.'' In ''Language,'' a woman ''hears the cries of animals. She looks down over a ledge into a small slaughterhouse by the sea below: a bull, a pig, a sheep, wail and hurl themselves against the walls of their pens.'' Three men slaughter the animals, then eat a hearty lunch -butchering is nothing to them. The story concludes, ''The woman who watches them is very young, and a foreigner: she doesn't speak their language but she understands.''

title: WESTERN NATIONS SPLIT OVER UNESCO HEAD'S FUTURE
description: Serious divisions have emerged among Western members of the United Nations over a strategy for removing Unesco's Director General when his second term of office expires next year, diplomats say.

title:
A NEW CLOUD OVER WALL STREET?;
A 'FAIRNESS LETTER' IS JUST AN OPINION
description: AS the size and number of corporate acquisitions have increased over the past few years, the roles of investment bankers, as key participants in these transactions, have grown. Their expertise is called upon to assist in negotiations, seek out alternatives for their clients, and, in many cases, to analyze and give an opinion of the fairness of the price to be paid in a transaction. This last function, issuing what is called a fairness letter or opinion, is generating criticism that is unwarranted.

title: Victim of Berlin Blast Dies
description: An American soldier died today of wounds suffered in the bombing of a discotheque here April 5. An announcement by the United States Army's Berlin Command said the soldier, Staff Sgt. James E. Goins, a 26-year-old infantryman from Ellerbee, N.C., died at Steglitz Clinic. Another American soldier and a Turkish woman were killed in the bombing, in which about 230 other people were wounded.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Frederik Pohl's latest novel, THE COMING OF THE QUANTUM CATS (Bantam, Paper, $3.50) takes off from the premise that, at crucial moments in history, reality somehow ''branches,'' so that there exists, for example, another universe in which Lee Harvey Oswald's bullets missed President Kennedy, and yet another in which Senator John F. Kennedy lost the Presidential election in 1960 to Richard Nixon, and yet another in which Jack's older brother Joe lived to become President Kennedy, and so on. The notion of parallel universes or branching time-lines is not new in science fiction, but only in the last few years have theoretical physicists, in an effort to account for some of the bizarre findings of quantum mechanics, begun speculating about similar hypotheses. Mr. Pohl is well aware of these speculations; he is also aware of a complication that the physicists have yet to deal with - that each of us would have a nearly identical double in each nearly identical universe.

title: Caldwell Again Takes 100-Mile Championship
description: Dr. Lion Caldwell, a 35-year-old general practitioner on an Indian reservation in White River, Ariz., regained the Track Athletic Congress National 100-Mile Championship by crossing the finish line along third base in Shea Stadium after 13 hours 53 minutes 16 seconds just before 7 o'clock yesterday morning.

title: PUTTING THE ARBS IN THE HOT SEAT
description: WHEN Cavalcade Partners, a Texas-based investment group, announced in early April that it would attempt a takeover of the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, Wall Street's arbitragers began scrambling for information.

title: Betsy Levey, Teacher, Weds Dr. Evan Zahn
description: Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Betsy R. Levey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Levey of Jericho, L.I., and Dr. Evan M. Zahn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Zahn of Lake Worth, Fla. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: Koch Vetoes Curb On Gay Rights Bill
description: For only the fifth time in his nine years in City Hall, Mayor Koch last week vetoed a measure approved by the City Council. The Mayor rejected a controversial amendment to New York's new homosexual rights law that would have increased the number of dwellings exempt from the legislation, which forbids housing discrimination based on sexual preference.

title: Bronx Woman Is Found Slain In Elevator at Her Residence
description: An 18-year-old Bronx woman was found stabbed to death yesterday in the elevator of her high-rise building, the police said.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NO NEWS IS GOOD. By Julie Edelson. (North Point Press, $16.95.) In Julie Edelson's first novel, the year is 1970 and the country is rife with antiwar protest.

title: THE RACE FOR SQUEEZABLE KETCHUP
description: PLASTICS had a lot to overcome before they made it into food packaging. They used to leach chemicals into the foods or liquids they contained. And they were associated with cheapness and tackiness, certainly not images food companies wanted to convey for their products.

title: WRIGHT AERO, SILENT SINCE '46, IS REBORN AT PATERSON MUSEUM
description: IN THIS city of industrial ghosts, perhaps the bleakest of once-flourishing factories is the Wright Aeronautical Corporation plant on Beckwith Avenue.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE pollution liability crisis still looms, and legislative committees have taken or are considering a variety of approaches.

title: BALLET: CAPUCILLI IN GRAHAM'S 'HERETIC'
description: THERE is nobody like Martha Graham - and there are no dances like hers. Attending Friday night's performance by the Martha Graham Dance Company at the City Center, ostensibly to review a spate of debuts, one had to be amazed again at the sheer originality behind every work on view.

title: PENTAGON IS SEEKING TO HALT COAL SHIPMENTS TO GERMANY
description: Millions of dollars is spent each year to ship Pennsylvania coal 3,000 miles to heat American bases in West Germany, and the Pentagon wants it stopped.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Can I go directly by boat to Nantucket Island from Orient Point on Long Island or from Connecticut? If not, what is the route by sea? - C. M., Queens Answer:The regularly scheduled ferryboats that go to Nantucket leave from Hyannis and Woods Hole on Cape Cod. There are ferries from Long Island and from Connecticut but they do not sail to Nantucket. Passengers can cross between Orient Point and New London, Conn., for example, and between New London and Block Island, R.I.

title: SOME POLICE AND FIRE OFFICERS BALK AT REQUIRED EXERCISE
description: REQUIRING police officers and firefighters to exercise to keep in shape has met with some resistance at station houses and fire companies around the state. While many of the men enjoy lifting weights and jogging, others resent being forced to do these activities.

title: A CHANCE FOR CHANGE SEEN IN SOUTH KOREAN TALKS
description: Politicians, intellectuals and diplomats here say continuing talks on the crucial issue of constitutional revision offer changes that might ease growing political tensions and allow Koreans more say in choosing their Government.

title: Bahrain Causeway: A Road Few Yet Travel
description: A 16-mile-long causeway that cost a billion dollars and took five years to build links this small island in the Persian Gulf with Saudi Arabia, but hardly anyone is allowed to drive across it.

title: DRUG-TAMPERING SUSPECT HAS LONG ARREST RECORD
description: Edward Arlen Marks, accused of poisoning over-the-counter drugs in an attempt to make a killing in the stock market, has a six-year history of charges involving forgery, bad checks, larceny and credit card fraud, according to the authorities in California and Massachusetts.

title: Miss Roosevelt Becomes a Bride
description: Verdery Anne Roosevelt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver W. Roosevelt Jr. of Birmingham, Ala., was married yesterday to William J. Capone, the son of Mrs. William R. Capone and the late Mr. Capone of Glens Falls, N.Y. The Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherill, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn.

title: ARCHITECTS DEFEND RIVAL PLANS FOR ELLIS ISLAND
description: Amid warm personal words and professional decorum, the architects of two competing proposals for the southern half of Ellis Island disagreed last week on just about every aspect of how the former entry point to the nation for millions of immigrants should be rebuilt.

title: Wendy A. Wallace Marries R. S. Murphy in Nantucket
description: Wendy Ann Wallace, the daughter of Mrs. Guy Darby Drake of Boston and Osterville, Mass., and Robert Edgar Wallace Jr. of New York and Falls Village, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Scott Murphy, a son of Audrey Murphy of Worcester, Mass., and David L. Murphy of Boston. The Rev. Thomas Richard performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: THE T.V.A. MOTHBALLS ITS NUCLEAR AMBITIONS
description: WELL before the nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union, sharp questions were being raised about this country's second largest nuclear power system, which is owned by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: Dr. Anastasia Golfinos And C. P. Daifotis Wed
description: Dr. Anastasia A. Golfinos, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Argyrios J. Golfinos of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher P. Daifotis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter N. Daifotis of Cheyenne, Wyo. The ceremony was performed at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York by the Rev. Robert Stephanopoulos.

title: Miss Steinman Exchanges Vows With R. S. Klapper
description: Laura Bette Steinman, a daughter of Michael Steinman of McLean, Va. and the daughter of Geri Rossen of Berkeley, Calif., was married last night to Robert Stevan Klapper, a son of Mr. Burt Klapper and stepson of Sharon Klapper of Armonk, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated at the ceremony at The Loft in New York.

title: Seeking the Past In Brooklyn
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS were busy digging last summer on a former parking lot on the edge of Brooklyn Heights, hoping to find traces of Breukelen, as the area was known to its 17th century Dutch residents.

title: ANGELS WIN, 8-2; JOYNER HITS 18TH
description: Reggie Jackson's two-run double keyed a five-run third inning, and the rookie Wally Joyner broke out of a slump with a double and his 18th home run as the California Angels routed the Cleveland Indians, 8-2, today.

title: Miss Morton, D. B. Shontz Are Married
description: Hilary Morton, a daughter of the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and Mrs. Morton of New York, was married yesterday to David Beard Shontz, a son of Col. Howard B. Shontz, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Shontz of Kensington, Calif. Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York performed the ceremony at the cathedral.

title: A FAMILY PORTRAIT: 'PAINTING CHURCHES'
description: THE Churches in Tina Howe's play, ''Painting Churches,'' recently seen on public television and now at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, are not the frequently painted, picturesque, steepled structures of New England charm.

title: JEAN MAYER'S DECADE AT TUFTS: A STAMP OF PASSION
description: Dr. Jean Mayer had been talking dispassionately about his career and about Tufts University, which he runs, when the subject changed to hunger in Africa, a specialty of his. Sounding suddenly angry and incredulous, he declared that the African drought had lifted, food could be grown again, but human factors threatened to prolong intense hunger.

title:
REVSON REDUX, ADMAN'S ANATHEMA AND OTHER NEW OFFERINGS FROM THE BUSINESS SCENE;
PEOPLE GO PUBLIC
description: Successful showmen have always known how to sell themselves - as artists or producers. Now there's a new twist. Show business luminaries are packaging themselves as commodities and selling shares in their future.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A COUNTRY SHOW IN AN APPROPRIATE SITE
description: SEVENTY-FIVE antiques dealers are scheduled to display their wares here next Sunday in a quality country show that offers an unusual harmony between theme and location.

title: BARBERSHOPS, ALAS, NEED NO STATE HELP TO SPEED THEM ALONG TO EXTINCTION
description: WOMEN'S lib is fine. Unisex is all right. Even androgyny has something to be said for it.

title: NORTHERN IRELAND LOSES TO SPAIN, 2-1
description: Spain kept alive its hopes of moving into the second round of the World Cup, defeating Northern Ireland, 2-1, today and proving to itself that the Northern Irish are not as invincible as previous games between the teams had suggested.

title: RED SOX PITCHING SCRAMBLED
description: NO epidemic of injuries has struck any team the way it did the pitching staff of the Chicago Cubs last August (all five of the Cubs' starters were on the disabled list at the same time during that month, and four of the starters missed most of the last two months of the season). Nevertheless, contending teams in two divisions this season have significant pitchers ailing, and their absence figures to have some effect on the races in those divisions.

title: NEW TYCOONS RESHAPE POLITICS
description: RICHARD DENNIS, A BEEFY, RUMPLED 37-YEAR-OLD IN A short-sleeved shirt with no tie, sits in a noisy grill in Chicago, talking politics between glances at a Quotron machine. A commodities trader, he is a major Democratic contributor. ''I am trying to get a Democrat nominated for President who's not in the special-interest generation,'' Dennis says. For him, the old-fashioned trading of votes for favors ''means bargaining away the heart and soul of the political process.''

title: Mary Godfrey Is Wed To Richard B. Green
description: Mary Kempton Godfrey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Loren Godfrey of Farmington, Conn., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Richard Burdon Green, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Lee Green Jr. of Dorset, Vt. The bridegroom's father, a retired Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CAMP HAPPY DAYS
description: When Michael DiFabio of Cortlandt returned from his first visit to Camp Happy Times, a camp for children with cancer, he announced to his parents: ''I'm so glad I have leukemia. I can go to camp.''

title: HOW FREE DO WE WANT TO BE?
description: THE TOLERANT SOCIETY Freedom of Speech and Extremist Speech in America. By Lee C. Bollinger. 295 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95. IN 1977 a neo-Nazi group applied for a permit to march in Skokie, Ill., a suburb of Chicago whose large Jewish population includes survivors of German concentration camps. When the permit was denied, the American Civil Liberties Union filed suit, arguing that the free speech clause of the First Amendment protected the group's right to march. The issue stirred up a broad national controversy; 30,000 A.C.L.U. members resigned in protest. Ultimately, the courts said the Nazis could march in Skokie. (They didn't, but held a brief demonstration in downtown Chicago instead.) Whether the Constitution should protect speech that defames religious and racial groups or advocates totalitarian government has long been controversial. Neither the language of the First Amendment nor the history surrounding its adoption answers these and other difficult questions concerning its scope and application. Rather, courts have muddled along as they do in most areas of law, their doctrines both relying on and giving rise to theories, or models, of the amendment. In ''The Tolerant Society,'' Lee Bollinger, a professor at the University of Michigan Law School, criticizes two standard theories and proposes a third.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE TRIUMPH. By Ernest K. Gann. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) This absorbing sequel to ''The Antagonists,'' on which the television mini-series ''Masada'' was based, picks up the story of the Roman general Flavius Silva the morning after his Pyrrhic victory over the Jews, who chose to commit mass suicide rather than submit to Roman domination.

title: COMING POLITICAL STORMS
description: In the next couple of years, by the accidents of the political calendar, most of the allies will be facing elections that could change the course of world events.

title: Look for Tennis Under 'Business'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Tug-of-War Over Harry Winston's Land
description: WITH a developer standing by, prepared to spend $3.7 million for a Scarsdale site for a dozen houses, the heirs of Harry Winston, the New York jeweler who died in 1978, are awaiting a court decision that could stop the development.

title: Lisa Mitchell to Wed Daniel M. McGeough
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Mitchell of South Barrington, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Marie Mitchell to Daniel Morgan McGeough, a son of Ellabelle M. McGeough and the late Dr. James W. McGeough of Crystal Lake, Ill. An October wedding is planned.

title: REAGAN AND DEMOCRATS SEEK BIPARTISAN PUSH FOR TAX BILL
description: Calling the current tax system an obstacle to economic growth, President Reagan said today that he hopes to sign a tax overhaul bill by Labor Day.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WEAPONS IN SPACE. Edited by Franklin A. Long, Donald Hafner and Jeffrey Boutwell. (Norton, $16.95.) President Reagan's desire for a space-based defense against Soviet missiles came as an equal surprise to defense analysts and the public.

title: FORMULA FOR A HIGH-SCHOOL REUNION
description: NAME. Address. Phone. Spouse.

title: COMPROMISES SOUGHT ON MAJOR BILLS AND BUDGET
description: WITH the July 1 deadline for action approaching, members of the State Senate and Assembly are trying to reach some compromise on Governor Kean's $9.3 billion state budget and working on other major bills, including changes in liability-insurance laws and a constitutional amendment to allow voters to directly affect state law.

title: TV MAY QUICKEN THE SENATE'S PULSE
description: ON a normal day in the Senate, four or five members are granted ''special orders,'' permission to make speeches on any subject before the main business begins. On Wednesday, the number of special orders jumped to 24. Senator Mark O. Hatfield, an Oregon Republican, noted dryly that the increase ''might be interpreted as having some relevance to the fact that we are now on television.''

title: THE CLOUDLESS SKIES OF AMERICA WEST
description: TAN, youthful and fit, Edward R. Beauvais, the 49-year-old chairman of America West Airlines, looked west into the desert sunset from the parking lot of his company's Tempe, Ariz., headquarters. There was not a cloud for miles. In fact, the clear blueness was broken only by one of his Boeing 737 jets, which had begun its slow descent into Phoenix's Sky Harbor International Airport. ''There's nothing I'd rather be doing than running America West,'' he said.

title: Pitching Over Punting
description: His football coach didn't think much of him as a punter - or as a baseball pitcher, for that matter -but fortunately for Peter Murphy, college football coaches aren't the last word in athletic evaluation, and Harvard plays baseball as well as football. Murphy, who left the Columbia football team last fall after he was blamed by Coach Jim Garrett for a 49-17 Columbia loss to Harvard Sept. 21, has signed a minor league contract with the Pittsburgh Pirates, largely on the strength of his shutout of Harvard April 27.

title: BATTERED LEBANON LEANS ON U.N. UNIT FOR UPKEEP
description: In Lebanon, where work carried out by the Government is virtually at a standstill, more than two-thirds of the population has been relying on rehabilitation projects undertaken by the United Nations Children's Fund, with a considerable part of the financing coming from the United States.

title: I.R.A.'s Are Protection Against Pension Loss
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
ALLIUMS: ORNAMENTAL AND EDIBLE
description: THE alliums are probably the most widely grown of all garden plants, and everyone, gardener and nongardener alike, is familiar with them, if not by their proper scientific names, then by their more common ones. This group of plants includes the onion, leek, garlic, shallot and chive.

title: A NEW AUTOMATIC IN MINOLTA'S MAXXUM FAMILY
description: QUIETLY, the Maxxum 5000, the third member of Minolta's new family of autofocus cameras, slipped into the photographic marketplace this spring. The junior member of the Minolta club has joined the Professional Maxxum 9000 and the Maxxum 7000 as the lowest priced and least complicated of the trio.

title: Pregnancy in the Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
ALLIUMS: ORNAMENTAL AND EDIBLE
description: THE alliums are probably the most widely grown of all garden plants, and everyone, gardener and nongardener alike, is familiar with them, if not by their proper scientific names, then by their more common ones. This group of plants includes the onion, leek, garlic, shallot and chive.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ALEC GUINNESS AND GUY LOMBARDO
description: Stevie Nicks: I Can't Wait. MusicVision, 29 minutes. $19.95.

title: DANCE: VAN HAMEL AS ABT'S 'SPHINX'
description: DANCEGOERS should avoid declaring certain plots or themes undanceable, for as soon as they have made such a generalization about a theme, it may inspire a gifted choreographer to create a masterpiece. Nevertheless, after seeing Glen Tetley's ''Sphinx,'' presented by American Ballet Theater for the first time this season on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, this dancegoer will disregard his own advice and proclaim the story of Oedipus and the Sphinx undanceable.

title: BEHIND THE ADMINISTRATION'S THREAT TO DISPOSE OF SALT II
description: SECRETARY of State George P. Shultz held an unpublicized all-day meeting in his office last weekend to hear the views of a dozen arms-control experts on what the Reagan Administration should do next. The session underscored Washington's sense of uncertainty regarding arms-control policies.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PEEP SHOW. By David Black. (Doubleday, $16.95.) David Black's third novel suffers from an acute case of literary schizophrenia. Its focus is the impact of a 16-year-old nymphet on a tired marriage, but its animus lies entirely in the lively digressions of an otherwise listless narrator.

title: Paperback Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW SETS SHED LIGHT ON CAREERS IN JAZZ
description: A remarkable 17-LP collection of all of Sarah Vaughan's recordings for Mercury Records from 1954 to 1959 has just been released in three boxed sets (''The complete Sarah Vaughan on Mercury,'' Volume I, Mercury 826-320-1, three disks; Volume II, Mercury 826327-1, three disks; Volume III, Mercury 826333-1, three disks) at the same time as a two-disk selective collection of the records made by the George Shearing Quintet for M-G-M Records between 1949 and 1954 (George Shearing, ''Lullaby of Birdland,'' Verve 827-977-1, two disks) and a reissue of recordings of Art Tatum playing solo piano at a party in Beverly Hills in 1955 (Art Tatum, ''20th-Century Piano Genius,'' Emarcy Jazz Series 826 129-1, two disks).

title: GENERATIONS: KEEPING IT IN THE FAMILY
description: FROM shirtsleeves to shirtsleeves in three generations is the fate of members in most family-run businesses. Yet there are always exceptions that find third-generation members of a family successfully operating grandpa's business: such as Jeffrey R. Adelman, who runs Larchmont Wines and Liquors in Larchmont, and Larry H. Colin, president of Colin Service Systems Inc. in White Plains.

title: CONCERT: CANTICUM NOVUM
description: FROM the theater music of Purcell to the great oratorios of Edward Elgar and beyond, British music has been unjustly neglected in the New World. As one who loves the English repertory - for its temperance, dignity and lack of sensory manipulation - this listener found the Canticum Novum Singers' Friday night concert at St. Peter's Lutheran Church deeply satisfying.

title: WHEN INSURERS WON'T PAY MEDICAL BILLS
description: WHEN Mary, a 32-year-old teacher, was hospitalized with breast cancer, she thought her only worry was whether her treatment would be successful. She was wrong. After the California woman was discharged and faced some $40,000 in medical bills, her insurance company rescinded, or canceled, her health policy and refused to pay a penny.

title: Why a Woman Should Lead Boy Scouts
description: To the Editor:

title: RAG TRADE REVOLUTIONARY
description: THE ASSISTANT BLOUSE BUYER IS cheering, stomping her feet to the blaring beat of a Bruce Springsteen tape. A fashion coordinator is dancing in the aisle. On the stage, a senior executive flashes cue cards: ''Get loud,'' ''Act crazy,'' ''Go wild.''

title: Topics; Bullhorn Behavior; The Teacher
description: Having already sung his praises around the country, Secretary of Education William Bennett last week paid a visit to Joe Clark, the principal of Eastside High School in Paterson, N.J. With tough discipline and some unconventional methods, Mr. Bennett said, Mr. Clark had turned the school into a true ''place of learning.''

title: Q AND A
description: Business or Home Loan? Question: I am trying to buy a three-family house that has a space for professional offices in the basement. The price for the house, which will be an investment property, is $215,000. I am looking for a mortgage of about $150,000, but so far all of the banks I have been in touch with have turned me down. They will only offer commercial mortgages with rates of about 14 percent that carry up to 5 points. Since the piece of property I am trying to buy is primarily a residence, why won't the banks give me a home mortgage? . . ., M. P., Bronx Answer: The fact that your are buying the house as an investment and not for your own use has as much to do with your difficulty in obtaining a standard home loan as does the fact that the building has a commercial space basement, said Stanley Greenstein of Mortgage Clearing House, a mortgage consultation, processing and placement company. Mr. Greenstein said that if you were going to live on the property, the banks would consider your personal income in establishing your credit worthiness. But as an investment, the property must sustain itself on its income alone. Since you are looking for a $150,000 loan, Mr. Greenstein said, it is possible that the banks did not feel that the rents would cover the monthly payments. Ban on Barbecues Question: I live in a cooperative apartment that is on a low floor at the rear of my building.

title: Nancy Gerrity And J. N. Achilles Married in Maine
description: Nancy Sheffield Gerrity, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joe W. Gerrity Jr. of Loudonville and Lake Placid, N.Y., and Jonathan Newell Achilles, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Laurence Achilles Jr. of Weekapaug, R.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Laman Bruner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Trinity Church in York Harbor, Me.

title: Data Bank: June 8, 1986
LUNDINE: A QUIET STYLE FOR CUOMO TEAM
description: Representative Stan Lundine, Governor Cuomo's choice to be his running mate for lieutenant governor, is the subject of unusual attention because, in that office, he would become Governor if Mr. Cuomo ran for President in 1988 and was elected.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ALEC GUINNESS AND GUY LOMBARDO
description: Peter Martins: A Dancer. Directed by Jorgen Leth, Kultur, 54 minutes. $59.95.

title: Midlife Macho
description: As I read Christopher S. Wren's article ''Midlife Macho'' (About Men, May 4), I marveled at how enlightened he was - until I reached the last paragraph, in which he writes, ''But when the courage was desperately needed, they delivered it, and afterward . . . they got on with less remarkable lives.''

title: DR. JEFFREY G. SCHNEIDER WEDS LAURA KAUFMAN
description: Laura Ann Kaufman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Kaufman of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Gary Schneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Schneider of Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Mark Goldman performed the ceremony at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

title: LILCO SUIT STIRS A SUFFOLK SPLIT
description: A RECENT vote by the Suffolk County Legislature to file a Federal racketeering suit against the Long Island Lighting Company has revealed growing tensions among county officials.

title: SOVIET CRACKING DOWN ON WEALTHY CHEATERS
description: The Soviet Union, citing a need to use ''the full force of the law'' against corruption, has announced new penalties for embezzlement.

title: Karen Einbender Weds Rink Smith
description: Karen Ann Einbender, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin H. Einbender of New York, was married yesterday to Walter S. Smith Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Abington, Pa. Rabbi Alvin J. Reines of Cincinnati, a cousin of the bride's mother, performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan.

title: EUROPEAN HOTELS FOR FAMILIES
description: You might think that first-class European hotels and small children are a lot like oil and water. Small children aren't particularly impressed with how many red castles a hotel has in the Michelin guide. And the concierge at these distinguished establishments often blanch when guests appear on their doorstep with several youngsters in tow.

title: ACCOUNTING FOR BLACKS
description: In 1963, Bert N. Mitchell sought a job with some of the Big Eight accounting firms, but at the interviews, he says, he was told: ''Well, you know, we would consider hiring you, but our clients wouldn't want a black accountant.''

title: THE NIGHT THEY ATE OUT
description: RECENTLY, FOOL THAT I AM, I suggested to my wife that we go out to dinner.

title: Reading With Adolescents
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: CONCORDIA
description: CONCORDIA is a chamber orchestra unusual for its inventive mix of jazz and European elements. It is also unusual for its quality. At Alice Tully Hall Friday night, there were many familiar faces from New York's freelance pool peering out from this 35-member ensemble, but its conductor, Marin Alsop - who also plays the violin in the New York City Ballet orchestra - had what is virtually a pickup orchestra responding with impressive clarity and poise. Miss Alsop also conducts with the gift of tempo -a sense for just the right movement to propel music without hurrying it.

title: VINTAGE PLOTTING PROPELS MACH II PLANES IN 'TOP GUN'
description: ''He's a wild card - flies by the seat of his pants,'' says the senior officer of the brash young pilot in his command. ''He's completely unpredictable.''

title: Experiencing Apartheid
description: Sheila Rule's article ''Nothing Prepares You for Apartheid'' (May 4), although a more personal narration of her experiences, ties in beautifully with J. M. Coetzee's portrait of suburban white Afrikaners (''Tales of Afrikaners,'' March 9).

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I don't think senators are elected to be rubber stamps.'' - Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, on the tax bill.

title: Who Wants To Teach?
description: I read with special interest Nick Taylor's article ''Who Wants to Teach?'' (May 4). Mary Jo Knipper appears to have what it takes to be a good teacher in today's classroom.

title: TIPTOEING AROUND THE SHADOW OF DEATH
description: HOW civilized we were. I had left him at 6:45 A.M., maybe for the last time. We had kissed the kind of kiss you kiss in front of a nurse and orderly. We had smiled, told each other to take care.

title: INSIDER ACCUSATIONS YIELD 5 GUILTY PLEAS
description: Dennis B. Levine pleaded guilty to Federal charges that he used inside information to make $12.6 million in illegal profits. And he settled S.E.C. civil charges by agreeing to return nearly $11.5 million. In addition, Mr. Levine, a former investment banker who was accused of insider trading while at several firms, agreed to cooperate with a widening inquiry into the pervasive but ambiguously defined Wall Street practice of leaking information. Mr. Levine, who traded through the Bahamian subsidiary of a Swiss bank, was accused of using such information to trade in the stocks of companies involved in takeovers.

title: EXECUTIVE FUN AND GAMES
description: NO, I DON'T PLAY GOLF,'' THE SENIOR executive admitted. Then he added, with a narrow-eyed stare, ''But I'll never talk to you again if you print that. I can't let it be known that I don't play. When I'm invited, I always have that emergency meeting that keeps me tied up.''

title: MOISTURE IN THE CRAWL SPACE CAN MEAN TROUBLE UPSTAIRS
description: IF your house has a crawl space under it instead of a full basement, it is important that this space be adequately ventilated year round to prevent excess moisture in the house.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BOSTON;
Block of Condos May Be the Last
description: THE New Gainsborough Street Condominiums, which sold out last month, may mark the first and last time that a single developer could buy, rehabilitate and resell all the housing on both sides of a block here.

title: Woody Stephens's Musical Ride
description: IN the uproar of the winner's circle after the 118th Belmont Stakes yesterday, Chris McCarron was getting off Danzig Connection.

title: Summer's Soft Prize
description: EVERY SUMMER WHEN I WAS A child, my grandfather and I would take long walks through the woods in the Vosges, near Paris, to find morels - his favorite mushrooms.

title: MEETING BIRTH PARENTS CAN BRING HAPPINESS
description: It was unfortunate that Lynne Ames's article, ''Bonds'' [ ''About Westchester,'' May 11 ] , focused on a natural mother's initial confusion during the early stages of the reunion process rather than upon the more common feelings of relief, happiness and acceptance that most adoptee-initiated reunions engender. This atypical birth-parent reaction may cause some prospective searchers to delay, unnecessarily, pursuing contact with birth relatives.

title: WHY THEY STRETCHED THE SLIMS
description: THREE COUPLES WALK INTO AURORA, a swank new restaurant in Manhattan. The women, in their late 30's, are dressed with studied elegance. They know their fashion magazines. The men elbow each other and exclaim over the $30 entrees. But it's good-natured. They can afford it. The couples laugh. They order cocktails.

title: George Fazio, Ex-Pro Golfer And a Designer of Courses
description: George Fazio, a professional golfer for 25 years and a designer of courses after his playing days, died Friday of cancer. He was 75 years old.

title: Carol G. Pierson Becomes a Bride
description: Carol Godwin Pierson, a vice president of Citibank, and Reynolds Walker Holding, an associate with the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, were married yesterday at Christ St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Joseph M. Zorawick performed the ceremony.

title: Maureen Footer Marries in West
description: Maureen Wilson Footer, a daughter of Mrs. Arthur Wilson Footer of Piedmont, Calif., and the late Dr. Footer, was married yesterday to Thong Minh Nguyen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Minh Van Nguyen of New York. The Rev. Samuel Lindamood performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Piedmont Community Church.

title: CLUB-LIKE AMBIENCE IN SUMMIT
description: SUMMIT'S venerable Suburban Hotel came under new ownership six months ago, and it has since been transformed - to the tune of some $7 million - from its dowdy dotage into a handsome hostelry with the more upscale name of The Summit.

title: A SWISS CITY MISSES THE AMERICANS
description: Mark Twain wrote about Lucerne after he climbed the Rigi, and American G.I.'s talked about it when they came here after World War II. Last year about 500,000 tourists, half of them Americans, visited Lucerne to ride the fleet of paddle-wheeled lake steamers and to shop.

title: Experiencing Apartheid
description: I have seldom read anything so thoroughly frightening as ''Nothing Prepares You for Apartheid.'' Miss Rule's article only validates what I have been thinking and observing for many years: the Afrikaner mentality is that of a madman and his behavior is only fueled by a maniacal view of humanity.

title: THE BUSINESS OF SPYING
description: The heavy spate of spy stories surfacing lately revives issues of what this business is really about and what obligations, if any, it imposes on governments.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Long Beach's Stock Again on the Rise
description: IN the days before jet travel and the extension of the Long Island Expressway into eastern Suffolk, Long Beach was considered a prime vacation resort for city residents. Now vacation-home seekers are again discovering the city's appeal.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The table of contents in The Times Magazine today misidentifies the writer of the Food column. As shown on page 71, it is by Colette Rossant.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
COIN DESIGNS WILL BE JUDGED THIS WEEK
description: The Federal Commission of Fine Arts will pass judgment Thursday on the proposed designs for the new United States gold and silver bullion coins at its monthly meeting in Washington, D.C. As in most matters involving U.S. coins and national medals, the Fine Arts Commission has only an advisory role. If it should choose to reject all or part of the designs, the United States Treasury would not be legally bound to come up with anything different.

title: Third World Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BUSINESS WORLD
description: The Business World joins the ranks of The New York Times Magazine/Part 2, a series of publications expanded in recent years to include The Sophisticated Traveler and The World of New York.

title: PORTRAIT OF A COLLECTOR WHO LEFT HIS IMPRINT ON THE MET
description: Collectors come in all kinds and sizes, and some of them are so pleased with themselves that if Pericles came back from the dead to pronounce their funeral oration, they would hear him out in the heavens and say that, all things considered, he might have been more gracious.

title: WHARTON REACHES FOR THE STARS
description: WHEN I CAME HERE,'' SAYS RUSSELL E. PALMER, dean of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School since 1983, ''I tried to look at Wharton from the viewpoint of the marketplace. And I realized that if we asked the question, 'What is Wharton known for?' the marketplace would sing out, 'Finance.' That was the perception.''

title: DINING OFF THE GREATS AND OTHER DIVERSIONS
description: IN the May issue of Vogue, I read that Brooke (Hayward) and Peter (Duchin) use stacks of books as place mats when they have guests for dinner.

title: Cable TV
description: For those who prefer to take their crises vicariously, two of this week's cable movies offer them in two forms: fantastic and familial.

title: MUSEUM RE-CREATES SLOANE'S STUDIO
description: ERIC SLOANE, the artist and writer who lived in the northwestern town of Warren, helped establish a small museum in nearby Kent to commemorate, he said at the time, the ''early American's ingenuity, craftsmanship and reverence for wood.''

title: STATE TICKETS EYE L.I. VOTERS
description: REPUBLICAN and Democratic officials on Long Island strongly disagree on the effect that the Republican state ticket, which is heavily tilted to the suburbs, and the Democratic ticket, which has no suburban representation, will have on the Long Island vote.

title: Finding and Shaping Space to Fit a Company's Needs
description: CHILLINGWORTH/RADDING, an advertising and design firm, spent its first six years snuggled into the warmth of a brownstone on East 48th Street in the Turtle Bay section of Manhattan. But as it expanded, the partners were faced with the necessity to relocate.

title: Selling a House At a Tag Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: GROWTH IN JOBS SINCE '80 IS SHARP, BUT PAY AND QUALITY ARE DEBATED
description: The number of jobs in the United States has grown at a rapid pace since 1980 as the economy has improved under the Reagan Administration. But a sharp debate has developed over whether the new positions pay enough money, provide enough full-time work and are available in parts of the country where they will help the chronically unemployed.

title: Drusilla Pratt Is the Bride Of Stephen Otto in Boston
description: Drusilla Hubard Pratt and Stephen George Otto were married yesterday at the Arlington Street Unitarian Church in Boston. The Rev. Frederic Reynolds, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A FINE EXCESS. By Jane Ellison. (Secker & Warburg/ David & Charles, $18.95.) Jane Ellison, a London journalist who works for the satirical magazine Private Eye, has written a short, funny first novel about British poets, their rivalries and their critics.

title: AFTER 15,000 GAMES, STILL BEHIND PLATE
description: MANY baseball fans over the age of 40 will recall how, years ago, it was a common practice for the home plate umpire at amateur and semiprofessional baseball games to announce the ''batteries'' before the game began.

title: Philip Kopp 3d Weds Dr. Elaine Angelides
description: Dr. Elaine M. Angelides, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the New York University Medical Center, and Philip J. Kopp 3d, a stockbroker with Philips, Appel & Walden in New York, were married yesterday at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Jamaica Estates, Queens. The Rev. Salvatore Riccardi officiated.

title: IT PAYS TO WIN...
description: The fruits of winning are always sweet, but especially so for the team with the nation's top player.

title: NICE DAY FOR REID AS MILESTONE NEARS
description: The rainy weather and gusting wind were problems for most of the golfers in the third round of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic here today, but not to Mike Reid, who spends a lot of time in Seattle and is familiar with rainy weather conditions.

title: A Fashion Star
description: I found it moving to read the articles about Donna Karan, the designer, and Mary Jo Knipper, the biochemistry teacher (''Designer Donna Karan: How a Fashion Star is Born,'' by Carrie Donovan, May 4). Both represent the best of American womanhood, well-educated, energetic, empathetic to the needs of each's particular audience and in love with what they create, whether it is clothes or students' ideas.

title: BEACH BUGGIES AT ISSUE
description: FOR more than 20 years, the noise of four-wheel-drive beach buggies has mixed with the sounds of the ocean in the Village of Southampton.

title: Music
description: There's a lot of new music around town this week - of all kinds, in neighborhoods throughout the city.

title: Five Guilty Pleas In Insider Cases
description: The two cases had common threads - well-situated young men were accused of trading illegally on insider information about impending takeover bids - and most of the defendants pleaded guilty in the same Manhattan courtroom one day last week.

title: KOREA'S OPPOSITION IS INCHING TOWARD ITS GOAL
description: THESE are heady days for opposition leaders here. Encouraged by recent events, they dream of assuming the national power they have sought for years.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: DELAWARE TRIES TO MAKE ITSELF OVER
description: THIS CITY, once marked by residential decay and abandoned urban renewal projects, has in the last five years become a 20th-century El Dorado, according to state banking officials the country's second-largest private depository for gold and silver. The treasure, untold billions, is in Wilmington because a 1981 state law raised usury limits and reduced taxes for large financial institutions. More than 30 banks rushed in, building vaults for the gold and silver and offices for electronic and paper transfers, sparking a boom that transformed the city.

title: Adrienne Rich Receives New Award for Poetry
description: The poet Adrienne Rich today was awarded the $25,000 Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize, reportedly the largest award offered to poets in the United States.

title: Monica Woodford Marries Thomas Luby, Executive
description: The wedding of Monica Kathleen Woodford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Stanley Woodford of Convent Station, N.J., to Thomas James Luby, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Matthew Luby of Lighthouse Point, Fla., took place yesterday.

title: Midlife Macho
description: Christopher Wren's article was sensitive, and enlightening to all readers, male and female.

title: ONCE AGAIN, DUARTE IS IN A MOOD TO TALK
description: IN AN unexpected move last week, President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador ended 19 months of stalemate by offering to reopen peace talks with leftist guerrilla leaders later this summer. The rebels almost immediately accepted the offer. But few Salvadorans were optimistic that an end to the six-year civil war might be in sight. Two past meetings between the guerrillas and Government have ended in deadlock, with the rebels demanding a share of power, and Mr. Duarte offering only a chance to stand in elections.

title: Sharing the Wealth
description: In the end, four months and 75 witnesses after the matter went to trial, the survivors of J. Seward Johnson found a way to divide his millions. Barbara Piasecka Johnson, his widow, is to keep $340 million of the $500 million estate under the out-of-court settlement reached last week. Mr. Johnson's six children by two previous marriages, who had been virtually disinherited, will receive $42.5 million to divide as they may.

title: WALDHEIM POSING PROBLEMS FOR THE YUGOSLAV LEADERSHIP
description: The disclosures about the World War II record of Kurt Waldheim are confronting Yugoslav Government officials with an array of problems.

title: WHITE-COLLAR MANHUNT
description: They take pleasure in making me redouble my vigilance; they have false information brought to me. They laugh at my worries. - Montesquieu's ''Persian Letters.''

title: A HISTORY OF THE U.N. IN JUST 50 MILLION PAGES
description: THE United Nations Archives are tucked away on the top two floors of an office building at 345 Park Avenue South, near 25th Street. The records there might have remained among the most obscure resources of the United Nations had it not been for the recent discovery that the 50 million pages of documents included a secret file accusing Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General, of war crimes.

title: MACAO PLANS FOR A FUTURE UNDER CHINA
description: Not quite two years after Britain and China fashioned a formula for the return of Hong Kong to China, Portugal and China have agreed to open negotiations on a similar deal for Macao, the oldest European enclave on the China coast.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Trade Deficit Dip -The nation's trade deficit remains large, despite the weaker dollar. But Allen Sinai, chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., says that before the year is over, it will narrow enough to brighten the outlook for economic growth.

title: STAGE: DUANE SHEPARD AS 'BROTHER MALCOLM X'
description: MANY persons, especially New Yorkers past age 40, have vivid memories of Malcolm X, the legendary Black Muslim leader who was assassinated in 1965. Many easily envision the tall, bespectacled, light-tan-complexioned, crisp-voiced figure on the television screen, moving about receptions held by African delegations at the United Nations, jousting with reporters or speaking at rallies in Harlem streets. These strong memories make it difficult to portray him on the stage.

title: FACELIFT FOR A VALUED HALL
description: Carnegie Hall isn't the only important city auditorium undergoing renovation this year. McMillin Academic Theater, located at 116th Street and Broadway in Columbia University's Dodge Hall, will be rebuilt and renamed this fall.

title: DANCE: SPANISH COMPANY IN 'PASION'
description: WITH Liliana Morales as guest artist, Roberto Lorca and Carlota Santana of the Spanish Dance Arts Company presented an ambitious program called ''Pasion!'' Thursday night at the University Theater of New York University. Their offerings included traditional flamenco dances and contemporary attempts to use flamenco forms to establish dramatic situations. It was an evening that improved as it progressed and it was most convincing when it was most traditional.

title: FRATERNITY GATHERS FOR LOVE OF WINE
description: THE procession of crimson- and gold-robed officials made its way up the aisle slowly, solemnly.

title: Struck Utility Reaches Pact
description: Boston Edison and officials representing 1,500 electrical workers reached agreement on a tentative new contract and pension package Friday, three weeks after a strike began. Local 369 of the Utility Workers of America scheduled a meeting for Thursday where the rank-and-file members will vote on the pact.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
WAYS OF THE FAMILY
description: CORINNE OLSEN, 72 years old, was remembering her grandmother. ''In her apartment in New York City, she had a white marble mantle. On it was an English china hunting set - figurines of dogs, horses, the whole scene. And on the white marble table, a ruby red oil lamp.'' Mrs. Olsen paused, looked at a painting of a woman arranging fancy china in a wooden cabinet. ''See that, right there. That would have been her place.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ROCK HALL CONCERTS - Back in 1767, when settlers from the West Indies island of Antigua came to what is now Lawrence and built their family mansion, Rock Hall, it probably was frequently the site of what passed for entertainment in those days. Nowadays, though the Hewlett family no longer lives there, the house, maintained intact with period furniture and artifacts by the Town of Hempstead as a museum, still echoes with the sounds of what turned the colonials on. Today, the museum begins a series of summer concerts in its colorful, authentic gardens. A performance by the Colonial Dancers at 2 P.M. starts the festivities, which continue Saturday at 1:30 P.M. when Heather Forest, storyteller, appears to beguile children. There will be concerts on the pianoforte June 22 and Aug. 24; puppet shows July 7, 28 and Aug. 4, and, strictly from this century, ''Fascinatin' Gershwin'' Aug. 11. The museum is at 199 Broadway. There's no admission charge, but bring your own seating.

title: THE DANCE: GRAHAM'S 'EVERY SOUL'
description: WHO would have thought that the wry and witty humor of ''Every Soul Is a Circus'' would be fresh today, in such different times, 47 years after Martha Graham created the piece? Those who doubt the durability of comic art are advised to hurry to City Center for a taste of this keen-flavored nectar of a dance, revived by the Martha Graham Dance Company on Thursday at City Center.

title: COUNTY SEEKS NEW SUBSTITUTE FOR DUMP IN CROTON
description: WITH only a little more than three weeks left to find a landfill to replace the Croton Point Landfill, the county dumping site that is scheduled to close on June 30, Westchester officials appeared to be preparing to adopt dramatic measures.

title: A NEW OWNER AND A NEW OUTLOOK
description: THE first change you may notice at Caminari's, a 47-year-old landmark in Locust Valley that acquired a new owner-chef two months ago, is the dinnerware. The restaurant is using the basket pattern that has been the signature of a number of top French chefs.

title: STAMFORD BALLET SCHOOL SPAWNS A NEW DANCE COMPANY
description: A PROFESSIONAL ballet company has joined the growing list of performing-arts organizations making their home in Stamford.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GOING FOR IT! How to Succeed as an Entrepreneur. By Victor Kiam. (Morrow, $16.95.) After generously sprinkling his text with the word ''entrepreneur,'' Victor Kiam no doubt wondered what additional spin was needed to move this account of his business exploits. Mr. Kiam, president of Remington Products, bought Remington and appears in the television commercials for the company's electric shaver.

title: PHARMACEUTICALS: A SUBTLE REVOLUTION
description: THE pharmaceutical business has been undergoing a subtle revolution that may well contribute to redefining the practice of medicine in the latter part of this century.

title: ISRAEL SUFFERING A BIG LOSS OF AMERICAN TOURISTS
description: At a Jerusalem dinner party recently a group of Israelis were sitting around over coffee complaining that their country's tourist industry was being wrecked because many American tourists were apparently afraid to visit.

title: FOR PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES
description: Bob Zywicki is a tour operator from Bayonne, N.J., who says he prefers to take groups to Europe because it is easier to accommodate them there than in the United States. His company, Whole Person Tours, arranges travel for people with disabilities; many of them, like himself, use wheelchairs. In Europe, he says, nearly all tour buses have lifts to get wheelchairs aboard, anchors to secure them and restrooms that are readily accessible, but there are very few such buses in the United States.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ITALIAN BAROQUE AND ROCOCO ARCHITECTURE. By John Varriano. (Oxford University, Cloth, $27.95. Paper, $16.95.) A fashionable as well as scholarly work, this comprehensive study of Italian architecture from 1600 to 1750 should be of interest not only to those in the profession but to architecture buffs too. Mr. Varriano, a professor of art history at Mount Holyoke College, devotes separate chapters to three major Baroque architects - Francesco Borromini, Gianlorenzo Bernini and Pietro da Cortona - and discusses the genesis of various design schemes and the role that personal connections, papal patronage and church politics played in determining style and commissions.

title: ANATOMY OF A LAUGH IN NICHOLS'S 'SOCIAL SECURITY'
description: Herewith some reflections on a laugh - a real boffola that comes along in about the middle of ''Social Security,'' the flippant little foolishness at the Barrymore directed by Mike Nichols, who knows whereof he tweaks.

title: Men Who Stormed Bank Got $2,200, Police Say
description: Holdup men who stormed a bank in East Allen Township Friday, killing three employees and wounding two other people, stole about $2,200, the police said today.

title: BOARDING SCHOOLS' HARD BALANCING ON DRUG TESTS
description: Boarding schools around the country are struggling with the question of whether, and how, to set up policies on testing students for drug use.

title: SHORT FURS STAGING COMEBACK FOR FALL
description: IT'S been a long time since the fur stole or, for that matter, the little fur jacket occupied an important place in a woman's wardrobe. But by fall, the picture may change. A lavish fur stole may be wrapped around many wool suits or coats. A fluffy bolero may protect bare shoulders as a woman steps out for the evening.

title: RAIN PUTS DAMPER ON BELMONT PARADE
description: The splashy morning was followed by a grim afternoon, and the sky sifted rain onto the track at Belmont, wreaking havoc on the oddsmakers and picnickers. Mud, an abundance of it, threatened to disturb the peculiar magic that surrounds the track on Belmont Day.

title: Diplomatic Ties With the Vatican Violate the First Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Jessica Knight Is Wed to Leonard Casoni on L.I.
description: Jessica Townsend Knight, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Townsend Jones Knight of New York and Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Leonard Casoni, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ugo Casoni of Florence, Italy. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee officiated at the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ALEC GUINNESS AND GUY LOMBARDO
description: The Ladykillers. Starring Alec Guinness, Peter Sellers, Katie Johnson; directed by Alexander Mackendrick, 1955, Thorn EMI/HBO Video, 87 minutes. $39.95.

title: COMING TO THE NET
description: Tennis commentators mutter:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SEA MUSIC - Stan Hugill will return to Mystic Seaport's annual Sea Music Festival Friday through next Sunday, as he has done for the seven years that the event has taken place. He is ''recognized as one of the last of the chanteymen,'' said Lisa Brownell, a spokesman for the Seaport.

title: Ex-Astronaut Apparently Has Heart Attack While Jogging
description: James B. Irwin, one of a dozen astronauts to walk on the moon, collapsed while jogging Friday, apparently of a heart attack, and was unconscious in critical but stable condition today in Penrose Hospital here, the authorities said.

title: NEWPORT DRAWS MORE MAXIS
description: The size of the fleet in the Newport to Bermuda Race this year is smaller than it has been in 28 years. But a larger-than-ever number of maxi- boats indicates that the 80-year-old sailing competition still exerts plenty of yacht-racing muscle.

title: Roxana Idonea Grant-Suttie Planning To Marry Ogden Mills Reid in August
description: An August wedding is planned by Roxana Idonea Grant-Suttie and Ogden Mills Reid, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ian Grant-Suttie of Woodstock, Vt., have announced. Mr. Reid is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden Rogers Reid of Purchase, N.Y.

title: Cocaine Found in Madrid
description: Two abandoned suitcases containing 50 pounds of cocaine with a street value of $10 million were found at the Barajas airport in Madrid, the police said today. The cocaine, which was found on Thursday, was disguised in neatly wrapped packages. The luggage, bound for Geneva, had been boarded in Bogota, Colombia, and arrived in Madrid by way of Caracas, Venezuela.

title: WHY GLASS HOLDS ITS LIQUOR BEST
description: ABOUT five years ago, the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms ruled that liquor could be packaged in polyethylene terephthalate containers - the same type of plastic bottles that were approved for soda in 1973.

title: VENICE
description: The inauguration of the renovated Palazzo Grassi on the Grand Canal as a permanent center for cultural events heralds what promises to be a superb Venetian season. The 18th-century building, again resplendent in white, halfway between the Rialto Bridge and St. Mark's Square, started its new life on May 3 with an exhibition on Futurism.

title: Phillies 3, Expos 1
description: Juan Samuel and Glenn Wilson hit run-scoring singles, keying a three-run rally in the seventh inning that lifted Philadelphia over Montreal.

title: JUST FOR THE RECORD...
description: IT was not a case of the Senate's treating the House of Representatives with disdain, but rather a matter of following a procedure that just might strike some people as wasteful.

title: A TWO-DAY TOUR OF MIES'S LEGACY
description: No other city bears as strong an imprint of Mies van der Rohe as Chicago. Other major cities, like New York with its Seagram Building, may have only one Miesian gem mixed in with diluted forms of what came to be called the International style. But Chicago is the place to see the broadest sampling of his work from 1938, when he moved there, until his death in 1969.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: OVERLOOK HOSPITAL in Summit was prepared for a modest turnout when it announced it was participating in Older Americans Skin Cancer and Melanoma Detection Week by providing free skin cancer screening on May 30.

title: THE BIG BOARD'S BETA OPTION
description: By their nature, ''growth'' stocks are seldom average achievers. They rise - or fall - fast. Market technicians can measure a stock's volatility by computing the variability in its price changes, and then comparing it with the variability of the entire market.

title: A CRICKET FIELD BY A WINE-DARK SEA
description: Homer was a poet and not a geographer, and many of the sites in the ''Iliad'' and ''Odyssey'' still serve as academic battlegrounds for distant scholars, who struggle to locate them on today's map of Greece and Turkey. Nor is there agreement among the professors of classics that the first great writer really wrote a phrase that can be accurately translated as ''wine-dark sea.''

title: ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS ADAPT
description: IN THE winter of 1981, officials of the East Williston School District seriously considered closing the alternative School-Within-a-School at the Wheatley School.

title: SIBELIUS' SHADOW HAUNTS NORDIC MUSIC
description: Contemporary Scandinavian composers have a problem. The name of their problem is Jan Sibelius.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ALEC GUINNESS AND GUY LOMBARDO
description: The Police Tapes. Produced by Alan and Susan Raymond, Lightning Video, 73 minutes. $59.95.

title: TEACHER DIES IN LEAP AT HOSPITAL
description: A Bronx schoolteacher who was admitted to Presbyterian Hospital after a suicide attempt earlier this week apparently jumped from an 11th-story bathroom to his death yesterday afternoon while a female attendant who had escorted him there waited outside the door, the police said.

title: HOW AMERICANS RATE BIG BUSINESS
description: THE AMERICAN PEOPLE do not think much of the honesty, sense of social responsibility or products of big business in this country, a New York Times Poll shows.

title: ASSESSING THE SHAKER STYLE
description: ''Do all your work as if you had a thousand years to live, and as you would if you knew you must die tomorrow.'' Those are the words of Ann Lee, 1736-1784, a revolutionary and a religious leader whose teachings changed the spiritual practices and social behavior of thousands. Her followers were responsible for the most admired of all design developments in 19th-century America - the Shaker style.

title: Filipinos to Appeal Ruling Favoring Marcos
description: A Government commissioner seeking the recovery of the wealth of Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that the panel would seek reconsideration of an American judge's decision returning $7 million in belongings to the former President.

title: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF A SMALL BUSINESS
description: X-PANDO CORPORATION WAS 53 YEARS years old in April, and gone for good the next month. Lost our lease.

title: Tropical Storm Falters Off North Carolina
description: Boaters stayed ashore but surfers were out in force today as Tropical Storm Andrew, the first of the 1986 hurricane season, brought wind, waves and rain to North Carolina's coast.

title: Market-Rate Housing for the Bronx
description: ALONG the eastern shore of the Bronx, at the point where Pugsley's Creek meets the East River, the old Castle Hill Beach Club property stands vacant and unused, awaiting its fate. Daniel Z. Nelson, a developer, bought the 18.6-acre site last December and now hopes to build a condominium community on it.

title: VICTIMS ASSISTANCE EARNS STATE AWARD
description: ONE day last June in White Plains, a 15-year-old girl was fatally wounded and another girl was seriously injured when an armed intruder opened fire on them as they walked into one girl's apartment.

title: MAYORAL RUNOFF SET IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: VOTERS here will go to the polls Tuesday to pick the winner in a runoff for Mayor. In the previous election last month, no candidate in a field of four achieved the required 50 percent of the vote plus one.

title: DEBATE OVER ANALOG VS. DIGITAL MAY BE POINTLESS
description: They are arrayed like armies. On one side, partisans of analog audio root for tradition and the old LP.

title: Sweden Suspects Alien Sub
description: The Swedish Navy fired a salvo of antisubmarine charges today in the waters off Stockholm for the second time in 24 hours after suspecting the presence of a foreign submarine, a Swedish military spokesman said. The explosions failed to produce immediate evidence of foreign intrusion, he said.

title: AIDS FOR STANDARDIZED TESTS INCREASING
description: A TOTAL of 86,000 ninth-grade public-school students took this year's High School Proficiency Test in April; of that number, 42,000 are expected to have failed one or more of the three sections - mathematics, reading and composition.

title: ITINERANT ENTHUSIAST PREACHES CARING
description: WAYNE MEISEL is a modern-day Johnny Appleseed, roaming across the country, planting the seeds among college students for a grass-roots movement of community involvement.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: NATURAL PATRIOTISM - A 15-foot Statue of Liberty made of moss and creeping fig over chicken wire is the centerpiece of the New York Botanical Garden's observance of Lady Liberty's centennial. James Male, a graduate of the Botanical Garden School of Horticulture has created the statue, which goes on display Thursday and remains until Sept. 7.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LETTERS FROM A YOUNG SHAKER: William S. Byrd at Pleasant Hill. Edited by Stephen J. Stein. (University Press of Kentucky, $15.)

title: A REPORT CARD FOR ADMEN
description: Among the advertising ideas that Marion Harper tossed off - and he tossed them off by the score - only one was so appealing and distasteful at the same time. Why, he asked, shouldn't advertising agencies be paid more if their ads work and less if they do not?

title: REJUVENATING OLD MONEY
description: WHEN HENRY PHIPPS, A SHOEMAKER'S son, was growing up in Allegheny City, Pa., Andrew Carnegie lived nearby. Henry turned out to be good at figures, and in 1865 he became a partner in Carnegie's Union Iron Mills. Three decades later, when J. P. Morgan was putting together United States Steel, he coveted Carnegie's company and arranged a meeting. Legend has it that Morgan asked, ''What's your price?'' Carnegie pushed a piece of paper across the table. Morgan glared at the figures and nodded. That nod yielded about $226 million for Carnegie, more than double the price he'd asked in a deal that had fallen through 18 months earlier. Henry Phipps received $43 million - roughly $500 million in today's money. Receiving the news, Phipps burbled, ''Ain't Andy wonderful?'' The Phipps fortune was made, and over the years it survived. The vehicle Henry Phipps chose to accomplish that end, back in 1907, was one that old wealth has traditionally favored: a private family office.

title: BRITISH INQUIRY ON ULSTER POLICE GETS NEW DIRECTOR
description: A top British police commander has been rushed in to rescue a seemingly stalled and highly sensitive inquiry into police conduct in Northern Ireland. The action comes after the sudden and mysterious suspension from duty of the officer who had been in charge of the investigation for the last two years.

title: In Brief, Mr. Manion Is Unfit
description: When President Reagan set out to reshape the Federal bench, he made two promises. He would choose non-activists who knew the judiciary's proper limits and were content to interpret law, not make it. And he would pick lawyers of the highest caliber. The President has indeed found candidates who share his judicial philosophy, including several of outstanding ability. But two recent nominations broke the promise of quality and assaulted the intelligence of the Senate.

title: The Police Begin to Test Their Own
description: Members of the elite unit that investigates organized crime in the New York City Police Department have long been held to higher standards than other officers. Since investigators in the bureau, which includes the narcotics division, are exposed to multimillion dollar drug transactions and assorted other temptations, their conduct is scrutinized with care.

title: Delta Queen
description: To the Editor: My trip on the Delta Queen was so different from Paul Grimes's account (Travel, May 11) that rather than ''Up a Busy River'' my title would be ''Down a Lazy River.''

title: COLORFUL CARPETS OF YUGOSLAVIA
description: Each year vacationers flock to Yugoslavia in search of warm sun and clear blue sea along the dramatic Adriatic coast. The more discerning also discover that Yugoslavia's natural beauties are not its only attractions. Its woven and knotted handmade rugs, which come in dazzling variations of design, style and color, are simply too good to miss.

title: Curry Is Easy Winner Of British Amateur Golf
description: David Curry won the British Amateur golf championship today by the biggest margin since 1934. Curry, 22 years old, beat Geoff Birtwell, a fellow Briton, 11 and 9, in the 36-hole final.

title: UNDER COMPARABLE WORTH, JOBS WON'T HAVE GENDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quality Returns To the Hill
description: FROM a high vantage point, Tony Salazar looked out over the neighborhood where the unusual development company he serves is trying to recapture a piece of Kansas City's more colorful past, a place that generations of Missourians have called Quality Hill.

title: OFF OFF BROADWAY, THERE IS AN OLD, FULL AND VERY BUSY FARM
description: ''THE road will turn to dirt, you'll go around a big S-curve and we are the next house on the left . . . an old peeling yellow farm house with a cobblestone driveway.'' That is the final part of the directions to the farm. When we first moved here to South Salem, 20 years ago, there was an old brass sign that read, ''Flood Farm.'' The house is said to go back to the 1740's and the original farmer's name was Flood. Through the years, we and our friends shortened it simply to The Farm.

title: Puffins and Petrels in the Pacific, New Paradors in Spain
description: BIRD WATCHING OFF THE COAST OF CALIFORNIA - Twenty-five miles to the west of the Golden Gate Bridge, in the vastness of the Pacific Ocean, lies a group of rocky outcroppings known as the Farallon Islands.

title: NBC SEEKS DISCLOSURE OF LaROUCHE MONEY SOURCES
description: Armed with a $202,000 court judgment, lawyers for NBC-TV are moving in Federal court to force the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. to disclose who pays the bills for his country estate, armed guards and laundry.

title: JAZZ: NEW-MUSIC SERIES AT THE KITCHEN
description: THE KITCHEN opened an eight-night series of new-music triple bills Wednesday - 24 groups and individuals from ''downtown,'' which is more a mindset than a geographical area. The newest downtown music tends to be eclectic and noisy, built from fragments of various traditions; it might be fully improvised, completely composed or somewhere in between. It can also be rebellious, imaginative, daring or silly.

title: SOUTHAMPTON WARMING UP FOR THIS WEEK'S OPEN
description: THE Town of Southampton is preparing for one of the year's major sporting events, the U.S. Open golf tournament, to be held at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club Thursday through next Sunday. Officials hope that months of planning will enable the town to cope with the estimated 100,000 people expected to attend.

title: BATTLE PLANS
description: AMERICA CAN WIN The Case for Military Reform. By Gary Hart with William S. Lind. 301 pp. Bethesda, Md.: Adler & Adler. $17.95. THE timing of this book could scarcely be better.

title: Topics; Bullhorn Behavior; The Hammerer
description: In Zimbabwe last week, plainclothes police arrested Michael Auret and Nicholas Ndebele, the chairman and director of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace.
