Their apparent offense was embarrassing Prime Minister Mugabe's regime by passing information used in critical reports by Amnesty International and the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights.

title: Miss Lenard Wed To James Angley
description: Patricia Mary Lenard, a student at the Fordham University School of Law, and James Patrick Angley, an assistant treasurer of the Bank of New York, were married yesterday at the Chapel of Our Lady of Good Counsel in White Plains. Msgr. William T. White officiated.

title: WHEN CITIZENS OF THE WORLD BREAK THE LAWS OF NEW YORK
description: THE release of Iran's chief delegate, Said Rajaie-Khorassani, after a brief detention last month on charges that he had tried to shoplift a $99.99 raincoat raised questions once again about the immunity enjoyed in one way or another by 35,000 foreign diplomats, dependents and staff in New York City.

title: A PRETTY NICE WAY TO MAKE A LIVING
description: RED A Biography of Red Smith. By Ira Berkow. Illustrated. 302 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95. PEOPLE expect an awful lot from their newspapers, and the news isn't the half of it: they also expect the Last Word on practically everything. Thus the poor drudges who blunt their taste at bad plays night after night, and the drones who have to master two books a week - books of a kind that most people put aside a whole summer to read - are assumed to be the most important critics in town, while the hurry-up sages of the editorial pages may be the only voice some people will ever hear on the Middle East or the decline of the yen. (All the above, by the way, is supposed to be done entertainingly.) It's a lot to ask for 30 cents, but certain hardy souls devote their lives to bucking the odds and making newspapers just that good; and of these, none delivered the goods more consistently than Red Smith, the subject of Ira Berkow's skillful biography. Un-initiates might object right off that sportswriting is too slight and easy to count in the Sisyphus League, but it is easy only in whatever sense six-day bicycle racing is easy. The sports guy merely has to pump his way round and round the same old sports calendar ''making it new,'' in Ezra Pound's words, every time around. To do this, he is advised to maintain, or simulate, the fresh heart and clear eye of a rookie - not to mention the zest for motel rooms of a political candidate -until he drops.

title: Growing Old Gracefully
description: IN THE 1930'S, when the Barnhart family purchased this New Jersey property, there was no pond, and weeping cherry trees did not bloom by the pump house. ''It was a wreck of a place,'' says Mrs. Robert Barnhart. Besides renovating the main house, a clapboard structure that dates from around 1800, the Barnharts went to work creating a landscape that has romantic vistas at every turn.

title: Jane Danenberg Wed To Norman W. Alpert
description: Jane Sally Danenberg, a daughter of Mrs. Sol Shurkin of Baltimore and the late Isador Danenberg, was married yesterday to Norman Wasserstrom Alpert, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joel J. Alpert of Boston and East Parsonfield, Me. Rabbi James Bleiberg performed the ceremony at the Belvedere Hotel in Baltimore.

title: 2020 FORESIGHT
description: ''Prediction,'' says John F. Magee, chairman of Arthur D. Little, ''is not what we do best.'' But on the occasion of its centennial, the nation's oldest think tank - set among the oaks on a 40-acre campus in Cambridge, Mass. - has gone out on a limb. Herewith, the future as Little sees it:

title: Harlem Boys Choir Concert
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem will present a benefit concert of pop, jazz, classics and spirituals at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8 o'clock, with the Orchestra of St. Luke's.

title: IRANIAN DISSIDENT LEAVES FRANCE UNDER PRESSURE
description: An Iranian opposition leader left France under Government pressure today in a move apparently intended to improve French relations with Iran and speed the release of French hostages held in Lebanon.

title: STUDY URGES CHELSEA TO PLAN ITS OWN DEVELOPMENT
description: Residents of the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan were given a study yesterday that said the community would have to devise its own, local development plan to protect its diversity from intense real-estate pressures.

title: JERSEY CITY, IN BUDGET TROUBLE, TRYING TO KEEP MUSEUM OPEN
description: FOR THE second time since it was established in 1901, the Jersey City Museum may have to be closed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a producer's change of plans, a theater listing and a front-page picture caption today in The Guide, section 2A, give an outdated opening schedule for ''Lies My Father Told Me.'' The play, now in previews, will open June 18 at the Jewish Repertory Theater, 344 East 14th Street.

title: INKSTER FIRES 69 FOR 8-SHOT LEAD
description: Juli Inkster shot a 3-under-par 69 today and increased her lead to eight shots after the third round of the $450,000 L.P.G.A. McDonald's Championship at White Manor Country Club.

title: Pushkin at the Golden Gate
description: To the Editor:

title: IN JAPANESE BARS, CROONING'S THE RAGE
description: After a hard day at the Japanese Consulate, Seiichiro Ohtsuka, the Deputy Consul General, likes to relax at a bar with a few drinks - and a microphone and loudspeakers.

title: THE PILGRIMAGE OF GEORGE BERNANOS -- 'THE SUPREME GRACE WOULD BE TO LOVE OURSELVES'
description: AMONG French novelists of the 20th century, Georges Bernanos is one of the least known and appreciated by English-speaking readers. Even the relatively sophisticated ones who are likely to have read many of the novels or essays of Camus or Sartre or Gide and who may know Mauriac by reputation draw a blank on mention of Bernanos. In France and, indeed, throughout the Continent, it has been otherwise - Bernanos's novels and his social or political essays were widely appreciated during his lifetime (1888-1948), and they still command the strong interest of a literate public, especially that segment of it with religious and philosophical interests. As for his ''Diary of a Country Priest,'' it was a great success among both general readers and critics when it was published 50 years ago, and it has been, unquestionably, the Bernanos novel that has earned the most lasting interest of readers, no matter what their background or nationality.

title: AN ANNIVERSARY AND HISTORICAL EVENTS PROVIDE THE THEMES
description: The 350th anniversary of the settling of Rhode Island will be commemorated by the United States Postal Service on a 14-cent postal card to be issued June 26. The card will be released in Providence, R.I. at the statehouse.

title: THE CORPORATE WINE CELLAR
description: What we serve,'' says Felix G. Rohatyn, a senior partner with Lazard Freres, the investment bankers, ''is not the crown jewel of our escutcheon.'' Three floors down, on the 29th floor at 1 Rockefeller Plaza, Robert S. Pirie, C.E.O. of Rothschild Inc., another investment house, concurs: ''I've drunk Felix's wine, and he's right.''

title: A MASSACHUSETTS TOWN WHERE HISTORY PREVAILED
description: Sometimes a city derives its special charm from an event that in its day spelled disaster. So it is with Newburyport, Mass., a small city at the mouth of the Merrimack River, which flourished during the first half of the 19th century. In 1811 most of the downtown succumbed to fire. The town's leaders -shipbuilders, captains, enterprising merchants - saw to it that the area was speedily rebuilt. Brick replaced wood as the chosen material; the dignified, serene lines dear to the Federal era were selected for the commercial buildings clustered around the waterfront and Newburyport assumed the uniform, harmonious look that makes it so appealing today.

title: Susan Kelly Hagopian Plans to Wed Bronson Goddard 2d Next October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis T. Hagopian of Darien, Conn., and Jupiter, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Kelly Hagopian, to Bronson Goddard 2d, a son of Helen K. Goddard of Nonquit, Mass., and Richard M. Goddard Jr. of Madison, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: THIRD WORLD DEBT
description: To the Editor:

title: Gillian Jolis Is Married To Andrew Goldstein
description: Gillian Jolis, director of sales for Warner Audio Publishing, and Andrew E. Goldstein, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's father, Bernard Jolis, in Manhattan. Jacqueline W. Silbermann, acting justice of the New York State Supreme Court, New York County Criminal Division, officiated.

title: Verbatim; Unequal Access
description: 'I don't like to be told by some Hollywood producer that I don't have access to the President of the United States. I also don't think the President should give a medal that's invented by David Wolper.'

title: STUDY SEES UPSURGE IN NEW YORK STATE POPULATION
description: A detailed demographic portrait of New York State in the year 2000 predicts that a strong spurt of growth will reverse the population decline the state suffered in the 1970's.

title: PARAGUAY TIES MEXICO, 1-1
description: The whole game was in front of Hugo Sanchez, only 12 yards away, with only the goalkeeper to stop him. But Mexico's only world-level player was out-thought by Roberto Fernandez on a rare penalty kick in the closing minute today, as Paraguay salvaged a 1-1 tie in the World Cup with a goal in the 86th minute.

title:
GARDENING;
ALLIUMS: ORNAMENTAL AND EDIBLE
description: THE alliums are probably the most widely grown of all garden plants, and everyone, gardener and nongardener alike, is familiar with them, if not by their proper scientific names, then by their more common ones. This group of plants includes the onion, leek, garlic, shallot and chive.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SECRET TRAUMA: Incest In the Lives of Girls and Women. By Diana E. H. Russell. (Basic Books, $24.95.) Diana E. H. Russell, a professor of sociology at Mills College, has combined an empathetic understanding of the dynamics of incest with stringent scholarship to produce much-needed research on the pervasive and destructive effects of incest on women's lives.

title: COST OF AIDS CARE IS HALF WHAT WAS PROJECTED, ECONOMIST REPORTS
description: The per capita cost of providing hospital care to AIDS patients is roughly half that projected by Federal health officials, a leading health economist has reported.

title: First Amendment Comes to Cable
description: The Supreme Court has held for the first time that cable television operators enjoy some First Amendment protection, but neither the regulators nor the regulated can claim victory yet.

title: HOW MANAGERS SHOULD HANDLE THEIR ANGER
description: IT WAS AN ORDINARY MORNING WITH THE usual round of planning meetings and appointments until the young middle manager picked up the telephone and heard from his boss that the company had, in effect, disappeared. In a Kafkaesque scenario that is becoming commonplace in corporate America, the firm had been absorbed by a huge conglomerate.

title: EXECUTIVE FACES INQUIRIES ON CITY SEWER CONTRACT
description: Federal and city agencies are investigating whether a politically connected business executive paid kickbacks to help him obtain a $53.6 million contract to build a sewer plant in Brooklyn, according to law-enforcement officials.

title: ALTERING OF LABOR PACTS RESTRICTED IN BANKRUPTCIES
description: A Federal appeals court in Philadelphia has ruled that a bankruptcy judge improperly allowed the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, which reported financial distress, to dissolve its contract in 1985 with the United Steelworkers of America.

title: JAZZ: ALDEN-BARRETT FIVE
description: WHEN jazz of the 1930's and 40's is played live by contemporary groups, it is usually done by big bands that copy old swing-band arrangements or play in a similar manner. But there were also a lot of small groups in those days. The music of two of them, the John Kirby Sextet and the Red Norvo Trio, serves as an inspiration and starting point for an unusual new group, the Howard Alden-Dan Barrett Quintet, which played a twilight concert on Thursday afternoon in the lobby of the Olympic Tower, Fifth Avenue at 51st Street.

title: U.S.F.L. Owners' Merger Strategy in '84 Revealed
description: In the nine months before the United States Football League filed an antitrust lawsuit against the National Football League, owners in the U.S.F.L. discussed and formulated strategies designed to achieve a merger with the N.F.L., court records show.

title: ON THE PHENOMENON THAT WAS THE VIETNAM ERA
description: To Kenneth J. Wittwer, a 24-year-old college senior from California and the son of a Vietnam veteran, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial here, its below-ground wall of black granite slabs engraved with the names of more then 58,000 American war dead or missing, seemed ''like a dam, holding within it a reservoir of souls, emotion and knowledge.''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 3 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 3 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 3 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Brewers vs. Boston Red Sox, at Milwaukee (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Padres vs. Atlanta Braves, at San Diego (Television - WTBS, 4:05 P.M.) N.C.A.A. Division I College World Series, at Omaha. (Television -ESPN, 8 P.M.) Basketball Celtics vs. Houston Rockets, at Boston. A Celtic victory would earn Boston its 16th title. A loss would foce a seventh game Wednesday night. (Television -Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Stroh's Rucker Professional League, doubleheader, at the Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, West 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, 3:30 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. Boxing Shawn O'Sullivan vs. Simon Brown, at Toronto, welterweights, 10 rounds. O'Sullivan, the Canadian Olympian silver medalist who dropped a controversial decision to Frank Tate for the gold in 1984, is 11-0 with 8 knockouts as a professional. Brown, from Jamaica, West Indies, is 22-1 with 16 knockouts. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M.) Golf Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, at Westchester Country Club, Harrison, N.Y., final round, 8 A.M. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M.) L.P.G.A. McDonald's Championship, at Malvern, Pa., final round. (Television - USA Network, 4 P.M.) Running Westchester Half-Marathon (13.1 miles) at White Plains, 9 A.M. Paulding Street at Maple Avenue. The finish line is at Iona College in New Rochelle.

title: THE SUMMER FORECAST IS FOR EVEN LESS OF THE SAME
description: Conventional wisdom has it that television viewers long ago accepted the limitations of the medium and have moderated their expectations accordingly. My own experience is that viewers, even of the more ''sophisticated,'' upscale variety, are almost childishly irrational in their demands to be entertained several hours a night, seven days a week. Recently, I was personally taken to task by several friends and acquaintances who were incensed one Sunday evening when they discovered that ''Murder, She Wrote'' had been pre-empted on CBS for a special. Making matters worse, public television's Masterpiece Theater was bogged down in a dreary mini-series about civil war in 17th-century England. ''There was absolutely nothing to watch,'' cried the scorned viewers, darkly implying that I should somehow correct the situation. In fact, it has long seemed to me that television's ability to turn out a nonstop, multi-channel flow of programming is little short of astounding. And regularly finding islands of quality in that morass borders on the miraculous.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: RANDOLPH GUGGENHEIMER knows that some wives wake up and greet their husbands with ''Good morning, darling'' or ''Good morning, dear,'' or even a simple ''Good morning.'' He does not, however, know this first hand. His wife, Elinor, greets him each morning with a slightly different phrase. No matter how it's worded, it always boils down to the fact that the minute she opens her eyes she remembers that there is something she hasn't remembered.

title: LONG-RANGE STATE PLAN OUTLINES SOCIAL SERVICE GOALS
description: THE state is holding hearings this month on revisions to its long-range plan for the development of Connecticut, which for the first time outlined goals for social services.

title: IN A DANCER'S WORLD, THE INEXORABLE FOE IS TIME
description: All dancers wage a losing battle against gravity and time, their bodies the instruments of betrayal in a world obsessed with youth and fairytale illusion. Airborne grace and quicksilver technique come of daunting offstage labor and a singular passion for physical perfection. With the years, the dancer's artistry gains nuance and depth, yet, paradoxically, speed, power and flexibility begin to wane.

title: Travels With Jackson
description: While many Presidential hopefuls tend to avoid choosing sides in primary battles - whichever choice they make is bound to lose them some friends - the Rev. Jesse Jackson has kept up a heavy campaign schedule in recent weeks around the nation.

title: BRIGHT FLOWERS ATTRACT WINGED VISITORS
description: A close encounter with a hummingbird is not to be forgotten. My first eye-to-eye contact occurred shortly after trading the city's asphalt for a home and backyard in the suburbs.

title: JOHN P. CARMICHAEL
description: John P. Carmichael, whose sportswriting for nearly 40 years at The Chicago Daily News earned him induction into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1975, died Friday.

title:
DINING OUT;
A VIEW FROM THE RIVER'S EDGE
description: AS the approaching warm weather invites lingering out of doors, we can think of few more felicitous county spots at which to while away the long summer evenings than the deck of The Chart House, perched on a tiny spit of land at the Hudson River's edge. If one insists upon dining during peak hours, the wait for tables can sometimes run to an hour and a half. However, judging by the number of cheerful patrons watching the sunset from deck chairs, it's easy not to mind the wait. Making it even easier, a recently installed oyster bar yields clams and oysters, and these together with a number of new appetizers help to assuage the proverbial appetite that dining near the water stirs.

title: GARNER'S DOUBLE LIFTS ASTROS
description: Phil Garner hit a two-run double with the bases loaded in the eighth inning today, lifting the Houston Astros to a 7-5 victory over the Dodgers.

title: 100,000 Pakistanis Greet Bhutto in Hometown
description: The opposition leader Benazir Bhutto told a crowd of 100,000 people today to be ready to exert pressure to ease out President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq and have fresh elections by next fall. She spoke at rally marking her first visit to her hometown in southern Sind Province since she ended a European exile in April.

title: Philadelphia Road Delayed
description: Construction on a crucial 3.5 miles of the Schuylkill Expressway from Vine Street to Roosevelt Boulevard is three weeks behind schedule, prompting state officials to worry that the work may not be completed by the deadline, Oct. 27. Each day before the reconstruction about 86,000 cars used the Vine Street interchange, the primary exit for downtown Philadelphia, said Lois Morasco, a spokesman for the State Department of Transportation.

title: STATE SENATE KILLS BILL ON CAMERAS IN COURTROOMS
description: The State Senate narrowly defeated legislation this week to allow cameras in New York trial courts, delaying until next year any further action on the measure.

title: MAKING MORRIS THE CAT DO DOUBLE DUTY
description: SINCE January, Martin J. Friedman, the editor of DFS Dorland New Product News, has counted more than 1,048 new products on supermarket shelves around the country. The 263 total for May, Mr. Friedman said, was the highest monthly total in the 22 years he has edited the newsletter.

title: Court Reinstates Sentence Of Man Condemned to Death
description: A Federal appeals court today reinstated the scheduled execution Monday of Rudy Ramos Esquivel, sentenced to die for killing an undercover narcotics officer in Houston.

title: AN ECONOMY STRUGGLES TO BREAK ITS FALL
description: ELIAS ALVAREZ, a 46-year-old accountant from the Gulf Coast state of Tamaulipas, is taking off the entire month of June to attend the World Soccer Cup here. During half-time, while delightedly watching Mexico defeat Belgium, Mr. Alvarez confessed that he had come without his employer's permission. ''This is the World Cup,'' he shouted above the din in the stadium. ''I can always find another job.''

title: Putting the I.R.S. On the Case
description: THE Senate also passed amendments designed to crack down on those who are delinquent in repaying student loans. One provision would allow the Government to sell the defaulted loans to collection agencies. Another would require the Government to partially garnishee the wages of Federal employees who have unpaid loans. ''We could increase the loan program by over 30 percent every year if we could recoup the money in default,'' said Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who introduced the amendments.

title: Who Wants To Teach?
description: Although it would appear that Mr. Taylor's intention is to show that teaching is a viable career choice for intelligent young people, his purpose is undermined by the very situations he describes: the conversations with the cooperating teacher who suggests to Mary Jo that ''there's always a chance [ the class ] might learn something'' if she's flexible and that low quiz grades can be neatly replaced by having students ''summarize a science-related article''; the realization that rather than ''generating interest,'' she may be reduced, at exam time, to the desperate task of trying to ''force learning'' on her students.

title: Malaysian Crisis Ends In State of Sabah
description: A yearlong political crisis in the Malaysian state of Sabah was resolved this week when the state's ruling party was made part of a national coalition.

title: HOWE'S 'PAINTING CHURCHES' IN HARTMAN PRODUCTION
description: AS the curtain falls on Tina Howe's ''Painting Churches'' at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Fanny and Gardner Church, an elderly couple, begin a life-affirming waltz. At that transcendent moment, one is confident that ''Painting Churches'' will survive, for the playwright's lyric and literate words and genuine feeling have peered through a pedestrian production. This is a tribute to Miss Howe, but not to the Hartman.

title: New York Area Alerted to Home-Improvement Fraud
description: HOMEOWNERS in the New York metropolitan region are being advised by consumer-protection agencies to be on the alert for a new outbreak of home-improvement fraud.

title: 3 TOWNS OPPOSE BUILDING OF SHOPPING MALL IN ORANGE
description: ENCOURAGED by the blocking of a proposed shopping mall in the area last year, officials in New Haven and two suburbs and the owner of an existing mall are hoping to stop the construction of another shopping center project.

title: NEW CASSETTES: ALEC GUINNESS AND GUY LOMBARDO
description: The Big Bands: Guy Lombardo and His Royal Canadians. Produced and directed by Herb Sussan, Kartes Video Communications, 54 minutes. $19.95.

title: HARDHEARTED MARGARET
description: EXPENSIVE HABITS By Maureen Howard. 298 pp. New York: Summit Books. $17.95. IN ''Facts of Life'' (1978), Maureen Howard told the story of her childhood and self-education in Bridgeport, Conn., among Irish-American Catholics. Now, her fifth novel opens with an echo of the blunt priestly send-off from a confessional: ''Go and sin no more.'' The second word of this novel's title resonates with the word for a nun's outfit, but ''habits'' spreads a wider net than costume can define.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is a gross distortion about crack, that it is just a teen-age problem and that it is a problem of the poor.

title: BUGS IN THE BELFRY
description: From Wednesday through Friday the Old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow, which had its 300th birthday last year, will be sealed inside a plastic tent while the Orkin man releases quantities of a fumigating gas called Ficam, to rid the building of powder post beetles. It is the first step in a major restoration project, the details of which will be determined by what can be salvaged after the beetles are gone.

title: THE SURGEON AS PROFIT CENTER
description: For two and a half hours, Dr. Bruce P. Mindich has been more or less glued to the same spot in an operating room at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan, sewing minute stitches on the surface of the heart before him. When he is done, he spins a clamp in his right hand like a six-shooter, then heads for the door.

title: 'ALTERNATE' TEACHING ASSAILED OVER ERROR OF $400
description: FRESH out of Swarthmore College, 24-year-old David H. Malone was hired to teach 10th-grade biology at East Orange High School last fall. His supervisors say that his work is outstanding.

title: THE RAPTURE AND THE BOMB
description: BLESSED ASSURANCE At Home With the Bomb in Amarillo, Texas. By A. G. Mojtabai. 255 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95. ''Y

title: Jamie Lehrer Has Wedding
description: Jamie Kendall Lehrer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Lehrer of Washington, and John Kennedy O'Brien, a son of Col. John O'Brien, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. O'Brien of Louisville, were married yesterday at the Sheraton-Carlton Hotel in Washington. The Rev. Fred Lehrer, a Baptist minister who is the bride's uncle, officiated.

title: ENERGY-AID CUTS FOR NEEDY ASSAILED
description: NEEDY families in New Jersey and 26 other states are being unfairly penalized under Federal guidelines for distributing energy funds, according to Representative Matthew J. Rinaldo.

title: Jacqueline Gelles Weds
description: Jacqueline Danielle Gelles, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Gelles of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dean Kent Cutler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin G. Cutler of Scarsdale. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. officiated at the Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
PLAY BRINGS POLLOCK BACK TO LIFE
description: IN THE last five months, William Mesnik has been Jackson Pollock in public about two dozen times.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: YOU CAN GO HOME AGAIN
description: POOR Geraldine Page's character in ''The Trip to Bountiful'': She yearned to go home, and when she got there it was all gone. For me, the opposite was true.

title: AIRLINES FORECASTING A RECORD FOR SUMMER TRAVEL
description: The nation's airlines are forecasting record travel this summer, with an increase on domestic routes more than compensating for what terrorism and the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl have done to discourage trips abroad.

title: Quake in Soviet Turkmenia
description: An earth tremor shook the towns of Nebit-Dag and Krasnovodsk in western Turkmenia in Central Asia today without causing injuries or damage, the press agency Tass reported. The epicenter was 25 miles north of Nebit-Dag, and the tremor measured 4 to 5 points on the Soviet 10-point scale.

title: Miss Bunij Weds K.G. Langone Jr. In Tucson Church
description: Karen Leilani Bunij and Kenneth G. Langone Jr. were married yesterday at the Newman Roman Catholic Church of the University of Arizona in Tucson. The Rev. John Borley performed the ceremony.

title: Soviet Launches 8 Satellites
description: The Soviet Union launched eight satellites with one booster rocket on Friday, Tass, the official Soviet Government press agency, reported. It was at least the second time the Soviet Union has launched multiple satellites since March 1985, when eight satellites were launched with one booster rocket.

title: U.S. AID TO L.I. TO FAIL
description: FEDERAL community development funds for Long Island's cities, towns and villages will be slashed by almost one-third next year, according to the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: A Modest Start
description: LAN Associates is dreaming big. And starting small.

title: INTRICATE JULY 4 SECURITY PLANS WILL COVER LAND, SEA AND AIR
description: Police and Navy helicopters with video cameras will search New York Harbor and the streets of lower Manhattan for signs of danger. Dozens of Coast Guard boats, equipped with fire hoses, machine guns and M-16 rifles, will patrol the bay.

title: SUMMER PROGRAMS FOR GIFTED STUDENTS
description: FOR 342 New Jersey junior high school students, summer will mean not an escape from classrooms, but - quite the contrary - entering a world of sophisticated intellectual challenges.

title: A PIANIST MAKES BACH HIS INSTRUMENT
description: ''THERE'S this strange notion that Bach didn't compose for the piano,'' the pianist Charles Rosen said, ''and it refuses to die out.''

title: SHARING A HOME WITH FERRETS
description: ANYONE seeking a definition of cute need go no farther than Debra Longo's living room. There, four little creatures tumble and cavort, greet visitors with curious nose nudges, chase each other madly, then suddenly curl up in a sleepy huddle. The animals are ferrets and have alert, pointy faces, bright eyes and furry coats.

title:
DEBT OUT OF HAND;
DEVISING A BANKRUPTCY PLAN FOR MEXICO
description: WITH its economy on the edge of collapse, and in virtual default on its foreign debt, Mexico is in desperate need of major political and economic reforms. Stop-gap efforts, such as emergency infusions of capital, will only reinforce the vicious cycle of debt-expansion and harsh austerity measures. But to work, a rescue plan must be comprehensive and involve all the major parties - Mexico, the United States, commercial banks and the major international financial agencies.

title: HOT MARCH WEATHER REDUCES NORTHEAST MAPLE SYRUP CROP
description: Good weather in the first days of spring put an early end to the maple syrup season this year for producers in the Northeast, who supply more than two-thirds of the syrup in the United States.

title: LUSH KASHMIR FEELS A POLITICAL CHILL
description: The coldest winter in two decades has at last receded from the lakes and lush green gardens of the Kashmir Valley. But spring has also brought a season of recrimination, tension and political instability.

title: Cracking Down on Computer Fraud
description: Local law officers sometimes complain that the absence of broad Federal restrictions makes pulling the plug on computer crime more difficult. Now Capitol Hill has begun zeroing in on errant hackers; the House last week passed a bill that makes the use of computers for certain types of fraud or theft a Federal felony.

title: ARTS AIDE REFLECTS ON A TOUR OF CHINA
description: CHINA today is still an enigma, but the key to the mystery can be summed up in two words: China Reconstructs.

title: Reagan Nominee Is Voted Down
description: Nearly six months after it began deliberations, the Senate Judiciary Committee rejected last week the nomination of Jefferson B. Sessions 3d to be a Federal judge in Alabama. The vote against Mr. Sessions, who had been accused of making a number of racially insensitive statements, marked the first time the panel turned down a judicial nomination of President Reagan.

title: YONKERS CAMPAIGN URGES PARENTS TO PICK A MAGNET SCHOOL
description: IN the wake of a Federal Court desegregation order, the Yonkers School District has begun an unprecedented campaign to encourage enrollment in enriched academic programs known as ''magnets.''

title: MORE FOSTER CARE FOR OLDER CHILDREN UPHELD
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has affirmed an injunction issued last year requiring city officials to expand programs that prepare older children in foster care to live independently after they reach the age of 18.

title: CRACK ADDICTION SPREADS AMONG THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: The junior executive first heard of crack last January, from a colleague.

title: Slaying in Greenwich Village
description: A New Jersey gun dealer was found shot to death in Greenwich Village yesterday, a police spokesman said. The body was found in a mini-van parked at 162 Perry Street in the West Village, the spokesman, Sgt. John Venetucci, said. The 60-year-old man, whose identity was withheld pending notification of relatives, had a gunshot wound to the forehead.

title: SIGNIFICANT VOTE LOOMS FOR MEXICO
description: What could be the sharpest electoral challenge to the 57-year dominance of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party is developing in state election campaigns here.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
TRENTON WEIGHS PLANS FOR A CIVIC CENTER
description: FOR decades, the economic question in Trenton seemed to be, ''Which is the quickest way out of town?'' But now things seem to be swinging Trenton's way.

title: THE RISKS OF REPORTING
description: SUING THE PRESS By Rodney A. Smolla. 277 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $18.95. CHARLES HORMAN, a young American writer, was in Chile in 1973 when a military coup overthrew Salvador Allende's Government. Two days later he disappeared. His father came to look for him - and became convinced that the American Embassy was obstructing the search, perhaps because his son had learned something about a United States role in the coup. Charles Horman's body was later found in a cemetery in Santiago.

title: WITH SHAWM AND PIANOFORTE, A FESTIVAL OF EARLY MUSIC
description: FLUTE music written by Frederick the Great and the first performance in modern times of an 18th-century harpischord concerto will be among the offerings of the Connecticut Early Music Festival this month.

title: JAZZ: BRACKEEN ON PIANO
description: JOANNE BRACKEEN'S forceful and virtuosic piano playing has recently gone through a slight change of emphasis. At the urging of Bradley Cunningham, the owner of Bradley's, 70 University Place near 10th Street, where she ended a brief engagement last night, Miss Brackeen had been putting an increasing number of pop standards into her repertory.

title: CHICKEN SALAD MANIFESTS ITSELF IN MANY WAYS
description: THE possibilities for creating chicken salad seem almost infinite. That's a good thing, too, because it is nearly impossible to have too many of them in the summer repertory.

title: The New York Stance
description: To the Editor:

title: Haiti's Chief Sets Date for Election
description: Haiti's new Government, beset by its most serious crisis, moved to regain control of the situation. As a wave of anti-Government protests continued in the capital, Port-au-Prince, and outlying towns, Gen. Henri Namphy, President of the three-member council that took charge four months ago after the fall of Jean-Claude Duvalier, went on national television to announce that Presidential elections would be held within 17 months. the announcement followed an earlier television appearance by General Namphy in which he warned that the country was on ''the edge of anarchy'' and civil war.

title: ARTIST AND MODEL: WHY THE TRADITION ENDURES
description: Last month the sculptor Anthony Caro, renowned since the late 1950's for his abstract structures of painted and welded steel, surprised his New York audience with a new body of work - a group of small, figurative bronzes done from a female model. In 1983, teaching at a summer workshop he runs in upstate New York, he spent evenings drawing from a professional model ''for fun.'' So enjoyable did he find the process that the following year he took to sculpturing the model, Concetta Branson, in clay. Next came the translation into bronze. ''I had not modeled from the figure since the academic exercises of my student days,'' he noted, ''and I have no doubt it will come to feed the mainstream of my work.''

title: CHIEF IN SAN JOSE BATTLES GUN LOBBY
description: Joseph D. McNamara, Chief of Police in this hub of high technology, is at war again, this time with the National Rifle Association.

title: 15 Years of Arms Control Demolished
description: President Reagan's decision to abandon the second strategic arms limitation accord will, unless reversed, severely harm United States security interests. At present, the SALT limits are the only existing agreed constraints on strategic weapons. Without them, we will face the dangers of a totally unrestricted nuclear arms race.

title: NEW YORK CITY OFFICIALS CITE 36 FOOD OUTLETS FOR VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 36 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: NEW COAST GUARD CHIEF PREPARES FOR ONSLAUGHT
description: The new Coast Guard commander of New York's waterways has taken up his post just in time to oversee what he says will be the largest massing of Coast Guard and auxiliary vessels for a single event since World War II - Liberty Weekend.

title: Casey Burke Married To R. Howard Romero
description: Dorothy Raegener Burke, an advertising copywriter, and R. Howard Romero, an architectural designer, were married yesterday at their home in Johnson, Vt., by Jack Anderson, a justice of the peace from Hyde Park, Vt.

title: TIACOH WINS 400, SETS MEET RECORD
description: Gabriel Tiacoh, a 23-year-old graduate student at Washington State, said before his race tonight that he wanted only to win, not necessarily to run fast. As it turned out, he did both in taking the 400-meter title as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's outdoor track and field championships ended.

title:
ART;
THE SOUND OF ART, OR VICE VERSA, AT THE THORPE INTERMEDIA
description: LIVING up to its rather high-tech-sounding name, the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery is presenting a show of sound art. In true mixed-media fashion, however, visuals are not left entirely behind.

title: ASSEMBLYMAN'S VIEWS ON INSURANCE FAULTED
description: In a March 30 Opinion Page article on automobile insurance, Assemblyman Thomas J. Deverin, Democrat of the 20th District, claimed that too many questions remained about the verbal threshold and that, as a result, the current insurance reform measure should be stalled by the State Senate.

title: ON ARMS CONTROL, EUROPE WOULD PREFER TO SPEAK FOR ITSELF
description: FEW would question that Margaret Thatcher has earned the right to be called Ronald Reagan's best friend in Europe. But every time that accolade is extended by an overeager Washington proconsul, she slips a little further in British opinion polls. Last week, she disagreed with the President openly on a major issue for the first time since the 1983 Grenada invasion, but neither London nor Washington appeared to listen.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE ''UNCENSORED WAR'': The Media and Vietnam. By Daniel C. Hallin. (Oxford University, $22.50.) Did an adversarial news media make it impossible for the American Government to win the war in Vietnam? Not really, says Daniel C. Hallin, an assistant professor of political science at the University of California, San Diego. He writes that ''what began to change in 1967 . . . was the conviction that the forces of good would inevitably prevail.'' Skepticism in the news media ran apace with skepticism within Government and was limited to technical matters - whether this program was actually working or that hill was worth taking - rather than addressing fundamental questions of American interests and Vietnamese society. Mr. Hallin looks closely at The New York Times (and occasionally at other papers) from 1961 to mid-1965, the years of increasing involvement, then turns his attention to network television. He writes that in The New York Times ''the lead stories focused on the public statements of top officials and were written 'straight,' as though the reporters knew nothing of the information printed inside the paper,'' that is, long after columnists on the editorial page had begun doubting the war. Mr. Hallin suggests that, in the end, President Nixon's Vietnamization program enjoyed the kind of support that winning the war had once received under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson and that ''the administration not only succeeded in putting Vietnamization on the news agenda, but was able to produce a favorable balance of coverage of the South Vietnamese army.''

title:
INVESTING;
A NOT-SO-DULL CELANESE AMAZES WALL ST.
description: TWO years ago, few would have thought that the stock of a rather dull chemical company would become a market standout. But that is just what Celanese, one of the world's largest producers of man-made fibers, has done - and it continues to amaze Wall Street. Trading as low as $70 a share in 1984, it has surged as high as $235 this year; last week, it was at $229.

title: INVESTMENT BANKING'S DIRTY LITTLE SECRET
description: LATELY, investment banks have been rushing into one of the most ethically dubious corners of the financial world - the issuance of so-called ''fairness letters.'' These documents are a deceit upon the investing public and upon the marketplace generally, and certainly unworthy of institutions with serious national responsibilities and trust.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JUNE 8, 1986
description: International The Soviet Union has resumed arms shipments to Nicaragua, President Reagan will charge this week in a campaign to try to win Congressional approval for new aid for Nicaraguan insurgents. White House officials said that intelligence sources had information showing that a Soviet freighter delivered a large cache of military supplies to Managua in early May. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Austrians will vote for a president today with opinion polls unanimously predicting that Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General of the United Nations, will be elected. His Socialist opponent, Kurt Steyrer, said he regretted that Austria's image had been damaged by allegations about Mr. Waldheim's implication in war crimes in Greece and Yugoslavia during World War II. [ 16:1-3. ] An influential Catholic Jesuit journal, in a commentary officials said reflected Vatican thought, called the acquittal of six people charged with conspiring to kill Pope John Paul II a ''disconcerting sentence.'' The journal, La Civilta Cattolica, added that it appeared the attack was the result of ''an international plot.'' [ 9:1-3. ] An exiled Iranian left France under Government pressure in a move apparently intended to improve France's relations with Iran and speed the release of French hostages held in Lebanon. France said the Iranian opposition leader, Massoud Rajavi, had left voluntarily and had not been expelled. [ 22:1-3. ] National Critics say NASA's shuttle report omits a number of important criticisms among the conclusions it draws. Members of the Presidential space shuttle commission and outside experts say the report is missing recommendations on the composition of the crews of future flights and the preparation time the agency should take between launchings.

title: The Reagan Letters
description: President Reagan is trying to get back to a ''Ron-Brian'' relationship with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada after the recent trade tiff over Canadian building materials.

title: Waiting for Menotti
description: A 65-year-old woman wrote from Vienna that she had ''an indescribable wish'' that could be fulfilled only in Washington. A woman in Canada wrote that Washington was where she wanted to cope with the angst of her 30th birthday.

title: John B. Foley Is Wed To Christina Rikhoff
description: Christina Anne Rikhoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Rikhoff of High Bridge, N.J., was married yesterday to John Brian Foley, a son of Bonnie Foley of Chicago and John J. Foley of New York. The ceremony was performed at the Clinton (N.J.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. James Barber.

title: YANKS LOSE AGAIN; DEFENSE LACKING
description: The final score was no consolation, certainly not for Bobby Meacham. Making it close only focused more attention on the error of his ways. Meacham has become accustomed to the scrutiny he receives for his play in the field, but recently every mistake has been magnified, every bobble further evidence of why he sometimes feels he is the Yankees stopgap, not shortstop.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: ATLANTA;
Water's Edge In Central Park
description: IN Atlanta's bustling north central suburb, where luxury office space is outgrowing demand, developers are always looking for any angle that might give them a competitive edge. The developers of 60-acre Central Park, an office-hotel complex rising among a half-dozen similar projects, are touting lakes fed by artesian wells rather than the runoff water that fills the retention ponds typically found in such projects.

title: FRIENDSHIP DOESN'T ALWAYS DETER ESPIONAGE
description: IN a sense, good diplomats are good spies, even when posted to friendly countries. If they are doing their jobs, they ferret out confidential information that would be of value back home. Sometimes the focus is super-secret intelligence about defense or politics - but not always. The home government might have a keen interest in, say, classified details of a large agricultural deal or strategy in upcoming trade talks.

title: NEW YORK READIES JULY 4 CAMPSITES
description: Using the shell of the old Billy Rose Aquacade as command post, the city's Parks and Recreation Department is preparing for the arrival of up to 5,000 campers who may stay at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park over Liberty Weekend.

title: THREE-WAY TIE FOR LEAD AT WESTCHESTER CLASSIC
description: Mike Reid has come close but never won in nine and a half years on the PGA Tour. Today he put himself in contention for that elusive top prize when he birdied the final hole to move into a three-way tie for the lead after three rounds of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic.

title: SUBURBANITE, WON'T YOU SPARE THAT TREE?
description: I AM proud to report that I have earned the reputation of being the neighborhood crank, and it is a well-earned title.

title: ZIMBABWE'S FERTILE FIELDS
description: MAREVA GURAJENA, a stocky bearded man wearing a beige baseball cap, peeled the husk from a thin ear of corn and muttered. At his side, Jeff Chirisa bent down and shook his head. ''The plants are too close together,'' said Mr. Chirisa, spreading his fingers between two stalks. ''And the rows are too close together.''

title: CLASS OF '86 ADDS VIDEOTAPE TO THE MEMENTOS OF SCHOOL DAYS
description: YEARS from now, when they gather to reminisce about the good old days of 1986, the former students of Staples High School in Westport can recapture their youth with the flick of a switch.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CLASSROOMS AWEIGH -LEONARD J. FROSINA, a teacher at Shoreham-Wading River High School, doesn't like to go out in the sunshine on his days off. ''I'm looking for shade on Saturday and Sunday,'' he said recently.

title: AT RALLY IN BRONX, HUNDREDS CLAMOR FOR AID IN DRUG FIGHT
description: Chanting ''Crack can kill,'' several hundred residents of the Bronx gathered in a rally at the Grand Concourse and Fordham Road yesterday, calling for more help from the police and city officials to rid their streets, parks and schools of drug pushers.

title: WINNING THE U.S. OPEN IN THE BATTLEFIELD OF THE MIND
description: WINNING the United States Open is one of the dreams of every person who strives for greatness in golf. Winning a United States Open at a championship course such as Shinnecock Hills is a childhood fantasy come alive.

title: CASUALTIES OF A 'PURE WAR'
description: COLLECTED WRITINGS By John Cornford. Edited by Jonathan Galassi. 203 pp. New York: Carcanet. Paper, $10.50. AMERICAN COMMANDER IN SPAIN Robert Hale Merriman and the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. By Marion Merriman and Warren Lerude. Illustrated. 255 pp. Reno: University of Nevada Press. $16.95. THIS year marks the 50th anniversary of the start of the Spanish Civil War. Franco has been dead for a decade, Spain is a democracy once again, and as the passions of that time gradually ease, these two books are fitting commemoratives for the internationalists who went to the defense of the republic. One is ''Collected Writings'' by John Cornford, the English poet who was killed in 1936, leaving behind a truncated oeuvre, some political exhortations and a handful of letters from the Aragon front. The second, ''American Commander in Spain,'' is a personal recollection by his wife of Robert Hale Merriman, a young teacher at the University of California, Berkeley, who became chief of staff of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion and died in the retreat from Belchite in 1938. (As Mrs. Merriman notes, the organization was a battalion and only much later became popularly known as the Abraham Lincoln Brigade.) The charismatic Merriman may have been Hemingway's inspiration for Robert Jordan in ''For Whom the Bell Tolls.'' The two men met briefly in Madrid, and Hemingway was deeply impressed.

title: Assessing the Final Verdict on The Challenger
description: Although the final report on the Challenger disaster will not be formally presented to President Reagan until tomorrow afternoon, it is already getting mixed reviews.

title: English Earl's Home Is Empty This Year
description: An English earl who depends on tourism to maintain his 300-year-old mansion has said that a decline in the number of American visitors, largely caused by fears over terrorism, has cost him $150,000 in lost revenue.

title: HOSPITAL BEDS: 'MOTHBALL' THE EXCESS
description: I read with great interest ''Hospital Beds: The New Math'' [ May 4 ] . The presentation was thorough, but I would like to add a new dimension in thinking on this very vital subject.

title: BANKS LOWERING CREDIT CARD RATES
description: CONSUMERS here would save almost $17 million a year under a bill that would restrict the amount of interest that can be charged on credit card balances.

title: JESUIT JOURNAL FAULTS VERDICT ON POPE ATTACK
description: An influential Jesuit journal, in a commentary that officials here said reflected official Vatican thinking, today called the acquittal of six people charged with conspiring to kill Pope John Paul II a ''disconcerting sentence.''

title: LEARNING LESSONS OF THE LAND AND SEA
description: ''DO I hear evidence of a stream nearby?'' asked Tyrone Coles, a 12-year-old seventh grader from Bridgeport, as he hiked through Webb Mountain Park in Monroe on a recent Saturday morning.

title: SOGGY CREW RACES SWEPT BY HARVARD
description: Harvard turned the foulest weather into the fairest of victories today, sweeping all three crew races from its archrival Yale in the 121st rowing of America's oldest intercollegiate sporting event.

title: 15 Blacks Die in Unrest Across South Africa
description: Fifteen more blacks were reported today to have been killed in political turmoil sweeping South Africa, amid growing signs that the Government will take tough new steps to crack down on the unrest.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Making a Call From Metroliner - WITH just the slide of a credit card, busy travelers between New York and Washington can call the limo to meet them at the station, or the pizza parlor to deliver piping hot pepperoni for the precise time they will arrive home. If they are riding a Metroliner, that is.

title: Pushkin at the Golden Gate
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THAT fine spring morning, it was as if the old maple in front of the house had decided to drop all its winged seedlings at once, on my car. And I had just had the car washed.

title: A CAPITALIST OF A VERY DIFFERENT CUT
description: ''FORBES said we are one of the 200 best-managed companies in the United States,'' said Franklin G. (Jerry) Bishop of Rockville Centre. ''That's not too bad for an old socialist.''

title: State Dept. Is Said to Block Briefings for Allies on Arms
description: A Pentagon official accused the State Department on Friday of blocking briefings for allied foreign ministers on reported Soviet violations of arms control agreements and on the United States policy on nuclear testing.

title: INTERFACING WITH BIZ SPEAK
description: THERE WAS A TIME WHEN only the bureaucrats and the sociologists seemed determined to murder the English language. Now, assassination squads are all over the place - and the business person is the new point man. He and his minions have triggered an avalanche of jargon, a blizzard of buzzwords burying thought. And, what's worse, these abominations are making their way into common parlance. Just the other day I heard a woman, referring to her second marriage, announce that she had ''traded up.''

title: Deedy Henning Marries Walton Clark
description: Eleanor Ruth Henning, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Valentine Henning of Glen Cove, L.I., and Walton Vincent Clark, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Devlin Clark of Winston-Salem, N.C., were married yesterday in the Garden City (L.I.) Community Church. The Rev. Ralph A. Ahlberg, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

title: ONE DEATH INSPIRES $15 MILLION CANCER FIGHT
description: T.J. Martell had just tackled his first year of college and was spending the summer of 1973 at home in Madison, N.J., pursuing his two favorite activities - golf and playing the drums.

title: House Votes to Rehab, Not Build
description: A growing belief in Congress that the billions of dollars Washington has spent on public housing has failed to provide decent homes for the poor expressed itself last week in a vote by the House of Representatives to redirect the program to the rehabilitation of existing units rather than the construction of new ones.

title: DANZIG CONNECTION WINS THE BELMONT FOR STEPHENS
description: The railbirds began chanting ''Woody! Woody! Woody!'' in midstretch, as Danzig Connection pulled away to win the 118th Belmont Stakes yesterday and provide his trainer, Woody Stephens, with his fifth straight and most improbable winner of the final leg of the Triple Crown.

title: William J. Riley Wed To Susan Marie Banks
description: Susan Marie Banks, an assistant vice president of European American Bank in New York, and William James Riley, a financial consultant with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York, were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Who Wants To Teach?
description: The story of Mary Jo Knipper reminded me of all the reasons why I, too, was drawn to the profession of teaching.

title: On Stage, on Impulse
description: A farewell tribute to Sir Oliver Wright, the British Ambassador who is returning to England after four years in Washington, was recently held at the Arena Stage before a performance of Shakespeare's ''Taming of the Shrew.'' The tribute was organized by the Arena and by the Congressional Arts Cau-cus, and the affinity between actors and politicians seemed clearer than ever before. Speaking from the stage for his Congressional colleagues, Representative Jim Wright, the Democratic leader, said, ''There exists within us an impulse to perform.''

title: AS STRIPED BASS RUN UP HUDSON THE PACE QUICKENS AT HATCHERY
description: HAULING in a 500-foot seine, four men fished the muddy waters of the Hudson River in Westchester's Haverstraw Bay. They were out to capture striped bass, but they weren't fishermen. They were aquatic biologists collecting spawning fish. Back at the Striped Bass Hatchery in Verplanck, after the fish eggs were fertilized, 18 million larval fish emerged. In late summer, when the fish are three inches long, they will be released in the Hudson River.

title: IN AUSTRIA, SILENCE LOUDER THAN OOM-PAH-PAH
description: ''Through her political scandals Austria has managed to draw the big world's attention to herself and at last is no longer confused with Australia.''

title: GROUP NURTURES U.S.-JAPANESE LINKS
description: In an unusual program, 24 American executives learned recently of the rigors of Japanese school life, the esprit de corps of the Japanese corporate team and the niceties of bowing, offering gifts and dining with Japanese corporate officials.

title: Reading With Adolescents
description: To the Editor:

title: TIES TO FAR RIGHT DOUBTED FOR 2 IN BOMBING
description: A bomb-wielding couple who held 150 Wyoming children for ransom at a rural school do not appear to have had any direct ties to Posse Comitatus or other far-right, white supremacist groups, according to the sheriff in charge of the investigation.

title: Round One In the Battle For the Senate
description: The early primary season drew to a close last week with elections in nine states. The results in three of them - California, South Dakota and Alabama - could portend the answer to the year's big question: Will the Democrats recapture the Senate majority? They need four more seats to do so.

title: BROWN CREW WINS CLOSE ONE
description: The three crews crossed the finish line together and the oarsmen did not know which had won. Milissa Galazzi, the coxswain for Brown, suspected that her boat had been ahead of Penn and Wisconsin but she did not tell the others. ''I wanted to be sure,'' she said. She was right. When what appeared to be a dead heat on the finish line was sorted out by the officials, Brown's heavyweight eight indeed had won the national championship at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's 84th annual regatta.

title: ABANDONED FARMSTEADS ARE SIGN OF HARD TIMES
description: The emerald green countryside around Sioux Falls contains the visible signs of the American farm's gradual advance in size and decline in employment. A thicket of elm, ash and buffalo berry on a far hill conceals the remnants of a homestead, the eyeless windows and failing roof joists proof of some distant abandonment. Down the road, a house of more recent construction is also falling into neglect, its outbuildings now used to store machinery, but without inhabitants.

title: IT'S ABOUT THE AIR
description: IT takes only a few days in Mexico for a visitor to come to the conclusion that the Mexicans are a superior people, whose lungs, gastric systems and tempers are able to cope with the smog, the water and the traffic.

title: A YANKEE LEARNS TO BOW
description: After receiving his B.A. degree in history at Yale University in 1982, with a concentration in Japanese studies, Jeff Irish spent two years as the only American among 5,000 employees in the Tokyo headquarters of a major Japanese construction company. He lived in a company dormitory and found his friends among the men and women with whom he worked. He is currently on the staff of the company's New York office. In the following article, he describes a typical day in Tokyo as he experienced it: the office routine and decision-making process, the relationships among workers and between workers and managers, the impact of the Japanese corporate culture upon a Westerner. The names of his colleagues have been changed to protect their privacy.

title: Focus: New Orleans; Toe-to-Toe Riverside Space Race
description: AMID the usual din of the old New Orleans waterfront, the paddlewheelers, boat whistles, street musicians and tourist traffic, there are new competing sounds from a breed not much in evidence before: leasing agents intent upon a hard sell.

title: Family Court And Sex Bias
description: Bias against women is so prevalent in the New York City Family Court system, administrators say, for the simple reason that Family Court deals with more women than any other court.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch last Sunday from Allentown, Pa., about a lawsuit by police officers misidentified one of those who contested their demotions. He was Thomas Bennis, not Dennis.

title: Israeli Cabinet Fires a Zealous Attorney General
description: After decades of living with the threat of terrorism, many Israelis are ready to subject attackers to the Old Testament code that requires an eye for an eye. Reflecting those sentiments and perhaps additional concern about findings that might embarrass the Government, the Israeli Cabinet dismissed Attorney General Yitzhak Zamir last week. Mr. Zamir had insisted on proceeding to investigate an alleged coverup after two terrorists were battered to death in 1984.

title: U.A.W. PLEDGES TO ORGANIZE EMPLOYEES AT JAPANESE PLANTS IN U.S.
description: The problem of organizing workers in Japanese-owned production plants in this country clouded the triennial meeting of the United Automobile Workers here this week.

title: Katherine Weeks Is Wed
description: Katherine Weeks, the daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Oliver Weeks of Jacksonville, Fla., was married yesterday to Stewart Hardison, the son of Mrs. S. Ralph Hardison of Raleigh and Newland, N.C., and the late Mr. Hardison. The Revs.

title: Forms Inundate State's Rent Regulators
description: THE Rent Stabilization Association, the main organization of owners of rental buildings in New York City, put out a handbook this year called ''Rent Regulation Forms, Notices and Applications: What Every New York State Apartment Building Owner Needs to Know.''

title: Banner for Botham
description: The stately demeanor of a London cricket match at Lord's between England and India was rudely interrupted when Ashley Sommers, a 22-year-old model from Bolton, ran across the grounds clad only in a bikini bottom and waving a banner that read: ''Bring Back Botham.'' The banner referred to the English cricket player Ian Botham, who was recently banned by authorities for two months after admitting that he smoked marijuana. Miss Sommers was covered by a policeman's jacket and led away by the police.

title: IF IT WORKS, IT'S THEATER. IF IT DOESN'T...
description: Sometimes it starts with an unlikely combination of characters placed in an equally improbable situation. The Pope, a rabbi and a bagel salesman all find themselves at Zabar's at the same time, along with Mr. Zabar. A clown, a Mafioso and the obnoxious neighbor of the deceased come together over a dead body at a funeral parlor. A family celebrates the birthday of a daughter who has just won the lottery while the grandfather is committing suicide in the bathroom.

title: No Headline
description: FOR years, efforts to establish residences for the retarded on Long Island have met with resistance in many communities. Now, New York State plans to try a new idea - creating a new neighborhood around the retarded.

title: ...AND TO LOSE
description: One of the oddities of the college sports business is that losing can pay. Not nearly as much as winning, of course, but enough to make a profit for some schools.

title: INNOCENCE UNDER SIEGE
description: A FUNNY DIRTY LITTLE WAR By Osvaldo Soriano. Translated by Nick Caistor. 108 pp. New York: Readers International/ Persea Books. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, $6.95. MOST of the Argentine literature that has made its way into English is associated with the work of Jorge Luis Borges and other fantasists, his spiritual children. But there is another kind of imagination at work in the Babel of Buenos Aires, feisty and brawling, rooted in the reality of the nation and its frequently noxious political atmosphere. Very often the writer looks with jaundiced eye at the repressive power structure that dominated the nation from the military coup of 1930 until the comic-epic encounter with Britain over the Falklands. None of the generals, now happily toppled, would be happy with Osvaldo Soriano's mordant vision of Juan Peron's dictatorship and that of his numerous successors.

title: Reagan Wins On Weapons Sale To Saudi Arabia
description: Ronald Reagan telephoned; George Shultz telephoned; even Jimmy Carter got on the phone to urge support for the President's foreign policy in general and the sale of weapons to Saudi Arabia in particular. In the end, the Administration prevailed, with 34 senators voting for the deal last week.

title: Social Events; SPRING SALUTES
description: At Gracie Mansion June 9 - There will a tour of Gracie Mansion and a light breakfast from 10 A.M. to noon to benefit jointly the Volunteer Services for the Elderly of Yorkville and the Gracie Mansion Conservancy. Tickets, $40, from 212-744-0425. Legal Aid Benefit

title: More Fighting Rages in Beirut
description: In much of the world, Moslems were quietly observing Ramadan, their holy month of daytime fasting, but it was violence as usual in Beirut last week. Using Syrian-supplied Soviet T-54 tanks and heavy artillery, Shiite Moslem militiamen battered Palestinian districts south of the city.

title:
GARDENING;
ALLIUMS: ORNAMENTAL AND EDIBLE
description: THE alliums are probably the most widely grown of all garden plants, and everyone, gardener and nongardener alike, is familiar with them, if not by their proper scientific names, then by their more common ones. This group of plants includes the onion, leek, garlic, shallot and chive.

title: Lori E. Garjian, Physician, Weds Jean-Marie Atamian
description: Dr. Lori Ellen Garjian, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Haig Garjian of Tenafly, N.J., and Jean-Marie Lucien Atamian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Atamian of New York, were married yesterday at St. Thomas Armenian Church in Tenafly. The Rev. Arnak Kasparian officiated.

title: Recent Sales
description: Aberdeen $133,500 129 Andover Lane *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 22-year-old colonial; *2*den, attic fan, family room; taxes $2,862. Kinnelon $215,000 Miller Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, new contemporary; stone foyer, skylights, *2*2 decks; taxes to be assessed. Morristown $206,000 290 Western Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; hardwood *2*floors, built-in bookcases, circular driveway; taxes $2,785. North Brunswick $99,000 313 Constitution Circle *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old ranch condominium;slate fireplace, *2*central air-conditioning, $68 monthly maintenance; taxes $1,492. Scotch Plains $223,000 1964 Inverness Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial; *2*plaster walls, 2-car garage, fireplace; taxes $3,570. Orange $210,000 294 Elmwynd Drive *2*6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 55-year-old colonial; butler's *2*pantry, library, heated garage; taxes $4,952. OTHER AREAS St. James, L.I. $175,000 37 Richie Court North *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath 24-year-old ranch; new kitchen, *2*skylights, patio; taxes $3,900. Roxbury, Conn. $143,000 Baker Road *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; hardwood *2*floors, fine landscaping, 2 acres; taxes $960. Bronxville, N.Y. $480,000 17 Oriole Avenue *2*5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor/ Norman; *2*library, sunroom, eat-in kitchen, .43 acre; taxes $10,135.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Pre-Father's Day Duds At Up to 60% Off Tress Clothes Factory Outlet represents retailing experience that began four decades ago on Stanton Street off Delancey in Manhattan, continued on Fordham Road in the Bronx and moved to the town of Greenburgh section nearest White Plains nearly four years ago.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Soviet Fishing Pact Sought
description: A PRIVATE American group is seeking to conclude a reciprocal agreement that would enable sportsmen from this country to fish and hunt in the Soviet Union.

title: CHRIS EVERT LLOYD: SKILLED ATHLETE BY ALL DEFINITIONS
description: TWENTY years ago in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., young people with athletic stirrings leaned in one of two directions: swimming or tennis. As I chased my dreams of becoming the best in the former, a girl down the street relentlessly pursued perfection in the latter.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HOLLYWOOD DESTINIES: European Directors in America, 1922-1931. By Graham Petrie. (Routledge & Kegan Paul, $29.95.) For a brief decade before the advent of sound, the films of European directors like F. W. Murnau, Victor Sjostrom, Mauritz Stiller and Ernst Lubitsch played, with modest success, in Peoria.

title: Cost Control
description: NOT LONG AGO, THIS newspaper reported the sad story of a chap who turned up at his automobile dealer's showroom to be told that the $12,000 Honda he had ordered some weeks earlier would cost him $12,588. He had been done in by the weakened dollar.

title: Bruce Gets 3-Year Pact
description: Ohio State's football team has done better than 9-3, but not recently, and school athletic authorities are apparently satisfied. Earle Bruce, who coached the Buckeyes to identical 9-3 records for the last six years, was given his first multiyear contract, a three-year pact with an initial salary of $87,120. ''It's great for our program,'' Bruce said after signing the contract.

title: New York to Raise The Ante on Fraud
description: Under New York State law, someone who steals a wallet by threatening the victim with a weapon receives a mandatory prison term as long as 25 years. But someone convicted of embezzling more than $1 million gets 7 years at most and may not have to serve time at all.

title: COLORFULLY UPDATED 'TWIN SETS'
description: ONCE upon a time, 50 years ago to be more precise, ''twin set'' simply meant a cardigan and pullover sweater in matching colors. Today, the twin set has taken on new meaning and a whole new look. The updated version is a knitted cotton sweater with a flower or abstract intarsia motif that is repeated in a smaller print on a coordinated silk skirt or cotton trousers.

title: The Botnick Principle
description: Why is Victor Botnick, a 32-year-old former aide to New York's Mayor Koch and a man who does not even hold a bachelor's degree, in charge of the nation's largest municipal hospital system? Apparently because the Mayor prefers the Peter Principle to the principle of finding the best person for the job.

title:
ART;
NEW GALLERY AT DOWLING OPENS WITH COLLAGE SHOW
description: ''TRANSFORMED ELEMENTS,'' an exhibition of collages by six Long Island artists, inaugurates the new art gallery at Dowling College in Oakdale.

title: O'NEILL TO SIGN BILL TO FINANCE TEACHER RAISES
description: Although Connecticut lawmakers rejected his proposal to require each town to pay teachers at least $20,000 a year, Gov. William A. O'Neill will sign a $92 million education bill that was passed Friday by the General Assembly, an aide said yesterday.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICE;
Photography
description: Much as they lend themselves to interior decoration, photographs are not often thought of as furniture. Yet furniture they can be, as the current exhibition at Marcuse Pfeifer Gallery (568 Broadway, at Prince Street, through June 26) demonstrates.

title: Emil Ysona Wed To Denise Sabal
description: Denise M. Sabal and Emil Ysona were married in a civil ceremony yesterday at The Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla., by Judge Thomas E. Sholts of the 15th Judicial Circuit Court of Palm Beach County.

title: On Language; The Word's the Thing
description: THE FIRST THING you learn in general semantics is ''the word is not the thing'' - that is, the referent is not the source, or, to put it understandably, cow is merely a word, a sign, a name, and is not the flesh-and-blood thing that has an udder and goes ''moo.''

title: FROM TERRA INCOGNITA TO TARRAGON RAMPANT
description: AFTER my neighbor, who had been wintering in Florida, picked up her geraniums, which had been wintering on my windowsill, I lured her into my garden.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: For his first season as the artistic director of the Stratford Festival in Canada, John Neville decided to stress Shakespeare's romances with main-stage productions of three of his last plays, ''Pericles,'' ''Cymbeline'' and ''The Winter's Tale.'' The selection could certainly be regarded as a challenge to the audience, favored through the 34 years of the festival - the good years and the less good years - with a repertory that has emphasized Shakespeare's better known and better loved comedies, tragedies and histories. That diet has, in recent times, been further spiced with Gilbert and Sullivan. It is perhaps with that latter fact in mind that Mr. Neville chose as his fourth main-stage play, the Rodgers and Hart musical, ''The Boys From Syracuse'' - an entertainment to leaven an otherwise weighty season.

title: CITY INVESTIGATION CHIEF OUTLINES WAYS TO CUT HIS CASELOAD
description: MORE questions were raised last week about the conduct of New York City officials, and the legal skirmishes growing out of the municipal scandal continued. The beginning of a Federal trial in which six defendants are accused of bribery and racketeering in the Parking Violations Bureau was postponed until July, and lawyers agreed to move it outside New York City. City records indicated additional irregularities in the awarding of taxi medallions by Jay L. Turoff, New York's former Taxi and Limousine Commissioner. Officials said Federal prosecutors had begun a broad investigation of the Brooklyn Democratic organization. And at a hearing of a city-state commission examining integrity in government, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn called for stringent new restrictions on the activities of county political leaders.

title: ADVANCING HEALTH, BY STEPS
description: ONE year ago, the State Commissioner of Health Services announced that he would celebrate Connecticut's 350th birthday, and call attention to the need for good health, with a 350-mile ''Walk for Wellness'' through the state.

title: POLLS SHOW WALDHEIM WILL WIN PRESIDENCY TODAY
description: Austria's presidential election campaign drew to a close today with opinion polls predicting that Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General of the United Nations, would be elected.

title: LLOYD IS WINNER IN FRENCH OPEN
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, the queen of soft courts, worked her magic again today at the French Open. She transformed a pitifully losing game into a spectacularly winning one and defeated her arch rival, Martina Navratilova, 2-6, 6-3, 6-3, in the final.

title: Marianthe Pappas, Nurse, Marries Dr. John M. Hale
description: Marianthe Pappas, the daughter of Lily Mobile Pappas of Washington and the late Nicholas J. Pappas, and Dr. John M. Hale, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Hale of New York, were married yesterday at the St. Sophia Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. John Tavlarides, Dean of the Greek Orthodox cathedral, and Msgr.

title: ISRAEL'S MASTER POET
description: YEHUDA AMICHAI'S HOME IN JERUSALEM, looking out over the Valley of Hinnom on the looming walls and turrets and domes of the Old City, might seem like a perfect vantage point for a Hebrew poet.

title: OFF TO OFF-BROADWAY IN EAST BRUNSWICK
description: AS IF in a direct, affirmative answer to the stock question ''Is There Life After High School?'' a drama coordinator for the East Brunswick school system has, for a change, coordinated an Off Off Broadway musical with the help of the district's high school students.

title: A Tougher Shultz Criticizes Pretoria
description: Constructive engagement, as the Reagan Administration's quiet coaxing of South Africa's white-minority Government is called, was buttressed last week with criticism that may have seemed anything but constructive in Pretoria. ''Apartheid is wrong,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz told a clerical conference in Washington.

title: GAMBLING ON CBS
description: ON THE MORNING OF JULY 3, 1985, THE telephone rang in the New York office of Laurence A. Tisch. As usual, the 63-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Loews Corporation was working alone with his two-line phone, his Quotron machine and his brain. The Quotron, with its steady parade of up-to-the-minute Wall Street news, is useful, but the brain, encased in an almost completely bald head, is Tisch's chief asset in the game of making money.

title: STYLE AS STRATEGY
description: EXECUTIVE STYLE IN THE SUMMER OF '86 is worldly and self-expressive, an indicator of the global marketplace in which upward strivers are now operating.

title: Emily Sohmer, a Historian, Becomes Bride of Paul Tai
description: Emily Sohmer, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Bernard Sohmer of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday to Paul Tai, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Tai of Coral City, Fla. Judge Renee Roth of the New York State Surrogate's Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony in her chambers.

title: A DESPOTIC REIGN THAT CHANGED THE COURSE OF CHINESE ART
description: ''The Elegant Brush: Chinese Painting Under the Qianlong Emperor, 1735-1795'' goes beyond most exhibitions of Oriental art. It is not a theme show; nor is it a display of masterpieces. It includes exceptional paintings. But there are also mediocre and even tacky works in which the sense of purpose generally identified with Chinese art is absent. By including both court painting and scholar painting, both commissioned and private work, the show brings one of the most controversial periods of Chinese art to life.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Postcard From the Patient We have more records of psychoanalysts interpreting patients than the other way around. In ''Melanie Klein: Her World and Her Work'' (Knopf), Phyllis Grosskurth quotes the ambivalent recollections of a man in his mid-50's who had been analyzed by Melanie Klein when he was 16.

title: HIGH PROFILE HAS PITFALLS, CANADA FINDS
description: Like the timid wallflower at the dance who bounces into the center of the ballroom and kicks off her shoes, Canada has surprised Americans and, some say, embarrassed itself by trying to play politics by Washington's rules.

title: THE RISE AND RISE OF BIG MAC
description: CHEF salads and shrimp salads have recently joined the McDonald's hamburger empire.

title: BELMAR TRIES TO SOFTEN EFFECT OF SUMMER INVASION
description: AS SUMMER begins, officials and residents here are waiting to see if a new law requiring bars to close at midnight will stem the tide of unruly weekend visitors that has disrupted life in this Shore community.

title: GHOSTS AND A PHANTOM
description: For the general public the distinction between a ghost and phantom is a murky one. But for bridge-players the line is easy to draw: The ghost is human, a great player of the past who has made his mark upon the game, while a phantom is technical, a save ventured against a contract that was due to fail.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: TALL SHIPS IN BALTIMORE - The tall ships of the world, the last of the great sailing vessels, will return to Baltimore's Inner Harbor next weekend to launch a Summer of Sail and help commemorate Flag Day.

title: Carolyn R. Field Becomes a Bride
description: Carolyn Rundle Field, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James B. Field of Houston and Hilton Head, S.C., was married yesterday to Gerard Anthony Purcell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Purcell of Farmingdale, L.I. The Rev. Robert Lubrano performed the ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title: IAN'S MOTHER LIVES WITH JANE
description: HIDDEN PICTURES By Meg Wolitzer. 294 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95. BOY meets girl. Boy marries girl. Boy loses girl. In light of standard publishing policies, this topic would have been thrown into the wastebasket along with stories about an Airedale biting a postman. But when boy loses girl - to another girl - and for good measure she takes along their 3-year-old son, we're talking news and what lies at the heart of Meg Wolitzer's second novel, ''Hidden Pictures.'' It is a challenging scenario, demanding an intense re-examination of our views on lesbianism, parenting and the structure of the traditional family. And it's a challenge that Meg Wolitzer, more often than not, meets.

title: IN FAR HILLS, ''IRON BYRON'' GIVES GOLF BALLS A TRYING WORKOUT
description: THE only golf played at the United States Golf Association's picturesque headquarters here is played by machines, but it has far-reaching effects on the game.

title: BLACK SWANS AND AN ICY LAKE
