description: ''Who said swans have to be white?'' Lincoln Kirstein asked a visitor recently.

title: STRETCHING EXERCISES FOR THE MIND
description: A MASTER plan designed to equip children with imaginative problem-solving methods that will arm them for life in the 21st century has created some interesting classroom situations in the Princeton elementary schools.

title: WHY INVESTORS ARE SOUR ON CHINA
description: TO many people, the opening of China to foreign investors at the outset of the 1980's seemed like one of the most promising political and economic developments since World War II. But now, fresh on the heels of the American Motors Corporation's well-publicized problems with its jeep-making venture here, there is a growing sense among Americans and Chinese alike that the lure of investing in China has dimmed.

title: Mary Duncan Is Married To Mark Roy Thompson
description: Mary Hammond Duncan, the daughter of John Bruce Duncan and the late Leila Hammond Duncan of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Roy Thompson, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Malcolm C. Thompson of St. Louis.

title: IN SUMMER, ITS OWN PACE
description: ''You could come back in November,'' Sheila M. K. Thwin said philosophically as we waited in a small pagoda in Pegu to escape a summer cloudburst.

title: HIGHLAND FALLS
description: ON Saturday afternoons in early fall, some Highland Falls residents lay in supplies early to avoid going into town while others enjoy strolling along Main Street to watch the spectacle.

title: AIDS VICTIMS GAIN IN FIGHT ON RIGHTS
description: Justice Department lawyers have tentatively concluded that people with AIDS are ''handicapped individuals'' entitled to protection under Federal civil rights law.

title: Talking Strangers; Curbing 'Guests' In a Co-op
description: A GROWING problem for directors of New York City co-ops is what to do about strangers who are suddenly discovered living as guests, roommates, house sitters or clandestine tenants of tenant-shareholders.

title: FRESH AIR FUND'S GIFT: RELIEF FROM CITY HEAT
description: Yakini Johnson knows what he likes, and one thing he does not like is summer in the city. ''It's too hot and boring,'' said Yakini, a 12-year-old from Jamaica, Queens.

title: Sarah Briggs a Bride
description: Sarah Elaine Briggs and Ernest Pereira, first violinists with the Charlotte (N.C.) Symphony, were married yesterday at the Belk Chapel of Queens College in Charlotte. Loyd C. Dillon, a Unitarian Spokesman, officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. William F. Briggs of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Pereira of Pretoria, South Africa.

title: NEW CHIEF TO REFOCUS CHILD-AID FOUNDATION
description: When Barbara B. Blum takes over this fall as the president of the Foundation for Child Development, she wants to steer the 86-year-old, New York-based philanthropy into demonstrating how much can be done with limited money to help poor children in this country.

title: CRIME
description: Of the many mystery writers who base their stories on art, John Malcolm is one of the best, and he follows previous form in THE GWEN JOHN SCULPTURE (Scribners, $13.95). Again the hero is Tim Simpson, the tough young art expert with an easily kindled temper. He had started an art investment fund for a merchant bank. As this story opens, there has been a palace revolution in the bank, and Simpson has been promoted. But he retains control over his fund, and off to France he goes to look for a hitherto unknown Rodin sculpture. Others have the same idea, and they are not particularly gentle in disposing of the opposition.

title: Headliners; A 'Very Serious Mistake'
description: For a while, Dan Rostenkowski was just another one of the governed. Arrested on drunken driving charges, the Illinois Democrat, who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, posted a $497.50 bond and tried to finish out a quiet weekend in the country before calling a news conference to explain.

title: SPIRITUAL LAND OF PRAYERS AND PAGODAS
description: As we now believe pop stars and sports heroes are superhuman, the Burmese believe in nats. Their 37 nats are half human, half spirit, angels and demons asking offerings not to make our lives difficult. In ancient Burma before Buddhism came, every village had its special nat in each tree and field. There were wind and water nats, rice and wild game nats. Then a reforming king, who founded the first Burmese Empire, decided that too many nats spoiled the brotherhood and decreed that there would be only 36, commanded by a king nat. Rather like the saints of the Roman Catholic Church, each nat had his or her duty of intercession between God and mankind. Most of them had been human beings who had died famously or tragically like the beatified Christian martyrs; stories about their lives and deaths are a bardic history of Burma. They have marvelous titles such as Lady Golden Sides, The Brown Lord of Due South, The Lord With the White Umbrella, The Younger Inferior Gold, and Lady Bandy Legs.

title: THE JOY OF GIVING
description: Summer may be at hand, but the corporate gift industry is possessed by the Christmas spirit. Consultants who suggest the presents that corporations send their most important customers report the waning of one trend and the re-emergence of another: electronic gadgets and appliances are yielding to traditional, expensive bric-a-brac.

title: CELEBRATION OF OLIVIER AND THE BARD
description: This year marks the 50th anniversary of the first of Laurence Olivier's seven memorable film appearances in Shakespearean roles, and Bravo will acknowledge the occasion with a retrospective of the movies beginning Tuesday, with five of the films running on consecutive nights at 8 P.M.

title: Tales That Ties Tell
description: A NECKTIE SPEAKS its own language.

title: MOM CATCHES A LAZY AFTERNOON WITH SONS AND FISH
description: AN early spring breeze blew gentle ripples across the lake. The red-and-white bobber suddenly seems to hide behind a small wave. There is no tug on the line to announce a nearby fish, just nature creating crannies for the bobbers to hide behind.

title: Renovations
description: About four years ago, London & Leeds approached the Young Women's Christian Association about buying the unused air rights of its building at Lexington Avenue and 53d Street. The deal brought $5 million to the association, enabling it to start planning renovations of its 10-story structure, built in 1918.

title: Spokesman for A.T.&T. Backs Striking Workers
description: The actor Cliff Robertson, who does television commercials for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, threw a curve into the weeklong nationwide strike by the Communication Workers of America by telling union picketers here, ''I'm with you.''

title: Lisa A. Kuhlman Wed in St. Louis
description: Lisa Anne Kuhlman, who received her master's degree in business administration from Washington University last month, and Roger Lawrence Krakoff, a financial analyst with the I.B.M. Information Systems and Communications Group in White Plains, were married yesterday in the May Chapel of Temple Israel in St. Louis. Rabbi Alvin D. Rubin and the Rev. Jerome F. Wilkerson, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: IN EXILE FROM THE PROMISED LAND
description: WINTER IN JERUSALEM By Blanche d'Alpuget. 269 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95. HER deliciously Princess-of-Cleves-type name notwithstanding, Blanche d'Alpuget is an Australian born and bred, the author of a vivid biography of that country's Prime Minister Bob Hawke among other books, and, as ''Winter in Jerusalem'' proves, a writer of talent and feistiness.

title: THAT PORSCHE MYSTIQUE
description: I WISH that I liked a couple of things better. One of them is hockey. The other is Porsches.

title: PATERSON GETTING ARTS SCHOOL
description: ON Sept. 3, when the Rosa Parks High School of Fine and Performing Arts opens here, the people who nurtured a dream for eight years may finally believe in its reality.

title: HOSTAGE KIN TO VISIT LEBANON
description: The sister of an American held hostage in Lebanon since 1985 said yesterday that she had been granted a visa by the Lebanese Government and planned to travel to Beirut to talk with President Amin Gemayel.

title: Child Molester To Serve 2 Years at His House
description: A Superior Court judge, in a rare move, has sentenced a convicted child molester to stay in his house for two years except for work and Naval Reserve meetings.

title: Donald Trump Takes to the Ice
description: The Wollman Memorial Skating Rink in Central Park will not carry Donald J. Trump's name, but it will surely bear his mark. The developer, known for luxury apartment houses, hotels and shopping plazas, agreed last week to rebuild the city's problem-plagued ice-skating rink at no profit.

title: 3 PERUVIANS KILLED BY BOMBS IN PLAZA VISITED BY PRESIDENT
description: Four bombs exploded today in a Lima plaza, killing three people and wounding at least five, just before and after President Alan Garcia attended a ceremony in the square, the police reported.

title: IS THERE A MUSICIAN IN THE HOUSE?
description: TONE DEAF AND ALL THUMBS? An Invitation to Music-Making for Late Bloomers and Non-prodigies. By Frank R. Wilson. 210 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95. FOR those who were not prodigies, the lure of being able to make music has strong appeal. The usual alibi is, ''It's already too late. I'm too old to start now.'' In ''Tone Deaf and All Thumbs?'' Frank R. Wilson, a physician, delivers a refutation that is a blend of scientific analysis, personal experience and enthusiastic encouragement. He presents an analysis of the brain and the muscular system; considers the neurological basis of auditory perception; describes the biology of timing, rhythm and tempo; explores the visual system and its application to musical notation; discusses principles of learning theory; confronts the problem of stage fright; and offers advice on getting started.

title: Sunday Observer; Millions on the Line
description: NOW THAT THE country is crawling with millionaires, I am constantly asked why I am not one of them. Here is a typical letter from a reader:

title: A Brother Gone Away
description: A FEW weeks ago, I got a late-night call from Mom in California. The subject of the call was my brother. He'd been arrested again, she said, and this time the authorities had extradited him to Hawaii to face charges he left hanging when he jumped bail there.

title: PROTESTERS BATTLE POLICE AT WEST GERMAN A-PLANT
description: Demonstrators clashed with the police today as thousands of people tried to lay siege to a nuclear power plant in this small town in northern Germany.

title: FRENCH LESSONS WHILE THE NEIGHBORS STARVE
description: THE NEWS FROM IRELAND And Other Stories. By William Trevor. 285 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $16.95. TEN novels, six story collections and numerous dramatic writings have already come to us from William Trevor, and in this his seventh book of short fiction he proves once more that he is best when writing about his native land. Born in County Cork and educated in Dublin, he now lives in Devon. That England has been his home for a long time can be surmised from the quantity of fiction he has written about the English - country English, village English, London English, the English abroad. Mr. Trevor is a sturdy writer of clear and satisfying prose, who knows how to seek out the fictionally viable character and how to catch the pulse beat in a relationship or the secret strain within a heart. Yet his English stories seem strangely ''produced,'' planned instead of crying to be written. It is the news from Ireland that, wander where he will, he is always returning to give voice to - and these are the stories with flow and power.

title: COLLEGES AND YOUTHS HUNT THE BEST
description: WHEN Frances Schwartz scanned the lapel of Fletcher Tomic's seersucker jacket and noticed the ''Harvard Class of '51'' name sticker, she was glad she had come to the far corner of the gym to hear what the alumnus was saying.

title: WESTPORT REGULATING THE RIGHT TO CLAM
description: THE Cockenoe clamming flats off Westport are considered the most fertile on Long Island Sound, but people who want to gather mollusks there are caught in a conflict over who should regulate the clamming rakes.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 8, 1986
description: Fiction:

title: FUNDS URGED FOR ACTIVITIES IN SCHOOLS
description: While athletics at New York City public schools are well financed, other extracurricular activities such as school newspapers, chess clubs and drama groups are barely surviving, an education monitoring group says.

title: LOBBIES CAN'T ERASE RIGHTS VIOLATIONS
description: Twenty-five years ago, when an organization called Amnesty International was founded to investigate and report on injustice and cruelty around the world, ''human rights'' was not a widely used term. Nowadays, it is seen and heard everywhere. But where once the enemy was ignorance and apathy, today a brand new barrier confronts the human rights advocate: the big-time professional public-relations firms that collect astronomical fees from governments to push their clients' interests and sell their images.

title: Masked Gunmen Fire On Hindus in Shrine
description: Masked gunmen fired on Hindus praying at a Sikh shrine in the Punjab today, killing two and critically wounding one, the authorities reported, adding that Sikhs were suspected.

title: A MUSEUM IS PLANNED ALONG PICO
description: The center of the Jewish community of Los Angeles is on the move again.

title: TEXAN EXECUTED BY INJECTION FOR KILLING OF A DRUG AGENT
description: A man convicted of killing an undercover narcotics officer in 1978 was executed by lethal injection early today after the United States Supreme Court denied his request for a stay of execution.

title: 'What Is the Sense?'
description: A hawkish old national security hand shook his head. ''It's just irrational,'' he said. The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Representative Les Aspin, asked, ''What in the name of God is the sense?''

title: Margaret Rudolf, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Margaret Suzanne Rudolf, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Rudolf of New York and Mount Desert, Me., was married yesterday to Dr. Tom Kendall Coffey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Coffey of Portland, Ore. Rabbi Bernhard Cohn performed the ceremony at Congregation Habonim in New York.

title: Florida State In Title Game
description: Richie Lewis earned his second save of the College World Series by retiring Miami in the ninth inning to help Florida State advance to the championship game with a 4-3 victory.

title: The Right and Wrong Kinds of Pension Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: June 9, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GALLERY HOPPING The new Whitney Museum of American Art at the Equitable Center, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street (554-1113), might be worth a visit even if there were nothing on exhibit there. As with the Whitney branch in the Philip Morris building near Grand Central Terminal and with the big Whitney itself on Madison Avenue, it is an eye-catching space. In this case, it is two separate spaces on the ground floor, set in a formidably modern building lobby, and one is thankful that this valuable area has not been converted to commercial enterprise.

title: Alamito Deal Is Completed
description: Osceola Energy Inc. said Friday that it had completed the acquisition of the shares of the Alamito Company of Tucson, Ariz., an electricity wholesaler, for $165 a share, or $376.2 million.

title: CONCERT: LATVIAN COMPOSERS
description: THE composers who led musical nationalism throughout Europe in the latter part of the 19th century included, alongside the few true masters whose works are well known internationally, many fine craftsmen remembered only at home. Typically, they blended then-current European techniques with a certain infusion of folk melody and dance, and drew inspiration from their histories and sagas. They handled these materials with great skill and honest fervor, and as a result, though their music may sound derivative, it does not sound stale.

title: YANKS ARE ROUTED, 18-9 AS LACY HITS 3 HOMERS
description: True, it was Bat Day, and it is always nice when the competing teams cooperate, getting into the spirit of the event. But by the end of the seventh inning yesterday, the Yankees and Orioles had worn out the theme like a pair of favorite jeans. The handful of fans remaining from the original crowd of 52,021 probably would have given back their bats just to see two guys who were not doing impressions of Ed Whitson when he pitches at Yankee Stadium.

title: ADAPTABLE ROOKIE HELPS METS WIN
description: Like the city mouse lording it over the country mouse, the Mets put a somewhat transient lineup on the field today and still beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3, then left town with four victories in five games over a last-place team.

title: Name Chosen: It's Omnicom
description: And the name of the holding company for BBDO International and DDB Needham Worldwide is (the envelope, please) the Omnicom Group. Oh, Gee! The company has been publicly nameless since the merger announcement at the end of April, and since then the lawyers have been clearing Omnicom.

title: REPORT FAULTS ELECTION OF CIVIL COURT JUDGES
description: The election process for Civil Court judges in New York City amounts to little more than the appointment of judges by powerful county Democratic leaders, according to a report to be released today by a nonpartisan court-monitoring group.

title: COLOMBIA JUSTICE AIDE ACCUSES ARMY
description: Colombia's Attorney General has charged that this country's army and police are increasingly using torture, ''disappearances'' and other human rights abuses in their fight against leftist guerrillas and ordinary criminals.

title: Elizabeth Smithers Is Wed To William Vance Weaver
description: Elizabeth Anne Luther Smithers, a daughter of Michael Luther of Woodbridge, Conn., and Elizabeth Schulze Luther of New York, was married yesterday to William Vance Weaver, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vance Weaver of Sherman, Conn., and New York. Justice of the Peace Frederick Moss of Woodbridge performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: Julie A. Salzberg and Paul Perlin Exchange Vows
description: Julie Ann Salzberg, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Salzberg of Paradise Valley, Ariz., was married yesterday to Paul Alan Perlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bart Perlin of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Martin Freedman performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Mets return home to face the Pennsylvania teams this week.

title: Stockman in Hospital After Cyclist Hits Him
description: David A. Stockman, the former budget director for the Reagan Administration, was hit by a bicycle messenger as he was waiting to cross an intersection near his office in the Financial District on Friday and suffered a knee injury, according to Mr. Stockman's associates and family.

title: Steven David Lofchie Weds Dr. Sarah Fox
description: Dr. Sarah Jane Fox, a fellow in child psychiatry at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, and Steven David Lofchie, a financial analyst at Citibank, were married yesterday at the West Orange, N.J., home of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Weinstein. Rabbi Alexander Shapiro officiated.

title: BELMONT IS PART OF AN OVERTURE
description: The Belmont Stakes usually is the final act of the year's drama for the 3-year-olds, but this year the Triple Crown races served instead as an overture. The three races answered few questions while setting the stage for some dramatic showdowns ahead.

title: Bay of Pigs Commander Visits U.S. After Prison
description: Col. Ricardo Montero Duque, the last imprisoned senior officer of the 1961 Bay of Pigs invasion, arrived in the United States today after his release from a Cuban prison, the State Department reported.

title: SUCCESSFUL REUNION FOR 2 OKLAHOMANS
description: Although there are just two golf courses in Stillwater, home of the Oklahoma State University Cowboys, the school has been a pipeline to the PGA Tour.

title: N.Y.U. FILM GRADUATES OPEN HOLLYWOOD DOORS
description: A group of New York University film school graduates is trying to help current N.Y.U. students take their first steps toward Hollywood careers by arranging to have their films shown to the movie industry.

title: Primaries Tomorrow In Four States
description: After eight years of forceful leadership by Gov. Dick Riley, four fellow Democrats are competing to fill the power vacuum created by his departure, while an invigorated Republican Party waits in the wings.

title: SOVIET DENOUNCES WALDHEIM CRITICS
description: The Soviet Union today harshly denounced Washington and ''Zionist circles'' for waging ''a campaign of personal hostile attacks'' against Kurt Waldheim.

title: Mohawk Board's Fight Brings Edelman Back
description: Asher B. Edelman is back as board chairman at the Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation, a struggling computer company in which he holds a 10 percent interest.

title: REFUGEES IN SUDAN FIND WELCOME WEARING THIN
description: As the glimmering haze of a steamy afternoon yielded to dusk, the Karkora refugee settlement was overflowing with activity.

title: ECONOMY DESCRIBED AS STABLE
description: As the American economy enters the second half of its fourth straight year of growth, economists and leading business executives find conditions sounder than they have been in two decades or more and see signs of further growth right through next year.

title: Why Gamble on Making Books?
description: If John Le Carre's American publisher were to print copies of ''The Perfect Spy'' in Britain for sale in America, Mr. Le Carre would be protected by his American copyright. But if David Stockman's American publisher imported foreign-printed copies of his best seller, anyone would be free to steal the words. What's the difference? Citizenship. Copyrights are void for works written by Americans but printed abroad.

title: DALLAS FACES TAX WOES BY CUTTING CITY SERVICES
description: The public swimming pools here opened two weeks late, waiting lines are lengthening at municipal offices and people who want to trace family histories at the Dallas Public Library face an uncertain delay before the genealogy room opens again.

title: CHEMICAL CARS IGNITE AS SPAN, WEAKENED BY FLOOD, GIVES WAY
description: A bridge weakened by flooding last week collapsed as a Missouri Pacific freight train crossed it today and at least five tank cars caught fire, triggering an explosion that injured five people and forced the evacuation of as many as 2,000 others, the authorities said.

title: Saatchi Picks Executive To Head Detroit Office
description: Here and there in agencyland there are major personnel changes.

title: Days for the Dodgers
description: Brooklyn embraced its rich baseball history over the weekend and, not surprisingly, its beloved Dodgers were at the heart of the celebration.

title: THE GOLFERS' BEST FRIENDS
description: CADDIES at the United States Open must start their preparations early. Their goal is to be efficient helpers for their golfers, perhaps the way registered nurses are for surgeons in the operating room.

title: Bankrupts in Security Posts
description: Records filed in Federal District Court in Baltimore since 1981 show that 56 Government employees who work in intelligence or other national security positions have declared bankruptcy, according to a newspaper report.

title: Brooklyn Throws a Party
description: For many who filled the streets yesterday, home is a place where people are not afraid to say ''earl'' for ''oil,'' where a baseball team that went west a few decades back still inspires teary-eyed nostalgia, where the native sons savor the jabs almost as much as the compliments.

title: PLAYERS TO WATCH
description: Seve Ballesteros - The Spaniard, playing only his fourth tournament in the United States this year, is always a threat in a major. He has won two British Opens and two Masters tournaments, and some think he is the world's top player right now.

title: HATCHER HAS 4 HITS IN ASTRO VICTORY
description: The right-hander Mike Scott and Dave Smith combined on a five-hitter, and Billy Hatcher went 4 for 5 with a home run to lead the Houston Astros to a 3-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

title: CELTICS TROUNCE ROCKETS, 114-97 FOR 16TH TITLE
description: With Larry Bird at his best and with their capacity home-court crowd in a game-long frenzy, the Boston Celtics won their 16th National Basketball Association championship today.

title: A Perfect Place To Store Memories
description: ''This place is perfect,'' Matthew McGuire said, his voice reverberating up to the 55-foot-high ceiling of the labyrinthine anchorage on the Brooklyn side of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Londonderry Bomb Defused
description: Army explosives experts today defused a 200-pound bomb inside a hijacked truck that was parked in the center of Londonderry, the police said. It was the first bomb incident in Londonderry, a stronghold of resistance to British rule, since November, when a blast for which the Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility damaged a shopping center.

title: The Interloper at Liberty's Party
description: The Statue of Liberty, born of French admiration for liberty in a sister republic and consecrated by Emma Lazarus as the ''Mother of Exiles,'' is soon to be rededicated as the symbol of America's political life and principles. Incredibly and intolerably, Chile's dictatorship has been invited to participate with an ugly symbol of its political style.

title: INCREASED SCHOOLING AND PAY ACCOMPANY RETURN TO BASICS
description: Students and teachers in Westport, Conn., have two additional days in school this year, while 700 teachers in Irvington, N.J., are enjoying pay rises that got them up to the state's new $18,500 minimum salary.

title: Beryl Ann Cowan Becomes a Bride
description: Beryl Ann Cowan, a lawyer, and Dr. Howard B. Frumkin, a physician, were married yesterday at the Vale, a mansion in Waltham, Mass. Rabbi Michael Luckens officiated.

title: SWISS GYPSIES: A TALE OF VANISHING CHILDREN
description: The President of Switzerland has apologized to the nation's 30,000 gypsies for the actions of a Government-backed youth charity that has acknowledged taking more than 600 gypsy children from their parents between 1926 and 1973 for their ''well-being.''

title: A Fleeting Memory
description: Most Washington correspondence is aimed at the masses of journalists and Government aides.

title: Two Names, One Dream
description: Nine days ago, at the United States Football League's tryout camp at Giants Stadium, his name was Ed Washington. He did well enough in basic drills that, among 200 hopefuls who showed up, he was one of only three allowed to attend the Generals' rookie camp two days later. By then, he was Tom Alexander.

title: CENTRAL BANKS' GLOOMY VIEW
description: Western central banks present a generally gloomy view of the world's economic prospects in a new report, saying that despite some improvements the severity of many key problems ''has diminished little, if at all'' over the past year.

title: Florida Legislature Approves Bill to Revise Liability Rules
description: State lawmakers have approved a bill that would reduce liability insurance premiums by at least 40 percent and provide greater supervision of the industry.

title: A Lasting Verdict on Judge Friendly
description: The bench and bar are gathering today to amend legal history in an important way. They want finally to record their professional judgment that Henry Friendly, who died last March 11, was the pre-eminent American jurist. He sat for 27 years on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, including three years as Chief Judge, hearing cases from New York, Connecticut and Vermont. But Judge Friendly's writ ran nationwide.

title: ROCHESTER DEATH BY HEAT STROKE IS INVESTIGATED
description: The State Health Department is investigating the actions of a Rochester hospital where a city official died of heat stroke after running in a 10-kilometer race May 18.

title: AS SHUTTLE INQUIRY CLOSES, CONGRESS IS SET FOR ITS TURN
description: Although the report Monday by the Presidential commission on the space shuttle disaster will end one investigation, it will open an intense Congressional review that is expected to change the way the space agency operates.

title: SWEDES SEEK PALME CASE CLUE IN '76 ASSASSINATION IN U.S.
description: The Stockholm police are reliably understood to have asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to open its files on a 10-year-old assassination of an opponent of President Augusto Pinochet of Chile in hopes of finding leads on the killing this year of the Swedish Prime Minister, Olof Palme.

title: Antismoking Bill Is a Discrimination Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1986
description: The Economy The economy is at its soundest level in two decades, economists and others say, and further growth is expected. Yet great distress is seen in the Farm Belt and the oil patch of Texas and across much of the West's mining and timber country. [ Page D1. ] Retail sales in New York City rose 4 percent in May, according to a spot-check. It was the second-best gain of the year. [ D1. ] Senators will not fight a key part of the tax plan on the floor. Instead, those seeking to preserve the deduction for state and local sales taxes will move in the Senate-House conference. [ D1. ] Insurers are facing a crisis with long-term consequences. The companies are caught in the fallout of price wars of the early 1980's, which will likely affect the cost of insurance for many years. [ D1. ] Companies Anderson, Clayton formally rejected the offer by two New York investment firms to acquire it for $54 a share. The company said it hoped to execute its recapitalization plan soon. [ D2. ] International Japan's central bank has been receiving political heat at home for helping to raise the value of the yen - a move that has resulted in more-expensive exports and lower corporate profits. [ D1. ] Mexico's ability to pay its $98 billion debt may be in jeopardy unless it can recover some of the $50 billion in holdings its citizens have transferred abroad, according to bankers and American officials. [ D4. ] The Mexican Government has started buying back some of its foreign loans at a discount in an effort to encourage outside investment and reduce overall indebtedness.

title: One Killed and 9 Hurt In Fighting in Beirut
description: Heavy fighting erupted tonight between Shiite Amal militiamen and Palestinians defending the Shatila refugee district, and a child was killed, Palestinian witnesses reported.

title: Kohl Asks Help From Reagan To Free 8 Held in Nicaragua
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany has made an appeal to President Reagan to use his influence to gain the release of eight West Germans kidnapped by United States-backed rebels in Nicaragua, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Market Place; Closed-End Country Funds
description: KNOWN on Wall Street as country funds, investment companies that tailor their portfolios primarily to securities of a single foreign country are reaching the new-issue market with increasing speed. These companies are going public in a period when stocks in many foreign countries have enjoyed bull markets of their own.

title: FIVE PROS OFFER THEIR BEST SHOTS
description: BEN CRENSHAW The 34-year-old Crenshaw won the 1984 Masters and is a recognized historian of the game who favors old, traditional courses such as Shinnecock, which he played once in 1973.

title: HOW TO ENJOY THE SHOW
description: FOR visitors to the United States Open at Shinnecock Hills, the 19th hole stretches from Westhampton Beach clear to Montauk. In and around the dozen or so villages that are known collectively as the Hamptons, there are places that offer pleasant dining to suit various tastes and budgets. Along with the fresh fish, lobsters, mussels and clams, there is often a lovely waterfront view as a bonus. Continental dining in a Colonial inn, new American in an elegant barn, huge steaks, chicken and ribs and commendable Chinese fare are some other choices. Pizza, burgers, sushi, tacos and old-fashioned soda-shop sandwiches are also available. But there are very few well-known fast-food operations in the area.

title: INDIA COURT AWAITING BHOPAL SUIT
description: Like its counterparts in the United States, the hulking Tis Hazari courthouse in Old Delhi is a place of human woe. Some 50,000 people, wearing suits or wearing rags, are said to enter its portals each day seeking justice.

title: Peggy Samuels Weds in Florida
description: Peggy Anne Samuels, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Samuels of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Rochester, and Lester L. Schwalb, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Schwalb of Scranton, Pa., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents in Fort Lauderdale. Rabbi Kenneth Hain officiated.

title: 'JANET BAKER,' DOCUMENTARY ON DIVA
description: ''JANET BAKER: FULL CIRCLE,'' which will be shown tonight at 10 o'clock on the Bravo pay-cable service, is a fond, nostalgic television representation of the great English mezzo-soprano's last year on the operatic stage. It is more engrossing than a typical opera-star documentary simply because Miss Baker is more interesting than the typical opera star, but one suspects that viewers will have mixed reactions.

title: Earthen Dike Bursts On Rising Salt Lake
description: The Great Salt Lake, now at its highest recorded level, has burst a dike and is threatening to surge toward an interstate highway and Union Pacific Railroad tracks, officials said today.

title: The Right and Wrong Kinds of Pension Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: REVISITING A NUCLEAR MISHAP
description: WATCHING ''Thirty Years to Justice: An American Nightmare'' (tonight at 10:30 on Channel 13), a viewer is inevitably reminded that danger and death can be an unforeseen byproduct of nuclear mishap from places closer to home than Chernobyl and that nuclear radiation is no respecter of boundaries or political systems.

title: SALES TAX DEDUCTION IS BACKED
description: A group of senators seeking to preserve the deduction for state and local sales taxes said today that they would not try to amend the Senate Finance Committee's tax revision bill on the Senate floor.

title: Advertising; Western Dominance Of Awards
description: NOW there is no doubt about it:

title: REACTION IS MIXED
description: The head of Haiti's provisional Government announced late Saturday night that presidential elections would be held in 17 months, and the reaction today included both praise and criticism.

title: Treasury Offers 3- and 6-Month Bills
description: Treasury financing this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. In advance of the auction, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at 6.32 percent, while the six-month issue was at 6.38 percent.

title: N. Korea May Get Olympic Events
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, said today that some events in the 1988 Summer Olympics, scheduled for Seoul, South Korea, would be offered to North Korea, but under strict conditions.

title: The Poli-preachers
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and the the Rev. Marion G. (''Pat'') Robertson have this in common: neither preacher is really running for the job of President of the United States.

title: Roof and Top Floors Collapse In Lower East Side Building
description: An abandoned seven-story building on the Lower East Side collapsed into itself last night but there were no reports of any injuries, the police reported.

title: Germans Arrest 300 In Antinuclear Protests
description: Nearly 300 people were arrested and several policemen were hurt in clashes today as antinuclear protests in West Germany continued for a second day.

title: ISRAEL OMITS SENDING WALDHEIM A VICTORY NOTE
description: President Chaim Herzog of Israel tonight pointedly omitted sending a congratulatory telegram to Kurt Waldheim on his victory in Austria, as is required by diplomatic protocol.

title: Fed Nomination Pushed
description: Fearing the possibility of a 3-3 tie should a vote to cut the discount rate come before the Federal Reserve Board now, the White House has accelerated efforts to get H. Robert Heller seated on the board.

title: Pope to Visit Argentina
description: Pope John Paul II said today that he would visit Argentina in April and would celebrate the Roman Catholic Church's World Youth Day during his stay there. The Pope disclosed the date for the trip, which will also take him to Chile, before 20,000 people in St. Peter's Square.

title: DARTMOUTH COLLEGE: 2 ARRESTED AT COMMENCEMENT
description: A student activist and the mother of a Dartmouth senior were arrested by the police today at Dartmouth College's commencement ceremony.

title: Felicia Freed Is Married to Jesse Laurance Cohen
description: Felicia Freed, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Freed of Vineland, N.J., was married yesterday to Jesse Laurance Cohen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurance Cohen of New York. Rabbis Judah Nadish and Murray Kohn performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Marilyn Weitzer Weds in Queens
description: Marilyn Weitzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Weitzer of Highland Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Yitzchak Francus, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Israel Francus of New York. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father at the Jewish Center of Jackson Heights in Queens.

title: Kogo Is Winner In Half-Marathon
description: Steve Kogo of the New York Track and Field Circuit won the ninth annual Westchester Half-Marathon today in 1 hour 7 minutes 9 seconds.

title: SUCCESS OF 'TALES FROM THE DARKSIDE'
description: At an abandoned mattress factory in east Los Angeles, Laurel Entertainment has established an unconventional studio for a low-budget but highly successful syndicated television series, ''Tales From the Darkside.''

title: NICKLAUS PLAYS IT HIS WAY
description: ON the third tee at Shinnecock Hills, the world's most famous 46-year-old golfer surveyed the thick trees and bushes down the left side of the 453-yard hole.

title: RUNNERS-UP WON'T TRY HARDER
description: WHEN Greg Norman hit his 4-iron approach to the 72d hole of the Masters tournament wide right into the crowd, there was a slightly delayed but enthusiastic reaction from the huge crowd surrounding the 18th green. The crowd had realized that Jack Nicklaus, who had putted out moments before, was virtually assured of victory.

title: TWAY BIRDIES 18TH, WINS WESTCHESTER
description: Bob Tway lofted a near-perfect sand wedge shot off the fairway and onto the final green today to put his ball 2 feet from the hole. He then stroked the ball into the cup for a birdie 4 to win the 20th annual Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic by one shot over Willie Wood, a former golf teammate at Oklahoma State.

title: VALLONE ASSAILS KOCH BUDGET ON GAP
description: The City Council majority leader accused the Koch administration yesterday of balancing the Mayor's proposed budget ''with blue smoke and mirrors.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1986
description: International

title: INKSTER CAPTURES TOURNAMENT
description: Juli Inkster refused to let one of the worst final rounds she ever played spoil her triumph today in the $450,000 McDonald's Championship tournament.

title: Sampson's Long Day
description: BOSTON history is replete with villains of different sizes and offenses, from George III to the Boston Strangler, but this afternoon they were forgotten, and the rancor of the multitude centered on a new one, a young man in size 17 sneakers.

title: Virgil Thomson Tribute
description: A tribute to the composer Virgil Thomson on his 90th birthday will open the 1986-87 season at Merkin Concert Hall on Sept. 21, Andrew Berger, director of the Hebrew Arts School's concert division, has announced.

title: DENMARK DEFEATS URUGUAY TO GAIN
description: Denmark, making a sensational World Cup debut, used the attacking skills of Preben Elkjaer and Michael Laudrup to beat Uruguay, 6-1, today and become the second team to advance to the second round of the soccer championship.

title: WELCOME TO THE CLUB
description: IT happened in Biarritz in the south of France one day in the winter of 1890, and a few of the lions of New York society were there watching. They were watching the celebrated Scottish sportsman Willie Dunn demonstrate his skill at the mysterious game of golf.

title: REAGAN'S LEGACY HINGES, IN PART, ON NOVEMBER FIGHT FOR THE SENATE
description: The struggle for control of the Senate involves not only the 34 seats at stake, political leaders and analysts say, but whether the Democrats can turn President Reagan into a truly lame duck, by thwarting him in such areas as judicial appointments and his increasingly aggressive and conservative foreign policy.

title: Chadian Leader Says Qaddafi Bars Peace
description: President Hissen Habre said today that he had abandoned all hope of a negotiated end to his country's civil war.

title: Dr. Lisa K. Rubin Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Lisa Karen Rubin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Rubin of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth James Kornblau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules H. Kornblau of New York and Fair Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Leon Fink performed the ceremony at the Seawane Club in Hewlett Harbor.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports yesterday about the World Cup soccer game between Spain and Northern Ireland on Saturday misidentified the player who scored the first goal for Spain. The goal was scored by Emilio Butrageno.

title: MOODS OF AN ANGLER
description: THE longtime angler need not be perturbed if suddenly and for the first time he has no urge to make another weekend walleyed-pike excursion with the boys. His days of fishing aren't done. All he's suffering from is an overdose of walleyes, and after a suitable hiatus he'll probably find them as exciting as before.

title: 4 More Beached Whales Die
description: Four more of the 27 false killer whales grounded off Florida died Saturday, leaving only five survivors, marine experts said today.

title: A ROOT OF MUNICIPAL SCANDALS
description: Few spectacles are quite as entertaining as the public in one of its periodic parades of municipal morality. Reformers strut next to prosecutors, urging new regulations and more disclosure forms. Reporters, columnists and editorialists can't rush fast enough to pen the hoariest cliches about political corruption. What often gets forgotten - it is less colorful, after all - is that scandals occur also because we no longer have any real political parties.

title: In Changes at U S West
description: Few executives encourage competition to the extent of giving up a company's monopoly position, but that is what Jack A. MacAllister has done since the divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation led to the formation of U S West in 1982.

title: A Touch of Twain
description: The new Soviet Ambassador to Washington, Yuri V. Dubinin, arrived in the capital the other day, traveling by Amtrak from New York, where he had served briefly as chief delegate to the United Nations.

title: LENDL WINNER OF FRENCH OPEN
description: Somebody finally figured out how to beat Mikael Pernfors before he ran away with the French Open.

title: FAMILY: BOTH CAUSE OF AND CURE FOR STRESS
description: A new and more complex view of the powerful effects of stress on the nation's families has emerged from a gathering of scholars here. The researchers also offered new insights on the family's paradoxical role in both causing and relieving stress, and underscored the importance of the family in social scientists' attempts to understand how stress affects individuals.

title: WALDHEIM VICTOR IN AUSTRIAN VOTE WITH 53.9 PERCENT
description: Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General of the United Nations, was elected today to a six-year term as Austria's head of state.

title: CITY BALLET: FARRELL IN BALANCHINE'S 'MOZARTIANA'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Mozartiana'' is probably one of his most exalted works, taking its spiritual cue from the score, an homage by Tchaikovsky to Mozart. ''Mozartiana'' requires exalted dancing, too, and it got it in an exhilarating performance by City Ballet Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Jesse Jackson's Monochromatic Politics
description: Even before the polls opened in New Jersey's 10th Congressional District last week, Donald Payne had suffered a loss. The Newark City Councilman, who was looking to unseat veteran Representative Peter Rodino, had already been reduced by the primary campaign from being an impressive challenger to being ''the candidate backed by the Rev. Jesse Jackson.'' And Mr. Jackson insisted on a deplorable choice by race: Mr. Payne's blackness over Mr. Rodino's whiteness. The voters, most of them black, had a keener sense of their interest, including civil rights, and had no qualms about choosing Mr. Rodino.

title: RECRUITING CHASE BEGINS EARLY
description: FOR Bronx-born Rod Strickland, the journey to Division I college basketball began in the fifth grade with a New York-based club team. It continued at two different New York City public high schools, then at Oak Hill Academy in Mouth of Wilson, Va. The journey ended last year when Strickland, a freshman at DePaul, became a starting point guard.

title: A National Primary Just Wouldn't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: WHO THE WINNERS ARE
description: In response to requests from several senators, Senator Bob Packwood released a list of the beneficiaries of transition rules in the Senate tax overhaul bill. It was merely a list of names, with no explanation of who the Senate sponsor was or what rule was being applied. For the record, following are the beneficiaries: Agri-Beef Air Products Albany City Center Alcoa Allegheny Electric Co-op Aloha Tower Development Program Applied Energy Services Archibald Power Arrowhead Springs Arrowhead Stadium Atlanta Stadium Atlanta Underground Project Avon Ball Corporation Pollution Control Baltimore Gas and Electric Baltimore Stadium Bangor solid waste Barbara Jordan 2d Bayonne Co-generation Bayside Center Ben Tillman Redevelopment Project Big Horn Co-generation Bond pooling Bonneville Power Authority Brooklyn Union Gas Buffalo Stadium Cable television Cafeteria plans Cajun II coal-fired generating unit Capital District Energy center Cellular telephones CF Industries ammonia plants Channel Chester Solid Waste Association Church pension plans Cimarron Coal Company CMC/Colt Co-generation projects Commercial National Bank Continental Airlines Control Data Cox Enterprises Dade County Aviation Notes Dallas Rapid Transit Delaware Power and Light Delta Air Lines Diamond Star Project Dineh Power Plant Downtown Denver retail project Duke Power Polution Control Project Dulles Rapid Transit Eastbank Wastewater Treatment Facility Enesco Federal Express Satellites Fiber-optic communications Florida solid waste projects Frankfort Arsenal General Development General Mills General Motors special tool Gilberton Power Company Grand Gulf Nuclear Plant Great Northern Nakoosa Pulp Mill Greenbriar Leasing Harborplace Hawaii Multifamily Housing Projects Hayber Development Hellsgate Hydroelectric Hennepin County Solid Waste Project Hot Springs National Park Houston Astrodome Hydroelectric power Isle of Wight Sports Facility Jacksonville Landing Kansas independent colleges Kern River pipeline Keyser Power Kiel Auditorium Lake Superior Paper Laundry detergent plant Life insurance company Long Lake Energy Corporation Louisiana ESOP's Manhattan, Kan., Urban Development Action Grant projects Manville Corporation M.C.A. title: BRIGHT SIDE OF F.B.I.'S TOUGH YEAR
description: If William H. Webster does not change his mind, President Reagan must soon begin thinking about candidates for Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Webster, in his ninth year as Director, says he will not ask that rules be bent to allow him a second 10-year term.

title: D'AMATO'S ADS TO PORTRAY MAN OF COMPASSION
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato will begin a monthlong $1 million television advertising campaign today that is designed at least partly to portray him as a compassionate politician.

title: Linda Lazarus Wed in Capital
description: Linda Lazarus, an assistant corporation counsel for the District of Columbia, and Andrew Jay Schwartzman, a public interest telecommunications lawyer in Washington, were married yesterday at the Calvert Collection in Washington. Rabbi Harold S. White, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Everett C. Parker, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at the ceremony.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: WHEN THEY TEE OFF
description: Pairings and starting times (E.D.T.) for the first and second rounds of the 86th United States Open Thursday and Friday at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Southampton, N.Y. (*-Denotes amateur). 7 A.M., 11:29 A.M. - Bob Eaks, Colorado Springs, Colo.; Wayne Smith, Alpharetta, Ga.; Thomas Cleaver, Tampa, Fla. 7:09 A.M., 11:38 A.M. - Scott Williams, Renton, Wash.; Roy Biancalana, Lemont, Ill.; Jeff Maggert, Woodlands, Texas. 7:18 A.M., 11:47 A.M. -

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Ability wins and they had the best team.'' - Ralph Sampson of the Houston Rockets, speaking about Boston Celtics. [ C6:2. ]

title: BIRD DOES IT ALL IN SPECTACULAR FINALE
description: Watching Larry Bird perform must be very much like being on the same court with him, only safer. The unfortunate teammate who looks away or relaxes for just an instant may get smacked in the temple with the basketball. Bird doesn't take it well when one of his passes is fumbled out of bounds. He glares disdainfully at the offender.

title: MAY RETAIL SALES IN CITY GAINED 4%
description: May retail sales in New York City rose 4 percent over sales in May 1985, a spot-check of seven major retailers has found. The advance was the year's second-best after a 6.6 percent increase in March.

title: Elena Carousis Is Wed To Dr. Harry Coniaris
description: Elena Michals Carousis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Louis Carousis of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Harry John Coniaris, a son of Mrs. John Coniaris of Maplewood, N.J., and the late Dr. John Coniaris. The Rev. Alexander Leondis performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in Westfield, N.J.

title: THAI CHIEF WON'T ENTER ELECTION
description: Thailand's Prime Minister, Prem Tinsulanonda, announced today that he would not run for a legislative seat in the election on July 27.

title: Red Sox Are Beaten, 7-3, by Brewers and Leary
description: Tim Leary pitched eight shutout innings before needing relief help, and Ben Oglivie drove in three runs as the Brewers defeated the Boston Red Sox, 7-3, today.

title: JUNKYARD OPERATORS FINDING 'JUST NO OPPORTUNITY LEFT'
description: For generations, the junkyard has been part of the national scene: part treasure trove, part social center, a hunting ground of rusting steel hulks where teen-agers and other amateur mechanics ferret out spare parts and then, like modern organ transplant surgeons, use them to bring new life to faltering old cars.

title: Dianne Miller, a Teacher, Is Wed to Paul Ruderman
description: Dianne Miller, an elementary schoolteacher, and Paul Ruderman, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Camelback Inn in Scottsdale, Ariz. Rabbi Herbert Silberman officiated.

title: Washington Watch; Commissioners In Trade Fight
description: THE guard is about to change at the International Trade Commission, the Federal agency that helps decide the height of the nation's tariff walls.

title: New Woolcott President
description: Andrew J. Melnick has been named president and chief operating officer of Woolcott & Company, a New York investment banking firm specializing in services for small and medium-size companies. Mr. Melnick is currently director of research at L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin. Lawrence J. Twill, chairman and chief executive of Wolcott, announced the appointment on Friday.

title: Police Find Dynamite In New Haven Garage
description: More than 700 pounds of dynamite and explosives paraphenalia was discovered yesterday morning in a garage that had been rented behind a building on the edge of downtown New Haven, the police said.

title: 3-DAY WEDDINGS JOIN THE MARRIAGE SEASON
description: Here comes the bride all dressed in white. Here comes the bride again dressed in Nikes. And again in a bathing suit, in blue jeans, a cocktail dress, a life preserver for white-water rafting. This is the age of the weekend wedding, the wedding that lasts longer than some marriages.

title: JAPANESE CENTRAL BANK TAKING POLITICAL HEAT
description: The Bank of Japan is normally not a subject taken up by the Japanese tabloids. But some weeks ago, a magazine known for its tantalizing photos of starlets published a two-page spread on a high-ranking bank official, complete with a fuzzy picture of the official walking his dog.

title: Senator Misses a Putt
description: It is the time of year when Washingtonians begin to plot their escapes in earnest. Primaries are proceeding apace, the general election is not far off, and the agencies grind on through hot weather and cool.

title: In Search of a Publisher
description: Nine Republican members of the House, each the author of a chapter, have completed a manuscript on better ways to run the Government, particularly the House of Representatives. ''It's about why we need to reform the rules and procedures of the House,'' said one of the authors, Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi of Westchester.

title: Brooklyn Center Season
description: Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College will present 24 events - 8 music, 8 dance and 8 pops - in its 1986-87 season, which begins in October.

title: A Sect's Survivors
description: It was not hard to spot Sister Frances at a crowded reception the other night at the Museum of American Folk Art. Among the pinstriped suits, ropes of pearls and dangling earrings, she was in simple Shaker fashion - a light purple dress buttoned up to the throat.

title: Terrorists Aren't the Only Risks on Cruise Ships and Airplanes
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Company, Hartford, named Robert B. Nicholas senior vice president to head the corporate planning and development department.

title: City Opera Orchestra Ratifies 3-Year Contract
description: The New York City Opera Orchestra ratified a new three-year contract over the weekend. The agreement calls for 5 1/2 percent wage increases for each of the first two years and 5 percent for the third year.

title: More Ad Clients Edgy About Huge Mergers
description: Advertiser dissatisfaction with the results of megamergers appears to be spreading.

title: CHUBB PUTS THREE IN EXECUTIVE OFFICE
description: The Chubb Corporation, a major insurance company, has made some changes at the top, naming Percy Chubb 3d to the new post of vice chairman and Dean R. O'Hare president.

title: Record World Bank Profit
description: Like its commercial siblings, the World Bank, which is a publicly owned institution of 150 governments, tends to make a lot of money when interest rates are declining. The rates banks charge on their loans never go down as fast as their cost of borrowing - resulting in the wider ''spread'' that increases profitability, experts say.

title: Victory Takes $37 LNC Offer
description: Victory Markets Inc., a New York State supermarket chain, agreed yesterday to be acquired by LNC Industries Proprietary Ltd. for $37 a share, or a total of about $69 million.

title: HOW TO SEE THE ACTION
description: NEVER before has a United States Open course provided the panoramic view of so many holes as Shinnecock Hills offers to the 18,000 spectators who will fill the grand course each day. If a battle to the wire becomes reality late Sunday afternoon, most of the fans will be crowded on the clubhouse hill or below the 18th green intent upon the action playing over 16, 17 and 18. They will certainly be gathered there to watch the leader play up the hill to the 18th green even if the issue is settled before then.

title: WYOMING SEEKS U.S. HELP TO REPAIR LEAKY DAM
description: Among Western water projects, the Fontenelle Dam has never been much of a success.

title: CORRECTION
description: Articles on May 15 and May 16 about ABC's and NBC's use of film that was fraudulently said to show the Chernobyl nuclear plant misidentified the seller of the film. It was not an Italian photo agency named Albatross; a 24-year-old Frenchman, Thomas Garenq, was arrested in Italy and charged with fraud in connection with the incident, but was released after the networks decided against pressing charges.

title: LARCHMONT'S FOREIGN COLONY ADDS A GALLIC TOUCH
description: In summer, visitors to the beach here are more likely to imagine themselves in Antibes than on Long Island Sound. The neighborhood specialty food shop has taken to stocking lapin, or rabbit, as Americans like to say. And the guest list for Newcomers Club luncheons often reads like a page from a French phone book.

title: Telephone Talks Proceeding With Aid of Federal Mediator
description: Negotiations between the American Telephone & Telegraph Company and striking communications workers, assisted by a Federal mediator over the weekend, were ''moving forward,'' a union spokesman said today.

title: Judge Cites Robins Error
description: A Federal judge said Saturday that it was clear the A. H. Robins Company improperly paid certain debts last summer after entering bankruptcy court in the wake of mounting claims against its Dalkon Shield contraceptive device.

title: HEMPSTEAD TO ENDEAR
description: Woody Stephens, fresh from sending out Danzig Connection to win the Belmont Stakes Saturday, scored again at Belmont Park yesterday when he saddled Endear to a six-length upset victory over heavily favored Lady's Secret in the $140,250 Hempstead Handicap.

title: EAST GERMANY IS CANCELING CONTESTED CHECK AT BORDER
description: East Germany has told embassies in East Berlin that it will issue them new diplomatic passes and stop passport checks on the border with West Berlin, Western diplomats said today.

title: WILLIAMS COLLEGE: CAUTION ON SCIENCE IS OFFERED
description: Key questions about science's effect on society and humanity lie ahead, Zbigniew Brzezinski told more than 500 graduating seniors at Williams College today.

title: Carrie Feiner a Bride
description: Carrie Feiner, a pianist and music consultant, and Michael Howard Trenk, an actuary for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company in New York, were married yesterday at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Louis Gerstein officiated. Mrs. Trenk, who will retain her name professionally, is a graduate of the Mannes College of Music and received a master's degree from the Juilliard School. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Feiner of Scarsdale, N.Y. Mr. Trenk, who received bachelors' degrees cum laude in economics and mathematics from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: REJECTION CALLED MOTIVE IN ATTACK ON CITY MODEL
description: Hostility between Marla Hanson and the former landlord charged with hiring two men to slash her face with a razor apparently stemmed from her rejection of his sexual advances as well as a dispute over an $850 security deposit, investigators said yesterday.

title: Death in an Undertow In First Tropical Storm
description: An undertow caused by Tropical Storm Andrew has swept a woman out to sea where she drowned, and dozens of other swimmers were caught in the current, the authorities said.

title: Argentine Devaluation
description: The central bank devalued the austral 1.15 percent against the dollar Friday.

title: Terrorists Aren't the Only Risks on Cruise Ships and Airplanes
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Engagement
description: Foreign policy has been the subject of much debate as Democrats try to chart new directions for their party.

title: Board Rebuffs Wall St. Firms' Bid
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company said today that its directors, during a weekend meeting, formally rejected the offer by two New York investment firms to acquire the company for $54 a share. The company said it hoped to execute its own recapitalization plan soon.

title: Levine, Huntley Wins A Fast-Food Account
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver has won its first fast-food account: Whataburger Inc. of Corpus Christi, Tex., which operates 400 eateries in the Sun Belt and spends more than $3 million a year on advertising.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE OUTSIDE STORY: How Democrats and Republicans Elected Reagan. By Richard Brookhiser. 299 pages. Doubleday. $17.95.

title: ARISTS' UNION TO PROTEST TAX BILL
description: Warning that the Senate Finance Committee's proposed tax bill would have a ''devastating'' impact on their members, three major unions representing performing artists are mobilizing to protest changes they contend would unfairly penalize performers.

title: AT ANDERSON, A CLAYTON FEALTY
description: William L. Clayton made his wealth by building what, in his day, was the world's largest cotton-trading company. The company grew to become a billion-dollar conglomerate, with interests in insurance, food and trucking.

title: A CHILD'S DEMANDS AFTER A DIVORCE
description: SEVEN-YEAR-OLD Jeffrey Keating asked his divorced father, John, to buy him a video game on their first visit together. The Chicago executive complied, and the next Saturday, Jeffrey asked his father for a bicycle. The child got that too and then hinted that he wanted a certain computer for his birthday. Mr. Keating dipped into his savings and purchased the $1,500 model.

title: Capital Flight Adds to Burden of Debtor Nations
description: Bankers, politicians and economists differ over how to combat capital flight, in part because they cannot even agree on how to define it.

title: THE 4 DEADLY FALLACIES, PATHETIC AND OTHERWISE
description: THERE is a little joke that never gets explained in James Atlas's amusing first novel, ''The Great Pretender,'' about a culture-ridden young man who takes forever to break clear of intellectual pretension. In a poetry course at Harvard, the teacher remarks of a poem the young man has submitted: ''And this pathetic fallacy: 'The stars' mad vacant stare.' It's too bizarre. The reader balks.'' Misunderstanding the teacher's remark, the student asks himself, ''Was my work pathetic, then, on top of everything else?''

title: Getting to the U.S. Open
description: LONG ISLAND RAILROAD

title: Tainted Frozen Pasta Recalled in Northeast
description: A frozen-food manufacturer has recalled lasagna and stuffed-shell products after outbreaks of food poisoning in New York and New Jersey, company and state officials said.

title: A TIE TO THE PAST
description: RESTING on high, sandy land on the eastern end of Long Island, the Shinnecock Hills golf course spills forth in grand style from the north side of its old Stanford White clubhouse, a throwback to the Scottish courses associated with the game's origins.

title: Ex-Astronaut Is Better After a Heart Seizure
description: James B. Irwin, the former astronaut, was awake but ''rather confused'' today, two days after suffering cardiac arrest.

title: PROGRESS, THEN A PAUSE FOR ONE PLAYER
description: Professional, college and high school programs share a common need for supple bodies. This need is the magnet that draws pools of talent from level to level, though few athletes and parents understand the nature of the relationships until high school.

title: PERES SEES EFFORT IN U.S. SPY INQUIRY TO MAR ISRAELI TIES
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel today denounced attempts to ''foul the atmosphere'' between Israel and the United States with suggestions that Israeli spying in America was more extensive than Israel has said it was.

title: INSURANCE INDUSTRY UNDER FIRE
description: Five or six years ago, when interest rates were the highest since the Civil War, the insurance industry saw an opportunity to make a killing.

title: NEW YORK LAW SCHOOL: JUSTICE BRENNAN ADVOCATES PUBLIC SERVICE
description: Calling lawyers ''uniquely situated to play a creative role in American social progress,'' Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court of the United States told graduates of New York Law School yesterday that ''every lawyer should have at any given time at least one public-service project'' in progress.

title: Put the Indian Museum in the Custom House
description: To the Editor:

title: TERRORISM AS VIEWED BY YOUTHS
description: The Foreign Policy Association, a New York-based group that encourages the study of global affairs, invited high school students in the New York area a few months ago to compete for awards by writing essays on any of six international topics.

title: MEXICO'S LOSS OF ASSETS IMPERIlS DEBT PLAN... AS ITS GOVERNMENT BUYS BACK SOME LOANS
description: When the Senate Foreign Relations Committee takes up the issue of Mexico's economic situation on Tuesday, a major focus is expected to be the huge amount of funds that have left the country.

title: Bridge: A Homecoming at Hofstra For Former Football Player
description: For one of the contestants, the Long Island Regional Championships in Hempstead, L.I., in May made for a nostalgic homecoming.

title: 2 ARE SHOT DEAD INSIDE VAN
description: Two men were shot dead in the back of a van in a Bronx parking lot early yesterday after they had been abducted on a Queens street, according to the police.

title: STAGE: A NEW COMEDY, 'THE NICE AND THE NASTY'
description: SMART and funny writers don't automatically write smart and funny plays. In ''The Nice and the Nasty,'' his new comedy at Playwrights Horizons, the talented Mark O'Donnell unleashes an almost nonstop barrage of erudite barbs - all aimed at such unassailable contemporary nemeses as greed, pollution and apocalyptic warfare. The play has a considered style as well: it's written in knowing absurdist parody of Hollywood kitsch, complete with a set (by Loren Sherman) that could be the glassy corporate Manhattan of the Doris Day-Rock Hudson comedies in midnuclear meltdown. But ''The Nice and the Nasty'' has two deficiencies that all the sophistication, cleverness and social conscience in the world cannot remedy - it isn't funny enough, and it isn't theater.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In the history of the N.B.A championship series, how much of an advantage has the home court provided?

title: CALMER TRADING IS EXPECTED
description: Battered for the past two weeks by erratic price movements and panic-style trading, the credit markets seem poised for a return this week to activity based on a more sober assessment of economic fundamentals.

title: CHINESE STUDENTS THRIVE AT SEWARD PARK HIGH
description: When Min Xiang Jiang arrived in New York from his village in China, he confronted a language he did not understand, a school where he was expected to shed his shyness and new friends who listened to something called ''hard rock.''

title: MORE THAN THE BIBLE AT ISSUE AS SOUTHERN BAPTISTS GATHER
description: The Southern Baptist Convention's annual meeting, which opens in Atlanta Tuesday, will likely present a Faulknerian drama of ambitious outsiders slowly wresting power from more established, privileged insiders.

title: Housing by 92d St. Y
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO'S PLAN FOR TESTING DOCTORS IS PART OF GROWING NATIONAL EFFORT
description: Governor Cuomo's proposal to make New York the first state to require periodic reviews of physicians' competence is part of a growing national effort to monitor doctors more rigorously.

title: Curbing Booster Abuses
description: When the National Collegiate Athletic Association learns about money passed from a booster to a student athlete, the athlete and his school find themselves in hot water. Since the N.C.A.A.'s jurisdiction ends at the campus gates, however, the booster suffers very little burn at all.

title: THOUSANDS OF MARCOS SUPPORTERS BATTLE THE POLICE IN MANILA STREETS
description: Thousands of supporters of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos fought antiriot forces in a running street battle here today for the second time in a week.

title: WHEN THE TAX RULES DON'T QUITE FIT
description: The tax bill before the Senate this week is one of the most sweeping pieces of legislation Congress has considered in years. A 1,489-page opus, it would completely overhaul the Federal income tax system and affect the taxes paid by nearly every person and company in America.

title: Mayor Plans Awards For Liberty Weekend
description: Mayor Koch, critical of the organizers of Liberty Weekend's plans to give medals to only a dozen prominent naturalized citizens, said last night that he would host a separate awards ceremony and give medals to 70 citizens who ''represent mainstream immigration.''

title: ICEE-USA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Why Local TV News Covers Crime So Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Rostenkowski Fined $555
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was fined $555 today after pleading guilty to driving drunk while returning from a high school reunion June 1. The Illinois Democrat did not appear in Racine County Traffic and Misdemeanor Court but was represented by a Milwaukee lawyer, David P. Lowe. Under state law for first-time drunken driving offenders, Mr. Rostenkowski automatically had his Wisconsin driving privileges suspended for six months.

title: PIONEER IN ECONOMETRICS AT M.I.T.
description: Prof. Edwin Kuh, a pioneer in the field of econometric studies who taught at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for over 30 years, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Cambridge. He was 61 years old. Professor Kuh was widely known for his work with econometric models to forecast production, savings, investment, business cycle, unemployment and related functions. He became a full professor of economics and finance in 1962 and held dual appointments at M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management and the Department of Economics.

title: Don't Weep for I.R.A. Deductions
description: What? Cut back on tax-sheltered Individual Retirement Accounts? That has become the most controversial aspect of the Senate Finance Committee's admirable tax reform. It shouldn't be. The bill would bestow dozens of special-interest favors that are more offensive. The I.R.A. changes would not, as critics charge, rob middle-class Americans of their savings.

title: Pentagon; Navy Seeks to Save Its Autonomous Ships
description: Ever since the days of John Paul Jones, American naval officers have believed that their service is different from other branches of the armed forces and should be given the autonomy to operate on its own. In that belief, the Navy has felt that no naval vessel or unit should ever be placed under the control of an Army or Air Force officer.

title: Five Arrested in Slaying of 2 After an Abduction in Queens
description: Four teen-agers and a 22-year-old man were arrested yesterday in the killing of two men inside a van in a Bronx parking lot early Sunday, the police said. A woman, also shot at the time, remained in critical condition.

title: REFLECTONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $469,118 for the quarter and $703,641 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $93,324 for the quarter and $461,396 for the year. d-Net income.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $75,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months. c-After tax credits of $64,000 for the quarter and $281,000 for the 9 months.

title: IN SEOUL, LEGISLATURE BEGINS TO DEBATE CHARTER REVISION
description: Legislators from the governing and opposition parties formally opened debate today on revising the nation's Constitution.

title: REINVENTING SUPERMAN: HE'LL BE UPWARDLY MOBILE
description: What kryptonite, Lex Luthor and the Metropolis underworld have been unable to do in 48 years, DC Comics is about to do, if only temporarily: knock Superman out of circulation.

title: AUSTRIAN QUITS AS CHANCELLOR OVER LOST VOTE
description: The Chancellor of Austria, a Socialist, resigned today, a day after Kurt Waldheim won election to the largely ceremonial post of President.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Exeter Foods to Marvin & Leonard Advertising, Boston, for Howard Johnson brand packaged foods.

title: Boycotting the French
description: The owner of two radio stations in New York's Westchester County says he will boycott a French Embassy dinner to protest the French refusal to allow the United States use of its air space in the American bombings of Libya.

title: BLUE CROSS REPORTS SAVINGS
description: Blue Cross and Blue Shield asserted today that it saved subscribers $9.7 billion in 1985 through shortened hospital stays and other measures.

title: Sutton Gains 299th Victory
description: Don Sutton, backed by Doug DeCinces' three-run homer, pitched a two-hitter for his 299th career victory, leading the California Angels to a 3-0 victory tonight over the Chicago White Sox.

title: EVIDENCE OF SYRIAN LINK TO TERROR STILL MURKY
description: White House and Reagan Administration officials have concluded that although Syria's involvement in terrorism may be ''much more professional, much more deadly'' than Libya's, the evidence remains murky about Syria's direct links to recent acts of violence.

title: UNITED EDUCATION & SOFTARE reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $38,000 for the latest quarter and $30,000 for year- ago period.

title: Rodino Sees Possibility Of Insurance 'Gouging'
description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee said today that an investigation of insurance company premiums and payouts suggests ''price gouging and bloated profits'' by the industry for the past 10 years.

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: 24-Hour Gambling Bill Tabled by Senate Panel
description: A bill to allow 24-hour gambling at Atlantic City casinos for a 15-month trial was tabled today by a State Senate committee, and the committee chairman said he considered the measure dead.

title: Junior Achievement
description: At his current pace, Jose Canseco of Oakland will finish the season with 151 runs batted in, a record for a major league rookie. These are the players who have driven in at least 100 runs in their first season:

title: BIOTECH RESEARCH LABORATOIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Comings and Goings
description: Donald Carter, the owner of the Dallas Sidekicks, folded his Major Indoor Soccer League team after he failed to find a suitable buyer for the franchise. . . . The Cleveland Indians have suspended Julio Franco for two games without pay - $3,194 - and fined him an additional $200 for missing Sunday's game with California. Manager Pat Corrales said Franco's absence was because of personal problems and ''had nothing to do with drugs or alcohol.''

title: G.M. Research Awards
description: Three scientists whose discoveries produced important advances in understanding and treating cancer and insights into the biology of life were named winners yesterday of the General Motors Research Foundation prizes for 1986.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HOUSTON OIL FIELDS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TEXSTYRENE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $356,651, or $3.57 a share. The common shares outstanding figures give retroactive effect to a 20- for-1 stock exchange.

title: ANONYMOUS LETTERS TO F.B.I. PRESENTED IN ESPIONAGE TRIAL
description: Prosecutors in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth today introduced a series of four letters they hope will convince the jury that Mr. Whitworth knowingly participated in a Soviet spy ring.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Dutiful in Austria
description: Like Kurt Waldheim during Hitler's war, a majority of Austrian voters have done what they took to be their patriotic duty. By a margin of 54 to 46, they elected Mr. Waldheim President, as if to exonerate all Austria of complicity in Nazi atrocities. Since the office is chiefly ceremonial, their choice is mainly symbolic - but what a symbol! Austrians have put a conspicuously flawed figure on their highest pedestal.

title: Ex-Nynex Aide Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted an employee of the Nynex Mobile Communications Company, accusing him of accepting more than $70,000 in bribes from a construction company under contract with Nynex.

title: Jacobs, Pickens
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said he had agreed to pay T. Boone Pickens the proceeds exceeding $21 a share from the sale of his 15.2 percent stake in the Pioneer Corporation. In March, Mr. Pickens, the chairman of Mesa Petroleum, acquired the option to buy the five million Pioneer common shares held by Mr. Jacobs. That agreement, which is amended by the new arrangement, ended the battle between the two investors for control of Pioneer, which Mr. Pickens acquired in a complicated deal valued at up to $860 million.

title: NASA's Rigorous, Vigorous Judges
description: Why did the flight of the shuttle Challenger end in disaster? The immediate cause was a rubber seal; its fundamental cause was the management of NASA. In diligently tracing the link between the two, the Presidential commission led by William Rogers has provided a rich, many-layered explanation that helps explain the past and prepare for NASA's very different future.

title: TRANSMATION INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $62,300, or 3 cents a share.

title: Coastguardsmen Told To Shed Their Beards
description: Bearded Coast Guard personnel have six days to shave their faces clean.

title: A Viewer's Guide to the Senate
description: To help the uninformed who tune in to newly televised Senate sessions, the Senate Republican Policy Committee has put out a booklet that explains such arcane matters of procedure as cloture, markups and motions to reconsider. It is rather dry reading, but sprinked here and there are some fascinating historical tidbits. To wit:

title: SUPERIOR HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
