description: The company said that the previous year losses represented those of Bycom Systems Inc., a telecommunications construction company which, as a result of an Aug. 22, 1985, reorganization, is now a subsidiary of Superior Holding. The current year results include both the new telephone wire and cable manufacturing subsidiary, Superior Cable Corporation, which has generated profits in the seven months since its acquisition in August, and the scaled-back Bycom construction subsidiary which incurred losses of approximately $2.4 million during the year, substantially all of which occurred prior to the reorganization.

title: BANK AID UNLIKELY FOR MEXICO
description: Central banks are reluctant to bail out Mexico a second time in five years, and they apparently see that country's latest crisis as an opportunity to force the Government to put its economic house in order.

title: FLORIDA INSURERS ASSAIL PREMIUM ROLLBACK BILL
description: The insurance industry sharply criticized yesterday a measure enacted by the Florida Legislature mandating a 40 percent rollback in commercial premiums and making future price increases more difficult. Insurers say the law would make underwriting in Florida unprofitable and they feared other states would follow suit.

title: MASON HOFFENBERG
description: Mason Hoffenberg, a poet who was best-known as the co-author, with Terry Southern, of the 1964 novel ''Candy,'' died of lung cancer June 1 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in New York.

title: CANADA IS ELIMINATED WITHOUT SCORING
description: Canada completed its first trip to the World Cup with a 2-0 loss to the Soviet Union today.

title: SILVAR-LISCO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Bankers Stress Accord
description: Bankers in New York said yesterday that it was crucial that Mexico quickly reach a lending agreement with the I.M.F. to keep from falling behind on its interest payments. A team of top Mexican officials is expected to travel to Washington this week to try to reach such an accord.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A RUSSIAN 'WOLF' STOPS IN ALBANY
description: Natalia Sats stepped out on the stage of the Moscow Arts Theater as narrator in the first performance of ''Peter and the Wolf,'' the symphonic fairytale written at her suggestion by Sergei Prokofiev.

title: Advertising; New Magazine On Arthritis
description: First in 1984 there was Chocolatier, a magazine for chocoholics with mouth-watering cover art. Then came Ahoy!, a magazine for owners of Commodore computers.

title: Arizona Offers Revenue Bonds
description: The Arizona Department of Transportation is tentatively offering $225 million of revenue and refunding bonds to yield as high as 7.96 percent for an 7 7/8 issue due in 2001 at a price of 99 1/4.

title: A SOLEMN TRIBUTE TO HENRY FRIENDLY, A QUIET GIANT OF THE APPEALS BENCH
description: They came to celebrate the intricacies of a brilliant legal mind.

title: TANDY PLANS FOREIGN RETAIL SPINOFF
description: The Tandy Corporation said today that its board of directors had approved a plan to spin off its international retail operation, turning it into a new publicly held company. The new company, Intertan Inc., will be created through the issuance, in the form of a tax-free dividend, of one share of Intertan common stock for each 10 shares of Tandy stock owned.

title: Metromedia May Sell Paging Unit
description: Metromedia Inc., the communications giant that has been divesting itself of assets since it went private in 1984, said it had hired Morgan Stanley & Company to explore the sale of its radio paging and cellular mobile telephone business, the company's last remaining large asset.

title: DEBUT IN BLUE: POLICE CADETS START TRAINING
description: Crystal Warden sat on a ledge in the bright noon sun on East 20th Street yesterday, reading a paperback book titled ''Cops: Their Lives in Their Own Words.''

title: OBSCENTIY DEBATE FOCUSES ATTENTION ON MAINE, WHERE VOTERS WEIGH ISSUE
description: A statewide referendum on obscenity Tuesday is drawing the attention of civil libertarians around the country. They describe the vote as an unusual test of public attitudes at a time of increasing debate about a link between obscene materials and rape and child abuse.

title: Police in India Detain 600 Hindu Protesters
description: The police detained about 600 Hindu protesters near Parliament today who were demanding military rule in four districts of the Punjab that are considered strongholds of militants.

title: MCCLAIN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LETTER UNRAVELED LEVINE CASE
description: An anonymous letter sent from Caracas, Venezuela, to the Manhattan headquarters of Merrill Lynch & Company in May 1985 was the key to piecing together the insider trading case that resulted in the guilty plea of Dennis B. Levine last week, according to a number of Government and outside lawyers involved in the case.

title: Chess: Alburt Wins 2-1 Game Playoff Against Speelman in London
description: Lev Alburt of New York, the United States champion, has won the second United States-United Kingdom challenge match in London.

title: Iowa Plans Yield Of 4.55% on Notes
description: Iowa, which has no outstanding long-term bonds, is offering short-term tax and revenue anticipation notes for the second consecutive year.

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Greenpeace Ship Off Norway Loses Contact With Her Base
description: The Greenpeace antiwhaling ship Moby Dick lost radio contact with her Hamburg base while battling heavy seas off the northern coast of Norway, the environmental organization said today.

title: 52 Vietnamese Rescued
description: A West German rescue ship picked up 52 Vietnamese refugees today, including a 17-day-old baby from a fishing vessel adrift in the South China Sea, the relief agency Cap Anamur said. The relief ship, the Cap Anamur II, rescued 77 refugees in a similar operation two days ago.

title: FOR THE BRONX, A NEW IMAGE IS A TOUGH SELL
description: Like other national institutions of higher learning competing for top students, Fordham University has to sell itself. Unlike most other schools, it also has to sell the Bronx.

title: Careers; Combining Studies in U.S., Japan
description: SMALL, new graduate programs do not necessarily indicate a trend, but they can be pacesetters. The University of Rochester's Graduate School of Management recently started a program with Keio University in Yokohama, a leading Japanese school.

title: RIGHT UPHELD TO PRESENT SITUATION AT CONFESSION
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a criminal defendant has a constitutional right to present testimony to a jury about how the police obtained his confession to support his argument that it was not true.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMAX Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a producer of minerals and metals, has apppointed Robin A. Boyer senior vice president of the company and managing director of its mineral and metals sales division.

title: U.S.F.L. Trial Is Postponed
description: Testimony in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League was postponed yesterday when Harvey Myerson, the U.S.F.L.'s lead counsel, could not appear in court because of a stomach virus.

title: SPORTING LIFE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $46,000. c-Includes tax credits of $92,400 for the quarter and $187,400 for the 9 months.

title: AFRICANS ACCUSE CHINESE OF RACISM
description: A noisy campus party celebrating African Liberation Day provided the spark for a confrontation between the authorities and African students, who used the occasion to charge that their treatment in China was racist.

title: Top Arizona Utility To Buy Thrift Unit
description: In a move that startled banking and utilities analysts, AZP Group Inc., the holding company for Arizona's largest utility, agreed yesterday to acquire Merabank, Arizona's largest thrift institution, for $51 a share, or about $440 million.

title: HIGH COURT UPSETS U.S. INTERVENTION ON INFANTS' LIVES
description: The Supreme Court today invalidated Reagan Administration regulations that were designed to require life-prolonging medical treatment for newborn infants with severe handicaps.

title: Lesotho to Deport Rebels
description: About 40 members of the African National Congress, which is seeking to end the South African system of apartheid, were rounded up today and taken to a transit center for deportation to Zambia. The 30 men were kept at the center until departure on Thursday; the 10 women were sent home for the night. The 40 were among 63 South African blacks told last week that they would be expelled on June 14.

title: Shame on Austria
description: Now that Kurt Waldheim has been elected president of Austria, the international community must, sadly, heed the observation of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, that his election amounts to an act of symbolic amnesty for the Holocaust.

title: The U.N. Today: June 10, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHIEF OF SEAGRAM WINE LURED TO NAPA VALLEY
description: Richard Maher, who is about to become president of the distributor for the Christian Brothers brandy and wines, said he was looking forward to the move as a homecoming to the Napa Valley. He is moving to a much smaller operation at a critical time.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $145,000. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $353,000 for the quarter and $376,000 for the 9 months. The 1985 results have been restated to reflect the disposal of the SL Modern Creative and SL Electronics divisions and SL Homalite Corporation and a 1985 pooling of interests. The share earnings for the year-ago results have been adjusted for a 6 percent stock dividend declared in October 1985 and distributed in November 1985 and a 4-for-3 stock split distributed in February 1986.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $1,006,000 for the quarter and the 9 months.

title: CPAC INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The 1985 results represent 12 months for Cpac Inc., and 6 months for its Trebla Chemical subsidiary, purchased in October 1984, through an exchange of stock.

title: STERLING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-The company went public May 21 and did not report figures for the comparable year-ago period.

title: DOW DROPS BY 45.75, A RECORD
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell nearly 46 points yesterday, the biggest one-day point loss in its history, as major investment houses, relying on computerized trading programs, sold shares heavily.

title: China Clothing Exports
description: China's clothing exports in the first five months of 1986 totaled $550 million, about half the $1.02 billion value for all last year, the New China News Agency said today. But the quality of clothing (China's No. 2 export after crude oil) must improve for further growth, the official agency added.

title: Unveiling a Secretive Agency
description: Though it is concerned with neither military nor intelligence matters, the International Monetary Fund is one of the most secretive organizations in Washington.

title: BOTNICK ADMITS LIE TO HEALTH AGENCY
description: Victor E. Botnick, the mayoral aide who admitted misrepresenting his educational background to reporters and on one city document, said yesterday that he had lied about his background on at least one other occasion.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: BELUSHI FRIEND TO ADMIT HER GUILT IN PLEA BARGAIN
description: The woman who gave John Belushi an injection of drugs the night he died plans to plead guilty to involuntary manslaughter, attorneys said today.

title: 'Loot' to Close Saturday
description: ''Loot,'' the revival of Joe Orton's 1966 farce, will close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Music Box Theater. Directed by John Tillinger, the play will have run for five previews and 80 regular performances.

title: THE 'IMPORTANT' BLOUSE SCORES
description: Call them blouses this season, not shirts. The styling is simple enough -soft turtlenecks and surplice effects are prominent - but the fabrics are luxurious silk satin or crepe, and the colors are white or black.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy & Mather Unit Buys Virginia Agency
description: Ogilvy & Mather Direct, a property of the Ogilvy Group, has acquired the Targeted Communications Corporation of Vienna, Va., which is an advocacy agency that works on the projects level.

title: ISRAEL RECALLS ENVOY
description: President Reagan joined a variety of foreign leaders today in congratulating Kurt Waldheim on his election as President of Austria.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Aquino Repeats Charge Of Marcos Intervention
description: President Corazon C. Aquino reiterated accusations today that Ferdinand E. Marcos was directing and financing anti-Government demonstrations with money stolen from the Filipino people.

title: INFANT DEATH RATE IS HIGH IN WELFARE HOTELS
description: The infant mortality rate in New York City's welfare hotels surpassed the rates of the poorest neighborhoods in the city and even of some poor, developing nations between 1982 and 1984, according to a recent study by the City Health Department.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
ROVING YOUTHS ROB 30 AFTER CONCERTS AT GARDEN
description: Roving youths, sometimes in packs of up to 20 people, swept through the streets around Madison Square Garden and Times Square Sunday night during and after a rock concert and robbed about 30 people of purses, chains and other jewelry, the police said yesterday.

title: Program Trading
description: Program trading, a subject of considerable controvery on Wall Street, is not so complicated as it seems, even though it takes a computer to do it.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Playing Hockey By the Rules
description: The rinks of the National Hockey League may all too often resemble prizefight rings, but, particularly in recent seasons, the N.H.L. has hardly been alone. When the members of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's ice hockey committee met in Kansas City last month, they expressed ''extreme dissatisfaction'' with ''the violence that has come into our game,'' and they passed two rules to help deal with it. From now on, (a) a player assessed a minor penalty will always be required to serve the entire two minutes (if the opposing team scores, his squad will have to use another player to return to full strength), and (b) a game official will have discretion to impose either a minor or major roughness penalty against a player who makes contact with an opponent after the whistle.

title: ANIXTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: All share earnings and shares outstanding figures have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1986.

title: Exxon Sees Few Layoffs
description: Two senior executives of the Exxon Corporation said yesterday that the response to its voluntary separation package had probably made the company's need for further dismissals ''minimal.''

title: ST JOE GOLD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After increases of about $400,000 for the quarter and $1.1 million for the 6 months as a result of the tax-sharing agreement with the Fluor Corp. c-After increases of about $600,000 and $1.3 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, as a result of the tax-sharing agreement with Fluor.

title: Union Says A.T.&T. Is 'Playing With Truth'
description: With little progress to show at the bargaining table, the union for 155,000 striking telephone employees has begun a newspaper advertising campaign against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JUNE 10, 1986
description: International

title: TEXAS MURDERER IS PUT TO DEATH
description: Rudy Ramos Esquivel, telling his friends to ''be cool'' as they read him passages from the Bible, was executed by injection early today for shooting to death a narcotics officer eight years ago.

title: AN UNLIKELY STAR, PERNFORS MOVES UP
description: As Mikael Pernfors advanced through the draw at the French Open, he rewarded himself for each successive upset victory by upgrading his hotel accommodations. First he abandoned his free single room to pay for a double. Then he moved from the Sofitel, the players' hotel, to the swank Meridien. Finally, after his semifinal victory over Henri Leconte, he ordered up a Meridien suite costing several hundred dollars a day.

title: DEP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The 1985 share earnings have been restated to give effect to the 3-for-2 stock split to shareholders of record March 28, 1986.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S INVESTIGATORS: EXECUTIVES AND SPECIALISTS
description: The Presidential Commission on the Space Shuttle Challenger Accident was formed by executive order on Feb. 3, six days after the shuttle disaster. Its formal mission was to ''review the circumstances surrounding the accident to establish the probable cause or causes'' and to ''develop recommendations for corrective or other action.''

title: Voters Today Choose Successor to Addabbo
description: Voters in the 6th Congressional District in southeastern Queens will select a new Representative in a special election today from an unusually large field of five candidates, four of them Democrats.

title: Bridge: The Points From Overtricks Provided a Winning Margin
description: ''Take care of the pence,'' says an old English saying, ''and the pounds will take care of themselves.''

title: OPTIMISM IS LACKING
description: President Reagan and King Hussein of Jordan met today and expressed regret that they had been unable to revive the stalled Arab-Israeli peace talks, a senior Administration official said.

title: Municipalities Consider Bonds for Self-Insuring
description: As state and local governments find that liability insurance is unavailable or prohibitively expensive, they are studying proposals to insure themselves by selling tax-exempt bonds and holding the proceeds in an insurance reserve.

title: 100 Buildings Are Flooded In Louisiana; Samaritan Dies
description: Five inches of rain fell on northwestern Louisiana today, flooding 100 homes and businesses and leading to the death of a good Samaritan, officials said.

title: Round the World
description: Is there life after the major leagues for a player who was jailed in the Kansas City cocaine case three years ago, batted only .205 with Toronto two years ago and was in the minors one year ago?

title: NEW EXTREME-PRESSURE TOOLS EXPLORE THE NATURE OF MATTER
description: FOR more than a century, scientists have yearned to explore the bizarre effects expected to occur when matter is subjected to truly crushing pressures - pressures capable of changing the character of things and transforming even hydrogen, water and diamonds into metals.

title: EIL INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. SEEKS TUROFF INDICTMENT DECISION
description: Federal prosecutors have asked a grand jury to indict the city's former taxi and limousine chief, Jay L. Turoff, on charges that he accepted a $30,000 payoff to give a company a competitive advantage in selling taxi meters, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: REAGAN PRESSES FOR ANTI-SANDINISTA AID
description: President Reagan said today that support for Nicaraguan insurgents ''towers above partisan concerns'' and that a failure to provide aid would abandon the rebels.

title: Poles Agree To Debt Plan
description: Poland has accepted a proposal by its creditor banks to reschedule 95 percent of about $800 million in bank loans that fall due this year, but was expected to ask for an interest rate reduction on the loans.

title: Murdoch Plan Is Opposed
description: Journalists at Rupert Murdoch's Sun newspaper voted today against continuing to work at the high-technology printing plant that has been the target of protests by production workers.

title: AN ERA OF BOAT BUILDING FADING OUT ON THE OHIO
description: An American time is ending here, a time that began in the first decades of the 1800's and that saw the nation develop the Middle West and then the Far West, and become the country it is today.

title: REAGAN IS TOLD OF NORWEGIAN WHALING INFRACTIONS
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige today took steps that could lead to an embargo on Norwegian fish products if Norway continued to catch whales.

title: SOFTWARE FOR MAPMAKING
description: DO you remember those purple-outline maps that teachers used to crank out on their ditto machines, the ones they'd pass on to their students with the request that they fill in all the state capitals or color all the states where forestry was an economic factor green, all those where wheat was grown yellow, all the industrial states black and so on? I remember them quite well, for a query as to why the school couldn't afford to buy maps with all that crucial information already printed on them was rewarded with what in those sterner days was considered the appropriate response. Well, all that's about to change. The production of maps for schools and businesses is about to undergo a metamorphosis, thanks to the computer and the Atlas AMP ($449 for the I.B.M. PC and compatibles with a Color Graphics Adapter or a Hercules Card, from Strategic Locations Planning, San Jose, Calif. 95117, (408) 985-7400). This is a new, relatively low-cost thematic map generator.

title: SUSPENSION & PARTS INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE SELLING OF THE ROYAL FAMILY: The Mystique of the British Monarchy. By John Pearson. 350 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $17.95. THE worldwide fascination with the British royal family has become such an obvious fact of life in recent years that it is tempting to take its growth for granted - how could it have been otherwise? Yet in reality there was nothing inevitable about it. As Britain's standing in the world declined, the monarchy could easily have dwindled into a faded minor attraction, of largely local interest. That it should have evolved instead into one of the greatest shows on earth remains a much more extraordinary business than is commonly acknowledged.

title: Destinations, Denver
description: Two Washington-based organizations with opposite philosophies, National Right to Life and the National Organization for Women, are planning to head west for Denver later this week, partly to set policy but also to set their political pots bubbling.

title: YANKEES WIN ON 2 IN 11TH
description: Dave Righetti looked toward Lou Piniella's office in the visitors' clubhouse at Tiger Stadium tonight and shook his head. ''That poor guy in there,'' the Yankees' premier relief pitcher said. ''We're gonna kill him. That's the worst thing about messing up. Lou's going to snap.''

title: Irving Bank in Vermont
description: The Irving Bank Corporation today became the first out-of-state bank to open its doors in Vermont. Irving, based in New York, will initially operate in Vermont solely as a lender and eventually will enter the credit-card market, according to Robert Kaphan, the manager of the Irving Financial Center.

title: SPLENDID DAY AT SHINNECOCK
description: Flags whipped from their poles and the tall, golden beach grass bent in the bright sunshine today as a 20-mile-per-hour northwest wind turned the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club course into a near perfect example of what a links course is supposed to be.

title: Girl Swallows Toothbrush
description: A 14-year-old girl swallowed her toothbrush Saturday while she was brushing her teeth with a slippery brush and wet hands. The girl, Kerry Shea, said, ''I was brushing the back of my tongue because I saw on TV that it helps get a lot of the sugar that way.'' Doctors at St. Vincent Hospital in this suburb of Green Bay examined Miss Shea's stomach, found the toothbrush and removed it with a hook.

title: Bring Back the Glories Of Rockaway Summers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Polish View
description: To the Editor:

title: TARTIKOFF SIGNS 3-YEAR NBC CONTRACT
description: Brandon Tartikoff, the NBC program executive who fashioned the most successful slate of prime-time programs in the network's history this year, has signed a new three-year contract with NBC, it was announced yesterday in Maui, Hawaii.

title: PAN AM ADS TOUTING SECURITY PLAN STIR A DEBATE
description: Pan American World Airways has stirred widespread debate in the airline industry and the Government over its decision to trumpet its new efforts to protect international travelers from terrorists.

title: The Central Park Skier And the Commissioner
description: Dr. Robert Schehr was startled to see the Parks and Recreation Commissioner in Central Park. The Commissioner was equally startled to see Dr. Schehr.

title: Let Governors Choose Running Mates
description: Once in office, New York's lieutenant governors often feel more like losers. Waiting to fill a vacancy that rarely occurs, they have little to do - even less if they were not chosen by the governor.

title: Savings Unit Is Taken Over
description: The Carteret Savings Bank of Morristown, N.J., took control of the Admiral-Builders Savings and Loan Association today, giving the thrift institution's 5,600 customers free access to their deposits for the first time in almost 13 months.

title: Iraqi Raid Cuts Phone Links Of Iran With Other Countries
description: Iranian telecommunications with the rest of the world were cut today after an Iraqi air raid on a satellite ground station.

title: Texas Bank Cites Talks
description: Daniel C. Arnold, chairman and co-chief executive officer of the First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc., said today that the Houston bank holding company had held ''exploratory'' talks with Frank Cahouet, the former chief executive of the Crocker National Corporation. Mr. Arnold said, however, that the discussions had been held in a ''very preliminary way,'' in order ''to see if there could be an area of mutual interest.''

title: IN BEEF, 'GOOD' COULD BECOME 'SELECT'
description: A consumer group, with backing from health organizations and tentative support from the meat industry, asked the Government today to rename the ''good'' grade of beef ''select'' and to start a campaign to sell Americans on eating leaner meat.

title: ENERGY RELAY USING A GAS
description: ANEW technology is being tested that transports energy long distances by using high temperature to convert a mixture of gases into an energy-rich combination, then shipping the mixture by pipeline at close to room temperature. At the far end the stored energy can be released to generate steam or for other purposes.

title: Former Lazard Partner Finds Place at Salomon
description: Raymond S. Troubh, a former partner of Lazard Freres & Company, has joined Salomon Brothers Inc. as an adviser in its merger and acquisitions department.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''NOW I can say I am designing Caroline Kennedy's wedding gown,'' Carolina Herrera confirmed last week. ''But details I cannot give.'' Who can? ''She will say it herself.'' When? ''Later on.'' And that was that - for now. BLACK-TIE variations were the visual attraction at the Cutty Sark Men's Wear Awards on Sunday at the New York Penta Hotel. The event, a benefit for Save the Theaters, was dedicated to the late Perry Ellis.

title: In Colleges: a High Tone, a Low Practice
description: Pick up the admissions literature of almost any college or university and you will find references to integrity, the enrichment of human values and the pursuit of excellence. One role assumed by academe is to act as a conscience for society: what is morally reprehensible is publicly condemned and actively opposed by those who populate our nation's campuses. Co-existing with this high moral tone, however, is a questionable practice engaged in by more than 90 percent of our institutions of higher education.

title: HARTFORD IS CHOSEN AS THE TENTATIVE SITE OF FRIEDMAN'S TRIAL
description: Defense lawyers and Federal prosecutors have tentatively agreed to move the Federal corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman and five other defendants from New York City to Hartford, officials involved with the case said yesterday.

title: Phillips Debt
description: The board of the Phillips Petroleum Company voted, in response to a management recommendation, to make about $400 million in excess pension funds available to reduce long-term debt. At the end of 1985, the company's pension fund assets totaled $1.4 billion with benefit obligations of $727 million. Phillips has about 24,000 employees.

title: Arizona Wins College Series
description: Mike Senne and Gar Millay hit two-run homers in the sixth inning, and Gary Alexander pitched a seven-hitter as Arizona defeated top-ranked Florida State, 10-2, tonight to capture the N.C.A.A. College World Series title.

title: Indictment Unsealed
description: An indictment charging two former Tennessee football players, Tony Robinson and Kenneth (B. B.) Cooper, in a cocaine conspiracy was unsealed in Knox County Court.

title: ECUADOR LEADERS FEUD AND NATION IS TORN IN TWO
description: Osvaldo Hurtado Larrea, a soft-spoken Jesuit-trained intellectual, was Ecuador's last President. Leon Febres Cordero, an extroverted millionaire businessman, is the current leader. Two men could hardly be more different.

title: 2d Trial Jury Picked
description: After a flurry of pre-trial motions, a jury of six was selected in New Orleans yesterday for the second trial of the former Tulane basketball star John (Hot Rod) Williams. His first trial on point-shaving charges last summer was in its second day of testimony when it abruptly ended in a mistrial based on accusations of bad conduct levied against the district attorney's office.

title: Ex-Boesky Officer Starts Up a Firm
description: Stephen J. Conway, former president and chief operating officer of the Ivan F. Boesky Corporation, announced yesterday that he was stepping out on his own in the competitive world of investment banking.

title: On the Manufacture of Indonesian History
description: To the Editor:

title: Church Seeks Refuge For Cuban Prisoners
description: Cuba's Roman Catholic Church has held high-level talks with the Reagan Administration to urge it to accept 75 prisoners whose release has been offered by the Cuban Government, church sources said today.

title: In Fighting Terrorism, Why Not Use Force?
description: It has been nearly two months since the American air strike against Libya, and many Americans have added their voices to the widespread foreign criticism of the use of force in the fight against terrorism. The threat of state-sponsored terrorism has not yet been eliminated and similar American actions against Libya, Syria, Iran or other states may well be waged in the future. It is therefore important to affirm the legitimacy and utility of military responses to terrorism.

title: VISION TECH INC reports earnings for 13wks to April 23
description: b-Net loss.

title: Reagan News Session Set
description: President Reagan will hold a nationally broadcast news conference at 8 P.M. Wednesday at the White House.

title: PALISADES TOWNS BRACE FOR THE FOURTH
description: As with other police chiefs in the small towns atop the Palisades, Arthur Siebert is preoccupied with the Fourth of July weekend.

title: WELDED TUBE COMPANY OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
PROTESTANTS SEEK MORE DIVESTMENT
description: Although several liberal Protestant denominations have voted to divest themselves of holdings in companies operating in South Africa, their pension funds, bound by stricter rules of investment, have been reluctant to follow suit.

title: MITTERAND TO VISIT SOVIET
description: President Francois Mitterand of France will visit Moscow for talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev from July 7 to 10. The visit will follow a meeting with Presi-dent Reagen in New York, where Mr. Mitterand will be for July 4 celebra-tions of the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty.

title: BATS, BOOK, BULGARIAN
description: A book party in the Washington suburb of Bethesda, Md., the other night was a modest af fair, launching the publication of Atanas Slavov's autobiographical novel,''With the Precision of Bats.''

title: CITY MAY GET FREE BUSES IN A TEST OF CLEANER FUEL
description: The General Motors Corporation has tentatively agreed with the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to develop buses that burn clean methanol fuel and to give the first six buses free to New York City.

title: NEW PLAN OFFERED ON ALIEN WORKERS
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn said today that he had a plan that might resolve an intense dispute over the admission to the United States of foreign agricultural workers, under a comprehensive immigration bill.

title: PITCHER, 29, EXCELS IN DEBUT, BUT METS FAIL TO HOLD LEAD
description: It was a noble experiment, and Rick Anderson says he will remember it for the rest of his life: the night he pitched in the big leagues for the first time at the age of 29 and delivered seven innings of four-hit ball for the Mets against the Philadelphia Phillies while his mother and father and a crowd of 26,050 cheered him in Shea Stadium.

title: Mortgage Rates Decline
description: Interest levels on fixed-rate mortgages continued to decline between early April and early May, according to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, but at a significantly slower rate than in previous periods. Adjustable-rate loan rates also fell slightly in May.

title: A RISKY BRAIN OPERATION PROCEEDS
description: His head affixed to a frame on an operating table, Meyer grabs at his left arm, struggling to remove the blood-pressure collar.

title: Bush Canada Visit to Focus on Trade
description: Vice President Bush will try to ease rising tensions over American and Canadian trade during a visit this week to Canada, his aides said today. But a dispute over Canada's lumber exports to the United States that could drag on for months threatens to complicate the discussions.

title: MODERATE EXERCISE LATE IN LIFE IS FOUND TO REVERSE MANY OF THE EFFECTS OF AGING
description: IN a series of new studies prompted by the geriatric population explosion, researchers are finding that moderate exercise can not only retard the effects of aging but can actually reverse them.

title: DANCE: LOUIS JOHNSON
description: IF only Louis Johnson had offered ''The Ball'' and not ''At the Movies.'' Or if only he had offered ''At the Movies'' and not ''The Ball.'' Instead, both works were presented Sunday night when the Louis Johnson Dance Theater Ensemble appeared at the Harry DeJur Playhouse of the Henry Street Settlement. That was a mistake for, though the dances treated different subjects, they were similar in form and possessed similar strengths and weaknesses.

title: JILL CONRAD
description: Jill Zubof Conrad, former photo editor for Associated Press Newsfeatures, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Glen Ridge, N.J. She was 37 years old.

title: NBC and Abbas
description: To the Editor:

title: TREASURY BOND PRICES TUMBLE
description: Volatile trading in the Government bond market yesterday sent prices tumbling for both futures contracts and cash securities.

title: Rights Leader Accepts A Methodist Transfer
description: The Rev. Joseph Lowery, the president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, bade an emotional farewell to the church he had pastored for 18 years and reluctantly accepted a transfer.

title: VIDEO DISPLAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
A SPACE AGENCY ON DISASTER'S EDGE
description: In its report to the President, the shuttle panel describes a space agency as on the brink of disaster for months before the 74-second flight of the Challenger, an agency so driven to meet its own schedule that it was increasingly unable to train its crews properly or even find spare parts for its spacecraft.

title: Robert A. Comfort, 53, Robber at Pierre Hotel
description: Robert A. Comfort, one of five men who committed a $3 million dollar robbery at the Pierre Hotel in 1972, died Friday at Rochester General Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived in Fairport, N.Y., a suburb of Rochester.

title: RENEWING TRADITIONAL VALUES
description: The wallflower is becoming the belle of the ball. A decade-long debate over what is wrong with American business and how to cure it has produced a surprising model for success: the family business.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COLLECTOR'S CHOICE The eighth annual Museum Mile Festival, opening the doors to as eclectic a selection of art objects as one can find anywhere in the world, takes over upper Fifth Avenue today from 6 P.M. to 9 P.M.

title: WERTHEIM SELLING A BIG STAKE
description: Schroders P.L.C., a major British merchant bank, will buy 50 percent of Wertheim & Company, a small, old-line Wall Street investment banking partnership, for $100 million, the two firms announced yesterday.

title: Ferrets Are Not Friends
description: Ferrets are turning up everywhere these days. They should not be.

title: WALL ST. FIRMS DISAVOW REPORT OF INSIDER INQUIRY
description: Two of the nation's most prominent investment houses in the takeover business - Goldman, Sachs & Company and Lazard Freres & Company - declared yesterday that they had no knowledge that their investment bankers were under investigation in the deepening insider trading scandal, as reported by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Market Place; Dow Volatility: Divisor's Effect
description: WHEN the Dow Jones industrial average climbs to nearly 1,900 from 1,300 in little more than eight months, investors are well advised to fasten their seat belts against the possibility of turbulent single-day point swings. In addition to program trading, whose impact was demonstrated in yesterday's record 47.75-point drop, stock splits among the components of the Dow average are contributing to the increasing volatility.

title: UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago figures include a pre- tax charge of $30,000 from the writedown of goodwill and other expenses.

title: Dr. George Jervis, 82; Expert on Retardation
description: Dr. George Amede Jervis, former director of the Institute for Basic Research of the New York State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities, died Thursday at his home in Stony Point, N.Y. He was 82 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Biogen N.V., Cambridge, Mass., said laboratory studies showed that its genetically engineered substance, gamma interferon, helps relieve symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis with few side effects.

title: MILTON RICHMAN
description: Milton Richman, the award-winning sports columnist and former sports editor of United Press International, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: HEMINGWAY IN FOUR STAGES
description: IN the 1970's, public television had a series called ''Hollywood Television Theater.'' Produced out of Los Angeles station KCET, the weekly offerings ranged from Pirandello's ''Six Characters in Search of an Author'' and ''The Lady's Not for Burning'' by Christopher Fry (starring Richard Chamberlain) to a slew of forgettable efforts by lesser-known playwrights. Budgets were generally modest and the productions were inevitably uneven, but there was a nobility of purpose about the proceedings. New and established writers were being taken seriously, which is practically unheard of in commercial television.

title: SHUTTLE COMMISSION BLAMES NASA AND ROCKET BUILDERS FOR CHALLENGER EXPLOSION
description: The President's shuttle commission said today that the Challenger disaster had a single physical cause, the failure of a rocket joint, but it cited a wide array of management problems in the space agency and the rocket manufacturer as fundamentally responsible for bringing about that failure.

title: 5,000 Taiwanese Protesters Encircle City Council Offices
description: Thousands of demonstrators besieged the offices of the city council today to protest jail sentences imposed on three magazine editors.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JUNE 10, 1986
description: International The jittery peso fell further against the dollar, closing in bank-owned exchange houses at 727 pesos to the dollar, a fall of 30 percent in the last six trading days. Mexico City's exchange market was filled with swirling rumors about Mexico's intentions toward its foreign debt and uncertainty about the country's economic future. [ Page A1, Column 1. ]

title: LIEBERMAN CLOSES ON A DREAM
description: It may appear to be a frivolous pastime, this business of a young woman pursuing a professional basketball career. A mother would almost rather see her daughter spending time at the mall. Nancy Lieberman is 27 years old now and still practicing making all the right moves on and off the court. ''Nancy Bird'' is the name she answers to in her fantasies, but Lieberman is the name she would like to hear announced just once in the lineup of a National Basketball Association team.

title: Control Data Files 2 Securities Issues
description: The Control Data Corporation has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $250 million in senior notes due in 1991 and $100 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2011, with underwriters to be led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: SAGA BOARD CLEARS OFFER BY MARRIOTT
description: The Saga Corporation said today that its board had agreed to accept a sweetened tender offer from the Marriott Corporation. Marriott, which last month proposed to acquire the Menlo Park, Calif., company for $34 a share, raised its offer to $39.50 a share, or about $501.7 million, under a merger agreement reached over the weekend.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Frigitronics Offer
description: Frigitronics Inc., a maker of eye care products, said it had received an unsolicited buyout offer of $33 a share, or about $110 million, from Medchem Products Inc. for its 3.25 million shares outstanding.

title: Striking Out
description: The windup, a full-pendulum arm swing, is known as the windmill, and in Cathy Kaminski's case, that's thoroughly appropriate. When the 18-year-old New Jerseyan cranks it up and lets go, batters are simply blown away.

title: 'LAUGH-AT-LUNCH' SERIES AT THE AMERICAN PLACE
description: The tinny bray of Al Jolson warbling ''Give My Regards to Broadway'' fills the air. The lights come up on a room overlooking Times Square, with a washbasin for a focal point. A fat man in a fedora with a brim as big as a flying saucer, flowered undershorts and garters holding up black socks is getting a hot tip over the phone from Harry the Horse.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption of a front-page picture from The Associated Press yesterday about Cuba's release of a Bay of Pigs veteran, Col. Ricardo Montero Duque, misidentified the woman seen with him. She was Ana Lloaneta, a friend.

title: Oil Companies in Libya
description: The House voted today to order five American oil companies to leave Libya by June 30, a step President Reagan said he was prepared to take by executive order on that date. The five companies were granted an exception from President Reagan's Jan. 7 order barring American companies from conducting economic relations with Libya to permit them time to wind up their affairs.

title: Business and the Law; Contraceptive Suits a Concern
description: FOR many years, a woman's right to choose has been an issue in the legal morass surrounding abortion. Now the question of choice in contraceptives is becoming a legal issue as well - but for very different reasons, having to do with economics rather than religion or ethics.

title: PERU HALTS ERRANT PAN AM JET
description: A Peruvian military jet forced a Pan American World Airways airliner with 105 people aboard to land after it violated Peruvian airspace today. The plane was allowed to resume its flight to Los Angeles after paying a $5,000 fine.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Veteran Insiders Babble
description: After Ronald Reagan's big political success, I naturally assumed that actors would rush to cash in on the public's appetite for greasepaint government. Except for Clint Eastwood getting elected Mayor of Carmel, Calif., though, there has been no significant trend boding new political career opportunities for thespians.

title: Advertising; Agencies In City Lag In Awards
description: THOSE important advertising awards slipping out of New York to the boondocks have not gone unnoticed by the sophisticates of Big Apple advertising.

title: White Sox Name Haller
description: Tom Haller, the former general manager and coach with the San Francisco Giants, was named general manager by the Chicago White Sox vice president, Ken Harrelson. Haller was elevated from his job as manager of the White Sox franchise in Birmingham, Ala., in the Class AA Southern League. Haller will serve under Harrelson and take over part of the duties of running the major league club.

title: Only Yank In the World
description: David Socha feels he has more in common with Zubin Mehta or Andre Previn than with American baseball or football or basketball officials, who operate in groups.

title: Waldheim Is Accused Of Beating Greek Jew
description: A Greek Jew now living in Israel was quoted today as saying that he saw Kurt Waldheim beat his brother at a time during World War II when, he said, Mr. Waldheim was supervising deportation of Greek Jews to concentration camps. Mr. Waldheim was a lieutenant in the German Army.

title: New York City Minority Employees' Pay Is Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Air's Plea Rejected
description: The Department of Transportation, citing concerns about the Texas Air Corporation's recent sale of popular air-shuttle routes to Pan American World Airways, today rejected Texas Air's plea that it be allowed to take immediate control of Eastern Air Lines.

title: GIAMATTI GETS BASEBALL POST
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, a Renaissance scholar and the retiring president of Yale University, was elected president of the National League yesterday at a meeting of the 12 club owners. He will be introduced today as the successor to Charles (Chub) Feeney as the operating chief of baseball's senior league.

title: KEY PORTIONS OF COMMISSION REPORT ON CHALLENGER ACCIDENT
description: Following are key portions of the text of the summary of the Rogers Commission report on the accident of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, 1986, in which the crew of seven astronauts were killed: Preface The accident of space shuttle Challenger, mission 51-L, interrupting for a time one of the most productive engineering, scientific and exploratory programs in history, evoked a wide range of deeply felt public responses. There was grief and sadness for the loss of seven brave members of the crew; firm national resolve that those men and women be forever enshrined in the annals of American heroes and a determination, based on that resolve and in their memory, to strengthen the space shuttle program so that this tragic event will become a milestone on the way to achieving the full potential that space offers to mankind.

title: ATHLETIC SUPPLIES: STAKES ARE HIGH
description: The defending national champion University of Oklahoma football team is spending $6,000 this year to purchase 75 helmets at $80 each from the Bike Athletic Company. The Sooners are buying 75 face masks from Bike, at $7.35 each, to go on those helmets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the decision-makers had known all the facts, it is highly unlikely that they would have decided to launch 51-L on Jan. 28, 1986.'' - The Rogers Commission Report. [ C10:6. ]

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes tax credits of $22,250 for the quarter and $172,250, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $57,800, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $93,500, or 1 cent a share, for the 6 months.

title: Ex-Fox Chief Settles Suit
description: Dennis C. Stanfill, who resigned as chairman and chief executive of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation in 1981, has accepted a settlement of about $4 million in a wrongful termination suit filed against the studio and its former owner Marvin Davis, a lawyer for Mr. Stanfill said today.

title: Carr Resigns at Florida
description: Bill Carr, whose tenure at the University of Florida saw a dramatic financial turnaround, but also scandal, in the school's sports program, announced his resignation as director of athletics.

title: TSI INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW CHANCELLOR FOR AUSTRIA: A BLEND OF STYLE AND SUCCESS
description: Franz Vranitzky, the man chosen yesterday to succeed Fred Sinowatz as Chancellor of Austria, is a Socialist with the credentials of a banker and brings a fresh new face - one of youth and vigor - to the Austrian and European political landscapes.

title: BLACKS BATTLE AGAIN NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: At least five people died and thousands were left homeless in chill winter weather today after renewed fighting between rival black groups in a squatter camp near here.

title: Operating Rigs Slump in U.S.
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States is at the lowest level since March 1942.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
3 COLOMBO BROTHERS AND 12 OTHERS PLEAD GUILTY IN U.S. COURT
description: Three sons of the late Joseph A. Colombo and 12 other people identified by officials as members and associates of the Colombo organized-crime family pleaded guilty yesterday to a Federal racketeering conspiracy charge under a plea agreement worked out with Government prosecutors.

title: OIL COMPANIES IN LIBYA PRESSED
description: The House of Representatives voted today to order five American oil companies to leave Libya by June 30. President Reagan has set a similar deadline, saying he is prepared to enforce it by executive order.

title: Duvalier Resettles in France
description: Jean-Claude Duvalier, the deposed president of Haiti, moved to a new home today, four months after fleeing his homeland. Local French officials said Mr. Duvalier left his villa in Grasse when his lease expired and moved to Mougins, a suburb of Cannes.

title: WESTERN PUBLISHING GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $4,665,000 from a prepayment penalty. c-Net income.

title: NASA CHIEF VOWS TO FIX PROBLEMS
description: Acknowledging that the Rogers Commission's criticisms were ''certainly not entirely undeserved,'' the head of the space agency pledged today to overcome ''our errors,'' overhaul the shuttle management and restore the agency's reputation for safety and success.

title: PIRATING OF JOBS CITED IN VOIDING OF JERSEY GRANT
description: The Federal Government has terminated a $9 million Federal grant to help develop a financial center here, saying the city had failed to show that the project would not take jobs from New York City.

title: STAGE: 'WRITER'S CRAMP' AT THE HUDSON GUILD
description: IN John Byrne's early play ''Writer's Cramp,'' the characters are stand-ups, the plot hardly matters, many of the jokes are old-fashioned British bawdy, Scottish accents are the stuff of merriment - and there are so many good laughs that one comes away with a new respect for old formulas. Much of the success of the first American production of the work, at the Hudson Guild Theater, depends on the vigorous direction of David Kerry Heefner and the frenetic performances of Brooks Baldwin and Sullivan Brown set against the languid movement of K. C. Kelly, but Mr. Byrne has given them a text to work with that is most effective when it just fails to contain lunacy.

title: Beatrice to Sell Knitwear Unit
description: The Beatrice Companies said today that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell Esmark Inc., the parent company of its knitwear division, to Eaglewood Partners, a New York-based investor group. Terms were not disclosed.

title: '1986,' NBC'S ANSWER TO 'WEST 57TH'
description: WHEN ''West 57th'' made its debut last year, CBS said the magazine show would usher in a new and zippier kind of television journalism. Let's hear it now for prescience; CBS was right. ''1986,'' on NBC, is ''West 57th'' without yuppies. It can be seen on Channel 4 at 10 tonight.

title: U.P.I. Plan Accepted
description: The creditors of United Press International have voted 132 to 5 in favor of a reorganization plan that could set the stage for the sale of the news service for $41 million to a partnership controlled by a Mexican newspaper publisher, Mario Vazquez-Rana, a U.P.I. spokesman said today.

title: GORBACHEV OFFERS AN A-PLANT PACT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, making his first visit to Hungary as Soviet leader, called today for an international accord to deal with the aftereffects of nuclear accidents such as the Chernobyl disaster.

title: A DISPUTE OVER BOND INTEREST
description: Always eager to supplement their budgets, local governments around the country are closely watching a banking dispute in New England that highlights a potential new source of income.

title: U.S. WILL PUBLISH RIGHTS REPORTS
description: The State Department is planning to publish a series of reports on Communist countries where human rights violations often go unreported in the Western press, United States officials said today.

title: Boy Interrupts Robbers On Subway and Is Slain
description: A Bronx teen-ager was fatally shot yesterday afternoon when he encountered a robbery in progress on an IRT subway train at the station at 103d Street and Lexington Avenue, the authorities said.

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
RESEARCHERS SEE HOPE FOR COUNTERING THE WEAR AND TEAR OF LIFE AT BASIC BIOLOGICAL LEVELS
description: THE nation's leading researchers on how the body ages are drawing a picture of the process that, although more complicated than in the past, holds more hope that the ravages of aging can be fought at the most basic biological levels.

title: STAGE: 'SILLS & COMPANY,' IMPROVISATIONAL REVUE
description: NO theatrical presentation could more successfully disarm drama critics than ''Sills & Company,'' the improvisational revue that has brought a delightful crew of friendly comic faces to the Lamb's Theater. This show of pickup ''theater games'' really does change every night - depending on the mood and inspiration of the cast and the sensibility of the audience. Given the talent of the performers on stage and the axiom that everyone in New York is a comedian, ''Sills & Company'' should levitate more often than it sinks. My own evening at the Lamb's was on and off, but even when I wasn't laughing, I was rarely bored. Better spontaneous silliness than canned clowning.

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CBS AIRS 'AMERICA IS'
description: THERE are many faces to New York's Lower East Side and one of the most radiant is portrayed in tonight's hourlong special, ''America Is,'' at 8 o'clock on Channel 2.

title: Higher British Prices Also Deter Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Thrifty Sells Stake In 2 Companies
description: The Thrifty Corporation, which recently announced its acquisition by the Pacific Lighting Corporation in a stock exchange valued at $886 million, said it had sold its interests in the Crown Books Corporation and Trak Auto West Inc.

title: K.C. JONES CALLS CELTICS 'GREATEST'
description: Through 82 victories, 67 during the regular season and 15 in the playoffs, Coach K. C. Jones, his aides, and Red Auerbach, the club's president, were repeatedly asked whether the Boston Celtics were the best team ever assembled in the 40-year history of the National Basketball Association.

title: TBC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
OPPONENTS OF KHOMEINI SAID TO LEAVE FRANCE FOR IRAN-IRAQ BORDER
description: More than 1,000 members of the largest group opposing the Iranian Government have left their headquarters in suburban Paris for an area on the Iran-Iraq border, the group said here today.

title: YOUNG PANTHER TRACKED IN FLORIDA
description: Scientists are hoping a 55-pound bundle of fur known only as No. 10 will teach them enough about the habits of the Florida panther to help save the animal from extinction.

title: LINDNER REPORTS A 6.2% STAKE IN CHRIS-CRAFT
description: Carl H. Lindner, an Ohio investor and the chief executive of the American Financial Corporation, said yesterday that the company holds a 6.2 percent stake in Chris-Craft Industries, an announcement that surprised many analysts.

title: REAGAN'S SPEECHWRITER SAYS HE WAS DISMISSED IN DISPUTE
description: President Reagan's director of speechwriters for the last three years said today that he was dismissed by Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, after ''constant battles'' over the President's public remarks.

title: SOME ADVICE ON THE ADVICE GIVERS
description: MANY individuals and small business operators recognize that computers can improve productivity, but they have no hands-on experience with the technology and little understanding of what computers can and cannot do.

title: PERSONAL DIAGNOSTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CONCERT: FLORILEGIUM IN BIBLICAL SCENES
description: FLORILEGIUM'S choral concert at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday night re-created biblical scenes in the most dramatic of musical terms. Though the sources were ancient, the settings covered a lot of music history - from Schutz and Purcell to Charpentier, Kodaly and Copland, and resting finally with a new work by Judith Lang Zaimont. All were conducted by JoAnn Rice.

title: JUSTICE AND STATE DEPTS. AT ODDS IN ASSESSMENTS ON ISRAELI SPYING
description: Officials of the State Department and the Justice Department made conflicting statements today about the extent of Israeli spying in the United States. The statements brought additional confusion to an issue that has already strained American-Israeli relations.

title: WHEREHOUSE ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-earlier period's results have been restated to reflect the 5-for- 4 stock split paid Nov. 13, 1985, to shareholders of record Oct. 11, 1985.

title: DOLE SUGGESTS TAX BILL MAY PASS THIS WEEK
description: The Senate resumed debating tax-revision legislation today, and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, suggested that the measure might be passed by the end of the week.

title: Eastern Fine Recycled
description: To the Editor:

title: Angolan Rebels Claim Recent Battle Victories
description: The Angolan rebel movement said today that its forces killed more than 100 Angolan soldiers and shot down several aircraft in battles last week.

title: POLITICIANS PROMISE A TOMATO IN EVERY PLOT
description: Hudson County is famous for political scandal, so no one paid too much attention when a recall election was held here last year and a new slate of candidates swept into power, promising clean government.

title: Museum Benefit Dance
description: A benefit dance for the Cooper-Hewitt Museum is planned for Thursday at 9 P.M at the museum, 2 East 91st Street.

title: LEARNING MATH BY THINKING
description: SCHOOL reformers, business executives and politicians are demanding more mathematics for American children. Schools are responding, at least in terms of the hours given to math. Not all mathematicians are cheering. They worry that pressures for more hours of mathematics may hurt rather than help, unless mathematics is taught differently.

title: PESO VALUE FALLS AMID UNCERTAINTY ON MEXICO'S DEBT
description: The jittery peso fell further against the dollar today, amid swirling rumors about Mexico's intentions toward its foreign debt and uncertainty about the country's economic future. .

title: Swedish Police Doubt Chilean Connection
description: The Swedish police cast doubt today on a British newspaper report that said investigators suspected the Chilean secret police had plotted the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme.

title: Wolves Through History
description: Rasta and Wolfie sprawled on the floor of the American Museum of Natural History yesterday, as docile as dogs. But they are wolves, born in captivity and living at the National Audubon Society center in Sharon, Conn.

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM
description: NOW in its final week at City Center, the Martha Graham Dance Company has turned a potentially risky season into a huge success, as the packed houses and brilliant level of dancing have testified.

title: PUBLISHING: THE LEGACY OF 'SON OF SAM' LAWS
description: A number of legal decisions affecting books and the publishing industry have been handed down recently, dealing with everything from the so-called ''Son of Sam laws'' to libel.

title: 40,000 Squatters Must Go, Mayor of Washington Says
description: Forty thousand people who are living illegally in public housing here will have to leave by the end of the month, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today.

title: BOOK ASSERTS MACMILLAN DOOMED THOUSANDS AT END OF WAR
description: A new book published here asserts that Harold Macmillan, who later became Prime Minister of Britain, doomed thousands of Russians and Yugoslavs by handing them over to Communist forces at the end of World War II. The allegations have been denied by a member of the Macmillan family.

title: A NOVELIST AND A BIOGRAPHER
description: Merle Miller, a former president of the Authors Guild who wrote best-selling oral biographies of Harry S. Truman and Lyndon B. Johnson, died yesterday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital of an abdominal infection with peritonitis. He was 67 years old and lived in Brewster, N.Y.

title: Economic Scene; Austrian Fears On Waldheim
description: AUSTRIA'S business executives and bankers are greatly concerned that the election of Kurt Waldheim as President will hurt their country's economic relations with the United States and Western Europe.

title: AUSTRALIAN BARBECUE IS A SOCIAL EVENT
description: AT beach-front homes north of Sydney, an Australian city in love with the outdoors, wafts of white smoke rise into the summer twilight skies, a signal not of some religious event but of a basic eating ritual.

title: TAX DEBATE PACE SLOW IN SENATE
description: No senators were willing to be the first to step forward to offer amendments to the tax-revision bill today. The Senate continued with slow-paced discussion without votes.

title: GOURMET CLUBS PUT FRIENDSHIP ON THE MENU
description: Only when all seemed right to Dorothy Pietrucha - when the crystal gleamed, when the champagne was chilled, when the flags and place settings and fresh-cut flowers were in place -only then, after 13 hours of preparation, did she relax and start enjoying her Saturday. As she waited for her guests to arrive, she looked forward to the time when one of them would be the host and she the guest at an equally elaborate dinner.

title: Justices, and Justice, Delayed
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey, a Republican, has, to his credit, renominated two distinguished Democrats for permanent seats on his state's Supreme Court. Two Republican State Senators, to their shame, suggest they may block the appointments.

title: ITALY ADVANCES TO 2d ROUND
description: Italy today accomplished something it could not do when it won the World Cup of soccer in 1982: it won a game in the first round.

title: OFFICER IS ACQUITTED OF ASSAULT
description: A State Supreme Court jury acquitted a Brooklyn police officer yesterday of charges that he had beaten a handcuffed man, first in a patrol car and later in a cell, after the man was arrested in February 1985.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Wilmington, Del.; '81 Bank Law Fueling Growth
description: IN the five years since the state enacted its ''bank haven law'' - the Financial Center Development Act, which granted businesses favorable income-tax treatment and ended interest-rate ceilings - 26 banking companies and more than 3.5 million square feet of new offices have arrived in New Castle County. So much speculative building has taken place that some brokers fear as much as a five-year surplus by 1990 if all the proposed office projects - totalling a further 3 million more square feet - are built.

title: Son of Dr. King Enters Race
description: Martin Luther King 3d, the eldest son of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., announced his candidacy Monday for the Fulton County Commission.

title: Nuptial Special
description: It was not your traditional wedding garb. But then again, it was not your traditional wedding.

title: DRUG ISSUE PUBLICIZED BY SOVIET
description: After long portraying drug addiction as a curse of the West, the Soviet press has acknowledged a growing problem at home.

title: LATE RALLY PARES DOW'S LOSS TO 2.96
description: Still stung by its record fall on Monday, the stock market declined sharply early in yesterday's session before recovering to finish the day with a loss of less than three points.

title: HOUSE PLANS TO ACT ON ARMS TREATY
description: House Democratic leaders have decided to press ahead with a bill that would enact into law the limits on strategic weapons negotiated by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1979.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE cats came with the house. They lived in the backyards, tiger gray, orange marmalade, calico, black. They slithered through the evergreens at the back perimeter, and during mating season their screams were terrible. Sometimes I shook black pepper along the property line, and for a night or two all was still. Then the rain came and they were back. The cats came because of the woman next door. She and her husband, said to be bedridden, had lived on the third floor for many years. Every evening after dinner she went into the alley with a foil pie plate heaped with cat food and scraps: cabbage, rice, the noodles from chicken noodle soup, whatever they had had for dinner. Before she would even get to the bottom of the stairs the cats would begin to assemble, narrowing their eyes. She would talk to them roughly in a voice like sandpaper, coarse from years of cigarette smoke. ''Damn cats,'' she grumbled as she bent to put the food down.

title: Soviet Criticizes U.S. Over Chemical Arms
description: Viktor L. Israelyan, the Soviet delegate to the United Nations Disarmament Conference here, today criticized a United States plan to resume production of chemical weapons next year. He said this would violate agreements reached at the Soviet-American summit meeting in November.

title: Canada Trade Surplus
description: Exports and imports both rebounded in April, leaving Canada with a $1.1 billion (Canadian) surplus in the trade of goods, down from $1.3 billion in March but well above the six-year low of $144 million posted in February, the Government said today.

title: In 1986, All Animals Are Equally Politicized; Orwellian Newspeak
description: To the Editor:

title: FEYNMAN'S OWN FINDINGS: THEY 'FOOLED THEMSELVES'
description: Managers of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration ''exaggerated the reliability of the space shuttle to the point of fantasy,'' Dr. Richard P. Feynman, a member of the Presidential commission that investigated the Challenger disaster, said in presenting his personal findings today.

title: IRISHMAN IS CONVICTED IN THATCHER HOTEL BOMBING
description: A man accused of heading an Irish Republican Army terrorist cell was found guilty today of setting a bomb that killed five people and seriously wounded 30 in an assassination attempt on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Cabinet in 1984.

title: Wisconsin Bond Yields Range From 4.6% to 8%
description: While a number of large issues sensitive to fluctuations of interest rates have not yet been priced because of unfavorable market conditions, there is an ample supply on the competitive calendar.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the SportsMonday special report this week about the United States Open, on how to enjoy the tournament, misstated the hours for the Inn at Quogue. It is open every night during the week of the Open and every night for the rest of the summer.

title: STUDY DISPUTES PENTAGON ON READINESS OF NEW CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: Congressional opponents of new chemical weapons released a report today contradicting the Pentagon's contention that a bomb designed to spray nerve agents behind enemy lines is ready for production.

title: No Headline
description: ''The Celtics mean everything to Boston. They are part of the working class, the professional class, the whole city.''

title: 'SECOND TYPE,' AIRS ON 13
description: ''THE SECOND TYPE'' is a modest, hopeful look at the lives of some disabled people. They live better now than they did. New technology and their own self-assertion have led them, as Bill Cosby, the narrator, says, ''to an increasingly less isolated way of life.'' This is a cheerful message. The program will be seen on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight.

title: Advertising; Creamer Acquired By WCRS
description: TAKING a leaf out of an early chapter of the Saatchi & Saatchi how-to book on giantism, Britain's WCRS Group, a publicly held company, has reached out across the Atlantic to acquire HBM/Creamer, an agency twice its size. Shades of Saatchi and Compton!

title: Classics and Kool By Harlem Boys Choir
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem, under the direction of Dr. Walter J. Turnbull, is a worthy organization that seeks to help children realize their creative potential through performance of a varied repertory of music. And varied was the word for the troupe's Sunday night concert at Alice Tully Hall, with the soprano Yvonne Frazier, the tenor George Shirley, the flutist Hubert Laws and the Orchestra of St. Luke's.

title: House Bill Would Ban Cigarette Advertising
description: Seven members of the House of Representatives introduced legislation Monday to ban all forms of tobacco promotion, including newspaper and magazine advertisements, athletic sponsorships, billboards, posters and even matchbook covers.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a $5.1 million gain from the anticipated withdrawal of excess funds from an overfunded pension plan. c-Net loss after a $10 million pre-tax loss related to disposal and realignment of certain operations. The share earnings reflect a 4 percent stock dividend to be paid July 1.

title: HOUSE DEAVER PANEL IN CONFLICT OVER WITNESS
description: Democratic members of a House panel said today that they might ask the Justice Department to investigate charges of conflict of interest against Fred F. Fielding, former White House counsel, who testified today about his relationship with Michael K. Deaver.

title: STEIN BLAMES A KOCH HEALTH ADVISOR
description: State health inspectors have found ''systemic'' widespread medical and health code violations in three municipal hospitals in New York City, including cases in which unlicensed and unqualified doctors performed surgery at Harlem Hospital while dentists provided anesthesia.

title: NEW YORK COURT SAYS MENTALLY ILL HAVE RIGHT TO REFUSE MEDICATION
description: Patients involuntarily committed to state psychiatric hospitals cannot be forced to take antipsychotic drugs without a court order, New York's highest court ruled unanimously today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The National Hockey League Players Association reached agreement with Alan Eagleson, its executive director, on a five-year contract. Eagleson has been head of the union since its inception in 1967.

title: MANUFACTURER REPORTS STEPS TO REDESIGN SHUTTLE ROCKET
description: Morton Thiokol Inc., the manufacturer of the booster rockets identified as the cause of space shuttle disaster, said today that it had already taken steps to redesign its solid-fuel rocket motor in compliance with a Presidential commission's recommendation.

title: Japan Studies Car Curb
description: The Ministry of International Trade and Industry may direct Japanese auto makers to restrain exports to the European Community to ease trade friction, ministry officials said today. Since the community requested ''moderation'' of shipments, the ministry has considered seeking a reduction of 10 percent to 15 percent, a ministry official said.

title: Political Ripples in Bonn
description: Before the announcement of the hostages' release, supporters of Chancellor Helmut Kohl expressed fear that Mr. Kohl's Government could be in jeopardy if the captives were killed or seriously wounded. There was also apprehension over the potential effects on West German-American relations.

title: People
description: * Richard L. McCullough has joined E. H. Brown Advertising, Chicago, as executive vice president and principal.

title: Murchison Debt Plan
description: A Federal bankruptcy court will be asked on Monday to approve a reorganization plan of the finances of Clint Murchison Jr., who once controlled a personal fortune of $350 million. The plan also covers the Corland Corporation, a holding company for many of Mr. Murchison's interests. Mr. Murchison filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in February 1985 with debts of about $400 million. Corland, which filed for protection two months later, reported debts of $130 million.

title: Vintage Connors
description: Now that his 10-week ban has ended, Jimmy Connors offered this perspective: ''I missed playing the tennis, and missed seeing people filling the stands, but I enjoyed being away from all the garbage that goes on in tennis and all the people trying to making it a non-democracy-style event.'' Connors, who is 33 years old, made the comment yesterday after a 6-1, 6-2 victory over Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands in an opening-round match of the Stella Artois grass courts tournament at Queens Club in London. Connors was fined $25,000 and given a 10-week suspension by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council because he walked off the court following an argument with officials in the Lipton International Players Championships in Boca Raton, Fla., in February.

title: Get Ready for Galantine
description: MORE than half a century of working in kitchens has convinced me that cooking techniques, like narrow lapels, go in and out of fashion as the years go by. There is certainly nothing new about boned stuffed chicken - galantine is the classic term for it -yet I detect a new-found passion for this sort of preparation among today's young chefs.

title: Tax Cuts No Reason To End Aid to Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TRIUMPH OF PIERROT. The Commedia dell'Arte and the Modern Imagination. By Martin Green and John Swan. Illustrated. 297 pages. Macmillan. $25. WHAT do Stravinsky, Degas, Chaplin, Isak Dinesen, Meyerhold, Monty Python and T. S. Eliot have in common? What do such disparate works as Picasso's ''Family of Saltimbanques,'' Bergman's ''Sawdust and Tinsel,'' Waugh's ''Put Out More Flags'' and Pirandello's ''Six Characters in Search of an Author'' share? As Martin Green and John Swan persuasively argue in their new book, all have been influenced by the Italian commedia dell'arte.

title: Finding Hostesses For Liberty Weekend
description: Where did your ancestors come from? Were you born in the United States? Do you speak any other languages? Have you visited the Statue of Liberty?

title: Merkin Hall Raga Cycle With Pandit Pran Nath
description: Pandit Pran Nath, exemplar of the Kirana school of Indian singing and product of the (to Westerners) unbelievably lengthy and disciplined study that has preserved the subtle intensities of India's music through centuries of slow change, is engaged in a ''Raga Cycle'' of concert performances at the Dia Art Foundation Performance Space (155 Mercer Street). Last month he gave a program of morning ragas, and Sunday he returned to sing ragas associated with the afternoon.

title: TREASURY SECURITIES MIXED
description: Prices for Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday as the credit markets awaited the release later this week of Government reports on retail sales and producer prices for fresh signals on the direction of the economy.

title: SANDINISTA DELAY REPORTED BY U.S.
description: Before the Nicaraguan announcement of the release of eight West Germans by the rebels, the United States had blamed the Sandinista Government for the delay in freeing the captives.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Fringe Benefits
description: Although Jim Calhoun, the new basketball coach at the University of Connecticut, will be paid a base salary of $70,000 a year, he is expected to earn, including income from basketball and shoe contracts and a basketball camp, a total of more than $100,000. Calhoun, the former coach at Northeastern who was named last month to replace Dom Perno, met on Monday with John Toner, the athletic director, to complete negotiations.

title: BRITAIN REPORTEDLY DECIDES TO DISSOLVE ULSTER ASSEMBLY
description: The British Government has decided to dissolve the Northern Ireland Assembly because it failed to bring together the province's Roman Catholics and Protestants, official sources said today.

title: SWIFTER WARMING OF GLOBE FORESEEN
description: The rise in carbon dioxide and other gases in the earth's atmosphere will have an earlier and more pronounced impact on global temperature and climate than previously expected, according to evidence presented to a Senate subcommittee today.

title: NMR OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The year-ago period's operations commenced July 1, 1984 to March 31, 1985.

title: View From the Chorus Line
description: Jack H. Olender, a Washington trial lawyer who won four of four cases this month, with judgments totaling $5 million, decided to pay his debt to society, so to speak, and volunteered for jury duty, grandly forgoing the $30 daily allowance. After being thrown off six juries by peremptory challenges, he made it to the box on the seventh, as an alternate. Mr. Olender, a regular at Kennedy Center premieres, says he now knows what it is like to ''star in four consecutive hits and then be rejected as a member of the chorus line.''

title: Sampson Fined $5,000
description: The fight involving Ralph Sampson of Houston during the fifth game of the N.B.A. Finals between the Boston Celtics and the Rockets will cost the Rockets' center $5,000. Sixteen other players, from the two teams, have been fined lesser amounts.

title: BUSINESSES AND SCHOOLS ARE SHUT IN A ONE-DAY PROTEST BY HAITIANS
