description: Schools and most businesses in the capital and in half a dozen other towns were closed today in a resumption of the anti-Government protests that swept the country last week.

title: Remove Stigma From AIDS Test; An Insurer's View
description: To the Editor:

title: WNET TO CUT SHOWS FOR PBS
description: WNET, Channel 13, will present a plan to its board today calling for a shift away from its role as a principal supplier of programs to the nationwide Public Broadcasting Service, station officials said last night.

title: The Miranda Case, 20 Years Later
description: This Friday marks the 20th anniversary of the United States Supreme Court's decision in Miranda v. Arizona, perhaps the most highly publicized - and most misunderstood and severely maligned - criminal procedure in American history. The occasion provides a timely opportunity to explain what Miranda was and was not.

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After deduction of non-recurring litigation costs of $6.7 million, pretax.

title: HOME SHOPPING NETWORK reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company began broadcasting nationally on July 1, 1985, and went public on May 13, 1986.

title: Financial Corp. In Sears Deal
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that in an effort to gain more low-cost consumer deposits, its thrift unit had agreed to buy 16 branches from the Sears Savings Bank, which has $480 million in deposits. The agreement reflects

title: WALKER TESTIFIES IN FOOTBALL TRIAL
description: Testimony in the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League was limited yesterday to the cross-examination of Herschel Walker because of the absence of the U.S.F.L.'s lead attorney.

title: SALE OF U.P.I. WINS APPROVAL, ENDING A YEAR IN BANKRUPTCY
description: With champagne and a worldwide distribution of victory ties and scarves to staff members, United Press International yesterday celebrated its re-emergence as a financially independent news service after more than a year as a ward of the Federal bankruptcy court.

title: SHUTTLE PANEL IS FAULTED FOR NOT NAMING NAMES
description: Democratic senators complained today that the Presidential commission that investigated the space shuttle disaster failed to blame any individuals for the accident and did not vigorously pursue its investigation to the highest levels of the space agency and the White House.

title: HISTORIC DISTRICT BEING WEIGHED FOR RETAIL HUB
description: The proposed creation of one of the city's largest historic districts was debated yesterday before the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which will decide whether the hundreds of extravagant architectural remnants of New York's gaslight shopping mecca add up to one whole landmark.

title: RIVAL BLACKS BATTLE AT CAMP NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: Hundreds of black vigilantes, reportedly supported by the South African police and army, overran a tangled squatter camp near here today in a second straight day of fighting against a black anti-Government group.

title: SALADS OF GRAINS
description: WARM weather is arriving in earnest, a good excuse to spend some time experimenting with salads. Though salads made with a variety of fresh, crisp greens, now flooding our markets, certainly should be a part of everyone's daily diet, salads made with grains have many advantages. They are more filling than plain green salads and can often form the basis for a light meal. Whole grains are complex carbohydrates and an excellent source of fiber. Another advantage is that grain salads can be made in advance - indeed, they benefit from a period of maceration to develop their flavors.

title: Y.M.C.A.'S TAX STATUS CHALLENGED
description: After more than a century in the fitness business, Y.M.C.A.'s are besieged by commercial health clubs challenging their tax-exempt status in a pitched battle for America's exercise dollars.

title: Court Blocks Anderson, Clayton's Buyback Plan
description: The Delaware Chancery Court yesterday blocked Anderson, Clayton & Company, the Houston-based consumer products concern, from executing its management-sponsored recapitalization plan.

title: Condition Unchanged
description: The condition of Kathy Orsmby, the distance runner who suffered spinal damage and paralysis of her legs in a leap from a 50-foot bridge in Indianapolis last week, remained stable at Wishard Memorial Hospital. The condition of Miss Ormsby, 21 years old, who apparently attempted suicide after dropping out of the women's 10,000-meter run at the National Collegiate Athletic Associatioin track and field championships one week ago, was upgraded from serious to stable last weekend.

title: AU PAIR IN AMERICA: FIRST GROUP ARRIVES
description: THE au pairs have landed -or at least 36 of them have.

title: Remove Stigma From AIDS Test
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Labels for Fast Food - Last week, Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, introduced legislation to require that the ingredients be listed on the labels of fast food, in the process adding his name to a growing list of like-minded legislators and other Government officials. ''Millions of Americans with allergies, high blood pressure and other health problems suffer serious risks when eating these foods with unknown ingredients,'' said Mr. Solarz, whose bill is virtually identical to one introduced in the Senate last month by Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island. Labeling in fast-food restaurants would be enforced by the Food and Drug Administration and Department of Agriculture. Father's Day Chocolates

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day yesterday misstated the new position of Tom L. Roach at the Associated Dry Goods Corporation. He was named chairman and chief executive of the J. W. Robinson division.

title: WHITE HOUSE REJECTS NEW TAXES AS FINANCING FOR MILITARY BUILDUP
description: The White House said today that it opposed a proposal by the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee to use tax increases to pay for the higher military spending the Reagan Administration wants.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Macfadden Raises Offer for John Blair
description: Macfadden Holdings Inc., escalating a bidding war for several profitable broadcasting properties, yesterday sweetened its hostile offer for John Blair & Company to $30 a share in cash and a package of notes, or a total of about $340 million.

title: HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $36 million and a reversal of a tax credit of $2.3 million for the quarter and a loss of $35,666,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $15,433,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $2.5 million for the quarter and $3,461,000 for the 6 months. The 6 months' net was also after an extraordinary gain of $2,847,000.

title: BACHARACH-SAGER TEAM NO. 1 WITH 'ON MY OWN'
description: IN the fickle world of pop record making, where a hitless year can render a hot songwriter or producer obsolete, Burt Bacharach and Carole Bayer Sager are triumphant veterans. They wrote and produced ''On My Own,'' Patti La Belle's superbly crafted duet with Michael McDonald, which this week became the husband-wife team's second No. 1 single in six months. Last December, ''That's What Friends Are For,'' which they wrote and produced for Dionne and Friends -an all-star quartet led by Dionne Warwick, with Stevie Wonder, Gladys Knight and Elton John - rose to No. 1 and raised more than $500,000 for the American Foundation for AIDS Research. The two records have each sold more than a million copies, a feat achieved by only four other singles this year.

title: Canadian Club Classic To USAdvertising
description: USAdvertising, one of the agency subsidiaries of Lorimar-Telepictures, has been assigned Canadian Club Classic whisky by Hiram Walker Inc., effective Sept. 1.

title: Kaiser Outlook
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said that it expected losses from its aluminum division to widen in the second quarter, reflecting the negative impact of a mill fire at a fabrication plant, higher scrap metal costs and a less favorable product mix. However, the company said it expected third-quarter results to be better than those of both the first and second quarters.

title: Hot and Cold
description: The Minnesota Twins may be in sixth place, but they're also hitting home runs at a pace that, at least by first appearances, threatens the major leagues' single-season record of 240, set by the Yankees of Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle in 1961. Inasmuch as the Twins are not particularly renowned as a collection of power hitters, the current barrage is being widely attributed to their indoor stadium, the Metrodome.

title: Memories of Vietnam
description: A close vote is expected today on a bill that would authorize the award of Congressional Gold Medals to the three people who mounted the successful campaign to establish the Vietnam Veterans Memorial.

title: Guilty Plea in Plane Bombing
description: A man pleaded guilty today to placing a bomb on a jetliner carrying his wife and three children, apparently to get insurance money. The bomb exploded in the luggage compartment after the plane, an American Airlines jetliner, landed at Dallas Oct. 30, causing minor damage but no injuries.

title: SRI LANKANS LAMENT LOSS OF A LINGUISTIC BRIDGE
description: Bombs have come to Colombo, bringing fear, heightening wariness between ethnic groups and shattering the confidence of a cosmopolitan city that was once a model of progress and development for southern Asia.

title: ON 125TH ST., NEW HOPE FOR HARLEM'S RENEWAL
description: The restoration of the Apollo Theater along with a number of more modest recent projects have fueled a new optimism along 125th Street in Harlem, an area accustomed to proposals rather than results.

title: CHARLES L. STILLMAN
description: Charles Latimer Stillman, former executive vice president and treasurer of Time Inc., died of pneumonia Sunday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.

title: Israelis Detain Palestinians
description: Israeli security forces have detained two Palestinian guerrilla squads suspected of planting bombs in Israel and mines at Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, a military communique said tonight. It did not disclose the total number of suspects detained in two separate sweeps in the West Bank.

title: BABY DOE DECISION: A TENTATIVE FIRST STEP ON A PROFOUND ISSUE
description: The Supreme Court decision on Monday invalidating Federal regulations designed to require life-prolonging medical treatment for severely handicapped infants is seen as a major ruling, but only one step in the long and painful development of new policies to govern society in the face of rapidly advancing medical capabilities.

title: 'SALUTE TO YOUTH' ON 13, WITH LUCIANO PAVAROTTI
description: TONIGHT'S music special on WNET/Channel 13 at 9 o'clock certainly has a ringing title: ''Pavarotti in the Verdi Requiem: A Salute to Youth.'' But on second glance, it does seem a bit odd. After all, unlike the Brahms ''Requiem,'' which employs settings from the Bible, the Verdi composition is very much a mass for the dead. Most of the youth I know would appreciate something less somber than a ''missa pro defunctis'' by way of a salute.

title: Citicorp Rates On Paper Drop
description: Rates fell yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper, as the bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day commercial paper at an average rate of 6.799 percent, down from 6.837 percent last week.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $115,000 for the quarter and $351,000 for the 6 months.

title: Bonn Reports Arrest Of American in Spy Case
description: West Germany said today that an American had been arrested on espionage charges. West German security sources said he was a former soldier who had offered to sell information to the Soviet bloc.

title: PLAYING AGAIN AT THE APOLLO: TOP DOG NIGHT
description: Ralph Cooper climbed the steps from the stage to the dressing rooms of the Apollo Theater. ''This is the stairway,'' he said. ''The stairway to the stars.''

title: Beirut Airs TV Appeal
description: Lebanese television today aired a videotape showing Glenn Richard Anderson Jr., a cancer-stricken American, pleading for the release of his brother, Terry Anderson, correspondent for The Associated Press, who is being held hostage. Glenn Anderson died three days ago after having recorded the two-minute tape.

title: WHITE HOUSE SIDES WITH STATE DEPARTMENT ON ISRAELI SPYING ISSUE
description: The White House today publicly took the side of the State Department in its dispute with the Justice Department over whether there is evidence of wide Israeli spying in this country.

title: Mayor of Atlantic City Re-elected to Full Term
description: Mayor James L. Usry was re-elected today to his first full four-year term by a margin of 1,329 votes over Assemblywoman Dolores G. Cooper.

title: In 1986, All Animals Are Equally Politicized
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Michael Curtis and Jean LaPoint, pitchers; Darren Eggleston, shortstop; Michael Reeder, first baseman; and Eddie Williams and Eric Woods, outfielders.

title: 66 Concerns Form Insurance Unit
description: In a move to provide commercial liability coverage, 66 major companies have invested $395 million to create a new offshore insurance company. Under the plan, each corporation would invest $5 million or $10 million in Exel Ltd., parent company for the X. L. Insurance Company Ltd., a Barbados subsidiary.

title: Anti-Americanism Grows New Roots
description: Widespread European criticism of President Reagan's announcement that the United States may no longer comply with the second strategic arms limitation accord has brought into focus the increasingly common European view that American society is violent, chaotic, crime-ridden and, under President Reagan, hell-bent on the use of force.

title: A HARD ROAD FOR 'DADDY'S LITTLE GIRL'
description: Compared with their brothers, daughters often enjoy closer relationships with their fathers, who are less likely to see them as a competitive threat, psychologists and behavior specialists say. But the daughters can have an even tougher time than their brothers in proving themselves and being taken seriously. No matter how old they are, to their fathers - and often to the company's customers and employees - many say, they are always ''Daddy's little girl.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Clear Channel Communications Inc., San Antonio, said it had agreed to buy two radio stations, WHAS-AM and WMAZ-AM, from the Bingham family of Louisville, Ky., for $20.1 million.

title: IOWA SHEEP FARM'S COTTAGE INDUSTRY
description: A couple from the city who knew nothing about farming or sheep moved to a farm several years ago. The woman took up knitting as a hobby to pass the time. Eventually, with an excess of wool sitting around the house, she started her own knitwear business.

title: SHIPMENT OF ARMS IS CALLED ROUTINE
description: Western diplomats and others who monitor the Sandinista Army said this week that a shipment of Soviet weapons that arrived here by freighter last month did not represent a major new development in Nicaragua's military preparations.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the finest American foods is crab. Whether it be blue crab from the Chesapeake, Dungeness crab from the Pacific or stone crabs from the Florida coast, there is a sweetness and meatiness about the flesh that may be equaled but cannot be surpassed by crab found elsewhere in the world. Small wonder that crab cakes are one of this nation's gastronomic treasures.

title: NEW ACTION URGED IN FORD GEAR CASE
description: The General Accounting Office recommended today that the Government take further action to reduce accidents caused when certain Ford automobiles equipped with automatic transmissions slip from park into reverse.

title: THE ISRAELI ARMY FILMS ITS TROUBLES IN LEBANON
description: In the last year of Israel's occupation of Lebanon, the Israeli Army decided to produce a training film to prepare soldiers for fighting in a country so torn by war that not even the law of the jungle seemed to apply.

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
The Clangorous Pop Of Depeche Mode
description: The British pop quartet, Depeche Mode, which accomplished the feat of selling out three shows at Radio City Music Hall this weekend without the benefit of a hit single or top-selling album, has amassed a large and fervent cult following through a shrewd mixing and matching of styles.

title: U.S. ACTS TO SPEED RECOMMENDATIONS OF SHUTTLE PANEL
description: The Reagan Administration is moving quickly to order the space agency to carry out all recommendations of the Presidential commission and not resist any onerous changes and tests even if they might further delay space shuttle flights, senior White House officials said today.

title: Time for Politicians to Play With Expectations
description: In the world of politics, it is time again for the Great Expectation Game.

title: Lindenauer's Lawyer Says Client Is Not Ill
description: A lawyer for Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the Government's key witness in its municipal corruption case, yesterday denied assertions that Mr. Lindenauer had recently suffered a nervous breakdown.

title: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY: GRADUATES URGED TO BE LOYAL
description: Princeton University's president, William G. Bowen, urged graduating seniors today to remain loyal to the university in coming years.

title: Texas School Vigilantes Are Given Jail Terms
description: Five members of the Legion of Doom, a student vigilante group that sought to eliminate crime and drug abuse at a high school by intimidating suspected wrongdoers, have been sent to jail.

title: RECORDS REBUT CITY ON WOMAN IN SHOVING CASE
description: The State Court of Appeals disclosed today that a doctor had recommended the release of a mental patient just weeks before she was charged with pushing a stranger into the path of a Manhattan subway train last October.

title: Will Albany Promote Parks, Open Space?
description: Within the next two weeks, the New York State Legislature can make history. It can approve a bond issue to assure adequate open space and urban park land for the foreseeable future - or it can muff the ball and cheat generations to come of their rightful heritage.

title: Penalty Seen For Bank Leu
description: Bank Leu International, the Bahamian subsidiary of a Swiss bank, may be forced out of Nassau's Association of International Banks and Trust Companies, the leading trade group, because of its admitted involvement in the Dennis B. Levine insider trading case on Wall Street, according to bankers in the Bahamas.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The California Department of Water Resources is offering $210 million of Central Valley Project facilities revenue bonds through underwriters led by the Bank of America.

title: Sperry Chairman Reduces His Stake
description: Gerald G. Probst, chairman of the Sperry Corporation, reduced his stake in the New York-based computer concern after it had agreed to be acquired by the Burroughs Corporation.

title: Hostage to Fashion
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: FINNS RECORD SUDDEN BURST OF RADIATION
description: Authorities said today that a Finnish monitoring station near the Soviet Union had recorded a mysterious, 10-second peak of atmospheric radiation levels even higher than those recorded immediately after the Chernobyl nuclear accident.

title: The U.N. Today: June 11, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Arrests in Wife's Death At Westchester Home
description: The husband of a woman who was killed Monday and a man who the police said he hired to kill her were arrested and charged with second-degree murder, the police said today.

title: 20 Are Killed in Crash Of an Egyptian Airliner
description: An Egyptian airliner that had been diverted to Alexandria because of sandstorms crashed today as it was returning to Cairo, and 20 of the 25 people aboard were killed, officials reported.

title: YANKS ESCAPE; METS WIN IN 11Th, 8-4
description: To Tim Teufel, pinch-hitting in the bottom of the 11th inning last night in Shea Stadium, ''it looked like a lot of people were on top of me.'' And he was right.

title: President of Gruss Shuns Limelight
description: A little-known Wall Street firm called Gruss & Company moved into the limelight this month when it teamed with Bear, Stearns & Company in an effort to take over Anderson, Clayton & Company for $655 million. Martin Gruss, the firm's president, is hoping for a successful conclusion but rues the loss of privacy that comes with publicity.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 10
description: b-After a charge of $357,000 relating to union pension matters for the quarter and 9 months.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 11, 1986
description: International

title: 'CHILDREN OF ELLIS ISLAND'
description: WARMING up for next month's Statue of Liberty ceremonies, which already are causing some viewers to yearn to breathe free, a modest half-hour program called ''The Children of Ellis Island'' is offered today on ABC at 4 P.M. There are no surprises, and the talk of the American Dream inevitably sounds sentimental, but the sentiments are wholesome enough.

title: IRAQ-SYRIA TALKS EXPECTED FRIDAY
description: A meeting between the Foreign Ministers of Iraq and Syria, which have been political foes for years, is planned on Friday along the countries' border, an Arab diplomat said here early today.

title: Britain Halts the Sale Of Children's Aspirin
description: All children's aspirin products are being withdrawn from sale in Britain because of United States research suggesting a link between aspirin and Reye's syndrome, a rare but often fatal childhood disease, a manufacturers' group said today.

title: SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
TALK AGAIN OF SPINKS-COONEY
description: Over the weekend, Dennis Rappaport, the manager of Gerry Cooney, got a telegram from Butch Lewis, the promoter of Michael Spinks, the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion.

title: Reagan News Session To Be Broadcast at 8
description: President Reagan's news conference tonight will be broadcast live at 8 P.M. on the CBS, NBC and ABC television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network. WNET, a PBS affiliate in New York City, will give a tape-delayed broadcast at midnight.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss. The latest quarter results have been restated to reflect only that quarter's share of the pension credit adjustment in accordance with provisions of FASB 87.

title: FROM DANTE TO DARLING
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti once described himself as a household name only in his own household. An apt description, perhaps, for someone who just six years ago was teaching college kids a course in Myths and Mythography in Renaissance Cultures.

title: Down With the Press
description: The press has been criticized more than usual here lately by such philosophers as Cappy Weinberger at the Pentagon and Bill Casey at the C.I.A. We are, they say, a nosy and cheeky bunch, which is true, always interfering with their good intentions, and deserve to be condemned. Most folks seem to agree and so do I, but for a different reason.

title: NEW YORK CITY TO ADD OFFICERS FOR THE FOURTH
description: New York City officials, responding to complaints from community leaders, agreed today to improve preparations for the city's Fourth of July weekend festival and the millions of spectators it is expected to draw.

title: South Korea Is Accused Of Torturing Dissidents
description: An Amnesty International report on South Korea says that hundreds of people are jailed each year for criticizing the Government and that some are tortured to extract false confessions.

title: YONKERS COUNCIL VOTES TO APPEAL COURT ORDERED DESEGREGATION PLAN
description: The Yonkers City Council voted 10 to 3 tonight to appeal a Federal court order directing the city to finance a $37 million school desegregation plan and to develop low- and moderate-income housing in predominanty white neighborhoods.

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Japanese Trade Surplus Record
description: Japan released figures today showing yet another record trade surplus, but there was a glimmer of hope for its major trade partners beneath the surface of the raw statistics.

title: CITY ANNOUNCES PROGRAM TO CURB INFANT DEATHS AMONG HOMELESS
description: Mayor Koch announced a $1.6 million medical program yesterday for homeless families housed in welfare hotels. The program, officials said, should significantly reduce the high infant-mortality rate in the hotels.

title: VOTERS IN MAINE DEFEAT ANTI-OBSCENITY PLAN
description: A ballot issue that would have made it a crime to sell or promote obscene materials was defeated today, with incomplete returns showing a wide margin of opposition.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Excludes gains of $1,041,000 for the latest quarter and $638,000 for the year-ago period on disposition of rental properties.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 11, 1986
description: International

title: New Works by Mamet And Miller to Be Read
description: New short works by the playwrights David Mamet and Arthur Miller will be presented in a benefit reading on Monday at 7:30 P.M. at the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street, between Ninth and Tenth Avenues. A cast of noted actors, including Danny Aiello, Georg Stafford Brown, John Mahoney, Ben Stiller and Wallace Shawn will take part in the staged reading to benefit New Writers at the Westside, a group at the theater that features works in progress by new playwrights.

title: MILITARY REACTORS ARE ISSUE AT NUCLEAR PARLEY IN VIENNA
description: Countries with nuclear weapons are undecided whether to allow military nuclear plants to be covered by a treaty requiring prompt notification of any nuclear accidents.

title: CORRECTION
description: Charts in the special SportsMonday report this week about the United States Open, with an article about runners-up, misstated the career PGA Tour earnings for three golfers.

title: ITALIANS SAY ABBAS MASTERMINDED SHIP HIJACKING
description: A report by Italian prosecutors has accused the Palestinian leader Mohammed Abbas of masterminding the hijacking of the Italian liner Achille Lauro last October.

title: Of Wiesel and Reagan
description: While at the White House last year to meet with President Reagan, Elie Wiesel was practically immobilized by anguish. The President, determined to carry on with his planned visit to a cemetery in Bitburg, West Germany, had said that most of the German soldiers in the cemetery were as much the victims of the Nazis as the Jewish prisoners in the concentration camps.

title: In Re Letter and Spirit of Lobbying
description: Leo Levin, director of the Federal Judicial Center, recently recalled the Talmudic tale of a highly placed rabbi who had hired two workers to carry a cask of wine. The workers dropped the cask, and the rabbi refused to pay them, instead suing them for negligence. A religious court ordered the rabbi to pay the workers. ''Is this the law?'' the rabbi asked. ''For you it is,'' the judge replied.

title: ACCORD ON LOANS TO RESCUE MEXICO IS REPORTED NEAR
description: Agreement on a $5 billion to $6 billion package of new loans to help Mexico cope with its debts and deteriorating economy is near, Reagan Administration and international banking authorities indicated today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An art review in Weekend last Friday misstated the admission policy at the Center for African Art, 54 East 68th Street. The suggested contributions are $2.50 for adults and $1.50 for students and those over 65.

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
METS' LEE MAY JR. HOPES TO UPHOLD FAMILY TRADITION
description: Lee May Sr. would try to get his son to go out and shag fly balls as the Baltimore Orioles took batting practice, but the boy preferred to stand by the cage and watch the big men hit the ball out of the park. He always liked the power hitters.

title: SPEAR REPORTED CLOSE TO SELLING UNIT
description: Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a large securities firm that acts principally as a broker's broker, has failed in its efforts to sell all or a portion of the firm at its asking price, but is close to selling its options clearing unit to a British financial institution, according to a source close to the talks.

title: WINE TALK
description: WRITING in Le Petit Journal here the other day, the magazine's restaurant critic, Vincent Toledano, noted in French: ''The Americans may not have the right to fly over France, but they can still open restaurants.'' Then he added, in Franglais: ''Vraiment too much, non?''

title: Behind the Ow! in the Dow
description: Monday's record 46-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average wasn't quite as dramatic as it first appeared. For one thing, it only went down three more points yesterday. And in percentage terms the Monday drop was 2.4 percent, less than the 3.5 percent drop of Oct. 25, 1982, and much less than the 12.8 percent drop on Oct. 28, 1929.

title: More Eastern Jobs
description: Eastern Airlines has begun a campaign to hire 1,300 flight attendants by October, a company spokesman said. The move comes less than six months after the carrier laid off 1,010 flight attendants in the face of a financial crisis. Increased flight schedules and a high attrition rate among flight attendants are forcing Eastern to begin one of its most aggressive efforts to increase its air crews, according to Woody Montgomery, the manager of Eastern's flight crew employmement.

title: Senior P.L.O. Member Is Slain in Athens
description: An Arab was shot and killed by two men in downtown Athens on Monday, and today the Palestine Liberation Organization said he was a top-ranking member of the group.

title: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Year to March 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $261,000, or 12 cents a share.

title: WARD ASKS DRUG TEST FOR ALL OFFICERS
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that he strongly favored unannounced drug testing for all police officers as a means of preventing corruption and impaired ability.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: T.V.A., ONCE MODEL AGENCY, NOW SWAMPED BY TROUBLES
description: When it was created in 1933, the Tennessee Valley Authority embodied the very essence of New Deal idealism: It was to build the dams and tame the rivers and bring electricity and economic possibility to the poor hills of the middle South.

title: COMPUTER CHIP INDEX DECLINES
description: A closely watched indicator of the health of the semiconductor industry declined in May for the first time in nine months, providing some of the first statistical evidence that the recovery in the computer-chip business has stalled.

title: MARSHALL DREW
description: Marshall Drew, a survivor of the Titanic, died Friday at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Westerly, L.I.

title: Teamsters to Represent Capital School Workers
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters won the right to represent 2,500 employees of the city's public school system today, defeating a rival labor group in a hard-fought, expensive battle.

title: McDonnell Chip
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had developed a new gallium arsenide integrated computer chip for use as a microprocessor.

title: SOUTHWEST COOKING MARRIES NEW AND OLD
description: THERE is little point in trying to untangle the complexities of Southwestern food, setting right the names of each variety of chili, meticulously delineating what is Mexican, Tex-Mex or Southern, what is Indian, Spanish or Anglo. The commingling of cultures has been going on for centuries. The result is food that is earthy, exotic and compelling. So much so that America is currently in love with any combination of chilies, corn, beans, tomatillos and cilantro, what the San Franciscan chef Jeremiah Tower calls ''glamorous but approachable food, reflecting the open air, the open spaces and the beautiful colors of the region.''

title: CITY BALLET: 'SWAN LAKE' DANCED AT STATE THEATER
description: NO doubt about it, the stars of the New York City Ballet's new production of ''Swan Lake'' are the costumes and scenery. The choreography of George Balanchine's one-act version is still intact, but it has been dressed up to very different and spectacular effect.

title: CONTRAS RELEASE 8 WEST GERMANS HELD FOR 24 DAYS
description: Eight West Germans captured by anti-Government rebels 24 days ago were freed this evening, according to a report on the Nicaraguan Government television.

title: Ratings Error Changes NBC Win Into a Draw
description: Just as ''NBC Nightly News with Tom Brokaw'' was celebrating a second straight weekly win over CBS News yesterday, the A. C. Nielsen Company announced a mix-up in its ratings that negated NBC's victory last week.

title: AZTECH INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MAPMAKERS GO HOLLYWOOD IN MANHATTAN
description: Now, after decades of lagging behind Los Angeles, and just in time for the opening of the tourist season, New York City has its own ''Map of the Stars' Homes.''

title: Windshield Mayhem
description: To the Editor:

title: PROGRESS ON AN OYSTER FOR ALL SEASONS
description: OYSTER lovers who do not eat oysters during warm weather may be in for a surprise. Sandra L. Downing and Standish Allen, research associates at the University of Washington School of Fisheries in Seattle, have developed an all-season oyster that reportedly stays firm and sweet year round.

title: A Source of Help
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Textiles Split U. S., Seoul
description: The United States and South Korea have failed to agree on the size of Seoul's future textile exports to Washington, trade officials said today. The two countries have held talks over the last two days on a United States bid to freeze imports from South Korea at 1985 levels for the next three years.

title: FOR DAD, GIFTS AND WEARABLES
description: 1. Black, White and Soft These matching ''his and her'' cotton terry cloth robes in Dalmatian prints are available in two combinations, white spots on a black background and black spots on white.

title: The Mysteries Of Belle Glade
description: To the Editor:

title: TUROFF IS INDICTED ON FRAUD COUNTS
description: New York City's former taxi chief, Jay L. Turoff, was indicted yesterday on charges of fraud, conspiracy and tax evasion by a Federal grand jury that said he had used his official position to enrich himself and business associates.

title: SCREEN: A YOUTH'S DAY OFF
description: FERRIS BUELLER, an amazing high-school senior, leads a charmed life. First of all, he is actually popular across group lines - breaking a teen-age hierarchy that makes India's caste system look egalitarian. The jocks, druggies, heavy-metal types, preppies, losers, grinds and popular kids all think he's swell. Why? Because he has that magic ability so prized in adolescence - he can get away with anything.

title: Dear DC Comics
description: We write as friends. We like your plan to modernize Superman. Still, we'd like to make a passionate suggestion.

title: FILM: 'EYES OF THE BIRDS' DEPICTS URUGUAYAN JAIL
description: THE Uruguayan prison for political prisoners is called - in the logic of authoritarianism - Libertad (Liberty).

title: NORTH, WINNER IN '85, EYES 3d OPEN TITLE
description: Andy North, who won the United States Open championship in 1978 and again last year, still smarts from some of the remarks after his first title, at Cherry Hills Country Club in Denver.

title: FLAKE HAS SLIGHT LEAD IN QUEENS HOUSE VOTE
description: The Rev. Floyd Flake, a Democrat running as an independent in a five-way special election to choose a successor to the late Representative Joseph P. Addabbo in Queens, led Assemblyman Alton R. Waldon, the Democratic organization nominee, by 41 votes out of nearly 40,000 in a virtually complete count of returns last night.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: NO doubt you've heard about spectacular athletic accomplishments by the elderly such as the California physician Paul Spangler, who began running at age 67 and went on to set more than 40 records by age 85. Or the tennis champion Kirk M. Reid, who at 80 was still winning national tournaments. Although these are unusual people in exceptionally good physical condition, their stories have significance for older men and women with far less athletic prowess.

title: WHAT HAS RED, GREEN AND JOY ALL OVER?
description: In this city, which has produced Paul Revere, John Adams and John F. Kennedy, there is only one man who has been deified by a statue erected in his lifetime - Arnold Auerbach.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SETTING THE STAGE - ''Take 1/New York on Film,'' an exhibition beginning today at the Queens Museum (718-592-2405), concerns movie production designers, the people who head art departments, build and plan the sets and create the tone and look of a film. They devise a screen reality that supports and enhances the characters and story. The designers' drawings, designs, models and other tools of the trade are the preliminary work of movies. The exhibition consists of these tools for 18 movies made in and around New York, films including ''The Cotton Club,'' ''Heartburn,'' ''Prince of the City,'' ''The King of Comedy'' and ''Manhattan.''

title: It's Gretzky Again
description: Wayne Gretzky was awarded the Hart Trophy last night as the most valuable player in the National Hockey League for an unparalleled seventh straight season. Gretzky, the 25-year-old center for the Edmonton Oilers, scored a record 215 points on 52 goals and 163 assists.

title: 'Cuba and Teddy Bear' May Move to Broadway
description: ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear,'' a play written by Reinaldo Povod and starring Robert DeNiro that is scheduled to end an eight-week run Saturday at the Public Theater, will ''most probably'' move to Broadway's Longacre Theater in July, according to Joseph Papp, director of the Public Theater.

title: George Hirsch in Race For House Seat in City
description: George Hirsch, publisher of The Runner magazine, declared his candidacy yesterday for the House of Representatives from the 15th District, on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Scoa Plans to Sell Dry Goods Unit
description: The Dry Goods Company, formerly known as the Wilmington Dry Goods Company, is being sold by Scoa Industries to a group including Oppenheimer & Company and two executives of the Cohoes Specialty Stores Ltd. of Cohoes, N.Y. The Dry Goods chain operates seven department stores in Delaware, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, with offices in Aston, Pa., and has estimated annual sales of about $100 million.

title: BERCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Net income.

title: Another Moment of Truth for Mexico
description: Time is running out for debt-ridden Mexico, once again in financial crisis. Export revenues, cut one-third by the oil glut, fall well short of covering the country's minimum needs. Foreign exchange reserves are dwindling and panic has hit the peso. A short-term rescue package is being negotiated with the Reagan Administration involving funds from several sources. Without it, the prospects are default or hyperinflation or political crisis or some combination of the three.

title: 50 Years for S.I. Zoo
description: Fifty years ago to the day yesterday, the Staten Island Zoo opened. As zoos go, the one on Staten Island, operated by the Staten Island Zoological Society, is not large - four and a half acres compared with more than 200 acres for the Bronx Zoo.

title: BANKERS CAUTIOUS OVER RESCUE PACKAGE
description: Bankers reacted cautiously yesterday to news that a financial rescue package for Mexico was imminent, saying they had known about the package for months and that, its success still depended on Mexico's agreeing to an International Monetary Fund economic program.

title: INFANT UNDERGOES SURGERY AFTER HEART DONOR IS FOUND
description: A 16-day-old baby underwent heart-transplant surgery today after a nationally televised announcement that a brain-dead donor was available.

title: 15 Years of Pride
description: The Washington-based Women's Legal Defense Fund, founded in 1971 by a group of young feminist lawyers, some just out of law school, celebrates its 15th anniversary today with some reason for a feeling of accomplishment. Among its founders are Marna Tucker, first woman to become president of the District of Columbia Bar Association; Isobel Dunst, associate general counsel of the Department of Health and Human Services; Susan Ross, professor of law at Georgetown University Law School; Judge Gladys Kessler of the District of Columbia Superior Court, and several partners in Washington law firms.

title: Aquino Murder Petition
description: A commission appointed by the Supreme Court will begin hearings Monday on a petition seeking to reopen the trial of the former military chief, Gen. Fabian Ver, and 25 other people acquitted of involvement in the killing of President Corazon C. Aquino's husband, Benigno.

title: KILLER OF 4 MEMBERS OF A FAMILY IN SEATTLE IS SENTENCED TO DEATH
description: A self-proclaimed soldier against Communism faces a death sentence after a verdict today by the same jury that last week found him guilty of murdering four members of the locally prominent Charles Goldmark family.

title: Real Estate; Luxurious New Hotel At Taft Site
description: WHEN the redevelopers of the old Taft Hotel announced two years ago that they would convert the 60-year-old structure at 51st Street and Seventh Avenue into Executive Plaza, a mixed-use residential and commercial building, they said the new hotel to be included would have 270 moderately priced rooms.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Business Roundtable, an association of chief executive officers of some 200 corporations, elected as its chairman Roger B. Smith, chairman and chief executive officer of General Motors Corp.

title: Pit Bull Kills Michigan Baby
description: A 20-month-old boy playing outside his home was mauled to death today by a pit bull, and his mother was injured trying to rescue him, the authorities said.

title: DR. ISRAEL KNOX
description: Dr. Israel Knox, an author and a retired professor of philosophy, died Monday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Livingston Awards Are Given To Four Reporters Under 35
description: Four reporters were named the winners yesterday of the 1986 Livingston Awards, which honor print and broadcast journalists under the age of 35.

title: CONTRACTORS CALLED LAX ON KICKBACK TAKERS
description: Employees who leave military contractors while under suspicion of receiving kickbacks from subcontractors often are able to find new jobs with other military contractors, according to Congressional officials who have been investigating the aerospace industry's practices.

title: PLAN FOR TOURIST TRAIN IN THE NAPA VALLEY DIVIDES RESIDENTS
description: ON a cloudless spring day, a hot-air balloon drifts over the Napa Valley. Below, the vineyards are green and vibrant again after months of winter dormancy and a disastrous flood. With luck and good weather, the grapes, just green and black buds now, will be plump and juicy by September, ready for harvesting, crushing and bottling into a new vintage of chardonnay, cabernet sauvignon, pinot noir, sauvignon blanc and other premium wines.

title: McLAUGHLIN SAID TO SEEK PLEA DEAL
description: The former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, John J. McLaughlin, has offered to plead guilty to fraud charges and provide information about municipal corruption, senior law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Loss Doubles At Alfa Romeo
description: Alfa Romeo S.p.A., the Italian automobile maker, reported today that it slipped further into the red in 1985, with losses more than doubling to 245 billion lire, or about $163 million. Losses for the company's 1984 fiscal year had been put at 111 billion lire, or about $74 million.

title: ROY D. WOOSTER
description: Roy D. Wooster, former chairman of the Borden Company, died of pneumonia Sunday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Addendum
description: * Adam I. Friedman & Associates, Greenwich, Conn., and Kanan, Corbin, Shupak & Aronow, New York, have merged to form KCS&A/Adam I. Friedman Group, a public relations firm.

title: POWER IN PURSE STRINGS
description: Whether they are pompon-waving alumni motivated by school pride or successful businessmen trying to enhance their standing in the community, athletic boosters have secured a prominent role at universities that have teams playing major sports. Because those universities can no longer meet the increased costs of athletic programs with money earned just from ticket revenues and television rights, boosters are being counted on more than ever to provide financial aid.

title: KNEPPER WINS 10th AS ASTROS ROLL, 12-1
description: Bob Knepper pitched a four-hitter to become the National League's first 10-game winner, and Kevin Bass and Bill Doran each hit home runs as the Houston Astros routed the San Diego Padres, 12-1, tonight.

title: Why Not Begin Schooling With 3-Year-Olds?
description: To the Editor:

title: NOW SEEKS TO CURB ANTI-ABORTIONISTS
description: The National Organization for Women announced today that it had filed a lawsuit seeking to put people who try to drive abortion clinics out of business under the same legal restraints that have curtailed the activities of the Ku Klux Klan.

title: FUNDAMENTALIST CHOSEN BY SOUTHERN BAPTISTS
description: The Rev. Adrian Rogers, a popular Memphis preacher, was elected today as the president of the Southern Baptist Convention, a victory that places fundamentalists in a position to take full control of the nation's largest Protestant denomination.

title: Market Place; Big New Issue Of MAI Basic
description: THE biggest initial public offering since mid-1983 from the high-technology industry - 5 million shares of MAI Basic Four Inc. - is expected to reach the market around late June. The preliminary pricing for the stock, with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. acting as lead underwriter, is between $17 and $20 a share.

title: Acronymic Opining
description: At a breakfast meeting with reporters yesterday, Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, mused over what he called the Reagan Administration's ''mind-boggling'' process of making foreign policy. He concluded that it really was no more than Bogsatt. Huh? ''Bunch of guys sitting around the table,'' said Mr. Aspin, an old Pentagon hand with a penchant for acronyms.

title: Peso Gains 11.7% Against Dollar
description: Mexico's peso, after falling 30 percent in value against the dollar in the last six trading days, bounced back sharply today to close at 642 pesos to the dollar in bank exchange houses, a gain of 85 pesos, or 11.7 percent.

title: WHEN THE RELATIVES FALL OUT
description: His wife, Vicki, stands stone-faced and silent, but Sam Sebastiani cannot hide his anguish as he chews a Tums in his home in the hills of California's wine country and mourns the loss of his job and his family. After he spent six years struggling to save his family's winery following his father's death, he said bitterly, his mother, brother and sister have rewarded his efforts by throwing him out.

title: Being a Good Patient
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Fit That in Your Pipe
description: A sign at the entrance to the parking lot of the Pipe Fitters Union on Massachusetts Avenue warns, ''This lot is American Made and will accept American Made Vehicles Only.''

title: Little Lady Liberty
description: As part of the observance of the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty, late this month Meridian House International will display a 50-inch-high scale model of the statue, cast in 1886 by the sculptor of the monument, Frederic Auguste Bartholdi.

title: Front-Runners
description: Heading into last night's play, the Mets were setting a pace that would give them a 13-game lead at the midseason break, the largest halfway-point margin since baseball began taking a summer respite for the All-Star Game in 1933. That alone may be good news for New York, but it gets better: All the clubs that have entered the break with a lead of at least 10 games have gone on to finish in first place, most of them by even wider margins. Here's the list:

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
YANKS ESCAPE; TIGERS BEATEN, 6-3
description: After the Yankees pulled out an 11-inning, 9-7 victory over Detroit Monday night, Lou Piniella was giddy, joking in his relief over the outcome. Tonight, the Yankees held on for a 6-3 victory over the Tigers, but the manager wasn't laughing.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WE'VE all seen them in recent months in the rear windows of cars, those ubiquitous diamond-shaped yellow stickers that say in black lettering:

title: SIDNEY LANIER
description: Sidney Lanier, a former senior vice president of Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died Friday at his home in Stamford, Conn.

title: 2 Bodies Found in Train That Derailed in Texas
description: Firefighters found two charred bodies today near the burning wreckage of a train that derailed Sunday while carrying dangerous chemicals, the authorities said.

title: Suitor of Esmark Plans To Broaden Its Lines
description: Byron A. Hero Jr., managing partner of Hero & Company, a private investment banking firm, has obtained a substantial stake in the women's leotard and hoisery industry.

title: Pernfors Dresses For Success, Fast
description: Ian Hamilton signs and services tennis endorsement contracts for Nike, and at the French Open one evening last week he was under more pressure than the players. As Nike's president, Phil Knight, put it to him, ''I give you the biggest budget in the world, and still you can't get us anybody in the final rounds.'' Like the hero in an old-fashioned success story, Hamilton declared over the long-distance wire, ''Hold on, I've got just the guy for you.''

title: Helpful New Yorkers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Envirodyne Offers Stock and Notes
description: Envirodyne Industries, a Chicago-based manufacturer of plastic dining products and electrical equipment, began an offering of common shares and 10-year subordinated notes in connection with debt it incurred for the purchase in February of the Union Carbide Corporation's film packaging business for more than $200 million.

title: TWO FEDERAL AGENCIES START DRUG ABUSE TESTS FOR JOBS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Drug Enforcement Administration have begun a widespread program to test thousands of new employees for drug abuse, the agencies said today.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
HOUSE PANEL BACKS NEW SOUTH AFRICAN SANCTIONS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved and sent to the floor today a measure that would impose a new range of economic sanctions against South Africa, setting the stage for another legislative confrontation with the White House.

title: Bridge: A Chicago-Based Company Sponsors an Event in Paris
description: An American visitor to a European tournament is likely to have at least two major surprises and one minor one. For example, in Paris in April, he would have found both cash prizes and a commercial sponsor: Molex, the Chicago-based manufacturer of electrical conductors.

title: Behind the Merger Of 2 Small Agencies
description: Agency mega-mergers may be grabbing the headlines and the imaginations of the industry. It's the size that makes the story. Mergers and acquisitions are nothing new along the Madison Avenues of this world. They are very much a part of the scene, but the smallish ones don't rate the headline treatment.

title: 3 Die in Sinking Off Sicily
description: At least three people died and 22 were missing today after a hydrofoil ferry sank in flames off the Sicilian coast, the Civil Protection Ministry said. The cause of the fire aboard the Freccia Di Messina, which carried 54 passengers and a crew of 6, was not known.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Tabasco Sauce Account Goes to Tracy-Locke
description: The 30-year relationship between the McIlhenny Company, maker and marketer of Tabasco sauce, and Fitzgerald Advertising of New Orleans has come to an end.

title: HART SEES SHIFT IN SUPERPOWER ROLES
description: Senator Gary Hart in effect staked out a foreign policy program today for use in his expected bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1988.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET SURVEY PLANE IS AIDING NICARAGUA
description: The White House said today that a Soviet reconnaissance plane based in Nicaragua had been flying missions over that country to help the Government there.

title: SOVIET PROPOSES MAJOR TROOP REDUCTIONS IN EUROPE
description: The Soviet Union proposed today that the Warsaw Pact alliance and its NATO counterpart each demobilize up to 150,000 soldiers in Europe within a year or two.

title: How Much Spying Between Friends?
description: No, it is not some ''anti-Israeli'' cabal in Washington that wonders whether Israel has yet made a clean breast of its espionage against the United States. Neither is it some group of naifs who think friendly governments never snoop on each other. The issue in American eyes is limits, which the Israelis, in their understandable embarrassment over the Pollard affair, do not yet recognize.

title: More New Products
description: The month of May and the first five months of the year saw record numbers of new-product introductions in the grocery products, toiletries and cosmetics fields, and the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News credits some of that record number to the large number of new products introduced during the Food Marketing Institute's annual convention. In May, there were 263 new products, up from 235 in the same month last year, while the first five months showed a total of 1,048, up from to 908.

title: PRESBYTERIANS ELECT FORMER HOSTAGE
description: The Rev. Benjamin Weir, a former missionary to Lebanon who was held hostage there for 16 months, was elected today to lead the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) ''I am aware that we live in a complex world and my church is realizing that in my election,'' Mr. Weir said after his election as moderator of the denomination of 3.1 million people, which was formed when the Northern and Southern branches of the Presbyterians merged in 1983.

title: THEATER: 'ELECTRIC MAN'
description: IF Mark Eisenstein's strange comedy ''Electric Man'' fails, it is not from lack of effort by Philip Bruns; it is simply the odd fate of this work to be more interesting in a reading, where it raises echoes of all kinds of classics, than in performance, where its unresolved contradictions become apparent.

title: FINNS BLAME FAULTY GEIGER COUNTER FOR RADIATION
description: A Finnish Government radiation expert yesterday discounted reports that a significant pulse of radiation had been been measured in his country earlier this week.

title: PANAMA STRONGMAN SAID TO TRADE IN DRUGS, ARMS AND ILLICIT MONEY
description: The army commander of Panama, a country vital to United States interests in Latin America, is extensively involved in illicit money laundering and drug activities and has provided a Latin American guerrilla group with arms, according to evidence collected by American intelligence agencies.

title: MONEY IN THE WIND
description: Wind was blustering across the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club yesterday when a Japanese visitor to the United States Open fished into his pants pocket. Suddenly half a dozen bills of American currency spun out and fluttered across the lawn sloping from the brown-shingled clubhouse designed in 1892 by Stanford White.

title: THE FURRIER'S SECRET: A 15-YEAR BOOM
description: SALES of furs have been booming for 15 years. ''It's one of the best kept secrets in the fashion business,'' said Bernard Groger, co-publisher of Fur World, a weekly fur trade newspaper. ''Outside the fur industry, few people are aware of this unbroken climb since 1971,'' he added.

title: RAIN STOPS, CLEMENS STARTS, GOES TO 11-0
description: Unbeaten Roger Clemens extended his streak tonight, with last-inning relief help from Bob Stanley, notching his 11th victory as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-2.

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Market Place; Best Returns For Investors
description: FINANCIAL assets - stocks and bonds - rank as kingpin investments so far in the 1980's, displacing collectibles and commodities that rewarded their holders so handsomely during the higher-inflation decade of the 1970's.

title: RESTRUCTURE AT UNION PACIFIC
description: The Union Pacific Corporation yesterday announced a costly restructuring that will include the buyout and retirement of many employees, the write-down of some oil and gas properties and a substantial buyback of its common stock.

title: The Court Pushes Back; Relief at Last for 'Baby Doe' Families
description: The child, born in October 1983 to a Long Island couple, suffered from birth defects that caused multiple mental and physical handicaps. Spinal surgery would prolong her life but would not correct her severe retardation. Her parents, after consultation with doctors, clergy and social workers, therefore chose more conservative treatment.

title: ROCHESTER COMMUNITY SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The per share earnings are not available because the bank converted from mutual to stock form on April 29.

title: Hot and Angry Words From the Wordsmiths
description: For five years, President Reagan's speechwriters have used their spirited prose to help him define his conservative ideology and agenda and to skewer his opponents. But now some of the writers are taking aim, with equal enthusiasm, at targets within the White House itself who they say are close to betraying the Reagan dream.

title: The Court Pushes Back; Landslides Do Not Legitimize Extremists
description: These have not been good days for the crusaders of the Reagan Justice Department - but they have been good for justice and a credit to the Supreme Court. In case after case the Court has been striking down cold, sometimes cruel Administration actions that shatter the bipartisan social consensus developed over three decades. The zealots have behaved as though the President's landslides gave them license to swing every pendulum hard to the right. Yesterday's abortion ruling is the latest example of Court decisions that push back, resolutely, to a decent center.

title: LURIA, L & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: FOR TEACHERS FROM SPAIN, A YEAR OF LEARNING
description: New York City students are harder to discipline than those in Spain, and the paperwork that comes from being a teacher in the city's public schools is much more than expected.

title: RESHUFFLING AFTER THE SHUTTLE DISASTER
description: NASA:

title: Basque Suspects Arrested
description: Spain's Civil Guard today arrested four suspected members of the Basque separatist guerrilla group near this northern coastal city, authorities said. They identified the detainees as Jose Maria Odriozola, Cayetano Carabias and two brothers, Jose Antonio and Jesus Maria Moraleja.

title: 'Loot' Cancels Closing
description: ''Loot,'' the revival of Joe Orton's 1966 farce, which posted its closing for Saturday, will remain open because of increased ticket sales. The play, which was directed by John Tillinger, will continue indefinitely at the Music Box Theater.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The defenseman Gaston Gingras, who rallied from an up-and-down National Hockey League career with a solid playoff performance to help the Canadiens to their 23d Stanley Cup, signed a two-year contract with Montreal. . . . The St. Louis Blues extended the contracts of the assistant coach Barclay Plager and his brother, Bob, who is an assistant to the director of operations. . . . The quarterback Mark Malone signed a multiyear contract with the Pittsburgh Steelers. He is entering his seventh year with the Steelers. . . . The Green Bay Packers have allowed the veteran quarterback Lynn Dickey to become a free agent after being unable to reach an agreement with him on contract terms.

title: WRESTLING WITH VULNERABILITY
description: Last year's sale of Richardson-Vicks Inc. to the Procter & Gamble Company for $1.22 billion sent shock waves through other family businesses. If Richardson-Vicks was vulnerable, their leaders reasoned, what family company was not?

title: ORGAN: THOMAS MURRAY
description: LISTENING to Thomas Murray play the organ at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Tuesday night was like turning the clock back 40 years and more to a time when most organ playing was in the vein of Mr. Murray's. Even then, E. Power Biggs and Carl Weinrich were leading a vanguard calling for a return to the principles that governed both design of instruments and keyboard performance in the time of Bach, but adherents were still very much in the minority. Since their ideas did win out, however, Mr. Murray's recital - with its Neo-Romantic emphasis - must be regarded as something of an anomaly in the 1980's.

title: ROY D. WOOSTER
description: Roy D. Wooster, former chairman of the Borden Company, died of pneumonia Sunday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Automatix Settlement
description: Automatix Inc., a designer and maker of factory robots, said it had settled a complaint filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. began an investigation after the company announced in March 1984 that it was correcting its financial statements for three quarters of 1983. By agreeing to a consent decree, which was announced Tuesday, Automatix did not admit any wrongdoing, but is enjoined from filing inaccurate reports in the future.

title: 2 Britons Jailed for Attempt To Dig Up the Body of a Duke
description: Two British animal rights campaigners who plotted to dig up the body of an aristocrat and mail his head to Queen Elizabeth's daughter, Princess Anne, were jailed for two years today.

title: FIRST UNION TO BUY GEORGIA BANK UNIT
description: The First Union Corporation, seeking to expand its presence in the lucrative Georgia banking market, agreed yesterday to acquire the First Railroad and Banking Company of Georgia in a stock swap valued at $779 million.

title: 2 Collateralized Mortgage Issues
description: Among some of the larger financings yesterday were two issues of collateralized mortgage obligations totaling $240 million by Oxford Acceptance Corporation III and Countrywide Mortgage Obligations Inc.

title: Greyhound Sees Fraud
description: The Greyhound Corporation said that it had lost more than $21 million because of a purportedly fraudulent scheme by two executives of its Swiss leasing and financing subsidiary.

title: THE DANCE: A CAST CHANGE IN GRAHAM'S 'CIRCUS
description: THE Martha Graham Dance Company's 60th anniversary season has brought back a wide-ranging group of revivals - including one of Miss Graham's rare comedy pieces, the 1939 ''Every Soul Is a Circus.''

title: House Chairman Calls Air Carrier 'Deficient'
description: Galaxy Airlines, which won a United States Air Force charter contract while a Federal safety panel was still investigating a crash in Nevada that killed 70 people, is ''deficient'' as an air carrier, the chairman of a House investigations subcommittee said Tuesday.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes gains of $1.2 million, or 13 cents a share, on the sale of securities for the quarter and the 6 months.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: REFORM: MANY IDEAS, LITTLE AGREEMENT
description: There is wide agreement among educators, coaches and athletic directors that college sports in America are beset with serious ills. But there is less agreement on what specifically is wrong, and almost none on the cure.

title: NO-CONTEST PLEA IN BELUSHI DEATH
description: Maintaining that she was not morally responsible for the drug overdose death of the comedian John Belushi, Cathy Evelyn Smith admitted in Superior Court here today that she had injected him with heroin and cocaine, which medical officials say caused his death.

title: JAMES AMSTER, 77, DECORATOR, DEAD
description: James Amster, an interior decorator known for his traditional design style and his longstanding community involvement on the East Side, died of leukemia yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: REGIONAL BANKS WARY OF ROLE IN LOAN PACKAGE
description: Small and midsized banks will again balk at participating in a financial rescue of Mexico if such a bailout involves providing significant amounts of new loans, the banks indicated yesterday.

title: OFFICER CLEARED IN FATAL SHOOTING
description: A New York City police officer has been acquitted of manslaughter in the fatal shooting of an unarmed man on a Brooklyn street last year.

title: Stopping the Press
description: Representative John F. Seiberling, Democrat from Ohio, is not a large man, but he can throw a mean body block.

title: Boy, 8, and a Girl, 7, Hurt in Separate Falls
description: An 8-year-old Bronx boy was critically injured in a fall from his sixth-floor apartment when a window guard gave way last night. An hour and a half later a 7-year-old Brooklyn girl sustained serious injuries when she fell three stories from a ledge connecting her apartment with the roof of a neighboring building.

title: Baby With New Heart Reported Doing Well
description: Baby Jesse, showing no signs that his body was rejecting a heart transplanted from a brain-dead Michigan infant, was described today as looking extremely well by his father.

title: P.S.A.L. Title To Tottenville
description: Nick Salerno hit a triple, double and single in three times at bat and he drove in one run and scored another yesterday to lead Tottenville to a 4-0 victory over Lafayette for the Public Schools Athletic League championship at Yankee Stadium before a crowd of 4,005.

title: ENTERTAINMENT MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MARSHALL DREW
description: Marshall Drew, a survivor of the Titanic, died Friday at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Westerly, L.I.

title: NETWORKS VS. FREE SPEECH
description: One would think that organizations that espouse the value and necessity of free speech would be reluctant to adopt rules that inhibit robust and wide-open debate. But that is exactly what the three commercial television networks have done in rejecting an advertisement about the Federal deficit produced by W. R. Grace and Company.

title: Storm Clouds In Cincinnati
description: When Marge Schott, a longtime Cincinnatian, bought principal interest in the Reds late in 1984 and kept the team from absentee ownership, she called her purchase a Christmas gift to the city. Now a number of the club's eight limited partners have begun to look that gift in the mouth, and the Reds give every appearance of suffering as much from turmoil in the front office as from setbacks on the field. There's even an effort afoot to have Mrs. Schott removed.

title: COVENT GARDEN 'FALSTAFF' ON THE A&E NETWORK
description: ''FALSTAFF,'' Verdi's last opera and one of only two comedies the composer created in his long career, is a mercurial work with no hint of valedictory. Indeed, this three-act opera, with a libretto distilled from Shakespeare by Arrigo Boito, is so rapidly paced, so full of youthful effervescence, that it is hard to believe it comes from the end of a career that spanned more than half a century.

title: Fox TV Stations
description: Fox Television Stations Inc., a unit of the News Corporation, said that on July 1 it would redeem $460 million worth of its increasing-rate exchangeable guaranteed preferred stock. Fox said the funds for the redemption would come from overseas borrowing and working capital. In a written statement, Rupert Murdoch, chief executive of the News Corporation, said, ''This redemption of high-cost securities will result in a significant reduction in annual carry costs and thereby should result in increased earnings during the next several years.''

title: BROWN-FORMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MICRON TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Net income.

title: WALDHEIM TEAM AT JUSTICE DEPT.
description: Kurt Waldheim sent his son and two lawyers to the Justice Department today to rebut allegations that the Austrian President-elect was involved in war crimes against Jews and Yugoslav guerrillas during his World War II service in the German Army.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes net gains from sales of securities of $500,000 for the quarter and $1,251,000 for the year. c-Net loss and includes a net loss of $2,009,000 from expenses related to the discontinuance of certain product lines. The 1985 results also reflected net capital gains of $399,000 for the year.

title: IN ISRAEL'S BUS-STOP WAR, A SYNAGOGUE BURNS TOO
description: Tensions between militantly Orthodox Jews and secular Jews worsened today, touching off a chaotic debate in Parliament and prompting the Prime Minister to call a special ministerial meeting.

title: WALDHEIM PLEDGES FIGHT AGAINST BIAS
description: Kurt Waldheim, holding his first news conference since his election as Austria's President, said today that his victorious election campaign had been devoid of appeals to anti-Semitism and he promised to oppose discrimination against Jews.

title: DECORATORS HAVE VANS, WILL TRAVEL
description: A FEW months ago, the subdivisions of North Edison, N.J., didn't matter much to Debbie Pryor. All those lanes, drives and crescents, all those houses with the whirling lawn sprinklers, had simply been a neighborhood, not the target of a decorating commando operation.

title: Addendum
description: * Edward G. Infurna has reacquired the assets of Mayo-Infurna Design from Saatchi & Saatchi Compton.

title: Chairman Leaving White Consolidated
description: A.B. Electrolux of Sweden said yesterday that Ward Smith, chairman of its newly acquired White Consolidated Industries, was leaving the company.

title: BOTNICK DISPLAYED WIT AS WELL AS BRASHNESS
description: There are no detailed press releases about Victor E. Botnick in the files at City Hall. No biographical sketches. No resumes. No profiles. Barely a mention of his name. Yet Mr. Botnick, who resigned yesterday from his government posts, rose from obscurity, without the benefit of a college degree, to become at the age of 32 one of the most powerful behind-the-scenes figures in the Koch administration and head of the municipal hospital system.

title: REAGAN REPORTS NO FIRM DECISION ON '79 ARMS PACT
description: President Reagan, while continuing to express hostility to the 1979 treaty with the Soviet Union limiting strategic arms, said tonight that he had not firmly decided to abandon observance of the terms of the unratified agreement.

title: A 'LEGEND' LEAVES THE GAME
description: Barring some special Irish miracle today in World Cup play in Guadalajara, the scrappy but undermanned team from Northern Ireland will succumb to favored Brazil in its final first-round match and be eliminated.

title: Tchaikovsky Contest Opens in Moscow
description: A message from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, stressing the important role of art as an instrument of world peace opened the eighth Tchaikovsky international music competition in Moscow today.

title: European Boom Seen In TV Ads
description: CONSIDERING that John M. Eger's specialty is worldwide communications and considering the boom times that are being forecast, no wonder he is leaving CBS Worldwide Enterprises with hopes of wallowing in the expected pools of gold.

title: MILLIONS IN CONTRA AID MISUSED, G.A.O. SAYS
description: Congressional investigators asserted today that millions of dollars in American aid to the Nicaraguan rebels had instead been funneled into offshore banks, paid to the Honduran military or kept in the United States.

title: Sports Warp in the Colleges
description: ''A lot of people wish to turn the clock back to where the game on Saturday was just a game between bona fide students. But it's a fact of life that we just can't support all of the sports without gate receipts and television money.''

title: CRAFT FAIR, FLOWERS AND TOURS
description: A.C.C. Craftfair, Eastern States Exposition Fairgrounds, Route 147 (1305 Memorial Avenue), West Springfield, Mass.; 212-944-8230 and 413-787-0140 for recorded information; 914-255-0039.

title: DOMENICI TO OFFER MEASURE TO LINK ARMS TO REVENUE
description: In continued opposition to Reagan Administration wishes, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee said today that he would propose a new budget plan to formally link some increased military spending directly to revenue increases that would have to be approved by the President.

title: Pleasure and Pain
description: Winning the 16th basketball title with the Boston Celtics was pure pleasure for Larry Bird, but at an award ceremony in Boston yesterday he had a few words to say about pain. ''I didn't know if I was going to be able to play again,'' Bird said in alluding to the back pain that plagued him the last three months of 1985, as the season began.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After net of $431,000, or 23 cents a share, from discontinued operations and extraordinary income of $3,108,000, or $1.65 a share.

title: MILITARY TENSIONS RISE IN ARGENTINA
description: In recent days, there have been signs of tensions between the Government of President Raul Alfonsin and the armed forces apparently growing out of the dismissal of a key military commander and the naming of a new Defense Minister.

title: ALBANY AIDES SENT TO MONITOR A CITY HOSPITAL
description: State health inspectors will be sent into the Harlem Hospital Center as part of an unusual joint effort by the state and city to correct the hospital's medical, nursing and administrative problems.

title: MALPRACTICE REFORM THAT IS FAIR TO ALL
description: Doctors, lawyers and insurers have all had their say on the issue of medical malpractice insurance. Their advertisements flood the media, their lobbyists crowd state capitols, with each faction pointing a finger at the others. Legislatures, bombarded with petitions and position papers, are under pressure to respond with reforms. The legislators and the public might like to find one villain who can be blamed for high premiums, doctors who go out on strike and combative lawyers, but everyone realizes the problem is not that simple.

title: APARTHEID PANEL OFFERS ARGUMENTS FOR SANCTIONS
description: A group of Commonwealth leaders appointed to assess whether a negotiated solution is possible in South Africa advances arguments for economic sanctions in a report that is to be officially published here on Thursday.

title: WNET BOARD AGREES TO CUT SHOWS TO PBS
description: The board of trustees of WNET, Channel 13, approved a five-year business plan for the station yesterday that would impose major cost-reduction measures and de-emphasize WNET's role as a major supplier of programs to the national Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Boola Hula
description: To make sure that Yale graduates don't forget how to knot their old school ties, officials of the university's alumni association sponsor an array of seminars across the country and educational tours abroad, including lavish lecture cruises to the Mediterranean. Now they've come up with a new wrinkle, one that should have special appeal to Old Blues with less interest in Yale's wealth of academic offerings than its sports fortunes: a football junket to Hawaii.

title: Article 699586 -- No Title
description: Government investigations and audits uncovered $50.3 million worth of fraud, embezzlement and abuse of Federal education loans and grants over a six-month period, the Education Department announced today.

title: GERMANS, WELCOMING RELEASE OF 8 BY CONTRAS, QUESTION U.S. ROLE
description: The West German Government thanked the United States today for supporting efforts to free eight West Germans held captive by American-backed Nicaraguan rebels.

title: PRESIDENT IS OUT AT T.W.A.
description: Richard D. Pearson, president of Trans World Airlines, has been dismissed as president in a rivalry with a newcomer to the company, D. Joseph Corr, sources close to the company said yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Hoechst Corp., Somerville, N.J., which produces biochemical, serological and immunological diagnostic reagents and polyester fibers, elected Dr. Heinz K. Hofmeister executive vice president.

title: THE 'COOKIES AND PUNCH' SET NOW RIDES HERD ON SCHOOLS
description: For years, the Parent-Teacher Organizations here dared not speak out on controversial issues.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The states are not free, under the guise of protecting maternal health or potential life, to intimidate women into continuing pregnancies.'' - Justice Harry A. Blackmun. [ A1:6. ]

title: SOVIET OFFERS FIRST NUCLEAR FALLOUT ESTIMATES
description: Preliminary Soviet estimates of the amount of radioactive material released by the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident last month appear to be about half of Western estimates.

title: Hit to Remember
description: Johnson, incidentally, who is not known for his modesty, is especially proud of his record as a major league hitter, including one memorable plate appearance that makes him the answer to a trivia question: ''Who got the last hit off Sandy Koufax?'' Johnson says his pride in the achievement lasted about a year.

title: House Defeats Plan to Give 3 Vietnam Veterans Medals
description: The House today voted down a move to award Congressional gold medals to the three veterans who led the effort to build the Vietnam Veterans Memorial on the Washington mall.

title: Sperry Shares To Burroughs
