description: The Burroughs Corporation has been offered nearly twice as many shares as it needed to win control of the rival Sperry Corporation in a $4.78 billion bid to create the world's second-largest computer manufacturer. Burroughs said it would pay $76.50 cash for 31 million of the 58 million shares of Sperry common stock that were tendered by shareholders after the companies agreed to a Burroughs takeover.

title: FLOOR CLOTHS FOR SUMMER
description: PAINTING floor coverings is a tradition that dates back at least to the 18th century in England and the United States.

title: WITH A BROAD-BASED APPEAL, LIBERTY TICKET SALES PICK UP
description: In March, the promoters of Liberty Weekend sent out 3,000 gold embossed invitations to pay $5,000 a ticket for prime seats to the major events of the Fourth of July festivities. The ''by invitation only'' cards, enclosed in elaborate silver envelopes, went to socialites and big contributors to charity.

title: Some Revlon Business Is Moved From Grey
description: Revlon, now under the ownership of Ronald O. Perelman, is moving a number of assignments from Grey Advertising, a Revlon agency for a quarter of a century, and giving them to Bozell Jacobs Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: DeNIRO TAKES CUT FOR 'CUBA'
description: Robert DeNiro and his co-stars in ''Cuba and His Teddy Bear'' have agreed to work for minimum salaries so that the show, which ends a sold-out run at the Public Theater on Saturday, can move to Broadway. Joseph Papp, the Public's director, said yesterday that the show would open July 16 at the Longacre Theater for a 10-week run through Sept. 21. Some tickets will be sold for $10.

title: People
description: * Donald H. Rice has been named chairman of Fahlgren Swink & Nucifora, the Atlanta division of Fahlgren & Swink, Cincinnati.

title: Silas Leaves Nets
description: After one season as an assistant coach with the Nets, Paul Silas has resigned to pursue a business opportunity. ''The challenge of being an assistant coach just was not there,'' Silas said in a statement released by the team. After retiring as a player in 1980, Silas coached the San Diego Clippers for three seasons.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT OPINIONS ON ABORTION REGULATION LAW
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 5-to-4 decision today striking down a Pennsylvania law that regulated abortion. Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote the majority opinion, joined by Justices William J. Brennan Jr., Thurgood Marshall, Lewis F. Powell Jr. and John Paul Stevens. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger dissented. Justice Byron R. White dissented separately, joined by Justice William H. Rehnquist. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor also dissented separately, joined by Justice Rehnquist.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JUNE 12, 1986
description: International Panama's army chief is involved extensively in drug trafficking and illicit money laundering and has provided a guerrilla group with arms, according to evidence collected by American intelligence agencies. Senior officials said the evidence also showed that the army commander, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who is in effect Panaama's leader, has been supplying intelligence information to both the United States and Cuba for 15 years. [ Page A1, Columns 1-2. ]

title: Short-Lived Reprieve For Airline Attendant
description: An airline flight attendant, Ashgan Attia, told friends she felt reborn when she survived a hijacking that left 60 people dead in Malta last November.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Harold Petty vs.

title: A Ford Reunion
description: Something of an alumni association from the Ford Administration met in Washington the other day to swap recollections and to raise money for a foundation in the name of Gerald R. Ford that provides stipends for students doing graduate work in government.

title: Of Humilities and Humanities
description: ''Describe me as quite tall!'' said Lynne V. Cheney, who measures 5 feet 2. But even as she issued that self-mocking request, it was clear that the new chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities needed no added height to give her stature.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Arete Systems Corp., San Jose, Calif., said it would supply about $100 million of minicomputer systems to Sperry Corp.

title: New Air Links To Japan Due
description: An administrative law judge recommended today that Portland, Ore., and Dallas-Fort Worth be given nonstop airline service to Japan under an agreement signed last year with Japan. John M. Vittone, the judge, also urged that Delta Air Lines operate between Portland and Tokyo and American Airlines between Dallas-Fort Worth and Tokyo.

title: John Bubbles Memorial Set
description: A memorial service for John Bubbles will be held on Friday at 8 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. Mr. Bubbles, a tap dancer who was the original Sportin' Life in George Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess,'' died May 18 at the age of 84. Among those expected to participate in the service are the performers Clayton (Peg Leg) Bates, Eddie Bonnemere, Joe Attles, Bob Kindred and Jane Goldberg, as well as the Broadway dance arranger Henry LeTang and the writer Billy Rowe.

title: Technology; Improving Machine Vision
description: IF there was a surprise star at last week's machine vision show in Detroit, technologically speaking, it was probably a small, privately held company that recently changed its name from Advanced Computer Concepts Inc. to Vartec Inc. The seven-year-old company based in Costa Mesa, Calif., displayed a system that dealt with one of vision's trickiest problems: How to see at high speed small changes in surface textures of contoured objects, such as fruit or machined parts with curved surfaces.

title: WOMEN WHO RAISED FAMILIES NEED I.R.A.'S
description: To the Editor:

title: SUMMER PROTECTION FOR WINTER CLOTHES
description: Few experiences are more frustrating than pulling on a favorite sweater in the fall and finding a moth hole.

title: GUIDRY IS BEATEN BY TIGERS, ERRORS
description: The Yankees tried something new tonight, but a couple of old problems undermined their effort to improve their performance against left-handed starting pitchers. The problems that continued to vex the Yankees were their defense and Ron Guidry's pitching, both of which contributed to their 9-3 loss to the last-place Detroit Tigers.

title: CORRECTION
description: A television review yesterday of ''Pavarotti in the Verdi Requiem: A Salute to Youth,'' on Channel 13, misidentified the station that presented the program. It was WHYY-TV in Philadelphia.

title: ... and Thousands of Runs For Those on the Trucks
description: It is worth noting on the occasion of Medal Day that New York fire companies are the busiest in the nation.

title: MEXICO GAINS BY BEATING IRAQ
description: The Mexican people received another reprieve from having to think too closely about the country's economic troubles as the national soccer team finished first in its World Cup group with a 1-0 victory over Iraq today.

title: MANAGERS AT T.V.A. DEFENDING RECORD
description: The top managers of the Tennessee Valley Authority defended themselves today against a nearly six-hour barrage of criticism from Congressional investigators studying what the T.V.A. chairman acknowledged was an ''unhappy chronology'' of failures in the agency's $12 billion nuclear power program.

title: THE BEST PAINT STRIPPER MAY BE THE PRO
description: STRIPPING heavily overpainted furniture or architectural elements - mantels, balusters, doors and moldings - is a labor of love for some homeowners. But it is time-consuming and can mean weeks or months of living with drop cloths and chemical fumes.

title: RECORD BANK FAILURES SEEN
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said yesterday that a record number of banks will fail this year, surpassing last year's record 120 bank failures.

title: CABARET: PEGGY LEE RETURNS
description: PEGGY LEE returned on Tuesday to the Ballroom, where a year ago she made her first New York cabaret appearance in a decade, and gave a demanding two-hour performance that revealed a new sense of security in both her singing and her stage presence.

title: CBS Magazines Buys Leisure Time Package
description: Leisure Time Electronics, which comes in three parts, has been acquired by CBS Magazines from U.S. Business Press and will be tucked under the wing of Roman Beyer, vice president, publisher of Stereo Review.

title: LOW SALT LEVELS LINKED TO DEATHS
description: The sudden, mysterious deaths that sometimes occur in healthy people after routine surgery may be caused by a drastically low level of body salt and abnormal fluid retention, according to a report in The New England Journal of Medicine to be published Thursday.

title: In Era of Change, New York Port Is Still Greatest in the Country
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA EXAMINES SEVERAL POSSIBLE ESCAPE SYSTEMS FOR SHUTTLE CREWS
description: Engineers at the Johnson Space Center in Houston are studying several promising ideas for crew escape systems in certain shuttle emergencies, in response to the Presidential commission's recommendations, and are expected to report their findings to space agency managers June 30.

title: 2 CLAIMING VICTORY IN QUEENS ELECTION
description: The Rev. Floyd H. Flake, a Democrat running as an independent, and Assemblyman Alton R. Waldon Jr., the regular Democratic candidate, each claimed victory yesterday in a five-way special Congressional election Tuesday in Queens.

title: U.S. Steel Prices
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it was raising by $15 a ton the transaction price on certain grades of its hot-rolled bar products. The company said the new prices would apply to carbon and alloy grade bars on shipments made from Aug. 1 through July 31, 1987. The company said it would also raise transaction prices by $15 a ton for leaded steel grades for all bar products on Aug. 1.

title: A Correction: Republican Justice
description: In an editorial yesterday, Justice Stewart Pollock of the New Jersey Supreme Court was incorrectly identified as a Democrat. He is a Republican. That fact, however, does nothing to clarify the reluctance of the Republican State Senator from his county to endorse his merited reappointment by Governor Kean, also a Republican.

title: Q & A
description: Q.When I was applying a polyurethane finish to my bedroom floor, some of the urethane spilled onto a marble slab that separates this floor from an adjoining bathroom floor. This has hardened, but I want to remove it. I'm afraid to scrape it off for fear of scratching the marble. Do you have any suggestions? A. There is a good chance that if you scrape carefully, using a razor blade held almost flat against the marble surface, you can scrape the polyurethane off without damaging the surface - particularly if the marble has been waxed before. If this doesn't work, you should be able to remove the urethane by first softening with a paste-type paint remover.

title: GAMMA BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an asset writedown of about $3 million for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HOT PROPERTIES. By Rafael Yglesias. 408 pages. Dutton. $16.95.

title: STUDY CALLS GUNS IN HOME A DANGER
description: Keeping firearms in the home may endanger, not protect, the individuals who live there, according to an article released today by The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Posthumous Medal For Fallen Firefighter ...
description: It has been eight months since Capt.

title: SUSPECT IN A ROBBERY IS SHOT BY SECURITY GUARD NEAR U.N.
description: One of two men who had just robbed the wife of a South African attache was shot and seriously wounded yesterday afternoon by a security officer at a 43-story luxury building near the United Nations, the police said.

title: ARLEDGE EXPLAINS
description: Roone Arledge, the group president of ABC News and Sports, expressed a familiar theme yesterday at the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League: The N.F.L. never influenced ABC's decisions about the U.S.F.L.

title: MODERN DANCERS' BALLET: MORE GIMMICK THAN ART
description: A FUNNY, but not necessarily amusing thing may be happening in modern dance. Increasingly, ballet companies are commissioning new works from modern dancers. Since companies everywhere suffer from a choreography shortage, nobody can object to this, especially when modern-dance choreographers manage to create works that both employ skills ballet dancers already possess and challenge those dancers esthetically and technically. But what too often happens is that the resultant modern-dance works are blighted by gimmickry.

title: UP TO 43 PEOPLE KILLED IN SRI LANKA BOMBINGS
description: Time bombs believed to have been planted by Tamil terrorists exploded today on two buses in this island country's troubled eastern distict, killing up to 40 people and wounding 73 others, officials said.

title: FRENCH GOVERNMENT SEEKS TO CURB ILLEGAL ALIENS AND SELL TV STATION
description: The new conservative Government, stepping up its legislative pace, introduced two new bills today. One would make it easier to expel illegal immigrants from France, and the other would reduce the state's traditionally paramount role in television broadcasting.

title: Libyan Oil Output
description: Libyan oil production climbed sharply during May, to an average of 1.4 million barrels a day from just under a million at the start of the year, diplomats said.

title: SENATE, BY NARROW MARGIN, KEEPS I.R.A. DEDUCTIONS OUT OF TAX BILL
description: The Senate, by a narrow margin, voted tonight to reject proposals that would have maintained tax deductions for all Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: NASA CHALLENGED ON ROCKET QUERY
description: The chairman of the House space subcommittee charged today that officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had certified that the space shuttle's booster rockets met contractual requirements for withstanding cold when in fact they did not.

title: RECITAL: DeGAETANO, PIANO
description: THE pianist Robert DeGaetano, who played a program of Mozart, Liszt, Scarlatti, Rachmaninoff and his own music at Merkin Concert Hall Monday night, has a gift for the big picture. He was at his best in Liszt's Sonata in B minor, which he held together with admirable fortitude and intensity.

title: Pests Are the Smallest Chapter in the Insect Story
description: To the Editor:

title: COMAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. The company attributed the loss in the latest quarter to competitive fares and operational difficulties caused by a tornado at the Greater Cincinnati Airport on March 10. The loss includes a gain of $650,000 from estimated insurance proceeds for tornado-related damage.

title: Lawsuit Fear Cuts Contraceptive Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTRACTORS PLAN STEPS ON JOB GRAFT
description: Defense contractors today recommended voluntary steps to prevent employees who are discharged under suspicion of accepting illegal kickbacks from moving on to new jobs in the industry.

title: The U.N. Today: June 12, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DECLINE IN RATES SPURS STOCK RISE
description: The stock market's two-day slump ended yesterday when a decline in interest rates allowed share prices to rise moderately. But trading was restrained as investors remained cautious.

title: Utility Company Head Faces New Challenge
description: AZP Group Inc. had not considered acquiring a financial institution when it restructured itself just last year, according to the chairman of the utility holding company, Keith L. Turley.

title: AT TANDON, A FRESH BEGINNING
description: Until last year, the Tandon Corporation was a world of shirt-sleeves, informality and profits. But as the computer disk drive business collapsed, Tandon plunged into the red and looked as if it might return to the garage in which it had started a decade earlier.

title: Hunger Is Nonpolitical
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Engineer Backs a Finding
description: Lawrence B. Mulloy, the space agency rocket engineer who was criticized for his actions in the decision to launch the shuttle Challenger, said today that he agreed with the report of a Presidential commission on the accident's cause.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC ISSUES
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times OPENING STATEMENT

title: MAYOR CITES AIDE'S 'AGONY'
description: Victor E. Botnick, a trusted aide of Mayor Koch who has been under growing criticism for his conduct in office, resigned yesterday as chairman of New York's municipal hospital system.

title: ARMY BANS SMOKING AT WORK AND IN ITS VEHICLES OR AIRCRAFT
description: The Army has issued orders to make ''nonsmoking the norm'' for military offices, barracks, vehicles and aircraft.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $7,580,000 in respect of prior years store closing provisions for the quarter and the year. This charge reflected an adjustment to the store closing reserves originally provided as part of a corporate restructuring two years ago.

title: Women Who Raised Families Need I.R.A.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW TEAM AT ALTMAN'S TO KEEP ITS TRADITION
description: B. Altman & Company, which has occupied its site on 34th Street and Fifth Avenue since 1906, has a new set of officers since its sale last year by the Altman Foundation. They held a breakfast conference this week to report that its traditions will continue and to show, through displays and models, the directions the New York store's two main areas, home furnishings and fashion, will take next fall.

title: STRICT BILL GOVERNING TOXIC MATTER GAINS AN ALBANY ACCORD
description: Illegal dumping of toxic substances would be punished more severely and more often under the terms of legislation agreed to today by Governor Cuomo, key lawmakers and Attorney General Robert Abrams.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD ABORTION RIGHTS BY NARROW VOTE
description: A deeply divided Supreme Court today reaffirmed its landmark 1973 decision establishing a constitutional right to abortion, which the Reagan Administration had urged it to abandon.

title: Fecundity at the Zoo
description: Each year, more than 1,000 animals are born at the Bronx Zoo. Not only do the babies make joyous viewing for the public, but they also symbolize the zoo's effort to protect and propagate endangered species.

title: Democracy Can Cure Africa's Economic Ills
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSTON EXECUTIVE IS FOUND SHOT DEAD AT WALDORF-ASTORIA
description: A 27-year-old Houston executive for a hotel company who was in Manhattan for a convention was found shot dead in his room at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, and the police said they had no explanation for the slaying.

title: Altobelli Loses Credit for Goal
description: FIFA, the international governing body of soccer, today took away the third goal originally awarded to the Italian striker Sandro Altobelli against South Korea, ruling that it was an ''own goal'' by a defender, Guido Tognoni, a spokesman for the group, said. Italy won the match by 3-2

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Carbide Move Due Today
description: Today is the deadline for Union Carbide to respond to a Federal judge's decision on which country's courts should hear the lawsuits arising out of the 1984 gas leak at its plant in Bhopal, India. While most lawyers involved in the case expect the company to accept the conditions the judge set forth, many of them believe that will leave Union Carbide in a very vulnerable position.

title: Frank Cousins Is Dead; British Union Leader
description: Frank Cousins, the longtime trade union leader who served two stormy years as Britain's Technology Minister in the 1960's, died in a hospital today, apparently of an heart attack, his son John said. He was 81 years old.

title: 16 INDICTED OVER KICKBACKS INVOLVING SCHOOL CONTRACTS
description: A total of 16 present and former employees of the city's public-school system, most of them building inspectors, were indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy involving kickbacks from contractors.

title: INVENTION, DESIGN, ENGINEERNG ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a charge of $71,000 for new product development. c-Net income

title: S.E.C. Cites 2 Executives
description: The Worldwide Ventures Corporation and two senior executives were charged today by the Securities and Exchange Commission with falsifying the company's business activities and financial prospects from 1982 through 1985.

title: ROTECH MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AT HOME IN THE OFFICE
description: America's vast, silent army of workaholics will now find it easier both to live at the office and to work at home. More and more furniture coming on the market blurs the distinction between home and office. This week at Neocon - the four-day annual National Exposition of Interior Contract Furnishings that closes Friday - the trend in office furniture was to a strongly domestic appearance with traditional or transitional styling and softer lines, colors and materials.

title: AIDE SEES NEED TO HEAD OFF GLOBAL WARMING
description: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that ''some intervention'' by Government to address the buildup of manmade gases in the atmosphere now appears to be necessary.

title: Gorbachev Comment Retracted by Reagan
description: President Reagan said tonight that he ''must have goofed'' two days ago in linking ing Mikhail S. Grobachev with Fidel Castro, Muammar el-Qaddafi, and Yasir Arafat.

title: Weekly News Magazine On Electronics Planned
description: In September, the Viare Corporation, under the leadership of Richard Ekstract, will begin to publish Twice, This Week in Consumer Electronics, the first weekly news magazine in the field.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CAMBEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credit of $15,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $15,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $40,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Cannes on the Potomac
description: Richard H. Fein, the Ambassador from the Netherlands, made his residence available the other evening for a reception to announce that the 12 nations of the European Community would conduct an annual film festival in the United States.

title: Delhi Gas Loses Case
description: The Delhi Gas Pipeline Corporation, a major subsidiary of the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation, was found guilty today of breaching a gas purchasing contract with Texas Crude Inc. of Houston. The jury returned a verdict of about $108 million on behalf of Texas Crude, which had filed suit in July 1985. Forrest E. Hoglund, president and chief executive officer of Texas Oil and Gas, which was recently acquired by the United States Steel Corporation, said the company would appeal.

title: Convergent to Buy Display Data
description: Convergent Technologies Inc. said that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Display Data of Hunt Valley, Md., which markets computer systems to automobile dealers, beverage distributors and lumberyards.

title: A Chapter 11 Filing for Eagle
description: Eagle Computer Inc., once one of the most promising personal computer manufacturers in the Silicon Valley, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws. The company, now based in

title: MUSIC: ALUMNI IN BENEFIT FOR YOUNG CONCERT ARTISTS
description: SINCE 1961, Young Concert Artists has been perhaps the most important conduit for fine young performers from the conservatories into the professional world of music. Tuesday night the organization gave a benefit gala for itself at Alice Tully Hall, with performances by 18 of its better-known alumni.

title: 'NIGHT HEAT,' POLICE SHOW FROM CANADA ON CBS
description: SEVERAL years after ''Hill Street Blues'' brought a new edge of reality to television's standard police show, it is still cops and robbers, old style, in the precincts outside prime time. Consider ''Night Heat,'' regularly scheduled on CBS on Thursday nights at 11:30, right after the late news and up against Johnny Carson on NBC. ''Night Heat'' is being taken seriously because it often tops the Carson show in key markets like New York and Chicago.

title: G.E. Unit Gets 80% Kidder Stake
description: General Electric Financial Services, a division of the General Electric Company, said it had completed its acquisition of 80 percent of Kidder, Peabody & Company, first announced in April. G.E. will pay a reported $600 million for its interest in the Wall Street investment bank.

title: REAGAN SEES NO WIDE ISRAELI SPYING
description: President Reagan said tonight that the Administration had no evidence that the Israeli Government had conducted widespread spying in the United States.

title: YIELDS ARE MIXED
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Warner Stake In Cable Value
description: Warner Communications Inc. and the Cable Value Network said yesterday that Warner would acquire a stake in the cable network. The size and cost of the stake were not disclosed.

title: OPERA: 'HOFFMAN'
description: For a long time people had realized that ''The Tales of Hoffmann'' - left incomplete at Offenbach's death in 1880 -was a bit creaky at the joints, but it was not until about 15 years ago that producers and musicologists began in earnest to fix it. Since then, with the discovery of much missing music, the elucidation of what Offenbach's posthumous arrangers had done and a controversial scholarly edition by the late Fritz Oeser, the content of the opera has gone into a state of flux much more bewildering than when opera companies were just tinkering with the familiar version.

title: N.H.L. Offers Fund
description: National Hockey League club owners made their first major move in contract negotiations with the players' union yesterday by offering $7.5 million toward a post-career fund. The current collective bargaining agreement expires Sept. 15, 1986, with free agency the biggest issue.

title: BENEFIT CODES DON'T VIOLATE RELIGIOUS RIGHTS, COURT SAYS
description: The Supreme Court ruled by 8 to 1 today that the Government may use Social Security numbers for citizens in its administrative procedures even if it conflicts with their religious beliefs.

title: 3 Indicted in Slashing Of Manhattan Model
description: Three men were indicted by a grand jury yesterday in the razor attack on a fashion model last week on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: CONSTITUTIONAL DOUBT SCUTTLES HARTFORD LEGISLATIVE SESSION
description: For Connecticut, whose nickname is ''The Constitution State,'' today's special session of the General Assembly was truly special.

title: Ausimont Begins Public Offering
description: Ausimont Compo N.V., Waltham, Mass., a diversified international chemical company, yesterday began the public offering of three million common shares at a price of $27.75 a share through underwriters led by Wertheim & Company.

title: Agriculture Dept. Chief Pledges Fight on Bias
description: Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng has demanded a report within 60 days on the Agriculture Department compliance with civil rights laws, and has told officials that their highest priority must be to fight discrimination.

title: A MAGNA CARTA ARRIVES IN CITY FOR CELEBRATION
description: One of the original Magna Cartas, to which King John affixed his seal at Runnymede in 1215, arrived in New York yesterday by jet plane and armored truck to take part in an exhibit of liberty documents for the Statue of Liberty centennial.

title: VIDEOTAPE VENDING MACHINES: FOR VIEWERS IN THE FAST LANE
description: IN a land of remote-control garage-door openers, 24-hour banking, permanent-press suits, and frozen ready-to-serve dinners, Krauszer's store here has introduced the latest convenience - a vending machine that dispenses videotapes.

title: PROSECUTORS, AFTER 11 WEEKS, END EVIDENCE AT SPY TRIAL IN CALIFORNIA
description: Eleven and a half weeks after they began, prosecutors in the espionage and tax fraud trial of Jerry A. Whitworth completed the presentation of their case today.

title: STUDY DISPROVES A MYTH ON HERPES
description: Contrary to a widely held notion, victims of genital herpes may transmit the disease to their sexual partners even when they have no visible sores or other symptoms, doctors said today.

title: Trade Deficit Drops 2.1%
description: The United States foreign trade deficit edged down 2.1 percent, to $36.6 billion, in the first three months of the year, as a gigantic drop in petroleum imports offset price increases for other foreign goods, the Government reported today.

title: FOR EASIER WATERING
description: A SYSTEM of plastic couplings allows an ordinary garden hose to be attached quickly and easily to an outdoor tap and to accessories. Instead of twisting brass couplings, one simply snaps the modular plastic pieces in place.

title: Bridge: Some Partners Must Strive To Find Common Language
description: India has several hundred dialects, which is a source of some confusion. Speakers of related dialects may find it necessary to compromise by speaking Hindi, Urdu or English.

title: Ex-Students Testify
description: Three former Tulane students who have admitted participating in a basketball point-shaving scheme testified yesterday said they heard the former Tulane star John (Hot Rod) Williams brag about his part in fixing two games. Defense attorneys attacked the honesty of the witnesses, David Rothenberg, Gary Kranz and Mark Olensky, pointing out they have pleaded guilty to sports bribery charges in exchange for testifying against Williams and other defendants in the case.

title: HERS
description: ''I AM not the maid!'' my mother used to shout as she'd storm through my room picking up pleated skirts, giving them a terminal shake, folding the waistline in fours, and hanging them up in the closet. ''I am not in the business of running a hotel here, for you!'' Other times she'd be mild: ''Take a run through the house and see if you can find any dirty ashtrays, willya?'' But most often she performed these tasks in perfect fury - changing linens like a sailboat tacking through choppy seas, whirling sheets around her head like a practicing dervish as she explained to her daughters the nature of life. ''You've got to take grief, you've got to take . . . . '' The things women had to take were unspeakable. And as she poked a dust mop under our beds and sometimes brought out, along with loathsome dust, a Coke bottle with a cockroach in it, she'd shout again, occasionally breaking dishes (cheap ones they gave away in movie theaters on Thursday nights during the Great Depression) as punctuation: ''I am not the maid!'' But of course she was. My dad owned the house. Fury is hereditary. The last 20 years of feminism have been laced with intricate paragraphs of fine print in the contract between the sexes. If I take out the trash on Wednesday, then you must run the vacuum Saturday. Don't think - if you're a man -that you can get out of it by sawing a cord of wood if we live in the country, or turning on the furnace pilot light if we live in town, because those chores come only once a year.

title: MTV MAKES CHANGES TO STOP RATING SLUMP
description: After a period of sagging ratings, MTV is making major programming changes. It has started a new-music show, added situation comedies to its schedule and - for the first time since it started in 1980 - has added a new on-camera video jockey (V.J.). The 24-hour cable channel, which generally broadcasts promotional rock video clips, has added a new V.J., Julie Brown, and dropped two of its five original V.J.'s, Nina Blackwood and J. J. Jackson.

title: EDELMAN PLANS TO COURT FRUEHAUF STOCKHOLDERS
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York financier whose efforts to acquire the Fruehauf Corporation have been thwarted by management, said yesterday that he would take his case directly to the shareholders of the Detroit-based maker of truck trailers.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 17
description: b-After tax credits of $390,000, or 11 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $495,000, or 13 cents a share, for the year-ago period.

title: REAGAN SUPPORTS 4th ORBITER FOR SPACE SHUTTLE PROGRAM
description: President Reagan tonight endorsed the construction of a new space shuttle orbiter.

title: FOREIGN GOLFERS FACE RULE CHANGE
description: All foreign members of the PGA Tour, including such players as Seve Ballesteros of Spain, Bernhard Langer of West Germany, Greg Norman of Australia, Sandy Lyle of Scotland and Isao Aoki of Japan, will be required next year to play an equal number of tour events in the United States in order to retain their card and playing privileges.

title: DUVALIER DENIES STEALING MILLIONS
description: The ousted President of Haiti, Jean-Claude Duvalier, has denied in an interview that he embezzled millions from the Government he headed and insists he did ''the best that I could to try to improve the material conditions of my people.''

title: VOLCKER ASKS LENIENCY IN MEXICO DEBT TALKS
description: The Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, indicated today that lenders should be lenient in their dealings with Mexico as it struggles with its troubled economy and huge debts.

title: U.S. and Hanoi Resume Talks on the Missing
description: American and Vietnamese officials resumed talks in Hanoi today on the nearly 1,800 American servicemen listed as missing in action in Vietnam, ending a two-month freeze caused by the raids on Libya by the United States.

title: Mideast Shift for France
description: Even the French press winced with some distaste at the forced departure of Massoud Rajavi, the Iranian leader of the People's Mujahedeen, who had taken refuge here alongside thousands of other Iranians with assorted views. It seemed to compromise France's vaunted right of asylum in hopes of getting kidnapped French hostages returned from Lebanon.

title: Accounts
description: * Marion Laboratories, Kansas City, Mo., to Rolf Werner Rosenthal for the angina medication Cardizem.

title: Woolworth P.L.C. Gets Improved Bid
description: Dixons Group P.L.C. sweetened its hostile bid to acquire another British retailer, Woolworth Holdings P.L.C., to the equivalent of $2.9 billion. Woolworth, a variety store chain, was spun off from the F. W. Woolworth Company of the United States in 1982.

title: BALLET: 'LA BAYADERE'
description: ''LA BAYADERE'' has just about everything: love, jealousy, vengeance, retribution, poisonous snakes, opium dreams, Indian temples and lilting waltzes. No wonder it created a sensation when Marius Petipa choreographed it in 1877. As staged by Natalia Makarova, it looked impressive once again when American Ballet Theater presented it Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: GARDEN SCULPTURE MAKES A COMEBACK
description: THE nearest that gardening gets to a fashion show is the Chelsea Flower Show, held every year in the third week of May on the grounds of the Royal Hospital in London. Generals, bishops and professors of horticulture assemble at Chelsea from all over the world, not formally to confer, but simply to keep in touch with garden gossip and admire a virtuoso display that has no rival.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $393,000 for the quarter and $751,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,620,000 for the quarter and 6 months and tax benefits of $1,677,000 and $1,964,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: 'Final' I.O.C. Offer
description: The International Olympic Committee today offered North Korea and South Korea a ''final'' compromise proposal designed to end their dispute over the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, and avert a possible boycott.

title: Filipino Delegate Sees Long Peace Discussions
description: The delegate picked by the Communist Party to take part in cease-fire talks with the Aquino Government said today that negotiations would be long and difficult but that the rebels were ''determined to seek the road to peace.''

title: Wounded Palestinians Evacuated From Siege
description: Ambulances entered the embattled Palestinian district of Burj al Brajneh in southern Beirut today and evacuated 10 wounded inhabitants for the first time since fighting began there three weeks ago.

When Don Sutton outdueled Tom Seaver, 3-0, on Monday night, he not only pulled to within one victory of 300 but also notched career shutout No. 58. That ranks second on the list of active pitchers, the top 10 of whom in the category are: Tom Seaver...61; Don Sutton...58; Steve Carlton...55; Nolan Ryan...54; Bert Blyleven...51; Tommy John...45; Phil Niekro...45; Vida Blue...37; Jerry Reuss...37; Joe Niekro...29.

title: SHOOTINGS PROVOKE CONCERN ON RACE ISSUE IN CLEVELAND
description: After months of uneasiness on an all-white block where one home had been rented to a black family, a 24-year-old black man fired a 12-gauge shotgun toward a group of whites last night, the police said. Eight people were wounded, none of them seriously.

title: 7 Dates Sold Out
description: The 1986 United States Open Tennis Championships do not begin until Aug. 26, but already seven of the 13- day sessions are sold out, the United States Tennis Association announced yesterday. The tournament runs to Sept. 7, and day sessions are sold out on Aug. 29, 30, 31 and Sept. 1, 5, 6 and 7. Tickets are available at the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow or through Ticketron.

title: PROSECUTORS VIE OVER TRIAL DATES IN SCANDAL CASE
description: The United States Attorney in Manhattan and the chief lawyer for Stanley M. Friedman asked a Federal Court yesterday to force the Manhattan District Attorney to delay the state's municipal corruption trial.

title: Oxford Death Mystery
description: The 22-year-old daughter of a British Cabinet minister was found dead at Oxford University today after a student party, the police said. They said Olivia Channon, daughter of Trade and Industry Secretary Paul Channon, was found lying fully clothed on a bed in the room of a friend shortly before 8 A.M. An autopsy was being performed to determine the cause of her death.

title: QADDAFI IS ABSENT FROM OBSERVANCE
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi failed to appear tonight at what Libyan officals had said would be his first major public appearance since the April 15 American air raids on this country.

title: Five I.R.A. Members Convicted in Bomb Plot
description: Five accused members of the Irish Republican Army were found guilty today of planning an elaborate ''bomb calendar'' in which automatic timers were to detonate 16 explosions on consecutive days last summer at London and seaside tourist hotels.

title: Reagan Seems to Mix Supreme Court Cases
description: At his news conference tonight, President Reagan seemed to mix up two decisions by the Supreme Court.

title: LEE BICKMORE, EX-CHAIRMAN OF NATIONAL BISCUIT COMPANY
description: Lee Smith Bickmore, who rose from a sales job with the National Biscuit Company in Pocatello, Idaho, to the chairmanship of the company, died last Saturday in Vero Beach, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 78 years old and a former resident of Short Hills, N.J.

title: Harvard Fined $2,500 By Nuclear Agency
description: Harvard University has been fined $2,500 by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for mishandling radioactive materials and posing what the agency said was potential danger in three Massachusetts communities.

title: Bank Gets An Extension
description: The First National Bank and Trust Company of Oklahoma has an additional two months to raise about $40 million in capital to meet the demands of Federal regulators, according to the bank's chairman.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST exposed wood in a house is protected by paint, but fences, railings, posts, decks and other outdoor additions face attack by the elements and insects. Some woods are more rot- and insect-resistant than others - certain types of redwood and cedar, for example -but most lumber for such additions should be protected by one of the preservatives sold in all paint and hardware stores and in most lumberyards.

title: THE SCREEN: 'SAY YES'
description: WHEN a movie opens without any advance word, it usually means that someone is meeting a contractual obligation to release the film theatrically, and believes the movie is so terrible that it's better off dying in peace. ''Say Yes,'' which has sneaked into the Embassy 2, isn't that bad.

title: SHAD ASKS NEW CHECKS ON FINANCIAL PLANNERS
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, John S. R. Shad, endorsed efforts today that would place the soaring number of investment advisers and so-called personal financial planners under closer state regulation and industry scrutiny. But Mr. Shad refused to endorse any new Federal regulation of advisers.

title: ELBIT COMPUTERS LTD CP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $717,000 from a change in accounting principles. Elbit is a subsidiary of Elron Electronic Industries Ltd.

title: VANGUARD TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LIBERTY IN BLOOM -Not to be outdone by anyone, the New York Botanical Garden has created its own Statue of Liberty, one that is just a part of the extravaganza ''A Floral Salute to Lady Liberty,'' the exhibition that opens today at the Garden, located in the Bronx across from Fordham University and next to the Bronx Zoo.

title: YONKERS SCHOOLS DEFY CITY COUNCIL
description: The Yonkers Board of Education said today that it was continuing to put a school desegregation plan into effect despite a decision by the City Council last night to appeal the court-ordered education program as well as a housing integration plan the city has been told to carry out.

title: Handicapping
description: Dave Johnson, the Mets' manager, is also a scratch golfer, and when he made a midtown promotional appearance yesterday afternoon, someone asked if he had ever played Nancy Lopez, the champion golfer married to Johnson's third baseman, Ray Knight. Johnson said he had, but not before taking a few precautions.

title: COMMUNICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $157,000 for the latest quarter and $37,000 for the year-ago period.

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-Net loss. c-Includes a credit of $2,209,000 from an accounting change.

title: BOND AND NOTE PRICES GAIN
description: Prices for Government bonds and notes briefly spurted higher yesterday as traders responded to a rumor late in the day that Commerce Department figures on May retail sales, due for release this morning, had been leaked and would show a sharp decline.

title: NEW SOVIET OFFER IS MADE ON ARMS
description: The Soviet Union has presented a new proposal for reducing strategic nuclear arms, which would be less extensive than the 50 percent cut it previously proposed, but would exclude some American weapons in Western Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: DISOBEDIENCE URGED ON SOWETO ANNIVERSARY
description: The United Democratic Front, South Africa's principal nonparliamentary opposition movement, called today for mass disobedience of official orders prohibiting commemorations of the Soweto uprising on June 16.

title: AT CRAFT MEETING, DISCUSSIONS ON ART
description: THE American Craft Council, the national organization for craftsmen, convened its first conference in nine years last week in Oakland, Calif., and for the first time considered in an organized way such philosophical questions as function versus esthetics and ''Is craft art?''

title: MARGIN OF VOTE IS CALLED KEY TO ABORTION DECISION
description: Advocates of a woman's right to choose an abortion fervently applauded what they saw as today's reaffirmation of that right by the Supreme Court.

title: Rabies Kills British Woman
description: A British woman died of rabies in a Hamburg hospital after being bitten in India by a dog, the British Consulate said today. A consulate spokesman said Ann Vedmore, 28 years old, from Prescot near Liverpool, died Tuesday of the disease.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO SOFTEN CURB ON ALIEN HOUSING
description: The House of Representatives voted unanimously today to permit illegal alien families to continue to live in public housing projects if at least one member of the family was an American citizen or legal resident.

title: A Senate Team
description: Senators Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, Alan Cranston of California and Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii are to announce today that they are running together as a team for re-election to their Democratic leadership posts. Mr. Byrd is the Democratic leader, Mr. Cranston the whip and Mr. Inouye secretary of the Democratic conference.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 12, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Message to Austria
description: What Ronald Reagan began at Bitburg last year the voters of Austria have now significantly advanced. That is the process of making forgetfulness acceptable -forgetfulness of the Nazi past in Germany and Austria.

title: FICKLE WEATHER CONCERN AT OPEN
description: Bill Williams, president of the United States Golf Association, described the character of the 86th United States Open championship that begins Thursday at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club when he said, ''I'd like to welcome you to the first playing of the British Open in the United States.''

title: S.E.C. TAKES TESTIMONY ABOUT INSIDER TRADING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, working closely with the United States Attorney's office, is ''subpoenaing records, interviewing people and taking testimony'' in two separate insider trading investigations, a top commission official said yesterday.

title: 3 Reported Contaminated At Nuclear Test Site
description: Radiation from a United States nuclear weapons blast that went wrong earlier this year has contaminated three workers, two of them twice, at the Nevada test site. But the Department of Energy said today that the three were in no danger.

title: CARL KARCHER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to May 19
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Murdoch's Offer of Pay Raise Placates British Journalists
description: The publisher Rupert Murdoch averted the threat of a rebellion by journalists on his best-selling tabloid, The Sun, today.

title: A 2d Democrat Seeks East Side House Seat
description: Charles B. Finch Jr., who made a brief run for Congress in 1984, said yesterday that he was seeking the Democratic nomination to oppose Representative Bill Green, a Republican, in the 15th Congressional District on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: MUSIC: WALTER THOMPSON
description: WALTER THOMPSON writes for big band with a modern classical composer's ambitions - to stretch melody and harmony and to construct new forms. Now and then, he also wants the music to swing.

title: Traffic at Shinnecock
description: While most competitors, officials and spectators are looking forward to a different and exciting United States Open at Shinnecock Hills, there is still some concern about traffic in and out of the isolated golf course.

title: Warrants Are Offered To Buy Ginnie Maes
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. yesterday announced the offering of 1,000 warrants to buy $250 million of 8 percent Government National Mortgage Association securities at a fixed price of 93 1/2.

title: MAINE ANTI-OBSCENITY PLAN SOUNDLY DEFEATED
description: Voters here said no Tuesday by a margin of more than 2 to 1 to a proposal that would have made it a crime to sell or promote obscene material.

title: Not-So-Vital Statistics on Admiral Crowe
description: Adm. William J. Crowe has occupied the post of Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff since October. An Oklahoma native and a Navy officer with more than 43 years of service, he previously served as Commander of American forces in the Pacific and has held commands in the Middle East and Southern Europe as well. As the first officer to be promoted to chairman of the Joint Chiefs from a unified command rather than from the top ranks of his own service, Admiral Crowe has become an important participant in the debate on restructuring the responsibilities of the Joint Chiefs. Here are some insights into the admiral, as supplied by him:

title: Utah Housing
description: The Utah Housing Finance Agency is offering about $91 million of single-family housing revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: FMR Buys Stake
description: The Boston-based investment holding company FMR Corporation and an affiliate have purchased a 7.6 percent stake in the Adams-Millis Corporation, an apparel company based in High Point, N.C. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, FMR said it had purchased the Adams-Millis shares ''in pursuit of specified investment objectives.'' Between March 5 and April 29, FMR purchased 60,900 Adams-Millis shares on the open market for prices ranging from $25.50 to $27.57 a share. Adams-Millis shares closed at $31.50 today, up 75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: METS TOP PHILS BEHIND DARLING
description: Small wonder that the Mets are not exactly the most popular bunch of guys among their peers around the National League. First, there's that rah-rah image. Second, there's all that talent.

title: BAPTIST SETS A FUNDAMENTALIST TONE
description: The Rev. Adrian Rogers, the fiery Memphis preacher who was elected Tuesday to the presidency of the Southern Baptist Convention, says he felt a divine call to the job.

title: BEST SELLERS ARE YEAR-ROUND AFFAIR
description: Years ago most of the big-name novelists were published in the fall, but that has not been true for some time. As evidence, the current best seller list includes recently published novels by John le Carre, Judith Krantz, Robert Ludlum, Dick Francis, Lawrence Sanders and John Gardner. And that list is likely to be joined soon by Louis L'Amour and John D. MacDonald, whose latest books are just now in the stores.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago results were restated to include operations of 3H Industries acquired in May 1985.

title: Use of Nicaragua Aid Is Defended by Shultz
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that a Congressional report asserting widespread misuse of United States aid to Nicaraguan rebels was a politically motivated effort to discredit the Administration's Central America policy.

title: SCREEN: 'DEATH SENTENCE'
description: ''DEATH SENTENCE,'' the first film by the Polish director-writer Witold Orzechowski to be shown in this country, is a wartime melodrama with some sillier-than-strictly-necessary aspects. The tale is set in Nazi-occupied Poland in 1943. The hero, one Smukly (Wojciech Wyosocki), joins the ''execution squad'' of the underground Home Army in the town of Zamosc. His assignment is to kill Gestapo officers and Polish informers.

title: OPERA: 'ABDUCTION FROM THE SERAGLIO'
description: ONE of the miracles of Mozart's art is that it seems to have precomprehended our century's ways of understanding drama and the psyche. His operas can seem fully modern, and bear modern stage direction without squirming. But wonderful as some of the others are, that assertion really applies to the three operas Mozart wrote with Lorenzo Da Ponte. The attempt of Graham Vick, the director of productions for the Scottish National Opera, to produce ''The Abduction From the Seraglio'' in those terms for the Opera Theater of St. Louis, was an honorable and sometimes engrossing effort that fell short, perhaps inevitably, of success.

title: BALLET: 'BAYADERE' CHANGES
description: TALK of favorite works with ballet fans and they'll pretty readily come up with ''La Bayadere,'' with its spectacle, colorful storytelling and purest of classical dancing. Two mostly new casts of dancers gave the ballet well-danced performances worthy of that distinction when American Ballet Theater presented Natalia Makarova's production of ''La Bayadere'' on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: PLATINUM PRICES SURGE ON SOUTH AFRICA UNREST
description: Platinum prices posted strong, fresh increases yesterday, as traders bid up prices in response to unrest in South Africa, where much of the precious metal is mined.

title: ITALY WEIGHS CUT IN USE OF LIBYAN OIL
description: The Italian Government is considering moves to reduce its imports of Libyan oil as a means of putting economic pressure on the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, senior Italian officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: EXCITED BUT GRUMBLING A BIT, SOUTHAMPTON GREETS THE OPEN
description: The wind howled and the rain poured. But still, the United States Open began today, as hordes of spectators in a kaleidoscopic blaze of umbrellas, parkas and rain pants slogged and squished their way across the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

title: Dialing for Credit
description: xetting the wrong number is not easy to fix these days.

title: IN SCANDAL OF 1930'S, CITY SHOOK AND A MAYOR FELL
description: Fifty-five years ago, the biggest investigations of municipal corruption in the nation in this century rocked the foundations of New York. They affected every department and corner of the city and resulted in some reforms, at least temporarily, in the relationship between public officeholders and private corrupters.

title: Black Bass Events For a Tight Budget
description: If you live in the Northeast, have been hankering to test your skills as a black bass fisherman in competition but have not done so because such tournaments were too distant or too costly to enter, you have a choice of seven relatively inexpensive events in the region this season.

title: Two Are Charged Over Heroin at Oxford
description: A cousin and a close friend were charged today with supplying heroin to Olivia Channon, the daughter of a Cabinet minister. She was found dead after end-of-term celebrations at Oxford University.

title: BRAZIL AND SPAIN ADVANCE
description: Brazil and Spain registered 3-0 victories today in the World Cup, and the results helped determine all but the final participant for the second round of the tournament.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Window-Guard Law: Procedures and Fee
description: The window-guard law that was added to the health code in 1976 requires landlords to inform all new tenants by letter - return receipt requested - that window guards are available for families with children 10 years old and younger.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: MANY purists insist that the best Chinese food is found only in restaurants that are (a) cramped and deafening, (b) as brightly lit as a supermarket and (c) filled with tables of Chinese families fiercely poking at wondrous creations that never seem to be on the menu. An exception is Auntie Yuan, the stylish three-and-a-half-year-old establishment owned by David Keh that turns out a host of compelling dishes rivaling some of Chinatown's finest - albeit at steep uptown prices.

title: Races in Central Park
description: Old and young alike will be lacing up running shoes on Sunday for races through Central Park, sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club.

title: Prime to Transfer Restaurants
description: Prime Motor Inns Inc. agreed to transfer its 120 Howard Johnson restaurant franchises to a group of franchise owners, who will form a new corporate entity to operate the units.

title: FREY IS DISMISSED BY CUBS
description: Jim Frey was dismissed today as manager of the Chicago Cubs, less than two years after leading the team to the National League East title.

title: OTHERS DETECT NUANCES
description: A new Soviet arms proposal may have figured in President Reagan's apparent move Wednesday to shade, but not to alter, his decision to disavow the strategic arms limitation treaty of 1979, according to Administration officials.

title: MORE ASIANS, SEEKING STRONG SCHOOLS, CHOOSE THE SUBURBS
description: To Carl Guardino, owner of the Sea King Sea Food Market here, the problem of East-West trade barriers is no longer simply the stuff of international summits.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 10
BROADWAY
description: IN ENGLAND, he's been critically acclaimed as a man with the kind of face found on the side of a medieval cathedral, an unremittingly hilarious performer expert at debunking pretension. He won the Society of West End Theaters award for the best comedy performance of 1981. Now the question is - will Rowan Atkinson's brand of humor survive the Atlantic?

title: Notre Dame President Trying Again to Retire
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, the president of the University of Notre Dame for the last 35 years, will resign next year and university trustees have begun a search for his replacement, a school spokesman said today.

title: REAGAN TO SPEAK AT JERSEY GRADUATION
description: President Reagan will deliver the commencement address next week at the public high school in this small southern New Jersey city, a community best known as the site of the summit meeting 19 years ago between President Lyndon B. Johnson and the Soviet Prime Minister, Aleksei N. Kosygin.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PRODIGY. By Amy Wallace. Illustrated. 297 pages. E. P. Dutton. $18.95. FAME came early to William

title: Cash Traced to Jet Hijacking Is Given to Boy and Insurer
description: A 14-year-old Oklahoman and an insurance company Wednesday divided up $6,000 in tattered $20 bills that are the only trace ever found of the airplane hijacker D. B. Cooper.

title: THE MANY PLACES OF POP AND JAZZ: A MUSICAL GUIDE TO THE CITY
description: NEW YORK CITY, the birthplace of Tin Pan Alley, the home of Broadway and one of America's two main centers of broadcasting, can still lay claim to being the pop-musical capital of America, even though commercial pop music diversified dramatically after the rise of rock-and-roll.

title: Advertising; 'Dennis' Is Added To Lineup
description: UNLIKE so much of the TV programming for kids that is tied in with trendy toys and is short-lived by its very nature, the shows backed by General Mills are seeking immortality, or at least considerable longevity.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday -DIORAMA OF DREAMS -''The work is about urban life,'' Brookie Maxwell says of her 50-foot diorama ''42d Street: A Walk Across Twelve Blocks of Continuous Sculpture.'' ''42d Street'' is a three-dimensional representation of 12 actual blocks of 42d Street - complete with the Public Library, Theater Row, and even some movie houses. ''I've grown up in New York City and the people of this city are my people,'' Miss Maxwell said. ''If I convey a message in my art, it is, 'Have courage, hold on to your dreams.' If that's coming through in my work, then I'm successful.'' ''42d Street'' is now on exhibit at the School of Visual Arts, 209 East 23d Street; gallery hours are 9 A.M. to 8 P.M. Monday through Friday. Admission is free. Information: 679-7350. Saturday FOSSIL FREE-FOR-ALL In past years, visitors have brought in walrus teeth, the jaw bone of a whale, 100 million-year-old fish fossils, even an extinct cousin of the lobster, perfectly preserved. Saturday from 1 to 5 P.M., you may bring anything that intrigues you to the Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, for identification by museum experts. All objects - old or new, animal, vegetable or mineral - will be examined, although scientists will not identify gemstones and no appraisals or estimates of monetary value will be made. The museum established Identification Day in 1979 as a response to the large number of requests from the public for information about items collected every-GOG jump where from Staten Island to Sri Lanka.

title: THE TWO SIDES OF CAMACHO
description: Last month in Washington, at a World Boxing Council black-tie dinner honoring Ray Leonard, Hector Camacho broke protocol.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: THE paintings are paradoxes: cool in color yet splashy in execution; abstract yet filled with hints of human figures and trees and books; calm blues and whites and greens thrown on the canvas with verve.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $49,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $1,026,000, including $891,000 from settlement of litigation, for the 9 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $20,000 for the quarter and $75,000 for the 9 months.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS EXPRESS CONCERN OVER CHARGES AGAINST PANAMANIAN
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials expressed concern today about evidence that the army commander of Panama was involved in drug trafficking and money laundering and was linked to the killing of a political opponent.

title: FILM: 'BELIZAIRE THE CAJUN'
description: ''BELIZAIRE THE CAJUN'' is the story of a fictional herbalist and faith healer who is a folk hero. Brazen, plucky and wily, he helps to stop vigilantism in his southern Louisiana town in the years before the Civil War.

title: The Peril in Sri Lanka
description: A terrible civil war threatens Sri Lanka, the lovely island once called Ceylon. Both the Sinhalese majority and Tamil minority exploit each other's atrocities to justify fearful reprisals. But what propels this cycle is the majority's refusal to share power with the minority - even at the risk of turning Sri Lanka into another Lebanon. The one hope for deliverance is that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India may yet revive peace talks before the conflict spills into his country.

title: Don't Get Arrested For Drugs Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: RETAIL SALES FELL 0.1% IN MAY
description: Retail sales edged down one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the third setback in the last four months, as healthy demand for new cars and furniture failed to overcome weaknesses in other areas, the Government reported today.

title: 8 GERMANS FREED BY CONTRAS BLAME REAGAN
description: Eight West German volunteers who were abducted by rebels and held for 25 days said after their release that the Reagan Administration was to blame for their kidnapping.

title: Dining Out Guide: Father's Day
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMERICAN FESTIVAL CAFE, #20 West 50th

title: Control Data Sets Payments
description: The Control Data Corporation, the troubled Minneapolis-based computer maker, said today that it had completed the restructuring of its bank debt and had entered into a $125 million receivables purchase agreement with Manufacturers Hanover Bank. Control Data, which was in technical default of its debt obligations to 27 banks, said it would repay about $375 million of the debt by Dec. 31.

title: Dow Off 7.94 Points In a Slow Session
description: Wall Street yesterday drifted through a lifeless session of mixed prices and low volume.

title: CANADA EXTENDS APARTHEID STEPS
description: Canada, in a new protest against the policy of apartheid, announced today that it would no longer accept the nonresident accreditation of four South African diplomatic attaches living in Washington, New York and Los Angeles.

title: Tainting Report Clears Stores of Cigarettes
description: Thousands of packs of cigarettes have been pulled off the shelves of two Alpha Beta stores here after reports that the cigarettes had been tainted with sodium cyanide powder to terrorize smokers.

title: TV RADIATION LIMITS OFFERED
description: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed limits today on public exposure to radiation from radio and television transmitting equipment, citing possible health risks to people who live and work nearby.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SENATE PANEL ACCEPTS REVISED EXTRADITION TREATY
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a revised extradition treaty today between the United States and Britain that will make it easier to extradite Irish Republican Army fugitives sought by the British for prosecution as terrorists.

title: A TEST FOR MEXICAN RULERS
description: Mexico's economic crisis, which has worsened with the collapse of world oil markets, has handed the Government and the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party a challenge that could threaten their strong hold over Mexican life.

title: HOUSE PASSES MEASURE ON HOUSING ASSISTANCE
description: The House today passed a major public housing bill that requires more Federal money to be spent on the repair of existing units than on new construction.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JUNE 13, 1986
description: International

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I am of the opinion that the ordinary laws of the land at present on the statute book are inadequate to enable the Government to insure the security of the public and to maintain public order.''

title: BEAUTICONTROL COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: There were no share earnings reported in the year-ago periods because the company went public March 13.

title: Duets at Burgundy
description: The pianist Walter Bishop and the bassist Vishnu Wood are playing duets tonight and tomorrow at Burgundy, 467 Amsterdam Avenue above 82d Street (787-8300). Music begins at 9 P.M. There is a $10 minimum at tables and a two-drink minimum at the bar.

title: ADMINISTRATION MAKES MILITARY BUDGET OFFER
description: The Reagan Administration told Senate budget writers today that more Federal Government assets could be sold to pay for increases in the 1987 military budget.

title: GRAHAM-MCCORMICK OIL & GAS PARTNERSHIP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Share earnings represent units.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Peggy Lee, the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street (244-3005). This living legend combines the sensuality of a ghostly Mae West with echoes of Billie Holiday to weave a spell that is as mysteriously tantalizing today as it ever has been. Since her successful Ballroom engagement last summer, the singer has undergone open-heart surgery, but she is fully recovered and stronger than before. Miss Lee's hour-and-a-half program features many of her best-known songs, including ''Fever,'' ''Is That All There Is'' and ''Johnny Guitar,'' as well as a newly discovered gem, ''Just Keep Holdin' On.'' Backup includes Mike Renzi (piano), Grady Tate (drums), Jay Leonhart (bass), John Chiodini (guitar) and Mark Sherman (vibes). Shows are Tuesday through Saturday at 9 and 11 P.M. The cover charge on weekends is $30 plus a two-drink minimum. Reservations necessary.

title: TESTS ARE APPROVED FOR PESTICIDE MADE BY BIOTECHNOLOGY CONCERN
description: A small Pennsylvania biotechnology company today gained approval from the Environmental Protection Agency to conduct field tests in eight states of a microbial pesticide made from genetically altered strains of a common bacterium.

title: A Chance to Win
description: The New Democratic Forum, an organization of Congressional aides and political activists dedicated to the hope that the world has not passed them by, is holding a party on Sunday evening called ''The Party's Not Over.''

title: CHILDREN'S FALLS PROMPT BILL ON WINDOW-GUARDS
description: Eight-year-old Steven Brown was leaning out a bedroom window in his Bronx apartment at 1655 Monroe Avenue Wednesday night about 7:30, calling to his brother, when the window guard suddenly gave way. He fell seven floors to the ground, suffering a skull fracture and numerous compound fractures.

title: BODY OF POLICEMAN MISSING FOR 6 MONTHS IS FOUND IN HUDSON
description: The body of a Housing Authority policeman missing since last year was found floating in the Hudson River Wednesday afternoon, the police said. The officer had been shot four times.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Nets, seeking a replacement for Paul Silas, who resigned Wednesday as an assistant coach, have offered a contract to Garry St. Jean, an assistant coach with Milwaukee. St. Jean knows the Nets' head coach, Dave Wohl, well from Wohl's days with the Bucks. Yesterday, St. Jean said he was deciding between that and a more lucrative offer from Golden State. . . . John McEnroe confirmed to Wimbledon officials that he would not play in this summer's tournament.

title: ART: 'HEROIC SUBLIME,' OR THE USE OF THE STRIPE
description: AT a time of the year when ambition in the galleries tends to dwindle, if not actually disappear, a small prize should be awarded the Charles Cowles Gallery, 420 West Broadway, where an exhibition called ''The Heroic Sublime'' can be seen through July 11. Predicated on an idea put forward by Barnett Newman in his ''Vir Heroicus Sublimis'' (now in the Museum of Modern Art), this is a show that takes a certain notion of abstract painting and looks at it from 11 different points of view.

title: Mistaken Identity
description: Coach Bernie Bickerstaff of the SuperSonics, displeased at what other teams are offering to trade for Seattle's Jack Sikma: ''Santa Claus resides at the North Pole.''

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 359 money market mutual funds rose $80.1 million, to $224.67 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: FATHER AND SONS UPDATED
description: Every morning Michael J. Obus drives his 4-year-old son to nursery school before beginning his long commute from Manhattan to Long Island, where he is chief of the appeals bureau of the Nassau County Legal Aid Society.

title: LDBRINKMAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $4,267,000 for the quarter and $4,551,000 for the 9 months.

title: YALE GETS THE PAPERS OF ROBERT PENN WARREN
description: Yale University's Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, which already houses one of the most distinguished collections of American literary manuscripts, has acquired the complete papers of Robert Penn Warren. Earlier this year the 81-year-old author, the only writer to have won Pulitzer Prizes for both fiction and poetry, was designated the United States first official Poet Laureate.

title: Let the British Reform Northern Irish Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZILIAN SOCCER, GUADALAJARA-STYLE
description: In the nightclub of one of the large hotels here, a group of Brazilian dancers and musicians perform every night before enthusiastic crowds of Mexicans.

title: 'SOAPY' WILLIAMS TO GET A LAST HURRAH
description: The hair is quite a bit thinner now, but the trademark green and white polka-dot bow tie is still firmly in place and the manner as earnest as ever.

title: THE STAGE: 'KATHY & MO,' A COMEDY
description: WHEN we first see Kathy Najimy and Mo Gaffney, of ''The Further Adventures of Kathy & Mo,'' they are standing in a spotlight and giggling nervously. The light blacks out a second or two later, and the audience is left with an unresolved question. Are these young women laughing at themselves, laughing at us, or both? Ninety minutes later the answer remains inconclusive. ''Kathy & Mo,'' a two-woman comedy recital at the Second Stage, is a not untalented enterprise, but it's often at odds with itself. The performers, actresses from San Diego who write their own material, can't always decide whether they're unsparing satirists or smug public scolds.

title: New York City Offering
description: New York City yesterday offered $572.6 million in bonds tentatively priced at 98 1/2 with a maximum yield of approximately 8.64 percent for issues due between 2012 and 2016.

title: NOW MARKS 20TH YEAR AMID A STRATEGY DEBATE
description: The National Organization for Women will celebrate its 20th anniversary here this weekend at an annual convention expected to draw about a thousand delegates.

title: AIDE EXPLAINS HOW HE FAILED TO BAR SPACE SHUTTLE FLIGHTS
description: The top technical official in the space shuttle program today explained how he failed to stop shuttle flights last year until O ring seals on the booster rockets could be repaired.

title: IN CHINA, IN MONGOL STEPS, HORDES OF BACKPACKERS
description: At dawn, when a crescent moon lingers on the horizon, the donkey carts are on the move in this old Islamic town. Through an open doorway in a whitewashed wall, the murmurings of young boys reading the Koran filter into an alley. Old men in leather boots gather silently on a nearby bench, watching the sun spreading a wash of pink across the distant Pamir peaks.

title: Morris Is Freed
description: Eugene (Mercury) Morris, who played in three Super Bowls as a running back for the Miami Dolphins, won his freedom from prison in Miami yesterday by pleading no contest to a cocaine-conspiracy charge. Circuit Judge Ellen Morphonios sentenced Morris to four and one-half years in jail, giving him credit for three years he served before the state Supreme Court granted a new trial.

title: NICHOLS, S E INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate investments of $52,000 for the quarter and $332,000 for the 6 months.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday about commencement at Long Island University's Brooklyn center carried an incorrect identification issued by the university for Martin E. Segal, who received an honorary doctorate in humane letters. Mr. Segal is a businessman, not a lawyer, and is chairman emeritus of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

title: UNCLE COMMITS SUICIDE AFTER SLAYING 2 NIECES
description: Two girls were killed and a third was critically wounded in a basement playroom of their Queens home yesterday afternoon by shotgun blasts fired by an uncle who then shot and killed himself, the police said.

title: NICKLAUS SUFFERS BAD FIRST ROUND
description: Jack Nicklaus, seeking his 21st major victory two months after winning his 20th in the Masters at age 46, attracted the attention, the cheers and the help of his cold and soaked gallery today. The help came on the 10th hole. On that par-4, 409-yard hole, Nicklaus pushed his drive over a steep hill on the right side - so far right, in fact, that the ball went beyond the sea-grass rough into the dense, thorny bushes that grow thickly away from the fairways. He and his son, Jackie, as well as the huge gallery, searched for the ball. Jackie found it, but his father decided his time limit had expired. He teed off again, with a stroke penalty, and wound up with a double-bogey 6.

title: DEVELOPER BUYS STAKE IN SAFEWAY
description: Herbert H. Haft, a multimillionaire Washington real estate developer, said late yesterday that an investor group he headed owned 3.6 million shares, or nearly 6 percent, of the nation's biggest grocery chain, Safeway Stores Inc.

title: TENFOLD INCREASE IN AIDS DEATH TOLL IS EXPECTED BY '91
description: The total number of AIDS cases and deaths from the disease will increase more than tenfold in the next five years as the virus spreads widely outside New York and San Francisco and infects a larger segment of the heterosexual population, the Government predicted today.

title: ART: WILLIAM RIMMER WORKS ON EXHIBITION
description: THE illustration is of an image that, once seen, is never forgotten. ''Flight and Pursuit'' is its title - but which of the two men is fleeing, which pursuing? The facial expression and predatory hand of the forward figure, which is very much flesh and blood, suggest anything but fear, despite the menacing shadow behind him. He is also oblivious to the phantom in the background, raising the possibility that this is a scene of a man and his thinly disguised doppelganger hunting down a third party.

title: EAGLE TELEPHONICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: WILSON ADAPTS TO PLATOON JOB
description: One of the adages that baseball has produced is that there are two kinds of ballplayers, the kind that can step from the bench at any time and be helpful, and the kind that must play every inning to be happy and effective. These two types are so separate, is the old belief, that they must have been reared in opposite environments.

title: Latin Music
description: The Trio Musica Hispana, an ensemble featuring the pianist Pablo Zinger, the violinist Israel Chorberg and the cellist Alejandro Bacelar, will play a concert of classical works derived from the folk and popular music of Spain and Latin America, Sunday afternoon at 2 in Armor Hall, Wave Hill, 675 West 252d Street, the Bronx. Admission is $4 for Wave Hill members and $1 for members under 14; $5 for nonmembers, with a $2 admission price for nonmembers under 14. Information: 548-5449.

title: Unhappy in Cincinnati
description: Bill Bergesch, the general manager of the Cincinnati Reds, has reportedly told certain team owners he would leave the club at the end of the season if unrest in the organization persists.

title: U.S. VOICES FEAR CRACKDOWN WILL BLOCK PEACEFUL SOLUTION TO CRISIS
description: The United States said it was concerned today that the latest crackdown in South Africa had seriously jeopardized hopes for a peaceful resolution of the growing crisis in that country.

title: TALKS ON U.S. STEEL CONTRACT ARE OPENED AMID OPTIMISM
description: Negotiations opened in Pittsburgh yesterday between the United Steelworkers of America and the United States Steel Corporation, the last round of bargaining in the 1986 negotiations between the union and major steel companies.

title: FORT TRYON PARK BRINGS SCENIC DRAMA TO CITY
description: Visitors to the Cloisters should allow time to explore the scenic delights of surrounding Fort Tryon Park. Steep cliffs overlooking the Hudson, dense forests and a patchwork of lawns, gardens and terraces make it one of the city's most dramatic parks.

title: 9 Killed in Bekaa Clashes Between Lebanese Units
description: Lebanese factions battled today in the Syrian-occupied Bekaa region and the fighting raged in Beirut's refugee districts.

title: Student Is Slain and 5 Hurt In Clash With Ecuador Police
