description: A student was shot dead and at least five were wounded today when students protesting price rises clashed with the police here, doctors said.

title: Press 'Drove' Botnick From Post, Koch Says
description: Mayor Koch charged yesterday that news commentators he declined to name ''drove'' his close aide, Victor E. Botnick, from office as the city's hospitals chief.

title: STAFF REDUCTION OF 12% ANNOUNCED BY CHEVRON
description: The Chevron Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, yesterday became the latest in the industry to announce a sharp paring of its staff because of depressed conditions.

title: Price Drops Stir Cattlemen
description: The nation's cattlemen, alarmed by a continued drop in livestock prices on both spot and futures markets, may ask Congress to investigate futures- and cash-market trading, the industry's trade group said yesterday.

title: DAYS INNS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $4,040,000, or 38 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $1.9 million, or 25 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: Weinberger in Wonderland
description: There is an Alice in Wonderland quality to Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger's annual report to the Congress for fiscal 1987. This ''posture statement'' justifying defense expenditures of more than $300 billion contains assertions about the Soviet threat that just won't wash. In fact, two of its central arguments about Soviet intentions - the arguments that provide the underpinning for the United States defense budget - are demonstrably false.

title: A DATE WITH SERENITY AT THE CLOISTERS
description: PERCHED high above the Hudson in the forested hillsides of craggy upper Manhattan, the tower of what appears to be a medieval monastery etches its brown granite profile against the sky. This imposing building that seems to belong in some secluded valley of the Pyrenees is in fact one of the world's finest museums devoted to the arts of the Middle Ages. A branch of the Metropolitan Museum, the Cloisters is the crown of Fort Tryon Park, a Washington Heights oasis that also offers spectacular vistas of the Hudson, rugged woodlands, formal gardens and secluded lawns.

title: British Jobless Rate Up
description: Britain's unemployment rate rose to 13.3 percent in May from 13.2 percent in April, the Government said today. It was the six consecutive monthly increase. The number of adults out of work, seasonally adjusted, came to 3,208,600, up 5,600 from April.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE party circuit was replete this week with third-, fourth- and fifth-generation heirs of John D. Rockefeller, none of them busier than David Rockefeller. One of ''the brothers,'' as the third generation is called, Mr. Rockefeller served as co-chairman with his wife, Peggy, of Monday's benefit dinner-dance for the Center for Inter-American Relations. For most men, this would mean no more than donning black tie and showing up.

title: BIOCRAFT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bethlehem Cuts
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it was reducing the work force at its plant in Bethlehem, Pa., by 550 employees during 1986 to ''improve the competitiveness of the plant's structural mills and other operations.''

title: SOME SCENIC ROADS-ON-THE-HUDSON
description: With the Hudson Valley entering the full bloom of summer, it's a good time to tour the area's most scenic roads - officially certified by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Deuce at Jazz Fest
description: The Women's Jazz Festival continues this weekend at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street below East Fourth Street (505-5660). Tonight, the trumpeter Ellen Seeling and the saxophonist Jean Fineberg will lead their quintet, Deuce, at 9 P.M. The singer Carmen Lundy and her trio will perform at 10 P.M. Tomorrow, the singer Abbey Lincoln will perform at 9:30 and 11 P.M. Tickets are $10.

title: Anderson Sets Resolicitation
description: Anderson, Clayton & Company said today that it would resolicit proxies from its shareholders in a continuation of the June 3 stockholders meeting. Its decision followed a hearing Wednesday at the Delaware Chancery Court, which approved the action.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Bally Manufacturing Corp., Chicago, said it had completed the purchase of the 16 percent, or 3.9 million shares, it did not already own of its Bally's Park Place Inc. subsidiary.

title: COMPTEK RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOUSE PANEL PLANS TRIPS ABROAD IN DEAVER INQUIRY
description: A House panel plans to travel to Bonn and Tokyo later this month to take the sworn testimony of two United States ambassadors in connection with its investigation of Michael K. Deaver, committee sources said today.

title: Hands Across America Halfway to Fund Goal
description: Hands Across America, in which people linking hands coast to coast as an expression of concern for the needy, has collected almost $28 million, more than half its goal, according to organizers of the campaign.

title: ADOLPH STURMTHAL
description: Adolph Sturmthal, an economist who specialized in international labor relations, died of cancer Wednesday at his daughter's home in Avon, Conn. He was 82 years old and lived in Champaign, Ill.

title: Investigator for Prosecutor Commits Suicide at the Office
description: A 53-year-old investigator for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office shot and killed himself yesterday afternoon in a stairwell of the Brooklyn Municipal Building at 210 Joralemon Street, the police said.

title: TRAFFIC DEATH RATE DROPS
description: The percentage of people who died on the nation's highways dropped ''to the lowest level in history'' last year and deaths caused by drunken driving also declined, Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole said today.

title: EAST 27TH ST.: A QUIET AREA TURNS TOUGH
description: On one block of East 27th Street right off Fifth Avenue, there are three hotels, the Prince George, the Madison and the Latham, which together house more than 600 homeless families with 1,500 children - more homeless people than in all of Queens, the Bronx, Brooklyn or Staten Island.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
HONOR ARMS PACT, HOUSE PANEL SAYS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee adopted a resolution today urging the Reagan Administration to stay within numerical limits on nuclear weapons set by the 1979 treaty on limiting strategic arms. The vote was 29 to 11.

title: MELRIDGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NO MOTIVE FOUND
description: A hotel company executive who was shot dead in his room at the Waldorf-Astoria early Wednesday was apparently the victim of a ''deliberate and planned'' attack by a gunman who placed him on the floor and used two pillows to muffle the gunshot, police officials said yesterday.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $442,000 for the quarter and $1,458,000 for the 9 months. c-After extraordinary tax credits of $504,000 for the quarter and $1,245,000 for the 9 months. The share earnings reflect 1-for-14 reverse split of common stock, which became effective Feb. 14.

title: Combat on the Hill
description: Confrontation between members of Congress is a way of life on Capitol Hill, but rarely do they go hand to hand.

title: DAY OF LIES BY BOTNICK SEALED FATE
description: If Victor E. Botnick ever stood a chance of remaining in city government, that chance was lost last Thursday when he admitted that he lied about his college credentials - then proceeded to lie again at a series of news conferences, according to several advisers to Mayor Koch.

title: Venezuela Quake Kills 2
description: Two people were killed and at least 45 were injured Wednesday when an earthquake shook eastern Venezuela, destroying dozens of homes, Government officals said today. Two children were killed when their home collapsed in the town of Carioco, an official said.

title: Beirut Possibility
description: The leading candidate to replace Reginald Bartholomew in the sensitive and demonstrably dangerous job of United States Ambassador to Lebanon is John H. Kelly, a 46-year-old Foreign Service officer currently between assignments and attached to the State Department's management division.

title: FINANCIAL CORP. CHIEF SEES BLEAK '86
description: The chairman of the Financial Corporation of America said today that problem loans would rise, possibly substantially, and that the company was unlikely to show an operating profit until at least the end of this year.

title: Market Place; Positive Signs In Durables
description: BEGINNING last fall, sales of household durable goods slumped. For months, only intermittently did they rise above the level of a year earlier. In May, however, some positive signs of life were found in sales of consumer electronics, refrigerators, laundry equipment, furniture and related products.

title: 'ABC COMEDY SPECIAL' OFFERS 'HEARTS OF STEEL'
description: WASTE not, want not. That seems to be the policy motto at Capital Cities/ ABC Inc. these days. Following months of personnel cutbacks, the ABC Network division is now offering viewers a new series of dead-end comedies. The ''ABC Comedy Special,'' which can be seen on Fridays at 9:30 P.M., is a somewhat tattered package of sit-com rejects, the pilots of shows that probably will not go into series production. Consider the positive side: if you're distressed by the series that do make the regular schedule, look at what you could have been subjected to week after week.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Economic Scene; Austrian Seeks A New Balance
description: AUSTRIA's new Chancellor, Franz Vranitzky, the 48-year-old former Finance Minister in the Socialist Government, intends to reshape his nation's economic policy in response to the election to the presidency of Kurt Waldheim, the candidate of the conservative People's Party.

title: FORD PROPOSES INSTALLING AIR BAGS FOR DRIVERS IN MOST CARS BY 1990
description: The Ford Motor Company proposed today to install air bags on the driver's side of a majority of its new passenger cars by the 1990 model year if the Government would drop a more stringent requirement.

title: Required Reading; An Outlaw Congress
description: Representative Robert S. Walker, Republican of Pennsylvania, in a floor speech June 9:

title: Patriots Reward Berry
description: For his success in the 1985 season, the New England Patriots have rewarded Coach Raymond Berry with a five-year contract.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Haden, Motian, Redman and Carroll, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, near West Fourth Street (242-1785). Charlie Haden has been closely associated with Ornette Coleman's music since the late 1950's, but his work springs directly from the tradition of jazz bassists exemplified by Walter Page, Jimmy Blanton, and Wilbur Ware. Each of these players had a different melodic conception, but all of them believed the bassist's job was to fill out the bottom of the band with a big, fat sound and to firmly anchor the music's flights of fancy. This weekend, Mr. Haden is appearing with two familiar associates, the drummer Paul Motian and the saxophonist Dewey Redman, plus a newer voice, the lyrical trumpeter Baikida Carroll. This promises to be a superb quartet. Shows are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1 A.M. today and tomorrow, and at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. on Sunday. There is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Agency Wins First Account
description: Michael Cox and Paticia Greenwald, who worked together as executive vice presidents at the old deGarmo agency, have gone into business together as Cox & Greenwald.

title: COMMONWEALTH DELEGATES CHART DRIVE FOR SOUTH AFRICA SANCTIONS
description: The co-chairmen of a Commonwealth group that tried and failed to mediate between the Government in South Africa and its black opposition signaled the start today of an intensified international campaign for economic sanctions to bring about an end to apartheid.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: YANKEES OUTLAST BENIQUEZ
description: The last time a Baltimore batter hit three home runs against the Yankees, last Sunday in New York, the Orioles won, 18-9. Juan Beniquez duplicated Lee Lacy's feat tonight, but this time the Yankees won, 7-5.

title: Business Plans Less Spending
description: United States businesses expect to reduce spending on plant expansion and new equipment by 1.3 percent this year, as cutbacks in the slumping oil industry put a damper on overall business investment, the Government said today.

title: STEPHENS PLAYING A HOT HAND
description: There is a Grade I stakes race on the menu at Belmont Park tomorrow, which can only mean one thing: Woody Stephens is likely to end up in the winner's circle.

title: Bard College Concert
description: The pianist William Black and the violinist Stephanie Chase will play a concert of Mozart, Beethoven and Prokofiev at Bard College's Chapel of the Holy Innocents tomorrow night at 8.

title: Hewlett-Packard Retirement Plan
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced plans to offer early retirement benefits to 1,800 longtime employees and voluntary severance incentives to a ''small fraction'' of its 84,000 workers. The electronics manufacturing concern said it expected 1,500 employees to participate in the incentive programs and leave the company by Oct. 31.

title: Yonkers Between Justice and Contempt
description: Despite five years of litigation and months of negotiation, the Yonkers City Council has voted to appeal rather than obey Federal District Judge Leonard Sand's order to desegregate its public schools. A 10-to-3 majority of the Council balked at the estimated $37 million cost.

title: Learning Art at P.S. 190
description: The walls of Mrs. Batkey's first-grade class were hung with paintings, collages and woodcuts. Masks, sculptures and necklaces lined the shelves.

title: Piano Recital
description: The pianist Monica Jakuc will make her New York recital debut Sunday night at the Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, playing Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations. Tickets are $8. Information: 362-8719.

title: COMMUNICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $67,650 for the quarter, $157,000 for the latest year and $37,000 for the year-ago period. c-Net loss and includes a negative adjustment of $114,950 resulting from excessive tax credits. The latest year revenue is corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: FILM: 'BACK TO SCHOOL,' WITH RODNEY DANGERFIELD
description: RODNEY DANGERFIELD is definitely an acquired taste.

title: Donor Heart Is Found For Baby in Kentucky
description: A donor heart was found today for Baby Calvin, a dying 3-week-old infant who suffers from the same heart disease that afflicted a California baby who received a new heart Tuesday, a Kosair Children's Hospital spokesman said tonight. Transplant surgery was planned for early Friday morning.

title: SCREEN: 'MONA LISA,' STARRING BOB HOSKINS
description: NEIL JORDAN'S ''Mona Lisa'' is classy kitsch. It's as smooth and distinctive (and, ultimately, as insubstantial) as the old Nat (King) Cole recording of the song, which gives the film its title and a lot of its mood. It's also got high style, so you needn't hate yourself for liking it.

title: ABC to Share News At Liberty Weekend
description: Television's battle for Liberty was resolved today when ABC agreed that its rival networks could share all news portions of the Liberty Weekend opening ceremonies.

title: COALITION CITES 'CULTURAL BIAS' IN POLICE TESTS
description: A coalition of groups representing black police officers, attorneys and psychologists said yesterday that psychological tests that were established for police applicants less than a decade ago were ''culturally biased'' and had become a major obstacle to minority-group members applying for police jobs.

title: Pentagon to Push Tests Of Chemical Weapons
description: The Pentagon, ignoring Congressional criticism of the Bigeye nerve gas bomb, said today that it would go ahead with initial production of the weapon for test purposes.

title: Beecham to Focus On Health Care
description: The Beecham Group P.L.C., the British company that bought a big chunk of Revlon's businesses last fall, said it would focus on its core pharmaceutical and health-care products businesses and sell most of the operations that did not fit its long-term strategy. Beecham, based in London, said it would seek offers for its home-improvement and wine and spirits division, as well as its American-based Germaine Monteil cosmetics unit.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $426,000 for the latest year and $58,000 for the year-ago period. The 1985 year was also after an extraordianry charge of $326,000 for the early extinguishment of debt.

title: COMMERCE DEPT. OUSTING 3 IN DATA LEAK CASE
description: The Commerce Department said today that it would dismiss three employees for using advance knowledge of sensitive economic statistics for personal gain in the securities markets.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT ON SOUTH AFRICA ISSUED BY COMMONWEALTH MISSION
description: Following are excerpts from the report on South Africa issued here today by the Commonwealth mission known as the Eminent Persons Group:

title: New Chairman Named For Troubled Enterra
description: Stanley P. Gold, who heads an investment firm owned by the Roy E. Disney family, has been named chairman of one of the firm's latest investments - the Enterra Corporation of Radnor, Pa.

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: MERET INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-After a tax credit of $327,889 for the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months net was also after a gain of $1,938,338 from debt restructuring. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $3,033,030 for the quarter and $4,733,734 for the 9 months.

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective March 10.

title: The U.N. Today: June 13, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on renewal of mandate of peacekeeping force in Cyprus. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FRENCHMAN ASSAILED FOR DENYING NAZI CRIMES
description: ''I am not a neo-Nazi, I am not an anti-Semite,'' declared Henri Roques, 65 years old, a retired agronomist. ''But I do doubt that six million Jews were killed in Nazi gas chambers. I live in a free country, I have a right to doubt.''

title: WESTBURNE INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After writedowns of $69.9 million for the quarter and the year. c-Net income. The company said the $69.9 million in writedowns includes $36.6 million from the reduced value of its contract drilling assets, $31.5 million from the lower value of oil and gas properties and $1.8 million from the writedown of the fair market value of an investment.

title: DANCE: CAST CHANGES IN GRAHAM'S 'DENISHAWN'
description: IF one had to single out moments that explained why Martha Graham is Martha Graham, a prime example would be a fall to the ground by the one-woman chorus in Miss Graham's ''Cave of the Heart.''

title: REAGAN TERMED 'VERY UPSET' THAT HE CONFUSED QUESTIONS
description: President Reagan was described by a White House official today as ''very upset'' over his performance at nationally broadcast news conference Wednesday night, when he misunderstood two questions.

title: ANIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Deficit Is Worse Than We're Told
description: To the Editor:

title: US HEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a charge of $476,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: TREASURY ISSUES RISE IN PRICE
description: Prices on Government securities rose and short-term interest rates declined yesterday as traders responded favorably but still cautiously to signs that the economy remained weak.

title: AUCTIONS
description: EVER since quartz wristwatches began upstaging windups in jewelry shops and department stores over the last decade, prices have escalated on period mechanical versions sold in antiques shops and at auction. Wristwatches have been offered regularly at auctions since 1980. Over the last year, prices for extraordinary examples have doubled, spurring, in turn, unusual activity at auctions in Geneva and New York.

title: U.S. Divestment Moves Are Widely Known to South Africans
description: To the Editor:

title: TOBACCO TRADE ASSAILS ARMY SMOKING CURB
description: The tobacco industry and its supporters in Congress said today that they would oppose the Army's new policy of strict controls on smoking in military offices and buildings and an outright ban in Army vehicles and aircraft.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 13, 1986
description: The Economy

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 24
Cab Drivers Threaten Strike for July Fourth
description: Demanding higher fares, a coalition of New York City taxi drivers threatened yesterday to strike on the Fourth of July weekend.

title: STORM HAMPERS PLAY
description: A rousing nor'easter with winds gusting to more than 40 miles per hour and occasional heavy rain socked in Shinnecock Hills Golf Club today for the opening round of the 86th United States Open. The storm gave the mighty track such added strength that Tom Watson said the course went on the attack and the players on the defense.

title: On the Move
description: The Rangers and the Devils will be breaking some old preseason patterns and establishing some new traditions next fall. The Rangers, who for years have been concentrating their exhibition schedule in Lake Placid and other upstate towns, are planning a weeklong tour to San Francisco, Calgary and perhaps other Western cities, and the Devils, who have held practices at the Ice World rink in Totowa, N.J., ever since they arrived from Denver in 1982, will be moving to another workout site.

title: Filipinos Mark Holiday With Joyful Parade
description: Filipinos today celebrated their first Independence Day since President Corazon C. Aquino came to power with a big parade that was also intended to be a display of Mrs. Aquino's popular support.

title: Democrats Strive for Accord on Foreign Policy
description: After more than a decade of post-Vietnam disarray and nay-saying, Democrats are struggling to build a new foreign policy consensus at a time when some analysts contend that President Reagan and the Republican Party are losing political control in this area.

title: AT THE U.S. OPEN, CHILLS AND UMBRELLAS
description: It was more suited for a Bronte novel than golf: the moor-like greens, sodden under heavy gray skies; the intermittent rain; the people walking hunched over, fighting the biting wind.

title: SCREEN: 'MANHATTAN PROJECT'
description: ''I NEVER thought I'd say this to anybody,'' says young, clean-cut Paul Stephens (Christopher Collet), a high school science whiz, ''but I've got to go get an atomic bomb out of the car.''

title: Time, Please
description: People for the American Way, a Washington-based citizens group concerned with constitutional issues, maintains that the evangelist Pat Robertson has run afoul of the Fairness Doctrine in some of his television shows.

title: YES, WHITE HOUSE SAYS
description: Amid confusion over President Reagan's intention to abandon the 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty, the White House said today that the accord ''no longer exists.''

title: FIGURATIVE SCULPTURE OF THE 80'S
description: DESPITE the inappropriateness of its somewhat grandiose title, ''Figurative Sculpture: The 80's'' is one of the more solid gallery shows on figurative sculpture. It includes mature and emerging artists. There is work in bronze, pewter, wood, vinyl and plaster. Sculptures are free-standing, on the wall, or hugging the floor. The exhibition - at the Marilyn Pearl Gallery, 38 East 57th Street, through July 31 - has a thoughtfulness that does the subject a service.

title: Welfare Chief of City To Head State Agency
description: George Gross, the Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, will become the new executive director of the State Financial Control Board, Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

title: BAY OF PIGS INVADER WELCOMED IN JERSEY AFTER CUBA RELEASE
description: A man who was freed Sunday after spending 25 years in Cuban prisons for his part in the Bay of Pigs invasion received a tumultuous welcome here today from former comrades in arms. He also received an emotional greeting from his wife, whom he had not seen in 15 years.

title: Allis-Chalmers To Sell Unit
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation and the AC Material Handling Corporation said they had agreed in principle for AC to buy Allis-Chalmers's industrial lift truck business.

title: A Place to Play Is All He Needs
description: A switch-hitter with power and personality, Orestes Destrade seems to have everything going his way. He's been batting around .300 all season, he's second in the International League's home-run race, and he's the Yankees' best hitting prospect at Columbus. There's only one hitch. He plays first base, which has been deeded to Don Mattingly until the turn of the century or so.

title: JOHNSTON CHALLENGES BYRD IN RACE FOR DEMOCRATIC LEADER OF SENATE
description: Senator J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana said today that he would challenge Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia for the Democratic leadership of the Senate in the 100th Congress, which convenes in January.

title: Diner's Journal
description: HELL'S KITCHEN is smoldering with a whimsical new Cajun-Tex-Mex-Southern-you-name-it-style restaurant in the former McGraw-Hill Building on West 42d Street, called Southern Funk Cafe. Paul Prudhomme it's not, but where else in New York can you get an eye-watering bowl of Creole jambalaya replete with sausage, chicken and crayfish for $6.25? Southern-fried chicken, thickly battered, peppery and moist, is the same price - it cries out for a Lone Star beer ($2.75, no extra charge for the glass).

title: BRACES: HIDDEN ASSETS GO PUBLIC
description: It's hot and muggy, and all around town a sartorial secret of some of New York's most conservative men is being revealed as they doff their jackets on steamy streets.

title: 5 in Punjab Shot to Death By Sikh Militants
description: Sikh militants shot dead five people in Punjab State today, and a Sikh was killed in retaliatory violence by militant Hindus, the police said.

title: 'Nunsense' Canceled
description: ''Nunsense,'' the musical comedy at the Sheridan Square Playhouse at Circle Rep, will not be presented through Sunday because of stage damage incurred during yesterday's rainstorms.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ONE day a couple of years ago, Neil Jordan, a 36-year-old Irish writer and film maker, took a break from making his last movie, ''A Company of Wolves.''

title: Update on Knicks
description: The Knicks updated the status of their four key injured players. Scotty Stirling, the general manager, said the brace on Bill Cartwright's left foot was removed Tuesday and that he would begin walking in regular shoes.

title: Ups and Downs
description: The standings of all the major league teams as of yesterday, in terms of games better (+) or worse (-) than their records on the same date a year before.

title: RECEIVER TELLS COURT CITISOURCE COMPUTER IS AT LAST AN ASSET
description: A hand-held computer that prosecutors said was only ''an empty box with no working parts'' when it was sold to New York City's parking bureau now incorporates technology that ''gives it a 12-plus months' lead time in this field,'' according to the court-appointed receiver for the company that developed it.

title: KATHERINE DUNHAM GETS SCRIPPS DANCE AWARD
description: Katherine Dunham, a choreographer and founder of her own dance school, has been awarded the $25,000 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award.

title: BOTNICK, LOOKING BACK, ASSERTS PRIDE IN RECORD
description: Victor E. Botnick, who resigned as head of the city's hospital system this week amid questions about his credibility and actions, said yesterday that he was proud of his government record and had nothing to fear from any pending or future inquiries.

title: BUSH URGES RESTRAINT BY CANADA
description: Vice President Bush urged Canada today not to escalate the current trade dispute with the United States and defended recent tariffs on some Canadian products as necessary to forestall ''sterner medicine'' from Congress.

title: GOING TO THE MALL ON CABLE TV
description: Viewers who always thought the Veg-O-Matic commercials were the best part of television now have a network they can love - a 24-hour discount bazaar on cable television called the Home Shopping Network. And it is playing to raves on Wall Street.

title: What's With Wall Street? Just an Insider's Game?
description: ''What's going on?'' One meets this question everywhere these days. Perplexed journalists encountered at dinner, ''Rust Belt'' industrialists attending a convention, amateurs and professionals alike, the interested and disinterested, all want to know, What is going on with Wall Street? What does all this mean? Is Wall Street really crooked and the game fixed, played with the speculator's equivalent of loaded dice?

title: CHANGES BY BUYERS DELAY A WESTCHESTER COMPLEX
description: The idea of giving the customer what he or she wants often works fine in retailing. But applying that adage to 80 exclusive town houses in this Westchester community caused construction to slowly grind to a halt.

title: CBS FEARED LOSS OF N.F.L.
description: A senior CBS Sports executive acknowledged yesterday that CBS felt it was risking the loss of National Football League games if the network failed to pay $780 million in rights fees for the five-year period starting in 1982.

title: REBELLION GAINS IN WEST AND THE PLAINS OVER U.S. SPEED LIMIT
description: Like a driver in a hurry, a rebellion against the Federal speed limit of 55 miles an hour is gaining momentum in the Western and Plains states.

title: TAX BILL KEPT INTACT IN SENATE
description: With a sizable majority of senators opposing all amendments to the tax-revision bill whatever the merits, the Senate today warded off proposals dealing with sales tax deductions, abortions and consumer interest.

title: Tour of Chinatown
description: A walking tour through Chinatown tomorrow will begin a three-part series called ''The Orient in New York,'' sponsored by N.Y.U.'s School of Continuing Education.

title: Toll Road Bonds Set by Kentucky
description: The Kentucky Turnpike Authority is tentatively offering through the Cranston Securities Company and Morgan Stanley & Company about $225.7 million of toll road revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.549 percent for 8 1/2 percent bonds due in 2010 at a price of 99 1/2.

title: Replacing a Loss In the Mounted Unit
description: The newest addition to the police force will bear the name of a 40-year-old delicatessen because of an unusual death in the department's mounted unit.

title: McDonnell And Airbus
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is negotiating an agreement to cooperate with one of its main rivals, the European aircraft consortium Airbus, a senior West German official said today.

title: FORMER F.B.I. AGENT'S 2D TRIAL FOR ESPIONAGE NEARS THE END
description: The only evidence prosecutors have that Richard W. Miller gave classified documents to a Soviet spy are the former Federal agent's tainted admissions to interrogators, Mr. Miller's attorney said today.

title: MUSIC: A NEW JAZZ QUARTET
description: SWEET Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, near West Fourth Street, has presented a series of all-star new-jazz groups this season. The latest, appearing through Sunday, is a nameless quartet with Charlie Haden on bass, Dewey Redman on saxophones and Paul Motian on drums - all of whom were with the pianist Keith Jarrett in the early 1970's - plus Baikida Carroll on trumpet.

title: New York's Stained Hospital Record
description: For better or worse, New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation serves as the family doctor to millions. The departure of its chairman, Victor Botnick, following the bribery indictment of an agency president, seriously undermines the public's trust in a vital service.

title: Models at the Ritz
description: The Models, an Australian rock band, will perform tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Tetes Noires, a band from Minneapolis, opens at approximately 11:30 P.M., with the Models at 1 A.M. Tickets are $13.50.

title: JAMES TRUEMAN, 51, OWNER OF WINNING CAR IN INDY 500
description: James R. Trueman, the owner of the car that Bobby Rahal drove to victory last month in the Indianapolis 500 and president of the Red Roof Inns motel chain, died Wednesday of cancer at his home here. He was 51 years old.

title: MORE THAN 1,000 ROUNDED UP
description: South Africa's beleaguered white leaders today imposed a nationwide state of emergency and detained hundreds of activists in an effort to crush dissent before Monday, the 10th anniversary of the Soweto uprisings.

title: Kirk Testifies In Tulane Case
description: Dana Kirk, the basketball coach at Memphis State, testified today that he had watched videotapes of his team's game at Tulane in February 1985 at least six times and still saw nothing to suggest that John (Hot Rod) Williams did anything to throw the game.

title: A Top Arbitrager Is Won by Merrill
description: A top risk arbitrager has resigned from the Chemical Bank to join Merrill Lynch & Company, taking his staff with him.

title: The Soldier's Enemy
description: Maj. Bruce Bell was right on two counts when he said the Army's new ban on smoking in military offices, barracks, vehicles and aircraft ''essentially reverses our entire orientation.''

title: Poles Protest Drug Abuse
description: Several thousand people linked hands outside the Palace of Culture in Warsaw today in a demonstration against increasing drug addiction in Poland.

title: Peter Pears Memorial
description: There will be a memorial concert for the late British tenor Sir Peter Pears at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine tomorrow night at 7:30.

title: PIANIST BARRY HARRIS KEEPS YOUNG, AND BUSY
description: ''This is what you call trying to stay young, I guess,'' Barry Harris, the pianist and one-man jazz academy, said the other day. He was describing his seven-day-a-week schedule of teaching student classes in jazz singing, piano, guitar and improvisation at his Jazz Cultural Theater on Eighth Avenue.

title: Some Trans-Hudson Freight Could Ride Rails
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHWARTZ BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $58,553, or 7 cents a share.

title: Bridge: Bold Move at a Jersey Event Was Safer Than It Appeared
description: Some flighty moves at the bridge table, like flights in an airplane, are vastly less risky than nervous people tend to think.

title: GLOOM AND DOOM
description: Outside, a hard rain squall of a nor'easter pelted the windows of the Shinnecock Hills clubhouse. In the old locker room with small white wooden cubicles just big enough to hold a golf bag, Jack Nicklaus, who would tee off in about an hour, looked around at several touring pros watching television of the United States Open's early starters.

title: Carbide Responds In Bhopal Case
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to the terms of a Federal judge's decision to transfer lawsuits over the Bhopal chemical disaster from United States courts to India but reserved the right to appeal those conditions.

title: Hampton at Whippoorwill
description: The vibraphonist Lionel Hampton and his 17-piece band will perform tonight through Sunday at the Whippoorwill, 18 East 18th Street (675-7100). Sets are at 10 P.M., midnight and 2 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 10 P.M. and midnight Sunday; there is a $25 cover and a $10 minimum tonight and tomorrow, a $20 minimum and a $10 cover Sunday.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Arnold Foods Co., Greenwich, Conn., named John Wilcha president of Arnold Bakers.

title: Lack of Funds Stalling Some Federal Trials
description: Federal trial courts across the nation will not begin any new noncriminal jury trials until October if Congress does not provide more money, court officials said today.

title: THATCHER DISSOLVES NORTHERN IRELAND ASSEMBLY AFTER 4 YEARS
description: The British Government announced today that it was dissolving the Northern Ireland Assembly after four years of fruitless attempts to foster a debating ground for compromise between the politicians of the province's Protestant and Roman Catholic communities.

title: How Senate Voted On I.R.A. Proviso
description: Here is the Wednesday roll-call vote of 51 to 48 by which the Senate tabled - in effect killed - an amendment to retain tax-deductible Individual Retirement Accounts for all workers. A vote ''for'' was a vote to put the amendment aside, while a vote ''against'' was a vote to keep the amendment alive.

title: How Party Conventions Serve Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Mets Lead Balloting
description: The Mets have three players -Darryl Strawberry, Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez - leading in balloting for the National League team in the July 15 All-Star Game at Houston.

title: Coney Island Is More Than Scene of a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Toadying to Deaver
description: While in the White House, Michael Deaver headed a small committee to screen ambassadorial appointments. That foreign interest of an image maker seemed curious; now we learn why he wanted embassies beholden to him. 1. Passage to India: The Deaver choice for New Delhi was the diplomat John Gunther Dean; the two met in Indonesia and in Washington, and in overriding the State Department's choice for the post, Mr. Deaver said at the time, ''John Gunther Dean is a friend of mine and is helpful to me.''

title: DOUGLAS DUNN AND HIS DANCING DOOR
description: New dances are begun in a variety of ways. Douglas Dunn's ''Dances for Men, Women and Moving Door,'' a new, evening-long piece that will be performed tonight through Sunday at Marymount Manhattan Theater, grew out of Mr. Dunn's wish to work with the composer Alvin Lucier and the architect and sculptor David Ireland.

title: THE EMERGENCY DECREE AND WHAT IT WILL DO
description: South Africa's newest emergency decree offers all the nation's security forces - the police, army, prison warders and railways police - sweeping powers that take them beyond the control of the courts.

title: ISRAELI LEADERS ACT ON BUS-STOP CONFLICT
description: The conflict between secular and militantly Orthodox Jews in Israel intensified today, and Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir took steps to try to ease it.

title: ASTROS TURN BACK GIANTS, 4-1
description: Manny Hernandez won his first major league game and Mark Bailey hit a two-run homer tonight as the Houston Astros beat the San Francisco Giants, 4-1.

title: LIMITS ON LIABILITY GAIN IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Assembly passed a bill today that would limit the amount of money insurance companies would have to pay in damage awards and would grant immunity from most damage suits to public officials and volunteers, such as Little League coaches.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Italian Official, in U.S., Urges Resolution of Mideast Crises
description: Foreign Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy said today that the resolution of the different crises in the Middle East would help reduce the number of Arabs attracted to terrorist actions.

title: U.S. AIDES IN '72 WEIGHED KILLING OFFICER WHO NOW LEADS PANAMA
description: Law enforcement officials in the Nixon Administration once proposed the assassination of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was then chief of intelligence in the Panama Defense Force, as a partial solution to that nation's heavy drug trafficking, according to a Senate Intelligence Committee report.

title: HERITAGE ENTERTAINMENT YEAR reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $94,000. c-After a gain of $88,000 from debt restructuring and a tax credit of $424,000.

title: Reagan Medical Exam Is Set
description: President Reagan, who had intestinal cancer surgery nearly a year ago, will undergo a semiannual checkup within the next several weeks, Larry Speaks, the White House spokesman, said today. Mr. Reagan, 75 years old, had his last major checkup Jan. 17 at Bethesda Naval Hospital. Doctors said the tests revealed ''no evidence of any disease.''

title: Turnbull Upset In England Event
description: Larisa Savchenko of the Soviet Union upset third-seeded Wendy Turnbull of Australia, 7-5, 6-2, today in the $125,000 Dow Chemicals Classic.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: San Antonio Issue
description: A $185 million issue of San Antonio electric and gas revenue bonds was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley with a maximum yield of about 9.696 percent for 8 5/8 percent bonds due in 2014. The bonds are rated double-A by Moody's and S.&P.

title: FOR TEXANS, A RELUCTANT MISS LIBERTY
description: No one in Texas wants to place a lot of emphasis on having to call in the Mississippi National Guard to drop a 3,000-pound statue of the Goddess of Liberty back on top of the State Capitol in Austin.

title: Injured Runner To Be Moved
description: The distance runner Kathy Ormsby, who was paralyzed after a plunge from a bridge last week, will be transferred from Wishard Memorial Hospital to a facility at Duke University on Friday, a Wishard spokesman said today.

title: MUSIC: ROOMFUL OF BLUES AND GUESTS
description: THE jump-blues revival band Roomful of Blues has two superb guest vocalists - the singer Jimmy Witherspoon and the singer-saxophonist Eddie (Cleanhead) Vinson - in its engagement through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street. With them, Roomful of Blues becomes a snappy backup band.

title: Weighing the Espionage Damage
description: Nearly all of those implicated in last year's spate of espionage cases in this country have now been convicted. But Government officials believe the damage caused by the spying is likely to linger for years, affecting anything from naval tactics to the United States' capability for gathering sensitive information about the Soviet military.

title: PERRY ELLIS RECALLED BY FASHION INDUSTRY AT MEMORIAL SERVICE
description: Members of the fashion industry gathered yesterday to remember Perry Ellis, the sportswear designer whose clothes were known for their casual grace and inventiveness.

title: There Is More to Pornography Than the Rights of Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Fish to Fry
description: In 1913, Congress, which then had complete control over the District of Columbia, established a wharf on Maine Avenue at a channel leading to the Potomac River. The legislators' greatest concern was apparently that they be assured a constant supply of crabs and oysters from the nearby waters of the Chesapeake and the Atlantic.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income. c-Includes tax credits of $129,000 for the quarter and $258,000 for the 6 months. The company said the latest period results include a pretax charge of $475,000 for costs associated with the settlement of New England Tube & Machine Company litigation.

title: Tales of Anxiety
description: DELIRIUM ECLIPSE AND OTHER STORIES. By James Lasdun. 200 pages. Harper & Row. $15.95. James Lasdun loves metaphors. This sparkling new collection of stories by this young British writer absolutely bristles with them - as well as extended similes, striking descriptions and hallucinatory images. A college professor finds himself lost in a subway maze that reflects his own disordered state of mind. An ambitious writer watches a former mentor die of a wasting illness that reminds him of his own disloyalty to his ex-teacher's ideas. An unhappy child indulges in an orgy of eating and destruction that mirrors the torment he feels over his mother's burgeoning romance with a divorced man.

title: MOVIE EFFECTS INSPIRE NEW THEME - PARK RIDES
description: When an immense gorilla with bad breath begins to threaten patrons of the Universal Tour Friday, the influence of the movies over theme parks will be stronger than ever. Disneyland, of course, was built on Mickey Mouse, but now, such major movie directors as George Lucas and Francis Coppola are creating amusement-park attractions, and the spirit of Steven Spielberg presides over a whole new generation of rides.

title: Bridge; Same Hands Will Be Dealt Around the World Today
description: The biggest bridge event in history, the Epson world simultaneous pairs, will take place today.

title: Suit Charges Pay Bias By Los Angeles County
description: A lawsuit accusing Los Angeles County of systematic discrimination against women and members of minority groups was filed today on behalf of 47,000 employees.

title: 47 Tamils Reported Dead In Sri Lanka Attacks
description: Forty-seven members of the Tamil minority were reported killed today by men in army uniforms who burned down a village and by an air force helicopter gunship that opened fire on three passenger vans.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS IN CHICAGO PARADE CHEERED BY CROWDS
description: An estimated 200,000 people marched today in what sponsors called the largest parade of Vietnam veterans ever held, and a half million spectators cheered them.

title: GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago period's loss was reduced by $28,700 as a result of a restatement of research and development expenses to reflect a change in accounting for software development costs.

title: TOFUTTI BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income.

title: PERSICO CONVICTED IN COLOMBO TRIAL
description: A Federal jury hearing one of a series of major Mafia cases in Manhattan convicted Carmine Persico and eight others yesterday of operating the Colombo crime family in a widespread pattern of labor racketeering in New York City. Major parts of the case focused on charges that the Colombo group controlled several unions, primarily the District Council of the Cement and Concrete Workers, and extorted millions of dollars from construction companies in the city.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS LINK DUVALIER FATHER-IN-LAW TO COCAINE TRADE
description: United States officials say Ernest Bennett, the father-in-law of former President Jean-Claude Duvalier, was a prominent figure in narcotics trafficking here and was sometimes referred to as ''the Godfather.''

title: YANKEES GAIN 2D PLACE
description: Bob Tewksbury, the rookie who so impressed Manager Lou Piniella in the spring, returned from his banishment to the bullpen tonight and shored up the Yankees' sagging pitching forces.

title: Conservatives Rescind Marchi Endorsement
description: Is it possible to be both a Conservative and a Liberal?

title: CAMACHO GAINS SPLIT DECISION
description: Hector Camacho came into the Madison Square Garden ring last night to a hero's ovation, dancing and strutting in a sequined robe and shoes.

title: THATCHER REJECTS SUGGESTION OF PRETORIA SANCTIONS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher rejected a suggestion this evening that she might have to go along with economic sanctions against South Africa in order to prevent ruptures in the 49-nation Commonwealth.

title: COMPANY CHIEF IS FOUND SLAIN IN 63d ST. HOME
description: A 35-year-old Manhattan business executive was found slain in his apartment on the Upper East Side yesterday morning, apparently bludgeoned to death, the police said.

title: EARLY JUNE CAR SALES ROSE 0.8%
description: The major domestic auto makers said today that sales of new cars advanced a slight eight-tenths of 1 percent in early June from the comparable 1985 level. But analysts, who had been forecasting a decline, were pleased.

title: Pretoria Panics
description: A frightened South African regime confesses it cannot control Monday's observances of the 10th anniversary of the black uprising in Soweto. In all but name, it has imposed martial law. The army and police are raiding, banning and censoring and have jailed more than 1,000 suspected opponents without charges. Yet this panic is served up as proof of manliness. President P.W. Botha says, ''The world must take note and never forget that we are not a nation of weaklings.''

title: SHADES CUT COSTS OF COOLING
description: SUMMER air-conditioning bills can be lowered by an average of $100 a home, according to a 17-city study that examined how well window shades conserve energy. Conducted by Maureen Grasso, associate professor of home economics at the University of Texas at Austin, and Prof. David R. Buchanan of North Carolina State University's School of Textiles, the study calculated cooling costs when windows are left bare as well as the effectiveness of three standard window treatments -shades, draperies and venetian blinds - in lowering those costs.

title: Reagan Reports a Snag In Efforts for Hostages
description: President Reagan said today that the United States had recently been set back in its efforts to win the release of the American hostages in Lebanon and that his hopes for a breakthough had led to a ''great disappointment.''

title: Fast Opposing Waldheim
description: Since Tuesday morning, David Delshad and Ahmed Weis have huddled at the Isaiah Wall, across First Avenue from the United Nations. Braving chilly rain, a brisk wind and other dangers, they have been fasting to protest the election of Kurt Waldheim to the presidency of Austria.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe Montana, the San Francisco 49er quarterback who underwent surgery on his throwing shoulder June 1, said, ''I'll be throwing a baseball next week, and I'll be ready to start the season.'' Montana underwent an arthroscopic procedure to relieve nagging pain, but the operation was not disclosed until Thursday. . . . Carl Scheer, who has been the general manager of the Los Angeles Clippers for the last two seasons, has been named the commissioner of the Continental Basketball Association. . . . The Devils have signed two players who performed last season in the minor leagues: Andy Brickley, a left wing, and Jamie Huscroft, a defenseman.

title: UNITED TOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: REAGAN, CITING 'CIVIL WAR,' URGES RESTRAINT FOR ALL SOUTH AFRICANS
description: President Reagan said today that South Africa was in a state of ''outright civil war'' and urged both the Government and its black opposition to show restraint.

title:
PATENTS;
By Imitation Body Tattoos
description: Imitation tattoos that can be applied adhesively to the body were patented this week for the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, St. Paul.

title: JURY GETS ESPIONAGE CASE OF EX-F.B.I. AGENT
description: A Federal district judge today instructed the jury in the espionage trial of a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Richard W. Miller. The jury will begin its deliberations Monday.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES $800 MILLION TRIM FOR SPACE SHIELD
description: A Senate subcommittee has voted to cut the Pentagon's program to develop advanced defenses against nuclear missiles by nearly $800 million, a reduction that nonetheless allows the program more than $4 billion next year, Congressional sources said today.

title: Miami Indictment Names Seven From Police Force
description: Seven suspended or former Miami police officers used their police jobs to run a drug operation that used murders, threats and bribery, according to a Federal indictment unsealed today.

title: U.S. WARNS LATIN OFFICERS OF PERILS OF DRUG TRADE
description: A senior State Department official today warned a group of Latin American military officers against involvement in narcotics trafficking, saying the illegal drug business was ''rapidly becoming a regionwide menace.''

title: SEARCH NATURAL RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a $2,049,456 writedown of oil and gas reserves.

title: Bentley Kassal, Appeals Judge, Weds Miss Wax
description: Barbara Joan Wax, a former buyer and manager of the S'fari Room at Bonwit Teller in New York, was married yesterday to Associate Justice Bentley Kassal of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, First Department in Manhattan. Associate Judge Bernard S. Meyer of the Court of Appeals of the State of New York performed the ceremony at the courthouse of the Appellate Division in Manhattan.

title: DEAVER WON'T RENEW CONTRACT WITH CANADA
description: Michael K. Deaver, the former White House aide, will not renew his lobbying contract with Canada when it expires June 30, to spare the Canadian Government further political embarrassment, a spokesman for Canada's External Affairs Ministry said today.

title: MUSIC: RENSSELAER'S COMPUTER
description: The musical engineers at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute have created a musical instrument of considerable subtlety and scope and have been inviting composers to write music for it. The latest exponents of Rensselaer's instrument, the Synclavier - a computer system guided in part from a central keyboard - gathered at the Alternative Museum on Wednesday night. There were pieces by Rick Baitz, Neil B. Rolnick, Pauline Oliveros and Joel Chadabe. Mr. Rolnick's collaborators at the end were Sandy Moore, her films and bicycle-propelled projector, and the MIDI Synthesizer System.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Thursday listed a product erroneously among the Revlon brands being assigned to Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. The fragrance Scoundrel is being handled, temporarily at least, by the Revlon Creative Workshop.

title: Pennzoil Files Brief
description: The Pennzoil Company has filed a brief with a Texas appeals court asserting that the trial that led to a multibillion-dollar damage award against Texaco Inc. was conducted fairly, despite Texaco's view that it was riddled with legal errors.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Producer Prices Jumped 0.6% in May
description: Producer prices climbed by six-tenths of 1 percent in May, ending a four-month streak of the sharpest producer price declines on record, the Government reported today.

title: DENMARK BEATS W. GERMANY
description: If there was any doubt about Danish Dynamite, it vanished today in this historic city on the highland plains. Starting 10 players who make their living in leagues outside their homeland, and participating in its first World Cup, Denmark defeated West Germany, 2-0, to capture Group E. Called ''El Grupo de la Muerte'' -the Group of Death - because it was believed to be the strongest of the six groups in the first round, today it produced a vibrant match between two teams that had already qualified for the second round.

title: MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to May 11
description: b-Net income

title: ANOTHER 'OLD FELLA' TRIES TO WIN
description: The day after Jack Nicklaus won the Masters, Lee Trevino sent him a telegram.

title: Bid Spurred Unocal Debt
description: The Unocal Corporation of Los Angeles took on $4.2 billion in debt in May last year in its costly attempt to fight off a takeover by T. Boone Pickens.

title: COUNCIL GOING AROUND KOCH TO PUSH BUDGET
description: In an unusual show of independence, the leadership of the City Council is planning to lobby for the city budget in Albany next week, contending that the Koch administration has been too distracted to do its job.

title: Cynthia Recouso Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Denise Recouso, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Recouso of Lewisboro, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Charles Herbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Herbert of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. William F. Guido performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Savior in Manhattan.

title: Ex-Louisiana Congressman Gets 3 Years in Bribery Case
description: Former Representative Richard A. Tonry has been sentenced to three years in Federal prison and fined $15,000 for trying to bribe an Indian chief to allow bingo games on a reservation.

title: Sneak Preview
description: There will be an unusual Sunday session at the Supreme Court tomorrow.

title: Bell Brothers Convicted
description: Mike Bell, a defensive end with the Kansas City Chiefs since 1979, and his twin brother Mark, a tight end for five seasons with the Seattle Seahawks and the Indianapolis Colts, were convicted yesterday in Wichita, Kan., on felony charges that they attempted to buy cocaine through the use of a telephone on May 2, 1985. A sentencing date of July 31 was set by United States District Judge Wesley Brown for the 28-year-old brothers. Mike Bell could receive a maximum nine-year prison sentence and a $65,000 fine and Mark, who did not play last season after being released by the Colts on July 25, could receive five years of imprisonment and a $35,000 fine.

title: Stresses on Schmidt
description: Playing this season with a succession of injuries that have included cracked ribs, a pulled hamstring muscle and a recent pulled calf muscle has prompted Mike Schmidt, the 36-year-old inflelder for the Philadelphia Phillies, to contemplate retirement.

title: Frisbee Finals for Dogs Today in Central Park
description: Interested dogs (and owners) will have their day at the annual New York State finals in frisbee-catching today in Central Park, north of the Sheep Meadow, at 72d Street.

title: A Principal's Place In the New Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JUNE 14, 1986
description: International

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MAY OUTPUT OF INDUSTRY DOWN 0.6%
description: The output of the nation's mines and factories fell a substantial six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Federal Reserve Board said today, suggesting a more sluggish economic outlook than had previously been indicated.

title: PANAMANIAN SAYS CHARGES ARE AIMED AT NATION
description: Panama's military chief, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, has said reports that he was engaged in gun running and drug trafficking were directed against his country, not himself.

title: Rangel to Seek Inquiry Into Harlem Hospital
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel said yesterday that he would seek a Congressional investigation to determine whether minimum Federal health standards were being violated at Harlem Hospital Center.

title:
FOR MANY, FATHER'S DAY IS NO FIELD DAY;
Parental Leave For Men, Too
description: The role of fathers has changed radically in the last 25 years, primarily because of the dramatic increase in the number of working mothers who have young children. As a result, stereotypes of fathers as breadwinners and mothers as homemakers and child-rearers are breaking down.

title: POLICE HUNT REPUTED MOB OFFICER REPORTED MISSING FOR PAST WEEK
description: Robert DiBernardo, a reputed captain in the Gambino crime family and a key target of a Federal investigation into child pornography, is missing, authorities said yesterday.

title: Non-Hearing Hearing
description: When the hearing on an antismoking bill opened the other day before the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and the Environment, Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. objected that he had not been permitted to call his own, pro-smoking, witnesses. These included, he said, representatives of unions and veterans and armed forces organizations.

title: Flying Tiger Head Resigns
description: Lewis H. Jordan has resigned as president and chief operating officer of Flying Tiger Line Inc., the main unit of the financially troubled Tiger International Inc., the company announced today.

title: SECURITY TAG SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
Macmillan in Bid
description: Macmillan Inc., the publishing and information company, said that it had offered to purchase all outstanding shares of the Business International Corporation, a privately held publishing and consulting concern in New York, for $140 a share. The Macmillan statement announcing the offer did not indicate the number of Business International stock outstanding, but a publishing industry source said it was about 47,000 shares, for an indicated total value of about $6.6 million. Macmillan said that its offer would expire July 11 and that the deadline for the withdrawal of shares tendered was July 3.

title: Steelcase Expands
description: Steelcase Inc. will build seven manufacturing plants and four office buildings near this western Michigan city over the next 14 years, the company says.

title: FESTIVAL GROUP IS URGED TO BAR 'NOTORIOUS' SHIP
description: The Senate today urged the organizers of the Statue of Liberty centennial to withdraw their invitation to the Chilean naval vessel Esmeralda, saying she was used as a torture ship after a Government coup in 1973.

title: Topics; Worth Embracing; Reversal in Harare
description: Credit Robert Mugabe, Zimbabwe's Prime Minister, with redeeming decency and sense. To its shame, his regime had arrested Michael Auret and Nicholas Ndebele, the chairman and director of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace.

title: Genesco to Sell Hosiery Unit
description: Genesco Inc., the financially troubled footwear and apparel company, said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its Camp Hosiery division to the Union Underwear Company for an undisclosed price. The sale is expected to be completed within 30 days, according to a statement released from Genesco's headquarters in Nashville.

title: BENNY GOODMAN, KING OF SWING, IS DEAD
description: Benny Goodman, the King of Swing whose clarinet led a generation of music fans into the Big Band era in the 1930's, died yesterday afternoon at his Manhattan apartment, apparently of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

title: SUBWAYS ARE CLEANER, TRANSIT AUTHORITY SAYS
description: Car by car, station by station, New York City subways are getting cleaner, the Transit Authority says.

title: Topics; Worth Embracing; Smacked
description: When Linda Ballard visited the Tulsa Zoo with relatives last month, she got a big hello from a chimpanzee named Buddy. Waving his arms and running into her, he knocked Mrs. Ballard to the ground.

title: Crabs Called Safe to Eat
description: Crabs in the Baltimore harbor are safe to eat although they contain higher concentrations of contaminants than crabs from less-polluted parts of the Chesapeake Bay, according to the State Health Department. The department, in its first intensive look at crabs from the harbor, tested 179 crabs from 13 locations for seven toxic metals and 16 organic chemicals. Only in the case of one metal, copper, did the harbor crabs have a significantly higher level than their bay counterparts.

title: A.M.A. BOARD STUDIES WAYS TO CURB SUPPLY OF PHYSICIANS
description: Organized medicine is seeking to limit the rapid growth in the supply of doctors, particularly specialists, which leaders in the profession say is making a dent in the substantial incomes most physicians receive.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes income of $538,000 for the quarter and a loss of $2,622,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and is after income of $34,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income and is after income from discontinued operations of $374,000. The 1986 and 1985 earnings include credits for the reversal of deferred income taxes related to DISCs of $305,000, or 7 cents a share, for 1986 and $1,757,000, or 39 cents a share, for 1985.

title: OXYGEN ENRICHMENT CO LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
CONFUSION SURROUNDS MITTERRAND'S ROLE IN FESTIVAL
description: Details of the two-day visit of President Francois Mitterrand of France for the Statue of Liberty centennial are still being worked out amid indications that some French officials feel he is not being given so visible a role as they had hoped.

title: L.I. WOMAN, 61,SLAIN AT HOME
description: A Hempstead woman who regularly sheltered troubled young adults was beaten to death in her kitchen early this morning, and the police said they had arrested a young woman who was staying with her.

title: ABORTION FOE SEES HOPE INMORTALITY OF JUSTICES
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson, in a sharp attack on the Supreme Court, said today that opponents of abortion could look to the ''wonderful process of the mortality tables'' to change the composition of the Court and bring about a reversal of its latest decision on abortion.

title: ON BEING A BILLIONAIRE AT 40
description: Donald J. Trump turns 40 today, and it is about time.

title: NORMAN TAKES 3-SHOT LEAD WITH A 68 FOR 139
description: The Shinnecock Hills Golf Club's course demonstrated today in the second round of the 86th United States Open championship that, even in fair weather, it still held the upper hand as one of the strongest courses in Open history.

title: Red Sox Win, 5-3, On Double by Rice
description: Jim Rice went 2 for 3 and doubled home a fifth-inning run tonight, leading the Boston Red Sox to a 5-3 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: SAFEWAY SAYS IT PREFERS TO REMAIN INDEPENDENT
description: Safeway Stores, operator of the biggest chain of supermarkets in the country, yesterday spurned the idea of a takeover by Herbert H. Haft, a Washington multimillionaire, saying that the huge chain preferred to remain independent.

title: Man Extradited to U.S. In Technology Case
description: A West German accused of smuggling sensitive American high-technology equipment to the Soviet Union was extradited to the United States from Britain today, the Customs Service announced.

title: MACGREGOR SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $44,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $105,000, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $459,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,369,000, or 29 cents a share, for the 9 months. The latest 9-month period includes the operations of Riddell acquired in January 1985, account for as a purchase.

title: Demers to Red Wings
description: The Detroit Red Wings, whose 17 victories in 80 games last season left them with the worst record in the club's history, yesterday named Jacques Demers as their new coach, the 20th in their history and their fourth in the last year. Demers, who coached the St. Louis Blues for the last three seasons and was still under contract with the Blues, received a five-year deal from the Red Wings.

title: JUDGE BLOCKS BIAS BY FIRE COMPANIES
description: A Federal judge, saying a female firefighter had been subjected to ''inexcusable'' sexual harassment in her Queens fire company, issued an order yesterday warning that further harassment could lead to jailing and fines.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
MORE, MORE, MORE
description: Nobody can get enough anymore.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: A NEW BALM FOR AN ITCHY BANE OF SUMMER
description: Scientists working for the United States Forest Service say they have developed an aerosol spray that could protect millions of Americans from the rashes, bumps and blisters of poison ivy.

title: Johns Awarded Wolf Prize
description: The artist Jasper Johns has been awarded the Wolf Prize in Arts this year from the Wolf Foundation in Israel. The award, which carries a $100,000 cash prize, was given to Johns for being ''one of the most influential painters and printmakers of our time.'' The award is given to individuals in agriculture, mathematics, chemistry, physics, medicine and the arts for ''achievements in the interest of mankind and of friendly relations among peoples.''

title: Article 109286 -- No Title
description: Diane Hunt, 32 years old, a cleaning woman at a Neiman-Marcus store, has been charged with stealing 343 dresses worth about $686,000 over the past year, the authorities said. The police said up to four dresses a week had been stolen and sold for resale to Glenn Allen Baccus, 30, charged as an accomplice.

title: Lebanon Force Planned For Palestinian Areas
description: Lebanese Moslem leaders and Syrian officials announced today that a special force of the Lebanese Army would be deployed around three Palestinian districts in Beirut to subject them to Lebanese laws.

title: HEALTHFUL FOODS AT CARRYOUT SHOPS
description: Restaurants are serving spa-type cuisine. Diet cookbooks are taking over the best-seller lists. Supermarkets are stocking more vegetables and less beef. McDonald's is test-marketing salads.

title: PIANO RECITAL: RAUL SUNICO AT MERKIN HALL
description: Raul Sunico, a Philippine pianist, came to Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night to play works by Schumann, Liszt, Albeniz, Ravel and Barber.

title: Times Co. Will Charge 10 Cents a Share to Net
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that a decision of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court relating to the 1981 acquisition of its cable television systems could reduce 1986 earnings by 10 cents a share. It said it would take the charge in the second quarter.

title: TWO YEARS AFTER RENOVATION, BROOKLYN'S FULTON MALL STILL SEEKS AN ANCHOR
description: Merchants in the Fulton Mall in downtown Brooklyn were enthusiastic when a seven-year, $24 million renovation, which had worn their patience and that of their customers, was completed two summers ago.

title: ABC LIFTS SOME RESTRICTIONS IN LIBERTY WEEKEND DISPUTE
description: ABC, after being roundly criticized for claiming exclusive television rights to key portions of the Liberty Weekend ceremonies, has agreed to allow coverage of several more minutes of the celebration that CBS, NBC and the Cable News Network had insisted were national news events legitimately open to all.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OVER THERE, IN BROOKLYN - The reluctance that New Yorkers display when it comes to visiting boroughs other than the one in which they live or work is as notorious as it is traditional - a journey to foreign strands often seems less daunting. This is lamentable because boroughs outside Manhattan also have worthy attractions.

title: Play on Dancer's Life To Open at DanceSpace
description: ''The Sand Dancer,'' a play by the poet Sandra Hochman, based on the life of the dancer Howard (Sandman) Sims, will have its premiere on June 30 at 8 P.M. at the Nikolais/Louis DanceSpace, 33 East 18th Street. The work features music by Galt MacDermot, choreography by Sheila Kaminsky, and excerpts from the film ''From These Roots,'' by William Greaves.

title: The Stories to Be Quarried From Veins of Stone
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY FACES OF QADDAFI: SHOWMAN AND SURVIVOR
description: Earlier this year Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya tried to convince the West that he was not a terrorist.

title: GEODYNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss. The periods reported have been restated from the full-cost method to the successful efforts method of accounting for oil and gas producing activities.

title: Greece to Permit Abortions
description: Parliament has passed a law permitting Greek women to have abortions on demand at state expense. The new law, approved by acclamation in a late-night session Thursday, replaces a rarely enforced 1950 law that made abortion a criminal offense in Greece.

title: Murray Van Wagoner Dies; Former Michigan Governor
description: Murray Van Wagoner, who established the nation's first permanent state highway travel information center before becoming Governor of Michigan, died Thursday. He was 88 years old.

title: A New New York Dad
description: I used to laugh at my neighborhood bodega's vast stock of Pampers, but now I'm grateful. I have become a New York new father.

title: Marines Replacing an Officer Over Warplane Maintenance
description: The commander of the Black Knights fighter squadron, which joined in the raid on Libya in April, has been removed from duty after inspectors determined that some of his planes had been improperly maintained, a base spokesman said.

title: ON FIRE ISLAND, FAMILY HAVEN FROM CITY LIFE
description: Most of the time, this Fire Island village serves as a haven from the furies of city living, a place where privacy and propriety are valued and protected.

title: Political Committee Is Fined $15,000 for '82 Contribution
description: A Federal judge yesterday fined the National Conservative Political Action Committee $15,000 for illegally aiding the 1982 campaign of Bruce Caputo against Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: EINHORN DESCRIBES FUTILE TV TALKS
description: Eddie Einhorn, the owner of the United States Football League's inactive Chicago franchise and the league's television contract negotiator, described for a jury yesterday his futile attempts with the three major networks to get a contract for the fall of 1986.

title: Altering Genes Is Risky Business
description: To the Editor:

title: HALIFAX ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $12,000. c-Net loss and includes a net loss of $212,000 from discontinued operations.

title:
PATENTS;
More Than 200 Patents Ended by Unpaid Fees
description: More than 200 patents have been allowed to expire for nonpayment of maintenance fees since September 1985, when the expiration regulation became effective.

title: FEDERAL RULES CUT ASBESTOS PERMISSIBLE IN WORKPLACE BY 90%
description: The Reagan Administration issued new rules today that cut the amount of asbestos permissible in the workplace by 90 percent.

title: WIENERS AND POLICIANS LEAD TO A LOOK AT IMAGES
description: Some people call it the Wiener War, but that is a misnomer, says Larry Gilling, spokesman for a group that calls itself Wiener Wagon Workers United.

title: ADI ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: DOW SURGES 36.06 TO CLOSE AT 1,874.19
description: Wall Street rallied impressively yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average regaining much of the ground it lost earlier in the week as new signs of a lackluster economy proved a potent elixir for the troubling interest rate environment.

title: MICHAEL NAMED CUB MANAGER
description: Gene Michael, twice a Yankee manager and the team's third-base coach the past three seasons, was named manager of the Chicago Cubs today.

title: THE SELLING OF FATHER'S DAY
description: Signs abound of the new importance being attached to the role of the father, from the sharp rise in fathers attending hospital births to the increased time that American fathers are spending with their offspring.

title: '85 TAPE SHOWS NASA BRIEFING ON SHUTTLE FLAW
description: The space agency today released a videotape showing its top officials being briefed Feb. 21, 1985, on the history of the booster rocket problems that eventually caused the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: SHOPPERS WORLD STORES reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $84,000, or 7 cents a share. c-Net loss.

title: JULY 4 TICKETS ON SALE BUT MAIL ORDERS ARE UNFILLED
description: Irate callers complained to Liberty Weekend organizers yesterday that after sending in months ago for tickets to special events, they had just received word in the mail that their requests would not be honored - even though some tickets are still available by telephone.

title: O'CONNOR ON TRIP TO LEBANON
description: John Cardinal O'Connor left New York Thursday night for a visit to Lebanon under secrecy about the full nature of the visit and his itinerary.

title: CHEFS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: b-Net income

title: BUSH SEES ONLY A 'TIFF,' BUT MULRONEY DISAGREES
description: Vice President Bush, winding up a three-day visit to Canada, tried again today to defuse trade frictions with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and his Government.

title: STAGE: 'LIVERPOOL FANTASY' PLAY BY LARRY KIRWAN
description: It is not just the Beatles without success, but the world without the Beatles, that Larry Kirwan imagines in ''Liverpool Fantasy'' at Charas New Assembly Theater. There are funny moments when John Lennon and Ringo Starr, who never made names for themselves - along with their wives and George Harrison, who has become a Roman Catholic priest - get together in Liverpool in 1986 for a visit with Paul McCartney, who split from the group in 1962 and became the American singing superstar Paul Montana. The situation has enough built-in ironies to create its own humor and it gives Mr. Kirwan opportunities to satirize modern culture on many levels. But there is also a heavy layer of political message here that at times suffocates the play.

title: Open Attendance Soars
description: The sun came out gloriously today to make up for Thursday's rain, cold and wind. Attendance at the 86th United States Open soared, traffic ran smoothly and the trains brought in 1,100 passengers on time.

title: SELLING OF S.A.T.'S REPORTED AT STUYVESANT HIGH SCHOOL
description: The principal of Stuyvesant High School, one of the city's premier public high schools, said yesterday that students and parents had reported that stolen copies of college entrance examinations were offered for sale to students taking the examination there last Saturday.

title: TV: 'FILM ON FILM,' ON CINEMATOGRAPHERS
description: The film maker who was called the cameraman has come a long way since the days when he was depicted as a rather frantic fellow who wore his cap backward as he ground away at his equipment, which was either mounted on a tripod or quivered on his swinging camera boom, while the director shouted orders. Just how far things have come is shown in the current installments of ''Film on Film'' at 10 o'clock Saturday nights through June 21 on WNET/Channel 13.

title: U.S. TO SEND HAITI A $20 MILLION EMERGENCY GRANT
description: In an effort to demonstrate Washington's confidence in the interim Government of Haiti, the United States announced today that it would provide Port-au-Prince with an emergency grant of $20 million to avert a budget crisis.

title: HOW SPECIAL BREAKS GOT IN THE TAX BILL
description: When the Senate Finance Committee was struggling to put together its tax-revision bill, a law firm in Philadelphia set out to find a senator who would insert a special provision on behalf of one of its clients.

title: Puerto Rico Fire Kills 3
