description: An explosion and fire killed three workers and injured four others Thursday in a pharmaceutical plant, the police said. The deaths occurred at the Merck Sharp & Dohme Chemical Company, a manufacturer of veterinary medical supplies.

title: New PAC to Finance Kean's Political Trips
description: A national political action committee has been created to pay Governor Kean's travel expenses as he visits other parts of the country to talk about his ''politics of inclusion.''

title: Sales and Inventories Up in April
description: Business sales rose 1.4 percent in April, the first increase since December and the strongest gain in eight months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Becker Upset
description: Tim Mayotte upset Boris Becker, 6-7, 7-6, 6-2, yesterday to move into the semifinals of the $237,400 Stella Artois Grass Court championships at Queens Club in London, but the loss wasn't the biggest trouble for Becker. More distressing was the discomfort he had in the middle finger on the right hand.

title: 3-Week-Old Infant Gets New Heart in Louisville
description: Robert Dean Cardin, the 3-week-old first identified as ''Baby Calvin,'' received a new heart today, hours after his parents appealed for Congress to improve an organ donor network that allowed their child to be bypassed in favor of a more-publicized baby.

title: CRITICIZES DECREE SILENCING DISSENT
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu met today for the first time in six years with President P. W. Botha, a day after South Africa imposed its newest and most severe emergency decree.

title: Death-Qualified Juries Are Far From Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: THOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It has always been somewhat of a stiff, awkward holiday. That was in keeping with the traditional father's stiff, awkward role.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M., live, and 7:45 P.M., tape.

title: SENATE BUDGET NEGOTIATORS OFFER COMPROMISE ON REVENUE INCREASE
description: Challenging both the Reagan Administration and House Democrats, Senate negotiators today offered a 1987 budget compromise that would increase military and domestic spending by $7.3 billion, but only if the President and the House accepted revenue increases to pay for it.

title: PESO TRADING ON TEXAS BORDER
description: Simon Gonzalez Resendez held up a check made out Monday to his family's currency exchange business here for 74.5 million pesos, and shook his head.

title: Peronists Stage Strike Over Austerity Moves
description: Most of Argentina's business and industry came to a halt today in a Peronist-led protest against the economic austerity measures put in place a year ago by the Government of President Raul Alfonsin.

title: Topics; Worth Embracing; Common Sense Science
description: With all its numbers and carefully couched conclusions, Prof. Lawrence Schiamberg's study has the look and feel of science. It also sounds like common sense.

title: Action at Last?
description: Word from the State Department is that Senate hearings are expected shortly on the long-delayed confirmation of Frank G. Wisner to be Ambassador to Egypt.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $123,626 for the quarter and $829,872 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $269,358 for the quarter and $489,075 for the 9 months.

title: Ford, VW Discuss South America Tie
description: The Ford Motor Company and West Germany's Volkswagen A.G. are discussing ways for their subsidiaries in Brazil and Argentina to cooperate in manufacturing cars and light trucks, the companies announced today.

title: CARPENTER IS TRADED TO RAMS
description: Rob Carpenter, the 31-year-old workhouse fullback whose value to the Giants was diminshed last season by the emergence of Joe Morris, was traded to the Los Angeles Rams yesterday for a 1987 draft choice, reportedly in the sixth round.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: POLAND'S DEBT RESCHEDULED AGAIN
description: Western bankers and Polish officials meeting in Vienna this week have agreed to reschedule more than $2 billion in Polish debts that are due in 1986 and 1987.

title: Too Much Sun Can Cause Night Blindness
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about pop and jazz sources in New York City gave an incorrect telephone number for the New York Record Mart.

title: RURAL CO-OPS PLAN TV SERVICE
description: Rural electric cooperatives, responding to fears that the scrambling of satellite television signals would end reception in many homes, are planning to offer a low-cost package of programs to their customers who own satellite dishes.

title: CONTINUUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title:
Patents;
'Hard' Suit For Space Station
description: A ''HARD'' suit intended to be worn by astronauts on the space station that is planned to start operation in 1992 was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: A Safer Record in a Riskier Job
description: Piloting military aircraft has always been risky, even in peacetime, and the risks have risen as planes have become more powerful. Yet, perhaps paradoxically, military pilots have become less prone to accidents and, in 1985, scored their safest year yet.

title: WEAK ECONOMIC DATA SPUR BONDS AND STOCKS
description: Evidence of a weaker-than-expected economy caused a quick drop in short- and long-term interest rates yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 14, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Let the Mayor Run the Schools
description: Another chance to raise the quality of New York City's Board of Education is being muffed by the political leaders of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Staten Island, who apparently feel themselves beyond the voters' power. Never has it been more necessary to change the appointment process and to give the Mayor more authority over the schools.

title: ELECTRONICS, MISSILES & COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Two Kinds Of Arms
description: All three - Amy, the fierce 26-year-old children's advocate; David, the bone-crushing college athlete; and Elizabeth, the almost 3-year-old talking machine -will come tomorrow bearing gifts. If the day is soft, these precious gifts will be delivered in the park behind our house on a lovely bank of the Potomac less than two miles from the Pentagon, and I will experience deep parental joy but also grave doubt that I have lived up to my obligations as a father in the nuclear age.

title: Stolen Collectibles Found
description: A cache of ''priceless rare collectibles,'' including original letters of Charles Dickens, paintings, books and lithographs, has been recovered from a Bronx warehouse, the police said. Detectives discovered the collection of antiques and documents after a tip led them Thursday evening to a room at a warehouse at a U-Haul storage center at 2800 White Plains Road, a police spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell, said. The storage room had been rented by Fernando Gomez, 38 years old, who was arrested last month on charges of grand larceny , after he tried to sell some of the stolen works to Manhattan auction houses, the sergeant said.

title: PETER SICHROVSKY FINDS HAPPINESS IN BROOKLYN
description: After a long journey, Peter Sichrovsky of Vienna, Austria, recently rented a house in Flatbush, Brooklyn. The author said that in all his 38 years, spent for the most part in Europe and Asia, he has never been happier anywhere. Not in Berlin, not in Paris, not in London, not in Peking but near Prospect Park, in Brooklyn.

title: Continental Illinois Job
description: William E. Gibson, who recently declined appointment as a governor on the Federal Reserve Board, was named to the newly created position of executive vice president of the Continental Illinois Corporation. Mr. Gibson, 42 years old, a senior vice president of the Republicbank Corporation in Dallas, rejected an offer by the Federal Reserve in May because he wanted the position of vice chairman. Continental said Mr. Gibson would also assume the title of vice chairman of Continental's asset and liability management committee.

title: Uncle Who Shot Girls Was Facing a Charge
description: A Queens man who fatally shot two of his nieces and wounded a third before killing himself on Thursday was free on his own recognizance on a weapons-possession charge at the time of the shootings, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
Two Spherical Layers Used in Drug Capsules
description: Tiny capsules that gradually release drugs in the body were patented this week by Steven L. Regen, professor of chemistry at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa.

title: KALVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-There were no share earnings reported for the year-ago periods because the preferred dividends exceeded net income in the prior year and reduced net income to less than one cent a share in the year-ago quarter.

title: Quaker Oats Adds
description: The Quaker Oats Company, one of the world's largest food and marketing companies, said that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Golden Grain Macaroni Company for a combination of cash and stock.

title: U.S. SAID TO KNOW FIFTH ISRAELI SPY
description: The Justice Department has fully identified a fifth Israeli who purportedly conspired with an American naval analyst to steal American military secrets, a knowledgeable Reagan Administration official said today.

title:
PATENTS;
Electrical Device Tested And Delivered by Robot
description: Testing apparatus that includes a robot has been invented for the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: FREDA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Your Money; Lifetime Care In Retirement
description: EDGAR HAMILTON was 74 years old when he and his wife moved into Covenant Village, a continuing-care retirement community in Cromwell, Conn., in 1984.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 14. 1. Today, another attempt is scheduled to be made to maneuver ''The Goddess of Liberty Enlightening the World,'' onto its pedestal atop a state Capitol. What Capitol is it, and how does this Miss Liberty differ from the Statue of Liberty? 2. Law-enforcement officials in the Nixon Administration once proposed the assassination of a foreign official who has since become widely regarded as the politically dominant force in his country. Who is he and why was his assassination recommended? 3. In Boston, which has produced Paul Revere, John Adams and John F. Kennedy, there is only one man who has been deified by a statue erected in his lifetime. Who is he and why was he honored? 4. Advocates of abortion rights applauded the Supreme Court's reaffirmation of its landmark 1973 decision establishing a constitutional right to abortion, but there was nervousness in their satisfaction. What was the reason? 5. ''He's not going to be Rambo and he's not going to be a yuppie,'' said a business executive about a comic book character who will be out of circulation briefly, and then emerge as a ''modern kind of guy who has a Nautilus machine in his apartment.'' Identify the character. 6. For generations they have been fixtures of the national landscape -part treasure troves, part social centers, part hunting grounds - but now their numbers are declining.

title: MAYOR OF CHICAGO WINS A NEW ROUND
description: A judge gave Mayor Harold Washington a partial victory today in his continuing quest to put aldermen loyal to him into key positions of the City Council.

title: IN SURPRISING MOVE, SENATE VOTES TO KILL SPECIAL UNOCAL TAX BREAK
description: In a surprising challenge to special favors in the tax-revision bill, the Senate voted today to remove a tax break that would apply to only one oil company.

title: AEP INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
4 Survive Midair Collision
description: Two small planes collided and crashed upside down Wednesday but the four occupants were not injured, a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman said.

title: UNITARIAN UNIVERSALIST LEADER
description: The Rev. Dana McLean Greeley, a Bostonian who was first president of the Unitarian Universalist Association and minister of the First Parish in Concord, Mass., died of cancer yesterday at his home in Concord, Mass. He was 77 years old.

title: Courtesy Toward Tourists
description: Friendliness ranked second to last in motivators to visit New York, according to Holly Nolan of the State Department of Commerce. Glamorous nightlife ranked first in the Commerce Department survey, she said.

title: Must Mr. Reagan Tolerate Abortion Clinic Violence?
description: President Reagan's affable tolerance of anti-abortion violence threatens more than the women who need abortions and the doctors who perform them. It threatens the fabric of civilized society. The Administration's failure to condemn in any but the mildest words those who have bombed and set fire to abortion clinics has given these tactics respectability - even as some anti-abortion leaders have begun to shrink from the results of their own harsh words.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN'S STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a statement today by President Reagan on South Africa, as issued by the White House. A spokesman said the substance of the message was delivered orally to President P. W. Botha in Cape Town by Herman W. Nickel, the United States Ambassador.

title: Icing on Rink Cake
description: To the Editor:

title: QADDAFI DESCRIBES TALK WITH AMERICAN ENVOY
description: In a little-noted passage of a rambling speech broadcast earlier this week, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, gave some details of what he described as a private meeting months ago with William A. Wilson, the American Ambassador to the Vatican.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. The Capitol in Austin, Tex. The Goddess of Liberty holds Texas' lone star in one hand and a sword in the other. 2. According to a Senate Intelligence Committee report, the assassination of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, then chief of intelligence in the Panama Defense Force and now the army commander in Panama, was proposed as a partial solution to that nation's heavy drug trafficking, since there was evidence linking him to extensive involvement in illicit money laundering and drug activities. 3. Arnold (Red) Auerbach led the Celtics to their 16th championship in 30 years, the best record in the National Basketball Association. 4. The Court's majority shrank from seven of the nine Justices in 1973 to the barest minimum, five of nine. 5. Superman. 6. The number of junkyards is decreasing as the value of scrap and parts declines. 7. Higher, had profited. 8. Nothing. 9. The Apollo Theater in Harlem was the scene of a showdown of winners of Amateur Nights held there throughout the year. 10. Drug addiction. 11. Some ranchers in central Texas are using donkeys to guard livestock. 12. The bill would enact into law the limits on strategic weapons negotiated by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1979. 13. Three-day wedding celebrations are becoming more popular. 14. June 16 is the 10th anniversary of the start of the Soweto uprisings, a central day in the calendar of black opposition to the Government. 15. False. 16.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $133,000 resulting from certain net expenses incurred in connection with the Stauffer Chemical Company tender offer and purchase of 1,576,000 shares of the company's common stock.

title: Baltimore Sun Sale
description: Members of the families that control the A. S. Abell Company have ratified the sale of their holdings, including The Baltimore Sun and Evening Sun, to the Times Mirror Company for $600 million. The proposed sale to the owners of The Los Angeles Times, Newsday and six other newspapers drew quick approval and no discussion at a shareholders meeting Thursday.

title: KEY ELEMENT OF EMERGENCY DECREE: TOUGH NEW CURBS AGAINST THE PRESS
description: South Africa's newest emergency decree, covering the entire country, offers the authorities far greater powers of censorship than ever before, lawyers said today, making it an offense to publish a wide range of utterances deemed ''subversive.''

title: CDI CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
KEAN PRESSES SENATORS ON TENURE FOR 2 JUDGES
description: Governor Kean has been trying to convince two Republican state senators not to block his renominations of Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz and Justice Stewart G. Pollock to the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Bass Group Cuts Disney Co. Stake
description: An investment group led by the Fort Worth-based Bass family has sold more than 1.5 million shares of the Walt Disney Company, further lowering its stake in the entertainment concern from 19.3 percent, to 18.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group gave no reason for the sale of the Disney shares.

title: STANLINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago quarter's net includes a nonrecurring $90,000 bad debt recovery.

title: STRAWBERRY'S 9TH-INNING HIT LIFTS METS
description: It was an odd ending to one of the more curious games of the Mets' brilliant season, but it ended up as it almost always does: with the Mets winning, this time by 6-5, over the Pirates last night at Shea Stadium.

title: Budget-Bashing, New York-Style
description: Not three weeks before it goes into effect, Mayor Koch's $21.9 billion budget for New York City is under strong attack. The Citizens Budget Commission calls it ''larger but less productive'' than the current budget. And the City Council's majority leader, Peter Vallone, says it's balanced ''with blue smoke.'' Neither critique gives fair weight to the Mayor's struggle with diminished Federal aid, rising mandatory expenditures and stagnating revenues.

title: SOVIET WARNS U.S. ON ENDING ARMS PACT
description: Soviet diplomats warned today that the Soviet Union would stop adhering to the 1979 treaty limiting nuclear arms, possibly starting ''a chaotic arms competition,'' as soon as the United States exceeds the numbers of weapons permitted by the unratified accord.

title: NAKAJIMA FINDS FIRM TOUCH
description: It was Friday the 13th, a fact not lost on any of the dozen Japanese photographers and journalists who followed Tsuneyuki Nakajima yesterday round the often-maddening Shinnecock Hills Golf Club course.

title: DART GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
No Evidence of a Fix
description: John (Hot Rod) Williams played hard and well in one of the games in which he is accused of shaving points, the Southern Mississippi basketball coach, M. K. Turk, testified yesterday. Williams is being tried on sports bribery charges, accused of plotting to shave points in three Tulane games and of actually carrying out the scheme in two games - against Southern Mississippi and Memphis State in 1985. Thursday, the Memphis State coach, Dana Kirk, said he couldn't see any evidence of a fix in the game his team won at Tulane.

title: POP: PETER DEAN SINGS
description: THE rhythmic talents of Peter Dean, a singing thesaurus of rhythm songs of the 1920's and 30's, are complemented by an unusually able pair of rhythm guitarists in his performances on Thursday and Friday evenings at the Playbill, a room above Bill's Gay 90's, 57 East 54th Street.

title: IN LONDON, THEATER THAT MIRRORS BRITAIN TODAY
description: The first thing that a theatergoer notices at the London theater this season is the empty seats.

title: Mary C. Heller Is Wed To William W. Gridley
description: The Cathedral of St. John the Divine was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Mary Constance Heller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Heller of Winnetka, Ill., to William Winslow Gridley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gill Gridley Jr. of New York and Norfolk, Conn. The Very Rev. James P. Morton, dean of the cathedral, performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Daniel Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: SIGNS OF LIFE IN ENERGY-BELT BANK STOCKS
description: THE news coming out of Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana would seem to offer little hope to investors looking to buy the stocks of banks in those states. Regulators have repeatedly talked of the need to save a host of banks from insolvency. Numerous institutions reported large losses in the first quarter. Oil prices remain painfully low. Scores of office buildings in Houston and Dallas stand empty. And farmers continue to suffer.

title: PROSPECTS
description: As Mexico Goes...

title: HELPING COUPLES COPE WITH CHILDREN
description: ''JASON had always been a very difficult child,'' according to his father, 38-year-old Warren Donin of Great Neck. ''He never slept at night and, as a result, during the day he was impossible because he was always tired.

title: CARTER'S 7-8 JUMP TOPS AT ELLIOT MEET
description: Jerome Carter, who became a track celebrity by high-jumping in basketball shoes, made the highest jump of his life today.

title: Saving I.R.A.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE GREAT REHEARSAL: The Story of the Making and Ratifying of the Constitution of the United States, by Carl Van Doren. (Penguin, $6.95.) Carl Van Doren's narrative history chronicles events at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787 and the ratification process in the 13 states, interspersed with descriptions of the stage and portraits of the participants in the drama. In these pages in 1948, Dumas Malone said that in this ''fresh story of these great events, great men, and great arguments,'' the author ''has made both the actors and the issues come alive.'' FROM THE FAIR: The Autobiography of Sholom Aleichem. Translated by Curt Leviant. (Penguin, $7.95.) The Yiddish writer Sholom Aleichem (1859-1916) wrote his autobiography, done in the form of a novel, after a brush with tuberculosis. In these pages last year, Chaim Potok described the book as ''a delightful work, episodic in structure and jaunty in style.''

title: Judith G. Shepard Marries John Belash in Brookline
description: Judith G. Shepard, a vice president and associate general counsel of Goldman, Sachs & Company, and John W. Belash, a partner in the New York law firm of Gordon Hurwitz Butowsky Weitzen Shalov & Wein, were married yesterday. The Rev. Michael Boardman performed the ceremony at the First Parish, a Unitarian church in Brookline, Mass.

title: Mary Vermilye Weds Owen Wister Minott
description: Mary Stephenson Vermilye and Owen Wister Minott were married yesterday at the Manchester, Mass., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Vermilye. The Rev. Cynthia Kittredge, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Mexico Must Do Better On Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JUNE 15, 1986
description: International

title: Yu Retains Title
description: South Korea's Yu Myong-woo retained his World Boxing Association junior flyweight title tonight by stopping Tomohiro Kiyuna in the 12th round of a scheduled 15-round bout.

title: CHANGES SWEEPING CHESAPEAKE BAY THREATEN AND ISLAND'S OLD WAY OF LIFE
description: In the Revolutionary War the pirate Marmaduke Mister and his son, Stephen, had an agreement with residents of Smith Island: The islanders would feed the pirates and the pirates would leave the islanders in peace.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A FIFTH-GRADE teacher in the Essex County community of Short Hills is on the warpath again. First, it was Frank Perdue for his ''Perdue done it'' poultry products; now the producer Joseph Papp is getting it for ''Drood done it,'' a reference to the Broadway muscial ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood.''

title: Contras Finally Free 8 Germans
description: They turned out to be at the wrong place at the wrong time, but were eight West German citizens captured in a remote corner of Nicaragua on the wrong side? Relatives say the four men and four women went to Latin America on a humanitarian mission and were building housing when the American-backed, anti-Nicaraguan rebels attacked the area last month and took them prisoner. The rebels, known as contras, said the West Germans were armed, although the West Germans denied it.

title: Taxing Alcohol
description: To the Editor:

title: Line's President Takes a Tailspin
description: The airline industry's troubles were reflected in its executive suites again last week with the forced resignation of Richard D. Pearson, president for eight months of Trans World Airlines. The nation's fifth largest carrier, T.W.A. has been in particular difficulty because the costly takeover battle won last summer by Carl C. Ichan, the New York investor, was followed by a nine-week walkout by the 6,500-member Independent Federation of Flight Attendants. Mr. Pearson was asked to resign, he said, because of friction with D. Joseph Orr, an Icahn associate who was named a vice chairman in April.

title: Liberty Gala Is No Time or Place for Naysaying; The Wrong Symbol
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE stapler is missing. That may not sound like a big deal, but the Scotch tape is missing, too, as is the collection of oversized paper clips. In fact, all is chaos since one of the progeny moved back home to suburbia temporarily while searching for a new apartment in the city.

title: SURVEYS THAT MAY HELP ON BROADWAY
description: ''PRECIOUS SONS,'' a play set in Chicago in 1949, lasted less than two months on Broadway. But producers are likely to talk about it for a lot longer. The reason: ''Precious Sons'' was the first play to use pre-opening market research instead of out-of-town or Off-Broadway runs to figure out how to woo an audience. ''We wanted to get a handle on the audience so that whatever the critics said wouldn't matter,'' said Marty Bell, one of the play's producers.

title: CONNORS, MAYOTTE GAIN GRASS FINAL
description: Jimmy Connors and Tim Mayotte advanced today to the final of the Stella Artois Grass Court Tennis Championships, the major men's warmup for Wimbledon.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Can you supply information on musical cruises, with concerts on board? Is Paquet still doing them? - D. B. N., Scarsdale, N.Y. Answer:Paquet French Cruises has scheduled its 30th annual Music Festival at Sea from Sept. 1 to 15 aboard the Mermoz, sailing from Toulon, France. In recent years, the line has often had two music cruises, one in the Mediterranean, the other in the Caribbean, but the Mediterranean voyage is the only one planned for the next fall and winter season.

title: PROJECT MANAGEMENT ON A SHOESTRING
description: PLANNING software is hot. Management by the seat of the pants is dead.

title: Playing to a Local Audience
description: The source of WNET's financial bind, according to its managers, is the station's considerable contributions to the national Public Broadcasting Service. So the board of WNET, New York's Channel 13, approved a plan last week that will restructure its operations, eliminating its national program division.

title: A JURIED SHOW WITH SURPRISES
description: THE Long Beach Art League 25th Annual Juried Exhibition, on view at the Long Beach Museum of Art on the mezzanine of the Nassau Arena, attracted well over 300 entries.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: VERDI'S 'LOMBARDI'; A Teatro alla Scala production, featuring Jose Carreras, Ghena Dimitrova, Silvano Carroli, Carlo Bini, Luisa Vannini; conducted by Gianandrea Gavazzeni. Directed for television by Brian Large, 1984.

title: O'ROURKE OFFERS A LANDFILL PLAN
description: Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke has announced a series of steps to deal with the need to close the county's only landfill by July 1 to comply with a 1975 Federal court order.

title: Jeanne M. Fisher Married To Robert D. Michelman
description: Jeanne Michelle Fisher, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Gene Fisher of Hamilton, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Robert Douglas Michelman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Michelman of New Marlborough, Mass., and Pound Ridge, N.Y. The Rev. Morris E. Hollenbaugh performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: HOSTILITY TO U.S. GROWING IN KOREA
description: A new and virulent anti-Americanism, endorsed by a small but fervent minority of South Koreans, is finding expression in threats directed at Americans here.

title: Catherine Meacham Wed
description: St. James' Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Catherine Vose Meacham, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Noland Fontaine Meacham of Memphis, to Don Durgin, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Ryerson Durgin of New York.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Books for Breakfast - According to David McCullough, Harry Truman was one of our most bookish Presidents. This is from one of six essays by different hands in ''Extraordinary Lives: The Art and Craft of American Biography'' (American Heritage/Houghton Mifflin), edited by William Zinsser.

title: Article 306086 -- No Title
description: A woman left paralyzed when her former husband shot her three times in the head before killing himself has filed a $10 million claim against the town that gave him a pistol permit. Catherine M. Ford, 26 years old, said the Clinton Police Department was negligent in issuing and renewing the pistol permit of James H. Davidson.

title: ABUSED WOMEN GET LEVERAGE IN CONNECTICUT
description: IN May of 1983, Tracey Thurman told the Torrington Police Department that her estranged husband had beaten her and was threatening to kill her. Mrs. Thurman later testified that she was told to come back in three weeks, when the officer handling domestic cases would return from vacation.

title: HIGH STAKES AND HIGH PRESSURES
description: To the Editor:

title: CREATIVE MINDS AND THEIR PRODUCTS
description: MORE than 140 inventions, ideas and gadgets, all contributions by Connecticut residents, are on display at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

title: SNOB'S PROGRESS
description: CECIL BEATON A Biography. By Hugo Vickers. Illustrated. 656 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $25. CECIL BEATON, who died six years ago at the age of 76, was an English photographer, set designer, illustrator, portraitist and writer. Critics used to argue over whether he was a true artist in any of these pursuits or merely slick. But on one point everybody, tout le monde, agreed. Cecil Beaton was a great snob. He was not just a big snob but a great snob, an ingenious snob and a daredevil on top of that, a perfect snob and a snob clear through. So much so, that this book by Hugo Vickers, the biographer Beaton chose shortly before he died, turns out to be something Beaton may not have envisioned: an enormous, sloughing, tireless, unsparing, inch-by-inch trench-warfare chronicle of an English snob's progress through the 20th century.

title: IT TOOK TWO TO SAVE A TREE AND DESIGN A TERRACE
description: Conservation can mean more than writing your Senator to back the Clean Water Act. We found a project right in our own backyard.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bernardsville $289,000 21 Sycamore Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, new contemporary 3-car garage, *2*great room with cathedral ceiling, patio taxes to be assessed. Millburn $235,000 213 Sagamore Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1882 Victorian slate roof, *2*4 fireplaces, carriage house taxes $2,888. Newton $58,000 14 Cedar Drive *2*1-bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old ranch on Lake Paulinskill, *2*living-room fieldstone fireplace taxes $1,148. South Orange $197,000 203 Underhill Road *2*2-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch tiled kitchen, marble *2*fireplace in living room taxes $3,963. Union Township $435,000 Race Street *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1750 Colonial barn, pool, *2*6 fireplaces, 20 acres taxes $1,952. Westfield $255,000 931 Rahway Avenue *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 85-year-old colonial breakfast *2*room, study, carport taxes $3,028. OTHER AREAS Smithtown, L.I. $275,000 Ardra Court *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath new ranch center hall, large eat-in *2*kitchen, den, deck, 2-car garage taxes $4,400. Peekskill, N.Y. $146,500 263 Buttonwood Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old raised ranch *2*eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage taxes $2,383. Simsbury, Conn. $334,000 4 Hop Hollow *2*6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 14-year-old colonial on *2*private road with pond, 3 acres; taxes $5,944.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME EARLY SUMMER PROBLEMS
description: JUNE is a month of transition.

title: Self-Storage
description: The last red-and-black truck pulled away from the Ebinger Baking Company's plant in Flatbush on Aug. 27, 1972, leaving thousands of red-eyed customers bereft of blackout cakes and pecan coffee rings.

title: TITLES TELL THE STORY OF A DULL CROP OF MOVIES
description: We're at that time of year when most of the movies available have titles so all-purpose that they're interchangeable.

title: SONG CYCLES SPANNING CENTURIES EXERT THEIR CHARM
description: Few composers issue songs one at a time. They either write several in sequence, based on a theme or drawing on the texts of one author, or they assemble individual works they have written over a period of time into a single opus. The resultant song cycles -a variety of which will be considered here - have more intrinsic interest than single items.

title: Silvine Oesman a Bride
description: Silvine Oesman, an assistant fabric manager at Calvin Klein Ltd. in New York, and David William Harrison, a fund raising associate in the development office of Columbia College, were married yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, a Baptist minister at the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the nondenominational service. Mrs. Harrison, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ramana Oesman of Jakarta, Indonesia, attended Columbia University. Mr. Harrison, a graduate of the Belmont Hill School and Columbia University, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin J. Harrison of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: SPORTS EVENT FIGHTS DRUGS
description: A FEW years ago, ''a lot of organizations were sitting around wringing their hands about budget cuts and emphasizing the harm they could do'' in the fight against drug use by young people on Long Island, said Bunny O'Brien. ''We decided to go out and do something about this situation and to highlight the positive alternatives to drugs.''

title: JERSEY COUNTY DOUBLES CHILD-SUPPORT REVENUE
description: An Essex County effort to step up the collection of child-support payments from fathers has more than doubled the amount of money collected from men who had refused to accept financial responsibility for their children.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: STATE TO HALT MEDICAID FOR SOME PREGNANT YOUTHS
description: The Cuomo administration is planning to halt Medicaid assistance for abortions and prenatal care for young women with family incomes above the poverty line. The decision will drop as many as 4,000 pregnant women a year from the Medicaid rolls.

title: 4 BIRDIES FOR SUTTON ON THE BACK NINE
description: While most of the leaders were faltering on the back nine of Shinnecock Hills today, Hal Sutton chewed it up with four birdies to put himself into a tie with Lee Trevino for second place. His 66, four under par, gave him a total of 211, one stroke behind Greg Norman.

title: Alison Finn Weds Dr. B. G. Jacoby
description: Alison Mary Finn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Michael Finn of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Bradley Glenn Jacoby, the son of Barbara Jacoby of Montgomery, Ala., and the late Glenn Jacoby. The Rev. Joseph Zammit performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bronxville.

title: INSURANCE WOES MAY DIM FOURTH
description: CONNECTICUT'S skies might not be as bright and noisy this Fourth of July as in previous years, because organizers of fireworks displays are having difficulty obtaining liability insurance.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TO THE ENDS OF THE EARTH. By Michael Talbot. (Knopf, $18.95.) Basing his novel on the settlement of Australia by British convicts in the late 18th century, Michael Talbot assembles a diverse crew of voyagers, mostly credible if not especially engaging. For Commodore Arthur Phillip, who leads a convoy of semiseaworthy vessels into partly uncharted seas, the venture is a desperate race against the French for territorial expansion. For the prisoners below decks, it is an unexpected alternative to the gallows. The narrative shifts from group to group, bringing into focus varying backgrounds and perspectives through some singular character types: Phillip, a bootstrap tough, a born risk taker; Kitty Brandon, whose credentials include some onstage triumphs and an offstage murder; Joe Cribb, a former soldier turned loose to live by his wits amid the London low life; Levi, a onetime peddler and medical quack in whom Messianic fervor is at war with practical experience. Although he knows that nothing can be had for nothing, he dreams of Australia's Botany Bay as an earthly paradise for the lost tribes of Israel. The Anglican cleric Richard Johnson disdains a land of milk and honey; what he wants is a harvest of Christian souls. By the end of the book part of the fleet has reached Botany Bay, but since this is the first in Mr. Talbot's projected series of novels about the founding of Australia, journey's end is only a beginning. The author (under a pseudonym) of spy novels and thrillers, he knows how to keep readers engrossed in the drama and brutality of naval exploration.

title: WHY A CEILING ON LIABILITY MAKES SENSE
description: AFTER the Chernobyl accident, Americans are understandably concerned about how they or their fellow citizens would be cared for if one of our nuclear power plants were to experience a comparable accident. Some of these concerns have surfaced recently in the Congressional debate over the Price-Anderson Act, which must be reauthorized by August 1987.

title: LILCO PLAN AT COLISEUM UNDER FIRE
description: THE role of the Nassau Coliseum as an emergency evacuation center may be assuming critical importance in the dispute over the future of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.

title: Sally Anne Morgan Weds John W. Hornor
description: The Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sally Anne Morgan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Clarke Morgan of Pitman, N.J., to John West Hornor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. DeWitt Hornor of New York, and Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Francis X. Cheney, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. Leslie Merlin, a Presbyterian minister.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SOCIAL SECURITY: Visions and Revisions, By W. Andrew Achenbaum. (Cambridge University, $19.95.) Many politicians and some actuaries say the Federal Government solved the financial problems of the social security system, at least for the rest of this century, when it passed a bill to prevent the bankruptcy of the giant pension program in 1983.

title: POP: PETER GORDON, ACROSS THE SPECTRUM
description: LISTENING to the music of Peter Gordon, the ''downtown'' composer, saxophonist and clarinetist, one has the sense of a musician tromping merrily through a field of daisies. This feeling of playfulness may be the one consistent element in music that touches on a multitude of pop styles, from minimalism to big-band jazz, with an irreverent insouciance.

title: 'FORGOTTEN' SCULPTOR HAS DAY IN GALLERY
description: JOHN FRAZEE, an early American sculptor whose pieces have been accessible, yet unknown, for many years, is coming into his own with an exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery here.

title: Hirshhorn Curator Moving
description: Dr. Charles Warren Millard 3d, chief curator at the Smithsonian Institution's Hirshhorn Museum, will leave that post to become director of the Ackland Art Museum at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Dr. Millard joined the Hirshhorn, the Smithsonian's modern-art museum, in 1974.

title: Greek Cypriot Rejects Plan to Unify Island
description: President Spyros Kyprianou, the Greek-Cypriot leader, has rejected the latest United Nations draft agreement for the reunification of Cyprus, according to a report issued this week by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: AIDS EPIDEMIC UNCHECKED
description: Although there have already been more than 20,000 reported cases of AIDS, Federal health officials last week called them the tip of an epidemiological pyramid. Reporting on the results of a conference of experts on acquired immune deficiency syndrome, the United States Public Health Service predicted that cases and deaths from the disease would increase more than tenfold in the next five years as the virus spreads widely outside New York and San Francisco and infects a larger segment of the heterosexual population.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: After nearly four years without service, air travelers in the Princeton area will soon be able to fly, rather than drive, to Newark International Airport.

title: MEXICAN JITTERS DISCOUNTED
description: Jitters went through the big money center bank stocks last week when Mexico seemed to be about to default on interest payments on its $95 billion in bank debt. As stock prices fell in the early part of the week, the big bank issues seemed to lose more than the general market.

title: Aide to Mayor of Washington Dies in Fire Set by Arsonist
description: A political aide to Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. was found dead in her home this morning in what the police consider a homicide.

title: HE DID IT ALL FOR JANE ELIZABETH FIRESHEETS
description: OFF FOR THE SWEET HEREAFTER By T. R. Pearson. 283 pp. New York: Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $17.95. IT'S been just a year since the publication of T.R. Pearson's first novel, ''A Short History of a Small Place,'' in which he did his best to explain why an elderly woman in Neely, N.C., leaped backward off the town water tower. Our ribs have barely stopped aching when he's at it again, this time trying to sum up the ramshackle career of Neely's very own Bonnie and Clyde.

title: '81 REAPPORTIONMENT: ADOPTED PLAN HAILED
description: The belief that the 11th or ''public'' member of a reapportionment commission plays only a tie-breaking role, choosing between a Democratic plan and a Republican plan, is so appealingly simple it is small wonder that it is so widely held.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TIGHTENS THE VISE ON BLACK DISSENT
description: WITH its newest and most Draconian emergency decree, South Africa seemed to turn a corner last week, abandoning recent efforts to placate hostile outsiders and the restive black majority at home. Instead, as the state-controlled radio put it, the nation's white leaders were braced for ''a showdown with the forces of anarchy and revolution'' - presumably believing that the excision from society of black radical leaders and other activists would stem the angers they sought to articulate.

title: But Can He Cook?
description: Superman is not only faster than a speeding bullet, his creators say, he is also more sensitive. So the folks at DC Comics, publishers of Superman's adventures since 1938, announced last week that the Man of Steel was being sent back to the drawing boards for a personality overhaul.

title: DANCE: RENVALL IN 'MURDER'
description: IT is surely not easy to portray the leading roles in a ballet created for Mikhail Baryshnikov, especially when the ballet has been choreographed to emphasize Mr. Baryshnikov's puckish sense of humor as well as his amazing stage presence. David Gordon's ''Murder'' poses a special challenge, for most of its leading roles were designed to be portrayed by a single dancer - Mr. Baryshnikov.

title: DEAF IN MAINSTREAM
description: Deaf and hearing-impaired students will be an integral part of one nearby college community next fall, a goal difficult if not impossible to attain in the past.

title: SON OF A SAD SACK
description: A FATHER'S WORDS By Richard Stern. 189 pp. New York: Arbor House. $14.95. IN his new novel, ''A Father's Words,'' Richard

title: ACCORDS PAVE WAY FOR SAUDI CONTROL OF AWACS PLANES
description: The United States and Saudi Arabia have quietly concluded agreements to clear the way for the Saudis to take possession later this month of the first of five Awacs radar planes, Administration officials said today.

title: SOME SOUTH AFRICANS SHYING FROM MILITARY
description: South Africa's deep-rooted protest, now in its 21st month, has presented a generation of young whites with a quandary: to serve, or not to serve, in the nation's armed forces in a conflict that represents a first, sustained exposure to life in the nation's black townships.

title: Lauren Stella Baker Weds Robert Richman, a Writer
description: Lauren Stella Baker, the daughter of Robert C. Baker and Betty Lou Baker, both of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Steven Richman, a son of Teresa M. Richman of Wayne, N.J., and the late Murray C. Richman. Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated at Lyndhurst, a landmark structure in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: O'CONNOR HOPEFUL ON LEBANON HOSTAGES
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, who is on a three-day visit to Lebanon, said today that he was hopeful there would soon be a breakthrough in the case of the American hostages believed held by Islamic extremists.

title: VIETNAM, EAST AND WEST
description: SHALLOW GRAVES Two Women and Vietnam. By Wendy Wilder Larsen and Tran Thi Nga. 291 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: YOUNG ARTIST'S WORKS - An exhibition of 15 paintings by Bob Thompson, a figurative painter whose career was cut short by his premature death in 1966 when he was 29 years old, may be seen at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford until Sept. 21.

title: Rotting in Warehouses: People
description: Peggy Dowling appeared before the Senate Committee on Aging recently to talk about the last days in the life of her ''Gram,'' a Medicaid patient who suffered from a stroke - as well as from lax nursing-home supervision.

title: Yanks Demote Meacham
description: The Yankees, disenchanted with Bobby Meacham, decided today to send their error-plagued shortstop to Columbus and replace him with Ivan DeJesus, a 10-year major leaguer.

title: MAMARONECK PRESSES EFFORTS ON HARBOR
description: THE village of Mamaroneck - which has a jagged nine-mile coastline of inlets, coves and bays and is home to about 1,700 boats - won an award for its efforts to protect its shoreline and its boating, was forced to defend those efforts in court and unveiled a new harbor program, all in the last two weeks.

title: Another Tunis Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: NOW MARCHES IN SUPPORT OF THE RIGHT TO ABORTION
description: Members of the National Organization for Women, holding an annual convention here this weekend, marched through the streets today in support of legal abortion.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LONELY SEA. By Alistair MacLean. (Doubleday, $15.95.) In 1954 Alistair MacLean began his writing career with ''The Dileas,'' the story of two brothers who bravely sacrifice their lives during a raging storm.

title: Stockman and the Gold Standard
description: To the Editor:

title:
MUSIC;
FESTIVAL AT LAWRENCEVILLE TO PRESENT 2 'FAIRY-TALE' OPERAS
description: THE June Opera Festival of New Jersey will begin its third season Friday night with a new production of Mozart's ''Magic Flute.''

title: Social Events; On Land and Sea
description: Floating Dinner-Dance - June 18 - Formed a year ago, the National Committee on Youth Suicide Prevention distributes information, answers questions and aids research into what has been called a national epidemic among the young. Alfred B. DelBello, a former lieutenant governor of New York, founded the group, which has 49 state chapters. The group's first fund-raising event will be a black-tie dinner-dance aboard the yacht Entrepreneur as she sails around New York Harbor. Boarding at 6:30 P.M. at the Skyport Marina on the East River at 23d Street. Tickets, $250, from 212-957-9292. Party at the Saint June 18 - The National Children's Choir from Washington and the Dance Theater of Harlem will entertain at a benefit for the American Foundation for AIDS Research to be held at the Saint, 105 Second Avenue, at Sixth Street. The black-tie evening starts with cocktails at 7, followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment. Tickets, $300, from 212-563-3285 or 800-525-4846. For Anglophiles June 21 - The Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y., is holding a ''Hail Britannia'' benefit starting with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. Dinner, English theater music and dancing follows. Tickets for black-tie evening, $175, from 914-232-3681. Bring Bathing Suit June 21 - A group of soap-opera stars will join a cruise aboard the S.S. Amerikanis to benefit the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation. The cruise gets under way at 9:30 A.M. on the Hudson River at 55th Street and returns at 4 P.M. Snacks and a five-course lunch will be served, and there will be dancing, casino games and swimming in two pools.

title: Jane L. Mendillo Married at Yale
description: Jane Lisa Mendillo, a consultant at Bain & Company, and Ralph Earle 3d, managing director of Strategy Associates, both Boston management consulting concerns, were married yesterday in Dwight Chapel at Yale University. An ecumenical ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carl Nissen, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Steven Boguslawski, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Danielle P. Shaw Weds James Edward Virtue
description: Danielle Preble Shaw, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gale H. Shaw Jr. of Stowe, Vt., was married yesterday to James Edward Virtue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Virtue Sr. of Armonk, N.Y. The Rev. Philip H. Chase, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Stowe Community Church.

title: STRUGGLING TO CLIP THE WINGS OF CAPITAL
description: CAPITAL flight, the exporting of assets from countries in trouble, used to be talked about by only a few economists and bankers. Recently, however, it has become a major issue in international economic discussions, spilling over into headlines.

title: Services for Benny Goodman
description: The funeral for the bandleader Benny Goodman, who died Friday at the age of 77, will be private, according to a spokesman for the Bouton and Reynolds Funeral Home in Stamford, Conn. The family is making plans for a public memorial service, which is to be announced soon.

title:
THE TALK OF NORTHPORT;
A VILLAGE CHANGES AND STAYS THE SAME
description: UNLIKE the fashionable East End or the renovated, tourist-oriented village of Port Jefferson, Northport blossoms almost bashfully come summertime.

title: On Language; SUBJOIN THE FUN
description: ''IT SEEMED AS IF TOILET was falling into disuse,'' I wrote in a recent piece on euphemisms, on my way to the restroom, comfort station, john or loo.

title: David S. Herrick Wed To Cornelia Ann Lacy
description: Cornelia Ann Lacy and David Scott Herrick, both teachers, were married yesterday at the Westhampton Yacht Club in Remsenburg, L.I. The Rev. Richard Chapin, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: LOS ANGELES ARCHBISHOP LEADS DRIVE TO AID HISPANIC CATHOLICS
description: At a time when the National Conference of Catholic Bishops is moving to ask for changes in the nation's economy to aid the poor, the Archbishop of the country's largest archdiocese has issued a sweeping call to social activism in behalf of the Hispanic majority of his pastorate.

title: New Ideas for Elderly Tested in Jersey Shore County
description: THERE is no place in the New York metropolitan region that is a better proving ground for retirement communities than Ocean County, N.J., where, according to the county's Office on Aging, there are 33 with a total population of 48,000 to 52,000.

title: Siena
description: To the Editor: I read with great interest and no small bit of nostalgia the article on Siena and the Palio (Travel, May 11).

title: FEMALE CANDIDATES ARE NO LONGER SO CASH POOR
description: HARRIETT Woods recalls that in 1982, when she decided to run for the Senate from Missouri, she asked a seasoned politician about the essentials of mounting a campaign. He said the chief requirement was simple: ''You need to be able to look somebody in the eye and ask for a thousand bucks.''

title: THE CITY WILL WASH ITS DIRTY LINEN IN HARTFORD
description: AFTER five months of revelations, charges and denials, the Federal prosecutors and the defendants in New York City's municipal corruption scandal are suddenly turning shy. Having found reporters not only a rapt but also sometimes a useful audience as the investigations unfolded, both sides have now decided - with jury selection scheduled to begin sometime next month - to try to minimize the effects of past and future pretrial publicity in the interests of a fair trial.

title: WITH THE MUHJAHEDEEN
description: KARA KUSH By Idries Shah. 575 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $17.95. IT is sometimes hard for a reader to separate his literary judgment of a book from his feelings about the cause it espouses. Thus it is painful to report that this is a bad novel, although it is filled with flamboyant tales about the heroic Afghan people with whom it deals.

title: Liberty Gala Is No Time or Place for Naysaying; Inspired by Lincoln
description: To the Editor:

title: GENEVA TAKING LOOK BACK TO CALVINIST ROOTS
description: Geneva is holding a monthlong religious, cultural and historial commemoration of the 450th anniversary of its Protestant Reformation, with ecumenical services, street fairs and a re-examination of its historical past and contradictory present.

title: The F.B.I. Decides To Test Its Own
description: J. Edgar Hoover, the Federal Bureau of Investigation's first director, did not want the agency involved in drug investigations because, it was said, he was afraid his agents might become hooked on narcotics or on drug dealers' payoffs.

title: Parent's Kidney for Adoptee
description: Ruth Foisy, who gave up her daughter for adoption 20 years ago, donated a kidney to the young woman for a life-saving transplant operation Thursday, a hospital spokesman said. The mother met her daughter, Alicia Sferrino, a week ago for the first time since the adoption. Both were doing well after the operation, the spokesman said.

title: Kathryn Nixon Weds Ross Andrew Nabatoff
description: Kathryn Joan Nixon, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Charles Nixon of Ann Arbor, Mich., was married yesterday to Ross Andrew Nabatoff, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert A. Nabatoff of New York. Judge Joseph W. Hatchett of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Tallahassee, Fla., performed the ceremony at the Maclay Gardens in Tallahassee.

title: REMEMBERING THE BOQUETS FROM FATHER
description: I WAS 9 when my father sent me flowers for the first time. I had been taking tap dancing lessons for about six months when the school gave its yearly recital. As a novice, I was put into a chorus line that would appear on stage doing a beginner's specialty. I was excited by my first appearance dancing before an audience, but aware of my lowly status in the general cast.

title: A Shift at Spoleto
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Role for African National Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALY'S 'ALTA CUCINA'
description: WHEN TONY MAY BEGAN looking for a chef who could introduce America to alta cucina - Italian haute cuisine - at his new restaurant, Palio, in New York, Andrea Hellrigl seemed the obvious choice.

title: Data Bank: June 15, 1986
Iranian Exiles Leave France
description: As the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini well knows, those on the outs in Iran have often found a welcome in France. But last week there were reports that more than 1,000 members of the largest group opposing the Ayatollah, the left-wing People's Mujahedeen, had left their headquarters in suburban Paris for an area on the Iran-Iraq border, presumably to join anti-Government guerrillas the group says it maintains there.

title: A POLICE ACADEMY FOR THE PUBLIC
description: HUDDLED in the Vernon Police Department's community room, 30 men and women learned about search and seizure, the penal code, arrest laws, basic patrol operations and criminal investigations. But they will not carry a gun or handcuffs or be able to make an arrest.

title: YONKERS TO APPEAL ORDER IN BIAS SUIT
description: A VOTE by the Yonkers City Council last week to appeal a Federal Court order requiring the city to finance a $37 million desegregation plan and select sites for development of low- and moderate-income housing has opened another chapter in the turbulent history of the five-year-old lawsuit.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A CERTAIN MR. TAKAHASHI. By Ann Ireland. (Vanguard Press, $13.95.) Whatever the conductor Seiji Ozawa has, it's more exotic and potent than a combination of the perfumes Opium and Obsession.

title: The Calling
description: Unlike Jeffrey Vamos, I took a different road that led from Union Theological Seminary to Duke University (''The Calling,'' by David Black, May 11). After receiving my Master of Divinity degree from Princeton Theological Seminary, I arrived at the Union campus in September 1981 for graduate studies in theology, hoping to find the kind of rigorous intellectual and prophetic theology - in the tradition of Reinhold Niebuhr, Paul Tillich, John Macquarrie, et al.

title: Sarah L. Porter Weds Thomas W. Watts 4th
description: Sarah Lynn Porter, an analyst with Goldman Sachs & Company, and Thomas Wynne Watts 4th, a vice president in the New York office of CSP International, a telecommunications and business strategy consulting firm, were married yesterday in Paducah, Ky.

title: LIFE AT THE TOP CAPTURES MOTHER GOOSE
description: Jose Santos, Belmont Park's leading rider, had ridden 25 straight losers after yesterday's first race. By the end of the afternoon, though, he had three winners, his first Grade I stakes victory ever, and the beginning of an alliance with the nation's most powerful stable.

title: POLL FINDS TEACHERS OPPOSE 'REFORMS'
description: PUBLIC-school teachers are sharply critical of many ''reforms'' being advocated by state leaders, according to a new survey of 1,000 classroom teachers, who said they distrusted the state's Department of Education and, frequently, their own local school boards.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: STRANGERS. By Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $17.95.) Unknown to one another, a half-dozen people start to experience disquieting dreams, inexplicable phobias and paranormal powers.

title: SPIRITUALLY REORGANIZING HARRY
description: THE GARISH DAY By Rachel Billington. 335 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: Panama's Leader Is Under a Cloud
description: For geopolitical reasons of a high order, the United States and Panama ''need each other,'' as Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, head of Panama's National Defense Force, recently reaffirmed. But whether Washington needs a friend like General Noriega seemed less certain last week. It was reported that American intelligence agencies have amassed evidence that portrays the de facto leader of Panama as a longtime double agent who supplies intelligence information to both Washington and Cuba.

title: GOOD WORKS FOR GORBACHEV, BUT CONFUSING ONES ON TREATY
description: PRESIDENT Reagan spoke warmly of Mikhail S. Gorbachev last week as ''the first Russian leader, to my knowledge, that has ever voiced the idea of reducing, and even eliminating, nuclear weapons.'' Mr. Reagan said he ''might have goofed'' earlier in the week when he lumped Mr. Gorbachev with Fidel Castro, Muammar el-Qaddafi and Yasir Arafat. His facts were off - virtually every Soviet leader has endorsed nuclear disarmament, in principle at least - but Mr. Reagan seemed hopeful of making a deal with Mr. Gorbachev if they can sit down in a room together. At a news conference, he also repeated his hope that the Soviet leader would agree on a date for a summit meeting in this country this year.

title: AGENT ORANGE'S VICTIMS FIND SYMPATHY AT THE STATEHOUSES
description: AS questions about the long-term effects of exposure to Agent Orange among veterans of the Vietnam War have continued to be raised, a number of states have begun attempting to help provide some answers.

title: THE OLD SPEED GRAPHIC IS ALIVE AND CLICKING
description: FOR over half a century, from about 1900 to the mid-1950's, one camera ruled newspaper photography in the United States - the boxy, black Speed Graphic that produced 4-by-5-inch negatives and folded into what looked like a mini-attache case, leather handle and all.

title: Liberty Gala Is No Time or Place for Naysaying
description: To the Editor:

title: REFLECTIONS OF FIVE RIVERS
description: Dear water, clear water, playful in all your streams, As you dash or loiter through life who does not love To sit beside you, to hear you and see you? W. H. Auden was surely right. Everyone delights in a river and most of us have our special, personal loves - rivers that have blessed us, solaced us and come to fill, in memory, places almost like those of parents or lovers.

title: Caren Acker Wed To D. C. McGill
description: Caren Marie Emily Acker, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen R. Acker of New Cumberland, Pa., was married yesterday to Douglas Cornish McGill, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas G.B. McGill of Rochester, Minn., at the Peace Church, a historic landmark building in Hampden Township, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Andrew Waters Jr., a Church of Christ minister.

title: STAGE: 'CLINTON COMETS'
description: THE first 10 minutes of ''The Clinton Comets'' are quite funny and the last 10 contain a couple of spectacular shootings, but the 90 minutes between those segments are anything but dramatic. The play, by Terry L. Hamilton and Dan Tedlie - Mr. Tedlie also directs the performance, at Theater 22 - begins comically and struggles on in that vein almost to the end, when two murders on stage do as much violence to the genre as to the victims. The killings do have their uses, however; they bring this thing to an end.

title: OUTDOOR CONCERTS: SO MANY CHOICES
description: THE outdoor music season is in high gear. On Wednesday the 37th annual Plumb Memorial Carillon Concerts get under way at Trinity College in Hartford: Carillonneurs from three countries and four states will be heard in the course of the 12-week cycle, with George Matthew Jr. leading the way at the first concert.

title: High Stakes and High Pressures
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY WELL-PAID SUMMER JOBS AWAIT STUDENTS IN COUNTY
description: LIFEGUARDS can name their hours, and word-processing operators can name their salaries, or almost. Westchester has become a mecca for students looking for well-paid summer jobs, and employers say they would be delighted to have the students stay beyond September.

title: Dr. Weissman to Wed Richard I. Ellenbogen
description: Dr. Debra S. Weissman, a post doctoral research fellow at Mount Sinai Medical Center, and Richard I. Ellenbogen, a lawyer, have announced their plans to marry in August. Dr. Weissman, a summa cum laude graduate of Rutgers University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, also graduated from Mount Sinai School of Medicine and will begin a residency in dermatology at Mount Sinai in September. She is the daughter of Joseph Weissman of Glen Rock, N.J., and the late Celeste Weissman.

title: MARTHA GRAHAM - WHERE IT ALL BEGAN
description: Several things need to be said flat out about the 60th-anniversary season of the Martha Graham Dance Company. The celebration has been used as a springboard to revive very early solos or pieces associated with Miss Graham's dance educationat the Denishawn School and the start of her independent career. Seemingly against all odds, the revivals have succeeded on their own highly theatrical grounds.

title:
POSTINGS;
Walking Tours
description: New Yorkers have earned reputations as sophisticated shoppers, restaurant-goers and entertainment-seekers. But Robin Lynn, director of tours for the Municipal Arts Society, adds another quality: New Yorkers, she believes, are sophisticated walkers.

title: DEBT-MIRED MEXICO SEEKS A WAY OUT
description: A rescue plan for Mexico was hurriedly formulated in light of that nation's $97 billion in foreign debt, the dramatic drop of the peso and the drop in the price of oil, its major hard currency generator. Discussions on ways to solve the debt problem had been under way for months, but the crisis was precipitated but the plunge of the peso, which fell 30 percent in six days. The rescue package would require Mexico to sign a letter of intent with the I.M.F., promising to take steps to expand its economy. In return, Mexico would get $6 billion in new, one-year loans, including some from the I.M.F. and the World Bank.

title: THE STUNNING UPSET THAT FUSEDLOUIS, SCHMELING
description: THE whimsical, puckish fates that decide such things have decreed that Max Schmeling must walk in boxing's passing parade arm-in-arm with Joe Louis. This fusing of the German and the American, of two world heavyweight champions, comes to mind just from looking at the calendar, because it was 50 years ago, on June 19, 1936, that Schmeling knocked out Louis in an upset.

title: HAWK VS. PENTAGON
description: ON THE MEANING OF VICTORY Essays on Strategy. By Edward N. Luttwak. 315 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: REDISCOVERING THE DELIGHT OF SHAW
description: THE Long Island Stage is making a delightful habit of presenting plays by George Bernard Shaw. The company's current Shaw production, ''You Never Can Tell,'' is so rarely done that it is almost like discovering a new play.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
Office Buildings Join the Hoboken Revival
description: OVER the last decade, rows of condominiums and single-family houses and several apartment towers have been developed along the narrow streets of Hoboken, an old industrial city that hugs the Hudson River shoreline.

title: Elizabeth A. Gilmor, Funds Analyst, Is Wed to Kelly Peter Conlin on L.I.
description: The wedding ceremony of Elizabeth Anne Gilmor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gilmor Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., to Kelly Peter Conlin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Joseph Conlin of Minneapolis, took place yesterday. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: Alison D. Merow, A Teacher, Weds
description: Alison Dana Merow, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Merow of New York and Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Andrew Rasmussen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Rasmussen of Maywood, N.J. The Rev. John G. B. Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Linda Bryan Is Married to Alan Almond in London
description: The Danish Church in Regent's Park in London was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Dr. Linda Bryan, the daughter of Sir Arthur Bryan and Lady Bryan of Barlaston, Staffordshire, England and Dr. Alan Almond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Almond of Tollerton, Yorkshire, England. The Church of England ceremony was performed by the Rev. Harri Davies.

title: Anne Henderson Wed To D. G. Dannenbaum
description: Anne Ellen Henderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Gene Henderson of Spartanburg, S.C., was married yesterday to Daniel George Dannenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Daniel Dannenbaum of Philadelphia. The Rev. Dr. James E. Fogartie performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Spartanburg.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: A SEASON OF PEACE. By G. E. Armitage. (St. Martin's, $12.95.) A runner-up for Britain's Trask Award for the best first novel of 1985, ''A Season of Peace'' is an extended meditation on grief and sorrow. As the narrator deals with the army bureaucracy in order to claim the body of his soldier son, killed by a terrorist bomb in Ireland, he recalls two periods of his own life as an army engineer: when he directed the construction of an antiaircraft battery on the coast of the North Sea; and when, at the end of World War II, he directed the installation's demolition. The narrator, never more than a concerned observer, tells us the story of the people at Cable Point, especially the tragedy of a 15-year-old named Mary. The novel discovers that war disrupts lives, perverts values, and has consequences far from the field of battle long after the battle is done. G. E. Armitage writes cleanly and even elegantly, but trying to make fresh a theme as old as the ''Iliad,'' he strains for stylistic effects that become irritants. In lieu of a plot, we are presented with recurring images. Dead gulls, sailors, sharks or cats are forever being washed ashore at Cable Point, are always discovered by children, and are always made playthings. The characters speak elliptically. Little is said, a great deal understood, and a page or two later all is explained. The impatient reader will gloss over the dialogue and turn directly to the explanations.

title: HANDS-ON EXHIBIT OF BOOK ART OPENS AT NEWARK GALLERY
description: NOT SO long ago, exhibitions of book art - visual-art objects fabricated in the form of books - were as rare as picnics beneath the Pulaski Skyway.

title: BRITISH MANSION YIELDS A TREASURE TROVE OF JAPANESE PORCELAIN
description: While sipping tea at Burghley, the most magnificent of England's Elizabethan houses, Gordon Lang, a porcelain specialist at Sotheby's, asked about a large Korean vase that graced the mantel. His hosts, the Marquess and Marchioness of Exeter, said they hadn't a clue about its origins, but suggested that the white, bottle-shaped porcelain vessel might be listed in a 1688 inventory of Burghley. The palace, the Marquess's ancestral home in Lincolnshire, had been built a century earlier by William Cecil when he was Lord High Treasurer to Elizabeth I. Mr. Lang's question, posed in 1981, sparked a search through Burghley's 17th-century inventories and its 240 rooms, an investigation that uncovered descriptions of that vase - it is 15th century - and a thousand other works. Most of the finest ceramics identified were selected for ''The Burghley Porcelains,'' a traveling exhibition on view at Japan House Gallery through July 27.

title: Why Mr. Reagan Is Right About SALT
description: Bertrand Russell once remarked that we often defend most passionately those opinions for which we have the least factual basis. It is difficult to find any other way to explain the torrent of emotion that has greeted the President's decision that we are no longer bound by the second strategic arms limitation accord.

title: Cable TV
description: Some rewarding movie music can be heard on cable this week. Bravo has three entries. Monday's bargain at midnight is ''Carmen'' (1984), Francesco Rosi's realistic, gripping drama with Julia Migenes-Johnson and Placido Domingo, which Vincent Canby of The Times called ''probably the definitive screen version'' of Bizet's opera.'' Two brilliant adaptations of Shakespeare by Laurence Olivier have striking background scores by William Walton. ''Richard III'' (1956), with Mr. Olivier, Ralph Richardson, John Gielgud and Claire Bloom and the composer's brooding evocation of royal machinations, is showing on Friday at 8 P.M. and 2 A.M. In between, at 11 P.M., there is ''Hamlet'' (1948) with Mr. Olivier again, Eileen Herlie, Basil Sydney, Norman Wooland and Jean Simmons. The finale is thrilling, as a funeral cortege climbs the castle steps to the parapet, to the sound of Mr. Walton's swelling dirge and a booming cannon.

title: GOLF IS A FUNNY GAME; TENNIS NOT SO
description: GOLFERS and tennis players do not feud like the Hatfields and McCoys, but each group makes little effort to conceal a measure of disdain for the sport of the other. The golf enthusiast dismisses tennis in the words of the immortal P. G. Wodehouse as ''outdoor Ping-Pong,'' and the tennis player retorts, ''I'll take up golf when I'm too old to play tennis.''

title: FRESH FROM THE FARM IN MAINE
description: Cinderella had her pumpkin-coach, Beauty her prince-once-beast, but to a lot of Maine cooks and consumers, no transformation is as magical as the one that changes a chunk of plain street into a farmers' market. One minute nothing but asphalt and cars, the next a cornucopia of homegrown produce, direct from the folks who produced it.

title: Blair Bellis Marries Hugh Elliott Mohr
description: Blair Blauvelt Bellis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Latimer Bellis of Bedminster, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Hugh Elliott Mohr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Elliott Mohr of Madison, Conn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Naturally I told the President that I hope soon there will be some breakthrough in the question of American hostages.'' - John Cardinal O'Connor, after talks with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon. [ 3:4. ]

title: Region's Bluefish May Be Declining
description: ALTHOUGH great numbers of bluefish are reported all along the coast from Cape May, N.J., to Cape Cod, there are indications that this species, the bulwark of the Northeast's marine recreational fishery, may be declining.

title: FISCAL STIMULUS FOR THE TEACHER SUPPLY
description: ENROLLMENT in the education department at Queens College usually drops between the fall and spring terms. This year it rose, by 100 students, and the head of the school traces the shift to the fact that the pay for new teachers in the city was $4,000 higher last fall than it was in 1984. ''It may not all be the money,'' said Dr. Susanna Pflaum, the dean, ''but there's no question the higher pay is bringing in more teachers.''

title: G.O.P. CONGRESSWOMAN PUSHES AID FOR DAY CARE
description: When Representative Nancy L. Johnson's three daughters were young, she stayed home to take care of them. Occasionally, to supplement the family income, she graded school papers when the girls were taking naps.

title: Artificial Heart Recipient Is Reported Stable
description: A 32-year-old man who was given a Jarvik-7 artificial heart after his doctors decided they could not wait any longer for a human heart was listed in critical but stable condition today.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 15, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. 2 8 (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 2 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 1 8 (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 3 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 3 15 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 4 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. 1 (Bantam, $17.95.) An American test pilot stranded in Siberia. 5 THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest Hemingway. 6 3 (Scribners, $18.95.) A writer and his wife have affairs with the same woman on their European honeymoon; Hemingway's last unpublished novel. 6 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. 8 2 (Putnam, $18.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. 7* LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 5 42 (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 8 TAMING A SEA-HORSE, by Robert B. Parker. 1 (Seymour Lawrence/Delacorte, $15.95.) The private eye Spenser tracks a young woman through the seamy side of the world of tycoons. 9 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 7 30 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 10 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. (Harper 4 5 & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion. 11 NOBODY LIVES FOREVER, by John Gardner. 9 3 (Putnam, $12.95.) James Bond on the trail of the kidnapper of his devoted housekeeper. 12 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. 10 20 (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in Afghanistan. 12 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, 11 13 $17.95.) Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 14* THE BOOK OF ABRAHAM, by Marek Halter. 13 5 (Holt, $19.95.) A Jewish family through 100 generations. 15 HIGH HEARTS, by Rita Mae Brown. 16 5 (Bantam, $17.95.) The experiences of a Virginia belle who joins the Confederate cavalry. Nonfiction 1 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ 1 6 Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. 2 14 (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 3 THE TRIUMPH OF POLITICS, by David A. 3 6 Stockman. (Harper & Row, $21.95.) Why President Reagan was unable to balance the budget. 4 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by James 5 5 Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 5 ENTER TALKING, by Joan Rivers with Richard 4 6 Meryman. (Delacorte, $17.95.) The talk-show hostess' long professional climb. 6 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, by 6 9 Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95) A rabbi discusses ''the search for a life that matters.'' 7 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/ 7 18 Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 8 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Simon & 8 8 Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them in order to grow. 9 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager 15 47 and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) The story of the first man to fly faster than sound. 10 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 12 85 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 11 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT, by 9 11 Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) The loss of the faculty of recognition and other strange neurological disabilities. 12 ALL GOD'S CHILDREN NEED TRAVELING SHOES, by 13 4 Maya Angelou. (Random House, $15.95.) A memoir that carries the writer's story from her native Arkansas to her ancestral Ghana. 13 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. 167 (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 14* BESS W. TRUMAN, by Margaret Truman. 11 7 (Macmillan, $19.95.) Her daughter shows that the former First Lady was intelligent and caring as well as private and austere. 15 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda Ellerbee. 1 (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by an NBC correspondent. Advice and Self-Help 1 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn 1 43 Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin Katahn. 2 4 (Norton, $15.95.)
