A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 3 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie 3 29 Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises designed to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 4 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. 4 56 (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a revision that was made in 1983. 5 THE BE (HAPPY) ATTITUDES, by Robert 6 32 Schuller. (Word, $12.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman.

title: 2 HOSPITALS FREEZE EMBRYOS
description: TWO hospitals in the state have begun implanting embryos that had been frozen into women, the latest technological advance in combating fertility problems.

title: THE DANCE: DUNN'S 'MOVING DOOR'
description: DOUGLAS DUNN'S ''Dances for Men, Women and Moving Door,'' which Douglas Dunn and Dancers presented Thursday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, contained lots of surprises.

title: The Loan Crush
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ARI: The Life and Times of Aristotle Socrates Onassis. By Peter Evans. (Summit, $19.95.) Shortly before his death in 1975, Aristotle Onassis boasted to the British journalist Peter Evans that his life would make ''one hell of a story.''

title: BURGERS WITH A RAUCOUS BEAT
description: IT is a miserable, drizzly London afternoon, but things are the way Isaac Tigrett likes them. Inside, the music is blaring, the tables are full and a waitress in a short white uniform and cap has brought him a beer. Outside, a long line of customers waits under a canopy to get in for lunch. Most of them wander over to the souvenir stand near the entrance and return with a sweatshirt or baseball cap.

title: MAKING ARMS MAKERS DO IT RIGHT
description: TWO years ago, Navy pilots testing the new F-18 Hornet discovered that the fighter plane could turn more sharply and climb more steeply than the designers had planned. But those tight turns and sharp climbs put too much stress on the aircraft, causing cracks in its twin tails.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME EARLY SUMMER PROBLEMS
description: JUNE is a month of transition.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL SKITS ON SURVIVING SCHOOL
description: CONCEIVED by Elliott Taubenslag, a high-school drama coordinator for the East Brunswick, N.J., school system, ''How I Survived High School'' at the Jan Hus Playhouse is a musicalized psychology textbook for teen-agers that dramatizes adolescent problems in crudely written skits, monologues, and pop-rock songs.

title: Katherine Lyman Married
description: The wedding of Katherine Stevens Lyman, a daughter of Mrs. Stephen A. Richardson of Riverside, Conn., and the late Keith S. Lyman, to Kenneth Jerry Feit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Feit of Saginaw, Mich., took place yesterday.

title: Linda Grace Corradina Weds Jonathan Vesey
description: Linda Grace Corradina, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aldo Corradina of Peekskill, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jonathan Marshall Vesey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milburn D. Smith Jr. of Forest Hills, Queens. The Rev. David R. Hunter performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Forest Hills.

title: CAPITOL HILL LOOKS BEYOND THE REAGAN ERA
description: CONGRESS struggled last week to move forward on the two central elements of its domestic agenda for 1986, a sweeping overhaul of the nation's complex income tax code and a Federal budget for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. On each, the progress - or lack of it - illustrated the extent to which legislators are operating in a new environment.

title: FORECASTING FOR THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT
description: The world's warming trend is still imperfectly understood, but scientists generally agree that the 100-year forecast is worsening. The Senate Environmental Pollution subcommittee last week listened to experts on the ''greenhouse effect,'' the atmospheric buildup of carbon dioxide and other gases, primarily from the burning of fossil fuels, that slows the escape of heat from the earth's surface. Their principal conclusion: its impact will show up sooner than previously expected, perhaps within a decade. The most pessimistic projections envision a rise in global temperatures by as much as 8 degrees Fahrenheit by the 2030's.

title: WALDHEIM MUST FIND AN END TO AUSTRIA'S BITTERNESS
description: ''THANKS,'' say the cheery posters put up last week by the conservative People's Party, which sponsored Kurt Waldheim's triumphant presidential campaign. ''And now back to the future.''

title: TRADITIONAL HAND TOWELS OF JAPAN
description: Myriad are the uses for tenugui (pronounced tay-nu-gui) the graphically striking cotton hand towels traditionally used in Japan for mopping up spilled tea, tightly twisted as a sweatband (witness the sushi chef) or spread over a repast awaiting guests. Free from the confines of Japanese tradition, the ingenious shopper, inspired by the wealth of stunning designs, can devise any number of other uses - dinner napkins (average size is about 10 by 15 inches, but many are larger), place mats, dresser-top runners, dish or guest towels.

title: WISCONSIN SWEEPS CINCINNATI REGATTA
description: It was Wisconsin all the way today, as both its men's and women's varsity eight oared crews captured national rowing titles in the Cincinnati Intercollegiate Rowing Championship Regatta.

title: Machine-Gun Armed Suspect Held in $100,000 Jewel Theft
description: A robber wielding a hand-held machine gun was chased and caught by the owner of a Chinatown jewelry store yesterday morning after the man and two accomplices fled the store with more than $100,000 in necklaces and bracelets, the police said.

title: JAZZ: A CONDON REUNION
description: SINCE Eddie Condon's, the jazz club, lost its home on West 54th Street to the wreckers' ball a year ago, the two musicians who own the club - the cornetist Ed Polcer and the guitarist Red Balaban - have been looking for a new location. No permanent place has materialized yet, but for four weeks, through July 5, a floating group of Condon's veterans will be taking part in what has been called ''the first annual reunion of the Condon's gang'' at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street.

title: TRENTON CONSIDERS WIDENING WIRETAPPING LAWS
description: THE deliberate interception and taping of cordless-telephone conversations may be illegal in New Jersey some day, thanks to W. Cary Edwards and George Spanos.

title: Making a Town-House Dream a Reality
description: ''IT'S a roller-coaster experience - I wouldn't mind the ups and downs so much if there was a stretch between the peaks and valleys,'' said Ralph Strafaci, an airline executive. ''But if you have a good partner, it helps a lot.''

title: South Asians Reach Accord to Fight Terror
description: Officials from seven South Asian countries ended a three-day meeting here today by agreeing to cooperate more closely to combat terrorism in the region.

title: Nancy Yeadon Webb Weds David Corkery
description: Nancy Yeadon Webb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Webb of Marion, Mass., and Southern Pines, N.C., was married yesterday to David Pierson Corkery, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher C. Corkery of Portsmouth, R.I. The Rev. Ernest Cockrell performed the ceremony at St. Gabriel's Episcopal Church in Marion.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Dallas; Towering Leaseback
description: ACCORDING to one industry executive, it is called ''the Hawaiian Theory,'' apparently because of its place of origin. Another calls it simply a ''ground-sell, leaseback, leasehold mortgage deal.'' Whatever the name, it can be a boon to investors, developers, and lenders; one developer said the tax benefits alone can pay for an entire project.

title:
IN LONG ISLAND;
Pace of House Resales Slowing in Suffolk
description: AT the height of the spring selling season, the market for resale houses is showing signs of slowing down.

title: RECYCLING OUR DESIRES
description: CONSUMING PASSIONS The Dynamics of Popular Culture. By Judith Williamson. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Marion Boyars. $19.95.

title: ONCE MORE, ROCK STARS SING OUT ON BEHALF OF A CAUSE
description: Rock and roll takes center stage on cable this week, with the latest in pop music's charitable extravaganzas and a rare television concert by Bob Dylan among the offerings.

title: Aoki Leads by 3 In Sapporo Tourney
description: Isao Aoki shot par 72 today to hold a three-stroke lead over Shinsaku Maeda after three rounds of the $241,000 Sapporo Golf Tournament.

title: Mississippi Copter Crew Places Key Texas Statue
description: A helicopter crew from the Mississippi Army National Guard today placed the new ''Goddess of Liberty'' statue atop the Texas Capitol dome to the cheers and applause of hundreds of people.

title: PLAYERS SWAP MEMORIES OF YANKEES-ORIOLES 10-PLAYER TRADE
description: RICK DEMPSEY was so unhappy, he ''kicked his suitcase all the way from the lobby to his room.'' Scott McGregor did not kick his suitcase, but he was upset, too. Tippy Martinez was crushed. It was 10 years ago today that those players harbored those feelings. Today they feel altogether different.

title: OPINION: GETTING LIABILITY COVERAGE
description: A CRISIS of major proportions in liability-insurance coverage is threatening our economic and social structures and American life as we know it. Private citizens, governments, businesses, professionals and nonprofit organizations must deal daily with this problem.

title: IT'S BETTER SOMEWHERE ELSE
description: What is the art of travel? The question has a certain appeal to people like me. It suggests that, as a Westerner, my traveling roots lie with the ancient Greeks and the Aristotelian method. Define, classify. Travel is the art of seeing all the second-rate paintings in the Louvre in a single day; of knowing whether to carry Pepto-Bismol or Marezine; of wearing Banana Republic clothes in such a way that one doesn't look like a tourist.

title: CORRECTION
description: A May 25 article about bottled water omitted a major national distributor.

title: Mansell Sets Record And Wins Pole Position
description: Nigel Mansell of Britain set a track record today to capture the pole position for Sunday's Canadian Grand Prix.

title: EMOTIONS RUN HIGH AT TOXIC-WASTE SITE HEARINGS
description: FIVE years ago, the State Legislature decided that siting new hazardous-waste facilities should be a public process. Lately, the public - at least in 12 townships - has begun paying attention.

title: AL ARBOUR'S WAY FOR COACHING SUCCESS
description: WHEN I played for Al Arbour, we didn't always agree completely. When I coached with him, we became very close. Then this past season I coached against him and got no reaction at all.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Veteran's Day It was a long time between Kennedys for Ricardo Montenero Duque. ''Commandante Duque,'' as he was once known, was taken prisoner in Cuba in 1961 when he led one of three battalions that attempted to invade the island nation with the encouragement of the Kennedy White House.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: ALABAMA; MusicVision, 37 minutes. $19.95.

title: MAKING AMERICA ACCESSIBLE
description: A major problem for air travelers who cannot walk is getting into and out of airplanes. A notice published in the Federal Register last month put it this way: ''While many airport terminals now provide accessible restrooms, electric doors and ramps, aircraft manufacturers have not widened the airplane aisle to allow standard wheelchair access. Because a standard wheelchair will not fit down the airplane aisle (17 inches wide), it is necessary that some other device be used for boarding and deplaning disabled passengers.''

title:
COLLEGE SPORTS '86; Basketball;
THE PLAYER THE PROS WANT
description: BARELY a week remained until the National Basketball Association draft, and Brad Daugherty was in town to work at a summer basketball camp run by Dean Smith, the North Carolina coach. He quickly headed for Reid Hilton's farm, a 47-acre spread six miles from Chapel Hill, where Daugherty had sometimes gone before key Tar Heel games.

title: ADDRESSING THE NEEDS OF ALL OUR WILDLIFE
description: HAVE you praised a politician recently? You should if you are a Connecticut citizen. In Hartford and Washington, our representatives outdid themselves this spring to protect the wildlife we are learning to value more as it becomes rarer.

title: Kathleen Forbes Married To Thomas Vincent Klein
description: Kathleen Patricia Forbes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril P. Forbes of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., and Thomas Vincent Klein, a son of Mrs. Otto W. Klein of Palmyra, N.J., and the late Mr. Klein, were married yesterday. Msgr. Edward J. Larkin officiated at the service at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: FROM SLAPSTICK TO YUPPIE FANTASY
description: THEY COULDN'T BE MORE DIFFER-ent, Bill Murray and Robert Redford.

title: WALLSTREET'S COMPUTERS GAIN POWER
description: IT happens four times a year - on the third Friday of every third month - and it can make even the most seasoned Wall Street trader quake.

title: HUGE DEFICIT IS PREDICTED FOR FIRST GOODWILL GAMES
description: The first Goodwill Games, the Ted Turner quasi-Olympics to be held July 5-20 in Moscow, are assured of three things - the Americans, the Russians and a huge deficit.

title: JACKSON, TO CLASS, TELLS OF INJUSTICE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson told the graduating class of Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn yesterday that they faced a world imbued with much the same climate of injustice and inequality - in large part because of the Reagan Administration - as 23 years ago, when Medgar Evers, the civil rights worker, was slain in Mississippi.

title: THE DISH OWNERS VS. THE SCRAMBLERS
description: Star wars, of sorts, have started - luckily in a nonlethal fashion. The battle line is drawn in the sky, where the satellites fly; the conflict is down here on earth, where more than 1.5 million American households depend on direct satellite reception for their television watching. They are up in arms over the scrambling of their favorite channels by the originators of satellite-relayed programs, and their protests have stirred political passions. The United States Senate, displaying a rare sense of urgency, has tentatively scheduled hearings on the issue for July 15, 16 and 17.

title: Austria
description: To the Editor: Jonathan Hurdle's article ''Hiking Hut to Hut in Austria'' (Travel, May 11) brought back many memories, some pleasant, some less so.

title: Sarah Chapin Marries Stephen P. Columbia
description: Sarah Ann Chapin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh A. Chapin of Madison, N.J., and New London, N.H., and Stephen Paul Columbia, a son of Patricia Anne Columbia of Spring Valley, N.Y., and the late Peter Leroy Columbia, were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Madison. The Rev. Carol Henley, an Episcopal priest, and Msgr.

title: Medical Theater Party
description: The National Library of Medicine was established in 1836, but from 1866 to 1889 it was housed in Ford's Theater, so it is appropriate that the historic theater will be used tomorrow for a party to mark the library's sesquicentennial.

title: PULLING VICTORY OUT OF THE BLACK BAG
description: REVERSAL OF FORTUNE Inside the von Bulow Case. By Alan M. Dershowitz. Illustrated. 276 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95. ALAN M. DERSHOWITZ begins ''Reversal of

title: VOLUNTEERS WORK TO HALT THE DECLINE OF NATIVE BLUEBIRDS
description: ON a recent, breezy spring day, Art Gingert walked across a peaceful Salisbury meadow and approached a small, weathered wooden box that was mounted on a fence post. Upon opening the hinged side of the box, he was instantly rewarded. Inside were three bluebird nestlings, their eyes still closed, their tiny bodies practically naked.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: LIBERTY IN NEW YORK - The original manuscripts of the Magna Carta, the first French Constitution and the Deed of Gift of the Statue of Liberty from the people of France to America will be among more than 25 documents on display this week at Federal Hall National Memorial, 26 Wall Street, lower Manhattan.

title: BROOKLYN RUNNER WINS DASH
description: Nat Williams of Brooklyn Tech won the 100-meter dash in 11 seconds flat and later led off the Tech 400-meter relay that set a state record of 41.82 seconds today in the New York State High Schools Outdoor Track and Field Championships.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the film page of the Arts and Leisure section today lists the theaters for ''Legal Eagles'' incompletely. The film opens on Friday at Loews Tower East, Third Avenue at 71st Street; Loews State, Broadway at 45th Street; Loews 84th Street Six, at Broadway, and Movieland Eighth Street Triplex, east of University Place.

title: Todd Mitchell Gillenwater Is Married to Laura Katz
description: Laura Katz, the daughter of David Katz and Susan Grossel, both of New York, was married yesterday to Todd Mitchell Gillenwater, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Raymond Gillenwater Jr. of Barrington, Ill., and Dallas. The ceremony was performed at the Waldorf-Astoria by Judge Jeffry H. Gallet of the Family Court of the State of New York in Brooklyn.

title: AN ATTRACTIVE, WATERFRONT VIEW
description: ALFRESCO dining at water's edge can be one of the happiest experiences of summer. All too often, though, there is an inverse relationship between a beautiful, shoreside restaurant setting and the food served. This is an observation reinforced by several recent meals on the terrace at The Inn at Longshore in Westport.

title: Recording Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: Formula One Cars in North America
description: This weekend and next, auto racing fans in North America have the chance to see some of the most powerful road-racing vehicles in history as the international Formula One circuit makes its brief annual visit to this continent. The Formula One stars are competing today in the Canadian Grand Prix in Montreal and next weekend at the Detroit Grand Prix through the streets of that city.

title: CAPTAIN'S PARADISE: No. 1 MAN FOR STATUE CENTENNIAL
description: THE job qualifications were specific and staggering.

title: Bettina Kent a Bride
description: Bettina Jennifer Kent, a lawyer, and Michael David Spatt, a certified public accountant, were married yesterday at the St. Regis. Rabbi Mayer Perlmuter officiated.

title: Be Like an Eagle
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYERS ENCOUNTER FORMIDABLE FOES
description: It wore them down, nine pretty holes that began to appear menacing on a sunlit day and, finally, literally brought one golfer to his knees.

title: Blues Denounce Move
description: When Jacques Demers quit his job as the St. Louis Blues hockey coach and signed with the Detroit Red Wings Friday, he stirred up a hornet's nest in St. Louis. The Blues' owner, Harry Ornest, denounced the move, accusing the Red Wings of ''flagrant'' tampering, and insisting that he had ''a binding agreement'' with Demers to coach the Blues for the next three seasons.

title: A Persistent Feud Flares Anew In Sri Lanka
description: It was hard to say last week how Sri Lanka's latest cycle of ethnic violence began. Depending on which side was talking, it began with the hacking and shooting of 37 Tamil fishermen by the Sinhalese-dominated navy on Tuesday - or the bombing, presumably by Tamil militants, of two buses and a movie theater on Wednesday.

title: 'SCARE TACTICS' SEEN IN CONSTITUTION ARTICLE
description: The May 25 Opinion Page article ''The Constitution Is in Danger'' uses scare tactics, not facts, in arguing against a constitutional convention to pass a balanced-budget amendment. Writing that such a convention could revoke the Bill of Rights and our basic civil liberties implies that its actions would immediately become law.

title: 76ERS ARE KEEPING DRAFT OPTIONS OPEN
description: ''The Houston Rockets select Ralph Sampson.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: In the early 1960's, the Whitman Foundation led a successful campaign against a plan by the city of Camden to demolish the Walt Whitman home, owned at that time by the city.

title: THOUSANDS IN NEW YORK RALLY AGAINST APARTHEID
description: From all over Manhattan - Harlem and East Harlem, Chelsea and Greenwich Village, the Lower East Side and the Upper West Side - thousands of New Yorkers in two columns, from north and south, streamed together yesterday onto the Great Lawn of Central Park to chant their opposition to apartheid.

title: CHEMICAL A CONCERN TO APPLE GROWERS
description: EVERY July, John Lyman 3d of Middlefield sprays most of his apple trees with Alar, a chemical that has been widely used in the apple industry for more than 20 years. But this year Mr. Lyman, who operates Lyman Orchards, does not know if he will use Alar, which is under review by the United States Environmental Protection Agency following studies linking it with cancer.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ITALIAN COMPOSER IS HONORED
description: Domenico Scarlatti, a renowned 18th-century Italian composer, is honored on a new coin released by the Italian State Mint. The silver 500-lire coin commemorates the 300th anniversary of Scarlatti's birth and is part of a series of coins issued to mark the European Music Year which was actually 1985.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Delaware courts on June 1 misstated the full name of Judge Moore of the Delaware State Supreme Court. It is Andrew G. T. Moore.

title: THE RISE OF DHIMMI
description: SEMITES AND ANTI-SEMITES An Inquiry Into Conflict and Prejudice. By Bernard Lewis. 283 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

title: East Harlem TV Deal Unraveling
description: IT began more than a year ago as another dream to revive a bleak section of East Harlem. But now, after millions in cost overruns, substantial delays and counterfiled lawsuits, the plan to build television production studios in the old Washburn Wire Company plant is stalled indefinitely.

title: DESPITE DEBATE, N.A.A.C.P. CALLS BALTIMORE HOME
description: One of the many newly paved roads at the Seton Business Park here leads to the headquarters and, some say, a new beginning, for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: FOR ONE, A 'LAST STRAW'
description: LAST August, two weeks after he had learned that Medicare reviewers had denied payment for more than $19,000 in home-care services he had received, Terry Mitchell of Millburn put a gun to his head and killed himself. He was 31 years old.

title: Nancy Ellen Marx to Wed Jamie Better Next Winter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Marx Jr. of Mamaroneck, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ellen Marx, to James Marc Better, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Clifford Better of Los Angeles. The wedding is to be next winter.

title: Old-Timer, After 5 Years
description: Charles Z. Wick, Presidential confidant and former musician, movie executive and businessman, has marked his fifth year as director of the United States Information Agency, making his tenure the longest in the agency's 33-year history.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: R. MARLIN PERKINS, TV HOST FOR DECADES ON 'WILD KINGDOM'
description: R. Marlin Perkins, the zookeeper who became a household name as America's television safari guide on ''Wild Kingdom,'' died yesterday at his home in suburban St. Louis. Mr. Perkins, who had suffered from cancer of the lymphatic system for two years, was 81 years old.

title: IN HAITI, THE LAND IS WORN NEARLY TO THE BONE
description: GOING along a barren mountainside, a farmer stopped to point at the downpour of stones.

title: Lark McCarthy Is Wed in Capital
description: Lark V. McCarthy, a correspondent for ABC News in its Washington bureau, was married yesterday to James H. Williams Jr., professor of mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Superior Court Judge Iraline Barnes performed the wedding at the Sheraton Washington Hotel.

title: WHERE ROLAND BLEW HIS HORN
description: Probably the greatest military victory in the history of the vibrant Basque people was the defeat of Emperor Charlemagne's nephew, Count Roland of the Brittany Marches, at Roncesvalles, northern Navarre, on Aug. 15, 778. And yet this smashing triumph, in which, according to legend, Charlemagne lost the entire rear guard of the army with which he had invaded Spain, including 12 peers of France and a force of 20,000 men, is attributed to Moors in literature. Nothing in Basque history, which is so mixed with legends, can compare with this triumph, although the account of the slaughter accords the Basques no role.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: OLD HALL, NEW GALLERY - Despite its name, Temperance Hall, in its 138 years in Bellport, has been a tavern as well as a meeting place for the Sons of Temperance, a church and a sea captain's home. Today, the building, which is on the National Register of Historic Sites, takes on yet another life when it opens as the Temperance Hall Gallery. Purchased and renovated by Mary and David Reay, an artist and photographer respectively, it will have as its first exhibition ''Sun, Sea, Land - the Island,'' a group show featuring clay vessels by Nancy Baldwin, paintings by Stan Brodsky, Kathi Ince, Jacqueline Penney and Joseph Reboli, and wood pieces by David Ebner. The opening reception is from 2 to 5 P.M.; through July 20 the exhibition can be seen from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Thursdays through Saturdays, and from 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays. The gallery is at 164 South Country Road. HAPPY FATHER'S DAY

title: REAGAN IS SAID TO ASK GORBACHEV TO RESUME SUMMIT PREPARATIONS
description: President Reagan sent a message two weeks ago calling on Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, to reschedule talks between the two countries's foreign ministers on arrangements for a summit meeting this year, a high-level Administration official said tonight.

title: PAINTERS AND SURVIVORS
description: The Weimar Republic, Germany's failed experiment in democracy (1919-1932), is synonymous with artistic modernism. Variously expressed by Bertolt Brecht, Arnold Schoenberg, Walter Gropius and Paul Klee, the Weimar esthetic appears so revolutionary as to be ahistorical.

title: A CHILD'S-EYE VIEW OF ART
description: ''THEY remind me of people I saw in a movie,'' a second grader said of three heads drawn in profile by a German artist.

title: WILLIAMSBURG
description: EXTERIORS in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn are often deceiving. Bleak and seemingly abandoned factories provide dramatic loft space for artists. Just beyond desolate blocks, tree-lined streets are home to a vibrant Hasidic community. And suddenly, among burned-out buildings, churches distinctive in architecture and rich in history materialize.

title: FOR BRITAIN, A WORRISOME PARTNERSHIP
description: ''EACH trade agreement, each bank loan, each new investment is another brick in the wall of our continued existence,'' John Vorster, then South Africa's Prime Minister, declared in 1972. In its report last week to the 49-nation Commonwealth, a high-level panel called the Eminent Persons Group agreed with that assessment and in effect endorsed the use of economic sanctions against South Africa as a way to force it to change its policy of apartheid.

title: THE CIRCUS: HALFWAY THROUGH
description: THERE are times when it seems almost obscene to be visiting Mexico and thinking about futbol. One starts to rave about the dashing Danes or the rejuvenated Russians or surprising Morocco, until one is jarred by the reality behind the World Cup.

title: NEW LIBRARY EVOKES 'LOST GENERATION'
description: UNITL she was 20 years old and ''liberated'' by the outbreak of World War II, Perdita Schaffner recalls meeting ''very few normal people.''

title: MORATORIUM EYED FOR SMALL LOTS
description: uf9420>THE Brookhaven Town Board is considering two proposals that would limit all construction on lots measuring 50 by 100 feet or less.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SOPHISTICATED COUNTRY SHOW
description: AMONG the more-sophisticated and formal country antiques shows, and one of the most rewarding for serious collectors, are the semiannual events sponsored each November and June by the Bucks County Historical Society.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME EARLY SUMMER PROBLEMS
description: JUNE is a month of transition.

title: MASON GROSS LEVIN TROUPE REVERTS TO NEW-PLAYS-ONLY POLICY
description: THE theater company that introduced Eric Bentley's ''Are You Now or Have You Ever Been'' and William Mastrosimone's ''Woolgatherer'' and ''Extremities'' before they went on to successful Off-Broadway runs is reverting to its original mission: presenting only new plays.

title: AN INHERITANCE: GUILT AND RESPONSIBILITY
description: ONE bitterly cold day in late March, three months after my husband had died, I walked to the post office to get the mail. It had been almost a week since my last trip, and my box was stuffed with sympathy cards, bills from doctors addressed to my husband and the usual flood of junk mail that seemed, in some absurd parody of his absence, only to have increased in volume. Efficiently, emotionlessly, I began to sift and sort: one pile for the wastebasket and another to be opened, answered or paid. As I was about to consign the junk pile to oblivion, one very white, cellophane-windowed letter caught my eye.

title: ADVANCES IN AUDIO STIR EXCITEMENT AT A DEBUT IN CHICAGO
description: Each June, electronics manufacturers from all over the world converge on Chicago to introduce their latest audio and video equipment. The occasion is the annual Summer Electronics Show, held at McCormick Place, Chicago's enormous exhibition center, where products are spread out over an enclosed area equal to 28 football fields.

title: Family Tradition
description: What do Deron Johnson, Bill Robinson, Lee May, Terry Crowley and Jose Tartabull have in common with Deron Johnson, Bill Robinson, Lee May, Terry Crowley and Jose Tartabull? Give up? Well, the former are former major leaguers, and the latter were among the high school and college players just picked in baseball's amateur draft. Or is it the other way around? Johnson and Tartabull were picked by the Seattle Mariners, Robinson and May by the Mets and Crowley by the Baltimore Orioles.

title:
DINING OUT;
AN OLD STYLE ITALIAN RESTAURANT
description: MANY of the newest Italian restaurants are decorated in pastels, with mirrors, fresh flowers and other touches that are immediately recognizable as being ''elegant and sophisticated.'' The serving people (men and women) are usually in black tie, and the music, if any, is subdued classical.

title: Felice Ludington Exchanges Vows With J. N. Taylor
description: Mary Felice Ludington, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Henry Ludington Jr., of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to James North Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Wycoff Taylor of Oklahoma City. The Rev. Francis V. Boyle performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor.

title: Loss of Education Aid Is Tied to Misspending
description: The state and Federal Governments have refused to reimburse the city's Board of Education $2.5 million because of misspending by the board on salaries and supplies, according to an audit by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Miss Perrott Has Wedding
description: Gabrielle Ghislaine Perrott, a daughter of Ellen McAllister Perrott of Stamford, Conn., and Richard W. Perrott of Johnstown, Colo., was married yesterday to Robert Lawrence Brady, the son of Ethel Arnold Brady of Hawthorne, N.J., and Lawrence K. Brady of New Haven. The Rev. Pierre A. Botton performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, a picture caption was omitted last Sunday in the Westchester bookcase column. The photograph was of Leonard C. Yaseen, the author of ''The Jesus Connection''

title: RUSSIA'S OTHER COLD WAR
description: CHINA AND THE SUPERPOWERS By Roy Medvedev. Translated by Harold Shukman. Illustrated. 243 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $19.95.

title: BID MADE TO HEAL ATLANTIC CITY RIFT
description: Mayor James L. Usry, after his re-election Tuesday in a vote that closely followed racial lines, has moved quickly to try to unite the city's residentially segregated population.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 15, 1986
description: Fiction -

title: MAYOR IS THE ISSUE IN MAYORAL RACE
description: VILLAGE elections usually inspire little more than a yawn from most residents.

title: Pamela Primomo a Bride
description: Pamela Ann Primomo, the Albany City Clerk, was married yesterday to David deRochemont Alley, a portfolio manager for the Norstar Trust Company in Albany. The Rev. Thomas Brown, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Emma Willard Chapel in Troy, N.Y. The couple's parents are Dr. and Mrs. Peter V. Primomo of Loudonville, N.Y.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: MORE than 200 vessels from the Coast Guard Auxiliary will be based at the Harborside Financial Center on the Jersey City waterfront during the week of the July 4 Statue of Liberty centennial celebration. The vessels will use mooring, housing and berthing facilities donated by Harborside.

title: AS RENOVATION NEARS, USERS OF COUNTY CENTER RELOCATE
description: IF it rains July 1, Lionel Hampton, the musician, will go down in local history as the last performer to play at the outmoded, dilapidated Westchester County Center that opened 56 years ago with a musical festival involving 1,500 singers.

title: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS ARE FACING A SCHISM
description: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS have long been the victims of Northern misconceptions.

title: MONDELLO'S IMPACT ON THE COURTS
description: The profile of Joseph Mondello [ ''Mondello Puts Mark on G.O.P.,'' May 4 ] left unsaid a very important detail about what this new Republican leader is doing to the courts of Nassau County.

title: Jody Sollers Has Wedding
description: Jody Cregan Sollers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harry Sollers of Terre Haute, Ind., and Seattle, was married yesterday to Emil William Henry Jr., the son of Sherrye Patton Henry of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and E. William Henry of Washington and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Charles P. Henderson Jr. performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: Site Chosen for 'Witches' Film
description: Ending weeks of suspense, Warner Brothers has decided to film ''The Witches of Eastwick'' in this seaside Colonial town, a town official said.

title: Catherine Foley Wed To William Hartnett
description: Catherine L. Foley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Foley Sr. of Middlebury, Vt., was married yesterday to William M. Hartnett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy L. Hartnett of Syosset, L.I. Msgr. Paul Bresnahan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of the Assumption in Middlebury.

title: HUGE BOMB BLAST IN SOUTH AFRICA KILLS TWO WHITES
description: A powerful car bomb exploded outside a crowded restaurant in South Africa's southern port of Durban tonight, killing at least two white women, wounding 15 other people and damaging hotels, apartments and 50 cars parked nearby, the police said.

title: DOOR COUNTY'S SUMMER PLEASURES
description: Wisconsin's Door Peninsula is a narrow spit of land, 3 miles wide at its tip, protruding almost 80 miles from the state's Northeast corner into Lake Michigan. It offers all the usual summer attractions: sun, sand, sports and clean, dry air. But the true hold of the place on the imagination rests on such things as a vivid orange butterfly trailing across a field of Queen Anne's lace, pewter-colored waves slicing through mist and crashing deep inside limestone caves, the lake's penumbral blues - putty blue near the shore, aqua beyond the breakers and, farther out, the midnight blue of open water, the oceanic pulsing of the waves, sometimes lapping and other times pounding the pink sand.

title: Colombo Bosses Are Facing Jail
description: Carmine Persico and eight others described by prosecutors as ''almost the entire leadership'' of the Colombo crime family were convicted last week on Federal racketeering charges that could result in jail terms of 20 years or more. The verdict followed by only a few days a series of guilty pleas by three sons of the late Joseph A. Colombo - along with 12 other men - to other racketeering charges under a plea agreement providing for prison terms of 5 to 14 years.

title: A DUCAL TOUR OF THREE STATELY HOMES
description: Scotland's King Robert the Bruce died in 1329, before he could set off on a Crusade. His heart, in a silver casket, was then entrusted - so the account has it - to Sir James Douglas. The ''Black Douglas,'' as he was known, went off to fight the Moors in Spain, and fell mortally wounded, throwing the casket before him and crying, ''Forward, brave heart!'' The Douglas motto is still ''Forward,'' and winged hearts - in iron, stone, lead, wood and leather - now stay put, festooning Drumlanrig Castle, in Scotland's Dumfriesshire.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
WHITHER COLONNADES?
description: THEY are known as the Colonnades: two clusters of 17 columns rising 25 feet above Getty Square in Yonkers, replete with a fountain and a huge clock.

title: MICHAEL EJECTED IN CUB LOSS
description: Gene Michael, who was making his debut as manager with the Chicago Cubs today, was greeted with a 1-0 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals and an ejection.

title: HELA'S LEGACY
description: A CONSPIRACY OF CELLS One Woman's Immortal Legacy and the Medical Scandal It Caused. By Michael Gold. 170 pp. Albany: State University of New York Press. Cloth, $29.50. Paper, $10.95. TWO of President Nixon's laudable aims in the early 1970's were detente with the Soviet Union and the conquest of cancer. Both objectives were impeded in strange ways by a living legacy from a Baltimore woman who died of cancer many years earlier. ''A Conspiracy of Cells'' is the fascinating and troubling story of what has happpened to her cancer cells since she died.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ALL THE STAGE IS THEIR WORLD
description: THE dream: to have a theater, your own theater, where you can spend the days rehearsing, the nights performing, and the time in between doing just about anything you see fit.

title: FIXING A DOOR THAT STICKS CAN HINGE ON SEVERAL FACTORS
description: WHEN doors start to stick or bind or become hard to open and close, take steps to correct the problem promptly since it will only get worse.

title: HIDDEN PLACES IN THE VIRGINIAS' SPA COUNTRY
description: There is a village in Cornwall called Lostwithiel, which the Cornish say means ''lost within the hills.'' We have our own Lostwithiels, discovered, forgotten, rediscovered, subtle and hidden, kept secret by their proprietary lovers. They lie in fingers of narrow valleys that stretch from northeast to southwest for miles between the long mountain ridges of the Alleghenies in the border counties of Virginia and West Virginia.

title: LAROUCHE MONEY IS UNDER SCRUTINY
description: Washington State investigators have reported after an examination of bank records that members of groups associated with the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. apparently used money from investors for personal purposes.

title: THE ADDICTION OF THE GARDEN
description: BEFORE I became a gardener, I envisioned a gardener as a straw-hatted woman who went around clipping roses to carry in her basket into her house to place in crystal vases. I don't know where the Scarlett O'Hara misconception came from, but I now know a gardener is more like the impoverished Scarlett at Tara, planting in the dirt on her hands and knees and filthy with perspiration running down her aching body.

title: Jeanna Marie Petersen Becomes Bride Of J. Powers Shepard in Connecticut
description: Jeanna Marie Peterson and J. Powers Shepard were married yesterday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Mark Connelly performed the ceremony.

title: 'Dear Mr. President . . .'
description: There has always been some suspicion about the effectiveness of form letters. If a representative or a senator gets a thousand identical letters from constituents, will it change a vote? If a policymaker gets a carload of computer-generated mail, will that help make policy?

title: 2d PRISON FOR STATE CONSIDERED
description: A SITE in Fairfield Township, Cumberland County, has been selected for New Jersey's first Federal prison, with construction to begin in November, and Representative H. James Saxton is confident that Pemberton Township in Burlington County will be a leading candidate for a second such prison.

title: LONG AND COOL IN THE HEAT
description: THE bad news is that hot, muggy weather has made its first appearance of the year. The good news is that the stifling temperatures and humidity brought with them a dress that could be this year's hottest hot-weather item.

title: Dissent on Dickinson
description: To the Editor:

title: Carroll S. Hanley, Michael O. Hilton Exchange Vows
description: Carroll Stollenwerck Hanley, a daughter of Mary S. Hanley and William L. Hanley Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Otis Hilton, a son of Patricia M. Hilton of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late C. Nicholas Hilton Jr. The Rev. Walter Wagoner performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich.

title: YES, JUST A DUCK, BUT WHAT A DUCK!
description: THE summer I lost my heart to Shalimar Drake, I was desperately in need of garden help. Bugs, snails and slugs were taking over. Chemicals were out, organics were in and I was caught in the middle.

title: Monkey Business At City Hall
description: WHEN a delegation of Peking officials visited New York last September, Mayor Koch made a pitch to them for two giant pandas for the Bronx Zoo. A month later, the reply came from China: Until the pandas were available under a loan program, how about borrowing a pair of rare Beijing golden monkeys instead?

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Manchester, Vt.;
An Auction In Ski Country
description: HOWARD PIERCE and James Tobey thought they had a good investment four years ago when they bought a one-bedroom condominium in the Hotel Sugarbush at the base of the ski area in Warren, Vt. They had been building homes in the area for about a dozen years, and they knew the condominium market around Sugarbush was booming at the time. But the condominium turned out to be neither a good investment nor easy to resell, and next Sunday it will be one of 100 vacation homes and condominiums being offered for sale at a public auction here.

title: Paper Offers $1,000 Reward For Copy of First Issue
description: The Daily Hampshire Gazette is offering a $1,000 reward for a copy of its first issue if it is received it in time for the paper's 200th birthday celebration.

title: BLACKS DEBATING A GREATER STRESS ON SELF-RELIANCE INSTEAD OF AID
description: In a major shift of thinking, many black leaders are openly debating whether black Americans should rely more on their own initiative and efforts in solving critical problems long attributed to racism.

title: Leonie Glen Is Married To Peter Willett on L.I.
description: Leonie Glen, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dulaney Glen of Pfafftown, N.C., was married yesterday to Peter Sabin Willett, a son of Carolyn Willett of Larchmont, N.Y., and Peter S. Willett of Glens Falls, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Murphy performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Katherine Wilson Wed in Princeton To Adam J. Miller
description: The wedding ceremony of Katherine Loudon Wilson to Adam James Miller took place yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John Crocker performed the ceremony.

title: Peter Ginna Wed To Susan Hewitt
description: Susan Hill Hewitt, a partner in Orb Development in New York, and Peter St. John Ginna, an editorial assistant at St. Martin's Press in New York, were married yesterday at Emmanuel Church in Dublin, N.H. The Rev. Daniel Burke officiated at the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Coach Banned
description: Hermann Neuberger, vice president of FIFA, soccer's governing body, banned Omar Borras, the Uruguayan coach, from his team's bench for the next game in the World Cup tournament because of rough play in the opening round. Uruguay, the South American champion, was fined 25,000 Swiss francs (about $12,000).

title: RASMUSSEN GOES 7
description: Who said the Yankees have pitching problems?

title: Paris Seeks to Tighten Pretoria Trade Curbs
description: France said today that it would push for new European trade sanctions against South Africa at a meeting of Western European foreign ministers in Luxembourg on Monday.

title: 89th PRESIDENT OF STATE BAR
description: ''I LIKE lawyers; they're good company,'' said Charles E. Heming of Scarsdale, who on June 1 became the 89th president of the New York State Bar Association. ''For the most part they are intelligent people who tend to think logically. Because we tend to think logically, we tend to enjoy each other's company. We work quite hard, and I think we like to be proud of what we do.''

title: A DREAM HOUSE AT A PRICE THAT'S FAIR
description: MY husband and I had decided -we were going to buy a house.

title: BRINGING HOME A 'HOPELESS' CONTRACT
description: For most competitors in sporting recreational activities the quest for significant victory is, like the ''Bleak House'' case of Jarndyce and Jarndyce, ''perennially hopeless.'' In bridge this is true in the long run: Very few players have any realistic chance of winning a national or international title.

title: Maryland County Backs Catastrophe Insurance
description: The Montgomery County Council has voted to establish a program of insurance for catastrophes for residents.

title: A Dancer's Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: FIGHTING OFF THE CONSUMER BACKLASH
description: EVERY year it gets harder for consumers to escape the researchers. Questionnaires come in the mail with credit card and utility bills. Researchers call, write and stop consumers on street corners and in shopping malls.

title: Senate Again Votes New Mexico Into U.S.
description: Notions to the contrary notwithstanding, the Senate has affirmed that New Mexico is indeed a state of the Union and not a foreign country.

title: ABORTION IS AFFIRMED, BUT IN A LOWER VOICE
description: THE Reagan Administration, which has been more aggressive than any recent predecessor in pushing its political agenda in the Supreme Court, met with two sharp setbacks there last week, in cases that raised profoundly divisive moral and ideological issues.

title: BRIDES, GROOMS, READY, ACTION, CAMERAS
description: IF a wedding is a performance, complete with rehearsal, then the wedding photographer is the stage director, heightening the sense of theater. The bride and groom play their parts for a single day, costumed for the occasion and surrounded by a supporting cast of loving admirers.

title: RIVERBOAT CRUISES RESUME IN HARTFORD
description: MARK TWAIN, who immortalized the Mississippi River in his writings, had a similar affection for the Connecticut River when he settled in Hartford: ''There were graceful curves, reflected images, woody heights, soft distances, and over the whole scene, far and near, the dissolving lights drifted steadily, enriching every passing moment with new marvels of coloring.''

title: Nancy Altmayer Is a Bride
description: Nancy Grace Altmayer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Ulrich Altmayer of West Hempstead, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Peter Charles Silver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Silver of Cedarhurst, L.I. The Rev. John Weiser, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the interdenominational service at the Princeton University Chapel. Mrs. Silver is a construction project engineer at the Grumman Corporation in Bethpage, L.I., and her husband is a resident in pediatrics at the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center.

title: SIENA
description: To the Editor: Some very pleasant memories were recalled in reading about the Palio at Siena. Perhaps most memorable was the total saturation of everybody days and perhaps weeks before the actual horse race.

title: PETER GABRIEL SINGS OF LOST EGO
description: Peter Gabriel is fascinated by the ego. Not about how big it can get, but by what happens without it.

title: CONCERT: THE PITTSBURGH AT NEW SUMMER HOME
description: America's orchestras and the wilted Manhattanite have something in common - a yearning for that little slice of rural earth to call their summer home.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Everybody has religion now.'' - Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, on efforts to pass Senate tax bill intact.

title: FATHER AND DAUGHTER -- CAUGHT IN THE TANDEM OF AGING
description: MY FATHER turned 60 this year. Sixty scares me - it is much more ominous than 59 - and it makes me take a long look at both my father and myself caught in this tandem of aging. Who is my father? He is not the father of my childhood, not as tall as he seemed then, and not, perhaps, as strong as I imagined him to be then. His all-knowing, all-seeing eyes do not seem to be as intently focused on my every activity, as they seemed to be then.

title: HOW THE MYTHS AND VIOLENCE OF THE WEST INSPIRE ITS ARTISTS
description: As much as any New York institution, the Brooklyn Museum has been providing the New York public with a broad range of perspectives on contemporary art. The museum has a biennial print exhibition. Last year it inaugurated a program of regular exhibitions devoted to the growing number of artists living or working in Brooklyn. Next September there will be a show of large-scale drawings. And, for the second time, the museum is presenting a survey of contemporary art from 14 Western states.

title: THE SHADOW OF TERRORISM DARKENS PERU
description: After winning enormous popularity for his efforts to lift Peru out of a prolonged economic and social crisis, President Alan Garcia is now facing mounting public frustration over his Government's failure to deal with terrorist and criminal violence.

title: 'GREASE' STAGED IN BRIDGEPORT
description: WITH ''Grease,'' the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport is serving a double dose of nostalgia.

title: BETWEEN THE MARSHAL AND THE MARCHESA
description: WITHIN THE LABYRINTH By Norman Lewis. 258 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $16.95.

title: THEATER FOR VENTING EMOTIONS
description: THINK of someone you've always wanted to tell off, only you never had the nerve.

title: Which Stars Are We Aiming For?
description: NASA wants a new $2 billion orbiter to replace Challenger and press ahead with its flawed shuttle program. Expensive satellites and telescopes, vital to defense and commerce, are waiting to be launched and the space agency thinks that only to refit the three remaining orbiters would leave too little room for the accumulating cargoes and for malfunction.

title: FERNANDEZ EXCELS
description: Sid Fernandez, who is quietly becoming one of the dominant pitchers in baseball, did it again yesterday: He pitched a three-hitter for a 5-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates that continued the Mets' rousing start.

title: A RETURN TO OUTDOOR FORMALITY
description: IN RENAISSANCE Italy, the greatest gardens were adorned with carved marble or stone benches that were designed with as much care as the landscapes themselves. In the years since, outdoor furniture has proliferated, becoming increasingly sophisticated in construction and style. Whether crafted to follow the curved silhouettes of the foliage or perfectly proportioned to rest alongside a weathered garden wall, these objects were originally intended as architectural ornaments, useful for providing visual relief from the lushness of the greenery and for creating a romantic spot to survey the view.

title: CALL TO CLOSE AIRPORT RENEWED
description: CRASHES are the stuff of air-traffic controllers' nightmares and, in this city where ramshackle buildings stand in the shadow of glittering gambling casinos, of longtime residents as well.

title: D. P. Pitney Wed To Clare Powell
description: Clare D. Powell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Greatorex Powell of Bernardsville, N.J., was married yesterday to Douglas Philip Pitney, a son of Julia Chrystie Webster of Ithaca, N.Y., and Philip Hill Pitney of Basking Ridge, N.J. The Rev. Alfred M. Niese performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville.

title: A Slight Mistake In Palmetto Par
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SONG AND DANCE TO FILL CROTON PARK
description: THE summer solstice is a time for song, dance and celebration in countries around the world, but one doesn't have to go farther afield than Croton-on-Hudson to find one of the most jubilant observances of all. It's the yearly Clearwater Great Hudson River Revival, a two-day conclave of folk musicians, artisans, storytellers and environmentalists that turns Croton Point Park into a combination crafts show, science fair, dance festival and hootenanny.

title: TAXING ALCOHOL
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALY, FEARING TERROR 'IN PIPELINE,' TIGHTENS GUARD
description: Italian officials say continued pressure on Syria from the United States, Israel and Italy appears to have led the Syrian Government to exercise greater caution in its dealings with terrorist groups.

title: Jazz
description: Although the JVC Jazz Festival will not begin until Friday, one adjunct of the festival will start on Tuesday. The Bluenote, 131 West Third Street, will combine two events - the American debut of the Paris Reunion Band and a tribute to the drummer Kenny Clarke, who died in Paris a year and a half ago - in a weeklong program that recalls the days in the 1950's and 60's, and even as far back as the 30's, when a colony of expatriate American jazz musicians made the French capital jump.

title: 300th ELUDES SUTTON BUT ANGELS WIN
description: Don Sutton failed in his first try to win his 300th game today, but an eighth-inning home run by Doug DeCinces lifted the California Angels to a 6-5 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: Now the Good News About Tulane's Student-Athlete Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: 'DIE BEWEGUNG,' A NEW LAMHUT WORK
description: PHYLLIS LAMHUT called her last dance ''Klein Kunst,'' translated as ''Small Art,'' and used its brutal, joylessly bawdy cabaret performers as a metaphor for a society on the edge of collapse. Miss Lamhut and her collaborators take on a theme of even more heroic scale in ''Die Bewegung,'' or ''The Movement,'' a new, evening-long piece the Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company performed on Thursday in Playhouse 46, 423 West 46th Street.

title:
FASHION;
A FLAIR FOR THE ROMANTIC
description: ENGLAND has long had a tradition of producing luxuriant evening wear - for royalty and laity alike. These days, the multitalented Anouska Hempel, a newcomer to the London dress-designer ranks, is injecting a new glamour to that tradition.

title: MARKETING OF STATUE ALTERS NATURE OF FUND-RAISING
description: The fund-raising campaign for the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island has turned into one of the most successful efforts of its kind. In the process it has spurred striking changes in the fields of corporate philanthropy and marketing.

title: SHAKESPEARE'S PLAYS ARE AS ALLURING AS EVER TO OPERA COMPOSERS
description: Shakespeare beckons the opera composer but lays traps for him as well. No language is more musical yet so easily evades the musician's grasp.

title: QADDAFI REPORTED SHAKEN SINCE RAID
description: Two months after American bombers raided Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is still badly shaken, but apparently in control, according to diplomats and other sources here.

title: LEGISLATIVE RACES OFFER DEMOCRATS NEW OPPORTUNITIES
description: TWO years ago, when Representative Richard L. Ottinger relinquished his 20th Congressional District in Westchester, a seemingly secure Democratic seat became suddenly vulnerable. Election Day confirmed the Democrats' worst fears - a Republican, Joseph J. DioGuardi, was the winner by a narrow margin.

title: Catherine Stryker Wed To John Strawbridge
description: Catharine Duane Stryker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Bartlett Stryker Jr. of Darien, Conn., formerly of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to John Noble Strawbridge, a son of the late Billie C. Strawbridge and the late John Noble Costello, both of Philadelphia. The Rev. Kevin Beane performed the service at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: JORGE LUIS BORGES, A MASTER OF FANTASY AND FABLE, IS DEAD
description: Jorge Luis Borges, the Argentine short-story writer, poet and essayist who was considered one of Latin America's greatest writers, died yesterday in Geneva, where he had been living for three months. He was 86 years old.

title: Tarascon
description: To the Editor: I wanted to offer an addendum to the three interesting articles on Provence in your April 6 issue, and to ''France's Colorful Country Fabrics,'' in particular.

title: Catskills Revivals
description: Most of the movie palaces of the 1930's - grandiose places where whole afternoons could be whiled away quietly munching popcorn and watching glittering stars on a double bill - are long gone.

title: 'JAZZ 88' RADIO GETS NEW STUDIOS
description: WBGO, believed to be the most-listened-to jazz radio station in the country, was getting ready to begin broadcasting from its new studios here last week.

title: SALSIBURY PUTTING ARCHITECTURE TO A VOTE
description: TOMORROW the people of Salisbury will go to the polls for an unusual referendum:

title: REVERBERATIONS OF THE SPACE CRISIS: A TROUBLED FUTURE FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: The Challenger disaster and a series of other major setbacks in the American space program have damaged President Reagan's antimissile plan in ways that are far more serious and extensive than has generally been realized, according to scientists and aerospace analysts.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ON THE THRESHOLD OF FREEDOM: Masters and Slaves in Civil War Georgia. By Clarence L. Mohr. (University of Georgia, $35.) As documented by Clarence L. Mohr, an assistant professor of history at Tulane University, the antebellum Southern way of life had long since passed by the time of Lee's surrender at Appomattox.

title: SYMBOLS FOR WORLD PEACE INSPIRE NEW ISSUES
description: This is the International Year of Peace which the United Nations General Assembly declared at its 40th anniversary session held last October. Many nations are issuing stamps to express their commitment to the principles of the United Nations Charter and the search for worldwide peace.

title: Leading the League
description: A. Bartlett Giamatti, now playing out his eighth and last season as President for Yale University, had his option picked up by the National League last week. The baseball league's 12 club-owners unanimously elected ''Bart,'' as Dr. Giamatti likes to be called, to take over Charles S. Feeney's spot in the league presidential suite after Mr. Feeney's scheduled retirement this fall.

title: THE 'WHILE WE'RE AT IT' IDEA: LET'S PUT THE UPSTAIRS DOWNSTAIRS
description: IT all began with building the pool. Not that we don't live right next to a large body of water - the Atlantic Ocean, to be specific.

title: DEALING WITH HAZARDOUS WASTE
description: The following was written in response to criticism of the Hazardous Waste Siting Commission by Representative James J. Florio, as reported in the Environment column of April 6.

title: HALF A CENTURY OF SONG WITH THE GREAT 'ELLA'
description: Last month, Ella Fitzgerald, the serene classicist of American song, was awarded an honorary doctorate of music by Yale University. ''Not bad,'' she said with her typically modest good humor a few days later in a Chicago hotel room, ''for someone who only studied music to get that half credit in high school.''

title: CELEBRATING CLEARWATER'S 20th YEAR
description: THE sloop Clearwater is celebrating her 20th birthday this week and an estimated 22,000 people are expected to gather at Croton Point Park to honor the vessel, the environmental movement and the folk music the sloop has come to symbolize.

title: Riding Cleaner, If Not Faster
description: If a New York subway rider's chances of being delayed enroute have not improved markedly since 1983, the straphanger does stand a much better chance of spending those idle moments in a graffiti-free subway car, Transit authority officials said last week.

title: Virus Risk for Drug Abusers
description: Abusers of drugs taken intravenously, a group that is already considered at high risk to catch AIDS, also face greater danger of infection by two AIDS-related viruses linked to leukemia, according to researchers on cancer.

title: MASSEY TAKES LEAD IN KEYSTONE OPEN
description: Debbie Massey shot a 6-under-par 66 today to take a one-stroke lead after the second round of the $250,000 L.P.G.A. Lady Keystone Open tournament.

title: THE STRUGGLE: POWER AND POLITICS IN SOUTH AFRICA'S BLACK TRADE UNIONS
description: JUNE 16, 1976, IS WOVEN INTO THE SOUL OF BLACK protest in South Africa. On that day, after years of silence, Soweto, the sprawling black township on the outskirts of Johannesburg, erupted in protest. The agony and bloodletting that followed spread to black townships throughout the country, and by the time it was over the following year, more than 570 lives had been lost. So, too, had the sense of an immutable, white-run South Africa.

title: Oklahoma Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 G.O.P. ASPIRANTS GIVE HINT OF '88 STRATEGIES
description: When his turn came, Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York did not try to match the passion of the Rev. Pat Robertson's earlier speech attacking the latest Supreme Court decision reaffirming the right to abortion.

title: The Washington Version of Insider Trading
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige's announcement last week that three workers in his department would be dismissed for turning inside knowledge of sensitive economic information to personal gain in the securities markets illustrated one of the differences between public and private service.

title: U.S. Craving For Sweets
description: AMERICA was reported on a confectionery kick after losing interest in the 70's.

title: LOVE IN HEAVY ARMOR
description: HALF THE WAY HOME A Memoir of Father and Son. By Adam Hochschild. 198 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: TWO CULTURES, ONE TRANSPLANTED
description: MILK AND HONEY By Elizabeth Jolley. 185 pp. New York: Persea Books. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95. IT has often been said of Australian fiction that its style is essentially baroque - certainly its extravagant conceits, its mannered exuberance and its perverse comedy have struck an entirely new note in English writing since World War II. And there is a sense in which Elizabeth Jolley's latest novel, ''Milk and Honey,'' reflects this interesting development - even though she is an Australian by choice rather than by extraction. She was born in England, brought up in a German-speaking household, and did not immigrate to the other hemisphere until 1959 (at the age of 36); that is perhaps why the cultural landscape of this novel is essentially a European one, despite its Australian setting.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 41 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 41 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: A QUIET BOOM IN BLOOMS
description: ALTHOUGH it is Sunday and the local florist is closed, the Floral Shoppe at the Food Emporium, in New York's Greenwich Village, is bustling. After considering a blue iris for 90 cents, long-stem red roses at $1.50 apiece, lavender or white freesia for 90 cents and an array of bouquets, Judy Karlov finally purchased a $3.99 bunch of daisies. ''I've been keeping fresh flowers in my house continuously for the last six months,'' she says.

title: LIBERTY AND AUTONOMY FOR ALL
description: GENDER JUSTICE By David L. Kirp, Mark G. Yudof and Marlene Strong Franks. 246 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $19.95.

title: AT THE METS GET BETTER, DAVE JOHNSON GETS BOLDER
description: THIS is his third year as manager of the Mets, and Davey Johnson admits that he is bolder in strategy, richer in talent, more demanding, less forgiving and irreversibly stuck with his spring-training pronouncement: ''I expect us to win.''

title: MAINTAINING ETHICS IN STATE GOVERNMENT
description: RECENT developments exposing bribery and influence-peddling in New York City government, and the growing concern in Washington over the lobbying practices of former high-ranking Government officials, have focused attention on ethical standards for public officials.

title: Plot to Kill All in Bank Is Laid To Suspects in Slayings of 3
description: Two men suspected of shooting to death three employees in a bank here July 6 have said their plan was to shoot everyone so there would be no witnesses, the authorities say.

title: TOWNS OPPOSE TRUCK STATION
description: STATE transportation officials, believing there is a growing problem of overweight trucks on the Connecticut Turnpike, want to build a weigh station in southwestern Connecticut to monitor the vehicles.

title: Town Bans Sale of Pit Bulls
description: Mayor Albert V. DiVirgilio signed an emergency ordinance Wednesday banning the sale of pit bull dogs in the city, where a letter carrier was mauled by one earlier this month. The penalty for violating the emergency order is a $500 fine. The ordinance also banned all unregistered pit bulls, which are bred for fighting, and reaffirmed last year's order requiring all dogs to be muzzled.

title: MESSING ABOUT AND GROWING UP
description: MEMOIR OF A THINKING RADISH An Autobiography. By Peter Medawar. Illustrated. 209 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95.

title: WESTPORT STATION CALLS COMEDY KING
description: FOR 27 years, WMMM-AM in Westport had been successful, playing so-called adult contemporary music and focusing on community involvement.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The sports bribery case against John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane basketball player accused of taking money to shave points in three games in the 1984-85 season, is expected to go to a jury in New Orleans on Monday after prosecution and defense lawyers present their closing arguments. . . . Bo Jackson, the Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn who says he has not yet made up his mind whether to play professional football or baseball, received an offer from the Kansas City Royals his agent described as ''unique and very creative.'' Jackson said he would not make a decision until he had seen the offer from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. . . . Rick Majerus, who led Marquette to three National Invitation Tournaments since taking over as head basketball coach in 1983, has joined the staff of the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: PETERSON HAS MADE THE MOST OF HIS YEAR IN OFFICE
description: WHEN Ontario doctors went on strike last month, more than one-third of Canada's population was affected. At the center of the controversy was David Peterson, 42, who has now been Premier of Canada's most populous province for a year.

title: TROUBLED NEW YORK STENOTYPE SCHOOL CLOSES
description: The owners of a New York school for court reporters, faced with a class-action lawsuit filed by students, a union-organizing campaign by its faculty and investigations by two state agencies, have decided to close the school.

title: CLUES TO LOST COPTER SOUGHT
description: Federal authorities are examining fragments of fiberglass that may be from a helicopter that disappeared while carrying three Connecticut men to Nantucket, Mass., three weeks ago.

title: CATALOGUE SUCCESS: TWO EXAMPLES
description: MURRAY GERSTEIN is photographed with a model on every one of his FBS catalogues. Lillian Katz includes her picture with a letter to her customers in every one of her Lillian Vernon catalogues. Mr. Gerstein's catalogue company started 39 years ago in a retail shoe store, the French Boot Shop in New Rochelle. Mrs. Katz began 35 years ago in her home in Mount Vernon, selling a leather pocketbook by mail. And when she opened her first Lillian Vernon store last October, it just happened to be on the same site where the French Boot Shop once stood.

title: MILFORD STATE PARK IS STARTING TO GET LONG-DUE REPAIRS
description: WORK has begun in Milford to refurbish Silver Sands State Park, which area residents have long considered to be little more than a dump.

title: Taken With 'Manhattan'
description: To the Editor:

title: YEARS LATER, FRESH AIR FUND MEMORIES LINGER
description: Aunt Del and Uncle Ken Ryan. Of all the families Darlene Rood visited during her seven years as a Fresh Air Fund child, this couple in Latham, N.Y., provided her fondest memories.

title: British Tycoon Seeks a Speed Record
description: If anyone with a window to the Hudson River had peered out at about 6 P.M. last Sunday, they might have spotted Virgin Atlantic Challenger II speed by. But they would have had to look fast, because the boat was going nearly 60 miles an hour.

title: Mary McGue Millhiser Wed to Philip Halsey
description: Mary McGue Millhiser and Philip Crawford Halsey were married yesterday at the Rumson, N.J., home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ross Randolph Millhiser. Mr. Halsey is a son of Marita Conroy Halsey of Montclair, N.J., and the late Donald Post Halsey Jr. Mrs. Halsey, a principal with the Toucan Construction and Development Company in New York, graduated from the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Noroton, Conn. and Duke University and received an M.B.A. from Columbia University. Her father is a director and former president and vice chairman of Philip Morris Inc.

title: RENAISSANCE MAN (A.K.A. MY FATHER)
description: WE are out for a drive, the three children and I. It is one of my favorite times. It renders me noble in the eyes of their mother, who gets a dearly earned breather. The motion of the car, the passing landscape, the chatter that ping-pongs back seat to front, the trumped-up importance of our errand all bring excitement to the ride. It also makes my two young sons and daughter spontaneous, outspoken.

title: Miss Kelley Is Married
description: Sandra Loen Kelley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John H. Kelley of Des Moines, was married yesterday to John Hilton Knowles Jr., a son of Edith LaCroix Dabney of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and the late Dr. Knowles. The Rev. Joseph A. Bassett performed the ceremony at the Old North Congregational Church in Marblehead, Mass.

title: READINGS FROM JOYCE WILL MARK BLOOMSDAY ANNIVERSARY TOMORROW, YES!
description: JAMES JOYCE'S classic novel ''Ulysses'' has daunted many potential readers with its intellectual mystique. Even dedicated fiction-lovers often shy away from it, fearing that its dense allusions and knotty puns might prove impenetrable. One alternative approach to ''Ulysses'' is by ear. When the novel is properly read aloud, Joyce's fascination with language extends beyond meaning into a kind of literary music.

title: PINPOINTING WHO IS WATCHING WHAT
description: IN THE old days, the best indication of what America's 86 million television households were watching was what televisions in the 4,300 homes hooked into A.C. Neilsen's polling system were tuned to. Now a new device adds accuracy to the educated guesses.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TCHAIKOVSKY: The Years of Wandering, 1878-1885. Volume Three. By David

title: WHEN THE SCRIPT IS FROM THE PEN OF WINSTON CHURCHILL
description: These are days of lackluster oratory, at least in English, and one may be forgiven for nostalgic longing for the likes of a Winston Churchill brandishing his language in defense of his country much as a Shakespearean king wielded the sword for righteous causes. It is 21 years now since the death of the man whose name has been hallowed as an adjective, but the Churchillian spirit, manifest in those magnificent words, continues to beguile audiences.

title: John M. Collins Is Wed To Alison J. Bjorklund
description: Alison Jane Bjorklund, a saleswoman in the institutional money-market division of John Nuveen & Company in New York, and John M. Collins, an architectural historian and preservation consultant, were married yesterday at the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I. The Rev. William W. Rogers officiated.

title: ALAN JAY LERNER, THE LYRICIST AND PLAYWRIGHT, IS DEAD AT 67
description: Alan Jay Lerner, the lyricist and playwright who formed with the composer Frederick (Fritz) Loewe one of the legendary partnerships of the American musical theater, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. He was 67 years old.

title: PORTLAND, ORE., MAYOR CHEERILY FACES OUSTER DRIVE
description: Bud Clark has settled one problem by getting a new Police Chief, but Mr. Clark, the ebullient and charismatic tavern owner who became Portland's Mayor 17 months ago must still deal with an attempt to recall him from office.

title: Alexandra Brill Is Wed
description: Alexandra Brill, a daughter of Richard Brill of Gaithersburg, Md., and Nicole Dunn of New York, was married yesterday to William Lenderking 3d, the son of William Lenderking Jr. of Washington and Lois Haskell Stratton of Tulsa, Okla. The Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Putnam Valley, N.Y., home of the bride's uncle, Dr. Irving Dunn.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S probably a good thing that two people who intend to live with each other think only of the joys of togetherness. If they were rational, there's a good chance they'd never do it. Isn't it possible to make coffee and toast without leaving the kitchen looking like a disaster area? Is it normal to be unremittingly cheerful first thing in the morning? Does everyone have closets so tightly jammed that you need a shoehorn to get a suit out? What kind of an upbringing did he/she have to leave the toothpaste tube looking like that? If there's another soggy towel on the bathroom floor, I'll . . . .

title: TV Censorship Of Polish Soccer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Decision in Chelsea
description: Six years ago, recalls Dean James C. Fenhagen, president of the General Theological Seminary, he was faced with a $500,000 annual budget deficit and a collection of 19 spectacular, but rundown, buildings.

title:
ART;
DARK IMAGES OF VIOLENCE
description: WHEN the world is in a hostile mood, the tension is bound to be reflected in art.

title: FINALLY, THE LAST WORD ON 'ULYSSES': THE IDEAL TEXT, AND PORTABLE TOO
description: JAMES JOYCE'S theme in ''Ulysses'' was simple. He invoked the most elaborate means to present it. Like other great writers, he sensed that the methods available to him in previous literature were insufficient, and he determined to outreach them. The narrator figure who often in earlier novels chaperones the reader round the action disappears. In ''Ulysses'' his place is taken by a series of narrators, usually undependable, who emerge and disappear without being identified. A whole galaxy of new devices and stances and verbal antics, extravagant, derisive, savage, rollicking, tender and lyrical, is held in Joyce's ironic dominion. Behind all the manifold disguises can be felt the pervasive presence of an author who never in the book acknowledges his existence.

title: World Cup Attendance Passes 1.3-Million Mark
description: World Cup organizers said today that more than 1.3 million persons attended the 36 matches of the soccer tournament's first round, an average of about 38,000 a game.

title: MARSHALL BRICKMAN HUMANIZES THE NUCLEAR ARMS RACE
description: Marshall Brickman says that he is ''ambivalent about gadgets.'' He says this while sitting in an office on Central Park South surrounded by word processing and stereo gear, a copying machine, an electric piano and an air-conditioner apparently set at ''arctic.'' The sheet music on the electric piano is Bach's Six English Suites. A moment before proclaiming his ambivalence about gadgets he had announced, ''I'm a clean copy freak,'' while excitedly paging through a thick instruction manual for a computer program called Scriptor that ''sits on top of your word processing program and reformats your screenplay automatically.'' A moment after proclaiming his ambivalence toward gadgets he announces: ''If I weren't a film maker I'd probably be a handyman.''

title: SIENA
description: To the Editor: Readers interested in Siena and its Palio might wish to read Christopher Fry's play, ''A Yard of Sun.''

title: THE SON-IN-LAW: THE SON THAT MY FATHER NEVER HAD
description: ONE of the best presents I ever gave my father was a son-in-law. At last, after 23 years and three daughters, he had someone in the family who wanted to get up with him at 5 A.M. to go duck hunting or fishing, someone who would drink a beer and watch a ballgame on television with him.

title: CONNECTICUT SPECIAL SESSION SETS UP TEST OF POWER
description: The General Assembly ended a disputed, three-day special session this week that raised for the first time a constitutional test of the Connecticut legislature's power to convene itself to enact legislation.

title: Art
description: The day may come when people are sick of the very idea of the English country house. There is, after all, such a thing as overkill, and for quite some time now the English country house has been omnipresent - in museums, at the movies, in novels, at the ballet (Frederick Ashton's ''Enigma Variations'' for the Royal Ballet) and even in the opera house (Benjamin Britten's ''Turn of the Screw,'' for instance). It would be no more than human to weary of its continual parading. Even the ravishing and highly unrepresentative scenes in the Merchant-Ivory movie, ''A Room With a View,'' could end by cloying. There is such a thing as a ratty, dreary, rundown, uncomfortable country house with a hideous garden. That secret will get out, sooner or later.

title: Botnick Finally Steps Down, to Koch's Regret
description: The conduct and credibility of Victor E. Botnick, head of the municipal hospital system and close friend of Mayor Koch, were already under increasing scrutiny when he recently confessed to impersonating a college graduate. Suffering what Mr. Koch called ''great agony'' from this ''unfair'' criticism, Mr. Botnick last week dropped out of city government.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Debra Lynn Stricker Weds Richard J. Fife, Consultant
description: Debra Lynn Stricker and Richard Joel Fife were married yesterday at Tavern on the Green by Rabbi Balfour Brickner.

title: Miss Matthews, Student, to Wed Eldon Pence 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Gregory Matthews of Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ellen Matthews to Eldon Dryden Pence 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Pence Jr. of Fort Smith, Ark., and Six-Mile Ranch in Charleston, Ark. A March wedding is planned.

title: D. B. Stott Wed To Joan J. Quinn
description: Joan Johnson Quinn, a daughter of Worthington Johnson of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Mary C. Lake of Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Donald Bishop Stott, a senior partner of Wagner, Stott & Company, a New York investment concern of which his father, the late Robert L.
