Stott, was a co-founder. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: The full title of the book by Clyde E.B. Bernhardt and Sheldon Harris, from which an excerpt was published in the Magazine on June 1 under the headline ''The Memoirs of a Jazzman,'' is ''I Remember: Eighty Years of Black Entertainment, Big Bands, and the Blues.'' The publisher of the book is the University of Pennsylvania Press.

title: About Men; IN GRANDFATHER'S ROOM
description: MY MATERNAL grandfather lived until the age of 111. He was lucid to the end, but a few years before he died, the family assigned me the task of talking to him about his problem with alcohol.

title: IDYLL AND TRANCE
description: BERLIN WILD By Elly Welt. 368 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: REAGAN'S APPROVAL RATING IS HIGHEST YET, GALLUP POLL FINDS
description: Public approval of President Reagan's performance is higher than ever before, according to results of a Gallup Poll released today.

title:
Focus: Anchorage;
Oil Slump Turns Boom Into Bust
description: THIS city's once-hot real-estate market, fueled by a petroleum boom and rapid population growth in the first four years of the decade, has fallen victim to overbuilding and a precipitious drop in oil prices.

title: Marianne Fuller Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Marianne Mansfield Fuller and William Barclay Buchanan Jr. took place yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Roland M. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: TRINIDAD PHOTOGRAPHY, OLD WEST LORE
description: BUTTERFLIES AND ORCHIDS, BIRDS AND BUGS - On the island of Trinidad - home to 700 kinds of orchids, 622 species of butterflies, 400 species of birds, 108 species of mammals, 55 types of reptiles - a series of seminars designed to educate and entertain is scheduled this summer.

title: NEWARK: SCULPTURE, TEXTILES, POTTERY AND OTHER COPTIC ART
description: IN ''The Living Races Of Mankind,'' a popular survey designed to acquaint the belle epoque British with the nations encompassed by their empire, the Copts are treated as a people separate from their fellow Egyptians. The reason given is the Christianity they professed, which precluded intermarriage with Moslems and, hence, Arabs.

title: Elizabeth Grace Mandes Wed to Michael Nelson
description: Elizabeth Grace Mandes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Joseph Mandes of Villanova, Pa., was married yesterday to Michael Jude Thaddeus Nelson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William James Nelson of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Litchfield, Me. The Rev. Henry A. Boyle performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York, assisted by the Rev. Joseph P. Flynn.

title: A QUIET WAR ON HONKING
description: Mayor Koch, who rarely misses a chance to blow the city's horn, declared war this spring on drivers in the city who blow their horns unnecessarily.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: VERY LAST FIRST TIME By Jan Andrews. Illustrated by Ian Wallace. Unpaged. New York: Margaret K. McElderry/ Atheneum. $9.95. (Ages 5 to 9) THIS unassuming Arctic adventure is the very model of what a factual picture book can be.

title: 2 TOWNS CLAIM LIBERTY'S GRANITE
description: ELLEN BEATTIE HARE of Old Saybrook is still hoping for an official invitation to the Fourth of July celebration at the Statue of Liberty.

title: HONORING THOSE WHO FOUGHT BACK FROM INJURY
description: The 86th annual award ceremony for patients making outstanding progress in their physical therapy was to start at 2 o'clock sharp. ''Two o'clock sharp,'' the voice on the intercom at Helen Hayes Hospital kept warning.

title:
WHO SHOULD PAY FOR NUCLEAR ACCIDENTS;
MAKING INDUSTRY SHOULDER ALL THE COSTS
description: THE world woke up to the catastrophic potential of nuclear technology with the Soviet accident at Chernobyl; now it is time for Congress to wake up. While Americans deserve a law that protects them from the consequences of a nuclear accident, many members of Congress want to renew a law that protects the nuclear industry and makes the public foot the bill.

title: Dance
description: Clark Center for the Performing Arts and its director, Louise Roberts, have a reputation for doing the impossible - from fostering the careers of some of the most interesting modernists at work in New York today to maintaining a tradition of excellence in dance training over 27 lean years now. But they promise to outdo themselves with Clark Center Summer Festival '86, an eight-week dance series at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater on Theater Row.

title: Miss Henderson Wed to R. I. Mortimer
description: Cynthia TenEyck Henderson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warwick Peter Henderson of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Iselin Mortimer, a son of Barbara Paschal Mortimer of Bolinas, Calif., and Richard Mortimer of New York and Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Charles Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattington Episcopal Church in Locust Valley.

title: WALDHEIM'S U.N. TENURE SEEMS TO SHOW NO PATTERN FAVORING EAST OR WEST
description: At the height of Kurt Waldheim's campaign for the Austrian presidency, a vandal scratched a tiny swastika into the lower left-hand corner of the official portrait that hangs in the lobby of the Secretariat Building. When an attempt to restore the painting failed, the United Nations turned off the light over the portrait.

title: SOUTH AFRICA CAMERAMAN DIES OF WOUNDS
description: George De'Ath, a 34-year-old South African cameraman, died in a hospital in Cape Town today of head wounds inflicted while he was covering a fight between black factions earlier in the week.

title: NORMAN FALTERS, BUT HOLDS ONE-SHOT LEAD AT OPEN
description: Greg Norman, who narrowly missed two major victories in the last 24 months, had a four-shot lead at the turn of the third round of the 86th United States Open today, but lost all of it four holes later.

title: The Army's New Tactic On Smoking
description: The Army has taken sides in the war between smokers and nonsmokers. Starting July 7, it announced last week, soldiers and civilian employees will be allowed to smoke only in designated areas of military offices and barracks and will be banned from lighting up on Army vehicles and aircraft.

title: Richmond Silliman Wed
description: Richmond Silliman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Beach Silliman of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert James MacLeod, a son of James MacLeod of Dallas and Marlene MacLeod of Westport, Conn.

title: FEDERAL CUTBACKS ARE OPENING GAPS IN HOME HEALTH CARE FOR ILL AND AGED
description: IN A small, sunny bedroom in her daughter's home in this Gloucester County community, Agnes Kelly lies waiting to die.

title: THE SHARK SHOWS HIS TEETH
description: FOR one brief moment, the United States Open suddenly was disrupted by a finger-pointing argument. Out on the 14th hole at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club yesterday, Greg Norman was pointing his right forefinger at someone behind the yellow gallery ropes who had yelled at him, reportedly that he was ''choking'' -the ultimate insult to a golfer.

title: NOW, THERE'S A PEKING COMPETITION
description: China has announced the first Peking International Youth Violin Competition, which will take place in the Music Hall of the Central Conservatory from Sept. 18 through 29. The competition is open to young violinists of all nationalities, and will be divided into two sections - a senior competition for musicians between the ages of 16 and 20 and a junior competition for those under 16. Yehudi Menuhin will serve as the competition's honorary advisor; Henri Temianka will be among the jurors.

title: THE ART OF SELLING TO THE VERY RICH
description: NOBODY buys one of Gerry Grinberg's watches to get unbeatably accurate time. Mr. Grinberg admits it: You can get as good time on an $18 watch as you can on one of his hand-carved, $13,000 gold Piaget beauties or one of his diamond-studded $1 million watches.

title: HARRISON SCHOOL IN EXCHANGE PROGRAM WITH MASSACHUSETTS
description: THEY followed the daily routine, taught some lessons that had worked well in the past, shared a successful teaching strategy and talked about education with other teachers and administrators.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE NOT-JUST-ANYBODY FAMILY By Betsy Byars. Illustrated by Jacqueline Rogers. 149 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $13.95. (Ages 10 to 14) ABOUT two-thirds of the way through Betsy Byars's new novel for children, ''The Not-Just-Anybody Family,'' a kindly bus driver says to 12-year-old Maggie Blossom, ''You take care of yourself. You the only member of your family doing all right. Everybody else in jail, in the hospital.''

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: QUAKER WEDDING IN MASSACHUSETTS - David Ross of Williamstown, Mass., and his fiancee, Anita Bower of Bennington, Vt., ran into an obstacle last month when they began planning their wedding in a Quaker Meeting House in Massachusetts: Miss Bower wanted a representative of the Quaker meeting she attends in Vermont to officiate.

title:
ART;
PHOTOGRAPHIC VISIONS IN 2 SHOWS AT THE ALDRICH
description: A NEW YORKER at the bottom of the Grand Canyon is alive to the sensation of seeing the rock formations as Manhattan skyscrapers. (Indeed, some buildings in the 1920's and 30's were inspired by these pinnacles.) This odd but inevitable relationship between the natural and the man-made springs to mind when viewing the twin bill at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield through July.

title: FIRST U.S. HOSPITAL FOR AIDS PATIENTS SET FOR TEXAS
description: A 150-bed hospital here is about to be converted into what officials say will be the nation's first hospital devoted solely to AIDS patient care and research.

title: The First Father's Day
description: Most Americans view Father's Day as a happy coincidence of sentiment and commerce, a time to celebrate Dad with token presents, a festive meal, a weekend excursion. If they think at all about the origin of the holiday, they assume it to be the work of the greeting card industry.

title: Cynthia A. Sidey Wed in Maryland
description: Cynthia Anne Sidey, a saleswoman at the Polo/Ralph Lauren shop in Washington, and John Cochran Buck Jr., an investment officer for Wheat First Securities in Washington, were married yesterday at St. Francis Episcopal Church in Potomac, Md. The Rev. Almus Thorp and the Rev. Edward Swanson officiated.

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS AND 'FACTS OF LIFE'
description: The article ''Chernobyl: Lessons for Emergency Plan'' curiously leaves out the most important lesson. The opening sentence asks, ''What relevance does the Soviet nuclear reactor accident have for Long Island's $4.5 billion Shoreham Nuclear Power Station?''

title: STATE A LEADER IN DRIVE TO UPGRADE TEACHERS' STATUS
description: CONNECTICUT'S sweeping new plan for education puts the state in the forefront of national efforts to recruit and retain teachers by raising their pay and reshaping the rules under which they get and keep their jobs.

title: LABOR LEADERS CONFER BY TELEVISION AND SATELLITE
description: When 4,000 labor leadersgathered in union halls across the country today for a conference conducted by satellite and television, one of the issues they discussed was how to aid unionists on strike against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: CALL-IN SHOWS ARE TAPPING TV'S ABILITY TO INFORM
description: What are the good things television can do? It can, evidence suggests, promote good health habits and inculcate what researchers call ''prosocial'' values. Can it also save lives, intervening into matters of life and death? Can it prevent suicides? There is no evidence about that, although WNYW/Channel 5 makes a modest attempt at intervention tonight at 9 o'clock. The hourlong program is ''Suicide? Not My Kid!'' and it is made up of two distinct segments. In the first, tastefully done, parents whose children have committed suicide speak about what happened; in the second, viewers can call in and ask questions. This is a worthwhile piece of programming. It demonstrates once again what television can do as an interactive medium.

title: JUGGLING SHOW BIZ AND THE BOTTOM LINE ON THE STRAW-HAT CIRCUIT
description: This afternoon, when the 2 o'clock matinee of ''Evita'' at Pennsylvania's Pocono Playhouse is over, the sets will go into storage, and the actors will climb into a company bus bound for the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., where they will spend the next week performing ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers.'' By the time they arrive, another company of actors will have finished its 6 o'clock performance of ''Brigadoon'' and be ready to take the same bus to its next weeklong engagement at the Woodstock Playhouse in upstate New York. There, a third cast will have packed up the sets and costumes for ''South Pacific'' for the midnight ride from Woodstock to the Falmouth Playhouse on Cape Cod in Massachusetts. Bright and early in the morning, the cast of ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' will be waiting to take the bus from Falmouth back to the Pocono Playhouse, where they will perform the show for one more week while rehearsing ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat'' for an opening next week.

title: HIGH SCHOOL DROPOUTS: 3 MAJOR REASONS LISTED
description: More than a million young people who entered ninth grade in September 1981 did not graduate in June 1985. Three major reasons caused these students to drop out. They are related to:

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: WHO WILL EDUCATE TOMORROW'S YOUTH?
description: AFTER several years of being on child-care leave, I returned to teaching part-time at a private high school and have been enjoying almost every minute. After all, what was there not to enjoy in such a dreamlike situation?

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Many Lubin's Specials For Men and Boys - Lubin's has been selling clothing and accessories for boys and men for 32 years at the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers and to accommodate late Father's Day shoppers the opening today is at 9 A.M., three hours earlier than on a usual Sunday, with many specials to suit the occasion.

title: PUNK-ROCK: JOHN LYDON
description: JOHN LYDON'S past as Johnny Rotten, the lead singer of Britain's punk-rock provocateurs the Sex Pistols, is taken as a challenge by audiences for his post-punk band, Public Image Ltd.

title: PONDERING THE NEW-MUSIC DILEMMA
description: In one of his famously mordant flashes of wit, George Szell once referred to the all-contemporary concert as the ''common grave'' of new music. As an orchestra conductor he chose not to preside over such dismal rites, which experience had taught him were attended mostly by family members and close friends of the victims. But experience must also have taught him that mixing new works in with familiar older ones does not guarantee tolerant listeners. Place the new music first on the program and they come late. Put it last, they leave early. Drop it in the middle, they may refuse to come at all. What to do? George Szell left us a memorable one-liner but no solution to the dilemma.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Redmond, Wash.; A Liveable Workplace
description: LUNCHTIME loungers around the small lake at the Microsoft world headquarters here like to say that their new $30 million corporate campus is ''worker-friendly.'' With its rugged forest setting, basketball court, sports complex and views from each of the nearly 1,000 offices, the 30-acre site seems more like summer camp than home for one of the world's biggest computer-software suppliers.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: While the Statue of Liberty was undergoing a face lift in the harbor, a similar scene, on a rather smaller scale, was taking place in the lobby of Loew's Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ...IN THE ONLY RING - After earning a bachelor's degree at Dartmouth College and a master's degree in business administration at Columbia University, Paul Binder switched gears and became the founder and ringmaster of the Big Apple Circus. The one-ring circus, known for its personal, intimate style, sets up its 42-foot-high, 112-foot-diameter tent at the Kensico Dam Plaza Thursday through next Sunday.

title: The Right to Refuse Drugs
description: In a unanimous ruling expected to cause major changes at New York State's 23 psychiatric hospitals, the State Court of Appeals said last week that even a patient who has been involuntarily committed has the right to refuse medication. The opinion by the state's highest court referred only to antipsychotic prescriptions, but mental health officials said they assumed the administration of other drugs would also be affected.

title: CHALLENGER PANEL'S FINDINGS SHOW SHUTTLE DISASTER WAS INEVITABLE
description: LONG before the Presidential panel investigating the Challenger accident submitted its report last week, its main conclusions were widely known. Driven by unrelenting, if self-imposed, pressures to launch, the space agency's management ignored overwhelming evidence that the space shuttle's booster rockets were a disaster waiting to happen.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN MARKET RESEARCH
description: EIGHT out of ten Americans dream of winning the lottery, says a D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Inc. survey. A majority of Americans accept the idea of premarital sex, according to the Gallup Organization Inc. And about 85 percent of all Americans are ''technologically illiterate,'' says a study by Northern Illinois University.

title: Sunday Observer; GUILTY OF MOVING
description: DEAR TIM SULLIVAN: As deputy county clerk at the New York County Court House, you are professionally disinclined, I suppose, to take my word for it that I no longer reside in New York and am, hence, ineligible for jury duty.

title: STATE OPENS DRIVE FOR WAYS TO MEET THE COST OF COLLEGE
description: WITH college costs continuing to soar and the Federal Government retrenching its commitment to higher education, the state's Department of Higher Education has begun an intensive effort to find alternative sources of money for students.

title: IN NEW BEDFORD, UNION EFFORTS KEEP A PLANT ALIVE
description: At Morse Cutting Tools, some things have not changed much. The company still makes twist drills, reamers, end mills, taps and countersinks in its red-brick building here as it has done since the Civil War.

title: LACROSSE: ALL-AMERICAN GAME
description: One day in early spring, when the sap is running in the roots, lacrosse sticks suddenly sprout on the Onondaga Reservation. Boys and girls begin slamming hard rubber balls against their school's brick walls. Teen-agers choose up sides for boisterous scrimmages in muddy backyards. Old people gather to watch them. And the young men clear the playing field of winter's debris for another season of fierce battle among the Iroquois.

title: THE STORY OF A TOWN AND NUCLEAR WASTE
description: In the sidebar about the problem of nuclear-waste disposal, Malcolm W. Browne writes: ''Many scientists agree that subseabed disposal, while more costly, would be significantly safer than land burial.''

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS AND 'FACTS OF LIFE'
description: The May 18 article ''Chernobyl: Lessons for Emergency Plan'' is an excellent dissertation on the problems and ''facts of life'' that must be considered in the operation of a nuclear generation plant.

title:
DINING OUT;
PERSONAL TOUCH TO ITALIAN CUISINE
description: PEREGRINE'S is a spiffy little restaurant tucked in a corner of an Irvington building designed in the early 1890's by Stanford White. The Cosmopolitan Building, as it was originally known, housed the executive offices of that magazine and has since provided, at one time or another, space for some Hearst publications and for a film studio in the days of the silents. Neglected though it may be, the architecture is still worth an admiring look.

title: QUESTIONS NASA STILL HASN'T ANSWERED
description: Alex Roland, an historian with NASA from 1973 to 1981, has emerged in recent years as a leading critic of manned space flight. Now an associate professor of military history and the history of technology at Duke University, Mr. Roland spoke last week with Kyle Crichton, Business Forum editor, on the final report of the President's shuttle commission on the Challenger disaster. The report identified the cause of the accident and contained 11 recommendations intended to redress several technical and managerial shortcomings in the space agency's operations.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME EARLY SUMMER PROBLEMS
description: JUNE is a month of transition.

title: Hanoi Gives U.S. Data On Missing Americans
description: Vietnam has turned over more information on 21 Americans listed as missing in action in the Vietnam War and has promised to investigate reports that some American soldiers are alive there, an American official said today.

title: SUSHI IN THE RAW AND THE ROUND
description: THE distinctive feature of Junko, a Japanese restaurant in a less-than-glamorous motel complex in Huntington, is its sushi bar in the round.

title: THE STEELWORKERS: LIMPING AT 50
description: It will be a grim celebration in Pittsburgh on Tuesday for one of the nation's once-mightiest unions. As the United Steelworkers of America marks its 50th anniversary, it faces three wrenching battles - a strike against the Aluminum Company of America and two tough contract negotiations with the United States Steel Corporation and the Kennecott Corporation. For the already-groggy union, the test ranks among the most difficult since its founding during the Depression.

title: OPERA: ROSSINI 'VIAGGIO' IN ST. LOUIS PRODUCTION
description: Gioacchino Rossini's Paris debut was made in June 1825 with a piece d'occasion honoring the coronation of Charles X at Rheims in May. The score of ''Il viaggio a Reims'' (''The Journey to Rheims'') was dismembered soon afterward, and much of the music was recycled for another opera, ''Le Comte Ory.'' But much more was scattered or forgotten. Over the past two decades, the Rossini scholar Philip Gossett scouted out the far-flung bits, and Janet Johnson tracked them down and produced an edition (composing a few tiny bits that couldn't be recovered). The reassembled ''Viaggio'' was first heard in Italy in 1984, and reached America on Thursday evening in a triumphant production by the Opera Theater of St. Louis.

title: 15 Perish in Fire In Portuguese Forest
description: A forest fire raged out of control in the hills of central Portugal today, killing 15 people and injuring more than 50, officials said.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
SOCIAL STUDIES SOCIAL
description: When Irving Sloan realized he had been teaching eighth-grade social studies at Scarsdale Junior High School for a quarter of a century, he decided he ''had to do something about it.'' So he contacted as many former students as he could, and asked if they would like to get together. The result: a reunion, to be held next Sunday, 11 A.M. to 2 P.M., in the courtyard of the junior high school on Mamaroneck Road.

title: JONATHAN MILLER DEFENDS HIS 'JOURNEY'
description: To The Editor:

title: THE CALLING
description: In ''The Calling,'' I am identified as the tutor who would not, as a feminist theologian, answer a male student's question.

title: FROM DEAR OLD DAD, HARDLY A MEMORY
description: IN the post-World War I years, when unlike today words like separation and divorce were whispered in a quiet corner by adults, I was a lonely young boy who had no one he could call ''Dad.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THOSE WHO BLINK. By William Mills. (Louisiana State University, $14.95.) This is a book I wanted to like. The language is vivid and compelling, precise and detailed as it lovingly evokes a backwoods life in Louisiana.

title: ATHLETICS AS USUAL
description: HITLER'S GAMES The 1936 Olympics. By Duff Hart-Davis. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: BEACHES ON OCEAN, SOUND AND BAY
description: From its beginning at Sagamore Bridge to its claw-like tip at Provincetown, Cape Cod has more than 300 miles of shoreline. At scattered points are 77 of the longest, broadest, sandiest public beaches in New England.

title: SEXISM, RACISM AND BLACK WOMEN WRITERS
description: IN Carlene Hatcher Polite's 1967 novel, ''The Flagellants,'' Ideal, the young heroine, describes her love affair with a black poet as ''an irrevocable trauma.'' Later, after telling him to get out of her life, she delivers this indictment:

title: Q AND A
description: Building Blocks - Question: I have noticed that construction of buildings in Manhattan is usually of two types: poured concrete or steel beam. What are the basic differences between them and what goes into the decision to use one or the other? . . . D. L., Manhattan Answer: In concrete construction, wooden forms are used as molds for liquid concrete, which is poured around thin reinforcing bars of steel to make the supporting elements. When the concrete is set, the molds are removed and used again. The support system in steel construction consists of steel girders and beams that are augmented with horizontal metal decking and thin layers of concrete.

title: WORLD THEATER GROUPS SET FOR BALTIMORE FESTIVAL
description: ALMOST all the world's a stage beginning tonight in Baltimore, as the Theater of Nations Festival opens for a two-week run.

title: Anne T. Fox Is the Bride Of John Zaven Ayanian
description: Anne Tuthill Fox, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar C. Fox of Wilmington, N.C., and John Zaven Ayanian, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Zaven S. Ayanian of Matawan, N.J., were married yesterday by the Rev. Alfred Durrance at St. John's Episcopal Church in Wilmington.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'MISS LIBERTY' ON TAP - The timing could not be more perfect for reviving the Irving Berlin musical ''Miss Liberty,'' and that is just what the Summerfun Theater of Montclair has done.

title: THE SPACE SHIELD PLAN: 'STAR WARS,' 3 YEARS LATER
description: On March 23, 1983, President Reagan called on American scientists to find ways to erect a missile defense shield to render nuclear weapons ''impotent and obsolete.''

title: PARISIAN BLOCK PARTIES
description: FARCE AND FANTASY Popular Entertainment in Eighteenth-Century Paris. By Robert M. Isherwood. Illustrated. 324 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: Message for Pretoria
description: The future of apartheid has been settled. The question is no longer whether it will be abolished, but when, in what circumstances, and what will follow.

title: The Congress Dissents
description: The balance of power between the President and the Congress is clearly shifting against the President, except perhaps in the negotiations for nuclear arms control.

title: Diane Flannery Weds J.T. Knight
description: Diane Marie Flannery, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Flannery of Cheshire, Conn., and Harwich Port, Mass., was married yesterday to James Thomas Knight, a son of Virginia Armstrong Knight of Manchester, N.H., and the late James Vincent Knight. The ceremony was performed at St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church in Cheshire by the Rev. Joseph J. Dionne and the Rev. Neil Fitzgerald. Mrs. Knight, a candidate for an M.B.A. degree from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School in May, attended Smith College and is an alumna of Brown University.

title: Cutting Reactor Risk
description: James K. Asselstine, a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, in a lecture May 15 at the University of California at Santa Cruz:

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: The cover article in The Times Magazine today deals with the role of black trade unions in South Africa.

title: Verbatim; Outlawing Obscenity
description: 'It's really a question of whether you view the disease as worse than the cure.

title: Data Update
description: MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES...(Averages)

title: DIVIDING UP THE LOSSES
description: THE DREAM OF DELIVERANCE IN AMERICAN POLITICS By Mona Harrington. 308 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. ''THE American promise is in trouble,'' Mona Harrington warns in this ambitious and intriguing book. We face social and economic problems of great danger and staggering complexity; yet we deal with those problems by relying on simplistic and inadequate assumptions. Above all, we are crippled by our attachment to a longstanding and, in Miss Harrington's view, dangerous myth: the belief ''that human relations are, by their nature, harmonious, that serious conflict in human societies is unnatural and unnecessary,'' and that a series of relatively simple adjustments can establish a ''beneficent natural order'' in which all discord will be peacefully resolved ''without loss to any legitimate interest.''

title: The Story of a Town And Nuclear Waste
description: As an environmental reporter specializing in nuclear-news reports, I was touched deeply by Joyce Maynard's article ''The Story of a Town'' (May 11). Miss Maynard has focused on an issue that will become a national one in only five years when a President selects the first high-level nuclear repository, most probably in the West.

title: MINNEAPOLIS SHOWS OFF ITS VARIED TREASURES
description: As a portrait in museological terms of a great and difficult city, ''Tokyo: Form and Spirit'' at the Walker Art Institute in Minneapolis would be hard to beat. This particular visitor has never been to Tokyo, so that the show came to him as part wonderland, part horror-story. But, as a feat of presentation, the show is consistently vivid, inventive and - like Tokyo itself - a tour de force of signscape. Even the television commercials - an important part of the show - bear watching many times over.

title: A Conviction in Brighton Bombing
description: It was one of the most audacious plots against the British Government, coming ''within an inch,'' the prosecutor said, of assassinating Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and much of her Cabinet. Although Mrs. Thatcher was uninjured, the bomb that shattered a Brighton hotel during a Conservative Party conference in 1984 killed five people, including a Member of Parliament and a party official, and seriously injured 30. Last week, after five weeks of testimony and five hours of deliberations, a jury at London's Old Bailey convicted Patrick J. Magee, the accused leader of an Irish Republican Army cell. He and four others were also convicted of plotting other hotel bombings that were to have taken place in British resorts last summer.

title: Talking Insurance; Impact Of Liability Increases
description: THE upheaval in the insurance industry over liability coverage is starting to have an impact on homeowner policies - a change that has either benefits or drawbacks depending on the type of home that is owned and the coverage sought.

title: Doris Roll Weds Kieran Mahoney
description: Doris Jean Roll, the legislative coordinator for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and Kieran Vincent Mahoney, the legislative director for Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi, Republican of New York, were married yesterday at St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church in Inwood, W.Va. The Rev. Paul Tedesco officiated.

title: CONGRESS TO PRESS SHUTTLE INQUIRY
description: Congressional leaders said yesterday that they would ''harden'' their investigation of the space agency after new disclosures that its top officials apparently failed to act on repeated warnings of life-threatening trouble with the shuttle booster rockets.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HIROHITO: The War Years. By Paul Manning. (Dodd Mead, $16.95.) Much of the history and biography in Paul Manning's ''Hirohito'' has already been covered in William Manchester's ''American Caesar'' and the diaries of the Marquis Kido, Lord Privy Seal in the Imperial Government during World War II and after. Mr. Manning's problem is that the prewar Emperor was a divine, aloof being whom few Japanese even saw.

title: EXPERIMENTING WITH ETHNICITY IN THE MELTING POT
description: I ONCE came across a recipe in a magazine written in the form of a poem. It was called ''Eggs Maledict.'' Unfortunately, I forgot to cut it out, but I can remember exactly what the ingredients were: a piece of Spam and hard-boiled egg on a slice of Wonder bread, the whole thing topped off with a generous dollop of mayonnaise.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: BEAT THE DEVIL; Starring Jennifer Jones, Humphrey Bogart, Gina Lollobrigida, Peter Lorre, Robert Morley, Ivor Barnard, Edward Underdown; directed by John Huston, 1954. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video, 89 minutes.

title: BRACING FOR THE TAX CHANGE SWEEPSTAKES
description: RADICAL tax changes seem all but certain in 1986, and the only question is what shape the final legislation will take. Because the House and Senate tax plans contain widely differing provisions, a number of people are simply refusing to make any investment decisions until the Congressional conferees emerge with a finished product.

title: Lousy At Sports
description: I have always enjoyed a sweaty (solitary) workout simply because it feels good (''Lousy at Sports,'' by Mark Goodson, About Men, May 11). However, I was never enamored of organized team sports until I began to read the sports columnists of The New York Times while commuting to work.

title: A New Verbosity
description: Since the television cameras started live coverage in the Senate, many members have found that they have more to say. It used to be that, other than the majority and minority leaders, practically no one spoke in the morning period called special orders except Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, who urged every morning for many years that the Senate approve a treaty outlawing genocide, which it finally did.

title: A 'WORLD IN MOTION,' A WAIT IN LINE
description: Those who have the kind of impatient disposition that makes waiting in line a form of torture, be warned:

title: Art Museum In Esthetic Clash
description: IT shaped up as a battle pitting hundreds of critics, including prominent figures in architecture and art, against a leading architect and art museum.

title: EMPLOYEE HEALTH: THE EMPLOYER'S ROLE
description: Regarding the articles on employee assistance programs that appeared on April 26 and May 4, it is reassuring to know that corporations on Long Island are recognizing their responsibilities to employees with alcohol- and drug-related problems.

title: TOUGH QUESTIONS ABOUT TRANSPLANTS RAISED BY NEW HEART FOR 'BABY JESSE'
description: It is the stuff of soap operas, but it raises difficult moral questions that affect the most helpless of patients: newborns. The issues all center on what factors determine who gets the few hearts available for transplant.

title: CASTING DIRECTOR FINDS HER RIGHT ROLE
description: ''I WAS born wanting to be an actress,'' said Joy Todd of Manhattan and Springs.

title: DYNAMIC BUT RISKY
description: There are several good reasons for preferring dynamic play to passive defense: it challenges the opponent's initiative, denying him a leisurely free hand to screw down the pressure; psychologically, there is an undeniable lift just from knowing that you must have at least some play for a victory rather than playing to hold even; again psychologically, it unnerves some opponents, who are then likely to credit you with more than you really have.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Michigan 400, at Brooklyn, Mich. (Television -Channel 2, 1 P.M.). Seagram's Cooler 24 Hours, at Watkins Glen, N.Y., finale. Canadian Grand Prix, at Montreal (Television -ESPN, 11:50 A.M.) CART Portland 200, at Portland Ore., (Television -ESPN, 5 P.M.). Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Shea Stadium, doubleheader, 1:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1 P.M.). Yankees vs. Orioles, at Baltimore, 2:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.). Braves vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Atlanta (Television -WTBS, 2:05 P.M.). Bicycling Budweiser Classic, at Marcus Garvey Park, 3 P.M. There will be a 35-mile men's and 12-mile women's criterium round the park at Fifth Avenue, between 120th and 124th Streets. Boxing Henry Tillman, champion, vs. Bert Cooper, 12 rounds for the North American Boxing Federation cruiserweight title. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.). Golf United States Open, at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, Southampton, L.I., final round. (Television - Channel 7, 2 P.M. live. ESPN, 10 A.M. tape of third round). L.P.G.A. Lady Keystone Open, at Hershey Pa., final round. Soccer World Cup, opening of the elimination round. Mexico vs. Bulgaria at Mexico City, 2 P.M. (Television -Channel 4, 1:30 P.M. Channel 41, 1:45 P.M., live, and Channel 41 11 P.M. tape); Soviet Union vs. Belgium at Leon, 6 P.M. (Television - Channel 41, 5:45 P.M.).

title: U.S. AND ISLIP BATTLE ON AIRPORT
description: ANGRY words are flying over Long Island MacArthur Airport as the Federal Aviation Administration and the Town of Islip continue a dispute over runway expansion.

title: THE IMAGE IN THE BACKGROUND OF A WESTCHESTER BOYHOOD
description: THE motion pictures of memory gradually become snapshots as their places in time become more distantly removed. So it is with my images of the County Center.

title: Katherine Louise Allen Is the Bride Of Darren L. Luckfield in Short Hills
description: Katherine Louise Allen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Allen of Short Hills, N.J., and Darren L. Luckfield, the son of Marie Cope of Appling, Ga., and Fredric L. Luckfield of Boca Raton, Fla., were married yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills by the Rev. John D. Sweeney.

title: Barrie Ewing Todd Married to Kent Wilson Dahl
description: Barrie Ewing Todd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Todd Jr. of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Kent Wilson Dahl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. T. William Dahl Jr. of Norwich, Conn. The Rev. John T. Galloway Jr. performed the ceremony at the Fox Chapel Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE State Senate Natural Resources and Agriculture Committee tackles a new environmental issue this month: whether and how to regulate the use of genetically engineered organisms.

title: Julie Bea Bermant To Marry in July
description: Julie Bea Bermant and Richard Hilton Lobel plan to be married July 20, the future bride's father, Tobias J. Bermant of New York, has announced.

title: CAPE COD
description: By the beginning of the 20th century the descendants of those tenacious Puritan fishermen and farmers who had settled Cape Cod 200 years earlier were harvesting a different crop: tourists and summer residents. Many of their grandchildren are now doing the same, but under much different circumstances.

title: NEW YORK MAKES GAINS IN BATTLE AGAINST NOISE
description: Fourteen years after New York City enacted the nation's first noise-control code establishing legal noise levels, both city officials and critics say the city is less noisy.

title: WOE TO THE UNHANDY IN A DO-IT-YOURSELF WORLD
description: A WOMAN I know was lamenting that her husband was not what you would call handy. This is the same woman who once lamented about being average. Some people bounce from one lamentable situation to another.

title: UNIFIED PLAN'S AIM: SAFE WATER FOR ALL
description: A STATEWIDE effort to assure adequate safe drinking water for all of Connecticut began with a meeting in Danbury last week.

title: Lisa A. Schmidt Is Married To Andrew Bast in Wilton
description: Lisa Anne Schmidt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Schmidt of Hamburg, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew G. Bast, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Bast of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Stephen D. Parker performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Wilton.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RUNNING IN PLACE: Inside the Senate. By James A. Miller. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) For those who have wondered what transpires behind the closed doors of the leaders of the United States Senate and why courage and innovation are in short supply there, James A. Miller has provided an insider's account, based on a week (April 25-29, 1983) in the lives of three senators and three staff members. This is an unvarnished look at the Senate in microcosm - its humor, foibles, conceits, crises and occasional victories. It is a week in which Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee and the Majority Leader, seeks unsuccessfully to use his low-key powers of persuasion to unify Senate Republicans on a budget proposal. The Senator is aided by James D. Range, his counsel, ''a legislative cowboy - a southern, tough-talking, Jack Daniels-drinking, boyishly handsome, charismatic lawyer who long ago made the right connections on his way up north.'' It is a week in which Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, has alienated many colleagues by demanding a closed Senate session on Central America, and in which Senator Alan K. Simpson, a witty Wyoming Republican, is pushing for a new immigration bill. Rounding out the cast of characters are Stephen Bell, an aide to the Senate Budget Committee whose powers rival those of his boss, according to Mr. Miller, and Mary Jane Checchi, an aide to the newly-elected Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, who is tutoring her boss on the mores of the Senate.

title: COMMUNITY WORK OF STUDENTS CITED
description: WHAT Brian Johnson liked most about being a volunteer at White Memorial Foundation, a 4,000-acre wildlife sanctuary and recreation area in Litchfield, was ''getting to play with the snakes,'' he said.

title: THE STORY OF A TOWN AND NUCLEAR WASTE
description: When Joyce Maynard acknowledges that she has lived by the philosophy of minding her own backyard, it is difficult to sympathize with her shock at learning that her backyard, too, might have been endangered by toxic nuclear waste. Her sudden conversion to activism is typical of an American tendency to underestimate the dangers of toxic industry until personal health or property interests are directly implicated.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE NURSE BY THE SEA - A gardener on Fire Island breaks out in hives. A plumber who lives on the barrier beach needs to have his blood pressure checked. A woman vacationing with her young son in Ocean Beach is worried about bug bites. They all wind up on the doorstep of the Nurse by the Sea.

title: TIPS FOR GETTING THE MOST OUT OF THE FAIR
description: Ideally, a visitor who wants to see Expo 86 without physical collapse would go for a little while and go often - meaning that a few hours a day for several weeks is the best way to see a fair spread over 173 acres of waterfront on two downtown Vancouver sites, with more than 80 pavilions and a daily attendance that is expected to reach 200,000 this summer.

title: MARLIN PERKINS, ZOOLOGIST AND TV HOST, DIES
description: R. Marlin Perkins, the zookeeper who became a household name as America's television safari guide on ''Wild Kingdom,'' died Saturday at his home in suburban St. Louis. Mr. Perkins, who had suffered from cancer of the lymphatic system for two years, was 81 years old.

title: ANNENBERG HONORED AT BALL
description: Walter H. Annenberg was honored for his patronage of the arts here last night as he received the annual Swan Award under the elegant, chandeliered tent at the 24th annual Swan Ball.

title: BERRY ADDS MYSTERY TO DRAFT
description: Walter Berry was the near-unanimous choice as the college player of the year last season and, in most years, the player winning that honor was among the top three choices in the National Basketball Association draft.

title: WHAT DO WE DO NEXT IN SPACE?
description: The recommendations of the President's shuttle commission are an important first step in the painstaking process that will ultimately put us back in space. They address vital concerns such as design flaws, communications and management procedures. Yet the report does not address the larger issue: ''Where does the space program go from here?''

title: PHONE RATE INCREASES FOUND BELOW DIRE PREDICTIONS OF '84
description: When the Bell telephone system was broken up two and a half years ago, some phone industry executives, government officials and consumer advocates predicted that local rates would double or even triple, forcing telephones out of many homes.

title: Plan for Gandhi Statue Getting Mixed Reception
description: Conceived by Mohandas K. Gandhi's great-grandnephew, Yogesh K. Gandhi, bankrolled by the Murjani fashion empire, and endorsed by the City Parks and Recreation Department, a statue of the Mahatma is now being planned for the southwest corner of Union Square Park.

title: Tuscan Dairy Farms Switches to Lempert
description: Lempert Advertising of Belleville, N.J., has been named the agency for the Tuscan Dairy Farms of Union, N.J., which means it will have the sweet assignment of making ads for Tuscan Pops ice cream and Tofu Pops as well as for Diet-Time low-fat yogurt and the RSVP line of frozen cakes and soups. The advertising was handled previously by Robert Graham & Associates, an agency at Union.

title: LIMBO FEELINGS AT PERRY ELLIS
description: Jay Meltzer, an apparel industry analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company, said he was getting tired of being asked whether Perry Ellis, the company, could survive the death of Perry Ellis, the designer.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE UNDERGROUND EMPIRE: Where Crime and Governments Embrace. By James Mills. 1,165 pages. Doubleday. $22.95.

title: A QUICK TRIP TO OMAHA? FOR $49, WHY NOT?
description: Maura and Alfred Dorigo of Secaucus, N.J., flew in here Saturday morning, stepped off the plane and gazed at the wide Nebraska sky. They had never visited the state before, knew no one in Omaha and had no business here.

title: THE EYES HAD IT
description: HOLE after hole on the back nine, Raymond Floyd's blue-green eyes seemed to be getting bigger and bigger. Playing with him, Payne Stewart noticed those eyes. And up near Shinneock Hills' old white-and-brown gabled clubhouse, Lanny Wadkins was talking about the new United States Open champion's eyes.

title: SHOPPING ADDICTION: ABUSED SUBSTANCE IS MONEY
description: Sandi Gostin, a 48-year-old divorced mother of two, is an addict. Her addiction is not drugs, gambling or alcohol but spending.

title: METROMEDIA'S MOVE SPARKS PUZZLEMENT
description: In the spring of 1982, John W. Kluge was remodeling Metromedia Inc., a company that he had gained control of 23 years earlier. A television station in Boston was being added to the company's already sizable stockpile of operations, which included radio and TV stations in several major cities, a large outdoor advertising concern, the Harlem Globetrotters basketball team and the Ice Capades.

title: Libya Says U.S. Plane Debris Has Been Found on Its Coast
description: Wreckage from a United States bomber that took part in the April 15 raid on Libya has washed ashore on the Libyan coast, the official press agency said today.

title: DIAMOND SCANDAL SHAKES ANTWERP
description: Office-supply shops here in the world's diamond capital have added a new item to their usual store of scales and magnifying glasses: paper-shredding machines.

title: Accounts
description: * Noxell Corporation to Lotas Minard Patton McIver for new products and new businesses.

title: Gen. Herbert Thatcher Dies; Led Air Defense Command
description: Herbert B. Thatcher, a retired lieutenant general and former commander of the Air Defense Command, died Wednesday of respiratory failure. He was 77 years old.

title: Meacham Asks Why
description: Bobby Meacham, the Yankees' erstwhile shortstop, took his demotion to Columbus calmly today, but he said he felt he was being ''singled out'' among the team's error-prone players.

title: MAP SOURCE: 38 degrees 53' NORTH, 77 degrees WEST
description: Politicians and bureaucrats here often seem to lose their way. But a case can be made that they really have no excuse. More maps are produced in the Washington area than perhaps any other place on earth.

title: Sanctions vs. Apartheid
description: A clear message resounds in recent surveys in South Africa in which more than 70 percent of blacks supported sanctions against the Government. Blacks are saying: ''We are suffering already. To end it, we will support sanctions, even if we have to take on additional suffering.''

title: People
description: * Jeffrey Adams has been named chief executive of Lowe Marschalk, San Francisco, replacing Daniel E. Cohen, who is returning to New York as an executive vice president.

title: 2 SQUEEZE BUNTS LIFT GIANTS
description: Robby Thompson drove in two runs with suicide-squeeze bunts, and Jeff Leonard, Chris Brown, and Chili Davis each had three hits today, enabling the San Francisco Giants to defeat the Houston Astros, 7-2.

title: A DISPUTE ON CLERGY IN PRISONS
description: Sister Hannah Daly is a Roman Catholic nun in St. Augustine who does not mince words when it comes to the officials who run Florida's prison system.

title: Gunmen Raid Village In Sri Lanka, Killing 12
description: Gunmen suspected of being Tamil separatists raided a village today in northeastern Sri Lanka and killed 12 local militiamen, residents said.

title: Still Caught in the Yellow Rain
description: Admitting error is hard for everyone, and apparently close to impossible for governments led out on a limb by flawed intelligence analysis. Such is the case with ''yellow rain,'' the alleged biological warfare agent the Reagan Administration repeatedly accused the Soviet Union of supplying for use in Southeast Asia.

title: Man Charged in Killing Of Capital Mayor's Aide
description: A man who confronted the police for several hours last month in an incident at his home was arrested today and charged with the slaying of a top aide to the re-election campaign of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. The suspect, Kenneth Dion Hubbard, 25 years old, of Washington, was arrested at 1:30 A.M. and charged with strangling Peggy Russell Gee, 55, who had scheduled campaign events.

title: MEXICO GAINS QUARTERFINALS
description: In a stadium ringed by gaudy plastic butterflies, Manuel Negrete was the smoothest being of all today. The graceful midfielder for Mexico scored one goal and set up a second as the host team defeated Bulgaria, 2-0, to reach the quarterfinals of the World Cup.

title: OUSTED AT PARISH IN MCCARTHY ERA
description: The Rev. William Howard Melish, the Episcopal priest whose political views led to his ouster from his Brooklyn parish in 1957, died of cancer yesterday at his home. He was 76 years old and lived in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn.

title: MSSM Loses a Client But Wins 3 New Ones
description: MSSM, which recently changed its name from Martin, Sturtevant, Silverman & Marshall, announced that three new accounts had brought in a total of $4 million in new billings.

title: OPERA: AGEE'S 'FAMILY' PERFORMED IN ST. LOUIS
description: In ''A Death in the Family,'' James Agee took a tale so ordinary that it hardly needs explication beyond its title, and wove through it an intense, swarming poetry of observation, infinite detail and boundless feeling. Any dramatic adaptation faces a fearful challenge, since almost everything that makes the book what it is must be pruned away, and its original power somehow evoked by carefully judged sampling or, if the adapatation is operatic, by music.

title: Treasury Bills Lead Heavy Activity
description: The credit markets this week have in store a heavy calendar of Treasury, municipal and corporate offerings.

title: Service for Alan Jay Lerner
description: A private burial service for the lyricist Alan Jay Lerner, who died Saturday, will be held today. The family requests that donations be sent to the American Cancer Society or the Patient Volunteer Program at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. A memorial service is planned, and the date and location will be announced.

title: ACTING ON A DEADLY STAGE: A DRUG AGENT'S LIFE IN DEEP COVER
description: Some drug traders first saw him as a heroin smuggler in Thailand. Others met him as a cocaine buyer in Buenos Aires. And others as a gunrunner in Buffalo.

title: The Moving Pen Writes
description: Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court seems to enjoy ferreting out and noting in his opinions what he considers inconsistencies in the positions of both his colleagues and the Justice Department.

title: Florida Drug Tip Line Termed a Success
description: Since Florida's drug tip phone line was installed last year, calls have come from nearly 1,000 people, and the United States Customs Service is calling the program a success.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CHERNOBYL CHIEFS OUSTED FOR ERRING DURING ACCIDENT
description: The director and chief engineer of the Chernobyl atomic power station have been dismissed for mishandling the disaster at the plant in April, and other top officials have been accused of failings ranging from negligence to desertion, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.

title: JAILED U.S. JUDGE RESISTS RESIGNING
description: Senator Paul Laxalt and other Nevadans are suggesting that Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne, now in Federal prison, resign rather than face an impeachment trial in the Senate. But the judge says he will not resign. Judge Claiborne, who last month began serving a two-year term for violating Federal income tax laws, is the first sitting Federal judge in the nation's history to be convicted of a felony, sentenced to prison and actually go to prison.

title: Nancy Gail Drexler Is Married to Steven Mendell
description: Nancy Gail Drexler, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Drexler of Melville, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Robert Mendell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Mendell of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y. Rabbi Darryl P. Crystal performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: RIVALS FOR SENATE DIFFER ON STRATEGY
description: John S. Dyson and Mark Green have barely started the formal primary campaign for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, but already they disagree on strategy, some issues, whether they should criticize each other and whether Mr. Dyson is a ''real Democrat'' or a ''closet Republican.''

title: Boy, 2, Hurt in 3-Story Fall
description: A 2-year-old boy fell from a third-floor bedroom window of his home in the New Dorp, S.I., yesterday afternoon, suffering severe head injuries, the police said.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 16, 1986:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In a Terry Cashman song saluting baseball history, there is a line about the Boston Red Sox that refers to ''Stephens's three hits in one inning.'' Did a Red Sox player ever manage such a feat? How many runs did the Red Sox score in the inning? (It's got to be at least 13.) Did they win the game?

title: A WELCOME BOOM IN KOREA
description: This nation's economy is booming again - welcome news for South Koreans who have weathered a year of economic downturn and months of political turmoil.

title: VERDICT MIGHT NOT LIFT VEIL FROM BLOODY DAY IN RADICAL ERA
description: Final arguments are to begin Monday in the murder trial of Stephen M. Bingham, a Connecticut-born son of privilege and wealth who is accused of touching off a bloody spasm of violence at San Quentin Prison 15 years ago.

title: HE IS NOT ARRESTED
description: A retired Brooklyn truck driver stabbed his son to death Saturday night in the heat of an argument in which the son physically abused his father and demanded money for drugs, the police said.

title: McALLEN, TEX., RIDES PESO'S BUMPS
description: Just as the good times in Mexico brought jobs and money to this small town eight miles north of the Rio Grande, so the bad times are making some McAllen residents rich.

title: Mayors' Tax Resolution
description: A U.S. Conference of Mayors committee urged Congress today to retain the income tax deduction for local sales taxes and called for a constitutional amendment to protect local tax sources.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Pregnancy Prevention
description: Babies born to single mothers are off to a bad start: they're four times more likely to grow up poor than children of two-parent households. If the mothers are very young, the odds are worse. That means that every year in New York City some 13,000 newborns start life behind.

title: Sarah Carmichael Becomes a Bride
description: Sarah Hamilton Isabella Carmichael, the daughter of Mrs. William Hood and Joel Carmichael of New York and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to Tracy Walter Sundlun, a son of Mrs. Madeleine Gimbel of Washington and Bruce G. Sundlun of Providence, R.I. Rabbi Alan Lew officiated at the ceremony at the home of the bride's father in Amagansett.

title: F.B.I., AFTER SHOOTOUT, ORDERS AGENTS TO USE VESTS
description: As a result of a shootout in which two agents were killed and five were wounded, Federal Bureau of Investigation officials say they will require agents to wear bulletproof vests when they are apprehending armed suspects.

title: MAKAROVA AND NUREYEV SET DATES WITH BALLET THEATER
description: Natalia Makarova and Rudolf Nureyev will appear as guest artists with the American Ballet Theater during the final weeks of its current spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House, which ends July 5, the company has announced. Miss Makarova will give her first performance tonight when she dances the adagio from the second act of ''Swan Lake,'' partnered with Mikhail Baryshnikov.

title: To Condemn Is Human
description: To the Editor:

title: A James Joyce Reading With an Unusual Sponsor
description: There is nothing odd, in an Upper West Side way, about assembling dozens of actors in a former skating rink at Broadway and 95th Street to have them read from James Joyce until 1 o'clock in the morning.

title: SWASTIKAS DEFACE ISRAELI SYNAGOGUE
description: Vandals smeared swastikas on a Tel Aviv synagogue today and ransacked two religious schools overnight, as the conflict between Orthodox militants and secular Jews reached new depths of bitterness.

title: Big-Time Yalie
description: Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, concedes there is a lot of talk in Washington about the budget balancing bill he helped to write. But in most of the country, he says, most people think Gramm Rudman Hollings was Vice President Bush's roommate at Yale.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. BOSTON RED SOX, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television -Channel 11, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: Falkland Islands Mark 4th Anniversary of War
description: The Falkland Islands celebrated the fourth anniversary today of the defeat of occupying Argentine forces by British troops.

title: POP: ROBERTO CARLOS SINGS
description: THE Brazilian pop star Roberto Carlos has an interestingly gritty voice and an impish stage personality that transcend the stereotypical image of the Latin American pop crooner as an unctuous peacock. The singer, who appeared at Radio City Music Hall on Friday evening, sings in Portuguese and in Spanish, and projects a point of view about love that is more suavely amused than starry-eyed.

title: SYRIANS ACT TO END DISPUTE IN LEBANON
description: Syrian troops moved into a town in southeastern Lebanon today in an effort to end factional fighting there, and in so doing moved closer to the border with Israel.

title: SOVIET TEAM LOSES, 4-3
description: The Soviet Union was one of the powerhouse teams in the first round of the World Cup. The Belgians, wracked by dissension and unable to hold leads, were considered lucky to have made the second round.

title: Pakistan Arrests 6 Sikhs
description: Six Canadian Sikhs have been arrested here and charged with attacking four Indian diplomats in a Sikh temple here last week, the police said today. They said the six men were arrested Saturday and would be tried by a court in Lahore, capital of Punjab Province, which borders India's Sikh-dominated northern state of Punjab.

title: OLD NEW YORK IS BEING UNEARTHED ON ELLIS ISLAND
description: Under the Great Hall on Ellis Island, the door through which millions of immigrants entered America, archeologists last year discovered the skeletons of two American Indians.

title: Pope Urges Restraint In South Africa Unrest
description: Pope John Paul II assailed racial discrimination today and urged South Africans to resist ''the temptation to hatred and violence.''

title: POLITICS SHAPING TRADE MOVES
description: Despite its laissez-faire, free-trade rhetoric, the Reagan Administration has recently taken special measures to help American farmers, lumber companies, machine tool makers, semiconductor producers and other groups battling foreign competition.

title: Vietnam Urges the U.S. To Cooperate in Search
description: Vietnam said today that the remains of 10 Americans could probably be found, and urged the United States to be ''really cooperative'' so that the fate of nearly 1,800 Americans listed as missing in Vietnam could be resolved.

title: IRANIAN REBEL MEETS IRAQI CHIEF
description: Massoud Rajavi, a leader of opposition to the Iranian regime, met President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today and received support for his movement, the Iraqi News Agency reported.

title: NEW YORK'S OLD 'SALT CITY' STRUGGLING TO OVERCOME SETBACKS
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation's soda ash plant has stood on the edge of this city for so many years that few residents can imagine the skyline without its smokestacks.

title: LINK IS SOUGHT AFTER SLAYING OF 2D RUSSIAN
description: A Russian immigrant shot dead in Brooklyn Friday night may have been slain in reprisal for the murder of another Russian immigrant last February in what the police call an increasingly violent rivalry among criminal elements in the Russian emigre community.

title: EUROPE'S NUCLEAR OUTLOOK NOW DIMMER
description: The nuclear disaster at Chernobyl has dimmed the prospects of the Western European companies that build plants to generate electricity from nuclear power.

title: Evacuees Go Home In Wake of Derailment
description: The 2,000 people forced to flee when a freight train derailed, exploded and dumped hazardous chemicals were back home today.

title: THE HILTON WILL IN COURT: HEIR FIGHTS FOUNDATION
description: When Conrad Nicholson Hilton, the hotel magnate, died seven years ago, he left an eloquent tribute to his philanthropic philosophy: charity, not his children, were to receive the bulk of his multimillion-dollar estate.

title: Catching Up
description: Steve Smith, the rookie defenseman whose errant pass bounced off his own goaltender and into the Edmonton net one night seven weeks ago in a decisive playoff game against Calgary, bringing the Oilers' budding dynasty to a halt, says he's now over the resulting trauma. But the recovery took some doing.

title: Chief Quits At Kaneb
description: Kaneb Services Inc., an energy company in Houston, said its president and chief executive officer, Michael G. Shoup, has resigned. The company said Friday that Kaneb's chairman, James R. Whatley, will serve in the vacated posts until a replacement is chosen.

title: YANKS STUMBLE OVER A ROLLER
description: To think that the Yankees came within a checked swing of sweeping a four-game series from the Baltimore Orioles behind the starting pitching of Alfonso Pulido, Bob Tewksbury, Dennis Rasmussen and Doug Drabek.

title: A MODEL AND A MURDER: ITALY'S HIGH LIFE ON TRIAL
description: Ever since she was a teen-ager in South Carolina dreaming of a modeling career, Terry Broome has wanted to be famous. Now she is photographed every day in a Milan courtroom, where she has admitted killing an Italian playboy and has spelled out the details of her cocaine addiction and her love affairs.

title: Israel Names Chief Banker
description: The Israeli cabinet named Michael Bruno today as the governor of the Bank of Israel, the country's central bank. He replaces Dr. Moshe Mandelbaum, who was forced to resign in the wake of a bank shares scandal.

title: Maryland Dean Taking Economist Post at G.M.
description: On July 1, George C. Eads will be moving from his post as dean of the School of Public Affairs at the University of Maryland to be chief economist for the General Motors Corporation.

title: HAITI'S ROAD TO RECOVERY IS BLOCKED BY PROTESTS AND FLOODS
description: The city had been isolated for several days by floods and roadblocks manned by political protesters when a gray army helicopter banked over the long rows of shanties and dusty shops and dropped down on a grassy goat pasture.

title: A Shell, Some Glass And a Real Fossil Find
description: Everything from a lobster shell to a 135 million-year-old dragonfly fossil turned up at the American Museum of Natural History on Saturday, when visitors were invited to bring with them objects that they could not identify.

title: Howard Enders Wed To Valerie M. Dushkin
description: Valerie M. Dushkin, a clinical social worker, was married yesterday to Howard Enders, a film maker and an associate professor of film at the State University of New York at Purchase. Eileen Ginsberg, Justice of the Peace in Norwalk, Conn., performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Westport, Conn.

title: Fed Backs Bank Unit
description: The Federal Reserve Board said Friday that it had approved the application of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. of London to start a subsidiary to offer investment advice and securities brokerage services to institutional customers. The application by the bank and its American subsidiary, Natwest Holdings Inc. of New York, was to establish the County Securities Corporation.

title: COMMODITY PRICES: NO REVIVAL IN SIGHT
description: After four straight monthly declines, the six-tenths of 1 percent increase in wholesale prices during May served as a reminder that inflation, or at least some semblance of it, is still with us.

title: Trump to Testify At U.S.F.L. Trial
description: The United States Football League is scheduled to finish arguing its antitrust case against the National Football League this week in Federal District Court, with Donald Trump and Al Davis among those expected to testify.

title: Bridge: World Simultaneous Pairs Won by Two From France
description: The first world simultaneous pairs championship, sponsored by Epson under the auspices of the World Bridge Federation, was won Saturday by two French players, Francis Frainais, 40 years old, and Jann Bouteille, 42. They live in a Paris suburb and are, appropriately from the sponsor's angle, computer engineers.

title: Loose-Cannon Crony
description: If you are a crony of the President, you will be forgiven any ethical transgression. We have seen that with Charles Wick of U.S.I.A. and his secret telephone recordings; we saw that in the reluctance to examine the nest-feathering of Michael Deaver; now let us look at the Case of the Envoy Who Cannot Be Touched.

title: Bus Crash Death Toll Now 21
description: A 70-year-old woman died in a hospital here Saturday of injuries suffered May 30 when a tour bus plunged into the Walker River, about 90 miles from here.

title: Homosexual Rally in Boston
description: A crowd estimated by the police at 30,000 marked Gay Pride Day here Saturday with a parade and a rally on Boston Common. An organizer, Sherene Aran, said it was the largest turnout since the event began in 1970. ''We came out to celebrate and see each other and to fight for our right to be on the street without being harassed,'' she said.

title: Miriam De Fant Becomes a Bride
description: Miriam Ann De Fant, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. De Fant of Marquette, Mich., was married yesterday to Daniel Carl Berlin, a son of Roslyn Berlin Solomon of Englewood, N.J., and the late Gerald F. Berlin of Teaneck, N.J. Rabbi Yechiael Lander, a chaplain at Smith College, performed the ceremony at the Red Barn at Hampshire College in Northampton, Mass.

title: TO DOLE, IT WAS AN EDUCATION TO GET PAST DISABILITY
description: Bob Dole spent 10 minutes one morning recently buttoning the second button on his shirt.

title: Andrea Brown Is Married To a Corporate Executive
description: Andrea Brown and Robert M. Levande were married yesterday at the Lotos Club. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: G.E. DIKES TOXIC CHEMICALS AT 5 SITES
description: General Electric has finished building underground clay dikes around five hazardous-waste sites in upstate New York, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: KOHL'S TEAM WINS IN STATE ELECTION
description: The two parties that make up Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition in Bonn won a slender victory today in a state election in Lower Saxony that was seen as an important barometer of national trends.

title: KEY SENATOR COOL TO SOUTH AFRICA SANCTIONS
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee says he is doubtful about the effectiveness of any additional economic sanctions against the Government of South Africa.

title: THE DANCE: KIROV TOUR CONCLUDES
description: ''Where are all the men?,'' a Canadian critic asked plaintively at a press conference called by the Kirov Ballet as the company prepared to end its first visit to North America in 22 years.

title: SCIENTISTS ARE PUZZLED BY DECLINE OF A RARE CANCER IN AIDS VICTIMS
description: Kaposi's sarcoma, the cancer that was one of the original clues to the existence of AIDS, is mysteriously declining in its prominence among patients with the deadly disease.

title: MORE REPORTS ON SOVIET SPY PLANE
description: Airline officials who work at Augusto Cesar Sandino International Airport here say they have seen a Soviet plane that they believe has been conducting aerial reconnaisance on behalf of the Sandinista Government.

title: FLOYD, OLDEST TO CAPTURE OPEN, WINS BY TWO
description: Raymond Floyd, who felt at age 43 that time was running out on his chances, birdied three of the last eight holes today and became the oldest man to win a United States Open championship.

title: MEMORIALIZING PEACE
description: If you want to memorialize a person or event, Washington has long been the place to put your statue.

title: Protestants and Police Clash in Ulster Town
description: Protestant youths rampaged through a Catholic neighborhood early today, prompting fights with the police.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: U.S. ENVOY OUTLINING POLICY FOR PANAMA
description: The United States Ambassador here will deliver a formal definition of American policy on Panama to the Government here on Monday, according to an American Embassy spokesman, after charges in Washington that the head of the Panamanian Army is a drug dealer, money launderer and occasional spy for Cuba.

title: KOCH SAYS WORK IS STILL GOING ON DESPITE SCANDAL
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that while he was saddened by the resignation under pressure of a top adviser, Victor E. Botnick, he was not depressed and was moving to carry out a series of initiatives.

title: Ammirati, Fund Part
description: Ammirati & Puris announced late last week that it and the Oppenheimer Fund, which became a client in 1983, had split by ''mutual agreement.'' No one at either company could be reached to flesh out those bare bones.

title: IT'S CURTAINS FOR A CUB
description: ON Friday afternoon, John Christopher Vukovich was about to enter the manager's office for his first post-game interview as manager of the Cubs when he was met by the assistant general manager, John Cox.

title: CONTRAS SAY THEY FEAR A LONG WAR
description: A protracted guerrilla war in Nicaragua would work to the advantage of the Sandinista Government, according to five combat field commanders of the anti-Government insurgent forces.

title: Funeral for Benny Goodman
description: Family and close friends gathered in a private ceremony this afternoon to bury Benny Goodman, the ''King of Swing'' jazz. The bandleader was buried beside his wife in Long Ridge Union Cemetery in a 20-minute nonsectarian service attended by about 40 mourners. Mr. Goodman died Friday of a heart attack in his Manhattan apartment at the age of 77.

title: UPTOWN SWELL WINS BY NOSE
description: Uptown Swell swept to the lead in midstretch and then held off Palace Panther in the final stride by a head to win the $223,650 Bowling Green Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: HOW FAST, HOW FAR? NO LIMITS IN SIGHT
description: HOW fast is fast? It depends on whom you listen to.

title: ANDRETTI GIVES DAD MORE THAN NECKTIE
description: Mario Andretti caught his son Michael, who had run out of fuel, at the finish line today for the closest victory in Indy-car history in the Budweiser Portland 200.

title: 3 Die on a Roller Coaster
description: The last car on a triple loop roller coaster at a huge indoor shopping center here derailed Saturday evening, dumping four passengers to the concrete below. The police said three people died and up to 15 were injured.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The problem of our country cannot be solved by locking up people.

title: Religion Has a Place in American History
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBINS FOUND IN CONTEMPT
description: A Federal judge on Saturday found the A. H. Robins Company in contempt of court for illegally paying more than $21 million in debts it had incurred before filing for protection under United States bankruptcy law.

title: Bossier Bank Is Taken Over
description: The Bossier Bank and Trust Company of Bossier City, La., has been taken over as a branch of the First of National Bank of Shreveport, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said Friday.

title: METS TOP PIRATES TWICE, RUN WINNING STREAK TO 6
description: Gone are the days when the banners were paraded across Shea Stadium once a year imploring heaven to help the Mets, to preserve and protect them from the bullies of baseball. Now the Mets are the bullies of baseball, and 2,483 banners reflected that change of fortune yesterday afternoon while the Mets were hammering the Pittsburgh Pirates in both ends of a doubleheader.

title: Briefcases
description: President Reagan, at ceremonies Wednesday at the White House Rose Garden, will make private-sector initiative awards to 30 businesses and associations that have put into effect projects ranging from drug abuse education and increased public awareness of missing children to community economic revitalization and job training.

title: LIFE OF SHAME OF AMPUTEES IN THE SUDAN
description: ''I still wrap it,'' said John Ruben, 19 years old, as he held up the stump where his right hand had been, the limb hidden by a dingy cloth. ''My hand was cut off in September 1984 but it is still very painful. The authorities just cut it and bandaged it and sent me to find my own treatment. It is very difficult to get used to. People always look down on me.''

title: Omega Parent to Use Local Agencies for Ads
description: Although S.M.H., the Swiss watch maker, is a multinational company, it has decided to do its advertising country by country through local agencies. In Paris, it has already retained HCM.

title: 92d Street Y Announces Artists for 50th Season
description: The pianists Alexis Weissenberg, Earl Wild, Shura Cherkassky and Misha Dichter, the violinists Henryk Szeryng and Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, and the cellist Sharon Robinson will be among the guest artists in the 92d Street Y's 1986-87 season, the 50th-anniversary season of performing arts at the center. Two duos - the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the pianist Emanuel Ax, and the soprano Judith Blegen and the baritone Hakan Hagegard -will be heard in concerts.

title: INKSTER IS WINNER
description: Juli Inkster parred the first hole of a three-way playoff today to win her second straight Lady Keystone Open and her second L.P.G.A. title in two weeks.

title: IN ASHES, A CHURCH LIVES ON
description: It has been six days since a four-alarm fire roared through the Holy Angels Roman Catholic Church, destroying the 90-year-old edifice that once excluded blacks but has since become the center of the largest black parish in the Chicago archdiocese.

title: A FEDERAL JURY FINDS 2 BROTHERS GUILTY OF FRAUD
description: Two brothers who head a chemical trading business based in Mount Vernon, N.Y., have been convicted by a Federal jury here of fraudulently shipping hazardous and impure chemicals to a company in Zimbabwe that had ordered pure chemicals under a United States aid program.

title: ADDITIONAL DECLINES IN RATES SEEN
description: A spate of weak economic data for May has again convinced the credit markets that the way is open for further declines in interest rates this summer.

title: CABLE'S 'MAELSTROM,' A SIX-PART GOTHIC TALE
description: BILLED as a thriller, a six-part drama series called ''Maelstrom'' gets under way tonight at 8 on cable's Arts & Entertainment Network. Produced in 1984 by Vere Lorrimer for the British Broadcasting Corporation, it is not a typical British import. There are no period costumes or settings. There are no familiar faces from the standard repertory company that supplies so much of British television with so many impressive performances. In fact, except for the few opening scenes, the story doesn't even take place in England or an appropriate vestige of what was once the British Empire. ''Maelstrom'' was shot on location in Norway and, if nothing else, the scenic splendor should quicken the pulses of travel agents.

title: Knuckling Down
description: Tommy Joe Shimp is a 29-year-old right-hander who's been wandering around the minor leagues for 10 years, and under ordinary circumstances he very likely would have become a forgotten player by now. Instead, he's under scrutiny this season because of a rare kind of experiment being conducted by the Texas Rangers, who have asked Shimp and three of their other minor-league pitchers to become knuckleballers and have told them not to worry about such things as records and earned-run averages: For this year and next, the four subjects are assured of not being released.

title: Noteworthy Holtz
description: Seven memorable things that Lou Holtz has already said since arriving at Notre Dame, even before coaching his first game there:

title: REGIONAL DISCONTENT THREATENS TO SET BACK THE SOCIALISTS IN MADRID
description: A bomb was found under the stage when Felipe Gonzalez campaigned in this Basque capital four years ago. A political protest of another sort was found when the Prime Minister returned to campaign Saturday night.

title: Amy Leicher Marries Barrett Price in Jersey
description: Amy Beth Leicher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour J. Leicher of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Barrett Jody Price, a son of Vincent Barrett Price of Albuquerque, N.M., and the late Sandra Greenwald, were married yesterday at White Meadow Lake Country Club in Rockaway, N.J. Rabbi Z. David Levy of Morristown, N.J., officiated.

title: COMMERCIAL SATELLITE VENTURE BY CHINA AND U.S. PROPOSED
description: Chinese and American experts are studying a proposal to launch American satellites aboard Chinese-made rockets from a commercial space center in Hawaii, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: Chip Fisher Wed To Susan S. Stix
