description: Susan Sherwin Stix, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Thomas Howard Stix of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Avery Fisher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Avery Fisher of New York and Washington, Conn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Edward Feld in the garden of Prospect House at Princeton University.

title: Scouts Propose to Sell New Jersey Woodland
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Nimock Is Married To Campbell D. McLaren
description: Susan Nimock, the daughter of Jacqueline S. Nimock of Rye, N.Y., and Campbell David McLaren, a son of Janet McLaren of Indianapolis and Stirling, Scotland, and the late Alan McLaren, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Dr. Avra Goldman Marries A Ph.D.-M.D. Candidate
description: Dr. Avra Goldman and Steven Greenberg were married yesterday at the Wellesley College Club in Wellesley, Mass. Rabbi Marjorie Yudkin officiated.

title: CURB ON LOANS TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Bank of America, the nation's second-largest bank, has decided to end all lending to borrowers in South Africa until the system of racial separation known as apartheid is dismantled.

title: New Issue Tied To Price of Oil
description: The Standard Oil Company of Ohio yesterday announced plans to issue the first securities units tied to the price of oil.

title: 3 in a New Chief Office At Kodak
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has announced the formation of an office of the chief executive and a revision of the company's operations into five business groups.

title: Perceiving South Africa
description: South Africa must be the most thoroughly studied country on earth. Statesmen and scholars of all kinds have had their say. But there has been nothing like the Commonwealth mission to South Africa, just concluded. Its work and its findings carry special weight.

title: Arlene Selvern Is Married To J.F. Gordon in Roslyn
description: Arlene Margot Selvern, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murray E. Selvern of New Hyde Park, L.I., and Philmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joel F. Gordon, a son of Alexander Gordon of Harrisburg, Pa., and the late Dyna Gordon. Rabbi Daniel Isaak performed the ceremony at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Oregon Climber Is Released
description: A 16-year-old student who survived a sudden snowstorm and freezing temperatures while climbing Mount Hood last month has been released from a hospital. The student, Brinton Clark, who was released Friday, was on a school outing with 12 others when a blizzard came. Nine people died.

title: DESPITE SUPPORT, NORMAN COLLAPSES
description: They surrounded Greg Norman as he left the clubhouse today. Piranhas attacking the Great White Shark? ''Greg, your autograph, please.'' ''Greg, I've been trying to get you to sign my cap all week.'' ''Go get 'em, Shark.'' Norman, who on Saturday berated a fan who had needled him with a remark about ''choking,'' suddenly found himself basking in fan adulation and his native Australia's support as he entered the final round of the United States Open with a one-stroke lead. He even had a police escort.

title: Icahn's T.W.A. Aide Cites Gains at ACF
description: Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, has been a harsh critic of American corporate management. Now he has installed his own man, D. Joseph Corr, to run T.W.A. and it will be up to Mr. Corr to make the ailing airline work and prove Mr. Icahn right.

title: The Europe That Kurt Waldheim Grew Up In
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeffrey Kessler Is Married To Wendy Lisabeth Starr
description: Wendy Lisabeth Starr, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Starr of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and Jeffrey Roy Kessler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kessler of New York, were married yesterday at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. and Cantor Joseph Boardman officiated.

title: MUSIC: DELIBAB ENSEMBLE
description: FOR many people, Hungarian folk music is synonymous with the image of a gypsy violinist strolling through a restaurant and playing florid solos. But as the Delibab Folk Music Ensemble, a group from Debrecen, in eastern Hungary, demonstrated in a Saturday concert at the Washington Square Church, traditional Hungarian instrumental music has an unusually rich palette, with the violin only the leading voice in music with the vibrancy and mystically melancholic flavor one also finds in Eastern European chamber music.

title: CITY BALLET: 'GERSHWIN CONCERTO'
description: THE New York City Ballet emphasizes repertory rather than virtuosic star performances.

title: An Issue of Logos Robert McG. Thomas Jr.
description: Larry Fleisher, general counsel of the National Basketball Players Association, sees the logo dispute as a civil-rights issue, one in which a cherished freedom is at stake: a player's inalienable right to life, liberty and the socks of his choice.

title: 8 More Die in Search For Plane in Canada
description: A Canadian Forces plane crashed in mountains in western Alberta and all eight people aboard died, officials said today. It was the second fatal air accident during a nine-day search for a missing light aircraft.

title: A Guilty Society
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVING IN TWO WORLDS, BY AND FOR DESIGN
description: ''A lot of people don't understand what design is,'' Adele Chatfield-Taylor said the other day in her Washington office. ''Every single thing you encounter in your environment is design, whether it is the chair or the hat or the city or the newspaper or the can of soup. You can avoid some art forms - opera for instance - but be it good or bad design, you can't avoid design.''

title: POSTAL INSPECTORS' NO-FRILLS UNIT HANDLES BIG CASES
description: Some of the most significant criminal cases on Wall Street are investigated by a small team of postal inspectors working out of a no-frills office on the fringe of the financial district in lower Manhattan.

title: 'THE LADY NEXT DOOR,' FROM 'PROJECT LIBERTY'
description: ALTHOUGH most black people came to this country in chains from Africa rather than in steerage from Europe - and many were here long before the great waves of immigration early in this century - they are represented in an hourlong WCBS/Channel 2 documentary tonight at 10 called ''The Lady Next Door,'' another Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island program. Mention is also made, though without their participation, of American Indians, who were here ahead of everybody.

title: Justice Under Scrutiny
description: In the wake of the Administration's narrow defeat in the Supreme Court in its effort to curb abortions, public television will broadcast an hourlong special early next month maintaining that the Justice Department has become highly politicized under Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, possibly to the detriment of evenhanded enforcement of the law.

title: CHINESE TOMB FOUND TO BE VICTIM OF GRAVE ROBBERS
description: An ancient nobleman's tomb that archeologists had described as one of the most significant discoveries ever made here has been opened and found to be virtually empty, apparently because a gang of grave-robbing gamblers made off with its contents at least 700 years ago.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN REBELS MEET WITH A TOP AFRIKANER
description: Senior members of the African National Congress held a clandestine meeting on Long Island this month with the leader of the Afrikaner Broederbond, a secretive South African society that includes most, if not all, of the leaders of the Pretoria Government, according to some who were present.

title: Teasury's Presence at Parley
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and Deputy Secretary Richard G. Darman have reconsidered and probably will not go to a privately sponsored monetary conference June 28-29 in Zurich, according to others in the Administration.

title: REAGAN SAID TO ASK SOVIET TO ACT ON SUMMIT
description: President Reagan sent a message to Mikhail S. Gorbachev two weeks ago calling on the Soviet leader to reschedule a meeting between the two countries' Foreign Ministers to work out arrangements for a summit meeting this year, a high-level Administration official said Saturday night.

title: VIRGINIAN DEFENDS PAYING CONGRESSMEN WHO TOURED COAL MINES
description: Representative Frederick C. Boucher, Democrat of Virginia, has defended arranging a trip for 14 House Democrats to a Virginia coal company to tour mines, discuss energy issues and receive $2,000 each in honorariums.

title: Move the Mail, or the Postal Service
description: Who is not angered by mail that takes three days to cross town - and mail rates that climb even as service deteriorates? The Post Office so often fails its own delivery standards that Representative Bill Green of Manhattan is ready to smash its monopoly, at least for first-class mail in major cities.

title: Dorothy Gilbert Marries
description: Dorothy Leslie Gilbert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel F. Gilbert of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to David Philip Goldstone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Goldstone of Brooklyn. Rabbi Max D. Rothschild officiated at the picnic house in Prospect Park. The bride, a graduate of Radcliffe College, heads program development for Daniel Wilson Productions, a television and motion picture production company in New York. Mr. Goldstone, a graduate of the State University of New York at Syracuse, is an assistant construction supervisor for the Parks Department.

title: Hospital Corp. Chooses Ogilvy
description: After a far-ranging search for an ad agency, the Hospital Corporation of America, based in Nashville, has decided on Ogilvy & Mather and will be served by its three-month-old health care unit.

title: Washington Watch; Polish View On New Loans
description: Although Poland has just become the 151st member of the International Monetary Fund and will soon join the World Bank as well, the Warsaw Government is unlikely to draw any money from either institution this year.

title: LATIN DEBTORS AWAIT MEXICO PACT AS GUIDE
description: Latin American debtor nations are hoping to benefit from any special concessions given to get Mexico out of its financial crisis, according to foreign bankers and regional officials.

title: Advertising; British Car Is Agency's First Client
description: THE Grace & Rothschild advertising agency, founded three months ago by a pair of creative stars from Doyle Dane Bernbach, has just announced its first client: Range Rover of North America, which will be selling high-priced, British-made, four-wheel-drive station wagons to affluent drivers who may never go off the road but want to know they could.

title: More Can Be Done With Inmate Work Program
description: To the Editor:

title: IN CHINA, A NEW '100 FLOWERS' DRIVE
description: Chinese intellectuals who associate the ''Hundred Flowers'' campaign of 1956 with the Communist Party's most notorious betrayal of the principle of intellectual freedom have been faced with a new version of the campaign in the past few weeks. The new version comes complete with the slogan that continues to chill many of those who were punished for speaking out 30 years ago.

title: AMNESTY CONCERT IN JERSEY
description: A two-week, six-city, all-star tour to benefit Amnesty International wound up with a celebratory 11-hour concert today at Giants Stadium. A potential audience in the millions watched on MTV and tuned in to radio broadcasts of the concert across the United States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ampal-American Israel Corporation, a subsidiary of Bank Hapoalim B.M., named Michael Arnon president and chief executive, replacing Ephraim Reiner, who resigned, effective July 1.

title: IN PITCHING ROTATIONS, IT'S DAZZLE VS. FRAZZLE
description: IF a psychologist played a word-association game with a baseball fan and said ''Boston pitching,'' the fan most likely would say ''Roger Clemens.'' If the psychologist said ''Yankees' pitching,'' the fan likely would laugh. If the phrase were ''Yankees' starting rotation,'' the fan might not be able to stop laughing long enough to ask, ''What rotation?''

title: 'ADULT' MAGAZINES LOSE SALES AS 8,000 STORES FORBID THEM
description: More than 8,000 convenience stores around the country have removed ''adult'' magazines from their shelves since the beginning of this year, according to distributors, and the magazines' sales are suffering.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CROSS-CULTURAL 'ANT'

title: AIRLINE HEADS WERE ALLOWED TO TAPE U.S. REPORT
description: Federal officials informally gave Continental Airlines a draft report on findings of safety violations at the airline, according to a Continental vice president.

title: INJURY STOPS CONNORS IN 2D SET OF FINAL
description: Tim Mayotte gained his second career tournament victory today, one that also may cost Jimmy Connors his chance at Wimbledon.

title: PREHN EDGES DANE IN 156-MILE RACE
description: Thomas Prehn of Boulder, Colo., gave himself an early wedding present today. In a tingling sprint to the wire, he beat 36-year-old Jorgen Marcussen of Denmark in the CoreStates United States professional cycling championship. He won the 156-mile race by 5 yards.

title: Tribute to Immigrants Set for Public Library
description: A tribute to immigrants is planned with the opening of exhibitions on the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island this Saturday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. Several hundred items, ranging from bronze models to engravings, are included in ''Liberty: The French-American Statue in Art and History,'' which will be on view through Aug. 30 on the main floor.

title: Bonner Fails to Reach Moscow as She Pledged
description: Yelena G. Bonner failed to arrive in Moscow from Gorky today, after telling friends of her plans to return.

title: Rona Woldenberg Wed To Dr. Burt Greenberg
description: Rona Fern Woldenberg, a fourth-year medical student at the University of Pennsylvania, and Dr. Burt Greenberg, a chief resident in plastic surgery at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital, were married yesterday at the Plaza. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated assisted by Cantor Abraham Davis.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1986
description: International

title: BECK RECALLS HELP FROM FLOYD'S FATHER
description: The final hours of the 86th United States Open today brought to the leader board a constantly changing cast: Norman, Sutton, Trevino, Crenshaw, Floyd, Tway, Stewart.

title: Market Place; Speculating In Warrants
description: PEOPLE pay scant attention these days to the old-fashioned warrant - a venturesome vehicle that gives holders the right to buy a stock at a set price within a specified period.

title: ON THE FERRY, A 25-CENT RIDE AND A GLIMPSE OF THE LADY, TOO
description: Mary and Bob Johnson of Greenwich Village viewed yesterday's outing on the Staten Island Ferry as a potential civics lessons for their son and an opportunity to view the Statue of Liberty in advance of Liberty Weekend, when they intend to flee the hullabaloo for their country home in Connecticut.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1986
description: The Economy Further declines in interest rates this summer are seen in light of weak economic data for May, but a discount rate cut by the Fed may hinge on Japan and West Germany acting first. [ Page D1. ]

title: W.R.G./East President
description: Richard V. Hopple, 39 years old, is joining Wells, Rich, Greene Worldwide as president of W.R.G./East, replacing Ronald K. Sherman, 53, who has been named vice chairman for development. Mr. Hopple is a senior vice president, account group director and board member at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles. A 1959 Northwestern alumnus, he worked at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample before joining Benton & Bowles in 1972.

title: URUGUAYAN VISITS U.S. WITH TRADE AS TOP ISSUE
description: On a recent trip to Egypt President Julio Maria Sanguinetti asked the manager of the Hotel Luxor where the hotel bought its beef.

title: THE LIVES AND TIMES OF A COUPLE OF BALLETOMANES
description: ''Have you seen the Bronislava Nijinska exhibit at Cooper-Hewitt?'' Miriam Pellman asked a friend. ''We hope to go tomorrow, after the American Ballet Theater rehearsal.'' Her week also included three days of volunteer work for the New York City Ballet, and two performances by the company. Mrs. Pellman and her husband, Edwin, are balletomanes.

title: 2 Big Award Events: International and Clio
description: Two award events were held last week: the Clios at the Waldorf-Astoria on Friday and the International Advertising Festival of New York in the Sheraton Centre on Thursday. Both are private, profit-making operations that have gotten so big that they give out print and radio awards at an event separate from their television prizes.

title: NORMAN LEAR STARTS OFF MUSEUM LECTURE SERIES
description: Almost a decade after ''All in the Family'' and its offspring ''Good Times,'' ''Maude'' and ''The Jeffersons'' left prime-time television, the impact of those shows and their creator, Norman Lear, will be the subject this week of a television retrospective at the Museum of Broadcasting.

title: NEW BRITISH STUDY: THE NORMAL NEED NOT APPLY
description: Here in Britain, where eccentricity has long been recognized as an established fringe of the social fabric, a scientific study of what it is all about is under way.

title: BOGGS IS REINJURED IN LOSS TO BREWERS
description: Robin Yount and Ben Oglivie each hit two-run homers and run-scoring doubles today to power the Milwaukee Brewers to a 7-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: KIROV MAY STAGE U.S. WORKS
description: Ballets from American companies, and specifically ballets by George Balanchine, may be performed for the first time by the Kirov Ballet in Leningrad, Oleg Vinogradov, the Kirov's artistic director, has announced.

title: The U.N. Today; June 16, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3:30 P.M. on complaint by Angola against South Africa.

title: ABORTION CLASH IN DENVER
description: Their paths crossed little, if at all, and when they spoke to each other, it was generally through reporters. But the National Right to Life Committee and the National Organization for Women, separated by about six blocks and a world view, transformed this city into a vast debating hall over the weekend. The topic was abortion. Each group was here for its annual convention and each asserted that political momentum was on its side. Dr. John C. Willke, president of the National Right to Life Committee, said there was a ''tidal'' movement in the country against legal abortion, despite ''wishful thinking down the street.'' Eleanor Smeal, president of the National Organization for Women, countered, ''The more attention they call to this issue, the more our numbers will just multiply.''

title: OUTDOORS: THE LURE OF THE BASS
description: ALTHOUGH some passionate trout anglers scarcely recognize their existence, the black basses, largemouth and smallmouth, are regarded by many as the supreme fresh-water game fishes.

title: BETWEEN CARETAKER AND PARENT
description: THEY are the ultimate hybrids: part of the family and yet apart; parental figures but not parents; friendly but not familiar, necessary invaders of privacy and space. They are the caretakers, the people that parents, mostly women, hire to mind their children at home during the day. For both parent and caretaker, the relationship can be an awkward one.

title: Publication Focusing on Fed
description: With all the changes in policy and personnel at the Federal Reserve, a need might be there for a publication dealing with nothing but that. So Paul Weaver, a former Fortune magazine reporter here, is starting a publication called Fed Fortnightly. Economists whose support he has been soliciting say Mr. Weaver wants to concentrate on Fed policies, not on the technical esoterica that is the fodder of Wall Street newsletters.

title: KILLINGS CONTINUE AS PRETORIA GIRDS FOR ANNIVERSARY
description: South African authorities reported unabated bloodshed today as the nation braced for the 10th anniversary on Monday of the Soweto uprising.

title: Jeffrey K. Elsner Married To Jacqueline S. Hermann
description: Jacqueline Simone Hermann and Jeffrey K. Elsner were married yesterday at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y. Rabbi James Perman officiated. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Hermann of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Elsner of Eastchester, N.Y.

title: PIANO: MONICA JAKUC RECITAL
description: THE pianist Monica Jakuc devoted her entire recital at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday night to Bach's ''Goldberg'' Variations. On first thought, this might seem a limited program for a debut; in fact, it was anything but.

title: ISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Crime Control
description: Crime Control Inc. said it had agreed to be acquired by the National Guardian Corporation for about $60 million.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LADIES' MILE More than 65 years after it ceased to flourish, New York's Ladies' Mile is back in the news, and in fashion, in ''Ladies' Mile,'' a new exhibition that opens today in the upper gallery of the Fashion Institute of Technology, 27th Street and Seventh Avenue (760-7848).

title: For West Side Principal, 20 Is a 'Neat' Number
description: In his 20 years as principal of the Adolph Ochs Public School 111, Dr. Jerome Green has seen many changes in the neighborhood. including its name.

title: GUIDRY LOSES 6TH IN ROW AS CLEMENS SOARS TO 12-0
description: As Roger Clemens added another impressive line to his remarkable 1986 record last night, Ron Guidry added another major question mark to his perplexing 1986 record. Guidry offered Clemens no real opposition in his briefest outing of the season, extending the worst losing streak of his career to six games.

title: VALUE OF STRICTER CURRICULUMS IS QUESTIONED
description: A recent study by the Massachusetts Department of Education concludes that the imposition of strict new course requirements for high school graduation by itself will not improve a student's education, and might even increase the dropout rate.

title: RYKOFF-SEXTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
WILTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CITY HALL INTERNS GET A BAPTISM BY SCANDAL
description: When the 19 government interns began their jobs with the Koch administration last September, some were optimistic about careers in public service, and others arrived with questions and doubts.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-Net income. The latest 9-month period includes an after-tax provision for restructuring of $14,795,000.

title: Bayer Chemicals Unit Names Chief Executive
description: The Mobay Corporation, the big United States chemical arm of Bayer A.G., has named Nick H. Prater president and chief executive, the company announced yesterday.

title: BATTLES PAST AND FUTURE BLEND AT NOW'S PARLEY
description: The National Organization for Women held a historical T-shirt contest at its annual convention here last weekend, as part of the celebration of its 20th anniversary. Members showed up in faded shirts that were resonant of past battles, won and lost.

title: PRESENCE ON MADISON AVE.
description: Bonni Keller was on Madison Avenue last week surveying the capital of her domain.

title: REAGAN BARS TIES TO AFGHAN REBELS
description: President Reagan, in a meeting with Afghan rebel leaders today, turned down their request that the United States extend diplomatic recognition and sever relations with the Soviet-backed Afghan Government, the White House said.

title: OHRBACH'S TO CLOSE ITS DOORS
description: The 12 Ohrbach's apparel stores are to be discontinued after 24 years of ownership by the Amcena Corporation, the American arm of the Brenninkmeyer interest of the Netherlands.

title: Market Place; Hospital Issues Struggling On
description: STOCKS of hospital management companies have failed to climb aboard the bull market bandwagon this year. This was borne home anew to investors yesterday when Humana Inc., an industry leader with a steady string of profit gains over the past decade, traded at a 52-week low of 24 3/4 before closing at 25 1/4, down 1/8.

title: JOHN W. CHRISTENSEN
description: John W. Christensen, a former vice president of CBS Laboratories in Stamford, Conn., a subsidiary of the broadcasting company, died of a heart condition last Thursday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: WILLIAMS ACQUITTED IN TULANE SCANDAL
description: John (Hot Rod) Williams was acquitted tonight of taking part in a sports- bribery scheme that had caused Tulane University to abandon its men's basketball program and kept Williams's professional basketball career on hold for a year.

title: COURT SILENT ON BUDGET ACT
description: On Sunday, ABC News reported that the Supreme Court ''will announce tomorrow that a key provision of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction law is unconstitutional.''

title: ACCUSED OF PLOT AGAINST INDIA
description: A provincial court in Hamilton, Ontario, ordered today that seven Sikhs charged with conspiring to commit violent crimes in India be held until a bail hearing on Thursday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Fleet Aerospace Corp. said Aeronca Inc. had accepted its improved offer of $6 a share and had agreed to be acquired by a Fleet subsidiary.

title: Study Predicts a Slump In the State's Economy
description: Without structural economic changes, New York State will continue to lag behind many other states in productivity and employment and see its strength eroded in foreign markets for the remainder of the century, according to a study submitted to Governor Cuomo today.

title: VATICAN SAYS O'CONNOR'S TRIP IS TO SHORE UP THE CHRISTIANS
description: The Vatican said today that John Cardinal O'Connor's visit to Lebanon was not part of a Holy See peace mission to the country, but was designed to show solidarity with the country's besieged Maronite Christians.

title: New York's Welfare, and the Mayor's
description: The departure of George Gross from the Human Resources Administration and of Victor Botnick from the Health and Hospitals Corporation present Mayor Koch with a rare opportunity - to demonstrate that he is not paralyzed by the municipal scandals.

title: SCHOOLS EASE CURBS ON DRUG AND WEAPON CHECKS
description: Scores of school districts in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, hoping to deter students from using drugs or carrying weapons, have written new policies that make it easier for administrators to search desks, lockers and the students themselves.

title: OPEC Output Rise Reported
description: Oil output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is heading toward a two-and-a-half-year high of 19 million barrels a day as several of its members, mainly in the Middle East, raise their production above agreed limits, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly reported today. The authoritative oil industry newsletter said in its latest issue that Iran and Iraq were raising their volumes despite the Persian Gulf war, and that Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Libya were also contributing to the upsurge. The latest output estimate is far higher than the overall ceiling of 16.3 million barrels a day for the current quarter agreed to by OPEC ministers only two months ago.

title: COMARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest first quarter results reflect the inclusion of operations from two companies purchased late last year. The results have been restated to reflect the change to a Jan. 31 fiscal year. The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 6, 1986.

title: UNITED TELECONTROL ELECRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
Manhattan Boy Found Slain
description: A 14-year-old Manhattan boy was found stabbed to death shortly before midnight last night at West 46th Street and the West Side Highway by several of his friends who had been roller-skating with him on 12th Avenue and 54th Street near his home an hour earlier. The police, who withheld the boy's name, said he had suffered three stab wounds to the head and neck. The police said there was no apparent motive for the slaying.

title: The Ignorance About Hunger Is Mostly in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: SPACE-AGE METHODS PENETRATE ART OF THE PAST
description: THE same computer-based image processing that brought the rings of Saturn into vividly detailed view as well as other modern techniques are giving art historians a new look at the legacy of the great masters.

title: KEY FLAWS CITED AT VANDENBERG SHUTTLE SITE
description: The new shuttle launching facilities at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California are suffering ''significant technical and structural problems'' that could prevent their use for shuttle launches until July 1989, according to a report prepared for Senator James Sasser, the ranking Democrat on the Senate subcommittee on military construction.

title: COKE TO BUY BEATRICE BOTTLING UNIT
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase a major Coke bottling system from the Beatrice Companies for about $1 billion.

title: Murchison Debt Accord
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge consented today to a reorganization plan for the debts of Clinton W. Murchison Jr., a Texas oil executive and founder of the Dallas Cowboys football team.

title: Ford's Brazil Chief Gains Truck Post
description: The Ford Motor Company yesterday announced a new general manager for its truck operations and a new director of company research.

title: OPPENHEIMER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
INSTALLATION AND REPAIRS TOP PHONE PROBLEMS
description: The nation's telephone service is gradually recovering from the confusion that followed the breakup of the Bell System two and half years ago, according to industry and government officials and consumer groups.

title: From Home to Speakeasy To Bar to Landmark
description: To find the Federal-style house that James Brown built in 1817, one has to look for the Ear Inn, a funky-style neighborhood joint.

title: Popular Host
description: John V. Lindsay, the former mayor, is not intimately identified with the New York Democratic Party -he joined it just before he decided to run for President in 1972.

title: TRITON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Includes a loss of $293,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $365,000. c-Includes a gain of $77,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $2,769,000.

title: CUOMO ASKS THAT LILCO PAY ALL SHOREHAM COSTS
description: Governor Cuomo proposed revised legislation today to bar the Long Island Lighting Company from charging its customers for the Shoreham nuclear power plant if it never goes into operation.

title: SOME LIGHT ON WEAPON TERMINOLOGY
description: In arguments over the merits of retaining or scrapping the 1979 treaty on strategic arms, the precise meanings of key words and phrases are often lost or deliberately obscured.

title: Addendum
description: * Grey Advertising acquired Berland S.A. de C.V., Mexico City, and will merge it with Ideas y Hechos/Grey to form Grey Mexico.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: BOMBS IN PAKISTAN NEAR AFGHAN BORDER KILL 4 AND INJURE 60
description: A bomb exploded in front of a Peshawar movie house today, killing three policemen and wounding 25 people hours after another bomb attack derailed the Khyber Mail express train, killing one person and wounding 35, officials said.

title: California Court Blocks Civil Trial Suspensions
description: Two Federal appeals court judges today stopped a plan to halt all Federal civil jury trials in southern California.

title: PLENTY OF TALK, LITTLE ACTION
description: It was to be a year of maneuvering among teams hoping to improve their status in today's National Basketball Association draft and those trying to exchange their higher-rated picks for one, two or more proven players. Yet as last night's midnight deadline passed, only two trades had been made.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Commodore Executive Moves to Ailing Victor
description: An early casualty of the shakeout in the personal computer business, Victor Technologies filed for Chapter 11 protection in February 1984. Now, Alfred T. Duncan, who was named Victor's chief executive yesterday, vows to take the company back into the fray, with two new machines aimed at American business users.

title: AWAITING THE SALMON'S RETURN TO CONNECTICUT
description: The sun was up, but the morning was still cool when Steve Gephard walked down the 14 stairs to his concrete bunker beneath the Farmington River, sat in his desk chair, picked up his clipboard and swiveled slightly left so he was properly positioned for the day's work - staring out his office window.

title:
ADVERTISING;
People
description: * Harry W. Clark is joining Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt as a senior vice president.

title: TEXTS OF SOUTH AFRICAN PRESS RESTRICTIONS
description: Following are the texts of notices issued to journalists by the South African Government on press restrictions under the emergency decree, and a passage from the decree defining ''subversive statement'':

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JUNE 17, 1986
description: The Economy

title: METS WIN IN 10TH ON STRAWBERRY HIT
description: The humid afternoon dissolved into a cold, wind-swept evening, but the Mets stayed hot. They survived a sudden drop in the temperature, two rain delays totaling more than two hours and extra innings. Then, in the 10th, Darryl Strawberry's single brought home Wally Backman from second base and the Mets went on to a 4-1 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $50,059, or 2 cents a share, for the latest year and $424,938, or 17 cents a share, for the year- earlier period.

title: Guinness Outlook
description: Guinness P.L.C. said its initial review of the business of the Distillers Company confirmed the potential for significant improvements in productivity and performance. Guinness acquired Distillers for $4.1 billion in April, the largest takeover ever in Britain. Guinness also reported results for its first half, ended March 31, showed a 68.5 percent increase in pretax profits to $90.1 million, from $53.5 million.

title: BRAZIL GAINS, 4-0, WITH STYLISH PLAY
description: Brazil danced around Poland to the beat of bongo drums and tambourines at Jalisco Stadium today en route to the quarterfinals of the World Cup.

title: BRZEZINSKI, IN A BOOK, IS OFFERING NEW U.S. STRATEGY TOWARD SOVIET
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, has recommended a revision of nuclear strategy toward the Soviet Union.

title: Ticklish Spot
description: Representative Ed Zschau, who represents a wealthy and overwhelmingly Republican district in Silicon Valley in California, is in a ticklish political position on economic sanctions on South Africa in protest against apartheid.

title: Airbus-McDonnell
description: Airbus Industrie, the European group formed to compete with the major United States plane manufacturers, said its talks with McDonnell Douglas would not mean an end to any Airbus projects. Airbus and McDonnell Douglas have been holding talks for three months about the proposed A330 and A340 Airbus planes, according to European government ministers. The A340 is similar to the McDonnell Douglas MD-11, which has failed to win any orders so far and has not moved into development, which would cost $600 million.

title: Columbia Post: Talks Reported
description: Columbia Pictures is in the early stages of negotiations to hire David Puttnam, the British film producer, in a senior position, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Geezer of Steel
description: DC Comics, publishers of Superman's activities since 1938, has announced that the Man of Steel may soon become a newspaper columnist. I suspected something was in the wind. Several weeks ago the architects began creating a new office down the hall but refused to say who it was for. Naturally that stirred talk of a ''mystery columnist'' soon to join us.

title: SPEEDIER MAC FOR THE TECHNO JET SET
description: THERE I was unpacking the new Macintosh Plus, which features an 800K disk drive with twice the capacity of the older floppy disks, as well as a whole megabyte of random access memory. It looked much like its predecessors, right down to the 9-inch monochrome monitor. But the keyboard has been expanded to include a numeric keypad and a separate set of cursor keys.

title: QUOTE OF THE DAY
description: ''There is probably less freedom in South Africa at present than there is in Communist Russia.

title: THE YOUNG AND RESTLESS
description: When 120 golfers tee off tomorrow in the United States Women's Amateur Public Links Championship at Stevens Point, Wis., one of the players to watch will be the youngest in the field: 13-year-old Vicki Goetze of Hull, Ga., who qualified for the tournament by defeating two members of the University of Georgia team. Vicki, an eighth-grader, gained that victory with a three-under-par 71 on the Bulldogs' tough course, a score that even Cindy Schreyer, Georgia's 1984 N.C.A.A. champion, never achieved there.

title: 'GLITCH' CITED IN JULY 4 TICKET MIX-UP
description: The 2,000 people who received notices last week that their requests for Fourth of July Operation Sail and fireworks tickets would not be honored will receive letters explaining that it was all an ''unfortunate glitch'' and that seats will be made available.

title: SOWETO UPRISING RECALLED
description: South African blacks consider June 16, 1976, a crucial date in the struggle against apartheid.

title: EINHORN WARNING ON SHIFTS REVEALED
description: Eddie Einhorn, the United States Football League's television contract negotiator and the owner of the inactive franchise in Chicago, told the other owners at a league meeting in 1984 that vacating large cities would jeopardize the league's chance of getting a television contract for the fall in 1986.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JUNE 17, 1986
description: International

title: Ads to Oppose Judicial Choice
description: People for the American Way, a liberal lobbying group, today announced a radio advertising campaign that calls one of the Reagan Administration's judicial nominees ''unfit by any standard.''

title: REYNOLDS FACES F.T.C. CHARGES IN SMOKING ADS
description: The Federal Trade Commission charged today that the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company had illegally misrepresented and understated the health risks of smoking.

title: Mexico Deserves Full U.S. Attention
description: Events last week - the peso fell precipitously and Washington stepped in to try to help negotiate an emergency loan of some $5 billion - once again brought home the urgency of Mexico's economic crisis. The United States ought to be relieved that the crisis has as yet had almost no political repercussions, but this is no time to hide our heads in the sand.

title: PARKS CHIEF WARNS CUTS MAY FORCE CLOSINGS
description: The director of the National Park Service says some big parks might have to close by 1988 if funds are cut from the park system to help balance the national budget.

title: GOOD NEWS AND THE BAD ON JOBS IN THE MIDWEST
description: Two years ago, Lew Crowell quit his job as a telephone company engineer who designed equipment to route calls over copper cables. He joined a new telecommunications company to help set up a 1,300-mile network that transmits calls over glass fibers thinner than a strand of hair.

title: ANTI-DRUG GROUP LOSES U.S. FUNDS
description: The Justice Department said today that it had suspended a $1 million grant for a private group organized to combat drug abuse, amid allegations that most of the grant had been spent for travel and salaries.

title: Computerland
description: The Computerland Corporation, the personal computer retailer, yesterday introduced its first private-label computer system, in an apparent effort to offer low-cost, compatible alternatives to the International Business Machines Corporation's own models. The entry-level machine, similar to an I.B.M. XT, will be sold for $1,495, and a machine comparable to the AT will sell for $2,895, the company said. They are made in Korea by Tri Gem Inc.

title: Gift From Monaco
description: Prince Rainier III of Monaco will visit Washington in mid-October to give the National Portrait Gallery a bronze bust of his late wife, Princess Grace.

title: THEATER: 'TRINITY SITE,' BY JANEICE SCARBROUGH
description: OF all the forms of fallout produced by the atomic bomb, few are more persistent, if less noxious, than the mindless anti-bomb melodrama. For every inspired ''Dr. Strangelove'' on screen or ''Dead End Kids'' on stage, there are many trivializing works that don't contemplate the unthinkable so much as connive to exploit it for maudlin effect. Janeice Scarbrough's ''Trinity Site,'' the new play at the WPA, is the latest example of the genre, and surely one of the least. This effort almost gets the audience rooting for its fictional characters' doomsday, if that's what it takes to bring the curtain down.

title: PUBLICATION GIVES EDGE IN SPACE TO SOVIET
description: In the wake of the Challenger shuttle disaster, the Soviet Union holds an ''almost frightening'' lead over the United States in space experience, according to the new edition of Jane's Spaceflight Directory.

title: Careers; Openings In Security Field Grow
description: CORPORATIONS and government entities are taking more interest in security precautions and are spending more money in the quest for safety. This offers job opportunities, and has already resulted in a number of new courses and programs in security at universities and community colleges across the country.

title: 13,000 Hindus Arrested For a Protest in India
description: Nearly 13,000 Hindus marched in sweltering heat today, demanding that the army be used to combat Sikh terrorism in the Punjab.

title: EFFECT OF OBSERVERS UPON THE SENATORS OBSERVED
description: Last week, Senator Carl Levin of Michigan talked on the Senate floor about racial problems in South Africa. Senator Alan J. Dixon of Illinois made a speech about tax reform, and Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee commented on the transportation of chemical waste. In each case, taped excerpts from their remarks were fed by satellite to local television stations in time for the evening news.

title: BLACKS BY MILLION QUIT JOBS FOR DAY IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Millions of blacks, defying the Government's most severe crackdown on dissent, stayed away from work today in a subdued protest to mark the 10th anniversary of the 1976 Soweto uprising.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income and includes gains from discontinued operations of $150,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,150,000, or 78 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: DANCE: LINDA MUSSMANN
description: THE multimedia productions of Linda Mussmann often seem to occur in theatrical worlds all their own. Yet they are not totally sealed off from reality.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ALCOHOL AGENCY WARNS OF HIGHLY TAINTED BRAND OF AUSTRIAN WINE
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said today that one brand of Austrian wine in the United States had been found to have an extremely high content of a toxic chemical, and warned consumers not to drink it.

title: Rosa Mundi Is a Rose
description: June, the month of roses, brings on a good deal of horticultural name dropping. How is Queen Elizabeth? one solicitous gardener will ask another.

title: Hawaii Raises Drinking Age
description: Gov. George R. Ariyoshi of Hawaii, hoping to reduce traffic deaths and at the same time save Federal highway money, has signed into law a bill raising the state's legal minimum drinking age to 21 from 18. The Federal Department of Transportation threatened to withdraw as much as $19 million in highway funds unless Hawaii raised the drinking age. Only six states have not passed similar bills.

title: Shuttle Commander's Widow Assails NASA Management
description: Breaking months of silence, Jane Smith, the widow of Michael J. Smith, commander of the space shuttle Challenger, sharply criticized NASA management yesterday for its role in the explosion of the craft shortly after liftoff Jan. 28.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
TAX BREAK FOR PHILLIPS KEPT IN BILL
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to keep a special tax exemption for one oil company in the tax-revision bill that seems almost certain to be passed this week.

title: Chess: Kasparov Vanquishes Miles In Exhibition Match in Basel
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union has demolished Tony Miles of Britain by 5 1/2- 1/2 in an exhibition match in Basel, Switzerland.

title: Joe Pytka Wins Five Clio Awards
description: Joe Pytka, the California director now very much in vogue, won five television Clios last night, beating out the arrayed might of the advertising agency business.

title: AIKENS IN MEXICO
description: First base was on fire. Thick, acrid smoke drifted into the stands of the stadium in Puebla, reminding visitors from the capital of what passes for air in Mexico City.

title: Federal Guidelines Needed for Organ Transplants
description: To the Editor:

title: Capacity Use Down 0.6% in May
description: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at only 78.6 percent of capacity in May as the country suffered the steepest four-month decline in operating rates since the end of the last recession, the Government reported today.

title: Morgan Guaranty
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, a subsidiary of J.P. Morgan & Company, began offering $125 million of 7.30 percent deposit notes, due in 1989, at par through underwriters led by E.F. Hutton & Company. The notes, rated triple-A by Moody's, yield 43-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: Affirmative Action for Older Workers, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: GORBACHEV ON ARMS OFFER
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today made public elements of the latest Soviet arms proposal, under which the Russians would reduce strategic arsenals if the United States restricted research on its space-based defense program and agreed to abide by the antiballistic missile treaty of 1972 for at least 15 more years.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: School Spirit Etymology
description: Though it escaped nationwide attention, one of the great events in sobriquet history occurred in the semifinals of the Illinois Class A basketball tournament earlier this year, when the Wooden Shoes of Teutopolis High School met and defeated the Corn Jerkers of Hoopeston-East Lynn. The Shoes went on to kick the daylights out of the Ohio High Bulldogs for the state championship, thereby bringing a measure of immortality to a nickname that deserves it.

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a $701,000 gain on the sale of property. The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid April 1.

title: STAGE: WORKING THEATER'S 'ONE-ACT FESTIVAL '86'
description: AS one might expect from the Working Theater, the emphasis in the group's ''One Act Festival 1986'' at Intar Stage Two is on the acting and directing. Four of the five pieces in Evening A of the festival are designed precisely to challenge actors - and directors - to impose their own meaning on them. In each case they do, with mostly amusing results.

title: Soviet Official Calls the U.S. Unyielding in the Arms Talks
description: A Soviet military official said today that the United States had failed to respond positively to recent Soviet arms proposals.

title: Theater Museum to Close
description: The Theater Museum, an annex of the Museum of the City of New York in the Minskoff Theater Arcade, 1515 Broadway, between 44th and 45th Streets, will close on June 30 because of poor attendance, the museum announced.

title: A War Crimes Suspect Loses High Court Plea
description: The Supreme Court rejected today the appeal of Boleslavs Maikovskis of Mineola, L.I., paving the way for his deportation to Latvia, where he has been sentenced to death for war crimes.

title: DELTA AIR ACCUSES AMERICAN
description: Delta Air Lines filed a complaint with the Transportation Department yesterday charging that American Airlines had devised a ''scheme'' to favor its flights over those of other airlines in its Sabre computer reservation system, the most widely used in the nation.

title: China Study on Failures
description: A Chinese parliamentary committee is considering a draft of the country's first bankruptcy law since the Communist takeover in 1949, the New China News Agency reported today. The agency said the law was needed to deal with a number of state-run enterprises that had been recording heavy losses over a number of years.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, the Quotation of the Day on Sunday, from an anti-apartheid rally in Central Park, was misattributed in some copies. It was the entertainer Harry Belafonte, not Representative Major R. Owens of Brooklyn, who said, ''The U.S. and Great Britain are the key to sanctions and the key to divestment. Divestment and sanctions are pivotal.''

title: C.H. Masland In Burlington Deal
description: C. H. Masland & Sons, a leading carpet maker for cars and homes, accepted a sweetened cash offer yesterday from Burlington Industries of $73 a share, or a total of about $117 million. Burlington, the nation's largest maker of textile products, offered Masland $68 a share in late May, but the carpet maker rejected the bid.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income after a tax credit of $48,000.

title: MUSIC: TRIBUTE TO PETER PEARS
description: THE English tenor Peter Pears died in April, and, on Saturday night, three fine musicians - the tenor Grayson Hirst, the harpsichordist Gerald Ranck and the lutanist and guitarist William Zito - presented a memorial concert at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, in a chapel to the right of the altar.

title: Mulroney Trade Plea
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney tonight urged Canadians to support the removal of trade curbs with the United States. Broad-ranging trade talks between the two nations are set to begin Tuesday in Washington.

title: Chesapeake Phone Offering at 9.41%
description: To help finance the redemption of some high-interest debt and the repayment of short-term debt, the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company is offering $100 million of debentures through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: U.S. ARMS OFFICIALS FINDING PROBLEMS IN OFFER BY SOVIET
description: The latest Soviet arms proposals, although signaling a shift on medium-range weapons in Europe and on sea-launched cruise missiles, still pose some problems for the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: Scripto Tokai Shift Seen To DYR-Los Angeles
description: It looks like DYR-Los Angeles will be getting the Scripto Tokai account.

title: BROAD ALERT OVER AIDS: SOCIAL BATTLE IS SHIFTING
description: FIVE years and 12,000 deaths after a vicious new malady seemingly sprang from nowhere, the nation's battle to contain AIDS must become broader and more aggressive, according to experts inside and outside Government.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Ex-Congressman Loses Bid for Shorter Sentence
description: Former Reprepresentative George V. Hansen, an Idaho Republican, lost his effort today for a reduced sentence for his conviction of filing false financial statements to Congress.

title: HOTEL CHAIN REBUFFS TRAFALGAR BID
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the English conglomerate that purchased the Intercontinental hotel chain five years ago from Pan American World Airways, said it had rejected a $900 million cash offer for its hotel interests from Trafalgar Holdings Ltd.

title: FOSSILS OF 'MAN TRACKS' SHOWN TO BE DINOSAURIAN
description: IN a new analysis of giant fossil footprints in a Texas riverbed, paleontologists have concluded that there is no evidence of human prints mingled with those of dinosaurs. The finding, they said, undermines a key argument advanced by religious fundamentalists who have cited the ''man tracks'' as scientific evidence of a relatively recent, divine creation of life on earth, in keeping with a literal interpretation of the Bible.

title: CZECH PLAY WITHDRAWN FROM THEATER FESTIVAL
description: A Czechoslovak play that was to have been presented at an international theater festival in Baltimore has been withdrawn at the request of Prague, the Czechoslovak mission to the United Nations said yesterday.

title: BULGING MONEY SUPPLY GIVING THE FED PAUSE
description: Sharp increases in the nation's money supply in the last five months are causing a problem for the Federal Reserve Board as it considers a further cut in interest rates.

title: U.N. Chief to Mediate Rainbow Warrior Case
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has agreed to mediate a dispute between France and New Zealand over the sinking of an environmentalist protest ship, a spokesman for the Secretary General said today.

title: BRENDLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

PLAYERS;
HEIDEN SETS NEW GOALS
description: Eric Heiden has no complaints about life. In the 1980 Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, he won all five gold medals in men's speed skating and became a hero for the ages. Now he is a professional bicycle rider, a champion at that, too.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank Ltd. elected four senior executive vice presidents: George W. Carmany 3d, formerly a senior vice president of the company; David F. Stein, formerly managing director at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.; Heinz D. Zimmer, general manager of American Express Bank (Switzerland) A.G., Zurich, and Amos Z. Bergner, president of the general management of Trade Development Bank, Geneva.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on the removal of ''adult'' magazines from convenience stores around the country misidentified an educational foundation whose president commented on the situation. The foundation is the Poynter Institute for Media Studies.

title: 9.7% RATE RISE IS WON BY BLUE CROSS
description: Monthly medical insurance rates will rise 9.7 percent for 2.4 million individual and small-group subscribers to Blue Cross-Blue Shield in the New York metropolitan area.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Abortion Dialogue at Court
description: ''I have always had the highest respect for his views on this subject,'' wrote Justice John Paul Stevens of his colleague Byron White. The subject was abortion; the occasion was the Supreme Court's reaffirmation of 1973's Roe v. Wade, and that opening remark was a sure sign that Justice Stevens was about to blast Justice White. Their exchange, drowned out in the day's news, was the Court's liveliest in print in years.

title: A Time for Lawyers
description: A Washington-based group that for nearly 30 years has provided leadership seminars for black South Africans says it will go ahead with a program for black lawyers next month despite the South African Government's declaration of a state of emergency.

title: Henley Forms Medical Unit
description: Henley Group Inc. said today that it had formed a major medical and scientific technology unit that would generate about $1 billion in annual sales and could eventually become a publicly held company.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. BOSTON RED SOX, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television -Channel 11, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: In Pursuit of History
description: If the Mets were to continue their current pace, they would finish the regular season with 118 victories, a major league record. These are the leaders they would pass: 1906 Chicago Cubs...116-36;1954 Cleveland Indians...111-43;1909 Pittsburgh Pirates...110-42;1927 New York Yankees...110-44;1961 New York Yankees...109-53;1969 Baltimore Orioles...109-53;1970 Baltimore Orioles...108-54;1975 Cincinnati Reds...108-54;1907 Chicago Cubs...107-45;1931 Philadelphia Athletics...107-45;1932 New York Yankees...107-47;

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $225,000 for the latest quarter and $83,000 for the year-ago period. The 1985 results have been restated to reflect the change for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, 1986, from the LIFO method of valuing inventories to the FIFO method.

title: SHIFTS MAKE FOR RED FACES OVER CITY HALL GREEN BOOK
description: The unprecedented is tough to come by at City Hall, but the release yesterday of the latest Green Book - formally known as the Official Directory of the City of New York - comes close.

title: AND STILL CHAMPION: CRAY'S CHESS COMPUTER
description: TO the surprise and dismay of its electronic challengers, Cray Blitz has narrowly held off a field of 22 computers in Cologne, West Germany, to retain its title as computer chess champion of the world.

title: U.S. OPEN AT SHINNECOCK RECEIVES RAVE REVIEWS
description: What started in fear and trepidation ended Sunday as perhaps the most successful United States Open in history on one of the finest courses ever used for the event. The smoothly run tournament ended with a champion, Raymond Floyd, who is a strong believer in the traditions of the game that were so well displayed at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTEANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1986 share earnings for series A is 55 cents for the quarter and $2.55 for the year. The 1985 share earnings for series A is 47 cents for the quarter and $2.18 for the year. The 1986 share earnings for series B is 55 cents for the quarter and $2.55 for the year. The 1985 share earnings for series B is 50 cents for the quarter and $2.30 for the year. The 1985 share earnings for the quarter and year have been adjusted for subsequent stock dividends.

title: We Shouldn't Expect Africa to Do as We Do
description: To the Editor:

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes $160,000 after-tax gain from the sale of land.

title: Schlichter Joins Bills
description: Art Schlichter, the former Indianapolis Colts quarterback suspended in 1983 for gambling, has agreed to terms with the Buffalo Bills as a free agent. ''There are some details that need to be ironed out and they're in the process of being ironed out, but the contract is agreed to'' said the Bills' general manager, Bill Polian, in an interview with The Buffalo News.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Scott Henion, a right-handed pitcher from Kansas City, and Richard Lundahl, a shortstop from Menlo Park, Calif., both chosen by the Mets in this month's amateur free agent draft, have been signed and assigned to the team's Class A farm clubs. Henion, the fourth pick in the secondary phase goes to Kingsport (Tennessee) of the Appalachian League and Lundahl, the 21st choice of the regular phase, will report to Little Falls in the New York-Penn League. . . . The Los Angeles Dodgers placed the catcher Mike Scioscia on the 15-day disabled list with an injured right ankle. . . . The Atlanta Braves activated the outfielder Claudell Washington, who has been bothered by a neck injury, from the disabled list Monday and returned the outfielder-infielder Gerald Perry to their Richmond farm club. . . . Edwin Moses, the world-record holder and two-time Olympic gold medalist, will not compete in this week's USA/Mobil Track and Field Championships in Eugene, Ore.

title: CIMCO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CANDIDATE WITHDRAWS IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: A Republican candidate for Governor announced tonight that he would drop out of the race because of his false claim that he had been a captain in the Army Special Forces in Vietnam.

title: LAUNCHING A BOYHOOD DREAM INTO A REALITY
description: When Bob Tiedemannn was growing up in Greenwich, Conn., he used to sneak into boat yards and climb inside the boats stored there. Other children his age were too busy playing baseball in the park to care much about that sort of thing, but Tiedemann thought of little else.

title: Business and the Law; If 'Poison Pill' Is Too Strong
description: JUDGE Richard A. Posner - who became famous as a University of Chicago law professor by preaching that the nation's courts should look more closely at the economic dimensions of legal issues - examined the economics of ''poison pills'' in an important recent decision. Judge Posner looked at how these corporate defenses against takeovers affect not only shareholders but also the stock market's ability to discipline or replace inefficient managements.

title: HOUGH LOSES NO-HITTER AND GAME IN 9TH
description: Charlie Hough of the Rangers held the Angels without a hit for eight and one-third innings tonight, but a single, a three-base error and two passed balls in the ninth left Hough and Texas 2-1 losers.

title: 'Partisans of Vilna' Benefit
description: ''Partisans of Vilna,'' a documentary by Josh Waletzky about Jewish resistance fighters in Lithuania, will have its premiere on June 26 at 7:30 P.M. at the 57th Street Playhouse, 110 West 57th Street.

title: A JUDGE ORDERS DELAY IN FILLING ADDABBO'S SEAT
description: The House of Representatives seat left vacant by the death of Joseph P. Addabbo will not be filled until at least June 27, when a state judge is to hear arguments about the validity of absentee and military ballots cast in last week's special election in Queens.

title: MADISON AVE.'S NEW IDEA MAKERS
description: WHEN Jamie Seltzer announced that she was going to be an advertising copywriter, the people who knew her best were not supportive. ''You don't read,'' said her sister, a group head at Benton & Bowles. ''You don't even speak English.''

title: SPY ONCE REGAINED ACCESS TO SECRETS
description: The Navy restored a security clearance to Jonathan Jay Pollard, an analyst who later admitted spying for Israel, after he threatened to file a grievance against his superiors, a Reagan Administration official said today.

title: WNET LOOKS AT CLASH OVER AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: ''ASSAULT ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION ,'' another timely documentary in the ''Frontline'' series, takes a critical look at the efforts of the Reagan Administration's Justice Department to put limits on one of the most fought-over aspects of the civil-rights agenda of the last two decades. The hourlong program can be seen at 10 o'clock tonight on WNET/Channel 13.

title: NEWS ORGANIZATIONS REACT CAUTIOUSLY TO RESTRICTIONS ON COVERAGE
description: As news organizations gingerly contend with the latest restrictions on news coverage in South Africa, many news executives say they fear that the South African Government intends to apply the rules stringently.

title: Canadian Doctors Strike
description: Five hospital emergency wards were closed today in Ontario Province by striking doctors who threatened to shut down as many as 15 others in a fee dispute with the provincial government. The strike began Thursday over proposed legislation to limit how much the physicians may charge.

title: Wimbledon's No. 1's
description: Martina Navratilova, seeking her fifth consecutive women's singles title, and Ivan Lendl, the French Open champion, were named yesterday as the top-seeded players for the Wimbledon tennis championships. The world's premier grass-court tournament begins its two-week run next Monday at the All-England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club.

title: BALLET: GIMI HARANGOZO
description: JUST when we thought the dance season was meandering to a close, American Ballet Theater is springing some new faces upon us. Rudolf Nureyev is not exactly in that category, but he has not appeared as a guest with the company since Mikhail Baryshnikov became director in 1980.

title: FOR DRIVERS, THE FUN IS BACK
description: ''Are you having fun yet?'' That is what advertisements along the West and Gulf coasts of the country are asking sales prospects as they promote the Suzuki Samurai, a small, four-wheel-drive Jeep-like vehicle that was introduced into the American market late last year.

title: Jail Population in U.S. Sets Record at 503,601
description: The number of inmates in state and Federal prisons rose above the half-million mark last year as tougher sentencing packed already overcrowded facilities, the Government said today.

title: Trade Commission Chief
description: President Reagan has designated Susan W. Liebeler to become chairman of the United States's International Trade Commission, succeeding Paula Stern, whose term as chairman expired yesterday but who will remain a member. Mrs. Liebeler had been vice chairman.

title: JUSTICES DENY APPEALS IN NORFOLK BUSING CASE AND ON A LIBEL SUIT
description: The Supreme Court today preliminarily cleared the way for Norfolk, Va., to end its busing of elementary schoolchildren for desegregation purposes this fall.

title: WON ACCLAIM AS ILLINOIS JUDGE
description: Walter V. Schaefer, widely regarded as one of the pre-eminent state jurists of this century, died of cancer Sunday at a hospital in suburban Lake Forest. He was 81 years old.

title: A Unit of Crocker May Be Up for Sale
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it was discussing the sale of the Crocker Investment Management Company to Fred Alger Management Inc., a New York-based investment management company that mainly manages pension funds.

title: South Africa's Non-Voters Vote 'No'
description: The vulnerable underside of white power in South Africa is an industrial economy's dependence on six million black workers. What didn't happen yesterday, on the 10th anniversary of the Soweto uprising, is therefore an even bigger story than the violence of recent months. Buses rode empty, shops stood shuttered and urban workplaces fell silent as millions of blacks stolidly withheld their labor and patronage.

title: FREEDOM SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects a $1.5 million provision for loan losses. c-Net income includes an extraordinary income of $4.9 million, or $1.72 a share, from the sale of six branch offices and reflects a $550,000 provision for loan losses. Gains on the sales of investments during the first quarter of 1986 totaled $5.4 million, compared to $3.5 million for the year-ago period.

title: Model of Enzyme
description: An international team of scientists has developed the first three-dimensional model of a bacterial enzyme that destroys penicillin. The scientists believe the model will aid in the design of tougher penicillins and help microbiologists trace how bacteria evolve to resist antibiotics.

title: Solidarity's Captured Leader Is Shown in TV Interrogation
description: Polish television today showed film of Zbigniew Bujak, Solidarity underground leader, under interrogation. It was the first time he had been seen since being captured last month.

title: Dow Off 2.42; Trading Slows
description: Share prices were mixed on Wall Street yesterday and trading volume declined sharply from the level reached Friday, when the stock market was rallying on hopes of lower interest rates.

title: EUROPEAN BLOC DELAYS A DECISION ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Western European foreign ministers postponed a decision today on whether to impose new sanctions against South Africa.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
KOREA IS BREEDING A NEW KIND OF COLLEGE RADICAL
description: This is the haunting image of the new South Korean student activism: Lee Dong Soo, 22 years old, slowly and deliberately douses himself with gasoline and sets himself on fire. As the flames engulf him, he shouts, ''Out with U.S. imperialists!'' and throws himself from a third-story ledge at Seoul National University.

title: Laotians Storm Village In Thailand, Killing 35
description: Thai Government officials said today that 35 people were killed and 16 were wounded when Laotian troops stormed a village in Thailand and opened fire on its residents.

title: South African Activist Ordered to Shun Press
description: Winnie Mandela, the black activist, was told today not to speak to journalists and to stay at home at night, a Government order said.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for 13wks to March 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $993,000, or $1.06 a share, from the sale of assets. c-Includes gains from the sale of assets of $201,000, or 22 cents a share, for the 13 weeks and $223,000, or 24 cents a share, for the 26 weeks.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Plan for Murchison
description: United States Bankruptcy judge, Harold Abramson, approved a plan to pay off Clint Murchison Jr.'s estimated $200 million in debts.

title: Weaker 1986 Economy Seen
description: President Reagan's budget director, James C. Miller 3d, said today that the economy looks weaker this year than the Administration thought it would but that next year it would prove stronger.

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $660,000, or 6 cents a share, on the sale of idle facilities. c-Includes a gain of $377,000, or 3 cents a share, on the sale of idle facilities.

title: THE TAX BILL AND ARTS PATRONAGE
description: Arts organizations say they are concerned that tax legislation pending in Congress would undermine financial incentives for patronage of the arts.

title: IN BROOKLYN, A ONCE-PROUD HIGH SCHOOL IS SHAKEN BY DROPOUTS AND DECLINE
description: It was once a distinguished school, one known for its academic excellence.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A movie review on June 11 about ''The Eyes of the Birds,'' a 1983 French film by Gabriel Auer, described the film's depiction of conditions in a Uruguayan prison for political prisoners. The fiction film, which Mr. Auer has said was based on facts obtained during 18 months of research and more than 30 hours of interviews, told of a ''house of horrors'' in which detainees included teachers, unionists, doctors, artists and farmers.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HOW TO FIND AND HIRE A CONSULTANT
description: THE goal of a good microcomputer consultant is to wind up unemployed as soon as possible, having used a wide variety of skills to work his or her way out of a job.

title: Stopping Dropouts
description: Dropouts may not be a such a pressing problem at the Ochs school, but they are one of the city's top priorities in education. Last night, 13 educators received awards in recognition for their work in preventing youngsters from dropping out.

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''IT didn't swallow your credit card, did it?'' Mohan B. Murjani, chairman of Murjani International, asked at last week's press conference unveiling what may be fashion's first Coke machine. The electronic kiosk, known as Eric (after its supplier, the Electronic Retailing Investment Corporation), sells Coca-Cola fashions 24 hours a day outside Murjani's Fizzazz boutique at 280 Columbus Avenue, at 73d Street.

title: REAGAN SEEKS BIPARTISANSHIP ON CONTRAS
description: President Reagan, appealing for bipartisan support of aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, said today that a newly deployed Soviet reconnaissance plane used by the Nicaraguan Government had given the Sandinistas ''a significant advance in its military and intelligence capabilities.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart published on June 12 about NASA personnel changes since the Challenger explosion described the status of Dr. William R. Graham incorrectly. He remains deputy administrator, awaiting confirmation as President Reagan's science adviser.

title: Arkansas and Michigan Celebrate 150 Years
description: Bells rang and boat horns blared Sunday to mark 150 years of statehood, capping a weekend of celebrations here and in Michigan, which entered the union together with Arkansas.

title: U.S. Envoy to Panama Delivers a Note on Policy
description: The United States Ambassador delivered a formal clarification of American policy toward Panama today, but he refused to characterize the statement. The action followed reports implicating Panama's army chief in criminal activities.

title: CENSORSHIP HINDERS REPORTING ON ARREST OF 250 AT A CHURCH
description: Among the incidents that could not be reported from South Africa yesterday under new censorship restrictions was the arrest Sunday of 250 people, including two Americans, at an Anglican church service near Cape Town. South African policemen, calling the gathering a subversive meeting, seized everyone in the church, including many children.

title: A STUDY OF ACHILLE LAURO HIJACKING
description: NBC NEWS reconstructs the hijacking of the Achille Lauro tonight. Tom Brokaw visits the Italian cruise ship and re-enacts, in effect, the voyage that left Leon Klinghoffer dead. Mohammed Abbas, who by his own admission was the mastermind of the hijacking, appears in something like a cameo role. The program, ''Achille Lauro: A Study in Terror,'' will be seen on Channel 4 at 10 P.M.

title: S.E.C. ACCUSES REVLON OF MISLEADING INVESTORS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged that Revlon Inc. misled investors during its takeover battle with Pantry Pride last fall by not promptly disclosing friendly buyout talks with two investment companies.

title: CELLULAR PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to March 31
APPROVAL GIVEN TO DEMONSTRATE AT ST. PATRICK'S
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the police must permit up to 100 members of a homosexual-rights group to hold a peaceful demonstration on the sidewalk in front of St. Patrick's Cathedral during the annual Gay Pride Parade on June 29.

title: INLAND VACUUM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NASSAU REJECTS COLISEUM'S USE IN EVACUATIONS
description: Nassau County lawmakers today barred the use of the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum as an emergency evacuation center for the Shoreham nuclear power plant, creating a potentially serious obstacle to the opening of the plant.

title: CONTRADICTORY SIGNALS ON STUDENT BEHAVIOR
description: HOW do Americans expect college students to behave?

title: FROM ADOLFO, WILLOWY LINES FOR FALL
description: The Adolfo crowd showed up at the St. Regis-Sheraton yesterday in their fresh summer dresses to check out what the designer had in mind for them to wear next fall. They found almost everything fitted gracefully to the body, in a lean, willowy line. This includes the suits, knitted dresses, even many of the evening clothes.

title: Man in Queens Wins $11 Million in Lotto
description: A Queens subway car inspector yesterday claimed an $11 million Lotto jackpot as the sole winner in the Lotto 48 drawing on Saturday.

title: U.S. SAYS BOTHA SPURNED APPEAL FROM REAGAN TO RESCIND DECREE
description: White House officials said today that President P. W. Botha of South Africa had defiantly rejected a personal appeal from President Reagan for restraint and an end to the nationwide state of emergency decree.

title: David Kalstone Is Dead at 53; Author, Critic and Professor
description: David Kalstone, a literary critic, author and professor of English at Rutgers University, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 53 years old.

title: Calico Jak Wins Belmont Feature
description: Calico Jak, ridden by Richard Migliore, took the lead in midstretch and held off Gold Crest by three-quarters of a length yesterday in the $27,000 feature race for 3-year-olds and up at Belmont.

title: Remember the Indians On Liberty Centennial
description: To the Editor:

title: BEAUTIFYING WHITE HOUSE SECURITY BARRIERS
description: Those heavy concrete barriers at key points around the White House may provide security, but art they are not, according to complaints received by the Secret Service.

title: Advertising; Fewer Agencies For I.B.M.
description: THE word spread like wildfire in and around the halls of power in the ad agency business late yesterday - I.B.M. is consolidating agencies.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WHO GOES OUT IN THE MIDDAY SUN? An Englishman's Trek Through the

title: PROSECUTORS AGREE TO LET U.S. TRY FRIEDMAN FIRST
description: State and Federal prosecutors agreed yesterday to let Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic chairman, and five co-defendants be tried in Federal court before state court.

title: PRETORIA AND THE PRESS
description: There are few areas that better demonstrate the South African Government's contradictory desires as its attitude toward the foreign press. South Africa yearns to be accepted as a country of Western democratic values, but to maintain its system and self-image it enforces the information practices of authoritarian regimes.

title: ACTION REJECTED AT STATE AGENCY DESPITE INQUIRY
description: More than two weeks after a report by the State Commission of Investigation that charged the Office of General Services with ''a general disregard for ethical conduct'' and ''carelessly implemented procedures,'' the Cuomo administration said today that it planned no major changes in the agency.

title: Crazy Eddie Files Offering
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., the electronics retailer, announced yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of $65 million of 25-year convertible subordinated debentures, through underwriters led by Wertheim & Company.

title: Federal Guidelines Needed for Organ Transplants
description: To the Editor:

title: REVIEW IS ORDERED ON RAIDERS' AWARD
description: A Federal appeals court today sent back to a lower court the $34.6 million damage award won by the Los Angeles Raiders in the club's antitrust suit against the National Football League.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Citicorp Acquires Control of Quotron
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it had gained control of Quotron Systems Inc., the worldwide provider of stock quotations and other financial data, which had reluctantly decided not to contest Citicorp's bid.

title: Day for Andrettis
description: It was a better Father's Day for the Andretti clan than previously reported. While a national television audience on ESPN was watching Mario Andretti beat out his son Michael by seven-hundredths of a second, the closest finish in Indy Car history, Mario's nephew, John, the son of Mario's twin brother and former racing partner, Aldo, was wrapping up the overall victory in the Seagrams Cooler 24 hour endurance race in Watkins Glen, N.Y., part of the I.M.S.A. Firestone Firehawk Circuit.
