title: 100 NATIONS MEET TO BACK SANCTIONS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, speaking at a United Nations conference here today, said Western countries were involved in a ''sleazy partnership with despotism and state terrorism'' because of their refusal to support economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: PROSECUTOR WHO TOPPLED PHOENIX PUBLISHER IS FACING MISCONDUCT CHARGE
description: With a plot that might have been devised by Shakespeare, a public drama involving two powerful figures continues to unfold in the desert heat here. Like Hamlet plotting against Claudius, the first player exacted revenge upon the other, only to bring grief upon himself in the process.

title: Bridge: Last 2 Deals Are Important To Simultaneous Pairs Team
description: The last two deals of a duplicate game at one's local club may be of minor importance or of no importance at all. But that was not true for Marty Bergen of White Plains and Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J., who played Saturday at the Y.W.C.A. in White Plains, in the Epson World Simultaneous Pairs.

title: THURMOND EASES PROPOSED LOBBYING CURBS
description: Strom Thurmond, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, has agreed to soften proposed new restrictions on lobbying by former Federal officials, committee aides said today. The move is an effort to enlist support for the measure from Democrats, who had found Senator Thurmond's proposals too broad.

title: BLACKS KEEP OFF STREETS
description: Today in South Africa's largest city, it appeared as if the architects of apartheid had realized their dream.

title: I.B.M. STRENGTHENS OFFICE LINE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, saying it was moving quickly to bolster its troubled midsized computer line, yesterday introduced several new models of its System/36 and System/38 computers and a range of software to help them communicate.

title: Demonstrator Upsets Koch's Proclamation
description: As Mayor Koch was reading a proclamation last night declaring next week as Gay Pride Week, a demonstrator ripped the proclamation from the Mayor's hands and then was subdued by detectives, the police said.

title: Identifying a Mummy
description: X-ray studies of a kind used in orthodontic dentistry have conferred royalty and gender identity on an Egyptian mummy that has baffled experts for almost 80 years.

title: LEBANESE MOSLEM RECEIVES O'CONNOR
description: Amid the sound of explosions and machine-gun fire, the Archbishop of New York, John Cardinal O'Connor, went to West Beirut today for a meeting with Sheik Hassan Khaled, the Grand Mufti, who is the spiritual leader of Lebanon's 650,000 Sunni Moslems.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption of a picture from Agence France-Presse on Saturday, with an article about a Soviet warning on the strategic arms limitation treaty, reversed the indentifications of two Soviet diplomats. Oleg M. Sokolov was at the left, Vitaly L. Churkin at the right.

title: 60 Injured in Collapse Of Bleachers at Circus
description: More than 60 people were injured, six of them seriously, when wooden bleachers set up for a traveling circus collapsed last evening at a shopping center near Hudson, N.Y., shortly before a performance was to begin.

title: Ford Milestone at 83
description: The Ford Motor Company, which marked its 83d birthday today, said it would produce a record 10 millionth vehicle at a single factory. The milestone car, a silver Ford Thunderbird, will be built Tuesday at the 28-year-old Lorain, Ohio, assembly plant near Lake Erie, said Ford, which planned a ceremony there. Lorain's first vehicle, produced in 1958, was an F-100 pickup.

title: Dr. Irwin J. Fox, 59, Pioneer In Measuring Heart's Output
description: Dr. Irwin J. Fox, a pioneer in developing procedures to measure the heart's blood flow, has died of cancer here Sunday. He was 59 years old.

title: JUDY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WOLLMAN RINK: 6 YEARS OF ERRORS AND DELAYS
description: The concrete was diluted, the start of a flood cleanup was delayed for two months, and one end of the skating rink was designed to be six inches lower than the other. But no single cause and no single contractor or New York City official was responsible for the city's failure to renovate the Wollman Memorial Rink, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Getting the Word
description: The Smithsonian's program in English as a second language is offering a series of five courses for members of Washington's large international community who are baffled by all the jargon in the corridors of power and on the social circuit.

title: COVERING ALL ANGLES
description: These eyes have not found golf an easy sport to watch on television. Trying to keep mental track of even a handful of participants is more work than pleasure, and the accepted broadcast technique of jumping from hole to hole, player to player, live to taped - amidst generous doses of car and beer pitches - has usually caused an early decision to take out the garbage.

title: Athens Advised to End Case Against Reporter
description: The Athens District Attorney has recommended dismissal of the case against a Cypriot journalist accused of threatening terrorist acts against Greece's largest newspaper, a court spokesman said today.

title: NUTRI/SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a charge of $724,000 related to the closing of the company's weight-loss operations in Germany.

title: Fed Backs Natwest Plan
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. said yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had granted permission for its New York subsidiary, Natwest Holdings Inc., to offer investment research and brokerage services to institutional customers.

title: PRISONER'S DILEMMA HAS UNEXPECTED APPLICATIONS
description: YOU and your accomplice have been caught red-handed. Together your best hope is to cooperate by remaining silent: You will each get off with a 30-day sentence. But either of you can do better for yourself: Double-cross your partner and you will go free while he serves 10 years. The problem is, if you each betray the other, you will both go to prison - and not just for 30 days, but for eight years.

title: Feminism's Next Challenge: Support for Motherhood
description: The most urgent problem facing modern American women is reconciling the demands of childbirth and child rearing with those of earning a living. For them, conditions are onerous and getting worse.

title: TREASURY BOND RALLY IS STALLED
description: Treasury bond prices were little changed yesterday, stalling a rally that began last week.

title: Time Cable Unit Sets Deal
description: American Television and Communications Inc., the cable division of Time Inc., said yesterday that it would become an equity partner in Cable Value Network, the cable television shopping service that is owned by the C.O.M.B.

title: Phone Bond Yield 9.57%
description: Even though yields have declined recently, investment bankers noted that corporate spreads over Treasury securities remained fairly wide, thereby attracting investors to the corporate market.

title: KETTLE RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Net loss.

title: MATERIAL SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE BEST CHICKEN STOCK IS ALWAYS FRESH
description: ONE dictionary lists nine definitions for stock before getting around to the culinary reference - ''the broth from boiled meat or fish, used as a base in preparing soup, gravy or sauces.'' But the first definition -''a supply accumulated for future use'' - correctly conveys an important culinary meaning. Stock is essential to cuisines from the classical French to Chinese, winter or summer.

title: Hiram Walker Lawsuit Altered
description: Olympia & York Enterprises Inc. and the Gulf Canada Corporation, which have been seeking to invalidate an agreement that would sell the liquor business of Hiram Walker Resources to Allied-Lyons of Britain, said yesterday that they had simplified their suit.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Thursday about Victor E. Botnick, who resigned as a senior aide to Mayor Koch, misidentified the high school from which he graduated. Mr. Botnick attended Yeshiva University High School in Upper Manhattan for three years, but transferred to the Rabbi Jacob Joseph School, then on the Lower East Side, and graduated in 1972.

title: King Refuses Comment
description: It is hard for a public figure to make public appearances on the steps of City Hall and still remain a non-story, but Bernard King of the Knicks was doing a very good job of that yesterday. The injured King was there for the announcement of the opening of the 1986 Big Apple Games along with other sports celebrities such as Tim Daggett, the Olympic gold medal gymnast; Bob Brooke of the Rangers, the former St. John's star Chris Mullin and the former Montclair State star Carol Blazejowski, whose 1977 Madison Square Garden scoring record of 52 points, King broke with his 60-point performance on Christmas Day 1984 against the Nets.

title: Georgia Halts Execution For Mental Evaluation
description: A mentally retarded man whose fight to escape execution drew support from international rock stars and mental health groups won a reprieve today, eight hours before he was scheduled to die.

title: A QUIET PLACE AT RCA'S SUMMIT DRIFTS ONTO THE PAGES OF THE PAST
description: After 53 years of offering an unusually tranquil skyscraping vantage - a kind of front porch 850 feet in the air - the observation roof atop the RCA Building has been closed for good.

title: The U.N. Today: June 18, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: MENGELE'S SON ADMITS ENGAGING IN COVER-UP
description: The son of Josef Mengele told an American television audience yesterday that he had helped conceal the fugitive Nazi war criminal because ''I would never betray my father.''

title: O'CONNER ENDS TRIP TO LEBANON
description: The Archbishop of New York, John Cardinal O'Connor, left today after a three-day visit, saying he had failed to make contact with five American hostages.

title: Ramsey Clark Sees Qaddafi
description: Ramsey Clark, who was Attorney General under President Lyndon B. Johnson, met today with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi at the Bab el-Aziziya military barracks, Libyan television reported. Mr. Clark, who has been a critic of American foreign policy, told reporters that he was in Libya on a private visit for legal matters involving companies he is representing.

title: AS THE TWIG IS BENT...
description: MOST parents know almost instinctively that what their children eat makes a crucial difference to their present and future well-being. Yet few areas in the parent-child relationship have more potential for confusion, self-doubt, guilt and conflict. Most child-care handbooks have dealt with diet and feeding in an offhand and mechanistic manner, advocating good nutrition but ignoring the importance of nurturing.

title: Frances Lucas Phillips, 90, A Former Editor at Morrow
description: Frances Lucas Phillips, former editor in chief of William Morrow & Company, died Sunday at Spartanburg General Hospital in Spartanburg, S.C. She was 90 years old.

title: WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WHERE BURGER IS HEADED
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger will now be devoting himself to the Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution, whose 200th anniversary, Sept. 17, 1987, falls on his own 80th birthday.

title: Bethlehem Steel Workers Back Concessions Pact
description: Members of the United Steelworkers of America have ratified a new contract with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel company, that includes reductions in wages and benefits, a union spokesman said Monday.

title: OLDIES ON RISE IN ALBUM-ROCK RADIO
description: To hold on to older listeners, FM rock radio - once the primary outlet for new rock songs and performers -is cutting down on current music. Across the United States, so-called album-oriented rock (AOR) radio stations are playing an increasing amount of older material, sometimes as high as 80 percent. In some cities, these album-rock stations now face direct competition from a new kind of oldies format -''classic rock,'' which draws exclusively on the 1960's and 1970's staples of album rock.

title: HIGH COURT STRIKES DOWN A NEW YORK LAW ON VETERANS' RESIDENCY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that New York and other states that grant special preferences for Civil Service jobs to veterans may not limit this benefit to those who were state residents when they entered the military.

title: COLLECTION OF 1,000 EAKINS WORKS SOLD
description: A trove of paintings, drawings, photographs and manuscripts by the painter Thomas Eakins, which has been held privately and which art historians say could shed new light on the 19th-century artist, has been purchased by the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.

title: JUDGE ALLOWS U.S.F.L. TO SEEK $1.69 BILLION
description: A Federal District Court judge ruled yesterday that the United States Football League is entitled to seek as much as $1.69 billion in damages from the National Football League in their current antitrust lawsuit.

title: Fewer Rubles Under the Table
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's declaration of war against underground income in the Soviet Union is much more than a simple ritualistic exercise. The aim of this decree is to destroy all channels of income not controlled and sanctioned by the state; and, judging by the success of a previous Gorbachev stunt -the campaign against alcoholism initiated more than a year ago - it seems clear that he means business.

title: Tax Proposals And Shelters
description: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC. may be facing its most critical test as the Senate Finance Committee's tax provisions take shape.

title: Triple Play Near?
description: The G.T.E. academic all-America baseball team was announced the other day, and one of the members, elected to the second team, was Mickey Tresh, a junior from Miami of Ohio. Tresh is the son of Tom Tresh, who played nine years at shortstop and in the outfield for the Yankees of the 1960's and who in turn is the son of Mike Tresh, a 12-year catcher for the White Sox and the Indians.

title: Others Have Retired As U.S. Chief Justice
description: Warren E. Burger, the 15th Chief Justice of the United States, is the 6th to retire from the bench.

title: Brings the Blues
description: Rick Rhoden of the Pirates, after walking the opposing pitcher, Danny Cox, amid a St. Louis rally: ''That was a Cardinal sin.''

title: ENGLISH THINKER (1748-1832) PRESERVES HIS POISE
description: Jeremy Bentham, the father of the Utilitarian school of philosophy and various strains of modern British thought on society and law, addressed himself a year before his death in 1832 to what might have seemed to him to be the ultimate utilitarian question: ''Of what use is a dead man to the living?''

title: ELECTRO AUDIO DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains on the exchange of notes and debentures of $266,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and $266,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: A PLACE IN THE SUN ON JAPANESE TERMS
description: Leron Lee worries about Leon, his younger brother, when Leon does not hit the way Leron thinks he can. This started last year after Leon had finished his eighth year of playing baseball in Japan - and Leron, his ninth - when the Yokohama Whales decided they did not want Leon anymore. The team announced that he had not hit in the clutch, which did not make sense because Leon had had his usual good season - 31 home runs, 110 runs batted in and a .303 batting average.

title: WINE TALK
description: ADDING a good year to a vintage chart is always a pleasure, and 1985 was for the most part a very good year. California, France, Italy and Germany all made good wines - not as much as in 1984, in some instances, but certainly as good and often much better.

title: Waiver by Friedman Keeps Puccio on Case
description: The Bronx Democratic leader, Stanley M. Friedman, yesterday agreed that as a condition of retaining Thomas P. Puccio as his attorney, he would waive his right to cross-examine the former president of Citisource Inc. on certain issues.

title: Advertising; WCRS Is Causing Quite a Stir
description: IN British advertising circles, when you finish talking about the Saatchis, and if there's some time left, the conversation could very well get around to the WCRS Group, the publicly held parent of the seven-year-old Wight, Collins, Rutherford, Scott agency.

title: Kern Is Released
description: The Cleveland Indians released the veteran pitcher Jim Kern and recalled Dickie Noles from a 20-day rehabilitation program. Kern, 37, was 1-1 with a 7.90 earned run average in 16 appearances for the Indians this year.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
QED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SELECTION PRAISED BY G.O.P. SENATORS
description: Republican leaders of the Senate today praised President Reagan's selection of Justice William H. Rehnquist to become Chief Justice of the United States and predicted that he would be easily confirmed.

title: Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization June 13June 6June 14 #1986#1986#1985 Gasoline production, daily#7.1#7.2#6.6 Distillate production, daily#2.8#2.7#2.7 Gasoline stocks#226.8#222.9#216.8 Distillate stocks#101.1#99.6#107.1 Crude imports, daily#5.3#4.1#4.4 Product imports, daily#1.9#2.1#1.5 Crude stocks#319.1#330.7#352.9 Crude production, daily#8.8#8.8#9.0 Refinery utilization (%)#87.8#87.6#79.8 Source:

title: Chrysler Subcompacts
description: The Chrysler Corporation is planning to introduce twin, American-made small cars to be sold this summer by its Dodge and Plymouth divisions. The 1987 Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance are subcompacts, but will have more equipment than Chrysler's current economy cars.

title: MET STREAK HALTED AT SEVEN GAMES
description: It might be baseball's most intriguing question of the season: How does a team beat the Mets? Tonight, the Montreal Expos did it with pitching and with defense, and then, when the night was done, they talked about a race that still has the distinct appearance of a runaway.

title: AFGHAN REBEL'S VICTORY GARDEN: OPIUM
description: Fields of purple, red and white poppy flowers, contrasting brilliantly with the dull gray of the surrounding deserts, stretched toward the horizon. In one field, where the petals had fallen to the ground, a line of farmers scraped a brownish-black gum from pale green pods about the size of golf balls.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SUMMER'S first missive from the Hamptons arrived by mail earlier this week. Dear Diary: I am at Paulo's chic East Hampton beauty salon, and I watch as a client has her hair blow-dried and sprayed.

title: GENCORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
11 BLACKS KILLED DURING PROTESTS, PRETORIA REPORTS
description: Eleven blacks were killed across the country Monday during the one-day strike commemorating the uprising in Johannesburg's black satellite city of Soweto 10 years ago, the Government said today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank appointed J. Webster Hull president of Chase Bank of Florida.

title: Acronymophilia
description: When the Library of Congress installed a new computer system not long ago to keep track of new acquisitions, a contest was started to select a name for it. The old system was known as LOIS, for Library Order Information System.

title: Welcome Waldheim or No
description: It may be some time before Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d reaches a decision on whether Kurt Waldheim, the newly elected President of Austria, should be barred from the United States as a result of his activities in the German Army in World War II.

title: PRISM ENTERTAINMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
No Second Thoughts
description: ''The jury's verdict won't influence my decision pertaining to men's basketball at Tulane,'' Eamonn Kelly, the school's president, said about the acquittal on sports bribery charges of John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane star. ''My decision to drop basketball was based on N.C.A.A. violations and I don't have any second thoughts about that decision,'' Kelly said. The verdict cleared the way for the 6-foot-11-inch Williams, who had signed a two-year pact at $300,000 a year plus incentives, to play for the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: When in England . . .
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: FROM JELLYBEANS TO WIGS, LIBERTY SEASON IS ON
description: ''As impossible as this may seem,'' Kevin Simons said yesterday, ''I think New York may actually be even a little weirder than usual'' - what with the torrential hoopla over the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration.

title: Doors Accidentally Fly Open On a Rush-Hour IRT Express
description: Doors flew open on a moving Lexington Avenue express train packed with morning-rush commuters yesterday, the Transit Authority reported.

title: U.S. MAY ESTABLISH AFGHAN REBEL TIES
description: A senior Administration official said today that President Reagan held open the possibility that the United States would extend diplomatic recognition to the Afghan rebels if they acquired ''more of the attributes of a government.''

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for 13wks to May 3
description: The latest 6 months' results reflect pre-tax charges of $453,000 associated with first quarter reopening of stores, $360,000 for costs associated with closing two stores in the second quarter and a pre-tax gain of $114,000 on the sale of a store in the second quarter. The year-earlier 6 months' results include a $574,000 pre-tax gain on the sale of a store.

title: BURGER'S LETTER TO REAGAN AND THE REPLY
description: Following is the exchange of letters between President Reagan and Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, both dated June 17, 1986, as released by the White House:

title: Tosco Dismissing Chief
description: The financially troubled Tosco Corporation has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that Matthew J. Talbot, Tosco's president and chief executive, is being forced out of office. In proxy material filed with the S.E.C., the energy company said it had exercised its right to end Mr. Talbot's employment agreement as of Aug. 15.

title: Woman Guilty in BMT Attack
description: A former mental patient accused of shoving a 22-year-old woman into the path of an oncoming subway train pleaded guilty yesterday to attempted murder.

title: PROGRAMS MULTIPLY TO HELP DISPLACED HOMEMAKERS COPE
description: A LOUNGE near the elevators serves as the commencement hall. The speeches are warm, encouraging and brief. The audience includes a handful of faculty members and well-wishers. The luncheon is potluck: a variety of ethnic specialties made by the graduates.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEMENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: LIFT FROM HOUSING DATA EBBS
description: An unexpected decline in May housing starts bolstered prices in the Government bond market early yesterday, but the brief flurry of activity consisted largely of professional trading and failed to produce a significant rally.

title: SPY EXRADITION BY ISRAEL POSSIBLE
description: The Israeli Justice Minister said today that his Government would consider extraditing Israelis to the United States if they were indicted for involvement in an Israeli spy ring that bought American military secrets.

title: Recount Puts Waldon Ahead in Queens Vote
description: The results in the Sixth Congressional District special election were reversed yesterday, as the final count of paper ballots gave Assemblyman Alton R. Waldon Jr., the Democratic candidate, a 278-vote margin over the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, who had led by 197 votes in the count of voting machines.

title: NEWS? ONLY IF ROOM 159 SAYS IT IS
description: The Union Building here, designed by Sir Herbert Baker and built in a brown stone that suggests solid power, is the seat of the nation's executive authority - South Africa's equivalent of the White House, and more.

title: RENT RISES OF UP TO 9% ARE VOTED FOR STABILIZED APARTMENTS IN CITY
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board, in a meeting that was unusually brief and calm, yesterday approved basic rent increases of up to 9 percent for hundreds of thousands of rent-stabilized apartments.

title: Strength in Numbers
description: When Pamela and W. Averell Harriman open their Georgetown home for a Democratic fund-raising event, as they frequently do, tickets are likely to cost hundreds or thousands of dollars. But Friday, to attract younger and less affluent Democrats, the charge will be only $34, or $1 for each of the 34 Senate races that are at stake this fall.

title: 4 Die in Air Force Crash
description: A United States Air Force jet tanker trying to land at Howard Air Base near Panama City crashed into a hill early today, killing all four crew members, officials reported.

title: SOME KEY COURT DECISIONS BY JUDGE SCALIA
description: Here are some important decisions by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in which Judge Antonin Scalia took part:

title: FILM: IVAN REITMAN'S 'LEGAL EAGLES'
description: WITHIN certain limits, it's just possible that Debra Winger can do anything - Ellie Andrews in ''It Happened One Night,'' Rosalind in ''As You Like It,'' Amanda in ''Private Lives.'' She's not yet ready for ''The Trojan Women,'' but then, who is? Juliet might be a stretch; it'd be difficult to believe that a young woman of Miss Winger's common sense couldn't come up with a better plan to save her marriage than the one devised by the addled Friar Lawrence.

title: MEETING 3 WEEKS AGO SET OFF SEARCH, A WELL-KEPT SECRET
description: It was at a White House meeting three weeks ago that Chief Justice Warren E. Burger told President Reagan unequivocally that he wanted to retire, Administration officials said today.

title: Arson in Washington Blaze
description: A fire that caused $60,000 in damage to the offices of the United Palestinian Appeal was deliberately set, the District of Columbia police said today.

title: 202 DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: TRADE IS WORKED WITH 76ERS
description: Brad Daugherty went to bed Monday night thinking he might become a Philadelphia 76er. But by the time the 6-foot-11 1/2-inch University of North Carolina center-forward awoke yesterday morning, he was several hours away from the Cleveland Cavaliers making him the first pick in the National Basketball Association draft.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NEW BECKETT - A new Samuel Beckett creation, ''Worstward Ho,'' presented by the Mabou Mines experimental theater group, starts preview performances today at the C.S.C. Theater, 136 East 13th Street.

title: MEXICO'S FINANCE CHIEF IS OUT
description: President Miguel de la Madrid today abruptly replaced his powerful Finance Minister following reports of sharp differences within his Cabinet over Mexico's response to its latest foreign debt crisis.

title: 17 Notables in the U.S. Condemn South Africa
description: Twelve university presidents and five other prominent Americans issued a statement yesterday calling on the South African Government to ''change its course before the nation is engulfed in mass violence and irreconcilable hatreds.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LAST BLOSSOM ON THE PLUM TREE. A Period Piece. By Brooke Astor. 244 pages. Random House. $16.95. 8420THE characters in this charming new comedy of manners like to use phrases like ''top drawer'' and ''good blood'' and ''well bred.'' They ride about in Crane Simplexes and Hispano-Suizas; vacation in Monte Carlo and Baden-Baden; go dove-shooting in South Carolina and hunting in Kenya, and they live in homes with names like Villa Contenta and Bella Vista. When in London, they stay at Brown's; in New York, at the Ritz; in Rome, at the Hassler. They get their clothes from Paris, their butlers from England. The men refer to their girlfriends as mistresses; the women worry about what the servants will think.

title: SENATOR AGREES NOT TO BLOCK RENOMINATION OF JERSEY JUDGE
description: Calling it ''an extremely difficult decision,'' a key lawmaker agreed today not to block Governor Kean's renomination of Justice Stewart G. Pollock of the New Jersey Supreme Court.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: DOMINUS vobiscum. Et cum spiritu tuo.

title: BISHOPS REJECT MOVES TO EXPAND PRIESTHOOD
description: The Roman Catholic Church in this country faces a severe shortage of men entering the priesthood and of both men and women entering religious orders, a conference of bishops concluded Monday. But the bishops rejected such proposals as allowing women to be ordained or priests to marry.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,408,000 from an accounting change.

title: HOUSE BILL SEEKS SWEEPING MILITARY CHANGES
description: The House Armed Services Committee today published details of a draft bill to reorganize the nation's military, giving added power to senior generals and admirals who command combat forces in the field.

title: FRANCE EASILY DETHRONES ITALY
description: Can a team be truly called a defending champion if five key players from its championship season are no longer on the field?

title: Russian Is Round 1 Pick
description: The Portland Trail Blazers, plagued by injuries to Sam Bowie and Kenny Carr and following the old rule that you can never have enough big men, used the second of their two first-round draft picks yesterday to take Arvidas Sabonis of the Soviet Union. The 7-foot-2-inch, 245-pound Sabonis was not unknown in the United

title: Near-Record Trade Deficit
description: The United States registered a $33.67 billion deficit in the broadest measure of international trade for the first three months of the year, close to the record set in the previous quarter, the Commerce Department said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Friday about Citisource Inc., a company that once held a city contract to manufacture hand-held computers, misidentified the court-appointed receiver for the company. He is Arnold G. Fraiman.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 18, 1986
description: Court Era Ends

title: DEDICATED CONSERVATIVE JURIST: WILLIAM HUBBS REHNQUIST
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist, nominated to be Chief Justice of the United States by President Reagan today, is a conservative jurist whose polished opinions have won grudging respect even from those who oppose his views.

title: THEATER: 'THE BOYS NEXT DOOR'
description: It is hardly surprising that ''The Boys Next Door,'' Tom Griffin's play having its premiere at the McCarter Theater, is emotionally appealing. It is the story of four retarded men living in a city apartment and working at simple jobs. Mr. Griffin avoids most controversial aspects of the subject and concentrates on the men's hopes, affections and frustrations. That is a narrow focus; only a few times in two hours do we get impressions of how the rest of the world treats these men. In his determination to keep the play upbeat Mr. Griffin creates some funny situations, but he relies excessively on verbal humor throughout, and some of it is pretty corny.

title: CAMACHO HURT BY FICKLE FANS
description: Hector Camacho, who retained his World Boxing Council lightweight title on a disputed split decision Friday over Edwin Rosario, came out of the fight with a swollen nose and a cut over his left eye that required three stitches. But Camacho said his feelings were hurt worse than his face.

title: On Sleuth Cookbooks
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: ISSUE OF SEA-LAUNCHED CRUISE MISSILES IS REVIVED
description: The Soviet offer on strategic weapons has reinvigorated a debate over whether limits on nuclear-armed sea-launched cruise missiles can be verified.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD APPROVES HOTEL WITH CONDITION
description: The Board of Estimate, in approving last night a proposal to build a new first-class hotel in Brooklyn, included a provision that, for the first time, would require the developer to step aside if he were indicted on criminal charges.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in Business Day on May 24 about a consolidation in the fashion industry questioned the financial health of Jonathan Logan, the apparel company.

title: U.S. AGENCY CANCELS GRANT TO BALTIMORE STAGE FESTIVAL
description: The United States Information Agency has canceled a $45,000 grant to the group sponsoring an international theater festival in Baltimore to protest the group's withdrawal of a production of ''Animal Farm.''

title: CUOMO SAYS STATE IS WIDENING EFFORT TO COMBAT CRACK
description: New York State will expand drug rehabilitation programs and allocate $2 million to the special narcotics prosecutor as part of a new effort to fight crack, the smokable form of cocaine, Governor Cuomo announced yesterday.

title: Decision Due on Coach
description: The Islanders, who have been without a coach since Al Arbour announced his retirement last month, are expected this morning to name Terry Simpson to that post. The 42-year-old Simpson has been with a junior team, the Prince Albert Raiders of the Western Hockey League, for the last 15 years and is expected to resign his position as coach and general manager there to become head coach for the Islanders. . . . Gil Perreault, an original Buffalo Sabre and the team captain, has announced his retirement from the National Hockey League. The 35-year old Perreault, who was the first player chosen in the 1970 amateur draft, the same year Buffalo entered the N.H.L., said: ''It was a tough decision to make but there's a time for everything and today's the day.''

title: Toward a Rehnquist Court
description: With two unambiguous Supreme Court nominations, President Reagan has done what he said he'd do, what his warmest supporters hoped and strongest foes feared he'd do. Permitted to name a new Chief Justice, he chose William Rehnquist, once a lonely dissenter on the Court's extreme right wing. And to fill the vacancy he picked Antonin Scalia of the Federal Court of Appeals in Washington, who most closely promises the judicial philosophy of the President. The nominees are not only of like ideology; both are skilled and energetic.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS GETS ACCORD ON ACCOUNTING
description: The American Express Company won a compromise settlement yesterday in its two-year battle with the Securities and Exchange Commission over accounting practices that the commission said had artificially inflated the company's earnings in 1981 and 1982.

title: 6 Victims in Racial Strife Ask Charges Be Dropped
description: Six of the eight white people who were shot in a racial incident last week, reportedly by a black man, have asked that charges be dropped against the suspect in order to relieve tensions.

title: Former Fed Official Hired by Yamaichi
description: Scott E. Pardee, a former official of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has joined a Japanese securities firm, Yamaichi International (America) Inc., as vice chairman, the firm announced yesterday.

title: Pirate Protest Is Upheld
description: Charles Feeney, the National League president, today upheld the Pittsburgh Pirates' protest that the rain-abbreviated game they lost, 4-1, to the St. Louis Cardinals Monday night was improperly called by the umpires.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. BOSTON RED SOX, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television -SpotsChannel, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 17
description: b-Includes tax credits of $910,000 for the latest quarter and $310,000 for the year-ago period.

title: ITALIAN TRIAL TO OPEN TODAY IN HIJACKING OF ACHILLE LAURO
description: Fifteen people are to go on trial here Wednesday accused in the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE character of omelets seems to change from nation to nation and even from region to region. The most basic is the French omelet, with eggs and butter in a pan cooked over high heat. The eggs are then flipped into an oval shape onto a plate. Fillings are optional.

title: FOR FLEDGLING ARTISTS, A PLACE TO GROW
description: WORKING on a recent morning in a sun-drenched space above the galleries of the Studio Museum in Harlem, Nadine DeLawrence-Main, one of the museum's two current resident artists, bent over canvas of irregular forms. Swirling on color, a pulsating shade of orange, with a painter's knife, the artist, dressed in faded jeans and a sweatshirt, stepped back from time to time to survey her strokes.

title: JUDGE WITH TENACITY AND CHARM: ANTONIN SCALIA
description: To Judge Abner J. Mikva, a liberal member of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, his colleague Antonin Scalia is a conservative but not antigovernment.

title: WHITES ENFORCED A PEACE ON MONDAY, BUT BLACKS SHOWED STRENGTH IN STRIKE
description: If South Africa's sadness and agony had some kind of scorecard, then its figures today - the day after the 10th anniversary of the most significant date in the chronicles of black resistance - would seem lopsided in favor of the white authorities.

title: U.S. Eases Rules for Hospitals
description: The Government today issued new standards that it said would reduce the administrative burdens that about 1,500 small, mostly rural hospitals must meet to qualify for Medicare and Medicaid payments.

title: A PORTRAIT OF CHURCHILL
description: AS a producer, David Susskind has been unusually fond of one-man shows. His credits include two Shakespearean solos, ''The Ages of Man,'' with Sir John Gielgud, and ''Acting Shakespeare,'' with Ian McKellan. Closer to home, he offered ''Mark Twain Tonight.'' In the political arena, there have been portraits of Harry S. Truman and John F. Kennedy. In each case, the biographical study has been unabashedly admiring, and more of the same is on tap tonight, on WNET/Channel 13 at 9 o'clock, for ''Winston Churchill.''

title: STRIKING UNION REACHES AN ACCORD WITH A.T.&T.
description: The Communications Workers of America and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company reached a tentative settlement yesterday that could end the strike by 155,000 union members by Sunday.

title: CYANIDE DEATH HALTS THE SALE OF EXCEDRIN CAPSULES
description: The manufacturer of Extra-Strength Excedrin asked stores around the country to quit selling it today after the death of a banker here was attributed to cyanide-laced capsules of the pain-reliever.

title: HOW SOLOISTS SELECT STYLES FOR THE STAGE
description: FREDERICA VON STADE, the Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano, loves ruffles and bright colors - especially blue - and shoes, and not necessarily in that order.

title: BASQUES ARE BLAMED
description: Two army officers and their driver were shot dead in southern Madrid today, and the police and political leaders said they suspected Basque separatists had carried out the killings to upset national elections scheduled for Sunday.

title: DOCUMENTARY OF EVE PERON
description: IF you saw ''Evita,'' the big Broadway musical, you really don't have to watch ''Queen of Hearts,'' the hourlong documentary on WNET/Channel 13 tonight at 11 o'clock. The subject, the life and times of Eva Duarte de Peron, is similiar and so is the viewpoint from which it is seen. The only difference is that the documentary, narrated by Diana Rigg, uses interviews and old newsreel film.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for 13wks to May 31
Colombian Gunmen Use Crane to Attack Official
description: Leftist guerrillas rammed a crane into a motorcade carrying Colombia's Interior Minister as he rode through central Bogota today and fired at his bodyguards, the police said. The official escaped unhurt, but a policeman was killed.

title: INTEGRITY OF WITNESS ATTACKED AS DEFENSE OPENS AT SPY TRIAL
description: Two witnesses in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth testified today that they might have unwittingly been used by the prosecution's star witness, John A. Walker Jr., to leave stolen military data for Soviet agents.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 18, 1986
description: International

title: N.B.A. DISORDER: KEVINMCHALEITIS
description: Kevinmchaleitis is the medical world's newest physiological disorder. Although contagious, it is found only in the thinking process of National Basketball Association teams hoping to dethrone the Boston Celtics as champions. The primary symptom is the acquisition of a forward capable of coping with the 6-foot-10-inch Celtic for whom the disorder is named. Both before and during yesterday's National Basketball Association draft, several teams appeared to be afflicted.

title: 76ERS TRADE MALONE TO ACQUIRE RULAND
description: Seeking more speed and proven talent, the Philadelphia 76ers carved the center out of last season's team with a series of last-minutes trades.

title: CARDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes provisions for losses on disposal of engine remanufacturing operations of $193,000 for the quarter and $343,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and includes losses from discontinued engine remanufacturing operations of $63,800 for the quarter and $87,700 for the 6 months and tax credits of $397,400 for the quarter and $534,300 for the 6 months.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN REBEL LEADER AT U.N. CONFERENCE
description: The Rev.

title: HELEN OF TROY (CO)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss. The 1985 figures for the year are not available because the company changed its fiscal year-end to Feb. 28 from Dec. 31.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net loss

title: Trial Date Set in Murders
description: Richard Ramirez, accused of 14 slayings and 31 other felony counts stemming from a series of nighttime attacks that terrorized Californians, was ordered to stand trial Sept. 2 after a defense request for a delay was rejected today. Arturo Hernandez, a defense lawyer, also said today that he would seek a change of venue to northern California because of the widespread publicity here about the case in killings done by a man often described as the ''night stalker.''

title: U.S. PRINTING MAY LOSE ITS OLD SHIELD
description: All but overlooked in the high-voltage debate over international trade, an obscure little corner of United States trade policy is about to have a moment, perhaps its last moment, in the spotlight.

title: Dedicated Conservative Jurist - William Hubbs Rehnquist
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 - Justice William H. Rehnquist, nominated to be Chief Justice of the United States by President Reagan today, is a conservative jurist whose polished opinions have won grudging respect even from those who oppose his views.

title: The High Price Of Success
description: Even as all of Brazil waits breathlessly to see how its national team fares against France in the World Cup quarterfinals this Saturday, there's a reminder that everything has a price. According to an article in Rio de Janeiro's most prestigious daily newspaper, Jornal do Brasil, the Brazilians' soccer success is having a deleterious effect on the country's economic health, which, given one of the biggest external debts in the world, is none too good to begin with.

title: FEMALE FIREFIGHTERS CHARGE INACTION ON SEX BIAS
description: The head of the city's female firefighters association charged yesterday that women in the Fire Department experienced pervasive sexual harassment - ranging from tasteless pranks to the denial of various jobs - and that department officials have done little to correct the problems.

title: King of the Road
description: Get tired of driving? Then consider Richard Petty, who's rolled up some 350,000 miles on the race track alone since joining the stock-car circuit in 1958.

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $62,000 on a tax credit.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON RESIGNATION OF CHIEF JUSTICE
description: Following is a transcript of a statement in Washington yesterday by President Reagan announcing the resignation of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and key questions and answers that followed, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: SWEDLOW INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
THE POPSICLE'S REJUVENATION
description: In an age of Frozfruits, Pudding Pops and $2 Dove Bars, is there still a place for the simple Popsicle?

title: Dow Off 5.99, to 1,865.78
description: Stock prices drifted downward on Wall Street yesterday and trading volume remained depressed as investors, already concerned about this week's expiration of stock index options and futures, were also bothered by weakness in the economy.

title: Hartford National
description: The Hartford National Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the First New England Bankshares Corporation of Taunton, Mass., and its subsidiary, First Bristol County National Bank. Hartford National said it would exchange common shares valued at $88.1 million for all 2,077,746 shares of First New England subject to an adjustment based on the market price of Hartford National stock before closing.

title: NETWORKS CITE PRESSURE FOR SELF-CENSORSHIP
description: The South African Government's ban yesterday on live news transmissions and its earlier restrictions on news coverage were seen by broadcast journalists as a frustrating but effective ploy in South Africa's effort to force self-censorship on television journalists.

title: NASA STUDIES ROLE OF HEADQUARTERS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it was investigating the extent to which headquarters personnel should have been aware of problems with the space shuttle's O ring seals. Officials of the agency also said that a high-level office would be established to monitor such problems in the future.

title: TENNIS LADY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Net income after an extraordinary gain of $75,000 from an accounting change.

title: U.S. AWAITING RETURN OF SOVIET AMBASSADOR
description: The new Soviet Ambassador is expected to return here from Moscow soon with the Kremlin's thinking about moving ahead with plans for the next meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Administration officials said today.

title: RUMORS SPUR SAFEWAY STOCK
description: Safeway Stores stock jumped $2.625 in heavy trading yesterday, to $50.50, as market rumors spread that the nation's biggest supermarket chain was considering several defensive steps to fight off a possible takeover move by the multimillionaire Haft family of Washington.

title: U.S. TO SPUR LICENSING OF EXPORTS
description: The Reagan Administration, under mounting Congressional and business pressure to strengthen the nation's trading position, announced a plan today to streamline the unwieldy process that companies go through to receive an export license.

title: May Starts Of Housing Down 7.4%
description: Starts of housing construction, one of the few bright spots in the economy, suffered a 7.4 percent drop in May for the biggest setback in a year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: At the Border: From Coolies to Demons
description: If there were a Layman's List of Favorite Demons, fruit and vegetable growers would probably place near the top. They depend on poorly paid illegal aliens. Worse, many people think the growers also mistreat them cruelly, refusing even such minimal decencies as field toilets. No wonder the growers oppose the proposed immigration reform bill, according to the demonology; it would curtail the supply of exploitable labor.

title: Drexel Expects Building Deal
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. expects to sign a lease today for a 47-story tower under construction at 7 World Trade Center on Vesey Street between West Broadway and Washington Street. The securities firm will consolidate its operations from four other buildings, according to Robert E. Linton, Drexel's chairman.

title: Kodak Markets Debentures
description: The Eastman Kodak Company began offering $300 million of 30-year sinking fund debentures yesterday through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: OVEX FERTILITY CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $28,529, or 3 cents a share.

title: Logs for the Scouts Lodge At Pouch Camp
description: Last March, the Boy Scouts activities lodge at the William H. Pouch Camp on Staten Island burned down in a fire set by vandals.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $272,000 for the quarter and $871,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $466,000 for the quarter and $596,000 for the 9 months. The latest 9-month period includes a gain of $571,000 on the sale of land.

title: Walker Picked First By Knicks
description: Scotty Stirling emerged from 10 days of self-imposed exile late yesterday afternoon looking haggard, worn and very much like a man filled with diverse emotions. His first draft day as a Knick executive was primarily a success. After going to great lengths to hide his intentions from the public, Stirling selected the player he says he wanted all along - Kenny (Sky) Walker, a 6-foot-8-inch hard-working forward from the University of Kentucky.

title: 11 GIMBELS STORES ARE SOLD BY BATUS
description: Batus Inc., which has been divesting itself of the Gimbels department store chain, announced the sale yesterday of 11 Gimbels stores in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Neill Cameron has been elected a member of the board at Ogilvy & Mather U.S. and Jerry McGee, Brendan Ryan, Jay Schulberg and Jennifer Stewart were named executive vice presidents.

title: COMPUTERS: AN EXTRA BECOMES AN ESSENTIAL
description: The young artist burst into giggles, tickled by her portrait's mischievous grin, or perhaps its green hair.

title: THATCHER HOLDS FAST IN BATTLE OVER SANCTIONS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher stood up to criticism in the House of Commons today in resisting the adoption of British economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: Required Reading; Sickbedside Monitor
description: Excerpts from remarks by Mark S. Fowler, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, at a recent public meeting in which he praised the commission's decision to allow the Bell telephone companies and A.T.&.T. more flexibility in marketing call-answering, message-storage and other ''enhanced'' services:

title: Milton 18, Destiny 0
description: My Uncle Milton has been a new man ever since the Internal Revenue Service notified him of the date he is going to die.

title: Better School Boards, Large and Small
description: ''Responsible'' is both a compliment and a description; both meanings apply to Mayor Koch's desire for more authority over New York City's Board of Education. It's not often that public officials want to be held accountable for agencies' performance. A full response to the city's deteriorated school system, however, needs to address the community school boards as well.

title: Group Vice President For Du Pont Auto Unit
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which already sells $2 billion a year in materials to the auto industry, expects that market to grow, especially if the auto built largely of plastic becomes commonplace. The key Du Pont official shepherding this growth is John P. McAndrews.

title: Housing Discrimination Against Children Is Illegal in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPECT SOUGHT
description: A 15-year-old boy who was roller-skating on an abandoned stretch of the elevated West Side Highway in Manhattan was stabbed to death there Monday night, and the police were seeking a homeless man for questioning in the slaying.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Let Esmeralda Sail in Liberty's Flotilla
description: To the Editor:

title: BLEACHER COLLAPSE WAS 2D FOR CIRCUS
description: The collapse of bleachers at a circus performance in Greenport, N.Y., on Monday night was the second such incident for the circus in about a month, officials said yesterday.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Fresh, Cold Juice - Just Pik't is pure fresh-squeezed Florida orange juice, flash frozen and shipped to market in an oblong plastic bottle designed to expand and contract as the juice freezes and thaws. The product, marketed by the Fresh Juice Company of Great Neck, L.I., is delicious and exceptionally sweet, superior to concentrate or pasteurized juice, which have a cooked flavor.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 18
description: Latest quarter results include an after-tax gain of $5,345,000, or 20 cents a share, from the settling of the accumulated benefits under a retirement plan by purchasing annuities with plan assets. Latest quarter earnings also include an after-tax gain of $2,817,000, or 11 cents a share, from the May 16 sale of the company's Hot Sam Cos. division.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'AIDA' IN CENTRAL PARK CONCERT
description: GIVEN halfway decent weather, the first free Metropolitan Opera concert performance each year in Central Park is always an event, and last night's ''Aida,'' opening the company's 20th parks season, was no exception. The weather was beautifully clear and crisp, not to say downright chilly, and between 75,000 and 100,000 opera lovers turned out for the occasion, complete with picnics, balloons and a raucous blend of cheers and boos for Mayor Koch, who made a shorter address than usual to his assembled constituents.

title: COURT REBUFFS BID TO TIGHTEN POISON CONTROL
description: The Supreme Court today spared the Federal Government from having to tighten its control over some poisons in food.

title: STAGE: 'TEXAS DREAM BAR JAMBOREE'
description: ''ALL aboard the self-pity train - it's leaving on that same old track again!'' announces Sam (Harry Bennett), the homily-spouting bartender of a downtown New York country-and-western bar toward the end of ''The Texas Dream Bar Jamboree.''

title: F.D.A. Questions Upjohn Statement
description: The Food and Drug Administration has accused the Upjohn Company of issuing a false and misleading press release in April regarding the effectiveness of a drug that the company is seeking to market as a treatment for baldness.

title: Hear Ye in the Court
description: The surprising thing about the coming changes on the Supreme Court is that they have not occurred earlier.

title: ROBOT DEFENSE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BRITISH ROCK BANDS ADD A MESSAGE TO THE MUSIC
description: AMERICAN rock musicians have been heard to complain, with some justification, that they can play in small clubs and struggle for years without attracting the interest of a major record label. In Britain, they point out, the rock audience's voracious appetite for novelty results in the discovery of a new band every 15 minutes or so. And once these new British bands are discovered and recorded, American labels would rather pick one of them up - prepackaged, so to speak - than put in the hard work entailed in keeping track of promising new bands in the United States.

title: Connecticut Issue Of $162.6 Million
description: Connecticut began offering $162.6 million of general obligation bonds yesterday to refund outstanding bonds sold when interest rates were higher.

title: Worker Who Spawned Solidarity Is Arrested
description: Anna Walentynowicz, the crane operator whose dismissal touched off a nationwide strike that led to the creation of Solidarity in 1980, has been arrested by Polish authorities, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Supreme Court of the United States is the final arbiter of our Constitution and the meaning of our laws.

title: WARNER COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SCALIA, APPEALS JUDGE, CHOSEN FOR COURT
description: President Reagan today announced the retirement of Warren Earl Burger as Chief Justice of the United States after 17 years and the intention to nominate Associate Justice William Hubbs Rehnquist to replace him.

title: Fink Aide Announces His Candidacy
description: The man behind the political scenes is coming out front.

title: LET ESMERALDA SAIL IN LIBERTY'S FLOTILLA
description: To the Editor:

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The 1985 quarter and year share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in October.

title: ANDERSON TO BLOCK CURB ON CAMPAIGN FINANCES
description: The majority leader of the State Senate said today that his house would not support new restrictions on campaign financing, in effect killing the Democratic proposal for this legislative session.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a $6.3 million loss from discontinued operations. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Bridge: Goren Foursome Is Winner Of Cavendish Challenge Cup
description: An unusual event was inaugurated last week by the Cavendish Club, 105 East 73d Street in Manhattan.

title: RED SOX HOLD OFF YANKS, 7-6
description: Ken Griffey baffled the Yankees by his unexplained absence last night, and Alfonso Pulido baffled Boston with his assortment of off-speed pitches. The Yankees nearly put one over on the Red Sox, but they fell a run short, losing by 7-6, after leaving six runners on base in the last two innings.

title: Ethics Unit Rules Aide To City Can Take Job
description: The City Board of Ethics ruled yesterday that a top aide to Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin would not violate conflict-of-interest rules by accepting a position with an investment house that does business with the city.

title: Making Mushrooms Fancy
description: FLUTING a mushroom is one of the first techniques I learned as a teen-age apprentice in the restaurant kitchens of Paris. Back in those formal and highly stylized days, a chef would no sooner send out an unfluted or uncarved mushroom than he would greet customers while wearing a grease-smudged kitchen jacket.

title: THE BERRIES: FROM FOOL TO FLUMMERY
description: BERRIES and summer go hand in hand, the one evoking the other as naturally as strawberries and cream. Berries are everywhere now: along the Maine shore, wild strawberries are adrift in the salt meadows, while low bushes of blueberries are starting to ripen in the mountains of Vermont; thimbleberries and sour serviceberries, a boon to thirsty backpackers, rim glacial pools high in the Colorado Rockies, and along Michigan roadsides, fields of cultivated raspberry canes bow down with the weight of the maturing fruit.

title: What Economic Rebound?
description: These are heady days on Wall Street. With stock prices soaring and new issues surging through the market, there has been a revival of economic confidence. While the steady stream of rosy economic news we have been hearing since the deep recession of 1982 has turned a bit less rosy in the past year, most economists remain optimistic. After all, unemployment is way down from its 1982 peak of nearly 11 percent, inflation remains low and oil prices have sharply declined. Nevertheless, the economy has not recovered.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WELSH HAS KEY HIT AS REDS WIN, 5-4
description: The pitcher Chris Welsh lined a two-run single to highlight a decisive three-run sixth inning tonight that carried the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-4 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Layoffs at GTE
description: The GTE Corporation said it would lay off about 300 employees at the Burlingame, Calif., headquarters of GTE Sprint as a result of the previously announced merger of Sprint with U.S. Telecom, the long-distance unit of United Telecommunications Inc. The merged concern, U.S. Sprint Communications Company, will be based in Kansas City, Mo. A Sprint spokesman said 450 employees would be transferred there from Burlingame.

title: PANAMANIAN, DENYING CHARGES, SAYS HE WON'T QUIT
description: The commander of the Panamanian Army denied all charges of involvement in criminal activities today and brushed aside calls from the opposition for his resignation.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL LOS ANGELES (NL) - Purchased the contract of the catcher Jack Fimple from Albuquerque of the Pacific Coast League.

title: PHOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE SUPREME COURT: DECISIONS IN THE OVAL OFFICE
description: From John Jay to Warren Earl Burger: The 15 Chief Justices John Jay...Born: Dec. 12, 1745, in New York City.... Died: May 17, 1829, in Bedford, N.Y.... College: King's College (Columbia)....Appointed: By Washington in 1789; Resigned: 1795.; John Rutledge...Born: September 1739, Charleston, S.C....Died: June 21, 1800, in Charleston...Law school: Inns of Court, London....Appointed: Pro tem by Washington in 1795 for less than one year...Served as Associate Justice.; Oliver Ellsworth...Born: April 29, 1745, in Windsor, Conn....Died: Nov. 26, 1807, in Windsor....College: Princeton...Appointed: By Washington in 1796...Resigned: 1800.; John Marshall...Born: Sept. 24, 1755, Germantown, Va....Died: July 6, 1835, Philadelphia, Pa....Law school: William and Mary...Appointed: By Adams in 1801. Died in office.; Roger Brooke Taney...Born: March 17, 1777, in Calvert County, Md....Died: Oct. 12, 1864, in Washington, D.C....College: Dickinson...Appointed: By Jackson in 1835, confirmed in 1836. Died in office; Salmon Portland Chase...Born: Jan, 13, 1808, in Corninsh, N.H....Died: May 7, 1873, in New York City...College: Dartmouth...Appointed: By Lincoln in 1864. Died in office.; Morrison Remick Waite...Born: Nov. 29, 1816, in Lyme, Conn....Died: March 23, 1888, in Washington, D.C....College: Yale...Appointed: By Grant in 1874. Died in office.; Melville Weston Fuller...Born: Feb. 11, 1833, in Augusta, Me....Died: July 4, 1910, in Sorrento, Me....College: Bowdoin...Law school: Harvard...Appointed: By Cleveland in 1888. Died in office.; Edward Douglas White...Born: Nov. 3, 1845, in Parish of Lafourche, La....Died: May 19, 1921, in Washington, D.C....Colleges: Mount St. Mary's, Georgetown.

title: Thailand Reports Rise In Vietnamese Refugees
description: The number of Vietnamese ''boat people'' reaching Thailand in the first five months of this year climbed by nearly 20 percent over the comparable period last year, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Changing of Guard At the High Court
description: In the Oval Office, a surprise announcement by the Chief Justice three weeks ago set off a high-level secret search for his replacement.

title: PRECISION FILM & VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wire-by-Wire View Of the Javits Center
description: At Electric '86, the first trade show of electrical-equipment suppliers at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, a tour of the building yesterday turned out to be one of the biggest attractions.

title: YELENA BONNER MEMOIR TO BE PUBLISHED IN FALL
description: Publishers in the United States and seven Western European nations will simultaneously publish this fall a memoir by Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of the Soviet physicist Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov. The book, which was written during Miss Bonner's recent six-month visit to the United States, will describe the Sakharovs' life in Gorky, the Soviet city to which Dr. Sakharov was exiled in 1980 after he publicly criticized the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. It will also describe Miss Bonner's recent experiences in the United States.

title: G.M. in Venture With Egyptians
description: The General Motors Corporation will make compact and midsized cars in Egypt in a joint venture with Egyptian partners beginning next year, G.M. said. A company statement said the joint-venture concern, the General Misr Car Company, will build and market compact Opel Corsas and midsized Opel Asconas, with production scheduled to begin in mid-1987.

title: A BELOVED BRITISH ECCENTRIC
description: Lady Diana Cooper, the legendary beauty of an age long past, who moved with equal ease among High Bohemians and Britain's political elite, died Monday at the London home where she had been bedridden for two years. She was 93 years old.

title: Houston Bonds' Top Yield Is 8.24%
description: A $183.5 million issue of Houston refunding and capital improvement bonds was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

title: New Foreign Minister Is Selected in Austria
description: Peter Jankowitsch, a foreign policy specialist for Austria's Social Democratic Party and a former delegate to the United Nations, was named Foreign Minister on Monday to succeed Leopold Gratz.

title: HARVEST STARTS OF SMALLER CROP, A RESULT OF LAW AND WEATHER
description: A stillness lay over the vast, golden plains of Oklahoma and Kansas. Heavy clouds hung low overhead, and no breath of wind stirred any stalk of wheat.

title: FRANKFURT COURT BANS TWO BOOKS
description: The manager of Frankfurt's repertory theater has obtained temporary court injunctions banning the distribution of two books that quote him as saying the ''no-hunting season'' for Jews is over in West Germany - meaning that West Germans could now criticize Jews freely.

title: NEW REPORTS ON SCANDAL ROCK ISRAEL
description: A new dispute erupted in Jerusalem today over charges that the former Attorney General leaked secrets to reporters this week to put pressure on his successor, Yosef Harish, to investigate allegations against the head of Shin Beth, the internal security organization.

title: F.T.C. Settles With Warner
description: Warner Communications and Polygram Records agreed to seek Government approval before attempting to acquire any interest in another record company, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday.

title: BUDGET PRESSURES FORCING ISSUE OF ISRAELI FIGHTER
description: For years, Israel has enjoyed a special place in the United States program to provide military assistance to friendly nations.

title: To Another Grown-Up
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on the front page of Metropolitan Report on Saturday misidentified a resident pulling a small wagon on the dock at Saltaire, L.I. He was Donald Rubin, not Michael Winship.

title: OUT WEST, RESTAURANTS DIVIDE TO CONQUER
description: In a town that thrives on sequels - ''Poltergeist II,'' ''Karate Kid II'' and the various generations of ''Jaws'' and ''Rocky'' -some of the most popular restaurants in Los Angeles are opening spinoffs of themselves, in a sort of ''son of'' movement for food aficionados.

title: MUSIC: 'THE WARRIOR ANT,' BY BREUER AND TELSON
description: LEE BREUER and Bob Telson have made considerable names for themselves with their vernacularly based music-theater pieces - ''Sister Suzie Cinema,'' a ''doo-wop opera,'' in 1980 and ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' a blend of the Oedipus tale with gospel singing, in 1983.

title: RESHAPED COURT TO FACE MAJOR ISSUES
description: In the next few years the Supreme Court will probably face a series of momentous cases dealing with civil rights, abortion, church-state relations and the constitutionality of independent Federal agencies, according to lawyers who follow the Court.

title: KATE SMITH, ALL-AMERICAN SINGER, DIES AT 79
description: Kate Smith, whose vibrant voice made ''God Bless America'' an unofficial national anthem and was one of the most popular singers of the century, died yesterday afternoon at Raleigh (N.C.) Community Hospital. She was 79 years old and lived in Raleigh.

title: St. Francis Prep Takes Title, 4-0
description: Rob McDermott, an undefeated right-hander, won his 10th game as he pitched St. Francis Prep to a 4-0 victory over Nazareth in the New York City Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship yesterday afternoon at Shea Stadium.

title: A Vote for the City
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: 51,000 PAROCHIAL SCHOOL STUDENTS LOST REMEDIAL AID AFTER RULING
description: The number of parochial school children receiving federally financed remedial instruction has declined by more than 50,000 as a result of a Supreme Court ruling last July, an Education Department official said today.

title: Deterrence Overkill
description: To the Editor:

title: MEASURING THE GREAT LADY
description: When the museum at the base of the Statue of Liberty opens to the public on July 5, visitors will find among its many exhibits life-size reproductions of the statue's face and left foot, which they can touch to gain a sense of Lady Liberty's size.

title: Police Seeking a Man In Strangling of Priest
description: A 57-year-old Episcopal priest from New York City was found strangled in his vacation home here Sunday and authorities were looking today for a young man seen with the priest hours before the murder.

title: TRADE TALKS: EUROPE HOPEFUL BUT WARNS U.S.
description: The 12 European Community nations said today that they were ready to open new global trade-freeing negotiations covering agriculture and services as early as September, but they warned that the United States must also be ready to make concessions.

title: 51-Story Hotel Planned For Site on W. 54th St.
description: A 51-story hotel, consisting entirely of luxury suites and catering to traveling executives, will rise on West 54th Street, the developers announced yesterday.

title: HOUSE REJECTS OFFER FROM SENATE ON 1987 BUDGET
description: House and Senate negotiators remained deadlocked on a 1987 budget today as the House rejected a Senate compromise offer.

title: CBS Stake Lifted
description: The Loews Corporation said today that it had increased its stake in CBS Inc. from 17.7 percent, to 19.7 percent.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: HANDSOME CONTAINERS
description: 1. Miniature Chest:

title: Real Estate; Suburban Site Gets New Look
description: ALTHOUGH White Plains has led the pace of commercial development in Westchester County, some people believe that many of the sleek buildings that have recently risen bring coldness to the central business district.

title: Why the U.S. Is Modernizing Chemical Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: ISSUE OF WOMEN AS RABBIS BREAKS UP JEWISH UNIT
description: The Jewish commission that has approved rabbis as chaplains for the United States armed forces since World War I broke up yesterday over whether a rabbi who is a woman can serve as a military chaplain.

title: REPEAL OF TAX ON FOREIGNERS LOSES
description: Senator Bob Packwood and the Republican leadership suffered their first defeat on the tax-revision legislation tonight when the Senate approved a measure involving foreign investors in the United States.

title: Torch-Bearers Sought
description: If Washington can ever have an excess of liberty, a surfeit of symbolism, it may happen over at the Capital Hilton Hotel this afternoon when Ron Smith conducts his search for the best Statue of Liberty look-alike. Mr. Smith has a sort of no-talent talent agency in Hollywood that he calls Ron Smith's Celebrity Look-Alikes, which says it has found 10,000 otherwise unexceptional people who look like President Reagan, the Princess of Wales, Dolly Parton and many others.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: AS millions of sun-hungry Americans head for sea and shore, summer camps and lakeside cottages to enjoy the outdoors, almost all of them should take along one item - a sunscreen.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section on April 17 about discount furniture retailers in North Carolina described the status of the Dawl Furniture Company of High Point incorrectly. The company is currently in a Chapter 11 reorganization proceeding and continues to operate.

title: LATEST CRISIS AT THE U.N.: PRICE OF MIDTOWN PARKING
description: While the Security Council wrestled with South African raids on Angola today, three floors below, in a basement conference room, speakers debated another delicate issue: the price of parking.

title: Walgreen Offers New Debentures
description: The Walgreen Company, a major drug chain based in Deerfield, Ill., is offering $100 million of 9 1/2 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2016 at a price of 99.75, to yield 9.525 percent, through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: BURGER RESHAPED OFFICE IF NOT LAW HE INHERITED
description: Warren E. Burger will be leaving a Supreme Court that in terms of judicial doctrine has not been notably different from the one he inherited 17 years ago when President Nixon named him the 15th Chief Justice of the United States.

title: Dual-Purpose Offering By State Urban Agency
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation tentatively priced $510 million of correctional facilities revenue and refunding bonds yesterday with yields as high as 8.10 percent for bonds due in 2015.

title: APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $495,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income and includes a tax charge of $45,000. d-Includes a tax credit of $288,000.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The latest 9-month period includes results of Cluett, Peabody & Company, which was acquired Jan. 15, 1986. The results have been included only since that date.

title: Mothers Are Favored In Most Custody Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Howard, Merrell Lands A $12 Million Account
description: For an agency with $23 million in billings, winning a $12 million account is a real windfall. And such a bonanza has befallen Howard, Merrell & Partners of Raleigh, N.C.

title: COURT WOULD EASE TOWARD CONSERVATIVISM WITHOUT ABRUPTLY CHANGING IN DIRECTION
description: The ideological balance of the Supreme Court is likely to shift perceptibly to the right if the Senate confirms President Reagan's selections of Justice William H. Rehnquist to become Chief Justice and Judge Antonin Scalia to become an Associate Justice.

title: Judge With Tenacity and Charm - Antonin Scalia
description: WASHINGTON -- To Judge Abner J. Mikva, a liberal member of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, his colleague Antonin Scalia is a conservative but not antigovernment.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Economic Scene; Little Change For the Czechs
description: ALTHOUGH the world may little note nor much care, Czechoslovakia has a new Government this week. The old Government resigned last Friday and 87-year-old President Gustav Husak appointed a new Government Monday morning, acting in behalf of the Communist Party and the National Front Central Committee.

title: Key Rates
Parole Appeal Is Lost By Clemency Winner
description: Gary McGivern, serving a prison sentence of 25 years to life in the fatal shooting of a deputy sheriff, has lost a second round in his bid for parole, the State Parole Board chairman said today.

title: Morales Jailed
description: George Morales, the world powerboat racing champion, has been jailed by Federal officials in Miami on charges he conspired to smuggle 1,200 to 1,500 kilograms of cocaine into south Florida. The 37-year-old Colombian-born Morales, was arrested on a warrant from the United States Drug Enforcement Administration Friday and Magistrate Peter Palermo agreed to hold him without bail Monday after Assistant United States Attorney Greg Kehoe called Morales a danger to the community because of the amount of drugs.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., said it had agreed to sell six acute-care hospitals in Texas and Oklahoma to Medical Homecare Inc. for $52 million.

title: FRANK PETITO, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: Frank A. Petito, former chairman of Morgan Stanley & Company, died of prostate cancer Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and had homes in Manhattan, Stone Harbor, N.J., and Tequesta, Fla.

title: Two Get Prison Terms In Theft at St. Patrick's
description: Two men who carried out a $7,000 robbery at St. Patrick's Cathedral were sentenced to prison yesterday by Justice Irving Lang in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: SCIENTISTS HOPEFUL OF RESTORING CHALLENGER TAPES
description: Scientists say they have developed a process that they hope can save any voice recordings that might have been made by astronauts in the final seconds of the flight of the space shuttle Challenger, according to space agency officials.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We are building a vacation home in the mountains that will have an exterior of redwood siding. The builder tells us that redwood needs very little maintenance. Can you tell us how it ages and what we should do to maintain it? A. Redwood stands up very well outdoors, even if given no protection. However if unprotected it will turn gray and darken and may even tend to split or check - but this depends on the grade of redwood. That is why most experts recommend that you apply a sealer and continue applying additional coats as necessary when the wood first begins to show signs of weathering.

title: JAZZ: PARIS REUNION BAND
description: THE Paris Reunion Band, an eight-piece ensemble made up of American jazz musicians who now live in Europe, primarily in Paris, or who once lived in Paris for an extended period, began a brief existence as a group on Tuesday evening at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street. It is playing there through Sunday with the Roy Haynes Quartet in a salute to the late drummer Kenny Clark, a longtime resident of Paris.

title: DALTON COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Bill on Telephone Companies
description: Power to control the future of the nation's largest telephone companies would shift from a Federal court to the Federal Communications Commission under legislation introduced today by Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader.

title: DANGEROUS ASIAN MOSQUITO INVADES FOUR SOUTHERN STATES
description: An aggressive, dangerous Asian mosquito has established itself for the first time in the United States, and health experts fear it will spread and become a major new carrier of serious diseases in this country, Latin America and the Caribbean.

title: NO NEW INSIDER LAWS ARE NEEDED, SHAD SAYS
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that no new legislation was necessary to combat problems with insider trading. He also complained about charges that the S.E.C. was incapable of stopping the widespread abuse of inside information.

title: DEL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
FRIEDMAN TRIAL MAY BE MOVED A SECOND TIME
