description: If the Federal corruption trial of Stanley M. Friedman and five others is forced to be moved again by a delay -which appears likely - it may be held in Waterbury, Conn., officials familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Key Rates
description: Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net Income

title: A Great Performance
description: Cliff Robertson, the actor, and Pelle Petterson, a yachtsman from Sweden, joined forces to win the Sebago Celebrity Regatta in New York harbor yesterday.

title: NET'S WASHINGTON: TALENT PLUS STYLE
description: The telephone lines weren't jammed, and there wasn't a string of eager fans, with money in hand, stretching from the ticket windows to the surrounding streets itching to satisfy their basketball desires by purchasing a pair of season tickets. Then again, this isn't Madison Square Garden, nestled in the heart of Manhattan. It's the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, sitting on acres of marshland seven miles away.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: UNLIKE the water supply pipes in a home plumbing system, the drainage system is never supposed to be under pressure; it carries waste water away entirely by gravity. To accomplish this, all drainpipes slope downward to the sewer line through what is referred to as the drain-waste and vent (D.W.V.) system.

title: SUNRESORTS LTD NV reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
9 Wounded in Mutiny At 3 Prisons in Peru
description: Left-wing rebel inmates took over parts of three prisons in metropolitan Lima today in a coordinated mutiny, wounding nine police officers and guards and taking nine hostages, the authorities said.

title: CONGRESSIONAL ACCORD ON SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDS BILL
description: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement late today on a multibillion-dollar spending bill designed to keep a number of Federal agencies and programs running through the end of the fiscal year.

title: U.S. Talks in Taiwan
description: A United States delegation indicated today that trade talks here had failed to resolve differences over how to further open Taiwanese markets to United States products.

title: Laidlaw Ends Mayflower Bid
description: Laidlaw Transportation Ltd. said today that it was dropping its $29.25-a-share tender offer for the Mayflower Group Inc., ending a monthlong takeover attempt to acquire Mayflower for about $225.2 million. Both are major school busing contractors.

title: Market Place; For Analysts, Ford Is No. 1
description: SHARES of the Big Three automotive companies have pulled back recently, after speeding ahead between late 1985 and this spring. Wall Street analysts are right now picking their favorite entries in this giant industry, and are also looking down the road, as they estimate profits for the soon-to-end June quarter.

title: Schott Meets Critics
description: Marge Schott, the majority owner of the Cincinnati Reds, met yesterday with the team's eight minority partners to discuss their criticisms of her front-office dealings.

title: CRITICS ASSAIL LOBBYING BILL AS TOO SWEEPING
description: Critics of proposed new restrictions on lobbying by former Federal officials told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that such legislation would be unconstitutional and unnecessary and would create an exodus of Government employees.

title: Britain's Deindustrialized Fate a Portent?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SEES MERIT IN SOVIET PROPOSAL
description: The Soviet Union's latest proposal on strategic arms has merit and is being seriously considered by the United States, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said today.

title: BAYLOR HIT IN 9th SWEEPS YANKS; GRIFFEY BACK, FINED $10,000
description: Ken Griffey, who did not appear Tuesday night for the Yankees' game with the Boston Red Sox, returned to Yankee Stadium yesterday and learned he had been fined $10,000 for his absence.

title: Order for Boeing
description: Boeing, the world's largest airplane maker, said it had received an order worth $253 million for seven planes from the International Lease Finance Corporation.

title: ENVOY ADMITS VISITING LIBYA IN 1985
description: The American Ambassador to the Vatican, William A. Wilson, said today that he had visited Libya in November. He denied reports from Administration officials that he was in Libya early this year after the terrorist attacks on the Rome and Vienna airports.

title: FAR EARLIER EVIDENCE OF HUMANS IN AMERICAS
description: New evidence that humans lived in the Americas thousands of years earlier than previously thought has been found in a rock shelter in northeast Brazil, French scientists reported yesterday.

title: I.B.M. CHIEF SEES FLAT 1986 RESULTS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation expects flat results for the balance of 1986 unless the economy strengthens, John F. Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said today.

title: STRIKES BY BLACKS MULTIPLY; EMBARGO ON TRADE
description: The House, in a surprise development, approved and sent to the Senate today a measure imposing a trade embargo and requiring complete divestment by American companies and citizens of their holdings in South Africa.

title: Coaxial Metaphor
description: Washington has a long love affair with the metaphor, and so, evidently, does Wall Street.

title: ISRAELI DISMAYED AT PROSPECT
description: A senior Israeli official expressed great disappointment tonight at the prospect that the United States might indict Col. Aviem Sella of the Israeli Air Force.

title: FRANCES SCOTT SMITH, WRITER AND CHILD OF THE FITZGERALDS
description: Frances Scott Smith, the only child of Zelda and F. Scott Fitzgerald, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Montgomery, Ala. She was 64 years old.

title: Technology; New Approach On Diseases
description: WHEN the body is invaded by a virus or other disease-causing organism, it responds by producing antibodies that attack the invader. What is less well known is that the antibodies themselves can be attacked by a second wave of antibodies, and this wave attacked by yet a third wave, and so on.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
When Artists Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Reform Marred by Taxidermy
description: Both the Senate and House have stuffed their tax bills with special exemptions for taxpayers powerful enough to get a hearing before the ink was dry. Some of these claims for privilege are deserving but many are obnoxious. All are disguised by a misnamed concern for rules of ''transition'' from old taxes to new ones.

title: N.B.A. DRAFT SPURS MORE TRADE TALK
description: In Milwaukee yesterday, Don Nelson, the Bucks' coach, met with his two new assistants, Del Harris and Rick Majerus, and Stu Inman, the director of player personnel. The subject: ''possible trades.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 19, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Safety Panel Nominee Is Rejected by Senators
description: A Senate committee today rejected the nomination of a Texas lawyer for a seat on the panel that oversees workplace safety after he was accused of trying to undermine enforcement of employee safety laws.

title: Baltimore Festival Aides Say Czech Will Perform
description: Officials of an international theater festival in Baltimore said yesterday that they expected the Czechoslovak actor Bolek Polivka to perform as planned tomorrow night, despite reports that he was ordered not to do so by the Czechoslovak Government.

title: Take the Bow, Point the Finger
description: The batter has just stroked a game-winning hit, and now he's in the locker room surrounded by reporters. ''Aw shucks,'' he says, ''their guy's curve just wasn't breaking today.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers have called a news conference for today and are expected to name Wayne Embry as general manager.

title: SOVIET PLAN AFFIRMS BIG NUCLEAR POWER ROLE
description: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov today affirmed Soviet plans to expand nuclear power production, although he said that the Chernobyl disaster had demonstrated the need for stricter reliability.

title: City Finds Way to Cut $160 Million Shortfall
description: Koch administration officials said yesterday that they had found a way to reduce by a third the $160 million gap in the city's proposed budget for next year.

title: '85 REAGAN RULING ON AFGHANS CITED
description: President Reagan told Congressional intelligence committees around the New Year that the United States' covert program of military aid to the Afghan rebels was aimed at removing Soviet forces from Afghanistan ''by all means available,'' according to Administration officials.

title: Ford Tractors To Reorganize
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would reorganize its domestic tractor operations into a wholly owned subsidiary with operational control of the company's New Holland business. The company will be called Ford New Holland Inc., taking the name of the agricultural implements business that Ford bought from the Sperry Corporation earlier this year.

title: ADMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Some of the 1985 quarterly results are not available because the company went public.

title: THE GRACIOUS ASTILBE: VERSATILE AND DEPENDABLE PERENNIAL
description: ALL truly serious gardeners, I suspect, carry around in the back of their minds a list of plants they haven't grown yet but mean to get round to one of these days. My own list at the moment is headed by acanthus, gunnera and rodgersia, all notable for their bold and dramatic foliage. But there's one genus of perennials that's missing from my list this year. I finally got round to planting some astilbes, and I'm very glad I did.

title: International Thomson Buys 5 U.S. Magazines
description: International Thomson Business Press, part of Canada's International Thomson Organization, is about to buy five monthly magazines from U.S. Business Press that it will then assign to its CES Publishing unit.

title: JUDGE QUESTIONS CLEARING UNIT'S ROLE IN COLLAPSE
description: In a heated finale to the failure of the Volume Investors Corporation, a commodities brokerage firm that went into receivership last year, a Federal district judge has suggested that the Comex Clearing Association may have been partly responsible for the collapse by permitting gold market trading to become disorderly.

title: O'CONNOR CALLS FOR A HOMELAND FOR THE PALESTINIANS
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, called today for the creation of ''a homeland'' for Palestinians and warned that by keeping hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in refugee settlements, ''we are creating a monster.''

title: Speculation Lifts Fruehauf Stock
description: The Fruehauf Corporation's shares rose in heavier-than-normal trading as speculators bought stock in advance of a regular meeting of the company's board scheduled for today.

title: CIVIL JURY TRIALS HALTED IN MOST U.S. COURTS
description: No more civil jury trials will start in the nation's Federal court system until October, except in southern California, unless Congress votes additional money to pay juror costs. Money for such costs has been exhausted for the current fiscal year.

title: To Depict a Stand
description: While it sits in an empty room in an East Village art gallery, it looks like any other newsstand.

title: Sri Lanka Approves Plan for Councils
description: The Cabinet approved a plan today that is intended to resolve the island's ethnic conflict, which has claimed more than 3,000 lives in the last three years.

title: AMERICAN NUCLEONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PRESIDENT CERTIFIES SAUDI ARABIA AS ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE 5 AWACS
description: President Reagan certified Saudi Arabia today as eligible to receive Awacs surveillance planes, saying the Saudis had made ''substantial'' efforts toward advancing the Arab-Israeli peace process.

title: TRANSFORM LOGIC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
AFGHANS PUT CASE BEFORE ALL FORUMS
description: It was a long day for the Afghan resistance leaders. They were interviewed at 8 A.M. by Radio Marti, the anti-Castro radio station; they taped an interview with Dan Rather for ''The CBS Evening News''; they met briefly with Vice President Bush; they went to a lunch given in their honor at the State Department by Deputy Secretary John S. Whitehead. And now, they were starting the first of four afternoon interviews with news agencies and newspapers.

title: To Avoid a $2 Subway Fare
description: While capital financing for New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority lurches from one legislative proposal to another, the agency has resorted to borrowing in the bond market. Servicing that debt will drive up fares and perpetuate a self-defeating cycle: The higher fares reduce ridership and yield hardly any benefit.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, a bank holding company, is offering $150 million of 8 1/4 percent non-callable senior notes due 1993 at 99.85, to yield 8.28 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The 10-year notes, rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and AA+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, yield 8/10 percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: 'Facts' About Smoking
description: If all the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company had done was what its competitors do - use advertising to imply that cigarette smoking makes one sexier, handsomer, prettier, manlier and, oh yes, more liberated - it wouldn't be in trouble with the Federal Trade Commission.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JUNE 19, 1986
description: International

title: Journalists Denounce Pretoria's News Rules
description: The Foreign Correspondents' Association protested today against the Government's restrictions on news reporting, saying they had progressively become among the world's strictest since the state of emergency was declared last week.

title: A LOOPHOLE EXPANDS S.B.L.I.
description: An apparently unintended legal loophole has handed state-chartered savings banks in New York the right to issue some life insurance policies with unlimited coverage - something the thrift units have spent decades fighting for and which could mean substantial savings for consumers.

title: KAZIMIROFF TRAIL TO OPEN IN BRONX
description: The sixth carefully-plotted hiking route within the city's parks system - the Kazimiroff Nature Trail in Pelham Bay Park - will be officially opened today, providing New Yorkers with another opportunity to escape the hurly-burly of the metropolis.

title: Austrian Jews Condemn Waldheim Supporters
description: Austrian Jewish spokesmen accused Kurt Waldheim's supporters today of exploiting anti-Semitism in the presidential campaign and said they would not let the matter rest.

title: WILLOW FURNITURE: A FOLK ART IS THRIVING
description: NINE years ago David Hand started making folk art, as he is not too self-conscious to call his handcrafted willow furniture. Recession had stilled his construction business, and a divorce had left him in debt. ''I was down to $6 and half a tank of gas,'' he said. So he headed into the North Alabama hills, as his father had done half a century earlier on similar missions, and hauled back enough swamp willow to make a love seat and two chairs. He sold them for $50 and recalled gratefully, ''It bought a lot of groceries.''

title: ORDER OF NUNS DEFIES VATICAN ON MOVE TO OUST 2 DISSENTERS
description: An international order of Roman Catholic nuns said yesterday that it would refuse a Vatican request to dismiss two Americans who signed an advertisement supporting the right to dissent from the church's teaching on abortion.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Tuesday about the installation of a new Deputy Police Commissioner gave an incorrect title for Robert J. Johnston Jr. He is Chief of Department, not Chief of Patrol.

title: Frozen Orange Juice Up On Citrus Disease Fear
description: Frozen concentrated orange juice futures closed sharply higher today amid concern about citrus disease in Florida and possible trade restrictions against Brazilian imports.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. CHICAGO CUBS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: HERS
description: I COLLABORATE with my older daughter. Or she collaborates with me. We are two-thirds of a popular novelist called Monica Highland. The story of how we began is simple. One summer six years ago we were fairly broke. It was hot and our only solace was television. In the evening, at the beginning of a bad mini-series, we heard Lee Remick opine to Rock Hudson, ''You're looking at a truly desperate woman!'' It was a mark of our fine characters that we laughed. The next day we began (with a male friend) to write new kinds of stories that we hoped would end up on television.

title: 2d Donor Heart Found For Critically Ill Child
description: Doctors prepared today to perform a second heart transplant on a Texas child after finding another donor heart in a frantic search begun when the first transplanted organ failed only hours after the operation.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY REGULATIONS ARE SIGNED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan today signed a comprehensive package of rules, guidelines and definitions that will set the nation's policy for regulating the nation's fast-developing biotechnology industry for the rest of the decade and possibly through the 1990's.

title: STATE LAWMAKERS GIVE CITY LOW MARKS ON ITS LOBBYING
description: Several key lawmakers say that New York City has failed to mount a consistently effective lobbying effort at the State Capitol this year and that, as a result, some bills opposed by the city are advancing while other measures favored by it are languishing.

title: ABORTION KNITS RELIGIOUS RIGHT INTO G.O.P. FABRIC
description: Carolyn Thompson, chairman of the Pro Life Action Council in Iowa, a politically active anti-abortion group, said it was not too many years ago that Presidential candidates ''wouldn't even talk to us.'' That is no longer the case, at least with Republicans.

title: Herman Shoe
description: The Joseph H. Herman Shoe Company said it would shut down its 64,000-square-foot plant here starting Aug. 15, laying off all 230 workers by Dec. 1.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Shipwrecked Sailors Keeping Vow to Wed
description: The Pride of Baltimore's first mate and the ship's boatswain -survivors of four days in a life raft after a storm sank the schooner -said today they would marry, fulfilling a vow they made while treading water in the Atlantic.

title: CIRCUIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Kasten Opposes Loan
description: Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr. said today that the United States should oppose a $500 million World Bank loan to Brazil for hydroelectric projects because they were environmentally unsound.

title: ACHILLE LAURO TRIAL OF 15 OPENS IN ITALY
description: The trial of 15 men charged in the hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise ship began here today amid signs that the proceedings will be marked by political as well as legal disputes.

title: Americans Improve in Hammer Throw
description: Jud Logan is on a roll. This year, he has broken the American record for the hammer throw four times in four weeks, raising it to 265 feet 4 inches. He has become the 11th longest thrower in history behind six Russians, two East Germans, a West German and a Finn.

title: Jeffrey Martin Seeking Strategy
description: Jeffrey Martin Inc., the maker of Lavoris mouthwash, Topol Smoker's Toothpolish and other consumer products, said it had hired Morgan Stanley & Company to help it consider a possible sale of the company or other ''strategic alternatives.'' Sources close to Jeffrey Martin said the company had not had any formal contacts with prospective acquirers, but they indicated that in the last several years other consumer products concerns had expressed interest in a merger.

title: SPY TRIAL DEFENSE TO COMPLETE CASE
description: In a surprise move, defense attorneys in the espionage and tax fraud trial of Jerry A. Whitworth said today that they expected to complete the presenation of their case Thursday, only four days after it began, without calling Mr. Whitworth.

title: AMERICAN ELECTROMEDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes tax credits of $10,000 for the quarter and $16,000 for the 9 months.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
O'Rourke Backs Plea For Harris Clemency
description: The Republican gubernatorial candidate, Andrew P. O'Rourke, who criticized Governor Cuomo for granting clemency to a deputy sheriff's murderer, has signed a petition calling for clemency for Jean Harris.

title: Missouri Begins $385 Million Offer
description: Missouri is offering $385 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, which submitted the winning bid yesterday.

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Tri-Honda Auto
description: Korey, Kay & Partners considers itself the first beneficiary of megamerger fallout. Its new account is the Tri-Honda Auto Dealers Association, which should spend in the $4 million to $6 million range. The account came loose from its former agency, Needham Harper Worldwide, because it was merging with Doyle Dane Bernbach, long the agency for Volkswagen, certainly a competitive auto company.

title: The Political Education of Jesse Jackson Continues; In Intellectual Thrall
description: To the Editor:

title: DEFIANT TUTU ASKS SANCTIONS BY WEST
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, risking arrest under the state of emergency, urged the West yesterday to impose sanctions against South Africa. He called President Reagan an ''accomplice, after the fact,'' in South Africa's racist policies.

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CYBER DIGITAL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary income of $14,222 for the quarter and $43,136 for the year. c-Includes extraordinary income of $19,733 for the quarter and $124,918 for the year. The company had no revenue in the prior-year periods.

title: People vs. Person
description: Donnie Walsh, the Pacers' general manager, after his selection of Chuck Person with the No. 4 pick was booed by fans at an Indianapolis draft party: ''I realize that everybody has their own person that they like. This is my Person.''

title: Crash of Air Guard Jet Starts Pine Barrens Fire
description: A New Jersey Air National Guard jet fighter crashed in a remote section of the Pine Barrens in Burlington County yesterday, starting a fire that scorched at least 90 acres of woodland. The two fliers aboard ejected safely before the crash and were reported to have sustained minor injuries.

title: U.S. COMPANIES RETAIN TIES, ALBEIT SMALL
description: While more and more American companies have been withdrawing from South Africa in the last 18 months, nearly 300 continue to maintain a presence in that country. They include some of the best-known names in American business, including I.B.M., Mobil and American Express.

title: GEORGE L. STAFF
description: George L. Staff, a management consultant for the textile industry, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 68 years old.

title: IN HIS OWN WORDS: ANTONIN SCALIA ON ABORTION, BIAS AND LIBEL
description: In the abortion situation, for example, what right exists - the right of the woman who wants an abortion to have one, or the right of the unborn child not to be aborted? In the past that was considered to be a societal decision that would be made through the democratic process. But now the courts have shown themselves willing to make that decision for us.

title: JERSEY SENATOR THREATENS TO BLOCK A 2D TERM FOR STATE CHIEF JUSTICE
description: A State Senator who could block the reappointment of Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz said today that he wanted to meet with Mr. Wilentz ''in an open forum'' before deciding whether to let the Senate vote on the nomination.

title: NOISE AS WELL AS SAFETY AT ISSUE IN PARK FLIGHTS
description: The collision of a helicopter and a twin-engine plane on sightseeing tours over the Grand Canyon yesterday underscored a long-standing debate on restricting flights over the national park.

title: Dow Gains 3.16 Amid Light Trading
description: Trading activity remained light yesterday on Wall Street, where blue-chip stock prices rose a bit because of institutional buying programs that did little to help the broader market.

title: Reagan's Checkup Is Friday
description: President Reagan will enter Bethesda Naval Hospital Friday for his third hospital checkup since undergoing successful surgery for colon cancer last July 13, the Presidential spokesman, Larry Speakes, said today. He said he assumed the President would have a thorough examination of his colon, as well as other post-operative tests, but did not know precisely what procedures would be performed.

title: Perkin-Elmer
description: Citing the slump in the semiconductor industry, the Perkin-Elmer Corporation, a leading maker of semiconductor equipment and analytical instruments, said it would lay off about 300 of its 14,800 employees. The company said orders for semiconductor equipment were down 28 percent from a year ago. Perkin-Elmer, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., said that nearly 60 percent of the personnel cuts would be made from the company's operations in Fairfield County, Conn.

title: The Lie Detector Bill Hits a Snag
description: With sponsorship by Democrat Edward Kennedy and Republican Orrin Hatch, it looked like smooth sailing in the Senate for the proposed Employee Polygraph Protection Act, which would outlaw most uses of lie detectors in private employment. Nobody, apparently, reckoned with Senator Strom Thurmond.

title: INTENSE SCRUTINY IS SEEN FOR HIGH COURT CHOICES
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 - While President Reagan's choices for the Supreme Court seem likely to win Senate confirmation with little trouble, they will face stiff questioning on Capitol Hill about the ideological underpinnings of their legal views, leading Democratic Senators said today.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The reduction of the latest first quarter revenue reflected the Feb. 28 sale of the company's Freezer Queen division.

title: Window Opens Into New York's Immigrant Past
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The California Housing Finance Agency is offering $241.8 million of home mortgage revenue bonds tentatively priced to yield a maximum of 8.14 percent for bonds due in 2016.

title: To Expand French Institute
description: An American who lived most of her life in France has made it possible for the French Institute to begin an expansion of its facilities at 22 East 60th Street.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: The Political Education of Jesse Jackson Continues; Rainbow Platform
description: To the Editor:

title: Shops for a Cathedral
description: BENJAMIN HOLLOWAY, chairman of Equitable Assurance Real Estate, decided to help the Cathedral of St. John the Divine with its construction costs by offering it a favorable lease on two shops in the lobby of the Equitable Assurance building, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street. One shop, the Treasury, sells goblets, vases and jewelry reproduced from museum collections around the world.

title: Fares Reduced By Greyhound
description: Greyhound Lines Inc. will halve its maximum one-way fare to $59 in a summer campaign to recapture passengers attracted to low-cost airlines, the nation's biggest bus company said yesterday.

title: Most Yields Fall Again
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts declined for the week ended yesterday. But money market mutual funds rose.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What we did today is going to give a tremendous boost to the momentum of the anti-apartheid movement in this country,'' - Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, after the House voted an embargo on South African trade. [ A1:6. ]

title: CAMPAIGNING STARTS IN JAPAN FOR JULY 6 VOTE
description: Official campaigning began today for parliamentary elections that may determine whether Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone can defy political odds and stay in office beyond this year.

title: SCALIA'S VIEWS, STYLISHLY EXPRESSED, LINE UP WITH REAGAN'S
description: Judge Antonin Scalia, whom President Reagan said Tuesday he will name to the Supreme Court, has criticized several major Supreme Court precedents and expressed clear views contrary to existing law on a wide range of contentious issues.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Advertising; Institute To Offer The Basics
description: AS the former president of an agency, Robert I. David is accustomed to counseling the children of friends on how to get into the advertising business. As a member of the Harvard Club's Career Advisory Committee, he dispensed even more advice to the young.

title: AIR CRASH KILLS 25 AT GRAND CANYON
description: A twin-engine plane and a helicopter carrying vacationers on sightseeing tours above the Grand Canyon collided today, killing 25 people and leaving charred wreckage on a canyon wall.

title: SANCTIONS SOUGHT BY HEAD OF REBELS
description: The head of the African National Congress said here today that the imposition of economic sanctions against South Africa by the West would hasten the collapse of South Africa's system of racial segregation.

title: Marking the Turf
description: Presidential hopefuls are not just scrambling for money and supporters in this early stage of the 1988 campaign; they are also staking out ideas and issues. Senator Gary Hart unveiled his foreign policy agenda last week, and Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona recently announced the creation of a 15-member bipartisan commission to review national welfare and family policy.

title: SPANISH RIGHTIST IS RUNNING HARD, BUT UPHILL
description: This balmy Mediterranean island of stone windmills and rocky coves is one of Spain's favorite hideaways, but Manuel Fraga Iribarne was not here to relax.

title: STAGE: 'LIES,' BY ALLAN
description: THE new play ''Lies My Father Told Me,'' which opened last night at the Jewish Repertory Theater, is so sweet and sentimental, so lovingly offered, that it verges on brutality to refer to the shortcomings that keep it from being the completely satisfying piece of work it ought to be.

title: TRANSTECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
Tofutti Brands Gives Account to Ketchum
description: Tofutti Brands of Rahway, N.J., has shifted its non-dairy, soy-based frozen dessert products to Ketchum Advertising, New York, from Campbell-Ewald, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Top Court Upholds Tax On Foreign Carrier Fuel
description: States may require foreign airlines to pay taxes on all fuels purchased within their borders, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: High-Ticket Package
description: In what might be called the ''$10,000 Weekend Getaway Package,'' former Gov. Pierre S. du Pont 4th of Delaware is inviting a select group of friends and supporters to celebrate the Fourth of July with him in New York.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. ENVOY IS CALLED INTRUDERS' TARGET IN SWEDEN
description: A bodyguard to the United States Ambassador, fearing an assassination attempt, opened fire Tuesday night on two armed men he discovered in the grounds of a mansion near here where the Ambassador was a guest at a dinner party.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
State U. Board Picks Provost And 3 Other High Executives
description: The board of trustees of the State University of New York, the nation's largest public university system, today named Joseph Burke, president of the State University College at Plattsburgh, as provost.

title: Leo Burnett Looking Internally for Growth
description: While all around them mergers and acquisitions are changing the face and the temper of the advertising business, the management of the agency that the late great Leo Burnett founded 51 years ago in Chicago will continue to do it his way.

title: A Queens Studio Leader Combines Two Talents
description: Michael Bennahum started out in the entertainment industry as a story editor for Warner Brothers. Then he shifted to investment banking and now he has combined his financial and entertainment talents to become president and co-chief executive at Kaufman Astoria Studios, the venerable Queens film studio that has been renovated and put back into use.

title: SIMPSON IS NAMED COACH OF ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders, as expected, named Terry Simpson as their new coach yesterday, replacing Al Arbour, who resigned last month after 13 seasons and four Stanley Cup championships.

title: U.S.F.L. REJECTED ON SOME EVIDENCE
description: Before an economist explained to a jury in Federal District Court yesterday why the United States Football League is entitled to as much as $1.69 billion in antitrust damages from the National Football League, Judge Peter K. Leisure ruled against the U.S.F.L. regarding the admissibility of certain testimony.

title: OHIO MATTRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $765,000 and $1,043,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Resorts Write-Downs
description: Resorts International Inc. said yesterday that it would take $50 million in write-downs and reserves in the second quarter, including a reduction in the value of its Pan American World Airways stock.

title: Why Pesticides?
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: COUNCIL PANEL VOTES TO EASE RESTAURANT MUSIC RESTRICTION
description: A City Council committee approved a bill yesterday that would allow wind and percussion instruments to be played in thousands of restaurants and clubs that now have to ban them.

title: ANCIENT STRING PATTERNS SHARPEN SKILLS IN MATH
description: WITH the academic year drawing to a close, the students in James R. Murphy's math classes at Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and the Arts have set down their strings for the summer.

title: Asset-Backed Certificates
description: The business of packaging financial assets into securities continues to be a popular form of funding by many borrowers.

title: POISONED EXCEDRIN SUSPECTED IN 2D SEATTLE DEATH
description: Scientists investigating the poisoning death of a woman here have found a second bottle of Extra-Strength Excedrin laced with cyanide, the authorities said late today. They said that bottle belonged to a man who died two weeks ago, The cause of the man's death is being re-examined in light of the discovery.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alaska Mutual Bancorp., Anchorage, said Joseph C. Miller had resigned as president. Barry L. Hulin was named his successor.

title: Wringing Our Hands
description: If 1,600 white people had been killed in South Africa in the last year and a half, would Ronald Reagan do nothing but murmur ambivalent regrets?

title: The Political Education of Jesse Jackson Continues
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY TURNPIKE SCLES BACK EXPANSION PLAN AFTER FUROR
description: After criticism from citizen groups and the Kean administration, officials of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority have agreed to scale back their plan to widen the roadway, state officials said today.

title: DASA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: PASTA & CHEESE INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
K-V PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: CIRCUIT CITY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
EXPERTS EXPECT DEBT PACT SOON BETWEEN MEXICO AND I.M.F.
description: The resignation of Jesus Silva Herzog, the Finance Minister of Mexico, provides the clearest indication yet that Mexico will soon reach a lending agreement with the International Monetary Fund, bankers in New York and analysts of the Latin debt situation said yesterday.

title: Reagan Renews Pledge To Aid the Contras
description: President Reagan, faced with a warning from Nicaraguan rebels that they desperately need military equipment, renewed his pledge today to provide United States assistance.

title: Butrageno Scores 4 Goals
description: Emilio Butrageno equaled a World Cup record with four goals today, leading Spain to a 5-1 victory over Denmark. It was the first four-goal performance in the tournament since Eusebio of Portugual did it in 1966 against North Korea.

title: THE NAMES MAY CHANGE, BUT THE BEAT GOES ON
description: THE other night at a rhythm-and-blues show in a downtown club, several guest musicians put in appearances. One, an alto saxophonist, was rooted in the modern jazz styles of Charlie Parker and Jackie McLean. A clarinetist played phrases derived from blues harmonica players and drew on early New Orleans jazz and Dixieland influences. A pianist contributed New Orleans-style blues of a later era, as exemplified by artists like Professor Longhair and Fats Domino. Everything fit together seamlessly. After the performance, someone asked, ''What would you call that?'' A simple answer did not come readily to mind.

title: FEDERATED GROUP INC reports earnings for 13wks to June 1
SADOWSKY IS APPOINTED TO CITY BOARD OF EDUCATION
description: Edward L. Sadowsky, a former City Councilman, was named to the New York City Board of Education yesterday, a move that together with another appointment expected next week, almost certainly assures a new direction for the board under the leadership of Robert F. Wagner Jr. In order to gain more control of the seven-member board, which sets the policies for the city's schools, Mayor Koch has said he was banking on new appointees who would form a majority behind Mr. Wagner.

title: MUSIC: SHARON MABRY, MEZZO
description: THE mezzo-soprano Sharon Mabry chose an unusually venturesome program for her Monday night debut recital at the Merkin Concert Hall. There was not one war horse on the bill: instead we heard three chansons by the short-lived Lily Boulanger (sister of the fabled Nadia); Rhian Samuel's ''Songs of Earth and Air''; an aria from ''Rachel,'' Kenton Coe's operatic biography of Andrew Jackson's wife; selections from Aaron Copland's Dickinson songs; ''Sounds and Shapes IV'' by Christina Kuzmych; four ditties by Charles Ives; Elizabeth Vercoe's ''Irreveries from Sappho,'' and Katherine K. Davis's ''Nancy Hanks.''

title: 3,000 REPORTED HELD BY PRETORIA IN CRACKDOWN
description: Nearly 3,000 people have been detained in the first week of South Africa's state of emergency, officials of the World Council of Churches said yesterday.

title: INNIS, CORE LEADER, ENTERS BROOKLYN RACE FOR CONGRESS
description: Roy Innis, the civil-rights leader who has moved to the right politically in recent years, announced his candidacy yesterday for Congress in Brooklyn's 12th District.

title: BUSINESS COMPUTER SOLUIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Maloney Resigns
description: Dan Maloney, who guided Toronto to the National Hockey League quarterfinals last season, resigned yesterday as coach of the Maple Leafs. Maloney parted company with the Leafs after the team's owner, Harold Ballard, failed to offer him a multi-year contract.

title: Spinks Suspended
description: The boxer Leon Spinks was given a 90-day suspension yesterday by the Nevada Athletic Commission for testing positive to traces of a depressant following his March 22 loss to Dwight Qawi.

title: AFTER DECADES, GAMY GOWANUS GETS A CLEANUP
description: Steeped in stereotypes of tough guys and stoop-sitters; linked in lore with a twist of tongue called Brooklynese, known well and too widely for its pungency, Gowanus and its canal may soon breathe freer.

title: Safeway Sues Hafts For Takeover Talk
description: Safeway Stores accused the Haft family yesterday of manipulating the stock market by tipping traders about supposedly ''secret accumulations'' of Safeway shares so as to create speculation about a possible takeover of the huge supermarket chain.

title: GUN BILL FOUGHT BY CITY IS ADVANCING IN ALBANY
description: Thousands of handguns now barred from New York City would become legal under the terms of legislation that was passed by the State Senate earlier this session and is making unexpected progress in the Assembly.

title: AT HERALD SQ., GIMBELS NEARS A BITTER END
description: Gimbels was telling nothing yesterday. Not to Macy's. Not to its workers. Not to the few shoppers who could be found wandering through its nine floors on 33d Street.

title: U.S. REPORTED TO PURSUE INDICTMENT OF ISRAELI COLONEL IN SPY CASE
description: The Justice Department has decided to seek the indictment of a prominent Israeli Air Force officer who has been linked to an Israeli spy ring, a knowledgeable Reagan Administration official said today.

title: Flies Kill Endangered Falcon
description: A young peregrine falcon under observation by ecologists trying to reintroduce the endangered species to Minnesota has been attacked and killed by blackflies, researchers said this week.

title: Bridge: Turning Age 55 Makes One A Senior at the Card Table
description: Bridge players may spend more time being ''senior'' than any other category of the population. This is not so much because the active intellectual effort required extends one's life, although that is probably true, but because of a ruling of the American Contract Bridge League: age 55 and over is ''senior.''

title: A.M.A. Delegates Seek To Replace Medicare
description: Policy makers for the American Medical Association today proposed replacing the Medicare system.

title: Ad Spending Up
description: Advertising expenditures in daily newspapers in March increased 5.9 percent, to $2.22 billion, from March 1985, according to preliminary estimites from the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. Classified advertising showed the greatest increase, up 6.8 percent, to $781 million; national ad expenditures rose 4 percent, to $291 million, and retail spending rose 5.7 percent, to $1.15 billion.

title: People
description: * W. Robert Boris has been named vice president of advertising sales at Raben Publishing Company.

title: A Legend at Issue
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: NEW DESIGN PLEDGED FOR SPACE SHUTTLE PARTS
description: The company that built the faulty booster rockets on the space shuttle Challenger is exploring new designs for the rocket joints that will have backups for all critical components and may not require O ring seals, a company official testified today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DANCING FEET The feet that start dancing tonight on 42d Street, at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, are moving to the tune of the Clark Center ''Summer Dance Festival '86.'' This eight-week event, through Aug. 10, offers a different theme or company each week.

title: Note and Bond Prices Mixed
description: Prices for Government notes and bonds were mixed yesterday, with professional trading continuing to dominate the market while retail investors await clearer signals on the direction of the economy and interest rates.

title: Camera Uses Floppy Disks
description: In the latest development in electronic photography, Canon U.S.A. Inc. yesterday introduced the first still-camera system that uses computer floppy disks instead of conventional film.

title: 47 MAJOR DRAWINGS TO BE AUCTIONED
description: One of the most important private collections of Old Master, Impressionist and modern drawings formed in recent years - including works by Leonardo da Vinci, Rembrandt, Raphael, van Gogh, Picasso and Matisse - will be sold at Sotheby's in November, John L. Marion, chairman of Sotheby's North America, announced yesterday.

title: A SPECIAL CHEMISTRY IN 'RAPPAPORT'
description: Not long ago in the middle of a performance of ''I'm Not Rappaport,'' Cleavon Little, one of the two stars, fell asleep on stage and missed a cue.

title:
ADVERTISING;
3 Agencies Are Pared From I.B.M.'s Roster
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, which on Monday confirmed that it would be consolidating its advertising with a smaller number of agencies, said yesterday that it had already given notice of termination to Doyle Dane Bernbach and Leber Katz Partners, and was ''winding down'' its activities with Geer DuBois.

title: RACING PATTERNS ON A SHEET
description: They pace restlessly outside the Saratoga bus depot at midnight or rush to the binocular stand when the gates open at Belmont Park, men driven by a need for the secret knowledge they think can bring them riches. They are the ''sheet-players,'' a growing number of mostly affluent horseplayers who pay from $20 to $100 a day for privately published speed ratings on every horse racing that day.

title: SANDGATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: The year-ago periods reflect only Anglo American Auto Auctions Inc.'s consolidated results of operations except for the presentation of shares outstanding and share earnings. The calculation for the 3 and 9 months ended May 3, 1985, is based on the number of shares of Sandgate common stock issued upon consummation of the merger, restated to give effect to the stock ''split up'' declared in January 1986.

title: Big Coup
description: For a White House known to grow irritable at leaks, it was a moment to savor. A major announcement was aborning: the retirement of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, his proposed replacement with Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist, and the decision to nominate Judge Antonin Scalia to the Court.

title: Adviser Disciplined
description: Mark Emerson Spangler, a Boston-based investment adviser accused of misusing clients' funds, settled a disciplinary proceeding today and was barred for life from the securities business.

title: RED SOX WIN BY 5-2
description: Earlier in the day, George Steinbrenner said, ''Maybe I made a mistake.'' About six hours later, Don Baylor presented the Yankees' owner with Exhibit A in the evidence he has been compiling all season to show that, indeed, Steinbrenner and his braintrust made a mistake, a bad mistake, perhaps a fatal mistake.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MEN'S LIVES: The Surfmen and Baymen of the South Fork. By Peter Matthiessen. Illustrated. 339 pages. Random House. $29.95.

title: WALL ST. BUYS INTO THE ACTION
description: Wall Street firms have raked in hundreds of millions of dollars as advisers in takeovers in recent years, and some have even dabbled in corporate buyouts themselves.

title: Citrus Canker Suspected On Island in Florida
description: What appears to be citrus canker has been found in residential plantings on Anna Maria Island near Bradenton, Fla. The announcement was made by Dr. S.A. Alfieri, director of the Florida division of plant industry, to members of the Florida Citrus Commission in a meeting here Tuesday.

title: Surging England Beats Paraguay, 3-0
description: Could England be the Italy of this World Cup? After two atrocious performances that had their supporters ready to put back on their pants and shirts and go home, the English have willed themselves into the quarterfinals.

title: 'FAME, FORTUNE AND ROMANCE,' A NEW SERIES ON 7
description: YOU may have thought that television had squeezed the last exploitative ounce out of the contemporary ritual of celebrity watching, but you would be underestimating the ingenuity of Robin Leach and Al Masini. They have taken what look like throwaway outtakes from ''Life Styles of the Rich and Famous,'' the syndicated series that stars Mr. Leach as indefatigably eager host, and strung them together for a new series of half hours called ''Fame, Fortune and Romance.'' The project is now being tested for two weeks on Channel 7 at 11 A.M., Monday through Friday.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income after a tax credit of $5,000.

title: CENTURY MEDICORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
AA IMPORTING CO reports earnings for 13wks to May 4
Magazine Rate Talks Backed by N.W. Ayer
description: Although for years the print media have generally adhered to their rate cards while broadcast rates were negotiable, a growing number of multidivisional advertiser companies have been pushing hard recently to get better deals from the print media, particularly magazines. This has brought a statement from N.W. Ayer, the country's oldest agency.

title: HAROLD W. TRIBBLE
description: Dr. Harold W. Tribble, former president of Wake Forest College, whose dream of seeing the school become a university was realized before he retired in 1967, died Tuesday at the Moravian Home here.

title: SUTTON BEATS RANGERS FOR 300
description: Don Sutton pitched a three-hitter for his 300th career victory tonight as the California Angels beat the Rangers, 5-1. The 41-year-old right-hander, in his 21st major-league season, became the 19th pitcher in baseball history to win 300 games. Tom Seaver of the Chicago White Sox and Phil Niekro, who was with the Yankees at the time, did it last year.

title: Disney and France
description: The Walt Disney Company and the French Government again missed a deadline to sign a definitive agreement to build a $1 billion Disneyland theme park and resort in Marne-la-Vallee, a suburb about 20 miles east of Paris, Disney executives said.

title: QUICK CHANGES FOR OLD CABINETS
description: WHETHER you choose a knob of bright plastic or a sleek handle of brushed chrome, changing the hardware on kitchen cabinet doors and drawers can give the room a quick update. While no substitute for a complete renovation, it can be, for the price of a dozen or so knobs and pulls, an inexpensive way to improve a kitchen's look, particularly in rental apartments.

title: Oil of Olay to Saatchi In European Markets
description: Procter & Gamble has assigned Richardson-Vick's Oil of Olay product to Saatchi & Saatchi Compton in several European countries, and billings could be between $20 million and $30 million.

title: IN HASIDIC HOMES, RITUAL SHAPES DESIGN
description: ROSALYNN MALAMUD and Sheina Konigsberg pack kosher lunches when, during the spring, they leave their Hasidic community in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn and drive off to decorator show houses on Long Island looking for design ideas. Partly as a result of their trips, the kitchen that Mrs. Malamud installed two years ago in her home is modern, all white and filled with light. It is also kosher, with two ovens, two stovetops, two dishwashers and three sinks - the double kitchen facilitates cooking according to Jewish dietary laws, which require separating meat and dairy products.

title: THEATER: UPDATED VERSION OF 'FORBIDDEN BROADWAY'
description: ''FORBIDDEN BROADWAY,'' the long-running musical revue that lampoons Broadway shows, is to the Great White Way what the sorely missed Canadian television series ''SCTV'' used to be to mainstream television. Like ''SCTV,'' it offers blistering satirical parodies that are more entertaining and cuttingly smart than nine-tenths of the shows at which it takes aim. At the same time, its air of deep-dish knowingness about the personalities and business of Broadway gives one a delicious sense of being privy to a cynical insider's point of view.

title: EXXON CUTS FINANCING TO 'GREAT PERFORMACES'
description: The Exxon Corporation has announced that it will significantly reduce its financial contribution to the ''Great Performances'' series on public television next year and perhaps not finance it at all in the future.

title: WORMHOLES IN FURNITURE MAY CALL FOR INSECTICIDE
description: Although it takes only a couple of years or so for them to be genuine, the presence of wormholes in furniture seems to be considered a sign of antiquity. One even hears stories how the simulation of age is done by forging wormholes - by judicious use of a fine drill or an apocryphal shotgun blast. No matter how crude the attempted deception, the results are invariably better than the real thing, for beneath those holes the wood is being munched away unmercifully.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: All the U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen at the rate of 168 yen equals U.S. $1, the Tokyo foreign exchange market rate as of April 30, 1986. Share earnings represent American Depositary Shares, or ADR, and each ADR represents one share of common stock.

title: FUN, FUN, FUN, A 1960'S CONVERTIBLE FOR A DAY
description: When Vivian Pummill was invited to a beach party last weekend, she did not worry about what to wear. She worried about what to drive.

title: MEXICO'S PLAN SEEN AS FIRM
description: A senior Mexican official said today that the Government's strategy of seeking a negotiated solution to its latest foreign debt crisis had not been affected by the unexpected change in the country's Finance Minister on Tuesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report on Monday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misattributed a reference to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d as President Reagan's ''ideological soulmate on the political right wing.'' The comment was made by Fred Graham, narrator of a forthcoming Public Broadcasting Service program, ''Justice for All,'' and not by Benno C. Schmidt Jr., president-designate of Yale University.

title: Hall Financial Refinancing
description: Craig Hall, chairman of the troubled Hall Financial Group, said today that his company had reached an agreement with its largest single lender, the Westwood Savings and Loan Association, to refinance $132 million in mortgages. The loan modifications involve seven company-sponsored partnerships that own 14 properties, including the corporate headquarters of the American Motors Corporation in Southfield, Mich.

title: WILDERNESS EXPERIENCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CORRECTION
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about criticisms of the space agency by Jane Smith, the widow of Comdr. Michael J. Smith, incorrectly described Commander Smith's Challenger assignment. He was the shuttle's pilot.

title: ACA JOE EASTERN reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
Sun, Chromalloy To Weigh Merger
description: The Sun Chemical Corporation and the Chromalloy American Corporation plan to discuss a possible tax-free merger, according to Sun Chemical, which owns 44 percent of Chromalloy's 15.3 million shares outstanding.

title: France's New Mood
description: French ''cohabitation'' is working in the sense that there is no crisis of government. But the atmosphere is turning sour and politicians on all sides are chafing at unaccustomed restraints.

title: Penicillin Found to Aid In Treating Cell Disorder
description: Babies with sickle cell anemia should be given daily penicillin pills to prevent blood infections that are the leading cause of death among young victims of the inherited disorder, a new study concludes.

title: 'PAVAROTTI IN LAS VEGAS,' ON A&E
description: WHAT to make of Luciano Pavarotti? He has a tenor voice of extraordinary sweetness, and he has captured the public imagination as no opera singer since Caruso. Yet it is possible to have misgivings about his career. ''Pavarotti in Las Vegas,'' which will be shown tonight at 10 on the Arts & Entertainment cable network, documents the tenor's stage act in all of its effusive glory. Those who consider Mr. Pavarotti a virtual incarnation of high culture in our time may enjoy this carefully executed festival of charm. Those in search of meaningful musical entertainment will want to look elsewhere.

title: TREATING BREAST CANCER: A STATUS REPORT
description: BREAST cancer continues to strike women with undiminished force and still baffles science, despite marked progress in prolonging lives and the development of new methods of treatment. The central questions asked by generations of women - what causes breast cancer and what can be done to prevent it - remain unanswered.

title: NEW TAX LAW: MANY ITEMS ALREADY SET
description: The Senate's expected approval of its sweeping tax-revision plan would effectively seal many major provisions into any final package enacted into law by Congress.

title: To Celebrate the Hot Dog
description: Murray Handwerker was getting a hard time from Mayor Koch yesterday. As crowds arrived at Times Square, near Nathan's restaurant, for the 70th anniversary of the hot-dog chain, the Mayor was complaining about the demise of the nickel hot dog.

title: 'WE'RE NOT GOING, SO THEY HAVE TO': THE BRONX BATTLE CRY AGAINST CRACK
description: On the door of a rundown apartment building in the northwest Bronx hangs a warning from residents: ''Cracker stay the hell off this hallway, building and roof.''

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'AIDA' IN CENTRAL PARK CONCERT
description: GIVEN halfway decent weather, the first free Metropolitan Opera concert performance each year in Central Park is always an event, and Tuesday night's ''Aida,'' opening the company's 20th parks season, was no exception. The weather was beautifully clear and crisp, not to say downright chilly, and between 75,000 and 100,000 opera lovers turned out for the occasion, complete with picnics, balloons and a raucous blend of cheers and boos for Mayor Koch, who made a shorter address than usual to his assembled constituents.

title: Volcker Optimistic
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he expected Mexico would soon come to terms with the International Monetary Fund.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Sport Pages yesterday on the Philadelphia 76ers' draft-day deals incorrectly portrayed the team's trade with the Cleveland Cavaliers. The 76ers sent the first pick in Tuesday's draft to Cleveland in exchange for Roy Hinson and $750,000.

title: GOODEN ROCKED FOR 7 RUNS IN 6Y INNINGS
description: The night began with boyhood friends pitching in the same game for opposing teams. But it was not a memorable performance that Dwight Gooden gave tonight, not the kind of game that he would want to hash over years from now with Floyd Youmans.

title: The Death Penalty: 10 Dark Years
description: Students of capital punishment will soon mark a special anniversary. Nearly 10 years ago, the United States Supreme Court issued four related decisions that provided the framework for reintroducing the death penalty.

title: CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding for the year period have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 21, 1985.

title: WORLCO DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $235,950 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: To Brighten a Carillon
description: For all its steeples, New York City is short on carillons, those collections of musical bells found almost exclusively in church steeples. One of them, a 42-bell version, is in the belfry of St. Martin's Episcopal Church at Lenox Avenue and 122d Street in Harlem.

title: His Supreme Court Opinions Clearly Show An Abiding Conservatism, Past and Present
description: William H. Rehnquist has spent his 14 years on the Supreme Court at the cutting edge of conservative legal doctrine. The Court has not always followed him, but it has always had to respond to his strongly held views and distinctive voice.

title: Dean Reed Dies at 47; U.S. Expatriate Singer
description: Dean Reed, an American-born singer who had a legion of fans in the Communist bloc, died Tuesday in East Germany, where he had lived since 1972. He was 47 years old.

title: O'CONNER WAS ALSO REPORTED CONTENDER
description: Reagan Administration officials and conservatives close to the White House said today that Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor had been a key contender to replace Warren E. Burger as Chief Justice of the United States. They said, however, that she was rejected in favor of William H. Rehnquist on the ground that she was relatively new to the Supreme Court.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $44,000 for the quarter and $133,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $44,250 and $132,750, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income and includes extraordinary gains of $120,000 for the quarter and $999,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $120,250 and $998,750 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: DELAWARE LAW ALLOWS LESS DIRECTOR LIABILITY
description: The Governor of Delaware, a state that is home to many of the nation's major corporations, yesterday signed into law a provision that would allow corporations to eliminate the financial liability of their directors for some kinds of mistakes.

title: CALENDAR: PENNSYLVANIA DUTCH FESTIVAL
description: Kutztown Folk Festival, just off Route 222 in Kutztown, Pa., between Allentown and Reading, 215-683-8707.

title: STRIKES BY BLACKS MULTIPLY; ARRESTS PROTESTED
description: Strikes and sitdown stoppages by black supermarket workers erupted across South Africa today in protest at the detention of union leaders under the state of emergency declared last week by the white authorities.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $286,000 for the quarter and $465,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $45,200 for the quarter and $91,300 for the 6 months. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes a charge of $400,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Continental Bancorp Inc., Philadelphia, said its shareholders had approved the merger of Continental into Midlantic Banks Inc. of Edison, N.J.

title: BLOOMSBURY RETREAT IS OPEN TO PUBLIC
description: IN 1916, the novelist Virginia Woolf wrote to her sister, Vanessa Bell, about Charleston, a rambling old Sussex farmhouse she had seen. ''It has a charming garden, with a pond and fruit trees and vegetables, all now rather wild, but you could make it lovely.''

title: SMOKING RESTRICTIONS GROWING IN WORKPLACE
description: Despite opposition from both management and labor groups to laws requiring smoking restrictions in the workplace, more and more businesses are adopting policies spelling out when and where employees can light up.

title: 10 Killed in Floods in Chile
description: Widespread flooding in central Chile has left ten people dead and almost 35,000 homeless, the Government's National Emergency Office said today. The flood waters began to recede today, but water supplies to half of Santiago's four million residents, cut off since Monday evening, returned slowly and tankers were sent out to take fresh water to poor neighborhoods.

title: Who Got $27 Million Intended for Contras?
description: Before Congress votes for more assistance to anti-Sandinista rebel forces, the Reagan Administration needs to provide answers to a number of serious questions being raised about what happened to the $27 million in tax dollars appropriated by Congress for that purpose last year.

title: Books: Of Bias and War
description: WAR WITHOUT MERCY: Race and Power in the Pacific War. By John W. Dower. 399 pages. Illustrated. Pantheon Books. $22.50. FOUR and a half decades after

title: SENATE REJECTS A TAX AMENDMENT TO BENEFIT MIDDLE-INCOME PEOPLE
description: The Senate, nearing a final vote on legislation that would restructure the Federal income tax system, rejected a proposal yesterday that would increase taxes on the wealthy and give larger tax reductions to middle-income Americans.

title: HOMELESS HAD HAVEN: CITY'S EDGE
description: For more than two years, a handful of men lived in their own small private world on the edge of midtown Manhattan, a world that official New York discovered only this week, after a murder took place there.

title: Don't Let the Private Developers Get Their Hands on OTB
description: To the Editor:

title: Seattle Host for Games
description: Organizers of the Goodwill Games, struggling with financial and logistical problems for the first competition in Moscow July 5-20, have come up with a site for the 1990 Games. The site is Seattle, and the dates, still to be selected, are between Aug. 5 and Sept. 5. ''We are most impressed with the facilities and venues that the Seattle area offers to house the 1990 Games,'' said Robert Wussler, the executive vice president of Turner Broadcasting System, which has organized the games.

title: Tottenville Wins Metro Bowl, 1-0
description: Scott Tierney and Charlie Wonsowicz combined for a two-hitter as Tottenville beat St. Francis Prep, 1-0, for the Metro Bowl, emblematic of the New York City schools' championship, yesterday at St. John's University.

title: TEXAS MURDERER IS PUT TO DEATH
description: A former marine who killed a convenience store manager in a robbery 12 years ago was put to death by the State of Texas early today, despite pleas for mercy from the victim's father.

title: BAYSWATER REALTY & CAPITOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The 1985 share earnings have been restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split, in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend, distributed April 14 to holders of record March 12.

title: U.S. CALLS INQUIRY ON LOSS OF SECRETS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has ordered an investigation of allegations that hundreds of classified documents have been mishandled or are missing from aircraft plants operated by the Lockheed Corporation.

title: SMD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $878,198 for the quarter and year.

title: President Promoted At Bankers Trust
description: Charles S. Sanford Jr. has been promoted from president to deputy chairman of the Bankers Trust Company and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, its parent, the bank announced yesterday.

title: FINIALS, PLAIN AND FANCY
description: FINIALS, which attach a lamp shade to a lamp, can be hidden from view or add a decorative touch. When a finial is used for decorative purposes, the style of the lamp dictates the type of finial. An Oriental lamp, for instance, might take an ornate finial made of jade, whereas an Early American lamp could have a finial with a brass eagle on top.

title: FORMER FIRE COMMISSIONER
description: Edward F. Cavanagh Jr., an innovative New York City Fire Commissioner and later a Deputy Mayor, died Tuesday in Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 79 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Good Man in a Pinch
description: When Greg Gross of the Philadelphia Phillies came off the bench Tuesday and delivered a run-scoring single at Chicago, he moved past Rusty Staub into 10th place on the major leagues' career pinch-hit list.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH AT 2.9% RATE
description: The Government reported today that the economy grew at a revised rate of only 2.9 percent during the first three months of the year, down from the 3.7 percent rate that was reported a month ago.

title: Article 185786 -- No Title
description: The Florence J. Gould Foundation has donated $1 million to the French Institute/Alliance Francaise toward the construction of a 400-seat concert hall and performance space under its building at 22 East 60th Street.

title: Four-tune Teller
description: During his four-year stay at Philadelphia, perhaps the most widely quoted remark by Moses Malone came in the spring of 1983, when he boasted that the 76ers would go ''four-four-four'' right through the playoffs.

title: TO DRESS PROPERLY FOR SCHLEPPING
description: WHAT do you call a New Yorker carrying a croquet mallet? In this case, because it's a woman, ''ma'am'' is strongly suggested. But ''stylish'' would be appropriate, too.

title: Squibb Unit Offer
description: The Squibb Corporation has been asked by the management of its New York-based fragrance and cosmetics subsidiary, Charles of the Ritz Group Ltd., to consider a leveraged buyout by Charles's management.

title: DART & KRAFT IS SPLITTING UP
description: Dart & Kraft Inc. will split into two companies, undoing much of the 1980 merger of Kraft Inc., the food powerhouse, with Dart Industries, the industrial and consumer products concern.

title: MANAGEMENT GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income. All results are in Canadian dollars.

title: After That Bike
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today: June 20, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Tax Changes Make an Actor's Life Harder
description: To the Editor:

title: New Job Has Burger On Air
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, who is retiring from the Supreme Court to give full time to the chairmanship of the Commission on the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution, says he intends to bring a teacher's enthusiasm to his new post.

title: SUTTON AND FEHR SHARE LEAD
description: Hal Sutton and Rick Fehr put together bogey-free rounds and gained a share of the first-round lead with six-under-par 66's in the $500,000 Georgia-Pacific Atlanta Golf Classic today.

title: Samuel Viviano, Pianist
description: The pianist Samuel Viviano will present the premieres of two new works by Don Freund and John Anthony Lennon at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, Sunday afternoon at 3.

title: OPERA: MET'S 'ROMEO'
description: EVERY year about this time the Metropolitan Opera packs a little Verdi or Puccini on its back and makes the rounds of the city's boroughs. The current ''Met in the Parks'' season is offering ''Aida'' and ''Romeo et Juliette.'' ''Aida'' opened in Central Park on Tuesday; Gounod's sweetly irresistible Shakespearean confection played Wednesday night on the grounds of Staten Island's Snug Harbor - to an enthusiastic, if slightly chilled, audience of several thousand.

title: HAYDON, ARTIFICIAL HEART RECIPIENT, DIES
description: Murray P. Haydon died yesterday morning, 16 months and 2 days after becoming the third person ever to receive an artificial heart. With his death, only one artificial heart patient, William J. Schroeder, survives.

title: Where Have All the Inventors Gone?
description: Is inventiveness on the wane in this country? Where is that old creative, enterprising American spirit?

title: O'CONNOR ON PALESTINIAN TERROR
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, said today that the plight of the Palestinian people, if left unresolved, ''has to spawn terrorism.''

title: Market Place; Early Holiday For Toy Stocks
description: CHRISTMAS is a long way off, but selected toy stocks - thanks to innovative new products and Wall Street estimates of higher profits for 1986 - are already on the move.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Trotter Breaks Yonkers Record
description: Newmarket S set a Yonkers Raceway track record for 3-year-old filly trotters tonight, winning by three-quarters of a length over Britelite Lobell in the fourth division of the Hudson Filly Trot.

title: Bartholdi Alliance Grows
description: The Statue of Liberty centenary has brought, if not quite fame, at least recognition to its sculptor, Frederic Auguste Bartholdi. And Bartholdi has brought, if not quite fame, at least recognition to Colmar, where he was born and where there is a museum devoted to his work.

title: Tamed Tiger
description: Manager Sparky Anderson, whose wildly optimistic predictions about Detroit rookies have sometimes embarrassed him later, after Eric King ran his record to 3-0 with a 10-strikeout five-hitter against Baltimore: ''He's 22 years old. Let him speak for himself. I don't know him from Adam.''

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES SHARP CUT IN DEVICE TO ATTACK SATELLITES
description: A House subcommittee voted a sharp cut in financing today for the Pentagon's $3.8 billion program to build and test a weapon that would destroy orbiting satellites, Congressional aides said.

title: Sailor Accused of Espionage Pleads to Lessened Charges
description: A Navy enlisted man accused of espionage pleaded guilty today to reduced charges in a plea bargain that averted a possibile life sentence. He was given a two-year sentence and a dishonorable discharge.

title: ROWLEY-SCHER REPROGRAPHCS reports earnings for Year to March 31
RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
AT HIS QUEENS GRADE SCHOOL, CUOMO OFFERS WORDS OF HOPE
description: Mario M. Cuomo (Class of '43) urged Moses Carter (Class of '86) to aspire to be governor, or even President, ''but not too soon.''

title: UNDER-PRESS CURB, BAD NEWS IS NO NEWS
description: A week after their introduction under the nation's harshest emergency decree ever, South Africa's press restrictions have reduced to an authorized trickle a flow of information that the South Africans once boasted was the most free on the continent.

title: ACTIVIST OF LEFT
description: Sidney Lens, a writer, union organizer and senior editor of Progressive Magazine, died of cancer Wednesday at the University of Chicago Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: Grace Suma, Soprano
description: The soprano Grace Suma will sing music by Wagner, Rossini, Catalani and Giordano at the Damrosch Park Bandshell at Lincoln Center tonight at 7:30.

title: CRASH DOESN'T DETER TOURISTS FROM GRAND CANYON FLIGHTS
description: A day after the worst air crash in 30 years at the Grand Canyon, tourists once again lined up at the counters of air tour operators here for the experience of a scenic flight into the rugged gorge.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL METS VS. CHICAGO CUBS, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS.

title: DANCE: WENDY OSSERMAN
description: WENDY OSSERMAN likes to invent unusual ways of getting dancers together.

title: INTERNATIONAL LEASE FIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid last July.

title: Salvadoran Guerrillas Attack Army Garrison
description: About 500 leftist guerrillas, using mortars and mines, attacked an army garrison in this eastern provincial capital today, killing or wounding at least 50 soldiers, a military commander said.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Ames Department Stores, Rocky Hill, Conn., said Peter Hollis, president of Fisher's Big Wheel, a discount department store chain, would join Ames as president and chief operating officer around Aug. 1.

title: Qaddafi Recalls Night Of U.S. Tripoli Raid
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said today that he was at home when American planes bombed Tripoli in April and that he helped rescue his wife and children while ''the house was coming down around us.''

title: BALLET: 4 ROLE DEBUTS IN TUDOR'S 'DARK ELEGIES'
description: ONE could not have a better lesson in the expressive power of sheer movement than Antony Tudor's ''Dark Elegies,'' a spare, plain ritual of grief that American Ballet Theater performed this week at the Metropolitan Opera House. And two rounds of role debuts underscored that lesson.

title: ROBERT E. MULCAHY JR.
description: Robert E. Mulcahy Jr., a prominent home builder in northern New Jersey for many years, died Wednesday at his home in Mendham, N.J. He was 80 years old.

title: Bravos on the Bench
description: Just two days after Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist was named to head the Supreme Court, he got his first favorable notice from one of his colleagues.

title: Another Giant Attraction
description: The National Air and Space Museum, scorning false modesty, calls itself the world's most popular museum, and one of its biggest attractions over the past decade has been a series of giant-screen motion pictures. So big, in fact, that the museum is running a contest next month with a prize for the person who comes closest to guessing the total attendance of ''To Fly!'', the first of the films, which opened in 1976 and is still running.

title: EXOTIC SOLOS AND FAMILIAR STYLES
description: ''THERE'S something very exciting for me about putting the pieces together,'' Louise Roberts said the other day. ''You chop. You peel. And pretty soon you've got a wonderful dish.''

title: Janus Festival
description: The following is the schedule for the Janus Film Festival at the Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. For times and ticket information, the number is 431-1590.

title: FORMER F.B.I. AGENT FOUND GUILTY OF ESPIONAGE FOR THE SOVIET UNION
description: Richard W. Miller, the only Federal Bureau of Investigation agent ever charged with spying, was convicted today on six counts of espionage for the Soviet Union and bribery.

title: Bernstein and Baldwin Join Legion of Honor
description: Leonard Bernstein and James Baldwin today were made Commanders of the Legion of Honor, one of France's highest awards, by President Fran cois Mitterrand.

title: Restricting African Exports Is Bad Trade Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECIAL ANTIBODY WINS APPROVAL AS TREATMENT FOR KIDNEY PATIENTS
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved the first therapeutic use of a special type of tailor-made antibody that has been described as a potential miracle cure for a wide variety of ailments for the past decade.

title: Tommy Flanagan
description: The pianist Tommy Flanagan will lead a trio tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: ENERGY CAPITAL DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WAS THE CHIEF TOO TOUGH? DEBATES DIVIDES SAG HARBOR
description: To his supporters, John Harrington was the epitome of a good small-town police chief: tough, but not too tough, even-handed, compassionate and concerned about the community.

title: Chip Maker's Loss Widens
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation today reported a loss of $7.1 million for its fourth quarter, far exceeding the loss of $2.7 million it reported in the period a year ago.

title: THEN PANEL PUTS DECISION OFF
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today swiftly approved sweeping restrictions on lobbying by former Federal officials but then agreed to reconsider the bill.

title: MAGNETIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes $568,724 in losses resulting from the discontinuance of company's Universal Silicon Inc. subsidiary. c-Net income

title: NONSMOKING-SECTIONS BILL FOR RESTAURANTS IS BACKED
