description: Antismoking activists, led by a prominent lung-cancer surgeon, opened a campaign yesterday to support legislation before the City Council that would restrict smoking in restaurants and other public places.

title: Religion Is Irrelevant To Vatican Post
description: To the Editor:

title: Foot Jousts on L.I.
description: For those who enjoy watching a good foot joust (that is, a joust without horses), the annual festival sponsored by Medieval Studies and Restoration Inc. will take place this weekend at the Sands Point Park and Preserve at Port Washington, L.I. Also featured will be medieval foods and crafts, puppet shows, music and dance, and a fashion show. Hours are 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, rain or shine; the fair will also go on next weekend.

title: EXPERIMENTAL DRUG RAISES HOPE ON DIABETES
description: An experimental drug that protects diabetic animals against abnormal changes in their blood vessels may prove useful in treating the disease in humans and in preventing important ill effects of aging, scientists reported yesterday.

title: AT A TEA DANCE, MEMORIES
description: Brooke Astor calls her new novel, ''The Last Blossom on the Plum Tree,'' which is set in the heady, pre-crash days of 1928, ''a period piece.'' So to celebrate its publication, she put on a period party, a the dansant at the Plaza Hotel.

title: JEM RECORDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A Privacy Issue Cuts Across Ideological Lines
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the conservative Utah Republican, is not often found on the same side of an issue as organized labor and the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: SCREEN: 'KARATE KID PART II'
description: AS junk food, John G. Avildsen's ''Karate Kid'' (1984) was popcorn soaked in hot margarine - not great as a steady diet but harmless as a short-term binge. There was also something vestigially satisfying in its story, which seemed to have been adapted from those long-ago cartoon ads for Charles Atlas's muscle-building courses.

title: Who Says Hospital Work Is a Punishment?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'ME AND MRS. C,' SITCOM, ON NBC
description: APPARENTLY determined to let stereotypes have their unfettered way, NBC is dragging forth ''Me and Mrs. C,'' a sitcom that can be seen on Saturdays at 9:30 P.M. for the next six weeks. ''Mrs. C'' is Mrs. Conklin (Peg Murray), a money-strapped widow who, in order to avoid moving in with her silly son, Ethan (Gary Bayer), and his even sillier wife, Kathleen (Ellen Regan), decides to take a boarder into her picture-postcard suburban home. ''Me'' is Gerri Kilgore (Misha McK), the 22-year-old boarder, who is brash, beautiful and black. There have, perhaps, been less promising premises for a show. This one was created by Scoey Mitchlll, the program's executive producer.

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 8
SERVICE CORPORATION INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes gains from dispositions of $313,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $1,213,000, or 5 cents a share, for the year. c-Includes gains from dispositions of $355,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $1,849,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year.

title: El Nino's Current
description: A warm Pacific current flows down the west coast of South America that affects everything from our weather to the price of fish. It is known, and feared, as El Nino.

title: SEX HARASSMENT ON JOB IS ILLEGAL
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that sexual harassment of an employee by a supervisor violates the Federal law against sex discrimination in the workplace.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for 13wks to June 1
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,948,000. The latest quarter's net includes a after-tax gain of $3.3 million, or 10 cents a share, from the sale of 470,000 shares of Symbolics Inc. common stock.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
GLASSBORO: HISTORY'S TWIST
description: There is a historical irony in President Reagan's decision to speak on Soviet-American arms control at Glassboro, N.J., today.

title: MEADOWLAKE IS OUT FOR REST OF YEAR
description: Meadowlake, the 3-year-old colt whose brilliance has been matched only by his perpetual unsoundness, suffered a hairline saucer fracture in his right front cannon bone during a workout Wednesday morning and will be sidelined for the rest of the year.

title: Head of Company That Sold Tainted Cheese Is Sentenced
description: The president of a company that processed Mexican food was sentenced today to 30 days in the county jail and fined $18,800 in connection with a cheese contamination that killed up to 80 people last year.

title: Debt Securities At Record Pace
description: The booming volume of debt securities offered so far this year yesterday surpassed the total volume for all of 1985, which had been the record year, according to the Securities Data Company.

title: Brazil Loan Is Approved
description: The World Bank approved today a $529 million loan for a hydroelectric project in Brazil, a nation that owes more than $103 billion and is the third world's largest debtor.

title: PINCH-HIT BY EVANS BEATS ORIOLES, 7-5
description: Darrell Evans, pinch-hitting, singled home the tying and lead runs in the eighth inning, and Lou Whitaker added a two-run home run in the ninth as the Detroit Tigers beat the Baltimore Orioles, 7-5, tonight for a sweep of their four-game series.

title: Smokey Robinson
description: The pop-soul songwriter Smokey Robinson will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Red Parrot, 617 West 57th Street (247-1530). Tickets are $25 for the 8:30 shows and $30 for the 11:30 shows.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 20, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Pork Bellies Advance; Grains, Soybeans Gain
description: Futures prices for live hogs and frozen pork bellies jumped for the second consecutive day today, as supplies continued to dwindle on farms and in slaughterhouses.

title: Let's Be Bullish on Ethics
description: The integrity of American business has been shaken by a wave of indictments of Wall Street traders and by criminal charges against some corporate giants. With reports of illegal insider dealings on securities, defense contract padding and bribery scams, the ethics of business leaders are being questioned almost daily.

title: Auto Loans Back G.M.A.C. Issue
description: For the second time this year the General Motors Acceptance Corporation is offering asset-backed securities through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Simple Ways to End Taxi-Flagging Scam
description: To the Editor:

title: Bargain Ballard
description: Harold Ballard, owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs, when asked what he was looking for in a coach after Dan Maloney's resignation: ''Anything I can get within the $75,000 range.''

title: AID TO CITY BUDGET GAINS IN ASSEMBLY
description: Leaders of the State Assembly said today that they had reached an agreement with New York City officials on how to close the gap of more than $160 million in the city's proposed budget for next year.

title: HUMANITAS TV AWARDS GIVEN
description: ''Do You Remember Love?,'' a CBS television movie about the devastation caused by Alzheimer's disease and the power of love to transform tragedy, and episodes of ''Cagney and Lacey'' and ''The Cosby Show'' were awarded the Humanitas Prize today for the 1985-86 television season.

title: ENTERTAINMENT HALLS
description: Brooklyn's famed entertainment halls, past and present, are the subjects of a bus tour tomorrow sponsored by the Prospect Park Environmental Center.

title: CHURCHES AND NEWSPAPERS CALLED TARGET OF RAIDS
description: South African authorities turned the strength of their crackdown on church workers and journalists yesterday, as security forces raided the offices of a number of organizations and detained employees, according to South Africans and information reaching Europe and the United States.

title: Economic Scene; Czech Mystery: The Affluence
description: THE great mystery of this country is how it manages to provide a standard of living that is probably the highest in the Communist world out of an economy that appears stagnant.

title: Just Dandy, Don
description: Don Sutton's 300th career victory means that there are now four active major league pitchers at or above that plateau for the first time since 1891, when the category was crowded by Old Hoss Radbourne, Pud Galvin, Tim Keefe and Mickey Welch.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PATIENT GETS AIDS VIRUS DESPITE BLOOD TEST
description: Health researchers today reported the first case of a patient becoming infected with the AIDS virus from a blood transfusion that had been tested and showed no signs of the deadly disease.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THE oldest known illustrated medieval manuscript of the life of St. Thomas a Becket will be among a number of rare works auctioned this weekend and next week in London, New York and Monte Carlo. In addition, there will be a Modigliani portrait of the artist's mistress, a table used as an altar attributed to John Goddard and a painting of the Holy Family attributed to Mantegna.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on May 24 about a wage dispute at the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund overstated the salary levels of the organizations' professional economists.

title: 30 Named 'Living Treasures' For Contributions to the City
description: Thirty people who have made significant contributions to New York City were honored as ''living treasures'' yesterday by View From the Torch, an organization devoted to promoting New York's cultural, ethnic and artistic diversity.

title: 7 Courts May Resume Civil U.S. Jury Trials
description: A Federal appeals court judge has granted temporary resumption of civil jury trials in Federal courts in seven states, overturning a national order imposed for budgetary reasons.

title: TIDBIT ALLEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: Sales comparisons for year-ago quarter are not applicable since company began operations in September 1985.

title: Royal Crown Sues Over Rivals' Deals
description: The Royal Crown Cola Company filed an antitrust suit seeking to stop the Coca-Cola Company from completing its proposed merger with the Dr Pepper Company, and Pepsico Inc. from going ahead with its plan to acquire the Seven-Up Company. The suit, filed in a Federal court in Columbus, Ga., asserts that the proposed deals ''will substantially lessen competition'' in the industry.

title: Fraud Bill Draws Fire
description: A majority of Securities and Exchange Commission members said today that they opposed a provision of a bill that would require outside auditors of companies to report to the Government their suspicions of fraud.

title: BIG PRESIDENTIAL FIELD IS SEEN
description: The Republican national chairman, Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., said today that the 1988 election could attract an unusually large field of Presidential aspirants, with as many as 15 candidates vying for the nomination of each party.

title: HIJACKER OF THE ACHILLE LAURO RECANTS CONFESSION OF KILLING
description: In defiant but often contradictory court testimony, the Palestinian gunman who prosecutors say once confessed to killing a disabled New York man during the Achille Lauro hijacking denied today that the crime had ever taken place.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes losses of $23,000 and $886,000 from discontinued operations for quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes net income of $129,000 and $137,000 from discontinued operations for quarter and year, respectively.

title: Overkill
description: The mushroom clouds on their football helmets will seem bizarre to some, indeed may send shivers up the spines of the nuclear-sensitive. But when the Richland (Wash.)

title: FROM MASTERPIECES TO BEST OF WORST IN 3 FILM FESTIVALS
description: IRRESISTIBLE.

title: SOVIET DOOMS WAR CRIMINAL WHO WAS DEPORTED BY U.S.
description: Fyodor D. Fedorenko, a 78-year-old suspected war criminal deported by the United States, was sentenced to death today by a Soviet court.

title: CHARVOZ-CARSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income. The share earnings for both year- earlier periods have been restated to give effect to a 5-for-4 stock split effected in December 1985. The company said its latest quarter loss reflects an inventory writedown of $110,000, a $100,000 non-recurring charge related to the early retirement of its former chairman and a change in determining gross profit margins based on the strengthening of foreign currencies.

title: Reliance Alters Its Blair Offer
description: Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Capital Group sweetened the cash in its bid for John Blair & Company to $31 a share. But it also reduced the number of shares it is seeking and the face value of notes in a package worth about $340 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on June 10, about the departure of President Reagan's director of speech writers, misidentified him. He is Bently T. Elliott.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST UP 5.6%, TO RECORD LEVEL
description: The following Big Board companies show large changes:

title: Unicef Says Fund for Africa Is at Only 3 Percent of Goal
description: The United Nations Children's Fund has received only $3.2 million of the $102 million in voluntary contributions for which it has appealed to fund its 1986 emergency programs in 16 African countries, a spokesman at the agency said today.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Advertising; A Beer Joins The Grey Fold
description: For Grey Advertising it's been a long time between beers. Not since it handled Rheingold, a regional brew, in the 1960's has the country's 11th- largest agency had a brewery it could call its own.

title: Consumers Power
description: The Consumers Power Company said that it planned to delay seeking permission to charge customers for $1 billion of the cost of its idled Midland nuclear plant. Consumers Power said it would ask the Michigan Public Service Commission to include $2.1 billion of the Midland costs in its rate base, rather than $3.1 billion requested earlier. The remaining $1 billion represents costs for the part of Midland that can be converted to a natural gas-fired plant.

title: To Test, or Not to Test: That Is the Nuclear Question; WHY TRUST MOSCOW ON A MORATORIUM?
description: Like the nuclear ''freeze'' that would have frozen into place a dangerous strategic imbalance, the Soviet proposal, made last August and later repeated, for a joint moratorium on underground nuclear testing is a hoax. Once again, it is a rallying cry for those who favor symbolism over security and substance.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on June 4 about a valuable lot on West 52d Street incorrectly identified the authority that prohibits companies from owning an interest in both a retail and a wholesale liquor business. It is the state government.

title: Big Financing by Austin
description: The largest municipal financing yesterday in a market that began firm but ended down by 3/4 to 1 percentage point was a $100 million competitive issue of Austin, Tex., general obligation bonds.

title: Dining Out Guide; Lincoln Center Area
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CAFE DES ARTISTES, #1 West 67th Street (877-3500) -

title: INDUSTRY SEES MORE CONCERNS OVER SAFETY OF DRUG CAPSULES
description: The latest fatal drug-tampering incidents are sure to increase already heightened consumer fears about products in capsules, and should lead to additional safety measures from nonprescription-drug makers, industry executives said yesterday.

title: First Maryland
description: A city circuit judge placed the bankrupt First Maryland Savings and Loan into receivership, marking the first step in returning funds to depositors,who have been unable to withdraw money since last fall. In granting the state's request for receivership, Judge Joseph H. H. Kaplan rejected a proposal by an attorney for a depositors' group that said it had a potential buyer for the thrift institution. Under the state's payout plan, First Maryland depositors could withdraw up to $5,000 at the end of July.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Beginning today, The New York Times will use ''Ms.'' as an honorific in its news and editorial columns.

title: Delay Sought By Argentina
description: Argentina will probably delay negotiations with the International Monetary Fund about a new standby loan, official sources said today, until Mexico resolves its problems with the I.M.F.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Guru Heads for Jamaica
description: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the Indian guru who left the United States last November after immigration charges were brought against him, has left Uruguay and flown to Jamaica via the Brazilian city of Manaus, the Brazilian Air Force said today.

title: EIGHT LEGAL SECRETARIES FACE JAIL
description: A state appeals court in Brooklyn has ordered eight legal secretaries jailed for civil contempt unless they agree to testify in a disciplinary proceeding against a lawyer.

title: HOUSE MEASURE BACKS '79 ARMS PACT
description: The House of Representatives approved a resolution today urging President Reagan to stay within the limits on nuclear weapons established by the strategic arms treaty negotiated with the Soviet Union in 1979.

title: KEMP STEPS DOWN AT FOUNDATION TO AVERT DISPUTE ON ELECTION ROLE
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, Republican of upstate New York, has resigned as chairman of the Fund for an American Renaissance, a tax-exempt foundation he set up five years ago.

title: California's Curb On Primaries Is Voided
description: A Federal appellate court has ruled that barring political parties from endorsing candidates in primary elections is ''a form of paternalism that is inconsistent with the First Amendment.''

title: Thompson to Spurs
description: The Portland Trail Blazers forward Mychal Thompson has been traded to the San Antonio Spurs for the forward Steve Johnson in a deal that includes the rights to Larry Krystkowiak, a Portland draft choice from Montana. Thompson, a first-round draft choice from Minnesota in 1978, was the only Blazer to play in the team's 82 regular-season games last year.

title: RAGAN, BRAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $3,128,000.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STORM CENTER: The Supreme Court in American Politics. By David M. O' Brien. Illustrated. 384 pages. W. W. Norton. $18.95.

title: Versace Campaigning
description: ''If they'd like to get back to the top 10, I'll take the challenge.''

title: Simmons Offers $900 Million for NL
description: NL Industries received a $900 million acquisition offer yesterday from Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor, whose affiliates in recent days have amassed more than 10 million of the company's shares.

title: Auto Parts Maker Offers Debentures
description: AP Industries, a privately owned automobile parts manufacturer, yesterday began offering $100 million of 12 3/8 percent subordinated sinking-fund debentures due 2001 at par through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. A sinking fund starting in 1994 will retire 64 percent of the debentures by maturity.

title: Daggett Leads Gymnastics Meet
description: Tim Daggett, winner of a gold medal in the 1984 Olympics, led the field in the United States national gymnastics championships while his Olympic teammate, Scott Johnson, had problems and was 24th after today's compulsory phase of the two-day competition.

title: U.S. TO CITE VOTE TO PRESS PRETORIA
description: The Reagan Administration, while publicly opposed to the trade embargo against South Africa approved by the House Wednesday, intends to take advantage of that vote to try to persuade Pretoria to approve steps changing its apartheid system, senior Administration officials said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S SPEECH AT JERSEY SCHOOL
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by President Reagan today to the graduating class at Glassboro High School in New Jersey, as made public by the White House:

title: YANKEES DEFEATED IN 10TH FOR FIFTH STRAIGHT LOSS
description: The numbers were impressive: 9 runs, 18 hits, home runs from Rickey Henderson and Mike Pagliarulo, four-hit games from Don Mattingly and Ken Griffey. But consider the result: a 10-9 defeat in 10 innings to the surging Toronto Blue Jays and a Yankee losing streak that has now reached five games.

title: MSGR. T. J. McGOVERN
description: Msgr. Thomas J. McGovern, former pastor of the Guardian Angel Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan and chaplain for the Port of New York, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: Stars and Stripes Forever
description: When the United States Marine Band performs for the Statue of Liberty under the direction of Col. John R. Bourgeois July 4 and 5, it will be a double anniversary. Just 100 years before, the Marine Band played for the original dedication, under the baton of John Philip Sousa.

title: HOUSE UNIT BEGINS IMPEACHMENT INQUIRY ON JUDGE
description: Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne was brought from prison to testify today at the start of impeachment proceedings against him by a committee of the House of Representatives.

title: VAST SUMS ARE REPORTED NEEDED TO RESTORE U.S. RECREATION AREAS
description: A Presidential commission contends that heavy investment and new leadership are needed to restore the ''deteriorating'' natural and man-made resources Americans use for recreation.

title: Venturing South
description: General Manager Pat Williams of the Philadelphia 76ers, who stunned the National Basketball Association just before the college draft Tuesday by trading the center Moses Malone, along with Philadelphia's No. 1 pick, is making another bold move. He is leaving the 76ers to join a group in central Florida attempting to bring an N.B.A. franchise to Orlando.

title: G.E. in Deal With Japan's Fanuc
description: The General Electric Company and Japan's Fanuc Ltd. said yesterday that they would establish a joint venture to sell machine-control equipment and systems.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday WELCOME BACK, WILL It's time for free Shakespeare in Central Park again, and the New York Shakespeare Festival is opening its summer season at the Delacorte Theater this weekend with ''Twelfth Night.'' The production, set in Illyria in the 16th century, is directed by Wilford Leach and stars F. Murray Abraham as Malvolio and Peter MacNicol as Sir Andrew Aguecheek. Mr. Abraham appeared at the Delacorte two seasons ago in ''The Golem,'' but is best known for his Academy Award-winning portrayal of Salieri in ''Amadeus.'' Mr. MacNicol, who recently starred in ''Rum and Coke'' at the Public Theater, also played Stingo in the movie ''Sophie's Choice.'' Joining them onstage in ''Twelfth Night'' will be Tony Azito, William Duff-Griffin, Thomas Gibson, Kim Greist and Kathleen Layman. The music is by Rupert Holmes, who - like Mr. Leach - has just won a Tony Award for ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood.'' Performances of ''Twelfth Night'' are tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 8 o'clock. Free tickets are distributed, one to a person, at the Delacorte box office starting at 6:15 P.M. on the evening of the performance. Information: 861-7277.

title: Baxter Travenol
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. said its 1986 earnings would not be hurt by a recent ruling of a Federal appeals court affirming a $44 million patent infringement judgment against one of its newly acquired units. It said the ruling involves the heat exchanger element of an oxygenator made by Bentley Laboratories, a subsidiary of the American Hospital Supply Corporation, which was acquired last November. The company said it was considering several possible actions, including a petition for a rehearing and a motion for relief from the judgment.

title: Academies Map A TV Offensive
description: At a time when the nation is just a couple of months away from being overrun by another glut of fall football programming, the three service academies have banded together to bring some military order out of the chaos of saturation Saturdays. They've concluded a deal with a Colorado Springs syndicator to offer an 11-week season of games involving Army, Navy and the Air Force.

title: PERCEPTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PRETORIA ORDERS CURFEWS IN AREA OF BLACK UNREST
description: The South African authorities, invoking the nation's emergency decree, imposed a curfew and other prohibitions tonight on segregated black townships in 13 areas in the restive Eastern Cape, the Government Gazette reported.

title: MICHAEL RETURNS TO SHEA
description: After 12 years, Gene Michael returned to Shea Stadium last night in a new role and with a new team.

title: Heroin Addicts, 'Collars' and the Spread of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. ATTORNEY CHALLENGES ECONOMIST
description: An attorney for the National Football League tried yesterday to portray the United States Football League's request for antitrust damages as excessive, saying the economic study used to determine the request was based on false assumptions.

title: Stars and Stripes, II
description: Stars and Stripes, the armed forces newspaper that reached a circulation of over one million in World War II, may be in for some changes. After a yearlong study, the General Accounting Office has recommended that the European and Pacific editions of the paper, now printed in Darmstadt, West Germany, and Tokyo, be merged into a single publication that would be largely written and edited in the United States, transmitted by satellite and printed in the existing plants abroad.

title: Two Operas Presented
description: Golden Fleece Ltd.: The Composers Chamber Theater will present two short operas at the Actor's Outlet Theater Center, 120 West 28th Street, this weekend.

title: THE BIG SQUEEZE IN RETAILING
description: Caught between aggressive discounters and such thriving higher-priced chains as Macy's and Bloomingdale's, old-line department stores catering to the broad lower-income market are facing an increasingly bleak future, especially in New York.

title: Padre All-Stars
description: For the time being, two San Diego Padre teammates, Steve Garvey and Tony Gwynn, have broken into the starting lineup in balloting for the National League All-Star team.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: ''First Annual Reunion of the Condon's Gang,'' Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street (758-2272). While the JVC Jazz Festival is being held in concert halls around town, Michael's Pub has created a small-scale, monthlong jazz festival by providing a home for the musicians who played at Eddie Condon's Manhattan jazz club until it was razed last summer. There are the basic personnel each week, with a changing list of guests. Tonight and tomorrow, one of Eddie Condon's contemporaries in the Chicago jazz world of the late 1920's, Wild Bill Davison will be the band's cornetist. Another veteran of those days in Chicago, the pianist Art Hodes, will play tonight, to be replaced tomorrow by Marty Napoleon. The clarinetist Peanuts Hucko, a member of the band at the original Eddie Condon's on West Third Street 40 years ago, will be on the stand both tonight and tomorrow, and the bassist Jack Lesberg, another Condon's veteran, will also play both nights. Chris Flory, the exciting young guitarist in Scott Hamilton's group, will play tomorrow (Red Balaban will be the guitarist tonight) and the trombonist Tom Artin and the drummer Danny D'Imperio will perform both nights. Shows are at 9 and 11 P.M. There is a $10 cover charge and a two-drink minimum.

title: UNIVERSITY MOURNS LEN BIAS
description: Outside, the sun shone brightly and the state flag hung at half-staff as members of the University of Maryland athletic department gathered today in the cool darkness of Cole Field House to mourn Len Bias.

title: 2 DIE AND 10 INJURED IN ONE VAN
description: Two men were killed and 10 other men were injured when a van in which they were all riding to work collided with a truck on the rain-slicked Whitestone Expressway in Queens last night, the police said.

title: WHITE HOUSE PRODS FED, GENTLY, FOR RATE CUT
description: President Reagan wants new cuts in interest rates to revive a sagging economy, the White House said today. But it said he was not trying to put pressure on the Federal Reserve Board to orchestrate them, and economists said any new cuts are unlikely for several weeks.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JUNE 20, 1986
description: International The President praised the Kremlin, saying it had begun to make a serious effort toward arms control that could represent a turning point in Soviet-American relations. Mr. Reagan made the comment in addressing a high-school commencement in Glassboro, N.J., where President Johnson and Alexei N. Kosygin, the Soviet Prime Minister, met 19 years ago. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: ART: PAINTINGS BY HENRI ON VIEW AT BERRY-HILL
description: NO one can deny that American art achieved autonomy with Abstract Expressionism. But now, it seems that independence, regardless of the way it was secured, was inevitable, given the political and economic state of the postwar world and the fact that the seeds of this independence had already sprouted.

title: Hook or Crook
description: Don Sutton, often accused of enhancing his breaking pitch by doctoring the baseball, after hurling career victory No. 300: ''I've been trying, legally and illegally, to get here for years.''

title: IN SUBWAY, AN ACCENT ON CULTURE
description: Waiting for their trains, subway riders read. They read newspapers, books, anything to pass the time. Yesterday, at the IND station at 53d Street and Fifth Avenue, they were reading the walls.

title: A.M.A. SAYS STUDENTS WITH AIDS SHOULD NOT BE BARRED BY SCHOOLS
description: Children with AIDS should be allowed to attend public schools, the American Medical Association said at its 135th annual convention that ended here today.

title: HORNE JOINS FESTIVAL FOR HUDSON
description: The Clearwater Great Hudson River Revival has rallied an unusual assortment of musicians to the cause. Scanning the bill, one is not surprised to find the name of Pete Seeger - he was, after all, one of the project's founders - nor the names of such reliable pop and folk artists as Odetta, Happy Traum, Richie Havens and Country Joe McDonald. But Marilyn Horne singing folk songs on a Hudson River sloop?

title: INTERNATIONAL CAPITAL EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $145,000. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $22,000 for the quarter and $123,000 for the 9 months.

title: Rainbow Warrior Case Ready for U.N. Scrutiny
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will rule on the dispute between France and New Zealand over the bombing last July of the environmentalist ship Rainbow Warrior ''in the very near future,'' a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: REAGAN MUST PRESS PRETORIA
description: President Reagan has already made clear that he opposes the measure passed in the House this week requiring the severing of all economic ties with South Africa. Holding fast to the policy of constructive engagement, the President argues that quiet diplomacy, not sanctions, is the best way to influence Pretoria. But how much influence has the Administration had in South Africa? What have we gotten from our infinitely patient, penalty-free policy of back-channel communication with the only regime in the world based on racial domination?

title: Lieut. Emmi McLean Wed in Honolulu
description: Lieut. Emmi Alexandra McLean, U.S.N., a daughter of Lieut. Col. Ellis A. McLean, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. McLean of Great Falls, Mont., was married yesterday to Lieut.

title: FOR GLASSBORO, A BRIEF VISIT IS ENOUGH
description: President Reagan spent barely an hour here today, but for the 130 graduating seniors, their parents, friends and thousands of others on the grounds of Glassboro High School, it seemed to be enough. ''It's neat,'' said Troy

title: 'Evening of Bel Canto'
description: The soprano Evelyn Quaife, the mezzo-soprano Adelle Nicholson, the tenor Dale Smith and the baritone Neil Eddinger will present ''An Evening of Bel Canto'' at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, tomorrow night at 8. Tickets are $8 and $10. Information: 362-8719.

title: THE GANELIN TRIO COMES TO TOWN FOR A NIGHT OF JAZZ TO A SOVIET BEAT
description: Probably the most surprising thing about the appearance of the Ganelin Trio at the JVC Jazz Festival in New York City Saturday night is that it hasn't been there before.

title: Charges Against Mother Dropped in Baby's Death
description: The State Attorney General's office and the police said today they were dropping all charges against a woman who had been accused of murdering her 4-month-old daughter and conspiring with her husband.

title: EXPERIENCE TEACHES McKAY
description: Antonio McKay has won a gold and a bronze medal in the Olympics, national titles indoors and national collegiate titles indoors and outdoors. Two years ago, in his first race against collegians, he ran the fastest 440 yards indoors ever to that time.

title: SALES TAX PROVISO IN SENATE BILL
description: The Senate agreed today to allow people who live in states with little or no income tax to deduct a portion of their state and local sales tax payments on their Federal tax returns.

title: AFTER 15 WITNESSES, DEFENSE ENDS IN NAVY SPY TRIAL
description: The defense in the espionage and tax fraud trial of Jerry A. Whitworth ended its case today after presenting 15 witnesses over four days.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Replacements, the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Ornery, unpredictable, funny, defiant and rough-edged, the Minneapolis-based Replacements carry a rock-and-roll spirit into the ever-slicker 1980's. The band's grainy-voiced singer and songwriter, Paul Westerberg, is impatient with pretension and double talk, but steers clear of easy cynicism; among his titles are ''Color Me Impressed'' and ''Lay It Down Clown.'' Mr. Westerberg has an ear for melody, and the band's music touches on everything from the Beatles to folk-rock to Kiss to soul. Their opening acts at the Ritz are also worth hearing. Steve Earle, a honky-tonking country-rock singer, will appear tonight, and Green on Red - a group that can sound like the Velvet Underground, Creedence Clearwater Revival and the Band all at once - will open for them tomorrow. Opening acts begin at 11 P.M., with the Replacements at 1 A.M. Tickets are $12.50 in advance, $13.50 the day of the show.

title: Dual Position Is Filled By American Petrofina
description: Kenneth W. Perry was named president and chief executive officer of American Petrofina Inc., succeeding Paul D. Meek, who stays on as chairman of the Dallas energy and chemical concern, the company's board said today.

title: REAGAN DISCLOSES A 'SERIOUS EFFORT' BY SOVIET ON ARMS
description: President Reagan said today that the Soviet Union had begun to make a serious effort toward arms control that could represent a turning point in relations between the two countries.

title: PRETORIA AIDES CIRCULATE A 'COMMUNIST' TRACT
description: When South African officials seek to justify their reasons for the nation's state of emergency, they do so partly by referring to a document they say was intercepted from the outlawed South African Communist Party.

title: CITY BOARD ANNULS FRIEDMAN'S PENSION RIGHTS
description: Officials yesterday revoked the pension rights that Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, gained by giving a three-hour lecture on politics at Lehman College in 1983.

title: Joint Phone Operation
description: Joint operation of the GTE Corporation's Sprint long-distance service and United Telecommunications Inc.'s US Telecom as U.S. Sprint has been approved by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: By Mistake, a Good Insurance Buy
description: New York savings banks have long offered a good buy in low-cost life insurance. Now, thanks to an error by the insurance lobby, the good deal has gotten even better.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 2 Slain and One Hurt In 2 Shootings on L.I.
description: A man with a handgun stopped a couple leaving a Long Island restaurant Wednesday night and demanded their money, but killed the man before he could cooperate and then killed the woman as she handed him the man's money clip, the police said today.

title: The Abandoned Dog And the Ballet Star
description: ''Do you want this dog?''

title: Cable System Sale By Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said that it had completed the sale of its 140 cable television systems for $1.7 billion to a consortium of cable operators.

title: Child Gets 2d New Heart
description: A 3-year-old boy was given his second heart transplant in two days today, and doctors said the new organ appeared to be good.

title: PREP TALENT IN N.H.L. DRAFT
description: Twenty years ago, even 10 or five, the distances between the frigid rinks of the New England prep schools and the Boston Garden or the Montreal Forum, the palaces of the National Hockey League, were closer to infinity than reality.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have indicated to General Secretary Gorbachev my willingness for our representatives to meet to prepare for the next summit.

title: ALL-AMERICAN BASKETBALL STAR, CELTIC CHOICE, DIES SUDDENLY
description: Len Bias, who was the second selection over all and the first by the Boston Celtics in the professional draft of college basketball players Tuesday, died suddenly early yesterday morning.

title: A TAX EXCEPTION FOR 8 PEOPLE
description: A handful of Americans were bestowed with a one-of-a-kind, multimillion-dollar exception in the Senate tax-revision bill this week. One of these eight individuals, it turns out, is Edward L. Gaylord, who heads an Oklahoma-based media empire. Other members of the group include one of his business associates, a Colorado mineral lawyer and a former political opponent of Senator Gary Hart.

title: SUIT ASKS COURT TO RUN CEMENT UNION
description: Federal prosecutors asked a court yesterday to take control of the concrete workers union in New York City, charging that it was a ''captive labor organization, which has been infiltrated, dominated and exploited by the Colombo family'' of the Mafia.

title: Burger Cancels Plan For Liberty Speech
description: Warren E. Burger, the retiring Chief Justice of the United States, has withdrawn as keynote speaker for ''Liberty - the Next 100 Years,'' a conference that will be part of the Liberty Weekend celebration.

title: MARQUEST MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to March 29
Advertising; Workshop Isn't Just For Work
description: ON a weekday morning someone wearing a name tag in the foyer of the Waldorf-Astoria Grand Ballroom is quite a common sight. And, since yesterday was the 19th annual Association of National Advertisers-Radio Advertising Bureau Workshop, the tag identifying Carl Sandberg's affiliation as LFW caused no talk.

title: COHALAN SEEKING TO BUY SUFFOLK LANDS FOR PARKS
description: Suffolk County would spend $60 million to buy and preserve 4,833 acres of scenic and undeveloped open land under a plan announced today by the County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan.

title: TRI-COUNTY SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $257,000. The company said the latest year loss includes a loan loss provision of at least $9.5 million related primarily to loans secured by second mortgages on condominium units located throughout the U.S.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: SIX-YEAR-OLD Lavin's, a comely new-American-style restaurant in midtown, is a victim of the mysterious black-hole phenomenon that afflicts certain neighborhoods in Manhattan. Situated in the heart of the busy garment district on West 39th Street, midday finds Lavin's as mobbed as the fitting room at Bloomingdale's, yet in evening it is a cool and lonely place.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SANDINISTAS RETURN BUILDINGS TO CHURCH
description: The Sandinista Government today withdrew soldiers who had been occupying a Roman Catholic social agency for eight months and returned the agency's buildings to church authorities. There was no indication that the agency would be allowed to reopen, however.

title: CYANIDE IN PILLS CAUSED 2ND DEATH
description: Laboratory tests have determined that a second death was caused by cyanide-laced Extra-Strength Excedrin capsules, top law-enforcement officials here said today, and they raised the possibility that other cyanide deaths might be discovered.

title: PHILIP JACOBSON
description: Philip Jacobson, former program coordinator for the National Jewish Community Relations Advisory Council, died Monday at Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: THE MEN WITH SQUEEGEES: TROUBLING FACT OF CITY LIFE
description: Suddenly, as if appearing from nowhere, a man in his 30's moved up to a car stopped for a traffic light on Houston Street at Broadway and began to wash the windshield. With beard stubble and black wraparound sunglasses, he was a troubling figure.

title: TIMES AND SULZBERGERS TAKE STEPS TO KEEP COMPANY UNDER FAMILY
description: The New York Times Company yesterday announced several financial moves that would keep control of the company in the Sulzberger family indefinitely.

title: BORN IN A TRUNK: THE STORY OF THE HORNES
description: Several years ago, Lena Horne asked her daughter, Gail Lumet Buckley, to store in her basement an old family trunk that had belonged to Miss Horne's father.

title: Morgan Grenfell
description: Morgan Grenfell Holdings Ltd., the London merchant bank, will make its initial public offering of stock today, according to company officials. Morgan Grenfell expects to raise $:150 million, or the equivalent of more than $226 million, from the issue of stock, which will increase its capital 50 percent, to $:450 million. The shares are expected to be sold for about $:5 each, but the exact price will not be set until next Thursday and will depend on the demand for the stock.

title: BROADWAY
description: IF you're making your first solo Broadway producing effort, it might as well be a prestigious one, especially when there will likely be some $800,000 at stake. So, for Carole J. Shorenstein, it's the playwright August Wilson and the director Lloyd Richards and ''Fences,'' which just won the American Theater Critics' first Outstanding Play Award. The play was first produced at the Yale Repertory Theater last year, as was ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' for which the same two men were responsible, and which also made it to Broadway. At the moment, ''Fences'' is scheduled to open next spring, after a month in San Francisco in February.

title: CITY OPERA NAMES A MUSIC DIRECTOR
description: Sergiu Comissiona, the Rumanian-born music director of the Houston Symphony Orchestra, has been named music director of the New York City Opera, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Comissiona will assume his new position on Jan. 1. He succeeds Christopher Keene, music director since 1983, who announced in January that he would resign as of the end of this year.

title: 2 BILLION WITNESSES
description: Well, to turn around Richard Nixon's unkept promise, we won't have Uruguay to kick us around any more. This was only one of the developments in the second round of the World Cup, as eight teams were eliminated and eight qualified for this weekend's quarterfinals.

title: DELTA COMPUTEC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BELLEVUE WHISTLE-BLOWER CLEARED OF WRONGDOING
description: A social worker who complained about what he said were improprieties at Bellevue Hospital Center and who then became the subject of an investigation himself has been cleared of any wrongdoing by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 8
A Price Cut Spurs Sales At West 89th St. Project
description: IN February, Vincent L. Riso, a development partner in the Centra, a 108-apartment condominium at West 89th Street and Columbus Avenue, noticed that sales turned ''sluggish.''

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY ACTS TO CURB LIABILITY IN DRUNKEN-DRIVING
description: The New Jersey Assembly enacted bills today that would reduce the liability of social hosts if their intoxicated guests later have motor-vehicle accidents.

title: POLICE ITEMIZE SECURITY PLANS FOR THE FOURTH
description: The Police Department said yesterday that it would use 31 boats, 48 bullhorns, 375 life rings, 8 helicopters, 5,778 wooden barriers, 7 robots, and 4 bomb trucks to help protect the millions of people expected to attend the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration in two weeks.

title: TIME PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO 16% OF ITS SHARES
description: Time Inc., the giant magazine and cable company, yesterday authorized the repurchase of up to 10 million shares of its stock, or 16 percent of Time's total 62.9 million shares outstanding.

title: BROOKLYN MUSEUM SELECTS 5 ARCHITECTURAL FINALISTS
description: Five architectural teams have been chosen as finalists in the competition to design a master plan for the Brooklyn Museum, the museum's chairman, Alastair B. Martin, announced yesterday. Each of the five will produce a proposal for the phased restoration and renovation of the museum's interior and an expansion that would nearly double its space.

title: U.S.F.L.'s Allure
description: Tony Casillas, the all-America defensive tackle from Oklahoma, was drafted on the first round by the Atlanta Falcons of the National Football League and the Arizona Outlaws of the shaky United States Football League. Yesterday he said he had reached a two-year agreement in principle with the U.S.F.L. team and could sign with the Outlaws in two weeks. President Bill Tatham Jr. of the Outlaws said he agreed on Wednesday to a final counterproposal made by Casillas that the player's agent, John Maloney, valued at more than $1 million.

title: LOSS OF RETAIL ADS HURTING PAPERS
description: The changing fortunes of such retail giants as Gimbels, Alexander's and Ohrbach's are being felt, in varying degrees, by the advertising departments of the city's newspapers.

title: FILM: RAOUL RUIZ'S 'TOP OF THE WHALE
description: ''TOP OF THE WHALE,'' written and directed by Raoul Ruiz, the Chilean exile whose opaque surrealistic films ''City of Pirates'' and ''Three Crowns of the Sailor'' were shown at the New York Film Festival in 1984 and 1985, is what some people think of as an ''intellectual'' film. But it is related to the truly intelligent, deeply stirring films of Ingmar Bergman, for example, the way a slice-and-dice film compares to the films of Alfred Hitchcock. It is pretentious, practically incomprehensible, and most of all, utterly boring. It's the kind of self-indulgent cerebral nonsense that makes for a new appreciation of, say, Rodney Dangerfield. Since the characters speak five languages, changing from one to another every few sentences, it may also have the dubious distinction of being the first film to be made in something resembling Esperanto.

title: Indian Vocalist
description: The Indian vocalist Pandit Pran Nath, accompanied by La Monte Young, Miriam Zazeela and Ray Spiegel, will present an evening raga at the Dia Art Foundation Performance Space, 155 Mercer Street, tomorrow night at 9. Tickets are $8. Information: 925-8270.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch yesterday about President Reagan's Supreme Court nominations misstated the votes of Judges Antonin Scalia and Robert H. Bork in a 1984 decision of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. Judge Bork joined the majority in dismissing a libel suit by a Marxist professor against the syndicated columnists Rowland Evans and Robert Novak. Judge Scalia dissented.

title: NASA DROPS PLANS TO LAUNCH ROCKET FROM THE SHUTTLE
description: Because of serious safety concerns, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration is abandoning plans to use a rocket fueled with a highly volatile liquid to launch scientific and Defense Department payloads from the space shuttle, officials said yesterday.

title: KLIPPER'S FIRST HIT BEATS EXPOS
description: Bob Kipper combined with three pitchers on an eight-hitter and drove in the winning run with his first major-league hit in the fifth inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Montreal Expos, 4-2.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: DAVID ZIFF has catered all kinds of parties, but never anything like the one the other night. He managed to give himself a surprise 40th birthday party, right in his own home.

title: WORLCO INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ARCHDIOCESE TRIES MARKET RESEARCH
description: Does your priest talk too much about money? Are you happy with his sermons? What's your opinion on the church's stand on women's issues? Is the church providing enough help for working parents, drug addicts and the homeless?

title: 'The Emergency Is Working'
description: South Africa's Information Bureau permits us to report a ''marked decrease'' in violent incidents of the type we are not allowed to report, and cites this as ''proof that the emergency is working.''

title: COLUCHE, 41, A FRENCH ACTOR KNOWN FOR IRREVERENT HUMOR
description: Coluche, a comic actor celebrated in France for his often outrageous, irreverent, acid-tipped humor, died in a motorcycle accident in southern France today. He was 41 years old.

title: Swedes Guard Envoy After Intruder Incident
description: The United States Ambassador, Gregory Newell, apparently unfazed by police concern that two men might have been stalking him, made a festive visit to his family roots in Dakarna Province today. He was carefully escorted by police bodyguards on the lookout for the two men who were chased from a private estate where the Ambassador was dining Tuesday after guards found them lurking with guns.

title: Dow Falls 13.08 Points After Final-Hour Selloff
description: Stock prices dropped moderately yesterday as selling pressure swelled at the end of the session. Investors took cover before the often-volatile expiration of stock index futures, index options and individual stock option that occurs today.

title: Senate Panel Backs Naming Of Maloney as U.S. Attorney
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved the nomination of Andrew J. Maloney to be United States Attorney in Brooklyn, sending it to the full Senate for confirmation.

title: FILM: 'THE WALL,' AT PUBLIC THEATER
description: IN ''The Wall,'' which opens today at the Public Theater, the camera's eye views a prison in Ankara, Turkey, the way a scientist might scrutinize an anthill. It creates an odd clinical detachment that is effective in showing the dehumanization of the prisoners. The camera frames shots through bars or barbed wire. It peers down from above, through the edges of broken bottles placed atop walls to discourage escape. The view takes in several courtyards at once, revealing the curious human specimens scurrying about in frantic social interaction. It is an appropriate technique to re-create the sense of claustrophobic helplessness associated with imprisonment.

title: BRITISH TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: All results are based on United Kingdom accounting principles. Results reported in pounds sterling have been expressed in U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of $1.47 to the pound, the rate prevailing on March 31, 1986 the last date of the reporting period. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipt, or ADR. Each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telcom ordinary stock.

title: NEW YORK OFFICIALS REACH LIABILITY INSURANCE ACCORD
description: Sweeping changes in the state's liability insurance industry, including greater restrictions on rates and curbs on the payment of victims' compensation, were agreed to today by negotiators for Governor Cuomo, the Assembly and the State Senate.

title: Thanks, but . . .
description: The hunt for a chief White House speechwriter to succeed Bently T. Elliott has resumed. Mr. Elliott was dismissed two months ago in an intramural Administration controversy and has taken a job with Representative Jack. F. Kemp, an undeclared Presidential candidate.

title: High-Flying Official
description: Seeking to raise awareness of city services, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development had herself raised several feet above the ground.

title: ART: WAREHOUSED OLD MASTERS IN MET EXHIBITION
description: IN opening for the first time a series of study galleries in which European Old Master paintings not normally on view can be examined, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is helping to dispel the ancient, popular and hugely tenacious fallacy that in every big museum there is a basement filled with unseen masterpieces. True as this may sometimes be in the case of museums of modern art, it is usually a delusion in the context of older art -and a delusion that many great museums are now working hard to refute.

title: SALUTING BE-BOP AND THE BLUES
description: JAZZ from points as distant in time and space as New Orleans in the 20's and Russia in the 80's will be part of the JVC Jazz Festival, which starts its 10-day celebration tonight.

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $404,000 from the utilization of operating loss carryforwards of foreign subsidiaries of Wilson Learning Corp. c-Includes income of $350,000, or 8 cents a share, from filing amended tax returns.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEARTS: BOLD EXPERIMENTS STILL HAVE TO PROVE WORTH
description: The death of Murray P. Haydon in Louisville yesterday leaves only one person, William J. Schroeder, living on a permanent artificial heart, and his mental functions have been severely damaged by several strokes.

title: TRADERS CROSS FINGERS FOR THE 'WITCHING' HOUR
description: The stock market is not likely to be jarred today by violent price swings caused by professional trading programs, Wall Street experts said yesterday. Analysts said that many of the institutions that practice such program trading appear to have taken profits and have already closed out their positions.

title: Son of Frazier
description: Mike Tyson, the up-and-coming heavyweight with the almost-perfect 20-knockout record in 22 fights in 15 months as a professional, will meet Marvis Frazier, the son of former heavyweight champion Joe Frazier, in a July 26 fight at the Civic Center in Glens Falls, N.Y. The fight will be shown nationally on ABC-TV. Frazier (16-1 and 7 knockouts) lost his only fight as a professional to the former heavyweight champion Larry Holmes.

title: Expansion Plans At Woolworth
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company said it expects to spend $225 million this year on further expansion of its specialty retail business and the continuing renovation of its general merchandise stores.

title: PERSONAL INCOME DOWN 0.1% IN MAY
description: Americans' personal income, held back by weak growth in wages and salaries, fell one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the Government said today. It was the first drop in a year.

title: COURT SAYS STATES CAN'T QUIT SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that California and other states cannot withdraw their state and local government employees from the Social Security System.

title: 2 Members Leave Robins Pay Panel
description: Two A. H. Robins Company directors have resigned from the board's compensation committee after a court ruling cited Robins for civil contempt because the company made unauthorized payments to certain creditors and executives. Robins's vice president, John Taylor, said that William Zimmer 3d, a former Robins president, and George E. Thomas, a retired executive vice president, resigned at Tuesday's board meeting.

title: EDWARDS, A G & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed in May.

title: VIOLIN: SERGUI SCHWARTZ
description: SINCE mastery of a musical instrument is not necessarily accompanied by mastery of musical interpretation, Sergiu Schwartz's recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night fell short of artistic success. An Israeli violinist who has studied with Dorothy DeLay at the Juilliard School, Mr. Schwartz encountered no technical problems in a program that included Ysaye's Unaccompanied Sonata No. 3 and Wieniawski's Polonaise Brilliante No. 2 along with sonatas by Beethoven, Franck and Debussy.

title: PANAMA GENERAL ACCUSED IN KILLING
description: In an effort to confront the military Government, Panamanian opposition leaders today supported a formal accusation that the army chief here ordered the beheading of an opposition leader last year.

title:
TO TEST, OR NOT TO TEST: THAT IS THE NUCLEAR QUESTION;
To Halt the Arms Race
description: Earlier this month, my wife, three sons and I - and 144 other Americans - were arrested for trespassing at the nuclear weapons test site in Mercury, Nev. We had crossed a painted white line that marked the boundary of the site in order to protest the resumption of American testing. We couldn't understand why the United States is determined to test again despite the Soviet moratorium that began in August 1985. It seems plain enough that an end to testing would effectively stop the development of new warheads and significantly curb the arms race. The 149 people who crossed the white line - and the hundreds of others standing by in the 105 degree heat - were making a statement in the hope that they might help others find the courage to speak out. Our protest was different from many previous demonstrations, for it included many Americans who do not ordinarily participate in such actions. Among those arrested were physicians, professors, educators, lawyers, writers, celebrities and people from working class backgrounds who came to Nevada at considerable personal sacrifice.

title: Miss Durfee Wed To R. L. McLean
description: Linda K. Durfee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Durfee of Spokane, Wash., was married yesterday to Robert L. McLean of New York and Southampton, L.I., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. McLean of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Sony Earnings Decline
description: The Sony Corporation's second-quarter earnings fell 10.5 percent from a year earlier because the yen's sharp appreciation against the dollar has hurt sales and profit margins, the Japanese electronics giant reports. Sales fell 4.7 percent, to 325.83 billion yen, equal to $1.9 billion.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: EVERY time I see a film being shot, I get excited.''

title: SLAYER OF STORE MANAGER EXECUTED DESPITE PLEA BY FATHER OF VICTIM
description: A former marine who killed a convenience store manager in a robbery 12 years ago was put to death by the State of Texas early Thursday, despite pleas for mercy from the victim's father.

title: Hill & Knowlton Names Chairman
description: Richard E. Cheney, who found a rich public relations lode in the titanic merger battles of the last few decades, has been named chairman-elect of Hill & Knowlton Inc., the public relations company announced yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS (NYT BRIEFS)BRIEFS
description: * Dresser Industries, Dallas, said it would form a joint venture with Ingersoll-Rand Co., Woodcliff Lake, N.J., combining their reciprocating compressor and turbo-machinery businesses.

title: Election Laws on Trial in Queens
description: A gross injustice seems about to occur in the Sixth Congressional District in Queens, snatching a narrow victory at the polls from the Rev. Floyd Flake. Trouble is, this impermissible outcome is virtually guaranteed by the workings of New York and Federal laws. Only the judicial imagination may yet find a fair way out.

title: A Court Reflecting Its Country
description: How should we remember the Burger Court? Probably best as a study in contradictions. For 17 years Warren Burger tried to lead the Court away from its prior activism, and he succeeded often. Yet his Court handed down abortion decisions that made the Warren Court look strict-constructionist. Chief Justice Burger wanted to brake the civil rights revolution but he himself refused to abandon affirmative action and gave equal rights for women their first enforcement.

title: The Vital Role That the Garment Union Plays
description: To the Editor:

title: Macy's Buyout Backed by Vote
description: Stockholders of R. H. Macy & Company approved a $3.7 billion management buyout proposal yesterday by a vote of 40.4 million shares, or 78.3 percent of the shares outstanding, to 885,800 shares. Two-thirds of the shares outstanding were needed to approve the $68-a-share cash offer.

title: Bridge: Some Suits Are More Likely To Bring a Doubled Contract
description: Try a bridge conundrum. If you are playing a doubled contract, what particular suit is the most likely? Or would you expect no-trump?

title: BONDS FALL ON REPORTS ABOUT FED
description: Treasury bond prices tumbled and short-term interest rates rose yesterday as the erratic credit market mood turned negative once again on reports suggesting that the Federal Reserve Board was adopting a ''wait and see'' attitude toward cutting the discount rate.

title: Diner's Journal
description: AFTER a year of delays and false starts, the Casual Quilted Giraffe, a high-tech extravaganza offering an all-day menu of tidbits and full meals in the A.T.&T. Arcade (Madison Avenue and 55th Street), is set to open June 30. To characterize this new venture as a ''grazing'' restaurant is somewhat like describing the Juilliard Quartet's performances as ''jamming.''

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 359 money market mutual funds grew $229.3 million, to $225.3 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 85 institutional funds were down $377.5 million, to $60 billion, while the 188 general-purpose funds rose $225.7 million, to $62.7 billion, and the 86 broker-dealer funds rose $381.1 million, to $102.5 billion.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2 percent stock dividend paid in March.

title: Stride Rite Rejects Buyout Overture
description: The Stride Rite Corporation said that it had spurned the overtures of a company interested in acquiring the large shoe manufacturer. Stride Rite, which makes Keds children's shoes and Sperry Topsiders, refused to identify the company and said no formal offer had been made.

title: Polish Films of an American Shown as Evidence of Spying
description: The Polish television tonight showed film of an American diplomat talking with Polish dissidents, offering the segment as proof that the United States was sponsoring Solidarity's clandestine opposition for espionage purposes.

title: EARLY DETECTION IS KEY IN BREAST CANCER
description: Despite the attention being paid to new treatment options, a detection device, the mammogram, is considered the most potent weapon against breast cancer. If all women who are 50 years old or older and others in high-risk groups were to have annual X-rays of the breasts taken in conjunction with physical examinations, the number of deaths from breast cancer could be reduced by one-third, according to extensive studies reported or under way in this country, Sweden, the Netherlands and Canada. In the United States, that would amount to 13,000 lives this year alone.

title: LURE FOR HORSES, AND MAYBE BEARS
description: For Ed and Wanda Carr, one recent Monday morning was exciting enough. It was their first day as the new co-managers of a budget motel just north of here. But by midafternoon they could not believe their good fortune.

title: Halcyon Holds 8.7% of John Blair
description: A New York-based limited partnership, Halcyon Investments, said that it holds an 8.7 percent stake in John Blair & Company and 6.4 percent of the Fruehauf Corporation.

title: Everybody's Talking
description: Washington can buzz for days on a nuance - a minor staff change, a Presidential choice of words, an absence at a party. So an event of real significance almost overloads the synapses.

title: Soviet Agent Reported To Defect to U.S.
description: A Soviet diplomat who was working under cover as an intelligence agent in northern Africa has defected to the United States, intelligence sources said today.

title: MARY JANE BURROWS
description: Mary Jane Burrows, the former fashion director of the Tanners Council of America, died Wednesday at Sarasota (Fla.)

title: Charges of Nuclear Cover-Up and Collusion Have No Merit
description: To the Editor:

title: PANZANELLA, A SALAD PERFECT FOR SUMMER
description: Waverley Root speaks none too fondly of panzanella: ''a poor man's lunch,'' he calls it, ''salad dressing on bread, producing a sogginess which accounts for its name (little swamp).''

title: DR. HAROLD FELDMAN
description: Dr. Harold Feldman, former dean and vice president for financial affairs at Fairleigh Dickinson University, died of a heart attack Wednesday on his way home from a business appointment. He was 67 years old and lived in Mahwah, N.J.

title: U.S. UNVEILS RULES ON BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: The Reagan Administration today unveiled a complex and far-reaching program for overseeing genetic engineering research and the products of the nation's maturing biotechnology industry. The package of guidelines, rules and definitions, affecting four Federal regulatory agencies and two research agencies, is the first coordinated framework that any nation has produced for regulating the new industry.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for 10wks to May 24
description: b-Includes extraordinary utilization of loss carryforwards by foreign subsidiaries of $400,000 for the 10 weeks and the 25 weeks. c-Net income.

title: GETTING READY FOR THE 4th
description: It seems somehow fitting that one of America's greatest traditions should be used to help mark a milestone birthday of another.

title: Another Big Bluster
description: The plans for the Statue of Liberty business remind me of a song somebody ought to write. Its title would be ''America the Blowhard.'' Patting yourself on the back once in a blue moon is forgivable, but constantly thumping your chest about how wonderful you are soon makes you an embarrassment to friends and neighbors.

title: INFLATION NEWS BUOYS PRICES
description: Better-than-expected news about inflation helped revive spirits in the credit markets yesterday, raising prices by more than a point on some longer-term Treasury issues and shaving several hundredths of a percentage point off interest rates on six-month and one-year Treasury bills.

title: Local Costs Down 0.2%; Drops for Energy Cited
description: Lower costs for gasoline and electricity helped push consumer prices for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area down by two-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Kristi Rose and Band
description: The country singer Kristi Rose and her band, the Dying Breed, will perform tonight at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Double bills, with the blues band Marked Deck, begin at 9:30 P.M. and midnight; there is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title:
Patents;
Credit Card Telephone
description: A telephone pay station patented this week for the Reliance Electric Company of Cleveland ''reads'' the magnetic strip on the back of a credit card for payment on a call.

title: SOVIET DANCERS IN MISSISSIPPI CONTEST
description: For the first time since the International Ballet Competition came to Jackson in 1979, three Soviet dancers are among the 63 competitors from 26 countries vying for recognition in the contest, one of four leading worldwide ballet competitions. The others are held in Varna, Bulgaria, Helsinki, Finland, and Moscow.

title: ACCEPTING DIVORCE: THE IRISH FACE A DELICATE VOTE
description: With the campaign to introduce a civil right to divorce winding into its final stages, the Legion of Mary here in County Tipperary has called for a three-hour prayer vigil in the cathedral in order to preserve Ireland as the last European nation that is constitutionally committed to the Roman Catholic ideal of an indissoluble marriage bond.

title: BIBLICAL PASSAGE DECIPHERED
description: Biblical inscriptions on two pieces of silver rolled into cylinders like scrolls and apparently worn as amulets have been dated to the seventh century B.C., the Israeli Museum has announced.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. It is a computer model of the face of the Statue of Liberty. 2. The cultivation of opium. 3. No. 4. Yelena Bonner, the wife of the Soviet physicist Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov. The line refers to her decision to leave her family in the United States after her recent six-month visit and return to the Soviet Union. 5. Better. 6. The observation roof of the RCA Building. 7. The House approved and sent to the Senate sanctions against South Africa that President Reagan disapproves of and which he could decline to carry out if they were enacted into law. Sanctions against foreign governments are usually initiated by the President. 8. Washington, D.C. 9. Gimbels. Orbach's. 10. Floyd, who will be 44 years old in September, was the oldest golfer to win the event. 11. Was not. 12. Federal District Judge. Impeachment proceedings have begun in the House of Representatives. 13. A smaller, single-stick version of the Popsicle has been introduced, replacing the familiar twin-stick design that presumably allowed a single ''pop'' to be shared. 14. Environment, particularly noise. 15. At talks between President Johnson and the Soviet leader, Aleksei N. Kosygin, in Glassboro in 1967, the United States pressed for a curb on missile defense weapons, a move opposed by the Soviet Union. Now the United States favors developing such a defense system, and the Soviet Union opposes it. 16. The skeletons of two American Indians were discovered under the Great Hall on Ellis Island. 17.

title: HAVE TOYS, WILL TRAVEL: CHILDREN FLY ALONE
description: It is 10 o'clock on a Saturday morning and the parade of the children is beginning at Houston Intercontinental Airport.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Soviet Unit to Review Censored Films
description: The new head of the Soviet Film Makers' Union, elected last month in a purge of the union's old leadership, said today that the group had set up a commission to review censored films.

title:
Patents;
Cap for Pen or Pencil
description: Eugene L. Heyden of Spokane, Wash., has invented a retractable cap to protect the tip of a pen or pencil and prevent marking such things as shirt pockets. Patent No. 4,595,307, granted to him this week, says that the sheath folds upon itself and can be re-extended. The inventor says the device can also provide insulation for an electrical instrument.

title: PUSH IS ON TO FINISH JERSEY RESERVOIR
description: Deep in the hills of northern New Jersey, the metropolitan area's first new reservoir in nearly 20 years is rapidly taking shape.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $5,609,000 and a tax credit of $211,000. The share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 10 percent dividend paid in February 1986.

title: Winnipeg Picks Coach
description: Dan Maloney, who quit as coach of the Toronto Maple Leafs Wednesday after the owner, Harold Ballard, refused to give him a two-year contract, was hired as coach of the Winnipeg Jets yesterday and received a three-year contract. The hiring was announced by General Manager John Ferguson, who had filled in as Winnipeg coach after dismissing Barry Long on March 4.

title: LEWIS VICTORIOUS IN TWO EVENTS
description: Carl Lewis says you should take his word for it. No matter what happens here in the 111th annual United States outdoor track and field championships, now known as USA/Mobil, he insisted, he is as good as ever. Then he proved tonight he was.

title: DANCE: 'DEFILE,' A CHOREOGRAPHED FASHION EVENT
description: MTV could have done it better, but then MTV was not invented by the French and the peculiarly French dance event that took place at the Palladium Wednesday and Thursday nights had a certain Gallic charm.

title: Two People Rescued From Colorado Cave
description: Rescuers with drills today freed a teen-ager wedged in a narrow mine shaft overnight and a man who was seriously injured while trying to pull the youth to safety.

title: EX-OFFICERS ACCUSE CONTRA CHIEFS OF SIPHONING OFF U.S. AID MONEY
description: Several former officers of the Nicaraguan rebel forces assert that their top military leaders are siphoning off large amounts of money received from the United States, to enrich themselves at the expense of their troops.

title: Law on Tap Water Toughened
description: Federal legislation to step up efforts against the growing hazard of contaminated tap water has been signed by President Reagan, who expressed concern about some of the new law's enforcement provisions.

title: TRW Lawsuit
description: The military contractor TRW Inc., the subject of a $1.2 billion price-fixing lawsuit, improperly charged the Defense Department for work, routine company audits show. A company spokesman, Michael Johnson, said internal audits showed ''improper charging of costs'' but would not say if that meant overcharging in all cases. Preliminary results of an internal investigation at TRW Microwave Inc. in Sunnyvale, Calif., were given to Pentagon officials and a report was being prepared concerning accounting procedures at TRW's Military Electronics and Avionics division in San Diego, TRW said.

title: 'Mona Lisa' Is Find Paris Lonely
description: Mass hysteria certainly has its benefits. Like Paris sans tourists. Last year, Americans who wanted to see Monet's ''Water Lilies'' at the Musee de l'Orangerie were forced to endure crowds like those on a rush-hour Lexington Avenue subway train. But on a quiet Thursday afternoon in May there were a mere five of us in one of the rooms where the eight panels are displayed: myself, two British women and a French couple.

title: How Not to Win Friends
description: Jonathan S. Miller has a clear-eyed view of his job. ''I think I'm going to lose a lot of my buddies,'' said the new deputy assistant to the President for administration.

title: U.S. TOBACCO WINS SUIT OVER LIABILITY ON SNUFF
description: A Federal court jury ruled in favor of the U.S. Tobacco Company today in a liability suit brought by the mother of a teen-ager who developed oral cancer after dipping snuff for six years.

title: Cable Along Thruway Wins Approval of U.S.
description: The Federal Government has cleared the way for New York Telephone to install a fiber-optic cable along a six-mile stretch of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway between Albany and Schenectady. The cable will link centers of higher education and high-technology industry.

title: Forest Service Isn't Destroying Alaska's Tongass
description: To the Editor:

title: Anton Kuerti to Open Beethoven Matinees
description: A recital by the pianist Anton Kuerti will open the 11th season of matinees sponsored by the Beethoven Society on Oct. 18 at Alice Tully Hall. The program, called ''Beethoven in a Lighter Vein,'' features Fantasia (Op. 77); Six Bagatelles (Op. 126); Sonata in G (Op. 31, No.1); Andante Favori; Two Rondos (Op. 51), and Sonata in C minor (Op. 10, No.1).

title: Campaign Complaint
description: Robert Neall, the Republican contender for Maryland's Fourth District seat, has filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission against his chief Democratic opponent, Tom McMillen, accusing the former Washington Bullets star of misusing travel money from the basketball team to finance campaign trips. ''It is bad enough that McMillen thinks good dribbling qualifies him for the House of Representatives, but it's time for the F.E.C. to call a foul when a N.B.A. team that is a corporation subsidizes a candidate's travel and fund-raising,'' said Neall.

title: PAUL E. NASON
description: Paul E. (Jerry) Nason, who covered 50 Boston Marathons as a reporter and wrote the definitive history of the annual race, died Thursday of a heart attack. He was 77 years old. Mr. Nason worked for The Boston Globe from 1927 until 1974, the last 33 years as executive sports editor.

title: PERU REBEL FAILS IN ATTACK ON WORLD SOCIALIST MEETING
description: A guerrilla tried to fire a mortar shell at a building where the Socialist International began its annual meeting today but the weapon exploded and killed her, the police said.

title: EXCITEMENT MOUNTS FOR BRAZIL-FRANCE
description: The World Cup enters the quarterfinal stage this weekend and the fear of failure hangs over the eight teams the way the brown smog embraces this city.

title: A Hole in Albany's 'Balanced' Budget
description: New York State's budget for the current fiscal year appears balanced - but only because of Governor Cuomo's imprudent raid on the State Insurance Fund. Receipts equal outlays because the budget treats as current revenue a $325 million transfer of money from the fund. Yet the fund's 1985 report suggests the money is actually a loan - and a device that circumvents generally accepted accounting principles. It's a dubious maneuver for a Governor supposedly wedded to rigorous fiscal standards.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for 16wks to May 24
U.S. EXPELLING TOP SOVIET OFFICER CAUGHT WITH SECRET DOCUMENTS
description: The senior Soviet Air Force officer in the United States was ordered expelled from the country today after he was caught in what Federal agents described as an elaborate counter-espionage operation.

title: OTHER OUSTERS OF RUSSIANS
description: The move today to expel the Soviet air attache is but the latest incident in which Soviet Embassy employees have been detained and expelled for ''activities inconsistent with their diplomatic status.'' Other reported Soviet officials expelled for espionage were:

title: 2 More Bank Failures
