description: Two more United States banks have failed, making a total of 59 this year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced Thursday.

title: Soviet Body Presses Congress on Accords
description: The Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, issued an appeal to the United States Congress today to join in preventing the Reagan Administration from scrapping major arms-control agreements.

title: Beryl Elizabeth Brown Marries Scott H. King
description: Beryl Elizabeth Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Archibald Hoadley Brown of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, and Boston, was married yesterday to Scott Harris King, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore King of Morrill, Neb. Canon Thomas N. Nisbett performed the ceremony at the Old Devonshire Episcopal Church in Devonshire Parish, Bermuda.

title:
Patents;
A Method to Produce Sterile Fruit Flies
description: The Department of Agriculture patented this week a method and equipment to raise large numbers of certain fruit flies that are among the worst pests of citrus and deciduous fruits and vegetables. .

title: 5 Flee Alabama Prison; 3 Are Promptly Caught
description: Five convicts serving life sentences, including three murderers, fled Alabama's maximum security Holman Prison after setting fire to the power station and blacking out the entire prison, officials said today.

title: Laurie Lisle Wed To D. B. Meltzer
description: Laurie Lisle, an author, and Daniel B. Meltzer, a playwright and writer for CBS News, were married yesterday at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York by the Rev. Richard Leonard.

title: What an Insider Steals And From Whom
description: To the Editor:

title: I.M.F. Loan for Bolivia
description: The International Monetary Fund has approved a $58 million loan for Bolivia. In return, Bolivia has promised to continue to restrain prices, cut spending, promote market forces and reform the tax system.

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August 1985.

title: DRIVER EDUCATION EFFORT A PART OF AUDI RECALL
description: Volkswagen of America, which is recalling more than 100,000 Audi cars in response to incidents of sudden acceleration, plans a driver education effort, using audio and video cassettes, as part of a program that will include repositioning the brake and accelerator pedals.

title: THE FIREMAN'S MUSTACHE: BADGE OF THE BROTHERHOOD
description: It was an unusually slow day at the firehouse on Eighth Avenue and 48th Street, and the men put on a pot of coffee and got to talking about, of all things, mustaches.

title: Old School Tie
description: For those who count such things, Judge Scalia will be the 14th alumnus of Harvard Law School to serve on the Supreme Court. The Harvard Law School Alumni Center notes that the 14 included one Chief Justice, Melville Weston Fuller, who served from 1888 to 1910.

title: PAIN-FREE PACKING: SOME HINTS
description: THE best part of traveling is usually seeing new places or revisiting favorite spots. The worst part of traveling has got to be packing. Even the thought of filling an empty suitcase can keep some people from making an unnecessary trip. But with a bit of forethought and organization, packing can be a simple enough task. Ask anyone who travels a lot, whether on business or pleasure, and tidbits of advice will come pouring forth.

title: Private Insurers Match Wisconsin State Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL - CHICAGO (AL) - Dismissed Manager Tony LaRussa and Dave Duncan, pitching coach. Named Doug Rader interim manager and Dick Bosman interim pitching coach.

title: Cuomo Is Wrong On State Prisons
description: Governor Cuomo of New York recently made public a 146-page list of his administration's accomplishments. These include, he says, more funds for education, a housing program for New York City and 10,000 new spaces for the state's prison system. For the Governor's sake, we hope his claims about housing and education gains are solid, because his prison policies have failed by almost any reasonable standard.

title: U.S. SAYS MANY SEIZED ARE TOWNSHIP LEADERS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the single largest group of detainees in South Africa were local township leaders from citizen associations and youth groups.

title: KEAN LOVES NEW YORK IN SUMMER
description: Governor Kean, who is featured in a $3 million advertising campaign extolling the vacation attractions of New Jersey, still has a warm spot in his heart for New York.

title: Czech Actor Appears At Theater Festival
description: Bolek Polivka, a Czechoslovak actor and playwright, performed last night at an international theater festival in Baltimore. Earlier this week, he had received orders from Prague not to perform at the festival.

title: Karin Wittlinger Becomes a Bride
description: Karin L. Wittlinger and Bruce S. Butterfield were married yesterday at St. Matthew's Lutheran Church in White Plains by the Rev. Dr. Frederick J. Schumacher.

title: BRISTOL-MEYERS WILL END SALES OF NONPRESCRIPTION CAPSULES
description: With two deaths attributed to cyanide-laced Excedrin capsules, the Bristol-Myers Company said yesterday that it would end the sale of all its nonprescription drugs in capsule form.

title: Some Dissent Is Unpopular on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM 6 NEW BENEFACTORS, 425 COLLEGE DREAMS
description: ''I've got an offer I hope none of you can refuse,'' Paul Tudor Jones 2d told the 85 students sitting in front of him at graduation ceremonies at Public School 5 in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday. ''I'll pay your way through college.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and schedule in Weekend yesterday about the ''Canned Film Festival'' on Channel 9 listed an incorrect time. The program of films and comedy vignettes will start at 11:30 P.M. each Friday through Sept. 12, except for July 4, when the television program will begin at midnight.

title: New Auto License? Go This Way:
description: You need your New York State driver's license renewed? Yes. You know that renewal now requires a personal appearance for eye test and photographing? Yes. You know where to go for the process? No. Your notice as a Manhattan resident says, ''Call your Motor Vehicle Bureau Office.'' No mention of a telephone number. Look in your directory's blue pages. The number is 587-4620. Try it. Just try it, as my assistant and I did. Eighty times. Yes, 80 times, finding it always busy.

title: Refinancings And 'Points'
description: A RECENT announcement by the Internal Revenue Service concerning the deductibility of ''points'' paid for refinancing a mortgage is likely to have an adverse effect on about a half-million taxpayers who refinanced last year and more than a million others expected to do so this year.

title: Bridge; The Danes Are the Winners Of This Year's Europa Cup
description: One of the toughest events in the world, and one of the oldest, is the European Championship, initiated in 1932. For many years this was an annual event, but it is now played only in odd-numbered years to correspond with the Bermuda Bowl at world level.

title: Jets Waive Jackson
description: Bobby Jackson, plagued the last two seasons by hamstring injuries, was placed on recallable waivers yesterday by the Jets, who are attempting a trade for the veteran cornerback. Jackson, 29 years old, played in 12 games last year, starting 11, but was slowed by tendinitis in a hamstring.

title: No Beer in the Tank
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWYER SAYS TESTS ABSOLVE TRAINER
description: An attorney for Alain de Royer-Dupre, the French trainer whose New York license was revoked when one of his horses, Lashkari, tested positive for a powerful stimulant after a Breeders' Cup race last fall, said yesterday that tests at four other laboratories had disputed that finding.

title: Bo Jackson to Decide
description: Bo Jackson, who is coveted by the Kansas City Royals as an outfielder and by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers as a running back, will make one of those teams happy today. One of his attorneys said yesterday that Jackson will announce today which team he has decided to join.

title: General Mills
description: General Mills Inc. has no plans to spin off any of its businesses in the manner proposed by Dart & Kraft Inc., which said Thursday that it would split into two companies, a General Mills spokesman said.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: STAGE: 'ANIMAL FARM,' IN BALTIMORE
description: One of the explanations advanced for the banning of ''Animal Farm'' from the International Theater Festival now going on here was that the staging by Britain's National Theater was too explicitly anti-Soviet. The charge aroused skepticism. Had Sir Peter Hall, who adapted George Orwell's ''fairy story,'' really tampered with a message that was delivered with such glowing clarity in the original? A visit to the Morris A. Mechanic Theater, where ''Animal Farm'' is now completing a brief run outside the festival auspices, proves reassuring. The allegation is flapdoodle. This production of ''Animal Farm'' is true to the book - and it is the book's cold look at the Russian Revolution that rulers of the Soviet Union have always found offensive. If they didn't, the work would be a failure.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NL Industries Suit Names Two
description: NL Industries filed suit against Harold Simmons, the Dallas investor who earlier this week offered to acquire the company, and Coniston Partners, in a Mercer County, N.J., Superior Court.

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE PROPOSE INITIATIVES FOR ELECTION YEAR
description: House Democrats today released a program of proposed initiatives that emphasize the need to make the country more economically competitive.

title: DOCTORS REMOVE TWO SMALL POLYPS IN REAGAN'S COLON
description: Doctors today removed two small polyps from President Reagan's colon in a routine examination to see if cancer had reoccurred in his large intestine.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A picture on Jan. 29, published after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, showed the parents and sister of Christa McAuliffe, the teacher astronaut.

title: 'BEWITCHED' DOW SOARS 23.68
description: The ''triple witching hour,'' famous for its bizarre fluctuations in stock prices, lived up to its reputation yesterday, when blue-chip stock prices soared and trading volume skyrocketed as professionals and large institutions started buying stocks by the bucketful just minutes before Wall Street was to close for the weekend.

title: WORLD PRESSURE FOR PRETORIA SANCTIONS RISES
description: International and domestic pressure on the South African authorities to release those detained under the emergency decree increased yesterday, and South African opposition leaders warned of a possible new wave of arrests under security legislation that becomes law today.

title: BOOM TIMES FOR VENDORS OF STARS AND STRIPES
description: ''It's crazy, crazy,'' mumbled Mel Flamm, an American-flag salesman too busy this week to stop and talk much, hustling from one customer to the next in the showroom of AAA American Flag Company in the garment district.

title: Extra Racing Approved
description: A request by Yonkers Raceway to conduct eight racing programs a week, including two on Tuesdays, has been approved by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board, according to the board's chairman, Richard Corbisiero. The first doubleheader, with nine races starting at 1 P.M. and 11 races starting at 8 P.M., will be Tuesday. The track's Sunday program begins tomorrow at 8 P.M.

title: Bartholdi Alliance (Cont.)
description: Alongside the American flag, the French flag flew over the New York Public Library as 100 French and American guests arrived for a preview Thursday night of ''Liberty: The French-American Statue in Art and History.'' In speeches and in ambiance, the glittery evening was mostly about Franco-American friendship, as is the exhibition.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FOR HAWLEY, U.S. IS THE FUTURE
description: In Britain, cleaning and maintenance is only a billion-dollar business. But in the United States, the business amounts to some $17 billion a year.

title: Twilight Card at Belmont
description: The first of four experimental twilight racing cards at Belmont Park yesterday drew mixed reviews and mixed results.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 21, 1986
description: Companies

title: CORRECTION
description: A Los Angeles dispatch on Thursday, about the status of civil jury trials in Federal courts, misidentified a lawyer whose suit prevented the halting of such trials in southern California. He is Stephen Yagman.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JUNE 21, 1986
description: International

title: INVESTIGATION CONTINUES IN BIAS DEATH
description: Officials continued to gather facts today concerning the final hours of Len Bias's life while his friends and acquaintances continued to mourn him.

title: Reputed War Criminal Faces Loss of His U.S. Citizenship
description: A Lithuanian-born man accused of taking part in Nazi atrocities against Jews during World War II was ordered stripped of his United States citizenship by a Federal appeals court today.

title: JESSE JACKSON FAULTS CUOMO'S AID TO HOMELESS AND ROLE FOR LUNDINE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that Governor Cuomo was not doing enough to end homelessness and had ''made matters worse'' by choosing a running mate who voted for the Federal deficit-reduction law.

title:
Patents;
Machinery Disposes Of Nuclear Reactors
description: Machinery for dismantling and disposing of a nuclear reactor at the end of its planned operation was patented this week for the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority in London.

title: LABEL ON 3 FILMS BACKED BY COURT
description: A Federal appeals court panel has ruled that the Justice Department may label as ''political propaganda'' three Canadian films dealing with the subjects of nuclear war and acid rain.

title: Irish Concern Buys 81 Jets From Boeing
description: The Boeing Commerical Airplane Company, a division of the Boeing Company, said today that it had received an order for 81 Boeing 737 jets, worth about $2.3 billion, from GPA Group Ltd., a major international aircraft leasing concern based in Shannon, Ireland. The company said it was the fourth-largest Boeing jet aircraft order in history, by dollar amount.

title: Legionnaire's Disease Is Cited in Deaths of 3
description: Three patients at the Hospital of St. Raphael have died after contracting Legionnaires' disease, health authorities said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Kate Smith on Wednesday incorrectly described the origin of the song ''God Bless America.''

title: TV: 'SEEING THINGS,' A COMEDY
description: Louie Ciccone, the Toronto-based reporter-detective who is the protagonist of the mystery-comedy series ''Seeing Things,'' could be journalism's answer to Peter Sellers's bumbling Inspector Clouseau. When asked for tips by a cub reporter covering the opening of a local Egyptology exhibition, he natters on about ''the five W's,'' but can only remember four - ''who, what, when and where,'' and ends up borrowing the young man's pen and notebook. His one saving grace as an investigator is a gift for clairvoyance that strikes at the oddest moments.

title: 29 Hurt in Tour Bus Crash
description: Twenty-nine people were injured Thursday when a tour bus carrying mostly elderly people stalled on I-95 on the Delaware Memorial Bridge and was struck from behind by a truck that was in turn struck by another truck, the police said today.

title: Baby May Face New Surgery
description: A 3-year-old child recovering from his second heart transplant in a week may need surgery to ease constriction in a major blood vessel that contributed to the failure of the first transplant, a hospital official said today. The child, Nicky Carrizales of San Antonio, Tex., remained in critical at Loma Linda University Medical Center, where doctors implanted the second heart Thursday, a spokesman said.

title: LaRussa Is Dismissed
description: The Chicago White Sox have dismissed Manager Tony LaRussa, the team vice president, Ken Harrelson, said today. The dismissal came six weeks after management grudgingly gave LaRussa a vote of confidence and one week after LaRussa's counterpart in Chicago, Jim Frey, was let go as manager of the Cubs.

title: PEOPLE CUTS AIR FARES ABOUT 30%
description: In an unusual move that is indicative of its problems, People Express cut its fares by about 30 percent yesterday in most of its markets.

title: Tosco Holds Talks On Possible Sale
description: The Tosco Corporation, an independent refiner, said today that it was in preliminary discussions that could lead to its sale to one of several potential buyers, including major oil companies and foreign countries that export oil. The company also announced that its president and chief executive, Matthew J. Talbot, would step down on Aug. 15.

title: Tax Amnesty Cut From Senate's Bill
description: The Senate today eliminated a provision in its tax-revision bill that would have allowed a limited amnesty for taxpayers who voluntarily confessed their cheating to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: SECRET SHUTTLE MISSION MAY BE SHIFTED TO FLORIDA
description: A secret space shuttle mission for the Defense Department may be switched from a facility being built at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California to the Kennedy Space Center in Florida because of the aerospace crisis, an official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title:
Patents;
Computer Is Operated By a Gaze
description: A COMPUTER that can be operated by gazing at a portion of the screen was patented this week by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about American companies that operate in South Africa listed one erroneously. American Express withdrew its employees last November, although it does have a franchise arrangement with a South African bank, Nedbank.

title: Oberlin Update
description: To the Editor:

title: ACHILLE LAURO HIJACKER TESTIFIES AGAINST COMRADES
description: One of the hijackers of the cruise ship Achille Lauro told an Italian court here today that a fellow hijacker had admitted killing a handicapped New York man aboard the ship. He also testified that the operation had been directed by Mohammed Abbas, leader of a Palestinian guerrilla faction.

title: METS OVERWHELM CUBS
description: Before their millionth Shea Stadium customer of this sparkling season, the Mets prevented the nearly unthinkable last night - a three-game losing streak - and wore down the Cubs, 10-3.

title: C3 INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pork Bellies Gain Again; Coffee and Wheat Drop
description: Futures prices of hogs and pork bellies posted sharp gains again today as the market prepared for an Agriculture Department report expected to show a broad decline in the number of hogs on farms.

title: LUSKIN'S INC reports earnings for 13wks to May 3
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end from Dec. 31, to Jan. 31, effective for fiscal year Jan. 31, 1987. As a result, the latest first quarter ended May 3, 1986 is being compared to the 13-week first quarter ended March 30, 1986.

title: Consumer Prices Up by 0.2% in May
description: After three months of decline, consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in May, signaling a return of modest inflation, the Labor Department said today.

title: Romantic Remembered
description: Beginning Sunday, much of the music wafting through Washington is likely to be that of Franz Liszt, as the capital is the scene of a weeklong series of events to honor the centennial of his death.

title: PANEL IN SENATE CUTS FUNDS FROM MISSILE DEFENSE PLAN
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved a military budget for 1987 that cuts $1.4 billion from the Reagan Administration's program to develop advanced defenses against nuclear missiles.

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
TEWELL LEADS AT ATLANTA
description: Doug Tewell, compiling the best season of his 12-year career after considering ''semiretirement,'' posted an eight-under-par 64 today to take the second-round lead in the Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: Burroughs, Sperry
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it would take 53.4 percent of the more than 58 million shares of the Sperry Corporation common stock that was offered in its successful bid to buy the rival computer maker for $4.78 billion.

title: Hire the Whole Family
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, the Republican Presidential aspirant from upstate New York, has mentioned on occasion that Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, would make an excellent Secretary of State.

title: Bearish Bent Seen in Buying Frenzy
description: The frenzy of buying near the end of yesterday's ''triple witching hour'' on Wall Street does not mean the big institutional traders are feeling good about the market.

title: KOCH ISSUES ORDER TO HELP ENFORCE NEW LAW ON HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS
description: Mayor Koch issued an executive order yesterday to carry out provisions of the city's new homosexual-rights law and related human-rights legislation.

title: Ex-Lawmaker Begins Federal Prison Term
description: Former Representative George Hansen of Idaho surrendered today at a minimum-security prison camp to begin serving a 5- to 15-month sentence for falsifying financial disclosure statements.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL - METS VS. CHICAGO CUBS, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M., live, and 7;30 P.M., taped. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) YANKEES VS. BLUE JAYS, at Toronto, 1:15 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 1:15P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 1:15 P.M.) ATLANTA BRAVES VS. REDS, at Cincinnati, 7:05 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 7 P.M.) LOS ANGELES DODGERS VS. PADRES, at San Diego, 10:05 P.M.(Radio - WCBS 880, 10:05).

title: PRETORIA LEADERS PASS 2 NEW LAWS TO CRUSH UNREST
description: Overriding the opposition of the country's two nonwhite chambers of Parliament, South Africa's white leaders tonight forced into law two security measures that give the authorities sweeping powers to deal with unrest.

title: The Police: Still Thinking Triage
description: During the fiscal crisis of a decade ago, New York City's badly depleted Police Department resorted to triage: scarce resources were focused on big crimes like robbery and rape. Lesser offenses like graffiti writing and marijuana smoking were virtually decriminalized.

title: Red Cross Lines Open To Tall Ships' Sailors
description: Officers and cadets of the tall ships participating in Operation Sail will be allowed to make free three-minute telephone calls to relatives and friends overseas, the American Red Cross said yesterday.

title: Withhold Aid To Liberia
description: Dramatic changes in governments, other than through elections, are often foreshadowed by the courage of ordinary citizens who challenge the actions of repressive leaders. Recent events in Liberia, a small country in West Africa with close historical links to the United States, indicate that country may be on the brink of such a change.

title: DEATH OF A YOUNG STAR
description: Len Bias was born Nov. 18, 1963, four days before John Fitzgerald Kennedy was shot to death at age 46. On Thursday morning, Bias died suddenly at age 22, with no clues or alarms or history of any physical problems.

title: F.T.C. ACTS TO BLOCK SODA DEALS
description: The Government said today that it would act to stop the Coca-Cola Company and Pepsico Inc. from buying two smaller soft-drink companies because the mergers could substantially reduce competition.

title: 443-60-3761 Is Pleased to . . .
description: It is a question for the etiquette books, how best to juggle the demands of security with the imperatives of manners. Witness a very correct invitation to a reception at the Old Executive Office Building, sent by Robert H. Tuttle, a deputy assistant to the President, and Donna C. Tuttle, an Under Secretary of Commerce.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LIBERTY - Perhaps the most extraordinary exhibition about the Statue of Liberty, apart from the spectacle of the lady herself in the harbor, opens today in midtown Manhattan, in the palatial rooms and corridors of the New York Public Library, 42d Street and Fifth Avenue. Although the city will be awash all summer with Libertyana, a visit here should slake almost all thirst for the subject.

title: Ontario Bans Breaches Of Doctors' Fee Limits
description: A bitter dispute between the Ontario government and the province's doctors appeared to deepen today, as the provincial legislature voted to prohibit physicians from charging higher fees than those set by the government.

title: Community Council Awards
description: New Yorkers do care, according to the Community Council of Greater New York, an umbrella organization of 185 social service agencies. And to prove it, the council honors certain New Yorkers who have done something about their concerns.

title: Democracy's Twisted Path in Peru
description: President Alan Garcia of Peru has gained an international reputation as an idealist, and friends of freedom have been pleased to place his country on the list of newly emerged democracies. But now both distinctions are challenged by his Government's apparent massacre of hundreds of guerrilla captives.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny and Western Energy Corp. said it had been approached by another company, whose identity was not disclosed, about a possible merger or other combination.

title: CUOMO OPPOSED TO MERGING CITY AND TRANSIT POLICE FORCES
description: Governor Cuomo came out yesterday against the proposed merger of the transit police with the city's Police Department, a move long sought by Mayor Koch.

title: Briggs & Stratton In China Venture
description: The Briggs & Stratton Corporation has announced a joint venture to build small engines in China with a privately owned Chinese company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've got an offer I hope none of you can refuse.

title: CABARET: STEVE EARLE AND NICOLETTE LARSON
description: The young Nashville-based singer and songwriter Steve Earle has stirred an unusual amount of critical attention with his debut album, ''Guitar Town,'' a collection of spare country-rock tunes whose austerity and directness go against the current trend toward opulence in country music.

title: CITY TRACES ORIGINS OF HOMELESSNESS
description: The gentrification of neighborhoods is not the primary cause of homelessness, the city's Human Resources Commissioner, George Gross, asserted yesterday after releasing three studies profiling the city's homeless population.

title: Model Gets 14 Years For a Slaying in Italy
description: An American model was convicted and sentenced to 14 years in prison today for voluntary homicide in the shooting of an Italian playboy.

title: A Possible Outlay By Chrysler Seen
description: The Chrysler Corporation is prepared to invest about $1.2 billion over several years to renovate its aging Jefferson Avenue car plant in Detroit and build a new assembly plant on an adjacent site, a top United Automobile Workers union official said. A U.A.W. vice president, Marc Stepp, said in an interview that the investment depended on the outcome of talks over a new local operating agreement between Chrysler and the U.A.W. local that represents the plant's 4,800 hourly workers.

title: Soto on Injured List
description: For the second time this season, Mario Soto, once considered the anchor of the Cincinnati Reds' starting rotation, has been put on the 15-day disabled list to give his ailing right shoulder a rest. Soto, 29 years old, started the ga'e Thursday night against the Houston Astros but had to leave after giving up three runs in the first inning of what turned out to be a 6-2 defeat.

title: Delayed Opening of Beach
description: To commemorate the delayed official opening of the beachfront in Coney Island and Brighton Beach yesterday, Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden took off his black suit jacket. He patrolled the Boardwalk as if he were a drill sergeant conducting inspection.

title: EX-HOSPITALS AIDE ASKS DISMISSAL OF INDICTMENT
description: The state bribery trial of John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, began yesterday with a secret hearing on a defense motion to dismiss the indictment on the grounds of prosecutorial misconduct.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $124,000 for the quarter and 9 months and includes a writedown of certain assets of $6.8 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $3,827,000 for the quarter and $5,402,000 for the 9 months and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $3,969,000 for both periods.

title: Capital Outlay By May Stores
description: The May Department Stores Company, one of the nation's largest retailers, will spend $2 billion between 1986 and 1990, the largest capital spending program in the company's history, shareholders were told yesterday at the company's annual meeting in St. Louis.

title: Coming to Terms
description: HALF THE WAY HOME. A Memoir of Father and Son. By Adam Hochschild. 198 pages. Viking. $15.95. To the world, Harold Hochschild was not only an enormously successful businessman (the head of Amax Inc., one of the largest mining concerns in the world) but also the consummate gentleman - charming, generous and fluent in the worlds of business, politics and the arts.

title: Why Was Mary Ventura Released?
description: Mary Ventura, a young New York woman with a history of psychiatric trouble, pleaded guilty this week to attempted murder. Last Oct. 22 she pushed Catherine Costello, a young accountant, into the path of a subway train. The plea answers the question of Miss Ventura's guilt but leaves open a larger one about the responsibility of city mental health officials. She committed her crime only three weeks after being released from Kings County Hospital. Why was she released? Shortly after the incident, a Health and Hospitals official tried to blame patients' rights lawyers and the courts. ''The lawyers' group goes to court and pleads with the judge to have the person released,'' he said. ''Our doctors go to court and explain why this person should not be released, and it is up to the judge.'' The judge, Acting Supreme Court Justice Louis Douglass, protested that in ordering Miss Ventura's release he took the recommendation of the city's doctor.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $2.3 million, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $5.6 million, or 6 cents a share, for the year. c-Net income. d-Includes extraordinary credits of $3.8 million, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $8.8 million, or 10 cents a share, for the year. The company changed its method of recognizing revenue on sales to distributors during the latest quarter.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. A life-size reproduction of a famous face that will soon go on display would not have been possible without this. What is it and what face is it? 2. ''Everyone is taking it up,'' said a rebel commander in Afghanistan about an activity that is increasingly financing the guerrilla war against troops of the Soviet and Afghan armies. What activity is it? 3. The Supreme Court over which Warren E. Burger has presided for 17 years as Chief Justice has overruled (two/three/no) major doctrines of the Earl Warren court. 4. ''It takes incredible will power to force yourself to learn once again how to breathe without air, swim without water, walk without ground,'' is a line from a memoir to be published this fall. Whose memoir is it and to what does the line refer? 5. Patients who have Kaposi's sarcoma, the cancer that was one of the original clues to the existence of AIDS and is now mysteriously declining, seem to fare (better/worse) than patients who do not have it. 6. After 53 years as a kind of front porch 850 feet in the air, an unusually tranquil skyscraping vantage in Manhattan has been closed. What is it? 7. A White House confrontation with Congress may result from an initiative by the House of Representatives that is usually the President's prerogative.

title: GRAND CANYON PLANE CRASH SPURS CALL FOR FLIGHT RULES
description: The midair collision in the Grand Canyon on Wednesday has reinforced demands that binding rules replace the voluntary procedures established for flights there.

title: COURT AIDE AND 15 OTHERS INDICTED IN MOVE AGAINST GAMBINO GROUP
description: For eight years, a clerk in the Federal Courthouse in Manhattan passed confidential information about organized-crime cases to members of the Gambino crime family, Federal prosecutors charged yesterday.

title: BROOKS SHARP AS EXPOS TOP PIRATES, 7-2
description: Hubie Brooks went 4 for 4 with two runs batted in and Tim Raines also drove home two runs tonight to lead the Montreal Expos to a 7-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Pope Calls for Accords On Peaceful Space Use
description: Pope John Paul II today urged ''joint agreements and commitments'' among governments to insure ''the peaceful use of space resources.''

title: President Quits At Varian
description: Varian Associates Inc. has announced the resignation of Jerome J. Meyer, its president and chief operating officer. Mr. Meyer, who is 48 years old, joined Varian in the newly created post in November 1984.

title: PROPOSED LEASE POSES DILEMMA FOR CITY BOARD
description: It was one item out of 640 in the two-inch-thick calendar of the Board of Estimate. In 11 paragraphs of arcane legal language, it suggested the kind of dilemma, both practical and ethical, that can bedevil a municipal government, particularly one buffeted by a corruption scandal.

title: FATAL RADIATION DOSE IN THERAPY ATTRIBUTED TO COMPUTER MISTAKE
description: A computer malfunction apparently caused excessive radiation doses for two cancer patients at a treatment center, causing the death of one man, a Texas official said today.

title: YANKEES RECOVER, WIN IN 10
description: The ninth inning seemed to drift away, as if some higher element had decided to deny the Yankees for one more night. When George Bell delivered the grand slam that tied the game, Dave Righetti dropped to his knees on the pitcher's mound. When the umpire threw out a new ball, the pitcher heaved it angrily over the fence in right field.

title: Jury Gets Case of Lawyer Accused in '71 Uprising
description: A jury began deliberations today in the murder and conspiracy trial of Stephen Bingham, 15 years after the Government charged he played a major role in San Quentin prison's bloodiest day.

title: A FORMER PREMIER IS SEEKING A COMEBACK IN SPANISH VOTE
description: The former Prime Minister, Adolfo Suarez, rose before a cheering crowd crammed into a small theater here.

title: Just In, Postal Chief's on Way Out
description: Barely six months into his term as Postmaster General, Albert V. Casey is already preparing to leave. In September, he will begin a professorship at Southern Methodist University's business school.

title: U.S. SHIFTS A BIT IN PRETORIA STAND
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Reagan Administration favored a careful use of tangible forms of pressure, in addition to political persuasion, to end apartheid in South Africa.

title: A TRIATHLON STAR BACK FROM BRINK
description: Competing in a triathlon means pushing yourself to the brink.

title: SOUTH AFRICA IMPOSED NEW CURBS ON 119 GROUPS
description: The South African police, invoking the nation's emergency decree, announced new prohibitions today affecting 119 political and church groups around Cape Town.

title: STOCKMAN'S MEMOIRS: A POSTSCRIPT
description: The following letters from Robert D. Novak, the columnist, and Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Defense, were received in connection with a review by Michael Kinsley of David A. Stockman's book, ''The Triumph of Politics,'' in the May 11 Book Review. Both letters were forwarded to Mr. Kinsley for comment. NOVAK'S LETTER

title: WEBER'S MUSIC IS FULL OF SURPRISES
description: My love for the music of Carl Maria von Weber goes back to when I was still a teen-ager. In the summer of 1953, I attended the Vienna Academy of Music courses in Gmunden, Austria, and on my way home to enroll as a freshman at Columbia College, stopped off in Hamburg. It was Sept. 1, 1953, and that evening the opera season was opening with Weber's best-known opera, ''Der Freischutz.''

title: HOUSTON MAYOR FACES TOUGH CHOICES ON PERSONNEL
description: A proposal for an across-the-board salary cut instead of layoffs for 770 city employees is highlighting both the human and political uncertainties brought on by this city's continuing economic slump.

title: IRONY TINGES HURDLE'S SHIFTING FORTUNR
description: CLINT HURDLE refuses to dwell on it. ''You think about it, but it doesn't do any good,'' he said. ''All it'll do is give you a brain cramp.''

title: Kary Mertz to Marry Brian Joseph Clancy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar T. Mertz of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kary Elizabeth Mertz, to Brian Joseph Clancy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cummin Clancy of Garden City, L.I., and Windham, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: CRIME
description: Dortmunder is back - hurray! - in GOOD BEHAVIOR by Donald E. Westlake (Mysterious Press, $15.95). John Dortmunder, a veteran thief, is a combination of Napoleon and the Sad Sack. If only fortune would smile on him! He is a brilliant strategist. He plans everything painstakingly. He tries to take all contingencies into account. But something unforeseen always happens, and Dortmunder flaps around and gasps like a beached flounder.

title: SPAIN'S NEW FACE
description: ASALSA BAND LED by two bare-bellied young women and a balding singer wearing a bow tie had been working up the crowd.

title: BORDER ON NORTH INVISIBLE, INTEGRAL
description: THOSE of us who live along Peach Lake and sail, row and water ski across the invisible Westchester-Putnam line in summer or skate across it in winter care about the future of both counties. Whether there will be a pooper-scooper law for North Salem's magnificent horse population is as close-to-home a debate as where Putnam will incinerate its garbage. In such places as Peach Lake, vulnerable water plays on the sensibilities from sunrise to sunset. One cannot forget the highest allegiance begs to be the environment.

title: Paraguay for the Paraguayans
description: I have been living in exile from my native Paraguay since 1982. This week, I am going back - much as Benigno S. Aquino Jr. tried to go back to the Philippines and Kim Dae Jung went back to South Korea - to challenge Gen. Alfredo Stroessner and assert my right to my homeland.

title: STALKING CITY BYWAYS
description: HOW it started, no one is quite sure. But certainly the romantic figure cut by Meryl Streep as Karen Blixen in the film ''Out of Africa'' didn't hurt.

title: Braving the Rain for Tuckahoe Condos
description: Nortuck Venture Corporation, the developers of the Tower Club at Westchester, clearly thought an elaborate marketing effort would be necessary to sell its 200-unit condominium project in Tuckahoe. The company built a temporary sales office with a fully landscaped, 25-foot-high atrium and it completely furnished four model apartments.

title: DANCE: CLARK CENTER BILL
description: CLARK CENTER opened its ambitious ''Summer Dance '86'' festival Thursday with a program that symbolized the variety of the dance to come in the eight-week series at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater on Theater Row. In a selection of eight pieces presented by three strong solo performers, there was the wild theatricality of Bertram Ross, the poetry of Chiang Ching and the antic grace of Margaret Beals.

title: BOHLANDER LEAVING PUBLIC WORKS POST AFTER 18 YEARS
description: IN his 18 years as a Westchester County government employee, Frank C. Bohlander, the Public Works Commissioner, has seen countless projects scuttled by political factions and was even hospitalized once with stress-related chest pains.

title: SUTTON LEADS BY 2 AFTER A 67
description: Hal Sutton shot a five-under-par 67 despite three bogeys and took a two-shot lead after three rounds of the $500,000 Georgia-Pacific Atlanta Golf Classic today.

title: MUSEUM RECALLS ERA OF THE CARRIAGE
description: THE joys of riding in a horse-drawn carriage, specifically one with the fringe on top, were described in a song by Rodgers and Hammerstein in the musical ''Oklahoma!'' Though these pleasures are lost to the modern world, a new museum in Lebanon has set out to recapture some of the atmosphere of that more leisurely era.

title: BOY GETS GIRL, CHANGES WORLD HISTORY
description: THE CHINA CARD By John Ehrlichman. 523 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95. IN reading John Ehrlichman's new espionage novel, ''The China Card,'' one is reminded of how out-of-date the updated maxim ''Politics is the last refuge of a scoundrel'' has become. Many in the White House class that graduated into political oblivion after Watergate along with their President, Richard Nixon, lost little time in recycling themselves directly into the writing profession. In the years since, they have produced a blizzard of books capitalizing on both their experiences in office and their well-known, albeit variously besmirched, names. And now, like an unexploded mine from this period, one of the most prolific, Mr. Nixon's former adviser on domestic affairs, John Ehrlichman, has produced yet another offering, this time a thriller about the opening of diplomatic relations with China, a central event of the Nixon Administration.

title: MORRIS COUNTY SEEKS TO REGULATE GROWTH
description: WHEN Morris 2000 - a term used to denote both a volunteer study group and a process - pondered a report last November urging a stronger planning role for Morris County government in managing the county's phenomenal business growth, municipalities positioned themselves for a fight over home rule.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN TO HARVEST THE FRUIT OF THE GARDEN
description: WITH the arrival of summer, sitting in the shade with a cool drink tends to assume top priority in the garden. While it's nice to be able to sit back and enjoy the fruits of one's labors, the fact remains that there are tasks to be performed. Weeds continue to grow; water must be applied; deadheading will pay dividends in continued flowering, and harvesting is a must if fruits and vegetables are to be of any use.

title: DANCE: DONALD BYRD
description: LAST year Donald Byrd and his company performed a dance called '' . . Concerning Vices, Circumstances and Situations.'' On Friday, Mr. Byrd addressed the largely negative reaction to that event in ''Formal Response,'' a new, evening-long piece performed at the La Mama Annex, 74A East Fourth Street.

title: 2 CYPRIOTS FREED BY BEIRUT CAPTORS
description: Twenty-four hours after two French hostages were set free, kidnappers in Moslem West Beirut today released two Cypriot students who had been missing since April 28.

title: GRASS ON THE BATTLEFIELD
description: BROTHERS IN ARMS A Journey From War to Peace. By William Broyles Jr. 284 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: FOR ETHIOPIA, NEW VILLAGES, NEW CONCERNS
description: The huts, once scattered higgledy-piggledy across the rolling highland hills, are now grouped in rigidly straight rows like so many regimented soldiers. Their owners dismantled the houses at their previous locations and, traveling on foot, brought them piece by piece to a swath of land outside this city in the Harar Province in eastern Ethiopia.

title: A VITAL ALTERNATIVE FOR FAILING BANKS
description: THIS week, the House Banking Committee will begin considering a bill that would permit emergency acquisitions of failing banks by out-of-state financial institutions. In view of the current economic distress in the farm belt and energy-producing states, as well as the pressures on the Government's deposit insurance funds, speedy passage of the legislation is essential.

title: JAZZ: DIZZY GILLESPIE QUINTET
description: Dizzy Gillespie has always had a penchant for mixing a modest bit of comedy with his virtuoso trumpeting. But his current quintet, which will be at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue at 17th Street through June 29, offers him opportunity to increase his sight and sound gags and even to expand his old routine about introducing his musicians - to each other.

title: 'Roommate' Law
description: To the Editor Your statement that ''New York State's new 'roommate' law (Real Estate Property Law section 235-f) does not aply to co-op buildings'' (''Curbing a Co-op's 'Guests,'' June 8) may mislead co-op board members and their tenant-stockholders.

title: DISCOVERING THE RIGHT NICHE IN THE GARMENT BUSINESS
description: ,uf9405>EVEN then they knew: In Bernard Holtzman's high school yearbook the prediction was made that his future would be in the textile industry.

title: U.S. Coach Named
description: Dave Peterson, the 55-year-old head coach at Southwest High School in Minneapolis for the last 27 years, has been named the United States Olympic hockey team coach by the United States Amateur Hockey Association.

title: ONE EVENT, 70,000 PLAYERS
description: The past year has been marked by a variety of mass participation events, culminating last month with the ''Hands Across America'' effort. Eight days ago, on June 14, bridge seems to have set a world record for participation in a competitive activity with what might well be termed ''Hands Across the World.''

title: Storms Upset Race Across the Atlantic
description: A series of ocean gales has battered a fleet of sailboats that left Plymouth, England June 8 for a race to Newport, R.I. Although no injuries have been reported, 10 of the 49 yachts that started the Carlsberg Trans-Atlantic Race were damaged and have headed back to shore.

title: FRIENDS OF BIAS ARE BAFFLED
description: The first impulse is to ask why. But that may be too simple a reaction to a tragedy that may have been the result of a young athlete's struggle to cope with his rising fame.

title: PANAMA GENERAL SAID TO HAVE TOLD ARMY TO RIG VOTE
description: The United States has assembled conclusive evidence showing that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military strongman of Panama, ordered the Panama Defense Force to intervene and overturn the results during the 1984 Presidential elections in Panama, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: CLASSICAL STUDIES CHALLENGE PUPILS
description: WILDA RODRIGUEZ, a 10th-grade student at Hartford Public High School, acknowledged that she was upset four years ago when her mother enrolled her in the city school system's Classical Magnet School Program.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CAMPING
description: JUST about everyone remotely involved with the camping business is looking forward to a busy summer. The expected scenario: Lower interest rates and gasoline prices will increase sales of motor homes; a weak dollar and fears about terrorism overseas will keep thousands of vacationers at home, and direct marketing campaigns will lure them to campgrounds.

title: Bookshelf
description: SOCRATES AND THE THREE LITTLE PIGS By Tuyosi Mori. Illustrated by Mitsumasa Anno. Philomel. $12.95. (Ages 7 and up) Another in the developing series of books on mathematics and logic by the Japanese illustrator and winner of the Hans Christian Andersen Prize.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: GROWING THE CLEAN GREEN - IT'S not a large farm, only 3.7 acres; but the land use is ''very diverse,'' according to Crow Miller, the chief farmer, instructor and caretaker of the Spring Meadow School of Organic Farming and Gardening in Head of the Harbor.

title: ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CAN BE A CONTACT SPORT
description: WHEN Middle Western governors met here last week, cooperation was much on their minds. To help farmers whose greatest fear is foreclosure, they promised to prepare a regional agriculture strategy. To help blue collar workers worried about the continuing erosion of industrial strength, they pledged in various conversations they would stick to an informal agreement not to steal factories and jobs from one another.

title: 50 SUPERIOR ART WORKS LENT FOR BOSTON SHOW
description: ''AN unerring sense of quality.''

title: SUPPLY OF MAYORS TO PERFORM WEDDINGS FALLS SHORT
description: ON A recent Saturday, Mayor Marshall Boggio of Point Pleasant Borough officiated at five weddings. That was a record for Mayor Boggio, an engineer by profession, who estimates he marries about 100 couples a year.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: BALTIMORE ZOO PARTY - Sixty Baltimore restaurants will be represented Friday night at the third annual fund-raising effort for the Baltimore Zoo. This year's entrants include the Cafe des Artistes, The Brass Elephant, Jean Claude's Cafe, and Haussner's. From booths set up in the zoo's mansion house, they will offer the house specialty, enabling guests (black tie, please) to roam and sample.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: AUTO RACING DETROIT GRAND PRIX FORMULA ONE RACE, at Detroit (Television -Channel 2, 1:30 P.M.) IMSA CAMEL GRAND PRIX, at West Palm Beach, Fla. (Television - ESPN, 3:30 P.M.).

title: Navratilova Takes Title At Eastbourne Again
description: Martina Navratilova captured her fifth consecutive Pilkington Glass Ladies Tennis Championships singles title today, overcoming Czechoslovakia's Helena Sukova, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4.

title: BLUE-COLLAR ENIGMAS
description: SUCCESS STORIES By Russell Banks. 183 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: The Confusion Plot
description: President Reagan now describes the recent Soviet arms control proposals as a ''serious effort'' and calls for the U.S. and Soviet Union to ''leave behind suspicion between our peoples and replace it with understanding.''

title: IS IT A MYSTERY OR A SATIRE?
description: PLAYS do not spring to the stage as Pulitzer Prize-winning masterpieces. Between the quill pen, typewriter or word processor and the theater is a lengthy process that involves experimentation and rewriting and the all-important audience response.

title: EAST END MOOD MIXED AFTER U.S. OPEN
description: THE golfers are gone, the crowds have disappeared and the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club is quiet again. But the United States Open has left a mixed reaction in its wake in Southampton.

title: The Iowa Writers' Workshop
description: I attended the Iowa Writers' Workshop in the fall of 1979, immmediately after finishing my bachelor's degree. Many good things happened to me there.

title: Peruvian Troops Kill Hundreds In Rebel Uprisings
description: Revolutionaries suffered a devastating defeat in Peru last week when Government troops killed 250 rebels in uprisings at three prisons. The next day, a guerrilla plot to blow up a meeting of the Socialist International backfired.

title: PROTESTS AT ISLIP MARINA
description: ISLIP residents are protesting what they say is the commercialization of the Bay Shore Marina, Islip Town's largest marina.

title: SCHOOL IN PRINCETON MINES THE POTENTIAL OF DYSLEXIC CHIDLREN
description: STUDENTS at the Lewis School here listened intently to their teacher, watching her every move. Although they have to work harder than other students, almost every one is a success story.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Metaphor in Midocean - In ''The Traveling Woman'' (Vehicle Editions/ Talman), Roberta Allen describes a disappointed woman on the deck of a trans-Atlantic ship, searching the horizon for a sign or symbol with which she can console herself.

title: NETWORKING OVER THE TELEPHONE
description: NETWORKING, the linking of a number of computers in order to permit an exchange of data and programs or the sharing of expensive but often underutilized peripherals, has been a coming thing for several years now. On the whole, however, the concept still has a long way to go.

title: FRESH AIR FUND CAMPS: SITES OF SUMMER FUN
description: Ivonne Mosquera does not like boating. Her small, freckled face crinkles when she thinks about taking off her shoes and socks and getting her feet covered with sand and, worse, mud.

title: 'The Character Factory'
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Beth Navin To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Laurence Navin of Hingham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Beth Navin, to Walter Joseph D'Agostino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Joseph D'Agostino Jr. of New York and Point Lookout, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: Drinking Yes; Smoking, No
description: The 210-seat Pillar House restaurant next month will become the first in Massachusetts with a liquor license to ban all smoking. While other restaurants have nonsmoking areas, none have so far prohibited all smoking while continuing to serve alcohol, according to the ''Nonsmokers' Guide to Massachusetts'' published by the state Health Department and the American Lung Association.

title: BLOOD DATA SOUGHT IN AIDS DRIVE
description: IN AN effort to curb the spread of AIDS, the nation's major blood-bank organizations have asked their New Jersey affiliates to help find recipients of blood transfusions that may have contained the AIDS virus.

title: The Iowa Writers' Workshop
description: Reading Maureen Howard's article about the Iowa Writers' Workshop, I found myself simply green to be there (''Can Writing Be Taught in Iowa?'' May 25).

title: Krista Ann Carlson Wed
description: Krista Ann Carlson, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. W. Bernard Carlson Jr. of West Long Branch, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Brill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Brill of Great Neck, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Acting Justice Anne Feldman of the New York State Supreme Court, a cousin of the bridegroom, at the home of the bridegroom's parents. Mrs. Brill is a reference librarian for the New York law firm of Mudge, Rose, Guthrie, Alexander and Ferdon. Mr. Brill is the tennis professional at the Tennis Club at Grand Central Terminal in New York.

title: Karen M. Upton Marries Lawyer
description: St. Boniface Roman Catholic Church in Lunenburg, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Karen Marie Upton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Allen Upton of Lunenburg, to James Kendrick Noble 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Noble Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Mulcahy performed the ceremony.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS HIS NOMINATIONS TO FEDERAL BENCH
description: President Reagan, saying criticisms of his judicial nominations were politically motivated, today denounced ''partisan use of the confirmation process'' by Democrats in the Senate.

title: CORRECTION
description: Publishing information should have accompanied Stephen Spender's essay ''Writers in Uniform'' in the June 8 Book Review. The article was adapted from his introduction to ''Voices Against Tyranny: Writing of the Spanish Civil War,'' copyright c 1986 by Stephen Spender, edited by John Miller, which will be published next month by Charles Scribner's Sons on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the beginning of the war.

title: Onita Connington Marries Dr. Vijay Michael Thadani
description: The wedding of Onita Canning Connington, a daughter of Florence K. Connington of Stone Ridge, N.Y., and the late Richard Dewey Connington, to Dr. Vijay Michael Thadani, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jivat N. Thadani of Washington, took place yesterday at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. John H. O'Brien performed the ceremony.

title: THE PROMISCUOUS COOL OF POSTMODERNISM
description: I THOUGHT we had finished with these matters, but I see they are still on every academic agenda: in conferences, symposiums, special issues of the quarterly magazines. Every student of modern culture is evidently required to state a position on modernism and postmodernism, even though it is not clear what these words denote. They mean, it appears, whatever we want them to mean.

title: GUY EARL Jr.
description: Guy Earl Jr., a longtime Los Angeles businessman and publisher, died there Wednesday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Shultz Arrives in Hong Kong
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived in Hong Kong today for a rest stop at the beginning of a 10-day swing through Southeast Asia. A Hong Kong official said Mr. Shultz would not attend any public functions here. He is scheduled to leave for Singapore on Monday and will also visit Brunei before proceeding to a meeting of Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Manila on Tuesday.

title: NEW HAND AT THE HELM
description: NORTON L. BERMAN of Plainfield, recently named executive director of the American Crafts Council, has taken on the task of steering that organization through a time of growth and change.

title: Mary Wolfe Wed To John Malcolm
description: Mary Lee Wolfe, a daughter of Dr. Clara L. Wolfe of Tallahassee, Fla., was married yesterday to John Gulton Malcolm, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Malcolm of Tenafly, N.J. Judge James C. Hill of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta performed the wedding at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Atlanta.

title: 'INFIGHTING' IS SAID TO DELAY SUPERFUND
description: WHEN exasperated House members met last April to resolve their differences over a long-stalled toxic-waste cleanup bill, even their tight-lipped efforts at politeness could not mask their frustrations, especially with Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, who headed the conference.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: INVISIBLE HAND: The Marijuana Business. By Roger Warner. (Beech Tree/Morrow, $17.95.) By writing his workmanlike investigation now, Roger Warner is able to reflect on the marijuana industry's evolution over the last decade or so.

title: TAKING THE KIDS CAN BE FUN
description: Like many parents, I have memories of traveling with small children that I would prefer to forget. For example, holding an infant in my arms for seven hours because the plane had no room for an infant carrier. Losing my temper on a 400-mile summer drive because our three bored sons were constantly arguing, howling or punching each other in the back seat. Having to forgo a night out with my wife in a new city because we could not arrange for a baby sitter at our hotel.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: PICTURES FROM THE WATER TRADE: Adventures of a Westerner in Japan, by John David Morley. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) This is a travel book with a difference - though nonfiction, it is written in the third person, about an English traveler named Boon who explores Tokyo and observes its people and their lives. ''It is travel literature at its best - a kind of sinking in,'' Anne Tyler said here in 1985, by an author who ''manages truly to enter the heart of a foreign territory.'' LESS THAN ZERO, by Bret Easton Ellis. (Penguin, $5.95.) Bret Easton Ellis was 21 years old when he pub-lished this tale of life among a collection of affluent, jaded and narcissistic Los Angeles teen-agers. In The Times last year, Michiko Kakutani found the work ''one of the most disturbing novels I've read in a long time.'' The author, she said, possesses a good ear and a ''keen eye for grim details.''

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN TO HARVEST THE FRUIT OF THE GARDEN
description: WITH the arrival of summer, sitting in the shade with a cool drink tends to assume top priority in the garden. While it's nice to be able to sit back and enjoy the fruits of one's labors, the fact remains that there are tasks to be performed. Weeds continue to grow; water must be applied; deadheading will pay dividends in continued flowering, and harvesting is a must if fruits and vegetables are to be of any use.

title:
THE TALK OF HIGH ISLAND;
IT'S HIGH SEASON FOR THIMBLES DEVOTEES
description: PHOEBE MASON BRUCK started spending her summers on High Island in the Thimbles off Branford when she was 6 months old. She lived in Illinois then and since it was before turnpike travel, the trip took three days.

title: When Fritz Pollard Played in Akron
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New Rules on Liability Insurance
description: Under pressure that was rising as fast as liability insurance rates, negotiators for Governor Cuomo and the State Legislature reached agreement last week on proposals aimed at curbing those mushrooming costs.

title: Breland Stops Munduga
description: Mark Breland floored John Munduga with a right-left-right combination and stopped his opponent in the sixth round of a scheduled 10-round welterweight bout today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LOVE IS A DURABLE FIRE. By Brian Burland. (Norton, $17.95.) This third novel of a family saga is a singularly uninspired work of historical fiction.

title: REPAIRS TO CLOSE BARNUM MUSEUM
description: THE Barnum Museum, as eccentric a place as the man who created it, will close for two years, beginning next Sunday, for renovations.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH. By Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95.) In his best-selling book ''When Bad Things Happen to Good People,'' Rabbi Harold S. Kushner confronted human pain.

title: The Iowa Writers' Workshop
description: Maureen Howard quotes the Iowa Workshop's director, Jack Leggett, as saying that ''in judging the poems and stories of applicants, the selection committee avoids extremes, steering clear of experimental work. . . .''

title: THE PRESIDENT SENSES AN 'OPPORTUNITY'
description: THE Soviet Union is as totalitarian and expansionist as ever, President Reagan said last week, but when it comes to arms control ''a moment of opportunity'' may be at hand. He said Moscow had begun to make ''a serious effort'' at the moribund negotiations in Geneva.

title: THEATER'S GEORGE ABBOTT: ON THE ROAD TO 100
ONE OF POP ART'S PIONEERS IS MAKING WAVES AGAIN
description: James Rosenquist is painting a new mural. It will be 18 feet long and 11 feet high and is to be hung - corporate executives willing - in a communications technology exhibit in the A.T.& T. building at Madison Avenue and 55th Street. Pulling a chair up to the kitchen table in his spacious Manhattan loft the other day, Mr. Rosenquist excitedly described the work.

title: Australians Lose Appeal In Malaysian Drug Case
description: Two Australians lost their final appeals today against death sentences for drug smuggling and are to be hanged.

title: New Hampshire Judge Says Principal Was Ousted in Error
description: A judge has reinstated a nationally recognized high school principal, saying a town school board violated state law when it failed to hold a public hearing on why it was not renewing his contract.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WOMEN'S WORK: Contemporary Short Stories by New Zealand Women. Edited by Marion McLeod and Lydia Wevers. (Oxford, Paper, $16.95.) If one were to take the characters in these stories as signposts for an understanding of New Zealand women, the conclusion would have to be that they lead rather isolated, often melancholy lives encrusted with memories of school days and struggles with the burdens of domesticity.

title: Bass Hits 19th Homer
description: Randy Bass, formerly with the Texas Rangers, hit his 19th home run of the Japanese League season today as the Hanshin Tigers edged the Chunichi Dragons, 3-2.

title: John Bessone Marries Elizabeth A. Twyman
description: Elizabeth Ann Twyman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Twyman of Cincinnati, was married yesterday to John Peter Bessone, the son of Amo Bessone of Haslett, Mich., and Englewood, Fla., and the late Mary Kennedy Bessone. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Reichel at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Chapel in Cincinatti.

title: 252,000 Housing Units: Can the City Do It?
description: MAYOR KOCH recently announced a $4.2 billion plan to ''produce, preserve and upgrade'' 252,000 units of housing in New York City. Housing specialists who now have had a chance to assess the plan universally welcome it as the first major commitment by the city and the state to replace the big Federal housing programs that the Reagan Administration began tapering off five years ago.

title: Alison Bermack Marries
description: Alison Bermack, an assistant vice president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation in New York City, and Alan Rubenfeld, a planning analyst in the corporate finance department of the Continental Insurance Corporation in New York City, were married last night at Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I. Cantor Richard Berman officiated. Mrs. Rubenfeld, a graduate of Brandeis University, has a master's degree from the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Rubenfeld is a graduate of the University of Michigan, where he also received an M.B.A. degree.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SHAKESPEARE TO POP-SOUL
description: Donizetti's 'Mary Stuart,' An English National Opera production, featuring Janet Baker, Rosalind Plowright, David Rendall, John Tomlinson and Alan Opie, with the chorus and orchestra conducted by Charles Mackerras; directed for television by Peter Butler, Thorn EMI/HBO Video, 138 minutes. $39.95.

title: Sunday Observer; More Praise for Caesar
description: JULIUS CAESAR GOT things done. He thought he'd like to try to conquer Gaul, so he tried, and he conquered it.

title: Drive to Save Piping Plovers
description: AFTER competing for years with bathers and commercial developers for beach space, the piping plover, a shy bird that prefers privacy when nesting, faced extinction.

title: Maggie Joyce Becomes Bride of Richard J. Bailly
description: Marie-Louise Maguire Joyce, a media planner at Grey Advertising, and Richard Jeffrey Bailly, an auditor for Coopers & Lybrand, were married yesterday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Robert Collins officiated at the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Jacqueline Lee Is Wed To George H. Antoine
description: Jacqueline LaGrange Lee, a daughter of Pauline Herzog Daly of Rowayton, Conn., and Dr. Burton James Lee 3d of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to George Harry Antoine, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Joseph Antoine of Minneapolis. Judge Emile Rinaldi of the Adams County Court in Bright, Colo., performed the ceremony at the Ryssby Swedish Lutheran Church in Boulder, Colo.

title: CARL ICAHN'S WILD RIDE AT TWA
description: CARL ICAHN is showing the mounting strain of keeping Trans World Airline in the air. His hair is graying fast; his look is haggard. Gazing vacantly from his 27th floor window toward Central Park, he repeated himself frequently during a recent interview.

title: BIAS FOUND AT 2 PRINCETON CLUBS
description: The two remaining all-male eating clubs at Princeton University illegally discriminated against a female student who sought to join them in 1979, an administrative law judge has ruled.

title: Aquino and Key Minister Deny Reports of Schism
description: President Corazon C. Aquino and Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile appeared today at an air force gathering and denied reports of widening political differences between them.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE IMPACT ZONE By Ray Maloney. 246 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up) TO surfers, the place on a wave where the water is just about to collapse and explode is ''the impact zone'' - the spot of greatest danger, but also the greatest potential for thrilling achievement. For 15-year-old Jim Nichols, in Ray Maloney's fine first novel, it is a symbol of the way he is beginning to live his life.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection, which has been criticized recently for failing to crack down on several companies accused of violating pollution laws, has taken long-awaited action against one.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MEDIEVAL DAYS - Knighthood is in full flower at the Sands Point Preserve, which is in the midst of its Seventh Annual Medieval Festival. At 11 A.M. today, Saturday and next Sunday, a grand procession of the Royal Court heralds the start of the day's activities. Through 5 P.M. each day there will be music by madrigal singers and troubadours, maypole dancing, falconers, magicians and jugglers, and even the storming of Castlegould, a mansion on the estate. Everything is designed to re-create with as much authenticity as possible the excitement of a 14th-century European tournament and fair. The preserve is on Middle Neck Road. Admission is $3, $1 for children. ON THE SQUARE What's a summer without square dancing under the stars? For devotees, probably nothing. This is the week their dreams start coming true as the state parks begin their seasonal programs and the Clark Garden offers a special addition. At the garden, on I. U. Willets Road in Albertson, Bill Kattke does the calling at 7 P.M. Tuesday; the No Frills Band provides the live music. Tickets are $2.50, or $1.50 for children and senior citizens, and blankets or folding chairs are recommended for seating.

title: FROM CARAMOOR TO A GARDEN PARTY WITH OPERATIC DUETS
description: SUMMER officially arrived yesterday, and with it the outdoor music season swings into high gear. Today at 5 P.M., for instance, you can enjoy a musical garden party at Rosecliff, a luxury community on Wilderness Way in Briarcliff, with operatic duets and Broadway favorites sung by young artists of the Westchester Lyric Festival. The programs (there will be another one next Sunday at the same hour) have been designed as benefits for the Lyric Festival, an organization that has sponsored various operatic concerts and even some full productions in the county over the last several years, and the host will be its founder-director, Franco Iglesias. For more details, call Claire Polk, the festival's general chairman, at 664-2252.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SHAKESPEARE TO POP-SOUL
description: Patti La Belle in Concert: Look to the Rainbow Tour, U.S.A. Home Video, 74 minutes. $29.95. It took more than 20 years for Patti La Belle to become a major star, and this concert video, taped more than a year before her breakthrough, shows how she did it.

title: Candace F. Byers Becomes a Bride
description: Candace Forman Byers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James N. Byers 3d of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Robert Clermont Livingston Timpson Jr., a son of Elizabeth Hutton Timpson of Kent, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., and Mr. Timpson of Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Daniel Burke performed the ceremony at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Providence.

title:
ART;
JURIED SHOW MIXES THE UNUSUAL AND THE TRADITIONAL
description: JUNE is a popular month for the juried exhibitions presented by a number of Long Island organizations. Judging by participation, attendance and enthusiasm, these events seem to play a useful community role - in spite of the often uneven quality.

title: Outside Use of Its Name Nettles Princeton
description: WHEN the Toombs Development Company broke ground recently for Princeton Forrestal Village, a $130 million shopping and office center, its choice of name was no surprise.

title: GUIDELINES AIDING HOMES FOR RETARDED
description: WHEN a group home for 12 retarded adults was proposed in a residential area of Bedford, the town's advisory board had several meetings before recommending that the group home be approved by the town.

title: END OF SEASON
description: West Side Shakespeare - June 23 - Manhattan seems big enough for two Shakespeares in the park, and two years ago the Watery Star Theater was formed to celebrate the bard in the long underutilized Rotunda Pavilion in Riverside Park at West 79th Street. In the first season, some 3,000 people saw free performances of ''The Winter's Tale.'' This season ''The Taming of the Shrew'' will open July 30 and play through Aug. 31, Wednesdays through Sundays at 8 P.M. To support this third season, a 6:30 to 9:30 P.M. benefit party will be held in the pavilion with a buffet supper, cabaret entertainment and Shakespeare readings. Tickets, $30 or $50 a couple, from 212-316-9416. Theater Party

title: Afghan Visitors Bring Complaints
description: President Reagan gave the Afghan guerrillas increased visibility last week, and they promptly used it to complain about what they are not getting - diplomatic recognition and long-promised Stinger antiaircraft missiles.

title: IT'S SMART TO BUY USED
description: THERE are 240,123,000 people in this country, and the Census Bureau says they occupy 87.5 million households. There are also 128,660,000 cars on the road, and that breaks down to about one and a half automobiles for every family.

title:
LESSONS FROM 19TH CENTURY BRITAIN;
'FAIR TRADE' COULD TRAP THE DEMOCRATS
description: WITH the trade bill that cleared the House last month, the Democrats have rallied behind the new doctrine of reciprocity. They now prefer ''fair trade'' to free trade. ''Level playing fields'' are their goal. Electoral advantage is their hope. If history is any guide, however, the Democrats could be dead wrong. For history offers a remarkable parallel, with a denouement that the Democrats ought to ponder.

title: NICARAGUA VOLUNTEERS
description: ''One way, you get more mosquitos, the other way you get more dust,'' Marianne R. Maloney said, as she recalled facing a decision between picking coffee or cotton in Nicaragua.

title: WALDHEIM CALLED BUSH IN APRIL TO DENY CHARGES
description: Kurt Waldheim privately telephoned Vice President Bush two months ago seeking to assure the Reagan Administration at a high level that the accusations that he took part in Nazi war crimes were not true, White House officials say.

title: Fond Farewell By British Pair
description: As the British Ambassador in Washington for four years, Sir Oliver Wright has learned first-hand how the two cultures take divergent paths at times.

title: YANKS WIN IN 10; OROSCO FALLS TO CUBS, 8-6
description: In a rare and classic bottom-of-the-ninth confrontation, the Mets sent three of baseball's top hitters to the plate against Lee Smith of the Chicago Cubs yesterday, each representing the winning run.

title: ITALY TRIES TO GET SOME DISTANCE ON THE MIDEAST
description: THE Italian Foreign Minister, Giulio Andreotti, recently delivered to Parliament an encyclopedic review of Italy's foreign policy, but there were three words he never uttered: Palestine Liberation Organization. The absence was notable. Just last February, Mr. Andreotti emphatically reminded Parliament of the Government's longstanding belief that the P.L.O. must play a role in any Mideast peace negotiations and that its chairman, Yasir Arafat, was a key moderate in the region.

title: ANOTHER SUMMER OF GOOD INTENTIONS
description: OUR fat black-and-white cat, Tessa, just caught her first June bug of the season. Catching June bugs is her only talent - except for being perennial winner of the Clean Plate Club. She walks around with the bug, still alive, in her mouth - a cat with a loud, mean buzz, watched with admiration by the rest of the cats and with complete puzzlement by passing pedestrians. After a while, Tessa gets tired of the game, the angry buzz is cut off abruptly, and she crunches her victim to a grim death. Tessa, we always say, will eat anything.

title: An Era Is Ending On Herald Square
description: The ultimate department at Gimbels might have been labeled ''stores.'' Batus Inc., the American subsidiary of the British company that bought the famous retail chain in 1973 and has been selling it off since January, announced last week that it had sold 11 outlets and was closing its two Manhattan stores, one of them the Herald Square flagship, pending their disposal.

title: THE SECRET OF SCHLOSS LABERS
description: My guidebook was stamped ''Top Secret.'' In its pages nearly 40 years ago, a State Department intelligence officer set about documenting the clandestine flight of Nazis, Jewish refugees and Communist spies out of a shattered Germany and through a mysterious underground railroad along the Brenner Pass route to Italy. It told of forged passports and rings of smugglers and profiteers, arms runners and war criminals. And it told of a castle in the Italian South Tyrol where an SS task force, assisted by some Jewish collaborators, secreted Nazi loot and a large cache of counterfeit British pound notes.

title: Rory A. W. Browne Weds Dr. Grace Chang at Yale
description: Dr. Grace Chang, a postdoctoral fellow and chief resident in psychiatry at the Yale University School of Medicine, and Rory Alexander Woodthorpe Browne, a lecturer in history at Yale, where he is also dean of Branford College, were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas P. Gariepy performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Chapel of St. Thomas More at Yale.

title: BOTANY CLASS OFFERS THERAPY AS BONUS
description: ALTHOUGH his students at Ramapo College here say that Dr. Joseph Dallon's seemingly simple course in horticulture is ''personally enlightening'' and that he is a ''brilliant'' man, some of his colleagues accuse him of teaching psychology when his focus should be on seeds and flowers.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
PITCHER WHO SAW BEYOND THE PLATE
description: I BELIEVE that life is a series of alternatives. We have a lot of decisions to make along the way, and we can leave ourselves with many different choices if we prepare wisely. Although that may sound overly philosophic, I believe it is true.

title: HAS REAGAN GOT THE COURT HE WANTS?
description: IN the heat of the 1984 Presidential campaign, Justice William H. Rehnquist gave a speech entitled ''Presidential Appointments to the Supreme Court.'' It is natural and proper, he said, for a President to seek to shape the course of the law by naming Justices ''sympathetic to his political or philosophical principles.'' But, he added, the effort ''is apt to be only partially successful.''

title: Getting Treatments
description: Eddie Johnson, 31-year-old Cleveland Cavaliers guard, volunteered for drug rehabilitation approximately a month ago and has been undergoing treatment at a California center, according to a report in The Cleveland Plain Dealer. Charles Grantham, executive vice president of the National Basketball Association Players Association would not identify the facility where Johnson is being treated, but told the newspaper that Johnson ''came forward for help and is progressing well'', adding that Johnson will remain in the center ''for an undetermined time, anywhere from one to three months.'' Team officials would not comment on Johnson's status, although the Cavaliers' new general manager, Wayne Embry, is known to take a strong stance against drug abuse.

title: Irradiating Food
description: To the Editor:

title: RAIL SERVICE FROM NEW YORK TO CAPE COD EXPECTED SOON
