description: Amtrak and Massachusetts officials expect to sign a contract within a few weeks for the first passenger rail service since the 1960's between New York City and Cape Cod.

title: Julie S. Baker Marries David Lee Downs Jr.
description: Julie Suzanne Baker, a daughter of Pauline C. Baker of Clearwater, Fla., and Robert Alt Baker of College Park, Md., was married yesterday to David Lee Downs Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Downs of Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. Andrew Cusack performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the St. Catherine of Siena Church in Riverside, Conn.

title:
DINING OUT;
TEX-MEX COMES TO THE PALISADES
description: THE colorful cooking of the Southwest is in, it's hot and it has arrived in Bergen County, where a three-month-old restaurant called Albuquerque Eats is serving up versions of Tex-Mex and New- and Old-Mex dishes. This is the first outpost of the chain, which has two establishments in Manhattan.

title: HIGH NOON AT RED COACH
description: THEY looked to all the world, one member of the group recalled, ''like innocuous Westchester housewives,'' headed downtown for lunch at the Red Coach Grill in White Plains. But this was 1970, and women were not allowed to eat at the tables in the room reserved for businessmen, although they were allowed to sit at the bar.

title: SORORICIDAL WARFARE
description: FEMINISM ON TRIAL The Ginny Foat Case and the Future of the Women's Movement. By Ellen Hawkes. 420 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Over Where?
description: State Representative Royall H. Switzler was probably right on the money last week when he told voters he was dropping out of the Massachusetts gubernatorial contest because ''I cannot reasonably expect your support.'' Mr. Switzler, who sought the Republican nomination, recently admitted that he had lied when he said he had seen combat in Vietnam as a captain in the Army Special Forces; actually, he conceded, he had served in peacetime Korea as a sergeant. His departure from the gubernatorial race left Massachusetts Republicans in a bit of a quandary. The other leading candidate for the nomination, Gregory S. Hyatt, saw his campaign falter when a former employer said a female assistant had twice discovered Mr. Hyatt naked in his office.

title: 7 Killed, 2 Are Hurt In Fire at Kelso, Wash.
description: A fire that officials suspect was caused by a smoldering cigarette from a late-night party engulfed a house today, killing seven people, including five children, the authorities said. Two other children were critically burned.

title: ALLY SHEEDY'S FILM CAREER TRACKS THE IMAGE OF YOUTH IN THE 1980's
description: According to entries penned in her journal, Ally Sheedy was very much in love last year. In tender verses, she wrote that she never wished to be away from her love, that she adored the way he looked, that he was the only one who understood her, and that she would love him forever - even if his circuits completely shorted, which, of course, they did.

title: Lynn Boffa Is Married To Michael A. Sullivan
description: Lynn Elizabeth Boffa, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Boffa of Los Angeles and Michael A. Sullivan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay A. Sullivan of Hingham, Mass., were married yesterday at the Pomona, N.Y., home of the bride's grandmother, Hilda Striker.

title: CRIME ON L.I.: CITY ROLE IS KEY
description: AT LEAST half of the serious crimes in Nassau County are committed by New York City residents, police officials say. And, they agree, the problem is getting worse.

title:
MINOR LEAGUES '86; Pittsfield Cubs;
BASEBALL WITH A ROCKWELLIAN TOUCH
description: EVERY evening at Wahconah Park, home of the Eastern League's Pittsfield Cubs, Little Leaguers take positions on the field alongside their Cub counterparts for the playing of the national anthem. The tableau adds a touch of Norman Rockwell to the evening's main business: minor league baseball.

title: At Wrigley Field, Tradition Rules
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bettina M. Arndt Marries a Lawyer
description: Bettina M. Arndt, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Heinz W. Arndt of Canberra, Australia, was married yesterday to W. Warren Scott 3d. The bridegroom is the son of Lieut. Gen. Willard W. Scott Jr, Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, and Mrs. Scott of West Point, N.Y. The Rev. Edmund Campion, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Australian Naval Memorial Chapel in Watson's Bay, Sydney.

title: Ballesteros Shoots a 68 To Lead at Irish Open
description: Seve Ballesteros of Spain shot a third-round 68 in bright, breezy weather today to stretch his lead to five strokes in the $300,000 Irish Open.

title: BOTTLES AFLOAT IN THE COMPOSERS' SEA
description: The need to compose music and hear it played for audiences is a powerful impulse, probably as primordial in origin as the urge to beat on hollow trees and wake up the neighbors in the next cave. We may be confident that in the absence of a nuclear winter thousands of the mysteriously driven musicians we call composers will go on writing and trying to arrange performances of their works. Hundreds will even do so without thought of insuring tenure at a university. Or dozens, anyway.

title: Senate Plan Hurts I.R.A. as an Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: CREWS BEAT OLD CADENCE IN HONG KONG
description: The opening ceremonies of the 11th annual Hong Kong International Dragon boat races took place today on the Kowloon waterfront of Victoria Harbor in a ceremony that recalled the 2,000-year-old origin of this event. It commemmorates the death of Chu Yuan, a Chinese poet and patriot who threw himself into the sea as a final protest against the corrupt government of his time.

title: Cable TV
description: A welcome opportunity to enjoy the art of the late James Mason in the summer and winter of his long and varied career arises this week when two of his better films -''The Seventh Veil'' (1945) and ''The Shooting Party'' (1985) are shown on cable.

title: Another Death Tied to Excedrin
description: Early this month, Sue Snow Webking collapsed and died in Auburn, Wash., a suburb of Seattle. Last week, after laboratory analyses determined that she had died of acute cyanide poisoning, the poison was found in a bottle of Extra-Strength Excedrin capsules in her home.

title: Tampering Is Charged
description: The St. Louis Blues' owner, Harry Ornest, has filed a claim with the National Hockey League against Detroit, charging the Red Wings with tampering before last week's signing of Jacques Demers as head coach. Demers, the Blues' coach last season, and his agent, Art Kaminsky, said that because the Blues had never filed a signed contract between the club and Demers with the N.H.L., the team could not win the tampering claim. John Ziegler, the president of the N.H.L., said that the league's Board of Governors would vote on the claim, and that a simple majority of the 21 team owners would be needed for the Blues to win.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 22, 1986
description: Fiction

title: OUTPOSTS ON CHINA'S GREAT SILK ROAD
description: The oasis appeared first as a dark green speck on the desert horizon.

title: DRONGOS IN BORNEO, HANG GLIDING IN ISRAEL
description: WILDLIFE ADVENTURE IN ASIA -On the trail of such exotic animals as orangutans and bearded pigs, of such remarkable birds as barbets and drongos, of such unlikely reptiles as flying lizards, a tour will leave Los Angeles in September for Hong Kong, Borneo, Singapore and Maylasia.

title: M. W. Robinson 3d, Advertising Aide, Engaged to Tracy Anne Mergenthaler
description: Tracy Anne Mergenthaler and Malcolm Weeks Robinson 3d plan to be married Aug. 23, the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Francis William Mergenthaler of Westport, Conn., have announced. Mr. Robinson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson Jr. of Wilton, Conn.

title: Art
description: Before photography usurped their function, artists used to go on archaeological digs to make a visual record of the site and its findings. And last winter, the Brooklyn Museum, which has long been excavating in Egypt, happily revived the practice.

title: YANKS WIN IN 10; BUT RIGHETTI FAILS AGAIN
description: In the game's tightest moment, Lou Piniella waved toward the bullpen one more time today. Dave Righetti came in. The afternoon crumbled. It has been this way three times in three games here. Righetti has failed to do his job, and the Yankees have struggled. This time, however, they were saved by Rickey Henderson and by Mike Easler, who made decisive contributions in a 4-2, 10-inning Yankee victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: NEW YORK TRANSIT UNIONS GO PUBLIC IN POWER STRUGGLE WITH MANAGEMENT
description: One advertisement features a cartoon of the Transit Authority's president, David L. Gunn, flushing bags of money down a toilet. Another depicts a passenger falling out of a moving subway car as the doors accidentally fly open. A third describes millions of dollars in fees paid to consultants.

title: AN UNCOMMON GRADUATION
description: AS my son's high-school graduation approaches, I am reminded of my own many years ago. My son's will be a much celebrated event: a prom, a solemn ceremony, a reception, gifts and a marathon party with numerous door prizes culminated by breakfast on the beach. My own in Ireland was a very different affair and memorable, too.

title: Daniel D. Moyer Wed To Jennifer Jo Flusser
description: Jennifer Jo Flusser, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Flusser of New York, was married yesterday to Daniel D. Moyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Moyer of Germantown, Md., and Farmingdale, L.I. An ecumenical ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Garcia, an Episcopal priest, at St. Mark's Church in-the-Bowery in New York.

title: TURNPIKE PROJECT REVISED
description: THE $2.2-billion plan to widen the New Jersey Turnpike -announced last year amid considerable fanfare - has been scaled down once more following months of public debate over the size, cost, scope and need for the project.

title: A LIFE IN PHOTOGRAPHS OF OTHERS
description: DOROTHY NORMAN did not select the 30 photographs by her that go on exhibit today at Guild Hall in East Hampton. ''I don't like interfering with someone else's work, so I left it up to the curators,'' said the photographer, writer and editor who played an important role in the artistic, intellectual and social ferment that swept America from the 1920's to the 50's.

title: DRUG BILL FOR ELDERLY GAINS IN ALBANY
description: The State Senate and Assembly agreed this week that legislation to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs would cost much more than expected, but they remained far apart on other key elements of the program.

title: KEAN SEEKS STATE CONTROL OF WORST SCHOOL SYSTEMS
description: Governor Kean has proposed a measure to allow the state to assume control of school districts that continually fail to meet state education standards.

title:
INVESTING;
HUNT FOR VALUE, NOT BARGAINS, ON WALL ST.
description: HARVEY P. EISEN does not understand why so many top investors say they cannot find any stocks worth buying. Even though stock prices have risen more than 45 percent since September, the president of New York's Integrated Resources Asset Management continues to be a buyer of both stocks and convertible bonds.

title: KING EYES STRATEGY FOR STATE CAMPAIGN
description: NASSAU County Comptroller Peter T. King, who is used to running for office in the politically friendly environment of predominantly Republican Nassau, must now run as an underdog statewide candidate against a strong Democratic incumbent, Attorney General Robert Abrams.

title: Blame the Banks
description: To the Editor We are in this dismal creditor condition because of indiscriminate lending by central city bankers (''End the Charade on Third World Debt,'' Forum, May 18). Loans were pushed on lesser developed countries with disregard for what use would be made of the credits and with little or no monitoring to insure that the loans had a chance to be self-liquidating.

title: IF POLITICAL POWER INHERES IN THE PEOPLE, PEOPLE NEED POWER
description: ARTICLE I of New Jersey's Constitution contains the following radical premise:

title: KEEP YOUR EYE ON THE SMALL PICTURE
description: WHO PROFITS Winners, Losers, and Government Regulation. By Robert A. Leone. 248 pp. New York: Basic Books. $17.95.

title: Political Boosters
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
TWO GROUP SHOWS AT BRONX MUSEUM
description: THE darkest hour is just before dawn, and right now the facade of the Bronx Museum of the Arts is in terrible shape; this is only a stage in the building of a sleek new exterior that will be ready this fall. But inside the museum it is business as usual and usual means pretty - and sometimes remarkably - good.

title: CHURCHES' MEMBERSHIPS INCREASED 1% IN 1984
description: Religious congregations rose in membership by nearly 1 percent in 1984, continuing a pattern of recent years, according to statistics released by the National Council of Churches.

title: A NEW TYPE OF HORTICULTURE: JUST ADD WATER
description: WHEN Bob Nickson, a pilot and farmer from Sharon, teamed up with Scott Cully, who grew the world's largest pumpkin at 515 pounds last year, their experimental greenhouse was bound to foster some new horticultural techniques.

title: HANDICAPPED CHILDREN AND SPECIAL EDUCATION
description: In reply to Parnel Wickham-Searl's letter to the Long Island editor on May 18: When I said that profoundly handicapped children would benefit from a law that would provide them with a lifetime of care, I meant just that [ Letters, April 20 ] . This statement did not imply that handicapped children should not be taught self-help skills till the age of 21.

title: August Wedding For Miss Dwyer
description: Mrs. Allan M. Shapiro of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Peter J. Dwyer of Kingston, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Doris Turner Dwyer to Charles Henry Chu, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Chu of Rockville, Md. The wedding is planned for Aug. 2.

title: Buying Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BIAS MYSTERY
description: IN a commencement address Thursday at Public School 50, in South Jamaica, Queens, the elementary school's most famous alumnus, Governor Cuomo of New York, class of '43, urged the students to ''shun the drugs,'' that could disrupt their dreams and that ''if a friend offers some to you, then at that moment he is no longer your friend.''

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks 'Could Be Fun . . .'
description: GENE MICHAEL was wearing Cubs blue, but upon re turning to New York his Yankee pinstripes were stuffed in a corner of his mind. In his Shea Stadium office, the Cubs' new manager joked about how his life has changed now that he's no longer the Yankees' third-base ooach.

title: MENTALLY ILL YOUTHS ASSESSED
description: DRAMATIC increases in teen-age pregnancies, drug abuse and 10-year-old alcoholics are the results of ignored mental illness among young people, according to a private report.

title: Dance
description: Going, going, almost gone. Two major ballet companies are nearing the end of their seasons at Lincoln Center. Therefore dance fans who want to keep up with what's happening in ballet might wish to ponder the schedules of the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater and American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. Sunday, in fact, the New York City Ballet offers its two final performances of the spring.

title: IRELAND CONSIDERS THE LEGALIZATION AND POLITICS OF DIVORCE
description: IN a debate on the nettlesome issue of divorce in 1925, only three years after the Irish Republic came into existence, a non-Catholic Senator aroused Catholic resentment with a prophetic speech. ''If you show that this country, southern Ireland, is going to be governed by Catholic ideas and Catholic ideas alone, you will never get the north,'' said Senator William Butler Yeats, who was better known for his poems. ''You will create an impassable barrier between north and south.''

title: LIFE ON THE RUN: SHAVE YOUR BEARD OR GROW ONE
description: It was the anxiety, the man said, that left the deepest scars - anxiety bred by fear of being caught, or by ignorance about the destiny of the family left behind.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'AIDA' FOR FREE - The Metropolitan Opera Company pays a visit to the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx at 8 P.M. Wednesday. Its stage will be set up in front of the Museum Building for an al fresco performance of Verdi's ''Aida,'' concert-style with full orchestra and chorus.

title: Good and Bad Mothers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul E. Kramer Weds Catherine Lee Streich
description: Catherine Lee Streich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Wakely Streich of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Paul Eugene Kramer, a son of Mrs. Harriet Weber Kramer of Eastchester, N.Y., and the late William W. Kramer. The Rev. Phillip E. Perkins performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: The Death of a Son
description: A YEAR ago, I learned of the death of our only child, our 22-year-old son Paul. One of my early thoughts was that my wife and I would have no grandchildren. There would be no passing on of either our tangibles or intangibles. There would be no children or grandchildren to inherit our antique organ, the glassware blown by Betsey's grandfather, our silverware, our china or our modest financial estate. Nor would there be children or grandchildren to listen to the family stories about my father and his colorful relatives, the stories of my youth, of Paul's youth, of my wife's family or of our solid, if uncolorful, married life.

title: DANCE: CHIANG CHING IN SOLO PROGRAM
description: SOME dancers in solos try to impress viewers with their assertiveness. Chiang Ching, in contrast, was most interesting when she seemed to be about to vanish from sight during the solos she offered Friday night at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater as part of Clark Center's ''Summer Dance '86.''

title: HISTORY, AS SEEN BY THE RANK AND FILE
description: MEMBERS of several unions gathered at a labor headquarters in Lower Manhattan one night to watch a film about the railroad workers' strike of 1877. Although the strike was a pivotal event in American labor history - more than 100 people were killed and 1,000 injured as it spread along the tracks from Martinsburg, W. Va., to Pittsburgh and other cities and turned into a general strike - few people, including union members, have heard of it.

title: MATCH PLAY DOESN'T ALWAYS HAVE TO BE HUMDRUM
description: Match play has usually been thought of as dull by comparison with tournament play because the players are so often playing not to lose rather than to win. But, of course, it all depends on the players.

title: Cognac's Expanding Market
description: THE ADVERTISEMENT SHOWS a young middle-class black man in an armchair, in front of a television screen on which a football game is being played. But he is not looking at the game. He's looking over his shoulder at a strikingly handsome young woman, clad only in a bit of black lace, who is perched on the back of his chair. In her hands she holds two snifters of Cognac. The caption says: ''Hennessy, the civilized way to end the game.''

title: BROOKLYN SETS LANDFILL FIGHT TO KEEP OUT STRATFORD
description: A BATTLE over a 54-acre tract of land in the town of Brooklyn has state and local officials worried about whether eastern Connecticut will become the dumping ground for the well-off towns of Fairfield County.

title: KEMP, WITH NATIONAL DREAM, FACES FIGHT AT HOME
description: While Jack F. Kemp was tossing a football for the Buffalo Bills 23 years ago, James Keane was showing fans to their seats.

title: DAVIS DRIVES IN 2 TO POWER GIANTS
description: Chili Davis singled home a run in the first inning and doubled home another in the fourth today, raising his National League-leading total of runs batted in to 50 and powering the San Francisco Giants to a 2-1 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: FENTON P. FUTTNER
description: Fenton P. Futtner, political director of the Republican State Central Committee and a former State Agriculture Commissioner, died Friday after apparently choking on food at a restaurant.

title: Maria B. Doelger Married to Bennet K. Langlotz
description: Maria Barbara Doelger, a daughter of Mr.and Mrs. Frank G. Doelger of New Canaan, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to Bennet Karl Langlotz, a son of Laine B. Bryce and Philip F. Langlotz, both of St. Paul. Msgr. Francis X. McGuire performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan.

title: 'RAN' WEATHERS THE SEASONS
description: In any context, in any year, the grandeur of Akira Kurosawa's ''Ran'' could not go easily unrecognized. One would have to be willfully blind. In this mingy season, however, ''Ran'' is almost a religious experience - an epiphany, a reminder that there still can be life before one softens to death in the ooze of late 20th-century popular culture. ''Ran'' stands above all other 1985-86 movies with the implacable presence of a force of nature.

title: Turnaround In the Valley
description: The five-story building at 4 West 104th Street, built in 1890 and demolished in 1975, was a fairly typical example of Manhattan Valley real estate: a turn-of-the-century walkup tenement that was condemned by the city.

title: LESS DRASTIC THEORY EMERGES ON FREEZING AFTER A NUCLEAR WAR
description: American climate researchers have moderated the most extreme predictions of prolonged freezing and possible human extinction put forward three years ago as part of the outlook for the aftermath of a nuclear war.

title: EXPLORERS HONORED
description: A block of four 22-cent United States stamps was issued May 28 to honor five Polar explorers. The block was issued in North Pole, Alaska, a station of the Fairbanks post office. The first day ceremony at North Pole High School was attended by Alaska state and Congressional officials.

title: HOW A LEGENDARY KOREAN DANCER HONORS HER HERITAGE
description: There is only one Living National Human Cultural Treasure in dance in the Republic of Korea and her name is Han Young-Suk. Miss Han was given the honor by the South Korean Government in 1969, as part of its continuing program to preserve traditional Korean culture in its pure form. This week, for the first time in more than two decades, the 65-year-old dancer will appear on the East Coast of the United States. Audiences will have a rare chance to see Miss Han when the American Dance Festival presents her in performances on Monday and Tuesday in Durham, N.C., and on Thursday at the Korean Cultural Service in New York City.

title: The Mail-Order Marriage Business
description: I empathize with Filipino women in search of financially stable lives. But I am hardly surprised that a man who would pay someone else $150 to sign his name to 12 ''personal'' letters, ''by hand in blue ink - a nice touch,'' would also have difficulty maintaining a relationship with an American woman in the 1980's. DIANE ASHACHIK Passaic, N.J.

title: Fiedler's Yiddish
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW SAID TO SIGNAL WILLINGNESS TO WORK ON ARMS PACT VERIFICATION
description: Soviet negotiators have signaled a willingness to work on verification problems for long-range mobile missiles and have for the first time suggested some possible verification measures, Administration officials say.

title: TAKING FILM TO ITS LIMIT AND BEYOND
description: ALMOST everything in photography can be made to work automatically except film. No film can adjust itself to produce a perfectly exposed print. But photographers can increase their chances of creating high-quality prints by mastering a variety of techniques for processing film in the darkroom.

title: BRINGING AMERICA'S CREATIVE TALENTS INTO FOCUS
description: ''I choose people whose work has really changed their discipline, people of whom one can say that things weren't quite the same afterward,'' says Susan Lacy. Mrs. Lacy isn't a college professor talking about her curriculum, but a TV producer describing the subjects of her new documentary series, ''American Masters.'' ''Yet, they don't all have to be giants,'' she adds. ''There can be little giants, too.'' The 15-part series, which will make its debut tomorrow night at 9 on WNET/Channel 13, stakes out for its territory a wide range of creative activity, from Charlie Chaplin and Eugene O'Neill to Georgia O'Keeffe and Katherine Anne Porter. Other ''Masters,'' both living and dead, appraised by the series include the composers George Gershwin and Aaron Copland, the architect Philip Johnson, the painter Thomas Eakins and the novelist Truman Capote.

title: Molitor Hurt Again
description: Paul Molitor, shuttling back and forth between active duty with the Milwaukee Brewers and the disabled list, is out again and this time it could be for a month. Molitor got what was diagnosed as a partial tear of the right hamstring on May 9 while charging a bunt from third base against the California Angels.

title: HIGH-TECH REPLACES FARM AT FARMINGDALE COLLEGE
description: Farmingdale is dropping the farm.

title: Laura Ann Lyng Wed To Peter Millner Good
description: Laura Ann Lyng, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Lyng of Clifton Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Millner Good, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell H. Good of New York and Fair Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Robert E. Richmond performed the ceremony at the Shenendehowa United Methodist Church in Clifton Park.

title: Presidential Tennis
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mexican Time Bomb
description: Every once in a while the Reagan Administration thinks seriously about Mexico - for example, when it's not thinking about Nicaragua.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE former reception center on Ellis Island, where 17 million immigrants were processed, will be 100 years old in 1992, and celebration preparations already are under way.

title: U.S.F.L. to Call 3 Witnesses
description: The United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League reaches a midpoint of sorts this week. Starting tomorrow, the U.S.F.L. has roughly three days more to present its case in Federal District Court, after which the N.F.L. will begin its defense.

title: Bowling Ratings Are Impressive
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
INVESTMENT STRATEGY
description: Rare coins have become an important investment vehicle, attracting thousands of buyers who formerly were preoccupied with stocks, bonds, commodities and the like. The influx of money has driven up prices dramatically. Unfortunately, though, many of the newcomers haven't invested the necessary time to learn essential facts about the hobby and the market. Some, in fact, literally don't know heads or tails about coins, even though they're spending many thousands of dollars to acquire them.

title: Cold Comfort; Pentagon Economy
description: The Pentagon usually digs in firmly against budget assaults, battling fiercely for every program, no matter how costly.

title: 2d Approach to LaRouche
description: Paul G. Kirk Jr., the Democratic national chairman, has deliberately had very little to say in the past about Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the controversial candidate for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination. After LaRouche associates won Democratic nominations for lieutenant governor and secretary of state in Illinois last March, Mr. Kirk sent this memorandum to party leaders: ''LaRouche candidates thrive on making Democratic leaders respond to them through the news media.

title: BLACKS IN CONGRESS ARE BRANCHING OUT
description: THE special election held June 10 to fill the House seat of Joseph P. Addabbo, the Queens Democrat who died earlier this year, produced an exceptionally close race. Justice Burton S. Sherman of the State Supreme Court ruled last week that the contest could not be decided until he had heard arguments about disputed absentee ballots.

title: Lisa A. Schubert, James Thomas 3d Exchange Vows
description: Lisa Anne Schubert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Schubert of Miami, and James Augustus Thomas 3d, a son of Anne M. Thomas of Locust Valley, L.I., and Mr. Thomas Jr. of Becket, Mass., were married yesterday in New York at the home of the bridegroom's aunt and uncle Mr. and Mrs. John Elliott Jr. The Rev. Paul Abels, a retired United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Q.& A. With the City's Top Planner
description: As construction sites and development projects have mushroomed in New York in recent years, the City Planning Commission has come under increasing criticism from community groups and politicians who say the commission has primarily reacted to proposals instead of forming its own overall plan for the city.

title: THE RIGHT TO BE IN COMBAT
description: STRENGTH FOR THE FIGHT A History of Black Americans in the Military. By Bernard C. Nalty. Illustrated. 424 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

title: ISRAELI'S CHANCE TO LIVE: SOVIET VISA FOR SISTER
description: A Soviet Jewish immigrant with leukemia is awaiting word from the Kremlin on whether his only sister can come to Israel from Moscow for the bone marrow transplant that holds the one hope for his survival.

title: OLD-TIME SENATOR IS LEAVING ALBANY
description: IN a world where politicians campaign by television and play racquetball after sessions, State Senator John E. Flynn, the Yonkers Republican who is retiring this year, may be one of the last of the state's old-time lawmakers.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
FRONT-BOAT SEATS
description: As a youngster growing up in Hastings-on-Hudson, William Ewen Jr. loved the Hudson. He would go out in his father's motorboat, he recalled recently, and ''meet the big steamers and sidewheelers'' churning through the water.

title: NASA Gives Up On a Rocket Plan
description: Even before the Challenger disaster Jan. 28, astronauts were reportedly uneasy about plans to attach the highly volatile Centaur rocket to payloads carried by the space shuttles. With good reason, it turns out.

title: BRITAIN'S CHANNEL 4 WHERE COMMERCE SERVES CULTURE
description: What do the following have in common? The films ''My Beautiful Laundrette'' and ''Letter to Brezhnev.'' Television recordings of Peter Brook's ''Carmen'' and the Royal Shakespeare Company's ''Nicholas Nickleby.'' The glossy soap-opera mini-series ''A Woman of Substance'' and a Susan Sontag essay on the stage works of Pina Bausch. ''Max Headroom,'' the world's first computer-generated music-TV host, and Salman Rushdie, the novelist, delivering a lacerating indictment of racism in England. ''Acceptable Levels,'' a considerably less than flattering drama about British attitudes toward Northern Ireland, and ''26 Bathrooms,'' a laconic guide through a multitude of British bathrooms and a kind of earthy antidote to the recent traveling exhibition devoted to a number of stately British homes.

title: PRESERVING SCHOOL DAYS ON VIDEOTAPE
description: Video yearbooks have come to the campus, and nostalgia may never be the same.

title: DAGGETT CAPTURES TITLE
description: The men's national gymnastics championship was on the line as Tim Daggett headed to the pommel horse, his favorite event, leading the competition.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:My wife and I are planning a trip to Western Samoa. Where can we get information? - T. M. P., North Chatham, Mass. Answer:Since Western Samoa does not maintain a travel office here, the likeliest sources of information are travel companies with special knowledge of the area and airlines that fly to the South Pacific. There is a government travel bureau in the territory - the address is: Department of Economic Development, Apia, Western Samoa - but getting a response from it by mail, according to some travel planners, cannot be counted on.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BLIND CORRAL. By Ralph Beer. (Viking, $16.95.) The West, as writers like Sam Shepard are quick to point out, is the West no longer. Today it is filled with shopping malls, trailer parks and yuppie bars.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 22, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis L'Amour. 4 2 (Bantam, $17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 2 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 2 9 (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 3 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. (Knopf, 1 9 $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 4 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence 6 3 Sanders. (Putnam, $18.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin reveals a New York dynasty's scandals. 5 THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest 5 4 Hemingway. (Scribners, $18.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 3 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. 4 57 (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a revision that was made in 1983. 4 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with 3 30 Sallie Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores.

title: Vezelay
description: To the Editor: Richard Bernstein's radiant account of his stopover in Vezelay provided a welcome opportunity to reexperience some of the pleasures of my own recent stay.

title: NO FADED COPY
description: XEROX American Samurai. By Gary Jacobson and John Hillkirk. 388 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95.

title: Barbara Lemmen Married To a Doctoral Candidate
description: Barbara Elizabeth Lemmen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Jerome Lemmen of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Geoffrey Nunes Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Nunes of Lincoln, Mass.

title: THE LITTLE RED BOOK AND THE BOTTOM LINE
description: AFTER THE NIGHTMARE A Survivor of the Cultural Revolution Reports on China Today. By Liang Heng and Judith Shapiro. 240 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: STOP THE PARENT WHO OFFERS ALCOHOL
description: IF we in the schools were despairing people, we might accept defeat at the hands of parents who condone alcohol parties in their homes. But so much is at stake that we have to try again to convince them to cooperate.

title: Why Colleges Need to Give Merit Scholarships
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER UNEVEN YEAR, BECKER RETURNS TO DEFEND TITLE
description: BORIS BECKER'S year after Wimbledon ends at 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon when, in keeping with tradition, the gentlemen's singles champion walks onto Centre Court to begin his defense of the title won last July. Becker is expected to make short work of Argentina's Eduardo Bengoechea, carving the first divots in a lawn any suburban homeowner would envy. As for the remainder of the tournament, however, Becker's prospects are not quite so clear.

title: Tentative Settlement in Phone Strike
description: Both sides saw last week's tentative settlement to the three-week old A.T. & T. strike as a victory, though the terms of the proposed contract are little different from those the union rejected before walking out June 1. The 155,000 members of the Communications Workers of America would receive wage and benefit increases of 10.2 percent over three years, and the company would stop subcontracting to other, often nonunion, concerns when layoffs are taking place.

title: SUPPORT GROWING TO START RIGHETTI
description: Two nights produced two games of anguish for Dave Righetti. Now, with the Yankees in need of pitching help and with a pair of horrendous performances still hanging above him, there is renewed talk of returning Righetti to the starting rotation.

title: A Bet on Bogardus
description: In ''Cast-Iron Architecture in New York,'' Margot Gayle cited James Bogardus, a 19th-century architect and inventor, as the first man to build a cast-iron building.

title: Fixing the Blame At Chernobyl
description: In the weeks following the disaster at the Chernobyl nuclear power station, the Soviet press was filled with accounts of the heroism and selflessness of the stricken plant's workforce. Last week, though, Pravda painted quite a different picture.

title: Victoria Rhodes Becomes a Bride
description: Victoria Lammot Rhodes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Anthony Rhodes Jr. of Waverly, Pa., was married yesterday to Owen David Gutfreund, a son of Joyce Low Gutfreund and John Halle Gutfreund, both of New York. Judge George Clark of Magistrate's Court in Waverly performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Capital Spending Slump - As estimates of first-quarter economic growth were revised downward last week, some economists predicted a rebound in the second half. But Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist for Morgan Stanley & Company, does not share the optimism. His reason:

title: MUSINGS ON DELIS, GROCERS OF YORE
description: I WAS standing in the express check-out aisle of a big supermarket in Eastchester. Only 10 items to a customer, the sign said, but the lane wasn't moving as fast as I had anticipated. As I was thinking that I could have baked a loaf of Irish soda bread by now, and had a nice cup of tea besides, the check-out girl yelled, ''Next, Next!''

title: THERE'S JUST NO END TO THE AREA'S STOP AND GO
description: DRIVERS were fed up with stopping every few miles on the Connecticut Turnpike to throw coins into toll baskets. Eliminate the eight toll plazas, many argued, and traffic would move both faster and more safely.

title: Why Colleges Need to Give Merit Scholarships
description: To the Editor:

title: Randolph Abood, A Lawyer, Weds Marion Markham
description: The wedding of Marion Hiscox Markham, an actress, to Randolph G. Abood, a partner in the New York law firm of Burke & Burke, took place yesterday at the Watch Hill (R.I.) Chapel. The Rev. Paul Peppin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Focus: Cleveland; High-Rise Completes 1903 Plan
description: WITH the construction of the 45-story Standard Oil Headquarters, Daniel Burnham's ambitious 1903 master plan for downtown Cleveland has finally been completed - but not in the way the 19th-century architect imagined.

title: Miss Hodes Wed To Michael Gross
description: Barbara A. Hodes and Michael Gross were married yesterday in Manhattan by Acting Supreme Court Justice Richard Lee Price at the penthouse of the Galleria, 117 East 57th Street.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SHAKESPEARE TO POP-SOUL
description: Macbeth, A Bolshoi Ballet production, featuring Alexei Fadeyechev, Nina Timofeyeva and Valeri Anisimov; music by Kirill Molchanov, 1984, Kultur, 105 minutes. $59.95.

title: CAMDEN RIVERFRONT GETTING A NEW LOOK
description: THE start of demolition of a giant warehouse here has signaled the beginning of this city's long-planned $175 million waterfront redevelopment project.

title: TONY RIVERA, LOST AT HOME
description: DREAMS OF AN AVERAGE MAN By Dyan Sheldon. 312 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $15.95.

title: Doubt on Drug Findings
description: As the police continued to reconstruct the final hours in the life of Len Bias, a deputy medical examiner today held out the possibility that traces of a drug reportedly found in the body of the Maryland basketball player might have been something other than cocaine. Dr. John Rodgers, the deputy medical officer of Prince Georges

title: SHIFT IN STRATEGY IS SOUGHT ON CITIES
description: There is so little public support for Federal aid to cities that an entire new strategy for urban renewal is needed, according to experts at a three-day conference here.

title: OOOOOH! QUEL LANGAGE! A VISIT WITH THE PORT AUTHORITY POETRY LEAGUE
description: THE rejected are in revolt. The Port Authority Poetry League, which last year published a first issue of The Port Authority Poetry Review dedicated to bad poetry, has just issued a second number in which members of the league try to write better-than-bad poetry. A tiny organization with an acronym pronounced ''papal'' putting out a journal with an acronym pronounced ''paper'' might seem a passing whim. But these bards will not be intimidated by public indifference; they are at work on a third issue of their biannual in which they will compete with Shakespeare and Racine.

title: AN AFRICAN TRIBE'S ART IS ENDANGERED
description: For decades, perhaps centuries, Ndebele women in South African villages have adorned their house fronts and town walls with bold and colorful abstract paintings. They have also translated the same distinctive graphics - crosses, diamonds, triangles, half moons, squares and rectangles - into arresting examples of beaded jewelry, clothing and hair ornaments. These tribal works, which are enthusiastically collected here and in Europe, are now threatened with destruction as a result of violence in the villages and the resettlement of Ndebele people organized by the South African government.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 85 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 85 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Walk, Do Not Run, Out of South Africa
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Thatcher balk at stern sanctions against South Africa, where even possessing the wrong T-shirt is now a crime. But Westerners clamor to dissociate themselves from the Pretorian culture. The most eloquent argument for sanctions is the spectacle of President P. W. Botha fulminating about Communism to make apartheid seem an expression of Western values. To do nothing seems only to encourage his attempts to perpetuate a racist system by criminalizing its opponents.

title: SOUTH AFRICA WITHOUT APARTHEID
description: CAUGHT between a black revolt that seems more persistent and blood-stained than ever before and the harsh state of emergency declared earlier this month by the white authorities, South Africa's business leaders found themselves in a curious position during the last few days.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JERUSALEM, JERUSALEM. By Lesley Hazleton. (Atlantic Monthly, $16.95.) When Lesley Hazleton arrived in Jerusalem she was a young woman of 20 years, innocent and in love.

title: A PHOTOGRAPHER WHO SCATTERS CLUES TO HIS SUBJECTS' PSYCHES
description: Portraiture is one of photography's mainstays, but its practice has changed drastically in the last 10 years, fueled by a dissatisfaction with the single image. Much of today's most adventuresome portrait photography is marked by experiments with new forms, involving serial imagery, multiple arrangements of pictures, and a sculptural approach to presentation. By employing these devices, some photographers aim to get at a psychological truth about the subject that they feel the single portrait cannot supply. Others seek to demonstrate that there is no truth in portraiture in any absolute sense - that appearances are by definition deceiving.

title: AN AWFUL LOT OF COFFEE - AND MUCH MORE
description: BRAZIL By Errol Lincoln Uys. 1,005 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
DOCTOR'S DAY
description: IT is 11 o'clock on a Thursday morning, and Dr. Mark H. Borkin is celebrating his birthday at work. He has already seen five patients; now he's taking a few seconds - literally - to gulp down cake presented by a nurse in his office here. The confection is made of ice cream and everyone laughs as it begins to melt and the blue letters reading ''Happy Birthday'' sag. The festivities end less than a minute later, when the next patient arrives.

title: A RESIGNATION IN PARIS RAISES QUESTIONS ABOUT THE CITY'S ARTISTIC LIFE
description: Like the character in ''Alice in Wonderland,'' I have sometimes believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast. Even so, I had trouble with the news that Dominique Bozo had submitted his resignation as director of the Musee National d'Art Moderne in Paris. If ever anyone was at the top of his particular tree, it was Mr. Bozo, who last fall was the man primarily responsible for two triumphant episodes in the cultural history of Paris. Between them, the opening of the new Picasso Museum and the reinstallation of the Musee National d'Art Moderne made Paris, once again and after 40 years, the place where it was necessary to be. How could he possibly resign, and for what reason? Admittedly, no man could direct both the Picasso Museum and the Musee National d'Art Moderne indefinitely, and it was known that Mr. Bozo wished to hand over the running of the Picasso Museum, once it was launched. In due time, the curator and art historian Pierre Georgel was appointed as his successor. At the Musee National d'Art Moderne there was, on the other hand, a great deal still to be done, and it was universally hoped among the museum profession that Mr. Bozo would stay until the task had been completed. (Both physically and administratively, the Musee National d'Art Moderne is part of the Pompidou Center.) It was known, however, that in relation both to its mission and to its potential, the museum is short of space, short of manpower and short of money.

title: Tricia Sullivan Plans To Wed in September
description: Patricia M. Sullivan, a daughter of Mrs. Edward O. Sullivan and the late Mr. Sullivan of Bedford, N.Y., plans to marry Robert G. Merrick 3d in September. He is a son of Mrs. Herbert A. Wagner of Owings Mills, Md., and Mr. Merrick Jr. of Baltimore.

title: BLAME THE BANKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Testing At Wimbledon
description: The Men's International Professional Tennis Council announced today that drug testing would take place at the Grand Slam event at Wimbledon, which begins Monday.

title: LEWIS FAILS TO WIN 3D TITLE
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 21 -

title: Kamille Kassees a Bride
description: Kamille J. Kassees, a chemist at American Testing Laboratories Inc. in Lancaster, Pa., and Craig Steven Beittel, an accountant with the Lancaster firm of Kuntz Lesher Siegrist & Martini, were married yesterday at the Lancaster (Pa.) Church of the Brethren. The Rev. J. Calvin Wenger, assisted by the Rev. Donald E. Hollinger, officiated. Mrs. Beittel is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kassees of Lancaster. Mr. Beittel is a son of Mrs. Herbert Frey of Lancaster and William Richard Beittel of Wildwood Crest, N.J. The bride and bridegroom are graduates of Elizabethtown College.

title: Mannequins
description: To the Editor:

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE WEDDING REALITY IS MORE FANTASTIC THAN THE FANTASY
description: I DUG out my childhood drawing of my ''future wedding'' the other day, the one in which I am wearing a billowing white gown and balancing a towering beehive hairdo.

title: THE REAGAN LEGACY
description: HE COMPARES HIS legacy to F.D.R.'S. and if Franklin D. Roosevelt's impact on the nation remained powerful years after his departure, Ronald Reagan believes -and numerous politicians, academics and economists agree with him - that his impact will prove just as far-reaching.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''There is so much at stake here on all sides that you don't let serious negotiations go sour just because there has been a change in the cast of characters.'' - Jane Burch, analyst, Business International, on the switch in Mexican finance ministers.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about efforts in the village of Mamaroneck to protect its harbor incorrectly identified Dolores A. Battalia. She is Supervisor of the town of Mamaroneck. The Mayor of the village is Paul J. Noto.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
Houston: Apartments Go Begging
description: IN the scramble to attract tenants in the glutted apartment market here, one complex offered an apartment full of free furniture in return for signing a year's lease. Others offered five months' free rent for a 13-month lease, free trips to Mexico and Las Vegas, microwave ovens, video recorders and free laundry service.

title: Still Another Puzzling Chapter In the AIDS Story
description: One of the first signs of the syndrome that became known as AIDS is fading. Kaposi's sarcoma, a rare cancer that usually appears on the skin, is now identified in 14 percent of AIDS diagnoses, as against 34 percent five years ago, and no one knows why.

title:
SHOULD BANKS CROSS STATE LINES?;
A THREAT TO LOW INCOME COMMUNITIES
description: BEFORE we plunge further into interstate banking, Congress should take a long look. We need to assure that a system of huge banks operating under absentee ownership will adequately serve the interests of all communities, including low and moderate income areas.

title: Cynthia Ann Crowley Becomes Bride Of Michael McClintock in Nantucket
description: Cynthia Ann Crowley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Crowley of Wayland and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Robert McClintock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George D. McClintock of Wayzata, Minn. The Rev. Lawrence J. Drennan performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Mary's Our Lady Church on Nantucket.

title: SAGA OF THE GRITTY BAYMEN, TOILERS BY THE SEA
description: Following is the preface to ''Men's Lives: The Surfmen and Baymen of the South Fork,'' a new book that tells the story of fishermen and their families on the East End from the 1600's to the present day. A review of the work appears in today's Book Review.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HEART'S DESIRE. By Gwyneth Cravens. (Knopf, $16.95.) At the beginning of Gwyneth Cravens's sad, funny, intelligent - why not just say glorious - second novel, the Hammonds of New Mexico, three generations of them, have gathered for their annual camping trip.

title: IN MARCO POLO'S FOOTSTEPS
description: Westerners who live in China are accustomed to being told how fortunate we are. But for us there is a company of foreigners still more to be envied, those who journeyed here before the Communists closed the outlying reaches of the country to the world. One has only to read the accounts of Somerset Maugham, who visited here in 1921, or of Peter Fleming, who was here in 1935, to know the beguiling possibilities of a China where travel was less hindered.

title: Adirondack Guide For All Seasons
description: IT would take a decade of summer vacations to become intimate with even a small portion of New York State's Adirondack Park, but that should not dissuade one from launching the effort. Reading Barbara McMartin's ''Discover the South Central Adirondacks'' (Backcountry Publications) would be a good way to start.

title: GYPSY MOTHS INCREASING IN NORTHEAST
description: ''Listen, it sounds like rain,'' said Peter Innes, a forester for the State Environmental Conservation Department, standing in bright sunshine in a grove of almost leafless oak trees on Cherrytown Road here.

title: STRIP SEARCHES AT ISSUE IN GIRL'S SUIT
description: That Friday night, Samantha Hodges was on her way to a ''teen disco'' at a Manhattan nightclub for what promised to be the highlight of her weekend. Instead, the 16-year-old Brooklyn girl was arrested on a criminal charge that has never been explained or supported, handcuffed behind her back, taken to a cell and strip-searched by two female Police Department employees.

title: THIS WEEK, CAUSTIC COMEDY AND JAZZ FROM MONTREAL
description: For many theatergoers, it may be cause for concern to hear that Eric Bogosian has, so to speak, cut down on his drinking. When the 33-year-old performer's one-man show ''Drinking in America'' played earlier this year at the American Place Theater in Manhattan, it won the kind of reviews that young artists buy scrapbooks for. Alone on stage for upward of 90 minutes, assisted by few props, Mr. Bogosian brought to life a gallery of American males united by addiction - to narcotics and alcohol, but also to power, money and illusory dreams. And in putting together this panorama of tattered characters - often as comic as it was caustic - Mr. Bogosian, a longtime fixture of Manhattan's downtown scene, began breaking through to new audiences.

title: REFLECTIONS ON A BOAT REVIVING THE HUDSON
description: IN June 1966 a small committee raised $167.50 and started planning to build a 100-ton wooden sailboat, a full-size replica of the 19th-century cargo sloops that had dotted the Hudson River. This year the 8,000-member Clearwater organization has a $750,000 budget.

title: 'NINE,' MUSICAL IN NEW FAIRFIELD
description: ON the evidence of assorted productions, there are two standard ways to stage ''Nine,'' the musical. One is the extravagant way, with an emphasis on embellishment.

title: Marcia Friedman Marries
description: Marcia Lynne Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Friedman of Muttontown, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Benjamin Ripka, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Ripka of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster officiated at Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadow Park in Queens.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT AND THE JOHNSON WAX BUILDINGS. By Jonathan Lipman. (Rizzoli, Cloth, $35. Paper, $19.95.) Frank Lloyd Wright's designs for the headquarters of S. C. Johnson & Son in Racine, Wis., are among the most famous in the history of architecture.

title: CITY BALLET: MARTINS'S 'HISTOIRE DU SOLDAT' SUITE
description: THE season's first performance of Peter Martins's ''Suite from Histoire du Soldat'' and debuts in two of George Balanchine's ballets made for an unusually exciting program at the New York City Ballet Friday night.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THEATER OF REBELLION
description: Today Punch and Judy may be primarily a holiday treat for children, but it wasn't always so. In THE PUNCH & JUDY SHOW: History, Tradition and Meaning (University of Georgia, $25), Robert Leach explores the origins of the traditional play that pits Punch against wife, hangman and the devil (or, as Mr. Leach puts it, the ''three prongs of social control - family, state and religion'') in the late 18th century, when the anarchy of public fairs and the cruel spectacle of public hangings were still giving birth to a true urban working-class popular culture.

title: Cold Comfort; Summer Homeless
description: Summer brings relief to New York agencies that care for the homeless. But the Partnership for the Homeless, which coordinates small neighborhood shelters in church basements and storefronts, finds summer as frustrating as winter.

title: REAGAN'S POLYPS ARE NOT CANCER, HIS DOCTOR SAYS
description: Two tiny polyps removed from President Reagan's intestine were not cancerous, his personal physician said today.

title: Copters Douse Towns In Chernobyl Vicinity
description: Helicopters have been dumping water on deserted towns near the damaged Chernobyl nuclear reactor to keep windstorms from spreading radioactive dust to surrounding farmland, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN TO HARVEST THE FRUIT OF THE GARDEN
description: WITH the arrival of summer, sitting in the shade with a cool drink tends to assume top priority in the garden. While it's nice to be able to sit back and enjoy the fruits of one's labors, the fact remains that there are tasks to be performed. Weeds continue to grow; water must be applied; deadheading will pay dividends in continued flowering, and harvesting is a must if fruits and vegetables are to be of any use.

title: ISOLATED, STRONGLY LED SECTS GROWING IN U.S.
description: Religious scholars say Americans are flocking to new ultra-fundamentalist Christian sects dominated by leaders who exercise virtually unlimited control over members' lives and thoughts.

title: BETTE MIDLER IS UP AND IN IN HOLLYWOOD
description: ''No,'' said Bette Midler, flashing her familiar, sly grin, ''I'm not going to tell you. It's the magic of movies.''

title: Kenneth Grevers Wed To Carol Russo on L.I.
description: Carol E. Russo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Russo of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth A. Grevers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. August Grevers of Chappaqua, N.Y. Msgr. Francis X. Gaeta and the Rev. John Lynch performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Queen of the Rosary Church in Bridgehampton.

title: HERR S.'S SECRET
description: BREAKING THE SILENCE By Walter Laqueur and Richard Breitman. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95. IN August 1942 an astonishing report reached London and Washington from Switzerland. A major German industrialist had disclosed during a visit to Zurich that the Nazi regime planned to slaughter the millions of Jewish men, women and children in the vast territories it controlled. Among the means being considered, the report indicated, was wholesale gassing. Like numerous subsequent reports, this news encountered disbelief among Allied officials. As Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter explained at the end of 1942 to an eyewitness from Poland who described the details of one extermination center, it was simply impossible to believe such horrendous crimes were possible. Yet even before the first report came via Switzerland, the Holocaust was well under way.

title: CASSETTE RECORDERS CAPTURE SONIC MEMENTOS OF SUMMER
description: Summer, just arrived, is the season for sound safaris. Increasingly, travelers use portable cassette recorders to supplement their cameras, and return from vacations with sonic as well as visual mementos.

title: BEYOND THE MALL, SUBURBAN POETRY
description: IT'S not easy to find poetry in the suburbs. House after house after house -clones except for siding here, an extension there.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JUNE 22, 1986
description: International Panama's 1984 election was rigged by the nation's military strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, conclusive evidence assembled by the United States shows. Reagan Administration officials said the evidence suggests that during the nation's 1984 presidential elections, General Noriega ordered the Panama Defense Force to intervene and overturn the results. [ Page 1, Column 4. ] The kin of South Africa's missing are flocking to the offices of the Detainees Parents' Support Committee with stories of late-night arrests and detentions. The Support Committee's 40 offices around the country search for those blacks who have been detained under the state of emergency declaration. [ 1:2-3. ] South Africa issued new prohibitions affecting 119 political and church groups around Cape Town, but restrictions on reporters were eased. Meanwhile, the Government also reported a ''significant decrease'' in violence. [ 10:3-6. ] At Stonehenge, the summer solstice was greeted, but rolls of barbed-wire barricades were raised to keep most people out. The barricades were erected to fend off the ''Hippies,'' a band of about 1,000 caravan wanderers who have alarmed British authorities. [ 1:1. ] Soviet negotiators have signaled a willingness to work on verification problems for long-range mobile missiles and have for the first time suggested some possible verification measures, Administration officials say. Officials said the move should be seen as another sign that the Geneva arms talks still have the potential for serious give-and-take. [ 14:1-3. ] National President Reagan attacked critics of his judicial nominations, saying their actions were politically motivated, and denounced ''partisan use of the confirmation process'' by Democratic senators. Mr. Reagan said the criticisms were aimed at qualified conservatives who failed to conform to ''liberal ideology.''

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN TO HARVEST THE FRUIT OF THE GARDEN
description: WITH the arrival of summer, sitting in the shade with a cool drink tends to assume top priority in the garden. While it's nice to be able to sit back and enjoy the fruits of one's labors, the fact remains that there are tasks to be performed. Weeds continue to grow; water must be applied; deadheading will pay dividends in continued flowering, and harvesting is a must if fruits and vegetables are to be of any use.

title: STATUE OF LIBERTY EVOKES SPECIAL PRIDE FOR ALSATIANS
description: Among the millions of people expected to be in New York for the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration will be a small, intensely proud group of Alsatians and Alsatian-Americans, who think of the statue as an extension of their own heritage.

title: 3 City Hospitals Fined by State
description: Three New York City hospitals cited for State Health Department violations - including allowing unlicensed physicians to perform operations - have been fined a total of $189,000.

title: Deportee Convicted
description: At his trial on war crimes charges in the Soviet Union last week, Fyodor D. Fedorenko attested that ''Jews were among my best friends, both in the Soviet Union and later.''

title: From Biden To Babbitt to Nunn
description: Phil Gailey's article demonstrates the inadequacies of applying conventional political wisdom - with its rigid dichotomies between left and right, liberal and conservative - to current political debate: such wisdom tends to obscure rather than illuminate today's political geography.

title: OWNING A BUSINESS, THE FRANCHISE WAY
description: ALMOST a half a million Americans have set up their own small businesses by buying a franchise. Among them are Marilyn Parkinson and Robert H. Stone.

title: Missile Defused in Vienna
description: The police defused a homemade missile aimed at the Iraqi Embassy here today 29 minutes before it was due to fire. A police spokesman said the missile, made of two tubes, each with a small grenade, plastic explosive as a propellent and a time device, was found on a wall of the Danube Canal.

title: HELP FOR SANDINISTAS: YOUNG PEOPLE FROM ABROAD
description: After 25 days in captivity in the hands of rebel guerrillas, eight young West German volunteers who came here to work with the Nicaraguan Government say their ordeal only strengthened their support for the Sandinistas.

title: MARTHA CLARKE SPEAKS THE LANGUAGE OF ILLUSION
description: In ''The Garden of Earthly Delights,'' Martha Clarke dramatized the Hieronymus Bosch triptych, just as in ''Vienna: Lusthaus,'' she dramatizes the atmosphere and character of fin de siecle Vienna. In each case, a theatergoer experiences - rather than simply watches - a performance art piece and receives emanations that are both visceral and visual. Each play lasts only 60 minutes, but is a full theatrical event, dense with voluptuous imagery. Both are haunting dreams that unify theater, dance, music and fine art. They were originally produced by Lyn Austin's Music Theater Group/Lenox Arts Center, and, in an extended engagement, ''Vienna: Lusthaus'' can now be seen at the Public Theater.

title: Ed White Retires
description: The thing that told Ed White, the San Diego Chargers ironman offensive lineman, that it was time to call it quits happened in a family softball game two weeks ago. ''I had to let my 9-year-old daughter run for me,'' said the 39-year-old White, who missed only 6 games in 17 pro seasons and started in 117 of 120 games as a Charger, appearing at left and right guard and right tackle.

title: MINIMIZING LOSSES IN A CAR ACCIDENT
description: LAST December, Ken Byrne, an account manager with Standard & Poor's, stopped at a red light in Manhasset on his way home from a last-minute shopping trip. As he waited, his car was hit in the rear by a driver who skidded on the lightly snow-covered road; when he looked around to investigate, Mr. Byrne saw a third car hit the second, which again plowed into his own vehicle.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: 3 SMALL STATES, ONE BIG WINNER - When New Hampshire, Maine and Vermont began the country's only multistate lottery in September, skeptics doubted the jackpot would ever reach the $1 million implicit in its name, Tristate Megabucks, because of the lure of the giant games in neighboring New York and Massachusetts.

title: EXPRESSIONS OF VIENNA, CIRCA 1900
description: ON JULY 3, THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART in New York will open its biggest show of the season, ''Vienna 1900: Art, Architecture & Design.'' Many of the works have been seen in two recent major exhibitions in Europe, where, to judge by the crowds and the attention in the press, they kindled a keen interest in turn-of-the-century Viennese art. Officials of the Museum of Modern Art expect that the same enthusiasm will now be stirred up in New York.

title: The Mail-Order Marriage Business
description: Lisa Belkin's article ''The Mail-Order Marriage Business'' (May 11) conveys the impression that the American men who participate in such programs are primarily losers and that the Asian women they write to are mainly poverty stricken and desperately seeking entrance into the United States. As someone who knows something about the mail-order process and is now very happily married to a former teacher from Indonesia, whom I met through correspondence, I feel that the article presented a rather unfair description of those who seek a life partner in this way. CHRISTIAN J. EILERS Sunnyside, Queens

title: MANUEL W. LEVINE
description: Manuel W. Levine, a former State Supreme Court justice, died Friday at Long Island Jewish Hospital after a brief illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: Tracey and Allison Blackfield, Sisters Plan Weddings in July and September
description: Tracey Christine Blackfield plans to marry David Edward Smith in July, and her sister, Allison Clark Blackfield, plans a September wedding to Jeffrey Allan McKinnon. The dual engagements were announced by the sisters' parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roy G. Blackfield of Darien, Conn.

title: ART IN UPSTATE NEW YORK
description: Two museums in New York's Southern Tier - one offering a glimpse of the American West and the other focusing on the works of 17th- and 19th-century European masters -are just 17 miles apart, affording visitors to the area a chance to take in both. The American West is depicted in the Rockwell Museum in Corning, which opened in 1982. The European masters can be found in the Arnot Art Museum in Elmira, founded a century ago but recently expanded by a wing that was opened last October.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SHAKESPEARE TO POP-SOUL
description: Corduroy and Other Bear Stories,CC Studios, 37 minutes. $19.95. The adaptations of three well-known children's books on this video cassette each employ a different technique and show why the Weston Woods Studio in Weston, Conn., which produced them for CC Studios, is so widely acclaimed.

title: PIANO: KAREN HUTCHINSON
description: THE pianist Karen Hutchinson's playing is characterized by an unusual combination of propulsive energy and formal clarity. On Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, Ms. Hutchinson played music by Mendelssohn, Franck, Chopin and the American composer Donald Keats.

title: Cardinal Concerns
description: While the Archbishop of New York, John Cardinal O'Connor, was occupied last week with weighty matters abroad, he was also seeking an evaluation of the job he is doing at home. His travels took him first to

title: Ralph L. Amey Is Married To Eunice Dunster Howe
description: Eunice Dunster Howe, an associate professor of art history at the University of Southern California, and Ralph Leonard Amey, an associate professor of chemistry at Occidental College, were married yesterday in Belmont, Mass. The Rev. George L. Blackman, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the chapel of the Belmont Hill School.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Where Vacant-Lot Buyers Get A Lot More
description: SUBDIVISIONS where purchasers buy vacant lots and build their own houses instead of settling for a builder's model have always occupied an important niche in the East End real estate market.

title: BETWEEN JUMPING AND DIVING
description: ONE WAY OR ANOTHER By Peter Cameron. 181 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: THE BIG IMPACT OF SMALL BUSINESS
description: The following remarks are from a recent speech by Irwin L. Kellner of Port Washington, chief economist for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, to the Nassau Council of Chambers of Commerce.

title: T.L. Palmer Wed To Miss Laidlaw
description: Christina Laidlaw, a daughter of Joanna Ziegler of Bainbridge Island, Wash., and the late David Laidlaw of Old Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy L. Palmer, a son of Glenn Palmer of Binghamton, N.Y., and the late Mrs. Palmer. The Rev. Whitney H. Burr performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass.

title: TV Shouldn't Allow Issue Commercials
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia C. Peyser Marries Tom William Perlmutter
description: Patricia Carolyn Peyser and Tom William Perlmutter, 1985 graduates of Princeton University, were married yesterday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington. Rabbi Joseph Weinberg officiated.

title: Youth Who Got 2 Hearts Dies
description: A teen-ager who underwent two heart transplants this week died early today, officials at the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh said. They said Tony Steele, 17 years old, of Cleveland, had been put on a dialysis machine Friday after his kidneys began to fail.

title: Alisa Harding Is Married To Mark A. Stein, Lawyer
description: Alisa Andrea Harding, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Harding of Madison, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Andrew Stein of Beverly, Mass., the son of Dr. Samuel Stein of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Elaine Shelnitz Stein. The ceremony was performed by Ann Wilson, Justice of the Peace of Belmont, Mass., at the Habitat Institute for the Environment in Belmont.

title: Guidelines Board Raises Rents, But Not a Rumpus
description: As meetings of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board go, last week's was unusually short and decorous: 90 minutes, compared with last year's six hours, and only one person ejected. More typically, the annual engagement in a war neither side is allowed to win still ended with both sides aggrieved.

title: INMATES SHOT AFTER GIVING UP, PERU SENATOR SAYS
description: A leading leftist politician accused the Peruvian military today of executing about 60 imprisoned guerrillas who had given up after prison riots this week.

title: ASSEMBLY RESUMING ITS MONTH OF TRAILERS TOMORROW
description: THE General Assembly, facing its third special session this month, will reconvene at the State Capitol tomorrow with differing agendas for action from Governor O'Neill and the Republican leaders of the legislature.

title: VIETNAM SCULPTURE GETS GO-AHEAD AS EFFORT ON HOLOCAUST RESUMES
description: TWO proposed memorials, one for Vietnam War veterans and the other for Holocaust victims, seized the attention of Westchester officials last week, with one taking shape and the other remaining enmeshed in administrative and artistic confusion.

title: John W. Passacantando Plans to Wed Suzanne Moyers, Teacher, in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bill Moyers of New York and Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Moyers, to John W. Passacantando, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond A. Passacantando of Whippany, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Debra J. Wattenberg Wed To Brett N. Rosen, C.P.A.
description: Debra Joy Wattenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Wattenberg of Great Neck, L.I., and North Miami Beach, Fla., and Brett Neil Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Rosen, also of Great Neck, were married last night at the Plaza Hotel by Rabbi David Kahane.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR SEEMS TO HIT STRIDE
description: After a year in which everything W. Wilson Goode tried seemed to fail, the Mayor this week regained his Midas touch.

title: BASKETS EVOCATIVE OF THE SONORA DESERT
description: In their language, the Papago Indians of southern Arizona are Tohono O'odham, the Desert People. Theirs is a wide land of dry washes and giant cactus, of bleak earth and the blue sky of the Sonora Desert. But the desert, which stretches from the mountains north of Phoenix down into Mexico, has often been called a land of deceptive barrenness, and to the Papago it yields a surprising bounty. While today most goods come to them from beyond the desert, the Papago still gather materials from the desert's dusty plains and mountains for baskets renowned for their striking designs and vivid natural colors.

title: Senate 'Courtesy' Galls Gov. Kean
description: An unwritten rule of ''senatorial courtesy'' allows New Jersey state senators to block consideration of gubernatorial appointees from their home districts without explanation. Often used behind the scenes in trading with the Governor for favors, this power of silent veto lay revealed last week in the full limelight of two high-profile appointments.

title: BUYING GROUND-FLOOR THRIFT STOCKS
description: Regulators, worried about the solvency of many depositor-owned savings banks and savings and loans, have encouraged the trend towards stock ownership for a decade. The thrift industry has raised perhaps $10 billion in equity through such conversion efforts.

title: A GOOD TIME TO ASK: WHAT DO WE MEAN BY 'LIBERTY'?
description: Americans from a broad range of professions will take part in a Liberty Weekend conference that will consider legal issues ''too important to be left to lawyers,'' according to the chairman of the two-day meeting.

title: MASPETH
description: JUST a 15-minute drive east from midtown Manhattan, Maspeth has managed to retain a friendly small-town atmosphere while offering the benefits of big city living. ''It's a little bit of the country in the city,'' said Peter N. Chahales, a 30-year resident who is considered the unofficial mayor of this Queens community just north of the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: Jennifer Sullivan Becomes a Bride
description: Jennifer Leslie Sullivan, an assistant account executive at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample Inc. in New York, and Allen Arthur Weaver, an assistant to the president of the Prudential Investment Corporation in Newark, were married yesterday at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church in Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. David Brainard Watermulder officiated.

title: North Korea Criticizes South Korea on Games
description: North Korea lashed out today at South Korea's stand in last week's talks on the 1988 Olympic Games.

title: Baltimore: Downtown Balancing Act
description: WHEN plans for this city's first air-rights office building were announced three years ago, some members of the local realty community viewed the concept skeptically as a gimmick more suitable for Manhattan. But the steel superstructure of the $30 million, 22-story Redwood Tower now hovers over a downtown Art Deco luncheonette and the developer, W. Scott Toombs, expects the 212,000-square-foot building to open next spring.

title: Susan Pruyn a Bride
description: Susan Lansing Pruyn and William Graham White were married yesterday at All Souls Church in Tannersville, N.Y., by the Rev. John C. Smith, an Episcopal priest.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Reagan's Polyps Termed Benign
description: In a brief statement, President Reagan's doctors said yesterday that the two small polyps removed from his colon Friday were benign.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE LATE, GREAT LAKES: An Environmental History. By William Ashworth. (Knopf, $17.95.) This account of ''the greatest reservoir of fresh water on earth'' is packed with geological details, observations by and about early explorers and fur traders, the origins of the giant cities that now dot the 5,000-mile coastline of the Great Lakes, the ships that sailed their waters and the metals that were mined on their coast and nearby.

title: OFFENBACH STILL BASKES IN POPULAR FAVOR
description: Poor Jacques Offenbach. All he wanted was to earn an honest living by the means he knew best - music and laughter. What he frequently got, however, was a good deal less satisfying. Although Rossini called him ''the Mozart of the Champs-Elysees,'' other estimates were not so kind. ''His music is wicked,'' wrote a waspish Bernard Shaw during his days as a London critic. ''Every accent is a snap of the fingers in the face of moral responsibility.''

title: HOW TO ENJOY THE GROWING SMALL TOWN
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago we bought a small Civil War saltbox house in a northwestern Connecticut village. It was our hope that this weekend home, nestled in this bedroom community of 1,600, would be our retreat from the pressures of life in the big city.

title: Sliver Isle Apartments
description: Ship Bottom, N.J., the center of a sliver of land known as Long Beach Island, has been popular with the summer beach crowd for many years. Every summer, from Memorial Day to Labor Day, the island's population soars as hordes of city dwellers arrive to bask in the sun and romp in the surf.

title: Miss Booher Wed In Massachusetts
description: Rynn Booher, the daughter of Jeannene Booher of New York and Otis, Mass., and Dale Booher of New York and Shelter Island Heights, N.Y., was married yesterday to Stephen Williams, a son of Nancy Hannah of Norfolk, Va., and Terence Williams of St. Paul. The Rev. David Lockhart performed the Congregational ceremony at the home of the bride's mother in Otis.

title: NEW HEART DRUG IS TESTED ON L.I.
description: FIFTY-six-year-old Dolores Cirillo of Little Neck could barely sit still in her bed by the ninth day of her hospital stay. She was up and about most of the time, rearranging her flowers or taking short strolls down the corridor.

title: GREEK ON GREEK AND EYE TO EYE
description: THE IDEA OF THE GOOD IN PLATONIC-ARISTOTELIAN PHILOSOPHY By Hans-Georg Gadamer. Translated, and with an Introduction, by P. Christopher Smith. 182 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $20.

title: Restorer Is Wed To Lisa Goodhue
description: Elizabeth Cushing Goodhue, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Thayer Goodhue of Katonah, N.Y., and Thomas Shade Cochran, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Cochran of Easton, Pa., were married yesterday in the First Church of Christ in Lancaster, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Wintle, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: Leigh W. Hamilton Weds John Rae 2d in Connecticut
description: Leigh Wilson Hamilton, the daughter of Janet H. Hamilton of Farmington, Conn., and Richard C. Hamilton of Vernon, Conn., was married yesterday to John Marshall Rae 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rae of Southport, Conn. The Rev. Richard Yerrington, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at Miss Porter's School in Farmington, Conn., from which the bride was graduated and where her mother is the alumnae director.

title: Mabeth Wilson, a Lawyer, Wed to Daniel S. Hudson
description: Mabeth MacFarland Wilson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce B. Wilson of St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday to Daniel Scott Hudson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Hudson of Woodstock, Conn. The Rev. James M. Murrey, an Episcopal deacon, officiated at the Valley Forge Military Academy Chapel in Wayne, Pa.

title: SALISBURY AWAITS 2d TOWN HALL PLAN
description: IT'S back to the drawing board in Salisbury, where voters on Monday rejected a design for a new Town Hall by a vote of 361 to 305. The architect's plan, opposed by many residents for its lack of tall columns in front, will now be redrawn to include them.

title: LIFEGUARD'S LOT IS HARDER THAN IT LOOKS
description: WHILE 15,000 daily visitors enjoy the surf, sand and atmosphere of this 2,694-acre public beach, A. Edward Kiziukiewicz Jr. coordinates the efforts of its 50 lifeguards.

title: Data Bank: June 22, 1986
