CLEMENS IS 7TH TO START AT 13-0
description: Roger Clemens became the seventh pitcher in major league history to start a season with 13 consecutive victories, giving up six hits over eight innings today as the Boston Red Sox beat the Baltimore Orioles, 7-2.

title: Nicaragua Makes Offer To Limit Some Weapons
description: The Nicaraguan Government said today that it would be willing to negotiate limits on military aircraft, ships and eight types of weapons as part of a Central America peace agreement.

title: The Rehnquist Court: a Watershed
description: President Reagan's long-expected chance to reshape the United States Supreme Court has presented itself at last, and the President has seized it in a way that signals a watershed in the history of the Court.

title: CHICAGO'S LARGEST BOOKSTORE CHAIN IS BEING TURNED OVER TO EMPLOYEES
description: Carl A. Kroch has cut back on his workload as chairman of Kroch's & Brentano's, this city's largest chain of bookstores. Now that he is approaching his 72d birthday Mr. Kroch works only five days a week. His reading appetite has declined too, down to five books every seven days.

title: EXPRESSWAY IS MAKING WAY FOR A HISTORICAL DIG
description: HIGH on a man-made plateau in Cromwell, Dr. Frederick W. Warner, an archeologist, sifted the dusty earth for evidence of American Indians who camped there 6,000 years ago. Below him, bulldozers loudly carved a new two-mile link in the Central Connecticut Expressway.

title: FRANCE BEATS BRAZIL ON PENALTY KICKS
description: In a dramatic and tense game that the grand finale may have trouble matching, France eliminated Brazil from the World Cup today, playing a 1-1 tie through regulation time and two overtime periods before outscoring Brazil on penalty kicks, 4-3.

title: Miss Curran Has Wedding
description: Catherine Adele Curran and Thomas McCarthy Souther, both graduates of the Fordham University School of Law and both associates in the law firm of Brown & Wood, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary in Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. John F. Curran, the bride's cousin, officiated, assisted by Msgr. Edward M. Connors and the Rev. William T. Wood.

title: Madhumita Basak Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Bijan K. Basak of Coudersport, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Madhumita Basak to David I. Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harley Smith of Erie, Pa. A July 21 wedding is planned in Calcutta, India.

title: Cold Comfort; Star Chamber
description: New Jersey's Constitution gives the state Senate the right to approve the Governor's appointments. By dubious tradition, the Senate's right is subject to a senator's right.

title: Unending Fight Over Westway
description: AFTER more than a decade of environmental and other wrangling over Westway, a proposed $2.3 billion highway and development project in Manhattan, Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo abandoned the plan last Sept. 19. They said they would trade in the $1.7 billion in Federal aid earmarked for Westway for other public works.

title: CIBA-GEIGY TRYING TO UPGRADE ITS IMAGE
description: CIBA-GEIGY'S plant here is in the midst of a $25 million program to improve the quality of the effluent it discharges into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Alfred D. Matt Marries Carol Conde Hamilton
description: Carol Conde Hamilton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John James Hamilton Jr. of St. Louis, was married there yesterday to Alfred Duffy Matt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Xavier Matt 2d of Utica, N.Y. The Rev. Jerome F. Wilkerson performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church.

title: LAWSUIT ACCORD ENCOURAGES CUTS IN FEES TO REALTY AGENTS
description: AN agreement reached in a 12-year-old lawsuit is expected to help reduce the commissions people selling homes pay real-estate agents.

title:
FOOD;
A PHILOSOPHY OF TASTE
description: JEAN ANTHELME BRIL-lat-Savarin, the 18th- and 19th-century gastronome, wrote in ''The Physiology of Taste'' that ''all tongues are not equally endowed.''

title: THIS IS THE WAY A WORLD ENDS
description: MEN'S LIVES The Surfmen and Baymen of the South Fork. By Peter Matthiessen. Illustrated. 339 pp. New York: Random House. $29.95.

title: SPANISH SOCIALISTS' MAJORITY AT STAKE IN VOTING TODAY
description: The Socialist Party of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez is heavily favored as Spaniards vote in parliamentary elections on Sunday.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: SOME people find it painful to say goodbye to a dollar, or even a dime. They don't enjoy themselves much except when the bank statement comes in. Other people can't wait to unload whatever cash they have. Their lives are fun and games, and let the future take care of itself. The future gives many of them a rude jolt, but that's another story.

title: Pamela Lee Parker Is Wed To Richard Arthur Schunk
description: Pamela Lee Parker, a daughter of Etta Schumann-Parker of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Lawrence Sherman Parker of Southport, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Arthur Schunk, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schunk of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev. Stephen Furrer, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Ridgefield (Conn.)

title: Rhonda M. Held, Lawyer, To Marry David P. Dupler
description: The engagement of Rhonda M. Held to David P. Dupler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irv S. Dupler of Oceanside, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Justice Gerald S. Held of the New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. Held, also of Oceanside. A Thanksgiving Day wedding is planned.

title: THE KIROV BALLET IS A COMPANY IN TRANSITION
description: The Kirov Ballet from Leningrad has come and gone. A monthlong tour took it from the opening of the Royal Bank World Festival at Expo 86 in Vancouver, Canada, through Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Trenton, Wolf Trap Farm for the Performing Arts near Washington, D.C., Montreal and Ottawa's National Arts Center.

title: TOP SECRET WEAPONS ARE DRAWING SOME FLAK
description: WHEN Representative John D. Dingell hears that a Pentagon program is ''black,'' he sees red, or so it often seems. In military parlance, a weapon is black when it is so secret that virtually every detail about it - costs, technologies, even its very existence - is kept from public view.

title: PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE BRITISH LANDSCAPE IN NEW HAVEN
description: WHEN the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven changes course, it does so in style. The exhibition of photographs now on view, an English import organized by Anthony Stokes, is the first of its kind and it is a smash. It remains through July 13.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let's be honest. The real objection to Dan Manion is that he doesn't conform to the liberal ideology of some senators.''

title: Melissa C. White Marries Timothy Ignatius Maloney
description: Melissa Constance White, the director of the art gallery section of Promenade magazine in New York, and Timothy Ignatius Maloney, an equity trader for the First Boston Corporation in New York, were married yesterday at Scarsdale (N.Y.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Donald Thiel, a Presbyterian minister, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Thomas McCaffrey, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music listing today in The Guide (section 2A) gives an incorrect schedule for the Bach Aria Festival. The concerts at the Fine Arts Center of SUNY at Stony Brook, L.I., will be presented on Wednesday, Friday and Saturday evenings at 8:30, with a young people's concert on Thursday at 7 P.M.; those at the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts, Roslyn, L.I., will be on June 29 at 1, 2:30, 4 and 7 P.M.

title: THE BECKONING GHOST
description: THE OPPOSING SHORE By Julien Gracq. Translated by Richard Howard. 292 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $19.95. AT last, 35 years after its first publication in French, Julien Gracq's major novel, ''Le Rivage des Syrtes,'' is available in English. Richard Howard's translation retains all of the novel's verbal magnificence and its full grip on the imagination.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
San Francisco: Vacant Bank To Be Arcade
description: ONE of the latest of this city's historic-structure renovation projects is the gray, seven-story former Federal Reserve Bank building at Sansome and Battery. Vacant since 1983, the building is undergoing a $17 million renovation that began last October under the auspices of the San Francisco-based architects, Kaplan McLaughlin Diaz. When finished, it will provide 155,000 square feet of space for offices and 78,000 square feet for shops, plus areas for a health club and a restaurant arcade.

title: 'RODEO' TESTS READINESS OF AIR FORCE ON GROUND AND IN AIR
description: ON A wind-swept, red-clay field here, assault troops watched anxiously as a C-130 transport appeared low over the horizon. Swirls of fine dust stung eyes and clung to clothing as the drone of the plane's engines grew louder.

title: Ford's Promising Offer on Airbags
description: It's the law: By 1990 all new cars must come equipped with automatic safety restraints. Automakers must still decide, however, whether they will comply by providing ''passive'' belts or inflatable airbags, which are more effective and more expensive. Ford now says it would choose airbags for drivers if Washington relaxes the safety-restraint rule for passengers. The Feds ought to meet Ford at least part way.

title: SOUTH AFRICA IS TESTING THE PATIENCE OF THE WEST
description: INSIDE its own borders, if nowhere else, South Africa's white-minority Government demonstrated its power and reach last week. Although restrictions on news reporting made it difficult to judge with certainty, a situation close to martial law prevailed in the country's black townships, and it appeared that the authorities had contained or at least muffled the signs of black anger, if only for the time being.

title: POLITICS SLOWING WORK ON MAJOR BILLS IN TRENTON
description: SHARP differences on major legislation between the Democratic-controlled State Senate and Republican Assembly are beginning to emerge as the two houses address some important legislation before taking their summer recess next month.

title: A Perfect View Of the Indy 500
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: OPERA: TWO ONE-ACTERS BY GOLDEN FLEECE LTD.
description: THE two new one-act operas at the Actors Outlet Theater Center Thursday night dealt heavily in nostalgia, each in its different way. Jack Gottlieb's ''Movie Opera (Prevue)'' made its way through numerous layers of film history, while ''The Island of Tomorrow,'' by Myron Fink, set its melodrama in a waiting room on Ellis Island - the year 1912. Both pieces were produced by Golden Fleece Ltd., a chamber-opera company primarily interested in new works.

title: Why Colleges Need to Give Merit Scholarships
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa M. Calicchio Wed To Donald J. Jackson
description: Lisa Mara Calicchio, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Calicchio of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Donald James Jackson, a son of Helen Jackson and the late Alfred Jackson of New York. Chief Judge David N. Edelstein of the United States District Court, Southern District of New York, performed the ceremony at the Southampton home of the bride's parents.

title: Diana Lee Weds Peter Hammond
description: Diana Lincoln Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Lee of Prouts Neck, Me., and Far Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter John Hammond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Neville Hammond of Perth, Australia. The Rev. Alfred N. Niese Jr. performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Prouts Neck.

title: HOSTILE TAKEOVERS ARE A CLEAR THREAT TO STATE'S ECONOMY
description: HOSTILE takeovers can no longer be considered an isolated issue affecting only complacent boards of directors of large corporations.

title: Getting the Goods on Those 'Nonprimary' Renters
description: IF you are a rent-regulated tenant in New York City, there is a good chance that you have been, are being or will be investigated by a new subspecies of private detective - the lease police.

title: Anne de Lain Warden Married to Blair Clark
description: The wedding of Anne de Lain Warden, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Warden of New York and Bedford, N.Y., to Blair Robert Clark, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Clark of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Colchester, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, assisted by the Rev. W. Richard Rowe.

title: Septuplet Birth: A Year Later
description: IT was the first septuplet birth in America, but for the parents, Patricia and Samuel Frustaci of Riverside, Calif., it appeared to bring as much heartache as joy.

title: Spy Saga Takes An Unusual Turn
description: Several Americans have recently stood accused of spying for the Soviet Union; last week, Government agents said they had, for a change, bagged a Russian.

title:
DINING OUT;
MIDDLE EASTERN TASTES IN NYACK
description: ONE of the cuisines the county seems to have in short supply is that of the Middle East. True, a bulgur salad or a couscous may be available here, a dolmah or a shish kebab there, but such dishes make only cameo appearances in kitchens that career along entirely different lines. However, tucked behind brick arches on Nyack's Main Street, Habebe presents the atmospheric and culinary flavors of the Middle East in its tiny restaurant that, with not much stretch of the imagination, could be in another country. The kitchen offers the food of Turkey, Iran, Morocco, Greece and the Arab World, with a nod to India, and turned out these dishes with a skill that if not entirely consistent was at least enthusiastic.

title: Senate Plan Hurts I.R.A. as an Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON BEARS DOWN ON SMOKING
description: SINCE June 1, recruits arriving at the Army base in Fort Jackson, S.C., have been told that they must abide not only by the traditional rules regulating the length of their hair and the hours they keep, but also by a new one: For the two months of their basic training, they are not allowed to smoke.

title: THE COUNT BASIE ORCHESTRA, LED BY FRANK FOSTER
description: COUNT BASIE is no longer with us, but the Count Basie Orchestra, which played on a dayliner sailing around Manhattan on the opening night of the JVC Jazz Festival, is no ghost band. Under the spirited and musicianly direction of Frank Foster - the saxophonist, composer-arranger and Basie alumnus - this band is creating vital, richly textured music in the here and now.

title: SIXTH GRADERS TAKE OVER AUF DEUTSCH
description: ''EVERYBODY will get a turn - just hang on,'' 12-year-old Marc Bala told a class of eager second graders. ''See?'' he said, encouraging a hesitant pupil. ''It's not hard.''

title: Neuschwanstein
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed reading Olivier Bernier's recent piece on the Bavarian castles of Ludwig II. (Travel, April 6). His articles are generally wonderful mental vacations for me.

title: STATE RESTUDYING COLLEGE-AID POLICIES
description: IN A SEARCH made pressing by rising tuition costs and tighter Federal purse strings, New Jersey, for the first time in a decade, is re-examining its assistance policies and programs for college students.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN CAMPING;
THE BOOM IN GADGETS AND GIMMICKS
description: AS a rule, people buy the camping basics - tents, sleeping bags, backpacks - when it is time to replace old, worn-out gear and not in response to design changes. As a result, manufacturers and retailers have come to expect fairly steady sales.

title: AIDES URGE U.S. TO WEIGH BACKUP FOR INDIAN POINT WARNING SYSTEM
description: Two members of a three-judge panel that studied safety at the Indian Point nuclear power plants have urged the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to consider requiring a backup system for the warning sirens in the region because of the sound-deadening effects of snow.

title: TV STATION AT CENTER OF PARIS STORM
description: France is a ''strange country,'' a magazine editorialist wrote recently, one where the ''march of philosophical ideas inexorably takes the form of ritual murder.''

title: Another Fix On the G.N.P.
description: ''This is one of those times,'' said Alan S. Blinder, an economist at Princeton University and at the Brookings Institution in Washington, ''when the reading of the tea leaves and readings of the fundamentals are at odds.''

title: Miss Noyer Is Married
description: Christine Elizabeth Noyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Lawrence Noyer of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Alexander Medina Seaver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Woodward Seaver of New York and Southampton, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. John Barry at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Roman Catholic Church in Southampton.

title: The Iowa Writers' Workshop
description: As a student at the Writers' Workshop in the 1950's, I went on to combine an interest in social problems with my training at Iowa.

title: AN OLD SAILOR BEDEVILED BY A CHANGING CITY
description: It appears that Walter Martin died from complications related to gentrification.

title: Books From The Times
description: ''Apple's Europe; An Uncommon Guide'' by R. W. Apple Jr., with illustrations by Mark Hampton, 264 pages, has been published by Atheneum ($14.95).

title: A Condo Instead Of a Dorm
description: WITH interest rates low and the cost of room and board at most colleges soaring faster than the rate of inflation - a 55 percent increase, on average, since 1981, according to the College Board -many parents are tempted to try to cut campus housing costs by buying a small condominium for their son or daughter.

title: PATROLS FIGHT THE CHATTAHOOCHEE'S FLOW OF ALCOHOL
description: On weekends, the languid green Chattahoochee River becomes the scene of the city's biggest summertime party, with 10,000 people stretched out in the sun and riding bank to bank in a flotilla of inner tubes and rafts.

title: Phone Company Sees End to Strike Soon
description: Negotiators for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and a union representing more than half of its workers met at six separate bargaining tables today, negotiating into the night in hopes of ending a three-week strike.

title: A 40's CLASSIC RETURNS TO BROADWAY
description: Devoted to each other and to their charities, the Brewster sisters are renowned for their thoughtfulness as they donate toys to poor children, make soup for the ill and jam for the healthy, and lavish their neighborly attentions on all who need them. This includes elderly gentlemen who are lonely and homeless. For them, the Brewsters' favorite charity is murder.

title: FATHER AND 3 CHILDREN DIE IN JERSEY CAR CRASH
description: A Jersey City man and his three children were killed yesterday afternoon when their car went out of control, spun three times, crashed into a parked car and a pole, then burst into flames, police and fire officials said.

title: TAKING ACCOUNT OF THE HIDDEN HOMELESS
description: THE new face of the homeless in New York City is that of a child. More than 10,000 children are without homes - five times as many as in 1981 - and they now make up almost half the city's homeless population.

title: BARRY HARRIS'S WRY HUMOR
description: BARRY HARRIS, who opened the JVC Jazz Festival's twilight piano concert series on Friday evening, brought a wry sense of humor to a tradition that is normally synonymous with a staid, detached gentility. Although an assured technician in many idioms, Mr. Harris is at heart an impressionist whose rich harmonies and lingering phrasing evoke the jazz equivalent of early 20th-century French salon music by way of Thelonius Monk.

title: R. G. Maier Wed To Faye White
description: Faye Marie White, a senior telecommunications analyst for the International Business Machines Corporation in White Plains, and Raymond Gustave Maier, a member of the law department of the Union Carbide Corporation in Danbury, Conn., were married yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Roland M. Jones officiated, assisted by the Rev. Richard Chapin.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN CAMPING;
CAMPGROUNDS THAT DOUBLE AS CLUBS
description: BRIAN and Lynne Marriott first stayed at campgrounds in 1983, when they drove to Florida from their home in York, Pa. They were not impressed. Rowdy behavior by other campers interrupted their sleep, and running water and a coin-operated laundry were often the extent of amenities. ''The price of a night's stay was no real indication of quality,'' said Mr. Marriott, an engineer in his early 40's.

title: TOP PREP PROSPECT DRAFTED BY RANGERS
description: Brian Leetch, the exceptional defenseman from the Avon Old Farms School in Avon, Conn., was the Rangers' first-round choice in today's National Hockey League entry draft.

title: Broadcast TV
description: It was just about two months ago, on April 20, that the Vladimir Horowitz concert from the Moscow Conservatory was brought to American television in a telecast direct from Tchaikovsky Hall. The good news of this week is that the program will be repeated Sunday morning from 9 to 11 on CBS's ''Sunday Morning'' with Charles Kuralt.

title: Miss Chafee Is the Bride Of a Lawyer
description: Georgia de Forest Chafee, the daughter of Senator and Mrs. John H. Chafee of Warwick, R.I., was married yesterday to Nicholas Nassikas 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John N. Nassikas of Dunbarton, N.H., and McLean, Va. The Rev. Alfred Warren Burns performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Greenwich, R.I., assisted by Canon Charles Martin, headmaster emeritus of St. Albans School in Washington, of which the bridegroom is an alumnus.

title: CONSUMER RATES
PRINCETON TO OFFER OUTDOOR CONCERNS
description: THE first of five free outdoor chamber-music concerts at Princeton University this summer will be presented Wednesday. Exception for one program, all will take place in the Graduate College Courtyard, beginning at 8 P.M.

title: A SCHEDULE OF LOCAL EVENTS FOR THE FOURTH
description: FIREWORKS and concerts, many of them emphasizing the theme of the State of Liberty, will entertain spectators celebrating the Fourth of July in Connecticut. Among the highlights are:

title: LISZT WEEK IN WASHINGTON
description: Franz Liszt, who died almost exactly 100 years ago, remains for many a virtual embodiment of the Romantic era. And, beginning today, scholars and musicians will meet in Washington, D.C., for a weeklong festival of concerts, lectures and master classes honoring Liszt's life and achievements.

title: John Connelly Jr. Wed To Jane E. Connerton
description: Jane Ellen Connerton, an engineer with Proto-Power Corporation in Groton, Conn., and John Humphrey Connelly Jr., an engineer with Harris Graphics Corporation in Pawcatuck, Conn., were married yesterday at St. Mary's Church in Stonington, Conn. Capt. Richard T. McCue, a Navy chaplain, officiated at the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: ISRAEL'S MIX OF RELIGION AND STATE
description: WHEN Orthodox militants burned bus shelters displaying advertisements showing women in swimsuits and secular Jews countered by daubing swastikas on synagogues, many Israeli politicians called the vandalism the isolated acts of a few fanatics.

title: PROPOSED SITE OF TRASH-BURNING PLANT ENCOUNTERS OPPOSITION
description: THE recent selection of the Port Washington sand pits as the proposed site for a North Hempstead Town resource recovery plant has already run into strong opposition from area residents.

title: PEPSICO FESTIVAL ACCENTS THEATER
description: THE two engaged couples in Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' sing in Italian, as expected, and for authenticity's sake the orchestra plays original 18th-century instruments. Nevertheless, the opera is not set in a Naples cafe, as written, but in a coffee shop somewhere in New York State.

title: NAME-DROPPING AT THE DELI
description: ''WE are an intensely label-conscious society,'' saidJeffrey Siegel, ticking off some familiar names: Jordache jeans. Gucci shoes. Sunkist oranges. ''Even Andy Boy broccoli,'' he said. ''People never bought broccoli by a name before. Brand names are all around us. They represent status and quality.''

title: Verbatim; Being Prepared
description: 'It's the largest event this Police Department has handled. We think we have explored everything; we have an obligation to be ready for any contingency.

title: ACCORD IN WRONGFUL JAILING
description: A man who was imprisoned two years for a Queens murder he did not commit has agreed to an out-of-court settlement of $450,000 from the city in return for dropping a lawsuit against the Police Department.

title: From Biden To Babbitt to Nunn
description: Phil Gailey correctly stressed the ascendancy of the Sun Belt wing of the Democratic Party in his article ''From Biden to Babbitt to Nunn'' (May 18).

title: THROWING THE BOOK AT THE BIG 8
description: ELI MASON, self-appointed champion of the nation's smaller accounting firms, rises from his desk and quickly proffers his hand to a visitor. ''Please be seated,'' he orders, simultaneously sending a secretary for coffee. After a few pleasantries, Mr. Mason charges full-speed ahead into his favorite topic: the big accounting firms are changing the profession irreparably, thereby harming thousands of small and mid-sized practices.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: In Search of the Trojan War,By Michael Wood. Illustrated. 272 pages. Facts on File. $22.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about art exhibitions in Minneapolis misidentified the catalogue editor for the show ''Tokyo: Form and Spirit'' at the Walker Art Institute. She is Mildred Freedman.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about legislative races incorrectly described Dolores A. Battalia's position on Bella S. Abzug's candidacy for the 20th Congressional seat. Mrs. Battalia, Supervisor of the town of Mamaroneck and also a candidate for the seat, said: ''Mrs. Abzug's challenging an elected woman Democrat within the district was inconsistent with her avowed feminist views of being supportive of women in office.''

title: JERSEY TOWN SHUTS BARS EARLY - AND STIRS DEBATE
description: Strobe lights flashed and music blasted as scores of sunburned people drank beer and danced into the night at D'Jais, a popular beachfront bar in this shore town.

title: Recent Sales
description: Lawrenceville $105,000 46 Trafalgar Court *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 7-year-old town-house condominium; *2*full basement, central air-conditioning, *2* $60 monthly charges; taxes $2,106. Livingston $133,000 28 Concord Drive *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old colonial; enclosed porch, 1-car *2*attached garage, attic fan; taxes $2,253. Phillipsburg $35,000 77 Brainards Street *2*5-bedroom, 2-bath, older two-family; full basement, *2*gas furnace with forced hot-air system; taxes $885. Scotch Plains $287,500 2 Brandywine Court *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old ranch; pool, central *2*vacuum system, cathedral ceiling in living room; taxes $4,752. Springfield $165,000 73 Severna Avenue *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 60-year-old colonial; natural *2*wood trim, beamed ceilings, dining room; taxes $1,994. West Orange $173,500 7 Barton Drive *2*3 -bedroom, 1-bath, 25-year-old split-level; *2*patio, new kitchen, den; taxes $3,353. OTHER AREAS Jefferson Valley, N.Y. $159,500 3841 Indian Hill Road *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 19-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in *2*kitchen, 2-car garage, walk to school, 1 acre; taxes $2,400. Litchfield, Conn. $465,000 Saw Mill Road *2*4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, restored 1759 Colonial; 6 fireplaces, *2*wide floorboards, 5.7 acres; taxes not available. Freeport, L.I. $110,000 88 Overton Street *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; *2*fireplace, porch, water view; taxes $2,000.

title: TIME THOSE SAUCES TO BE DONE WHEN PASTA'S DONE
description: THE challenge is to prepare a sauce for pasta in the amount of time it takes the pasta itself to cook. This helps keep the kitchen cool.

title: FUNKY BITS, FUNKY BITES
description: THE CULT OF INFORMATION The Folklore of Computers and the True Art of Thinking. By Theodore Roszak. 238 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $17.95.

title: JUDGE SUPPORTS SUNY STUDENTS ON VOTE REGISTRATION
description: IN a decision that could affect student voting rights statewide, students at the State University of New York in Purchase won a victory this month when a Federal judge upheld their right to ballot using a campus vote-registration address.

title: Vezelay
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to see Richard Bernstein's article on Vezelay and its Basilica of Ste.-Madeleine (Travel, May 11) one of the brightest spots of my visit to Burgundy a few years ago.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT'S June, and what will we give them? No matter who they are it is getting harder and harder to make up our minds on what they might like. We've made it through Mother's Day and Father's Day, and those are no real challenges. But there are also graduations, invitations to outdoor affairs and weddings.

title: FIVE HERBS THAT ADD SPECIAL ZEST TO THE GARDEN
description: Herbs have been steeped in magic, mystery and medicinal lore since ancient times. These days, more and more gardeners are squeezing an herb or two into the odd spot in the garden, planting them in pots for kitchen use, or going as far as turning an entire plot into a formal herb garden.

title: REVOLUTION AMONG THE FLAME TREES
description: BEACHMASTERS By Thea Astley. 185 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95. WITH nine works of fiction that preceded ''Beachmasters,'' Thea Astley achieved an awesome repute in Australia, winning the coveted Miles Franklin Award three times for novels described by critics as ''scathing visions.'' If the novels recently published here by Penguin and Viking are exemplary, the description is accurate. Miss Astley's visions of society in backwater Queensland or in the South Seas are scathing indeed. Yet they are compassionate in an oblique way, and they feature striking pages of rather heavy lyricism. The extent to which American readers will respond to her talent will depend very much on their appreciation of her idiosyncratic language and, in this novel, on the ready sympathy they bring to the subject of the rulers and the ruled in a Pacific Ocean colony.

title: PLEASANT SETTING FOR SEAFOOD
description: THE setting for Sterling Ocean House in Stamford is pretty as a summer picture: a spacious, white clapboard house near a golf course, facing well-kept greens and surrounded by trees. Inside, the main dining room is a study in Wedgwood blue and peach trim. An airy, glassed-in porch makes a second, even more inviting dining area. As a third choice, you can sit outdoors on a gracious veranda.

title: LONDON
description: Not everybody loves the place Dostoevski, appalled by the squalor of London's 19th-century slums, called it ''a Biblical symbol, some prophesy of the Apocalypse.'' And Thomas de Quincey, like so many, found the weather a bit dispiriting. ''A duller spectacle,'' he once complained, ''the earth of ours has not to show than a rainy Sunday in London.''

title: JURIES' AWARDS ARE DECLINING, ASSERT JUDGES AND LAWYERS
description: A NUMBER of Connecticut lawyers and judges say that in the past several months, and coinciding with the national debate on the high cost of insurance and tort reform, juries in civil suits have begun coming in with smaller awards or none at all.

title: BROAD SAILS AND FESTIVAL MARK STATE'S TRIBUTE TO MISS LIBERTY
description: UP to 10,000 people will be on hand in Guilford Saturday to celebrate the state's ties with the Statue of Liberty, which stands on a pedestal of Connecticut granite, and Ellis Island, from which most of the state's immigrants entered the United States.

title: Cynthia Cruice Weds David Swan Peterson
description: Cynthia Ludlow Cruice, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Seth Hopkins Cruice of Greenville, Del., and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to David Swan Peterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell V. Peterson of Fremont, Neb.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS SEARCHING FOR THE JAILED AND MISSING
description: In ones and twos they come to the dingy offices on second floor of the large gray stone building on De Villiers Street here. They are all black, and someone they know is missing.

title: A NORMAN VILLAGE AND ITS ABBEY
description: The most remarkable thing about Le Bec-Hellouin, a village in Normandy's Risle Valley (about two hours by car from Paris), is the serenity.

title: 2d Job for Rehnquist
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist probably hasn't given it much thought yet, but a collateral role he is likely to inherit if the Senate confirms him as Chief Justice of the United States is Chancellor of the Smithsonian Institution. By law, the Chief Justice is a member of the Smithsonian Regents, and, by tradition, he is elected Chancellor.

title: MORE READING (AND VIEWING) FOR SUMMERTIME PLEASURE
description: GETTING visual seems to be the theme for a growing number of book publishers, who have begun developing and marketing video cassettes.

title: Considering a 'Condop'
description: Question: I and the other tenants in my apartment building have received a preliminary offering plan for a cooperative that would also be one of three condominium units. The building's professional apartment and its commercial space, which would be held by the sponsor, would each have one share and the residential cooperative would have a share. I think this arrangement is unfair: Even if 100 percent of the tenants bought, we would all share only one vote. Has the Attorney General's office accepted any similar plans? . . ., J. W., Manhattan Answer: Yes, it has. According to David Fishlow, a spokesman for the Attorney General's office, the agency has been seeing an increasing number of plans in which the residential and commercial components are separate. One reason these plans, which are often referred to as ''condops,'' are becoming more popular is because retaining control of the commercial or professional space in a building is sometimes more profitable for the sponsor than selling the entire project as a single entity.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE RED BANNER MUTINY. By Andrew P. O'Rourke. (Bantam, Paper, $3.50.) Like Tom Clancy's best-selling ''Hunt for Red October,'' Andrew P. O'Rourke's ''Red Banner Mutiny'' considers the defection of a Soviet naval officer.

title: SOLIDARITY IS BEGINNING TO SHOW THE SIGNS OF STRAIN
description: THE resistance movement that formed around the Solidarity free labor unions five years ago is dividing and fraying under pressure of tactical successes by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's Government.

title: OPERA: 'MAGIC FLUTE' OPENS JERSEY'S JUNE FESTIVAL
description: Artur Schnabel, the pianist, once said that performing Mozart was too easy for children and too difficult for adults. Such problems are multiplied in the composer's operas - especially in ''The Magic Flute,'' which marked the opening of New Jersey's June Opera Festival here tonight.

title: SOVIET GIRL PROVES WE DID SOMETHING RIGHT
description: THE first time I saw Irina Kats the aura of her native Latvia still lingered about her. With her fine yellow hair drawn tightly into two long braids, tied with blue ribbons that matched her eyes, all she needed was an embellished pinafore to complete the image of Old World girlhood. Her manner matched that image, as she glanced about shyly and answered questions with an eagerness to please.

title: Susan O'Connell Married
description: Susan Dorothy O'Connell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. O'Connell of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Kelly Doherty, a son of Robert Doherty of Raleigh, N.C., and Mrs. Bruce Hennessy of New York. Msgr. Harrold Murray performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SHAKESPEARE TO POP-SOUL
description: Richard III, Starring Laurence Olivier, Ralph Richardson, John Gielgud, Claire Bloom; produced and directed by Mr. Olivier, 1956, Embassy Home Entertainment, 138 minutes. $39.95.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IN PRAISE OF WOLVES. By R. D. Lawrence. (Henry Holt, $16.95.) A field biologist, naturalist and the author of many books on wildlife, R. D. Lawrence uses his encounters with a captive group of wolves in Michigan's Upper Peninsula to develop his theories about the similarities between wolf and human societies; the importance of hormones in aggression, stress and recognition; and the role of predators in a habitat.

title: A Critic Rates Andre Previn
description: In his article ''Andre Previn, Back in L.A.'' (May 4), Joe Goldberg quotes a portion of a line from one of my reviews in The Los Angeles Times: ''Previn has 'proved himself a first-rate conductor of second-rate music.'

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BRIDGEPORT CELEBRATION - Elizabeth Pfriem, president and chairman of the board of the Bridgeport Post, will be the first female ringmaster in the 38-year history of the citywide Barnum Festival. Twenty events named for the circus showman and former mayor are scheduled for a 10-day period beginning Friday and culminating in a parade and fireworks at Seaside Park on July 6.

title: CENTER IN NASSAU AIDING ALCOHOLICS
description: FOR Jim, who had always considered that ''a man's basic right was a six-pack after a day's work,'' drinking was manageable, until he went to Vietnam.

title: THE EVOLUTUION OF A PIZZA PARLOR
description: THE metamorphosis of Casa Albona in Amagansett is complete. To those with long memories, it was a mecca for families with children who craved pizza and pasta. Gradually, over the decades (yes, decades), the pizza was relegated to the porch, then eliminated from the bill of fare entirely, and a somewhat tonier point of view gradually prevailed.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: VARIETY IN ENGLEWOOD - The comedian Richard Lewis will perform with the Aztec Two-Step, a folk duo, Thursday evening at the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood.

title: PARIS CACHET: INFINITE IDEAS
description: If the clothes shown here appear to exude a fascinating if somewhat excessively aggressive female newness, then turn to the ones on the folowing pages. Those fashions are inspired by everything from high Hollywood ''Busby Berkeleyism'' to English tweeds. They are touched with a certain mien of originality, yet evoke a comfortable sense of familiarity. This wide swing in points of view -- from perked-up normalcy to eye-popping propositions -- is what Paris fashion is all about.

title: Tutu Continues Peace Talks With Rival Squatter Factions
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu held another round of peace talks today between rival factions of black squatters living near Cape Town.

title: FIGHTING OVER BEER, 2 DIE IN FALL
description: Two men fighting over a spilled bottle of beer in the hallway of a Brooklyn welfare hotel plummeted 15 floors to their deaths early yesterday when the impact of their scuffle caused the lower portion of a freight elevator door to open, the police said.

title: Vezelay
description: To the Editor: I was interested to read Richard Bernstein's account of his visit to Vezelay. Several years ago my wife and I journeyed through the Burgundy region of France, mainly to indulge our keen appreciation of the ecclesiastical Romanesque style.

title: The Bloody Lesson East Timor Teaches
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: SENATE

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM SHAKESPEARE TO POP-SOUL
description: Irma la Douce, Starring Shirley MacLaine, Jack Lemmon, Lou Jacobi, Herschel Bernardi; directed by Billy Wilder, 1963, Key Video, 143 minutes. $59.98.

title: AMERICAN CITIES TAKE ON PRETORIA
description: SEVERAL days ago, the New York City Board of Estimate awarded an $8 million contract to the Eastman Kodak Company to provide high speed copiers for city agencies. It was a close call for Kodak. Although the company was the lowest bidder, it almost lost out because of business dealings half a world away. Kodak had sold film to the South African military, putting it at the mercy of a year-old New York law that allows city officials to bypass low bidders who do business in South Africa.

title: CHECKING OUT BOOKS WILL JUST GET EASIER
description: In response to a library user's despair concerning the local library card [ ''Little Library Card That Doesn't,'' Opinion Page, May 18 ] , how about the other side of the picture? When the library was renovated in 1973, an alternative to the extremely labor-intensive charge-out machine was initiated.

title: David Lee Rowe Weds Elizabeth Webb
description: The wedding of Elizabeth Sheffield Webb, the daughter of Thomas Dudley Webb of Hampton Bays, L.I., and Mrs. William Jourdan O'Brien of Quogue, L.I., to David Lee Rowe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Prentiss Eldon Rowe of Gaithersburg, Md., took place yesterday. The Rev. William Drew Dearnaley, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Westhampton Beach, L.I., home of Mrs. Henry Lewis O'Brien, the bride's stepgrandmother.

title: Panel Leaves Most Issues In Rail Strike Unresolved
description: A three-member Federal mediation panel has suggested that track maintenance employees who struck the Maine Central Railroad accept the company's offer of $26,000 in severance payments to any worker who is laid off. But the panel left most other key issues in the strike unresolved.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK;
Dayton, Ohio: The Next Picture Show
description: LIKE many other cities, this Midwestern community survived postwar suburban migration, loss of businesses and inner-city decline to discover that it no longer had any downtown movie theaters. It once had six.

title: A DUDE IN THE OUTBACK
description: When I asked the man in Cairns for the name of a dude ranch somewhere in northern Queensland, where I might have a chance to see Australian cowboys doing whatever Australian cowboys do, I got a very peculiar look indeed. It turns out that Australians don't have the phrase ''dude ranch'' in their lexicon, being rather contemptuous of the very notion of the dude, and that, in addition, the word ''cowboy'' is faintly insulting - it means, apparently, the somewhat precious youth who isn't reckoned tough enough to grapple with really mean cattle and so is detailed to look after the dairy cow on the family farm instead.

title: Seeing And Being Seen
description: NEW YORK'S MADISON AVENUE is a boulevard where men's attire is taken seriously. More quality men's-wear shops line it than perhaps any other American street, attracting a cosmopolitan clientele that truly appreciates well-tailored and stylish clothes.

title: NEED CITED FOR U.S. TESTING FOR HOSPITAL DISINFECTANTS
description: Federal officials say a significant proportion of the disinfectants approved for hospital use do not kill germs, but the Government's ability to act against the products is seriously hampered because Federal testing stopped four years ago.

title: YONKERS, COUNTY AT ODDS ON SHELTER
description: A POLITICAL struggle appeared to be developing last week between County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and Yonkers city officials over a county proposal to convert a former hospital in Yonkers into a shelter for the homeless.

title: Audubon Camp
description: To the Editor: Susan Schnur wrote an excellent article about the Audubon Camp on Hog Island, Maine (Travel April 6). It captured the flavor and spirit of the place.

title: SOURED REALTY DEAL SPAWNS ENMITY AND LAWSUIT
description: If there is one best example of how sour a real-estate deal can go in New York City, it is probably on West 44th Street in Manhattan, where four buildings were partly demolished on a cold January night last year.

title: Man Killed by L.I.R.R. Train
description: A man who was sitting on Long Island Rail Road tracks was struck and killed by an eastbound train here early today, the Suffolk County police said. The unidentified man, described as white, 20 to 25 years old and weighing 150 pounds, was hit about 3 A.M. by the train.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE FIRES BURN ON IN MILLVILLE, WHERE GLASS LETS IN LIGHT
description: Down in southern New Jersey, they make glass. By day and by night, the fires burn on in Millville and bid the sand let in the light. - CARL SANDBURG In the Pine Barrens, where glassmaking has enjoyed a long and rich history, the light Sandburg referred to shines with undiminished brilliance at the historic Wheaton Village Museum of American Glass here.

title: On Language; Invasion of the Arbs
description: THE ARBS ARE MOV-ing in. No, I am not using a clipped version of ''labor arbitrators,'' nor trying to pronounce ''Arabs'' in a single syllable, nor clandestinely using the acronym for Angle Rate Bombing System.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: FOR THE FOURTH: BIG BOOMS AND BIG SHIPS
description: A HOST of Fourth of July activities are planned over several days on Long Island, including tributes to the Statue of Liberty's 100th birthday. Events will range from a poetry reading devoted to the theme of liberty, to welcoming tall ships from abroad in Huntington Bay and Oyster Bay, to fireworks by the Gruccis.

title: 2 Die in Jersey Plane Crash
description: Two people died last night when their single-engine plane crashed in Evesham Township, N.J., about seven miles east of Camden, authorities reported.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SPECTATOR. By Rachel Salazar. (Fiction Collective, Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95.) Written in the form of vivid, deceptively simple vignettes, this intriguing first novel contains a house of mirrors: we watch the narrator watch the main character, Mara, who watches herself being watched by her husband, Rafael, a talented Mexican painter.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing on June 8 of New York City food establishments cited for health code violations carried an erroneous name provided by the Department of Health. The restaurant cited by the department was the Crab House of Douglaston Manor in Queens, not the Waterfront Crab House.

title: 'GENERAL MUSIC DIRECTOR OF EUROPE'
description: HERBERT VON KARAJAN A Biographical Portrait. By Roger Vaughan. 274 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: Miss Ucko Weds Michael Gumport
description: Pamela G. Ucko, the daughter of Dr. Gisela H. Ucko of Glen Rock, N.J., and Dr. Felix A. Ucko of Caldwell, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael A. Gumport, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephan Gumport of New York and Shelter Island, N.Y. Mayor Sam Spina of West Orange, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Essex County Country Club in West Orange.

title: Sex Harrassment On the Job Is Ruled Illegal
description: Sexual harassment may be hard to prove in court, but the nation's highest tribunal held last week that Federal law entitles a woman to try.

title: STERN'S TO REPLACE GIMBELS STORE AS ANCHOR OF CROSS COUNTY CENTER
description: GIMBELS's only department store in Westchester, the major anchor store in the Cross County Shopping Center in Yonkers, will cease business in August after more than 30 years. But the announcement last week, anticipated by the nervous staff for several months, was not without its strong element of irony. The store was the most profitable of all the eight Gimbels's suburban stores in the New York City area.

title: A New Manager For Mexico's Debt
description: There will be a new hand holding Mexico's hat as it tries to resolve its latest debt crisis. The powerful Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, lost his portfolio last week in a suprising shuffle. He was replaced by Gustavo Petricioli, head of the state-owned Nacional Financiera development bank.

title: TOPICS
description: I'VE always looked forward to saying goodbye to the discomforts of the hay-fever season just as the birds ceased their warbling to gather on my back fence each fall and cackle on about their flight plans southward.

title: GOLDEN STATE NAMES 2
description: Jack McMahon has been named director of player personnel and assistant coach of the Golden State Warriors and Herman Kull has also been appointed an assistant coach with the team.

title: DART & KRAFT GO SEPARATE WAYS
description: Dart & Kraft is undoing the merger that created it six years ago. The successful Kraft Foods and Duracell operations will form Kraft Inc.; the not-so-stellar Tupperware, West Bend, Hobart and Wilsonart units will form an as-yet-unnamed company. The move is viewed as a way to free the high-performers from any drag on earnings, while giving the less robust units a chance to prove their worth. Dart & Kraft's chairman, John M. Richman, will head the Kraft company; Warren L. Batts, the president, will be chairman of the other company. Some Dart managers have also expressed interest in a leveraged buyout of some operations.

title: Donald J. Hoffman Is Wed To Miss Guzek, a Designer
description: Alexandra Guzek, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thadeus Guzek of Jersey City, was married yesterday to Donald James Hoffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hoffman of Jersey City. M. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony in the ballroom at 24 Fifth Avenue.

title: Gunslinger Spur Wins Triple Crown First Leg
description: Richard Stillings, who trains and drives Gunslinger Spur, wanted the rail in the 32d annual Yonkers Trot, first leg of the triple crown for trotting, tonight. The Washington, Pa., driver got his wish and took the 3-year-old wire to wire to win in 2 minutes 2 seconds.

title: Why Colleges Need to Give Merit Scholarships
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW-AGE MUSIC SEARCHES FOR ITS PROPER NICHE
description: The proliferation of so-called ''new-age'' music into our record stores, our radio stations and our national consciousness poses a categorical confusion and an esthetic dilemma. The confusion has to do with just what this lulling, restful stuff actually is - new? old? interesting? boring? sincere? exploitive? - and where it should be filed in record stores, record catalogues and home collections. The esthetic dilemma is how one establishes any convincing critical standards for a music whose seeming purpose is to call as little attention to itself as possible.

title: 'SUSPICIOUS DEATH' FOR A RISING STAR
description: Early last week, Len Bias, a 22-year-old All-America forward for the University of Maryland and the Atlantic Coast Conference's Player of the Year, was the Boston Celtic's No. 1 pick in the National Basketball Association draft. Mr. Bias, who said he had long dreamed of playing for the N.B.A. champions, was to have joined several members of the Massachusetts Congressional delegation for lunch at the White House this week. But Thursday morning, Mr. Bias collapsed in his dormitory room in College Park, Md., and was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital.

title: Greek Denies Giving Passport To an Achille Lauro Hijacker
description: A Greek accused in Italy of giving his passport to one of the Palestinians who later hijacked the Achille Lauro has denied any involvement in the seizure of the cruise ship, an Athens newspaper has reported.

title: 'BOYS NEXT DOOR' AT THE McCARTER
description: DURING the first act of ''The Boys Next Door,'' the audience can be heard laughing almost continually. In a casual comedy, those sounds ought to be welcomed, not wondered about.

title: ATTACKING THE BACKUP IN BOSTON HARBOR
description: AT the New England Aquarium, visitors can see re-creations of coral reefs, tidal wetlands, the Amazon River and other underwater habitats. One of the more striking exhibits is a tank that represents Boston Harbor. It is littered with shoe soles, discarded bottles and rusty metal. But the first thing the eye settles on amid the murk is a sewage pipe.

title: NEW YORKER IS FIRST WOMAN TO LEAD BIG BROTHERS
description: A woman will lead the national Big Brothers organization for the first time since the group began helping fatherless boys by matching them with caring adults 82 years ago.

title: BACK HOME IN MONTANA
description: It started a few years ago as a simple vacation, one of those routine, relaxing journeys away from home designed to dip into another region for a few days of sightseeing, idle thought and irrational spending. But it was to become, almost accidentally over time, the methodical, complex creation of another life, with its own set of interests, priorities, friends and physical and emotional furnishings.

title: ENDURING LESSONS FROM THE 60'S
description: Like Kenneth Marion, I too am a child of the 60's who has grown into a suburban professional, raising children and enjoying the many pleasures of a once-scorned affluence [ ''A Former Student Activist Runs Up the Flag,'' Opinion Page, May 25 ] . My husband and I also want our children to appreciate our good fortune in living in America, and frequently speak with them about the meaning of living in a free society, as Mr. Marion has done with his children.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
WHY THER AREN'T MORE BLACKS PLAYING TENNIS
description: NEXT to ''What is John McEnroe really like?'' the question I am most often asked is ''Why aren't there more blacks in tennis?''

title: Senna Wins Pole Spot For Detroit Grand Prix
description: Ayrton Senna of Brazil bumped Nigel Mansell of England off the pole today in capturing the top position for Sunday's Detroit Grand Prix Formula One race.

title: Capitol Hill Jive
description: Popular culture often seeps into the political realm. ''Where's the beef?,'' the hamburger slogan, became the rallying cry of Walter F. Mondale when he sought to counter Senator Gary Hart's ''new ideas'' campaign in the 1984 primaries.

title: NO ANCIENTS IN STONEHENGE AT THE SOLSTICE
description: Stonehenge seemed even more inexplicable today with rolls of barbed-wire barricades up to keep the practicing Druids and everyone else from entry on a sunny summer solstice.

title: Picking on Flowers
description: To the Editor:

title: W. Germany Routs Mexico in Shootout
description: Harald Schumacher, the West German goalkeeper, stopped a pair of penalty kicks in a shootout and none of his teammates missed as West Germany moved into the World Cup semifinals with a 4-1 victory over Mexico today.

title: Janet M. Burke Plans to Marry John F. Connor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Churchill Burke of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Marie Burke, to John Farrell Connor, the son of Mrs. Frank Philip Connor of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Connor. A September wedding is planned.

title: One Killed by Police In New Punjab Unrest
description: One person was killed and eight others were wounded today when security forces opened fire to disperse angry crowds in the Punjab, the authorities said.

title: RAIDED, GRADED AND UPBRAIDED
description: THE BIG BOYS Power and Position in American Business. By Ralph Nader and William Taylor. 571 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.

title: PLUGGING IN THE OUTDOORS: HOW TO INSTALL OUTSIDE WIRING
description: AS MORE and more homeowners enjoy outdoor dining and entertaining during warm months, many find they need a source of electricity near the patio or terrace for lights, radios, barbecues or other equipment.

title: ANOTHER SIDE OF ELLA FITZGERALD
description: ELLA FITZGERALD, who sang at the first Newport Jazz Festival in 1954, opened this year's edition of the festival - now called the JVC Jazz Festival - at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening with a program that tried to respond to complaints that she always sings ''the same old songs.'' But she still provided listeners with what they had come to hear.

title: Carol Billerbeck Weds T.M. Kane
description: Carol Enid Billerbeck, a network buyer for the advertising agency Jordan, Case, Taylor & McGrath Inc. in New York, and Thomas Michael Kane, an institutional sales trader for Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church at Shrewsbury (N.J.) The Rev. David P. Muyskens officiated.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN CAMPING;
TRYING TO WOO RETIRED 'SNOWBIRDS'
description: WHEN Allen Martin retired from his home furnishings business in Milwaukee three years ago, he and his wife, Gladys, did something they had dreamed of for years. They sold their house, gave most of their worldly goods to their children, and hit the road in their motor home. After two and a half years of following the seasons from Maine to San Diego - and staying in 74 campgrounds along the way - the Martins, both 66 years old, could not be happier. ''It is just the greatest life,'' Mrs. Martin said.

title: AT HOME IN A MANOR IN PORTUGAL
description: The quinta, or manor house, of Sao Thiago is perched on the side of Sintra Mountain and the road to it is perilous, with deep rocky ruts, sharp curves and slippery descents that are best tackled on mule or by jeep. Even local taxi drivers, adept at alpine exercises, sometimes refuse to go or demand extra money for the trip.

title: Canker Feared Again In Florida Citrus Groves
description: A diseased tree found in a commercial citrus grove in southeast Florida has raised fears among agricultural officials of a new outbreak of citrus canker that could cripple the state's $4.3 billion annual citrus industry.

title: Nynex in Pact for Tel-Optik
description: The Nynex Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Tel-Optik Ltd. for $10 million, making Nynex a joint partner in a $600 million project to develop the first privately financed trans-Atlantic telephone cable system.

title: TAX BILL AND MUNICIPAL BONDS
description: As the Senate prepares for a vote Tuesday on the tax overhaul package, lobbyists are busy on the other side of Capitol Hill trying to block proposed changes in the use and tax treatment of municipal bonds.

title: KINER'S STYLE CORNERS THE MET MARKET
description: THE rain was still falling outside a nearly deserted Shea Stadium last Thursday night two hours after the Mets' game against the Chicago Cubs had been postponed. But as Ralph Kiner approached his car, two children ran toward him, asking for autographs.

title: MARCOS BACKERS ARE ROUTED
description: Anti-riot forces fired pistols, tear gas and water cannons at stone-throwing demonstrators who had gathered in front of a suburban army camp today, shouting their support of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile.

title: Henry Trevor Is Married To Elizabeth Amy Werter
description: Elizabeth Amy Werter, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howard D. Werter of Sands Point, L.I., and Henry Rumbough Trevor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. H. Trevor of New York and Nissequogue, L.I., were married yesterday at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel. Cantor Richard Berman officiated.

title: Esther Elkin Is Married
description: Esther Sheila Elkin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Elkin of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Mark Edward Mildner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Mildner of Yonkers. Rabbi Solomon W. Sternstein performed the ceremony at the Lincoln Park Jewish Center in Yonkers. Mrs. Mildner is a lawyer in the finance division of the law department of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Mr. Mildner is a certified public account for Coopers & Lybrand, an accounting concern in New York.

title: Westinghouse Officer Heads Automation Unit
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation's robotics operations have been struggling, just as have those of its competitors in a field that has not lived up to its early promise. Last week, Westinghouse reorganized its unit and put in charge John B. Yasinsky, who has worked a good deal of his time in Westinghouse's nuclear energy activities.

title: LEGAL CURRENCY FOR SALE, NOT CHEAP
description: For the serious investor, the Bureau of Engraving and Printing has an offer that might just be possible to pass up.

title: ROCK: THE REPLACEMENTS, A LIVELY NIGHT AT THE RITZ
description: ROCK often flirts with anarchy, puncturing pop-song structures with improvisation and noise. But few bands revel in anarchy like the Replacements, whose Saturday night show at the Ritz was a free-for-all on both sides of the spotlight.

title: NEW CHECK PLANNED ON UNUSUAL DEATHS IN CYANIDE INQUIRY
description: King County medical officials said today that they would review unusual deaths since January as part of the investigation into two deaths caused by Extra-Strength Excedrin capsules contaminated with cyanide.

title: BRAZILIAN TAKES DETROIT GRAND PRIX
description: Ayrton Senna, a 26-year-old Brazilian driving for the British Lotus team, overcame an early problem with tires today and convincingly won the fifth Detroit Grand Prix Formula One auto race.

title: 'LIBERTY,' A GLIMPSE OF HISTORY
description: PERHAPS, as the promoters are no doubt praying, elaborate preparations to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Statue of Liberty will whip up their own momentum and triumph over the general inertia that is traditional during the summer doldrums. That strategy, plus the fact that the competition on the other networks consists entirely of reruns, might win respectable ratings for ''Liberty,'' a Robert Greenwald production being unveiled on Channel 4 at 8 this evening. But no amount of hoopla and bluster can turn this three-hour television movie into anything more than an old-fashioned fizzle.

title: FOR WHITES, JUST ANOTHER WEEKEND
description: Smoke curled up from the white-hot charcoal fire grilling plump chickens and sausages lathered in red barbeque sauce. A clump of white men and women in their 20's warmed their hands over the grill. By the small pool, another cluster of guests talked excitedly about dipping real-estate prices.

title: Market Place; Hopeful Signs For Airlines
description: THE airline industry, plagued by intense fare wars and expansion of capacity that is running higher than traffic growth, had the worst first quarter in its history in 1986 in terms of operating losses.

title: Andrea E. Glanz Married To James H. Irish, Lawyer
description: Andrea Elise Glanz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan N. Glanz of Oceanside, L.I., was married yesterday to James Henry Irish, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elwood A. Irish of Yonkers. Betty Weinberg Ellerin, Associate Justice of the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, officiated at the ceremony in the garden of the Swan Club in Glenwood Landing, L.I.

title: Senate Tax Plan Can Increase Low-Income Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Tight Finish In Grand Prix
description: Doc Bundy withstood a frantic last-lap challenge to nip Darin Brassfield by 0.393 seconds as the inaugural Grand Prix of Palm Beach was capped today by the third-closest finish in International Motor Sports Association history.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Rosenfeld and Ally Get Health Care Accounts
description: The health care industry came though last week with new-product assignments for both Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey and Ally & Gargano/MCA Advertising.

title: Dispute Over Man's Death
description: Michael Reid, a 28-year-old prisoner who complained of pains in his arms and legs, died of a heart attack Saturday after waiting in a police wagon for 80 minutes outside the emergency room at D.C. General Hospital. Sgt. Joseph Gentile said the hospital had told the police Mr. Reid would have to wait because the emergency room was crowded. A hospital spokesman said it was never told that a sick man was waiting.

title: Two Founders Quit At Entre Computer
description: Steven B. Heller and James J. Edgette, who founded Entre Computer Centers Inc. in 1981 and saw it grow to a 250-store chain, have resigned as company officers in an apparent move to replace entrepreneurial skills with more traditional management.

title: ROCKLAND TOWN GETS CAUGHT IN A TELEPHONE BORDER WAR
description: Ethel Wishnia-Liss knew something was wrong last October when a caller asked if she was sitting down.

title: World Bank, Conable and Brazil
description: Barber B. Conable Jr., the former Republican Congressman who will become the seventh president of the World Bank on July 1, continues receiving advice from well-wishers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SPORTS PHOTOS Sports is a year-round thing, but there is something special about this time of year, when the call of the ballpark is heard far beyond the bleachers. It is also a season that brings into New York galleries the art of photographers who have chosen athletes as their subjects.

title: Setting Some Standards For Dating Services
description: Everything about the prospective date seemed right to the Queens resident. But there was a catch. The candidate picked by the dating service lived in Buffalo.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about savings bank life insurance misstated the home cities for the East River Savings Bank and the Goldome Federal Savings Bank. East River's main offices are in New York and Goldome's are in Buffalo.

title: 12,000 MEN AND A WOMAN: U.S. ARTIST'S SAUDI ROLE
description: Sheila Hicks, an internationally recognized artist and weaver, spent more than two years commuting from her New York and Paris studios to the Saudi Arabian desert, where she directed a team that selected, designed and commissioned 56 large artworks for an enormous new university.

title: A Conch Shell Tribute To Year's Longest Day
description: Many took advantage of the year's longest day by flipping an extra burger for the evening meal or watching a Frisbee soar in the lingering light. But a few diehards celebrated the beginning of summer at the beginning.

title: ELLIS LARKINS PLAYS THE BLUES
description: THE pianist Ellis Larkins played a full hour of elegantly bluesy standards Saturday evening at the Bruno Walter Auditorium at Lincoln Center - a long set for one of jazz's most famous miniaturists, but one that never failed to sparkle.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1986
description: International Spain's Socialists won in national elections, according to official preliminary returns. According to the Interior Ministry, the Socialist Party of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez will have a slightly reduced majority in Parliament, but it decisively turned back a spectrum of rightist, leftist and centrist parties that challenged it. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: North Koreans Reject Games Bid
description: A top North Korean sports official has rejected an offer to hold two events of the 1988 Olympics in North Korea, and has renewed the demand that North Korea act as co-host at the Games, the North Korean press agency reported today.

title: William J. Scott Dies; Ex-Official in Illinois
description: William J. Scott, who served as Illinois Attorney General for 12 years until he was convicted of tax fraud, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: QUESTIONS PERSIST AS BIAS IS MOURNED
description: For more than three hours this afternoon, the people who knew him long before he achieved greatness on the basketball court, as well as many who never met him once he did, said goodbye to Len Bias.

title: Hill, Holliday Turns Tables on the British
description: Yes, children, it is still possible for an American ad agency to acquire a British one, and Jack Connors, Boston's gift to international advertising, did it.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Motors Corp., Detroit, named Edward Lumley, former Canadian Trade Minister, to its board.

title: Peter Letsou, Lawyer, Weds Felicity Harper
description: Felicity Harper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Harper of New York and Locust, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter V. Letsou of Lowell, Mass., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Vasilios G. Letsou of Lowell. The Rev. Harry R. Sorensen performed the Episcopal ceremony at the All Saints Memorial Church in Navesink, N.J.

title:
ADVERTISING;
People
description: * John H. Glorieux and Tim M. Pollak have been promoted to executive vice president and Christine E. Jones Lawrence to senior vice president of Young & Rubicam, New York.

title: Let Ellis I. Mark U.S. Maritime Heritage
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; Rethinking Export Curbs
description: THE Reagan Administration, weighing a new step to improve the way the Government approves sensitive exports, has scheduled a meeting with business representatives today on easing the extra-territorial reach of American export controls.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: CATCHING UP
description: * When it comes to giving the fans some familiar names to buzz about, no other minor league team can match the San Jose Bees, who added yet another former big-leaguer to the roster last week. He's Todd Cruz, a 30-year-old infielder who became the 10th veteran of major league ball to sign with the unaffiliated Class A Bees this year.

title: Popular Science Shift
description: Grant Burnett, 48, with Times Mirror's Popular Science magazine six months, has been promoted to publisher, from advertising director. He replaces Terence Moyes, who left the company. Mr. Burnett formerly worked for Newsweek and Mechanix Illustrated at CBS Publications.

title: NORFOLK MOVING TO CUT SCHOOL BUSING
description: When Sarah Bell picked up her newspaper last Tuesday morning, she was relieved to learn that the United States Supreme Court would not block a reduction in busing to achieve racial balance in city schools.

title: Steven Rattner Weds Maureen White
description: Patricia Maureen White, an assistant vice president at the First Boston Corporation in New York, and Steven Lawrence Rattner, a principal in Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. Msgr. Timothy MacDonald and Cantor Robert Block officiated.

title: HAITI'S NEW OPPRESSORS: DISORDER AND INDECISION
description: Four months after the collapse of the Duvalier dictatorship, Haiti is in such a state of disorder and confusion that no one can predict what will happen next.

title: Advertising; Stability Is Stressed By W.R.G.
description: IT was announced by Wells, Rich, Greene at a news conference Friday that Gardner Advertising, its St. Louis subsidiary, had established a seven-person office of the president.

title: BLUE JAYS ROUT YANKEES; JOHNSON IS PLEASED BY PITCHER'S CONTROL
description: ''That's the Darling I love,'' said a relaxed Davey Johnson yesterday, without even one twitch in his brush mustache.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. RED SOX, at Boston, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: Police Kill Sikh Leader At Checkpoint in Punjab
description: The police shot dead a chief of a Sikh association in the city of Amritsar today as Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's yearlong effort to bring peace to the Punjab appeared close to collapse.

title: Yakity Yak Animals Coming From Hasbro
description: If you are the parent of a little one who perhaps does not talk enough, Hasbro has something for you: a new pair of talking stuffed animals, each with a vocabulary of 400 words.

title: Correction Officer Dies As Friend Is Wounded
description: A 39-year-old New York City corrections officer was fatally shot in the head yesterday and his 23-year-old girlfriend was shot in the mouth with the officer's service revolver in what police described as an apparent suicide and an attempted murder.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Democracy today has taken a new step forward. Spain enters a new phase.

title: PANAMA GENERAL ACCUSED BY HELMS
description: Senator Jesse Helms said today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the army commander and strongman of Panama, was ''head of the biggest drug trafficking operation in the Western Hemisphere.''

title: Reports of Progress on AIDS Expected at Meeting in Paris
description: The second International AIDS Congress opens here Monday, and more than 2,000 people have registered, including 600 Americans.

title: RIGHTS LAWS OFFER ONLY LIMITED HELP ON AIDS, U.S. RULES
description: Federal civil rights laws provide some protection to AIDS victims, but employers and public health officials who believe they are preventing the spread of the fatal disease may discriminate against people afflicted with it, the Justice Department has ruled.

title: Liberty Rent-a-View
description: To the Editor:

title: BELGIUM WINS IN SHOOTOUT, 5-4
description: Belgium, letting youthful shooters and a veteran goalkeeper lead the way, scored its second big upset of the World Cup today.

title: Jacqueline Hallo Weds D. A. Bunis
description: Jacqueline Louise Hallo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Hallo of New Haven, and David Allen Bunis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Bunis of Maplewood, N.J., were married yesterday in Congregation Mishkan Israel in Hamden, Conn. Rabbi Mark J. Panoff, Rabbi Robert E. Goldburg and Rabbi Alexander M. Shapiro officiated.

title: ORIOLES THWART RED SOX, 4-0
description: Storm Davis and Don Aase combined on a three-hitter, and John Shelby drove in three runs with three hits today as the the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Boston Red Sox, 4-0.

title: SHRINKAGE OF DEFICIT AWAITED
description: The decline in the Federal budget deficit, a trend that the Reagan Administration, Congress and private economists saw in the cards for this year, has not shown up. It should, they say - maybe in a month or two, maybe next year - but so far expectations are running ahead of the evidence.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Doyle Graf Chosen
description: Doyle Graf Mabley should be in high spirits, thanks to the assignment by the Kobrand Corporation of several alcoholic beverage brands. Besides some new products that will particularly interest the affluent market, there is Taittinger Champagne, Maison Louis Jadot Burgundy and Bouvet Brut sparkling wine. The last agency that did ads for them was Jordan, Case, Taylor & McGrath.

title: Ammirati & Puris Wins Fidelity Investments
description: Ammirati & Puris, which a week ago split with the Oppenheimer Fund Group, said yesterday it had won the Fidelity Investments account.

title: MILES DAVIS AND SPYRO GYRA
description: THE pairing of the Miles Davis Band and Spyro Gyra on a double bill at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday evening offered an instructive contrast in contemporary jazz-fusion styles. Both groups use Latin pop-funk rhythms as the rhythmic foundation of a majority of their music. Yet the two bands remain almost diametrically opposite in fundamental ways.

title: A PHONE UPHEAVAL IN EUROPE
description: A. C. Stark Jr. follows the news from Paris closely these days.

title: Ketchum Assignment
description: Ketchum Communications has won some $10 million in new billings from E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company following an agency review. The client was seeking advertising, public relations and promotion support for an array of industrial products in the optical disk and hybrid microcircuit area, including such products as Riston, Prylux and Kapon film. Du Pont is consolidating the work that had been at seven advertising and public relations firms.

title: FROM BOP TO POP ON PIANO
description: THE ''Piano Spectacular'' produced by the New Jersey Jazz Society on Saturday afternoon and evening at Waterloo Village, near Stanhope, N.J., as part of the JVC Jazz Festival not only ranged stylistically from Joanne Brackeen's muscular be-bop to Art Hodes's beautifully honed reflections on well-worn themes but also branched out to instruments other than pianos, although they were always present.

title: ENGLAND IS ELIMINATED BY ARGENTINA, 2-1
description: Diego Armando Maradona pushed Argentina into the semifinals of the World Cup this afternoon by displaying his brilliance and confirming the claims of his followers that he is the world's best soccer player.

title: PROCLAIM LIBERTY
description: Washington has a historic anniversary compulsion and is never embarrassed to engage in small sub-observances of somebody else's celebration. Thus, as July 4 approaches, the capital is breaking out in salutes to the 100th birthday of the State of Liberty.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch on the front page yesterday about benign polyps removed from President Reagan's intestine Friday misstated the size of the cancerous polyp removed last July. That polyp was five centimeters at its largest point, or about two inches, while the benign polyps removed Friday were one to one-and-a-half millimeters in size, or about one twenty-fifth to one seventeenth of an inch.

title: Youth Held on L.I. In Air Gun Attack
description: A 15-year-old boy was arrested and charged with second-degree assault today in the shooting of a motorist with a pellet gun on Thursday, the police said.

title: A PLACE FOR LADY LIBERTY'S SOUVENIRS
description: Diana Pardue was rummaging through a cardboard box, quite sure that this was it. Triumphantly she pulled out the treasure and held it up - a very large, green piece of copper with swirls on it.

title: Jennifer O'Brien Is a Bride
description: Jennifer Sarah O'Brien, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. O'Brien Jr. of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Timothy Landers, a son of Dr. David Landers of Teaneck, N.J., and the late Patricia Landers. The Rev. David Hegg performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown. Mrs. Landers is a public relations assistant at Tiffany & Company. Mr. Landers is an institutional salesman at Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: OFFICER SHOT AS YOUTHS BRAWL AT DENVER STREET FAIR
description: A police officer was shot Saturday night during a street festival held by the Denver black community, and stone-throwing youths prevented his rescue until officers dispersed the crowd with tear gas.

title: CHINESE CREW IS FIRST IN DRAGON BOATS
description: China, to no one's surprise, captured first place today - for its fifth consecutive victory - in the 11th annual Hong Kong international dragon boat races. But to everyone's surprise, the False Creek Canoe Club of Vancouver, British Columbia, placed second.

title: FREGOSI TAKES CHICAGO HELM
description: Saying there is enough time and talent to get the Chicago White Sox into the running in the American League West, Jim Fregosi took over today as the club's manager.

title: HOROWITZ TRIES AGAIN FOR TOUGH TOKYO CRITICS
description: Three years ago, when Vladimir Horowitz last appeared here, his audiences seemed to adore him, cheering with an abandon that was most un-Japanese. Then came the reviews. They were merciless. ''Miserable,'' said Hisatsugu Shimizu, an editor of a prominent music magazine.

title: IN SUFFOLK, STEPS TO PROTECT L.I.'S LAST WILD AREAS
description: After years of debate, Suffolk County officials are preparing to spend tens of millions of dollars for purchases that would protect Long Island's last great wilderness areas, including an ecological oddity existing nowhere in the world outside the northeastern United States.

title: AGENCY FAULTED BECAUSE IT KEPT OVERPAID FINES
description: The city's Environmental Control Board has acted unethically in failing to reimburse more than $2.2 million to people who overpaid fines for health and pollution violations, according to a preliminary report by the City Department of Investigation.

title: 2 STATES AGREE TO SHARE LIBERTY-ELLIS REVENUES
