description: Governors Cuomo and Kean have agreed to divide the sales-tax revenue from concessions on Ellis and Liberty Islands between New York and New Jersey, their spokesmen said yesterday.

title: New York State Voters Deserve a Choice for Lieutenant Governor
description: To the Editor:

title: UNBEATEN PHONE TRICK WINS AT BELMONT
description: Phone Trick, the fastest horse in the country, ran his record to nine victories without a defeat while scoring a comfortable victory under 127 pounds in the $110,800 True North Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: ALABAMA CONTEST A REMINDER OF THE OLD DAYS
description: When George C. Wallace decided he would not seek a fifth term as Governor, this spring's statewide primary was cast as the beginning of a new political era in Alabama.

title: TANZANIA'S 'GREEN GOLD' WOES
description: Sisal plants, like the tops of pineapples, march down the hillsides here in double files. In the colonial era, these plants were called ''green gold'' for the pale fibers they produced, fibers that were combed and spun into twine that bound newspaper bundles, rope that secured ships to their moorings and threads that were woven into burlap sacks for potatoes and onions.

title: Maryland Sailor Wins Liberty Cup
description: Gary Jobson of Annapolis, Md., won the Liberty Cup for the second year in a row yesterday, beating seven other international helmsmen in a series of match races in New York Harbor.

title: FILM INDUSTRY ESCALATES WAR AGAINST PIRATES
description: A feewweeks ago Warner Brothers placed an unusual advertisement in Variety, the movie industry's leading trade paper: ''Warning! Warner Bros. and 'Cobra' declare war on video piracy.''

title: FOR 40 SOVIET EMIGRES, 20 WEDDINGS, A LOT OF JOY
description: At exactly 2:08 P.M. today, 20 bridegrooms vigorously smashed 20 glasses with their feet. They then locked arms with their brides and strode beaming down the aisle.

title: SECTION 301, WHERE HUNGARY'S PAST IS BURIED
description: In a weedy, remote corner of the huge Pest Lorinc Cemetery here lie the unmarked graves of about 280 students, workers and political figures who were hanged for their participation in the Hungarian uprising of 1956.

title: RANGERS SAID TO BE CONSIDERING PATRICK'S DISMISSAL
description: It has been a month and a half since the Rangers' trip through the Stanley Cup playoffs was ended by the Montreal Canadiens. Their dramatic postseason revival, however, apparently did little to secure the position of Craig Patrick, the team's general manager.

title: Debra S. Cohen Wed To a Musical Director
description: Debra S. Cohen, a coordinator of clinical trials in the management office at the New York University Medical Center, was married yesterday to Zalmen Mlotek, a musical director and co-author of ''The Golden Land,'' the musical at the Second Avenue Theater. Rabbi Albert Feldman performed the ceremony at the Westville Synagogue in New Haven.

title: Phillips Captures Gymnastics Title
description: Kristie Phillips won her second straight national junior girls all-round title today in the United States Gymnastics Championships.

title: SENATE TAX BILL: HOW SUPPORT GREW
description: Late Tuesday afternoon, the Senate clerk will call the roll - ''Mr. Abnor, Mr. Andrews, Mr. Armstrong'' - and one senator after another will vote ''aye'' on one of the most sweeping legislative measures to come before Congress in years. No one will be surprised if, when the roll call is over, the vote approving the tax-revision bill is 100 to 0.

title: POLICEMAN SLAIN
description: Three bombs exploded around Durban late Saturday night and early today, and one of them caused a huge fire near an oil refinery, the police said. A mile-long slick of oil from ruptured pipes was spreading in the Indian Ocean this evening. No injuries were reported. The blasts came a week after a car bomb devastated a seaside section of Durban, killing three women, two white and one of Indian descent, and wounding 69 people. Oliver Tambo, the president of the African National Congress, a banned anti-apartheid group, said last week in Geneva that the earlier bombing in Durban might have been carried out by his guerrillas. Shooting of Brigadier

title: NEW THEORY OF UNIVERSE LEANING TO 'MOCK GRAVITY'
description: Not gravity but ''mock gravity'' may have been the force that pulled matter together in the pregalactic universe, according to a theory put forward by two scientists at the University of Arizona's Steward Observatory.

title: DANCE: NANCY ALLISON IN AMERICAN PROGRAM
description: A PROGRAM presented by Nancy Allison on Saturday evening at the Nikolais/ Louis Dancespace did span a long number of years of American modern dance, as promised by advance publicity. But the program's most appealing aspect was that it seemed to be a gathering of bright, inquisitive soulmates intent on exploring new and old territory.

title: PUBLISHERS FEEL THE INSURANCE PINCH
description: Sharply rising costs of liability insurance are causing deep concern among book publishers, and at least one publishing house - Stein & Day - has been refused such insurance altogether. The upshot, according to some publishers, is that books considered controversial are likely to have a harder time getting published.

title: U.S. WILL ANNOUNCE SPEED-UP IN AID TO PHILIPPINES, OFFICIALS SAY
description: The United States intends to tell the Philippines this week that it has expedited about $200 million for Manila's use in helping to deal with its immediate economic problems, American officials said today.

title: 5 Die as Truck That Troopers Chased Hits Van in Alabama
description: A truck being chased by troopers from two states plowed into a van near here, killing five people and injuring two others, the authorities said today.

title: OIL WEAKER, ECUADOR TOUGHER
description: Until late 1985, international bankers saw Ecuador as the one bright spot in Latin America's murky debt picture, an oil-exporting nation run by a pro-business government that believed in paying its bills without complaining.

title: MAY STORES SEEKS ASSOCIATED CHAIN
description: May Department Stores has offered to acquire Associated Dry Goods Inc., the owner of the Lord & Taylor and J. W. Robinson department-store chains, for the equivalent of $2.7 billion. The deal would create one of the largest retailing companies in the United States and continue an industry trend toward consolidation.

title: The U.N. Today; June 23, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY United Nations Conference on International Trade Law - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE STRAW GIANT. Triumph and Failure: America's Armed Forces. By Arthur T. Hadley. 314 pages. Random House. $19.95. IF you happen to care about the adequacy of the United States' armed forces, then ''The Straw Giant'' is discouraging in the way that most recent critiques of America's military strength are discouraging. Arthur T. Hadley - a veteran reporter who has served as consultant to the Joint Chiefs of Staff and has written seven books, among them ''The Nation's Safety and Arms Control'' - begins by reminding us in painful detail of the catastrophic 1980 hostage-rescue operation in the desert of Iran.

title: Driesell, Players To Be Questioned
description: Lefty Driesell, the University of Maryland's basketball coach, and several of his players will be called before a grand jury Tuesday to answer questions about the death of Len Bias, Arthur M. Marshall Jr., the Prince Georges County state's attorney, said today.

title: Measuring a Blast
description: Last summer a little band of mathematically minded baseball buffs determined that the longest home run ever hit was not, as some had supposed, the famous belt by the 21-year-old Mickey Mantle out of Griffith Stadium in Washington on April 17, 1953 (estimated at 565 feet), but rather a less famous one by the 28-year-old Mickey Mantle out of Briggs Stadium in Detroit on Sept. 10, 1960 (measured, from eyewitness accounts, at 643 feet). Now the same crew has concluded that the longest homer was really an obscure one hit by the 19-year-old Mickey Mantle out of Bovard Field on the Southern Cal campus on March 26, 1951 (somewhere between 654 and 660 feet).

title: CONTROLLER PLAN AT SMALL AIRPORTS IS HALTED BY U.S.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has quietly halted its program of hiring private companies to operate control towers at airports handling low levels of traffic.

title: Keep the Lid on Teapot Dome
description: The 1922 Teapot Dome scandal involved a conspiracy to sell the assets of the Naval Petroleum Reserve in California for less than full value; President Harding's Interior Secretary ended up in prison. Today, the Government is selling the daily output from the same petroleum reserve below market price, and proposes to sell off the entire reserve at a bargain price.

title: BOXING'S HOUSE OF CARDS
description: THE billboard on the busy thoroughfare in sun-drenched Las Vegas depicts three gloved fists raised up to the desert skies, with the open palm of each showing a different pair of surnames:

title: CALLS BY U.S. WORKERS TRACKED
description: About a third of all telephone calls made by Federal employees at five agencies were for personal rather than business reasons, according to preliminary Government studies made public Friday.

title: Katherine Wood Marries Andrew Berman in Idaho
description: Katherine Duell Wood, the owner of the Bald Mountain Cantina, and Andrew James Berman, a partner in Paul Kenney's Ski and Sports, both in Ketchum, Idaho, were married there yesterday. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk officiated at the Evergreen, a restaurant.

title: 2 Killed by Bomb Blast In Sri Lanka Market
description: A bomb that the authorities said was planted by Tamil guerrillas exploded in a crowded market in the eastern town of Kantalai today, killing 2 people and wounding 20, a military spokesman said.

title: BO'S BLAST: 450 FEET PLUS
description: IN the confusion, Bo Jackson had left the bag with his baseball bats, shoes and glove on the private jet that brought him to Kansas City, Mo., in the afternoon.

title: Outdoors
description: THE capture of a 700-pound female mako off Long Island more than a week ago served as a reminder that shark fishing is now under way in the Northeast.

title: BREAST CANCER: ASSESSING ROLE OF HORMONES
description: Breast cancer, a disease that will strike one in 11 American women, has in the last few years forced researchers back to square one in their efforts to understand its causes and develop methods of prevention.

title: L.I. STUDY FAVORS A 'REASONABLE' TAKEOVER OF LILCO
description: A takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company by a public power authority would reduce electricity rates if it could be arranged ''at a reasonable price,'' according to a study commissioned by Nassau County.

title: Smoking Over a Pack a Day Seen as Risking Alzheimer's
description: People who smoke more than one pack of cigarettes a day may be more than four times as likely to get Alzheimer's disease than nonsmokers, a researcher says.

title: MANVILLE NAMES 4 OUTSIDE DIRECTORS TO ITS BOARD
description: The Manville Corporation yesterday announced the names of four more outside directors who will serve on its board after it emerges from protection under bankruptcy laws.

title: Eric Richard Lewis Is Wed To Sheryl Ann Eisenstein
description: Sheryl Ann Eisenstein and Eric Richard Lewis, who received master's degrees from the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration June 5, were married yesterday by Rabbi Alvin Kass at the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Eisenstein of Brooklyn and her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lewis of East Hills, L.I.

title: A SMALLER U.S. QUARTERLY FINANCING
description: In addition to the regular auction of $14.8 billion in three- and six-month bills, the Treasury calendar this week includes a quarterly financing that begins with the auction of $7.25 billion in four-year notes tomorrow and $6.75 billion of seven-year notes on Wednesday.

title: Phone Union Rejects Offer From A.T.&T.
description: Union negotiators for two divisions of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today rejected a new offer as talks were held in the three-week strike.

title: TROUBLED TIMES FOR PIONEER TV PREACHER'S EMPIRE
description: On a cloudy morning, the top of the 60-story City of Faith medical clinic disappears into the misty heavens as if palpably mirroring the vision of the clinic's founder, the evangelist Oral Roberts.

title: Better U.S. Statistics Sought
description: The chairman and the ranking Senate Democrat on the Joint Economic Committee have called for a $31.7 million overhaul of Government statistics to provide data, for example, on the number of Americans working in such new fields as computer sales or the writing of software.

title: PLEASURES AND PERILS OF TOURS
description: A STOCK character on the escorted tour is the person who behaves as though the trip had been organized only for his or her benefit. Barry and Jane Linsky of New York encountered such a man on recent tour of China. In secret, they called him ''L.B.J.'' because of a physical resemblance to President Lyndon Baines Johnson.

title: Twice as Nice
description: When word got around that Mollie Marler had celebrated her birthday by bowling a score twice her age, it didn't seem especially remarkable. After all, any 9-year-old kid can do that.

title: THE COURT: REHNQUIST
description: By the standards of the world Americans enjoy extraordinary freedom. We do, I believe, in good part because of the institution of the Supreme Court. Through the strains of our turbulent history the Court has given concrete meaning to the Constitution's promises of liberty, its provisions against concentrated official power.

title: TAX TRIAL ONLY ONE OF POSNER PROBLEMS
description: The long-delayed tax-evasion trial of Victor Posner is scheduled to start today in the Federal District Court in Miami, affording a rare public glimpse into the dealings of the secretive financier and corporate raider.

title: Imagery in Motion
description: When Ladislav Pataki sneaked out of a Rome hotel with his wife and daughter last July and sought asylum at the United States Embassy, the move boded well for American athletics. Pataki, a former discus and hammer-throw coach who, as a biomechanical specialist, had been coordinator of a Czechoslovak training-research project, was the highest-ranking Soviet-bloc sports scientist ever to defect to the West. It seemed likely that he would soon be sharing some of Eastern Europe's legendary training secrets with the Americans.

title: NO CLEAR FAVORITE AT WIMBLEDON
description: With all due respect, it should be noted that Ivan Lendl, the top-ranked player in the world, is indeed entered in the men's singles at Wimbledon, and what's more, he is the top-seeded player. It should be noted because rarely has a dominant player suffered what Lendl says he thinks is the indignity of being virtually overlooked before a major tournament.

title: Laura S. Anker Weds a Lawyer
description: Laura Susan Anker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Anker of Jamaica, Queens, was married yesterday to Stephen Alan Grossman, the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Charles Grossman of Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Paul Steinberg performed the ceremony at Temple Adas Israel in Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Suppose Roger Clemens of the Red Sox is closing in on a 1-0 victory over the Yankees when Willie Randolph walks and Rickey Henderson hits a ground-rule double with two out in the ninth at Fenway Park. As the left-handed Don Mattingly approaches the batter's box, the Red Sox turn to a left-handed relief pitcher, Joe Sambito, in an effort to retire Mattingly and end the game. With first base unoccupied, Sambito can afford a walk to Mattingly, so he is instructed to keep the ball off the strike zone as much as possible in the hope that Mattingly will swing at a bad pitch. On the first pitch, though, Sambito throws the ball so far off the plate that it gets by the catcher. Randolph easily scores the tying run, but Henderson rounds third base too sharply, then slips and is thrown out before he can scramble back, ending the inning. If Jim Rice leads off the bottom of the ninth for Boston with a game-winning homer, who gets credit for the victory, Clemens, who shut out the Yankees until the last batter, or Sambito, whose only pitch was a wild one that tied the score?

title: STATES BACK RISKY VENTURES IN EFFORT TO CREATE NEW JOBS
description: Michigan put its money in fiber glass motor homes. Ohio bankrolled a device that helps surgeons find cancer cells. And Indiana gambled on artificial diamonds, warehouse-like retail stores and a publishing house for physical fitness books.

title: A DEMANDING SEASON FOR THE COUNSEL
description: At the conclusion of the daily 8 A.M. senior staff meeting at the White House three weeks ago, Donald T. Regan, the chief of staff, called Peter J. Wallison into his office and surprised Mr. Wallison, the White House counsel, with the news that Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has quietly informed President Reagan that he was planning to end his 17-year tenure at the Supreme Court.

title: U.S. Condemns Offer By Nicaragua on Treaty
description: The Reagan Administration today rejected as ''propagandistic'' an offer by Nicaragua to support a regional peace treaty if the United States ended its support for the rebels fighting to overthrow the Sandinista Government.

title: GANELIN TRIO'S DEBUT
description: THE Ganelin Trio - said to be the first Soviet jazz group to tour the United States -made its American debut Saturday at Town Hall with a set that was by turns earnest, intense, wry, enigmatic and silly.

title: A MORE PERFECT UNIVERSE
description: Inspired by the forthcoming bicentennial of the United States Constitution, the National Air and Space Museum and the Center for Democracy of Boston University are organizing a series of conferences aimed at drafting what they call ''a declaration of first principles for the governance of space communities,'' an international statement of rights and responsibilities for the residents of the first extraterrestrial colonies.

title: Immigration Policy in the Light of a New Torch
description: To the Editor:

title: 'HERO OF MY OWN LIFE,' STORY OF AIDS PATIENT
description: ''HERO OF MY OWN LIFE'' is a modest, unobtrusive and ultimately uplifting story about, and by, an AIDS patient. He is David Summers, diagnosed as having the disease in February 1985, and determined now, he says, ''to make my whole life about living.'' The program will be seen on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight.

title: Jennifer Parmelee Is Wed to an Editor
description: Jennifer Beale Parmelee, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gray Parmelee of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark McMullen Thomas, a son of J. Benedict Thomas of Oak Park, Ill., and the late Marie Louisa Thomas. The Rev. Dr. Stuart Grayson performed the ceremony at the First Church of Religious Science in New York, assisted by the Rev. Vincent O'Keefe, dean of Jesuits at Fordham University and formerly assistant general of the Jesuit order at the Vatican.

title: TAKEN ABACK
description: An official of the National Endowment for the Arts was startled to discover one morning last week that his office door had overnight acquired a new sign reading ''MEN.'' Inquiry developed that scenes for a motion picture called ''Deceit'' had been filmed the night before in the endowment's headquarters in the Old Post Office Building. The climactic sequence was to have been the murder of Gene Hackman in the sixth floor men's room, but that locale did not provide satisfactory camera angles and lighting, so both lavatory and slaying were swiftly moved down the hall to the official's more accommodating quarters.

title: THE FEW-FRILLS CONDOMINIUM
description: The largest builder of condominiums in the New York suburbs, Kevork Hovnanian, says his biggest sales problem is crowd control. ''We want to maintain public safety,'' he said the other day.

title: WHILE DEAVER CAN'T, EX-SENATORS CAN
description: In a vote count, Michael K. Deaver, former deputy White House chief of staff, could easily be named Most Discredited American of 1986. He deserves it, too. How dare he peddle his access to high officials for big bucks? How dare he betray the public trust and sell his insider's knowledge to foreign interests and domestic pressure groups? How dare he do what thousands of other high Government officials - including hundreds of Representatives and Senators - do all the time?

title: MATURITY REWARDED IN OUTDOOR TRACK
description: Track and field is obviously for the young, except when the old refuse to quit. Consider the success of the geriatric set in the 111th annual USA/Mobil outdoor championships, which ended here Saturday.

title: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS WIN SOLID VICTORY IN NATIONAL VOTE
description: The Socialist Party of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez won a solid victory in national elections Sunday, according to nearly complete offical returns.

title: COLUMBIA PROFESSOR PICKED TO HEAD CITY HIGH SCHOOLS
description: A professor of education who advocates a far-reaching reorganization of the city's 111 high schools has been selected as the new head of the Board of Education's division of high schools.

title: Stastny Brothers Get Nordique Pact
description: Peter and Anton Stastny, two of the major offensive weapons of the Quebec Nordiques, have signed multi-year contracts, the National Hockey League club announced today.

title: Steiger Tractor's Chief Confident Despite Woes
description: Irvin E. Aal, chief executive and president of Steiger Tractor Inc., has seen many of the ups, and lately, the downs, that the farm equipment industry has to offer.

title: Sally Ward Is Married
description: Sally Ward, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert K. Ward of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Kenneth Hoyt McGovern, the son of H. Kenneth McGovern of North Palm Beach, Fla., and formerly of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Elizabeth Hoyt McGovern. The Revs. T. Merton Rymph and Rebecca Spencer performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich.

title: DANCE: 'LA BAYADERE'
description: A MIXTURE of soap opera, spectacle and art, American Ballet Theater's three-act version of ''La Bayadere'' by Petipa offers its performers a range of opportunities for both dancing and acting. Two different interpretations were on view when Alessandra Ferri made her debut Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House as Nikiya, while Cynthia Harvey made her debut in the same role at the matinee.

title: OPEC SET TO MEET ON OUTPUT
description: For the third time since crude oil prices plummeted last winter, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet on Wednesday to attempt to reach an agreement on production.

title: EXODUS FEARED AT BATTERED CANAVERAL
description: Five months after the Challenger explosion, major activity at this once bustling space port has come to a virtual halt. Crucial projects have been canceled, hundreds of engineers and workers have lost their jobs, and those that remain have been wrenched by doubts about what lies ahead.

title: MUSIC: ART OF BEL CANTO
description: LISTENING to modern singers wrestling with the great artifacts of bel canto literature is to understand how lost an art this really is. Thus the music by Bellini, Donizetti and Rossini at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night offered tantalizing possibilities of lightness and grace, but rarely were the four singers entrusted with its care able to approach these ideals.

title: AS THE BERRIES ABOUND, SO DO THE RUSTING CARS
description: Hawkers at the vegetable stands in the Pike Place Market shouted the great news last week: ''Sweet, local strawberries. We got 'em.'' The first on the market sold the other day for $1.90 a quart, but that soon fell to 98 cents.

title: Cathy Lynn Stamm Wed
description: Cathy Lynn Stamm, a social worker and psychotherapist in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Jerome Kaufman, an attending psychiatrist at the Beth Israel Medical Center in New York. Rabbi Lawrence Raphael performed the ceremony at the Terrace Restaurant in Manhattan. The bride, who will be known as Mrs. Stamm-Kaufman, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Julian Stamm of Scarsdale, N.Y. Dr. Kaufman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kaufman of Sunrise Lake, Fla.

title: New Yorkers Soft on Corruption
description: Can New York's Legislature conceivably end its session without passing any of the dozen measures proposed to deal with political corruption? That shameful result now seems entirely possible. The Democratic Assembly, the Republican Senate, Governor Cuomo, Mayor Koch and a blue-ribbon reform commission have all suggested responses, some quite worthy, to the problems exposed by New York City's scandals. The trouble is they lack consensus on any major one.

title: SICILIAN VOTING POSES TEST FOR CRAXI
description: Sicilians voted today in regional elections that have become an unexpectedly important personal test for Prime Minister Bettino Craxi.

title: GIVING VIEWERS, AND SENATORS, A GRAPHIC FOCUS
description: Chart-making is a burgeoning business on the Senate side of the Capitol, where brightly colored graphics quickly became a regular prop when the Senate moved into the television era.

title: Award for a Blind Student Of Music and Literature
description: When Orlando Fiol sits down at the piano, he plays Chopin, Bach, Debussy or Vivaldi. On an electric piano, he leans to pop music and jazz.

title: LEADER OF MEXICO REJECTS DRUG REPORTS AS SLANDER
description: President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico, in an interview televised today, rejected as slanders and lies assertions by some United States officials of high-level corruption and involvement in drug trafficking by officials in his Government.

title: Wendy's Sale Completed
description: Wendy's International Inc. announced Friday that it had completed the sale of land and buildings for 85 restaurants leased to franchise owners in the United States to the Great Western Credit Corporation for $64.5 million. The transaction will result in a gain for Wendy's in the second quarter that will not be disclosed until it releases its earnings at the end of July.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 23, 1986:

title: U.N. Nazi Archives Must Be Opened
description: To the Editor:

title: Meet-the-Artist Snacks Before 'Mostly Mozart'
description: Seven of this summer's ''Mostly Mozart'' festival concerts at Lincoln Center will be preceded by meet-the-artist suppers, in the Helen Hull Room of Avery Fisher Hall. At each of the events, which take place from 5:45 to 6:45 P.M., a limited number of people will have the chance to dine and chat with the artists who are about to perform.

title: TWAY, AT 19 UNDER, IS FIRST IN ATLANTA
description: Returning to the area where he was reared, Bob Tway birdied five of the final eight holes today to complete a round of eight-under-par 64 and capture the $500,000 Georgia-Pacific Atlanta Golf Classic.

title: New York State Voters Deserve a Choice for Lieutenant Governor
description: To the Editor:

title: Brother of Officer Is Accused In Theft and Sale of Her Gun
description: The brother of a New York York City police officer was arrested yesterday after he admitted that he had sold his sister's service revolver for $100 to a narcotics dealer, authorities said.

title: DICKINSON'S EAGLE WINS IN ROCHESTER
description: Judy Dickinson holed an 87-yard shot for an eagle then made up for a double bogey with three birdies to gain a one-stroke victory today at the Rochester International.

title: RACKETS FIGURE, REPORTED MISSING BEFORE 2D NEVADA TRIAL, IS SOUGHT
description: A man who law-enforcement officials say is an organized crime leader is missing, and local police officers and the Federal authorities are investigating his disappearance.

title: THE RISE AND QUICK FALL OF A GENIAL CITY OFFICIAL
description: John J. McLaughlin arrived in New York City in 1970, fresh out of law school, with $500 in his pocket, a quick mind, a knack for getting along with people and an overriding drive to make it in the big city.

title: Revamped Mexican Lineup
description: Before leaving the Cabinet last week in a shake-up, Mexico's Finance Minister, Jesus Silva Herzog, was scheduled to be the luncheon speaker tomorrow at the Overseas Development Council's symposium on the World Bank.

title: SYRIA HOLDS OUT HOPE FOR END OF HOSTAGES' ORDEAL
description: Syria said today that the release last week of two French television journalists who had been held by Moslem militants was the beginning of the end of captivity for all Western hostages in Lebanon.

title: PERU SAYS TROOPS MAY HAVE ERRED AT JAIL
description: The Government has acknowledged that the military may have used excessive force in retaking one of the three prisons where imprisoned guerrillas rioted last week.

title: Runaway Truck Kills an Infant
description: A 6-month-old girl was killed after being thrown from a pickup truck that slipped into gear and rolled down a driveway as her parents looked on helplessly from the yard, the police said.

title: BLUE JAYS ROUT YANKEES; 15-1 DEFEAT WORST SINCE 1982 SEASON
description: Willie Randolph wore the scars of a long and difficult afternoon. He had been spiked on the left forearm, burned on the palm of his right hand by a slide into the artificial turf, and cut inside his mouth by a head-first slide into third base.

title: Move by Hildt And Sturtevant
description: Sturtevant & Hildt Advertising has been opened by Robert S. Sturtevant and Robert E. Hildt, a pair of 49-year-old copywriters who were executives at Martin Sturtevant Silverman & Marshall, which has just become MSSM.

title: SHELBY, CAR INNOVATOR, ADDING ZEST TO CHRYSLER
description: Carroll Shelby is back producing cars again after a lapse of a decade and a half, and his new operation, although small by Detroit standards, is an important part of the Chrysler Corporation's effort to project a more youthful image.

title: Bridge: Summer Festival in Greece Is Expected to Draw Well
description: The reluctance of Americans to vacation in Europe this year will no doubt have some impact on various European tournaments. But the well-organized ones in attractive settings will still appeal, especially to those with shorter distances to travel.

title: GIANTS SWEEP ASTROS FOR FIRST
description: Mike Aldrete's bases-loaded grounder in the eighth inning gave San Francisco a 3-2 victory over Houston and a sweep of today's doubleheader as the Giants roared past the Astros into first place in the National League West.

title: 30,000 Car Seats for Infants Recalled for Risk of Cracking
description: A manufacturer of car seats for infants is recalling 30,000 plastic safety cradles made in a five-month period because the model cracked in simulated crashes.

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, FRIENDSHIP BLOOMS IN WIDOWS' GRIEF
description: They are two women, two widows, bonded, in South Africa, by grief.

title: A Couple in Murder-Suicide
description: A 50-year-old man shot and killed his 43-year-old estranged wife last night then fatally shot himself in the head, according to the police, who described the incident as a murder-suicide. The man, Santo Torres, who lived at 865 Amsterdam Avenue in the Washington Heights section of upper Manhattan, went to the apartment of his estranged wife, Carmen Torres, at 1649 St. Nicholas Avenue, where he shot her three times with a .32-caliber pistol and then shot himself.

title: RESTORATION GROUP EXPANDING REACH
description: Montgomery Place, a Hudson River estate dating from 1805, has been purchased for $3.75 million by Sleepy Hollow Restorations, which maintains four historic sites in Westchester County.

title: Star Truck
description: Five months after the Challenger disaster, America's goals in space are still dangerously confused. NASA insists on building another shuttle orbiter and a space station. But neither of these are goals, only means to ill-defined ends. Even as a vehicle to Somewhere, the shuttle is deeply flawed; and the space station has been oversold as a platform for Something. What should America's goals in space be? Simply stated, low cost, high adventure. For every activity in space, the highest barrier is cost. NASA claimed that the shuttle, a recoverable vehicle, would cost less than throwaway rockets. But the shuttle's economics have proved as disastrous as its O-rings. Its expense has turned it into a giant barrier to the vigorous exploitation of space.

title: WHITE GRIP ON SOUTHERN SCHOOLS: KEEPING CONTROL
description: In hundreds of schools across the rural South, as the academic year comes to a close, another class of young black men and women is graduating from a system of public education that is almost as black as it was before integration, but that is still ruled by whites.

title: F.H.A. Plan Still Snarled
description: A measure to revive the operations of the Federal Housing Administration remained snarled in the Senate on Friday by arcane budgetary and parliamentary rules that delayed congressional action until this week.

title: Anastasia Skelos Wed To Dr. Thomas Lester
description: Anastasia Skelos, coordinator of staff education in the chemotherapy research nursing department at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, and Dr. Thomas John Lester, who last week completed an oncology research fellowship at the cancer center, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church in Hempstead, L.I. The Revs. Nicholas J. Magoulias and Joakim Valasiadis officiated.

title: PREPARE FOR GROUND WARS
description: As a veteran of two and one-half years of jungle warfare in the South Pacific and 38 years of Congressional combat over defense budgets, I'm increasingly persuaded that our defense priorities are out of whack.

title: Soviet Captain Charged In Wreck of Greek Boat
description: The police charged the captain of a Soviet cruise ship with manslaughter in the sinking of a Greek tugboat and the drowning of an engineer, a Merchant Marine Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Alice Peurala, Local Leader Of Steelworkers, Dies at 58
description: Alice Peurala, president of Local 65 of the United Steelworkers of America, the only woman to head a basic-steel local in the nation, died of cancer Thursday at home on the South Side here. She was 58 years old.

title: Artificial Heart Recipient Gets Human Transplant
description: A man who suffered from cardiomyopathy, the same heart disease that killed his twin brother, was recuperating today from heart transplant surgery after being kept alive by an artificial heart for eight days.

title: BADILLO NAMES MCCALL TO KEY CAMPAIGN POST
description: Herman Badillo, the Democratic candidate for state comptroller, made a key campaign appointment yesterday that some black elected officials said might help heal his rift with black politicians.

title: SANCTIONS ARE CALLED A SAFEGUARD
description: The leader of a high-level Commonwealth study group on South Africa warned this weekend that imposing economic sanctions against that country was the only way to protect Western investments there.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JUNE 23, 1986
description: Companies

title: GARY GETS ENGAGED
description: Gary Hart is the front-runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination. What this serious man had to say - in 21,000 fairly well-chosen words in a series of lectures last week - may become the foreign policy of the United States in 1989.

title: UTAH HONORS GARN
description: The University of Utah, from which Jake Garn graduated in 1955, has established the Garn Institute of Finance in honor of the state's senior Senator.

title: Use More Medical Resources for Prevention
description: To the Editor:

title: ARCHITECTURE: RENDERINGS OF SKYSCRAPERS BY FERRISS
description: Hugh Ferriss was our century's most potent architectural renderer, a man whose richly shaded drawings evoke a startling degree of romance, power, drama and hope. Ferriss's most famous drawings were of skyscrapers, and in the 1920's and 1930's, his visions of the city on paper were almost as important, in their way, as real buildings were in shaping popular perception of the new and immense cities that were rising all across the country.

title: MANPOWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,253,000.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: On the post-stock split basis, the latest first quarter results are equivalent to 21 cents a share, compared to year-earlier period of 22 cents a share. The latest shares outstanding reflect the addition of 1,437,500 shares of common stock sold in a public offering completed April 30.

title: The House After 1991
description: In this era of the perpetual campaign, political strategists never rest.

title: I.B. SINGER GETS PRIZE AND CHARMS CITY HALL
description: Isaac Bashevis Singer said it, as was fitting, with a story.

title: Ballesteros Sounds Off
description: Seve Ballesteros got the better of Deane Beman yesterday on the golf course as he won the Irish Open over a field that included the commissioner of the PGA Tour, who barred Ballesteros from the tour this season for not playing in enough Tour events last year. The two never came face-to-face, but Ballesteros made no sesecret of his displeasure over Beman's presence.

title: Going Over To the Other Side (Part I)
description: A detente has been reached between the Parks and Recreation Department and Steven Brill, the self-taught environmentalist arrested for picking edible plants in Central Park this year.

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BRIEFS
description: * AEL Industries, Montgomeryville, Pa., said its board had authorized the purchase of up to 500,000 shares of its common stock. The company has more than 4.6 million shares outstanding.

title: A Reminder That Diego Rivera Left His Art in San Francisco
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILS RAP 20 HITS, WALLOP CUBS, 19-1
description: Juan Samuel hit two three-run home runs and drove in six runs tonight as the Phillies set a National League record with 15 extra-base hits in support of six-hit pitching by Shane Rawley in a 19-1 rout of the Cubs.

title: Investor Reports J.P. Stevens Stake
description: Selim K. Zilkha, a Los Angeles-based investor, said today that he had purchased a 5 percent stake in J. P. Stevens & Company and might increase his holding.

title: HOUSING TAX BENEFIT PUT IN BILL
description: In an 11th-hour change to its sweeping tax-revision bill, the Senate agreed today to provide greater incentives for the construction of rental housing for low-income Americans.

title: A Taste of Wall Street -- Frenzy and All
description: The rumor mills of Wall Street are a lot quieter since the Government began its latest crackdown on the insider trading in which people with advance knowledge have illegally made killings on the stock market. But there is a spot here where the race to find out information ahead of other investors is as brisk as ever, and does not violate the law.

title: Mining the Moon
description: Future extraterrestrial construction projects may do well to get their concrete from the moon rather than earth.

title: METS LOSE IN 10; EXPOS 5, METS 4
description: The Mets staged a pair of tantalizingly poor performances last night before 44,199 spectators in Shea Stadium, and the bad actors were the two ''stoppers'' in the cast, in this order:

title: City Gives List of Cuts To Close Budget Gap
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it would have to hire fewer police officers, sanitation workers and firefighters if the State Legislature and the City Council fail to enact about $100 million worth of new taxes.

title: LESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared March 24, 1986, and paid April 15 to shareholders of record April 4.

title: CLOTH COAT: WINTER'S LOOK IS LONG
description: With initial orders from store buyers up as much as 30 percent compared with last year's, manufacturers expect a banner year for cloth winter coats. Most will begin shipping new ones to the stores next month, and there has already been some enthusiastic reaction from consumers.

title: CHARVOZ-CARSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income. The share earnings for both year- earlier periods have been restated to give effect to a 5-for-4 stock split effected in December 1985. The company said its latest quarter loss reflects an inventory writedown of $110,000, a $100,000 non-recurring charge related to the early retirement of its former chairman and a change in determining gross profit margins based on the strengthening of foreign currencies. Corrected from Friday, June 20, editions.

title: MAE LEVY WIEN
description: Mae Levy Wien, a patron of the arts, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 76 years old and had homes in Manhattan; Westport, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: PARIS, TOO, UNVEILS A NEWLY RESPLENDENT LIBERTY
description: France staged a preview of New York's July 4 celebrations today, unveiling a newly renovated copy of the Statue of Liberty.

title: In Albany: Nits and Narrow Interests
description: Two crucial bills hang in the balance as New York's Legislature accelerates toward adjournment. Legislators determined to put common good before narrow interests will take two giant steps: repeal the Wicks law and end petition nitpicking.

title: NOMINEE'S IDEAS FOR HIGH SCHOOLS DRAW CRITICISM
description: Several parent and professional groups yesterday sharply criticized the recommendations for reorganization that have been proposed by the newly nominated head of the New York City Board of Education's division of high schools.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BEYOND THE MEN'S RULES
description: THE computer industry is dominated by men. With rare exceptions, men design, build, sell and explain the machines and the software that runs them. Yet women hold the majority of clerical and office positions in business, the jobs most likely to use computers in the future.

title: Greyhound Sees 2d-Period Charges
description: The Greyhound Corporation said today that the company's sale of its stake in Conagra Inc. resulted in an after-tax profit of about $87 million but that the gain would be partly offset in its second-quarter results by a $25 million loss provision for its European leasing unit and a $12 million charge for the rehabilitation of its Pine Top Insurance Company subsidiary.

title: Farmers and Investors Make Deals at Land Fair
description: Financially strapped farmers seeking bail-outs and investors looking to turn a profit met today for a chance to make deals in person at the Chicago Farmers Club's second annual land fair.

title: PUBLIC ACCESS TO U.N. WAR CRIME FILES OPPOSED
description: The seventeen nations that made up the United Nations War Crimes Commission are unlikely to allow public access to its 36,000 files on war criminals, suspects and witnesses, according to diplomats and United Nations officials.

title: STOLEN S.A.T.'S REPORTED AT 2 TOP CITY SCHOOLS
description: The Educational Testing Service yesterday confirmed that copies of college entrance examinations had been stolen, reproduced and distributed outside Stuyvesant High School before the June 7 examinations. In addition, the Princeton, N.J., service revealed that the exams were also available at Brooklyn Techical High School.

title: PLEA OF NOT GUILTY IS ENTERED BY TUROFF IN CORRUPTION CASE
description: Jay L. Turoff, who for eight years headed the agency that regulates New York City's taxi industry, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he got a $30,000 payoff and committed other corrupt acts while in office.

title: Charter Financial
description: The Hartford National Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Charter Financial Corporation of Framingham, Mass., and its subsidiary bank, the Framingham Trust Company. Under terms of the deal, Hartford National will exchange $59.8 million worth of its common shares for all 1,284,000 Charter shares.

title: RAINOUT FOR LENDL, BREEZE FOR BECKER
description: Sometimes, the dark cloud that Ivan Lendl says follows him around Wimbledon actually does exist. Lendl's match was the only one completed on opening day here last year, which he interpreted as an insult. Perhaps Ken Farrar, the supervisor of officials for the men's professional tour, also remembered.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A.T.&T. SCIENCE PROJECT There is what amounts to a whole new science museum in town, a lavish four-floor permanent exhibition, the A.T.&T. Infoquest Center, in Philip Johnson's much-talked-about skyscraper built for the company at 550 Madison Avenue, at 56th Street (605-5555). This promotional installation demonstrates, in entertaining, colorful and hands-on ways, just what tricks communications equipment can perform. Its 40 exhibits explore microelectronics, computer software and light-wave communications.

title: Sex as a Weapon; In the Workplace, It Can Violate Federal Law
description: Short of outright rape, it's hard to think of a more loathsome abuse of power by an employer than forcing sexual attentions on an employee. Sexual abuse has long poisoned the workplace, and in recent years women have sought refuge in the Federal law against sex discrimination. Now they have won the unanimous support of the Supreme Court.

title: BODY POSITION IS FOUND TO AFFECT THE ACCURACY OF HEART DISEASE TESTS
description: AMONG doctors' favorite methods of estimating a person's risk of heart disease is to measure the blood concentrations of cholesterol and the blood lipids. But, had the patient been standing up or lying down before the blood samples were taken? It can make a big difference, scientists said after studying 41 men and women who were tested under both circumstances.

title: STATISTICAL FORECASTING MADE SIMPLE, ALMOST
description: CASTING entrails to divine the future has been part of man's culture in one form or another ever since the idea of a future was first conceived. As civilization evolved, the means employed in divination have become less bloody, and the methodology more scientific, although to many the results are as questionable as ever. Thus the release of various electronic equivalents of the I Ching should come as no surprise to anyone.

title: MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: O'NEILL REFUSES REAGAN REQUEST FOR HOUSE FLOOR
description: President Reagan asked today to address the House of Representatives on Tuesday to make a final appeal for $100 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, and the Speaker of the House turned him down.

title: Sell Programs Drop Dow by 15.28
description: Industry consolidations put retail and airline issues in the spotlight yesterday on Wall Street, but stock prices declined over all as the buyprograms of Friday turned into sell programs.

title: . . . And New Challenge for His Ex-Associate
description: The second company to emerge from the proposed Dart & Kraft disentanglement is yet to be named. It will be the smaller of the two companies, generating some $2 billion annually in sales while Kraft will have $8 billion. It will be headed by Mr. Batts, 53, who is currently Dart & Kraft's president and chief operating officer.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page last Friday about a book on Lena Horne's family by her daughter Gail Lumet Buckley incorrectly quoted a reference to the singer Marian Anderson. Recalling that Miss Horne's career lacked the family's approval, Mrs. Buckley said, ''The middle class considered show business declasse unless you were a concert performer like Marian Anderson.'' She used the word performer, not pianist.

title: ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
The Orchids and the Bees
description: Sexual competition among flowers is usually more subtle, but scientists studying neotropical orchids from the genus Catasetum have found the male orchids using an aggressive tactic to beat out their male rivals in the pollination of females. Plants in this genus are either male or female, and the flowers of each sex differ considerably in their structure and appearance.

title: HEINZ, H J CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for 1985 have been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split of the company's stock, effective Sept. 23, 1985.

title: Advertising; System Software Shifts To Ogilvy & Mather
description: There is apparently a very special expertise in the Dallas office of Ogilvy & Mather that is strong enough to attract an advertiser there from Chicago, where there is also an Ogilvy outpost.

title: Portugal Expels 2 Russians
description: Portugal ordered the expulsion today of two Soviet Embassy officials for acting against national security and interfering in Portuguese internal affairs, the Foreign Ministry said. A ministry statement said the two, Vladimir Galkin and Gennadi Chinev, had been given three days to leave the country. It accused them of ''unacceptable interference in Portuguese internal affairs against the security of the state,'' a formula that usually indicates involvement in spying activities.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE FINALLY WINS ONE
description: Bill Freehan hit two three-run home runs in the third inning to lead the American League to a 19-2 victory over the National League tonight in the Fifth Annual Old-Timers Baseball Classic. It was the first time since the game's inception in 1982 that the American League had won.

title: PENWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Fiscal 1985 earnings have been restated.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. RED SOX, at Boston, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: CCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After special tax credits of $563,799.

title: Market Place; Food Stocks Still Favored
description: WITH an absence of fanfare, food stocks continue to forge ahead this year, thanks to the choice ingredients of a sluggish economy, low inflation and declining commodity costs.

title: Hawkeye Bank Sale
description: The Hawkeye Bancorporation announced today that losses caused by the poor farm economy had forced it to put 17 of its 36 banks up for sale. The funds raised would satisfy a $100 million debt to creditors.

title:
WHAT TO DO ABOUT SOUTH KOREA;
STOP CODDLING THE REGIME
description: The violence, anti- Americanism and polarization that have marked the rising tide against South Korea's military dictatorship ought to cause the United States to rethink its policies, which are as much a cause of this worrisome trend as is President Chun Doo Hwan.

title: Why Protect Printers at the Expense of Authors?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hindu Troops Accused Of Beating Punjab Sikhs
description: Twenty-five Hindu paramilitary troops were charged today with beating three Sikh policemen and freeing Hindu militants from jail.

title: GENETIC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
For Kraft's Chief, A Familiar Job . . .
description: When Dart & Kraft Inc. splits into two companies, John M. Richman will be chairman and chief executive of the new Kraft Inc., and by all accounts, this will be the company that will be the most aggressive of the two, continuing Kraft's growth through a string of acquisitions.

title: LINCOLN CENTER SALUTES ITS DEPARTING CHAIRMAN
description: Shortly before 10 last night, the Marty Segal Singers swung into ''Everything's Coming Up Marty,'' the jubilant theme song for Lincoln Center's thank-you to Martin E. Segal. Mr. Segal was leaving after five years as the center's chairman of the board and many more years in the center's service. But the roses will have no time to fade before Mr. Segal is back in business, holding a news conference this morning in his new job as chairman of the New York International Festival of the Arts.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
VISUAL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes $55,001 in income from discontinued operations, a loss of $19,551 on disposal of a division and a tax credit of $45,000. c-Includes a loss of $84,314 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $169,000.

title: FOR JACKSON, WHAT CHOICE?
description: Put yourself in Bo Jackson's shoes. How could you not choose baseball over football? In this case, the outfield in the Kansas City Royals organization over the backfield for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Advertising; Hughes Aircraft Moves Account to DMB&B
description: After 35 years with Foote, Cone & Belding, Los Angeles, the Hughes Aircraft Company has switched its account to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in that city.

title: Utilities Shell Game
description: To the Editor:

title: VICORP RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 11
description: b-Net income

title: BIRDFINDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of $724,242 on certain assets for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Jail for Refusing AIDS Test
description: A sailor who refused to take a blood test for the antibodies to AIDS was found guilty at a court-martial today of disobeying an order.

title: DELIBERATIONS BEGIN ON '71 VIOLENCE AT SAN QUENTIN
description: Jurors today ended their first day of deliberations without a verdict in the murder and conspiracy trial of Stephen M. Bingham, the former radical lawyer accused of smuggling a gun into San Quentin Prison 15 years ago just before an outburst of violence left six people dead.

title: Shots Fired in Strike Incident At Weyerhaeuser Co. Sawmill
description: Strikers hurled stones and pieces concrete at a truck carrying a load of timber from a Weyerhaeuser Company sawmill today, and a woman in the truck was arrested for firing two gunshots in the air, the authorities said.

title: G.M.'S SPUTTERING OPEL UNIT
description: Adam Opel A.G., the sturdy West German subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, used to be called the money machine.

title: The Hot House
description: The heating and air-conditioning system at the White House, which dates to the Truman Administration, will be shut down for renovations for three weeks beginning Aug. 16. But the citizenry need not worry about wilting Reagans; they will be at their ranch in Califor-nia. August not being a particularly gentle month in the capital, National Park Service officials say the shutdown may affect public tours of the residential part of the White House but should not affect staff members toiling in office areas of the building.

title: Woman May Be Rapist, Maine High Court Holds
description: Women as well as men may be prosecuted for statutory rape, the State Supreme Court ruled today, paving the way for trial of a woman accused of raping a 13-year-old boy.

title: Bridge: The Manhattan Club Holds Its Own Version of the Draft
description: The football draft is a well-established institution, but who ever heard of a bridge draft? Only, perhaps, those who play at the Manhattan Club, 27 West 72d Street.

title: PIGEONS, ELVISES, IMMIGRANTS: STAGING PATRIOTISM FOR THE 4TH
description: David L. Wolper - the man who is bringing New York 200 Elvis Presley look-alikes and 300 Jazzercise ladies, Shirley MacLaine and 850 drill team girls on a moving stage with dancing waters, 5,000 homing pigeons playing doves of peace, 10,000 immigrants taking the oath of citizenship by satellite in Miami's Orange Bowl, square-dancing brain surgeons and physicists and the largest fireworks show in the history of the world - had a crazy idea.

title: INTERCO INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Levi Strauss To Sell Koret
description: Levi Strauss & Company said today that it had agreed to sell its Koret of North America subsidiary through a leveraged buyout to a Koret management group led by Richard Banks, Koret's president. Koret is a division of Levi's Battery Street Enterprises unit, which makes women's sportswear.

title: DIGITEXT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Folklife and Lawyers
description: What Washington produces is mostly policy, which is a hard thing to hum or hang on the wall. Perhaps that explains the popularity of the Smithsonian's annual Festival of American Folklife, which features scores of real people doing real things - musicians, weavers, quilters, spinners, hunters, story-tellers, stone-carvers and the occasional herbalist.

title: CITY STUDENTS' SCORES RISE IN GENERAL ON READING TEST
description: Almost two-thirds of the students in New York City's public elementary and junior high schools read at or above grade level, according to test results announced yesterday by Mayor Koch and Board of Education officials.

title: NIGEL STOCK
description: The British actor Nigel Stock, best known for his role as Dr. Watson in the BBC television series ''Sherlock Holmes,'' was found dead of natural causes on Sunday at his home in north London, his agent said today.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MCGUIGAN STUNNED BY CRUZ
description: At this morning's weigh-in at Caesars Palace, 22-year-old Stevie Cruz, a plumber's helper from Fort Worth, sat calmly in seats reserved for the press, largely ignored by the writers around him as he awaited his call to the scale. He will not be ignored any longer.

title: Careers; Managing University Real Estate
description: AUREO might sound like a cookie but it stands for Association of University Real Estate Officials, a group that holds annual meetings so that representatives of 100 institutional members can exchange ideas.

title: Resolutions at 60
description: When the novelist and playwright Thornton Wilder turned 60 years old in 1957, Justice Felix Frankfurter wired him: ''Welcome to the Great Decades!'' Wilder himself decided to take advantage of the ''new privileges'' he thought due anyone who had lasted that long.

title: METS LOSE IN 10; YANKEES 11, RED SOX 3
description: The timing isn't the same, but the idea is, as far as the Yankees are concerned, that is.

title: Saga Chairman Quits To Aid Marriott Link
description: Charles A. Lynch was credited with turning the Saga Corporation around after he joined the company as president in 1978, increasing efficiency and reversing a decline in earnings. Saga's results have slipped again in recent quarters, but Mr. Lynch said the company was poised for another comeback.

title: Strip Mining in West Is Seen as Reversible
description: Most strip-mined land in the West can be reclaimed, a Congressional agency said Sunday, but it said not all technical questions were settled.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Year to April 30
The Landlord May Be as Liable as the Boss
description: A single mother on welfare living in a Brooklyn apartment refused the sexual advances of her landlord. He shut off the electricity, rejected her rent check and followed her, menacingly, around the neighborhood . . . A Milwaukee landlord was ordered to pay $19,000 to a tenant after he was convicted of housing discrimination; he had demanded sex in lieu of rent . . . A young couple in Toledo faced eviction after the wife spurned the advances of their landlord.

title: Advertising; A 'Quick Response' For Fibers
description: ALMOST everything moves at a faster pace than it used to, including fashion.

title: DEMOCRATS URGED TO REASSESS IMPACT OF PUBLIC WELFARE PROGRAMS
description: A group of leading Democrats brought together yesterday by Governor Cuomo urged their party to reassess public welfare programs to determine how well they were alleviating critical problems confronting minority groups and the poor.

title: FIVE YEARS OF TURBULENCE
description: April 30, 1981: Service began with three planes based in Newark, offering trips to some smaller cities at fares discounted up to 60 percent. People Express lost $9.2 million that year.

title: DIRECT ACTION MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: SOUTH AFRICA TREASON TRIAL ENDS WITH AQUITTAL OF 4
description: One of South Africa's biggest treason trials ended today with the acquittal of the last four of 16 defendants.

title: Texas Appeals Court Grants Stay
description: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals today stayed the execution of a 25-year-old man, pending a hearing on his contention that minority groups were excluded from the jury that condemned him for the 1980 rape-murder of a Houston travel agent.

title: HOW SHOULD COLLEGES PICK STUDENTS?
description: PRETEND this is a multiple-choice question on the Scholastic Aptitude Test: (a) The S.A.T.'s are important to college admissions deans. (b) The S.A.T.'s are not needed by college admissions deans. (c) The college interview is important. (d) The college interview should be eliminated.

title: I.R.A. Member Is Sentenced To 8 Life Terms for Bombings
description: Patrick Magee, a member of the Irish Republican Army, was sentenced today to eight life prison terms for his part in bombing campaigns that were intended to kill the British Prime Minister and destroy hotels and seaside resorts during the tourist season.

title: In the Wake of Complaints, A Clean Subway Entrance
description: Alice Webb threaded her way through the ankle-deep sea of broken glass, discarded instant film and empty food cartons on the steps of an entrance to the Times Square-Grand Central Shuttle on 43d Street yesterday morning.

title: LILCO TAKEOVER SEEN AS LEADING TO LOWER RATES
description: A state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company could lead to electricity rates 7 to 9 percent below what they would be over the next decade if the utility remained a private corporation, a state commission has found.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Nola Anderson has been promoted to senior vice president/management supervisor of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, in Boston.

title: Tenneco and I.C.H. in Pact
description: Tenneco Inc., the natural gas producer, has reached agreement in principle to sell its vast insurance operations to the rapidly expanding I.C.H. Corporation of Louisville, Ky., for $1.5 billion in cash, the two companies announced jointly yesterday.

title: Tom Hayden Retains Seat in California House
description: The State Assembly narrowly rejected an attempt today to oust from its membership Tom Hayden, the onetime Vietnam War protester.

title: U.S. Certifies Vote In Hospitals Local
description: The United States Department of Labor yesterday certified the election of Georgiana Johnson as president of Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union. The department said Doris Turner, the incumbent who was defeated in a special union election last month, would have to give up her position by Friday as president of the largest union of hospital workers in the city.

title: Cyanamid Set To Buy Storz
description: The American Cyanamid Company, in a move to expand its new medical devices division, agreed to acquire the Storz Instrument Company for more than $100 million in cash.

title: Singing Their Praises
description: The American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers will honor six members of Congress today for their work in behalf of the arts at a reception featuring performances by songwriters including Sammy Cahn and Cy Coleman. The honorees are Senators Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah; Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, and Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, as well as Representatives Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Long Island; James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont, and Sidney R. Yates, Democrat of Illinois.

title: THE 4 CASES CITED IN THE COHN RULING
description: Following are summaries of the four cases that resulted yesterday in a finding of professional misconduct against the attorney Roy M. Cohn by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court. The descriptions are drawn from the court's 49-page decision:

title: Going Over To the Other Side (Part II)
description: Murray Schumach saw government from the outside in for most of his career. Now the former reporter for The New York Times, with 42 years of reporting behind him, is trying something new - seeing government from the inside out.

title: SHIFTING PATTERNS POINT TO COMPLEXITY OF AIDS
description: As the AIDS epidemic worsens, changes in various patterns of the untreatable lethal disease can be expected to increase the complexities of dealing with it, a leading expert said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A television review yesterday of ''Hero of My Own Life,'' a Channel 13 documentary about an AIDS patient, omitted some program credits that were missing from the tape supplied by the station. The program was directed by Debra A. Chapnick and produced by the Glines, a nonprofit cultural organization, and by Ms. Chapnick, Tom Brook and David Musselman.

title: Spy's Plan for Prison Escape In Oslo Is Thwarted by Friend
description: A plan to whisk a convicted spy out of an Oslo jail to West Africa has led to three arrests, the police said today.

title: Sequoia: U.S.S. Forever
description: The Sequoia, the Presidential yacht, is heading home. The historic craft, on which Truman played poker and Kennedy celebrated his last birthday, today received President Reagan's endorsement and will soon be taken back into Government service.

title: Slugging Saint
description: Jim Eisenreich, the Minnesota outfielder who was forced out of major league baseball in 1984 because of a nervous disorder that brought on uncontrollable twitches and interrupted his career several times, has been playing with an amateur team in St. Cloud, Minn., his hometown. And he still has hopes of returning to the majors someday.

title: TRUMP DESCRIBES TALKS WITH ROZELLE
description: Donald Trump, the New York real estate developer and the owner of the United States Football League Generals, told a jury yesterday that Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, had promised him a team in the N.F.L. if the U.S.F.L. would remain a spring league and would not file an antitrust suit against the N.F.L.

title: A DEPARTURE AT FED MAY BRING SHIFT
description: Stephen H. Axilrod, the Federal Reserve's top-ranking staff official and the man regarded by some as the central bank's second most powerful figure after the chairman, Paul A. Volcker, is leaving to join a major Japanese securities firm, it was announced today.

title: A LATIN-FLAVORED CONCERT AT THE APOLLO
description: MONGO SANTAMARIA, who left Cuba for the United States several decades ago, was the headliner, and Daniel Ponce, who arrived in New York City from Cuba in 1980, opened the Apollo Theater's Latin-jazz concert on Sunday. Both men were introduced, with not a trace of irony, as ''the world's greatest conga drummer.'' How many ''world's greatest'' anythings can there be? A showdown seemed inevitable.

title: STAGE: 'BURNING PATIENCE'
description: ANTONIO SKARMETA'S ''Burning Patience,'' at the Intar Theater, is a tribute to the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda. Mr. Skarmeta, a novelist who lives in exile in West Germany, obviously sympathizes with Mr. Neruda's politics, but he does not write with a heavy left hand. The poet's brief run as the Communist candidate for president of Chile takes up a few minutes, but otherwise, even at the play's end - when we are reminded of the assassination of President Salvador Allende and the imposition of the military dictatorship - politics is largely unspoken. Silence may be prudent in this case; before he died Mr. Neruda was bitterly attacked by Chilean student radicals who accused him of lapsing from the left.

title: PROTECTIONISM HAS RISKS, SHULTZ IS TOLD
description: The Prime Minister of this Southeast Asian nation warned Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that failure by the Reagan Administration to resist protectionist pressures in Congress could encourage Soviet inroads in this region of the world.

title: Newsprint Price Rise
description: Consolidated-Bathurst Inc., a Montreal-based paper company that is Canada's third-largest newsprint producer, said yesterday that it was raising by $35 a ton the price of newsprint for its customers in the United States beginning Oct. 1.

title: Strong Tremor Rocks Japan; A 2d Quake Hits New Guinea
description: A strong earthquake rocked Tokyo and central Japan just before noon today, but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage.

title: Ozone Team To Brave Antartica
description: Teams of scientists will soon make an unusual trip into the perpetual darkness of Antarctic winter to study a mysterious and alarming ''hole'' in part of the atmosphere that protects the Earth from harmful solar radiation.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Typewriter Evolution
description: Silver Reed America Inc. recently introduced what it calls a ''no-nonsense, back to basics'' typewriter, a ''low-end, high-quality durable machine.''

title: European Prices Up
description: Consumer prices in the European Community rose by two-tenths of 1 percent in May, reaching a 3.5 percent annual inflation rate, the community's statistics agency, Eurostat, said today. That rate was down from 3.7 percent in April.

title: READICARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss. Revenue represents patient revenue. The company was formerly Urgent Care Centers of America Inc.

title: Emergency Decree Imposed at Thai Resort
description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda declared a state of emergency in a resort town in southern Thailand today after 50,000 people protesting plans to open a chemical plant set fire to the factory, a hotel and six vehicles, officials said.

title: AT SERVICES FOR BIAS, TRIBUTES AND WARNINGS ARE OFFERED
description: Len Bias was described this morning as a ''blessing to our generation'' by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, and as someone whose sudden death should be a ''message'' to the young people who admired him.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Net income

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the Federal Trade Commission's opposition to two mergers in the soft-drink industry misstated some terms of Pepsico's agreement to acquire Seven-Up from Philip Morris. Pepsico is not required to pay Philip Morris if the acquisition is blocked on antitrust grounds, nor is it responsible for finding another purchaser.

title: DRUG SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income.

title: BRITISH OFFICIAL TO SEE SOUTH AFRICAN REBEL LEADER
description: The leader of the main underground movement in South Africa was invited today to meet a British official at the Foreign Office.

title: SANITATION WORKERS PROTEST PRESENCE OF VICTIM OF AIDS
description: Thirty-nine city sanitation workers were suspended yesterday morning when they refused to take their trucks from a Harlem garage in a dispute over the presence of a fellow employee who has AIDS.

title: Pentagon Charters Are Criticized
description: Airplanes chartered by the Pentagon to fly service personnel have failed a higher percentage of inspections by the Federal Aviation Administration than have commercial airliners, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: GROUP REVIEWING NATO POLICIES
description: Allied disarmament experts met today to begin what is expected to be a long effort to forge a new approach to the control of conventional arms.

title: ABC AIDE CONCEDES NETWORK WILL END SEASON IN 3D PLACE
description: Brandon Stoddard, the president of ABC Entertainment, has said that his network has no chance to move out of third place this season and does not expect to compete with NBC on Thursday nights.

title: Ineligible at Georgia
description: The University of Georgia football team has already lost three prospects to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's new academic standards, and Coach Vince Dooley says more might get away. The three would-be freshmen failed to meet the minimum SAT scores recently established by the N.C.A.A. for athletic eligibility.

title: 5 HELD HOSTAGE IN GEM ROBBERY ON RODEO DRIVE
description: An armed robber took five hostages in a jewelry store on Rodeo Drive this morning, causing the authorities to cordon off several blocks of one of the world's most exclusive shopping districts as they negotiated into the night for the release of the captives.

title: Reebok-Stride Rite
description: Reebok International said it had offered to buy the Stride Rite Corporation last week for $37 a share but was turned down.

title: MET PUZZLE: 5TH STARTER
description: The turnstiles are spinning more often and the victories are occurring more frequently than the occupants of Shea Stadium, on the field and in the stands, have ever known. Even the realists among Met fans are already looking beyond their summer calendars and planning their budgets to handle the happy expense of post-season tickets. Perhaps this is not the time to spoil their party.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NEW YORK COURT DISBARS ROY COHN ON CHARGES OF UNETHICAL CONDUCT
description: A New York State court yesterday ordered Roy M. Cohn disbarred, calling his conduct in four legal matters ''unethical,'' ''unprofessional'' and, in one case, ''particularly reprehensible.''

title: WILLIAM BRICKMAN
description: Dr. William Brickman, professor emeritus at the University of Pennsylvania, died Sunday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia, after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: House Backs Privacy In Electronic Devices
description: Electronic mail, paging devices, cellular mobile telephones and data transmission would be given the same privacy protection as first-class mail under legislation passed today by the House. An identical measure is pending in the Senate.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A lot of people are picking on me as the big Hollywood producer who's overcommercializing the Statue of Liberty.

title: ITALIAN COALITION IS VICTOR IN SICILY
description: Italy's governing coalition won an overwhelming majority in Sicilian regional elections today, while the opposition Communist Party lost ground.

title: THE TAKEOVER THREAT AT FAMILY NEWSPAPERS
description: Traditionally, the newspaper industry has functioned as a fraternity in which an unwelcome offer to acquire a newspaper was rare. And while that restraint remains the norm within the business, a new breed of buyer has emerged that suggests the old rules no longer apply.

title: The U.N. Today: June 24, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Conference on International Trade Law - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Correction Unit Plans Drug Tests
description: The city's Department of Correction is planning to begin random drug tests of all officers and civilian employees to combat increasing reported widespread drug abuse, officials said yesterday.

title: Children Contest Will Of Rockefeller Heiress
description: The children of an heiress to the fortune of John D. Rockefeller Sr. are battling their stepfather for the right to inherit their mother's multimillion-dollar estate, lawyers disclosed yesterday.

title: MANY CITIES EXPECTED TO FAIL TO MEET OZONE LIMIT BY '87
description: Many cities will fail to meet a deadline next year for reducing ozone pollution, a major component of smog, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: KATE VAIDEN. By Reynolds Price. 306 pages. Atheneum. $16.95. IN this, his 14th book, Reynolds

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Crackdown Goes By the Boards
description: The summer meetings came, the summer meetings went, and any chances that the National Hockey League might deal with the increase in fighting, slashing and high-sticking before the first puck is dropped next season have all but been put on ice.

title: LAW DEANS OPPOSE NAMING OF A JUDGE
description: Deans of more than 30 of the nation's most prestigious law schools are urging the Senate to reject the judicial nomination of an Indiana lawyer whose legal background and conservative politics have come under fire.

title: PRESIDENT DENOUNCES ABORTION AS 'MURDER'
description: President Reagan today called abortion ''murder'' but said he had made no effort to seek the views of his judicial nominees on this or any other social issue.

title: Kingman Strikes Again
description: Dave Kingman, the Oakland A's slugger who has been at odds with a female sportswriter covering the team, sent the reporter a gift-wrapped live mouse last night during the A's game against Kansas City. The reporter, Sue Fornoff of The Sacramento Bee, said she and Kingman have had problems since she took over coverage of the A's last season.

title: 'BOB DYLAN IN CONCERT' FROM AUSTRALIAN SHOW
description: BOB DYLAN can't be described as returning when he's never really left. The troubadour has been steadily recording albums from the early 1960's to the present. He has rebelled, he has been born again, he has rediscovered his roots. But the essential Dylan will remain closely identified with the songs of his early years, the various anthems that captured the sounds and images of an era even as he switched from a simple folk mode to electric rock-and-roll. Some of them, or at least their still powerful echoes, can be heard in ''Bob Dylan in Concert,'' a Home Box Office presentation that can be seen at 2 P.M. today (repeats are scheduled for June 27 and 30, July 2, 6 and 8).

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $125,000 from the early retirement of debt. c-After extraordinary credits of $363,598 from the early retirement of debt and from pension plan termination.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Year to May 31
Miami Pastels
description: In general, men do not do much to make the technology more accessible to women. Efforts to explain often become condescending.

title: 'GONE WITH THE WIND' BEST SELLER AGAIN AT 50
description: Fifty years after its publication, ''Gone With the Wind,'' Margaret Mitchell's sweeping saga of Scarlett O'Hara and Rhett Butler set against the backdrop of the Civil War, is back on The New York Times hard-cover best-seller list.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BODIES OF MISSING CRIME FIGURES FOUND BURIED ON INDIANA FARM
description: Two badly beaten bodies found in a shallow grave in an Indiana cornfield were identified today as those of brothers Anthony and Michael Spilotro, reputed mobsters who disappeared more than a week ago, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: PENNZOIL CASE TAKEN BY JUSTICES
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether lower Federal courts erred in allowing Texaco Inc. to pursue its legal battle with the Pennzoil Company without posting the potentially crippling $12 billion bond required by Texas law.

title: SEQUENTIAL INFORMATION SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
