description: b-Net loss

title: NATIONAL ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $215,000. c-Net loss.

title: PAT ROBERTSON LOOKS TO SOUTH AND EVANGELICALS AS KEY TO 1988
description: State by state, through the huge new churches, the handsome new clubs and restaurants of the New South, the Rev. Marion G. (Pat) Robertson, the television evangelist, is promoting himself for the Presidency. He is a Republican, and it is in a Southern regional primary, he says, that the nomination will be won.

title: Advertising; Thompson Gets North American Van
description: North American Van Lines, the household moving and trucking company based in Fort Wayne, Ind., has named J. Walter Thompson, Washington, to handle its advertising account of more than $1 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Credit Markets column in Business Day yesterday misstated the scope of a Senate Finance Committee tax provision on the corporate alternative minimum tax. Corporations subject to the tax would be required to include the interest income from all municipal bonds regardless of the date of acquisition.

title: The Natural
description: If ever there's been a young hockey player destined by surname alone for Madison Square Garden, then it has to be an 18-year-old whom the Rangers chose on the 10th round of last weekend's entry draft.

title: The World Bank as Buoy
description: As the third world debt crisis grinds on, attention is moving away from short-run budget deficits in debtor countries to focus on their more deeply rooted economic problems. The International Monetary Fund was the appropriate multilateral agency for helping out with emergency financial squeezes. The World Bank is the sole agency with the knowledge and breadth - and, potentially, the resources and clout - to tackle this new phase of the debt crisis. This makes it all the more important for the United States to provide the Bank with more resources.

title: Liberty Mutual
description: The Liberty Mutual Corporation made its first international debt offering through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The $150 million offering consists of 8 1/2 percent bonds, due in 1996, at a price of 101. Noncallable for life, the bonds are guaranteed by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company.

title: McEnroe Sets Return
description: John McEnroe will return to competition at the Volvo International tennis tournament at Stratton Mountain, Vt., in August. ''We received word from John McEnroe Sr. today that John has definitely committed to play,'' said the tournament's director, Jim Westhall.

title: The Hubbard Poll: Move Over, Gallup
description: Members of Congress use all kinds of measures to gauge their constituents' feelings on national issues. They read and count the mail, for example, and they meet with individuals, constituent groups and lobbyists.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, JUNE 24, 1986
description: International The President met for the first time with the new Soviet Ambassador, Yuri V. Dubinin, who presented his credentials and a letter from Mikhail S. Gorbachev. White House officials said the Kremlin had been sending ''positive signals'' about a summit meeting in the United States this year. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Cyanide in 2 Capsules Seen as From One Batch
description: The cyanide that killed two residents of a Seattle suburb who swallowed Extra-Strength Excedrin capsules came from the same batch of poison but was different from the cyanide found in other tampering cases, the Federal authorities said today. [ At the same time, the Food and Drug Administration announced that tests of more than 150,000 Excedrin capsules had turned up no further signs of cyanide tampering, United Press International reported.

title: WINNIE MANDELA VOWS LONG FIGHT
description: Winnie Mandela said in an interview broadcast today that blacks in South Africa regarded the emergency decree as ''a declaration of war,'' but that they would ultimately win.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CURREN UPSET AT WIMBLEDON
description: Well, the men certainly did not waste any time making their point today. Some of them have been saying that this should be called the Wimbledon Open because any number of players is capable of winning. Kevin Curren, who was the runner-up to Boris Becker last year, naturally included himself among the potential winners and was accorded a measure of recognition by the All-England Lawn Tennis Club that included a color action photo of Curren among those hanging in the interview room.

title: BRAJDAS CORP reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $81,751, or 3 cents a share. c-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $5,423,759, or $3.35 a share, on reorganization under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code.

title: Alarm About Panama
description: Alarming reports about government in Panama are a timely reminder that official corruption and drug trafficking can threaten United States security in the hemisphere as surely as direct political gains by Soviet clients.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, JUNE 24, 1986
description: Companies

title: COMTREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to March 31
Bond Tie to Stock Index
description: Mitsui & Company USA Inc. has introduced into the Eurobond market a new security called a stock performance exchange-linked bond, or ''spelbond,'' with a redemption price that is linked to the value of the New York Stock Exchange's composite index.

title: Drugs Top Threat To Police Integrity
description: Drug use, payoffs from narcotics dealers and the temptation to take cash or drugs seized in raids are the New York City Police Department's main corruption hazards, according to a survey of unit commanders made public yesterday.

title: COURT FINDS INSULT NO CAUSE FOR A NEW TRIAL
description: A bitterly divided Supreme Court today upheld by 5 to 4 a Florida man's conviction and death sentence for a brutal murder, despite what all nine Justices condemned as an improper effort by prosecutors to inflame the jury's passions.

title: NEW ENVOY GIVES GORBACHEV LETTER TO THE PRESIDENT
description: The new Ambassador of the Soviet Union conferred for the first time with President Reagan today and presented a personal letter from Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the White House announced.

title: NORTHSTAR MINERALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a loss of $19,125 from discontinued operations for the quarter and the 9 months. The company's revenue increased because this year's figures reflect the acquisition of Petroland Corp., a privately held Texas company.

title: NOVAMETRIX MEDICAL SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The latest year includes inventory writedowns of $1,487,000 and increased spending for research, product development and marketing programs.

title: CHALLENGER INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Israel Sends Messages To Officials in Austria
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel has sent a good-will message to the new Austrian Chancellor, Franz Vranitzky, a step diplomats described today as a sign that the two countries are moving to repair relations damaged by Kurt Waldheim's election as President.

title: TELECALC INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,574,000 for both quarter and 6 months.

title: TRIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Net income and after a tax credit of $48,000, or 3 cents a share. c-After extraordinary credits of $72,000 for the latest year and $307,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: AQUINO URGES SELF-RELIANCE FOR ASIA
description: President Corazon C. Aquino urged leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations today to look to the organizations's own shortcomings before blaming the developed nations for all of the region's economic woes.

title: Feeling Far Above Par
description: In capturing the Georgia-Pacific Atlanta Golf Classic on Sunday, Bob Tway became the first player to win three tournaments as a sophomore on the PGA Tour since 1963, when Jack Nicklaus took five.

title: MAYS, J W INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After prior years' real estate tax refunds of $40,976 in the latest quarter and $247,369 for year-ago period. c-After prior years' real estate tax refunds of $136,964 this year, compared to $297,803 a year ago. Sales are inclusive of leased departments.

title: THE FIERCE AND UGLY KOMODO DRAGON FIGHTS ON
description: THE last Komodo dragon in the United States, an aging female whose potential mate died six months ago, may yet become a mother and thereby help her race of man-eating lizards survive, thanks to a technique being pioneered by scientists at the San Diego Zoo.

title: Ex-City Aide Loses Bid To Dismiss Indictment
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has denied a motion by John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, to have his bribery indictment dismissed on the grounds of prosecutorial misconduct.

title: A BIT OF VENICE IN NEW YORK
description: Is it a fashion boutique? An antiques store? A gift shop? Actually, Portantina is all of those things.

title: PROGRESS IN TECHNOLOGY REVIVES INTEREST IN GREAT TUNNELS
description: A NEW era of underwater tunneling is under way, aided by giant mechanical ''moles'' and improved techniques for plotting courses and coping with ruptures far below the ocean surface. As a result, engineers say, interest is being revived in tunneling schemes long thought to be impractical.

title: Factory Collapses in India
description: Rescue workers struggled today to free six remaining workers trapped in the debris of a textile factory that collapsed.

title: Scripps-Howard Broadcasting Stake
description: The American Financial Corporation, an insurance company whose chairman is the Ohio businessman Carl H. Lindner, said that it had acquired a 5.1 percent stake in the Scripps-Howard Broadcasting Company.

title: Advertising; Advertising Partners
description: Advertising Partners and Ettinger Advertising announced that the former will acquire the latter on July 1. Ettinger, founded in 1953, is a general agency with $1.5 million in billings. Joel H. Ettinger will be a senior vice president at Advertising Partners, a specialist in sales promotion, which has $2.5 million in billings.

title: BID FOR DEBT RELIEF SEEN IN MEXICAN'S REMARKS
description: Mexico's new Finance Minister, Gustavo Petricioli, said tonight that the country could no longer maintain ''strict'' servicing of its foreign debt because of the sharp drop in its oil revenues.

title: CITY IS PLANNING A HOTEL SHELTER FOR AIDS CASES
description: The Koch administration is planning to take over a 48-room hotel in Greenwich Village as a shelter for homeless AIDS patients who do not need to be hospitalized.

title: DESIGNCRAFT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Latest quarter sales include $3,579,000 from the recently acquired Howard W. Sweet & Son Inc.

title: NIAGARA FALLS ROMANCES A BUILDER
description: Billions of gallons of cascading water once were enough to establish Niagara Falls as the honeymoon capital of the country and thereby insure its prosperity. But these days, newlyweds apparently are not so impressed by natural wonders, and with thousands of industrial jobs gone as well, Niagara Falls has fallen on hard times.

title: William J. Scott Dies; Ex-Official in Illinois
description: William J. Scott, who served as the Illinois Attorney General for 12 years until he was convicted of tax fraud, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Air Express International Corporation elected to its board Andrew L. Lewis 4th, a consultant with Lewis, Eckert & Robb, a governmental, financial and management consulting firm.

title: Wolper May Decline A Bonus for His Work
description: Besieged by criticism about Liberty Weekend, David L. Wolper says now that he would probably not accept a bonus.

title: Chess: Tseshkovsky Captures Title In the Soviet Championship
description: Chernobyl or no Chernobyl - it occurred around the 10th round - the 53d championship of the Soviet Union in Kiev went off as planned. It was won by the grandmaster Vitaly Tseshkovsky, who scored a glowing 11-6.

title: FLED TO PRAGUE OVER CHARGES
description: Alfred K. Stern, a former Illinois housing administrator who was charged in 1957 with spying for the Soviet Union, died of cancer today in his Prague exile, his wife said. He was 88 years old.

title: A Free-Trade Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: AIR FORCE PLANS MID-SIZED ROCKET FOR SPACE FLEET
description: In a major expansion of the Government's unmanned rocket program, Air Force officials said today they plan to build a new, mid-sized rocket to lift military payloads grounded by the loss of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Lack of Insurance Imperils Farm Concert
description: The singer Willie Nelson said today that a concert July 4 to benefit family farmers would be canceled unless liability insurance could be bought.

title: SHULTZ EXPLAINS '84 PANAMA VISIT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that despite charges of electoral fraud in Panama, he attended the 1984 inauguration of that country's civilian President because an official Panamanian commission had certified the results and ''we try to work with the Government that emerged.''

title: PEOPLE EXPRESS SAYS IT MIGHT HAVE TO SELL PART OR ALL OF AIRLINE
description: People Express Inc., which revolutionized the airline industry with its low-fare strategy, said yesterday that it might be forced to sell all or part of the company.

title: An Inside Look at Supreme Court and Its Cases
description: The announcement last week of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger's retirement and President Reagan's intention to nominate Justice William H. Rehnquist to succeed him have again drawn attention to the Supreme Court and its internal workings, which are largely a mystery to the public.

title: WILD CARD IN SOUTH AFRICA: COMMUNIST PARTY
description: President P. W. Botha has spoken at length about a Communist threat to the nation. The theme is not new among the nation's white leaders, but increasingly it finds a kind of counterpoint in the nation's segregated black townships.

title: EARTH'S CLIMATIC CRISIS EXAMINED BY 'NOVA'
description: PICKING up where a high-school chemistry class might end, ''Nova,'' the public-broadcasting science series, offers the nonmatriculating viewer an advanced course in worrying. The cause of the concern is all the carbon dioxide that's being pumped into the industrialized and motorized air. The hourlong broadcast is called ''The Climate Crisis: The Greenhouse Effect,'' at 9 tonight on Channel 13.

title: Republican Site Selection
description: Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., the Republican national chairman, will be meeting this week with officials in St. Louis, one of nine cities vying for the party's 1988 convention.

title: DIAGNOSTEK INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Soviet-Fijian Trade Talks
description: Fiji has agreed to discuss prospects for trade and technical cooperation with the Soviet Union, including a fishing agreement, a senior Government official said today.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2.9 million, or 7 cents a share, and $6.9 million, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Includes a tax credit of $2.2 million, or 5 cents a share. d-Includes a tax credit of $3.8 million, or 9 cents a share, and a credit of $20.1 million, or 47 cents a share, for the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting method. The company said its year-ago quarter sales included the company's refractories business, which has since been sold, and the medical-diagnostics business, which has been deconsolidated into an equity venture.

title: Talking Business with Fetterolf of Alcoa; New Challenge For Aluminum
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, has long escaped problems like those that have devastated the steel and copper industries. But now Alcoa and other aluminum companies are facing increasing pressure from imports and worldwide overcapacity. Aluminum prices and earnings have become more sensitive to cyclical swings in the economy.

title:
WHAT TO DO ABOUT SOUTH KOREA;
ENCOURAGE BOTH SIDES TO TALK
description: Some Americans have been so inspired by the fall of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines that they have set their sights on a new target: South Korea. The answer to the ''dictatorship'' of President Chun Doo Hwan, they say, is the ''democratic'' opposition. But the United States should refrain from taking sides in the internal debate over how to reshape South Korea's Government. We can be most helpful by encouraging dialogue and moderation on both sides.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TREASURY PRICES CLOSE MIXED
description: Prices on Treasury securities were mixed in light trading yesterday as dealers began positioning themselves for today's auction of $7.25 billion of four-year Treasury notes and an auction of $6.75 billion in seven-year notes on Wednesday.

title: Yamani Sees Gain in Talks
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said today that OPEC would probably move closer this week to an agreement on limiting oil production.

title: Close Encounters
description: If the National League West should remain tightly bunched all season long, then neither the Los Angeles Dodgers nor the San Diego Padres will be much surprised. The Dodgers and the Padres have played each other in 13 games this season, and 10 have been decided by one run.

title: Anderson, Clayton
description: A hearing set for Thursday on the plan by Anderson, Clayton & Company to have its shareholders vote again on a recapitalization plan has been postponed, according to Bear, Stearns & Company and Gruss & Company, the two investment houses trying to take over Anderson. Confirming reports that circulated on Wall Street yesterday, Bear, Stearns and Gruss said they had agreed to a postponement of the hearing, which is to take place in Delaware Chancery Court.

title: HERBIE HANCOCK'S QUARTET
description: WHEN the pianist Herbie Hancock leads a jazz group rather than his electronic funk bands, he likes the music volatile: full of swooping crescendos and shifting cross-rhythms, able to move instantaneously from sustained delicacy to percussive impact and back.

title: Comings and Goings
description: George Shinn, a Charlotte businessman, Gov. Jim Martin of North Carolina and Mayor Harvey Gantt of Charlotte, gave David Stern, the National Basketball Association commissioner, a check for $100,000 and formally applied for an expansion franchise. Charlotte joins Minneapolis and Orange County, Calif., as applicants. . . . Steve Kemp, who was released earlier this season by the Pittsburgh Pirates, has signed a minor-league contract with the San Diego Padres. . . . Coach Kevin Mackey, who led the Cleveland State basketball team to the Final 16 of the N.C.A.A. tournament last season, has signed a new four-year contract valued at more than $100,000 annually. . . . Lloyd's of London has asked a Federal judge to void a $1.6 million insurance policy on Pelle Lindbergh, saying the late Philadelphia Flyer goalie was in violation of the policy when he died following a car crash last November.

title: ASSOCIATED STOCK UP $19 AFTER OFFER
description: The common stock of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation soared $19 a share yesterday on the heels of the weekend buyout offer by May Department Stores. May's common stock, however, dropped $4.75 a share.

title: DYING WOMAN WINS JERSEY RULING TO END LIFE-SUSTAINING CARE
description: A New Jersey judge yesterday approved the request of a 37-year-old terminally ill woman to be removed from a respirator, saying that it would be cruel to sustain a life ''so wracked with pain.''

title: WILD BILL DAVIDSON TRIBUTE
description: THE JVC Jazz Festival concert at Town Hall on Sunday evening was variously announced as a tribute to the cornetist Wild Bill Davison, marking his 80th birthday, and a celebration of Chicago jazz in the 1920's. It was both, but it was also a tribute to a generally unrecognized quality of jazz musicians: their active longevity.

title: SOME DETAINEES ARE FREED
description: Some anti-apartheid activists and members of church congregations have been released from detention in South Africa, according to reports received in the United States yesterday.

title: Raggi Suggested For U.S. Judgeship
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato is recommending United States Attorney Reena Raggi for a Federal judgeship in Brooklyn.

title: Y.W.C.A. Official On School Board
description: Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan named Dr. Gwendolyn Calvert Baker, the executive director of the national Young Women's Christian Association, to the Board of Education yesterday.

title: GREASE MONKEY HOLDING CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: IMPROVED BELGIUM REACHES SEMIFINALS
description: Belgium was one of the founding members of FIFA, the world governing body of soccer, but its record in the World Cup has, until now, been dismal. Now, Belgium has joined Argentina, France and West Germany as one of the four teams left from the 24 who came to Mexico seeking soccer's most prestigious trophy.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: In the Eurobond market yesterday, J. P. Morgan & Company began issuing $100 million of deferred coupon bonds, due in 1993, at par through the Nikko Securities Company (Europe) Ltd.

title: Davis-Bacon Protects Workers From Dog-Eat-Dog Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE NAMES A TRUSTEE FOR UNION TIED TO MOB
description: In the first action of its kind, a Federal judge today named a trustee to take over operation of a union local that the judge said was run by ''mob-controlled gangsters'' to the detriment of the membership.

title: SOCIALISTS IN SPAIN HAIL VOTE, BUT SEE IT AS A WARNING, TOO
description: Socialist Party leaders said today that they and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez saw their weekend electoral victory as a mandate for continuity but as a warning also to be more cautious in style.

title: Top Wisconsin Yield at 8.07%
description: A $139 million financing yesterday by Wisconsin, the largest of the day, was tentatively priced through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: U.S. DELAYS VOTE ON BRAZIL LOAN
description: At the request of the United States, World Bank directors today postponed until Thursday their vote on a $500 million loan to improve the efficiency of Brazilian soybean farmers and other food producers.

title: EX-CRAVATH, SWAINE PARTNER
description: Maurice T. Moore, a former presiding partner in the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, died Sunday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 90 years old and also lived in Weston, Conn.

title: Homeless Families Slept in Offices
description: At least 23 homeless families with children were forced to stay overnight in the waiting rooms of city welfare offices last Friday.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
RAPID CHANGES SEEN IN YOUNG BRAIN
description: Evidence is mounting from a variety of fields that the human brain undergoes significantly more physiological reorganization in early adolescence than had been previously understood.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THERE are fashions for all sorts of things, and right now there is one for books that look like rock album sleeves, combining such bizarre design elements as olives and zebra-striped pants on their new wave-style dust jackets. Forget that new wave is old already. Look at trendy tomes as fashion accessories this summer, to be carried and coordinated with clothes. FASHIONS are crucial clues to character in these books. For example, Guy Huber, the black-clad protagonist of ''Social Disease,'' a novel by Paul Rudnick (Knopf, $14.95), dresses as ''an urban savage,'' Mr. Rudnick writes, in a T-shirt ''printed with the Japanese characters for life, death and shoes.'' CORNELIA COCHRANE

title: ALEXANDER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to March 31
CLASHES BLOCK A.T.&.T. PACT
description: Despite a tentative agreement at the national level, the strike by the Communications Workers of America against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company continued yesterday, with negotiations bogged down in divisional bargaining.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 4
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $16,459,000 for the quarter and $16,870,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $6,675,000 and $7,070,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and includes income from discontinued operations of $906,000 for the quarter and $1,223,000 for the 6 months. The company said the income from discontinued operations primarily reflected a $16.2 million gain on the sale of the company's intraocular lens subsidiary.

title: South Korean Dissidents Pledge to Help Detainees
description: South Korean dissident leaders, responding to criticism over their agreement to negotiate constitutional changes with the ruling party, pledged today to work for the release of political detainees.

title: ON TEACHING ABOUT SEX
description: DESPITE the disputes that often accompany sex education courses, a curriculum that includes an obstetrician's showing various contraceptive devices in the classroom has survived its recent test run in 650 schools, according to its creators.

title: This Name Flies
description: Everything that can possibly be said about the 1962 Mets was said long ago, except for the small impact that they would later make in rock music. And now that has been taken care of by Ira Kaplan, who was a 5-year-old Brooklyn boy when Richie Ashburn first cried, ''Yo la tengo!''

title: Mexico Asks Creditor Aid
description: Mexico's Deputy Finance Minister, Francisco Suarez Davila, said today his country had gone the limit of its ability to absorb the shock from collapsed oil prices and now required a ''deep degree of cooperation of creditors.''

title: CITY TAXES DEBATED IN ALBANY AS DEADLINE FOR BUDGET NEARS
description: Two days before the deadline for passage of New York City's $21.5 billion budget, state lawmakers wrestled today to fashion legislation that would permit the city to enact or extend more than $450 million in taxes.

title: Canada Accuses Man Of Dealing With Soviet
description: A French citizen has been charged in Montreal with illegally shipping Western technology to the Soviet Union.

title: PENTAGON PRESSED ON SMALL MISSILES
description: The House Armed Services Committee voted today to sharply limit the deployment of MX missiles until major development begins for a smaller mobile missile, Congressional officials said.

title: New Lab on 67th St.
description: A group of Rockefellers, a group of Secret Service agents and a group of speeches marked a ceremonial ground-breaking yesterday for the Rockefeller Research Laboratories.

title: METS FALL AGAIN TO EXPOS
description: When it was done, the Mets were still leading the Montreal Expos by eight games, and they still had the best record in baseball. But somebody or something was gnawing at all that success.

title: 9 HOSPITALS TO BE SOLD
description: In a major move reflecting the increased competitiveness among private hospital companies, National Medical Enterprises announced today that it would sell nine traditional hospitals and put more emphasis on psychiatric care, treatment of drug and alcohol abuse and care of the elderly.

title: PARAGUAYAN POLICE BEAT EXILE
description: The police today beat up an exiled opposition leader and a former United States Ambassador who was escorting him off a plane here, witnesses said.

title: Politics; Trade: A Multidirectional Street
description: The political debate over trade policy in the Washington that is the nation's capital is often waged along the narrow lines of free trade versus protectionism.

title: Norfolk Southern Picks Its Next Chief
description: In a surprise move, the Norfolk Southern Corporation, the railroad giant, said yesterday that Arnold B. McKinnon, its executive vice president for marketing, would succeed Robert B. Claytor as chairman and chief executive.

title: BRITISH OFFICIAL MEETS SOUTH AFRICAN REBEL LEADER
description: A senior British Government official met in London yesterday with Oliver Tambo, the acting president of the African National Congress, the most prominent of the groups seeking the overthrow of the South African Government.

title: REPEAT BEATS A NEWS SPECIAL
description: An NBC News special with Tom Brokaw on the hijacking of the Achille Lauro was soundly beaten in the ratings by a repeat of ''The Equalizer'' on CBS last week, according to figures released yesterday by the A. C. Nielsen Company.

title: Harold Judell, Lawyer, Wed to Celeste Grulich
description: Celeste Seymour Grulich, a television and advertising fashion stylist and fashion consultant in New York, and Harold B. Judell, a senior partner in the New Orleans law firm of Foley Judell Beck Bewley Martin & Hicks, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Jane Henderson performed the ceremony.

title: JAPANESE ECONOMY FALLS 0.5%
description: Hurt by falling exports, Japan's economy contracted last quarter, the first such fall in 11 years, the Economic Planning Agency reported today.

title: UPROAR IN ISRAEL OVER CONVERTS' ID'S
description: Israel's Interior Minister has ordered that the word ''converted'' be stamped onto the identity cards of anyone who immigrates to Israel after being converted to Judaism.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Moscow dispatch on June 11 about drug abuse in the Soviet Union incorrectly described the part of the poppy plant from which opium is derived. Normally the stems and seed pods, not the seeds, contain opium.

title: Officer Indicted in Shooting Of 17-Year-Old Newark Youth
description: An Irvington police officer who fatally shot a Newark teen-ager in April while searching him for weapons was charged with reckless manslaughter Tuesday by a sharply divided grand jury.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Chemed Corp., Cincinnati, a specialty chemical company, named Ronald J. Brickner senior vice president/controller.

title: FISH FIXED HEALTHFULLY
description: FISH is a high-quality protein that is low in saturated fats and cholesterol; the fats in fish like salmon are especially valuable because they actually decrease cholesterol. However, even when people know how important fish is in a healthful diet, many find it difficult to cook. The biggest fault is overcooking. Even the rule of cooking 10 minutes to the inch, measured at the thickest part of the fish, is too much; 8 minutes is better.

title: Scientific American Bids
description: At least three well-known publishing companies - Time Inc., the International Thomson Organization Ltd. and The Economist Newspaper Ltd. -are among the bidders for Scientific American Inc., according to sources familiar with the situation.

title: JETS FOR LUFTHANSA
description: Lufthansa, the national airline of West Germany, said that it had agreed to buy six Boeing 747-400-jumbo jets and spare parts, a pack-age worth about $800 million.

title: EXAMINER CONFIRMS COCAINE KILLED BIAS
description: Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star, died of intoxication from cocaine that he probably sniffed minutes before he collapsed in his dormitory room Thursday morning, the state Medical Examiner said today.

title: Topics; Presidential Insults: On Manion
description: Having insulted the Senate by nominating Daniel Manion for the U.S. Court of Appeals in Chicago, President Reagan has now disparaged his two Supreme Court choices by giving them the faintest of praise.

title: 3 GERMAN STUDENTS TELL OF MISTREATMENT BY CONTRA CAPTORS
description: Three of the 12 West Germans who were abducted last month by United States-backed rebels in Nicaragua asserted today that their seizure appeared to have been planned in advance with the approval of the rebel leadership.

title: Finally, a Standard for the 'Contras'
description: At long last, in a last-minute bid to rescue his $100 million military aid package for Nicaraguan rebels, President Reagan invites Congress to monitor the investment against open, measurable objectives. He promises to purge the rebel army of corrupt, antidemocratic elements and to support only an honorable civil war. He promises a still-incredible outcome - the establishment of democracy in Nicaragua - but calls that only the best guarantee that the Soviet Union will not gain another foothold in the hemisphere. He implies that he would also use the ''contra'' army for leverage in negotiations for different guarantees.

title: May Awaits Reply
description: The May Department Stores Company, which is offering $66 a share for the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, took no apparent action yesterday despite the passing of a 9 A.M. deadline for a formal response to its $2.7 billion bid.

title: CITY WEIGHS OUSTING AIDE UNLESS HE ASSISTS INQUIRY
description: The Koch administration is considering whether to dismiss the counsel to the city's Transportation Department for refusing to waive his immunity against prosecution and testify before a Bronx grand jury, city officials said yesterday.

title: Sobriety Checkpoints Barred in Michigan
description: A judge ruled today that highway checkpoints for sobriety are an unconstitutional, ineffective and unproved method of cracking down on drunken driving and barred Michigan state police from continuing the program.

title: FUGITIVE UNIONIST WARNS PRETORIA OF REPISALS
description: The fugitive signaled his presence with a single beep of the horn from an automobile parked in the dimly lit street, and waited for assurance that the house was safe.

title: Market Place; Funeral Stocks In Demand
description: FUNERAL-RELATED businesses get scant notice on Wall Street. But last week, two New York Stock Exchange issues in that industry traded at record levels - buoyed apparently by prospects of higher earnings.

title: DURABLES ORDERS UP 0.4% IN MAY
description: Factory orders for big-ticket durable goods, after declining for three consecutive months, rose a slight four-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Commerce Department said today. But the increase came exclusively from a surge in demand for military equipment.

title: 'Benefactors' to Close
description: ''Benefactors,'' a drama by Michael Frayn, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. Directed by Michael Blakemore, the play will have run for 217 performances and 12 previews.

title: EARLY SHADES OF NEW AGE FROM TANGERINE DREAM
description: HIGH technology is standard equipment for Tangerine Dream, the West German trio that has sold out the Beacon Theater Saturday for its first New York concert in nine years. Founded in 1967 by Edgar Froese, Tangerine Dream virtually abandoned guitars and drums for synthesizers back in 1973; since then, it has deployed ever more sophisticated electronics to make wordless, atmospheric music, using rock's simplicity but not its song forms.

title: FOR 4TH TIME, CONNECTICUT TRIES MAN IN MURDER OF FORMER IN-LAWS
description: For the fourth time in 10 years, Murray R. Gold went on trial here today on charges that he stabbed his former in-laws to death in 1974.

title: Garn Offers Banking Bill
description: Senator Jake Garn, Senate Banking Committee chairman, presented legislation today intended to strengthen the Federal deposit insurance funds and make it easier for out-of-state institutions to buy troubled banks.

title: SALUTE TO FORD'S THEATER
description: FEW gala fund-raising efforts get as much attention as the annual festivities arranged for Ford's Theater in Washington. Closed after the assassination of Abraham Lincoln in 1865, the theater was reopened in 1968 as a ''living memorial'' for the performing arts and has since become an approved charity for Washington society. For ''The 1986 Festival at Ford's,'' the honorary chairman is Mrs. Ronald Reagan, the general co-chairmen Mrs. Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. and Mrs. Paul Laxalt. With these women and their husbands in the audience for the event, taped this month, it is little wonder that the ''Kraft All-Star Salute to Ford's Theater'' can be seen in television prime time. CBS will carry the show at 8 this evening.

title: 2 VIEWS OF 'WOMEN OF SOUTH AFRICA'
description: WE denounce apartheid because we are supposed to; the word is associated with something wicked. What apartheid specifically is, however, is often vague, and images of armored cars, say, or crowds in Soweto do not necessarily explain it. ''Women of South Africa'' may not explain apartheid, either, but watch it, or at least its first part, and you will reach a fuller understanding. It will be seen on Channel 21 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: Danaher Deal
description: The Danaher Corporation, a Washington-based instrument and rubber products manufacturer with interests in real estate, and Danwest Partners, a New York investment group, have agreed to pay $38 a share, or $60.8 million, for the 32 percent of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company that they do not already own. Chicago Pneumatic, which makes tools, instruments and controls, had been fighting a takeover by Danaher for several months. Danaher said that Steven M. Rales and Mitchell P. Rales, its chief executive and executive vice president, had been elected to Chicago Pneumatic's board.

title: C.I.A. SAID TO WARN PUBLISHER ON BOOK
description: Random House officials say that William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, and an employee of the National Security Agency both made ''disturbing'' inquiries about a forthcoming book by Seymour M. Hersh that deals with the shooting down of a Korean Air Lines jetliner in 1983 by a Soviet fighter.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ACROSS. By Peter Handke. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 138 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The score is taxpayers 1, special interests 0.'' - President Reagan. [ A1:6. ]

title: HASSEY'S 4 HITS LIFT YANKS
description: Ron Hassey likely will not let his chronically bad left knee force him to miss another game against Boston. More to the point, the Yankees may not let him miss another one.

title: COURT AGREES TO RELEASE ASSETS IN FREIDMAN CASE
description: Stanley M. Friedman's bank accounts and other assets, frozen after his indictment, were ordered released yesterday by a state appeals court. The court said that no link had been established between the money and the charges, and that in any case, Mr. Friedman had only been indicted, not convicted.

title: In Re Folklife: Lawyers as Storytellers
description: Each year the Festival of American Folklife of the Smithsonian Institution explores such varied occupations as oystering, truck driving and bartending, each rich in its cultural traditions. This year, starting Wednesday, the subject will be trial lawyering.

title: Lerner Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for the lyricist and playwright Alan Jay Lerner will be held on July 10 at 11:45 A.M. at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street. Mr. Lerner died on June 14 at the age of 67.

title: Washington Issues Priced
description: A $206.3 million financing by Washington, D.C., was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by Lazard Freres & Company with a maximum yield of 8.209 percent for general obligation bonds with a final maturity in 2005.

title: Pipes Purged After Deaths
description: The Hospital of St. Raphael said Tuesday that it had cleansed a hot-water pipe contaminated by a strain of Legionnaires' disease that may have killed as many as three patients and infected another. The hospital announced Friday that it had removed nearly 30 patients from the area fed by the pipe. Three of the four patients have died, and the other was in critical condition Tuesday, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Potatoes That Impress
description: POMMES soufflees are an impressive-looking creation that one associates with the florid and time-consuming techniques of French cuisine. The truth is that these delicious puffed-up, oval-shaped potatoes are neither complicated nor laborious.

title: Architect for TV City
description: From the city of Battery Park, the architect Alexander Cooper has just drifted upriver to the city of Television, another ambitious undertaking on the Hudson shore.

title: Mack Trucks
description: As part of a continuing cost-reduction and restructuring effort, Mack Trucks Inc. announced a program to cut at least 10 percent of its 3,500 nonunion workers. The company, based in Allentown, Pa., said the cuts would be made through layoffs, induced retirements and resignations. Walter C. Meck, executive vice president of finance, said he could not determine how many layoffs would be needed.

title: MEESE CRITICIZES LAW DEANS IN DISPUTE OVER JUDICIAL NOMINEE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d criticized many of the nation's most prominent law school deans today for their opposition to a judicial nominee whose legal background and political views have been fiercely challenged.

title: State Democrats Urged To Head Off LaRouche
description: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee today urged New York party officials at a forum to do everything in their power to identify, disqualify or defeat candidates affiliated with Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. ''Particularly in this state, these people are more than a nuisance factor,'' said the national chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr., who today offered his first public denunciation of the LaRouche candidates. Mr. Kirk was addressing a political forum sponsored by Governor Cuomo and the New York State Democratic Committee.

title: THE SCREEN: SYBERBERG'S 'KARL MAY'
description: IN the last decades of the 19th century, Karl May (1842-1912) was the most successful author in Germany. His books sold like pancakes topped by wild blueberries and heavy cream. For 30 years he turned out 40 pages a day, constructing a staggering body of kitsch adventure-fiction that may originally have owed a certain debt to James Fenimore Cooper but that, finally, created a mythology quintessentially German.

title: CHERTOK'S FILM RETROSPECTIVE
description: DAVID CHERTOK 's program of jazz films at the 92d Street Y on Monday evening included a segment on the late Benny Goodman, which took Mr. Goodman from 1936, the year after he burst on the scene as ''the king of swing,'' to 1973, the year of the last New York performance of the original Goodman Trio with the pianist Teddy Wilson and the drummer Gene Krupa. Most of the clips were from the 1930's and 40's when Mr. Goodman, Mr. Krupa, Lionel Hampton and others in the band were relatively young - incredibly youthful in the 30's.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Transit Police Torpedo
description: At any time in the last 16 months Governor Cuomo could have said where he stood on the proposed merger of the New York City police and Transit Police, inviting reasoned debate. Instead he waited until Friday, only a week before the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was to decide the issue, to announce his opposition. His belated reason? A merger would infringe on the M.T.A.'s independence and accountability.

title: Pornography and Laughter
description: Most bold new ideas in Government circles are either ignored or shuffled off into the bureaucratic process never to reappear, but once in a while a suggestion is simply laughed out of existence. The other day, President Reagan was meeting with senior staff members at the White House, and the recent report by the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography came up, according to one of the participants.

title: RETARDED MAN, 33, ELECTROCUTED AS PLEA TO HIGH COURT IS REJECTED
description: A retarded man whose death sentence drew protests from celebrities and groups concerned about mental retardation was executed in the electric chair today after the convicted slayer's lawyers lost an 11th-hour bid for a stay.

title: Economic Scene; Troubles Spur Peace Hopes
description: NOTES and impressions on the economics of war and peace, after a swing through Europe and the Middle East:

title: DAVIS TELLS OF 'COLLABORATION'
description: Al Davis, the managing general partner of the Los Angeles Raiders, told a jury in Federal District Court yesterday that he thought the National Football League helped destroy the Oakland Invaders of the United States Football League. He also said that he viewed certain statements made by Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the N.F.L. to one U.S.F.L. owner as ''an enticement'' to lure the owner into the N.F.L.

title: POLE CITES SUBVERSION BY WEST
description: A general in the Polish secret police charged today that Poles were being trained at bases in the West, including one in New Jersey, for sabotage and terrorist attacks against Poland.

title: Chile Strike Call Broadcast
description: Leftist guerrillas raided the studios of two radio stations today to broadcast a statement supporting a general strike against Chile's military Government next Tuesday and Wednesday to press for a return to democracy after almost 13 years of military rule. The police said three men forced their way into the shared studios of Radio Mineria and Radio Galaxia, locked 10 staffers in a bathroom and transmitted a message in the name of the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front.

title: The Very Last Line of Defense
Army Launches 3 Missiles
description: The Army successfully launched three Pershing 2 missiles today. They were the first fully operational missiles fired to verify readiness under battlefield conditions. The first 8-ton, 35-foot-long missile, equipped with a dummy warhead, streaked away from its mobile launcher at the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station at 9:56 A.M. and headed toward an unidentified target in the Atlantic Ocean. The second missile was launched at 11:23 A.M. and the third at 12:33 P.M.

title: Esselte Letraset
description: To expand its product offerings, the Esselte Letraset division of Esselte Business Systems Inc., which makes office and graphic arts supplies, said it had reached an agreement to buy all the shares of the International Typeface Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. I.T.C. is a privately owned company and a worldwide supplier of typeface designs for typesetters, film fonts and computer and software programs. Esselte Business Systems Inc., of Garden City, L.I., earned $34.4 million on revenues of $695.5 million last year.

title: 'Regrets Only'
description: The book that social and journalistic Washington has been apprehensively awaiting for years has made its appearance. The first copies of ''Regrets Only'' by Sally Quinn, a former reporter for The Washington Post known for her acidulous writing, are circulating among insiders, and the usual roman-a-clef guessing game is under way.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A front-page dispatch from Johannesburg yesterday recounted a debate about the extent of Communist influence on the African National Congress, the most prominent South African guerrilla movement. The headline said, ''Wild Card in South Africa: Communist Party.''

title: First of the Tall Ships To Arrive Here Today
description: The first of the tall ships is to arrive today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S SPEECH ON AID FOR NICARAGUA REBELS
description: Following are excerpts from the text of President Reagan's speech today on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, as made public by the White House:

title: The Amazing Unsinkable Tax Bill, Cont.
description: The Senate's 97-to-3 vote yesterday does not enact tax reform, but the final leap to lower tax rates and fewer loopholes is now virtually assured. Two years in the making, a better tax code should come to pass within the next few months. How much better depends on the handful of legislators who will now marry the bills passed by each body.

title: WHITE HOUSE PLOY IS SEEN BY O'NEILL
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., charged today that the White House had tried to embarrass him by requesting that President Reagan be allowed to address the House of Representatives on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: OPEC Is Still Split on Cuts
description: OPEC oil ministers met informally on the Adriatic island of Brioni today, one day before beginning the group's regular summer session that will focus on ways to reduce crude-oil production and raise prices.

title: BRIGHTON BEACH IS PROPOSED SITE OF NEW PROJECT
description: A Miami developer announced plans yesterday to build a $300 million, 2,200-apartment condominium complex on the Atlantic Ocean in the Brighton Beach section that would be Brooklyn's largest new private housing development in at least 25 years.

title: Banc One to Buy Bank in Indiana
description: The Banc One Corporation, the fast-growing bank holding company based in Columbus, Ohio, said it had agreed to acquire the First National Corporation, which owns the First National Bank of Bloomington, Ind.

title: A 36% Rise in City Murders Cited in March Police Data
description: Led by a 36.2 percent rise in reported murders, the number of major crimes reported in New York City increased 8.6 percent in March from the same period in 1985, the Police Department announced yesterday.

title: People
description: * Norman Berry, creative head, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and president, Ogilvy & Mather, New York, has been elected to the executive committee of the Ogilvy Group.

title: 'HANDS-ON' CHAIRMAN AT MAY PRESSURES . . .LAISSEZ-FAIRE HEAD AT ASSOCIATED, THE PREY
description: David C. Farrell, according to people who know him, is a driven executive who loves a challenge, and he has a big one on his hands right now. Mr. Farrell, the chairman and chief executive of the May Department Stores Company, is seeking to acquire the Associated Dry Goods Corporation in a stock swap valued at $2.7 billion.

title: 'Ten by Tennessee' Closing
description: ''Ten by Tennessee,'' two rotating programs of one-act plays by Tennessee Williams, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Lucille Lortel Theater. Directed by Michael Kahn, the production will have run for 53 performances.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: An Olive Oil Returns This is the second year Huile d'Olive du Jardin will be available commercially and only in New York. One of the richest, most fragrant and fruity French extra-virgin olive oils yet, it comes from olive trees on the country estate of a Parisian doctor and his wife, a photographer, in the village of Lagnes, near Avignon. About 100 bottles of the cold-pressed oil are available exclusively at Custom Cuisine, 290 West 12th Street, telephone 212-691-7141. The oil is $25 a liter. The price includes delivery. Vintage Preserves

title: 3-NATION PLAN BEGUN TO SAVE RARE ASIAN OX
description: Wildlife specialists are using the current peace in Indochina, unsettled as it is, to see if an elusive wild ox, the kouprey, can be saved from extinction.

title: Barter Could Bring A Revolution in Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: A STICKY WICKET FOR MEESE
description: A lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the Federal Reserve System's vastly powerful Open Market Committee has put President Reagan's Justice Department in a ticklish spot.

title: ARTHUR L. SULLIVAN
description: Arthur L. Sullivan, a New York insurance executive, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 82 years old. Mr. Sullivan was president of Pension and Welfare Consultants Inc., from 1964 to 1972 and was its chairman from 1972 to 1986. From 1945 to 1964, he was general agent of Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Company and from 1932 to 1945 assistant manager with the Guardian Life Insurance Company.

title: Hotline
description: Manager John Felske, when the phone rang in the Phillies' clubhouse after their 19-1 rout of the Cubs: ''Who is it, Reagan?''

title: Advertising; Ted Bates Loses Two Big Clients
description: TED BATES, which recently agreed to be acquired by Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi to create the largest advertising company in the world, was hit yesterday by a double client loss for which conflicts growing out of that and other mergers were at least partly responsible.

title: Stand-Ins for Shy Darth
description: There hasn't been enough conservatism on the Supreme Court lately, but from now on there will be plenty. This is the burden of the news stories about President Reagan's remaking of the Court.

title: The U.N. Today: June 25, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Conference on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: A Doctor Pleads for Tolerance
description: A barrage of criticism has been leveled against physicians by people who believe doctors should personally pay out part of ''malpractice'' awards against them. It is easy to understand how these feelings originate. They are based on the idea that a physician guilty of malpractice is under the effects of drugs or alcohol or is opportunistically attracted to profit by any means. Most people conceive of malpractice that way, imagining a physician who abuses his patients cynically or with intentional negligence.

title: HOUSE APPROVES COMPROMISE SPENDING BILL
description: The House late today approved a $1.7 billion spending bill to keep a variety of Federal activities - including processing of tax returns, civil jury trials, air traffic control and farm programs - operating through the end of the fiscal year.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Plastic Surgeon on L.I. Indicted in Fraud Case
description: A Huntington plastic surgeon and his wife have been indicted on charges of defrauding patients by pressuring them to undergo plastic surgery and then providing substandard treatment, in some instances by unlicensed workers.

title: MEASURE TO EXTEND U.S. DAYLIGHT TIME IS SENT TO PRESIDENT
description: Daylight saving time would begin the first Sunday in April in 1987 rather than the last Sunday of the month under a bill passed by the House today and sent to President Reagan for his signature, which is expected.

title: Howe Reinstated
description: Steve Howe, cleared of an accusation that he was using cocaine again, was reinstated yesterday with the San Jose Bees, a Class A minor league team, and said he expects to be back pitching in the big leagues soon. Howe was suspended May 15 by John Johnson, president of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, after a disputed drug test.

title: ANGELS TIE RANGERS FOR LEAD
description: Rob Wilfong's three-run double highlighted a six-run third inning tonight as the California Angels beat the Texas Rangers, 12-3, and tied for first place in the American League West.

title: Nagelsen Upsets Shriver in 3 Sets
description: Her preparation begins in the early-spring, when many of the women are busy tackling the clay at the French Open. Pam Shriver slips discreetly away to the grass courts of England, putting the finishing touches on a game she thinks is suited to win the singles title at Wimbledon.

title: SHAKER GETS CBS WORKLOAD
description: A day after he was named the executive producer of CBS Sports, Ted Shaker confessed to some conflicting emotions.

title: Hearns Awaits Hagler
description: After retaining his World Boxing Council super welterweight title by stopping Mark Medal in the eighth round Monday night in Las Vegas, Nev., Thomas Hearns is awaiting word on whether Marvelous Marvin Hagler will give him a rematch. The rematch was thrown into limbo when Sugar Ray Leonard announced in early May that he would come out of retirement if Hagler would agree to fight him.

title: EXALTING IN ICE CREAM, EXOTIC AND PLAIN
description: The mother of the bride-to-be directed an urgent letter to the University of Wisconsin's dairy store. ''Having grown up in Madison on ice cream from Babcock Hall,'' the mother wrote on her daughter's behalf, ''she'd like to have some to serve with the cake.'' Enough for 150 guests shipped to central Illinois in the heat of June, if you please. Such are the burdens of ice cream excellence.

title: Kiwanis Bars Women In Closest Vote on Issue
description: Members of Kiwanis International today rejected a proposal to permit women to join the worldwide service club, marking the 11th time in as many years that such a proposal has been turned down.

title: TAX REVISION BILL PASSES SENATE, 97-3; PRESIDENT HAILS IT
description: The Senate passed the tax revision bill today with an overwhelming bipartisan vote, setting the stage for a conference with the House of Representatives.

title: Chicago Paper In Sale Talks
description: A group of investors led by publisher Robert E. Page is negotiating a leveraged buyout of The Chicago Sun-Times from Rupert Murdoch, the newspaper reported in today's edition.

title: SUSPECT IS ARRESTED IN KILLING OF BOY, 15, ON CLOSED HIGHWAY
description: A 46-year-old man whose home was a shack on the old West Side Highway was charged with second-degree murder yesterday in the June 16 slaying of a 15-year-old boy who had been roller-skating on the elevated roadway, the police reported.

title: JERSEY VEHICLES AGENCY CITED FOR BAD JUDGMENT
description: The State Commission of Investigation today accused the New Jersey Division of Motor Vehicles of mismanagement and Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, of ''professional misjudgment'' in their handling of a $6.5 million computer contract.

title: PERALES FAULTS CITY'S SHELTERS
description: The State Commissioner of Social Services yesterday called the city's system of finding shelter for homeless families ''badly managed,'' and threatened to assign a management team to supervise the operation if it is not improved.

title: New Book Tells of Nixon Plan
description: A former aide to President Nixon says the Watergate scandals ended Mr. Nixon's plan to get his son-in-law, David Eisenhower, elected to the White House.

title: Soldiers Move to End District Clashes in Beirut
description: Lebanese soldiers were deployed today around Palestinian neighborhoods on the southern margins of Beirut in an attempt to end five weeks of clashes between Palestinians and Shiites.

title: STAGE: ZALOOM'S 'THEATER OF TRASH'
description: TRASH, of any kind, has seldom been more interesting than it is in ''Theater of Trash'' by Paul Zaloom and Company, Fruit of Zaloom at the Dance Theater Workshop. A vacuum cleaner hose becomes a disco dancer high on cocaine, a garland of plastic lemons is a fleet of cars, shoes are children, milk cartons are cows and crumpled newspapers are agile puppets.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Larry H. Miller, an auto dealer and already a part-owner of the Utah Jazz, has purchased Sam Battistone's interest in the team to become sole owner and keep the team in Salt Lake City. The Salt Lake Tribune reported that Miller paid $12 million for Battistone's half-interest. . . . Two defensemen, Serge Savard and Leo Boivin, and a center, Dave Keon, were named to the Hockey Hall of Fame. . . . Brian Kilrea, former assistant coach of the Islanders, was named coach and general manager of the Ottawa 67's of the junior Ontario Hockey League. . . . Mike Krzyzewski of Duke was named coach of the United States men's basketball team for the 1987 World University Games in Zagreb, Yugoslavia.

title: Replay of Political Football's Block of the Week
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSERVATIVE DEMOCRAT APPEARS A NARROW VICTOR IN ALABAMA GUBERNATORIAL RUNOFF
description: State Attorney General Charles Graddick, a conservative and former Republican, appeared to eke out a narrow victory tonight over Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley for the Democratic nomination to succeed Gov. George C. Wallace.

title: Lopez to Resume
description: Nancy Lopez, who has been off the Ladies Professional Golfers Association tour since January awaiting the birth of her second daughter, Errin Shea, will begin hitting golf balls next week with an eye on defending her Henredon Classic title in August.

title: CHILE'S GRAPE GROWERS EXPAND EXPORTS
description: THERE was a time when Chileans thought grapes were something to be used only in making the country's high-quality wines. The wines - mostly chardonnay and cabernet sauvignon - were, and still are, the most pleasurable part of long lunches under the high, dry Andes sun, a constant of Chilean life.

title: HEADACHES OF CATERING THE EVENT
description: THE bidding for the catering job was intense. Winnowed down to the large, prestigious companies -Glorious Food, Abigail Kirsch Culinary Production Ltd. and Robert Day Dean of Restaurant Associates - Glorious Food was ultimately triumphant, winning the right to provide the food for the official Liberty Weekend festivities on Governors Island July 3 and 4.

title: MORE CYANIDE-LACED CAPSULES FOUND NEAR SEATTLE
description: Cyanide was found today in a package of Anacin-3 capsules in the same Seattle suburb where two poisoning deaths earlier this month were linked to tainted Extra-Strength Excedrin capsules, the police said.

title: Ohio Sewer Bonds
description: Columbus, Ohio, is tentatively offering $209 million of sewer system revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8 1/8 percent an issue due in 2008 through underwriters led by the Ohio Company. Yields on shorter maturities range from 5.70 percent for bonds due in 1989 to 6.30 percent in 1991 and 7.90 percent in 2000. The bonds, backed by revenues of the city-owned sewer system, are A+ by S. & P., with underwriters expecting an A rating or better by Moody's.

title: Warner-Lambert Closing Jersey Plant
description: The Warner-Lambert Company, the giant pharmaceutical and consumer products concern, said yesterday that it would close its Parke-Davis pharmaceutical plant in Morris Plains, N.J., by 1989.

title: SEVEN-UP SALE TO PEPSICO CANCELED
description: The Philip Morris Companies said today that it had ended its agreement to sell its Seven-Up Company to Pepsico Inc. because of opposition by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Jackson to Memphis
description: Bo Jackson, the 1985 Heisman Trophy winner out of Auburn who chose baseball over football and signed a contract with the Kansas City Royals, will begin his pro career in Class AA ball with the Memphis Chicks in the Southern League.

title: 106 HOURS, 24 VOTES, BUT IT'S NOT OVER
description: Despite the Senate's celebration of the historic tax revision bill it approved today, after 13 days of often late and grueling debate, there was a perceptible weariness in the air.

title: SOFT-SOLED REVOLUTION STRIDES INTO FASHION
description: AT 8:30 A.M. last Thursday, a steady stream of walkers poured out of Central Park's pathways onto sunny Fifth Avenue. But the clickety-click of hurrying heels could hardly be heard and only rarely was the flash of shiny shoe leather seen. Most of the morning's purposeful pedestrians strode silently by on the soft-cushioned soles of what were once known as sneakers, those dumpy but utilitarian Volkswagen Beetles for the feet.

title: INSURANCE CURBS TO HELP DOCTORS VOTED IN ALBANY
description: Governor Cuomo and leaders of the State Legislature announced agreement Tuesday on a plan to slow the rapid rise in medical malpractice insurance rates, which has forced some doctors to reduce services and has pushed up the cost of medical care.

title: COSTAL OFFERING
description: The Coastal Corporation, a Houston-based natural gas pipeline company, is raising $900 million through a two-part offering of 10-year and 20-year debentures to reduce existing bank debt having various interest rates and shorter maturities resulting from the $2.5 billion acquisition of American Natural Resources a year ago. Underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. are offering $500 million of 11 1/4 percent senior notes due 1996 at a price of par.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: On a hot city rooftop, the tar sticks to the bottom of your lounge chair and you wonder why you hadn't gone in on a Fire Island share. There's a couple who can't wait to go co-op, a bubbly, budding actress eating yogurt doing Yoga, and a retired dresser from some Broadway show with his Pekingese and toga. You hang your head over the ten-story drop, asking ''Why am I here?'' ''Where am I going?'' and ''What shall I have for dinner?'' Your friend says Monopoly was a waste of time since he was not the winner. You let your body be right where it is, on a hot tar beach, on a plastic chair, floating under the midtown skyline and wherever it is, you'd rather be there, than say, working the Alaskan pipeline.

title: A SUPER-DRUGSTORE IS SET FOR BEDFORD-STUYVESANT
description: Since the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation was established in Brooklyn nearly two decades ago, this nonprofit organization has developed a string of successful residential and commercial ventures.

title: Why We Are Better Off Without SALT II
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael D. Nott Wed To Dawn K. Upshaw
description: Dawn Kelly Upshaw, a soprano who is a member of the Metropolitan Opera's Young Artists Program, and Michael David Nott, who will be a visiting assistant professor of music at Vassar College in the 1986-87 academic year, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. DeWitt Mallory performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Topics; Presidential Insults: On 'Murder'
description: Last January, the President of the United States told a member of the National Right-to-Life Committee that an end to bombings and other violence would earn the movement ''a lot of Brownie points.'' This week, he himself committed the crudest rhetorical violence.

title: MID-JUNE CAR SALES ROSE 4.4%
description: Sales of new domestically produced automobiles remained firm in the June 11-20 selling period, with deliveries up 4.4 percent from the comparable period last year, the major manufacturers reported today.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 8.50 8.50 9.50 DISCOUNT RATE * 6.50 6.50 7.50 FEDERAL FUNDS * 6.88 6.91 7.60 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS * 6.07 6.12 7.07 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS * 6.10 6.18 7.25 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 7.44 7.57 10.46 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 7.37 7.45 10.68 TELEPHONE BONDS 9.22 9.26 11.84 MUNICIPAL BONDS * 8.14 8.22 9.43 * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. RED SOX, at Boston, 7:35 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS. MONTREAL EXPOS, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) ATLANTA BRAVES VS.

title: 17 ARE WOUNDED IN 2 BOMB EXPLOSIONS IN CENTRAL JOHANNESBURG
description: Two bombs exploded in a crowded fast-food outlet and outside a hotel here today, wounding 17 people.

title: MAIN BREAK AND FIRE CREATE HAVOC IN RUSH-HOUR SERVICE
description: More than a quarter of a million rush-hour passengers were delayed yesterday morning after a water-main break stopped service on the Lexington Avenue subway line and a trash fire in Grand Central Terminal blocked all incoming Metro-North Commuter Railroad trains.

title: The U.S. Can Trust Gonzalez
description: Americans ought to be pleased by the re-election of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. The charismatic 44-year-old incumbent is a known risk-taker and a Socialist determined to continue on the left-of-center course he has pursued for the past four years, but he has shown himself to be a staunch friend of the United States.

title: LOUD JULY 4 MAY TERRORIZE PETS
description: A LONG-HAIRED poodle named Ben, straining at his leash, stood on the fringe of Battery Park, which will soon be crowded with thousands of July Fourth revelers. The owner said she was taking her pet to Connecticut for the holiday weekend. ''I'm leaving Battery Park to the tourists,'' she said, hurrying off into the wind.

title: Dominican Clash Leads To General's Removal
description: President Salvador Jorge Blanco dismissed his commanding general today, a presidential spokesman said. The move came a day after five people were reportedly killed when troops opened fire on demonstrators protesting the result of general elections held last month.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT was not until I arrived in this country several decades ago that I discovered the delights of whole kernels of corn, either on or off the cob. When I was a child in France, corn was seldom, if ever, in vegetable markets. Although many acres were devoted to raising corn, it was the large-kernel variety grown for livestock feed. In France today, fresh corn is served at home, although rarely in restaurants.

title: New Mexico Bond Demand Is High
description: Strong investor demand for an $85 million issue of New Mexico severance-tax revenue bonds was noted yesterday, despite an announcment by Moody's Investors Service last week that it had lowered the triple-A rating of New Mexico's severance-tax bonds to double-A. The bonds are rated AA+ by S. & P. Since the bonds are backed by severance-tax collections from contractors who mine the state's natural gas, oil, coal and other minerals, Moody's felt that lower energy prices and diminished expectations for the mining sector could reduce margins of protection for bonds payable solely from severance taxes.

title: DICK WELLSTOOD ON THE PIANO
description: A PERFORMANCE by Dick Wellstood Monday evening in the JVC Jazz Festival's daily series of piano recitals at Bruno Walter Auditorium in Lincoln Center brought out both his striding skills and his pixie charm.

title: MEXICANS, HURT IN THE OIL CRISIS, TURN THEIR ANGER ON DE LA MADRID
description: Barely halfway through his term in office, President Miguel de la Madrid has become the target of growing disenchantment with the political system that has long dominated Mexico.

title: REAGAN, IN APPEAL TO HELP CONTRAS, CITES SOVIET PERIL
description: President Reagan, warning that the United States faced ''the reality of a Soviet military beachhead'' in Nicaragua, appealed to House members today to endorse a $100 million aid package to the rebels seeking the overthrow of the Sandinista Government.

title: Money and Fish
description: Tonight is a night for Democratic fund-raisers in unusual settings. Backers of Terry Sanford, the former North Carolina Governor running for the Senate, will hold a $50-a-person fish fry aboard The First Lady, a Potomac cruise ship moored at Pier 4 on Washington's southwest waterfront.

title: Bridge: 2 Americans to Represent Britain in a World Match
description: Europeans who have moved West across the Atlantic have sometimes represented their adopted country, but the converse is rather rarer.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday summarizing the cases that resulted in Roy M. Cohn's disbarment misidentified some parties who sued the estate of Lewis S. Rosenstiel, founder of the Schenley Distillers empire. The estate was sued by a bank acting on behalf of Mr. Rosenstiel's granddaughter Cathy Finkelstein, and by her father and brother. Her former father-in-law, Jerry Finkelstein, and her ex-husband, James Finkelstein, were not parties to the suit.

title: MUSIC: SAMUEL VIVIANO, PIANO
description: THE pianist Samuel Viviano devoted his entire Sunday afternoon recital at Merkin Concert Hall to 20th-century American music by George Crumb, Charles Ives, John Anthony Lennon and Don Freund. While one automatically respects such an endeavor, the fact remains that Mr. Viviano was, for the most part, better than his material.

title: SHULTZ SIGNS PACT TO SPEED AID TO MANILA
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz signed an agreement today to turn over $200 million to the Philippines to help it deal with its severe financial problems.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 25, 1986
description: International

title: NELSON H. CRUIKSHANK
description: Nelson Hale Cruikshank, president emeritus of the National Council of Senior Citizens who was an authority on the Social Security System, died Thursday at Stapeley Hall, a Philadelphia nursing home.

title: Voting and Marriage
description: The House of Representatives can be a remarkably accommodating institution. When Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the Republican floor leader, learned that one of his colleagues, Representative Jerry Lewis of California, was getting married back in the district next Saturday to his administrative assistant, Arlene M. Wills, he realized the event might draw some Republican lawmakers away from Washington at the end of the week.

title: A LITTLE FUN WITH THE GAMES
description: Soviet bureaucrats have a reputation for neither a wild sense of humor nor thick skins. So there were some knowing nods back in the States when word got around that Soviet sports officials, despite the millions of dollars in losses that the coming Goodwill Games in Moscow are certain to incur, had vetoed a couple of potential sponsors because the companies' television advertising was having some fun at the Russians' expense.

title: PANEL VOTES TO IMPEACH JUDGE
description: A House subcommittee today unanimously recommended that Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne be impeached. Members expressed outrage that the judge, jailed on a conviction for tax-evasion, continued to collect his $78,700 salary.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: PAVAROTTI ON STAGE IN PEKING
description: To shouts of ''Maestro!'' and ''Bravo!'' Luciano Pavarotti began a two-week engagement today in China, where a vogue for Western opera is overshadowing the traditional operatic forms.

title: CO-OP CITY: A REFUGE IN TRANSITION
description: After an 18-year history punctuated by corruption charges, power struggles and a yearlong rent strike, Co-op City in the Bronx stands as one of the most politicized parcels of New York. At the same time, it remains one of the most hopeful, still true to its conception as a refuge for the middle class.

title: Shubert Group Awards $3.3 Million in Grants
description: The Shubert Foundation and the Shubert Organization yesterday announced grants totaling $3.3 million, the largest in the history of the foundation, to 199 performing arts groups, graduate theater departments at major universities and other arts related organizations.

title: A Concern for Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: VIRAL hepatitis - the most common serious liver affliction - is one of the most difficult infectious disorders to conquer. More than a decade ago, medical researchers isolated the virus causing hepatitis B, or what was long called serum hepatitis. A method of screening donated blood was established to prevent its spread through blood transfusions, and five years ago a vaccine to protect those at greatest risk for hepatitis B was licensed.

title: WINE TALK
description: WRITING a regular column is a lot like tossing pebbles down a well. You can't see where they go, but you listen for the splash. Sometimes there is none, or only a very small one. But now and then something evokes an interesting response.

title: KILLER CAPTURED
description: A daylong hostage standoff at a fashionable Rodeo Drive jewelers' ended in gunfire and grenade blasts late Monday night, with three store employees slain.

title: THE WOES AT PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: When American Airlines cut some of its air fares below those of People Express early last year, Donald C. Burr, People's maverick chairman, was not worried. But when his own mother told him she was about to book one of the flights because she did not mind American's 30-day advance purchase requirement, he said, ''I knew they were onto something.''

title: DOUBT FOUND ON FAIRNESS AND CUTS
description: The American public, acknowledging that it knows little about the Senate tax bill, remains unconvinced that the bill would produce a fairer tax system or cut many people's taxes, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: HEADED NO-CAL SOFT DRINKS
description: Morris Kirsch, the retired chairman of Kirsch Beverages, which 30 years ago introduced the nation to sugar-free soda under the No-Cal label, died last Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 79 years old and lived in Bay Harbor Islands, Fla.

title: RAYMOND S. REED JR.
description: Raymond S. Reed Jr., a former president of the Manhattan toy company F. A. O. Schwarz, died of cancer Friday at his home in Darien, Conn.

title: Arbitron and SAMI Set Plans for Mediawatch
description: At a news conference yesterday, Time Inc.'s Selling Areas Marketing, and Control Data's Arbitron announced their plans for Mediawatch, a state-of-the-art system for monitoring television stations around the clock to verify that commercials are running as ordered, and also to supply a myriad of marketing data on the effectiveness of the advertising in creating sales.

title: SANDINISTAS' FOES AT HOME FAULT U.S.
description: Opposition political leaders in Nicaragua said in interviews this week that they wished the Reagan Administration would do more to support their cause.

title: CITY REPORT SAYS AMERUSO BROKE NO LAWS IN DEAL FOR PARKING LOT
description: Anthony R. Ameruso, the city's former Transportation Commissioner, did not ''willfully violate any law'' when he invested in a Manhattan parking lot, Mayor Koch's special commissioner investigating municipal corruption said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ART'S 'MUFFLED VOICES' There is a form of American art that does not fit into the established schools of either recognized folk art (which its protagonists say ended around 1900) or modern art (which its critics say doesn't fit into any school) This outcast form is called contemporary folk art, and one may sample it at the exhibition ''Muffled Voices: Folk Artists in Contemporary America,'' in the roomy Art Gallery, in the lobby of the Paine Webber headquarters building, 51st Street and Avenue of the Americas (713-2867).

title: Eastern Names Acting Chief
description: Joseph B. Leonard, the president and chief operating officer of Eastern Air Lines Inc., was named acting chief executive yesterday, succeeding Frank Borman, who earlier this month announced his resignation as chairman and chief executive, effective next Monday.

title: LILCO TAKEOVER STUDY SHOWS SMALL IMPACT BY SHOREHAM
description: Replacing the Long Island Lighting Company with a public utility could save ratepayers money whether or not the nuclear power plant at Shoreham is operated, according to a state report issued yesterday.

title: Shultz Given Award For Public Service; Perot Also Honored
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was honored today for outstanding public service and was praised for his flexibility on arms control.

title: Dow Up 11.29 on Hopes of Lower Rates
