description: New signs of a weak economy again raised hopes of lower interest rates, and this sent stock prices to near-record levels on Wall Street yesterday before profit taking forced the market to settle for a more moderate gain.

title: 7 COMPOSERS TO WRITE FOR '88 FESTIVAL
description: Seven original orchestral and chamber pieces have been commissioned for presentation at the first New York International Festival of the Arts, Martin E. Segal, chairman of the festival, and Willard C. Butcher, chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, announced yesterday.

title: A LAST CHANCE FOR LOBBYISTS
description: With Senate passage of its sweeping tax revision plan today, the last and most important battle over what will be incorporated in the final House-Senate package begins in earnest.

title: Why We Are Better Off Without SALT II; Mistake in Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 Vietnamese Officials Dismissed or Reassigned
description: Vietnam, apparently in an attempt to regain control of its economy before a Communist Party congress, has dismissed or reassigned eight ministers.

title: Upjohn Shifts Are Indicated
description: The Upjohn Company has made some changes with its proprietary drug assignments that it has not announced yet.

title: A LONG LOOK BACKWARD, AND AHEAD, BY ROSTOW
description: To get to Walt Whitman Rostow's eighth-floor office in the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library and Museum here, a visitor makes his way through memorabilia of another era, slightly eerie reminders that it has been almost two decades since the Johnson Presidency ended.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: THE second child was a year old yesterday.

title: 'My Name Is A-l-l-e-n Davis'
description: In the hushed hallway outside Room 318 in the Federal Courthouse at Foley Square, people were standing around, waiting for the United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League to resume. Several jurors had been delayed by yesterday's morning flood in the Lexington Avenue subway.

title: CBS Stock Up Sharply
description: CBS Inc.'s stock continued to rise yesterday, jumping $6.375, to close at $148.375 on modest volume of about 75,500 shares. The rise followed an increase of $3.25 a share on Monday.

title: CONNORS'S LOSS IN OPENER EARLIEST WIMBLEDON EXIT
description: Perhaps it was only fitting that the end came at twilight, when even the squeals of the usually reserved Wimbledon fans could not help Jimmy Connors reach far enough into the past to avoid defeat today. He did try, pumping his right arm after fighting off a second match point in a fourth-set tiebreaker against Robert Seguso on Court 1, daring Seguso to try that again. He saved another match point, too, and made a few more believers. This was going to be just like old times after all.

title: SEMIFINAL STIRS '82 MEMORIES
description: History often repeats itself in soccer the way it does in other fields.

title: To Disabled, New York Is Inaccessibility City
description: To the Editor:

title: Rhode Island Priest Gets Year in Sex Assault Case
description: A Roman Catholic priest pleaded no contest Monday to 26 charges of sexually assaulting boys and was sentenced to a year in prison.

title: HUNT'S SUIT SEEKS $1.2 BILLION FROM 23 BANKS
description: Members of the Hunt family and two of their energy companies filed a civil lawsuit today against 23 banks. The family, the Penrod Drilling Company and the Placid Oil Company say the banks breached the loan contracts and therefore are not entitled to be repaid the more than $1.5 billion of debt owed the banks. The suit also asks for at least $1.2 billion in damages.

title: Soviet Paper Discloses Expulsions of Americans
description: The Government newspaper Izvestia said today that two United States diplomats had been expelled in recent years as spies.

title: Plane Crash Attributed To Tail Malfunction
description: A malfunction in the airplane's tail control system caused the crash of a Provincetown-Boston Airline commuter flight in Florida that killed 13 people, Federal officials concluded today.

title: PANAMA'S STRONGMAN TRIES TO RIDE OUT THE STORM
description: Despite charges of criminal activity and opposition calls for his resignation, Panama's army commander appears to be fighting with considerable determination to remain as the country's pre-eminent leader.

title: Dollar, After Steep Fall, Stabilizes; Gold Is Up
description: The dollar stabilized late today, leveling off after a steep selloff that began suddenly Monday in the United States and spread today to Japanese and European foreign exchange markets today.

title: Prophets Who Deserve Honor
description: The death, last month, of Chester Bowles, a prominent diplomat from the Kennedy era, prompts a troubling question: why does America so consistently punish its prophets and reward its time-servers and knaves?

title: STUDY ABROAD SEEN AS FALLING VICTIM TO TERRORISM
description: Study abroad, increasingly an important part of the American college experience, appears to be suffering at the hands of international terrorism.

title: Kingman Fined $3,500
description: The Oakland A's announced tonight they had fined Dave Kingman $3,500 for sending a small live rat to a female sportswriter and said he would be released if a ''similar incident'' occurs. Kingman had the rodent delivered in a pink box to Susan Fornoff of The Sacramento Bee during the first inning of Monday night's Oakland-Kansas City game.

title: House Panel Lifts a Barrier To a Navy Port on Staten I.
description: The House Armed Services Committee today approved the spending of funds for a Navy port on Staten Island, removing the final barrier in Congress to the project.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $309 million refunding by the Metropolitan Government of Nashville and Davidson County, Tenn., was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum of 7.55 percent for 6 1/2 percent bonds due in 2006 at a price of 89 1/4.

title: GORBACHEV STILL SEEKING PROGRESS ON ARMS BEFORE SUMMIT MEETING
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has told President Reagan that a meeting this year would not make sense without ''concrete achievements'' on nuclear arms control, according to Administration officials. But they said the Soviet leader had also carefully avoided making this a precondition for a meeting.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 25, 1986
description: The Tax Bill

title: Nothing Centrist About Abortion Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Quick Hands, Square Bags
description: Karen Cosentino was defending her grocery-bag packing championship yesterday. And Jeanne Bakelar, a judge, was explaining the secret of Mrs. Cosentino's success:

title: PHYSICIANS DESCRIBE APPARENT RECOVERY OF AN AIDS PATIENT
description: American researchers said today that for the first time a human immune system severely damaged by AIDS had been restored to apparently normal health.

title: THE DANCE: ANNA HALPRIN IN FESTIVAL
description: The sight of nearly 300 women and children snaking their way in chain formation through a gym or standing still in a huge cluster while humming in unison may look old hat to alumni of the 1960's counterculture - it is certainly not the signature mark of the yuppie-filled 1980's.

title: BLAKE LEIGH LAWRENCE
description: Blake Leigh Lawrence, a partner in the family-owned New York textile concern of Folkard & Lawrence for 40 years, died Monday at his home in Charlotte, Vt. He was 88 years old.

title: SYRIA TERROR LINK CITED BY ITALIAN
description: Italy's Interior Minister said today that Italian judges had obtained ''concrete evidence'' that Syria was one of the sources of international terrorism.

title: COVERING THE GAMUT, FROM MODELING TO MUGGERS
description: Lisa Sliwa, national director of the Guardian Angels, holds a black belt in karate. According to her husband, Curtis, founder of the group, ''she also holds a black belt in cooking - she could kill you either way.''

title: Bond Prices in Strong Rally
description: Signs of continued weakness in both the American and Japanese economies helped to spark a strong rally in the credit markets yesterday, pushing up prices by more than a point on some long-term Treasury issues and lifting prices for corporate and municipal issues as well.

title: SESQUICENTENNIAL RECALLS SERVICE BY NUNS' ORDER
description: Fifty years before the Statue of Liberty was formally presented to the United States by France, the St. Louis area received another French gift: six young nuns who came here from Lyons to teach the deaf, work with the poor and proclaim the word of God.

title: POP: MIKE AND MECHANCIS
description: AMONG several offshoots of the long-running English art-rock group Genesis, Mike and the Mechanics -the quintet headed by the parent group's bassist-guitarist Mike Rutherford - is the most conventional. The quintet, which opened Pier 84's summer season of rock concerts, at 45th Street and 12th Avenue on Monday evening, makes competently crafted mainstream pop-rock that never strays very far from various proven commercial idioms.

title: Talks Ended By San Miguel
description: The San Miguel Corporation says its subsidiary that runs a brewery in Hong Kong has called off negotiations on selling the brewery to Anheuser-Busch International Inc.

title: CONCERT: THE COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA
description: THE American Composers Orchestra had been performing of late in Carnegie Hall. But Monday night the group put on a special concert in Merkin Concert Hall. With only a reduced string complement plus various soloists on hand, and five short pieces of a heterogeneous stylistic nature, the program trod a little too close to the sort of earnest small-scaled new-music concert normally heard in our smaller halls.

title: Shterna Klein Is Wed
description: Shterna S. Klein, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Binyomin Klein of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Rabbi Levi Y. Krinsky, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Yehuda Krinksy, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Kelman Marlow, the couple's fathers and five other rabbis performed the ceremony at the Lubavitch World Center in Brooklyn.

title: Reagan and the Judges
description: In defending his nominations to the Federal courts, President Reagan has denounced Democratic senators for opposing some of them on partisan and ideological grounds.

title: EX-CLIENT CHARGING DECEPTION, SUES COHN ON DIVORCE ACCORD
description: Roy M. Cohn, disbarred this week by a New York State court, is being sued by a former client who accuses him of deceiving her and secretly aiding her multimillionaire husband in a divorce proceeding.

title: Pacific Stereo To Be Bought
description: U.S. Electronics Group Inc., a chain of 30 stereo and video stores based in Aurora, Colo., said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement to acquire the Pacific Stereo Corporation, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month. The agreement is subject to approval by the bankruptcy court, and by the shareholders of Pacific, a closely held company that was once the world's largest retailer of brand-name stereo equipment.

title: Displaced Homemakers
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: FOR LIBERTY'S 100TH, FIREWORKS FROM 12 TOP CHEFS
description: INDEPENDENCE DAY has always been the quintessential American holiday - loud and brash as a marching band.

title: PANEL SAYS TESTIMONY COST AIDE JOB
description: A former city personnel official was dismissed last year principally because she publicly criticized a city examination for police officers, a New York State Senate committee concluded in a report released yesterday.

title: YANKEE DOODLE DANDIES
'It Can't Happen to Me'
description: What will be the effects of Len Bias's death on other young athletes? Will they be so frightened at the possibility of mortality from cocaine use - any cocaine use, any amounts - that they will cease and desist?

title: UBS Leads Issue For Transamerica
description: UBS Securities, the New York subsidiary of the Union Bank of Switzerland, took another step yesterday in its effort to become the first foreign-owned enterprise to break into the ranks of leading United States underwriters with its role as lead manager in a $100 million issue of Transamerica Financial Corporation notes.

title: DELIGHTING IN THE SCOTCH THISTLE
description: UNLIKE some of my friends out in the country, I am not plagued by deer browsing among the plants in my garden, and the nearest cow lives several miles a way. The fauna is restricted to a few squirrels and chipmunks, and a raccoon who occasionally knocks over a garbage can. (The raccoon's other act of mischief was stealing a pizza from a picnic table a couple of weeks ago while our backs were turned.) But some of the plants I grow could take care of themselves - even if a deer or a cow made an appearance.

title: ADACORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $511,000 for the quarter and $749,000 for the year. The quarter also includes a reversal of a tax credit of $70,000. c-Includes a loss of $107,000 from discontinued operations and a reversal of a tax credit of $103,000. d-Net income and includes a loss of $18,000 from discontinued operations and a tax benefit of $355,000. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: RACAL ELECTRONICS PLC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary net losses of $20,979,000 for the latest year and $13,327,000 for the previous year. All figures have been translated from British pounds at the balance sheet rate of 1 pound equaling U.S. $1.48 and rounding differences are shown.

title: 2 ABOARD ARE SAVED
description: A helicopter with two people aboard ditched in the Hudson River yesterday afternoon after winds blew the craft off course and the pilot chose to land in the water rather than crash into a parked helicopter.

title: OPENING IS GLUM AT PARTY CONGRESS IN YUGOSLAVIA
description: Yugoslavia opened its first Communist Party Congress in four years today in a glum and self-critical mood.

title: A Residency Bill Offered in Council
description: Mayor Koch and leaders of the City Council yesterday proposed a law requiring most new nonuniformed municipal workers to live in the city.

title: AUTOSPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HOLIDAY FOR THE WALLET: CHEAPER GAS FOR JULY 4
description: Contrary to the usual trend as the Fourth of July holiday draws near, the average retail price of gasoline around the country has fallen nearly 2 cents a gallon in the last two weeks, and may continue to fall through the holiday weekend.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Advertising; Leadership Climb at B.B.D.O.
description: IT should come as no surprise to anyone that J. Thomas Clark and Philip B. Dusenberry have moved to the pinnacle of command at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, since they really have been running it for the last year and a half anyhow. Oh, and by the way, they would much prefer to be known as just plain Tom and Phil. The former is just shy of 50 years of age, the latter isn't shy at all.

title: Ex-Leader in Belgium Is Convicted of Fraud
description: A former Prime Minister was convicted today of tax fraud and forgery and was given a three-year suspended sentence.

title: THE 'NEW' MADISON AVENUE: A EUROPEAN STREET OF FASHION
description: On Madison Avenue above 60th Street, boutique after boutique has been fitted into former brownstone after brownstone, and what a decade ago was still a neighborhood street for the Upper East Side has gradually become an international shopping district reminiscent of the great shopping streets in Europe.

title: Group W Cable
description: The Century Communications Corporation said it and four other members of a consortium had completed the $1.75 billion acquisition of the Westinghouse Electric Company's Group W Cable unit. Upon liquidation of Group W, Century said it would acquire nine cable systems in California.

title: Jane's Reports Syria Plans War With Israel
description: Jane's Defense Weekly says Syria is planning a limited war with Israel later this year to regain the Golan Heights and is seeking military support from its Arab neighbors.

title: Argentina Gets Loan
description: Argentina will be allowed to draw the last $270 million of a $1.4 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund despite failure to meet agreed-upon ''performance criteria,'' I.M.F. officials said. The draw-down opens the way for Argentina to get another $600 million from private banks.

title: Chicago Paper's Chief Seeks Buyout
description: A group of investors led by Robert E. Page, the publisher and president of The Chicago Sun-Times, is negotiating to buy the newspaper from the publisher Rupert Murdoch, according to an article in yesterday's editions of The Sun-Times.

title: Hospital Unit in Florida Sets Yield as High as 9%
description: The Hillsborough County Hospital Authority in Florida began offering $152 million of hospital refunding revenue bonds yesterday tentatively priced to yield a maximum 9 percent for bonds maturing in 2013.

title: NL REJECTS OFFER FROM SIMMONS
description: NL Industries, the New York-based oil services and chemical concern, said yesterday that its board had rejected a week-old $15-a-share bid made by Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, whose companies control about 17.5 percent of NL.

title: TRW's Space Tug
description: TRW's Space and Technology Group has been selected by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to design and produce a space utility tug called the orbital maneuvering vehicle. The contract with NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center, the precise terms of which have not yet been negotiated, is expected to be worth about $200 million, including an option for a second vehicle. The vehicle's missions would include placement and retrieval of spacecraft, re-boosting spacecraft when their orbits decay and retrieval of space debris and satellite servicing.

title: BACKERS OF HUNGER PROGRAMS PRESS CONGRESS FOR MORE AID
description: Representatives of organizations founded to combat hunger urged lawmakers today to pass legislation to increase Federal spending on Government food programs.

title: AN INVITATION'S INTENT
description: Yugoslavia's decision to invite the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to hold its annual summer conference on the sunny Adriatic island of Brioni reflects a desire to underscore the country's political support for the developing world, at the same time increasing the island's market value as a venue for international conferences.

title: BUDGET NEGOTIATORS AGREE ON FRAMEWORK
description: House and Senate negotiators early today reached a ''framework'' for a 1987 budget that they hope will lead to a final budget compromise later today.

title: New Watchdog Chief
description: The Citizens Union yesterday elected a new chairman, Robert F. Wagner Jr.

title: Advertising; Wendy's Spot Created By Lockhardt & Pettus
description: A Wendy's TV commercial starring Kool and The Gang, the pop rock group, started running this week and it was not done by the fast-food chain's national agency, DFS Dorland Worldwide. Quite surprisingly the spot was created by Lockhardt & Pettus, which is on the Wendy's agency roster as a specialist in preparing advertising for the black consumer market.

title: AUTHORS PLUG BOOKS BY SATELLITE
description: Television reporters in 20 American cities interviewed Robert Lacey on Tuesday, and for four straight hours the author did not stir from a studio in Hollywood. At seven-minute intervals, broken only by brief segments during which stations in those cities hooked up to or disconnected from the satellite feed, Mr. Lacey -author of the current best seller ''Ford: The Men and the Machine'' -joked, parried and discussed his new book for viewers in locations as far apart as Eugene, Ore., and Tampa, Fla.

title: Macfadden Raises Offer for Blair
description: Macfadden Holdings Inc. raised the cash part of its offer for John Blair & Company to $32 a share yesterday and reduced the number of shares it wants to buy to 7 million, from 8 million. Macfadden's cash offer tops by $1 a share last week's offer by its rival for Blair, Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Capital Group, which is also seeking 7 million shares.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE HORNES: AN AMERICAN FAMILY. By Gail Lumet Buckley. Illustrated. 262 pages. Knopf. $18.95. ''I AM a Horne, too,'' writes

title: A RENEWED INTEREST IN METAL BEDSTEADS
description: EVER since a version of Queen Victoria's brass bed was displayed at the 1853 New York World's Fair, Americans have had an affinity for the style. Just after the fair, brass beds immediately became popular with the carriage trade, and by the 1880's, a brass bed was de rigueur in fine homes across the country.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $304,000. The company said it took writeoffs of about $1.2 million during the third quarter, principally related to its previously announced decision to divest the manufacturing and product development portions of its minicomputer business. The third quarter does not reflect the company's moves to refinance and restructure its business. Also, because its restructuring is expected to be substantially complete by the end of June, the company said it will change its fiscal year-end to June 30.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The share earnings have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 7, 1985.

title: Whitworth's Defense Gains Crucial Ruling
description: In a key ruling for the defense, Federal District Judge John P. Vukasin Jr. said today he would instruct the jury in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth that the prosecution must have proved that he stole classified Navy data with the intent of aiding the Soviet Union.

title: Ah, Earliest Life
description: As Washington obsesses on the daily zigs and zags of politics and policy, the Smithsonian can be counted upon to reflect a longer view. The Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History is opening a new permanent exhibit tomorrow on ''The Earliest Traces of Life.'' It will include some of the old-est relics of life on the planet, including a 3.5-billion-year-old stromatolite, described as a ''layered structure of blue-green algae and bacteria from Western Australia.''

title: DANCE: THE ALOK COMPANY PRESENTS STORY OF A PRODIGAL
description: ''SEINEN (YOUTH)'' was what the Alok Dance Company called the work it offered Sunday afternoon at the Norman Thomas High School. It could also have been called ''The Prodigal Son,'' for its plot resembled that of the biblical parable.

title: Investor in J. P. Stevens Has Varied Interests
description: Selim K. Zilkha, the investor who has purchased a 5 percent stake in J. P. Stevens & Company, has a history of venturing into unrelated businesses and having varying degrees of success. He currently operates SKZ Inc., an oil and gas concern in Houston and is an investor in three related real estate ventures in California, the Newhall Land and Farming Company, Newhall Investment Properties and Newhall Resources.

title: Scalia Trivia
description: Since President Reagan announced his selection of Judge Antonin Scalia for the Supreme Court, the search for Scalia trivia has turned into something of a Washington parlor game. For example: One of the judge's nine children, 22-year-old Eugene, works as a writer and researcher in the Department of Education. His duties include speechwriting for William J. Bennett, Secretary of Education, according to a spokesman for the department.

title: Maryland Begins $164.6 Million Sale
description: Maryland is offering $164.6 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST roofs in the United States are made of asphalt shingles because they are cheap and last for years with little or no maintenance. But in time even the best roofs wear out or develop leaks.

title: GUGGENHEIM PLAN DEBATED AT HEARING
description: In a crowded municipal hearing room yesterday, officials of the Guggenheim Museum and their supporters argued vigorously for a proposed expansion to the building - and an equally large group spoke in passionate opposition.

title: COSELL CONTRADICTS 2 FORMER ABC BOSSES
description: Howard Cosell, the final witness for the United States Football League in its antitrust case against the National Football League, yesterday contradicted testimony given earlier in the trial by two of his former superiors at ABC Sports.

title: Brazil and the Cubans Renew Diplomatic Ties
description: Brazil announced today that it had re-established diplomatic relations with Cuba, which were broken off 22 years ago.

title: Required Reading; Honoraria Myth
description: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, in a recent floor speech:

title: BROWN TIDE OF ALGAE IMPERILS MARINE LIFE ALONG THE L.I. COAST
description: For the second year in a row, a huge algae bloom is spreading through the coastal waters of Long Island and other parts of the Northeast, posing profound environmental and economic problems for the region.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, JUNE 26, 1986
description: Companies

title: FRUEHAUF PLANNING A BUYOUT
description: In a move to fight off a hostile takeover bid, the Fruehauf Corporation said yesterday that it was prepared to pay $48.50 a share for the company's 22.4 million shares, or $1.1 billion. It said it would make a tender offer within the week.

title: Columbia May Pick Independent Briton
description: David Puttnam, the 45-year-old British movie producer, will be named chairman and chief executive of Columbia Pictures Industries today, sources close to the situation said. According to the sources, who asked not to be named, Mr. Puttnam will assume his new post on Sept. 1.

title: SEGUSO PROVIDES A WINNING ENCORE
description: Robert the Conqueror arrived at Court 2 this afternoon, suddenly thrust into the spotlight at Wimbledon. Robert Seguso said he wished there had been more time to enjoy his first-round victory against Jimmy Connors late Tuesday afternoon before having to gather his racquets and prove he was capable of winning again. No less a doubter than Connors said it was Seguso's obligation.

title: CARLTON DROPPED AFTER REFUSING TO RETIRE
description: Steve Carlton, the only pitcher to win four Cy Young Awards, was given his unconditional release today by the Philadelphia Phillies after the left-hander struggled for two seasons with a shoulder injury and control problems.

title: G.M. to Sell Bus Operations
description: The General Motors Corporation, citing reduced orders and a stagnant bus industry, said it had decided to try to sell its bus operations. Roger B. Smith, the chairman of G.M., said that employees were notified last week of the possible sale.

title: CASTELLANO WAS GUNNED DOWN ON GOTTI'S ORDERS, F.B.I. AGENT TELLS HEARING
description: Paul Castellano was gunned down in Manhattan last December on orders from his underworld rival, John Gotti, a Federal agent testified yesterday.

title: CHICO HAMILTON SEXTET
description: CHICO HAMILTON'S current sextet, the Young Altos, is considerably more than its name suggests. It is built around three young musicians -Marc Bernstein, Ken Lampl and Eric Person - all of whom play flutes and soprano saxophones as well as alto saxophones.

title: RESULTS OF ALABAMA PRIMARY MAY BE CHALLENGED
description: State Attorney General Charles Graddick said today that unofficial returns proved he won a razor-thin victory in the Democratic gubernatorial runoff primary Tuesday in Alabama. But his opponent, Lieut. Gov. Bill Baxley, would not concede and may demand a recount.

title: HELMS SEEKS VOTE ON ARMS TREATY
description: Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, proposed today that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee send the 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty to the Senate for consideration. He acted in the apparent expectation that the unratified treaty would then be formally disapproved.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page yesterday incorrectly described the help given by Washington Post reporters to Sally Quinn, a former Post reporter, for her forthcoming novel ''Regrets Only.'' The book was written solely by Miss Quinn. Her editor at Simon & Schuster, Alice Mayhew, said some of her colleagues had read the manuscript and offered suggestions that she used in revisions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THIS YEAR'S MODELS Why go to see a model of something when you can see the real thing? Perhaps because a cleverly wrought miniature not only astutely mirrors the full-size article but also gives the viewer a greater sense of mastery, of knowledge than can be gained from visiting the original. Whatever the reason, you can check it out for yourself starting today at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium, 81st Street and Central Park West (873-8828).

title: Jack Clark Out
description: Jack Clark, the St. Louis Cardinal first baseman, tore a ligament in his right thumb sliding into third base Tuesday and will undergo surgery, sidelining him until September, the club announced yesterday. Clark, 30, the Cardinals' cleanup hitter, injured the thumb while sliding head-first against the Pittsburgh Pirates. Jim Toomey, the Cardinals' spokesman, said that Clark's thumb would be in a cast for six weeks after the operation and that Clark would have to undergo at least three weeks of rehabilitation after the cast was removed. Clark was hitting .237, with 9 home runs and 23 r.b.i.'s.

title: BUSINESS CARDS TOMORROW reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Net income.

title: Language and Old Guard Impede Puerto Ricans; Generational Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
'PILOBOLUS' OFFERS AN HOUR OF DANCE
description: A CATEGORY called ''easy listening'' exists for music. If there were such a category for dance, ''Pilobolus'' would fit right in. Broadcast tonight at 11 P.M. on cable's Arts & Entertainment Network, ''Pilobolus'' is a pleasant but fairly soporific hour of dance created by the founders of the normally antic and outrageous Pilobolus modern-dance troupe.

title: RAPE VICTIM JAILED IN REFUSAL TO TESTIFY AGAINST DEFENDANT
description: A distraught woman who refused to testify against the man accused of raping her was found in contempt of court today and was sent for the second time to the same jail where the defendant was being held.

title: CLARK, J L MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Seaver to Go?
description: Tom Seaver ''is a very unhappy player who should get traded,'' Manager Jim Fregosi of the Chicago White Sox said last night. ''Tom and I had a meeting and there is no sense in his staying here, but we are doing our best to work out a deal,'' Fregosi said after Seaver, who is 2-6, failed to snap his four-game losing streak despite a 4-3 Chicago victory over Minnesota. Seaver, who is 41, has indicated he would not mind being sent to either the Yankees or the Red Sox, both close to the pitcher's Connecticut home.

title: SCIMED LIFE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: MET OPERA TO RECORD WAGNER 'RING'
description: The Metropolitan Opera and Deutsche Grammophon Records have announced that they will record the four operas of Richard Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' over the next three years, when the Met will be performing the series in the opera house. The first in the Met's series will be ''Die Walkure,'' and that will also be the first recording to be undertaken.

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Killer's Appeal Rejected
description: A circuit judge refused today to delay the execution of Theodore Bundy, who is scheduled to die in the electric chair July 2 for the 1978 slaying of two Florida State University sorority sisters. Judge Edward Cowart rejected claims that Mr. Bundy had ineffective trial and appeal counsel and that his current attorneys needed more time to prepare his case. Defense lawyers said they would now take Mr. Bundy's appeal to the Florida Supreme Court.

title: Eight Form Low-Key League
description: Eight major colleges, including New York University, have banded together to offer sports competition in an environment in which student-athletes are measured against the same standards as other students.

title: Zale Rejects Latest Peoples Bid
description: Zale Corporation, saying that it wanted to remain independent, rejected Peoples Jewellers Ltd.'s latest acquisition offer.

title: Advertising; Four A's Getting Help For Drug-Free America
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies' brave plan to go it alone in a vast public service advertising battle against the drug abuse problem, ran into reality. Apparently under pressure from the rest of the advertising community it has now agreed to make its Drug Free America effort part of the Advertising Council, which joins agencies with advertisers and the media to create and place advertising in the public interest.

title: CITY'S TOKENS SLUG-PROOF? WELL, ALMOST
description: It was to be a war fought to the last slug.

title: ROLL-CALL ON CONTRA AID
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 221 to 209 by which the House of Representatives approved $100 million in military and logistical support today to rebels fighting to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government. A ''yes'' vote is in favor of the aid package. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 51 Democrats and 170 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 198 Democrats and 11 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: Technology; Gene Mapping Is Improved
description: MOLECULAR biologists, assisted by a new generation of automated gene machines, are moving closer to the day when the entire genetic structures of people, crop plants and farm animals will be mapped and understood.

title: C.D., Fund Yields Fall
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all down slightly for the week ended yesterday.

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
INDIA REBEL CHIEF TO END 20-YEAR-OLD INSURGENCY
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, in a step enhancing national unity, won an agreement today from the leader of an insurgent guerrilla group to end a 20-year rebellion in mountainous northeast India.

title: Congress; Of Loose Ends and Looser Humor on the Tax Bill
description: There are few secrets in Congress, mostly because senators and representatives cannot hide. Several times a day, they must leave their offices and private meetings to go to the Capitol to vote. They cannot avoid being buttonholed by almost anyone interested in what is going on.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PROSECUTOR SAYS BRIBERY INQUIRY IS NOT FINISHED
description: A prosecutor disclosed yesterday in court that the Manhattan District Attorney had a ''current, continuing investigation'' in the bribery case against John J. McLaughlin, the former president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: 6 BROADWAY PLAYS TO CLOSE AT WEEKEND
description: Six out of the 10 straight plays now on Broadway are closing this weekend, only a week away from the Statue of Liberty centennial festivities that are expected to bring millions of visitors to New York City.

title: HUNT LAWSUIT CALLED 'WITHOUT MERIT'
description: The $1.2 billion lawsuit filed by members of the Hunt family of Dallas against 23 banks is regarded by many banking analysts as an effort by the Hunts to stymie the banks' attempts to collect on mounting overdue loans.

title: TOP DESIGNERS SIZE UP IDEA OF DOING AN R.V.
description: IN a highly informal survey, several leading Manhattan designers were asked whether or not they had ever designed, or would consider designing, a recreational vehicle. Mario Buatta

title: FERNANDEZ STOPS EXPOS FOR NO. 9
description: The Mets decided not to run for the hills yesterday just because the Montreal Expos were shoving them around. Instead, they finally did some cuffing of their own and beat the Expos, 5-2, while Sid Fernandez pitched his fourth straight victory and his ninth of the season.

title: MARADONA SCORES 2 IN VICTORY
description: With Diego Maradona scoring both goals, Argentina defeated Belgium, 2-0, today and qualified for the World Cup final here Sunday against West Germany.

title: Market Place; Stock Buying By Foreigners
description: FOREIGN investors continued as a powerful force in the bull market during the first quarter of this year with record-shattering net purchases of $6.4 billion in United States equities.

title: Q&A
description: Q.A few years ago I used Scotch tape to mount several prints on the door of my white refrigerator. After the prints became worn-looking I decided to peel them off, but I found I could not remove all the tape. Can you suggest how to remove these unsightly remains? A. First scrape off as much of the tape as possible with a plastic scraper similar to the kind used to remove ice from an auto windshield. These plastic scrapers won't scratch the finish the way a metal one would. If you have trouble scraping the tape off, try heating it with a hair dryer or heat lamp. To avoid scorching the tape, use mild heat only. If the tape gets too gummy to scrape, you may get better results by rubbing hard with a rag. Any sticky residue can be washed off with rubber cement thinner or lighter fluid. Q. I recently bought an apartment that has metal closet doors. These have been painted over a number of times and need repainting. How can I remove all of the old paint before I put the new paint on? A. One method is to use a chemical paint remover and another is to use a heat gun or electric ''stripper.'' The heat gun is a little slower than the remover, but will create less of a mess if handled carefully. Of course, you will have to buy or rent a heat gun and it may not pay if you have only one or two doors to do. Q. Our house has rough pine siding that was stained with a dark brown penetrating oil stain about nine years ago.

title: DANCE: 'FRESH TRACKS'
description: IF it is true that art somehow reflects the temper of the time in which it is created, then the works presented by Dance Theater Workshop on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater would have provided moralists, psychologists and political scientists with much to ponder. The program, called ''Fresh Tracks,'' was devoted to dances by new choreographers. And virtually all of those dances concerned such themes as cutthroat competition, failure, anxiety and sinister psychic forces on the loose.

title: RELIEF IS TOO LATE TO SAVE YANKEES
description: The Yankees did not get their sweep of the Boston Red Sox tonight, but they did get the kind of relief pitching they will need if they are to catch the first-place Red Sox at some later date.

title: INERTIA DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $87,449, $129,929, and $453,152 for latest 9 months, the year- ago quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: ON WEST COAST, RESURGING EXPORTS
description: Shipping companies and port officials on the West Coast say that, for the first time, they are seeing solid evidence of a resurgence of American exports because of last year's international effort to weaken the dollar in world trade.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The year-ago results include a gain on the sale of three hospitals of about $3 million, or 3 cents a share.

title: Tilley Asks Trade
description: Pat Tilley, a 10-year pro who needs just 15 catches to surpass Jackie Smith as the leading receiver in St. Louis Cardinal history, has asked to be traded.

title: SABATINI STRUGGLES, BUT TAKES OPENER
description: Playing tennis, as Gabriela Sabatini has discovered, is not comparable to learning how to dance. In tennis, the dance floor changes and a player has to learn new steps on the different surfaces. So sometimes, even the most graceful athlete can feel as if she is stumbling over her own feet.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
BancTexas Reports Buyout Bid
description: BancTexas Group Inc., the troubled energy bank based in Dallas, said yesterday that it had finally found a buyer, Gerald J. Ford, a wealthy Texas financier. But conditions placed on the buyout by Mr. Ford could easily kill the deal, the bank said.

title: ITT IS NEGOTIATING TO SELL FRENCH ITS TELECOMMUNITATIONS BUSINESS
description: The ITT Corporation is negotiating to sell the cornerstone of its business, its telecommunications operations, to Compagnie Generale d'Electricite of France for more than $2 billion, according to sources on Wall Street. The sale would be ITT's most dramatic reshaping in its 66-year-old history.

title: RECITAL: POWELL AND BALEY
description: THE clarinetist William Powell and the pianist Virko Baley joined forces for an unusually challenging concert of contemporary music at Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday night.

title: THE ADOPTION MARKET: A VARIETY OF OPTIONS
description: EILEEN thought she would never have a child of her own. She had put off starting a family because of her career and then found herself, at the age of 41, a vice president of a Wall Street brokerage firm, divorced and infertile.

title: MR GASKET CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes the effects of changes in estimates made in the first three quarters of the fiscal year 1985. These changes resulted in year- end adjustments which adversely affected fourth quarter earnings by approximately $2,315,000.

title: STATE REPUBLICANS BACKING HOTEL-ROOM TAX TO HELP CITY CLOSE BUDGET GAP
description: As New York City's budget deadline drew near, the Republican leaders of the State Senate agreed yesterday to support a new hotel room tax to help close a deficit in the city's financial plan. But they rejected any new taxes on real-estate transactions.

title: DESPITE THE PAIN, DAWSON ENDURES
description: In the lists of figures that measure Andre Dawson's decade of often painful brilliance, there have been two pieces of information that have never been attached to his name. He has never appeared in a World Series. And as he entered his 10th full season this year, he had never appeared on a disabled list. Neither of those facts made much sense.

title: SEAT Small Cars
description: The Spanish car company SEAT will concentrate on the production of budget cars after its takeover by Volkswagen, SEAT's general manager, Juan Antonio Diaz Alvarez, said. Mr. Diaz Alvarez said SEAT would specialize in the production of its most popular lines with the aim of obtaining a 2.5 percent share in the European small-car market. He said the short-term plan in Spain was to increase the joint share of SEAT, VW and Audi A.G. from 23 percent to 26 percent.

title: CCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $43,492 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $369,433 for the quarter and $563,799 for the 6 months.

title: U.S. Deficit Soared in May
description: The Federal budget deficit soared to $39.4 billion in May, the largest imbalance in a year, the Treasury Department said today.

title: REAGAN MAY PHONE SENATORS ON COURT CHOICE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the President might telephone key senators to seek their votes for a judicial nomination that has been described as a test of the Administration's ability to continue placing its choices on the Federal bench.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 12wks to June 1
description: The latest sales for the 40 weeks included the operations of K.Y. Rogers Inc., acquired May 1, 1985.

title: U.S. Ambassador to Miss Ceremony in Austria
description: The United States Ambassador, Ronald Lauder, has a prior commitment and will not attend the ceremony when Kurt Waldheim is sworn in as President next month, an embassy spokesman said today.

title: Nicole Gorelick, a Teacher, Wed to Harry R. Zlokower
description: Nicole Gorelick, a French and Spanish teacher at the Packer Collegiate School in Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Harry R. Zlokower, president of the Harry Zlokower Company, a public relations concern in New York. Ada Smith, a Deputy City Clerk, performed the ceremony in the Brooklyn Municipal Building.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A Routine Out
description: During 16 years as a major league shortstop, Larry Bowa acquired a deserved reputation for combativeness. That was before he started playing hardball with Pam Postema, who may or may not get the best of him.

title: QUESTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
VIDEOS FOR THE GARDENER: AN APPRAISAL
description: A RECENT visit to a video shop turned up quite a few cassettes on gardening.

title: OIL WORKERS FLEEING AS HURRICANE HEADS TOWARD TEXAS COAST
description: Thousands of workers fled their offshore oil rigs and residents boarded up beach-front businesses today as a hurricane, the first of the season, swept toward the Gulf Coast.

title: The Price of Imports
description: To the Editor:

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SARAH VAUGHAN AND BILLY ECKSTINE
description: SARAH VAUGHAN and Billy Eckstine are old friends with a lot in common. The two singers, who appeared at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening, are vocal instrumentalists first and lyric interpreters second. Both have hornlike voices that open up on the vowels at the ends of phrases. Rhythmically, they are confident swingers who demonstrate their sophistication through the insinuating way they scoop up on a phrase.

title: Fulbright Program: 40 And Still 'Pretentious'
description: It was the shock that he and so many other members of Congress felt after the destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki that inspired J. W. Fulbright, then a Democratic Senator from Arkansas, to propose legislation in 1945 that gave rise to what today is a renowned educational foreign exchange program bearing his name.

title: SCHOOL BOARD 2 FOCUS OF BATTLE IN A BITTER VOTE
description: After the first count of 13,091 paper ballots in the Community School Board 2 election, Sandra Neis lost by 29 votes, a result that gave control to the parents' slate.

title: U.S.-Soviet Regional Session On the Mideast Opens Today
description: Richard W. Murphy, Assistant Secretary of State on Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, arrived here today for talks on the Middle East with a Soviet Foreign Ministry official, Vladimir P. Polyakov.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WEST GERMANY, ARGENTINA IN FINAL
description: West Germany's physical strength, tenacity and excellent defensive tactics prevailed over France's finesse this afternoon in the first semifinal of the World Cup.

title: 87 CHOSEN FOR MAYOR'S LIBERTY MEDALS
description: Eighty-seven prominent people representing about 50 countries have been named to receive liberty medals from Mayor Koch, who had criticized the selection of 12 prominent Americans by Liberty Weekend organizers as not representative enough of the ethnic groups that have immigrated to America.

title: IN BROOKLYN: ONE HOUSE, TWO STYLES
description: JEAN-MARIE BLONDEAU, who grew up in an 18th-century stone house in France, wanted as old a house as New York City could offer. His wife, Neita, who grew up in 1940's bungalow in Long Beach, Calif., wanted something newly minted. Instead of compromising, they found a house in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn where they could have the 19th century on the parlor floor and the 20th century upstairs.

title: NORWEGIAN TALL SHIP ARRIVES AND OP SAIL BEGINS
description: As if she belonged in an old watercolor of New York Harbor, the 241-foot, full-rigged sailing ship sat quietly for a moment in the lapping waters of the Upper Bay.

title: 17 Killed in Explosions Of Buses in Sri Lanka
description: Bombs exploded under two buses today, killing 17 people and wounding more than 50 others in the Trincomalee District, the police said.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WILLIAM L. DENNIS
description: William L. Dennis, a former partner in the New York law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel, died Monday at the home of a friend in Beachwood, Ohio, after suffering a heart attack several weeks earlier. He was 72 years old and lived in Elizaville, N.Y.

title: Goldman Hires From Salomon
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that it had hired David F. Delucia to take charge of its corporate bond trading, sales and syndicate operations in New York.

title: BIAS CASE MAY SPUR REFORM IN ATHLETICS
description: The Chancellor of the University of Maryland said the death of the basketball star Len Bias after he used cocaine, and the revelations about the poor academic performance of Bias and some other athletes on his school's basketball team, are certain to be an impetus for reform in college athletics.

title: SPENDING PATTERNS OF HOME BUYERS
description: New home buyers spend more on furnishings, appliances and other home-related goods in the first year they own their homes than at any other time, a survey has found.

title: Military History
description: To the Editor:

title: The Good No-News From Spain
description: Spain held a quite ordinary election this week. That doesn't register as a major news event, but it should register as history.

title: U.S. Record Set In Swim Trials
description: Dan Jorgensen of San Diego broke the American record in the 400-meter freestyle tonight at the United States Swimming World Championship Trials.

title: R.V.'S SQUEEZE IN ALL COMFORTS OF HOME
description: SQUEEZING all the comforts of home into a recreational vehicle is, Sid Johnson says, like solving a jigsaw puzzle. It is worth the trouble because there are customers out there who want all the comforts: washers and dryers, central vacuum cleaner systems, even doorbells.

title: Senate Approves $1.1 Billion To Improve Embassy Security
description: A bill authorizing $1.1 billion to increase American embassy security against terrorist attacks was passed by the Senate today after lawmakers voted to earmark $34.5 million to thwart electronic surveillance of the missions.

title: ALLEGATIONS OF CHEATING PUT FIRE EXAM RESULTS IN DOUBT
description: The city is investigating allegations that the most recent test for fire lieutenant, taken by more than 4,300 firefighters in May, has to be thrown out because of cheating.

title: Article 923886 -- No Title
description: The Interfirst Corporation, the third-largest bank holding company in Texas, said yesterday that it expected to report a loss between $260 million and $285 million for the second quarter, partly because of loans to a former director. It also said that it would eliminate the dividend on its common stock ''for the foreseeable future.''

title: ROYAL BALLET'S 'NUTCRACKER' ON A&E
description: MOST ardent dance fans surely know ''The Nutcracker.'' So popular is Tchaikovsky's holiday ballet that it turns up not just in winter, but all year long. Therefore some fans may think they have seen a ''Nutcracker'' or two too many. However, a production American balletgoers may not know is the one by the Royal Ballet to be shown tonight at 8 on the Arts & Entertainment Network, for the British company has not yet exported this new staging, which dates from 1984.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 9
description: b-Net income.

title: Big Numbers
description: Steve Richmond, now of the Detroit Red Wings, who was called up, farmed out or traded a total of seven times last season: ''I lead the league in bank accounts and phone numbers.''

title: CHANCELLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for 12wks to June 14
description: Results in both the 1985 and 1986 second quarters include the Augusta, Ga., bleached paperboard mill and related facilities acquired on March 4, 1985.

title: Louvre's Cour Carree Reopened to the Public
description: Minister Jacques Chirac today reopened the Louvre's Cour Carree, the 16th- and 17th-century courtyard at the heart of the fortress and royal palace that have become one of the world's most famous art museums.

title: State Dept. Is Talking To Black South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES A COMPREHENSIVE MEASURE ON IMMIGRATION
description: For the third time in five years, the House Judiciary Committee today approved a comprehensive bill to revise the nation's immigration laws and to curtail the influx of illegal aliens.

title: ANDY LAVERNE, SOLO PIANIST
description: DEBUSSY and Bill Evans loom large in the music of the pianist Andy Laverne, who played their compositions and his own in a solo concert Tuesday evening at Bruno Walter Auditorium.

title: COCAINE USE CAN AFFECT HEART
description: Cocaine can cause sudden heart death by putting rapid stress on the heart, by causing microscopic heart-muscle damage, by disrupting the central nervous system or by a combination of those effects, heart and drug experts said yesterday.

title: Bid for Hispanic Stations Rejected
description: An investor group that includes the former United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, and the Hollywood executive A. Jerrold Perenchio has dropped its bid for Los Angeles television station KMEX and four other Spanish-language stations. ''We made an offer which was turned down,'' said Robert Cahill, the executive vice president of Chartwell Partnership Group, Mr. Perenchio's principal business.

title: Union to Vote On A.M.C. Plan
description: Workers at the American Motors Corporation are to vote this week on a contract offer sought by the auto maker in hopes of putting together a deal with the Chrysler Corporation. Alex McCloskey, the chief negotiator for American Motors, said that now Chrysler and A.M.C. officials must work out a deal for Chrysler to begin production of luxury cars early next year at the A.M.C. plant here.

title: Phone Company Edges Closer to Union Pact
description: Negotiators for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and 76,000 workers agreed today on a new contract, but disagreements over provisions covering 47,000 other employees continued to stall the settlement of a nationwide strike.

title: BRAZIL IS SEEKING STOLEN DOCUMENTS
description: The police are investigating a break-in at the Nicaraguan Embassy in Brasilia in which filing cabinets were ransacked.

title: 7 KILLED AND 38 HURT IN PERU BY BOMBING OF TRAIN FOR TOURISTS
description: A time bomb exploded on a tourist train in the station at Cuzco today, killing 7 people and wounding at least 38, the authorities reported.

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DIVIDED OPEC OPENS SESSION
description: Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began their regular summer conference here today deeply divided over a way to restrain crude oil production to dry up an oil glut and lift prices.

title: 3 WITNESSES REFUSE TO TALK ABOUT BIAS
description: The investigation into the death of Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star who died last Thursday of cocaine intoxication, has been stymied because three prime witnesses have refused to speak to the police, a spokesman for the Prince George's County police said yesterday.

title: BLOCK, H&R INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
Women's Liberation Without Lung Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: A LEADING DRAMA EDUCATOR
description: F. Curtis Canfield, a former dean of the Yale School of Drama and one of the nation's leading drama educators, died June 8 at the Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass. He was 82 years old and lived in Amherst, Mass.

title: CHARGIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DECISION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company changed its name from Decision Data Computer Corp.

title: LORETTA LYNN ROAMS IN A $375,000 BUS
description: IT sounds like fodder for a country music song, a sure-fire antidote to long, lonely nights. ''I sleep better on the road,'' Loretta Lynn, the country music star, admits. ''I guess I'd have to say I'm more at home on the bus than at home.''

title: Sheriff's Deputy Killed Beverly Hills Hostage
description: A sheriff's marksman mistakenly thought he had a gunman in his sights when he shot and killed one of three hostages the robber was using as a shield to escape from a jewelry store, the authorities said today.

title: New York's Ill-Tuned Cabaret Law
description: Rock's amplified guitars and pounding basses are permissible, but a jazz combo of piano, sax and drums can draw a hefty fine. That's the dissonant logic of New York City's cabaret law, a logic that has brought the musicians' union into court. The union complains of hardship to wind instrumentalists, drummers and singers - and makes a convincing case for overhauling the cabaret license system.

title: U.S. DRIVE ON DRUGS URGED
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Manhattan Democrat, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that the death of Len Bias, the University of Maryland basketball star, from cocaine intoxication underscored the need for a national drive to combat drug abuse.

title: ORDER BY KOCH LIMITS SMOKING IN CITY BUILDINGS
description: Starting next Tuesday, smoking will banned in nearly every public area of every municipal building, from auditoriums and mail rooms to the line at the marriage license bureau, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: CUSTER'S DEFEAT: A 110-YEAR MYSTERY
description: The remains of 36 troopers who fell with Lieut. Col. George Armstrong Custer were buried with those of their comrades here today in a ceremony marking the 110th anniversary of the Battle of the Little Bighorn.

title: ASSOCIATED HOLDERS OFFERED $60
description: The May Department Stores Company yesterday stepped up its attack on the Associated Dry Goods Corporation by going directly to Associated's stockholders with a tender offer of $60 a share for Associated's common stock.

title: The Shuttle Debate
description: White House officials are nearing the end of a debate over whether the President should call for the construction of a new space shuttle to replace the Challenger. According to one White House official, advocates of a new shuttle weren't helped by the announcement last week that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration was canceling a shuttle-related program because of safety concerns.

title: The Void in Austria
description: Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General, is to be inaugurated President of Austria on July 8. Fortunately, Austrian custom dictates a quiet inauguration. So other countries haven't to make an unpleasant protocol choice of showing distaste for the man or sending high-level delegations to the state. In any case, U.S. Ambassador Ronald Lauder has let it be known he won't attend, and will be represented by the charge d'affaires.

title: NEW FARM BELT CROP: INDUSTRY
description: This east Iowa community is sharing in the misery of the farm crisis, but its 6,300 residents can boast of one thing that will make other farm towns envious: During the last year, three companies have decided to open factories here.

title: Safeway Stock Up on Rumors
description: Shares of Safeway Stores Inc. surged $3.875 yesterday, to $51.50, in heavy trading amid rumors that the Haft family of Washington would soon make a tender offer for the nation's No. 1 supermarket chain.

title: U.S. Conducts Atom Test
description: The United States and Britain jointly conducted an underground nuclear weapon test today 1,800 feet beneath a remote desert plateau. The explosion, the sixth announced by the United States this year, had an explosive yield of 20 to 150 kilotons, equal to the explosive force of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We do not have censorship. What we have is a limitation on what newspapers can report.''

title: SHULTZ DECLARES HE IS 'BULLISH ABOUT PHILIPPINES'
description: Philippine leaders told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that they had no illusions that their offer to talk with Communist insurgents would end the rebellion, United States officials said. But they told the Americans they thought such an offer was necessary to demonstrate they had gone ''the extra mile'' to avoid bloodshed.

title: TIGERS TROUNCE ORIOLES
description: Kirk Gibson hit two homers and drove in five runs, and Darrell Evans and John Grubb also had homers as the Detroit Tigers routed the Baltimore Orioles, 11-2.

title: WASHINGTON STATE ACTING TO HALT SALE OF OVER-THE-COUNTER CAPSULES
description: In the wake of two poisoning deaths from cyanide-laced capsules earlier this month, the Washington State Board of Pharmacy overrode Federal objections today and recommended that retailers halt sales of over-the-counter capsule drugs.

title: The U.N. Today: June 26, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Conference on International Trade Law - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 'Aunt Dan' to Close
description: ''Aunt Dan and Lemon,'' the play by Wallace Shawn, will close after the Sunday matinee at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. The play, directed by Max Stafford-Clark, opened last October with Linda Hunt and Kathryn Pogson in the title roles and ran for 82 performances before closing in January. It reopened in March with Pamela Reed and Kathy Whitton Baker, and that production will have completed 109 performances.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $83,000 and $191,000 for quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $403,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss and for the year includes income from discontinued operations of $1,715,000, a gain of $3,657,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $2 million for the buyout of high-cost timber contracts from U.S. government agencies.

title: BRENTWOOD INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Some Goals for the Albany Rush
description: New York State's legislators like to close their sessions with a miraculous rush of bills about which they have bickered for months. Several now require urgent attention and two need to be held at bay.

title: THE WINDS OF WRIGLEY
description: A midseason weather report from Chicago's Wrigley Field: Games Runs Per Game Wind blowing in 22 8.2 Wind blowing out 9 12.3 Crosswind 2 14.0

title: Horse at Belmont Dies After Race
description: Juan de Fuca, a consistent 8-year-old gelding, collapsed and died as he was being walked out of the paddock after finishing third in the first race at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 6
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $626,802 and a gain of $1,480,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. The share earnings for all periods are adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split effective May 22, 1986.

title: Robins Asks Judge For Extension
description: The A. H. Robins Company has asked Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. to extend for three months the company's Monday deadline for filing a bankruptcy reorganization plan.

title: HOME ON THE ROAD
description: HER water tank cracked somewhere in Canada. Her furnace malfunctioned in Thunder Bay, Ontario. Nevertheless, when Esther Tallamy, a 68-year-old, twice-widowed former Long Island social worker, refers to her Winnebago Chieftain motor home, she calls it, in loving tones, ''Tiger.''

title: Apple Bank to Buy Eastern Savings
description: The Apple Bank for Savings, which has 16 branches in Manhattan and on Long Island, agreed yesterday to acquire the Eastern Savings Bank, which operates eight branches in the Bronx and Westchester.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding for both periods have been restated to give effect to a 20 percent stock dividend paid in November 1985.

title: DANCE: KOREAN CLASSICS AT DUKE U.
description: Han Young Suk, a woman of quiet intensity onstage and a performer of wider range than one might first suppose, is very obviously a dancer's dancer.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-Net income.

title: Vietnamese on Rescue Ship
description: The West German rescue ship Cap Anamur II picked up 60 more Vietnamese refugees today from two open boats in the South China Sea, the Cap Anamur relief agency said in a statement. The ship has brought 788 refugees to safety since March.

title: PANEL ACTS TO REVIVE AIR FORCE JET PRODUCED ON L.I.
description: The House Armed Services Committee moved today to keep alive a program to build a new training jet at the Fairchild Republic Company's Long Island facilities.

title: DANCE: HARRY STREEP AND HUMAN ARMS
description: HARRY STREEP and his engaging Human Arms company presented just the dance entertainment for a summer day on Tuesday at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater, 432 West 42d Street, where the company is performing through Sunday in Clark Center's ''Summer Dance '86.'' With hyphenated dance fashionable now, Mr. Streep's theater-dance pieces mix acting and sheer movement with unusual success. And he has evolved into a choreographer with a voice of his own - a modest voice but one with an attractively un-self-conscious simplicity and freshness to it.

title: Hannah to Retire
description: John Hannah, an all-pro guard the last eight seasons, is expected to announce his retirement from the New England Patriots at a news conference next Monday, according to team officials. Hannah has undergone surgery to repair torn rotator cuffs in each shoulder and cartilage and ligament damage in his left knee since the Patriots were beaten by the Chicago Bears in the Super Bowl last January. The injuries would mean Hannah would not be ready to play until September.

title: FIXING A ROLL-TOP DESK WHEN TAMBOUR STICKS
description: Even if it isn't fully functional most furniture is generally left alone by its owner, as long as it continues to serve its purpose. However, some elements - a chair rung or a woven wicker seat, for example - can become weaker with constant use.

title: A MIXED RESPONSE GREETS ISREAL'S RULE ON ID'S OF CONVERTS
description: American Reform rabbis called yesterday for the dismissal of Israel's Interior Minister, Rabbi Yitzhak Peretz, for ordering that the word ''convert'' be stamped onto the identity card of new Israelis who have converted to Judaism.

title: MEXICAN AIDE FLIES TO U.S. FOR TALKS
description: Mexico's new Finance Minister, Gustavo Petricioli, flew to Washington today after his Government decided to resume stalled talks on obtaining new concessions to help the country overcome its latest foreign debt crisis.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS CAPTURED PAIR ENLISTED IN MIAMI
description: Nicaragua put two Cuban prisoners on display today, describing them as ''soldiers of fortune'' recruited in Miami to fight alongside United States-backed rebels.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co. was granted a $76 million, or 6 percent, rate increase, by the Ohio Public Utilities Commission.

title: HIGH COURT AGAIN MOVES TO CURB LIBEL LAWSUITS AGAINST THE PRESS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that libel suits filed by public officials and public figures in Federal courts must be dismissed before trial unless the evidence suggests they can prove libel with ''convincing clarity.''

title: Roasting Mayor Young
description: Andrew Young, the Mayor of Atlanta, has never been noted for reticence - not as Mayor, and certainly not as chief United States delegate to the United Nations in the Carter Administration. But tonight he will be on the receiving end of rhetoric when he is roasted in the capital by a panel that includes the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Mr. Jackson's relationship with Mr. Young dates to the civil rights movement, but it showed signs of strain in 1984 when Mr. Jackson ran for the Presidency and Mr. Young chose not to support him.

title: Weak Demand Stalls Rally
description: The price rally that buoyed the credit markets on Tuesday fizzled yesterday as a weaker than expected demand for the Treasury's new seven-year notes pulled down prices for both long and intermediate Government issues.

title: HRE PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
DECORATIVE STAIR RODS ADD A VICTORIAN TOUCH
description: STAIR rods, which held stair runners in place during the Victorian era, are still popular with today's renovators and homeowners who like their decorative effect.

title: CONTINENTAL PLASTICS & CHEMICALS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: There were no share earnings reported because they have been adjusted for pro-rated dividend on preferred stock.

title: A Gift of Life From Lindbergh
description: John Keeler was still in the recovery room last November when word leaked out in Philadelphia that he was the cardiac transplant patient who had received the heart of Pelle Lindbergh, the Flyer goalie who had been fatally injured in an automobile crash. Keeler, a 52-year-old father of three and safety coordinator for Atlantic Electric in Atlantic City, says that the disclosure, which violated the transplant program's principle of confidentiality, was unsettling at first but that within a couple of weeks he'd grown used to the idea. ''Now,'' he says, ''it's just one of those things.''

title: SOUTH AFRICA REPORTS DRY UP
description: The trickle of information out of South Africa about the detainees held under the current emergency decree appears to have all but dried up.

title: WRITER, EXILED BY MAO, NOW GETS TOP CULTURE POST HE DIDN'T WANT
description: A writer who spent 17 years in internal exile after one of his early works displeased Mao Zedong was appointed Minister of Culture today.

title: DALFORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary item of $485,000, or 11 cents a share, related to an income- tax benefit that substantially offset the provision for income taxes.

title: Gorman Thomas Cut
description: Manager Dick Williams's house cleaning of the Seattle Mariners continued in earnest yesterday when the club released the veteran slugger Gorman Thomas, last year's American League Comeback Player of the Year. Thomas, 35 years old, was the highest-paid player in the Mariners' 10-year history at $650,000 this season.

title: REAGAN TO INVITE MEXICO PRESIDENT TO VISIT IN AUGUST
description: President Reagan, concerned about strains with Mexico and its economic crisis, plans to invite President Miguel de la Madrid to a meeting in the United States, American officials said today.

title: Language and Old Guard Impede Puerto Ricans
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Britain Protests Detentions And the South Africa Decree
description: Britain issued a formal protest today against South Africa's state of emergency and the jailing of anti-apartheid activists.

title: Contadora Foreign Ministers Plan to See U.N. Chief Today
description: The foreign ministers of four Latin American countries sponsoring the Contadora peace process will meet with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on Thursday.

title: Appendectomy Centenary
description: There is another centenary in New York this year, and the Secretary of the Interior has taken great pains to observe the occasion.

title: I.C.H. Chairman Sticks With a Tested Strategy
description: When Robert T. Shaw started his first insurance holding company 20 years ago, his strategy was straightforward: acquire older, established insurance companies.

title: The Court: Scalia
description: President Reagan's choice of Antonin Scalia for the Supreme Court has left most liberals in a state of numbed foreboding. They see Judge Scalia as an archetype of the modern legal conservative, ready to cut back radically on the definition and enforcement of constitutional rights.

title: Edward Rager Is Dead; A Councilman in 40's
description: Edward Rager, a former New York City Councilman, died Monday at the Sunnybrook Hospital in Toronto. He was 86 years old and lived in Toronto.

title: Maurice Durufle, Composer Known Best for His Requiem
description: Maurice Durufle, the French organist and composer, died in Paris on June 16.

title: TORRID, TENSE AND TESTY, INDIA AWAITS DELIVERANCE
description: This is the time of year when an extraordinary drama unfolds in the skies of northern India. The summer monsoon is coming, and people here talk of little else.

title: ISRAELI INTELLIGENCE CHIEF IS GIVEN IMMUNITY OVER 2 SLAIN HIJACKERS
description: The head of Israel's domestic intelligence service, accused of having ordered and then covered up the slayings of two captured Palestinian hijackers in April 1984, resigned today in exchange for immunity from prosecution.

title: '87 Fund Is Cut For S.I. Navy Port
description: The House of Representatives voted today to delete funds from the 1987 military budget for the Navy plan to disperse the fleet to ports around the country, including a battleship and her support group at Stapleton, S.I.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: CRAFT FESTIVAL, SALE
description: American Craft Festival, Lincoln Center, Columbus Avenue and 64th Street, 212-746-0091.

title: Advertising; Telmar Files Lawsuit On Competing Systems
description: The Telmar Group, a research company whose major function is delivering the data generated by Simmons and MRI to agencies and the media, has gone into Federal court seeking an injunction to stop those two companies' own new delivery system.

title: Graphic Scanning
description: The Graphic Scanning Corporation said its board had authorized management to sell certain assets, including its cellular radio businesses in four major markets. The board also authorized management to consolidate the company's remaining assets to enhance their value and to take immediate action to improve Graphic's cash position. The first step in the process, the company said, would be the sale by Graphic and its partners, including Metromedia, of cellular radio systems in Boston, Baltimore, Washington and Worcester, Mass.

title: Dow Up by 9.50 Points, to 1,885.05
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday for the second consecutive day on hopes of lower interest rates. They ended within a point of record territory.

title: ALL 20 ON SENATE PANEL MAY JOIN IN TAX TALKS
description: In what would be a departure from the way Congress traditionally negotiates tax bills, Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, is considering bringing all 20 members of his committee to the House-Senate conference that will seek agreement on a compromise tax revision package.

title: AIDS THERAPY: OBSTACLES ARE IMMENSE
description: Despite the heartening success in restoring immune function in one AIDS patient by bone marrow transplantation from his twin, doctors would face formidible obstacles in trying that form of treatment on a broad scale against the disease.

title: Medical Debt Ratings Cut
description: The debt ratings on $1.2 billion of outstanding securities of American Medical International Inc. and its subsidiary have been lowered, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sisterly Activities
description: A family album of New York's ''sister cities'' - Tokyo, Peking, Madrid, Cairo and Santo Domingo -has been compiled by the City Commission for the United Nations and for the Consular Corps. As in any family, the siblings are treated differently.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: RISE IN AIDS VIRUS INFECTION AMONG RECRUITS IS DETECTED
description: AIDS virus infection may be rising more rapidly among American military recruit applicants than many health officials had believed, according to the first detailed analysis of applicant blood tests.

title: CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: b-Includes $900,000, or 20 cents a share, reflecting adjustments related to estimates of LIFO reserves, compensation-related accruals and a revision of the effective income tax rate.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for 12mo to May 31
AMERICAN EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes gains from asset redeployment of $14.9 million, or 34 cents a share, for the latest year and $15.7 million, or 36 cents a share, for the year-ago period. The latest year also includes a gain from accounting changes of $11.5 million, or 27 cents a share.

title: PURGE REPORTED
description: The Philippine Army says that over the last few days it has discovered the bodies of 62 Communist guerrillas who were reportedly killed by fellow rebels in a purge.

title: PRETORIA WARNS PRESS ON REPORTING
description: South African authorities threatened further action today against journalists deemed to be violating regulations imposed under the nation's newest emergency decree.

title: CURBS BY STATE ON LIABILITY RATES BUY TIME, BUT THE LONG-TERM EFFECTS REMAIN UNCLEAR
description: With the passage of bills this week aimed at easing the state's liability insurance crisis, Governor Cuomo and the Legislature hope to curb spiraling rates and restore coverage for schools, physicians, local governments, nonprofit organizations and businesses.

title: Ailing French Shipyard
description: One of France's two main shipbuilding companies said that it could no longer meet payments after the Government reduced subsidies. The closely held Chantier du Nord et de la Mediterranee said it would make a formal declaration of its financial position to a Paris commercial court - a move that opens the way to the appointment of a receiver or liquidation.

title: WESTWOOD ONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
F.H.A. Back In Business
description: The Federal Housing Authority resumed processing applications for Government-insured home mortgages today after President Reagan signed legislation ending the agency's three-week shutdown.

title: U.S. SET TO ACT ON MEXICO BORDER DRUG FLOW
description: Illegal immigration, drug and arms trafficking and related violence have grown to such levels that officials say the United States is preparing to restrict the relatively free flow of people and materials across the Mexican border.

title: Percentage of Smokers Drops to 40-Year Low
