description: The percentage of adult Americans who smoke cigarettes is lower than it has been in more than 40 years, according to the latest Gallup Poll, but at least 3 adults in 10 continue to smoke them.

title: UBIQUITOUS LADY
description: THE likeness of the Statue of Liberty seems everywhere these days.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, JUNE 26, 1986
description: International The House approved aid totaling $100 million for the Nicaraguan insurgents. The approval vote, 221 to 209, was a major victory for the Reagan Administration. The Democratic-controlled House, which only three months ago rejected the aid plan, reversed itself in the face of intensive personal lobbying by President Reagan. [ Page A1, Columns 4-6. ]

title: REPUBLIC SAVINGS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-After a tax credit of $119,000. d-Net loss

title: TRANZONIC COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Sulzberger Award Presented
description: John F. Akers, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, received Barnard College's first Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger Award last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The award recognizes Mr. Akers's longtime efforts in behalf of women in higher education and in the corporate world. Mrs. Sulzberger, a graduate of Barnard, is the widow of Arthur Hays Sulzberger, former publisher of The New York Times, and mother of the current publisher, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger.

title: Divorce Lawyer and Author
description: ''Words to the Wise and the Not so Wise'' is the title of a book scheduled for November from Random House.

title: TELCO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a non-recurring expense of about $960,000 from an agreement settling differences with Pacific Bell related to delays in the development of a Telco Systems product for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,140,000, or 14 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: MAJOR VICTORY FOR REAGAN
description: The House of Representatives handed the Reagan Administration a major victory today by voting to provide military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: CORRECTION
description: The TV Sports column yesterday misidentified the position that Ted Shaker, the new executive producer of CBS Sports, held for the network at Super Bowls XVI and XVIII. He was executive producer of the pregame shows.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Latest quarter figures include the results of LFE Corp. and Gulton Industries, which were acquired as of June 1, 1985, and March 1, 1986, respectively. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 6.

title: A LOOK 'BEHIND BARS'
description: ''BEHIND BARS,'' the final documentary of the season on the weekly public-affairs program ''Metroline,'' is a disheartening look at a Dickensian problem that won't go away. The news peg is that 15 years have passed since the riots and deaths at Attica - a siege that has gone down in the annals of firepower but not as a precedent for cooling a prison rebellion. The hourlong program will be broadcast on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BOXING MARK MCPHERSON VS. KIETH ADAMS, middleweights, 10 rounds at Harrah's Marina, Atlantic City, N.J. (Television - USA 9 P.M.) GOLF UNITED STATES SENIOR OPEN, Scito Country Club, Columbus, Ohio.

title: Bridge: A Familiar Situation Makes Appearance in Unusual Way
description: Familiar situations at the bridge table sometimes appear in unexpected disguises, especially if the opponents are doing something offbeat.

title: HERS
description: MY girlfriend loves this story. She's told it a lot, and she knows the pauses, the timing: ''Yes, he snored, and he bet on the horses, and he spent all of our vacation money on Liberty ties, and he kept saying 'My house, my rules' even when his gonorrhea bills were sent home by mistake, but what I really couldn't take, finally, was that the only novel he'd ever read was 'For Whom the Bell Tolls' - that one where the earth moves when they're in the sleeping bag. So all he'd ask was 'Did the earth move for you? Did it? Did it? Did it?' Fourteen years. So. You can understand. When he left, I had two choices. I could have been a seismologist but that took too many years, and who wants to sit in an office all day long waiting for the Big One? Instead I struck out on my own, took out a loan on the house and bought an earth mover!''

title: Don't Straitjacket The State Dept.
description: The battle over whether to cut $176 million from the proposed $1.5 billion fiscal 1987 State Department operating budget is one of the most futile, self-defeating exercises of the current, and largely consequential, debate over matching expenditures to resources.

title: The Year of Character?
description: A new manual for Democratic candidates will be released today in which several Democratic pollsters assess the shifting currents of this election year. One of them, Peter Hart, argues that 1986 is the year when character will take precedence over issues.

title: STUDY COMPARES INCOMES OF SPOUSES
description: Wives of men in the highest and lowest income brackets tend to earn more than those married to husbands in between, a Census Bureau study shows.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tim Higgins, the right wing acquired by New Jersey in the 1983-84 season, has been traded to the Detroit Red Wings for Claude Loiselle, a center. The 28-year-old Higgins scored 9 goals and had 57 assists in 59 games for the Devils last season.

title: Joseph Hughes, Psychiatrist Who Was Neurology Expert
description: Dr. Joseph M. F. Hughes, a psychiatrist and neurologist who did research on reading problems, died Monday at Twining Village, a retirement community in Bucks County, Pa. He was 81 years old.

title: MILITARY PENSION BILL IS VOTED
description: The Senate voted today to approve a compromise military retirement bill that would cut the pensions of military personnel who enlist after Aug. 1.

title: Foreign Outlays Rise in U.S.
description: Foreign direct investment in the United States rose 11.2 percent last year with Britain maintaining its position as the leading holder of American investments, the Government said today.

title: A License to Hound AIDS Victims
description: Error and meanness suffuse the opinion on AIDS issued last week by Charles J. Cooper, head of the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel. His ruling, based on a mistaken reading of medical opinion about transmissibility of the disease, invites employers to dismiss people who have it, or who carry the AIDS virus, simply by invoking their fear of the disease being spread.

title: A CONCERT THAT WASN'T RAINED OUT
description: MUSIC listeners impatient with a dreadful performance - or those who take a good one for granted -would do well to show up occasionally before curtain time and see what it takes to get musicians on stage. Serene musicality behind the footlights is often the product of prior frenzy behind the scenes.

title: DECISION ON LOSS IN LAND USE RULES AVOIDED
description: The Supreme Court, for the fourth time in six years, today avoided deciding the multibillion-dollar issue of whether governments must pay compensation for restrictions on land use that temporarily destroy the value of property.

title: CALSTAR INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary tax benefits of $620,000 for the latest quarter and $450,000 for the year-ago period.

title: SANFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Pennsylvania Bank Law
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh signed legislation today opening Pennsylvania to regional interstate banking, saying the measure would lead to more competition.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $76,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $159,000.

title: DIMENSIONAL MEDICINE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company did not report any sales for the year-ago periods because it was in a developmental stage.

title: See Lightning? Shut Airports
description: Now that the thunderstorm season is at hand, the risks for American air travelers have increased dramatically. Four of the eight major crashes since 1975 involving domestic jetliners have taken place during such storms - and three of the four occurred during landing or takeoff. Indeed, landing or taking off during a thunderstorm is by far the most hazardous activity to which domestic passengers are exposed.

title: A WHITE CHURCH AND BLACK HOMELESS
description: It has been three weeks now since the 30 black women were burned out of the corrugated iron and cardboard structures they called home.

title: Advertising; Overseas Ad Spending Is Revised Upward
description: Because of the ''explosion'' of dollar spending in Europe brought on by changes in exchange rates, Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and director of forcasting at McCann-Erickson, yesterday dramatically revised upward his estimate of what overseas ad spending will be this year. Although he originally, in December, called for 9 percent growth, now he thinks it will be 26.9 percent, to $78.3 billion.

title: NATIONAL MINE SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Includes losses of $2,651,000 and $5,788,000 from discontinued operations for quarter and year, respectively, and a provision of $13 million for disposal of mining machinery operations for both quarter and year. c-Includes losses of $1,743,000 and $4,841,000 from discontinued operations for quarter and year, respectively.

title: In New York Potter's Field, Tiger Lilies Bloom
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OUTLANDS: Journeys to the Outer Edges of Cape Cod. By Robert Finch. 175 pages. David R. Godine. $15.95.

title: GRIDCOMM INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said it is still in the development stage and has no sales to report.

title: Dean Witter Unit Chief
description: The Dean Witter Financial Services Group said yesterday that B. Macon Brewer had been named chairman and chief executive of its capital markets division.

title: FOR ITT, AN ILLUSORY PROMISE
description: With the modern world becoming more amd more dependent on computers and the flow of information, few industries have looked more promising in recent years than telecommunications. So promising, in fact, that the ITT Corporation decided several years ago to cast off many of its diverse businesses in order to concentrate on its telecommunications roots.

title: New Lutheran Church To Put Offices in Chicago
description: Delegates from three Lutheran denominations trying to unite the bodies have decided to put the church's new headquarters in Chicago rather than Milwaukee.

title: BIG CITIES KISS PLAYBOY BUNNIES GOODBYE
description: Last November, Playboy's Empire Club opened at 515 Lexington Avenue, near 48th Street. It was planned as the first in what was to be a chain of updated Playboy Clubs, so modern that its Bunnies, as the club's waitresses are called, had male counterparts -Rabbits.

title: The Statue of the Statue
description: Do you find it hard to believe that the Statue of Liberty has been overlooked?

title: TALLEY ASSAILS BID
description: Talley Industries criticized an acquisition offer of $24.25 a share from a group led by American Investment Partners.

title: Dr Pepper, Coke To Battle F.T.C.
description: The owners of the Dr Pepper Company said that they would join with the Coca-Cola Company to fight the Federal Trade Commission's decision to block the merger between the soft-drink companies. ''We intend to proceed with our deal with Coca-Cola, which we think is in all respects proper and will increase competition,'' said Theodore Forstmann, general partner of Forstmann Little & Company, the New York investment concern that owns Dr Pepper.

title: U.S. INQUIRY INTO LOAN BY INTERFIRST IS REPORTED
description: Federal bank regulators have begun an examination to determine whether a loan made by the Interfirst Corporation, the troubled Texas bank holding company, to one of its directors may have violated banking laws, a regulatory source said yesterday.

title: Mexican Aide Meets Baker
description: Mexico's Finance Minister, Gustavo Petricioli, met Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d today, but Mexican and American officials refused to comment on the encounter. On a two-day trip here, Mr. Petricioli is also scheduled to see Jacques de Larosiere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, to try to end a six-month deadlock over a new I.M.F. loan to Mexico.

title: The Wolpe-Siljander Rivalry
description: When the opposing floor leaders of last week's House debate on new economic sanctions against South Africa squared off, there may have been a bit more at stake than the legislation itself.

title: Shultz Warns Asian Nations
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned Asian nations today that failure to open their markets wider to American goods would undermine the Reagan Administration's efforts to block protectionist legislation in Congress.

title: Expert Advice For Leonard
description: After the uneven and uninspired outing that Thomas Hearns had Monday night against Mark Medal before stopping him in the eighth round, the likelihood increases that Sugar Ray Leonard will end up as the next opponent of Marvelous Marvin Hagler. If the middleweight champion does elect to fight Leonard, rather than Hearns, then a recurrent question is certain to be raised again: namely, whether Leonard, who has already had one bout since surgery four years ago to repair a detached retina in his left eye, should risk another return to the ring. One man who feels qualified to speak to the subject is Harold Weston Jr., now a fight promoter but not so long ago a welterweight contender.

title: JOHNSON WEIGHING PITCHING DECISION
description: You wouldn't think a team with a nine-game lead had many hard decisions to make. But Manager Dave Johnson said yesterday that he was in the throes of making some, and indicated that they would recast the middle of the Mets' pitching staff.

title: Vitality of New York Port: A Water's-Edge View
description: To the Editor:

title: STEVENSON STRUGGLING TO STAY A VIABLE CANDIDATE
description: The candidate finished his impromptu speech to a handful of onlookers in the University of Illinois Student Union here. He looked up from the podium, held out a legal-size piece of paper and said, ''Now, does anyone want to sign my petition?''

title: Rebels Ask for Missiles
description: Nicaraguan rebel leaders asked today for shoulder-launched antiaircraft missiles and military training.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
APPLE BANK CHIEF CITES MERGER ROLE IN GROWTH
description: Jerome R. McDougal, chairman of the Apple Bank for Savings, which announced Wednesday that it would acquire the Eastern Savings Bank, knows the delights of relaxing as a fisherman and a trumpet player. When it comes to banking, however, he sticks to business.

title: Dining Out Guide; Fourth of July
description: Feeding the tidal wave of tourists who are expected to descend on lower Manhattan over the Fourth of July weekend is a chore that could make the Woodstock Festival look like a church picnic. Restaurants from TriBeCa to Bowling Green are gearing up for the occasion with special menus, expanded hours, beefed-up staffs - and great trepidation. Some are trying to cash in on Miss Liberty's birthday party by charging from $75 to as much as $800 a person for meals and entertainment, while others have resisted the temptation and will charge regular prices.

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Prosecution in Spy Trial Appeals Judge's Ruling
description: Prosecutors are appealing a ruling by the judge in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth, saying that there is a ''significantly greater chance'' of Mr. Whitworth's acquittal if the ruling is allowed to stand.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: OVER the last 16 years as Phoebe Tyler Wallingford, a character on the soap opera ''All My Children,'' Ruth Warrick has become an alcoholic. She has been jailed, divorced and remarried. She has fallen for a younger man and suffered a hysterical paralysis. But the dowager of the soap opera had never had a 70th birthday party.

title: REGIONAL GUIDE TO THE TREASURES AT FLEA MARKETS
description: IT is the season of the charm bracelet and the Chippendale chest, the sock and the socket wrench, the Queen Anne table and the Kewpie doll, of gold and lapis, glitter and felt, fishhooks and diadems, grandfather clocks and porcelain dolls, thimbles and goblets, treasures and trinkets, treadles and trivets, gimcracks, jewels and gems.

title: Lawyers' Favorites
description: Next to tourists, lawyers probably shuttle in and out of Washington more often than any other group of Americans. The American Bar Association's magazine, the ABA Journal, decided to find out which hotels and restaurants are the favorites of their readers, in Washington and other cities. On the basis of a random survey of 7,500 lawyers, some of them Washingtonians but most not, the favorite local hotels are the Four Seasons, the Mayflower and the Madison, and the favorite restaurants the Cantina D'Italia, Dominique and Le Lion D'Or.

title: CONSTITUTION SOMETIMES PROHIBITS EXECUTING THE INSANE, JUSTICES SAY
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the Constitution bars execution of convicted murderers who have become so insane that they do not know they are about to be killed and the reason for it.

title: Execution Is Due Today
description: Son H. Fleming, 56 years old, is scheduled to die in the electric chair at 7 P.M. Friday for murdering Ed Giddens, Chief of Police of Ray City, Ga. Chief Giddens was working his last shift before moving to Florida when he was killed by Mr. Fleming and two accomplices after a robbery in December 1976.

title: A DANCE THAT MAKES A 'SPLATTER'
description: Charles Moulton stood at the kitchen sink putting the final touches on a red jeep that he then sent zipping across the floor of his apartment on the Lower East Side. ''Well, it works anyway,'' he said. ''That's a start.''

title: SCREEN: JUM HENSON'S 'LABYRINTH'
description: ''LABYRINTH,'' which opens today at the UA Gemini Twin and other theaters, is the product of an impressive collaboration between its executive producer, George Lucas, who created Chewbacca, Darth Vader and R2D2, and its director, Jim Henson, who created Kermit the Frog, Fozzie Bear and the irrepressible Miss Piggy. The result, a fabulous film about a young girl's journey into womanhood that uses futuristic technology to illuminate a mythic-style tale, is in many ways a remarkable achievement.

title: Ford in Kia Deal
description: The Ford Motor Company said it planned to buy 10 percent of the Kia Industrial Company of South Korea, which will produce mini-cars for Ford dealers in the United States. The stock purchase by Ford is subject to approval by the South Korean Government and Kia stockholders, who will hold a special meeting next Wednesday in South Korea, according to a Ford spokesman, Ken Brown.

title: Adams at the Bank
description: The Women's National Bank of Washington officially changed its name the other day to the Adams National Bank, and its holding company became the Abigail Adams National Bancorp, all in honor, obviously, of the second First Lady of the nation. And who was the first new depositor to walk in after the name change? Who but Abigail Adams, who had read about it in the newspaper and decided to make a symbolic gesture of loyalty.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Arley Merchandise Corp., Taunton, Mass., said an unsolicited proposal from middle management to acquire 100 percent of Arley common stock at $10 a share had been received by the company's major shareholders.

title: The Planet Angerhofer
description: Unrecognized by most of us, there are about 4,000 minor planets in the solar system orbiting the Sun out there between Mars and Jupiter. Also known as asteroids, the first one was discovered in 1800, and the early discoveries were named after minor mythological deities.

title: BRIDGE COLLAPSE SPURS A BIG RISE IN PUBLIC WORKS
description: On June 28, 1983, a rusted span of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge fell into the Mianus River, killing three motorists and injuring three others. Three summers later, motorists are encountering the legacy of Mianus - widespread traffic congestion caused by the heaviest road rebuilding in memory in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: HURRICANE KILLS 2 IN BRIEF ASSAULT ON TEXAS COAST
description: Hurricane Bonnie struck the Gulf Coast before dawn today, killing two people with its 85 mile-per-hour winds and heavy rain that spun off tornadoes, destroyed homes and knocked out power to thousands.

title: John Blair Rebuffs Macfadden Again
description: John Blair & Company rejected a sweetened offer from Macfadden Holdings Inc. yesterday and again recommended that Blair shareholders accept a rival bid from Saul P. Steinberg's Reliance Capital Group.

title: HEILIG-MEYERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The figures for the year-ago quarter are for the first quarter ended June 30 because the company changed to a February year from a March 31 year.

title: McCann-Erickson
description: McCann-Erickson is now the second-largest ad agency in Britain, after Saatchi & Saatchi, as the result of having the Royds Advertising Group, with 10 offices and billings of $110 million, being merged into it. McCann's parent company, the Interpublic Group of Companies, announced yesterday that it had completed the $18 million deal, for which an agreement in principle was reached three weeks ago. Before the acquisition McCann had worldwide billings of $2.3 billion.

title: Leads
description: Dale Douglass lining up shot on the 10th green at Scioto Country Club during United States Senior Open in Columbus, Ohio. Page A25. (AP)

title: When Divided Command Cost 1,130 Lives at Leyte
description: To the Editor:

title: WILANDER GAINS IN LONG MATCH
description: This week will not be remembered by British sports fans as one of the empire's shining hours on the playing field. England lost a World Cup quarterfinal match to Argentina; Barry McGuigan, the World Boxing Association featherweight champion from Northern Ireland, returned from Las Vegas without his title; the English cricket team took it on the chin from India, and John Lloyd, the No. 1 gentleman in British tennis, lost a first-round match at Wimbledon and promptly announced his retirement.

title: U.S.-MEXICAN BORDER EFFORTS HAMPERED BY POLITICS AND INERTIA
description: It was billed as the greatest cooperative undertaking ever by United States and Mexican law authorities working on the border. But when it ended April 16, the operation served instead as a stark illustration of a central problem facing the United States as it tries to gain control of the border.

title: FILM: 'RUNNING SCARED'
description: IF your house is on fire, or you have $6 burning a hole in your pocket, you may want to rush out to see Peter Hyams's ''Running Scared,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters. Otherwise, stay home and watch ''Miami Vice'' or ''Cagney and Lacey,'' which costs you nothing but your time.

title: ALBANY LAWMAKERS NEAR VOTE ON STUDY OF BIAS IN COLLEGE ENTRANCE TESTS
description: College entrance examinations taken in New York would be studied question by question for racial or sex bias under legislation expected to pass both houses of the Legislature.

title: Withdrawal Set By Comdisco Inc.
description: Comdisco Inc., a computer manufacturer based in Rosemont, Ill., said yesterday that it was withdrawing a planned offering of $250 million in convertible debt and thereby postponing the redemption of its 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2003.

title: QUALITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES TOUGH NEW CURBS ON LOBBYING
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved tough new restrictions on lobbying by former Federal officials.

title: BUCKTAIL FLIES ATTRACT FLUKE
description: Quite by accident - I was after striped bass - more than 20 years ago I discovered that summer flounder or fluke would readily take a white bucktail fly.

title: NEWSPAPER TO BE SOLD IN DALLAS
description: The Times Mirror Company agreed yesterday to sell The Dallas Times Herald for $110 million in cash and notes, in an apparent acknowledgement that it was unable to win the heated Dallas newspaper war.

title: A's Dismiss Moore, Then Lose Again
description: The A's dismissed Manager Jackie Moore today and named Jeff Newman to the post on an interim basis, but the change did not end Oakland's slide.

title: SANCTION IMPASSE IN EUROPEAN BLOC
description: European Government leaders appeared deadlocked tonight over proposals for new economic sanctions against South Africa.

title: FILM: 'SPRING SYMPHONY,' ABOUT THE SCHUMANNS
description: AS every moviegoer must know by now, 19th-century composers were a romantic lot.

title: ISRAELIS CRITICIZED ON IMMUNITY GRANT
description: Israel's President and Cabinet came under a barrage of criticism today from lawyers, politicians and citizens' groups for their move to allow the head of Israel's domestic intelligence service to escape investigation in the slayings of two captured Palestinian hijackers.

title: The U.N. Today: June 27, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee Against Apartheid - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Politics and Food
description: There was a time when New York's Liberal Party could easily fill a hotel ballroom with more than 1,000 people, even if most of them were Democrats. Last night, the party held its annual dinner at the Omni Park Central Hotel, which expected only 300 guests.

title: Again, Dual Loyalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Spy, a New Magazine For the City
description: THERE are stirrings of new life on the top floor of the Puck Building, that venerable red-brick pile on West Houston Street, where three young men are putting flesh on the bare bones of a good publishing idea.

title: Walkout at Airline in France
description: A strike by the ground staff at the main French domestic airline, Air Inter, forced the company to cancel about 30 percent of the 320 flights it had scheduled for today, an airline official said.

title: Perils of Good Feeling
description: A specter is haunting Western democracies - the specter of coalitionary paralysis.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNAIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $8.1 million from the sale of facilities, a benefit of $1.8 million resulting from a lower effective tax rate and a $4.1 million reserve for severance costs for the quarter, and the 9 months includes asset writedowns of $114.6 million and about $60 million of additional reserves for medicare, accounts receivable and malpractice insurance. c-Includes a gain of $3.6 million, or 4 cents a share, from the dispostion of assets. d-Net income.

title: It's Degrading to Turn Soldiers Into Police
description: To the Editor:

title: BOARDED HARLEM BUILDING IS SITE FOR CONDOMINIUMS
description: To enter one of Charlotte Ballard's newest finds, you have to stoop down to climb through a hole in a bricked-over door. Inside the building, at 203 West 113th Street in Harlem, Mrs. Ballard's flashlight plays over a jumble of abandoned furniture that obscures the structure's original architectural details.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Don Cherry, the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street (255-4037). He was Ornette Coleman's trumpet player, his own Blue Note albums of the 60's were overlooked gems, and more recently he was a mesmerizing presence in Old and New Dreams. But Don Cherry also played rock with Lou Reed, and he was one of the first jazz-based musicians to explore in-depth the world's folk and traditional music. In short, Don Cherry is both a jazz master and one of those eternally curious souls who really believes, and acts on, the premise that good music is good music, and categories are for the faint of heart. He will play his African hunter's harp as well as the trumpet, with Jim Pepper on tenor-sax, Cameron Brown on bass, and the reliably brilliant Ed Blackwell on drums. Shows are tonight through Sunday at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; admission is $10, with a one-drink minimum.

title: 5,000th for Hawley
description: Sandy Hawley rode to his 5,000th career victory in the first race of Canterbury Downs' card yesterday in Shakopee, Minn., spurring Mighty Massa to a 2 1/2-length victory. Hawley, 37 years old, became the seventh rider in history to reach the 5,000 milestone.

title: Steven Crist on Horse Racing; PHONE TRICK MAY STRETCH OUT
description: The best news of the week is that Phone Trick, the fastest horse in the country, is likely to return to the races as a 5-year-old next year, and may try to stretch his brilliant speed beyond the sprint races in which he has compiled a record of nine for nine.

title: THE STAGE: ROBERT KLEIN
description: ROBERT KLEIN did a one-night stand on Broadway on Wednesday night, and those who relish his unique perspectives on the way we live will be grateful to know that that is by no means the end of it. The evening's two shows of stand-up comedy at the Nederlander Theater are being edited into one hourlong program that will be shown repeatedly on Home Box Office starting July 28 as ''Robert Klein on Broadway.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: PARLIAMENT VOTE HURTS ITALY'S COALITION
description: Italy's Socialist-led Government lost a crucial vote in Parliament tonight, and politicians predicted that the defeat would probably bring it down.

title: Irish Vote on Future Of Ban on Divorce
description: The Irish voted today in a referendum on whether to end a constitutional ban on divorce that has been in place for 49 years.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Tall Tales: Five-and-Dime Jewel
description: Its architect, Cass Gilbert, envisioned the gothic tower of the Woolworth Building as a jewel of light against the downtown skyline. Yet for 40 years the jewel didn't gleam.

title: COMPANIES PAY CITY $600,000 IN A PACT SETTLING BRIBE CASES
description: Two private collection companies that made payoffs to obtain and keep contracts at the city's Parking Violations Bureau have paid the city $600,000 in damages under out-of-court settlements disclosed yesterday.

title: U.S. ACCUSES SHEARSON OF MONEY LAUNDERING
description: Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and the former manager of its Philadelphia office were indicted today on charges of laundering at least $1.2 million for an organized-crime gambling syndicate.

title: Folger Theater Gets Funds From University
description: The Shakespeare Theater at the Folger Library today announced a long-term agreement with the University of South Carolina that will provide up to $500,000 a year over the next six years for the struggling theater.

title: Blues Name Coach
description: Jacques Martin, who led the Guelph Platers of the Ontario Hockey League to the Memorial Cup championship this past season, was named yesterday to succeed Jacques Demers as head coach of the St. Louis Blues. Martin, 33 years old, had just one year of head coaching experience at the major-junior level when he guided the Platers to the Memorial Cup victory.

title: Stranded in the Bronx
description: The Yankees may be leading the majors in runs scored, but they're farther ahead in runners left on base. Twice in the last 10 days they stranded 15 in games against Boston, and at their current pace they'll finish the season with a total of 1,295, breaking the club record (1,239, set in 1934) and nearing the major league mark (1,334, by the 1941 St. Louis Browns). Here's how all the clubs were faring as of yesterday in scoring efficiency - runs scored, expressed as a percentage of runs plus runners left on: AMERICAN LEAGUE LOB... Runs... Eff. Pct.... Twins... 484... 359... .425... Rangers... 442... 320... .419... Blue Jays... 507... 378... .418... Indians... 467... 325... .410... Angels... 510... 350... .406... White Sox... 464... 316... .405... Mariners... 483... 330... .405... A's... 489... 328... .401... Yankees... 575... 384... .400... Tigers... 483... 317... .396... Orioles... 490... 312... .389... Brewers... 499... 313... .385... Red Sox... 536... 328... .379... Royals... 510... 291... .363... NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: EASING OF EMERGENCY RULE BARRED
description: The South African authorities were reported today to have freed a dozen labor leaders held under the nation's two-week-old emergency decree.

title: A Bouquet for the Champions of the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Drug Experts Say New Efforts By Cuomo and Koch May Miss Goals
description: As public outcry has grown about the spread of crack, Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo have responded in recent weeks with two highly publicized moves. The Mayor created a special 101-officer unit to fight the extremely addictive form of cocaine, and last week the Governor announced that the state would enlarge drug rehabilitation and education programs.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $675,000 for the quarter and $1,348,000 for the year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $509,000 for the quarter and $795,000 for the year.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE STAGE: 'ARSENIC AND OLD LACE' REVIVAL
description: THOSE who haven't recently encountered ''Arsenic and Old Lace,'' Joseph Kesselring's smash Broadway hit of 1941, may be surprised to discover that its hero is a drama critic for a New York newspaper. His name is Mortimer, he's the nephew of the murderous Brewster sisters, and he is, of course, the most likable character on stage. In the revival at the 46th Street Theater, the role is played by Tony Roberts, who, early in Act I, can be heard muttering about the ''stinker'' he has to cover at the theater that night. But Mortimer is such a nice guy that he's willing to revise his judgments according to his mood. When his sweetheart (Mary Layne) gives him a big kiss, Mr. Roberts smiles and says, ''I may give that play tonight a good notice.''

title: Soft Drinks and Other Trusts
description: Big is not always beautiful, says the Federal Trade Commission. By unanimous vote, it has thrown itself into the path of two huge mergers, PepsiCo with Seven-Up and Coca-Cola with Dr Pepper, on the ground that yielding 81 percent of sales to just two companies would vastly reduce competition in soft drinks. Pepsi and Philip Morris, the owner of Seven-Up, responded by dropping their merger plan. The commission will fight Coca-Cola and Dr Pepper in court.

title: 'Legendary' Cowpoke To Sell a New Cigarette
description: Marketing people the world over know what the introduction of the cowboy to Philip Morris's Marlboro cigarette ads did for its sales.

title: CONTRA LEADERS PREDICT A YEAR OF HEAVY FIGHTING
description: Nicaraguan rebels said today that, with the prospect of American aid, a year of heavy fighting lay ahead.

title: Pentagon Invites Medical Plan Comment
description: The Defense Department has invited hospital chains and large insurance companies to comment on a sweeping proposal to change its system of providing health care for military dependents and retirees.

title: JOHN SPEICHER
description: John Speicher, a novelist and playwright and an editor for general books at The Reader's Digest, died Monday after a long illness.

title: Gloom and Budget Doom for Friends of the U.N.
description: As the Reagan Administration and Congress near completion of their budget-cutting surgery on the United States payment to the United Nations, friends of the world body are anxiously trying to rally a defense. The way is all uphill.

title: A.T.&T. WORKERS TO RETURN AS 26-DAY STRIKE IS SETTLED
description: The Communications Workers of America and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed on a new contract today, ending a 26-day strike.

title: Queens Symphony
description: The Queens Symphony Orchestra will present a free program of music by Morton Gould, Johann Strauss, Rossini, Tchaikovsky and other composers at Cunningham Park in Jamaica, Queens, tomorrow night at 7:30.

title: U.S. FAILS TO HEAL NEW ZEALAND RIFT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Prime Minister David Lange of New Zealand met today but failed to reach agreement on saving the 35-year-old alliance between their countries from collapsing later this summer over differences on nuclear policy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 27, 1986
description: Companies

title: FOR PINIELLA, MANAGING PROVES TRYING
description: As the Yankees close in on the halfway point of the season, two traits seem to stand out in the rookie managing of Lou Piniella: He has lost none of the temper for which he became notorious as a player and he has gained an inconsistency between his words and his actions.

title: Reagan Gets Measure On Military Pensions
description: The House gave final Congressional approval today to a major overhaul of the military retirement system, rewarding those who make life in uniform a career and reducing the pension checks of those who leave early.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 362 money market mutual funds fell $1.41 billion, to $223.84 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of 85 institutional funds fell $261.6 million, to $59.73 billion; 189 general purpose funds fell $505.4 million, to $62.2 billion, and 88 broker-dealer funds fell $645 million, to $101.9 billion.

title: Aquino Names Choices For Talks With Rebels
description: President Corazon C. Aquino today named her negotiators for cease-fire talks with Communist rebels and outlined the limits of her position, ruling out the power-sharing arrangements sought by the left.

title: Lightsey at Burgundy
description: Kirk Lightsey is playing piano solos tonight through Sunday at Burgundy, 467 Amsterdam Avenue, above 82d Street (787-8300). Music begins at 9 P.M. There is a $10 minimum at tables, and a two-drink minimum at the bar.

title: AFTER 7 WEEKS, U.S.F.L. RESTS IN ITS PURSUIT OF ANTITRUST GOAL
description: The United States Football League's antitrust case against the National Football League reached the halfway point this week, putting the U.S.F.L. within a month or so of a victory that could be worth as much as $1.69 billion or a defeat that could end its existence.

title: What I.R.A. Deduction Means to a Clergyman
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 MEXICANS LINKED TO DRUGS BY HELMS
description: Senator Jesse Helms, holding the third in a series of hearings on problems in Mexico, asserted today that information existed implicating a cousin of President Miguel de la Madrid and the head of the Mexican Judicial Police in drug trafficking.

title: New Talks On Key-tronic
description: The Key-tronic Corporation, the nation's largest independent maker of computer keyboards, and the Minebea Company ended negotiations yesterday for Minebea to buy 30 percent of Key-tronic. However, the two concerns opened new talks that could lead to Minebea acquiring all of the troubled Spokane, Wash., company in a stock swap.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''I HAD just finished '2010,' and I was quite determined to remain earthbound,'' said Peter Hyams as he explained how he came to direct ''Running Scared,'' which opens today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: WHILE horsemeat burgers never caught on in this country another fast food from the prairie may well catch on this summer: buffaloburgers. Silverbird, which opened this month describing itself as the city's ''First Native American Restaurant,'' serves a plump and tasty buffaloburger that is barely distinguishable in flavor from a good burger made with beef, except perhaps that it is noticeably leaner. Silverbird's buffaloburger is served with addictive blue corn tortilla chips and a hot chili salsa that ignites a brush fire on the tongue ($6.50). And what do you drink with such a repast? They suggest a 1983 Tualatin Pinot Noir from Oregon ($15) or, if white is your preference, a 1984 Snoqualmie Semillon from Washington State ($12).

title: CORRECTION
description: The author of yesterday's article ''See Lightning? Shut Airports'' was misidentified. He is Arnold Barnett.

title: HUMBLER NOW, NAKASONE BEGS FOR ONE MORE TERM
description: Here in the heart of wine-growing mountain country, Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone brought a message this week as plain as the enormous campaign ribbon on his chest.

title: Antidrug Messages
description: Acting on an idea first suggested by the NBC baseball analyst Tony Kubek, NBC Sports has announced plans to air antidrug messages delivered by the network's broadcasters during all its telecasts. The NBC Sports executive producer, Michael Weisman, who will oversee the 10-to-15-second-long segments, said that the spots would be produced by NBC Sports, independent of similar public service announcements produced by the National Collegiate Athletic Association or various professional leagues. The messages will be introduced during programming over the Fourth of July weekend.

title: RAID ON 3d CHURCH IN SOUTH AFRICA REPORTED
description: Amnesty International reported yestyerday that another church in South Africa had been raided by security forces and some 70 worshipers taken into custody.

title: British Boat Seeks Record
description: The British powerboat Virgin Atlantic Challenger II set out yesterday at 6:03 A.M. on an attempt to break the trans-Atlantic speed record of 3 days 10 hours 40 minutes set by the liner United States in 1952.

title: Negative Attitude
description: Manager Earl Weaver, whose Orioles played Wednesday night's game under protest on the ground that Alan Trammell of Detroit ran inside the base line on a key play during a first-inning rally: ''We'll wrap up the film and send it to the American League president and see what kind of excuses will follow.''

title: COURT CLARIFIES INFORMER'S ROLE IN CONVICTIONS
description: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that prosecutors may use incriminating statements made by a defendant to an informer planted in his cell so long as the informer does not ask questions or actively ''elicit'' the admissions.

title: GREAT COUNTRY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Great Country converted from a mutal savings bank to a capital stock savings bank Jan. 14 and reported per share figures only for the latest fourth quarter.

title: BLUE CROSS OFFERS NEW PREPAID PLAN
description: Empire Blue Cross-Blue Shield of New York yesterday announced a new prepaid health insurance plan that would cover all medical expenses, except for a $5 fee for each visit to a family physician.

title: Peru Arrests 6 Suspects In Bombing of Train
description: The police have arrested six people in connection with the bombing of a tourist train headed for the ancient Inca city of Machu Picchu, Peru's official press agency said. Officials said seven people were killed in the blast, including an American.

title: CONGRESS PASSES COMPROMISE PLAN ON BUDGET FOR '87
description: Congress early today approved a compromise budget of almost $1 trillion for the 1987 fiscal year. The measure soundly rejects President Reagan's military and domestic spending priorities and challenges him to raise revenue if he wants higher spending for the military.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The net for fiscal 1985 includes a gain of 7 cents a share from Telecredit's sale of DMC Systems' stock.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,804,000 from the sale of a cable TV subsidiary and other real estate for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Telenet Moves Billings To J.W.T. in the West
description: Telenet, which provides data communications products and services, has hooked up with J. Walter Thompson, San Francisco.

title: FOUR INDICTED IN PUERTO RICO IN 70'S JEWEL KILLINGS
description: A three-year Federal investigation into organized crime in Puerto Rico, including the murders a decade ago of three diamond merchants from New York and Chicago, led to the indictment today of three former San Juan detectives and a former police colonel who officials described as one of the crime chiefs on the island.

title: CUOMO AND SENATE IN DISPUTE OVER INACTION ON EHTICS BILLS
description: With only days remaining in the legislative session and with political pressure for action mounting, Governor Cuomo and the State Senate traded sharp charges today over who has been responsible for the failure to enact any plan for combating government corruption.

title: RIGHTS PANEL UNDER FIRE IN HOUSE
description: The House Appropriations Committee today approved an amendment that would eliminate money for the United States Commission on Civil Rights. The amendment would require the commission to cease operations by Dec. 31.

title: KODAK PRODUCTS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced two low-cost 35-millimeter cameras and a new color film with an ASA rating of 200.

title: Francis J. Galbraith, 72, Dies; Ex-Ambassador to 2 Nations
description: Francis Joseph Galbraith, a former United States Ambassador to Singapore and Indonesia, died of cancer Wednesday at George Washington University Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Times Names Executive
description: The New York Times Company yesterday named Nancy Nielsen, a 35-year-old public relations executive with editing and consulting experience, to the new position of deputy director of corporate relations.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: AKBAR, an aristocratic-looking Indian restaurant on Park Avenue that is frequented largely by urban Moguls from the Northeastern steppes of Manhattan, has surprising appeal for commoners as well -namely some beguiling food at reasonable prices. While the cooks here may not dazzle with inventive twists and impressive presentations, their straightforward, almost textbook-like approach to refined Indian cuisine almost always pleases. Vindaloos are appropriately hot, condiments are cool, curries are complex and tandoor-roasted foods are succulent. One cannot ask for much more.

title: Untrue and Unworthy
description: The American people seem unwilling to charge President Reagan with anything unpleasant, unworthy or untrue. It is nevertheless unpleasant and unworthy of him, as well as untrue, to charge that opponents of his unfit judicial nominee, Daniel Manion, are motivated only by ''liberal ideology.'' It's more nearly the other way around.

title: Kentucky Tops Japan
description: Kenny Walker, the Knicks' No. 1 draft choice, scored 21 points to lead Kentucky past the Japanese national team, 79-73, yesterday in an exhibition basketball game in Niigata in northern Japan. The teams were tied at 32-32 with three minutes left in the first half before Walker and Winston Bennett triggered a Kentucky surge that forged a 45-38 halftime lead. Kentucky has recorded four victories without a loss in their exhibition trip.

title: COLLEGE ANTIDRUG PLAN SOUGHT
description: The Chancellor of the University of Maryland said today that the National Collegiate Athletic Association should take a ''much more aggressive stance'' against drug use among athletes.

title: RULING ON AIDS PROVOKING DISMAY
description: Federal health officials, saying they were worried about possible misinterpretation of a Justice Department ruling on the civil rights of AIDS victims, have issued a statement stressing that the AIDS virus cannot be spread through casual contact in the workplace.

title: A POLISH RIDDLE: HIT-AND-RUN THRUSTS
description: For three days, an official in the Interior Ministry's press office has been asked to provide details of a statement this week by a Deputy Minister, Gen. Wladyslaw Pozoga, that Polish emigres are being trained as terrorists in New Jersey.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: THEY resemble hybrids of living things and machines, like the spinning contraption of silvery petals that looks like an unfolding flower one second, and is the spitting image of the Tilt-a-Whirl ride at an amusement park the next.

title: SUITCASE BOMB AT EL AL COUNTER IN MADRID HURTS 12
description: A suitcase being inspected by El Al security personnel exploded today at the Israeli airline's check-in counter here, wounding 12 people, the police said.

title: MAIN NICARAGUA OPPOSITION PAPER INDEFINITELY CLOSED BY SANDINISTAS
description: La Prensa, the combative opposition newspaper that for 60 years has been a principal source of news for Nicaraguans, was ordered shut today by the Sandinista Government.

title: Chiat Wins Competition For Sara Lee Business
description: Chiat/Day has emerged triumphant from a field of four agencies competing for the account of the Kitchens of Sara Lee, America's leader in sweet baked goods.

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Economic Scene; Tax Revision's Impact on U.S.
description: WITH the Senate's passage of a tax bill this week by the huge majority of 97 to 3, the United States is heading toward a thorough overhaul of its tax system. Optimism is high on Capitol Hill that, by early next fall, Congress will have a bill on President Reagan's desk that he can sign.

title: DOUGLASS POSTS 66 TO LEAD SENIOR OPEN
description: Dale Douglass, one of the new kids on the senior golf tour, has suddenly come upon riches never dreamed of before, like so many others playing this 50-and-up circuit. In just three and a half months, Douglass has won twice and has earned $154,816, or $63,000 more than he earned in any of his 23 years on the regular PGA Tour.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the Soviet Union is now genuinely seeking progress, we may have reached a turning point in our efforts to build a safer and more peaceful world.'' - President Reagan. [ A17:1. ]

title: Jack J. Amiel, Restaurateur; Owned 1951 Winner of Derby
description: Jack Joseph Amiel, who was the owner of a Kentucky Derby winner and was a partner in Jack Dempsey's restaurant in Times Square, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: PROSPECTS IN SENATE FOR CONTRA AID SEEM GOOD AFTER HOUSE APPROVAL
description: Prospects for Senate approval of military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels appeared to be good today after the aid was approved Wednesday night in the House of Representatives.

title: 13 Indicted in Rampage
description: Thirteen boys and young men were indicted yesterday on riot, robbery and related charges stemming from a series of crimes June 8 after a rock concert at Madison Square Garden. The suspects, ranging in age from 13 to 23 and all from Brooklyn and the Bronx, left a concert by the group New Edition at the Garden and, according to the police, attacked and robbed 14 pedestrians on Broadway, between 39th and 45th Streets, about 11 P.M.

title: It Had to Happen
description: Videos have now breached a new frontier, as publicity material in the annual lobbying effort by college sports-information departments eager to promote this player or that for all-America status. The trailblazer is Colorado State, which is now shipping to news media outlets across the country a six-minute tape starring Steve Bartalo, who returns to the Rams for his senior season next fall as the leading career rusher among active Division I-A players (3,394 yards).

title: ROLL-CALL IN SENATE TO CONFIRM JUDGE
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to confirm Daniel A. Manion as a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. The vote is subject to reconsideration and thus is not necessarily final.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Tuesday about law school deans who opposed the nomination of Daniel Manion as a Federal appeals court judge misidentified one school. It is the Vermont Law School, a private institution not affiliated with the University of Vermont.

title: Sports of The Times; Life and Death Beyond the Wall
description: The woman in the restaurant was surprised to learn that the slim, dark-haired man with the dark mustache and the glasses was a race-car driver.

title: Haiti Needs a Government
description: The discouraging news from Haiti - unrest in the cities and a slide toward anarchy in the countryside - casts doubt on the hopes excited by the fall of the house of Duvalier. But the country's sizable problems still would be manageable if there were someone managing. Sadly, there isn't.

title: PANHANDLE STOCK JUMPS ON TAKEOVER RUMORS
description: Shares in the Panhandle Eastern Corporation rose sharply yesterday amid rumors that Wagner & Brown, independent Texas oil operators and close associates of T. Boone Pickens, might attempt to take over the big natural gas pipeline company.

title: Moses Extends Streak
description: Edwin Moses made his long-awaited comeback tonight, winning the 400-meter hurdles in 48.89 seconds in his first race since 1984. It was Moses's 95th straight victory.

title: TURNS TIGHT AT MEADOWLANDS
description: Turn 5 is right where Mario Andretti and Bobby Rahal tangled last year, which took them both out of the race.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
'DIFFERENT FROM OTHERS,' FILM ON HOMOSEXUALITY
description: AS part of its ''Gay Pride Week'' lineup of programming, Channel 13 is broadcasting tomorrow night at 10 o'clock a rare and fascinating film fragment entitled ''Different From the Others.'' Being presented as part of the station's ''Film on Film'' series, this German production (''Anders als die Anderen'') was released in 1919. It survives by accident, having been found in East Berlin only a few years ago.

title: Industrialist Footing Bills for 50 Children
description: Fifty children - one from each state - and their teachers, will join Nancy Reagan in the official reopening of the Statue of Liberty on July 5.

title: Jesse Helms Proposal On Arms Pact Deferred
description: Senate critics and proponents of the 1979 strategic arms treaty today deferred efforts to have the Senate vote on the unratified treaty.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Blind to Abuses In El Salvador
description: During the past month, Salvadoran security forces have launched a broad-based attack on human rights organizations and church groups providing relief to the nation's 500,000 displaced people. The attack comes at a particularly perilous time for human rights in El Salvador, when the military struggle there has reached a standoff and world attention has shifted to other countries. This makes it all the more important for the United States to pay attention and make clear its commitment to human rights. Yet our embassy seems determined to close its eyes and gloss over the abuses of the Salvadoran armed forces.

title: Touche Ross Chairman to Leave
description: W. Grant Gregory, the 45-year-old chairman of Touche Ross & Company, announced today that he would retire from the international accounting firm Nov. 1 to start a ''second career.''

title: Dizzy Gillespie
description: The trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie and his quintet will appear through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and at 1 A.M. There is a $15 cover and a $10 minimum.

title: STATE JUDGE'S VERSE, WRITTEN ON BENCH, BECOMES EVIDENCE
description: Justice Bruce Wright of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, who is no stranger to controversy, is the focus of new attention, this time about verse he wrote in 1984 during a monthlong divorce trial.

title: Stock Prices Fall; Dow Is Off by 4.85
description: Wall Street suffered a mild setback yesterday as stock prices weakened as they approached record territory. Part of the softness was attributed to a rumor that President Reagan was ill, despite the fact that the report was quickly denied by the White House.

title: Software Account
description: Software Solutions, Trumbull, Conn., has named Ephron, Raboy, Tsao & Kurnit to handle its $2 million account. The three-year-old company, which had done its advertising in-house, produces Dataease, a data base managing system.

title: 3 OPEC NATIONS FIGHT TARGET OF $18 A BARREL
description: A majority of OPEC ministers appear to favor a production limit of 18 million barrels a day for the fourth quarter of this year in an effort to lift crude oil prices to about $18 a barrel by year's end, sources close to a meeting here said today.

title: Edelman Increases Offer for Fruehauf
description: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, renewed his bid for the Fruehauf Corporation yesterday, raising his offer to acquire the truck trailer and auto parts company to $49.50 a share, from $44.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Janis Ian, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Believe it or not, Janis Ian, the folk-music prodigy who became a teen-age sensation in 1967 with her hit ''Society's Child,'' is now 35 years old. Miss Ian, whose emergence as a mature pop composer climaxed commercially in 1974 with the brutally confessional ''At Seventeen,'' hasn't been heard from lately. Now, after a sabbatical from the pop-music arena, she is back for two nights at the Bottom Line tonight and tomorrow. Miss Ian, who writes equally on the guitar and piano, has amassed an impressive catalogue of little-known short-story songs whose harmonic sophistication and sometimes wounding psychological acuity cut a lot deeper than most contemporary pop songwriting. Her return is bound to be interesting, and if her newest songs are as strong as her best vintage ballads, it could be revelatory. Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 8:30 and 11:30, and tickets are $12.50.

title: N.F.L. BEGINS DEFENSE AT TRIAL
description: Two United States Football League club owners and one league official urged Chet Simmons, the U.S.F.L.'s first commissioner, to institute a policy to control rising player costs, according to documents admitted into evidence yesterday in the U.S.F.L.'s antitrust case against the National Football League in Federal District Court.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, JUNE 27, 1986
description: International

title: SHIFTS AT ENTERPRISE INSTITUTE
description: Sobered by the effects of its breakneck ride to the forefront of American politics, the American Enterprise Institute today announced the resignation of its president, William J. Baroody Jr., and the installation of the prominent Republican economist Paul W. McCracken as interim successor.

title: The Lone Ranger
description: Steve Buechele of the Texas Rangers has now hit 11 home runs this season, and all 11 have come with the bases empty.

title: Fast Fries Fried in What?
description: Arguably, the Federal laws that require ingredient lists on packaged foods sold in supermarkets could also apply to Big Macs, Whoppers and other standardized products sold by fast food chains. But Federal officials refuse to apply them, exaggerating the financial burden. Legislation to extend the rules to chains, in the interest of public health, has thus been offered by Senator John Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and Representative Stephen Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn.

title: BROADWAY
description: IT'S been almost three decades since ''A Raisin in the Sun'' burst onto the scene, the first play by a black woman to make it to Broadway. Since then, Lorraine Hansberry's drama has been published in 30 languages, has become a film and was the basis for ''Raisin,'' the 1974 Tony Award-winning musical - but it's never had a major theatrical revival. So after that preamble, it's no trick to guess that that revival is en route, via the Roundabout Theater Company.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Cinecom International Films says John F. Levy has joined the company in the new position of senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday:

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a gain on sale of investments of $16,000 for both the quarter and 6 months and a tax credit of $7,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After a gain on the sale of investments of $4,000 and a tax credit of $8,000. d-Net income and includes a gain of $336,000 on the sale of investments and a tax credit of $149,000.

title: BECKENBAUER: RETICENT COACH
description: He had always insisted that he would never coach once he retired as a player, but Franz Beckenbauer is coaching West Germany in the final of the World Cup against Argentina Sunday.

title: Bozell, Jacobs Appoints Head for Yellow Pages
description: Martin Daniels has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Yellow Pages. Mr. Daniels, 52 years old, has been with the division for seven years.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $139,000 for the quarter and $439,000 for the 6 months.

title: SANDINISTAS ASSAIL FOES IN NICARAGUA
description: A day after House approval of military aid to the rebels seeking the overthrow of Nicaragua's Government, the Sandinista press responded today with sharp criticism of not only President Reagan, but also opposition activists within Nicaragua.

title: The Reagans in Sunglasses
description: The White House has formally protested The Washingtonian magazine's publication of pictures of President and Mrs. Reagan on which were superimposed sunglasses identified by trade name and price. Peter J. Wallison, the White House counsel, wrote the magazine that it was a ''longstanding policy'' of the Administration and its predecessors ''to prohibit the use of the name or likeness of the President, the First Lady or the White House in advertising or commercial promotion in any way that suggests a connection between the President or First Lady and such advertising or promotion.''

title: CUOMO ACTS TO BAR PASS-ALONG OF SHOREHAM COST
description: Governor Cuomo proposed a plan today that would bar the Long Island Lighting Company from charging its customers for the Shoreham nuclear plant and would not impose the same measure on the owners of the Nine Mile 2 nuclear plant upstate.

title: WILLIAM B. LIEBMANN
description: William B. Liebmann, for many years a New York rare book dealer and collector, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: 'Alcestis' in Cambridge
description: Beginning tonight at 8, the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., will present ''Alcestis,'' a work by Robert Wilson based on the Euripides play. The production, which features music by Laurie Anderson, has been chosen to open the Festival d'Automne in Paris in September - the first time an American company has been invited to the annual event, which is regarded as one of the more prestigious metropolitan performing arts festivals in Europe. Other performances in Cambridge will be on July 11 and 12 at 8 P.M. and on July 13 at 2 and 8 P.M. Information: (617) 547-8300.

title: POLICE INQUIRY IN ULSTER RUNS INTO AN INQUIRY
description: There is little doubt that John Stalker, a high-ranking police official here who was in charge of a sensitive inquiry into allegations of police misconduct in Northern Ireland, committed an indiscretion. The question is whether his indiscretion involved excessive devotion to duty or carelessness in his choice of friends.

title: Moslem Militias Close West Beirut Offices
description: Moslem militias that have dominated West Beirut began to close their offices today in preparation for the deployment of Lebanese soldiers to re-establish law and order in the city.

title: Student and Teacher
description: The subject was English. The subject was also the English teacher.

title: Market Place; Suggestions on Mutual Funds
description: TWO observers of the booming mutual fund industry expressed optimism yesterday over prospects for the stock market and also suggested specific funds for investors.

title: NAVY PRESSING CAMPAIGN FOR FUNDS FOR BASE ON S.I.
description: The Navy, joined by New York's two senators and several representatives, began a campaign today to persuade Congress to restore funds for a new base on Staten Island amid widening signs that support for the much disputed project had faltered again.

title: American Wins Battle To Build Globe Theater
description: Sam Wanamaker, the American-born actor and director, has won a 17-year battle for the right to build a replica of the Globe Theater, where most of Shakespeare's plays were first performed, near its original site on the south bank of the Thames.

title: Jay L. Mortimer Weds Prudence Bach
description: Prudence Halle Bach was married yesterday to Jay Lawrance Mortimer at the home of her father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Julian Bach, in Manhattan by Justice Richard W. Wallach of the Supreme Court of the State of New York.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $150 million financing by TRW Inc. offered 8 1/4 percent notes due in 1996 at a price of 99.66, to yield 8.30 percent, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: VOTE TO AID CONTRAS KEEPS REAGAN'S POLICY ALIVE
description: By winning the vote in the House on Wednesday on military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, President Reagan keeps his policy alive in Central America and bolsters his power at home, in the judgment of Administration officials, legislators and outside experts.

title: INQUIRY ON EX-DEMOCRATIC AIDE
description: A Federal grand jury is seeking to determine if a former Queens Democratic Party aide arranged to have public funds illegally pay part of his secretary's salary in his private law practice, law-enforcement authorities say.

title: Perkins Plays Tramps
description: The blues pianist Pinetop Perkins will lead a quintet tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077), with sets at 9:30 P.M. and midnight. There is a $10 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: ART SHOWS CELEBRATE OUR FAVORITE STATUE IN HER MANY GUISES
description: AS everyone knows by now, the centennial of our favorite statue has given rise to exhibitions all over New York City. Three critics were assigned to them, and there were moments when it seemed as if 30 would be none too many. What follows is, therefore, a threefold choice, not an exhaustive listing.

title: BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. Steel's Offering Raised to $400 Million
description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday began offering $400 million of notes due Jan. 15, 1992, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Initially, the financing was to have been for $300 million, but strong investor demand allowed the issuer to increase the size of the offering.

title: TALL SHIPS TEACH ANCIENT LESSONS OF THE HIGH SEAS
description: The windjammers are beginning to arrive in New York - tall ships from around the world whose very presence bespeaks man's centuries-old struggle against the inexorabilities of the sea.

title: SCREEN: 'MY LITTLE PONY'
description: ''MY LITTLE PONY,'' a full-length animated film based on a pastel toy with a bushy tail, is probably the longest self-advertisement since ''The Care Bears.'' Both of these sticky-sweet creations typify a new idea in marketing. Invent the toy, blitz the children with television commercials for it, maybe throw in a television special that shows the toy in action, and finally top it all off with a full-length cartoon movie that will sell the toy and the movie tickets all in one gooey package.

title: 'ON THE WING' MELDS SCIENCE AND ART
description: The medium is always the message at the American Museum of Natural History's Naturemax movie theater, where gargantuan images four stories high seem to envelope audiences in a palpable reality. But the show that opens today is something special; not content with dazzling effects alone, the experts who made the film also came up with some scientific discoveries about the nature of flight.

title: U.S. and Soviet Set '86 Youth Exchange
description: United States and Soviet officials today announced their countries' first youth exchange program, under which young space enthusiasts will be allowed to visit Moscow and Washington.

title: Treasury Prices Are Mixed
description: Prices in the Treasury market were mixed in light trading yesterday, with activity governed by an unfounded rumor regarding President Reagan's health and confusion over reports on the state of the Japanese economy.

title: SWEET LIBERTY IS CAST IN CHOCOLATE
description: Made from an original mold found at the Louvre in Paris, this Miss Liberty is proud of her height and weight: 14 feet tall and two tons of pure bittersweet chocolate.

title: Maloney Is Sworn In As Federal Prosecutor
description: Andrew J. Maloney was sworn in yesterday as United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York in a private ceremony in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: Prof. Stephen W. Botein, 44, Of Michigan State University
description: Stephen William Botein, a professor of history at Michigan State University, died of a cerebral aneurysm Tuesday as he was preparing for the close of a 10-day seminar at the American Antiquarian Society in Worcester, Mass. He was 44 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: PACKWOOD SEEKS CONFEREE LEEWAY
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, is still weighing whether to take his full 20-member committee to the House-Senate tax conference or, as is customary, a much smaller delegation of senior members, aides said today.

title: ART: JAMES ROSENQUIST IN RETROSPECTIVE
description: VERY few people have known what to make of James Rosenquist, whose retrospective has just opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art and can be seen there through Sept. 21. From the fact that as recently as 1960 he was painting backdrops for window displays in Bloomingdale's, Bonwit Teller and Tiffany's, many infer that his paintings must have something coarse and commercial about them.

title: Biaggi Gets Subpoena In Inquiry on Vacation
description: Representative Mario Biaggi has been served with a Federal subpoena in connection with allegations that a vacation trip he made to Florida last December was paid for by Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, according to Mr. Biaggi's lawyer.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
MOTOROLA MAINTAINS CONTINUITY AT HELM
description: William J. Weisz, vice chairman and chief operating officer of Motorola Inc., was named chief executive officer yesterday. The maker of semiconductors and communications products called the move its first in placing key officials for the next generation of corporate leadership.

title: Let's Not Forget Radiation in the U.S.
description: It was a mild morning in late spring, April 26, when technicians with Geiger counters first discovered high levels of radiation, in some places many times normal.

title: The Hackensack River Focus of Festival
description: Nature walks, crafts workshops and puppet shows will all be part of this weekend's Hackensack River Festival, sponsored by the Hackensack Environment Center, Lyndhurst, N.J. A bird walk tomorrow morning at 8 o'clock starts the festivities at the center; throughout the day, there will be music, storytelling, films and workshops. All activities are free except the crafts workshops, which have a $2 registration fee.

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY AGREE ON $65 MILLION HOTEL TAX
description: Just hours before the city's deadline for passing a budget for the next fiscal year, political leaders in Albany agreed yesterday on a hotel tax to raise $65 million.

title: LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes losses of $62,000 and $1,108,000 from disposal of discontinued operations for latest and previous years, respectively. c-After an extraordinary loss of $39,000.

title: HADRON INCORPORATED reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $381,837 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $24,000.

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CUTS SAID TO SET BACK PLAN ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: Congressional cuts in funds for the Pentagon's research into defenses against nuclear missiles threaten for the first time to delay the Government's decision on the feasibility of such a space shield, the general who heads the program said today.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. BLUE JAYS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30P.M.) METS VS.

title: Morris Wins Golf
description: Kevin Morris of Westchester Hills defeated Marty Bohen of Spook Rock, 3 and 2, at the Brae Burn County Club today to win the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association championship for the second time in three years. Morris, a semifinalist in 1985, has clinched a spot in the P.G.A. Championship Aug. 7-10 in Cleveland.

title: THE SCREEN: RAFT SAGA, 'FLOODSTAGE'
description: EVERY summer for 10 years, a small group of young, dedicated, adventurous traveling players, the Otrabanda Company, journeyed by raft down the Mississippi from St. Louis to New Orleans, taking to the river communities along the way a peculiarly eclectic, down-home style of commedia dell'arte street theater.

title: Bridge: Rules Have Been Changing On the Two No-Trump Bid
description: Bidding textbooks of yesteryear often insisted on strict requirements for an opening two no-trump bid, and to a lesser extent for one no-trump. The two no-trump opening bidder was expected to have all four suits stopped, but the reader was not told how to bid with hands of the right strength with an unstopped suit.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch on Wednesday about Senate passage of the tax revision bill misstated the time it would take to phase in a restriction on the deductions for interest expenses.

title: Bond Losses Hurt Salomon
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. said yesterday that it was only marginally profitable in the month of May because of heavy losses from bond trading at its investment banking subsidiary, but that earnings were back on track during June.

title: U.S. BACKS FARM LOAN FOR BRAZIL
description: The Reagan Administration voted today to support a domestically contested $500 million World Bank loan to improve Brazilian agriculture. The loan was then approved unanimously by the bank's 150 member governments at a board meeting.

title: 'Portraits of Liberty'
description: The figure holding the torch in New York Harbor is a woman, and Channel 4, in the mass of media coverage about her centennial, has cannily chosen to tell us about the Statue of Liberty and some women who found better lives in her shadow.

title: An Unknown Parrot Is Found in Ecuador
description: Robert Ridgely, an ornithologist from the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences, has discovered a species of parrot that lives in a mountain forest in Ecuador, the academy announced today.

title: JAZZ: MAX ROACH'S M'BOOM
description: M'BOOM, the all-percussion octet founded by Max Roach in 1970, tinkles and rattles and rustles and roars. Opening a two-night engagement Wednesday at Sounds of Brazil, M'Boom's pieces drew on jazz, salsa and hints of African and European traditions.

title: LETTERS TO NEBRASKA
description: ''The 'soaps' may be in for some new competition.''

title: A PATTERN OF RACKETEERING IS CITED
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn accused a suspended Civil Court judge yesterday of arson, extortion, mail fraud and other crimes that, it said, constituted a pattern of racketeering in real-estate business for 13 years before his election to the bench in 1985.

title: No Eviction of Navajos Is Planned, Official Says
description: Federal officials do not plan to remove Navajo families from lands allocated to the Hopi tribe to enforce a July 6 relocation deadline, a spokesman for the Bureau of Indian Affairs says.

title: A Texan Goes Home
description: For William Dean Singleton the purchase of one of Texas's largest newspapers marks a triumphant return to the state where his newspaper career began.

title: AUCTIONS
description: TWO James Bond cars from ''Goldfinger,'' a gingham pinafore worn by Judy Garland in ''The Wizard of Oz,'' and Charlie Chaplin's bowler hat and cane are among the movie memorabilia that will be auctioned tomorrow and next month in sales in New York and London.

title: MAYOR-ELECT OF NEWARK PLANS BUREAUCRACY CUTS
description: Sharpe James, who will be sworn in on Tuesday as mayor of this troubled city, said he planned a widespread restructuring of the city government, including the elimination of some departments.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John McKay, the 62-year-old former coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and Southern Cal, was in excellent condition after undergoing triple-bypass heart surgery Tuesday night at St. John's Heart Institute in Santa Monica, Calif., and will be discharged in a day or two, a hospital spokesman said. McKay is in semiretirement as a consultant to the Tampa Bay club. . . . The Chicago White Sox have shipped the reserve catcher Scott Bradley, obtained in the Britt Burns-Neil Allen trade with the Yankees, to the Seattle Mariners for a player to be named and have activated the outfielder Reid Nichols.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: The latest quarter and 6 months reflect a change in accounting policy which increased second quarter net by $147,000 and 6 months net by $293,000.

title: FILM: 'RUTHLESS PEOPLE,' A COMEDY
description: THE most irresistible thing about the characters in ''Ruthless People,'' a conspicuously overconsuming, Beverly Hills update of O. Henry's classic ''Ransom of Red Chief,'' is that they all try with such earnestness to live up to their ruthless reputations.

title: IRISH MUSIC AND DANCE IN A 9-HOUR CELEBRATION
description: WHEN it began five years ago, New York City's annual Irish Music Festival consisted of just a handful of musicians performing for a tiny audience in a small park on Manhattan's West Side. Since then, the festival, which celebrates one of the world's richest folk-music traditions, has mushroomed into an all-day outdoor affair, featuring some 50 performers sprawled over five stages.

title: California Ballot to Have Referendum on AIDS
description: Followers of the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. have succeeded in placing a referendum on the Nov. 4 California ballot that could lead to the quarantine of AIDS victims, the office of the Secretary of State says.

title: BYRD MANEUVER STALLS APPROVAL OF A NEW JUDGE
description: The Senate Democratic leader, Robert C. Byrd, used an adroit parliamentary maneuver today to block, at least temporarily, the appointment of Daniel A. Manion as a Federal appeals court judge in Chicago.

title: U.S. Ruling Against Canada Wood
