description: The United States International Trade Commission held in a preliminary 5-to-0 decision today that Canadian softwood lumber imports were undercutting American sales and injuring American lumber producers. The ruling could lead to stiff duties on future imports.

title: FILM: MAGNOLI'S 'AMERICAN ANTHEM'
description: AMERICAN ANTHEM,'' which opens today at the Ziegfeld and other theaters, is a disco sound-and-light show about gymnastics. The nonstop sound goes from heavenly choruses to demonic rock but never manages to drown out the dialogue; the hyped-up lighting invests people with halos, and the colors must have been compounded by a punk hairdresser.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES TO IMPEACH JUDGE
description: The House Judiciary Committee voted today for impeachment of an imprisoned Federal District Judge, Harry E. Claiborne of Nevada, in the first such proceeding since the panel's votes to impeach President Nixon 12 years ago.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Tall Tales: Won't Wash
description: Why is the New York subway's new $20 million car wash like the ice maker at Central Park's Wollman skating rink? Neither works.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company Briefs column of Business Day yesterday omitted a condition on a rate increase given to the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company. The full increase of $76 million goes into effect when the company's Perry nuclear plant reaches 20 percent of power. For the interim, it got an increase of $37 million.

title: INDUSTRIAL ELECTRONIC HARDARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-After income tax credits of $64,656.

title: Senators at Bat
description: The fierce political rivalry between New York's Senators, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato, has shifted to the softball diamond where the Moynihan team edged the D'Amato entry in the Congressional league, 18 to 15. The contest was postponed several times by Senate preoccupation with the tax revision bill but was finally played Tuesday evening, the day the measure passed. The D'Amato team's defeat came despite three hits by the second baseman, Marla Lieberman, who was actually on loan from the Moynihan forces; she is the wife of Nick Allard, Mr. Moynihan's administrative aide.

title: Building Contracts Off
description: The value of new construction contracts awarded in May fell 9 percent to a seasonally adjusted rate of $226.25 billion, from April's rate of $248.73 billion, according to the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc.

title: LLOYD WINS 'TEDIOUS' MATCH
description: Chris Evert Lloyd wanted to discourage anyone from reaching a premature conclusion. Her uneven performance against Pam Casale today could be blamed on boredom, she said, more than on her opponent's effort to produce an upset. Thus, those fans interested in watching the demise of the top-seeded players at Wimbledon are advised to continue following the men.

title: REAGAN AGAIN SEES A 'TURNING POINT' IN THE ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan said today that recent Soviet proposals might lead to a ''turning point'' in the quest for an agreement in the Geneva arms talks.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: A dispatch yesterday from Santa Barbara, Calif., about United States relations with Mexico described President Reagan's plan to meet with President Miguel de la Madrid about current problems including drug traffic.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for 12wks to June 14
Many a New Edison Is Inventing Software
description: To the Editor:

title: A Surrogate Mother Has Triplets for Sister
description: A woman who agreed to bear a child for her infertile sister gave birth to triplets on the fourth attempt at artificial insemination.

title: JUDGE, CITING COMMERCIALS, DROPS TV CITIZENSHIP OATH
description: A Federal district judge here has refused to participate in a nationwide naturalization ceremony on July 3 because he says the dignity of the proceeding would be diminished by the introduction of television advertising.

title: EDITOR OF INFLUENTIAL BLACK SOUTH AFRICAN JOURNAL REPORTED SEIZED
description: The editor of an influential South African journal was forcibly abducted from his home near Johannesburg in the early morning hours yesterday, according to church sources in London.

title: HOVNANIAN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The 1985 share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1986.

title: EUROPEANS PLAN 2 SHUTTLES
description: The European Space Agency has adopted a $2 billion French project to build two space shuttles that would be operational by 1995, the agency said today.

title: Lost Water, Stunted Lives; Slow the Flow Faster
description: New York City's water crisis is gone but not, thankfully, forgotten by city officials eager to prevent a recurrence. They deserve a helping hand from the Legislature.

title: Ivy Bell, Account Executive, Weds Barry Berman
description: Ivy Sue Bell and Barry Berman were married yesterday by Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman at the Manhattan home of the bride's sister, Elly Sidel.

title: BILL ON LIBELING OF DEAD PEOPLE MAKES PROGRESS
description: A bill that would create a completely new category of libel - based on comments made about a dead person - is progressing in the State Legislature.

title: Wood Gundy Merger Is Off
description: In a surprise announcement, Wood Gundy Inc. and the Gordon Capital Corporation, two major Canadian securities companies, said yesterday that they were calling off a merger that they had announced publicly just three weeks ago.

title: Panhandle's 'Third Party'
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation of Houston, responding to rumors that the natural gas pipeline giant had become a takeover target, said yesterday that it had been approached by an unidentified ''third party'' wanting to buy the company. It said it rejected the interest ''at this time.''

title: INTERMARK INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results for 1985 have been reclassified to conform with latest year presentation.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD HIGH FEES PAID TO LAWYERS IN CIVIL RIGHTS CASES
description: A divided Supreme Court today upheld a lower court's award of $245,456 in fees to two lawyers who won $33,350 in damages for eight Mexican-Americans in a civil rights case.

title: A Life in Pictures
description: MARGARET BOURKE-WHITE. A Biography. By Vicki Goldberg. Illustrated. 426 pages. Harper & Row. $25.95. No doubt the reader is already familiar with her photographs, images imprinted on the national consciousness by Life magazine, Fortune and her own numerous books: a monumental view of the Fort Peck Dam as a massive feat of engineering, dwarfing the two tiny figures of workmen in the foreground; a close-up shot of plow blades as gleaming, abstract images of technology; a picture of flood victims, standing in line before a billboard (''There's no way like the American Way'') as a dark commentary on Depression-age America; a portrait of Gandhi, looking ascetic and otherworldly as he sits reading on the floor.

title: 8 Indicted in Vote Fraud In Southern Indiana
description: Eight people were indicted today on charges of buying Democratic votes in 1982 and 1984 races in southern Indiana, including a Congressional election that was one of the closest in the nation's history, the Justice Department announced.

title: PARAMEDICS WILL USE CARTS TO SKIRT TRAFFIC
description: The city will begin using small, motorized carts to squeeze through and around snarled rush-hour traffic in midtown and lower Manhattan so that the Emergency Medical Service can reach heart-attack victims and other emergency cases more quickly.

title: THE IRISH UPHOLD BAN ON DIVORCE BY 3-TO-2 MARGIN
description: The Irish have voted overwhelmingly to keep the nation's ban on divorce, delivering a severe setback to the Government of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald, according to returns announced today.

title: OPEC STILL AT IMPASSE OVER PRODUCTION CUTS
description: A majority group of OPEC ministers failed today to persuade a stubborn minority to accept a moderate cut in the organization's production of crude oil in hopes of bolstering prices to about $17 to $20 a barrel by the year's end.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: AUTO RACING - CHASE GRAND PRIX, at the Meadowlands, 8 A.M. Qualifying for Indy-type cars, 12:30 P.M. Super Vee Bosch Cup race, 2 P.M. , BASEBALL YANKEES VS. BLUE JAYS, at Yankee Stadium, 1:30 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 and 7:45 P.M., Radio -WABC, 770, 1:30P.M.) METS VS.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Every time I go away, something happens.'' - Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy, after a parliamentary vote brought down his Government while he was at a European Community meeting. [ 3:5. ]

title: Heart Transplant Costs To Be Paid by Medicare
description: The Federal Medicare system is soon to begin paying for a limited number of heart transplants, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Otis R. Bowen, said today.

title: Lobbying for Foreigners Is Worse
description: Should holders of high office be forbidden ever to lobby for foreign countries after leaving office? Yes, said Senator Strom Thurmond, charging that American textile interests have been damaged by an official-turned-lobbyist. He found support from many legislators angered by the excesses of Michael Deaver, the former White House aide.

title: ITALY'S CHIEF QUITS AFTER NEARLY 3 YEARS
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi resigned tonight, bringing an end to Italy's longest-lasting postwar Government.

title: Offer to Cyclops
description: The Cyclops Corporation of Pittsburgh received an offer of $90.5 million yesterday for its steel and nonresidential construction businesses, nearly two months after it agreed to sell the units to another company. H.W. Delano, vice president of Cyclops, would not disclose the name of the company that made the offer yesterday, but said it would be considered by the special committee of the Cyclops board despite a previous agreement to sell to the Hillman Company of Pittsburgh. The new bid is the second shift involving the units.

title: TO ASIAN REFUGEES, U.S. IS STILL LAND OF HOPE
description: Khounphom Sone expects to be living in Brooklyn by the Fourth of July.

title: Two Legs vs. Two Wheels vs. Four Wheels: Debate Whirls On
description: To the Editor:

title: The Scandal Behind the Tragedy
description: In less than a week, the Len Bias story has become much more than a stunning personal tragedy. The cocaine death of the college basketball star, just as he was being transformed into a millionaire in the pros, began as an obvious lesson about the grave danger posed by drugs. Now it has brought more evidence also of the tawdry standards of big-time college athletics. Len Bias may have been at fault for yielding to the drug temptation. But a large circle of educators and entrepreneurs bear responsibility for the deeper scandal his death revealed.

title: RACING CARS' POWER TO BE CUT
description: The ruling body of world auto sports today announced significant changes in Grand Prix auto racing and international rallying in an effort to improve safety.

title: U.S. Home Sets Restructuring
description: The U.S. Home Corporation, one of the nation's largest single-family home builders, said today that it was undertaking a comprehensive restructuring that would result in a ''substantial'' loss for its second quarter.

title: Time in Accord To Buy Science '86
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Science '86 magazine.

title: TV: 'LIFE AND OPINIONS OF JULES FEIFFER' ON 13
description: At the end of a tantalizing hour, Jules Feiffer, the Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist, playwright, screenwriter and novelist - says: ''That's it for now, ladies and gentlemen, another writer's near-miss.''

title: SALSA: CLASSIC VARIATIONS
description: The vibrant, sun-drenched, refreshing flavors of Southwestern cooking are nowhere more evident than in the new variations on the traditional salsas, the sauces that are so important to the cooking of the region.

title: Enduring Settlement House
description: Times and faces may have changed at the Hamilton-Madison House, but the principle has remained the same.

title: Tribute to Animator
description: A tribute to the animator Jay Ward, who created the characters of Crusader Rabbit, Bullwinkle the Moose and Dudley Do-Right, will begin today at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street.

title: Anita Baker Debut At Avery Fisher Hall
description: Anita Baker, a young pop-soul singer from Detroit, won several standing ovations during her exciting New York concert debut at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening. The singer, who appeared under the auspices of the JVC Jazz Festival, possesses an extraordinarily rich and flexible alto.

title: MOST AIRLINES HELD EXEMPT ON HANDICAPPED RIGHTS RULE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that almost all commercial airlines are not covered by a 1973 Federal law that bars discrimination against handicapped people.

title: Quintet at Carlos 1
description: The saxophonists Frank Foster and Frank Wess are leading their quintet tonight and tomorrow at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight; there is a $10 cover and a $7 minimum.

title: Maryland Plans Reforms
description: University of Maryland officials went to work today on a plan that would give the academic sector, not the athletic department, authority over the counselors who are assigned to help athletes with their studies.

title: Overall Trade Deficit Wider in May
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit widened to $14.2 billion in May from $12.1 billion the month before, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A Parent Is Always A Parent
description: No doubt the most banal, most unnecessary remarks ever spoken in the English language, or any other tongues, are those delivered by well-meaning parents to their offspring.

title: Mel Torme Salutes Broadway and Movies
description: Mel Torme's ability to pull together and energize a program was vividly demonstrated Thursday night in a JVC Jazz Festival concert called ''Jazz Salutes Broadway and the Movies'' at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: MERGER ISSUES STAR
description: With corporate merger activity suddenly on the rise, Wall Street was treated yesterday to a number of big stock gains in a market that otherwise rose only modestly on light volume.

title: Lost Water, Stunted Lives; Born Behind
description: Visit the nursery of any New York hospital and you're bound to see premature babies, dangerously underweight babies and babies born drug-addicted. Sad, but not surprising.

title: HOUSE VOTE ON NAVY PORT FOR STATEN ISLAND: A NEW YORK DELEGATION DIVIDED
description: The Navy's plan to build a port on Staten Island for the battleship Iowa was dealt a blow this week by, of all people, a group of Congressmen from New York City who three years ago urged the Navy to bring the Iowa here. In a vote in the House

title: Readathon at Library . . .
description: The lions sat quietly as Steven Kroll told of a pumpkin so large it took 10 field mice on motorcycles to bring it to town for show. While the big cats seemed dubious, the children and adults on the steps of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street yesterday were visibly impressed.

title: BROWNS SAFETY DIES OF CARDIAC ARREST
description: Don Rogers, the Cleveland Browns free safety who was the American Football Conference defensive rookie of the year in 1984, died today of cardiac arrest, authorities said.

title: Right-to-Die Case to Go To Jersey's High Court
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court agreed today to hear an appeal of a court ruling that would permit a life-sustaining respirator to be removed from a terminally ill woman who wants to die.

title: VINTAGE CARS, HIGH BIDDERS, MEET IN RENO
description: A yellow and black French-made Bugatti Royale was sold tonight for $6.5 million, the highest auction price ever paid for an automobile.

title: U.S. MAY BURN CHEMICAL ARMS AT 8 LOCATIONS
description: The Army has decided to destroy its stockpiles of outmoded chemical weapons at eight sites around the country where they are stored, avoiding the risks of moving the weapons to central locations for destruction, Government officials said this week.

title: RULING ON LAUNDERING
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that an employee could be convicted of criminal charges for causing his brokerage firm to violate a law requiring financial institutions to report transactions of more than $10,000.

title: Year's Fastest Mile
description: Steve Cram ran the fastest mile in the world this year yesterday, finishing in 3 minutes 51.43 seconds, but the United States still defeated England, 122-111, in an international track meet.

title: Use of History Was on Trial in Sears Sex-Bias Case; Management's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPERMARKET MACHINES TO TAKE CITICORP CARDS
description: Citicorp has embarked on a program to allow its bank cards to be used in automatic tellers in supermarkets and other retail outlets. The bank has already acquired 40 machines in supermarkets and is negotiating to buy others.

title: Dr. Hirschhorn, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Lisa Ruth Hirschhorn, a resident in internal medicine at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, and Bennett B. Goldberg, a doctoral candidate in physics at Brown University, were married yesterday. Rabbi Terry Bard officiated at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alan B. Goldberg, in Brookline, Mass.

title: SANDINISTAS SAY CLOSED NEWSPAPER BACKED U.S.
description: The Government said today that it had ordered the indefinite closing of La Prensa, the only opposition newspaper in the country, because the paper had sought ''to justify United States aggression.''

title: Bridge; Part-Score Factor Can Add To the Stakes and Tension
description: ''When is a door not a door?'' the old riddle asks. Answer: ''When it is ajar.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Among the charges of misconduct against Roy M. Cohn, who was disbarred in New York State, was that he pressed a dying client, Lewis S. Rosensteil, to put this signature on a codicil to his will naming Mr. Cohn, among others, as an executor of his estate. The expert disputed that the lines were a signature. 2. Mr. O'Neill refused to permit President Reagan to make a final appeal before the House of Representatives for $100 million in aid for Nicaraguan rebels, saying the President should appear before a joint session of Congress. Yes. 3. The appointment of Daniel A. Manion as a Federal appeals court judge in Chicago. To break a 47-to-47 tie, which would have allowed Vice President Bush to assure the appointment, Senator Byrd switched sides and voted in favor of the nomination, a move that under Senate rules gave him the right to call for reconsideration of the decision. 4. ''Gone With the Wind.'' 5. Section 301 is the unmarked grave of 280 Hungarians who were hanged for their participation in the Hungarian uprising of 1956. 6. Senate passage of the tax bill. 7. The telecommunications operations of the ITT Corporation. 8. The bills, a novelty, are sold in uncut form, the way they come off the presses. 9. True. 10. The statue is made of chocolate. 11. President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico. 12. A huge brown algae bloom is threatening marine life as it spreads through the coastal waters of Long Island and other parts of the Northeast. 13. 318. 14. Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the army commander and strongman of Panama. 15.

title: BUDGET ACCORD: PROGRAMS CONGRESS SAVED
description: The Congressional budget resolution approved early today retains 43 of 45 programs that President Reagan sought to end or significantly reduce, according to Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.

title: Stop Scolding New Zealand
description: New Zealand's policy banning nuclear powered or armed ships from its ports is, in one sense, self-pleasing posturing. The policy is popular not only because it diminishes the chance of a nuclear accident or because it removes New Zealand as a target for a potential nuclear attack. It is also popular because it makes an anti-nuclear statement, enshrining the principle that the nuclear arms race is sheer madness.

title: FRENCH-ITT DIFFERENCES CITED
description: The French Government has asked the ITT Corporation to grant it exclusive rights for 30 days to purchase the company's telecommunications business, but ITT has told the Government that a decision about the purchase must be made by the end of next week, according to sources familiar with the negotiations.

title: Pennsylvania Woman Guilty in Mall Shootings
description: A woman accused of killing three people and wounding seven others in a shooting rampage at a crowded shopping mall last October was found guilty today but mentally ill.

title: Guerrero Car Is Fastest
description: Five of the 26 drivers broke the lap record today on the Meadowlands road racing track. They were competing in the first qualifying session for the $700,000 Chase Grand Prix to be run here Sunday.

title: THE DANCE: ROCKVILLE PERFORMS
description: The RockVille Dance Company describes its work as representing ''an upbeat clash of symbols'' - the symbols being classical ballet and ''hot rock music.'' The two needn't necessarily clash, of course, as a few other choreographers have proven. But talent, experience and a sense of craft must be at work for them to mesh interestingly. None of those were in evidence in a program performed by the company on Wednesday at Marymount Manhattan Theater.

title: Naumburg Orchestra
description: The Naumburg Orchestra, conducted by Jens Nygaard, will give a free performance today at 8 P.M. at the Damrosch Park Bandshell at Lincoln Center, Broadway and 67th Street. The violinist David Nadien will appear with the orchestra. On the program are a Corelli concerto grosso; a Mozart divertimento; Kodaly's Minuetto Serio and Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto. Other concerts by the orchestra in Damrosch Park will be on July 5 and Sept. 7, both at 8 P.M.

title:
Patents;
Seminar on Thursday At New York Library
description: The Patent and Trademark Office will hold a seminar at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42d Street, from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. next Thursday.

title: MATERNITY-LEAVE SUIT HAS DIVIDED FEMINISTS
description: A lawsuit before the United States Supreme Court concerning the rights of pregnant workers has split the women's movement down the middle, with Betty Friedan and organizations such as 9 to 5 arguing on one side, and the National Organization for Women and the American Civil Liberties Union on the other.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. A handwriting expert said he had never seen anything like these lines in all his years of experience. Why was that newsworthy? 2. ''Having the President appear before only one house to lobby for a legislative proposal would be unprecedented,'' said Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House. What were the circumstances and, according to historical records, was he correct? 3. Using a parliamentary maneuver, Robert C. Byrd, the Senate Democratic leader, was able to block a Federal appointment, at least temporarily. What appointment was it and what was the maneuver? 4. A novel whose original title was ''Tomorrow Is Another Day,'' and whose heroine was named Pansy is back on the hard-cover best-seller list 50 years after its publication. What book is it? 5. As a 30th anniversary approaches, more people are visiting a plot of land, Section 301, where part of a nation's past is buried. What anniversary is it and what is Section 301? 6. ''The score is taxpayers 1, special interests 0,'' said President Reagan. To what was he referring? 7. Compagnie Generale d'Electricte of France is negotiating to buy the cornerstone of an American company for more than $2 billion. What is for sale? 8. The Bureau of Engraving and Printing is selling dollar bills with no numismatic value at a premium: 4 for $5.50, 16 for $20.25 or 32 for $38.

title: Former Officials Banned From Office by Nigeria
description: Nigeria's military ruler, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, announced today that former politicians would be barred from holding office for 10 years and presented a series of sweeping economic revisions.

title: 2 SHOT IN ATTACK ON INVESTIGATOR
description: A Manhattan private detective walking to his lower Fifth Avenue apartment was confronted by ''a wall of robbers'' early yesterday, drew his revolver as he was being yoked and pulled to the ground and shot two of the assailants, the police said.

title: BONN SEEKS TO SELL VW, VEBA STAKES
description: West Germany's Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, today proposed to sell to private investors the Government's stake in Volkswagen and in VEBA, the country's second-largest company.

title: LEADERS STYMIED ON CITY'S BUDGET
description: The day after missing their own deadline for passing a budget for the next fiscal year, New York City officials - with virtually no hope of additional help from state lawmakers -continued late last night to work on the plan.

title: SCOTT 2-HITTER BLANKS DODGERS
description: Mike Scott pitched a two-hitter, and Bill Doran and Kevin Bass each hit bases-empty home runs tonight, leading the Houston Astros to a 5-0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Browns Cut McDonald
description: The Cleveland Browns are banking on Gary Danielson to recover from his shoulder surgery at the end of last season and have put their reserve quarterback, Paul McDonald, on waivers in hopes of trading him within 10 days if no one claims him. McDonald, 28 years old, was the Browns' fourth-round draft pick in 1980 out of Southern California.

title: Achille Lauro Trial Suspended by Judge
description: The judge in the Achille Lauro hijacking trial announced today that he was suspending proceedings until Tuesday to consider whether to drop a juror whom the chief prosecutor asked to leave the panel.

title: Dorothy Schefer Wed To Richard G. Faux Jr.
description: The marriage of Dorothy Nadler Schefer, a daughter of Eli Isaac Schefer of Sands Point, L.I., and the late Rose Nadler Schefer, to Richard Gordon Faux Jr., a son of Natalie Brigham Faux of Quincy, Mass., and the late Mr. Faux, took place yesterday at the River Club in New York. Rabbi Eugene Lipse officiated with the Rev. Philip Clarke, minister of the Park Avenue United Methodist Church.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 28, 1986
description: Companies

title: Two Legs vs. Two Wheels vs. Four Wheels: Debate Whirls On
description: To the Editor:

title: GAINING ADMISSION: REFUGEES OFTEN FACE LENGTHY PROCESS
description: For Asians who come to the United States as refugees, the first stop is generally another Asian country, where they are given sanctuary and made available for interviews with resettlement countries.

title: Atlanta Bank Adds
description: The Citizens and Southern Corporation, the Atlanta-based bank holding company that operates banks in Georgia, Florida and South Carolina, has agreed to acquire Independent Community Banks Inc. for $69 million. Independent Community Banks, which operates the First National Mortgage Company and Retirement Accounts Inc., and banking subsidiaries in four Florida counties, had assets of $370 million on March 31. Citizens and Southern reported total assets of $17.3 billion for the same period.

title: Steeplechase To Le Rheusois
description: Le Rheusois of France won the Grand Course de Haies d'Auteuil steeplechase today.

title: Nicaragua, Reagan, Sandino
description: Once passed into history, a political figure can become a kind of Rorschach test, subject to widely conflicting interpretations. Such seems to be the case with Gen. Augusto Cesar Sandino, a Nicaraguan nationalist and rebel leader who was killed half a century ago.

title: Queens Worker Killed In Structure Collapse
description: A construction worker was fatally injured and three others were hurt yesterday morning when a building foundation partially collapsed onto an abutting excavation site where they were working, the authorities reported.

title:
Patents;
Electronic Translations Of Complete Sentences
description: An electronic translator, invented for a Japanese company, translates a complete sentence into another language.

title: EX-POSTAL CHIEF LAYS OUSTER TO INTERVENTION ON KICKBACK
description: Former Postmaster General Paul N. Carlin said today that he had been forced to leave the position because he had intervened in a kickback scheme involving a member of the Postal Service's Board of Governors.

title: Nicaragua, O'Neill, Aspin
description: In the House of Representatives, it was a week of passionate debate and fervid appeals as members finally voted on the Reagan Administration's request to send $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. In the end, the aid was approved Wednesday night with the help of 51 Democrats who voted with the Administration.

title: Ties to Ellis I.
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has a new broadcast commercial that tries to take advantage of the Statue of Liberty centennial hoopla.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press from Pasco, Wash., in some editions on Thursday misidentified a judge who found a rape victim in contempt of court for refusal to testify. The judge was Dennis Yule, not Albert Yencopal.

title: FOR HISPANIC NEW YORKERS, SUMMER OASIS
description: Every weekend morning at 9:30, a little wedge of the city breaks off from a pier at 42d Street and swirls upriver to Bear Mountain, where the air is pristine, the lake water sweet and much of the music rap, reggae, rock, salsa or mariachi.

title: New Columbia Chief
description: The British producer David Puttnam has been named chairman and chief executive of Columbia Pictures. Mr. Puttnam, whose appointment had been expected, will assume the post on Sept. 1.

title: Ban on Capsules Begins In Washington State
description: A 90-day state ban on over-the-counter capsule drugs went into effect across the state of Washington today and spread into Oregon because of the product-tampering scare arising from two unsolved cyanide poisoning deaths.

title: May Stores Loan
description: May Department Stores has arranged with Citibank to advance up to $300 million as part of a total $1.5 billion financing for the company's tender offer to acquire the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, according a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. May said that it would repay the borrowings within eight years.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RULINGS BY THE WORLD COURT
description: Following are excerpts from the rulings today by the International Court of Justice on Nicaragua's complaint against the United States:

title: NEW YORK CITY SCHOOL BUSES NEED SEAT BELTS
description: Most children in New York City who are transported to and from school in a school bus do not have seat belt protection. This dangerous situation must be corrected immediately. But, although it boggles the mind, the Board of Education opposes the idea.

title: PERU'S LEADER SAYS GUARDS MURDERED 100 INMATES
description: President Alan Garcia said today that the Peruvian police dragged more than 100 inmates accused of being guerrillas from a prison cell block, threw them on the ground and shot them in the head in a mass execution last week.

title: Two Legs vs. Two Wheels vs. Four Wheels: Debate Whirls On
description: To the Editor:

title: President Plays Las Vegas
description: In the 1950's, Ronald Reagan did a brief stint in Las Vegas as a master of ceremonies and comedian with a quartet called The Continentals. This week, President Reagan was back in Vegas as the headline act at a fund-raiser for Jim Santini, a Republican candidate for the Senate.

title: Republic Air Deal Backed
description: A Transportation Department administrative law judge today recommended approval of the proposed acquisition of Republic Airlines by Northwest Airlines.

title: THE HARDWARE GIANTS FALTER
description: In the wake of the broad success of home centers - the large hardware and building supply stores that revolutionized the do-it-yourself industry - an even bigger type of retailer started to appear in the early 1980's: the warehouse store.

title: Friedman Trial Is Set for Sept. 8
description: The date of the Federal trial of Stanley M. Friedman and five others on corruption charges was set for Sept. 8 yesterday by Judge Whitman Knapp in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Rain Complicates Met Pitching Plans
description: The Mets, casting an eye on the homestretch of the pennant race later this summer, got the last thing they wanted today in old Wrigley Field: a rainout.

title: MASSACHUSETTS MAN MAKES BALLOT BUT PARTY SHUNS HIM
description: The Massachusetts Ballot Law Commission today upheld the candidacy of Gregory S. Hyatt, the only candidate still running in the Republican gubernatorial primary this fall, whose nominating petitions had been assailed by both Republicans and Democrats.

title: THE DANCE: OTRABANDA'S 'RETURN'
description: The older we grow, the more we have to remember. Yet the older we grow, the easier it is to forget. This situation was examined in ''Return,'' presented Wednesday night at La Mama by the La Mama Experimental Theater Club and Otrabanda. Collaboratively created by Tim Buckley, Rocky Bornstein, Roger Babb and Ellen Maddow, who performed it to music by (Blue) Gene Tyranny, the mixed-media piece used movement and speech to suggest the elusiveness of memory and the subjectivity of experience.

title: U.S. ASSAILS COURT RULING AND CLOSING OF LA PRENSA
description: The State Department today rejected the World Court's finding that United States policy toward Nicaragua violated international law, denouncing the court as ''not equipped'' to judge complex international military issues.

title: Use of History Was on Trial in Sears Sex-Bias Case
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
Simulated Skin Helps Surgeons
description: SIMULATED human skin and artificial faces have been invented to help practitioners and students improve their skill in surgery. Trademarked Vera Derm, the skin is sold in surgical teaching workshops.

title: IN PERSON, CATHY TYSON BELIES HER ICY FILM ROLE
description: Aloof and elegant, she rides silently through the night in the long sleek car. When her driver pulls up in front of an expensive hotel, she wraps her coat around her whippet-thin body and walks through the lobby with her head held high, carrying herself as if she were an African queen. Underneath the coat, however, she is wearing only white lace undergarments; in her small overnight case is a set of manacles and a metal-studded black leather bikini.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS ENCOURAGED ON JUDGESHIP VOTE
description: Democratic lawmakers hoping to defeat the judicial nomination of Daniel A. Manion were encouraged today when two Republicans criticized political maneuvers that resulted in tentative Senate approval of the Indiana lawyer.

title: 'Liberty Lives in Jersey'
description: Miss Liberty has many claimants on her affections as she celebrates her centennial, but perhaps none so determined as Representative Frank J. Guarini, Democrat of New Jersey.

title: Offer Sweetened By Lloyds Bank
description: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. today sweetened its hostile bid to buy Standard Chartered P.L.C. to the equivalent of about $1.93 billion from $1.76 billion. A combination of the two banks would create Britain's biggest commercial bank, with assets of more than $106 billion.

title: MOVE BY HUSSEIN SAID TO FAIL
description: Arab and Western diplomats said this week that an effort by King Hussein to bring about an easing of tensions between Syria and Iraq had fallen apart.

title: Cleveland Is Where It's At
description: When it became clear that I was leaving New York for this much maligned north-central city, I suffered a significant period of denial. My wife and I treated the ''moving counselor'' from the van lines like an afternoon tea guest. ''Have you seen 'Chorus Line' yet?'' ''Do you suppose the Yanks will rehire Martin?''

title: AGGRESSIVE PROSECUTOR: ANDREW JOSEPH MALONEY
description: The secret to knocking out your opponents, says Andrew J. Maloney, the newly appointed United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, is to ''try to outsmart them with fancy footwork.''

title: PHILADELPHIA COUNCILMAN CHARGED WITH EXTORTION IN DEVELOPMENT
description: A Philadelphia City Councilman and his senior aide were arrested here today and charged with conspiring with a crime syndicate to extort $1 million from Rouse & Associates Inc., the developer of a key parcel in the city's effort to restore its waterfront.

title: WORLD COURT SUPPORTS NICARAGUA AFTER U.S. REJECTED JUDGES' ROLE
description: The International Court of Justice ruled today that the Reagan Administration had broken international law and violated Nicaraguan sovereignty by aiding the anti-Government rebels.

title: Mulgrew Miller Plays Solo Piano Concert
description: Mulgrew Miller's solo piano concert Wednesday at Bruno Walter Auditorium revealed unexpected aspects of his playing. In groups with Woody Shaw and Johnny Griffin, Mr. Miller has often sounded like McCoy Tyner, wielding grandiose modal chords and arpeggios.

title: 41st Caramoor Festival Is Opening Tonight
description: A performance by the Orchestra of St. Luke's tonight at 8:30 will open the 41st Caramoor Music Festival in Katonah, N.Y. John Nelson will conduct the orchestra in a program of works by Gabrieli, Carl Maria von Weber, Max Bruch and John Adams.

title: INSIDE A PERUVIAN JAIL, WHERE REBELS HELD SWAY
description: Five miles out to sea on a rocky speck of land shrouded in fog and washed by Pacific waves, one of the world's most determined guerrilla organizations built what seemed to many, until June 18, a secure stronghold.

title: Spain Holds 2 in Blast At Airport in Madrid
description: The Spanish police said today that two people were being held in connection with a bombing at the El Al Israel Airlines counter at the Madrid airport.

title: Tarpley Sentenced
description: ''He seems like a nice kid, he's just a lousy driver.'' That's what a Michigan District Court Judge said in sentencing Roy Tarpley, the former University of Michigan basketball star, to helping run a summer clinic for youngsters as part of his sentence for speeding.

title: DR. PAUL HENKIND
description: Dr. Paul Henkind, Frances DeJur Professor and chairman of the department of ophthalmology at Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of a brain tumor Tuesday at the medical center. He was 53 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: SHULTZ ENDS U.S. VOW TO DEFEND NEW ZEALAND
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the Prime Minister of New Zealand today that as a result of their Governments' rift over nuclear policy, the United States no longer felt bound to come to New Zealand's defense under the 35-year-old Anzus treaty.

title: JAYS ROUT GUIDRY, TROUNCE YANKS
description: The good could not overcome the bad and the ugly for the Yankees last night. Their home-run hitting and their relief pitching succumbed to their starting pitching, their fielding - and their relief pitching. And the bad and the ugly provoked Manager Lou Piniella into a postgame verbal blast at his players.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
SANDERS GETS OFFER FROM LORAL
description: A significant consolidation in the military electronics industry was proposed today as the Loral Corporation offered to buy Sanders Associates, a New Hampshire concern that specializes in electronic warfare systems, for about $862 million.

title: Bond Prices Spurt; Rate Cut Is Seen
description: Bond prices rose smartly yesterday, propelled by indications that the dollar - and interest rates - will probably have to fall further if America's trade deficit and the economy are to improve.

title: NASCIMENTO OF BRAZIL SINGS AT THE BEACON
description: Milton Nascimento, the Brazilian superstar who brought his band to the Beacon Theater Thursday and Friday, could carve out quite a career simply as one of the world's great pop voices.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL - CHICAGO (NL) - Purchased the contract of Dave Gumpert, a right-handed reliever from Iowa of the American Association; optioned right-hander Jay Baller to Iowa.

title: ROSTENKOWSKI OFFERS TO TRADE ON TAX RATE
description: Presenting the opening bargaining position of the House tax negotiators, Representative Dan Rostenkowski said today that he would agree to stick close to the Senate's top 27 percent rate if senators agreed to a bigger tax cut for the middle class and to higher corporate taxes.

title: LEGISLATION ON HOLDING OF CHECKS
description: A measure to reduce the length of time a bank may hold customers' checks without giving them access to the money is working its way through the Senate.

title: Two Legs vs. Two Wheels vs. Four Wheels: Debate Whirls On
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Court Limits Cathedral Protest
description: A Federal appeals court said yesterday that up to 25 members of a homosexual-rights group could demonstrate on the sidewalk in front of St. Patrick's Cathedral for 30 minutes during the annual Gay Pride Parade tomorrow.

title: Wetlands in Enemy Hands
description: Why did the Environmental Protection Agency recently have to rescue an embattled red maple swamp in Attleboro, Mass.? Because Robert Dawson, the new civilian head of the Army Corps of Engineers, seems to misunderstand the value of America's dwindling wetlands. A good case can be made for removing them from his jurisdiction.

title: M.T.A. DELAYS DECISION ON MERGING POLICE UNITS
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, apparently evenly divided over the Koch administration's proposal to merge the city and transit police forces, voted yesterday to defer action on the matter.

title: Teller System Talks Reported
description: The New York Cash Exchange, the regional automatic teller network known as NYCE, recently started talks with Honor, a statewide Florida teller network, to explore linking.

title: Historic Wharf Burns
description: A fire swept through the state's oldest working pier Thursday, damaging the Sea Center, a marine life complex that had been open less than a week, officials said.

title: Truth in Movies
description: ''Back to School'' has Rodney Dangerfield and a PG-13 rating, which means the movie house will let kiddies in though parents are ''strongly cautioned'' that some of the show ''may be inappropriate'' for people under the age of 13.

title: U.S. Judge Rejects Bid To Free Gotti Associate
description: A Federal judge ordered yesterday that Angelo Ruggiero, identified by authorities as an associate of John Gotti, remain in jail until a decision on his bail was reached.

title: FARM TRADE DEFICIT A RECORD IN MAY
description: In a stark demonstration of the weakness in American agriculture, the Commerce Department reported today that the nation imported more farm products in May than it exported.

title: U.S. MEDICAL ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Congressional Medals Urged for Immigrants
description: A coalition of ethnic groups that have criticized the selection process for the 12 Liberty medals to be awarded on Liberty Weekend said yesterday that Congress would be asked to authorize a new series of medals to recognize the contributions of a wider range of immigrants.

title: Job-Growth Rate Under Reagan Is Down
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE ROAD TO ANYWHERE BUT EUROPE
description: What it comes down to, Francine Florio said, is that her husband would rather face up to international terrorism than go to the Poconos.

title: REAGAN IS LIKELY TO USE NEW FUND TO AID PENTAGON
description: The Administration's budget director said today that President Reagan is likely to employ an unusual mechanism in Congress's new 1987 budget that would allow him to request increased spending for the Pentagon.

title: Your Money; Upbeat Signs For Gold Coins
description: FOR bullion coin collectors and investors, 1986 is a period of significant developments that could reignite the gold market. Among them, the United States will mint its first such general-circulation coins since 1933, while Australia and Japan also plan to produce new bullion coins. In addition, it is the first full year since Washington banned the importation of Krugerrands from South Africa.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Kevin Thomas Cahill Wed To Donna Marie Flotteron
description: Donna Marie Flotteron and Kevin Thomas Cahill were married by the Rev. Richard H. Reder yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. James J. Flotteron of Brooklyn and Mr. and Mrs. John T. Cahill of Hampton, N.J.

title:
Patents;
Oral Administration Of Hormones Improved
description: A more effective oral administration of sex hormones that have reduced toxicity and are synthetically produced by chemical methods was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services. Patent 4,596,795 was granted Dr. Josef Pitha, chief of a section in the National Institute on Aging, in Baltimore.

title: A LOSING PROPOSITION
description: When a ballplayer goes 5 for 6 at the plate, he has had a great day. When a horseplayer goes 5 for 6 at a New York race track, he goes home angry, frustrated and poorer. For that, horseplayers can thank the Byzantine way that gambling is legislated in the state of New York.

title: MARADONA MUST OVERCOME COVERAGE
description: Argentina will try to counter West Germany's physical power with quick midfield passes and a constant attack ''so that they can't catch their breath,'' Carlos Bilardo said today as his team prepared for the World Cup final Sunday.

title:
Patents;
Measuring Reactions Of Solids With Gases
description: An accurate analytical technique applicable to such projects as finding better ways to burn coal and prevent acid rain is the subject of patent 4,596,470, granted this week to Jin Y. Park, a chemical engineer and professor at the University of Idaho.

title: CLINICAL DATA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. Says Biaggi Is Inquiry Target
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they were seeking to obtain personal records from Representative Mario Biaggi because he was ''the target'' of a grand jury investigation into possible corruption and obstruction of justice.

title: CLEMENS RAISES MARK TO 14-0
description: Unbeaten Roger Clemens won his 14th game tonight, allowing seven hits and striking out 11 batters while pitching eight full innings, as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 5-3.

title: U.S COURT HALTS WHITWORTH TRIAL
description: A panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit halted proceedings in the espionage and tax fraud trial of Jerry A. Whitworth today at the request of the Government. Three days of closing arguments, culminating in a day of instructions to the jury, were to have begun Monday.

title: VWR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FAMILIAR SITE FOR INDY ROOKIES
description: If there ever existed such a thing as a home-field advantage in a competition of single-seat, multi winged, open-cockpit, turbopowered automobiles, the favorite for tomorrow's Chase Grand Prix would be as obvious as white block letters on the black side of a race car.

title: ... and a Bit of Refreshment
description: All that reading and listening made spectators at the Readathon thirsty.

title: MR. FRANK AND MS. VOLTAGE: 80's CATSKILLS TUMMLERS
description: It is lunchtime at the Raleigh Hotel here, and Barry Frank is working the dining room. ''How are you, darling?'' he asks a woman who just took his dance class. ''You did a wonderful chicken.''

title: ARMY'S ANTITERRORIST SQUAD TO BE IN CITY, OFFICIALS SAY
description: Soldiers from the Army's counterterrorist group, the Delta Force, will be deployed in New York City, ready to assist the police during the Fourth of July celebration, Administration officials said today.

title: Two Legs vs. Two Wheels vs. Four Wheels: Debate Whirls On
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonner Reports Decline In Her Health and Mood
description: Yelena G. Bonner told her son yesterday that her health took a turn for the worse after her return to the Soviet Union earlier this month and she became ''extremely depressed,'' although she has experienced some improvement in ''the last couple of days.''

title: DOUGLASS LEADS EVENT BY 3
description: Winds came up and took scores up with them in the second round of the seventh United States Senior Open championship today. As a result, it wasn't too hard for Dale Douglass to increase his lead with a one-over-par 72 on the Scioto Country Club course that is very difficult even on a calm day.

title: WESTERN EUROPEANS DECIDE TO DEFER PRETORIA SANCTIONS
description: European leaders agreed today on new political tactics to try to end South Africa's system of racial segregation. But they remained deeply divided on imposing economic sanctions.

title: UNIONISTS SCORN BILLER FOR PRAISE OF PRESSER
description: It was intended as a gesture of labor solidarity, says Moe Biller, president of the American Postal Workers union.

title: Interest in Carlton?
description: General Manager Bill Bergesch of Cincinnati says the Reds probably won't pursue Steve Carlton. Bergesch said he has talked briefly to Carlton's agent and with Reds scouts about the left-hander, who was released by the Phillies and won't clear waivers and gain his release until Tuesday. . . . John Candelaria turned in a strong performance Thursday night in his first appearance since April 17 arthroscopic surgery that removed bone-spur fragments and scar tissue from his left elbow.

title: AFTER 29 FLAMBOYANT YEARS, THE MAYOR OF MONTREAL IS RETIRING
description: Jean Drapeau, Mayor of Montreal for 29 of the last 32 years, said today that he would retire in November when his current term expires.

title: Georgia Killer Gets Reprieve
description: A condemned prisoner who has been on death row for nearly 10 years was granted a reprieve today, 11 hours before he was to die in the electric chair for killing a Georgia police chief.

title: LOVE STORY: FROM THAILAND CAMP TO MASSACHUSETTS WEDDING
description: The last-minute rush is under way for the wedding on Saturday. ''It's going to be close,'' worried the foster mother of the bride, biting her lip.

title: OF BEARS AND BLACKTOP: A MATTER OF TERRITORY
description: The view from Interstate 80 at Route 23 is of the sprawling Willowbrook Mall and whizzing cars, of gasoline stations and fast-food stops, of office buildings and overhead traffic signs.

title: MAYOTTE NEARS QUARTERFINAL WITH LENDL
description: Both live by the athlete's credo that it is unwise and in poor taste to look past the next round. But given these past few unseasonably clear days and the rapid disappearance of the seeded players in the top half of the men's draw, Ivan Lendl and Tim Mayotte cannot help but see each other waiting across the net in the Wimbledon quarterfinals, which is at least one aspect of this tournament adhering to form.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ISAMBA! - Carnival, the big Brazilian summer bash that splashes Rio de Janeiro in sound and color, occurs when it's winter in New York. Now that it's summer here, our local samba practitioners are today staging the first Annual Brazilian Summer Carnival Parade and Ball in the Lower East and West Side streets of Gotham, with the motif, of course, taking its cue from the Statue of Liberty.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, JUNE 28, 1986
description: International The Reagan Administration broke international law and violated Nicaraguan sovereignty by aiding the anti-Government rebels, the International Court of Justice ruled at a session in The Hague. The court, the judicial arm of the United Nations, ordered Washington to halt the''arming and training'' of the insurgents and to pay Nicaragua for damages caused by military attacks. [ Page 1, Column 2. ] The State Department rejected the World Court's finding that United States policy toward Nicaragua violated international law and denounced the court as an inappropriate body to judge complex international military issues. A department spokesman said the court's full opinion had not been received and therefore the American reaction would be only a preliminary one. [ 4:1. ] The Irish turned down, by more than a 3-to-2 margin, a measure to end the ban on divorce. The defeat in a referendum on a constitutional amendment proposed by Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald was seen as a severe blow to the coalition led by Mr. FitzGerald, who led the fight to end the Irish Republic's standing as the only Western European nation without legal divorce. [ 1:4. ] Italy's Prime Minister stepped down, bringing an end to the country's longest-lasting postwar Goverment. Former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, a Socialist, had held office since August 1983. He was forced to resign after his Government lost a secret-ballot vote on a local finance bill. [ 3:4. ] Suspension of the Anzus treaty between the United States and New Zealand was announced by the State Department after Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Prime Minister David Lange failed to mend their rift over nuclear policy. Mr. Shultz said the move was taken because Washington regarded New Zealand's insistence on banning visits by nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered ships as a repudiation of its obligations under the 35-year-old treaty, in which the United States promised to defend New Zealand.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PLACES CURFEW ON 11 MORE TOWNSHIPS
description: The Government announced today that curfews would be imposed in 11 more magisterial districts in the Orange Free State, bringing to at least 600,000 the number of South African blacks living under such formal restrictions.

title: GTE Merger Set
description: The Justice Department said it would approve a proposed merger of long-distance telephone operations and data communications services of the GTE Corporation and United Telecommunications Inc. On Jan. 16, GTE and United Telecommunications announced that they had agreed to form a partnership called US Sprint, consisting of their long-distance telephone units, GTE Sprint and US Telecom, and their data communications subsidiaries.

title: THE JAM AT MORTGAGE WINDOW
description: Douglas Hackett, a systems analyst, agreed to buy a house in Potomac, Md., in the last week of April and immediately applied for a $133,000 mortgage.

title: FRUEHAUF STOCK TOPS MERRILL'S OFFER
description: Investors led by Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday began their friendly buyout bid for the Fruehauf Corporation for $48.50 a share. But Fruehauf's stock price rose as high as $49.625, suggesting that investors expected a competing bid from Asher B. Edelman to push the price upward.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Armco Inc., Morristown, N.J., said its board had adopted a shareholder rights plan to deter hostile takeover bids.

title: BINGHAM CLEARED IN 1971 SHOOTOUT
description: Stephen M. Bingham, a Yale-educated lawyer who spent 13 years as a fugitive, was found not guilty today of murder and conspiracy charges stemming from a 1971 shootout at San Quentin prison that left six people dead.

title: JOHN HOWARD LAERI
description: John Howard Laeri, a former vice chairman and director of the First National City Corporation, now Citicorp, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Girl, 8, Thrown 31 Floors to Death
description: An 8-year-old girl was thrown to her death from a 31st-floor balcony in Harlem yesterday during a dispute with her uncle, the police said.

title: St. John's Is Aiding Inquiry by N.C.A.A.
description: Jack Kaiser, the St. John's University athletic director, said yesterday that he had written to the National Collegiate Athletic Association giving details of apparent rules violations involving air-to-ground telephone calls by two Redmen basketball players.

title: SLOW-STARTING JAYS FIND CONSISTENCY
description: The afternoon was warm and sticky when Jimy Williams emerged from behind the batting cage at Yankee Stadium and began hitting a succession of ground balls toward third base. He spoke of consistency as he worked, which seemed an appropriate subject at the time, his emphasis on the word striking hard each time he drove balls into the grass with his fungo bat.

title:
CURBING THE SUPPLY OF PHYSICIANS;
THE MORE THERE ARE, THE MORE WE PAY
description: EARLIER this month a special committee of the American Medical Association reported that the nation was facing a ''glut'' of physicians. The trustees warned that the ''impending surplus'' is likely to have negative consequences ''for the quality and cost of patient care.'' They called for cutbacks in medical school enrollment and limits on the number of foreign physicians entering the country.

title: Ruth Reiter, Executive, Wed to Paul M. Brown
description: Ruth S. Reiter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Shneider of Munster, Ind., was married yesterday to Paul M. Brown, a son of Rose L. Brown of New York and the late Irving H. Brown. The ceremony, at the Center for Inter-American Relations in New York, was performed by Judge Peter K. Leisure of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Delays Beset 255-Unit Modular Project in Brownsville
description: WHILE city officials mold a bold $4.2 billion plan for providing 252,000 affordable housing units over the next decade, 255 families are waiting to occupy houses they bought last year in New Horizons Village, a city-sponsored development in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: Elizabeth Ann Kuphal Becomes Bride
description: Elizabeth Ann Kuphal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Eugene Kuphal of Sun City, Ariz., and Edina, Minn., was married yesterday to Edward Lisk Wyckoff Jr., the son of Mrs. Wyckoff and the late Mr. Wyckoff of Middletown, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Roger R. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Christ Presbyterian Church in Edina.

title: PORTRAIT OF PRINCETON IN BLACK AND WHITE
description: AN IMPOSING pile with a polished brown-black granite facade and windows of smoked glass, United Jersey Banks' Princeton headquarters is beginning to settle into its surroundings at Carnegie Center on Route 1.

title: YUGOSLAV PARTY REJUVENATES ITS LEADERSHIP
description: The Yugoslav Communist Party wound up a national convention today by electing a rejuvenated Central Committee, in which 127 out of 165 members are new.

title: Soccer Among Diplomats
description: Of the 2 billion people expected to watch Sunday's World Cup soccer final between Argentina and West Germany, some of the most interested are in Washington: those nations' diplomats.

title: Iran Reportedly Hits 2 Ships Anchored in Port
description: Iranian aircraft hit two oil tankers with missiles today while they were anchored in United Arab Emirates waters, shipping sources said.

title: IN JERUSALEM, GIFTS WITH TRADITION
description: Any visitor to Jerusalem will want to spend some time poking around in the tiny, dark shops that line the narrow and even darker alleyways of the Old City, but only the most intrepid will be able to face the fevered bargaining required to shop there. Most will eventually buy something they do not much want, at an undoubtedly inflated price, and either slink off or simply bolt, depending on individual temperament.

title: 39 FIREWORKS SHOWS SET
description: A RUSH of last-minute applications to put on fireworks shows will give residents in many parts of Connecticut an opportunity to have a traditional celebration of the Fourth of July.

title: PRETORIA REPORTED TO DETAIN 2 TOP BLACK LABOR LEADERS
description: Reports reached here yesterday of arrests of two more South African labor leaders under the nation's state of emergency, but one of the reports could not be directly confirmed.

title: Janis Devereux Marries George Lloyd
description: The marriage of Janis Ann Devereux, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rickert Devereux of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., to George Wingate Lloyd, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wingate Lloyd of Washington, took place yesterday in Cotuit, Mass.

title: Marilyn Jacobs Marries
description: The marriage of Marilyn S. Jacobs, an associate television director for NBC News, to Thomas J. Furey, a news producer for the NBC ''Today'' show, took place yesterday at the Windows on the World restaurant in New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: AUTO RACING CHASE GRAND PRIX, at the Meadowlands, 1:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 4:30 P.M., tape delay).

title: THE CONSCIENCE OF A GREEN BERET
description: THE EMBASSY HOUSE By Nicholas Proffitt. 399 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $16.95.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE grass is always supposed to be greener somewhere else. That old saw is now undergoing a severe test. After a spate of what might be called ''Long Island Rail Road Horror Shows,'' I have decided to try driving into Manhattan for awhile.

title:
ART;
'AMERICAN ICONS' ON VIEW IN GREENWICH
description: A DELUXE Fourth of July like this one deserves a deluxe art exhibition to go with it. It is hard to imagine anything that is more in the contemporary American grain than ''American Icons'' at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through Aug. 29.

title: Leslie Stansfield Married
description: Leslie Sue Stansfield, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Stansfield of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married there yesterday to Jonathan William Holasek, the son of Joan Holasek of St. Petersburg, Fla., and the late William J. Holasek of Cleveland. The Rev. Randolph Roome performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church. Mrs. Holasek is a vice president of Independent Media Services, an advertising concern in Manhattan. Mr. Holasek is an account executive for Biederman & Company, an advertising agency in Manhattan.

title: FRANCE CELEBRATES MLLE. LIBERTE
description: This summer and fall, France also remembers the favorite daughter it sent the New World a century ago in token of a shared ideal. Exhibitions, concerts and celebrations of every kind are planned in Paris and elsewhere to mark the centenary of the Statue of Liberty.

title: LIBERTY AND AUTHORITY
description: In rededicating the 100-year-old Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor, it may be useful to reflect on what has happened to liberty in the world during the 20th century, and to define the meaning of the old monument.

title: RED SOX VICTORY INCREASES LEAD TO 7
description: Ed Romero drove in three runs and Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd won his 10th game today as the first-place Boston Red Sox defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 7-3.

title: MISSING IN ACTION - ADULT ROMANCE
description: It was news the other day when Matthew Broderick told a reporter that he'd played his last teen-ager (a high-school senior) in John Hughes's new comedy, ''Ferris Bueller's Day Off.'' Though Mr. Broderick turned 24 last March and could - without straining the imagination - take on a comparatively ''mature'' role as a young poet, businessman, banker, theoretical mathematician or psychotic bum, he isn't going to find it easy making the leap out of his screen teens.

title: 15 MONKEYS CAUSE A STIR
description: Several members of Congress have protested the National Institutes of Health action in moving 15 monkeys used in medical experiments to a research facility in New Orleans.

title: ARMED FOR ANYTHING, MARIETTA PROSPERS
description: MILITARY stocks may have lost much of their luster, now that Congress plans to cut Pentagon spending. But the Martin Marietta Corporation, a major arms contractor with $4.4 billion in total sales last year, remains high on the ''buy'' lists of many analysts.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MARKSMAN. By Sergey Yuryenen. Translated by Roger and Angela Keys. (Quartet/Salem House, $14.95.) The plot of Sergey Yuryenen's novel is sturdy and simple.

title: Leigh Armstrong Wed To David H. Hovey Jr.
description: At the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford yesterday Leigh Kenaston Armstrong, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Armstrong of Bloomfield, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., was married to David Huntington Hovey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hovey of Simsbury, Conn., and Chatham. The Rev. James D. Kidd performed the ceremony.

title: CONCERT: GOLDMAN BAND IN LINCOLN CENTER PARK
description: THE venerable Goldman Memorial Band has survived some financial crises in recent years, but every June its members and their conductor Ainslee Cox reappear, healthy and happy, for a round of summer concerts in Manhattan and Brooklyn. There will be 30 such evenings this summer, the band's 69th; the first performance was given Wednesday night in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center.

title: A PLACE FOR SPECIAL OCCASIONS
description: ''WHAT was this place called before?'' we asked the waiter at Ondine, just outside Danbury. ''Which time?'' he said with a smile, reeling off a list of previous inhabitants of the space. One name struck, and we recalled a particularly unhappy dining experience.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AN ENGLISHWOMAN IN INDIA: The Memoirs of Harriet Tytler, 1828-1858. Edited by Anthony Sattin. (Oxford University, $18.95.) The author of these memoirs wrote them some 40 years after the event they principally describe - the siege of Delhi during the Indian Mutiny of 1857-58.

title: SARATOGA SPRINGS
description: With the medicinal value of its springs discounted, its gambling casinos closed and its grandest hotels demolished, Saratoga Springs lay somnolent for a time beneath its elm trees. Only the Thoroughbred racing season each August continued as a reminder of its glory days, when society figures would pack Saratoga trunks and descend upon the small town in the foothills of the Adirondacks.

title: SEARCHING FOR THE 'THEORY OF EVERYTHING'
description: THE SECOND CREATION Makers of the Revolution in Twentieth-Century Physics. By Robert P. Crease and Charles C. Mann. 480 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $25.

title: OPERA: AMRAM-PAPP VERSION OF 'TWELFTH NIGHT'
description: THE opera composer who turns to Shakespeare has two options - either to make the music serve the words or else to create the kind of musical metaphor that indirectly reflects his original.

title: Developers Are Rediscovering Yonkers
description: ALONG its western boundary on the Hudson River, Yonkers is a fairly poor and rundown industrial community. But as it climbs the ridges of Westchester County, New York State's fourth largest city becomes increasingly rich, residential and polished.

title: BROKERAGE FIRM FACES CHARGES
description: For two years, Federal and city prosecutors listened closely to certain advice being dispensed at the Phliadelphia office of Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Last week they indicted some who gave it and some who took it, charging the lot of them, including the big brokerage house itself, with illegally laundering at least $1.2 million in profits from organized crime.

title: 'Ghosts'
description: Those of us who have an insatiable passion for mystery novels know that this appetite has very little to do with the love of literature in general.

title:
MUSIC VIEW;
JUST IMAGINE IF MOZART HAD STUCK TO THE VIOLIN
description: As an instrument of violent social change, the violin is not the first device that comes to mind. And yet, with the summertime ritual known as Mostly Mozart only a couple of weeks away, this may be as good a time as any to fiddle with that seemingly incongruous idea. In most history books, the storming of the Bastille on July 14, 1789, is picked out as the event that symbolizes the collapse of Europe's ancien regime, the beginning of the end for a privilege-encrusted society sharply divided between aristocratic masters and humble servants. However, eight years earlier a similarly symbolic act took place almost unnoticed in the provincial Austrian town of Salzburg. On May 9, 1781, a defiant servant and reluctant violinist named Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart gave up the instrument forever and left the employ of the Prince-Archbishop Hieronymus, Count of Colloredo.

title: STATE HONORS TWO COUNTY EXPORTERS
description: ON two vastly different fronts, a couple of Westchester companies engage in warfare every day, producing products used worldwide in fighting against terrorism and disease. One, Loral International Inc. of Yonkers, develops and manufactures ultrasophisticated electronics defense systems for ''friendly nation'' customers. The primary business of the other, Life Resources Inc. of Mount Kisco, is the collection and sale of human blood plasma and plasma derivatives used by the pharmaceutical industry overseas.

title: JUDGE IN LOS ANGELES LOSES POST IN DISPUTE OVER HER CONDUCT
description: The judges of the Los Angeles Municipal Court have voted overwhelmingly to remove the presiding judge in a dispute over judicial conduct. But she has refused to step down.

title: Carol Landorf Is a Bride
description: Carol Ann Landorf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd Landorf of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas Frank Lowell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lowell of Mount Kisco, N.Y. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y. The bride is a sales executive for Maxima Leathers, a women's sportswear manufacturer in New York. Mr. Lowell is a stockbroker for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in White Plains.

title: TEXANS FIGHT FOR THEIR LAND AND WAY OF LIFE
description: In one sense, the vast, flat panhandle of Texas might seem the ideal place to bury the nation's growing pile of nuclear refuse. The ancient salt beds half a mile below Deaf Smith County have been stable for 300 million years and might seem splendid for safely embracing the deadly waste for the next 300 human generations.

title: AMERICAN MUSIC FROM BROADWAY TO RIO IS SHOWCASED
description: In 1980, the first 10 releases of the Organization of American States'

title: SPORT IS A POINT OF CONTACT FOR A SHRINKING WORLD
description: THIS weekend marks the final of the month-long Mundial, the World Cup of football (soccer for us) and the midpoint of annual rites at Wimbledon. We have just recovered from the drama of the French Open. We wait, but admittedly without much interest, to see if Ted Turner can hire enough athletes to make gold (for himself and the Soviet Union) out of the lead of this summer's Goodwill Games. We are halfway between the charming simplicity of the Sarajevo Winter Olympics and the ''can-do'' Calgary Games of 1988; between the heady success of Ueberroth's Los Angeles Games and the first-ever games for a third world country in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Susan McNear Wed to Charles McNiff
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday Susan Walker McNear, a daughter of Suzanne McNear of New York and the late Robert Erskine McNear of San Francisco, was married to Charles Slowey McNiff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur McNiff of Peabody, Mass. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. James McNiff, a Roman Catholic priest who is the bridegroom's uncle.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A DOLPHIN SUMMER. By Gerard Gormley. (Taplinger, $14.95.) Fifteen years ago the author, a marketing consultant, was cruising off Gloucester, Mass., when he found himself in the midst of 15 finback whales who lolled and played alongside his boat for the next seven hours.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: BARRIER ISLAND. By John D. MacDonald. (Knopf, $16.95.) John D. MacDonald's latest novel features dozens of characters, an ever-thickening plot, a modicum of sex and violence and a narrative propelled mostly by dialogue, which bears Mr. MacDonald's lively, gritty stamp.

title: EX-AIDE TO ARAFAT, NOW A FOE, SAYS P.L.O. HAS A FORTUNE IN BANKS
description: A former aide who now opposes Yasir Arafat, responding to reports abroad that the Palestine Liberation Organization is going bankrupt, was quoted this week as saying the P.L.O. has amassed a fortune in bank accounts in Lebanon, Jordan and Switzerland.

title:
GARDENING;
IT'S NOT TOO LATE TO SOW MORE SEEDS
description: ABOUT this time of year voids in the garden become noticeable. Early plantings of lettuce, radishes and peas have been harvested, leaving behind an empty space, or openings appear here and there in the flower gardens where either early bloomers such as pansies have begun to fade or something counted upon to fill the space has failed.

title: Clothing Dispute With Coca-Cola
description: COCA-COLA clothes were being advertised by some retail outlets as ''All-American.'' But the advertised items, some American textile manufacturers complained, were being made in Hong Kong and Macao.

title: COURTS RARELY THROW THE BOOK AT LAWYERS
description: FOR Roy M. Cohn, a one-man institution among New York power brokers and politicians for more than 30 years, the lesser varieties of legal discipline were deemed insufficient. And so Mr. Cohn, disbarred by a unanimous panel of judges in Manhattan last week, joins a very small group.

title: State Judge's Order Prevents Hiring of Sanitation Workers
description: The Uniform Santitationmen's Association has won a temporary restraining order in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, preventing the city from hiring anyone who passed the most recent test for sanitation workers.

title: GREENBRUGH WEIGHS LARGER RESIDENTIAL ZONE
description: THE town of Greenburgh is considering an about-face in development: after 30 years of encouraging commercial growth, it may rezone two-thirds of its remaining commercially zoned land for residential use, largely for town houses.

title: IN PUNJAB, THE YOUNG ARE PARTICULARLY RESTLESS
description: ACTS of violence by Sikhs in Punjab have tormented India since the beginning of the decade.

title: METS TOP CUBS; 3-RUN NINTH PROVES DECISIVE
description: The Mets, who have been struggling a bit lately, scored three runs in the ninth inning today and beat the Chicago Cubs, 5-2. And they did it in style by getting the key hits off Lee Smith, who had stopped them cold by striking out three heavy hitters in a similar jam one week ago.

title: A GLIMMER OF HOPE ON AIDS
description: As they gathered in Paris last week, scientists fighting AIDS heard an isolated but encouraging item of news: One victim, the first among thousands, has made an apparent recovery.

title: BEYOND POCAHONTAS
description: THE COMPLETE WORKS OF CAPTAIN JOHN SMITH (1580-1631). In Three Volumes. Volume One, 448 pp. Volume Two, 488 pp. Volume Three, 513 pp. Edited by Philip L. Barbour. Illustrated. Chapel Hill: The Institute of Early American History and Culture/ The University of North Carolina Press. $150.

title: Elizabeth Rader, Media Planner, Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Sperry Rader, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Donald Rader of Greenwich, Conn., to Kevin Kenway Edwards, a son of Mrs. A. Porter Waterman of Naples, Fla., and the late Duncan Edwards Jr., took place yesterday in Greenwich. The Rev. Richard H. Stearns performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: CHARTING THE SUPREME COURT'S CONSERVATIVE DRIFT
description: To the Editor:

title: A HOMESPUN SYMBOL OF THE MEANING OF FREEDOM
description: AS FRENCHMAN by birth and American by choice, I have deep feelings about the Fourth of July and the ideals of liberty and democracy that it represents.

title: Equality Means That Men, Too, Are Responsible for Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Burger in School Position
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, who is retiring from the Supreme Court, has been elected chancellor of the College of William and Mary, school officials said Friday. Chief Justice Burger, 78 years old, will be William and Mary's 20th chancellor. The position, which has been vacant since 1974, is largely ceremonial.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 150 YEARS OF BLACK ART - One of the dual exhibitions that is to open Friday at the Wadsworth Atheneum focuses in part on black art from 1800 to 1950 and will be on view through August. The other exhibition is a collection of artifacts documenting the black experience in America from the earliest days of slavery through the civil rights movement of the 60's that will be on display through next February. This will be the only New England stop for the show, which is on a two-year tour of the United States. The United Negro College Fund will receive $1 from every paid admission to see the exhibitions this summer.

title: CENTER IN QUEENS OFFERS SERVICES CLOSE TO HOME
description: For many women who flock there daily, the sprawling new brick building in South Jamaica, Queens, means quicker and cheaper access to a nutrition program for pregnant women and mothers of small children.

title: Texans Barring Students From France as Guests
description: Texans angered because France refused to allow United States warplanes to fly over France to bomb Libya in April are refusing to be hosts to French exchange students.

title: Lara E. Young, a Model, Marries W. C. Garrett Jr.
description: Lara Elizabeth Young, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Young of Millington, N.J., was married yesterday to William C. Garrett Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Garrett of Chagrin Falls, Ohio.

title: Article 553986 -- No Title
description: NICARAGUAN guerrilla leaders have big plans for the $100 million the House approved last week. Once the money is also approved by the Senate, as is generally expected in Washington, the rebels say they intend to spend it on weapons and training. The guerrillas, whose bases lie near the Nicaraguan border about 140 miles from here, emphasize that the two items they would like to receive as soon as possible are surface-to-air missiles and ammunition.

title: Dr. V. Carney Hargrove, 85; President of Baptist Body
description: The Rev. Dr. V. Carney Hargroves, a former president of the American Baptist Convention and of the Baptist World Alliance, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Foulkeways, a Quaker Retirement Community in Gwynedd, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title:
IN NEW JERSEY;
COmmercial Futures for Two Landmarks
description: OVER the last century, many of the state's historic buildings have been converted into museums or maintained as private homes, often occupied by descendants of the original tenants. Others have been left vacant, ravaged by age and nature, because public funds to preserve them have decreased in recent years.

title: BILLY HART AND FRIENDS
description: THE continuing infusion of African influences into jazz and rock has helped to bring harder and more complex rhythms closer to the centers of both worlds. At St. Peter's Church on Friday evening, two young jazz ensembles - Billy Hart and Friends and the Rochester-Veasley Band -both of whom record for the small independent label Gramavision, offered jazz that was prominently drum-oriented.
