title: HOSPITALS SELECTED IN HEART STUDY
description: SIX area hospitals have been selected by the National Institutes of Health to participate in a major two-year study on the treatment of heart attacks that is expected to help extend life expectancy. The study has been designed to determine treatment protocol that follows the immediate use of a clot-dissolving enzyme used at the time of the attack.

title: SANDINISTA CELEBRATION TAKES AIM AT THE U.S.
description: On Friday night, a day after the Sandinista Government shut the opposition newspaper La Prensa and announced it would no longer tolerate critics who act as ''spokesmen for imperialism,'' thousands of young Government supporters gathered to cheer President Daniel Ortega Saavedra.

title: TRAVELS WITH A DANGEROUS WOMAN
description: KATE VAIDEN By Reynolds Price. 306 pp. New York: Atheneum. $16.95.

title: TAKING ON DRUGS IN BOSTON STREETS
description: The landlord shut down Roye's Variety grocery this week, but not for the usual tenant transgressions, according to the landlord's attorney, Robert Levite.

title: LEARNING TO LIVE WITH THE TWINS
description: FOR Amy Haas of Merrick, whose mother is a twin, it was ''always a family joke'' which of her siblings would have twins, she recalled.

title: Miss Clark Weds George Dilworth
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday Sarah Houston Clark was married to George Thayer Dilworth. The Rev. John Smith, chaplain of the Groton School, of which the couple are graduates, performed the ceremony.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: All in the Spirit Of Brotherhood - Brotherhood Winery opened in 1839 and has been continuously operated in Orange County about 40 miles north and west of the Tappan Zee Bridge in Washingtonville, N.Y., and west of West Point. The individual tour and wine tasting costs $2.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency has proposed stricter standards for sulfur dioxide emissions from industrial boilers, a move designed to address the problem of acid rain.

title: THE KING SEEKS CROWNING GLORY
description: ONE Mexican newspaper found the headline that said it all after Argentina's quarterfinal victory over England in the World Cup soccer championship here last weekend: ''Maradona 2, England 1.''

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: GONE FROM THE SHELVES
description: Tomorrow is not just another day for those who do give a damn about Scarlett O'Hara, et al. Monday marks the 50th anniversary of the publication of ''Gone With the Wind'' by Margaret Mitchell, an event that was celebrated last week with costume pageants in Atlanta and the happy calculation of profits in New York. There, publishers of Miss Mitchell's Old South romance watched the novel rise again on the bestseller lists.

title: Shahrastani Gains Double
description: Shahrastani completed the England-Ireland racing double today, winning the $410,700 Irish Derby by eight lengths over Bonhomie at the Curragh. In giving the trainer Michael

title: TV TACTICS: BACKSTAGE WITH THE DUVALIERS
description: I think I'm feeling a little uneasy about Michelle and Jean-Claude Duvalier. Not that the former so-called ''President for Life'' of Haiti and his exotic wife are pussycats who need protection, but because they are the last of a dying breed - those current or former heads of state who do not understand how to use television.

title: NO NEWSPAPER IS BAD NEWS TO CROTON RESIDENTS
description: THE Croton-Cortlandt News was not a perfect newspaper; it had its share of shortcomings and problems over its 98-year history. And The Patent Trader, which acquired The Croton-Cortlandt News in 1984 and closed it last year, was not considered perfect either, as its reporters were unfamiliar with the village. But, residents note ruefully, either was better than none.

title: MOVIES GO BACK FOR THEIR FUTURE
description: David Brown, the Hollywood producer, calls it ''Shintoism - ancestor worship.'' Sydney Pollack, the Academy

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GIRLS FOREVER BRAVE AND TRUE. By Caryl Rivers. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) In the seemingly endless parade of best-selling heroines who are unrealistically beautiful, wealthy and humorless about having it all - what a pleasure to run into funny, warm, often confused Peg Morrison and Constance Masters, the two best friends Caryl Rivers created in ''Virgins,'' set in the 1950's.

title: A CELEBRATION IN DEFENSE OF LISZT
description: Franz Liszt might seem securely enthroned in the pantheon of great composers, but his dearest defenders think otherwise. Leading Liszt scholars and performers feel their man has been grievously misunderstood: public attention then (in the 1830's and 40's) and now focused unfairly on his flamboyant virtuosity and charismatic showmanship at the expense of his serious side as a composer, conductor, teacher and man of God. ''Perhaps no person in musical history has been so widely misunderstood,'' announced the pianist Jerome Rose in his ''statement of purpose'' for his own Liszt Centennial Celebration this week in Washington.

title: WILL CRAXI GET ANOTHER ENCORE?
description: Bettino Craxi has been Prime Minister of Italy for nearly three years, an achievement that evidently had become annoying for dozens of members of Parliament who were outwardly loyal to his multiparty coalition. In secret balloting last week on an obscure local finance law, Mr. Craxi's Government was defeated, 293 to 255, with the help of an estimated 70 to 80 defectors. Mr. Craxi resigned and President Franceso Cossiga appointed him to head a caretaker Government until a new team can be assembled or national elections held.

title: Steuben Glass
description: To the Editor: Michael Kammen's fascinating article on the Corning Glass Center (Travel, May 18) reminded me of one of my most embarrassing gaffes.

title: TEAM'S SEARCH GOES ON FOR KILLERS OF CASTELLANO
description: Every workday morning, a group of New York City detectives and F.B.I. agents squeezes into a small, cluttered office on East 51st Street with one thought in mind: tracking down the killers of Paul Castellano.

title: Miss Taylor Weds Anthony Gorham
description: At St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa., yesterday Laura Young Taylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anson W. H. Taylor Jr. of Berwyn, Pa., was married to Anthony Masters McIntire Gorham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Gorham of Pembroke, Bermuda. The Rev. Stephen K. Jacobson performed the ceremony.

title: REAGAN AND THE CONTRAS WIN A ROUND IN THE HOUSE
description: THE Nicaraguan rebels had supporters to spare but few believers in the House of Representatives last week. It was striking, as the House voted 221 to 209 to send the rebels $100 million for their effort to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government, how many of those voting in favor nonetheless expressed deep misgivings about the worthiness of the rebels, also known as contras, and their ability to accomplish their goal.

title: SECT'S WAY OF TEACHING FACES CHILD-LABOR LAWS
description: The six boys, their faces reddened in the sweltering midmorning sun and dusty from the arid construction site, are intent on their work.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HOUSE MOTHER NORMAL: A Geriatric Comedy. By B. S. Johnson. (New Directions, Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $7.95.) The British writer B. S. Johnson created a large and formidable body of work before his suicide in 1973, including six novels, two collections of poetry, as well as drama and essays.

title: Visit Evokes Memories Of Storm 42 Years Ago
description: ''It was a gigantic task force and I can remember, the day of the landing, looking out over the horizon and there were ships as far as you could see,'' George P. Shultz said the other day as he reminisced about returning here for the first time in 42 years.

title: Miss Hughes Has Wedding
description: Katherine C. Hughes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. P. Edward Hughes of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to John D. Halpern, the son of Helen Halpern of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Raymond O. Halpern. Msgr. Paul J. Schierse performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's on the Brandywine Roman Catholic Church.

title: Photography
description: Now that the solstice has passed, it is high season for the rite of summer known as the group show. These potpourris of diverse talents can be as lightweight as drive-in movies, but occasionally there are real finds.

title: A TEAM PLAYER TAKES ON THE DEBT TALKS
description: SHORTLY before flying to Washington last week for critical talks on Mexico's latest foreign debt crisis, Gustavo Petricioli went out of his way to tell reporters that he would be presenting his Government's position, not his own.

title: DELVING INTO THE PHOTOGRAPHER'S BAG OF TRICKS
description: PHOTOGRAPHY is an ultra-flexible art form, offering a great variety of possibilities. Light, color and images can be manipulated through the use of lenses, special films and various darkroom processes. Images can be transformed and reshaped. Color can be altered, made surreal or distilled into severe black and white.

title: SLICING THE DATA A NUMBER OF WAYS
description: A CATCHY phrase can make all the difference when it comes to selling software. ''Word processing,'' for instance, has a nice clear conceptual ring to it. So does ''electronic spreadsheet.'' Both terms combine a more familiar noun, ''word'' and ''spreadsheet,'' respectively -granted, ''spreadsheet'' may not be in everyone's lexicon, but it is familiar to number crunchers - with a jazzy appellation connoting futuristic power and speed, ''processing'' and ''electronic,'' respectively.

title: Panel Urges Renewal Of L.I.R.R. Pact Talks
description: A Presidential board has recommended that the Long Island Rail Road and its labor unions resume contract negotiations, and has called for wage increases through 1988, the White House has announced.

title:
GARDENING;
IT'S NOT TOO LATE TO SOW MORE SEEDS
description: ABOUT this time of year voids in the garden become noticeable. Early plantings of lettuce, radishes and peas have been harvested, leaving behind an empty space, or openings appear here and there in the flower gardens where either early bloomers such as pansies have begun to fade or something counted upon to fill the space has failed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, JUNE 29, 1986
description: International

title: HISTORIC BOAT SAILS AGAIN
description: WHEN the Little Jennie, a 102-year-old bugeye ketch, sails into New York Harbor for the Fourth of July celebrations this week, she will be fulfilling the dreams of a Long Island group that has worked for more than two years to restore the one-time commercial oystering vessel.

title: LOW WAGES FOSTER SHORTAGE OF LIFEGUARDS ALONG THE SOUND
description: PERCHED in her chair at Weed Beach in Darien in mid-June, Meg Walsh watched as a girl about 3 or 4 years old entered the water alone as her mother chatted with another woman some distance away.

title: STATUE AT 100: RADIANT SALUTE
description: SHORTLY after sundown on the Fourth, President Reagan will push a button on Governors Island and send a laser beam shooting across New York Harbor. The light show then begins, casting in silhouette the statue that has been called the most captivating structure erected anywhere in the world during the past hundred years.

title: LIFEGUARD SHORTAGE KEEPS POOLS DRY
description: The sign at the entrance to the Anthony Wayne Recreation Area in Harriman State Park says, ''Sorry, pool closed.'' But people in cars enter anyway, paying $2.50 just to park and picnic.

title: Serena Yoon Is Bride Of David Francis Sally
description: The marriage of Serena Hanee Yoon and David Francis Sally, graduates of Harvard College, took place yesterday in the Memorial Church on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. John E. MacInnis performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Milwaukee;
Tapping A Resource
description: SCHLITZ, ''the Beer That Made Milwaukee Famous,'' and Blatz, ''Milwaukee's Finest Beer,'' are no longer brewed here, but their abandoned downtown breweries are being brought back to life.

title: 3 in Sri Lanka Killed By Rebel Land Mine
description: Three people were killed today when a rebel land mine blasted a van in a security force convoy in eastern Sri Lanka, the National Security Ministry said.Ministry said.

title: PIXELS ARE RESHAPING POCKET TV'S
description: Those tiny television sets that slip into one's pocket have been around for a while now, but so far they haven't made much of a stir. The price was too high and the picture quality too low.

title: FRESH AIR CAMPERS VISIT A MODEL FARM
description: As a farmer at the Fresh Air Fund's model farm last summer, Tracy Ward said she learned as much about child psychology as about farming.

title: LIBERTY WEEKEND NEAR, WORKERS RUSH TO PUT FINAL DETAILS IN PLACE
description: Lady Liberty needs paint, sod and muscle. Operation Sail 1986 needs more berths and fewer flood tides. The Harbor Festival organizers would settle for some electrical cable.

title: Selling to the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET'S BRIGHT YOUNG STAR
description: LIKE EVERY OTHER BUSINESS IN MANHATTAN, the Algonquin Hotel on West 44th Street knew it had to come up with something special by way of celebration for the Statue of Liberty weekend. Boisterous expressions of patriotism seemed the wrong sort of thing for the worldly atmosphere of the place, so the hotel booked the young singer and pianist Michael Feinstein to entertain in the Oak Room from July 1 through the 5th. In a light, penetrating voice that throbs with nostalgia, Feinstein will sing vintage Broadway show tunes and other old songs appropriate to the occasion.

title: METS TOP CUBS; BREAK STADIUM LOSS MARK
description: In the 62 seasons they have played at Yankee Stadium, the Yankees have recorded an impressive list of historic achievements.

title: STORE SHIFTS EXPECTED TO HEAT UP COMPETITION
description: LONG ISLANDERS will see new names on some local department stores, and most likely lower prices and more brand names in their aisles, as major changes in retailing occur in the next few months, industry sources say.

title: NEW MANAGERS OFTEN PROVE TO BE FAMILIAR FACES
description: JIM FREGOSI, Dick Williams and Gene Michael, three managers who have been hired by major league clubs since the season began, know what it was like for the people they replaced to lose their jobs in-season. They themselves had been dismissed from managing jobs during the season - Fregosi by the California Angels in 1981, Williams by Boston in 1969, the Angels in '76 and Montreal in '81, and Michael by the Yankees in '81 and '82. Tony LaRussa may join that group in the next few days as a new manager hired in-season who previously had been dismissed in-season.

title: The Liberal Guardian
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Scarlett Carries On
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW TONE FOR AN OLD PORT
description: Two hundred years ago, King's Lynn was a thriving river port from which some of the world's greatest mariners set out to make their fortunes - Horatio Nelson, George Vancouver and Captain Cook are all said to have sailed from here. From the Middle Ages to the late 18th century, King's Lynn merchants grew wealthy from the trade of wine, timber and grain.

title: G.O.P. GATHERING CONSIDERS POLITICAL LIFE AFTER REAGAN
description: Republican Party leaders today ended a three-day meeting here that publicly celebrated the political vitality of the Reagan Presidency and privately wrestled with the long-term implications of his latest victories on Capital Hill.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW MINT DESIGN
description: The Statue of Liberty centennial appears to have generated more medallic tributes than any single event since the U.S. Bicentennial. One of the most significant is a proof set which includes 11 new medals designed by Frank Gasparro, who served for many years as a chief sculptor-engraver of the United States Mint.

title: RADON POLLUTION MAY BE THE COUNTRY'S MOST FAR-REACHING ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARD
description: WHEN Stanley Watras walked through the radiation monitors at a Limerick, Pa., nuclear-power plant last year, he sounded an alarm across the country.

title: Article 674386 -- No Title
description: Relatives of Hugh Skinner, shot dead by a police marksman who mistook him for a gunman, filed a $2.5 million wrongful-death claim Friday, but Los Angeles County Sheriff Sherman Block angrily denounced it today.

title: PAROLE HEAD REVIEWS TENURE
description: AS THE words slowly sank in, the inmate's fist clenched and unclenched. Then he lunged across the table at the chairman of New Jersey's Parole Board, shouting:

title: SHULTZ COMPLAINS ON SUMMIT DELAYS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz expressed frustration today over Soviet refusal to set a date for talks leading to a summit meeting.

title: B. B. KING/ANDRAE CROUCH DOUBLE BILL
description: MORE than 25 years have passed since Ray Charles, Sam Cooke and other black pop singers shocked the more traditional members of their public by mixing gospel music and the sinfully secular lyrics and attitudes of the blues. But traditional ways of thinking have proved more resilient than one would have imagined. Concerts like Friday evening's jazz festival offering at Avery Fisher Hall, which paired the bluesman B. B. King and the gospel singer Andrae Crouch, are still something of a rarity.

title: Kristina M. Kokubun Becomes a Bride
description: At the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, Conn., yesterday Kristina May Kokubun, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Kei Kokubun of South Pasadena, Calif., was married to Robert Williamson McCain, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Williamson McCain Jr. of Fairfield. The Rev. George Coxe Bland Jr. performed the ceremony, assisted by the bride's father, a Disciples of Christ minister.

title: Mary Farnsworth Is Married to Alan R. Marsh Jr.
description: Mary Meyering Farnsworth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Farnsworth of Winnetka, Ill., was married yesterday to Alan Reid Marsh Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marsh of Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. C. Theodore Roos performed the ceremony at the Winnetka Congregational Church.

title: 7 South Korean Radicals Held After a Sit-In at Party Offices
description: The police arrested seven South Korean radicals who staged a five-day hunger strike in an opposition party office to demand democratic elections, party officials said today.

title: A CLASH OF TITANS CAN BE MESSY
description: Which is better, to have the hero smoothly overcome all obstacles and win with the grace of a Mozart symphony, or to have two titans smash sword after sword in a gigantic but imperfect struggle for supremacy?

title: U.S. AND FRANCE JOINTLY ISSUE STAMPS
description: The United States and France will jointly issue postage stamps on the Fourth of July to celebrate the centennial of the Statue of Liberty. Created by Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, the statue was presented to this country by the people of France.

title: LIVELY SEASON OF MUSIC IS GETTING UNDER WAY
description: A PARTICULARLY lively selection of musical events will take place throughout the state this summer, with concerts indoors and out, under tents and on picnic grounds and with and without fireworks and cannons.

title: 'Flowers and Fruit'
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGISLATURE FACING TEST OF ITS POWER TO CONVENE
description: THE executive and legislative branches of the state government are heading toward a constitutional test of the power of the General Assembly to call itself into session to enact legislation.

title: 'MOST HATED MAN IN AMERICA'
description: THE LIFE AND LEGEND OF JAY GOULD By Maury Klein. Illustrated. 595 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $27.50.

title: Dr. Kathryn Fraser Weds
description: Dr. Kathryn Janet Fraser, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stewart E. Fraser of Melbourne, Australia, was married yesterday to Dr. John J. Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Atherton Williams of Westfield, N.J. The Rev. Robert Fishel performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Barrington, R.I.

title: BALLET THEATER: A NEW 'ROMEO AND JULIET' CAST
description: MARIANNA TCHERKASSKY and Robert Hill offered a performance notable for its charming simplicity on Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera House, when American Ballet Theater presented yet another new cast in Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet.'' These were gentle, childlike lovers.

title:
ANTIQUES;
TALL MASTS, OLD SHIPS, NAUTICAL LOVE
description: RECALLING other eras in New Jersey's long maritime history, the Hudson River again will be crowded with spars and canvas as the tall ships begin arriving on Tuesday for Liberty Weekend festivities.

title: Czechoslovakia
description: To the Editor: As an ardent Czechophile and a frequent visitor to Bohemia, I very much enjoyed reading Richard C. Crisler's article ''Castles in Czechoslovakia'' (Travel, May 18).

title: HAVE A SOBER FOURTH: IT'S NOW THE LAW
description: THE Governor's signature is drying on the newest piece of legislation against drunken drivers. And it is just in time as we prepare to celebrate the Fourth of July holiday.

title: ALABAMA PRIMARY ENDS UP A SQUEAKER
description: WHEN voters went to the polls here in last week's Democratic gubernatorial runoff, they were not only choosing a candidate to succeed the retiring George Corley Wallace; they were also helping to chart a new political course for Alabama, or so they might have thought. For years, this has been one of the few remaining New South states with an Old South-style governor.

title: A JUDGE ACCUSES POLICE OF BIAS IN CAB SEARCHES
description: A state appeals judge, in an angry dissenting opinion in a search-and-seizure case, has accused the New York City Police Department of establishing a policy of ''arbitrarily stopping and searching minority passengers of cabs traveling in Harlem or Upper Manhattan'' to find incriminating evidence.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
IMMIGRANTS
description: ''In a way, the show is a piggyback on top of Liberty, but we really tried to go beyond that,'' said Susan Shoulet about the exhibition, ''Liberty's Eye: Reflections of the Immigrant Experience,'' which opens this afternoon at the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle. More than 50 photographs as well as memorabilia and oral history tapes document numerous aspects of the immigrant experience.

title: 2,200 BEDS ON FIFTH AVENUE
description: THE ELEGANT INN The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, 1893-1929. By Albin Pasteur Dearing. Illustrated. 250 pp. Secaucus, N.J.: Lyle Stuart. $16.95.

title: Joel Sanders Wed To Miss Kramer
description: Louise Kramer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Kramer of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Joel Sanders, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Sanders of New Hyde Park, L.I., and Lenox, Mass. Rabbi Dennis Math performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in Manhattan.

title: ORCHESTRAS TOGETHER
description: WHEN the 50 youthful members of the Westchester Conservatory Orchestra tune their instruments next winter, the sound will be distinctly professional. At a special February concert, the principal chairs for this highly regarded amateur group will be drawn from the New Orchestra of Westchester, the county's newest professional orchestra, and the conductors of the two groups will share the podium. Paul Dunkel, the musical director of the New Orchestra and a professional flutist, and Elliot Magaziner, a professional violinist who directs the Westchester Conservatory Orchestra, will each perform solo pieces with the combined group.

title: THE EXOTIC 'NEW AMERICAN' TOUCH
description: EFFORTS at translating concept into cuisine continue with moderate success in some restaurants, such as Crooked Hill in Commack, that subscribe to the ''new American'' philosophy. The menu offers an enticing, contemporary and stylish list; the food lives up to expectations intermittently.

title: BRITISH SEND NEW CARRIER WITH A PAST
description: The Ark Royal, Britain's newest aircraft carrier, arrived yesterday to take part in this week's celebrations of the Statue of Liberty centennial. She was escorted by two British Navy frigates, the Cleopatra and the Sirius.

title: STUBBING OUT A HEALTH HAZARD
description: They may not have to walk a mile for a Camel, but beginning Tuesday many city workers may have to take a hike to light up. Mayor Koch last week severely curtailed smoking in city buildings. The new rule applies to the public as well.

title: Ann Marie Fisher and Richard J. Bonti Are Wed
description: Ann Marie Fisher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Owen Fisher of Midland, Mich., and Richard J. Bonti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph Bonti of Larchmont, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. Ira Bush officiated at the First United Methodist Church in Midland.

title: AIR FORCE STEPPING UP ANTI-TERRORISM TRAINING
description: The Air Force's security police have begun a sweeping campaign to protect nuclear weapons, fragile aircraft and sensitive communications sites from the rising threat of terrorist attack.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GESTURES. By H. S. Bhabra. (Viking, $16.95.) Odd and civilized novels like this one should not be saddled with such dreadful titles.

title: AN ACTOR'S SEARCH FOR THE CORE OF A BALLPLAYER
description: WHEN the phone rang and the director told me I'd be doing the role of Swede Risberg in the play ''Out'' at the Judith Anderson Theater, my reaction was mixed. I had wanted the role of Joe Jackson -immortalized with the line ''Say it ain't so, Joe'' - but no actor is disappointed by getting a role, and the part of Risberg was definitely challenging.

title: HOW CONGRESS CLOGGED CANAL STREET
description: Congress was badly misled by New York's Senator D'Amato and Representative Molinari when it passed their law that ''tolls on any bridge connecting the Borough of Brooklyn, N.Y., and Staten Island, N.Y.'' may be collected only going westbound. There's but one such harbor crossing, the spectacular Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, and its new one-way tolls range from $3.50 for cars to $25 for some trucks.

title: MUSIC FOR THE 4TH, BIG AND BRIGHT
description: LIBERTY Weekend does not promise a cornucopia of opportunities for the quiet contemplation of music. This is a big, populist celebration, and nearly all the music special to that celebration will be big and bustling to match. But if you like your music amplified and in the company of thousands of others, you will find much to enjoy.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: 4 of 7 Sikhs Released On Bail in Ontario
description: Four of seven Canadian Sikhs, charged with plotting to bomb India's Parliament buildings, were released from custody Friday on $50,000 bail each.

title: That Stevenson
description: Eugenia A. Stevenson will be arriving in Washington shortly to take up her duties as Liberian Ambassador to the United States. Mrs. Stevenson, who once at-tended American University, was the first woman accredited as a Liberian Ambassador abroad, when she was posted to West Germany in 1973. Mrs. Stevenson has also served as Liberian Consul General in New York, was Liberia's representative to the International Commission on the Status of Women and served as president of the Association of African Consuls in New York. She was married to the late George B. Stevenson, who served as First Secretary of the Liberian Embassy in Washington in 1947.

title: PHILIP JOHNSON, AT 80 IS DEAN AND GADFLY OF THE PROFESSION
description: Is there anything to say about Philip Johnson that has not been said? No architect in our time has achieved greater celebrity, not only among his professional colleagues but across the length and breadth of the land.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: FORT WORTH;
A New Life for Stockyards
description: IN this city's historic Stockyards are saloons, huge honky-tonks, Western souvenir stores, even saddles to sit on in the hotel bar. There also are acres of authentic old Stockyard pens and barns, rotting and vacant since the years when millions of head of cattle came through Fort Worth slaughterhouses from ranches all over Texas.

title: AIR FORCE WANTS ITS OWN ROCKETS
description: The space shuttle may fly again in 1988, but the Air Force has already begun to take its business elsewhere. It announced last week that it will create a new class of unmanned, mid-sized rockets to launch its payloads, which were grounded by the destruction of the shuttle Challenger Jan. 28.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
SIX-SPOTTED TIGER BEETLE
description: Cicindela sexguttata - Size: One-half to five-eighths inch.

title: TYSON WINS IN FIRST ROUND
description: Mike Tyson knocked out William Hosea at 2 minutes 3 seconds of the first round of a scheduled 10-round heavyweight fight here tonight.

title: Cable TV
description: On cable, Liberty Week brims with interesting film fare, headed by a cluster of home-screen premieres. One plum arrives smack in the middle of the Statue festivities, for viewers who might want a breather. On Thursday at 9 P.M., HBO is unveiling ''Prizzi's Honor'' (1985), John Huston's pungent study of Mafia intrigue with Jack Nicholson, Kathleen Turner and Angelica Huston; it repeats Friday on WHT at 8 P.M. and 3 A.M.

title: BELL LAB SCIENTISTS WORKING AS LIBERTY'S 'DERMATOLOGISTS'
description: MILLIONS of visitors have climbed the Statue of Liberty, but few do it the way Dr. Thomas E. Graedel of Mendham has - from the outside - and the atmospheric research scientist from this Morris County community has some unusual souvenirs of his unusual visits to the statue over the last 18 months.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Discount Date - Last week, as falling exports had Japan's economy slipping for the first time in 11 years, the Bank of Japan insisted it would not cut its discount rate - already cut three times this year - anytime soon. But Ward McCarthy, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, expects the Japanese, ''in a coordinated effort with the United States Federal Reserve,'' to announce a cut of 50 basis points sometime after Japan's parliamentary elections next Sunday. The Fed will cut its discount rate simultaneously, he says, to maintain the yen-dollar spread and to stimulate the ''disappointing'' United States economy.

title: DANGERS IN THE HOUSE: BEFORE THE FALL
description: Window guards save lives. For a decade, New York City has required landlords to install them, on request, in apartments housing children under age 11.

title: 15 Accused of Teamster Plot
description: The newly elected president of the statewide teamsters union and 14 other teamsters officials have been indicted in what the Federal authorities charge was a scheme to embezzle health-plan funds.

title: Activist Cleared in Gun Case
description: A jury in Alameda County Superior Court has cleared Huey P. Newton, co-founder of the Black Panthers, of charges of being a former felon in possession of firearms. The verdict Friday verdict involved the discovery of two pistols in a raid in 1985.

title: Caterpillar and Union Extend Contract 5 Days
description: Contract negotiators for Caterpillar Inc. and the United Automobile Workers resumed talks yesterday in St. Louis after extending an expired contract for five days. The contract covers nearly 17,000 workers in five states.

title: SCHOLARY AND EPICUREAN BOLOGNA
description: Some time ago I was sitting with a friend in a favorite restaurant in Bologna. The friend is an academic, a musicologist; and we were discussing some fine points of Verdi interpretation. Beside the bottle of wine - a local, sparkling Albano - there was a little pile of scores, specialist publications and a sheaf of typescript, an article in progress. As we ate, drank and talked shop, I realized that our lunch was somehow emblematic: We were following the city's two great traditions, eating and learning.

title: FINALLY, LIMITATIONS FOR LEFTY
description: SEVERAL years before his self-imposed silence, Steve Carlton once talked about how ''man is the only one who puts limitations on himself; there are really no limits.'' And when the 41-year-old left-hander learned that the Philadelphia Phillies finally had put limitations on his long career by releasing him, his philosophy didn't change. The winner of 318 games is hoping for the opportunity to convince another major-league team that there are ''no limits'' yet on his career.

title: APPLE SNAPS BACK
description: What a difference a year makes. Last June, Apple Computer Inc. was in the doghouse. Sales of all models were slow, and a management dispute between chairman John Sculley and co-founder Steven P. Jobs over the company's future led to Mr. Jobs's departure.

title: RARE SAMPLERS HELP PRESERVE THE PAST
description: The body must decay The hands that wrought this work Must shortly lie in the tomb And moulder in the clay.

title: WHEN THE HONEYMOON'S OVER
description: AFTER returning from their two-week honeymoon cruise last month, Regina and Mitchell Tenzer sat down to discuss their joint finances. As they talked, their list of things to do grew longer and longer: ''We're starting from scratch, so there's everything to think about,'' Mrs. Tenzer said.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TRIPLE NICKLES: America's First All-Black Paratroop Unit. By Bradley Biggs. (Archon, $15.) For black Americans, World War II was two wars.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. #1 Index: December 1982 -100 #2 Index: 1967 - 100* Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: The Memoirs Of a Jazzman
description: Freddie Moore, pictured on the drums in the 1931 photograph of the King Oliver Jazz Band, is still going strong at 86. Every Sunday, he can be heard playing the washboard and singing with the Creole Cookin' Dixieland Jazz Band at the Front restaurant in Greenwich Village. Freddie is still making the band cook with his style and energy. DARACH GUILFOYLE New York City

title: CASH WINS WITH CHARM AT WIMBLEDON
description: He is the rogue of the outside courts, swashbuckling in his trademark white bandana, the center of attention among the schoolgirls who call his name and scale tall fences for a glimpse of him at play. How out of character it seems to see Pat Cash display this new found Australian charm, dispensing gifts of wristbands and headbands to his fans, when in the past, he was reluctant to give so little of himself on or off the court.

title: QUEEN MARY SUPERSTAR
description: Two new books trace the present popularity of the British royals to the public relations instincts of Queen Mary and the Queen Mother Elizabeth. John Pearson's entry, THE SELLING OF THE ROYAL FAMILY: The Mystique of the British Monarchy (Simon & Schuster, $17.95), sets out to explain why the British royal family has a megastar image worldwide when almost every other monarchy has vanished or become ''a shadow of ancient pretensions.'' He gives a plausible account.

title: IRVINGTON
description: NEARLY every street in Irvington leads to a dead end, just one of many factors that contribute to the charm and serenity of this Hudson River community.

title: BASHING THE FRENCH
description: THE SPANISH ULCER A History of the Peninsular War. By David Gates. Illustrated. 557 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.

title: Beashel Eyes America's Cup
description: Colin Beashel had more in mind than the Liberty Cup when he appeared here last week for the match-racing series in New York Harbor. Yes, he was hungry for a first-place finish. But more than that, as Australia's rising star among yachtsmen he was thinking ahead to the America's Cup.

title: Mailbox; The Racquet Is Mightier
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: COHALAN GIVES VIEW ON SHOREHAM
description: ONE year ago, Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan came out in support of a Federal emergency drill at the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station - a move that was widely perceived as a reversal of his earlier opposition to the opening of the plant.

title: A STRIKING SHIFT IS SEEN IN HAITI IN AIDS VICTIMS
description: Heterosexual intercourse is now the predominant route of the spread of AIDS in Haiti, according to new results of a continuing study reported at an international meeting that ended here today.

title: PARISHES SEEK WAYS OF CONTENDING WITH LACK OF PRIESTS
description: THE bells still ring at the St. Stanislaus Roman Catholic Church in Hastings-on-Hudson, but the sound heard most often is the telephone, unanswered.

title: STARS OF THE HARBOR: A ROSTER
description: The Lead Sailing Ships - Some have sailed halfway around the world. Others have come from around the corner. The 22 majestic ships in the vanguard of Friday's Parade of Sail - with their lore and echo of the past - represent nations from Indonesia to Uruguay. 1. Eagle United States: The host vessel, this white, steel-hulled bark - America's most famous tall ship-was built in 1936 in Hitler's Germany as a school ship. The United States acquired her as a war reparation and commissioned her for the training of Coast Guard cadets. The top of her three steel decks is covered with teak. Her figurehead is a golden eagle. Crew, 220; length, 295 feet; mast height, 147 feet. 2. Danmark Denmark: This white, steel-hulled and full-rigged training ship, built in 1932, visited the 1939 New York World's Fair and was in Flordia when Denmark was overrun by Germany. During the war, the Coast Guard used her for training, leading to the decision to acquire the Eagle, after the Danmark sailed home. Her figurehead is a gilded sea god. Cre, 99; length, 253 feet; mast height, 131 feet. 3. Christian Radich Norway: (Pronounced RAH-dik). Built in 1937 as a Norwegian merchant marine training ship, she visited the 1939 World's Fair. Germany confiscated her in 1940 and used her as a floating barracks. After the war, she was found sunk and rebuilt. This full-rigged ship has a white, steel hull and a figurehead of a young woman in a long blue dress.

title: STAKING A BET ON COW'S GOOD GENES
description: The mooing black-and-white Holstein that Roy Homan bought for $230,000 this afternoon may have bulging udders, but from his point of view she is not a milk producer.

title: INSURANCE CRISIS: GETTING TO THE ROOT
description: NOW, even Superman has a lawyer.

title: Tapley Allen To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas F. Allen of Swampscott, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tapley Allen, to Steven R. Sheresky, a son of Lyn Revson and Kenneth Sheresky, both of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title:
ART;
ROBERT MARTON CO. INAUGURATES GALLERY WITH WORK OF NOLAND
description: ONE would have to be completely cynical and misanthropic to say that the Robert Martin Company does not have the best of intentions regarding its commitment to fine art. But there are hurdles to this observer's lauding it completely. The Robert Martin Gallery at the rose-colored granite Westchester Financial Center at 50 Main Street in downtown White Plains reflects some of the problems bound up with corporate support of the arts anywhere in the country.

title:
GARDENING;
IT'S NOT TOO LATE TO SOW MORE SEEDS
description: ABOUT this time of year voids in the garden become noticeable. Early plantings of lettuce, radishes and peas have been harvested, leaving behind an empty space, or openings appear here and there in the flower gardens where either early bloomers such as pansies have begun to fade or something counted upon to fill the space has failed.

title: Jersey Wedding For Cynthia Hill And John Dopp
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday Cynthia Conwell Hill and John Michael Dopp were married by Canon E. Rugby Auer.

title: Jazz
description: Four unaccompanied saxophones have never sounded as self-sufficient as they do in the World Saxophone Quartet, which performs Tuesday through next Sunday at Carlos I, 432 Avenue of the Americas at 9th Street. The World Saxophone Quartet creates extraordinary music with a minimum of instruments - just the four saxophones (with the occasional substitution of flutes and clarinets) wielded by Julius Hemphill, David Murray, Oliver Lake and Hamiet Bluiett. Since its formation in the 70's, the group has built its own repertory and an ensemble sound based on, among other things, big-band saxophone sections, doo-wop or gospel vocal harmonies and modern chamber music; its four players are also composers, and its songbook includes blues, tone poems, strutting showpieces and marvels of delicacy.

title: BOSTON BAKED SEX
description: IMPOSTERS By George V. Higgins. 362pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $16.95.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ARBORETUM REOPENING - Hurricane Gloria uprooted more than 1,000 trees at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum, including two-thirds of the collection of exotic pines. But now the state park is open for business again. To celebrate, the Islip Arts Council today begins its traditional, if delayed, Summer Chamber Music Series at the park in Oakdale. Andrew Appel, a harpsichordist, and Ryan Brown, a Baroque violinist, lead off with the music of Bach, Corelli, Marini and Frescobaldi at 2 P.M. Though the concert, the first of 12 weekly programs, is free, it costs $1.50 for each adult (children under 12 free) to park. For a complete schedule call 581-1002.MUSIC OF THE GILDED AGE

title: Verbatim; Taking a Compliment
description: 'My grandfather, who was a rabbi, once in a sermon asked a question which embarrassed almost the whole audience. He said, ''Why is the Almighty so eager to get so much praise? Three times a day you have to pray to Him and say how great He is, how wonderful.

title: INSPECTOR GENERAL PLANNING HIS ROLE AS OMBUDSMAN
description: HENRI F. ERKELENS, who is leaving a long career in the Army to become Connecticut's first Inspector General, tells those who say his job is superfluous to look at history.

title: Miss Galbreath Marries in Ohio
description: Lizanne Galbreath and John F. Megrue Jr. were married yesterday at Darby Dan Farm in Galloway, Ohio, by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Sanders of the First Community Church in Columbus, Ohio.

title: America In the Mind of Israel
description: Mr. Friedman leaves the disturbing impression that Orthodox Jews who have immigrated to Israel have not made a positive contribution to the state. Were he to meet most of my friends who have made aliyah in the last 10 years, he would see that this impression is false.

title: SOUNDING AN ALERT ON OZONE
description: About a third of all Americans live in metropolitan areas where ozone pollution exceeds the limit established under the Clean Air Act, according to the Environmental Protection Agency. And although some of the cities have made progress, Lee Thomas, the agency's Administrator, warned last week, most will fail to meet a 1987 deadline for reducing ozone.

title: Woman Aboard a Cruise Ship On East River Is Hit by Bullet
description: A Manhattan woman standing on the deck of a cruise boat on the East River near the Brooklyn Bridge was shot in the arm Friday night.

title: MANDATORY INOCULATION OF CATS TO PREVENT RABIES ADVOCATED
description: STATE health officials and veterinarians are calling for mandatory inoculation and licensing of cats - as is required of dogs - because of an epidemic of rabies among wild animals that has reached Pennsylvania and is moving toward New Jersey at the rate of about 25 miles a year.

title: U.S. IS REASSESSING ITS OVERALL POLICY WITH SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Reagan Administration has begun a high-level reassessment of United States policy in South Africa intended, in part, to forge closer ties with black leaders involved in the conflict there, a high-ranking Administration official said today.

title: FROM DIJON, A 'TASTE OF THE DEVIL'
description: With an assertiveness and a pungency powerful enough to bring tears to the eyes, mustard is the king of French condiments. It's hard to imagine that this common household staple, a simple blend of mustard seeds ground and mixed with vinegar or slightly fermented wine and marketed in ordinary re-usable supermarket tumblers, could have such a regal history.

title: CLONING A COCOA PLANT
description: LAST fall, Pennsylvania State University was the host of a first-ever symposium on the potential of cocoa biotechnology. Now the American Cocoa Research Institute, an arm of the Chocolate Manufacturers Association, may make a sizable grant to the University's food science department to find ways to clone the cocoa plant - to reproduce genetically identical specimens in a tissue culture environment. Then, by selecting those that have the desired characteristics, researchers hope to develop plants that produce a higher-quality bean, have better yields, are more resistant to insects and disease, and can grow in more temperate zones.

title: BITTER BURLESQUE FROM THE ARENA
description: THE current Broadway revival of ''Loot'' has created a well-deserved rekindling of interest in the plays of Joe Orton. In response, the Arena Players Repertory Company in East Farmingdale is presenting a Joe Orton comedy festival consisting of two plays, ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane'' and ''What the Butler Saw.''

title: YOUNG ANDRETTI SETS RECORD
description: Michael Andretti set a lap record of 60.53 seconds, an average speed of 100.028 miles an hour, in qualifying today for the Chase Grand Prix Sunday at the Meadowlands.

title: Roof-Garden Restorations
description: Through the winter and into this spring, 15 workmen formed daily ''bucket brigades'' on the roofs of two of the low Rockefeller Center buildings that face Fifth Avenue. Moving thousands of plants and tons of soil by hand, they restored two of the Center's little-known roof gardens that are maintained to provide pleasant outlooks for tenants in the taller buildings.

title: COMPETITION THINS OUT AT 30,000 FEET
description: A decade ago, the Government might have approved a major airline merger, but only if one of the carriers involved was failing. And if the resulting merger gave the combined cariers a monopoly on any routes, the Government would in many cases make adjustments to assure customers a choice of airlines. Such were the basic tenets of the ''failing carrier doctrine,'' which governed mergers and acquisitions in an era of rigid regulation.

title: CHARTING THE SUPREME COURT'S CONSERVATIVE DRIFT
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OUR TEMPESTUOUS DAY: A History of Regency England. By Carolly Erickson. (Morrow, $18.95.) Regency England was like a compulsive bon vivant whose nightly overindulgence is matched each morning by the equally excessive appeasement of his Puritan soul. The historian Carolly Erickson, author of ''Bloody Mary,'' has spun out a lively and thoroughly enthralling account of this paradoxical age - 1810 to 1820 - whose gods were Byron and the Duke of Wellington (Napoleon's conqueror) but whose all-too-human ruler was a puckish, overweight boy-man given to wide mood swings and overdoses of laudanum and fast women. When his father, George III, began to recede into his own mad dream world, Parliament appointed the Prince of Wales, later George IV, as Regent. George both repelled and fascinated his subjects: they regularly castigated him for his profligacy and his very public battle to divorce his promiscuous wife, Caroline. But thousands of them also stood in line for hours just to glimpse his private chambers at Carlton House - and the remains of his legendary all-night ball. According to Miss Erickson, the excesses of the melancholy young Byron, both romantic and literary, took on symbolic power, dramatizing what she calls the ''diseased and violent'' undertow of the age, the sense that there was a ''canker at the root of things.'' Hannah More, a stern Christian evangelical, agreed and in her best-selling tracts exhorted Britain to cleanse itself of worldliness, encouraging the rise of a ferociously pious army of reformers.

title: STATE PANEL IS BULLISH ON A LILCO TAKEOVER
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has not been accused lately of selling its main product at bargain prices, but the company itself may be a good buy, according to several panels that have studied that prospect recently.

title: 'FLOWERS AND FRUIT'
description: To the Editor:

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening. Excerpts are from reviews by Times critics. Witness

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I grew up in Brooklyn and never went to the Statue of Liberty.

title: America In the Mind of Israel
description: Thomas Friedman refers to the ''ominous role'' some American Jews are playing by supporting ultra-Orthodox religious institutions in Israel with the misguided idea that such support ''will strengthen Judaism or save Jewish souls from assimilation.''

title: CHARTING THE SUPREME COURT'S CONSERVATIVE DRIFT
description: To the Editor:

title: The Skill of Bowling
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: He Who Changed the Face of Downtown
description: Oliver T. Carr has some fanciful ideas about his hometown.

title: Woman in Rape Case Released From Jail
description: A woman who refused to testify against a former boyfriend accused of raping her was released after three days in jail after a judge ruled that her imprisonment was further victimization.

title: SPAIN SAYS PALESTINIAN ADMITS BOMBING
description: A Palestinian has confessed to planting the suitcase bomb that exploded Thursday at the airport counter of El Al Israel Airlines here, the Spanish police said today.

title: SITING COMMISSION PRAISED ON TOXIC-WASTE PROCESS
description: Some readers of the June 15 article ''Emotions Run High at Toxic-Waste Site Hearings'' might be confused about the Sierra Club's position in the siting process. When the club helped draft the Siting Act, we joined with other local and state environmental groups and asked ourselves: ''If my community is selected, what process, provisions and safeguards would I want built into the law?''

title: SANCTUARY FOR ALIENS: FIGURES TELL THE STORY
description: The June 1 article on the sanctuary movement [ ''3 Communities Join Sanctuary Drive'' ] quotes the deputy director of the Hartford office of the Immigration and Naturalization Service as saying: ''It's very easy to stand up and say we deny these people asylum. But if they've never been in the system, how do we know?''

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's like a jogger on the last quarter mile. You know you're going to finish and not die. '' - Senator Thad Cochran, Republican of Mississippi, after 13 days of tax-bill debate.

title:
DINING OUT;
ACCENT IN FRENCHTOWN IS FRENCH
description: ONE of the greatest pleasures for a restaurant reviewer is the discovery of a good restaurant. When the place in question is situated in a charming old inn and is owned by an equally charming and very young couple who have a skilled and eager support staff, the pleasure is even greater.

title: GIRDING FOR GRIDLOCK: EXTRAORDINARY STEPS
description: THE face has already launched a thousand ships and a thousand products -from dog food to dust ruffles.

title: MUSIC: DUTOIT AND HORNE OPEN TANGLEWOOD SEASON
description: Tanglewood opening nights can be festive affairs, especially - as was the case Friday night - when the opener offers a full Boston Symphony concert, as opposed to the smaller-scaled events that have sometimes occupied the first week.

title: Gavin Is a Slanderer, Lopez Portillo Asserts
description: Former President Jose Lopez Portillo threatened to sue the former United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, saying Mr. Gavin had implied to a United States Senate hearing that corruption had made Mr. Lopez Portillo rich.

title: DANGERS IN THE HOUSE: HIGH-RISK DEFFENSE
description: Why shouldn't a fearful homeowner keep a gun in the house? Because a gun is likely to make the house more dangerous, not more safe.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE PLANT in Freehold has closed, the dust has settled and the two labor leaders have completed their journeys, one of them returning to his home in South Africa. But their campaign is still very much alive, and much of the bitterness lingers on.

title: Commercial Curbs Opposed
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN TO LIGHT TORCH IN OPENING CEREMONIES
description: IN the beginning, there will be dignity. There will be trumpets and presidents, Gershwin and Sinatra, Kirk Douglas and Gregory Peck. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger will give the oath of citizenship to Mikhail Baryshnikov. Then the Russian ballet star, who defected on a Bolshoi tour of Canada 12 years ago, will dance his first pas de deux as an American.

title: GERMANS IN THE TREETOPS, WAY UP HIGH
description: MOUNTAIN OF TRUTH The Counterculture Begins: Ascona, 1900-1920. By Martin Green. Illustrated. 287 pp. Hanover, N.H.: University Press of New England. $19.95.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ORDER/ORDER/ORDER
description: COULD you throw away molds of your son's teeth, taken before and after orthodonture?

title: PASSIONS OF A SHY WARRIOR
description: THE COLLECTED LETTERS OF W.B. YEATS Volume One: 1865-1895. Edited by John Kelly with Eric Domville. Illustrated. 548 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95. THESE letters from the first 30 years of William Butler Yeats's life are the statements of an obsessive mythmaker whose sense of purpose is casual and passionate and whose determination to gather material for his poetry from every possible source is so implacable that it verges on the predatory.

title: Sunday Observer; Whippersnapper Blues
description: WHEN THE INTELLECTUAL giants of journalism are being praised, whose name always heads the list? George Will's name, that's whose. And whose name is never even mentioned despite the fact that he is the only journalist in any hemisphere whose hobby is Marcel Proust?

title: R. B. Casey Wed To Leslie Weiss
description: Leslie Marie Weiss, the daughter of Lyn Cranston of Norwalk, Conn., and Frederick C. Weiss Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert B. Casey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict H. Casey of Cherry Hill, N.J. The Rev. Anthony McHale performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the home of the bride's father.

title: SHARED ROOTS FEED NEW ROCK'S VARIETY
description: The New York rock scene is always more complex and multifaceted than any single label or trend can account for. Looking back at the middle and late 60's, it seems the Velvet Underground must have utterly dominated its downtown milieu; at the time, without the benefit of hindsight, things weren't that simple. Bands as diverse as Auto Salvage, Circus Maximus, the Vagrants and Ars Nova all had their followings, but their reputations have faded, while the legend of the Velvet Underground continues to grow. Similarly, the early days of the mid-70's punk scene at CBGB witnessed the growth of a number of bands. Today, the Ramones, Television, Patti Smith and Talking Heads are fondly remembered or still with us; Tuff Darts, the Shirts and others seem to have disappeared into limbo.

title: America In the Mind of Israel
description: In his article ''America in the Mind of Israel'' (May 25), Thomas L. Friedman suggests that young Israelis would stay in Israel - rather than immigrate to the United States - if Israel would make itself more attractive by freeing itself from the influence of ''ultra-Orthodox messianic Jews [ and ] right-wing extremists, such as Rabbi Meir Kahane.''

title: A WOUNDED LIFE, A FATHER 'PERFECT IN DEATH'
description: IN his relatively brief and tempestuous life (1909-1955), James Agee as a writer exploded in many directions. He began as a poet (''Permit Me Voyage,'' published in 1934 in the Yale Series of Younger Poets), went to Fortune to report on the ravages of the Depression among Southern tenant farmers and reviewed books for Time. During his lifetime he achieved his greatest fame as the canniest and most dedicated film critic around, writing simultaneously for Time and The Nation.

title: Cherry Bowl to Pay Debt
description: The Cherry Bowl on Monday will pay off the remainder of the $498,000 it owes to each of the schools that participated in the 1985 college football postseason game.

title: Talking Boat Slips; Buying A Piece of The Dock
description: WITH more and more power and sailboats on the waters around New York, their owners are discovering that finding slip space - particularly along the crowded shores of Long Island Sound - is as hard, if not harder, than finding a parking place for a car on the streets of Manhattan.

title: THEOLOGICALLY, LIBERATION HAS LOST MUCH OF ITS STANDING
description: WHEN Pope John Paul II attacks Marxism, as he did last month in his encyclical on the Holy Spirit, no one is surprised. After all, this is a man whose bitter experiences with Communism in his native Poland have made him skeptical of its promises of liberation.

title: GLACIER PARK WELCOMES BACK 12 EXILED WOLVES
description: The mountainous border between Canada and the United States at this point is marked only by a narrow swath through the heavily timbered wilderness.

title: HOME OF AMERICAN LEGENDS
description: The upstate New York village of Cooperstown is stitched into American history and legend as tightly as the stripes on Old Glory. It was founded by and named after the father of James Fenimore Cooper, one of America's first renowned novelists, whose wordy tales helped create the romanticized image of early pioneer life. Three of Cooper's novels, in fact, were set in the area and many of the locations can still be visited, including Natty Bumppo's cave.

title: THE BRILLIANT SUNSET OF VIENNA IN ITS FINAL GLORY
description: At the end of World War II, there were very few people in this country - save those of Viennese extraction - who knew or cared anything about turn-of-the-century Vienna. The once-great city was a wreck, and under Allied occupation. The music was not heard. The books were not read. The paintings and drawings were not looked at. The decorative arts - once so inventive, so all-invading, so spirited and so delicate - could hardly have been more inappropriate to one of the more cheerless of decades. Turn-of-the-century Vienna seemed remote, effete and pointless. As for its rare great survivors - Arnold Schoenberg among composers, Oskar Kokoschka among painters - they had trouble scratching out a living, the one in Los Angeles, the other in London.

title: ON PHOTO SAFARI IN CALIFORNIA
description: You can reach up and hand a carrot to a giraffe, but it's better to feed a rhinoceros through the slats of the open-back pickup truck. If you really want to make a friend of a rhino, you'll drop an apple into its cavernous jaws, which make short work of the snack.

title: ONCE AGAIN, THE HOUSE TAKES UP IMMIGRATION
description: For the third time in five years, the House Judiciary Committee last week approved a broad immigration bill designed to curtail the flow of illegal migrants from Mexico and other countries. But there were sharper-than-usual divisions in the committee, suggesting that getting the full House to go along with the panel's handiwork, never an easy matter even when it is not an election year, may be tougher than usual.

title: OFFICIALS IN PACT ON CITY'S BUDGET
description: City officials reached agreement on a new budget last night, ending a confused, protracted process that brought the city closer to the start of its new fiscal year without an approved budget than at any time since Mayor Koch took office.

title: A VICTORY FOR SPAINISH SOCIALISTS
description: The Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez easily won Spain's national election last Sunday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about mutual funds in the special Personal Investing section on June 1 reversed the status of two funds. The Nicholas Fund is accepting new investments, but its successor, Nicholas II, is closed to all new accounts except Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: WHO SAID WE HAVE TOO MANY DOCTORS?
description: THE American Medical Association, like other professional associations, suffers from a split personality. While it is devoted to improving the quality of medical care, education and the profession, it also operates as a cartel to protect the economic interests of its members. Although the A.M.A.'s recent report on physician manpower reflects both personalities, the cartel strain is dominant. The report's assertion of a physician surplus and its recommendation that the surplus be eliminated by curtailing medical school enrollment are a blueprint for anticompetitive action.

title: U.S. AIDES REPORT COMPROMISE OFFER BY SOVIET ON ARMS
description: The Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has informed President Reagan that he is prepared to compromise on the issue of medium-range missiles, according to Administration officials.

title: SOUTHEAST ASIA'S ECONOMIC DOWNTURN
description: DESPITE the many problems facing the Philippines, Secretary of State George P. Shultz feels ''bullish'' about the country, and he said so last week in Manila. During discussions of economic strategies and efforts to end the Communist insurgency with President Corazon C. Aquino and her top aides, he also signed an agreement to deliver $200 million in aid.

title: U.S. DESIGN COMES BACK
description: One current development in audio has nothing to do with electronics. Rather, it is caused by the yen's rise vis-a-vis the dollar -a shift that now presents American audio firms with rare opportunities.

title: IN HIS KILTS, A MAN'S A MAN FOR A' THAT
description: The sight of the kilt was once enough to make an Englishman jump, and often not quickly enough. It was sometimes the last sight for the unwary Englishman in this life before he was set upon by naked Scots out of ambush, their stripped-off kilts coloring the air as they howled down the heather with their claymores windmilling to the abrasions of bagpipes. And a good thing it was too.

title: Enter Objecting
description: To the Editor:

title: DOUGLASS IS LEADER BY 4 IN U.S. SENIORS
description: Dale Douglass increased his lead to four strokes after three rounds of the seventh United States Senior Open championship today. But this time when the 50-year-old Colorado golfer looked over his shoulder it was Gary Player in second place poised for the final round Sunday at Scioto Country Club.

title: Surge in Offices
description: To the Editor:

title: Irradiated Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Tequila Tanker Causes Scare
description: About 100 people were evacuated Friday from a trailer park for about three hours after a parked tanker of tequila tipped onto a van and emitted vapors first thought to be hazardous, officials said. At first the trucking company relayed information that the vehicle carried hazardous anhydrous ethyl alcohol. The driver later informed officers at the scene he was hauling tequila.

title: Possible Mate Takes Sheepshead Bay
description: Possible Mate, a front-runner throughout her career, dropped far off the pace and then made an impressive late charge to win the $125,800 Sheepshead Bay Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Q: What If It Rains?
description: A: People will get wet. But the ships will sail and the show will go on.

title: America In the Mind of Israel
description: Although I agree with much of what Thomas Friedman has to say about the changing attitudes of Israelis toward the Diaspora (read United States Jews), I think he should have made his readers aware that, even at the height of the Hasmonean dynasty in Judea, in the first century before the common era, half the Jews lived in Babylonia and in Alexandria, where they were producing a great civilization. Some years later, many would migrate to Rome.

title: CITY OPERA RAISES THE CURTAIN ON BETTER TIMES
description: The banners are flapping from the Lincoln Center flagpoles, there are lines at the New York State Theater ticket windows, and on Tuesday night the New York City Opera will open its 1986 season with one of its most popular productions, Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide.'' Later on during the 20-week season will be a French festival, including new productions of Massenet's ''Werther'' with Jerry Hadley and ''Don Quichotte'' with Samuel Ramey. The other new productions consist of kitschy charm in Sigmund Romberg's operetta, ''New Moon,'' and accessible avant-gardism, with the jazz pianist and composer Anthony Davis's opera on the life of Malcolm X, entitled ''X.''

title: Data Bank June 29, 1986
Condo for 84th
description: The vacant structure, a former supermarket, sat for nearly seven years on the northeast corner of First Avenue and East 84th Street, a victim of the difficulties of developing in New York.

title: BINGHAM, CLEARED, LOOKS TO NEW LIFE
description: Stephen M. Bingham, the lawyer found not guilty in the deaths of six men in a convict's attempt to escape from San Quentin prison 15 years ago, says he may resume practicing law and will work for liberal causes again.

title: BUILDER SUES RHODE ISLAND'S TOP PROSECUTOR
description: In the latest step in a continuing dispute between Rhode Island's Attorney General and one of the nation's largest construction companies, the Gilbane Building Company has filed a $5 million civil suit in Federal court, charging Attorney General Arlene Violet with violating its constitutional rights.

title: PATIENCE IS THE SECRET WEAPON
description: GAME PLAN A Geostrategic Framework for the Conduct of the U.S.-Soviet Contest. By Zbigniew Brzezinski. Maps. 288 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: WEAK GOVERNMENT IS FEARED IN ITALY
description: Political leaders said today that resolving Italy's Government crisis could require a major Cabinet shuffle and changes in parliamentary rules and that such steps might lead to a weak minority government.

title: EXPOS DEFEAT PIRATES BY 3-2
description: Hubie Brooks hit his 14th home run and Jeff Reardon collected his 18th save tonight as the Montreal Expos defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-2.

title: THE DEMOCRATS ARE ISOLATIONIST? NONSENSE
description: As the campaigns for the 1986 and 1988 elections heat up, Democrats are struggling to respond to charges - many from within their own party - that their views on foreign policy are isolationist. These accusations are not only un founded, they lend credence to President Reagan's dangerous argument that failure to support every anti-Communist crusade he proposes amounts to abandoning major American interests.

title: HEARING THE FOURTH: SOUSA MARCHES AND RAGTIME
description: INDEPENDENCE DAY heralds an outpouring of patriotic music, and this year the honor of upholding America's creative heritage will go to jazz and orchestral pops. Concerts featuring orchestras and jazz musicians are slated for the days before the Fourth of July and the weeks following.

title: WINDHAM BAND TO STRIKE UP THE RADIOS
description: WHEN the ''band'' lines up for Windham's Fourth of July parade on Main Street Friday, there will be no horns or drums - just radios.

title: ONE COMPANY'S CRISIS IS SALT LAKE'S LUCKY BREAK
description: Charles Stromberg, a Tooele County Commissioner, takes little comfort in knowing that his county's headache is spelling welcome relief for the rest of the communities surrounding the Great Salt Lake.

title: MANION STILL IN LIMBO
description: Just as it appeared that the Senate had awarded Daniel A. Manion his judicial robes, a deft parliamentary maneuver by his Democrat opponents sidetracked his nomination for a Federal judgeship last week.

title: NEW YORK MAKING BID TO ATTRACT DEMOCRATIC CONVENTION IN 1988
description: Bidding to be the host of the Democratic National Convention in 1988, New York City will submit its written proposals to the party tomorrow for the use of either the new Jacob K. Javits Convention Center or Madison Square Garden.

title: TO PLAY ONESELF MAY BE THE GREATEST ILLUSION OF ALL
description: Anyone who grew up infatuated with the theater has surely done stage-door duty. For a theaterlover, the point of hanging around a stage door after a performance is not, as outsiders often assume, to collect autographs, to meet showgirls (or boys), or even, pace Eve Harrington, to break into the theatrical profession. What's entertaining about watching actors emerge from a stage door is that one can, if only for a few seconds, contemplate the yawning gulf that separates a performer from his role. Only moments ago, back inside, there had been a Falstaff, his gargantuan spirit permeating every crevice of an epic landscape. Now one sees a rather slender man in double-knit pants and polo shirt, nervously balancing the match for his cigarette in one hand and his half-read copy of Sports Illustrated in the other. Maybe he's the guy who one thought looked familiar from aspirin commercials after all.

title: Reed Blazes in 400 At U.S. Junior Meet
description: William Reed, the outstanding Philadelphia Central High School sophomore, returned to the track today after being sidelined for a month because of chicken pox and he looked sharp despite the layoff.

title: Israeli Security Chief Resigns
description: The Israel Government tried again last week to quash charges that senior officials of the Shin Beth domestic intelligence agency had ordered and then lied about the fatal beatings of two Arab terrorists. In a deal arranged by Prime Minister Shimon Peres and other leaders, Avraham Shalom resigned as head of Shin Beth and was granted immunity from prosecution.

title: A POTPOURRI OF PLAYS FOR THE SUMMER
description: THE state's summer theater season will offer a variety of new plays, old musicals and popular comedies, with only the classics in short supply as theaters - some just barely holding on -struggle for economic rather than artistic survival.

title: SPIRITED PERNFORS PROVES ADAPTABLE
description: Once again the question arises: What is a nice little tennis player like Mikael Pernfors doing in the round of 16 at a Grand Slam event?

title: RAIL AND ROAD SCHEDULE
description: For those who plan to plunge into the fray, these are some traffic tips and all-around survival advice. Traffic and Roads

title: PHILOSOPHICAL OBJECTIONS TO ELITE CITY HIGH SCHOOLS
description: GETTING into Midwood High School, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, is about as tough as getting into an Ivy League college. More than 12,000 eager eighth graders applied this year for 450 fall openings in Midwood's highly touted programs in the medical sciences and humanities. The principal, Leonard Harrison, is proud of the odds.

title: IF HAPPINESS IS A WARM PUPPY...
description: TO understand how I came to acquire a house in the country, there are a couple of things you should know about me. I love cars and dogs. About 18 years ago my wife showed early-warning signs of wanting a retreat from Manhattan and from the absurdities of the musician's itinerant life. At roughly the same time, I began to long for a puppy. The birth of our two sons shortly thereafter did little to dissuade either of us from our respective goals. I would remind her that most concerts occured on Fridays and Saturdays, thereby eliminating the possibility of ever visiting this weekend Eden, after which she would persuade me that keeping a dog in a city apartment was cruel. So we compromised and bought a car.

title: WHEN HOLIDAY FIREWORKS WERE OURS
description: IT'S hard to imagine how many children have never had the pleasure of an old-fashioned Fourth of July. To us, as children, it was second only to Christmas.

title: Youngstown Is Out
description: Trustees of Youngstown State University have voted to take the university out of the Ohio Valley Athletic Conference in the next two years. Travel costs and lack of fan support were cited as reasons.

title: COLONIAL TAVERN MARKS AN ANNIVERSARY
description: ON Friday, Kathryn Venus Rosa, in a floral colonial-style dress and a ruffled cap atop her head, will stride briskly across the wide floorboards of the Keeler Tavern in Ridgefield to make certain that everything from the parlor chairs to the clay pipes lining the taproom's mantle are perfectly positioned. Then she will invite the public to enter, as she has done countless times since the tavern's opening day exactly 20 years ago.

title: Drugs Tied to 2d Athlete's Death
description: A pathologist who conducted an autopsy on Don Rogers, the Cleveland Browns' star defensive back who died Friday in Sacramento, Calif., at age 23, said that the most likely cause of death was a drug overdose.

title: HOW IS ART MADE? SHOW OFFERS INSIGHT
description: AN EXHIBITION of Dorothy Gillespie's work at the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery here is the sort of solo show that offers an insight into the art-making process.

title: ANOTHER KIND OF POWER COMING FROM CHERNOBYL
description: FOR one who has lived with the name Chernobyl since my childhood days at the Westchester Day School in Mamaroneck, I responded to the news of the nuclear disaster while driving along the Cross Bronx Expressway with nothing short of a gasp. My throat became dry. It couldn't be. I turned up the volume on the radio. Was that the same Chernobyl? The one near Kiev?

title: MISS SCARLETT CARRIES ON
description: To the Editor:

title: OCEAN GROVE TRIES TO KEEP OLD CHARM IN NEW TIMES
description: THIS seaside hamlet is in transition, trying to incorporate century-old spiritual and civic patterns into the fabric being woven by newcomers.

title: Marilyn Pelias Marries Fellow Medical Student
description: Marilyn Evelyn Pelias, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald C. Pelias of Metairie, La., was married last evening at Temple Sinai of New Orleans to Wade Lawrence Fischer, a son of Drs. Beverly and William Fischer of Scotch Plains, N.J. Rabbi Murray Blackman performed the ceremony.

title: Kate Saltus Has Wedding
description: Katherine Elizabeth Saltus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Saltus 2d of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Edward Homer Painter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Painter of Urbana, Ill., and Sandwich, Mass. The Rev. Drs.

title: SUFFOLK DOWNS BOUGHT BY LEROUX GROUP
description: A group headed by Edward G. (Buddy) LeRoux, an owner of the Boston Red Sox, formally purchased Suffolk Downs in Revere, Mass., for $21 million from the Ogden Corporation Friday. The LeRoux group, known as Belle Island Limited Partnership, will be the landlord of the race track and its 200 acres of land.

title: EXTREMES MAKE LIFE HARD FOR PERU'S MIDDLE
description: SOCIALIST International delegates left Lima last week after a meeting that was supposed to buttress President Alan Garcia's position in the foreign debt debate. Instead, the organization of Western Social Democratic and Labor parties left him in deep domestic trouble, caught between fanatical Shining Path guerrillas and a tense and defensive military.

title: Those Shrivers
description: It can be argued that it pays to be a prominent television personality.

title: CONSUMER RATES
NORMAN HAS A 62 TO TRAIL BY 1
description: Greg Norman shot a 10-under-par 62 today to move one shot behind Bob Murphy, the leader after three rounds of the Canadian Open Championship.

title: 'SOPHISTICATED LADIES' WARMS UP AN EVENING DINNER THEATER
description: AN Evening Dinner Theater has come up with a spiffy, terrifically cast and excitingly performed staging of ''Sophisticated Ladies'' - a show that seems to be in search of a show.

title: EAST AND WEST TRY SPEAKING IN SOFTER WORDS
description: Washington and Moscow exchanged more words last week on arms control and the possibility of a meeting in the United States this year between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. The tone of the exchanges was calm and reasonable, with a distinct absence of sabre-rattling.

title: IN THE SHADOW OF THE BALANCED-BUDGET LAW
description: THERE was a clear shortage of pleasure among Capitol Hill's budget-makers last week as the House and Senate approved a compromise spending plan of almost $1 trillion for 1987 before leaving town for a two-week, Independence Day recess.

title: DAILY NEWS TELLS STAFF OF LAYOFFS
description: Facing a loss of almost $11 million a year in advertising with the closing of the Gimbels and Ohrbach's department stores, The Daily News will cut its staff and other operating costs and seek new sources of advertising revenue, the newspaper said yesterday.

title: The Memoirs Of a Jazzman
description: How beautiful and heartwarming were the memories of Clyde Bernhardt (''The Memoirs of a Jazzman,'' by Clyde E. B. Bernhardt and Sheldon Harris, June 1). And the photograph of King Oliver's New Orleans Creole Jazz Band should be a pinup for all music lovers.

title: Cylinders by Jahn
description: Most of the distinguished architecture of downtown Brooklyn, from the majesty of the General Post Office and Borough Hall to the intricacy of the brownstones and mansions of Brooklyn Heights, was built in the 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: SPOTLIGHT'S ON EVENTS
description: ONE OF the highlights of the summer here will be the centennial celebration of the E. H. Stokes Fire Company on July 25, 26 and 27. Some 100 fire engines and a fife-and-drum corps will parade through the streets on July 26, starting at 1 P.M.

title: ROUSING FINALE OF STARS AND MUSIC
description: FOR the closing ceremony Sunday, David L. Wolper has methodically crafted an evening of ''total madness.''

title: GRACE ELIZABETH WHITE
description: Grace Elizabeth White, a professor of social work, died of a stroke Monday at her home in Lexington, Ky.

title: 7.75% Loans
description: Starting tomorrow, the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority will begin offering mortgages with a fixed rate of 7.75 percent to low-income Connecticut residents.

title: STAR SPANGLED PICNIC
description: THIS YEAR, AS INDEPENDENCE Day approaches, America is looking back to the immigrant tradition that built our nation into such a vibrant place. What a wonderful opportunity, I thought, to look ahead -to Alice Waters, the doyenne of the ''New American Cuisine.'' How, I wondered, would the chef-owner of the famed Chez Panisse restaurant in Berkeley, Calif., celebrate the Fourth of July? Why, with a picnic, of course! Alice Waters's brilliance has been her ability to amalgamate a variety of culinary traditions into a distinctly American cuisine. On a recent visit I made to her restaurant, she combined foods of both American and French derivation - with an Italian touch tossed in, for the sake of ethnicity -to create an al fresco Fourth especially for the readers of The New York Times Magazine.

title: A LIBERTY SHOW, 103 YEARS LATER
description: WHEN it comes to celebrating the Statue of Liberty's 100th birthday this week, few of the activities will rival the Parrish Art Museum's contribution for authenticity.

title: HISTORY, LITERATURE AND THE ROAD TO PETERHOF
description: Some 27 years ago I published an article in The New York Times Book Review under the title ''It's History, but Is It Literature?''

title: PATROLS IN LEBANON ENFORCE PLAN TO END CONTROL BY MILITIAS
