description: Lebanese Army and paramilitary police units fanned out in the streets of largely Moslem West Beirut today to try to enforce a Syrian-sponsored peace plan aimed at stopping clashes between rival Moslem militias.

title: OSHA TAKES A CLOSER LOOK AT THE NATION'S FIREWORKS MAKERS
description: ONE year ago, after 21 people died in explosions at a fireworks factory in Hallett, Okla., it was disclosed that the Federal agency responsible for safeguarding the health and safety of workers in the plant did not even know of its existence. Officials for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration were all the more embarrassed by the oversight, because the same factory had been wracked by blasts six years earlier.

title: RAY BRYANT, THE PIANIST, IN RECITAL
description: A GIBRALTAR-like emotional solidity and a style directly connected to the wellsprings of black musical tradition are the hallmarks of Ray Bryant's solo piano work. The veteran keyboardist, who gave a recital at the Bruno Walter Auditorium early on Friday evening, wastes few notes.

title: NO WAY TO PAY FOR TAX ENFORCEMENT
description: Louis XIV was foolish to permit it, and so is the Senate Finance Committee: Using money extracted from delinquent taxpayers to pay for tax collection risks igniting public resentment.

title: Margaret Elizabeth Busby Wed to Henry Romaine Jr.
description: Margaret Elizabeth Busby, the daughter of Diana Wittig Busby and Jeffrey C. Busby, both of Birmingham, Ala., was married yesterday to Henry Simmons Romaine Jr., the son of Mrs. Erroll M. Petersen of Dubois, Wyo., and Mr. Romaine of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Frank Johnson performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Jackson, Wyo.

title: AN ASIAN ODYSSEY BY TRAIN
description: The Butterworth Express waits in Hualampong Station, Bangkok, a small fan moving the warm air from the window through the compartment and out into the corridor. The first-class compartment, for two passengers, is wide enough for a good leg stretch, 7 feet across. The walls are blond wood, luggage racks up high. In the corner is a built-in, porcelain washbasin with running water; above it, a cabinet holds bottled water and clean glasses set in racks. At 4:10 P.M., exactly on time, the whistle blows, a khaki-clad station official lowers the red flag in his left hand and raises the green one in his right. Thais on the platform, many family groups with children in tow, give the traditional slaute: palms together, fingers touching noses. The train moves out.

title: PLAYING TO SOPHISTICATED SNACKERS
description: A YEAR and a half ago, the Nestle Foods Corporation, the American arm of Swiss-based Nestle S.A., unveiled Alpine White, a ''white chocolate'' confection that is already the second best- selling Nestle bar, surpassed only by Nestle Crunch. The food giant now is test-marketing Henri Nestle, a line of elegant chocolates individually wrapped in gold foil.

title: USEFUL POLTICAL FALLOUT
description: The political fallout of the Chernobyl reactor accident has been impressive. It took a dreadful shock to budge major countries from their smug belief in nuclear sovereignty, but now things are beginning to move at the International Atomic Energy Agency here.

title: How It Was in World War II Yugoslavia
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FIREWORKS, BUT NO LADY - Independence Day observances of the Statue of Liberty centennial are notable for their absence in the county. Towns where fireworks and picnics have been a Fourth of July tradition are continuing the celebrations this year, but nothing has been added in recognition of the events going on in New York Harbor.

title: REGIONAL BATTLE ON TRANSIT FUNDS
description: Lawmakers from rural and Western states are squaring off with those from New York, New Jersey and other heavily populated states in a battle over legislation to extend programs costing billions of dollars a year for state and local highways, bridges and mass transit.

title: TAXI AGENCY NEEDS MORE THAN A TUNE-UP
description: What's yellow, clean and readily available, even during rush hours and rain storms? A miracle, of course, and Gorman Gilbert, the 43-year-old University of North Carolina professor Mayor Koch has chosen as the new chairman of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, says he can't promise one soon. He is known as an eager analyst of the taxi industry, however, and he comes to New York with the perspective of someone who has never lived or worked here, so changes can be expected. James Brooke, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, asked him about his plans. Excerpts follow.

title: LONG ISLAND'S BROWN TIDE
description: An algae bloom known as the brown tide has once again become a thumb on the ecological balance of marine life along the Long Island coast.

title: BIGGIES, BUREAUCRATS AND THE WORLD DRUG TRADE
description: THE UNDERGROUND EMPIRE Where Crime and Governments Embrace. By James Mills. 1,165 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $22.95.

title: SEOUL DEBATE: LEADING ROLL OF THE ARMY
description: A rumor swept this city not long ago, a rumor that revealed just how much the military is on people's minds. During a raucous dinner at an exclusive restaurant, the story went, high-ranking generals had beaten up the floor leaders of both the ruling and the opposition parties.

title: Victoria Smith Is Wed on L.I.
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., yesterday Victoria Warrington Smith, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Smith 3d of Mill Neck, L.I., was married to Nelson Salt Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Walsh of Buffalo and Lorraine, Ontario. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: HOUSING SALES IN NORTHEAST SET HOT PACE
description: The boom in home sales that started this spring is now shaping up in many parts of the country as the biggest and hottest since shortly after World War II, industry members and analysts say.

title: TEXAS WILL BE HOME FOR $6.5 MILLION '31 AUTO
description: Shortly after he bid $6.5 million Friday night for a 1931 Bugatti Royale, far and away the highest price anyone has ever paid for an automobile, Jerry J. Moore of Houston was asked what business he was in.

title: 6 More States Getting Auto Seat Belt Laws
description: Laws requiring seat belts to be used in automobiles will take effect in six more states Tuesday, a group promoting the safety measures said today.

title: A ROOKIE POLICE OFFICER IS KILLED IN A SHOOT-OUT IN A QUEENS ALLEY
description: A rookie police officer was shot in the head and killed yesterday afternoon during an exchange of 13 bullets with a man in an alley in Far Rockaway, Queens, police officials said last night.

title: THE CORNY, CARNY SPIRIT OF '86
description: New York's word of the week might easily have been Ugh, as in ''Ugh, I can't stand all the hype and commercialism about the Statue of Liberty,'' or ''Ugh, let's get out of town and leave the hoopla to the tourists.'' Nor are such sentiments limited to New York. ''Get ready,'' The New Republic advises, ''for the most revolting display of glitz in this country's history.''

title: SPY RING: THE UNTOLD STORY OF THE WALKER CASE
description: LAST MONDAY, THERE HAD been nothing. But today, when he opened his copy of The Los Angeles Times to the Personal Messages, he found it:

title: Q AND A
description: Surcharge Ruling - Question: Last year a New York State Suprpeme Court justice ruled that the city's Rent Guidelines Board had illegally allowed landlords to charge tenants of rent-stabilized apartments a fuel surcharge and a 15 percent vacancy allowance on leases signed between July 1 and Sept. 30, 1981. What is the current status of this ruling? . . . M M., Manhattan Answer: The ruling to which you are referring was made by Justice Bruce McM. Wright last December in Stein v. Rent Guidelines Board. According to Jonathan Lippman, chief clerk of Civil Term in the New York County division of State Supreme Court, a motion for reargument of the case was recently denied. However, a spokesman for the board said that the Corporation Counsel, who represents the city in legal matters, is preparing an appeal. Repairs in Condominiums Question: I have an electrical circuit problem in the living room of my condominium apartment that I believe is being caused by a short circuit in the wiring within the wall rather than in an outlet. If this is the case and the wall has to be broken into to correct it, who is responsible for paying for the repair of the wiring or the wall? . . . P. P., Manhattan Answer: According to Stuart Saft, a partner in the law firm of Gold Schmidt Oshatz & Saft, who is also a vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, electrical wiring in a condominium building is considered part of the structure's common area.

title: THE QUICK SOLAR FIX IS MAKING SUNBATHERS A RARE SPECIES
description: IF A TROUBLING trend continues, the Jersey Shore beachnik may soon be declared an endangered species by the Department of the Interior.

title: THE SENATE FOLLOWS THROUGH ON TAXES
description: THE Reagan Administration spent six months from November 1984 until May 1985 preparing a proposal it called tax reform. The House of Representatives devoted the rest of last year to producing its plan. And last week, after working on the measure all spring, the Senate, by a vote of 97 to 3, approved its version.

title: A FIRE ISLAND HIKE: 25 MILES OF SUN, SEA AND SELF-RENEWAL
description: THE Fire Island high dunes burst out of memory the same way they burst out of the beach west of Smith Point.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: 'BACKBONE OF NEW ENGLAND' - Nineteenth-century mill buildings and settings in 37 New England locations are represented in ''Schlesinger/Millwork: The Mill as Art,'' watercolors and drawings of New England textile mills by Marian Cannon Schlesinger, which opens today at the Museum of American Textile History in North Andover, Mass.

title: Recent Sales
description: Brick Township $119,000 488 Birchbark Drive *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 13-year-old ranch; central *2*air-conditioning, fireplace, den; taxes $1,720. Colts Neck $287,000 700 Lovett Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; central air- *2*conditioning, raised hearth fireplace, deck; taxes $3,693. Middletown $284,900 11 Southside Avenue *2*5-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old colonial; skylight in master *2*bath, central vacuum system, family room; taxes $4,206. Ortley Beach $135,000 235 Harding Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 6-year-old ranch; deck, garage, *2*walk to ocean; taxes $2,034. Warren $265,000 48 Brookside Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 3-year-old colonial; cathedral *2*ceiling, french doors, oak floors; taxes $3,098. Westfield $245,000 5 Fair Hill Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 37-year-old colonial; *2*Florida room, basement rec room, patio; taxes $4,643. OTHER AREAS Bronxville, N.Y. $120,000 107 Lockwood Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 21-year-old frame colonial; *2*eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,442. Hamden, Conn. $186,000 Deer Hill Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; hardwood floors, *2*family room with fireplace, 1 acre; taxes not yet available. Plainview, L.I. $237,000 134 Northern Parkway *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old split-level; den, eat-in *2*kitchen, dining room, pool, 1-car garage; taxes $4,600.

title: FROM MANY SOURCES, CELEBRATIONS OF THE COUNTRY'S DIVERSITY
description: The outsized tribute and the extravagant gesture seem to be setting the tone for the Centennial Celebration of the Statue of Liberty this coming weekend. Joining in the festivities is CUNY-TV, the television facility of the City University of New York, which is pre-empting more than five days of its schedule with dramas, documentaries and discussions devoted to immigrants in America -their origins, their aspirations, their experiences here and their contributions to American culture. CUNY-TV is carried on Channel A in Manhattan.

title: ON TV, MORE THAN 100 HOURS
description: NETWORK and local television programmers plan to broadcast more than 100 hours of Statue of Liberty-related news and public-affairs programs.

title: SMOOTHING IT OVER WITH MEXICO
description: For several months, officials in Washington have been emphasizing Mexico's economic problems and accusing Mexicans of corruption and connivance in the drug trade. The relations between the two countries have also been strained by American efforts to curtail the influx of illegal Mexican immigrants and by Mexico's opposition to American policy in Nicaragua and the rest of Central America.

title: GOODWILL GAMES COMBINE CAPITALISM AND COMMUNISM
description: THE FIRST Goodwill Games will begin Saturday in Moscow, and so far the reception has been mixed.

title: A Special Surgeon
description: Samuel G. Freedman's article ''In His Father's Footsteps'' (June 1), about Dr. William Cahan and his son Anthony, had special meaning for my family.

title: DANCER TURNS TO PHOTOGRAPHY
description: MOSES PENDLETON is making his way into the world of photography in a round about way. The dancer and choreographer from the town of Washington, known primarily through his work with the offbeat modern dance companies Pilobolus and Momix, is using the camera to explore the possibilities of freezing movements for later use in his dance work.

title: Bombs in Basque Area Kill Guard and Hurt 11
description: A civil guard was killed and 11 people were wounded in four bomb attacks in the Basque provinces of northern Spain early today, the police said.

title: Carol A. Mulford Becomes a Bride
description: Carol Anne Mulford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Mulford of Caldwell, N.J., was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Joshua Trueheart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Trueheart of Washington. The Rev. David L. Fountain, assistant minister of the Memorial Church at Harvard University, performed the Protestant ceremony at the home of Charles Trueheart, the brother of the bridegroom and his best man.

title: CHOOSING TO DIE
description: THE END OF LIFE Euthanasia and Morality. By James Rachels. 204 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95.

title: GIVING MINORITY YOUTHS ACCESS TO SUMMER JOBS
description: The article ''Jobs Abound at Higher Pay for Summer'' [ May 25 ] , while providing some insight into the availability of summer jobs on Long Island, mostly in the fast-food and service industry, does not address the special problems that minority youths experience in their search for summer employment.

title: A WIDE VARIETY OF OFFERINGS AWAITS SUMMER THEATERGOER
description: ON THE evidence of a seasonal theater survey, one could call the state a summer musical festival.

title:
DINING OUT;
PORTUGESE TASTES IN TARRYTOWN
description: THE feeling of well-being at Caravela begins at the door, where a table holds dewy fruit, an assortment of pastry and venerable ports. It continues through the charming assistance of Manuel Cabral, maitre d'hotel and co-owner (with his brother Fernando, who is also the chef) and settles at tables where fresh flowers nod from pretty blue and white Portuguese vases and appetizing, savory and sometimes superb food arrives on elegant china or painted folk pottery. To our mind, the food seemed nutritious as well, but this observation did nothing to remove the romance from the menu or to diminish the beauty or adventure of Caravela's fare.

title: SAMPLING OF EXHIBITS
description: Following is a selection of exhibits being held in conjunction with the Statue of Liberty Centennial celebration. American Museum of Immigration, Statue of Liberty National Monument, Liberty Island. The first permanent exhibit on the history and symbolism of the statue. Includes the original torch and flame, replaced during restoration; full-scale copper replicas of the statue's face and left foot; two 10-foot murals made of more than 1,000 postcards of the statue; letters and works of immigrants, and other original artifacts, models and photographs.

title: CONGREGATIONS CAUGHT UP IN A CONFLICT
description: THE police officer strode down the aisle of the church near Cape Town and, according to a court affidavit by a priest who was present, told the congregation that their prayer meeting was illegal. Then, the priest added, 200 people were detained under South Africa's newest emergency decree. Most of the worshipers were subsequently released, but the churches seemed caught, not only between the state and its perceived foes, but also between their commitment to pacifism and the nation's violence and repression.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 35, which was printed in advance, about the relighting of the Statue of Liberty, states the day of the ceremony incorrectly. It will take place on July 3.

title: CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: To the Editor: The excellent article on visiting castles in the beautiful, fascinating and orderly country of Czechoslovakia omitted an important bit of advice: do not drive after consuming an alcoholic beverage.

title: NEW YORK'S HOSPITAL UNION TRIES TO HEAL ITS WOUNDS
description: LOCAL 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, one of the country's largest predominantly black unions, established a reputation for social activism in the 1960's that prompted the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King to label it ''the conscience of the labor movement.''

title: A CHILDREN'S AUTHOR JOINS THE IMMORTALS
description: AT a banquet tonight at the New York Hilton hotel, the 66th John Newbery Award medal for ''the most distinguished contribution to literature for children published in the United States,'' the oldest and best-known award in the field of children's books, will be presented to Patricia MacLachlan for ''Sarah, Plain and Tall.'' The 58-page book, accessible to early readers, perfect for reading aloud, poignant and affecting even to jaded teen-agers and weary adults, is, as a New York Times reviewer said last year, ''the simplest of love stories expressed in the simplest of prose.'' A young girl living somewhere on the prairie with her widowed father and little brother toward the end of the 19th century tells how Sarah, a mail-order bride from Maine, came into their lives.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TREASURE WRECK: The Fortunes and Fate of the Pirate Ship Whydah. By Arthur T. Vanderbilt 2d. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) Except for its shaky morality and occupational hazards - the risk of being hanged principal among them - an 18th-century seaman could do worse than the pirate's life.

title: LIFTED BANS WERE BROAD
description: ALTHOUGH the strictly enforced blue laws, including a Sunday ban on traffic, are a thing of the past, it is never hard to find peace and quiet in some shady corner or in a sunny spot on the beach here.

title: NEW YORK PUPILS FIND FUN IN A READING PROGRAM
description: At Public School 92, in Harlem, 10-year-old Lashawna Bennett browsed through tables of books with her classmates. E.B. White's ''Charlotte's Web'' competed for her attention along with Judy Blume's ''Superfudge'' and the classic ''Black Beauty,'' but Lashawna settled on a slim paperback, ''Laura's Luck.''

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS;
description: AS Sheridan Anne Edwards, a volunteer bookkeeper at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Belvedere, Calif., told it, she had a guilty conscience in August 1984 and confessed to her priest that she had embezzled $28,000 from the church treasury. She said she expected absolution and a chance to repay the money.

title: NO LONGER A WASP PRESERVE
description: ON a snowy Christmas eve in 1969, Boris S. Berkovitch was summoned to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's Manhattan residence and offered the job of New York State Superintendent of Banks - a post that would have made him watchdog over the biggest and most powerful banks in the United States. No Jewish person had ever held the job.

title: A SALUTE TO 'THREE SAXOPHONE GIANTS'
description: A JAZZ festival program called ''Three Saxophone Giants'' at Town Hall on Wednesday evening was billed as ''a salute'' to the alto saxophonist Johnny Hodges, the baritone saxophonist Harry Carney and the tenor saxophonist Ben Webster, all associated with Duke Ellington's Orchestra and all dead for more than a decade.

title: On Language; Who Is an 'American'?
description: NOT LONG AGO (A euphemism for ''11 months ago, but time flies''), a request was made of readers to submit substitutes for the word American, meaning ''citizen of the United States.'' The reason was plain: other residents of the Americas were taking umbrage at this linguistic imperialism. Our persnickety good neighbors to the south are Americans, too; if we call them ''South Americans,'' should we not refer to ourselves as ''North Americans''? And if we do, would we thereby merge with Canada and Mexico by accident?

title: COLLECTIBLES THAT PACKED A CHARGE
description: The bang that Kenneth Legunn and hundreds of other collectors get out of firecrackers lasts long past the Fourth of July.

title: WHEN IN THE COUNTRY, DO AS THE PRACTICAL DO
description: WE opened our country house a bit late this summer. Because it is not ''winterized,'' being a glorified log cabin in the middle of the woods on top of a hill (without even a path to lead the way), cleaning it up can be a chore. During the winter, field mice come in and build nests in the strangest places, unraveling a pair of garden gloves or a pad of steel wool in order to provide themselves a comfortable birth place for their innumerable babies.

title: THE CELEBRATION COMMENCES
description: THURSDAY: 8 A.M.: First of the Fleet - A host of smaller sailing ships from Long Island Sound will move down East River, starting from Throgs Neck Bridge. 10 A.M.: A New Jersey Welcome - Official flotilla of small boats will greet main fleet, including tall ships, at Sandy Hook, N.J., anchorages. 10 A.M.: Ecumenical Service - Religious leaders to attend public ''Liberty mass'' at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Noon: Dreadnoughts Assemble -

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: JUNE 29, 1986
description: Fiction

title: Medical Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: GOOD MEESEL, MRS. SIMPSON
description: WALLIS AND EDWARD Letters 1931-1937. The Intimate Correspondence of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. Edited by Michael Bloch. Illustrated. 367 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: NEW MENDELSSOHN WORKS ARE FOUND
description: A trove of organ music by Felix Mendelssohn has been discovered in a library in Cracow, Poland.

title: BRINGING THE FLAVORS OF INDIA TO L.I.
description: ''WE FELT that while Manhattan has several Indian restaurants, Long Island was ready for a nicely decorated one like Sitar,'' said Renuka Rai, who gave up her career in computer programming to help her family set up the restaurant in Melville in 1978.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Maureen Ahn Weds Gene Kim in Chicago
description: Maureen Miran Ahn, a corporate strategic planner for Dow Jones & Company in New York, was married yesterday to Gene Kyum Kim, an assistant vice president of Nomura Securities International in New York. The Rev. David A. Donovan performed the ceremony at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Chicago.

title: THE ART OF MANAGING THE ICE-CREAM CONE
description: EVERY season has a harbinger. In spring it is the first time the snow appears more muddy than white. (Apologies to the robin aficionados or crocus spotters.) In autumn, it's that first crisp Saturday, usually in October, when it seems that the entire state, seized by a singular madness, will be out raking leaves. And winter isn't really here until the snow sticks. For summer, it isn't the change in temperature, the first barbecue or when you can go barefoot; it's the first ice-cream cone.

title: THE HEMINGWAY LETTERS
description: I SUPPOSE MOST MEN WHO HAVE heroes they've admired since youth have an itch to pass on their enthusiasm, their hero-worship, to their children. In my case, the hero was Ernest Hemingway. He shaped my life, changed my life and almost cost me my life. The legacy I have in mind for my children is a small batch of correspondence we refer to in the family as The Heming-way Letters.

title: NAVAL REVIEW
description: Beginning Thursday morning, New York Harbor will be the stage for an international display of naval might - from behemoth battleships and aircraft carriers to smaller frigates and nimble coastal patrollers. The show continues Friday when President Reagan, aboard the Iowa, reviews the ships. Here are examples of seven classes of ships scheduled for the review:

title: Those Nixon Papers
description: The 12-year battle over public access to the Presidential papers of Richard M. Nixon is shifting from Congress and the executive branch to the courts. Public Citizen, a consumer group founded by Ralph Nader, and the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press went into Federal District Court last week, seeking an order that would free the National Archives from the limitations of a Justice Department directive enabling the former President to designate as private any records he chose.

title: THE RIGHT TO DIE STILL SEEMS MORE THEORY THAN PRACTICE
description: IN many ways, the case of Kathleen Farrell, a 37-year-old New Jersey woman who suffers from the inevitably fatal ALS, or Lou Gehrig's disease, is typical of the growing number of ''right-to-die'' cases across the nation. A terminally ill patient asks to have life-support systems removed to be allowed to die. The doctor, fearful of criminal or civil liability, refuses, and the dispute moves into the judicial system.

title: DANCE TO PLAY ROLE IN LIBERTY WEEK
description: TO HELP celebrate the Statue of Liberty centennial, dance and music will be performed at Liberty State Park's historic Jersey Central train and ferry terminal, which once sheltered immigrants.

title: CHARTING THE SUPREME COURT'S CONSERVATIVE DRIFT
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Town Mystified By Encroaching Hole
description: A huge sinkhole that swallowed up a sidwalk, some small trees and parts of a street and a parking lot continues to mystify officials in this small borough near Allentown.

title: PRESSURES MOUNT TO AMEND CONSTITUTION
description: THE New Jersey Constitution adopted in 1947 has been widely praised as a model blueprint and has influenced other states in making changes. It not only turned one of the worst state court systems into one of the best, but also established the boundaries for the executive, legislative and judicial branches of government.

title: ARTIST TAKES LIBERTY WITH COLLAGES
description: AS A comparative newcomer to the United States, and an admirer of liberty, John Digby has a special regard for the Statue of Liberty.

title: Reconciling Growth and Historic Charm
description: LIKE dozens of other historic Connecticut communities, the Town of Guilford - a 47-square-mile cornucopia of sparkling white clapboard houses and quaint picket fences interspersed with rolling countryside and undisturbed salt marshes - has been struggling to create a formula that will allow it to accept growth without losing its original charm.

title: DANCE: 'CURRENT EVENTS' BY CAROLYN LORD GROUP
description: THERE was a lot to look at and to listen to in Carolyn Lord's ''Current Events'' on Thursday night at St. Mark's Church. Yet the work's choreography made it ultimately uncommunicative.

title: FLORIDA MAY FACE NEW FRUIT CANKER
description: Florida's citrus industry is facing a ''very serious problem'' posed by an outbreak of an apparently new kind of citrus canker, officials say.

title: IN POUGHKEEPSIE, A RUSTING BRIDGE EVOKES DREAMS AND ANGER
description: More than a decade has passed since the last freight train rumbled across the Hudson River over the huge steel span of the Poughkeepsie Railroad Bridge.

title: Beef Carpaccio, Japanese Style
description: I must compliment Craig Claiborne on his article ''The Carpaccio Renaissance'' (Food, June 1).

title: NEW TRAINING PROGRAM FOR POLICE BOLSTERS EFFORTS AGAINST COCAINE
description: THE growing use of crack, a highly addictive form of cocaine, in the northern suburbs of New York City has prompted the United States Drug Enforcement Administration to assign two officers to Westchester County and to begin a two-week training school for local police officers.

title: Gorbachev Said to Plan Trip to Polish Congress
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, will try to allay a rise in anti-Soviet feeling in Poland as a result of the Chernobyl nuclear accident when he attends the Polish Communist Party's 10th Congress, which starts Sunday.

title: STUDIES FIND WARNINGS OF VOLCANO WERE IN VAIN
description: The Mayor of Armero, Colombia, asked several government agencies to evacuate his city last September, eight weeks before it was destroyed by eruption of the Nevado del Ruiz volcano, killing the Mayor and 21,000 of his fellow citizens.

title: AN ACTOR PREPARES FOR MALVOLIO
description: Despite the sultry midday heat, all was astir in Central Park. At the Delacorte Theater, seemingly a world away, the actor F. Murray Abraham strode about the stage in straw hat, T-shirt and shorts reciting Shakespeare. The actor - best known for his Academy Award-winning portrayal of Salieri in ''Amadeus'' - was rehearsing a scene from ''Twelfth Night'' in which his character, the vainglorious steward Malvolio, gets his comeuppance.

title: Concern Over Drugs
description: Coaches, educators and the athletes must do more to stop drug abuse on the college campus, in the view of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's executive director, Walter Byers. ''I do not believe the higher education community has taken a strong enough stand against drugs,'' Byers said.

title: A LUSH VICTORIAN GARDEN FLOURISHES IN NEW JERSEY
description: Kurt Bauer is a man who applies enormous energy and thoroughness to his three hobbies: collecting antiques, restoring old houses and gardening.

title: JAMES BOND CAR IS AUCTIONED
description: The silver 1963 Aston Martin that James Bond used to elude his pursuers in the film ''Goldfinger'' was sold at auction yesterday for $275,000, according to a spokesman for Sotheby Parke Bernet, the auction house.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Galoshes of Lust - A truly terrible sentence can sum up the weaknesses of a whole school of writing. These two are among the winners in the second volume from the Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest for bad writing. They appear in ''Son of 'It Was a Dark and Stormy Night' '' (Penguin), compiled by Scott Rice.

title: Pact for Williams
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers' contract with John Williams, the former Tulane basketball star cleared of point-shaving allegations earlier this month, has been approved by the National Basketball Association. Williams's agent, Mark Just, said the pact was approved by the league on Friday.

title: Mary Ann P. Gallagher Weds David W. Tralka
description: Mary Ann Patricia Gallagher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Gallagher of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to David Wainwright Tralka, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Tralka of Ocean, N.J. Archbishop Edward T. O'Meara of Indianapolis, assisted by the Revs. Christopher Cardone and John Zec, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour.

title: OFF-BROADWAY THEATER, WITH AID FROM FOUNDATIONS, STARTS SCENERY CO-OP
description: Like other Off-Broadway theaters struggling to survive, Playwrights Horizons saw trouble ahead when the cost of scenery for an average production soared to $17,000 from $2,500. Squeezed for space as well as money, it was using its crowded lobby for a scenery shop, box office and rehearsal area.

title: IMAGES OF THE ENEMY
description: WAR WITHOUT MERCY Race and Power in the Pacific War. By John W. Dower. Illustrated. 399 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.50.

title: Those Frasers
description: Don and Arvonne Fraser were a well-known couple in Washington, so there was considerable interest in the capital last week in the latest developments in their two-career political marriage.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: VIRGIN TERRITORY. By Sara Maitland. (Beaufort, $14.95.) An American nun - a member of an order dedicated to helping the poor and oppressed in a fictional, militaristic city in South America - is brutally raped.

title: YOU'RE NEVER TOO OLD TO BE LOVESICK
description: THE LAST BLOSSOM ON THE PLUM TREE A Period Piece. By Brooke Astor. 244 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: CHARTING THE SUPREME COURT'S CONSERVATIVE DRIFT
description: To the Editor:

title: Bo Jackson Big Draw
description: Advance ticket sales are extremely brisk for Bo Jackson's professional baseball debut in the minor leagues tomorrow night. Jackson, the Heisman Trophy winner from Auburn, who snubbed a five-year $7 million pro football contract with Tampa Bay to sign for less than a million with the Kansas City Royals' organization, is scheduled to be in right field for the Memphis Chicks of the Class A Southern League against the Columbus (Ga.) Astros. ''We're expecting about 7,000 people or better,'' said Ted Tornow, the public relations director of the Chicks, who normally draw around 3,000 people a night.

title:
SEARCHING FOR A SAFE HARBOR;
WHEN INVESTMENT CAPITAL GOES ON STRIKE
description: JAMES MADISON reassured readers of the Federalist Papers that the economic elites had little to fear from democracy. Still, the ''haves'' generally are outnumbered by the ''have nots,'' and the specter of votes counting for more than dollars gives the well-to-do the jitters.

title: GRANDMOTHER'S LIBERTY: THROWING OUT HER WIG
description: IF my grandmother were alive today, I'm sure she would be eagerly awaiting the unveiling of the newly restored Statue of Liberty. Like so many immigrants of her generation, she regarded the statue with strong feelings of gratitude and affection. For my grandmother, however, Liberty was more than a statue. It was as if Liberty were a person - a real woman who inspired her to take her first step toward liberation.

title: MODERN MASTERS IN THE NETHERLANDS, TRADITIONAL INNS IN JAPAN
description: A DUTCH TOWN LOOMS LARGE IN MODERN ART - A major exhibition of 20th-century art -with more than 800 works of painting and sculpture by 250 artists - has opened in the town of Eindhoven in the Netherlands.

title: THE HOOP IS HIP AGAIN
description: BACK in the 50's - the 1850's, that is -hoop skirts were all the rage. Remember Scarlett O'Hara descending the staircase at Tara? If she had worn a tube skirt it just wouldn't have been the same.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CHOCOLATE
description: THIS November, the Hyatt Regency in Woodfield, Ill., will be the site of the fifth annual Chocolate Lovers Hyattfest Weekend. For $80, each of the 1,000 guests will get to gorge on two chocolate breakfasts, a mid-afternoon ''high cocoa,'' and an ''haute chocolate'' dinner, and to indulge in chocolate workshops, demonstrations, lectures, tastings, contests, and Chocoholics Anonymous meetings. Total expected chocolate consumption - 10,000 pounds. (No one wants to talk about total expected weight gain.) There are dozens of similar events around the country every year. And they are just one indication of America's growing passion for chocolate. Consumption is up from 8.5 pounds per capita in 1980 to 11.2 pounds last year; in the same period, dollar volume has shot from $3.1 billion to $4.8 billion.

title: Silvia F. Erskine, Architect, Is Wed To D. R. Radulski
description: Silvia Fioretta Erskine, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Russel Erskine 3d of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to David Robert Radulski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Radulski of Branford, Conn. The Rev. Robert W. Greene performed the ceremony at the Norfield Congregational Church in Weston, Conn.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 47 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 47 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: FROM PLAYGROUNDS, OBSERVATIONS ON LEN BIAS
description: Out on the asphalt, where young men dream of what Len Bias had, there was little illusion. That the basketball star's cocaine-related death was tragic, all agreed. That it would make those who revered him think twice about drugs, most doubted.

title: Susan Lewis, Art Director, Is Wed to Philippe Sadoun
description: Susan R. Lewis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis of Edgewater, N.J., was married yesterday to Philippe David Sadoun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sadoun of Paris. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Manhattan.

title: STUDENTS WIN POINT ON SEX EDUCATION
description: HIGH school students in the Three Village School District in Stony Brook have won a victory in their effort to convince officials to expand the district's sex-education program.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Detroit; G.M'S EFFORTS TO CUT ITS TAXES
description: THE General Motors Corporation is in the midst of a campaign to reduce its property taxes in the areas, mostly in the Middle West, where it has extensive production plants and other facilities. The company is arguing that the assessed values of many of its properties are well above current market values. But officials of some of the communities involved say they fear that any sharp reductions in taxes paid on G.M. plants will imperil schools and civic programs.

title: Cynthia J. Blish Weds
description: At the Noroton Presbyterian Church of Darien, Conn., yesterday Cynthia Joan Blish, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester Blish of Stamford, Conn., was married to Robert Joseph Philpott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Philpott of Middletown, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Lawrence MacColl Horton, assisted by the Rev. William Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: HOW SEE-NO-EVIL DOOMED CHALLENGER
description: MORE than two years before the space shuttle was first launched, a team of National Aeronautics and Space Administration engineers took one of its key contactors to task over shoddy workmanship on the critical safety seals that join segments of the shuttle's huge solid-fuel booster rockets. The booster's manufacturer, the Thiokol Corporation (now Morton Thiokol Inc.) insisted the design was adequate, but Government engineers were succinct in their disapproval: ''We find the Thiokol position regarding design adequacy of the clevis joint to be completely unacceptable,'' they wrote in a harshly worded memorandum on Jan. 19, 1979.

title: Technology and the Graybeard Angler
description: PERHAPS because my first saltwater angling was done from my father's open skiff, which - powered by a one-lung Lathrop engine - moved twice as fast as a man can row a dory, I have never been either emotionally or physically comfortable in one of today's modern sport fishing boats that can hurtle over choppy seas at 30 or 40 knots.

title:
ART;
ABSTRACTION DISPLAYS ITS ENERGY
description: ALTHOUGH a great deal of attention has recently been paid to the renaissance of figurative and expressionist painting, there is no indication that abstraction is passe. In fact, the pluralistic mood evident in the visual arts since the mid-60's is still very much in force, allowing the development of a vigorous abstract movement paralleling the New Realism and Neo-Expressionism.

title: Archeologist for a Week
description: Linda Towle, anarcheologist says ''when I tell people what I do, they always say, 'oh, when I was little, I wanted to be an archeologist,' or 'that's something I always wanted to try.' ''

title: LOBSTERMEN COMPETE FOR SPACE AT MARINAS
description: TO Stamford's lobstermen, not only the weather looked bleak last winter. Prospects for the future of their fishing business were equally grim.

title: Emily I. Polishook, Artist, To Marry Michael Sheiner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon M. Polishook of Whitestone, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Emily Irene Polishook to Michael Sheiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Sheiner of the Bronx.

title: Tanzania Lions Kill 10 in '86
description: Lions have killed 10 people in southwestern Tanzania since January, the Government-owned Radio Tanzania reported today. It quoted Boniface Poja, chief of the Ruvuma region, as saying the 10th victim, an unidentified man, was killed this week near the village of Mlingoti.

title: THE MAN SHADOWING BLACK IS BLUE
description: GHOSTS By Paul Auster. The New York Trilogy, Volume Two. 96 pp. Los Angeles: Sun and Moon Press. $12.95.

title: Local Help in Buying a Bit of Britain
description: NICHOLAS COWAN, the president of a New York business management company, flew to London the Saturday before Memorial Day. Three days later he returned to New York, clutching a contract that said he would soon be the owner of some British bricks and mortar.

title: SIGNS OF TROUBLE AT PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: All or part of People Express might be sold, officials of the airline said, as the carrier that started the era of low-fare air travel tries to bolster its finances. Begun in 1981, People has become the fifth-largest airline, but the expansion has been costly and the low-fare strategy has been meeting stiff competition. Company officials said any divestitures would be a last resort, and the betting was that the entire carrier would not be sold. Analysts thought it likely, though, that the newly acquired Frontier unit or some planes or airport gates might be shed. Stocks of other airlines rose sharply as investors concluded that People's problems could lead to higher fares.

title: IRISH VOTERS KEEP DIVORCE BAN
description: The Irish electorate voted last week to keep the country's ban on divorce. The decisive vote, by a margin of 3 to 2, left overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Ireland the only nation in Western Europe without legal divorce.

title: FIERY 'NECKLACE' BECOMES EMBLEM OF DEEPENING SOUTH AFRICAN VIOLENCE
description: The image is stark in its familiarity.

title: THERE DOESN'T SEEM A NEED FOR UNISEX SCOUTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: SENTRIES By Gary Paulsen. 165 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $11.95. (Ages 14 and up) PART ode to the incredible luck of being alive, part cry of alarm, wholly a plea that life go on, Gary Paulsen's new book, ''Sentries,'' is strange, hard to pigeonhole. Unlike his ''Dogsong,'' a 1986 Newbery Honor Book, this collection of short fictions isn't exactly a novel. It has seven main characters, yet they don't know one another. Their paths don't cross, yet their stories produce a unified effect.

title: THE CHALLENGE IN CHILE
description: SOCCER IS CHILE'S MOST POPULAR sport. But when about 1,000 students gathered last month at the University of Santiago to watch a group of fellow students play soccer in the quadrangle outside the chancellor's office, their interest was not recreational.

title: THERE'S MORE TO SARATOGA THAN TOUTS AND TUTUS
description: On a fine summer's day when the rest of the world is off at the ballet or the races, I can more likely be found (or not) rambling the beautiful hinterlands that surround this old spa. The countryside ringing Saratoga Springs combines aspects of the wild Adirondacks, at whose foothills the town nestles, and the historic Hudson Valley, with its pastoral loveliness and echoes of musketry.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Modular Houses Come of Age (and Price)
description: THE lowly factory-built house, once considered the affordable-housing solution for first-time home buyers, is moving up in the world - up into the $200,000 price range, in some cases.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE'S a certain moment at dawn when the sun strikes the windows of skyscrapers, the glass reflects glints of gold and New York is a magic city. This is a sight visible only to the men and women who live in apartments with views and who are not buried under bedclothes. While others are snoring, grinding teeth, sleeping away precious hours, they are up, view or not, enjoying, appreciating, communicating, accomplishing.

title: Bar on Food Concern Upheld
description: Chief Justice Robert N. C. Nix of State Supreme Court has upheld a lower court's ruling allowing the city to bar a food company that faces bribery indictments from getting a $1.4 million contract to provide summer lunches to needy children. A Federal grand jury indicted the concern, the Freshie Company, April 10 on charges of bribing school officials in exchange for school-lunch contracts.

title: HARTFORD GETS TV WITH OTHER ACCENTS
description: THE flags of Italy, Argentina, Poland, Portugal, Greece, Puerto Rico and the United States sit on the counter in the control room of W13BF, the state's newest television station, which bills itself as ''television from around the globe.''

title: SWARTZ QUINTET AND BLAKE QUARTET
description: HARVIE SWARTZ, a bassist, and John Blake, a violinist, both record for Gramavision, a company with a reputation for music that is both adventurous and accessible. On Thursday, Mr. Swartz and Mr. Blake and their combos shared a jazz festival concert at St. Peter's Church at the Citicorp Center.

title: Sarah White, W. M. Merck Are Married
description: Sarah Knox White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. White Jr. of Manchester, Mass., was married in Beverly Farms, Mass., yesterday to Wilhelm Morgan Merck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Merck of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. Frederick Buechner, assisted by the Rev. James Purdy, performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I am afraid to fly. Are there any support groups or courses in New York that help people overcome this fear? - C. W., Pittsfield, Mass. Answer:Here are details of three groups that run courses from time to time in New York: Freedom From Fear of Flying, 2021 Country Club Prado, Coral Gables, Fla. 33134 (305-261-7042); Freedom to Fly, Rural Route 1, Box 194P, Olde Noah Hunt Road, Cream Ridge, N.J. 08514 (609-259-9744); and Soar, Post Office Box 747, Westport, Conn. 06881 (203-259-0087 or 800-332-7359).

title: INDIAN IMMIGRANTS: KEEPING ALIVE THE OLD WAYS IN THE NEW LAND
description: The Fourth of July celebration this year is focusing on the Statue of Liberty and the millions of immigrants for whom she has been a symbol. Among these immigrants are Indians who have settled on Long Island in recent years. Here is their story:

title: Ballesteros, With Rally, Wins Monte Carlo Golf
description: Severiano Ballesteros of Spain won the $245,000 Monte Carlo Open golf tournament by two strokes over Mark McNulty of South Africa today for his third straight victory on the European circuit.

title: A VENETIAN MUSEUM STORES NEW WINE AND A VINTAGE BOTTLE
description: Culture financed by industry - or trade, at any rate -has always been a Venetian specialty; no one was more practical, or more profit-loving, than the great merchants who built the city's churches and palaces.

title: MASS TRANSIT IS SET FOR HOLIDAY CRUSH
description: THOSE heading for this week's Statue of Liberty centennial festivities may find their quickest and surest path is by way of NJ Transit buses and trains, especially to Liberty State Park in Jersey City, where private automobiles will be banned for four days starting Thursday.

title: BENEFITS TO PUPILS SEEN FROM FULL-DAY KINDERGARTEN
description: Three years after it was begun on a crash basis, New York City's effort to extend kindergarten to a full day from a half day appears to be paying educational dividends.

title: IRISH WIFE IS IN LIMBO AFTER VOTE
description: Now, more than ever, there can be no divorce for Clara Clark in Ireland.

title: CATERING TO THE WORLD'S SWEET TOOTH
description: LORA BRODY, a Boston caterer, has always indulged her chocolate cravings. So five years ago, Ms. Brody took a gamble. She ordered 10,000 business cards touting herself as a ''chocolate consultant,'' sent them to contacts in the food industry, and waited for the phone to ring.

title: Cecilia Waters Weds
description: Cecilia Theresa Waters, a daughter of Mrs. Edward A. Waters of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Waters, was married yesterday to L. Tobey Sanford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David N. Sanford of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Ronald D. Sanford, the bridegroom's brother, performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale Congregational Church. Mrs. Sanford is an assistant picture editor at Time Inc. Mr. Sanford is a freelance photographer.

title: Reagan Says Trade Bill Would Hurt U.S. Role
description: President Reagan said today that trade legislation passed by the House of Representatives was a throwback to the era of protectionism and asserted that it would hamper his power to deal with foreign nations in trade disputes.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL CHALLENGE VOIDED IN TIMES SQ. REDEVELOPMENT CASE
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan dismissed an environmental challenge to the proposed $2 billion Times Square redevelopment project last week, but allowed a group of local residents and business executives to resubmit the case to him by next month.

title:
WINE;
SELECTIONS TO SIP OUTDOORS
description: AS in the French countryside, a number of spots dot our area where residents and travelers can quaff wine outdoors amid scenic surroundings. But high outdoor temperature can change the character of a wine and also affect the taste buds. Therefore, selecting products for sipping al fresco requires some special consideration.

title: Mary Dunn Is Bride Of Kimball P. Mayer
description: Mary Helen Dunn, the manager of college relations for the Irving Trust Company in New York, and Kimball Powning Mayer, a financial analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. James E. Fogartie performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Spartanburg, S.C.

title: Elizabeth Butler Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Jane Butler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Butler of New York, was married yesterday to Christopher Gaston Boissard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gaston A. Boissard of Toms River, N.J. Judge Charles E. Ramos of the Civil Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: D. K. Duffee Wed To Miss Corredor
description: Livia Margarita Corredor, an associate in the New York law firm of Moore, Berson, Lifflander & Mewhinney, and David Kevin Duffee, an associate in the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, were married yesterday. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: THE SENATE STEPS GINGERLY INTO TV'S SPOTLIGHT
description: The arrival of television may not be the biggest watershed in Senate history; the 1913 decision to elect Senators by direct popular vote, rather than by state legislatures, was bigger, although in years to come it is possible that it will not seem bigger by much. Television alters both political structures and politicians. The Senators made it clear they recognized this themselves when live coverage of their sessions began earlier this month. Some Senators spoke earnestly about the new age of communications; others talked slyly about how television - Ho! Ho! Ho! -would leave them untouched. A few potential Presidential candidates, presumably fearful that they might seem immodest, stayed out of sight of the cameras. Meanwhile, as several of its members noted, the Senate was now forever changed.

title: Sports of The Times; The Real Number One
description: IT was four years ago when a few New Yorkers went out to a modest little pizzeria in the neighborhood. When they ordered their pie - sausage and peppers, hold the anchovies - they learned that cappuccino was on the house because Italy was the champion of the world.

title: STRAW-HAT JOBS - ALL IS NOT 'JOY'
description: To the Editor: Don Shewey's recent article on summer stock [ ''Juggling Show Biz and the Bottom Line on the Straw-Hat Circuit,'' June 15 ] dwelt at length on the ''joys'' of working at the Pocono, Bucks County, Woodstock and Falmouth playhouses, owned and operated by Ralph Miller. Mr. Shewey mentions in passing that the companies consist of non-Equity actors who are required to perform such additional duties as mopping the stage, laundering and mending costumes and striking sets.

title: KEEPING A FINGER ON THE PULSE OF THE CONSUMERS OF AMERICA
description: ''ONE of the advantages of direct consumer advertising,'' said Harry Dale of Dix Hills, ''is that it allows an advertiser to reach a highly selective and very important audience to their growth with virtually no waste. They don't have to spend money on people they're already doing business with. They don't have to send things to people who have no need for their product.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MACHINERY OF NATURE. By Paul R. Ehrlich. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A quarter of a century ago, Paul R. Ehrlich climbed a low ridge in California's coastal range and captured his first checkerspot butterfly. Mr. Ehrlich, a professor of biological and population sciences at Stanford University, has since expanded his study of the inhabitants of that hillside chaparral into an inquiry into the fate of living things throughout the world.

title: THE JUDGE'S JURY
description: The House Judiciary Committee does not begrudge Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne room and board at Government expense, but it apparently draws the line at keeping him on the payroll at the same time.

title: SOUTH AFRICA REPORTS A BOMBING AND SLAYINGS OF 9
description: An explosion rocked a South African shopping center today, wounding two whites. The authorities reported nine more blacks were slain in the nation's violence, four of them reportedly anti-Government guerrillas.

title: 'The Character Factory'
description: To the Editor:

title: MADONNA GOES HEAVY ON HEART
description: ''I like challenge and controversy - I like to tick people off,'' Madonna boasted, tossing her head and flashing a mischievous half-smile. The 27-year-old pop star was sipping a diet cola in a conference room at the New York offices of Warner Bros. Records. She appeared almost demure in a pink-and-blue flowered dress and a very short haircut inspired by the late-50's gamine look of Jean Seberg, Audrey Hepburn and Leslie Caron. Gone along with most of her hair was the heavy makeup and jewelry that made last year's Madonna resemble a contemporary street version of Marilyn Monroe in ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes.''

title: Sousa at the Bat
description: To the Editor:

title: LOWER MANHATTAN TO BE ONE BIG PARTY
description: THERE will be a Dixieland funeral procession through the same old streets of lower Manhattan that the British once wrested from the Dutch. There will be blues singers. Tennessee toe tappers. Bagpipers. Fiddlers. Drummers. Trumpeters. And dancing under the stars. There will be so many high school bands that at 11:30 A.M. each day a deafening Battle of the Bands will occur at the World Trade Center Plaza.

title: WHAT SOCCER MEANS
description: While watching soccer's World Cup this past week with friends in Europe and the United States, we reflected on why the world's most popular sport is only of minor interest in the United States, and why this particular championship did not include an American team. In most countries, the Cup commands major interest, filling the newspapers and dominating conversation. Normal commerce seems to come to a halt, and, particularly in Latin America, a visitor finds it almost impossible to do business with some government ministries.

title: FIREWORKS GALORE -- AND 'NO BAD SEATS'
description: THERE are fireworks and there are fireworks, but there will be only one Big Bang. That is what organizers are calling the pyrotechnic display scheduled for the climax of the Statue of Liberty celebration Friday night.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CARRYING A TORCH - Salutes to the Statue of Liberty will come in many different forms this Friday as the nation celebrates the Lady of the Harbor's centennial. But officials of the Town of Brookhaven and Smith Haven Mall are hoping their offering will be one of the more unusual.

title: EASTERN TOWNS SEE 'EPIDEMIC' OF MOTHS
description: PEOPLE who have lived with gypsy moth caterpillars know ''the awful living conditions'' many eastern Connecticut residents are enduring this summer, said Bunni Gauld of Ledyard.

title: FRUSTRATED BILLIANCE
description: The saddest bridge scenario of last year runs like this. As a member of a favored team playing in a hard-fought match in a major knockout event, the hero finds himself defending an apparently impregnable game contract. He finds a dazzling series of defensive moves to put the contract in jeopardy in a fascinating end-position. The declarer fails to solve a very difficult problem and the hero has triumphed. Or has he? No. Gall and wormwood is his lot, and the match is lost.

title: MORRIS AREA TO EASE ITS GROWING PAINS
description: FACED with the prospect that rapid business growth, if unregulated, could strain its resources and overburden its infrastructure, Morris County two years ago turned to the Regional Plan Association for help.

title: GRAND FINALE: A CLASH OF STYLES
description: A complete contrast in styles and approaches to the game will characterize the World Cup final between Argentina and West Germany when they play Sunday at majestic Aztec Stadium.

title: Bill for Philadelphia Center
description: A bill authorizing construction of a $455 million convention center in Philadelphia was signed into law Friday by Gov. Dick Thornburgh, who said it would enable the city to establish itself as an international site for major trade shows and conventions. The project will create 5,000 construction jobs and nearly 10,000 permanent jobs, the Governor said.

title: HELP OFFERED FAMILIES OF THE MENTALLY ILL
description: THE Advocacy League for the Mentally Ill, whose membership is made up of families and friends of those who have been treated for clinically diagnosed psychotic behavior, says its approach to the problem of mental illness is one of adjustment.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in The New York Times Magazine today about the Walker family spy ring refers to the trial of Jerry A. Whitworth on charges of espionage and tax fraud, saying that closing arguments were scheduled to start tomorrow.

title: PRESERVE A TOOL TO ATTRACT BUSINESS
description: In regard to the recent article ''Schools Phase Out Company Tax Help,'' which focused on the issues of local tax abatement and the recent actions of school districts and the resultant impact on economic development:

title: Mark Charles Hansen Marries Anne Samuels
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston yesterday Anne Elisabeth Samuels, a senior researcher at WGBH-TV, the public television station in Boston, was married to Mark Charles Hansen, an Assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. The Rev. John Cranston performed the ceremony.

title: AT PIER 84, CHICK COREA AND WAYNE SHORTER
description: THE keyboardist Chick Corea and the saxophonist Wayne Shorter each led a jazz-rock band Friday at Pier 84, playing high-powered, rock-flavored tunes with electric instruments. But where Chick Corea's Elektric Band revolved around fast fingerwork, Wayne Shorter's group proved that jazz-rock can be as unpredictable and emotionally searing as any other jazz idiom.

title: PUBLIC TV'S 'COMRADES' - IN-DEPTH PROFILES OR SOVIET PROPAGANDA?
description: A group of Russian schoolchildren are dressed in their best back-to-school uniforms - the girls in white pinafores, the boys with red kerchiefs of the Young Pioneers around their necks. Then, at the command of the school's headmistress, they salute and follow marching orders.

title: PURSUING A CAREER IN FUNERAL BUSINESS
description: JANET RUGGIERO of Ardsley has a master's degree in social work, but she is going to school again. In her new field, the 28-year old Miss Ruggiero will need the same communications skills she once used as a child-care worker. Miss Ruggiero is studying to be a funeral director.

title: BEST SELLERS: JUNE 29, 1986
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 LAST OF THE BREED, by Louis 1 13 L'Amour. (Bantam,$17.95.) The adventures of a United States Air Force major in Siberia. 2 A PERFECT SPY, by John le Carre. 3 10 (Knopf, $18.95.) The tale of Magnus Pym, a British secret agent, and his father, Rick, a flamboyant con man. 3 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 6 17 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 4 THE EIGHTH COMMANDMENT, by Lawrence Sanders. 4 4 (Putnam, $18.95.) The theft of a priceless Greek coin brings a New York dynasty's scandals to light. 5 I'LL TAKE MANHATTAN, by Judith Krantz. 5 10 (Crown, $18.95.) Rich, beautiful Maxi Amberville conquers the world of magazine publishing. 6 THE GARDEN OF EDEN, by Ernest 5 5 Hemingway. (Scribners, $18.95.) A writer and his wife have affairs with the same woman on their European honeymoon; Hemingway's last unpublished novel. 7 TAMING A SEA-HORSE, by Robert B. 7 3 Parker. (Seymour Lawrence/Delacorte, $15.95.) The private eye Spenser tracks a young woman through the seamy byways of a pleasure empire. 8 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison 9 44 Keillor. (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 9 ACT OF WILL, by Barbara Taylor 16 2 Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Three generations of talented, ambitious women in England and New York. 10 GONE WITH THE WIND, by Margaret 10 2 Mitchell. (Macmillan, $9.95; $16.95 after June 30). A facsimile of the original 1936 edition. 11 THE GOOD MOTHER, by Sue Miller. 8 7 (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A woman's attachment to her daughter becomes a consuming passion. 12 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. 11 32 Auel. (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 13 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken 14 22 Follett. (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in Afghanistan. 15 BARRIER ISLAND, by John D. 13 2 MacDonald. (Knopf, $16.95.) One man sets out to thwart a multimillion-dollar Mississippi land swindle. 16* LONESOME DOVE, by Larry McMurtry. 22 (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) The Old West seen larger than life. Nonfiction: 1 FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ 1 8 Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and ruminations from the television star and father of five. 2 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. 2 16 (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme; the first Dr. Seuss book for adults. 3 JAMES HERRIOT'S DOG STORIES, by 3 7 James Herriot. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Fifty tales by a Yorkshire veterinarian about his favorite animal. 4 THE TRIUMPH OF POLITICS, by David A. 4 8 Stockman. (Harper & Row, $21.95.) Why President Reagan was unable to balance the budget. 5 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee 13 87 Iacocca with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 6 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by 8 49 Chuck Yeager and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) The story of the first man to fly faster than sound. 7 WHEN ALL YOU'VE EVER WANTED ISN'T ENOUGH, 6 11 by Harold S. Kushner. (Summit, $16.95) A rabbi discusses ''the search for a life that matters.'' 8 FORD: The Men and the Machine, 9 2 by Robert Lacey. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) A history of the automobile company and the dynasty founded by Henry Ford. 9 ''AND SO IT GOES,'' by Linda 10 3 Ellerbee. (Putnam, $16.95.) Television journalism as experienced by an NBC correspondent. 10 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith 7 10 Viorst. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author argues, and we must confront them to grow. 11 ENTER TALKING, by Joan Rivers with 5 8 Richard Meryman. (Delacorte, $17.95.) The talk-show hostess' long professional climb. 12 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. 12 20 (Slack/ Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 13 THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE 11 13 FOR A HAT, by Oliver Sacks. (Summit, $15.95.) The loss of the faculty of recognition and other strange neurological disabilities. 14* ROCK HUDSON: His Story, by Rock 1 Hudson and Sara Davidson. (Morrow, $16.95.) An account of the actor's public and private life written with his cooperation. 15 MANHUNT, by Peter Maas. (Random 1 House, $17.95.) The capture and prosecution of a former C.I.A. agent who smuggled arms to Colonel Qaddafi. Advice and Self-Help: 1 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond 1 45 and Marilyn Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 THE ROTATION DIET, By Martin 2 6 Katahn. (Norton, $15.95.) A regimen based on the Vanderbilt University Weight Management Program. 3 THE RICE DIET REPORT, by Judy 5 9 Moscovitz. (Putnam, $16.95.) A diet developed more than 40 years ago at a clinic in North Carolina is explained by a successful user. 4 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney 4 31 with Sallie Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises designed to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 5 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. 3 58 (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A stamdard reference work, revised in 1983.

title: U.S. Hot Line For Informers
description: IT struck Senator James R. Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, that a hot line for citizen use might help nip many a fraud against the Government in the bud.

title: CELEBRATING THE NEW (OLD) WAY
description: LET'S try something new this Fourth of July. How about a big barbecue?

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section today, with the article about F. Murray Abraham's appearance in the New York Shakespeare Festival production of ''Twelfth Night,'' misidentifies the theater where Mr. Abraham acted in ''The Golem.''

title: DRUGS TIED TO ROGERS'S DEATH
description: A pathologist said here today that Don Rogers, the Cleveland Browns' star defensive back, probably died of an overdose of cocaine.

title: U.S. Editors' Society Urges Pretoria to Free a Journalist
description: The American Society of Newspaper Editors said today that it had asked the South African Government to release a prominent journalist who was arrested at gunpoint in his home in Soweto.

title: A CUSTOMS DECISION: TIME TO BE AMERICAN
description: AFTER living for nine years in the New World, there is one question I have come to expect: ''Where are you from, originally?'' This last adverb used to puzzle me, because it seemed to me that one's origin was not something that could be changed. I would then inevitably reply, in a rather solemn and patriotic manner: ''Originally, and to this day, I am from Belgium.'' After a while, however, I began to understand that many people did not mind acquiring a new nationality, for a variety of economic, social and historic reasons. As a European who was not forced to leave Europe, but left willingly to follow an American husband, I had not understood at first that an American passport was often the symbol of a new identity, the start of a new life.

title: MUSIC: IMAGES IN 'MEMORY THEATER'
description: NOT on or below but actually within the Brooklyn Bridge, a deftly imaginative exploration of memory has been taking place. It is a play with music called ''The Memory Theater of Giulio Camillo,'' which -in its restless, sometimes stilted but ultimately invigorating way -sweeps (often herds) its audience through a series of high, bricked vaults. Each is lighted and adorned to evoke the mysteries of the space, the bridge that stands above them and the water surrounding everything.

title: A SPOTLIGHT ON DOWNTOWN DINING
description: THE far reaches of lower Manhattan, traditionally associated more with commerce than cuisine, have emerged in the past few years as some of the more colorful new dining districts in the city - and next weekend they will take center stage.

title: GETTING CASH FAR FROM HOME
description: On Friday afternoon, June 6, I stopped at a push-button pay telephone in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and called 1-800-CASH NOW. After a short wait, I was connected to a customer service representative who identified himself, at my request, as Bob Walley. I said that as a holder of an American Express charge card, I was enrolled in the company's Express Cash program and needed to know the location of the nearest bank machine that could give me $100.

title: McILHENNY FINALLY BESTIRS ITSELF
description: THESE days, Edward McIlhenny Simmons, the president and chief executive of the McIlhenny Company, is the champion of a cause: He wants to liberate Tabasco sauce from its usual exile in the kitchen cupboards of America. ''We want to get Tabasco out of the cabinet and onto the dining room or breakfast table,'' Mr. Simmons declared. It seems a modest sort of ambition - but for McIlhenny, going after new markets or new uses for Tabasco is practically a sea change. This is, after all, the family-owned company whose 150 employees can still buy groceries at a company commissary. It is the company whose executives still cite a nearly disastrous push into specialty-food products in the early 1900's as a reason why they have generally shunned attempts to develop new products or capitalize on the well-known Tabasco name. Even Mr. Simmons, chief representative of the new guard at McIlhenny, cannot muster enthusiasm for new products -they are so ''iffy,'' he says.

title: OPEC EDGING TOWARD A MOVE TO LIFT PRICES
description: A majority of OPEC ministers appeared today to be edging toward a tentative agreement to curtail crude oil production and lift prices to a level of $17 to $19 a barrel from their current range, $12 to $14.

title: Focus: Seattle; Creating An Office Empire
description: INSTANT landmarks, like instant food, seem particularly suited to American tastes. While it took the tug of gravity and several centuries for the Tower of Pisa to lean its way into tourist brochures, and the French nearly tore down the Eiffel Tower before allowing it to become the symbol of Paris, there has seldom been an incubation period for structural icons in this country.

title:
GARDENING;
IT'S NOT TOO LATE TO SOW MORE SEEDS
description: ABOUT this time of year voids in the garden become noticeable. Early plantings of lettuce, radishes and peas have been harvested, leaving behind an empty space, or openings appear here and there in the flower gardens where either early bloomers such as pansies have begun to fade or something counted upon to fill the space has failed.

title: BOURNONVILLE'S BALLETIC STYLE IS MAKING INROADS HERE
description: For the past two weeks, a select group of dancers have been immersing themselves in the teachings and choreography of the great 19th-century Danish ballet master August Bournonville. In addition to working on the complex technical demands of his style, the students at the Bournonville Summer Academy have learned excerpts from his repertory, received instruction in 19th-century mime, analyzed the choreographer's use of music and attended lectures on the history and culture of Denmark during Bournonville's lifetime (1805-1879). This intensive exposure to the revered Bournonville tradition took place not in Copenhagen, where the Royal Danish Ballet, guardian of that tradition, is based, but - far from Denmark - in Midland, Mich., a two-hour drive from Detroit.

title: A PIPSQUEAK'S OBSESSION
description: THE AMBASSADOR By Andre Brink. 288 pp. New York: Summit Books. $16.95. ''I WAS born on a bench in the Luxembourg Gardens in Paris, in the early spring of 1960,''

title: THE TRUE COST OF THEATER FESTIVAL
description: The recent article on our first-ever International Theater Festival [ ''Wide Horizons for Drama Festival'' ] was well written.

title: EMIGRE DOCTORS FINDING NEW CAREERS
description: When Dr. Svetlana Fisher was a surgeon at a Soviet hospital, she loved her work so much that she never looked at her watch, she recalls. But she did not want her young son to be drafted into the Soviet Army someday, and so the family emigrated from Odessa to what she believed was the land of opportunity - the United States.

title: FROM JERSEY, A PRIME VIEW
description: ONE of the nicest holiday attractions at Liberty State Park in Jersey City will be the view.

title: Polly Bennett Is the Bride Of Clifton Truman Daniel
description: Polly Bennett and Clifton Truman Daniel were married in Wilmington, N.C., yesterday on the 67th anniversary of the wedding of the bridegroom's grandparents, the late President and Mrs. Harry S. Truman. The Rev. Thomas J. Brady performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: REPAIRING COPPER WATER LINES WITH A WRENCH AND PLIERS
description: MOST homes built in the last 40 or 50 years have copper water lines. This piping is joined with ''sweat'' fittings - elbows, T-joints and other fittings that are joined to the pipe by soldering. The technique is called sweat soldering.

title: ONCE, ALL THOSE BILLBOARDS MADE YOU WINCE. THIS BOOK EXPLAINS WHAT'S HAPPENED SINCE.
description: OPEN ROAD A Celebration of the American Highway. By Phil Patton. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: A Special Surgeon
description: One of the many things that made Dr. William Cahan so special is that he operated on a patient who was 95 years old. Normally, a 95-year-old woman would be told that she was too old for surgery.

title: Risk to Nonsmokers Debated
description: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop has warned again that people who do not smoke run a high risk of getting lung cancer from breathing the smoke of others.

title: THE BERKSHIRE THEATER'S HAPPY TURNAROUND
description: It was the first day of summer, bright and promising. And the actors, directors and staff of the Berkshire Theater Festival gathered for a picnic, savoring the anticipation of opening night on June 30.

title: REPORTS FROM PERU SEE 'COUP SITUATION' IN ARMY AND POLICE
description: President Alan Garcia's pledge to imprison policemen or soldiers if they are found guilty of killing rebel inmates after prison riots led to reports today of unrest in Peru's security forces.

title:
MINOR LEAGUES '86: RICHMOND BRAVES;
HARD PRESENT FOR BRAVES' 'FUTURE'
description: JUST two seasons ago they were hailed as keys to Atlanta's future, prized products of a farm system rated among the best in baseball. Brad Komminsk was touted as a certain fixture in left field, Atlanta's next Dale Murphy. Gerald Perry was the heir apparent at first base. The middle infielders, Paul Zuvella and Paul Runge, were supposed to challenge for starting jobs.

title: INQUIRY ON BIAS TO EXAMINE MARYLAND ATHLETIC PROGRAM
description: The University of Maryland, already rocked by the death of its all-America basketball player Len Bias from cocaine intoxication, appears headed for a different kind of trouble this week as a grand jury begins hearing testimony on the case.

title: RESORT RAIL LINE UNDER WAY
description: WITH a projected three-year construction project firmly under way, the restoration of passenger train service to Atlantic City before the end of the decade now appears certain.

title: A SAMPLER OF HAMPERS
description: LIKE everything else to eat in New York, picnics have an international flavor. Liberty Weekend - with its array of outdoor activities, from the parade of ships to the Central Park concert Saturday- is the ideal occasion for a picnic from this melting pot.

title: ABOUT CORDLESS TELEPHONES: WARNINGS ARE IN ORDER
description: By all means, prosecute anyone who makes use of private telephone conversations, as in the case of Plainsboro Committeeman George Spanos. But for the state Attorney General to seek to have the wiretap statute amended to prevent the private conversations of cordless-phone users from being monitored is far from a real solution.

title: Elizabeth Anne Rodgers Married to Tracy Barnes Elizabeth Anne Rodgers Married to Tracy Barnes
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Anne Rodgers, a Boston lawyer, to Tracy Barnes, a family therapist, took place yesterday at the T.Z.E. House on the Wellesley College campus in Massachusetts. The Rev. Scotty McClellan, chaplain at Tufts College and a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: ACCORD IS DISTANT IN AFGHAN-PAKISTANI TALKS
description: After four years of negotiations, Afghanistan and Pakistan are still deadlocked on crucial issues involving a settlement of the Afghan war, according to officials close to the talks.

title: Carla Freeman Wed To Jay C. Benkowski
description: Carla Park Freeman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Freeman Jr. of Washington and Bristol, R.I., was married yesterday to Jay Christopher Benkowski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin A. Benkowski of Milwaukee. The Rev. Thomas Ahlburn, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Freeman home in Bristol.

title: Short-Term Bias?
description: To the Editor:

title: 140-YEAR RUN OF FUN AT LAKE COMPOUNCE PERSEVERES
description: FOR a while it looked like Lake Compounce, the state's largest and the nation's oldest amusement park, would never reach its 140th anniversary.

title: WHEN TO VISIT
description: Liberty Island re-opens to the public on July 5. The Circle Line boat company will provide ferry service to the island - $3.25 round trip for adults, $1.50 for children 11 and under and $2.50 a person in groups of 25 or more. Admission to the island, the statue and the exhibits is free. There will be an elevator from the bottom to the top of the pedestal, but the curious must climb to the crown -171 steps. No one will be admitted to the torch. It can only be reached by a narrow 54-rung ladder and access will be limited.

title: Amanda Stirling Marshall, a Painter, And Christopher David Zingg Marry
description: Amanda Stirling Marshall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Marshall of New York and Stony Brook, L.I., was married yesterday to Christopher David Zingg, a son of Mrs. Richard G. Kehoe of New York and Lyme, Conn., and David D. Zingg of Sao Paulo, Brazil. The Rev. Karl W. Gillmeister, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Burden Mansion in New York.

title: MEXICAN PRESIDENTIAL CONTEST GETS A JOLT
description: The dismissal of Finance Minister Jesus Silva Herzog last week has caused worries among foreign bankers about the direction of Mexico's economic policies, but its main effect at home has been to shake up the odds on who might succeed President Miguel de la Madrid in December 1988.

title: SKIN-CANCER TESTING
description: As a major insurance company with an interest in keeping people well, MONY Financial Services, in partnership with the Skin Cancer Foundation, is sponsoring a free skin-cancer detection program in the workplace.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Annapolis Takes To the Boats - On the waterways surrounding the United States Naval Academy, all apparently is not shipshape.

title: Anne Atkins Is Bride
description: Anne Franchot Atkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Cornelius Atkins 3d of Indianapolis, was married yesterday to Robert Gilchrist Ilsey Young, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Adams Young Jr. of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. George Willis Jr. performed the ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson.

title: DANCE
description: New York can be a city of delightful happenings, planned and unplanned.
