Saunter down Theater Row and turn into the Douglas Fairbanks Theater some night this week and you'll discover a kind of microcosm of that grabbag of surprises in the Clark Center New Choreographers '86, opening on Tuesday and running through next Sunday.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE LOVER, by Marguerite Duras. Translated by Barbara Bray. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $5.95.) The narrator of this short, intense work, an old woman, looks back on her adolescence in Indochina and her passionate affair, at the age of 15 1/2, with a rich Chinese man. Diane Johnson, writing in The Book Review in 1985, said that in this ''small, perfect'' novel Miss Duras has found ''a felicitous and masterly balance between formalism and powerful emotional effect.'' CRAMPTON HODNET, by Barbara Pym. (Plume/ New American Library, $7.95.) Written in 1939-40 and published posthumously, this early novel by Barbara Pym brings together many of the characters and settings - the smug clergyman, the capable spinster, the cozy English town with its teas and jumble sales - that become familiar in her later works. In ''Crampton Hodnet,'' three sets of North Oxford characters grapple with as many ill-fated flirtations.

title: SECURITY AGENCY SCANDAL SPLITTING ISRAEL'S CABINET
description: A new showdown appears to be shaping up between the Labor Party and the Likud bloc, this time over the scandal involving Shin Beth, the domestic intelligence agency.

title: DECLARING INDEPENDENCE FROM RITUAL OF JULY 4
description: LIKE most families, we have always had a Fourth of July ritual. If the day was sunny and warm, we strolled to the beach for a late afternoon swim and an evening cookout before winding our way through the milling crowd at Jennings Beach to watch fireworks. If cloudy, we took in a matinee and settled for a double cheeseburger and shake at McDonalds. But one summer, not long ago, we broke tradition.

title: A BALLET PIANIST MAY EQUAL DANCERS IN IMPORTANCE
description: Audiences may not often think of pianists as being principal figures in dance companies.

title: SALE ALTERS WAR OF DALLAS PAPERS
description: For more than a decade, The Dallas Morning News and The Dallas Times Herald have flailed away at each other in what has been one of the nation's liveliest newspaper wars.

title: THE COURT RULES ON BIAS, LIBEL AND EXECUTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration received some encouragement from the Supreme Court last week in its narrow reading of the Federal antidiscrimination laws. In a case brought by handicapped passengers, the Court ruled, 6 to 3, that most commercial airlines are not covered by a 1973 statute forbidding bias against the disabled in ''any program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance.''

title: OFF THE HOOK
description: Stephen Bingham, for one, apparently doesn't need a weatherman to assess the political winds. Mr. Bingham, who said when he came out of hiding two years ago that he believed the climate in America had changed enough to allow him to get a fair trial, was found not guilty of murder and conspiracy last week. Prior to resurfacing in 1984, Mr. Bingham, a lawyer, had been on the run for 13 years, living mainly in Paris.

title: PIANO SOLOS BY STEVE KUHN
description: STEVE KUHN played a free-form set of piano solos Thursday at Bruno Walter Auditorium - two rambling suites incorporating his own pieces and standards, capped by a personalized version of ''God Bless America.''

title: CITY SHEDS LIGHT ON ITS STATUE
description: IN the cool and quiet of museums and exhibition halls - as well as amid the noise and pomp planned for New York Harbor and the streets of lower Manhattan - the restoration of the Statue of Liberty is now being celebrated, its history remembered and its meanings vividly explored.

title: 'Spaceman' in Action
description: Bill Lee, the colorful left-hander who picked up the nickname the Spaceman for his antics with the Boston Red Sox and the Montreal Expos, has lost none of his touch with the Moncton Mets of the Nova Scotia Senior League.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: EARFUL OF TCHAIKOVSKY - Land- and ship-based cannon fire and fireworks will accompany the Rutgers Festival Orchestra's performance of Tchaikovsky's ''1812 Overture'' at noon Wednesday in Wiggins Waterfront Park, Camden, and at 8 P.M. Saturday in Cooper River Park, Pennsauken.

title: Perreault Unsure
description: Gil Perreault, an original Buffalo Sabre who announced his retirement June 17, is having second thoughts.

title: WHY MEN ARE EDGING INTO THE SECRETARIAL POOL
description: ''WHEN people ask what I do, I hedge; I tend to say I'm a legal assistant,'' said Les Phillips, a 28-year-old secretary in Philadelphia. ''I just don't want to expose myself to all the stereotypes.'' After being the only man in his class at the local Katharine Gibbs School, Mr. Phillips - who eventually hopes to go to law school - last year became the only full-time male secretary at the law firm of Dechert Price & Rhoads.

title: DISCIPLINE, MEDITATION AND A STREAK OF MILITANCY
description: BY Asian standards, Sikhism is a relatively young sect, founded only 500 years ago by the first of 10 gurus who broke from Hinduism and preached monotheism, religious discipline, meditation and the virtue of martyrdom. The new religion also disavowed caste, idolatry and a formal priesthood.

title: Emily I. Stimson, Teacher, Marries
description: Emily Iselin Stimson, a daughter of Mrs. Frederick B. Stimson Jr. of Lakeville, Conn., and the late Mr. Stimson, an Episcopal priest, was married yesterday to Paul Edward Sugg Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sugg of Williamsville, N.Y. The Rev. Peter G. Cheney performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury, Conn., assisted by the Rev. Charles A. Bevan Jr. Faith A. Stimson was maid of honor for her sister and Andrew J. Sugg was his brother's best man.

title: ENGAGEMENT WITH THE OVERSOUL
description: THE AMERICAN NEWNESS Culture and Politics in the Age of Emerson. By Irving Howe. 99 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $12.50. IS America a success? The way to find out, said Henry Adams in a famous passage Irving Howe quotes early in this little book, is by asking whether American ''social power'' is being transformed into ''the higher forms of thought.'' Is the country giving ''new life to religion and art''? Are we creating and maintaining ''in the mass of mankind those habits of mind which . . . hitherto belonged to men of science alone''? In Adams's opinion nothing less than a revolution of spirit - a far-ranging democratization of culture - would be necessary for complete American fulfillment.

title: LUST FOR YOU NAME IT
description: ''If I cannot have too many truffles, I will do without truffles,'' Colette once declared, illustrating what might have served as her motto: ''All things in excess.'' The doted-on little girl grew up to be a jealous lover, a pitifully dependent wife and then an indomitable woman, and in time one of France's most loved and finest writers.

title: ODDS HEAVILY FAVOR LENIENCY FOR DRUG DEALING IN THE CITY
description: If you buy, sell or carry drugs on the streets of New York, the odds are overwhelmingly in your favor that you will not go to prison, even if you are arrested.

title: Still Milking New York Consumers
description: Why should New Yorkers pay an extra dime for each quart of milk just to keep local milk processors fat and happy? That shocking proposition has long been the policy of the state's Department of Agriculture and Markets, which carefully shields city dairies from additional competition. The policy is being tested again by Farmland Dairies, a New Jersey company known for rock-bottom prices, which seeks a license to sell milk in Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx. If Joseph Gerace, the department head, doesn't grant the license soon, Governor Cuomo should replace him with someone who thinks of consumers first.

title: The Demise Of Transitron
description: The Transitron Electronic Corporation, one of the first high-technology companies on Boston's suburban Route 128, where the current economic boom in Massachusetts began, says it is going out of business.

title: They Don't Like Ike
description: Dwight D. Eisenhower was ''a dedicated, conscious agent of the Communist conspiracy.'' So wrote the founder and longtime leader of the John Birch Society, Robert Welch.

title: NAT (KING) COLE TRIBUTE
description: THE musical legacy of Nat (King) Cole is remarkably wide-ranging. A pianist in the Earl Hines tradition who evolved into a suave pop balladeer, Mr. Cole fathered a flourishing school of jazz-inflected pop crooning. Johnny Mathis, George Benson and Al Jarreau are direct descendants of his polished soft-spoken style, while singers as dissimilar as Ray Charles and Lionel Richie also stand in his debt.

title: SHORT COURSE FOR WAITERS
description: ''It's like skiing or roller-skating,'' said Brianna Sutton, as she first balanced a tray of dishes on one hand, then confidently set them down on a nearby table. ''You've got to bend your knees.''

title: NEWS DIGEST: MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1986
description: International Moscow proposed a July meeting in Geneva between American and Soviet officials to discuss President Reagan's decision not to abide by the strategic arms agreement of 1979, Administration officials said. They said no decision had been made on how to respond to the Soviet proposal and that there was disagreement in the Administration about what it signfied. [ Page A1, Column 6. ] Poland's leader held out the prospect of limited amnesty for political prisoners as he opened the first congress of the Polish Communist Party since the time of the Solidarity union upheavals. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, wearing civilian clothes and speaking as the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, sat nearby, sought to stress in a three-hour speech that the Solidarity era had ended. [ A1:3. ] Thousands of armed Zulus were permitted by the South African authorities, who seem to favor some black factions over others, to crowd a sports stadium in Soweto in support of a rally by the Zulu leader, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi. The gathering was depicted as a prayer meeting for peace, but most of those who attended carried traditional Zulu weapons. In a speech, Chief Buthelezi expressed concern about ''the high toll of deaths of blacks at the hands of blacks.'' [ A1:4. ] National The new reality of U.S. immigration was represented by the arrival in Los Angeles last week of a young woman from Philippines who was coming to join her Korean-American husband in Garden Grove in Orange County, a California suburb, already full of the sights, sounds and smells of the Far East.

title: Sun-Times Publisher Wants to Run Show
description: Even to his critics, Robert E. Page, publisher and president of The Chicago Sun-Times, can be credited for not letting circulation slip away the way it was supposed to after Rupert Murdoch acquired the newspaper in 1983. Now, he may even get the chance to put his personal stamp on the newspaper.

title: It's the Parties That Have Lost Interest in the People
description: To the Editor:

title: Corporate Bug Wins Rich Race
description: Corporate Bug, ridden by Kip Didericksen, beat the 60-1 shot Cash Fever by a neck today to win the $640,000 Rainbow Derby quarter horse race at Ruidoso Downs. Corporate Bug paid $15.60 for $2 to win.

title: MUSIC: CARAMOOR OPENS
description: The Caramoor season opened here tonight on the elegant estate for which this music festival is named. The evening welcomed - the outdoor Venetian Theater surrounded by green, the atmosphere heavy with humidity and the Orchestra of St. Luke's precisely responsive under John Nelson. And then there was the program largely of Romantic music, all of it speaking in familiar, soothing and unthreatening ways.

title: Will the Planet Remain Habitable?
description: With unusual unanimity, scientists testified at a recent Senate hearing that using the atmosphere as a garbage dump is about to catch up with us on a global scale. The Earth's climate is changing rapidly and its protective shield of ozone is shrinking. The proposed orbiting of a space station may yet serve a useful purpose: as the last corner of the solar system suitable for human habitation. But if we quickly apply down-to-earth technologies we can avert the worst of these problems.

title: LAROUCHE FRINGE STIRS IN GERMANY
description: The 11,287 votes scored in the Lower Saxony state election this month by an obscure party called Patriots for Germany did not exactly shake the foundations of West German politics.

title: Hiram Walker Shares
description: The Gulf Canada Corporation said Friday that it had sold 22 million commmon and 2 million class B first series preferred shares in Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. to a subsidiary of Olympia & York Developments Ltd. for about $905 million.

title: Advertising; Cable TV Ties Into July 4 Gala
description: TODAY the USA Network, a cable TV fixture since 1980, gets into the patriotic fervor of Lady Liberty's 100th birthday by starting the first of a series of 50 one-minute spots featuring well-known Americans talking about their country.

title: DOUGLASS OUTSHOOTS PLAYER BY 1 STROKE
description: Dale Douglass, who admitted ''I was hanging on by my fingernails,'' survived a head-to-head battle today to win the seventh United States Senior Open by a single shot over Gary Player.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we do not do something about the high toll of deaths of blacks at the hands of blacks, we are on the verge of a civil war situation which will never be stopped, even if liberation is achieved tomorrow.'' - Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, addressing a Zulu rally. [ A1:5. ]

title: Advertising; New Agency Settling In
description: Mary Hodorowski, after a multitude of years in the pharmaceutical advertising field, has opened a place of her own: the Healthcare Communications Network at 340 East 80th Street. It is going to handle projects and has already been signed up by Ortho, Becton Dickinson and Lederle. Ms. Hodorowski was a senior vice president at Kallir, Philips, Ross.

title: YANKS SEND GRIFFEY TO BRAVES
description: Ken Griffey no longer has to renew his three-year-old request to be traded because the Yankees sent him to the Atlanta Braves yesterday. In acquiring Paul Zuvella along with Claudell Washington for Griffey, the Yankees hope they no longer will have to seek a shortstop who they believe can play adequately on a regular basis.

title: EAST HARLEM SCHOOL, IN FIRST GRADUATION, SEES DREAMS THRIVE
description: Coleman Genn had a dream: what Cornell University was for Ithaca, N.Y., his high school would become for East Harlem. If a center of learning could enhance a quiet upstate town, so, the principal reasoned, could a school of excellence help mend an area beset by drugs and dropouts.

title: First Nationwide Bank
description: First Nationwide Bank, the principal subsidiary of the First Nationwide Financial Corporation, said Friday that it had acquired two savings institutions near Cleveland. Terms were not disclosed, but the bank said it had acquired the assets and deposits of State Savings and Loan Company of South Euclid, Ohio, which has assets of about $392 million and nine branch offices, and of Citizens Home Savings and Loan Company of Lorain, Ohio, which has assets of about $165 million and six branch offices.

title: Advertising; Hill, Holliday Award
description: The management of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston was informed on Friday that the agency would be winning the Grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival of Advertising over the weekend and that they had better get someone over there to accept the award.

title: JERSEY WOMAN ON RESPIRATOR DIES
description: A terminally ill New Jersey woman, whose request to be disconnected from the respirator that kept her alive was to be heard by the state's highest court, has died, a Toms River funeral home reported yesterday.

title: Advertising; New Name, New Hope For Women's Sports
description: Remember womenSports, the magazine started by Billie Jean King and her Women's Sports Foundation in 1974?

title: Cheapskate, 72-1, Tops Broad Brush
description: Cheapskate, a 72-to-1 shot ridden by Marco Castaneda, held off a rally by the even-money favorite, Broad Brush, today to win the $300,000 St. Paul Derby at Canterbury Downs.

title: In the Middle
description: It has become part of the accepted lore of Stanford Law School that Associate Justices William H. Rehnquist and Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court graduated first and third, respectively, in the Class of 1952. Although Stanford officials say records of the class rankings no longer exist, several officials agree on that order and identify the classmate between the two as John F. Wells, who is now with a law firm in Oakland, Calif.

title: How a City Commission Acquired Its Protocol
description: Protocol is the name of the commission. But it did not get its name through protocol.

title: Stalker's Last Case
description: John Stalker was born with the perfect name for a policeman. The verb ''to stalk'' shares an Old English root with ''to steal,'' and means to creep stealthily in search of prey.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR, FACING STRIKE IN SANITATION, TACKLES DUMP ISSUE
description: With one of the big remaining struggles of his administration nearing a point of decision, Mayor W. Wilson Goode has taken the offensive in another. Both involve garbage: a mundane commodity ordinarily, but just now a fuel that seems to heat civic emotion here like no other.

title: CITY TAXES REMAIN THE HIGHEST IN U.S.
description: Despite a series of well-publicized tax cuts, taxes in New York City remain the highest in the country and are rising faster than the ability of New Yorkers to pay them, according to a study of city tax policy released yesterday.

title: DOROTHY DONEGAN ON PIANO
description: DOROTHY DONEGAN'S solo piano concert Saturday at Bruno Walter Auditorium was about half vigorous jazz, half shtick. The two were inseparably intertwined, because at the core of Miss Donegan's showmanship are bravura technique and no-nonsense swing.

title: A RURAL PHENOMENON: LYING-IN-THE-ROAD DEATHS
description: Every two weeks, on the average, somewhere in North Carolina, usually late at night along a rural highway, somebody gets drunk, lies down in the road and is run over and killed.

title: Pope Leaves Tuesday For Week in Colombia
description: Pope John Paul II will leave Tuesday for a seven-day visit to Colombia during which he will preach to a country troubled by terrorism and guerrilla war, street crime and a booming illicit drug trade.

title: PRETORIA'S SECURITY MEASURES DAMAGE CREDIBILITY OF MOVES TO SHARE POWER
description: With the South African emergency decree, President P. W. Botha has bought a respite from complaints from the far right wing of his Afrikaner constituency that he is softening in his response to black dissent.

title: BRIGHT SIDE FOR MINISTERS
description: Few oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, perhaps only those of Iran and Libya, could be classified as political radicals, so it was not incongruous when they settled in last week at a holiday retreat in the sunny Adriatic to figure out ways to raise oil prices and widen their revenues.

title: 1 Out of 4 Households Hit by Crime Last Year
description: One in every four American households was touched by a crime in 1985, but a sharp drop in personal theft kept the proportion of households affected by crime at the lowest level in a decade, the Justice Department reported today.

title: Moderate Republicans In Texas Win Party Vote
description: Conservatives have failed to take over the leadership of the Texas Republican Party, which has re-elected its moderate chairman.

title: EXPERTS SET AND TORCH 'LEGAL EAGLES' ART SCENE
description: When Arnold B. Glimcher, the owner of the Pace Gallery on the East Side, read the script of ''Legal Eagles,'' he did not find his profession portrayed in a sympathetic light.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the marriage of Polly Bennett and Clifton Truman Daniel misidentified the clergyman who performed the ceremony. It was performed by the Rev. Robert D. Cook, rector of St. James Episcopal Church in Wilmington, N.C. He was assisted by the Rev. Thomas J. Brady of St. Clement's Church in Harvey, Ill.

title: Death Out of the Closet
description: In a hospital or nursing home, D.N.R. stands for Do Not Resuscitate - a label for the patients whose lives are not to be saved should respiration or heartbeat fail. To indicate D.N.R., some places put a mysterious little symbol beside a patient's name. A Queens hospital, for instance, used a purple dot. Others use the ''slow code,'' which tells the resuscitation team to move at a snail's pace. Still others use the ''show code,'' instructing the team to feign resuscitation effort, for the family's sake. At other times, medical staffs make a point of prolonging painful dying with inappropriate, and often unwished-for, resuscitations.

title: Joining the Alliance
description: Until a few months ago, all Michael Reszler knew about NATO was what the letters in the acronym meant.

title: Advertising; Prince Pasta Account
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves has been rewarded for acquiring Fallon, McElligott of Minneapolis. Fallon's client, the Prince Company of Lowell, Mass., has asked Scali to handle the introduction of its new pasta, the President's Silver Award Pasta, now in test.

title: MARIO AMAYA, 52, ART CRITIC, EDITOR AND MUSEUM DIRECTOR
description: Mario Amaya, art critic, museum director, cultural impresario, magazine editor and former director of the New York Cultural Center and the Chrysler Museum in Norfolk, Va., died of cancer yesterday at a London hospital. He was 52 years old and lived in London.

title: G.M. Widens Financing
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would expand its 5.9 annual percentage rate financing program to six more models starting July 1. The move, which was expected, increases to 10 the number of car models in the program.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: BASEBALL YANKEES VS. DETROIT TIGERS, at Yankee Stadium, 7:30 P.M. (Television -SportChannel, 7:30 P.M., Radio - WABC, 770, 7:30 P.M.) METS VS.

title: U.S. ORCHESTRAS TACKLE OLD ISSUE OF NEW MUSIC
description: For the 1,200 musicians and managers attending the American Symphony Orchestra League's annual conference here, the main topic was not whether the nation's orchestras should be programming new music, but how.

title: Catherine S. Armandroff Marries a Sales Executive
description: Catherine S. Armandroff, a daughter of Joy Campagna of New York and the late Warren Armandroff of Cincinnati, was married yesterday to Michael L. Brownstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Brownstein of Philadelphia. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony aboard the yacht Riveranda in New York.

title: Advertising; Geer, DuBois Wins Jaguar
description: Jaguar Cars of Leonia, N.J., has chosen Geer, DuBois as the new agency for the British made, costly autos.

title: ASTROS WIN, 2-1, TO GAIN FIRST
description: Consecutive run-scoring singles by Kevin Bass and Jose Cruz in the seventh inning lifted the Houston to a 2-1 victory today over the Los Angeles Dodgers, and moved the Astros back into first place in National League West.

title: RENOIR'S BEAUTIFUL PEOPLE ARE BACK
description: Though part of the Washington scene for most of this century, the 14 people whom Renoir captured more than 100 years ago at Alphonse Fournaise's terrace restaurant on the Seine are not always present and accounted for.

title: O'Connor Said to Carry Demands for Hostages
description: Kidnappers holding five Americans hostage in Lebanon are reported to have issued new demands for freeing their captives.

title: MARCHERS LAUD CITY'S NEW LAW PROHIBITING BIAS
description: Thousands of homosexuals and their supporters marched yesterday afternoon in the 17th annual Gay/Lesbian Pride Day parade, following a lavender stripe from Central Park to Greenwich Village.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Sandoz Pharmaceutical Corp. to Romann S. Tannenholz for Tavist, a line of antihistamine products.

title: Mara Miesnieks Is Wed
description: At the Latvian Lutheran Church in East Brunswick, N.J., yesterday Mara Ruta Miesnieks, a vice president and securities anaylst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York, was married to Robert Duncan Balsbaugh, a government bond trader at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. The Revs. Imants Kuga and Zanis Kristbergs officiated.

title: MOSCOW PROPOSES A MEETING IN JULY ON '79 ARMS PACT
description: The Soviet Union has proposed that American and Soviet officials meet in Geneva next month to discuss President Reagan's decision not to abide by the strategic arms agreement of 1979, Administration officials said today.

title: WIDE HUNT FOR KILLER OF OFFICER
description: Investigators alerted hospitals, posted stakeouts at transportation hubs, canvassed homes and questioned witnesses yesterday in a hunt for a wounded, safari-jacketed man who killed a 22-year-old rookie police officer in an alleyway gun battle in a Queens beach community.

title: END OF GLORY DAYS FOR PACIFIC STEREO
description: Pacific Stereo was once the world's largest retailer of brand-name stereo equipment, relying on innovative advertising, savvy sales techniques and in-store service to stay ahead.

title: SHULTZ PINCHES PENNIES ON THE ROAD
description: At Secretary of State George P. Shultz's direction, the State Department's command post this weekend is not in Hawaii but in a wing of Hyatt Rickey's, a 40-year old motel that is well-known to the Stanford University community.

title: LATEST CHARGE OF RACISM PROMPTS A DEBATE
description: The Department of Agriculture's dismissal of its highest-ranking black woman has aroused a heated civil rights debate within Congress and at the agency's top administrative levels.

title: COCAINE KILLED ROGERS, TESTS INDICATE
description: Cocaine killed Don Rogers of the Cleveland Browns, a toxicologist confirmed today.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Nicole Cranberg-Crosby and Mark Hughes have been promoted to senior vice presidents of Doyle Dane Bernbach/New York.

title: Lynch Trade Is Expected
description: Ed Lynch, who has thrived during five years as the ''odd man'' of the Mets' pitching staff, will end a 20-day medical rehabilitation tour in the minor leagues Monday and is expected to be traded rather than restored to the staff.

title: TRAIL YEAR-AGO LEVEL
description: New orders for American machine tools rose 7.2 percent in May from April's level, according to a report to be released today by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

title: Washington Watch; Trade Split Over Japan
description: Another trade issue has split the Reagan Administration, as the State Department pulls one way and the United States trade representative and Commerce Secretary another over Japan's exclusion of American companies from participating in an $8 billion airport building project at Osaka.

title: FARRAKHAN, BACK IN CHAICAGO, TELLS OF SUIT ON BANS ON LIBYA
description: It was billed as ''the triumphant return'' of Louis Farrakhan, the fiery Black Muslim leader who had been abroad since Feb. 6, but at a rally Saturday night Mr. Farrakhan spoke as much about the possibility that he might face Federal prosecution for defying a 1981 executive order against traveling to Libya as he did about his ''triumph.''

title: Beth Turtz Is Married To Michael Jacobson
description: The marriage of Beth Turtz to Michael R. Jacobson took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Turtz of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi David M. Steinhardt performed the ceremony.

title: Guinness-Busch Deal
description: Guinness Ireland Ltd., a world leader in stout beer sales, signed an agreement to distribute and brew Anheuser-Busch's Budweiser brand beer in Ireland, the companies announced. Budweiser is the top-selling beer in the world, according to company sales figures. Under the agreement, the companies will work out a marketing and distribution plan for introducing Budweiser into Ireland.

title: A Homosexual Father Gains Custody of Son
description: A judge has awarded a homosexual man custody of his teen-age son after a four-year court battle with his former wife, a fundamentalist Christian, that drew nationwide attention.

title: The Senators' Judicial 'Litmus'
description: For more than a year now, the Senate Judiciary Committee has struggled to thwart President Reagan's constitutionally rooted power of appointment.

title: Chilean Torture Ship Mocks Liberty Gala
description: To the Editor:

title: ARGENTINA BEATS WEST GERMANY TO WIN WORLD CUP
description: In a game that was billed as a battle of continents, Argentina edged West Germany, 3-2, to win the World Cup today and set off a wild celebration among South American and Mexican soccer fans at Aztec Stadium.

title: CHILEAN TORTURE SHIP MOCKS LIBERTY GALA
description: To the Editor:

title: JELLY ROLL MORTON'S MUSIC
description: JELLY ROLL MORTON, the jazz pianist, composer and pool shark whose career was spent primarily in New Orleans and Chicago, was a more vivid presence in New York on Saturday evening at Town Hall than he may have ever been in his lifetime.

title: Privatization Explained
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD'S STOCK EXCHANGES UP ONLY SLIGHTLY IN 2D QUARTER
description: If the first quarter of 1986 was a feast for stock markets around the world, the second quarter, while not quite a famine, did not provide as sumptuous a meal for investors.

title: DANCE: TYR THRONE COMPANY
description: TYR THRONE subtitles his Throne Dance Theater ''the Tribe.'' It is a fitting name, for what the company performed in the first half of a program presented Saturday night at the Nikolais/Louis Dancespace looked more like a kind of gentle tribal ritual than concert dance.

title: Washington Watch; U.S.-Europe Trade Progress
description: THE United States and the European Community, after months of saber-rattling, are nearing agreement on new trade pacts to resolve disputes over agriculture and steel.

title: Outdoors: Still-Water Fishing
description: NEARLY all of the flood of literature devoted to wooing trout with an artificial fly is concerned with stream and river angling, but still waters - lakes and ponds - have their special rewards and challenges.

title: U.S. OIL CONCERNS SEVER LIBYAN TIES
description: The five remaining American oil companies with interests in Libya will halt all activity there on Monday to comply with the Administration's program of economic sanctions against the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi, according to corporate officials.

title: Lindsay P. Warwick Wed To Richard Todd Stafford
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Lindsay Paige Warwick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce L. Warwick of Greenwich, was married to Richard Todd Stafford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stafford of Somerset, Mass.

title: Speaking For a Nation
description: WHEN they started, there were 119 of them, national soccer teams bearing their countries' colors. By yesterday there were only two, Argentina and West Germany, both of them bearing the weight of hopes and fears and suspicions that usually accompany nationalism.

title: Sullivan Captures Meadowlands Race
description: Danny Sullivan's day had an early beginning at a stock car track in Belmar, N.J., and a triumphant afternoon on the road course around the Meadowlands' parking lots.

title: TOWNS AND YACHT CLUBS TO ENTERTAIN SAILORS FROM ABROAD DURING FESTIVAL
description: From Sandy Hook to Huntington, towns, yacht clubs and marinas along Long Island Sound and the Jersey Shore are ready to greet and fete the sailors coming from the far corners of the earth for the Statue of Liberty centennial.

title: Police Try to Quell Riots During Punjab Protest
description: Policemen in the Punjab arrested more than 100 Hindu militants today to try to avert violence during a Hindu protest strike, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Motors (Canada) Inc., Brampton, Ontario, a wholly owned subsidiary of American Motors Corp., named Ronald Hogue president, replacing William Carrol, who was appointed North American general sales manager.

title: Fault-Free Rider Wins Horse Event
description: Louis Jacobs of East Aurora, N.Y., turned in the fastest fault-free ride in an unusual one-round format to win today's $30,000 Lake Placid Grand Prix, the closing event of the 17th annual Lake Placid Horse Show.

title: Elizabeth Ann Smith Weds Lawrence Selig
description: Elizabeth Ann Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Jack Smith of Camp Hill, Pa., was married yesterday to Lawrence James Selig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Selig Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Langan, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Eli Cooper performed the ceremony at the Hershey (Pa.) Country Club.

title: TOWN TAINTED BY BITTERNESS OVER YEARLONG MINE STRIKE
description: Before the strike, they had celebrated one another's marriages, watched one another's children, mourned one another's dead.

title: Andrea Disario Weds Fred Marcusa, Lawyer
description: The marriage of Andrea Disario, an account supervisor at Creamer, Dickson, Basford Inc., a public relations concern in New York, to Fred Marcusa, a partner in the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, took place yesterday in the Tillman Chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York. The Rev. Robert Albert, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated.

title: TOP AWARDS TO RUSSIANS IN WORLD BALLET CONTEST
description: Three Soviet dancers, competing for the first time in the U.S.A. International Ballet Competition, were among the top award winners here Saturday night at the conclusion of the two-week-long event, which brought together 63 dancers from 36 nations.

title: Cousins Found Dead In Strip-Mine Blast
description: Rescue workers today found the bodies of two cousins who were killed when lightning set off explosives at a coal surface mine in central West Virginia, officials said.

title: Let the States Modify Speed Limits
description: The chief of South Dakota's State Highway Patrol, Jerry Baum, puts the matter starkly: ''We have lost the battle over 55, absolutely. So let's go out and fight a battle we can win.''

title: TOUGH TIMES AHEAD FOR IRELAND'S 'GARRET THE GOOD'
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald, his political future in doubt, was belittled in his own land today as ''Garret the Good'' who failed with his ''starry-eyed pluralism'' in trying to lead the Irish electorate to legalize divorce.

title: Market Place; Nasdaq Issues In the Spotlight
description: THE fact that the Nasdaq composite index closed Friday at a new high is only the latest sign that there is a growing interest in over-the-counter stocks.

title: Graying of the Court
description: Despite President Reagan's proposals for change, the graying of the Supreme Court continues inexorably.

title: Let's Take Better Care of New York City Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: MARYKNOLL WELCOMES NICARAGUAN
description: Amid the proud relatives taking snapshots today at the Maryknoll seminary near here was one of the Roman Catholic order's most prominent members, the Rev. Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann, the Foreign Minister of Nicaragua.

title: OWNERS USING AUCTIONS IN A WEAKENING MARKET
description: Joan and Bassam Omary stopped by a real estate auction at the Hotel Pierre Wednesday to see what a block of apartments on Central Park South would sell for. When no one else made an offer for an elegant five-room unit in a prewar limestone building, 11 floors up with a magnificent park view, Mr. Omary raised his hand.

title: Nigeria Plans Devaluation
description: The military Government, accepting the Western prescription for reviving the collapsed economy, has announced a plan to devalue Nigeria's currency, the naira.

title: Principals Do More Than Just Administer
description: To the Editor:

title: Chernobyl Firemen Honored
description: Firefighters injured in the Chernobyl nuclear accident placed flowers on the graves of six colleagues who died as a result of the disaster, a Soviet newspaper reported today. The newspaper, Sovetskaya Rossiya, said the surviving firemen were discharged from a Moscow hospital last week and would spend months at a sanitarium. It said the Ministry of Internal Affairs had given the firemen gifts of track suits.

title: Mark Haag Weds Susan Natalie White
description: Susan Natalie White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon White of Springfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Mark Robert Haag, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Haag of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Reeves-Reed Arboretum in Summit, N.J.

title: Washington Watch; Mexico Accord Expected
description: Mexico and the International Monetary Fund are expected shortly to come to terms on a $1.3 billion standby agreement, but Mexico is likely to have a more difficult time getting commercial banks to put up their $2.5 billion share of a proposed new rescue package.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JUNE 30, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Michael R. Irwin Wed To Deborah Greenberg
description: Deborah Jo Greenberg, a stockboker at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Michael Robert Irwin, a vice president in public finance at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The Rev. Harris Reardon, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of Our Lady in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: Cardinal in Nicaragua Makes Appeal for Priest
description: Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo appealed today for prayers for one of his senior aides, a priest who he said had been barred from returning to Nicaragua.

title: Look at California
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WHAT IS FREEDOM? This is the week of what promises to be one of the most glorious Fourths ever, the one that celebrates the centennial and the renewal of the Statue of Liberty, that towering representative of freedom. Freedom can be embodied not only in a statue, but in declarations, as a concept expressed in words. Some of the best words, in the most precious documents, are now on view in Federal Hall, the building at 26 Wall Street, at Nassau Street, on the spot where George Washington was sworn in as our first President.

title: JOY AND SADNESS AMONG CUP FANS
description: Contrasts in joy and sadness, jubilation and resignation were evident in two Queens neighborhoods following the 3-2 Argentine victory over West Germany in the final of the World Cup yesterday.

title: AMERICAN CONVICTED IN TOKYO AFTER A SERIES OF BURGLARIES
description: A Harvard-educated American gold dealer has been sentenced to six years in prison for a series of burglaries.

title: EDWIN SCHLOSSBERG: MANY-SIDED LIFE IN ART
description: Edwin Arthur Schlossberg's graduation photograph does not appear in his Columbia College class of 1967 yearbook. The only evidence of his matriculation is in the back, in microscopic type, in the list of those not pictured.

title: BILL AUCTION IS TREASURY HIGHLIGHT
description: Treasury activity is confined this week to the regular auction of three- and six-month bills. In advance of the auction, the outstanding three-month issue was bid late Friday at 5.97 percent, while the outstanding six-month issue was bid at 6.04 percent.

title: Bonneville Chief Quits Fray
description: When Peter T. Johnson resigned recently as head of the Bonneville Power Administration, he cited as reasons for leaving that ''a period of turbulence is largely behind us'' and that Bonneville, an influential marketer of electricity in the Northwest, is ''fiscally sound.''

title: PHILIP JOHNSON PROFILED ON 'AMERICAN MASTERS'
description: TONIGHT'S subject on ''American Masters,'' Channel 13's ambitious new series on Mondays at 9 P.M., is Philip Johnson, architect, writer, art collector, esthete and, as is made abundantly clear in this hourlong profile, shrewd businessman. The narrator is Rosamond Bernier, writer and lecturer, who quickly notes that she and Mr. Johnson have been friends for years. This does not, fortunately, prevent Miss Bernier from skillfully wielding charm and insight, from placing her subject in perspectives other than his own.

title: Obscure Legend
description: On the anniversary last month of Edward Sylvester Nolan's death, there was not even the briefest ceremony in Paterson, N.J. The town has simply forgotten a native son who became the most colorful baseball player it ever produced and, at least for some time, by far the most successful. Beyond those distinctions, no player ever had a more obscure or intriguing nickname than did Nolan, a pitcher who was born in Paterson on Nov. 7, 1857, and died there May 18, 1913.

title: ANOTHER JUDGE DROPS OUT
description: Federal District Judge John Nangle has decided not to allow a naturalization ceremony here to be televised July 3 as part of the festivities marking the restoration of the Statue of Liberty, making St. Louis the third city to withdraw.

title: MURPHY WINS BY 3 IN CANADIAN OPEN
description: Bob Murphy shrugged off a 40-minute rain delay while his closest pursuers faltered down the stretch, and he shot a one-under-par 71 for a three-shot victory over Greg Norman in the $850,000 Canadian Open.

title: The Concerts Are Free But Space May Not Be
description: Serious music lovers know enough to arrive hours early for the free summer concerts given by the Metropolitan Opera and the New York Philharmonic. Some even get to the parks by noon.

title: THE REAGANS WON'T TAKE MANHATTAN
description: With millions of visitors joining him next weekend in New York, President Reagan will take part in the Statue of Liberty festivities - but with a difference.

title: GOODEN HOLDS ON
description: Dwight Gooden was good today in Wrigley Field, but not great. So the puzzle of the last two months remained: Where did the mastery go? But the Mets went to the rescue of their 21-year-old ace by punishing Rick Sutcliffe and beating the Chicago Cubs, 7-4.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 30, 1986:

title: 5 Killed and 28 Wounded In Iraqi Bombing of Iran
description: Iraqi warplanes bombed two Iranian villages inside the southern Persian Gulf war front today, killing five civilians and wounding 28, Teheran radio reported.

title: Explosives Found in Bavaria
description: Eighty-eight pounds of explosives were found near a nuclear power station at Grundremmingen, the police in the southern state of Bavaria said today.

title: BIGGER IS BETTER IN DALLAS (DON'T TREAD ON THE CONTESTANTS)
description: With oil so far down the state faces a $2 billion budget deficit, these are not the best of times for Texas' self-image. But there are still some throwbacks to the time when the Texas ethic of Bigger Is Better still thrived. There are still visionaries like Mike Bohdan and Ron Shapp of Bizzy Bees Pest Control.

title: HOOKS ASSAILS REAGAN ON BLACKS' STATUS
description: Benjamin L. Hooks, the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, accused the Reagan Administration today of allowing soaring black unemployment to continue and of abetting the creation of a hostile racial environment.

title: DANCE: MIME FESTIVAL FEATURES JACQUES LECOQ
description: Mime becomes popular in a transitional period when theater is in decline and moves toward renewal - mime is often found in decadent times.

title: A Prison Guard Trainee, 21, Is Slain in L.I. Street Brawl
description: A 21-year-old Long Island man who was training to become a New York State corrections officers was shot and killed during a fight following a party in North Babylon, L.I., early yesterday morning, the Suffolk County police said.

title: PASTA TO FORTUNE COOKIES: SHIFT IN MORE THAN DIET
description: At the St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in San Francisco's Italian North Beach neighborhood, the 9 A.M. Sunday Mass is now celebrated in Chinese.

title: AMERICAN'S GOAL IS RIDE TO GLORY IN TOUR DE FRANCE
description: THE symbolism is too pat, even corny, Greg LeMond admitted, but still it excited him. ''The Fourth of July -hey, right, the perfect day to start the Tour de France. Perfect for me, anyway.''

title: CONTRACT TALKS WITH 2 COPPER PRODUCERS CONTINUE
description: Negotiators for 4,750 workers at three copper companies have agreed to pay cuts of about 20 percent in the last few days, but union officials say that talks with the Kennecott Corporation have stalled over the company's demand for a cut of 33 percent in wages and benefits.

title: EAST, A SENATOR FROM CAROLINA, A SUICIDE AT 55
description: Senator John P. East was found dead on the floor of the garage at his home in Greenville this morning. The County Medical Examiner ruled the death a suicide.

title: FINDING HOTEL ROOM: TRAVEL AGENT MAY HOLD KEY
description: About 2,000 of the city's 100,000 hotel rooms are still available for this weekend's Statue of Liberty Centennial celebration, according to the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau, but tourists may need a travel agent to find them.

title: Warrior for New Right
description: Over his five years as North Carolina's junior Senator, John P. East established himself as a persistent and erudite warrior for the agenda of the New Right.

title: JARUZELSKI OFFERS HOPE OF AMNESTY FOR POLITICAL FOES
description: The Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, held out the prospect of a limited amnesty for political prisoners today as he opened the first congress of the Polish Communist Party since the time of the Solidarity union upheavals.

title: U.S. Treaty With Caymans
description: The United States and the Cayman Islands plan to sign a treaty July 3 to help American law-enforcement officials skirt Cayman bank secrecy laws when investigating such crimes as insider stock trading and drug smuggling.

title: OPEC AGAIN FAILS ON OUTPUT QUOTAS
description: A meeting of OPEC oil ministers appeared to be unraveling today, snagged on the crucial issue of individual production quotas for member nations.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: FLOW OF 3D WORLD IMMIGRANTS ALTERS WEAVE OF U.S. SOCIETY
description: As the nation prepared to rededicate the Statue of Liberty, a young woman with an immigrant visa landed here last week, her arrival symbolizing the new reality of American immigration - and its problematic future.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Now that his son, Barry, is playing for the Pittsburgh Pirates, I wondered what players other than Bobby Bonds hit 30 or more home runs and stole 30 or more bases in the same season? How many times did Bonds do it?

title: ARMAS AND SELLERS HELP LIFT RED SOX
description: Tony Armas hit a two-run homer and Jeff Sellers pitched a nine-hitter today, helping the Boston Red Sox complete a three-game sweep of the Baltimore Orioles with an 8-3 victory.

title: SOUTHEAST ASIA WARS YIELD NEW CROP OF DESERTERS
description: He was a student drafted into the Vietnamese Army. But when he reached his combat unit, he said, he ''saw that the fight was terrible and unjust,'' and he deserted.

title: Powerboat Sets Crossing Record
description: Richard Branson's powerboat cut more than two hours off the speed record for an Atlantic crossing today, reaching Bishop's Rock off the southwest coast of England 3 days 8 hours 31 minutes after leaving New York, his headquarters said.

title: Privatizing Arms Control
description: In the search to control nuclear arms, Administrations since President Eisenhower's have been frustrated by Soviet secrecy and the Kremlin's refusal to permit inspections on Soviet territory. Suddenly, one of the keys so zealously denied to American Governments has been dropped into the lap of a private American group, the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: THE REVOLVING DOOR OF JUSTICE IN ONE CHRONIC DRUG CASE
description: The case of Frank Morales, 24 years old and a prisoner at the Ossining Correctional Facility, known familiarly as Sing Sing prison, illustrates how long it can take to keep a drug user and seller off the streets.

title: PROUD TRUTH WINS ON BELMONT TURF
description: Proud Truth, without a victory in six starts since taking the richest race in the country last year, made his first career start on the grass a winning one with an impressive victory in the $126,000 Tidal Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: CITY BUDGET: NEW FACTORS CAUSED DELAY
description: The process of adopting a city budget this year was seemingly never ending. Minds were weary, and analogies of all kinds were making their way through City Hall over the weekend as if the old building were a university rather than a political meetinghouse.

title: AT SOVIET WRITERS' MEETING, JEERS AND A NEW DARING
description: The Union of Writers, the largest and most venerable of the Soviet creative-arts unions, concluded a five-day congress Saturday that participants said was marked by extraordinary candor and debate.

title: Man Killed by Police At Atlanta Festival
description: An attempt to resurrect the downtown ''Light Up Atlanta'' festival, canceled last year after complaints of rowdiness, ended in turmoil as the transit police shot a man who opened fire at a subway station.

title: MAN IS SET AFIRE IN BIKE THEFT
description: A 20-year-old Bronx man who fled Crotona Park with his body covered in flames late Saturday night, told the police he was robbed of his bicycle, doused with gasoline and set on fire.

title: CHARGES OF COVER-UP BRING CALL FOR SHAMIR TO RESIGN
description: A leading Labor Party minister called on Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir today to resign from the Government because of his reported participation in covering up the killing of two captured Palestinian bus hijackers by Israeli agents.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A CAST OF KILLERS. By Sidney D. Kirkpatrick. Illustrated. 301 pages. E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: SEAGRAM DEPARTURE TIED TO BEVERAGES
description: The Seagram Company, in a move that some analysts see as an attempt to get its beverage business moving again, is changing presidents.

title: Japanese Intervention
description: The Bank of Japan was buying dollars against the yen this morning at around 165 yen, dealers said. The central bank stepped into the market shortly after the dollar opened at 165.15 yen and continued buying, they said. But the dollar still fell, to trade as low as 164.90, after closing at 165.30 in New York on Friday.

title: C. Stuart Chandler Is Wed To Stephanie Kurtz Prohl
description: Stephanie Kurtz Prohl, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. K. Prohl of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday to C. Stuart Chandler, a son of Joan Houze Chandler, also of Chappaqua, and Jerry Terrell Chandler of New York. The Rev. Jack Silvey Miller performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: After 100 Years, Linotype Is About to Be Buried
description: Dr. Wolfgang Kummer has come to New York both to praise the Linotype machine and to bury it.

title: Bound for Soviet
description: The first American scientists to be permitted to monitor nuclear test operations in the Soviet Union will hold a news conference this morning at the Natural Resources Defense Council before taking off for Moscow.

title: MCENROE TAKING CONSPICUOUS HIATUS
description: THE face was familiar, even though he was smiling and sporting a beard. John McEnroe is appearing at local newsstands during Wimbledon this year, most recently on the cover of a magazine, photographed while proudly holding his newborn son, Kevin, as if he were displaying the winner's trophy at Centre Court.

title: Cashing In on a Name
description: Can longevity as a pro bring prosperity after the pros? You bet, especially if you're Bill Lenkaitis. Lenkaitis spent 14 years as a center in the American and National Football Leagues, rattling the dental fixtures of opposing linemen every fall Sunday, picking up a degree in dentistry from the University of Tennessee in the offseason.

title: Miss Freyer Is the Bride of U. S. Aide
description: G. Diane P. Freyer, a former assistant vice president of the international financial institutions division of Chemical Bank in New York, and William Schneider Jr., Under Secretary of State for Security Assistance, Science and Technology, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Good Shepherd in Denver by the Very Rev. John V. Anderson.

title: A COLLABORATION OF DANCE AND VIDEO
description: EXAMPLES of the collaborations that may result when choreographers team up with video artists are on view on ''Alive From Off Center,'' tonight at 10 o'clock on Channel 31. The program, for which Susan Stamberg is host, suggests that such collaborators delight in perpetual metamorphosis.

title: YUGOSLAV DENIES THAT MILITARY SEEKS POLITICAL ROLE
description: A political role for the armed forces, a traditional taboo in Communist countries, was vigorously debated at the congress of the Yugoslav Communist Party, which ended Saturday.

title: Gladyce Largever Begelman, Author and Party Consultant
description: Gladyce Largever Begelman, a businesswoman active in philanthropy, died Friday at Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles where she was undergoing treatment for leukemia. She had homes in Beverly Hills and New York City and was 55 years old.

title: 150 Held as Missouri Docks
description: One hundred and fifty protesters were arrested here Saturday for blocking traffic by dumping debris on the Embarcadero near the Oakland Bay Bridge as the battleship Missouri arrived for a week's visit. Earlier, small boats carrying members of the ''Peace Navy'' greeted the refurbished warship as she steamed under the Golden Gate Bridge. A spokesman said the group was protesting the nation's arms buildup at sea.

title: SERIES PLOT: SEAVER-METS?
description: SUDDENLY, the possibility of the ultimate in mixed emotions for any Mets' follower now exists - Tom Seaver pitching for the Boston Red Sox against the Mets in the World Series.

title: Bridge: Decisions by a Jersey Judge Get Some Second-Guessing
description: On March 18, a New Jersey judge dismissed a suit by some citizens of that state challenging New York State's control of Liberty Island, and its famous statue, on the ground that it lies within the New Jersey border.

title: WHITE SOX TRADE SEAVER TO RED SOX
description: Tom Seaver's fondest desire was to end his playing career near his Connecticut home, and yesterday he was finally granted his wish. But it was the Boston Red Sox, the division leaders in the American League East, who landed the 41-year-old pitcher, apparently outmaneuvering the Yankees, who were unwilling to part with any of their young pitchers.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Corporate Lineups
description: By virtue of an accord announced last week, next Christmas Day will bring us a game known as the John Hancock Sun Bowl, the parties to the agreement being John Hancock Financial Services of Boston and the Sun Bowl of El Paso.

title: Pretoria's Prisoners Are of World Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: 10TH HOME DEFEAT
description: Maybe the Yankees can tie the Detroit Tigers tonight.

title: Safe and Sound
description: Frank G. Burke, the acting Archivist of the United States, admittedly found the news a little unsettling. The reliable Associated Press had moved a dispatch saying that the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, the treasures on guarded display in the National Archives, were not originals at all but copies made secretly a dozen years ago by a penmanship expert from Nebraska.

title: RATE CUT BY FED ANTICIPATED
description: As statistical evidence of a weak United States economy mounts, the guessing game in the credit markets is no longer whether the Federal Reserve Board will cut the discount rate, but rather how long the Fed can hold out for coordinated action with the Japanese and West Germans before giving up and going it alone.

title: NUCOR'S AMBITIOUS EXAPNSION
description: For years, the Nucor Corporation has been a shining light in the beleaguered steel industry. But the company's ambitious expansion plans, coupled with projections of little or no growth in the steel industry, have caused some to question whether Nucor will be able to maintain the strong earnings performance that has become its trademark.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Group in Talks For a Unit of Unilever
description: The Ogilvy Group, whose properties include the worldwide Ogilvy & Mather agency network, has begun discussions with the mighty Unilever that could lead to the acquisition of the Unilever Market Research Units, which has offices in 20 countries and affiliated organizations in 14 others and had sales of $50 million last year.

title: SPRINTERS IMPRESSIVE IN JUNIOR TRACK
description: Stanley Kerr, a Texas A&M freshman and Maicel Malone, a junior from North Central High School in Indianapolis, scored impressive sprint doubles as the United States junior track and field championships ended today at Towson State University.

title: THOUGHTS ON FARMS FROM 502
description: Frank Thompson normally sells fire extinguishers door-to-door across the western Illinois countryside. But watching the continuing farm depression force more farmers and smalltown shopkeepers out of business, Mr. Thompson decided he had to do something to help.

title: SOUTH AFRICA WAIVES BAN TO LET ZULU CHIEF HOLD RALLY IN SOWETO
description: The South African authorities, seeming to favor some black factions over others, permitted thousands of Zulus to crowd a sports stadium here today for a rally addressed by their leader, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi.

title: FINANCIAL CONTROL BOARD LOSES MOST OF IT'S CONTROL
description: At its inception in September 1975, it was called the Emergency Financial Control Board, and few doubted the appropriateness of the name. New York City, awash in $3.3 billion of debt, was near bankruptcy.

title: Steel Imports Edge Higher
description: Steel imports edged higher from April to May, but were down by 17 percent from a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported Friday.

title: Advertising; Plapler Russo Gets Job
description: Berkey Marketing Companies, a division of Berkey Inc. and one of the largest independent distributors of photographic equipment and video, is taking its advertising account to Plapler Russo & Associates. The former agency was Hicks & Greist. The billings have been around $2.5 million.

title: 'VIDAL IN VENICE,' TWO WORKS ON 13
description: ''VIDAL IN VENICE'' is just the tiniest bit mislabeled; it should be Vidal and Venice. Either way, however, it is appropriate that Gore Vidal's name comes first because the film is not so much about Venice as it is about how Mr. Vidal feels about the place. In fact, his feelings are ambivalent, although Venice, on film, is lovely.

title: 'CASUALTIES OF ADOLESCENCE' TO BE EXAMINED
description: The Carnegie Corporation, saying that troubled teen-agers were receiving inadequate attention, is creating a national council to deal with the ''casualties of adolescence.'' The aim is ''to stir the nation to improve its treatment of this age group.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Miss McCormick, Film Editor Wed
description: Sandra Louise McCormick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Brooks McCormick of Fullerton, Calif., was married there yesterday to John Andrew Steele Hill, a son of Louisa Horton Hill of New York and George Roy Hill of New York and Malibu, Calif. The Rev. Michael Landreth performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: OUTSIDE INCOME FOR LAWMAKERS SEEN TO RISE
description: Congressmen increased their earnings from speeches and writing by almost one-third last year to a total of more than $7 million, according to Common Cause, the public affairs lobby.

title: NEW ROLES FOR OLDER GENERATION
description: ONCE upon a time, not so very long ago, grandmothers and grandfathers came with predictable images and somewhat limited roles. She was that wrinkled old woman who cooked scrumptious meals. He was that arthritic gentleman who had trouble making himself understood. By the time the grandchildren reached adolescence, both grandparents were probably dead.
